Project Description:
Bancassurance has become a strong element in determining competitiveness and success in Guatemala's insurance sector. Seguros G&T S.A. ('Seguros') is Guatemala's largest insurance company in both, the property & casualty as well as life insurance segments with a premium split of 65% and 35%, respectively.  

However, unlike its main competitors, its cooperation with Banco G&T Continental ('Banco'), its half-sister company, the country's second largest bank, and an IFC client, has been limited to a few areas of cooperation so far.  However, Seguros' owners and Banco's owners have realized that a closer cooperation between both entities in distributing insurance products and services through Banco's branch network would offer substantial synergies, higher turnover for both firms and a better penetration of the Guatemalan insurance market.  To assist the parties in unleashing that potential, IFC will invest in Seguros and acquire an equity stake of up to 15%.
Impact: In strengthening the capital and operational base of the leading insurer in Guatemala, an institutional endorsement standard for other insurers in the country will be set.  This is expected to be a key contributor in setting the country's insurance industry on a more stable footing, which will enhance reputation and security, as well as facilitate an improved usage of insurance by Guatemalans, including the lower income segments.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves IFC support for the insurance and surety business and has been classified as Category FI. The Applicable Performance Requirements may include the IFC Exclusion List, the applicable national social and environmental laws and regulations and the IFC Performance Standards. The client will be required to: (i) develop a Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS), including a reputational risk screening process to ensure that applicable activities supported by the company are in compliance with the applicable requirements and to identify projects with potentially high environmental and social risks; (ii) identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the SEMS; (iii) demonstrate compliance with the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions; and (iv) submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: Founded by Mario Granai Andrino and Ernesto Townson Pinto in 1947, Seguros has been the first venture of the Granai and Townson partnership which eventually also led to the establishment of Banco.  Banco and Seguros are linked through Corporacion G&T, S.A. who owns 50% in Banco and owns 99.984% in Seguros.  Afianzadora G&T, S.A., a surety bonds underwriter (bid, performance, supply, maintenance and warranty bonds provider), is a separate legal entity  99.998%-owned by Corporacion G&T but is operationally fully integrated with Seguros.
Cost Nature: Up to $10 million in Seguros and Afianzadora's common shares. Given that Seguros represents 88% of the combined value of the two companies, up to $8.8 million will be invested in Seguros' share capital, and the remainder in Afianzadora's.

Location: Seguros is headquartered in Guatemala City, but is operational through agencies and brokers throughout the country.

Project Description: The proposed investment would support energy efficiency improvements in the district heating infrastructure of the city of Mytischi (the 'City') in 2011-2012. The Project, which would be a continuation of the broader infrastructure rehabilitation program supported by IBRD Municipal Heating Project (2001-2008) and IFC financing (2009-2010), is expected to finance installation of 178 automated individual heat substations.
Impact: Rehabilitation of the heating infrastructure in the City to be supported under the proposed project will improve energy efficiency, improve the quality of heating and hot water services to residents, and reduce heat losses and maintenance costs. Ultimately the project will contribute to improving the living conditions and environment in the City.
Environmental Social Issues: The Company is an existing IFC client. The environmental and social (E&S) review of IFCs first investment project was conducted in 2009. The project supervision revealed that the companys E&S performance is in material compliance with at-approval agreements. Further financing will not result in any material change in the E&S risks and impacts identified for the first project. Moreover, installation of the automated individual heating substations will have fewer in number and scale E&S impacts. Project Description: Star Hydro Power Limited (SHPL or the Company) is in the process of developing a 147 MW run-of-the-river greenfield hydroelectric power plant,  on a Build Own Operate and Transfer (BOOT) basis, situated in part on the Kunhar river,  which  marks the border between Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK) and the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province of Pakistan (KP) and in part on the Jhelum river in AJK (the Project). AJK is the Pakistan-administered portion of an area over which India and Pakistan have been in dispute since 1947. By supporting the project, IFC does not intend to make any judgment on the legal or other status of any disputed territories or to prejudice the final determination of the parties'' claims. The Project will divert a portion of the Kunhar River through a tunnel to a powerhouse located on the right bank of Jhelum River at the village of Alda opposite the Lower Chattar area of Muzaffarabad town.  The Project main components consist of a diversion weir (42 m height) across Kunhar River, near Patrind village, a headpond formed by the weir extending approximately seven km upstream on the Kunhar River contained by a natural gorge, an intake structure with siltation chambers, a 2.2 km headrace tunnel, an underground penstock, a surge chamber, a power house and tailrace structure.  Two temporary coffer dams and a diversion tunnel will be built on the Kunhar River to maintain dry conditions during the construction of the permanent diversion weir.Electricity from the Project will be sold to National Transmission and Dispatch Company (NTDC), Pakistans state-owned company.  NTDC will construct and operate a transmission line from the Project site to NTDCs national grid.  As of December 2010, options being considered by NTDC are either (i) 132 kV transmission line to Gahri Halibullah Grid Station (which is in the planning stage and the land is being acquired) which will be about 20 to 25 km from the Project site, or (ii) 132 kV or 220 kV transmission line to grid stations in Mansehra, with total transmission line distance of about 50 to 60 km.  The Jhelum River is classified as an International Waterway and together with its tributaries, including the Kunhar River, is subject to the Indus Waters Treaty of 1960.  In accordance with IFCs Policy on Social and Environmental Sustainability (April 30, 2006), IFC sent riparian notices to the IFC Executive Directors for both, India and Pakistan notifying them of IFCs proposed investment in the Project and its location in AJK, the Pakistan-administered portion of an area over which India and Pakistan have been in dispute since 1947.  By supporting the Project, IFC does not intend to make any judgment on the legal or other status of any disputed territories or to prejudice the final determination of the parties claims.
Review Scope: IFCs review of its proposed investment in the Project included: a review of environmental and social assessments prepared for the project by Pakistan Engineering Services (Pvt.) Ltd.  in May 2007, which were revised and expanded into an Environmental Impact Assessment and Resettlement Plan in June 2010 to address with the requirements of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), which will be one of the co-lenders to the Project; a review of further updated Environmental Impact Assessment dated November 2010 and supplemental studies on vegetation and fish fauna of November 2010; meetings with the Companys own management and technical consultants to review the environmental and social documentation prepared for the Project; a site visit to inspect all proposed components of the Project and meet with representatives of communities who will be affected by the construction and operations of the Project; follow-up consultation with the ADB environmental and social staff and consultants regarding the impacts and mitigation strategies of Project management; and an inspection of the environmental, health and safety performance of one of the Projects proposed principal construction contractors, which is constructing a smaller run-of-river project in the Mirpur area of Azad Jammu & Kashmir (AJK).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category A project according to IFCs Environmental & Social Review Procedure.  Although it will provide developmental benefits to the affected population, the Project could potentially involve diverse environmental and social impacts related to: increased silt load in the Jhelum River during construction; aquatic ecological stress caused by reduced flows in the Kunhar River downstream of the diversion weir; the influx of construction workers and their impacts on the surrounding communities, as well as worker health and safety; and the acquisition of land and the physical and economic displacement of occupants of that land.
Sector: BA - Large Hydro - Renewable Energy Generation

Project Description:
Star Hydro Power Limited ('SHPL' or the 'Company') is in the process of developing a 147 MW run-of-the-river greenfield hydroelectric power plant,  on a Build Own Operate and Transfer ('BOOT') basis, situated in part on the Kunhar river,  which  marks the border between Azad Jammu and Kashmir ('AJK') and the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province of Pakistan ('KP') and in part on the Jhelum river in AJK' (the 'Project'). AJK is the Pakistan-administered portion of an area over which India and Pakistan have been in dispute since 1947. By supporting the project, IFC does not intend to make any judgment on the legal or other status of any disputed territories or to prejudice the final determination of the parties' claims.
The Project, expected to generate about 632 GWh of energy per annum, will sell all of its output to National Transmission and Dispatch Company ('NTDC'), Pakistan's state-owned single buyer, under a 30-year Power Purchase Agreement ('PPA'). The Project programme indicates a construction period starting in 2011 with completion scheduled four years later.
Environmental Social Issues: Pending the outcome of ongoing technical studies IFC considers that this Project will result in a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines and design criteria.  The Project has been assessed as a Category A project from the environmental perspective.  This is consistent with the categorization approach of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), a co-lender to the Project.  Based on its review of project information, IFC identified potential environmental, social, health and safety risk in the following areas: environmental impacts of the Project during construction and operation, including increased silt load in the Jhelum River as a result of construction activities (the Kunhar River will be diverted to by-pass the construction area and will, thus, not be affected by construction activities at the weir site); construction materials stockpiling and disposal of construction wastes, including excavation muck; the influx of construction workers and their impacts on the surrounding communities; worker health and safety in the construction and operation of the project; the acquisition of  land for Project works and the physical and economic displacement of occupants of that land; the impacts of reduced flows in the Kunhar River downstream of the diversion weir on fisheries and other aquatic life as well as downstream use for water supply and irrigation by local communities. A detailed description of IFCs environmental and social due diligence of this investment can be found in the Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) which is also available on IFCs website at http://www.ifc.org/projects.
Sponsor:
Project company: Star Hydro Power Limited ('SHPL'), a Special Purpose Vehicle incorporated in Pakistan for the purpose of developing the Project. SHPL is 100% owned by KDS Hydro, a Singapore special purpose vehicle formed by the Project's Sponsors.

Sponsors: the Project's lead Sponsor is Korea Water Resources Corporation ('K-Water'), a Korean state-owned company whose primary activity is the management of Republic of Korea's water resources. The Project's other Sponsors are: Daewoo Engineering & Construction Company ('Daewoo'), a leading Korean construction and engineering company and Sambu Construction Company Limited ('Sambu') a Korean leading construction company. K-Water is expected to hold 80% of the shares in KDS Hydro while Daewoo and Sambu each holding 10% of the shares in KDS Hydro.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at circa $ 380-400 million (including contingencies). The proposed IFC investment will consist of an IFC senior loan (A Loan) of up to $50 million.

The design involves the construction of a weir across the Kunhar River, near the village of Patrind, about 12 km downstream of the Garhi Habibullah Bridge. The Project will divert a portion of the water of the Kunhar River through a tunnel to a powerhouse on the right bank of the Jhelum River near Muzaffarabad. Power will be delivered to a switchyard on the left bank of the Jhelum River which will be connected with the NTDC grid. Project Description: IFC proposes to invest in Bandhan Financial Services Limited ('Bandhan' or the 'Company'), the fourth largest microfinance institution ('MFI') in India. Bandhan operates in 18 Indian states in the northern and eastern parts of the country, including some of the poorest states, where population density is high and microfinance penetration is low. The Company focuses primarily on providing microloans to women micro-entrepreneurs in rural and urban areas.  Bandhan today has about 3.0 million borrowers and a loan portfolio of about US$520 million equivalent.  The proposed project intends to help Bandhan increase its outreach in the states where it operates as well as expand its operations in other states, where access to finance is most scarce; diversify its product base; and establish international best practice in its operations and governance.
Impact: The proposed project is expected to have a high developmental impact by: (i) increasing access to finance in some of the poorest states in the northern and eastern parts of India; (ii) promoting a more balanced growth of microfinance in India. Most of the MFIs operating in India are concentrated in southern India. Bandhan's operations are largely in the northern and eastern part where microfinance penetration is very low and very few MFIs of significant size are located; (iii) contributing to employment creation and poverty reduction in each of the states where Bandhan operates; and (iv) providing capacity building support in areas such as governance, product development and environmental and social standards so as to establish best practice.
Environmental Social Issues: The project involves IFCs support to Bandhan, Micro Finance Institution. The project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Bandhan will be required to: ·	Develop a procedure relevant to its business process, prior to commitment, that is satisfactory to IFC, and that ensures that all its investments are screened and processed to avoid supporting activities on the IFC Microfinance Exclusion List·	Identify qualified persons to manage and implement the procedure·	Demonstrate commitment and resources to implementing the procedure·	Demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions ·	Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.     Commit to establish a similar screening process to avoid supporting activities on the IFC Microfinance Exclusion List in MFIs in which it will invest.
Sponsor:
Mr Chandra Shekhar Ghosh, Bandhan's promoter, has over 25 years of experience in microfinance and is a Senior Ashoka Fellow. Mr. Ghosh is a recipient of the Skoch Challenger Award for Bandhan's financial inclusion work for the years 2008 and 2011.

The major shareholders in Bandhan include: The Small Industries Development Bank of India (SIDBI) with a 10.81% stake and three irrevocable public charitable trusts, including the Financial Inclusion Trust, the North East Financial Inclusion Trust and the Bandhan Employees Welfare Trust , which together hold an about 87% stake.
Cost Nature: IFC proposes to invest equity of up to $35 million equivalent for a stake in Bandhan.

The Company is headquartered in Kolkata, in the state of West Bengal.  Bandhan operates in urban and rural areas and has 9,094 employees.

Project Description:
The proposed investment involves supporting Banco Regional S.A.E.C.A. ('Banco Regional' or the 'Bank') in providing medium- and long-term financing to Paraguayan SMEs.

The primary objective of the Project is to support an existing client of IFC with a strong focus in the agribusiness sector, but that intends to expand into other economic sectors. By enhancing access to finance for SMEs (a key driver of the economic activity in Paraguay), the proposed investment will enable IFC to consolidate its programmatic approach in the local financial sector.
Environmental Social Issues: The Project involves IFC support for on-lending to SMEs and has been classified as Category FI. Because the key E&S risks of the project are associated with the Bank''s portfolio of investments, during appraisal IFC reviewed the Bank''s portfolio and capacity to manage E&S risks in order to determine the applicable requirements, which will be a combination of the IFC Exclusion List and the national E&S laws and regulations. The Bank has already developed S&E risk assessment procedures, which will be enhanced as part of IFC''s investment to ensure compliance with the applicable requirements and,  given the client''s focus on agribusiness, incorporate specific measures to manage S&E risks in that sector. IFC also reviewed the Bank''s labor practices according to IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions. Based on the review, the client will develop a grievance mechanism as part of the IFC investment.The Bank will be required to: (i) upgrade and maintain its Social and Environmental Management System to ensure compliance with the applicable requirements; (ii) demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2:  Labor and Working Conditions; and (iii) submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor:
Banco Regional was established in 1991 by a group of Paraguayan entrepreneurs, with the purpose of promoting the development of the productive and industrial sectors in the department of Itapua. Soon after its constitution, the Bank expanded its activities to other locations in the department of Alto Parana and other productive regions near Asuncion.

In January 2008, the Rabobank Group acquired a 40% stake in the Bank as part of the initiative of the Rabobank Development Program to support banks in developing countries through minority equity investments. 

In November 2009, Banco Regional completed the merger with the Paraguayan subsidiary of ABN AMRO Bank, becoming the largest player in the local financial system in terms of assets, with a 19% market share.

The Bank has been an IFC client since June 2008, when it joined IFC's Global Trade Finance Program.
Cost Nature:
The proposed project consists of a $30 million IFC loan to Banco Regional comprised by two tranches, as follows (the 'Project'):

- a 5-year multi-industry SME credit line for up to $15 million; and
- a 3-year multi-industry SME credit line for up to $15 million.

Company Name: Clearwater Capital Partners Emerging Markets LP
Project Description:
The global economic contraction, turmoil in the global financial markets and withdrawal of banks and other financial institutions from the Asia region have all contributed to significant price declines of financial assets in Asia. In this market environment, it is anticipated that over the next few years a number of viable companies that are now in financial stress become distressed as they exhaust their refinancing options, and/or violate covenants associated with their debt structure/obligations. These companies, many viable and typically mid-sized, face tremendous difficulties in the previously described scenario, as traditional banks stop lending to them while at the same time find it very difficult to reach adequate restructuring solutions.   

Clearwater Capital Partners, LLC ('CW' and Sponsor) a large and experienced Distressed Asset ('DA') investors in Asia, is currently closing an investment fund (Fund IV, the 'Fund') which will be dedicated to pursue DA opportunities in the Asia region.  The Fund primarily aims to: i) support the funding needs of mid-sized companies in the Asia region which are either too small for major banks or do not meet the risk profiles sought by such banks; and ii) purchase assets from financial institutions to help address asset quality and free up capital for new lending.  In that context, CW and IFC plan to structure a debt facility for certain Fund investments where leveraging would be appropriate.
Impact:
Support Private Sector Investment in NPL Portfolios:  Distressed asset transactions help improve the stability of banking systems by providing a way for banks to manage their NPLs/asset quality and allow banks refocus their recourses and activities back to lending.  In Asia, while there is private sector interest/activity in this segment, it is largely directed towards more developed markets (e.g., Japan, Australia).  

Without a means to support stressed companies or resolving NPLs, economic assets can lie stagnant and unproductive.  In addition, such investments can help many borrowers to de-leverage their balance sheets to sustainable levels, avoiding the unwinding of otherwise viable companies.
Environmental Social Issues: The project creates a co-investment vehicle to acquire and resolve debts of stressed/ distressed assets as well as pools of non-performing loans in Asian countries and has been classified as a Category FI project.  Considering the nature of activities supported, Clearwater or the project servicer will be required to: (i) develop a Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS), prior to IFC commitment, that is satisfactory to IFC, to assess potential environmental and social risks in consistent with IFC E&S requirements, which would include a combination of: the IFC FI Exclusion List, and/or the applicable national social and environmental laws and regulations, and/or the IFC Performance Standards; (ii) work with applicable commercial assets being resolved to ensure that the projects are operating in compliance with the IFC E&S requirements, or have an action plan to achieve the same within a reasonable time frame; (iii) identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the SEMS; (iv) apply the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions; (v) comply with local consumer protection and other applicable laws and follow international best practices or professional standards in its collection practices; and (vi) submit annual reports to IFC.
Sponsor: Clearwater Capital Partners, LLC, is an investment firm established in 2001 by a group of seasoned investors in the DA market. The firm has ample and successful experience investing in DA in Asia, being one of the most reputed investors in the market. CW has participated in more than 250 investments, including over 120 restructurings, 47 of which were led or actively negotiated by the firm. With offices in Mumbai, Seoul, Beijing Singapore, Hong Kong and New York, the firm is close to its market, which allows it to effectively take advantage of different business opportunities.

Project Description:
The proposed IFC investment consists of: (i)	an IFC loan to Caja Rural Nuestra Gente ('CNG' or the 'Company') of up to PEN56 million (US$20 million equivalent) to finance the growth of its microfinance loan portfolio; and (ii) one or more PCGs that can be issued either in US$ or PEN in connection with the Company's Bonds issuance program. The combined aggregate exposure of IFC under the loan and all PCGs will not exceed PEN56 million (or its equivalent in US$ calculated with respect to each PCG denominated in US$ at the time of its issuance).

The investment would help the Company increase the diversification of its funding mix and is part of a client relationship plan which builds on IFC's prior engagement (a $7.7 million equity investment).  

Through the proposed project, CNG will finance micro entrepreneurs and low income segments in frontier regions and small and medium sized municipalities, where commercial banks have limited outreach.
Impact: - Increased access to finance: If fully deployed, the loan and PCGs would help increase access to finance for micro entrepreneurs in Peru. CNG's portfolio is expected to increase by 20% on average annually during the life of the project from a base line of US$250 million in November 2010.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves IFC support for the business of Microfinance and has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  The key S&E risks of the project are associated with the portfolio of activities to be supported, which given the nature of the clients'' operations can be considered low. Under the existing project (No. 27292), the client has developed a satisfactory SEMS to avoid supporting activities on the IFC Microfinance Exclusion List and in certain cases check for compliance with applicable S&E laws and regulations. The same procedure would be a requirement under the new project. As part of this investment IFC will review the Nuestra Gente''s labor practices according to Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions.Considering the nature of activities supported, the client will be required to: (i) maintain its Social and Environmental Management System to the satisfaction of the IFC; (ii) demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2:  Labor and Working Conditions; and (iii) submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor:
CNG is the resulting company of the merger of Caja Sur, Caja Nor Peru and EdPyME Crear Tacna. The institution offers financial products to entrepreneurs in the coastal regions of Peru, primarily around Trujillo, Arequipa and Tacna.

CNG is controlled by Fundación BBVA para las Microfinanzas with a 83.6% shareholding.  IFC has a 16.4% shareholding.  Fundación BBVA was established in May 2007 by the BBVA Group ('BBVA' or the 'Bank') as an independent entity.  BBVA is the first private international banking group to wholeheartedly embrace global micro-finance with direct investment via a non-profit foundation.
Cost Nature: The proposed loan or a partial credit guarantee for up to PEN56 million ($20 million equivalent) will strengthen and diversify CNG's funding base.

Location: CNG is headquartered in Lima and has branches in 18 out of Peru's 24 departments.

Project Description: Kaizen Private Equity LLC ('Kaizen' or 'the Fund') is an approximately $80 million single sector private equity fund dedicated to investments in the education sector in India.  The target Fund size is capped at $100 million with over 50% of the investment expected from institutional investors.  The Fund aims to provide capital financing to education companies in their growth stage and will focus on operational improvements in its portfolio companies.  Kaizen will be the first education sector-specific private equity fund in India. The Fund will be incorporated under the laws of Mauritius as a public limited liability company.
Impact:
The project is expected to have a high development impact in the following areas:
Provision of long-term equity capital to institutions in the education sector value chain and thus increasing access to education in India.  This type of funding is not readily available in the market.
Operational improvements to portfolio companies in the education sector in India through the value add role of the Managers. This will improve the quality and sustainability of education sector institutions in India and make them more attractive to strategic investors.
Demonstration of successful private equity investments in an underserved sector, thereby building confidence amongst institutional investors to invest in India and the sector.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  During appraisal, IFC analyzed the activities proposed to be supported with IFC financing for types of transactions, size, tenor and industry sectors and determined the Applicable Performance Requirements. While it is not the primary activity, the funds investments may involve construction/ acquisition/ renovation of educational facilities. Based on an analysis of the potential Social and Environmental risks associated with the future sub-projects and considering IFCs investment, the Applicable Performance Requirements are: ·	The IFC FI Exclusion List·	The applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and regulations; and ·	The IFC Performance StandardsIFC also appraised the FIs HR practices and reviewed the FIs existing Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS), and FI capacity to implement the same. It was found that the FI has put in place the basic SEMS and has sufficient capacity to implement the same. The FI has satisfactorily informed the IFC regarding its HR management practices and working conditions.Based on the Applicable Performance Requirements and FI SEMS and capacity review, the project will be required to: ·	Update its existing SEMS to the satisfaction of IFC,  to ensure the compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements - prior to commitment; ·	Commit to implement the SEMS, to ensure that its investments/activities supported by IFC financing are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements; and·	Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.·	Submit the environmental and social due diligence reports for the first three projects, prior to the Funds investment, to ensure that the SEMS is adequate to identify and manage the subprojects environmental and social impacts."
Sponsor: The investment manager is Monterey Capital Management (MCM) and investment advisors to the Fund are Kaizen Management Advisory Private Limited (KMA). Kaizen was founded by Sandeep Aneja, who is currently the Managing Director.  In addition to Mr. Aneja, the core team includes four directors of  KMA; Jetu Lalvani, Amit Ratanpal, Monica Mehta, and Akhil Shahani.

Project Description:
The Project consists of an investment of up to $20 million in InterSwitch Limited (the 'Company' or 'Interswitch').    Interswitch was formed in 2001 by Techinvest Limited, Accenture and a consortium of seven Nigerian banks to address the need for a nationwide electronic funds transfer, transaction processing and switching entity in the country.  The Company has become the leading switching entity with about the majority of Nigeria's e-payment transactions routed through its payments switching infrastructure.  

Interswitch is currently pursuing a strategic redirection and capital expenditure program to take advantage of growth opportunities in the sector and the region.  The program would consist of (i) Phase 1: selling a significant stake of the Company to strategic equity partners/investors; and, Phase 2:  subsequent funding for their 2-3 year capital expenditure program to support expansion in Nigeria and the sub-region.  With this investment, Interswitch will be able to expand beyond the boundaries of its current switching business in Nigeria, and (i) penetrate the unbanked population; (ii) expand regionally; (iii) provide services to a larger addressable market in the region; (iv) penetrate further towards the base of the pyramid, building on its current debit card program and its network of POS devices; and, (v) develop more value added services for the electronic payment segment.
Impact: Providing a low-cost channel for the poor and people living in rural areas to participate more actively in the economy by providing access to the country's financial infrastructure has been shown to have a positive economic impact for both those populations and the country's economy overall.  Through the Project, Interswitch will enable the Nigerian population, especially the unbanked, (i) have access to easier forms of electronic payments that will reduce cash in circulation, which has been a source of crime, fraud and corruption; and (ii) make themselves eligible for more sophisticated financial services and products.
Environmental Social Issues: Based on the nature of this investment, this is a Category C project according to IFCs Environmental & Social Review Procedure and, as such, the preparation of an Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) is therefore not required as well as any requirement for disclosure.
Sponsor:
The current shareholders of Interswitch include Helios Investment Partners ('Helios'), Adlevo Capital Partners ('Adlevo'), Techinvest Limited, Mr. Dotun Sulaiman, and some Nigerian banks. The Company recently completed a process for the sale of a significant portion of its shareholding from existing shareholders to a strategic financial partner.  Helios was selected as the preferred strategic financial partner and it invested along with Adlevo.  IFC has been invited to acquire a stake in Interswitch.

Helios Investment Partners, an IFC investee fund, is an independent investment firm focused on private equity opportunities in sub-Saharan Africa.   Helios Investment Partners currently manages over US$600 million in investment capital and it invests through a wide range of equity and equity-linked financial instruments. 

Adlevo Capital Partners, also an IFC investee fund, is a private equity fund recently set up to take advantage of the growing opportunities for ICT enabled infrastructure and services investments in Sub-Saharan Africa, with a focus on Nigeria and South Africa.  The fund invests equity and equity-linked investments in growth stage companies that derive their competitive advantage through the development and exploitation of technology or technologically driven processes.

Techinvest Limited is a Nigerian ICT focused company that provides a wide range of software and network engineering solutions.  Techinvest developed the concept of a nationwide switching solution and helped set up and incubate Interswitch.

Mr. Dotun Sulaiman is the former Managing Partner/CEO of Accenture Nigeria where he worked for over 28 years.  His areas of expertise include: Corporate & Competitive Strategy/Strategic Planning, Corporate Governance, Board/Management Effectiveness and Transformational Change Management.  He has directorships in over 10 Nigerian companies including: Cadbury Nigeria Plc (Director), Cornerstone Insurance Plc (Chairman), Lionstone Company Limited (Vice Chairman) and SecureID Nigeria Limited (Chairman).
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $117 million.  IFC will invest up to $20 million in the form of straight equity and quasi equity for the acquisition of a portion of the Company's outstanding shares as well as to fund the Company's near term investment needs.
Investment: 10.50 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity10.50* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Interswitch is headquartered in Lagos, Nigeria.  Its switching systems and operations are also located in Lagos.

Project Description: The proposed project involves an equity and sub-debt investment in Ahli United Bank B.S.C (AUB or the Bank). AUB is a regional commercial banking group providing conventional and Islamic corporate, retail, treasury, private banking, insurance, brokerage and asset management services though a number of entities, including majority owned subsidiaries and affiliates. The Bank operates through a network of 131 branches. The project is intended to support AUB in its expansion strategy in the less developed countries in the MENA region (the Region).
Impact: The main developmental impact of the project is expected to be in the developing member countries in the MENA region where AUB plans to expand as follows:Improving the quality and operational standards of the local banks acquired/to be acquired by the Bank.Strengthening the financial systems in the local markets where AUB is/will operate through introducing new talent, modern management, best practices and comprehensive risk management frameworks. It would also increase competition, resulting in the provision of better financial services and banking products.Strengthening the capital base of the banks acquired/to be acquired that will lead to enhancing the access to finance in the underdeveloped markets in the Region and as such contribute to economic growth, capital formation, employment and private sector development.Developing the retail lending and housing finance capabilities of the banks acquired/to be acquired, which would benefit the underserved consumer segments.Supporting the flow of funds from the resource surplus GCC countries to the less developed markets and facilitate trade, investment, remittances, etc and thus increase regional economic integration.

During appraisal, IFC analyzed the FI portfolio, for types of transactions, size, tenor and industry sectors and determined the Applicable Performance Requirements based on an analysis of the potential Social and Environmental risks associated with the FI portfolio and considering IFCs investment. Project Description: The proposed project involves an equity investment in Commercial Bank of Iraq ('CBIQ' or the 'Bank').  CBIQ provides commercial banking services including trade finance solutions, money transfer foreign exchange services, current and saving accounts in addition to retail and corporate lending. The Bank has 9 branches in Baghdad (including its main branch and headquarters) along with one branch in Basra.
Impact: The proposed Project is expected to have a high development impact as it will (i) Provide fundamental banking services to an underserved market; (ii) Expand and help develop financial services and products, (iii) Advance capacity and institution building of CBIQ.
Environmental Social Issues: The Project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. During appraisal, IFC will analyze the Bank''s portfolio, for types of transactions, size, tenor, and industry sectors and determine the Applicable Performance Requirements, that would include a combination of: (i) The IFC Exclusion List(s); (ii) The applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and regulations; (iii) The IFC Performance Standards. IFC will also appraise the Bank''s labor practices according to the IFCs Performance Standards 2: Labor and Working Conditions and review, if required, the capacity of the FI to manage social and environmental risks and to establish and maintain a Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS). If required, IFC will suggest Supplemental Actions to address any gaps in the SEMS.Based on the review, the Bank will be required to: (i) develop an, or upgrade, if necessary, the existing Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS), prior to disbursement to the satisfaction of IFC; (ii) identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the SEMS; (iii) commit to implement the SEMS, to ensure that its investments/activities are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements; (iv) demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions; and (v) submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC
Sponsor: CBIQ is a publicly listed bank on the Iraq Stock Exchange and is majority owned by Ahli United Bank B.S.C ('AUB'), a Bahrain based publicly listed banking entity operating in the MENA region.
Cost Nature: The proposed equity investment is intended to further boost CBIQ's capital base within the applicable regulatory framework for all commercial banks operating in Iraq.

Project Description: The project involves an IFC investment in two subsidiaries of OAO Energomera Concern ('Energomera Group'): namely OAO Monocrystal ('Monocrystal'), and ZAO Energomera ('Energomera'). Energomera develops and produces a wide range of electronic metering technologies and equipment.  Monocrystal produces (i) synthetic sapphires - the key material for substrate used in the production of light-emitting diodes ('LEDs'), and (ii) special materials (namely aluminum photovoltaic paste) used in the production of solar cells.
Impact:
i.The project is expected to contribute to the energy savings in Russia through wider use of metering, especially new generation meters, and lead to reduced GHG emissions in the longer term. Monocrystal's increased production will support further reduction in GHG emissions through the use of LED lighting and employment of solar cells in electricity generation.
ii.Employment preservation: IFC's investment will support one of the largest employers in Stavropol.  Moreover, Energomera is a high-technology employer in a region where employment opportunities are generally limited to agriculture jobs. Currently the Company employs approximately 4 500 people of which 2 300 are female.
iii.	Monocrystal is an export oriented company which brings foreign currency denominated revenues to Russia.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed project would be the second IFCs investment with OAO Energomera Concern.  The initial investment has been regularly supervised and its E&S performance has been determined to be successful, with the company completing all actions included in the initial E&S Action Plan.  The proposed new investment will expand to cover operations outside the scope of the initial investment and these new areas have been evaluated by the IFC E&S specialist team.  This evaluation has concluded that the new project only will have limited and readily mitigable adverse social and environmental impacts, and the project has therefore been processed as a category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social procedures.  Details on IFC''s environmental and social evaluation findings can be found on the projects ESRS.
Sponsor: Energomera Group is a Russian Group. Neither the Group nor its subsidiaries are publicly traded at this stage. The Group has 16 years of operating history. Mr. Vladimir Polyakov, is the main shareholder of the Group and its subsidiaries, with 93.4% shareholding.
Cost Nature: Proposed corporate loans to Energomera and Monocrystal include senior loans up to $20 million (or its Ruble equivalent) to Energomera for refinancing its short-term loans; and up to of $15 million to Monocrystal to support the growth of Company's operations in 2011 and refinance its short term loans.

Project Name: Exim India: South Asian IDA countries Export Facility
Project Description:
Export-Import Bank of India ('Exim Bank') was formed in 1981 under the Export-Import Bank of India Act, and is a financial institution whose capital has been wholly subscribed by the Government of India. Exim Bank provides financial assistance to exporters and importers and also aims to develop relationships with export-oriented companies by assisting them in various capacities such as identifying overseas markets, providing loans and guarantees and export credit. Its non-institutional clients include mainly private sector entities. 

The proposed investment involves a long term loan on IFC's own account and mobilization by IFC of parallel loans from international commercial banks to Exim Bank. The proceeds of the IFC loan will be used to finance exports from India to other South Asian countries from private sector exporters, mainly middle market companies.
Impact:
The development impact of the project is expected to be: 

-	supporting international trade between India and other South Asian countries; 
-	providing access to finance to the underserved medium enterprise sector as they would be able to secure financing to execute export orders in the current weak market conditions; and
-	helping boost confidence in the Indian economy amongst other market participants and facilitate improvement in international credit flows to India.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves IFC support for the business of Trade Finance and has been categorized as Category FI project according to IFC Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Exim Bank had developed a Social and Environment Management System (SEMS) as part of an earlier IFC Project to ensure compliance with the IFC Exclusion List and has also confirmed to IFC that Exim Banks HR Policy and Procedures are in line with the IFC Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working Conditions. In the light of current investment, IFC will review the existing SEMS during appraisal and recommend enhancements, if needed.
Sponsor: The capital of Exim Bank is wholly subscribed by the Government of India.
Cost Nature: The proposed investment is up to $75 million of loan on IFC's own account and around $ 225 million parallel loans to be mobilized from international commercial banks.

Project Description:
TCG Holdings, Inc ('TCG', or the 'Company') is a Philippine holding company with interests in food service and manufacturing, hotel operations and education. TCG is undertaking an expansion of its education business line, in particular the Asian School of Hospitality Arts ('ASHA'), operated by the Center for Hospitality Arts Management Philippines ('CHAMP').

ASHA is a chain of education and training schools focused on the hospitality industry, specifically training for 'front-of-the-house' staff for hotels, restaurants, resorts, and other tourism industry service providers. ASHA offers bachelors' degree (Bachelor of Science in Hotel and Restaurant Management), diploma (Diploma in Hospitality Management), certificate (Certificate in Hotel and Restaurant Operations), and short courses under a flexible modular or 'ladderized' approach. ASHA is undertaking the expansion of two existing school facilities in Antipolo and Quezon City, and the establishment of four new campuses in Pampanga, Naga, Cebu and Taguig (the 'Project'). The expansion will increase ASHA's student capacity by 5,000 students from the current 1,410 students, and will require around 300 additional employees for the six locations.
Review Scope: The IFC review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information made available by the sponsor. The appraisal involved meetings with senior management of TCG, as well as a review of the Company environmental and social systems, policies and procedures and their application. As the funding will be used solely for expanding the ASHA business, the appraisal focused on the ASHA schools at Quezon City and Antipolo and the proposed expansion sites in these two locations as well as the potential sites for a new campus at Pampanga. Visits to the TCG head office and Centre for Culinary Arts in Katipunan, Seven Suites in Antipolo and The Orange Place in Quezon City were undertaken to review the implementation of group policies, notably the environmental management system and life and fire safety. Although visits were not made to the potential sites at Cebu, Naga and Taguig the selection criteria for these locations were reviewed.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
The project has been categorized as Category B according to IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The nature of ASHA's operations, which involve the provision of educational services, is such that adverse E&S impacts are minimal. Key environmental, social, health and safety impacts associated with the Project during construction and operation include: the sponsor's system to manage E&S issues during construction and operation of schools; land acquisition issues at campus sites; labor and working conditions; community and staff occupational health and safety issues; life and fire safety design and provisions; management and minimization of air, water and solid pollutants during construction and operation; energy and water usage efficiency; and community engagement.  

The project may result in a limited number of specific adverse environmental and social impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. ASHA will manage its environmental and social performance in accordance with applicable local laws and regulations and international standards, including IFC's Performance Standards on Social and Environmental Sustainability and IFC's Environmental, Health and Safety General Guidelines.

Project Description:
TCG Holdings, Inc ('TCG', or the 'Company') is a Philippine holding company with interests in food service and manufacturing, hotel operations and education. TCG is undertaking an expansion of its education business line, in particular the Asian School of Hospitality Arts ('ASHA'), operated by the Center for Hospitality Arts Management Philippines ('CHAMP').

ASHA is a chain of education and training schools focused on the hospitality industry, specifically training for 'front-of-the-house' staff for hotels, restaurants, resorts, and other tourism industry service providers. ASHA offers bachelors' degree (Bachelor of Science in Hotel and Restaurant Management), diploma (Diploma in Hospitality Management), certificate (Certificate in Hotel and Restaurant Operations), and short courses under a flexible modular or 'ladderized' approach. ASHA is undertaking the expansion of two existing school facilities in Antipolo and Quezon City, and the establishment of four new campuses in Pampanga, Naga, Cebu and Taguig (the 'Project'). The expansion will increase ASHA's student capacity by 5,000 students from the current 1,410 students, and will require around 300 additional employees for the six locations.
Environmental Social Issues: The project has been categorized as Category B according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The nature of ASHAs operations, which involve the provision of educational services, is such that adverse E&S impacts are minimal. Key environmental, social, health and safety impacts associated with the Project during construction and operation include: the sponsors system to manage E&S issues during construction and operation of schools; land acquisition issues at campus sites; labor and working conditions; community and staff occupational health and safety issues; life and fire safety design and provisions; management and minimization of air, water and solid pollutants during construction and operation; energy and water usage efficiency; and community engagement.  The project may result in a limited number of specific adverse environmental and social impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. ASHA will manage its environmental and social performance in accordance with applicable local laws and regulations and international standards, including IFCs Performance Standards on Social and Environmental Sustainability and IFC''s Environmental, Health and Safety General Guidelines.
Sponsor:
TCG was formed in 2007 to own four operational companies: i) Cravings Food Services Inc. ('Cravings'), ii) Innkeepers Inc. ('Innkeepers'), iii) CNA Culinary Services Inc. (CCA Manila), and iv) CHAMP which operates ASHA. TCG is a sizeable business group with about 650 employees across its array of related industries namely: (i) Food Service and Manufacturing through Cravings, ii) Hotel Operations through Innkeepers, and iii) Education thru CCA Manila and ASHA. The group's operations started when Cravings Bakeshop was established in 1989.

TCG is owned by the project sponsors Ms. Susana Guerrero (40%), her daughter, Ms. Marinela Trinidad (30%) and her son-in-law, Mr. Frederick Trinidad (30%). Ms. Susana Guerrero is Chairman of the Company, Ms. Marinela Trinidad is Group Treasurer and Vice-President, and Mr. Frederick Trinidad sits as Non-Executive Director.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is an A loan of up to Php 690 million for IFC's own account.

Project Description: The project involves an IFC investment in two subsidiaries of OAO Concern Energomera (Energomera Group): namely OAO Monocrystal (Monocrystal), and  ZAO Energomera (Energomera). Energomera develops and produces a wide range of electronic metering technologies and equipment.  Monocrystal produces synthetic sapphires - the key substrate used in the production of light-emitting diodes (LEDs), and special materials used in the production of solar photovoltaic cells. The loans will be guaranteed by the Energomera Group. The project contemplates extending A loans to Energomera for refinancing its short-term loans; and Monocrystal to support the growth of the two company''s operations in 2011 and refinance its short term loans.
Review Scope: The proposed project would be the second IFCs investment with OAO Concern Energomera (Energomera Group). The Energomera Group has two main business lines in Russia; OAO Monocrystal, ZAO Energomera, and beside this two minor business lines within agricultural equipment manufacturing and farming, and two minor assembly lines abroad.The initial project financing was to the OAO Monocrystal subsidiary - one of the worlds largest producers of synthetic single crystal sapphire. Environmental and social (E&S) review of the earlier investment was conducted in 2008, a summary of which can be found at the following link: http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/2bc34f011b50ff6e85256a550073ff1c/a36f49ac5bb9530c852576ba000e32db?opendocument&Highlight=0,EnergomeraThe initial investment has been regularly supervised and its E&S performance has been determined to be in material compliance with at-approval agreements. The company has completed all actions included in the E&S Action Plan. The most recent supervision visit to the Monocrystal operation in Stavropol by an E&S consultant on behalf of IFC was carried out in December 2010. During this supervision visit the consultant reviewed environmental and social (E&S) management policies and procedures; health and safety (HS) accident records; monitoring programs and data on air emissions, effluent discharges and waste disposal, covering the Stavropol and the parallel Monocrystal operation. in Belgorod (Atlas) with the help of the responsible company specialists.The proposed investment will expand outside the scope of the initial investment by also providing funding to ZAO Energomera, a producer of a wide range of electronic metering technologies and equipment with two production facilities:  ZAO Energomera  ZIP in Nevinnomysk and ETZ in Stavropol.  Both were visited by an E&S consultant in 2008 during the appraisal of the first project with the Energomera Group. Recently telephone interviews with specialists in charge of E&S matters at the ZIP and ETZ facilities were conducted to get an update on the current E&S performance of these factories.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This proposed project has been developed in accordance with national regulatory requirements. None of factories operated by the Energomera Group are scheduled for major retrenchments, closure, or expansions outside existing site boundaries.  This is a category B project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure, because potential adverse social and environmental impacts are limited and readily mitigable as described in the following sections.
Sector: BA - Electrical Machinery, Equipment and Components (Electric Lighting, Motors, Batteries, Insulated Wires and Cables, Fiber Optic Cable, Carbon and Graphite Products, etc.)

Project Description: Sagicor Financial Corporation (SFC or the Company) is one of the largest local insurers operating in the Caribbean region, with total assets of $4.9 billion and total equity of $744 million as of September 30, 2010. Its origins date back to 1840, when the Barbados Mutual Life Assurance Society (BMLAS) was founded. In 2002, BMLAS demutualised with support of its policyholders and the SFC Group was formed as a publicly-listed holding company. Today, the SFC Group offers life, health, P&C insurance, as well as annuities, pensions and mutual fund products in 22 countries throughout the Caribbean, the U.S. and the U.K.  The SFC Group is the number one provider of individual and group life and health insurance in Barbados, Jamaica and the East Caribbean region, and a significant provider in the Trinidad and Tobago market.  As of year-end 2009, operations in the Caribbean contributed two-thirds of the revenues of the group, while U.S. and U.K. operations combined contributed one third of the total group revenue.  A.M. Best rates SFC''s main Life and P&C subsidiaries as A- (Excellent), placing them in the top quartile of global peers in terms of financial strength.The proposed project consists of an IFC investment package of up to $100 million in the form of common and preferred shares of the Company.  The proposed investment will be used to secure additional funds for general corporate purposes and to pursue the Companys ongoing growth and expansion strategies in the region.
Impact: With the financial and institutional backing of the IFC, the Company is expected to strengthen its position in the market as a leading indigenous insurance company and to bolster its prospects for further expansion, while at the same time consolidating and strengthening its life insurance operations. In addition, by investing in SFC and, consequently, the local insurance markets, IFC can also play a critical role in driving more widespread access to financial and insurance services, as well as in developing the local capital markets.
Environmental Social Issues: This project will support the insurance business and has been classified as a Category C project. If the investment is completed, the company will be required to review potential commitments to ensure that their main business does not involve activities in IFC''s Exclusion List and to demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions (PS2). The company will also be required to inform IFC in the event of any change in nature or scope of its business or operations.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Sagicor Financial Corporation, a listed company on the Barbados, Trinidad & Tobago, and London Stock Exchanges. The largest shareholders are National Insurance Board of Barbados (6%), Republic Bank Limited (as nominee) (4%), T & T Unit Trust Corporation (3%), and RBTT Trust Limited (as nominee) (1%). The remaining shares are held by more than 37,000 shareholders, mostly individuals, each holding less than 1%.
Cost Nature: The proposed investment is for up to $100 million in the form of common and preferred shares of the Company.

Project Description:
Agrofertil (or the 'Company'), founded in 1993, is one of Paraguay's leading crop input distributor and agronomic services companies.  The Company assists farmers, cooperatives and small distributors providing technical support, agricultural inputs and pre-harvest financing. The Company's headquarters are in Ciudad del Este, and it has 9 distribution centers and 8 silos with a total capacity of 75,500 tons of grain storage.

The project consists of providing a working capital facility to Agrofertil to support the pre-harvest financing needs of its network of clients (the 'Project').  The Project will increase access to working capital finance for farmers in Paraguay, who will also benefit from Agrofertil's commercialization services and technical expertise. 

The Project consists of providing Agrofertil a one- year loan facility (the 'Facility') with up to five renewable tranches and composed of an A-Loan of up to $15 million and a B-Loan of up to $10 million, subject to market appetite.
Review Scope:
IFC's appraisal of the project encompassed site visits to the following facilities in Paraguay: Agrofertil's headquarters in Ciudad del Este, the distribution center in San Alberto; and the silos of San Alberto; Troncal 3 and Santa Fe. In addition, the team visited Agrofertil's reforestation project in Colonia Itakyry.

Site visits were supported by a review of environmental and social (E&S) documents provided by Agrofertil, which included written replies to an E&S questionnaire submitted by IFC; local permits and licenses (products, facilities and transportation); environmental reports and updates to the local regulators; and Human Resources policies and procedures.

Meetings were held with Agrofertil's administrative manager and his team responsible for the environmental, occupational health and safety (OHS) and human resources aspects of Agrofertil; with the grain department director, responsible for silos operations; and with the logistic manager, who is in charge of the transportation fleet.

Project Description:
Kordsa Global Endustriyel Iplik ve Kord Bezi Sanayi ve Ticaret A.S. ('Kordsa' or the 'Sponsor'), a existing IFC client, is the world's leading producer of nylon and polyester yarns, cord and industrial fabric mainly used in automotive tires, rubber parts, and transmission and conveyor belts. Kordsa has 11 manufacturing plants located in 9 countries. The proposed investment in the South American subsidiaries of Kordsa entails providing two separate corporate loans to Kordsa Brasil S.A. and Kordsa Argentina S.A. ('Kordsa Argentina'), to be utilized for refinancing part of their existing debt, working capital requirements and maintenance capital expenditures. This summary refers exclusively to Kordsa Argentina ('the Company').

Kordsa Argentina is located in Berazategui, about 20 Km south of Buenos Aires, and currently has three operational sections: spinning, utilities, and the tire cord fabric ('TCF) section, which includes twisting, weaving and dipping. The Company is currently restructuring its production to focus on yarn manufacturing only and the TCF section should close by the end of February 2011.
Review Scope: Social and environmental issues reviewed during the appraisal mission for this Category B investment included: Kordsa's social and environmental assessment and management systems; labor and working conditions at the Berazategui plant including workplace air quality, occupational health and safety and retrenchment; emissions to air and water; solid waste disposal; resource efficiency including potential to improve energy efficiency and recycling of waste; relations with the nearby communities.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFC's Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria as is described in the following sections.

Project Description: PTC India Financial Services Limited (PFS or the Company) is a non-deposit taking, non-banking finance company that has been categorized as an Infrastructure Finance Company by the Reserve Bank of India. PFS is focused on funding projects across the energy value chain in India. The Project, which includes IFC debt funding to PFS, will allow PFS to utilize these funds to increase investments in the Renewable Energy (RE) space in India.
Impact:
Wider impact: With IFC's support, PFS can support a wider range of clients in the RE space potentially across multiple technologies and increase the renewable energy generation base in India. 

Demonstration effect: PFS is a developing financial intermediary and its expansion in this space is likely to help attract other financial institutions to increase their risk appetite and invest more in these sectors. 

GHG Savings: The proposed investment will result in substantial savings of GHG emissions as it will encourage power generation from renewable and climate friendly fuels. This is critical in view of Government's overall intention to reduce carbon emissions. 

Institution building: IFC's support to PFS will help it to scale up its capacity to assess clean energy projects through sharing of its experience and knowledge of the sector worldwide.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  During appraisal, IFC analyzed the activities proposed to be supported with IFC financing for types of transactions, size, tenor and industry sectors and determined the Applicable Performance Requirements based on an analysis of the potential Social and Environmental risks associated with the FI portfolio and considering IFCs investment. The Applicable Performance Requirements are (i) the IFC Exclusion List; (ii) the applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and regulations; and (iii) the IFC Performance Standards. IFC has reviewed the FIs existing S&E risk management procedure. It was found that the FI:	Undertakes E&S regulatory compliance review for all projects as part of its Social & Environment Due Diligence (SEDD) process. It reviews project related documents such as EIA, SIA, EMP, etc and undertakes site visit at the time of appraisal.	Is in the process of developing a formal Social & Environment Management System (SEMS) for Renewable Energy projects i.e. Wind, hydro, solar, geo-thermal, waste to energy, bio-fuel and biomass based co-generation. The SEMS will be benchmarked to IFC Performance Standards and will include detailed sectoral guidelines. 	Has two officers charged with the responsibility of ensuring S&E risk assessment of projects. The S&E risk assessment is carried out by all investment officers along with project appraisal. IFC will appraise the FIs labor practices to ensure compliance with the IFC Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working Conditions. Based on the Applicable Performance Requirements and FIs existing S&E risk management procedures and capacity review, the project will be required to: 	Develop an Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS), to the satisfaction of IFC;	Ensure that there is adequate capacity within the FI to implement its SEMS and to ensure compliance of projects with the applicable requirements; 	Commit to implement the SEMS, to ensure that its investments/activities supported by IFC financing are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements;	Commit to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions; andSubmit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: PFS is sponsored by PTC India Ltd. (PTC)  the largest power trading company in India (operating since 1999). PTC currently holds a 77.6% equity stake in PFS while GS Strategic Investments Limited and Macquarie India Holdings Limited each hold a 11.2% equity stake.
Cost Nature: IFC plans to provide long term debt to PFS of up to $50 million in the form of a senior loan, which will be used exclusively for on-lending to companies and projects in the renewable energy space in India.

Project Description: The project is an equity investment of up to $35 million in Transcapitalbank (TCB), a medium sized Russian bank, well known to IFC from earlier projects.  The purpose of the project is to improve access to finance for mid-size companies and SMEs, particularly in regions outside of Moscow, and to strengthen the capital of the bank and support its preparation for an IPO.  IFC is also considering a loan of up to $25 million and advisory work to support lending in the area of energy efficiency.
Impact: The project is expected to have high developmental impact by a) improving access to finance for mid-size Russian companies and SMEs, b) strengthening the capital base of a well-managed Russian bank and supporting its planned IPO, and c) helping the development of funding for energy efficiency projects in Russia.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as Category FI.  TCB will be required to ensure compliance of the activities financed with the IFC Exclusion List, Russian environmental and social laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards.  TCB will also be required to demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions.
Sponsor: TCB is a successful and well-managed Russian bank which lends mainly to mid-sized corporates and SMEs.  Its main shareholders are Mrs. Gryadovaya and Mr. Ivanovsky who are spouses and together own 37,7% of the bank.  EBRD and KfW own 28.6% and 10.5%, respectively.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $60 million, consisting of equity for IFCs own account of up to $35 million and a loan for IFCs own account of up to $25 million.
Investment: 60.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan25.0Equity35.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: TCB is headquartered in Moscow.  Its main focus is lending to clients outside the large city centers.  With 18 regional branches and 71 points of sale, the bank is among the top five banks in the following regional markets: Perm, Syktyvkar and Ryazan - the latter two are considered frontier regions.

Company Name: OPERATORI I SHPERNDARJES SE ENERGJISE ELEKTRIKE SH.A.
Project Description:
CEZ Shpërndarje is the power distribution company of Albania. The Company operates under the power distribution system operator and retail public supplier licenses, serving around 1.1 million customers. The project is to provide long-term financing to the Company to support its 2009-2013 investment program, which is aimed at reducing distribution losses, enhancing operational efficiency, improving reliability of electricity supply and connecting new customers ('the Project'). 

CEZ Shpërndarje is 76 per cent owned by the Czech energy group, CEZ a.s. ('CEZ' or the 'Sponsor') which acquired this controlling stake in the Company through the privatization which was successfully concluded in May 2009.

The Company owns, operates and maintains Albania's electricity distribution system in medium and low voltage lines (from 35 kV to 0.4 kV) including substations (110 kV/35kV) and 35 kV step down substation transformers.  In 2009, the Company purchased 6,500 GWh from the grid and sold 4,260 GWh of electricity with the distribution loss of 34%.  This loss rate is expected to be improved to 21% in 2014.  The Company has about 5,000 employees.  

The Company's 2009-2013 investment program, starting from CEZ's acquisition of the Company, is expected to cost around 154 million and will consist of the following measures:  (i) modernization of the distribution network, including refurbishment of substations, (ii) installation of new meters, (iii) connection of new customers, and (iv) implementation of a new billing system.
Review Scope:
Documents reviewed:
- Information provided by CEZ Shpërndarje SHA (the 'Company') about the Company's environmental, health and safety and social performance and programs to implement, in response to IFC's questionnaires.
- The Company's newsletters to employees about how the Company is planning to improve its service 'Buletin informative per ponunjesit e OSSH-se).
- Technical and Environmental Due Diligence report prepared by FICHTNER (on behalf of IFC and EBRD), January 2011
- 'Private Sector Participation in Albanian Power Distribution, Distribution Network, Environment Baseline Conditions, SNC Lavalin, June 2008.

Company Interviews and Field Visit in March 2010:
Face-to-face meetings with CEZ Shpërndarje officers in charge of environmental, health and safety and human resources aspects, as well as field visits to selected facilities of the Company (electricity distribution lines, substations, administration buildings, customer telephone center, warehouses).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
The Project has been categorized as a category B project according to IFC's Procedure for Environmental and Social Review for Projects because the implementation of the Company's investment program aimed at reducing distribution losses, improving efficiency and reliability of supply, and improving the financial and operational performance of the Company is expected to (i) have limited adverse social and environmental impacts that are few in number, largely reversible, and can be readily addressed through mitigation measures, and (ii) have positive impacts on the Company's environmental and social performance.  

Key environmental and social issues reviewed during appraisal included the Company's environmental, health and safety management system, labor and working conditions including occupational health and safety and retrenchment of employees, pollution prevention and abatement (e.g. management of PCB contaminated transformers, leakage of transformer oils at used transformers storage areas), and community health and safety management.

Company Name: OPERATORI I SHPERNDARJES SE ENERGJISE ELEKTRIKE SH.A.
Project Description: CEZ Shpërndarje SHA (the 'Company') is the power distribution company of Albania, which was privatized in 2009. The Company operates under the power distribution system operator and retail public supplier licenses, serving around 1.1 million customers. The project is to provide long-term financing to the Company to support its 2009-2013 investment program, which is aimed at reducing distribution losses, enhancing operational efficiency, improving reliability of electricity supply and connecting new customers ('the Project').
Impact: The Project's expected development impact is as follows: (i) supporting the expected technical and financial turnaround of the power distribution sector in Albania, which in turn would improve sector sustainability and growth; (ii) enhancing energy efficiency through reduction of energy losses; (iii) upgrading and expanding the power system to improve the reliability and quality of electricity supply; (iv) increasing electricity access, especially for the poor and rural communities in one of the poorest countries in south-eastern Europe; and (v) supporting the country's power sector reform. Through the above, the Project is expected to deliver positive fiscal impact and contribute to Albania's long-term growth prospects.
Environmental Social Issues: The Project has been categorized as a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review for Projects because the implementation of the Companys investment program aimed at reducing distribution losses, improving efficiency and reliability of supply, and improving the financial and operational performance of the Company is expected to: (i)  have limited adverse social and environmental impacts that are few in number, largely reversible, and can be readily addressed through mitigation measures, and (ii) have positive impacts on the Companys environmental and social performance.  Key environmental and social issues reviewed during appraisal included the Companys environmental, health and safety management system, labor and working conditions including occupational health and safety and retrenchment of employees, pollution prevention and abatement (e.g. management of PCB contaminated transformers, leakage of transformer oils at used transformers storage areas), and community health and safety management.
Sponsor:
CEZ is the largest power utility in the Czech Republic, one of the ten largest utilities in Europe and an existing IFC client through IFC's investments in AkEnerji (Project No. 29359) and SEDAS (Project No. 27559). The CEZ Group has an installed power generation capacity of around 14.8 GW and a customer base of 9.3 million in the power markets of Central and Southeastern Europe. CEZ currently has power distribution operations in the Czech Republic, Albania, Bulgaria, Romania and Turkey.

CEZ owns 76% of CEZ Shpërndarje and the remaining 24% is owned by the Ministry of Economy Trade and Energy ('METE'), Albania.
