Location: CEZ Shpërndarje is the sole electricity distribution and retail company in Albania. The Company owns, operates and maintains Albania's electricity distribution system in medium and low voltage lines (from 35 kV to 0.4 kV), including substations (110 kV/35kV) and 35 kV step down substation transformers. The Company currently serves around 1.1 million customers throughout Albania.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The Project has been categorized as a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review for Projects because the implementation of the Companys investment program aimed at reducing distribution losses, improving efficiency and reliability of supply, and improving the financial and operational performance of the Company is expected to: (i)  have limited adverse social and environmental impacts that are few in number, largely reversible, and can be readily addressed through mitigation measures, and (ii) have positive impacts on the Companys environmental and social performance.  Key environmental and social issues reviewed during appraisal included the Companys environmental, health and safety management system, labor and working conditions including occupational health and safety and retrenchment of employees, pollution prevention and abatement (e.g. management of PCB contaminated transformers, leakage of transformer oils at used transformers storage areas), and community health and safety management.

Project Description:
The project involves the construction of a new 140-bed hospital in Lima, Clinica Delgado. The hospital will have strong oncology and cardiology operations and will be a referral center for a network of clinics, which are expected to be built in the medium and longer term in the outskirts and outside of Lima. Clinica Delgado will be the first in the country to have a partnership with an international operator, American Hospital Management Company (AHMC). Additionally, this new hospital will create vertical integration for its sponsor, Grupo Salud, which currently has an oncology insurance operation (Oncosalud) and is also involved in a PPP with ESSALUD (local administrator of Social Security) for the construction/operation of a an outpatient facility (known as 'Torre Trecca').

The project fits with IFC's strategy to support the healthcare sector in the region, including investments in Peru. The rationale for pursuing this investment is based on (a) presence of a reputable fund Sponsor, in which IFC has committed an investment, (b) the project's goal of creating a center of excellence in Lima, offering high quality services, (c) the Sponsor's medium term goal of expanding in middle income regions outside of Lima, and (d) the opportunity to strengthen IFC's health and education presence in Peru, which historically has been a difficult market to enter and where private health offer is poor and the population is underserved.
Impact: (i) Creation of high quality health services provider as a center of excellence in Peru ; (ii) Demonstration effect on viability of private health care institutions; (iii) Provision of services to middle and lower income patients through PPP facility (Trecca) which will benefit from the flagship hospital within the group, despite not being financed by IFC
Environmental Social Issues: Grupo Salud has agreed to an ESAP for social, environmental affairs, quality, occupational health and safety (SEMS).  Conditions of disbursement agreed upon are:  Appointment of E&S manager reporting to senior managementE&S Impact Assessment (ESIA) to address environmental and social impacts during construction and future operationsOccupational health and safety management systems procedureRetain a radiation protection scientific/technical expertise, satisfactory to IFC, to supervise the construction of the oncology facilitiesLife and fire safety system design Design and implement community engagement program procedureManagement Systems procedures addressing chance finds for cultural heritage Highlights of ESAP are:The ESAP developed and agreed with the Client is geared to operate a social and environmental management system to address and manage impacts during the construction as well as during the operational phase. It is envisaged that on completion of the construction, the Grupo Salud hospital will be operating in a manner consistent with Peru national law, IFC performance standards, WBG EHS General Guidelines, and health care facilities EHS guidelines. The likelihood of E+S impacts has been evaluated based on the project implementation phases including construction, commissioning, operation, and maintenance.During construction ESAP items will be addressing occupational health and safety of the workers; life and fire safety master plan design and certification; community engagement procedures to address impacts resulting from traffic, dust, and noise from construction equipment; generation of waste; chance finds procedure; and quality assurance during construction of the oncology facilities. The key E+S issues associated with the operational phase will encompass labor relations, including implementation of good hospital management practices, employee health and safety and radiation exposure monitoring; life and fire safety implementation, emergency contingency plan; food safety and hygiene; water conservation management procedure, pretreatment, adequate  emergency level of potable water; hazardous and non-hazardous waste management including disposal of radioactive waste as per Peruvian Regulation and International Atomic Energy Agency international Standards; establish procedure to ensure efficient energy and water use; community engagement and handling of grievances; pest and rodent management system. ** Additional to IFCs ESAP Grupo Salud has approval of traffic impact by Limas transportation authorities, permits from Peruvian

Grupo Salud is a holding company, grouping Oncosalud (the current operation) and other new projects, including Clinica Delgado. Project Description:
LLC Euro Leasing was established in 2004 by a large local car dealer/ manufacturer 'Atoll Holding'. Today Euro Leasing provides a full range of transport leasing services, including additional products which provide entire cycle of fleet management, including vehicles registration, insurance, daily fuel monitoring, damage control, fleet management, GPRS location, etc. Euro Leasing operates five regional representative offices in major Ukrainian cities, works with 150 car service stations throughout Ukraine.

The Company's market share approximates 13%, and it is one of the two serviced leasing providers in Ukraine. The Company leases passenger cars, commercial vehicles (trucks), buses and specialized transport (loaders, tractors and combines) of leading international brands. The client base of the Company includes international clients, as well as large local companies and SME's. Today, SME's account for approximately 72% of Company's clients by quantity and for 47% by total fleet.

The proposed transaction fits well into IFC's financial markets strategy in Ukraine. Euro Leasing is one of the leading leasing companies in the country dedicated to both, corporate and SME sectors. It also has substantial exposure to agricultural industry. With this Project, IFC is looking to provide an access to finance for local SMEs, including those engaged in the agricultural sector.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFC Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Under the terms of the proposed investment, Euroleasing will be required to ensure compliance of its leasing operations with the IFC Exclusion List and the Ukrainian Environmental and Social laws and regulations and to develop adequate procedures and capacity to manage potential social and environmental risks associated with leasing activities. The company also needs to apply IFC Performance Standards 2: Labor and Working Conditions to its own labor practices.  The company will be required to submit a periodic environmental and social performance report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC
Sponsor:
The Company is owned by Atoll Holding (60%) and private equity fund EuroVentures (40%). 

Atoll Holding is one of the major car dealers in Ukraine for Seat and VW Group brands, as well as manufacturer of Skoda cars (CJSC 'Eurocar') in Western Ukraine. The ultimate beneficial shareholder of the Group is a Ukrainian businessman - Mr. Oleg Boyarin.

Euroventures Ukraine Fund II is a Kyiv-based private equity fund focused on investments in Ukraine and CIS. IFC is the Fund investor alongside EBRD, FMO, F. Pictet, Swiss Investment Fund for Emerging Markets (SIFEM), IDI Emerging Markets and other reputable investors.
Cost Nature:
The total Project cost is estimated at $10 million at IFC's own account:

- A Loan for $5 million for 4 years, targeted towards leases of commercial transport for qualified SME-lessees, including a sub-limit targeted for the agri-sector financing. 
- A Loan for $ 5 million for 5 years, which will have a conversion option for the Company's shares.

Project Description: IFC, alongside ADM Capital ('ADM') and a large European pension fund (collectively, the 'Consortium'), is proposing to invest in Universal Saglik Yatirimlari Holding A.S. ('UHG' or the 'Company'), one of Turkey's largest hospital networks and healthcare providers. The Consortium will provide capital to UHG to support its regional expansion across 1st and 2nd tier cities in Turkey.UHG actually covers 18 hospitals, including 11 operational hospitals in Turkey (Istanbul, Diyarbakir, Bursa, Karabuk, Manisa, Izmir, and Bodrum), 1 in Tirana, Albania, and 5 hospitals currently under construction in Malatya, Kusadasi, Adana, Konya and Cizre.
Review Scope: IFC's review of this project consisted of site visits to five operational hospitals and clinics and to one hospital construction site, all located in Istanbul and Bursa. The documentation provided by UHG and ADM about these and other hospitals located in different parts of Turkey have been also reviewed. The review is made on available documentation about status of permits and licenses, certificates, building design, equipment checks, handling of hazardous chemicals and wastes, emergency management schemes, audit records by the Ministry of Health, Atomic Energy Institution of Turkey, Ministry of Environment, other third party control documents such as expert reports on building structure safety, life and fire safety, training records, information on human resources and management. Interviews were held with the corporate management team including General Manager, Group Quality Coordinator, Human Resources Manager, Hospital Managers, Engineering and Infection Control Staff.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The key environmental and social issues related to this project include permits, regulatory compliance; environment, health and safety practices during construction, renovation and restructuring; structural design and safety;  life and fire safety; emergency preparedness and response; control of air emissions from combustion and other operations; waste management particularly including medical, bio-hazardous and radioactive waste; waste minimization;  energy and water conservation;  treatment and disposal of liquid effluents; hazardous materials management; occupational health and safety including employee training and monitoring programs; adequacy of human resources policy and practices; community health, safety and security; prevention of nosocomial diseases; potable water supply and treatment; food safety; engagement with communities; respect for patient rights. The appraisal concluded that any impacts will be limited, site-specific and can be addressed by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Therefore, this is a Category B project according to IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedure.

Project Description: Grupo Salud (or the Client) is a holding company, grouping Oncosalud and other new projects. The project involves the construction of a new 140-bed hospital in Lima, Clinica Delgado. The clinic will have oncology and cardiology operations and will be a referral center for a network of clinics, which are expected to be built in the medium and longer term in the outskirts and outside of Lima. Clinica Delgado will be the first in Peru to have a partnership with an international operator, American Hospital Management Company (AHMC), and will most likely get involved in a PPP with ESSALUD. Grupo Saluds main strategic objective is to forward integrate into health provision. The Grupo Salud holding will encompass Oncosalud and Enfoca. Oncosalud is a prepaid health provider specializing in oncology services. It has over 20 years of experience in the Peruvian market, is a member of the International Union Against Cancer (UICC), and has around 400,000 affiliate members, and 268 affiliated doctors. With a current focus in Lima (3 centers), it operates day care treatment centers, as well as pharmaceutical distribution and labs for testing and diagnostic. Enfoca is a Peruvian private equity fund, managed by a local team of investment professionals. The proposed funding consists of a $25 million A loan for IFCs own account and a $15 million parallel loan from DEG.
Review Scope: IFCs environmental and social specialist visited the companys headquarters in Lima, Peru, in order to conduct a site assessment and desk review of planned environmental, occupational health and safety (OH&S), social and community operational procedures. Meetings were held with the CEO of Grupo Salud and with senior management representatives. The scope of the due diligence encompassed a site and surroundings visit where the Clinica Delgado will be built.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that may result have been or are being avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards (PS), guidelines or design criteria. This categorization is in line with other projects within the sector.

Project Description: Banco Cooperativo Sicredi S.A. (Bansicredi or the Bank) is the bank of the Sicredi Cooperative System (Sicredi or the System). With origins dating back to 1902, Sicredi has evolved from a small network of rural credit cooperatives to a sophisticated financial intermediary, the 6th largest in Brazil in terms of branch network. The Bank serves as an instrument to enhance the solidity of the System, to manage its liquidity, funding, risk, etc, and to standardize credit culture and policies, with the ultimate goal of increasing access to finance of the individuals who are members of the cooperatives of the Sicredi system.The project, which consists in the provision by IFC of subordinated debt to the Bank, as well as acquiring a participation in its share capital, will support and accelerate the growth of the credit portfolio of cooperatives members of Sicredi.
Impact: The project is expected to (i) increase access to finance to small farmers and other low income individuals in small cities and regions outside of the main urban centers, (ii) increase the loan term for the system members and (iii) support the development of new financial solutions for the system members.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves IFC support for a cooperative bank and has been classified as Category FI. During appraisal IFC reviewed the client''s portfolio and activities to determine their S&E risks as well as existing credit policies and labor practices. Based on the review, the client will be required to develop a Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS) to manage the S&E risks of its portfolio by assessing compliance of sub-projects with the IFC Exclusion List and the applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and Regulations. In addition, Sicredi will need to identify qualified persons to manage and implement the SEMS; demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions; and submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is the holding company (Sicredi Par) of the System. The System is composed of 128 affiliated credit cooperatives (the Cooperatives), 5 central cooperatives (the Centrals), Sicredi Par, the Bank (and its subsidiaries), a Confederation and a Foundation, serving 1.7 million individual members, primarily small farmers, who are ultimately the owners of the System.The System is structured in three levels. At the base, the Cooperatives are associated with the 5 different Centrals in diverse regions of the country.  The Cooperatives own 100% of the Centrals.  At the secondary level there is Sicredi Par, which is owned by the Cooperatives, through a direct participation of 49% and indirectly, through the Centrals which own the remaining 51%. The Confederation is controlled by the Centrals. At the tertiary level, Sicredi Par has 70% of the Banks share, being the remaining 30% owned by Rabo Financial Institutional Development, a financial arm of Rabobank.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment consists of a structured subordinated debt and equity transaction in an amount of up to $ 60 million. The proceeds will be used by Bansicredi to reinforce both its capital base and that of the Cooperatives of the System.

Company Name: QASIM INTERNATIONAL CONTAINER TERMINAL PAKISTAN LIMITED
Project Description: Qasim International Container Terminal Ltd. (QICT or the Company) operates a container terminal at Port Qasim approximately 50 kilometers southeast of Karachi, Pakistan. QICT is the leading container terminal operator in Pakistan with a market share of 36% in 2009. The project consists of an inland container depot ('ICD'), a container freight station ('CFS'), and other capital expenditure requirements of QICT, which will help to improve transportation services in Pakistan.  The ICD will be located near the industrial and agricultural center of Lahore and will enable upcountry customers to receive and deliver cargo from Lahore via rail, representing additional convenience and cost savings relative to trucking. The CFS and other capital expenditures will improve services and efficiency for QICT's existing clients at Port Qasim.
Review Scope: IFC's review of this second in a series of related investments included follow-up site visits to the original project facilities at Port Qasim and the proposed new inland facility location in Lahore, as well as meetings with members of QICT's management team at the company's corporate offices in Karachi and its branch office in Lahore in January 2011. IFC staff also reviewed and analyzed technical, environmental, and social information submitted by the client, including the findings of independent quality, environment, and occupational health and safety audits undertaken in the past two years, as well as the most recent operational performance monitoring reports dated June 2010.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The existing QICT facility is well managed and monitored against relevant international certification standards (ISO 14001, OHSAS 18001). The parent company, DP World, is a large and reputable ports management company. As an existing client, QICT submits annual environmental, social, health and safety that document its performance, and IFC's recent visits to QICT's operations (in March 2010 and January 2011) confirmed that there are sound systems in place to manage and monitor E&S and labor issues. The project's impacts are therefore not expected to be diverse, irreversible or unprecedented, resulting in the Category B designation.

Company Name: TAMEK GIDA VE KONSANTRE SANAYI VE TICARET ANONIM SIRKETI
Project Description:
Established in 1955 by Mr. Mehmet Melih Sipahioglu, Tamek Gida ve Konsantre Sanayii ve Ticaret A.S. (Tamek or the Company) concentrates on two main areas: (i) fruit juice and concentrates; and (ii) processed food, including tomato and pepper pastes, ketchup, mayonnaise, canned and stewed products, ready dishes, pickles, jams and marmalades. 

The proposed corporate loan will be utilized for refinancing part of the Company's existing short-term debt, working capital requirements and additional/maintenance capital expenditures (collectively the 'Project')
Review Scope:
The IFC's appraisal of this project included the following:

Site visits to Tamek Headquarters in Besiktas-Istanbul, contracted vegetable fields in Salihli, Tamek plants in Kiziksa-Balikesir, Karacabey-Bursa and Salihli-Manisa. Meetings were held with Supply Chain Director, Plant Production Managers, Operation Managers, Quality Managers, Technical Managers, Human Resources (HR) Director, Occupational Health and Safety (OHS) Consultant, Environmental Consultants, Agriculture Managers and Technicians, contracted vegetable growers, Plant Engineers, Quality engineers, occupational physicians and nurses, trade union representatives and representatives from Salihli Plant's WWTP construction company.

Review of available corporate environmental and social documents, including; Environmental & Social (E&S) questionnaires for each plant, internal regulations (Cell phone legislation, Vehicle legislation, Hiring legislation, Termination of employment legislation, Discipline legislation, Leave legislation, Work-hours legislation, Training legislation, Social benefits legislation, Sales team's premium legislation, Export team's premium legislation, Advance legislation, Travel expenses legislation) and procedures (Periodical meetings procedures, Security personnel procedure, Orientation procedure, Official correspondence procedure, Fire safety procedure), OHS meeting minutes, emission and discharge permits, ambient noise level permits, drinking and waste water analyses, emission measurements, plant maintenance programs, groundwater usage permissions, fire safety reports for Kiziksa and Karacabey plants, ISO 9001 management system certificates, supplier forms, supplier contracts, collective agreement and 2011 approved investment plan.

Company Name: TAMEK GIDA VE KONSANTRE SANAYI VE TICARET ANONIM SIRKETI

   - Local Supply Chain Linkages & Farmers Reached: The Company works with various distributors throughout Turkey and applies contracted farming for various raw materials. So, with the Project the Company would be able to (i) collaborate more with its distributors to increase efficiencies, (ii) support more individual farmers; and (iii) further extend its local supply chain coverage thanks to improved operational and financial performance at corporate level. 
   - Job Preservation & Increased Tax Revenues: With the Project, the Company will be able to retain its existing labor force while improved financial performance would lead to higher revenues/profitability resulting in returns to the society in form of taxes.

The Sponsor is owned by Sipahioglu and Sengor Families, and the remaining 5% of the Company is held by individual members of both families.

Project Description: The proposed project will support TuranBank, a new investment partner for IFC, in providing access to finance for MSMEs operating in Azerbaijan. The project consists of a senior loan of up to US$7 million.

Project Description: Established in 1996, Q & M is a private dental healthcare group listed on the Singapore Stock Exchange operating 40 dental clinics, two dental centers (a larger dental clinic with a more comprehensive range of dental services such as 3D Radiography), one mobile dental clinic, one dental laboratory and a dental supplies company in Singapore. The Sponsor is looking to expand in China and aims to establish a network of dental clinics and a number of dental laboratories (JV facilities).  Currently, the Sponsor has three local Chinese partners based respectively in Beijing, Nanjing and Yiwu, with which it is looking to set up joint venture entities. Q & M and its Yiwu JV partner has applied for a piece of 1.3 hectare plot in a nearby county to build a new facility building.Q & Ms expansion in China is estimated to cost US$30 million and IFC has been approached to provide financing of up to US$15 million to support this expansion.
Review Scope: The scope of review of Q & M Dental Groups (the Sponsor or Q & M) China operations included assessment of the Companys capacity to provide oversight and monitor compliance with IFCs Performance Standards as well as national environmental, social and occupational health and safety regulatory requirements in the Peoples Republic of China.  The scope of IFCs review focuses on Q & Ms China operations, and includes reviewing Q & Ms management system to ensure effective management of future Q & M sites and facilities within China. The review relied on documents and reports made available by Q & M and interviews with management and facility staff in China. IFC staff met with Q & Ms senior management team from Singapore including the Executive Director and the CEO of its China investment arm, and also visited joint venture or potential facilities (the Company or companies) in Beijing (dental clinics), Nanjing (dental clinics) and Yiwu (dental laboratory mainly producing dentures, porcelain teeth, ceramic and metal crowns, implants, and tooth bridges - to supply dental clinics within China) into which Q & M is planning to invest using IFC proceeds.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific and reversible environmental and social impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Key environmental, health and safety, human resources and social issues that were reviewed included the following: environmental and social management system; emissions to the environment  air, water and subsurface; solid, hazardous, biomedical and infectious medical waste and materials management, storage, collection and disposal; life and fire safety and emergency preparedness and response program; community and occupational health and safety; resource use and efficiency; and community engagement.

Project Description: Q & M is Singapores largest private dental healthcare group with clinics located island-wide.  It was listed on the main board of the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading Limited on November 26, 2009. Q & M Dental Group (Singapore) Limiteds (Q & M)s strategy in China is to first establish a network of reputable dental clinics in the first and second tier cities. Once Q & M achieves its objectives of transferring technology, operational practices and skills in the cities, it will work with established local Chinese partners to expand its services beyond main urban areas and to the frontier markets. To date, Q & M has signed agreements to establish joint ventures with two dental clinic groups in China, and it has also entered into binding master agreements with two Chinese dental equipment companies.This project is expected to improve access to high quality dental care in China where standards are generally low. There will be regional transfer of best management and clinical practices from Q & M''s operations in Singapore to facilities in China. This project will also create employment opportunities for dental workers in China and allow them to work in a high-quality, safe clinical environment.
Impact: - Increasing access to high quality dental care: Demand for dental care in China is increasing, yet standards are reported to be generally low. This project will include skills transfer from Singapore.  - Regional integration of best practices: Best management and clinical practices will be transferred from Q & M''s operations in Singapore to its facilities in China.- Employment generation: This project will provide employment opportunities to additional dental workers in China and allow them to work in a high-quality, safe clinical environment.
Environmental Social Issues: This Project involves Q & M investing into JV dental clinics and dental laboratories equipment manufacturing facilities. Key E&S issues include E&S management system to be set up in China; quality and sustainability of water resources; emissions to the environment  air, water and subsurface; solid, hazardous, biomedical and infectious medical waste and materials management, including transportation; life and fire safety provisions of clinics; community and staff occupational health and safety; community engagement; construction management and land acquisition.  The scope of the appraisal will include looking at: existing operations of the Chinese JV partner(s) (if any) and their systems, and proposed JV operations in Yiwu and Shenzhen. This project has been provisionally assigned category B and will require 30 days disclosure prior to board.

Q & M has diverse offerings including General Dental Treatment, Orthodontics, Periodontics, Prosthodontics, Oral Surgery, Dental Implants, and Aesthetic Dentistry.  The new dental center has been accredited by Singapores Ministry of Health as a learning center. Q & M has over 120 dentists on staff and 300 dental assistants. Dr. Ng effectively owns 32% of Q & M directly and indirectly.

Company Name: QASIM INTERNATIONAL CONTAINER TERMINAL PAKISTAN LIMITED
Project Description: Qasim International Container Terminal Pakistan Ltd. ('QICT' or the 'Company') operates a container terminal at Port Qasim approximately 50 kilometers southeast of Karachi, Pakistan. QICT is the leading container terminal operator in Pakistan with a market share of 36% in 2009. The project consists of an inland container depot ('ICD'), a container freight station ('CFS'), and other capital expenditure requirements of QICT, which will help to improve transportation services in Pakistan.  The ICD will be located near the industrial and agricultural center of Lahore and will enable upcountry customers to receive and deliver cargo from Lahore via rail, representing additional convenience and cost savings relative to trucking. The CFS and other capital expenditures will improve services and efficiency for QICT's existing clients at Port Qasim.
Impact: The proposed IFC financing will help strengthen the transportation sector in Pakistan by improving transport logistics between Port Qasim and Lahore, efficiency levels at QICT's existing container terminal, and value-added CFS services at Port Qasim.  The accompanied improvements in service levels, efficiency, and costs will benefit all port users including shipping lines, exporters, and importers. In addition, the long-term introduction of viable rail service between Port Qasim and Lahore will significantly reduce transport costs and emissions. The Project is expected to create new jobs and generate increased revenues for the Government of Pakistan through higher royalty and lease payments by the Company as well as higher taxes. IFC's financing will also send an important signal of support for sustainable Pakistani enterprises during the current challenging political and economic environment.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Additional details on IFC''s review of this project may be found in the Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) for the investment, which is also available on IFC''s website.

DP World is one of the world's leading marine terminal operators with 49 terminals and 10 new developments across 31 countries as of January 2011. DP World is owned 80.45% by the Government of Dubai, and the remaining 19.55% of DP World is listed on NASDAQ Dubai.

Project Description:
SGEL is the flagship entity of Shalivahana Group. The Group's operations are primarily power generation from non-conventional energy sources like biomass, and municipal solid waste (MSW). The Group has five operating biomass plants with a capacity of 47 MW including one MSW plant.  Till March 2011, the Group is expected to add 45 MW of capacity and will have a total operational portfolio of 92 MW of biomass projects, making it India's largest biomass power company. Till FY2015, the company plans to operationalize a total portfolio of about 250+ MW capacity consisting of primarily small- medium sized biomass/waste based projects as well as wind and small hydro power projects.

IFC is considering to make an equity investment in SGEL and providing project finance to SGEL's 100% subsidiary Rake Power Ltd. for the development of 23 MW biomass power projects each in Sundergarh, Orissa and Ranchi, Jharkhand.  As part of its sustainability efforts and to enhance its fuel supply chain, the Company is, in conjunction, also implementing a 3 year pilot project to explore the possibility deriving energy from municipal solid waste (MSW).  An MOU has been signed with the Karimnagar municipality in Andhra Pradesh for a 3 year phased effort to study, manage, and dispose of municipal waste with an aim to convert this to energy.
Review Scope:
IFC's review of this investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety (EHS) related information submitted by Shalivahana Green Energy Limited ('SGEL' or 'Company') including: regulatory permits, HR policies and procedures, technical details for existing power plants, environmental impact assessment reports; CDM project design documents, environmental monitoring records such as air emission data for Sponsor's existing operations. 

During the appraisal IFC visited SGEL's operational biomass plants in Macherial, Andhra Pradesh; and Ramtek in Maharashtra; operational municipal solid waste (MSW) processing facility in Karimnagar and MSW based power plant in Sultanabad, Andhra Pradesh and the under construction biomass power plant in Chindwara, Madhya Pradesh. The appraisal also included discussions with SGEL's senior management and technical personnel responsible for EHS management.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
Key environmental and social (E&S) issues associated with this investment include the capacity of the Company to: establish and maintain corporate level E&S assessment and management system; establish and maintain corporate human resource policies and procedures; manage worker health and safety both during construction and operating phases of all projects operational phase; ensure compliance and sound labor and safety management by contractors; sourcing and transportation of fuel for biomass projects; fire risks associated with storage of biomass fuel; manage waste discharges and air emissions from the power plant operations (especially for MSW-based power plants); and ensure health, safety and security of the communities directly affected by the construction and operation of its projects.

The Project will result in a limited number of potentially adverse environmental and social impacts which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria. This investment is therefore categorized as B.

Project Description: Moorhouse Properties Limited (MPL or the Company) is embarking on a $37.4 million expansion Project which involves the (i) construction of two 3- star hotels and two 2-star hotels to be implemented respectively by its operating companies A. M. Hotels Limited (AMHL) and MP Budget Limited (MP Budget); (ii) setting up of its corporate office and (iii) refinancing of debt (the Project). The main purpose of the Project is to meet demand in the middle and budget segments of the Nigerian hotel market by developing an easily-recognizable international brand (Ïbis) and an indigenous value brand (Travelhouse) of international standard.  MPLs expansion model is centered on offering to business and leisure travelers, comfortable and moderately priced lodging facilities in markets where such products are presently not available.  The emphasis is on providing room quality with less public area, food and beverage outlets than a full service.
Impact: The proposed Project will (i) bridge the supply gap for high quality under-served hotel markets in major business cities in Nigeria which is presently met with sub-standard accommodation and guest houses, (ii) contribute to the improvement of the business infrastructure of the country, (iii) create significant job opportunities to the local people and linkages with other sectors of the local economy many of which are SMEs, both during Project implementation and ongoing operations, such as small contractors, building material suppliers, agricultural and food processing, textiles manufacturers, etc, (iv) encourage improvements in the standards of existing hotels and transfer of hotel management expertise and training of the local staff, and (v) the Project has the potential to provide a demonstration effect and kick off the development of a mid and budget market hotel segment in Nigeria.    It is also important to note that international chains assure guests of an established product and service quality; often encourage broad improvements in the standards of existing hotels; and provide staff with compensation usually above local norms.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that may result will be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  IFCs review of this Project consisted of a document review, including the mandatory Environmental Impact Assessments as undertaken for the various existing developments, site visits to existing facilities including those being considered for new developments, and discussions with the client representatives.  Generally all of the existing developments occur within established urban areas on sites previously disturbed or developed, and this similarly applies to the new proposed developments being considered. IFCs review of the existing developments (including those under construction), determined that these are generally compliant with IFC requirements.     A number of potential issues associated with the Project were identified including:Ensuring compliance with IFC standards in the event that the facilities are located on occupied sites e.g. by informal traders;Occupational Health and Safety during the construction phase; Management of liquid and solid waste during the operational phase; andEnsuring design and construction in accordance with the requisite Fire, Life and Safety standards.   Implementation of the Project Environmental and Social Action Plan will ensure these issues are adequately addressed so as to ensure compliance with IFC requirements at existing and new developments.

Mr. Balogun is an entrepreneur and property developer/manager with a good track record. The Sponsors started MPL in 1996 with a primary focus in property development and asset management.

Project Description:
The proposed transaction consists of an IFC investment of USD 30 million in The Currency Exchange Fund N.V ('TCX' or the Fund) as straight equity, representing circa 5% of current shareholder capital. This investment will allow IFC to get access to TCX products as a client.

TCX is an innovative financial institution which provides long-term local currency ('LCY') and interest rate derivatives in emerging countries without active swap markets. TCX's objective is to promote long-term LCY financing for those borrowers in developing countries that do not have hard currency income, thereby contributing to a reduction in currency mismatches in the local market. 

TCX commenced with operations in February 2008. TCX's swap portfolio is naturally long emerging market currencies and short USD, because, unlike commercial providers of hedging products, TCX does not operate on a 'matched book' principle but instead relies on global portfolio diversification as the primary risk mitigation tool. TCX is structured to help its investors hedge exchange and interest rate risks associated with long-term investing in developing country currencies. These risks are transferred to TCX by means of medium to long-term swap agreements. TCX pools market risk from multiple investors with diversified geographical business. The resulting global diversification should lead to a risk reduction and economies of scale and scope. 

TCX is currently rated A- by Standard and Poors.
Impact:
TCX contributes to the development of the LCY markets by offering floating and fixed rate funding to counterparties for extended maturities and in situations where long benchmark rates are either illiquid or not available. This will facilitate future lending in LCY by fostering competition, price signals, extending the tenors and reducing the cost of LCY debt. 

The use of hedging reduces the currency/maturity mismatch of emerging market borrowers, strengthens their balance sheet and encourages a more efficient use of their capital.

TCX's focus on Sub Saharan Africa & microfinance aims to get a maximum effect where it is most needed. TCX is committed to achieve its focus in these two segments by establishing a lower minimum deal size and by charging less capital to transactions in these areas (Dutch government incentive).
Environmental Social Issues: This project consists of IFC investment in a currency exchange fund that provides currency and interest rate hedging in EM currencies and has been classified as a Category C project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The Fund has implemented its environmental policy which includes an Exclusion List which is consistent with IFC FI Exclusion List. No further review is required. The project is required to inform IFC in the event of any changes in nature or scope of its businesses.
Sponsor:
TCX is a rated public limited liability, tax-exempt, company incorporated in The Netherlands and established in September 2007.  

As of December 2010, shareholders included (i) Most international finance institutions operating in emerging markets, with The Netherlands Development Finance Company (FMO), Kreditanstalt fur Wiederaufbau (KfW) and European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) as the main shareholders. Other multilaterals include African Development Bank, Agence Française de Développement and Development Bank of Southern Africa; (ii) one private bank, Royal Bank of Scotland; and (iii) microfinance institutions such as Oikocredit, MFX Solutions and Dexia Micro Credit Fund.
Cost Nature:
The total project cost is USD30 million. 
TCX's has a total tier 1 capital of USD602 million.

Project Description: The proposed investment is in SEAF Caucasus Growth Fund ('SEAF Caucasus' or the 'Fund'), a $60-70 million private equity fund, sponsored by Small Enterprise Assistance Funds ('SEAF'), that will invest in small and medium enterprises ('SME') in the Caucasus region, primarily in the target countries of Georgia, Armenia, and Azerbaijan.
Impact:
This project is in line with IFC's overall strategy for investments in the Caucasus region. The expected development impact of the project includes:
- Support of SMEs: All target portfolio companies in the fund will be SMEs.
- IDA Country Focus: The three target countries of Georgia, Azerbaijan and Armenia, are IDA-blend countries.
- Economic Development: Provision of long-term capital to sectors traditionally overlooked by the formal banking sector will allow companies to grow which can lead to increased output and increased employment.
- Private Sector Development: Manager employs a hands-on, value-added strategy with portfolio companies, providing professional management and operations support and expertise leading to better competitiveness and sustainability in SMEs.
- Support a nascent private equity industry in the Caucasus.
Environmental Social Issues: The project involves an IFC investment in a Private Equity Fund that will invest in small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and has been classified as a Category FI project. The proposed portfolio involves investments in sectors with potential E&S impacts such as gypsum mining, slaughterhouse and meat-packing, and dairy farm in Georgia, Armenia, and Azerbaijan. The main E&S risk of this project is that the impacts of sub-projects are not adequately identified and managed. Sub-projects financed by the fund will need to comply with IFC FI Exclusion List, the applicable host country E&S laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards (the Applicable Performance Requirements).SEAF is an existing IFC client, with several active funds in various regions, and has developed a Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS). Project Description: The existence of a strong Distress Assets ('DA') market constitutes an important element contributing to the appropriate performance of the financial industry in any economy. In this context, the proposed project is part of IFC's program to promote the development of a DA market in the Andean and Central American regions. To achieve this, IFC would be partnering with Covinoc (the 'Company'), an IFC existing client to acquire Non-Performing Loan portfolios in the previously mentioned markets.
Impact:
The proposed project is expected to have a high development impact in the following areas:

(i)	Economic Development:  The successful implementation of the project will aid the development of a secondary market for distressed assets which in turn will serve as a stabilization factor for the financial system. This should enable institutions to focus on productive use of capital which can result in higher liquidity and increased capitalization levels at the lending institution level. 

(ii)	Business Environment:  As financial intermediaries increase the sale of their distressed assets to independent private investors, the transparency of those institutions' balance sheets would improve as these assets would be priced according to market conditions. In addition, the demonstration effect of the project will help promote international insolvency standards and creditors' rights while providing investors with risk mitigation, divestment routes, and out-of-court resolution mechanism. All of these factors will greatly increase the region's attractiveness to local and foreign investors.  

(iii)	Financial Infrastructure:  IFC's involvement in this project would allow Covinoc to positively impact the market place by building capacity in the financial markets. The project is expected to increase the ability of financial intermediaries in the country to offload their assets, particularly non-performing ones, improve liquidity and devote these resources to originating new transactions.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves the creation of a Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV) to purchase and service yet to be identified portfolios of non-performing loans in Colombia, Peru and Central America and has been classified as a Category FI project.  The servicer is an existing client with an existing Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS). Considering the nature of activities supported, the servicer will be required to: (i) maintain or upgrade its SEMS for commercial NPL assets to ensure that investments under the SPV are screened and processed to identify environmental and social risks, if any, and to avoid supporting activities on the IFC FI Exclusion List or with substantial unresolved social or environmental issues; (ii) work with applicable commercial assets being resolved to ensure that the projects are operating in compliance with the IFC exclusion list and the applicable national environmental and social laws and regulations, or have an action plan to achieve the same within a reasonable time frame; (iii) identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the SEMS; (iv) apply the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions; (vi) comply with local consumer protection and other applicable laws and follow international best practices or professional standards in its collection practices; and (iv) submit annual reports to IFC.
Sponsor:
Covinoc is a local specialized servicer, which for more than 50 years has provided recovery and portfolio management services to financial intermediaries in Colombia. The company is the largest NPL servicer in the country in terms of assets under management (approximately $ 1.4 billion as of December 2010), distributed over more than 300,000 loans.

Covinoc's shareholding structure includes: Lantro S.A. (19.4%), Ircanda S.A. (19.4%), Inversiones la Costa Ltda (19.0%), Arigu SAS (17.4%), IFC (12.98%), Delta Associates Inc (10.1%), Nicolas Gomez y Cia Ltda (0.9%), Nicolas Gomez Nieto (0.9%)

Project Description:
Shalivahana Green Energy Limited ("SGEL" or the "Company"), a privately owned entity, is a biomass power company in India with installed capacity of 47MW spread across 5 plants. The Company built its first biomass plant in 2002. The Company plans to undertake small to medium-sized projects in the biomass, hydro and wind energy sectors. 

3 new biomass power plants under construction will bring additional capacity of about 45MW by March 2011. The Company has a pipeline of approximately 200MW of which 2 biomass projects of 23MW each (project cost of about $25 million each) will be held in Rake Power Limited ("RPL"), a 100% owned subsidiary of the Company, with an existing 10MW installed capacity. 

The Company is part of the Shalivahana Group (the 'Group'). The Group's other businesses include civil construction, education and cement production.
Impact:
Increase power generation: The Indian power market is characterized by significant supply deficit which is expected to continue in the medium term. India's regulatory environment is increasingly supportive of renewable energy. Through this investment, IFC supports a company which will add approximately 200MW of renewable energy generation capacity over the next 3-4 years to meet the growing electricity demand in India. 

Climate Change Impact: The Project helps mitigate negative climate change impacts by helping avoid GHG emissions - IFC estimates a reduction of approximately 227,000 tCO2eq/year attributable to IFC's investment alone. 

Private Sector Development: 80% of power generation in India is still state-owned, with all major players focused on large thermal and hydro power projects. In line with its mandate, IFC's participation in this Project will help stimulate private sector development within the renewable energy generation sector. 

Development of Low Income States (LIS): The entire pipeline of SGEL's projects is in the LIS (Madhya Pradesh, Orissa, Jharkhand and Chattisgarh). SGEL's projects create employment opportunities and stimulate the development of the rural economy. 
 
Employment Generation: The Project creates employment opportunities during project identification, construction and operation. Significant employment is created during operations by biomass traders supplying fuel to the various plants of the Company and its subsidiaries.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects. Key environmental and social (E&S) issues associated with this investment include the capacity of the Company to: establish and maintain corporate level E&S assessment and management system; establish and maintain corporate human resource policies and procedures; manage worker health and safety both during construction and operating phases of all projects; ensure compliance and sound labor and safety management by contractors; sourcing and transportation of fuel for biomass projects; fire risks associated with storage of biomass fuel; manage waste discharges and air emissions from the power plant operations (especially for MSW-based power plants); and ensure health, safety and security of the communities directly affected by the construction and operation of its projects.Further details on the potential environmental and social impacts of the project, corresponding mitigation measures and guidance on how and where information about the project are provided in the IFC Environmental & Social Review Summary and Environmental & Social Action Plan.
Sponsor: SGEL is promoted by Mr. M. Komaraiah and family ('Sponsors'). The Sponsors hold 50.10% of SGEL, and the balance is held by IL&FS Energy Development Company Ltd (20%) and Axis Infrastructure Fund 1 (29.90%).
Cost Nature:
IFC will provide up to $15 million in corporate equity financing to the Company to finance its pipeline projects and up to $15 million in project debt financing in the form of IFC A' Loan to RPL for the 2x23MW biomass projects. The tenor of the A' loan will be up to 12 years with a grace period of 3 years.

The IFC Post-2012 Carbon Facility (the 'Facility') proposes to forward purchase up to 3 million Certified Emission Reductions ('CER') to be generated through 2020 and SGEL's renewable energy projects. SGEL will receive from IFC a pre-determined percentage of the CER spot price at the time of delivery, subject a floor and a cap. IFC will on-deliver CERs delivered by SGEL to the participants in the Facility on a pro-rata basis.

Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. As an existing client, Khan Bank has developed a social and environmental management system (SEMS), appointed staff to oversee the SEMS implementation, and submitted annual reports to IFC. Project Description: IFC proposes to establish the IFC Global Infrastructure Fund (the GIF), a $1 billion private equity fund.  Infrastructure is central to economic growth, living standards improvement, and broader development, and there are considerable infrastructure development needs in emerging markets. Governments in emerging markets are increasingly turning to the private sector to develop infrastructure projects; however, the availability of long term private sector equity capital for such projects is proving to be a constraint.  IFC sees an opportunity to alleviate this constraint by mobilizing private sector/institutional funding to co-invest in IFC funded projects.
Impact: This Project is expected to deliver strong development impact by: (i) mobilizing additional capital for infrastructure investments and thereby ensuring a larger number of projects are completed; (ii) enabling IFC to invest in more projects because project risk exposure will be shared by Fund Investors which will  increase the number of projects that will adhere to IFC Performance Standards; (iii) demonstrating that emerging markets infrastructure investments present an attractive investment opportunity; (iv) investing in frontier regions; and, (v) introducing large international investors to investing in infrastructure in the emerging markets in a sustainable manner.
Environmental Social Issues: GIF itself is a Category FI project.  IFC-originated projects will be individually categorized and appraised according to IFCs procedures for direct investments and consistent with the Policy and Performance Standards on Social and Environmental Sustainability.
Sponsor: GIF will be managed by IFC Asset Management Company (AMC). Large global institutional investors including sovereign and pension funds are expected to invest alongside IFC.
Cost Nature: IFC proposes to invest equity for its own account up to $200 million or 20% of the total commitments of the Fund. IFC and AMC will mobilize up to $800 million from large global institutional investors. The Fund will primarily invest in equity instruments and equity-like instruments in infrastructure projects/companies in emerging markets.  The Fund will invest in a diversified pool of investments across different sectors of the infrastructure and across different regions, including middle income and low income countries.

IFC-originated projects will be individually categorized and appraised according to IFCs procedures for direct investments and consistent with the Policy and Performance Standards on Social and Environmental Sustainability.

Project Description:
Simran, is a 100% owned subsidiary of Techno Electric & Engineering Company Limited (Techno or the Group). Techno is a power sector engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) company for the last three decades and has recently started investing in wind power projects. Techno including its subsidiaries already has 95.45 MW of operating wind power assets in Karnataka and Tamil Nadu.

The Company is developing two wind farm projects (75.90 MW + 51.00 MW) aggregating 126.90 MW located in Tirunelveli and Tiruppur districts respectively in Tamil Nadu ('Project'). Of the total capacity proposed, 25.20 MW comprised of 12 x 2.1 MW wind turbine generators (WTGs) is located in Amadapuram/Devarkulam, Sankarankovil Taluk, Tirunelveli district. A further 50.70 MW comprised of 12 x 2.1 MW WTGs and 17 x 1.5 MW WTGs is proposed at Rastha Taluk in Tirunelveli District. The 51.00 MW located in Mutthiampatti, Dharapuram Taluk, Tiruppur District is comprised of 34 x 1.5 MW WTGs.  All these sites are being developed by Suzlon ('Developer') on a turnkey basis, which involves securing land, necessary consents and approvals, material, construction and commissioning. Further, the Project will be operated and maintained (O&M) by Suzlon under an O&M contract with Simran.
 

The Project also involves setting up for each WTG a transformer switchyard and a transmission line to the nearest substation but other infrastructure facilities (i.e. central monitoring station, maintenance workshop; stores; and staff quarters) will be shared with Suzlon's other projects/WTGs. Typically, each central monitoring station (CMS) is an O&M hub (with stores and personnel from various functions) and  caters to 50-75 WTGs installed within a 15 km radius from the CMS.  A 11 kV or 33 kV transmission line comprised of conductors mounted on 11 m high poles will be constructed and connected to the nearest 220 kV substation, the nearest facility of the state utility (Tamil Nadu Electricity Board). The WTGs at Muthiampatti site will be connected to the 200 MW TNEB substation located at Velarasi Vadamalaipalayam, which is at about 7 km from the Muthiampatti site. Further, 25 MW of the Amdapuram site will be connected to a 100 MW substation at Amthapuram located at about 10 km from the site and the balance 50.70 MW will be connected to a 200 MW substation at Rastha located at about 7 km from the Rastha project site.

Total land required for the Project is expected to be about 375 acres spread over all the WTG locations in Tirunelveli and Tiruppur districts and includes the land for WTGs, transformer yard and access roads. Typically, each WTG is located in the center of a 100 x 100 m land plot, which includes also the transformer and switchyard for the WTG. However, 5 acres of land is usually purchased for each WTG location to be used as lay down area and for use by cranes during WTG installation and if required, for O&M purposes. The T-Line footprint is limited to a 1 x 1 m area around each pole. The Project WTGs will be located in a sparsely populated, generally flat or mildly undulating terrain on privately owned cultivated or barren land.
Review Scope: IFC is considering an equity investment in Simran Wind Project Private Limited ('Simran' or the 'Company') and a project loan to finance 126.90 MW of wind power projects being implemented by the Company in Tamil Nadu state in India. IFC's review of this investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information made available by Simran including the: Draft Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS) being developed for Simran; Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) Report of the two Wind Power Projects in Tamil Nadu dated March, 2011; Operation and maintenance agreements (O&M) with Suzlon, the O&M operator for the two projects; and Techno Electric & Engineering Company Limited (Techno) draft Human Resource (HR) policies. The appraisal team also interviewed Simran's corporate management and both Simran and Suzlon's site professionals. The appraisal also included visits by IFC staff to a sample of the proposed project locations in Tiruppur and Tirunelveli districts of Tamil Nadu, India.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The proposed investment in the Company and the Project is a Category B project because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Potential impacts in construction activities besides being mitigable are likely to be limited to project site; short term; and likely to have limited impact on environmentally sensitive areas. Further, it is possible to readily design and implement engineering and management measures to mitigate adverse impacts during construction and operations. The Company will manage its environmental and social performance in accordance with applicable local laws and regulations and international standards, including IFC's Performance Standards on Social and Environmental Sustainability.

Project Description: The proposed IFC project entails providing a risk sharing facility (RSF) in partnership with Raiffeisen Bank Aval (Aval or the Bank) of up to $70 million on the portfolio of receivables generated by Bayer Ltd. Ukraine (Bayer Ltd  or the Company) on the sale of crop protection products to existing and new farmer-clients. The Bank will provide a guarantee to farmers which will allow them to buy on credit from Bayer. An RSF will be signed with Aval on a portfolio of up to U$140 million equivalent with an IFC exposure of up to $70 million, under which IFC will share with the Bank 50% of principal losses on a portfolio of guaranteed Promissory Notes and guarantees to farmer- clients. IFC will have a first-loss counter-guarantee from the Company.  Aval is a universal commercial bank ranked number four in Ukraine by total assets as of December 31, 2010, and offering a full range of banking services to all kinds of customers  from big corporate to individuals. The Bank has a well established network of branches with around 930 outlets present in all regions. Aval deals with agri-businesses and has strong agri-finance record in the country. Since October 2005, close to 96% of the Banks equity has been owned by Raiffeisen International Bank Holding AG (since October 2010 - Raiffeisen Bank International or RBI), a fully consolidated subsidiary of Raiffeisen Zentralbank Österreich AG (RZB). The remaining stock (ca. 4%) is traded at the local stock exchange. Raiffeisen International has been a long-standing IFC client since 1987, and Aval has benefitted from three investments in the recent past: two subordinated loans in total amount of $70 million, a senior loan of $15 million, and a GTFP line of $30 million.Bayer Ltd., a Ukrainian entity fully owned by Bayer AG, is a main input supplier of crop protection products (mainly pesticides, herbicides and fungicides) in Ukraine with revenues of about US$100 million per year. The Companys clients are mainly represented by small and medium farmers. Bayer Ltd. operates under the CropScience division of Bayer AG.
Impact: IFC development impact in this investment will be measured according to the following indicators:i) increased and improved access to financial services for agricultural SME''s and farmers;ii) support agri-customers and one of the leading sectors of the Ukrainian economy through an innovative financial product;iii) demonstration effect to the local market that should encourage local banks to serve this crucial yet largely underserved sector;iv) improvement of Bayer''s and farmers'' integrated pest and disease management (IPM/IDM) approach, coordinated use of pest and environmental information along with available pest control methods, including cultural practices, biological, genetic and, as a last resort, chemical means to prevent unacceptable levels of pest damage.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures, given the fact, that transportation and storage are carried out by Bayers contractors, the Project has limited environmental and social (E&S) adverse impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to national laws and regulations, generally recognized good industry practices and guidelines. IFCs E&S review has confirmed that the project must be managed consistent with the following IFC Performance Standards on Social and Environmental Sustainability: PS1 (Social and Environmental Assessment and Management Systems); PS2 (Labor and Working Conditions); PS3 (Pollution Prevention and Abatement) and PS4 ( Community Health, Safety and Security).Key E&S aspects/impacts of the project include: Local QHSE Management System capacity to address potential direct and indirect E&S impacts associated with crop protection products transportation, storage, use and waste disposal; Compliance with national laws and regulations; the International Code of Conduct on the Distribution and Use of Pesticides, the World Health Organization (WHO) Recommended Classification of Pesticides by Hazard; the Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPs); Human resources policy; Working conditions and terms of employment, including occupational health and safety; Awareness and training of farmers on implementation of Integrated Pest and Disease Management Plans; Waste disposal/ recycling of empty containers; Emergency preparedness and response.The information about how these potential impacts will be addressed by the Company is summarized in the Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS). The Company is committed to implement all corrective actions identified in the E&S Action Plan (the ESAP) to mitigate negative E&S impacts and risks associated with its operations.  Upon implementation of the ESAP, the proposed project will comply with the E&S requirements of host country laws and IFCs Policies, Performance Standards and industry specific guidelines.
Sponsor: The Banks Parent company  RBI  is one of the leading corporate and investment banks in Austria and in Central and Eastern Europe (CEE). In CEE RBI operates an extensive network of subsidiary banks, leasing companies and a range of other specialized financial service providers in 17 markets. 56,000 employees service about 15 million customers through around 3,000 business outlets in the region. RZB owns about 78.5% of RBI common stock; the balance is free-float, listed on the Vienna Stock Exchange. Founded in 1927, RZB is the central institution of the Austrian Raiffeisen Banking Group (RBG) and acts as group centre for the entire RZB Group, including RBI.Bayer AG is Germany-based pharmaceuticals, polymers and agrochemicals conglomerate with sales of about 31 billion and EBITDA of about 6 billion in 2009. The groups structure consists of three divisions: Bayer Healthcare, Bayer CropScience and Bayer MateriaScience. Bayer CropScience manufactures herbicides, insecticides, fungicides, seed treatment and seeds.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $70 million at IFC own account, to be provided as a risk sharing facility on the portfolio of up to $140 million of receivables generated by Bayer Ltd. to existing and new farmer-clients. The Bank will provide a guarantee to farmers which will allow them to buy on credit from Bayer. IFC will share with the Bank 50% of principal losses on a portfolio of guaranteed Promissory Notes and guarantees to farmer clients. IFC will benefit from a first-loss counter-guarantee by the Company.
Investment: 70.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuarantee70.0LoanEquity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Bayer and the Bank are headquartered in the capital of Ukraine, Kyiv. Aval operates around 930 outlets located in big cities, provincial and community centers and villages across Ukraine. Bayer Ltd. covers the entire territory of Ukraine via the chain of local distributors.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures, given the fact, that transportation and storage are carried out by Bayers contractors, the Project has limited environmental and social (E&S) adverse impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to national laws and regulations, generally recognized good industry practices and guidelines. IFCs E&S review has confirmed that the project must be managed consistent with the following IFC Performance Standards on Social and Environmental Sustainability: PS1 (Social and Environmental Assessment and Management Systems); PS2 (Labor and Working Conditions); PS3 (Pollution Prevention and Abatement) and PS4 ( Community Health, Safety and Security).Key E&S aspects/impacts of the project include: Local QHSE Management System capacity to address potential direct and indirect E&S impacts associated with crop protection products transportation, storage, use and waste disposal; Compliance with national laws and regulations; the International Code of Conduct on the Distribution and Use of Pesticides, the World Health Organization (WHO) Recommended Classification of Pesticides by Hazard; the Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPs); Human resources policy; Working conditions and terms of employment, including occupational health and safety; Awareness and training of farmers on implementation of Integrated Pest and Disease Management Plans; Waste disposal/ recycling of empty containers; Emergency preparedness and response.The information about how these potential impacts will be addressed by the Company is summarized in the Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS). The Company is committed to implement all corrective actions identified in the E&S Action Plan (the ESAP) to mitigate negative E&S impacts and risks associated with its operations.  Upon implementation of the ESAP, the proposed project will comply with the E&S requirements of host country laws and IFCs Policies, Performance Standards and industry specific guidelines.
Sector: AG - Diversified Edible Agricultural Crops Production

Project Description:
The proposed IFC project is designed to improve access to finance for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) that purchase or would purchase, should they have access to credit, certified and top quality crop protection products from Bayer Ltd., Ukraine (the 'Company' or Bayer Ukraine) by providing a risk sharing facility on a portfolio of Bayer's Ltd. existing and new clients (the 'Project'). The proposed risk-sharing structure will entail partnering with a local bank (the 'Bank'). The Bank will either (a) fund loans to Bayer's Ltd. clients so that they may purchase crop protection products from the Company or (b) provide a guarantee to farmers which will in turn allow such farmers to buy on credit from Bayer.

Bayer Ltd., Ukraine, a fully owned subsidiary of Bayer AG, offers products in three business areas: CropScience (crop protection and non-agricultural pest control), HealthCare (pharmaceutical and medical products) and Material Science (high-tech polymers and materials). The Company is a main input supplier of crop protection products, mainly insecticides, herbicides and fungicides in Ukraine and the Project will support the Company's plans to extend its reach to a larger pool of farmers who currently lack access to credit and are using fewer and lower quality products for their agricultural production.
Review Scope:
IFC's environmental and social (E&S) review of the project consisted of field visits to the office of Bayer Ltd., Ukraine in Kyiv; a commercial warehouse located in Kyiv outskirts and leased by Bayer for storage of products after custom clearance; visits and meetings at three farms using Bayer's products; a visit and meeting with an independent distributor; discussions with Bayer's managers and regional representatives related to human resources (HR), quality, occupational health and safety (OHS) and environment, including product regulatory certification and registration. 

The appraisal also included a review of key documents (quality, health, safety, environment (QHSE) and social policies and procedures)  provided by Bayer Ltd., Ukraine in response to IFC's E&S questionnaire and follow-up request, namely QHSE Global and local policy and requirements; HR policy, local procedures and regulations; local compliant procedure and statistics; incident reporting, investigation and statistics; emergency communications and response; OHS and fire safety; product regulatory certification and registration; communications and actions for farmers on safe use of crop protection products.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Given the fact, that transportation and storage are carried out by Bayer's contractors, the Project has limited environmental and social (E&S) adverse impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to national laws and regulations, generally recognized good industry practices and guidelines. Therefore, this is a category B project according to IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedures.
Sector: AG - Diversified Edible Agricultural Crops Production

Project Description: The proposed project is to provide a $6 million senior loan (or local currency equivalent) to FINCA MicroCredit Company ('FMCC' or the 'Company'), a leading microfinance company in Kyrgyz Republic. Proceeds of the loan will be used to finance the expansion of their lending to micro and small entrepreneurs (the 'Project'). The Company currently seeks long-term funding to continue its dynamic growth and offer new products to its target clientele.
Impact:
The developmental impact is expected to be high:

-	The Project would provide funding for underserved segments of society in an IDA country, more specifically women entrepreneurs, and will contribute to employment creation and poverty reduction in Kyrgyz Republic.

-	The Project would support the efforts of FMCC to diversify and increase the volume of their funding and to better manage their asset and liability position at a time of limited funding opportunities.

-	In Kyrgyz Republic, the provision of term funding in the local financial market will have a very strong demonstration effect and build market confidence. This is extremely relevant in a post conflict environment.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves support for a microfinance company and has been classified as a Category FI project according to the IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The E&S appraisal focuses on reviewing Companys portfolio, E&S due diligence procedures and HR practices. The appraisal indicates that there is no stand-alone S&E policy, but elements of E&S due diligence are incorporated into the Companys credit policy and other internal documents, and corresponding S&E training is carried out. The Company is in compliance with the Performance Standard 2  Labor and Working Conditions. Based on the review, FMCC will be required to enhance/update its existing procedures in the credit policy or alternatively develop a separate policy to screen and process its investments to avoid supporting activities on the IFC Microfinance Exclusion List and be consistent with the ones of FINCA. The Company will also be required to appoint a qualified SEMS officer to manage and implement the procedures, to maintain compliance with the Performance Standard 2, and to submit an annual report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor:
FMCC has been active in the country since 1995 and was funded with a USAID grant. In 2003, FMCC was incorporated as a joint stock company and licensed by the National Bank of Kyrgyz Republic as a non deposit taking commercial micro credit company.

FMCC has been primarily targeting underserved clients in remote, mostly rural areas with no or poor access to credit, as well as very small entrepreneurs in semi-urban and urban communities, who due to very small business size and lack of collateral had no access to credit from the formal financial system. 

FMCC is 100 percent owned by FINCA International, Inc. ('FINCA'), a non profit organization headquartered in Washington, DC and one of the largest microfinance networks in the world with 21 affiliates in 21 countries, including 15 IDA countries. FINCA serves approximately 701,000 micro entrepreneurs, 70 percent of which are women.
Cost Nature: The proposed project involves a senior loan from IFC's own account to the Company in either US Dollar or Kyrgyz Som, in an amount not to exceed $6 million (equivalent).
