Project Description: The proposed project is to provide a $7 million senior loan, in local currency equivalent, to FINCA Azerbaijan (the 'Company'), a leading microfinance company in Azerbaijan. Proceeds of the loan will be used to finance the expansion of their lending to micro and small entrepreneurs (the 'Project'). The Company currently seeks long-term funding to continue its dynamic growth and offer new products to its target clientele.
Impact:
-	The Project would provide funding for underserved segments of society in an IDA country, more specifically women entrepreneurs, and will contribute to employment creation and poverty reduction in Azerbaijan.

-	The Project would support the efforts of FINCA Azerbaijan to diversify and increase the volume of their funding and to better manage their asset and liability and their local currency position at a time of limited funding opportunities.

-	In Azerbaijan, the provision of term funding in the local financial market will have a strong demonstration effect and build market confidence.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves support for a microfinance company and has been classified as a Category FI project according to the IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The E&S appraisal focuses on reviewing Companys portfolio, E&S due diligence procedures and HR practices. The appraisal indicates that the Companys lending procedure incorporates a separate environmental policy, a requirement to follow national E&S laws and an Exclusion List. The Company is in compliance with the Performance Standard 2  Labor and Working Conditions. Based on the review, FINCA Azerbaijan will be required to enhance and/or update its existing procedure to screen and process its investments to avoid supporting activities on the IFC Microfinance Exclusion List and be consistent with the one of the FINCA Microfinance Holdings. The Company will also be required to appoint a qualified SEMS officer to manage and implement the procedures, to maintain compliance with the Performance Standard 2, and to submit an annual report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor:
FINCA Azerbaijan was established in 1998 and registered and licensed by the Central Bank of Azerbaijan as a Limited Liability Non-Bank Credit Organization since 2000. During the period 1998 - 2005 FINCA Azerbaijan was an operator responsible for the US Government's assistance program. 

FINCA Azerbaijan is one of the microfinance market leaders in Azerbaijan with a gross loan portfolio outstanding of $84 million per December 2010, reaching 97,819 clients. Its product range includes individual and group loan products for urban and rural/agricultural markets. 

FINCA Azerbaijan is 100 percent owned by FINCA International, Inc. ('FINCA'), a non profit organization headquartered in Washington, DC and one of the largest microfinance networks in the world with 21 affiliates in 21 countries, including 15 IDA countries. FINCA serves approximately 701,000 micro entrepreneurs, 70 percent of which are women. FINCA has been actively preparing the ground for the establishment of a holding company to support the process of transformation of its network affiliates into licensed micro deposit taking institutions. IFC is in the process of finalizing its investment in this holding company (Project #29683) to which the ownership of the Company will be transferred.

Project Description: The proposed project is a 5 year Credit Line for up to CRC 7.5 billion (USD 15 million equivalent).  Coopenae (the Company) offers an attractive business opportunity for IFC to support a well performing and growing finance company to further grow its presence in Costa Rica as well as supporting its expansion into the MSMEs segment. The proceeds from the credit line will be used to increase, diversify and extend the duration of Coopenaes funding base by obtaining medium-term financing for on lending to consumer, housing and MSMEs in Costa Rica. The IFC loan will also mobilize additional financing from another IFI for equal value, for a total of $30 million equivalent.
Impact: 1.	Contribution to Private Sector Development: By supporting Coopenae, IFC will facilitate access to specialized financial services for consumers and MSMES.  These segments are generally underserved by large foreign-owned banks in Costa Rica.  SMEs represent a critical private sector segment, however, accounting for about 30% of the total number of registered Costa Rican companies.2.	Scaling up MSME Lending: This Project involves scaling up a local MSME lender by supporting it with long-term local currency debt funding.  Accordingly, IFC is playing a catalytic role in the sustainable development of the MSME sector. 3.	Contribution to Poverty Reduction: The Project will support productive MSMEs and employment generation in Costa Rica.  MSMEs account for 38% of the total formal employment in Costa Rica and the SME sector plays a crucial role in achieving poverty reduction and accelerating economic growth and is therefore key to the health of the economy.4.	Funding Mobilization: IFC will provide the loan in local currency and with FMO, which will provide parallel funding of equal amount.
Environmental Social Issues: This Project involves IFC support for a bank to increase its lending and has been classified as a Category FI project according to the IFC Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Since the main E&S risks of the project are associated with the client''s portfolio of investments, during appraisal IFC will review the portfolio and the client''s capacity to manage E&S risks in order to determine the applicable requirements, which may include a combination of the IFC Exclusion List, the national E&S laws and regulations as well as the Performance Standards. In this process IFC will also assess the clients labor practices according to IFCs labor standards. The client will be required to: (i) develop, upgrade or maintain a SEMS to ensure compliance with the applicable requirements; (ii) demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2:  Labor and Working Conditions; and (iii) submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: Coopenae is a leading regulated, deposit-taking, finance company organized as a cooperative with over 70,000 active members in Costa Rica. It was created in 1966 to provide services to teachers and started its financing operations in 1983. As of December 2010, Coopenae has $600 million in total assets and over 320 employees. The Company offers loans, savings, and insurance products nationwide through a network of 19 branches and serving around 50,000 clients. It is the largest of the 31 supervised financial sector cooperatives holding 27% of the cooperative market share and the second largest local private sector financial institution in terms of assets and deposits.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $30 million in local currency. The transaction entails an up to $15 million equivalent credit line from IFC and an up to $15 million equivalent from another IFI.

Location: The Company is headquartered in San Jose, Costa Rica. Coopenae is the largest cooperative in Costa Rica with 19 branches around the country.

Project Description:
Established as a multiple bank in 1989, Banco Fibra S.A. ('Fibra' or the 'Bank') is a mid-sized Brazilian bank focused on credit, operating both in the middle market and low income retail segments. As of December 2010, Fibra's credit portfolio reached BRL 7.9 billion. 

To ensure the sustainable growth of its lending business and accomplish its diversification strategy, the Bank is pursuing an equity capitalization during the first half of 2011.
Impact: Fibra has expertise in credit operations, particularly involving SME borrowers and low income individuals.  The major development impacts expected from this project are: (i) with a strengthened capital base, the Bank will be able to further expand its credit activities, increasing access to credit for both SMEs and low income individuals; (ii) the presence of well capitalized mid-sized banks in Brazil is an important factor to maintain competitiveness in the even more concentrated Brazilian banking sector after the crisis.
Environmental Social Issues: This Project has been classified as a Category FI project.  Fibra is an existing client and has implemented a Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS), under existing projects (25507, 26336, and 29471). The applicable environmental requirements are: the IFC Exclusion List, relevant national environmental and social laws, and the Performance Standards. IFC also assessed the client''s labor practices against the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions and found their practices satisfactory.  The client will be required to: (i) continue to ensure that its SEMS apply the applicable requirements; (ii) maintain responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the SEMS; (iii) continue to apply the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions; and (iv) continue to submit a periodic report to IFC.
Sponsor: Fibra is controlled by the Vicunha Group (the 'Sponsor' or the 'Group'), with a 92.08% share of capital stock. The Group has more than 40 years of experience operating in Brazil. In addition to the Bank, it also controls Vicunha Textiles and the listed steel-maker Companhia Siderúrgica Nacional (CSN), two of the largest Brazilian corporations in their respective industry segments. In 2007 IFC became a shareholder of the Bank, acquiring a 7.92% share of capital stock.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at up to BRL 240 million. The proposed investment entails a capitalization by IFC of up to BRL 80 million.  The remaining BRL 160 million would be subscribed by the Sponsor (BRL 80 million) and other investors, which may include the IFC African, Latin American and Caribbean Fund, managed by IFC Asset Management Company LLC.

Location: Fibra's headquarters is located in São Paulo.  The Bank has 20 branches spread throughout the country, covering more than 85% of Brazil's GDP to meet corporate clients' needs.  The Bank has also approximately 16 thousand retail sales locations.

Fibra is an existing client and has implemented a Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS), under existing projects (25507, 26336, and 29471). The applicable environmental requirements are: the IFC Exclusion List, relevant national environmental and social laws, and the Performance Standards. IFC also assessed the client''s labor practices against the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions and found their practices satisfactory.  The client will be required to: (i) continue to ensure that its SEMS apply the applicable requirements; (ii) maintain responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the SEMS; (iii) continue to apply the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions; and (iv) continue to submit a periodic report to IFC.

Project Description: Microvast is a growing Chinese research and technology driven company offering advanced power solutions for applications including electric vehicles, electric bikes, and power tools, as well as patented battery components such as membrane, anode, electrolyte and cathode. Microvast currently has three subsidiaries (Microvast Power Systems, Microvast New Materials and OChem Chemicals) which together form a vertically integrated advanced power and technology company. IFC proposes to co-invest on the same terms as another international investor up to $30 million in the form of equity and debt to support the Company's capital expenditures related to expansion, marketing and sales, and the continued R&D of new battery technologies. IFC finance will be used in support of the Company's operations solely in China.
Review Scope: The scope of review of Microvast's ('the Company's') compliance with IFC's Performance Standards and local environmental, social and occupational health and safety standards comprised: (1) assessment of effectiveness of the Company's environmental and social management system and (2) its ability to ensure and monitor compliance with regulatory requirements and IFC's Performance Standards in its operations.  The review relied on documents and reports made available by Microvast, and interviews conducted by IFC staff during their site visits to the Company's offices, manufacturing and system integration facilities in Huzhou, China; and a bus manufacturing company that Microvast may potentially acquire. During the visit IFC staff conducted interviews with key management personnel, supervisors, EH&S staff and Human Resources, as well as various support staff.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFC's Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because it may create a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria. Key environmental, health and safety, human resources and social issues that were reviewed included: environmental and social management system (scope and implementation); quality and sustainability of water resources; emissions to the environment  air, water and subsurface; solid, and hazardous waste and materials management, including transportation; life and fire safety; community and occupational health and safety; energy use and efficiency; community engagement; and land acquisition. Microvast has an actively engaged management program and has presented specific plans to address key issues and gaps to ensure continued compliance with local regulatory requirements as well as consistency with IFC Performance Standards and applicable Word Bank Group (WBG) Environmental, Health and Safety guidelines.

Project Description: Shangri-la Asia Limited ('the Sponsor') is a Hong Kong based international group owning and/or operating 68 luxury hotels around the world. Incorporated at Ulaanbaatar in 1993, MCS Holding LLC ('MCS') is a leading private company in Mongolia employing about 3,000 staff with business activities in sectors including energy & infrastructure, general manufacturing & services, information & communications, property development, and food and beverage. The Sponsor and MCS are jointly developing a 280 room, 21-storey 5-star hotel in the city center of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia ('the Project'), which is part of a mixed-use hotel, office and retail complex.  Groundwork began in May 2009, and construction work which is undertaken from March to October each year is expected to be completed in 2012. The hotel will be managed by a team appointed by the Sponsor when it goes into operation. IFC has been approached to provide debt financing of up to $50 million to support the Project.
Review Scope: Shangri-la Ulaanbaatar Hotel LLC (the 'Company'), a joint venture between two existing IFC clients - Shangri-La Asia Limited (the 'Sponsor') and MCS Holding LLC, Mongolia ('MCS'), is developing a 280 room, 5-star hotel in the city of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia (the 'Project') which will potentially utilize IFC financing. The environmental and social review of this Project included assessment of the capacity and management system of the Sponsor, the Company and MCS to ensure the Project's compliance with IFC's Performance Standards as well as national environmental, social and occupational health and safety regulatory requirements in Mongolia. The review relied on documents and reports made available by the Company, on site visits, and on interviews with Company, MCS, sub-contractor staff as well as Government representatives and members of the general public in Ulaanbaatar. IFC also met with the consultant who undertook the Environmental Impact Assessment for this Project, and with members of the Sponsor's management team in Hong Kong.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFC's Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific and reversible environmental and social impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Key environmental, health and safety, human resources and social issues that were reviewed included the following: environmental and social management system; labor and working conditions; emissions to the environment  air, water and subsurface; hazardous waste and materials management; life and fire safety and emergency preparedness and response; community and occupational health and safety; water and energy use and efficiency; land acquisition and involuntary resettlement; and community engagement.

Project Description: Shangri-La Ulaanbaatar Hotel LLC (the Company or Shangri-La Ulaanbaatar Hotel) is a joint venture between IFC's existing clients: (i) Shangri-La Asia Limited (Shangri-La or the Sponsor); and (ii) MCS Holding LLC (MCS). The project is to develop and operate a 280-room, 5-star hotel in the city of Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia (the Project).
Impact:
The Project's expected development impact includes the following:
(i)	Increased supply of hotel services: The Project will help meet the growing demand for hotel accommodation in the presently under-served 5-star hotel sector in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. 
(ii)	Employment creation: The Project will create a significant number of direct and indirect job opportunities for the local communities. 
(iii)	Benefits to the local economy and local linkages: The Project will help create demand for locally sourced materials, service, and labor, both during the construction and operation stages . The Project is expected to support small- and medium-sized enterprises, including a wide range of goods and service providers.  
(iv)	Increase in domestic revenue and foreign exchange: The Project is expected to contribute to the domestic economy through increased tax revenues and foreign exchange inflow.  
(v)	Private sector development: The presence of the Shangri-La Hotel in Ulaanbaatar will send a positive signal to other foreign investors who are considering investments in Mongolia where there is limited private sector activity. The Project is also expected to have an impact on the upgrade and development of retail and travel-related infrastructure in the city of Ulaanbaatar.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social (E&S) Review because a limited number of specific and reversible E&S impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Key E&S issues reviewed included the following: environmental and social management system; waste emission and discharge to the environment  air, water and subsurface; labor and working conditions; life and fire safety and emergency preparedness and response; community and occupational health and safety; water and energy use and efficiency; land acquisition; and community engagement.
Sponsor:
The Company will be 75% beneficially owned by Shangri-La and 25% owned by MCS. Shangri-La, headquartered in Hong Kong, is a leading owner and operator of deluxe hotels and resorts primarily in Asia. Shangri-La is listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.    

Incorporated in Ulaanbaatar in 1993, MCS is one of the leading private enterprises in Mongolia with subsidiaries operating in various business sectors, including: (i) energy and infrastructure; (ii) general manufacturing and services; (iii) information and communications; (iv) property development; and (v) food and beverages.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $123 million. The proposed IFC investment is an A loan of up to $50 million for IFC's own account.

Company Name: CONSTRUCCIONES METALICAS MEXICANAS COMEMSA S.A. DE C.V.
Project Description:
Construcciones Metalicas Mexicanas Comemsa Sa de CV ('Comemsa'), a Mexican subsidiary of Abengoa, is engaged in the designing and manufacturing of galvanized steel structures. Comemsa is implementing an expansion of its existing plant in Queretaro, Mexico to satisfy the increased demand of solar panel structures and transmission towers in the region. The Company plans to increase its existing production capacity from 30,000 tons to 50,000 tons of transmission towers and solar panel structures, each accounting for half of the additional capacity, by adding several production lines and an additional galvanization plant.

The project consists of a $40 mn investment of which IFC is providing a $24 mn loan. The Company has already started its expansion and since the end of 2008 has invested about $5.0 million equivalent in the acquisition of equipment for high voltage transmission lines and for the manufacturing of solar panel structures. 

The project will expand its capacity within the existing manufacturing site, so no impacts associated with additional land acquisition are anticipated.
Review Scope: Key E&S issues reviewed during appraisal include: management of environmental, health and safety performance at ongoing operations and during the construction of the new production lines; water and energy efficiency of the production processes; air emissions from combustion facilities and metal cutting, forming, welding and finishing processes; waste management; treatment and discharge of liquid effluents; and life and fire safety, including emergency preparedness and response. Labor conditions, occupational safety and community safety were also reviewed.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFC's Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria as is described in the following sections.

Production capacity is expected to increase from 30,000 tpa to 50,000 tpa as a result of the expansion project which will result in the addition of several production lines and an additional galvanization plant.

As a result of increased focus on transmission capability in Mexico and Central American, energy access is expected to improve. Supporting job creation in Mexico, a key objective for the Mexican government, both during the expansion and operation of the manufacturing facility.

IFCs review of this investment included a visit to Comemsa''s plant in Apaseo El Grande, and meetings with key management personnel, including human resources, operational managers and support staff. Abengoa Solar is a global leader in the application and development of solar technologies, as well as in the promotion and operation of solar energy plants. Abeinsa Ingenieria y Construcción Industrial SA, the flagship company of Abengoa SA and global leader in the EPC industry.

Project Description: PT. South Pacific Viscose is a long-term IFC client and is internationally recognized as a competitive low-cost producer of high quality viscose staple fiber. The proposed IFC investment will be used primarily to support SPV in financing the expansion of a fifth viscose production line (Line 5) and setting up of a wet gas sulfuric acid plant (WSA) for sulfur recovery and regeneration of sulfuric acid. After Line 5 is commissioned, the production capacity for the SPV facility in Purwakarta, Indonesia will increase to 325,000 tons per year of viscose fiber from its existing capacity of 245,000 tons per year. The proposed project is expected to cost $192 million. IFC is considering an A loan of up to $30 million and a B loan of up to $110 million.
Review Scope: The scope of review of PT. SPV's compliance with IFC's Performance Standards and local environmental, social and occupational health and safety standards, included assessment of the effectiveness of the company's environmental and social management system for its proposed capital expenditure projects and its ability to ensure and monitor compliance with regulatory requirements and IFC's Performance Standards in its operations.  The review relied on documents and reports made available by PT. SPV and interviews conducted by IFC staff during their site visits and follow up communications. During the visits IFC staff visited production facilities, the construction site adjacent to its existing facilities, and conducted interviews with key management personnel including managers, Environmental, Community Development, Health & Safety staff, Human Resources, as well as various engineering and support staff.
Sector: CB - Man-Made Fibers (Including Nylon, Polyester, Rayon, etc.)

Project Description:
The Project comprises a proposed IFC equity investment in Sanasa Development Bank (the 'Bank' or 'SDB'). SDB is the apex credit institution for thrift and credit co-operative societies and has led the co-operative movement in the country for several decades.  In 1997, SDB was registered as a licensed Specialized Bank by the Central Bank of Sri Lanka and it now functions as the key financial institution for the Sanasa movement. SDB comprises over 8,500 rural co-operative and via this vast network, it reaches nearly a million microfinance customers. SDB has over half a million account relationships, making it the largest Microfinance Institution in the country both in terms of outreach and portfolio. The Bank has been internationally recognized in the field of microfinance. Most recently, SDB was ranked 2nd best MFI in the world by Micro Finance Exchange Institution (MIX, an institution founded by CGAP for the purposes of microfinance industry benchmarking).

IFC intends to take up to 10% of SDB's total equity capital via the issue of new shares.  IFC will provide SDB with funding to strengthen its capital, access to international best practices in the operational and governance areas, and help the Bank develop a more robust and scalable business model.
Impact: The proposed project is expected to have a significant development impact in enhancing the Bank's ability to expand its outreach in the microfinance sector and result in improved economic development and poverty reduction.  The Project will also help in improving access to credit in underserved areas which are more difficult for the formal banking sector to reach. Moreover, the Project will also increase access to finance for women as a significant proportion of SDB's MFI clients are expected to be women.  Finally, the Project is expected to create a demonstration effect for other investors to invest into the microfinance segment.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves IFC support for the business of Microfinance, and has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Considering the nature of activities supported, the project will be required to: Develop a procedure relevant to its business process, prior to commitment, that is satisfactory to IFC, and that ensures that all its investments are screened and processed to avoid supporting activities on the Microfinance exclusion listIdentify qualified persons to manage and implement the procedureCommit to establish a similar screening process to avoid supporting activities on the IFC Microfinance Exclusion List in MFIs in which it will take a controlling stakeCommit to implement the procedure Inform and satisfy IFC regarding its labor and working conditions and demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions. Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC
Sponsor:
The primary Sanasa co-operatives/societies and SDB member clients collectively own the largest stake in SDB (approximately 80%).  The primary societies are in turn owned by their members, mainly comprising individuals from the low-income segments.

The remaining ownership structure of SDB is as follows:

The largest single shareholder is People's Leasing Company with 5.96%. People's Leasing is a fully owned subsidiary of People's Bank, a state-owned bank and the 2nd largest commercial bank in Sri Lanka. 
2nd largest single shareholder is R.F.Chandler with 4.27%.  R.F. Chandler was formerly known as Orient Global Singapore, founded by Richard Chandler, the brother of Christopher Chandler (founder of Legatum Capital)
3rd largest single shareholder is Etimos Lanka Pvt Ltd. with 3.51%. It is a local company that facilitates services offered by Consorzio Etimos, an Italy-based financial consortium that supports microfinance programs in developing countries.
Cost Nature: Project cost is expected to be up to $3 million, for an equity investment giving IFC an ownership in SDB of up to 10%.  In order for IFC to not become the largest single shareholder in the Bank, SDB is undertaking the formation of a Trust structure to consolidate the large (80%) shareholding of its cooperative owners.

Project Description:
Market Shopping Center Limited ('MSC' or the 'Company') is a newly created Rwandese real estate company undertaking the development of a $37 million greenfield mixed-use commercial property (the 'Complex') in the Central Business District (CBD) of Kigali, Rwanda (the 'Project').

The Complex with a gross leasable area (GLA) of 29,383 m2 would be the first purpose mixed-used commercial complex with first class facilities to offer a combination of retail, accommodation, food, entertainment and office space in Kigali.
The Company is seeking an IFC financing package of up to $13 million to support the development of the Project.
Environmental Social Issues: This project is provisionally categorized as B according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  IFCs early review of this investment has identified the following environmental, social, health and safety issues: compliance with relevant national requirements for an environmental assessment, labor and working conditions, including health and safety during construction, solid waste management, the adequacy of potable water and waste water treatment, and design and construction of the facilities in accordance with recognized building standards, as well as an internationally accepted life, fire and safety standard.  Given the development is located within the central business district of Kigali on a site previously occupied by a state-owned post office, at this stage biodiversity and resettlement concerns are not considered applicable. Opportunities to improve energy efficiency and resource use will also need to be considered.
Sponsor: The Company is owned by three shareholders: Mr. Bertin Makuza, the main sponsor, owns 90% of the Company, Ms. Irene Makuza and Ms. Francine Umuraza (who are both relatives of Mr. Makuza) together own the remaining 10% of MSC. Mr. Makuza is a seasoned and well respected local entrepreneur who has been in private business in Rwanda for over 40 years and owns several successful enterprises covering a wide range of business lines.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $37 million of which IFC is proposing to provide up to $13 million consisting of an up to $10 million A loan and up to $3 million of equity.

Project Description: PT South Pacific Viscose (SPV or the Company), an IFC client and one of the leading producers of viscose staple fiber (VSF), is undertaking a capital expenditure program (the Project) which includes: (i) a new VSF production line together with additional utilities and auxiliaries and associated infrastructure; (ii) a wet gas sulphuric acid plant (WSA) for sulphur recovery and regeneration of sulphuric acid required in the VSF production process; (iii) incremental working capital; and (iv) regular refurbishment capital expenditure.
Impact:
Sustainable development of the textiles industry: The Project supports the development of additional fiber capacities based on renewable raw material - dissolving grade wood pulp.  Arguably, viscose has a lower impact on the environment compared with cotton (due to lower usage of land and water per unit of fiber) and petrochemical-based synthetic fibers (considering the bio-degradable properties of viscose and lower usage of fossil-based sources). 

Job creation:  The Project is expected to create 270 new job opportunities for the local economy.  In addition, the Project will support the long-term growth of the Indonesian textiles sector through increased domestic production of VSF at internationally competitive quality and costs.  This, in turn, will ensure the retention and growth of employment across the textiles value chain in Indonesia, textiles being one of the country's key sectors in terms of employment and foreign exchange earnings.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects. The proposed IFC investment will be used primarily to support SPV in financing the expansion of a fifth viscose production line and setting up of a wet gas sulphuric acid plant (WSA) for sulphur recovery and regeneration of sulphuric acid. Upon successful implementation of the specific agreed mitigation measures, the proposed project is expected to comply with Indonesian laws and regulations, IFC Performance Standards and applicable sections of the corresponding guidelines.
Sponsor: SPV was established in 1978 near Purwakarta, 120 kilometers east of Jakarta, and began commercial production in 1983.SPV is an internationally competitive producer of high-quality VSF. SPV is about 90.6% (directly and indirectly) owned by Lenzing, the second-largest viscose manufacturer in the world. SPV's minority shareholders are P.T. Pura Golden Lion and an Indonesian individual.

Company Name: Mibanco - Banco de la Micro Empresa S.A.
Project Description: Mibanco was incorporated in 1998 as a private commercial bank specialized in microfinance. The Bank was a spin-off of the microfinance operations of Grupo ACP Inversiones y Desarrollo (Grupo ACP), which is the Banks main shareholder (60% ownership).The proposed project will support Mibancos expected portfolio growth through a syndicated transaction in local and foreign currency. In addition, Mibanco will maintain a presence in the international loan market and initiate relationships with new international investors.
Impact: The development impact of the Project is expected to be high, as it will enhance the Bank''s ability to support productive micro, small and medium enterprises which will in turn stimulate growth, employment generation and poverty reduction. In addition, Mibanco will be able to increase its outreach and sustainability incorporating thousands of new entrepreneurs to the formal financial sector. The Project will help develop the B loan market in local currency in Peru and reopen the syndication market for MFIs in Latin America, following the financial crisis.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Under existing investments the client has implemented a Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS) to ensure that it does not support activities in the IFCs Exclusion List through its financing. Because the key S&E risks of this project are associated with Mibanco''s support to micro, small and medium enterprises, IFC will review the Bank''s loan portfolio during appraisal to confirm adequacy of the Bank''s S&E capacity to identify and manage these risks and may require updates as necessary. IFC will also assess the Banks labor practices according to IFCs labor standards. The Bank will be required to: (i) maintain or upgrade its SEMS; (ii) demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2:  Labor and Working Conditions; and (iii) submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: Grupo ACP Inversiones y Desarrollo is a Peruvian non-profit organization which has operated in Peru since 1969. In addition to Mibanco, Grupo ACPs most important investment, Grupo ACP holds stakes in: Forjadores in Mexico, Microfin in Uruguay, FIS in Argentina, BancoSol in Bolivia, Apoyo Integral in El Salvador and Guatemala, and Financiera El Comercio  in Paraguay, where it also holds stakes in Gonzalito. Grupo ACP also has an alliance with CEAPE-MA in order to create the first specialized bank in microfinance in Brazil. In addition, Grupo ACP has entered the microinsurance segment with two investments in Peru: Protecta and Secura and has created companies in different segments as housing with Vivencia and Panecons, education and training with Aprenda, communications with Somos Empresa and Tiggres and corporate services with Conecta, Conect2, Futura and Innovacción.

Project Description: MedGulf is one of the leading insurance providers and one of the largest privately owned insurance companies in the MENA region.  MedGulf's main strategy is focused on further expanding its presence into the less served countries in MENA and Turkey where demand for insurance products is largely unmet.  It offers non-life and life insurance services and third party administration of medical insurance claims.

1. Spread awareness about insurance value as a risk insulation to the formation of more businesses and jobs and to the increase of social stability in the MENA countries.
 
2. Formalize best insurance risk management practices for participants in the MENA insurance market to stimulate more investment opportunities, economic efficiency, stability, and poverty reduction. 

3. Develop an economic multiplier effect through channeling insurance premiums into regional economies' investments and capital markets products to support the private sector development in the MENA region.

Project Description: The project concept is to have a Turkish bank utilize for the first time the Turkish covered bond legislation and help develop domestic capital markets. The bond issued by the bank will be direct obligation of Sekerbank and collaterals be ring-fenced for the benefit of bondholders. The proceeds would be used to fund SMEs in Turkey.
Impact: Open and create a covered bond market in Turkey and allow banks to raise long-term funding from domestic and international investors in order to finance SME's and other projects.
Environmental Social Issues: This project, which consists of the purchase of a bond issued by Sekerbank to be used for on-lending to SMEs, has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. IFC''s existing investment in Sekerbank consists of two senior loans for on-lending to MSMEs and to farmers and agribusiness companies, a trade line under GTFP, and a 5-percent ownership of Sekerbank''s shares. After some initial delays, Sekerbank has implemented a Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS) to screen onlending to SMEs and agribusiness against the IFC Exclusion List, and applicable environmental and social national laws and regulations. Following IFC''s equity investment, Sekerbank is in the process of revising the SEMS to apply the IFC Performance Standards to high-risk transactions. Sekerbank''s portfolio currently includes minor exposure (0,092%) to activities on the Exclusion List (0.026% to the defense industry, 0.034% to tobacco and 0.032% to alcoholic beverages). Sekerbank is in the process of developing a plan to reduce/phase out these exposures. Based on the last AEPR review for FY09, the environmental and social risk score is 2 and Sekerbank''s overall E&S performance is medium.For this particular project, IFC''s applicable requirements will be to ensure that loans to SMEs are screened against the IFC Exclusion List, and applicable environmental and social national laws and regulations. IFC''s appraisal will focus on Sekerbank''s ongoing implementation of the SEMS in particular progress made with respect to compiling applicable social and environmental regulations, internal training, roll out across the bank''s branches, and senior management approval."
Sponsor:
Sekerbank is a mid-tier Turkish bank established in 1953. Although the Bank has expanded and diversified its products and client base, its traditional area of strength remains SME lending. Currently, the Bank employs over 3,649 staff and has 266 branches in Turkey including in rural areas of Turkey.

Around 68% of Sekerbank shares are controlled by its Employee Voluntary Pension Fund and Kazakhstan's BTA Securities JSC, a 100% subsidiary of BTA Bank JSC, on an equal basis. The rest of bank's shares are publicly traded on the Istanbul Stock Exchange.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $200 million equivalent.  Sekerbank is expected to issue covered bonds in the domestic or international bond market to IFC and other international finance institutions as well as private investors. IFC's investment would amount approximately $25 million.

Sector: AC - Commercial Banking - Microfinance and Small Business

Project Description:
The proposed investment consists of an up to $10 million A loan to, and an up to $3 million Equity investment in Market Shopping Centre Limited (MSC Limited) for the development of a mixed use commercial property (the 'Complex') in the Central Business District (CBD) of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.  MSC Limited is owned by Mr. B. Makuza, a local businessman.  MSC Limited is a newly created real estate company that will undertake development of the $37 million greenfield mixed-use commercial property Complex, with a gross leasable area of approximately 29,000 m².  The Complex will be the first purpose built mixed-use commercial Complex in Kigali which will include a combination of retail, accommodation and office space, along with areas allocated to food outlets and entertainment.  The Complex has been designed as an 11 storey commercial building comprising of: parking space on two basement floors; retail space and food court on the lower ground, upper ground, first and second floors; and office space along with several residential units on the third to eleventh floors.  The Complex will utilize the entire site, and no portion of the site will remain open for gardens and the like.  

The project site is located in Nyarugenge Hill, a prime area in central Kigali, on a site that was previously occupied by a state-owned post office and a privately owned fuel service station.  The post office and service station were both demolished, and the land was cleared and the construction at the site is underway at the lower ground floor.  The total area of the two sites combined is 3780 m². The site is situated adjacent to Centenary House, housing Cogebank, to the north; the partially constructed Social Security Fund Building to the east; the Bank of Kigali to the south; and a few relatively smaller low rise commercial buildings, accommodating a number of small trading businesses, to the west. 

MCSL commissioned GMK Architects (GMK), a local company specializing in architectural design, engineering and project management, to design the Complex and undertake quality assurance during project implementation.  The China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation (CCECC), a Chinese state owned company, has been commissioned to construct the Complex.  Construction activities commenced in April 2010, with completion of the superstructure anticipated in 2012, and opening of the complex planned for 2014.  While construction has been delayed by approximately six months, the contractor has committed to advance work to ensure completion within the original timeframes.   

Whist the management structure during the operational phase has not been defined; it is likely that a professional property management company will be commissioned to manage the Complex on behalf of Mr. Makuza.
Review Scope:
IFC's review for this project included meetings with the client, Mr. B. Makuza, the financial consultant for the project, Mr. E. Luyombya, the architect and Project Manager, Mr. V. Kamiya, the environmental consultant Mr. N. Rubangura, and the Kigali City Planning Department Ms. D. Rubinoff, and a site visit of the construction site.

In addition the following information was reviewed: 

Reponses to the environmental and social appraisal questionnaire
The Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA)
Various authority approvals, including those related to the EIA and planning approval
Contractual documentation between MSC Limited and CCECC
The green building and energy efficiency plan compiled by the architect
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
This is a Category B project according to IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedure because the limited number of specific impacts that may occur are generally site specific, and those impacts can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, procedures, guidelines or design criteria.  

The Complex is located within Kigali's business district on a site that was previously developed for use as a post office and fuel service station.  MSC Limited has commissioned a local architectural and project management company to design the facility to recognized international standards.  CCECC is constructing the Complex with oversight from MSC Limited and GMK to ensure project implementation is in accordance with the specified design criteria.  Although it has not been defined how the Complex will be managed, it is likely that a professional property management company will be commissioned to do so.  Specific actions have been defined in the project Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) to enhance environmental and social performance to which the project sponsor, and his appointed agents, will be required to comply.

Project Description: Allana Potash Corp (the Company, or Allana) is exploring for potash on three contiguous licenses located in the Danakil Depression (the Project).  The Danakil Depression is a desert area in north-east Ethiopia, close to the border with Eritrea.  The potash mineralization in the Danakil Depression is well known and was mined intermittently from the early 1900s. The Project area covers part of the previously defined Musley potash deposit that was discovered between 1958 and 1967.  The Musley deposit was at that time reported to contain a resource of 171.27 million tonnes grading 32.48 % KCl.  Project area covers part of the Musley deposit and has a historic inferred potash resource of 105.2 million tonnes with a composite grade of 20.8 %.  The resource potential of the entire Danakil Depression is significant and is believed to be in the order of a billion tonnes.Allana has sought strategic investors to help develop the Project. The Company recently announced strategic partnerships with two major investment houses.   The Company is also seeking IFCs engagement as a strategic partner to provide additional financing for the Project and help develop the Project in line with industry best practice in environmental and social sustainability.
Impact: The Project is in an early exploration phase so its developmental impacts are limited in scope at this stage. However, the Project is located in an under-developed part of the country and will likely contribute significantly to the area''s development should it transition into a full operating mine through: (i) generation of employment; (ii) improved infrastructure access; (iii) stimulation of local economic development through purchase of local goods and services; (iv) payments to government in the form of royalties and taxes; and (v) improving the receipt of foreign currency to the government.The Company has committed to make public all material payments to the government as per IFC requirement.
Environmental Social Issues: The key social and environmental issues to address in this exploration project currently include: i) management of exploration activities; ii) potential economic displacement of artisanal salt miners and traders; iii) influx of potential workers seeking employment; and iv) community engagement and managing community expectations. These impacts are limited and can be managed through an Environmental and Social Action Plan; and Allanas Health Safety and Loss Prevention Policy, incorporating the IFC Standard Operating Procedures Manual.
Sponsor: Allana is listed on the TSX-V (symbol: AAA) and has a current (March 24, 2011) market capitalization of approximately C$243 million.  The Company was formed and incorporated in Alberta, Canada in 1995 and continue in the Province of Ontario, Canada in 2007, and it is currently headquartered in Toronto, Canada.  The stock is widely held with Liberty Metals and Mining, a subsidiary of Liberty Mutual Group, a large diversified financial services firm, being the largest shareholder with approx. 16.5% of the outstanding shares.  In all, management and directors hold approximately 4% of the Company.
Cost Nature: The Company plans to spend approximately C$22.0 million on exploration on the Project over the next two years.  The exploration program includes drilling and core sampling, preparation of a feasibility study and an Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) report.   The Companys cash at hand together with the proposed IFC investment of C$10.0 million is sufficient to complete the proposed work program.

These impacts are limited and can be managed through an Environmental and Social Action Plan; and Allanas Health Safety and Loss Prevention Policy, incorporating the IFC Standard Operating Procedures Manual.

Company Name: TIANJIN BINHAI RURAL COMMERCIAL BANK CO., LTD.
Project Description:
This project consists of an IFC risk sharing facility ('RSF') with Tianjin Binhai Rural Commercial Bank ('BRCB'). This is the first phase of CHUEE SME under which IFC intends to support energy efficiency ('EE') and renewable energy ('RE') projects with small and medium enterprises ('SME') in China through IFC RSFs with local financial institutions.  In this project, IFC will take 50% of credit risk in a maximum portfolio of RMB400 million to be originated and funded by BRCB. 

The Project is expected to receive support from the Global Environment Facility.
Impact:
(i)	Environmental benefit: Annual reduction of 160,000 tCO2/year during 2015 to 2018
(ii)	SME access to finance: At least 20 eligible loans will be disbursed by the end of 2014 from a baseline of zero loans as of December 2010
(iii)	 Demonstration effect: Encouraging the Chinese government at both central and local levels to participate in future public private partnership initiatives of this type; and 
(iv)	Capacity building: Promoting the development of industry specific loan underwriting criteria and improved risk management practices.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Considering the size and the EE technology applications of these subprojects, the Applicable Performance Requirements will include a combination of the IFC FI Exclusion List, the applicable Chinese social and environmental laws and regulations and applicable IFC Environmental, Health and Safety Guidelines. BRCB will be required to implement a social and environmental management system (SEMS) to properly assess and manage the E&S risks associated with the subprojects consistent with the Applicable Performance Requirements. A satisfactory SEMS will be a condition of the effectiveness of the risk sharing facilities. In addition, BRCB will be required to appoint designated staff to oversee the SEMS implementation and submit periodic reports per a form provided by IFC.
Sponsor: BRCB, was established in 2007 in the Tianjin Binhai New District following the consolidation of two local rural credit cooperatives and one rural credit union.  It has a diverse shareholding structure. Not a single shareholder holds more than 12% of equity stake in BRCB. Major Shareholders include Tianjin Rural Commercial Bank, local private companies and IFC.
Cost Nature: An IFC investment of up to RMB200 million in the form of an unfunded risk sharing facility for a portfolio of up to RMB400 million comprised of EE and RE loans originated by BRCB.

Project Description: Galnaftogaz ('GNG' or 'the Company'), an existing IFC client, is the third largest petroleum product distributor in Ukraine.  The Company operates mainly in the retail segment, through 307 gasoline stations, and in wholesale distribution, through more than 10 storage terminals.  Since 2004, IFC has continuously supported the Company with financing as well as with financial/technical expertise. The proposed construction project ('the Project') is to build/refurbish around 75 high-volume gasoline filling stations at prime locations and finance the associated working capital.
Review Scope: The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health, safety and social information submitted by the project sponsor, and field visits in March 2011. The environmental and social (E&S) appraisal team visited fuel terminal and retail stations in Lviv, Ukraine. The E&S team also held meetings with the management team and the labor union representative of GNG.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
Among 307 gas retail stations in GNG, 281 are its OKKO brand stations. The remaining stations will also be refurbished to OKKO brand gradually. All the new retail stations in this project are OKKO brand station. The OKKO brand stations are refurbished or built according to European Union (EU) standards, in which the underground fuel tanks have double steel layers and leak detection devices. Fuel tanks in most terminals have vapor recovery installation. The land acquisition for the new gas stations will be strictly on a willing buyer / willing seller basis. GNG has established EHS procedures for operations. Additional mitigation measures for the potential environmental and social impacts have been identified and are incorporated into an attached Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP).

The potential adverse E&S impacts of this project are therefore few in number and limited to project sites and may be readily mitigated.  This is therefore an E&S Category B project.
Sector: AC - Other Petroleum and Coal Products

Project Description:
The proposed investment will support the expansion of Galnaftogaz ('GNG' or 'the Company') - an independent distributor of petroleum products in Ukraine.  GNG has financing requirements of $210 million over the next two years ('the Project') for the following activities:

-  $150 million for expansion of its gas station network. GNG plans build/reconstruct around 75 high-volume gas filling stations and finance the associated working capital.  The stations will be built according to the highest EHS standards and will have energy efficiency elements. $15 million of the investment will be used to purchase energy efficient heating systems, insulation, lighting and electric controls, pumps and more fuel efficient tanker trucks.  Most of the planned stations will be in central and eastern Ukraine because GNG would like to increase its presence outside of its home region (western Ukraine).  The Project is expected to create at least 480-500 new jobs (newly created stations) and preserve another 380-400 jobs (purchased/reconstructed stations), for a total of at least 860 jobs.
-   $60 million to refinance mezzanine debt at GNG's holding level.
Impact:
- Development of Ukraine's infrastructure based on modern and safe standards.
- Access to high-quality petroleum products and services
- Employment creation/preservation.  GNG employs 4,700 people (only 2,000 in 2004).  The proposed investment is expected to create about 900 permanent jobs and 250 thousand man hours of construction jobs
- Development of local suppliers.  Convenience stores, automotive services and fast-food help local economies because such services at stations are primarily locally supplied.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review procedures. The potential adverse E&S impacts of this project are therefore few in number and limited to project sites and may be readily mitigated. The key E&S issues include prevention of groundwater/soil contamination, control of emission of volatile organic compounds (VOCs), operational hazards and emergency response, occupational health and safety, road transportation, and community engagement and development. The mitigation actions have been identified. Please refer to the Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) and the Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) for details.
Sponsor:
Galnaftogaz is an existing IFC client and based in western Ukraine.   It operates mainly in the retail segment, through 307 gas filling stations, of which 281 are operated under the proprietary 'OKKO' brand.  OKKO branded stations have a modern layout and up-to-date technical, safety and environmental specifications.  The stations offer high-quality petroleum products and various related products and services (shops, fast food, auto repair).  Consistent quality of products helps to attract and retain loyal customers to OKKO stations because Ukraine does not yet have a strict minimum quality of fuels (e.g. EURO-4 or above) and often other distributors sell fuels of low standards and lack proper quality controls.

The Company is the third largest petroleum distribution company in Ukraine by number of stations and the second largest by volume.  In 2010 the Company achieved revenues of $1,092 million and retail sales of 787 thousand tons.  For the same period, the Company generated $82 million EBITDA and $39 million Net Income on assets of $714 million.

GNG Retail Public Limited is the holding company of GNG and owns about 64% of shares of the Company.  Mr. Vitaliy Antonov, a reputable Ukrainian businessman, is the founder and the ultimate beneficiary of the group.  European Bank for Reconstruction and Development ('EBRD') owns about 10.3% and its stake will increase to about 19% after upcoming equity subscription which is the part of the financing required for the Project.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at about $210 million, while IFC's proposed investment is a financing package of $80 million, consisting of an A loan of up to $15 million and a C loan of up to $20 million both for IFC's own account, and a syndicated B loan of up to $45 million for the account of participant banks. EBRD is considering matching IFC investment in identical amounts.

Company Name: Bangkok Mitsubishi UFJ Lease Risk Sharing Facility
Project Description: The project entails a risk sharing facility ('the Facility') of up to $70 million equivalent to Bangkok Mitsubishi UFJ Lease Ltd, ('BMUL'). BMUL is one of active leasing companies in Thailand especially in an area of auto leasing business, established in 1993. BMUL is a subsidiary in Thailand of Mitsubishi UFJ Lease & Finance ('MUL') which is second largest leasing company in Japan (based on operating asset scale as of Dec.2010). This Facility's aim is to increase funding to energy efficiency ('EE') projects, renewable energy ('RE') projects and ESCO lease projects through BMUL.
Impact:
The following development benefits are expected:IFC is contributing to the development and diversification of the financial sector by assisting in the development of new markets and product lines with significant growth potential. By sharing credit risk in the EE/RE/ESCO lease portfolio, IFC provides comfort to and reduces risks taken by financial institutions, especially those entering into such new markets in Thailand for the first time. 
IFC's project complements BMUL's strategy to support the EE, RE and ESCO sectors and will enable BMUL to manage risk and grow its assets at a faster pace than it would on its own.Environmental and social benefits: Thailand is heavily dependent on energy as an input and has one of the highest electricity rates in the region. The project will contribute to increasing efficiency in industry and reduce operating costs. In addition, the project will also contribute to pollution reduction by increasing usage of more efficient technologies with fewer harmful side-effects.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. During appraisal, IFC analyzed the client''s environmental and social management capacity and the potential environmental and social risks of the activities to be supported by this facility and determined that the Applicable Performance Requirements are IFC FI Exclusion List, the applicable national social and environmental laws and regulations, and IFC Performance Standards. Based on the review, the project will be required to:  Finalize the development of a social and environmental management system, prior to commitment to the satisfaction of IFC Identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the SEMS Commit to implement the SEMS, to ensure that activities supported by IFC financing are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements Apply the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC
Sponsor: MUL is the largest shareholder in BMUL (44.0%). MUL is listed company on Tokyo Stock Exchange and playing significant role in lease & finance sector as one of Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, the largest financial conglomerate in Japan. The other main shareholders are Bangkok Bank Group (34.0%), Bangkok BTMU (10.0%), Toyota Tsusho Thailand Co., Ltd. (6.0%).
Cost Nature: The total size of the Facility is estimated to be $70 million. Under the proposed Facility, BMUL would be responsible for generating a portfolio of EE leases that satisfy certain eligibility criteria to be set by BMUL and IFC. IFC's participation would involve sharing the risk of that lease portfolio, which would include support from the Clean Technology Fund ("CTF").

Company Name: Grupo Financiero Mifel, S.A. de C.V.
Project Description:
The proposed project consists of an equity investment, in the form of common shares, in Grupo Financiero Mifel S.A. de C.V. (Mifel or the Group), a local-owned financial group composed of commercial banking, factoring, leasing and mutual fund management companies.  Banca Mifel, by far the largest entity of the Group, was established in Mexico City in 1993 and has traditionally targeted corporates, small and medium companies (SMEs), the agribusiness sector and medium-sized real estate developers.  Mifel's overall market share by loans, assets and deposits is less than 1% in the Mexican banking system.

IFC's equity investment would be between MXN 240 and 300 million ($20 to $25 million equivalent), or up to an 18% equity stake.  This project is eligible for an investment from the Africa, Latin America and Caribbean (ALAC) fund.
Impact:
Address Mexico's SMEs and agribusiness companies financing deficit and foster competition in both sectors where Mifel has traditionally focused on.

Support the consolidation of the Mexican financial sector by enabling the Bank as an acquirer or a more attractive target.
Environmental Social Issues: As a new IFC client, the key issue would be to ensure that Mifel, a financial conglomerate that focused on Mexican SMEs, has adequate capacity and procedures to ensure the compliance of its operations with IFC Exclusion List and the Mexican environmental and social (E&S) laws and regulations.  Since this project is an equity investment, the appraisal will focus on the assessment of E&S risk management capacity and procedures, labor practices, and the entire portfolio of Mifel including its leasing, banking, factoring, and mutual fund operations. As a Category FI project, Mifel will be required to: (i) develop a SEMS to ensure that its activities are in compliance with the IFC FI Exclusion List, applicable national social and environmental laws and regulations, and, if applicable, IFC Performance Standards; (ii) identify responsible, qualified persons to implement the SEMS; (iii) apply the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions; and (iv) submit an annual E&S report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: Mifel is an unlisted Mexican entity.  The project sponsors and major shareholders are Daniel Becker Feldman (CEO and Chairman of the Board) with 51% and Martin Werner Wainfeld with 17%.
Cost Nature: IFC proposes to provide between MXN 240 and 300 million ($20 to $25 million equivalent) in common shares.

Project Description:
The proposed project is an investment in Aavishkaar India II Company Ltd. ('AVI II' or the 'Company' or 'Fund'), a fund focused on financing early stage venture enterprises targeting fundamental market needs in rural and semi-urban areas in India. The 'Fund' will focus on scaling up affordable models targeting the 'Bottom of the Pyramid' in healthcare, water and sanitation, education, agriculture, renewable energy and other emerging sectors. The proposed project is a successor fund to Aavishkaar India Micro Venture Capital Fund (AIMVCF), a 2007 MSME-focused fund of  $14 million, which is fully committed. AIMVCF has invested in 23 companies (of which around 35% are directly operational in Low Income States (LIS) while the others are also focused on underserved India (segment of rural and semi-urban Indian populace that has been left out from the mainstream development process) across healthcare, education, dairy, technology, agriculture, and handicrafts with an outreach of over a million disadvantaged people. 

Some of the investments of AIMVCF include:-
GV Meditech - a group of hospitals providing affordable (low-cost; at a price point affordable by the rural Indian populace) and high-quality healthcare in Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, Madhya Pradesh and Chattisgarh. 
B2R (Business to Rural) Technologies - a rural Business Process Outsourcing (BPO) business in Uttarakhand that offers quality cost-effective services, while creating employment opportunities for rural youth.
Saraplast Private Limited manufactures and leases Portable Toilet Cabins' and provides cleaning, evacuation and waste disposal services to manual construction workers (esp. women), slums and tourist sites.
Milk Mantra  a dairy company that is building a strong dairy supply chain network in the state of Orissa.
Vortex Engineering designs and manufactures low cost solar powered ATMs, with the aim of facilitating access to banking services in remote rural regions of India. 
Waterlife provides rural communities with potable drinking water by setting up village-level water purification plants in states such as Bihar and Uttar Pradesh.

AVI II will continue to support the investment themes of its predecessor fund, including a strategic focus on low income states ('LIS') and the 'Bottom of the Pyramid' in India (current pipeline includes approximately 40-50% deals in LIS). 

The proposed 'Fund' will be incorporated under the laws of Mauritius as a private limited company.
Impact:
The team expects high development impact in the following areas:
1). Enhance early stage / VC investing in India and address asymmetrical distribution of PE/VC funds to some extent.
2). Attractive long-term capital appreciation by supporting high growth businesses.
3). Expand access to quality healthcare and education opportunities in India, reduce carbon emission and create employment opportunities. Provision of capital to scalable enterprises in low income states and rural and semi-urban areas in India. Target sectors include education, health, water and sanitation, agriculture and renewable energy sectors.  
4). Demonstration of successful venture capital investing in an IDA country such as India and underserved sectors, thereby building confidence amongst institutional investors to invest in the country and sectors.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  During appraisal, IFC analyzed the Funds expected portfolio and sectors of investment and determined as the Applicable Performance Requirements (i) the IFC FI Exclusion List, (ii) the applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and Regulations and (iii) the IFC Performance Standards. IFC also reviewed the capacity of the Fund to manage social and environmental risks and to establish and maintain a Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS). Based on the assessment the Fund Manager will be required to (i) revise the SEMS, prior to commitment, to the satisfaction of IFC to ensure compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements, (ii) identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the SEMS, (iii) commit to implement the SEMS to ensure that its investments are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements, and (iv) submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC. Additionally IFC will review the implementation and performance of the Funds SEMS for the first three projects, prior to the Funds investment, to ensure that the SEMS is robust.
Sponsor:
The 'Company' is initiated by Aavishkaar Venture Management Services Pvt. Ltd. ('AVMS'), which has initiated three funds before 'AVI II'. Currently, 'AVMS' acts as the advisor to the predecessor fund Aavishkaar India Micro Venture Capital Fund ('AIMVCF'), and sub-advisor to Aavishkaar Goodwell India Microfinance Development Company ('AGMIDC I'), and 'AGMIDC II'. AVMS was founded by Mr. Vineet Rai, who is currently the Chief Executive Officer and Managing Director of AVMS. Vineet Rai has over 17 years of experience in early stage investing, small business incubation, and microfinance. He is an Ashoka Fellow, and has received honorary membership to the Xavier Labour Research Institute (XLRI) Alumni Association, a premier management institute in India. In the G-20 Seoul Summit, Vineet represented AVMS as one of the 14 shortlisted best and most innovative proposals to catalyze finance for small and medium-sized enterprises. AVMS is the only winning entry from India to make it to this global challenge in 2010. In addition to Mr. Rai, the core team includes P Pradeep, Chief Investment Officer and board member of 'AVMS' and 14 professionals. 

Other Funds advised by Fund Manager: AGIMDC I (a JV with Goodwell and an IFC investee), is a 2007 microfinance-focused fund with $18.3 million (fully disbursed). The same Indo-Dutch Joint venture has also launched a follow-on fund (AGIMDC II) which achieved its first closing at $10 million in November 2010.
Cost Nature: The target 'Fund' size is expected to be around $100 to $150 million. IFC is proposing an equity investment in the proposed 'Fund' of up to $10 to $15 million, not to exceed 20% of the Fund's total commitments.

Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  During appraisal, IFC analyzed the Funds expected portfolio and sectors of investment and determined as the Applicable Performance Requirements (i) the IFC FI Exclusion List, (ii) the applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and Regulations and (iii) the IFC Performance Standards. IFC also reviewed the capacity of the Fund to manage social and environmental risks and to establish and maintain a Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS). Based on the assessment the Fund Manager will be required to (i) revise the SEMS, prior to commitment, to the satisfaction of IFC to ensure compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements, (ii) identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the SEMS, (iii) commit to implement the SEMS to ensure that its investments are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements, and (iv) submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC. Additionally IFC will review the implementation and performance of the Funds SEMS for the first three projects, prior to the Funds investment, to ensure that the SEMS is robust.

Project Description: Pran is the leading food processing company in Bangladesh, that produces and distributes beverages such as fruit juices, cola, bottled water; snacks, confectionery (candies, biscuits), culinary products, dairy and soft drinks. It enjoys a strong brand reputation in the country and exports its products to 70 countries. The proposed IFC investment in Pran Dairy Ltd. (one of the group companies) includes expansion and modernization of its existing milk processing operations, by upgrading some of the machinery and installing some new modern processing and packaging lines (Project).
Review Scope: IFCs review of this proposed investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety (EHS) and social related information submitted by Pran Group (Pran or Company) including: Environment, Health and Safety (EHS) and Human Resources (HR) related corporate level policies and procedures; food safety management system policies and procedures, organization chart; training records; reports of external audits (related to HR, resource efficiency/cleaner production); environmental monitoring reports; emergency response plans, etc. The appraisal included site visits to Prans food processing facilities in Ghorashal and the existing dairy operation at Pran Industrial Park (PIP), Polash; and discussions with Prans senior management, technical and EHS teams  at each facility as well as at the corporate office in Dhaka. This is a repeat investment by IFC in the Pran Group. The Environmental Social Review Summary (ESRS) for the previous IFC investment (PRAN, Project no. 27005), disclosed in June 2008, is available at: Project #27005This review also considered the EHS related information submitted by Pran Group through annual monitoring reports related to the previous IFC investment. This review thus, builds upon the previously disclosed ESRS, and covers specific EHS aspects related to the dairy project.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Key environmental and social (E&S) issues associated with this Project include: development and implementation of integrated management systems covering quality, environment, health and safety and food safety; assurance of fair, safe and healthy working conditions in compliance with local regulatory requirements and relevant Performance Standards; resource efficiency of the operations (water, energy); monitoring and management of air emissions, wastewater treatment and discharge, solid and other waste disposal; the impacts of operations on local ambient air quality; life and fire and safety management including emergency preparedness and response; and the supply chain of milk.The Project may result in limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards and guidelines. This is therefore a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.

Project Description: Apollo Tyres Ltd of India (Apollo or the Sponsor), a $2B sales company is an existing IFC client. Apollo acquired Apollo SA, (formerly Dunlop South Africa), in 2006 as part of its international expansion strategy. Apollo SA owns two tire plants in South Africa with daily production capacities of about 1,400 tires (mostly truck & bus radials) in Durban and 10,000 car and light-truck radial tires in Ladysmith. Apollo SA is undertaking an investment program to increase its radial tire production capacity in Ladysmith by 30% to 13,000 tires per day by implementing technology improvements ( Project) thereby allowing the Company to increase its cost competitiveness and product quality, and to meet market demand in existing markets and enter new export markets.
Review Scope: IFCs review of this proposed investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety (EHS) and social related information submitted by Apollo South Africa (Apollo SA or the Company) including: EHS policy; management system manuals; organization chart; HR policy and manual; training records; accident register; reports of external audits for workplace air quality, asbestos, hazardous materials; other environmental monitoring reports; emergency response plans, etc. The appraisal also included site visits to Apollo SAs operational manufacturing facilities in Durban and Ladysmith; including a visit to the construction site of the proposed project within its Ladysmith facility; and discussions with Apollo SAs senior management, technical and EHS teams  at each manufacturing facilities as well as at the corporate office in India.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards and guidelines.Key environmental and social issues associated with this Project include: adequate social and environmental assessment of the impacts of the Project during both construction and operations; implementation and scope of existing environmental and occupational health and safety management systems, engagement with local communities in accordance with local requirements and IFC Performance Standards; assurance of fair, safe and healthy working conditions during construction and operations; opportunities to enhance energy efficiency and the use of natural resources including recycling and reuse initiatives; management of air emissions, wastewater treatment and discharge, and solid and other waste disposal; handling and management of hazardous materials and hazardous wastes; the impacts of operations on local ambient air quality, and life, fire and safety, including emergency preparedness and response.The project involves an investment in existing operations in South Africa whereby compliance with national legislation generally meets the requirements of IFCs Performance Standards. Moreover, as consistently demonstrated by Apollo during IFCs past engagement; during the appraisal of this project, Apollo SA has demonstrated the capacity and the resources, to implement comprehensive environmental, health, safety and quality management systems in line with its internal corporate standards  and consistent with IFC Performance Standards and relevant guidelines.
