Project Description: Georgia Urban Enerji Ltd (GUE), intends to build and operate an 87 MW run-of-river Hydro Power Plant (HPP), on the Paravani River, near the town of Ahalkalaki, Georgia. The project Sponsors are the Anadolu Group, one of the leading Turkish conglomerates.  The rights to develop the Project are held by GUE, a Georgian special purpose vehicle owned 100% by the Sponsors. The project area is located in the Samstkhe-Javakheti Region of southern Georgia, close to the Turkish border. In addition to power generation facilities, the Project includes a conveyance tunnel of 13.8 km and a 32 km, 220 kV double circuit transmission line (T-line) linking the project to the new 500 kV Georgia-Turkey interconnector near Akhaltsikhe. The Project will supply electricity to the Georgian market in the three consecutive winter months, expected to be January, February and March, and export power to the Turkish market in the remaining nine months of the year. The total Project cost is estimated at US$ 156.5 million. The Project will be financed by IFC, EBRD and TSKB, a Turkish bank (as an IFC/EBRD B lender). The proposed IFC investment consists of an A Loan for up to $37.5 million, or 24% of Project cost. The project will consist of a 5 m high concrete gravity weir with a small (4000 m3, 0.5 ha) impoundment, a 13.8 km long power tunnel, a 1 km long penstock and a powerhouse with switchyard. The scheme will exploit a gross head of 420 m and the power house will have two Francis turbines. The intake structure will be located on the Paravani River a short distance downstream of the confluence with Korkhistskali Stream, at an elevation of around 1550 m. The small impoundment will not be designed for storage purposes and will store around five minutes worth of river flow. River diversion works during construction of the weir will include a bridge across the Paravani River to access the left bank, a 189 m concrete diversion channel on the right bank adjacent to the road, a 6 m high upstream coffer dam (temporary barrier excluding water from a river section to allow construction) and a 6 m high downstream coffer dam.The Paravani River is 66 km long and stretches from its source, Lake Paravani, to the Mtkvari River  also known as the Kura River - and the proposed weir site is located 53 km downstream from the lake. The weir site is located in a steep valley adjacent to a paved road and is remote from any settlements, the nearest of which is located high above the valley floor on top of the plateau. With flows ranging from only 6 to 30 m3/sec, the 13 km stretch of river downstream of the weir which will be most affected by the project is not currently utilized for drinking, livestock watering or irrigation purposes and is not currently inhabited. Two fish farms, one of which has a micro-hydro power plant utilizing a tributary stream, are located in this so called by-passed (or depleted) section, from which much of the usual flow will be diverted into the power tunnel. The powerhouse and switchyard will be located on a terrace on the right bank of the Mtkvari River approximately 1.5 km upstream of the confluence of the Mtkvari and Paravani Rivers and adjacent to a main road. Water will reach the powerhouse via the power tunnel, a surge tank and the penstock which will fall steeply from near the top of the plateau to the powerhouse site. Water will be discharged into the Mtkvari River via a tailrace canal.
Review Scope: IFC visited the project weir and powerhouse sites in February 2010 together with the Sponsor, the project environmental consultants (Gamma Scientific of Georgia) and EBRD. A project-related meeting was held in Tbilisi with the National Agency for Cultural Heritage Preservation and a senior UNESCO representative. IFC met with the Sponsor and other potential financiers again in July 2010 in Istanbul, after which a further mission was undertaken to Georgia including technical, environmental and financial staff of the main lenders and the Sponsor. A project visit was undertaken involving the proposed diversion weir site on the Paravani River, certain project access roads, the main construction camp site, the main power tunnel adits, access roads across the plateau, Chunchka Village  the closest settlement to the weir working areas  and the powerhouse site. Site meetings were held with village representatives at Chunchkha, pre-construction contractors and Project representatives. Brief visits were also made to Khertvisi Fortress and the Vardzia rock-cut monastery complex located at the respective ends of the Khertvisi-Vardzia cultural heritage area. A follow-up meeting was held in Tbilisi with representatives of the National Agency for Cultural Heritage Preservation and UNESCO National Commission for Georgia. A meeting was also held with Georgias Ministry of Environmental Protection and Natural Resources, to discuss the projects environmental and social impacts and related permitting and monitoring matters.IFC also reviewed and commented on several versions of the following key environmental, health and safety and social documents:·	Paravani HPP ESIA, 2009 ·	Paravani Transmission Line ESIA, 2010 ·	Paravani HPP and Transmission Line: ESIA Non-Technical Summary, 2011 ·	Paravani HPP and Transmission Line: Environmental & Social Action Plan, 2011 ·	Paravani HPP and Transmission Line: Stakeholder Engagement Plan, 2011 These documents were produced by Gamma Scientific Services, a Georgian consulting firm, on behalf of the Sponsors.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The Project is categorized A as it involves potentially significant adverse impacts related to tunneling and spoil management, access road improvement and construction, construction of a diversion weir in the Paravani River and construction of a 32 km high-voltage transmission line. Operation of the scheme will reduce flow in a 13 km downstream reach of the Paravani river by up to ninety percent.  In addition, part of the project will be located on the edge of a valley section rich in cultural heritage, in the buffer zone of the Kertvisi-Vardzia area which is on UNESCOs Tentative list as a future World Heritage site, having been proposed by the Government of Georgia in 2007. The Paravani River is a tributary to the Mtkvari (Kura) River, which is an international waterway flowing from Turkey, through Georgia and Azerbaijan into the Caspian Sea. This project has been categorized A by the EBRD, with whom IFC undertook joint due diligence.
Sector: BA - Large Hydro - Renewable Energy Generation

Project Description: Pran Group ('Pran' or 'the Group') has requested IFC's assistance to finance the expansion of its dairy operations, which are run under Pran Dairy Ltd ('PDL'), one of the Group companies.  Pran is a diversified group involved in the production and sale of a wide product range covering beverages, snacks, culinary products, confectionery, dairy products, rice and tea.  The proposed project consists of an investment of approximately $15 million for an expansion in PDL's processing and procurement capacity and related working capital needs ('the Project').
Impact:
The agriculture sector in Bangladesh accounts for 21% of its GDP, and 55% of its population is dependent on agriculture, including 20% in dairy activities. The local dairy sector is undergoing a slow transformation from unorganized to organized channels. Within the organized sector, there are a very limited number of private sector players. The Project will support the continued expansion into the dairy sector by one of the largest agribusiness companies in Bangladesh. Pran's extensive distribution reach in Bangladesh will enable it to reach to under-served populations while bringing in improved efficiencies in the sector.

The proposed Project will also have a transformative impact on the supply chain for dairy products. Pran currently works with 17,000 farmers on the dairy business. As part of this Project, PRAN will set up 60 new dairy hubs over a course of ten years, which will enable it to increase its reach to 90,000 additional farmers. The hubs will support smallholder dairies by providing entire package of logistic support including, veterinary care, animal husbandry, dairy housing, feed, breed improvement and training.

Project Description:
The proposed engagement with Kenya Commercial Bank Limited ('KCB' or 'the Group') is aligned to IFC's strategy for the East African financial sector. The Project is comprised of two related investments namely, a $100 million senior loan facility to KCB ,  one of largest and systemically important banks in Kenya and the East Africa region and a $5 million equivalent senior loan, in Rwanda Francs for KCB's wholly owned subsidiary KCB Rwanda Limited ('KCBR'). The Project is expected to provide the Bank with significant long-term financing support of its strategic objectives. 

The funding will be used to support the Group's regional expansion, increase access to finance for crucial sectors of the economy such as SME's, and facilitate increased mortgage lending especially for affordable housing. The use of proceeds will also reach the Bank's subsidiaries in the East Africa region and hence increase IFC reach in IDA countries. 

The senior loan facility to KCBR will be sourced through IFCs recently signed swap agreement with the National Bank of Rwanda ('NBR'), and will  boost its long term funding base and allow it to increase mortgage lending for affordable housing. The investment for this project will be coupled with IFC's mortgage toolkit technical Assistance to strengthen the Bank's mortgage finance business.
Impact:
i) Support Lending and Growth in the East African Market: 
The East African banking sector was affected by the global financial crisis, which led to a slowdown in the economy and reduced lending by the banking sector. Now that the situation has stabilized, KCB is well positioned to increase lending in the local market, which is important for investment and economic recovery in the region. The Project will, therefore, support the resumption of lending by KCB ultimately supporting renewed economic activity.

(ii) Increased Access to Finance for SMEs: 
SME's are a key growth sector for KCB. IFC will assist with SME development beyond financing to include advisory services for key aspects of its SME operations. The expected improvement in access to finance for SMEs will help to generate employment at the grass roots level and further facilitate regional trade which is expected to grow rapidly following the economic integration of the East African Community.

(iii) The investment in KCB Rwanda will have high development impact.  On an institutional level, access to longer term local currency financing will help KCBR manage its liquidity more effectively by limiting foreign currency risk.  On a sector level, the introduction of longer term financing in the market will afford more options to SME's and individual borrowers by providing longer term financing for mortgages and other new products.  In addition, the proposed technical assistance program will build the Bank's capacity in mortgage origination and monitoring in line with global best practice.

(iv) Support regional Expansion and integration

Project Description: Guangxi Hwagain Group Co., Ltd ('Hwagain' or 'the Company') is a major manufacturer of paper products in China using bamboo and scrap wood as raw materials. The proposed Project consists of a new kraft chemical pulp mill, two tissue paper production lines (which are integrated with the kraft pulp mills) located in Ganzhou, and new forest plantations ('the Project') in Guangxi and Jiangxi. The Company currently has manufacturing facilities located in Nanning, Guangxi and in Ganzhou, Jiangxi. It also operates its own bamboo and wood-based plantations in Guangxi and Jiangxi, and procures bamboo and wood fiber from third party suppliers. IFC has been approached to provide equity financing for the Project.
Review Scope: The scope of review of Guangxi Hwagain Group Co., Ltd ('Hwagain' or 'the Company') included assessment of the Company's capacity to provide oversight and monitor compliance with IFC's Performance Standards as well as national environmental, social and occupational health and safety regulatory requirements in the People's Republic of China.  The review relied on documents made available by Hwagain and on interviews conducted by IFC during visits to Hwagain's pulp and paper making facilities as well as forestry plantation operations at two locations in China: Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region (Guangxi); and Ganzhou Municipal City, Jiangxi Province. At both locations, IFC met with Hwagain personnel from the management, human resource, legal, environmental, safety, and operation teams. IFC also visited a number of local rural communities which have either leased forest land to or are supplying bamboo or wood fiber to Hwagain.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedures. The Project will result in a limited number of environmental and social (E&S) impacts which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Key environmental, health and safety, human resources and social issues that were reviewed included: environmental and social management system (ESMS); contractor and supply chain management; community engagement; labor and working conditions; occupational health and safety; water and energy use and efficiency; greenhouse gas emissions; air emissions, and water and solid waste discharge; community health and safety; land acquisition; and biodiversity preservation and sustainable forestry management.

Project Description:
The Company is a recently re-organized newly established Bolivian forest products company which produces hardwood veneers for regional and international markets.  Under the proposed investment the Company will increase veneer drying capacity and add a plywood production line which will reduce waste and increase wood recovery at its milling facility in Warnes, Santa Cruz.  The proposed investment would also provide working capital to increase the Company's internal harvesting capacity so the Company can reduce the use of independent harvest operators and contract directly with 8-10 IFAs operating within two Indigenous Territories (TCOs) in the Santa Cruz Department. 

Through an expanded and reciprocal relationship the Company proposes to assist these IFAs to establish forest management practices which will comply with strict national laws and achieve step-wise conformity with internally-recognized forest management practices through FSC certification.  By late 2012, SLV intends to be sourcing 50,000 m3 of logs from indigenous-managed communities, 80% of which will be extracted directly by SLV under long-term contracts with the communities and the remaining 20% provisioned through third party contractors providing legal verification of all wood.
Review Scope:
During appraisal SLV, Ltd ('the Company') was assessed against IFC's Performance Standards, local regulatory requirements and applicable requirements of the World Bank Group (WBG), and IFC's General Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines and EHS Guidelines to Forest Management and Harvesting and Sawmilling and Manufactured Wood Products.  IFC reviewed the Company's current environment and social management systems and the likely impacts associated with the proposed project.  Review included a multi-day site visit to the Company operating facilities in Warnes, Santa Cruz Department Bolivia and the areas of proposed forest management.  Interviews were conducted with representatives of nine of the 10 Indigenous Forestry Associations ('IFAs') from which the Company proposes to purchase wood as well as leaders of the indigenous federations and respective forestry arms.  IFC also conducted extensive interviews with community service providers and harvesting contractors, senior forestry department officials, and forest industry representatives. The team also reviewed applicable environmental regulations and permitting procedures for wood processing facilities, forest management and harvesting, and logistics.  The review relied on documents and reports made available by the Company and interviews with key management personnel, including those responsible for as aspects of wood product manufacturing and forestry operations. Key documents reviewed and available on-line included:

- Bolivia National FSC Forest Standard (http://www.consejoforestal.org.bo/) 
- Ley Forestal (No. 1700 of 1996,  http://bolivia.infoleyes.com/shownorm.php?id=2491)
- SLV Mission, Vision and Values: (http://slvbolivia.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layout=blog&id=46&Itemid=94&lang=en)

Through these activities, an assessment was made of the effectiveness of the Company's environmental and social management system for its proposed capital expenditure projects and its ability to ensure and monitor compliance with applicable laws and regulatory requirements, IFC's Performance Standards, and internationally-recognized wood manufacturing and forest management practices.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
This project represents a novel model of business engagement between a manufacturing entity and indigenous forestry groups with risk of potentially significant adverse social and environmental impacts which may be diverse and occur at an unprecedented scale.  Therefore this has been determined to be a Category A project according to IFC's Social and Environmental and Sustainability Policy.  

Key environmental, health and safety, human resources and social issues associated with the project and that  were reviewed include: 

Expansion of the Company's environmental and social management systems to forestry
Adapting industrial occupational health and safety practices to wood extraction operations  
Identification and conservation of natural habitats and management of priority ecosystem services 
Emissions to the environment  air, wastewater and noise during forestry, processing and transportation activities
Management of hazardous materials including all agrochemicals and operational petrochemicals
Energy use, efficiency and GHG impacts associated with all aspects of project development
Proposed approach and methods of community engagement likely to be employed during project roll-out

The Company proposes an approach and has documented practices which integrate social and environmental management systems at the processing facility with sustainable forest stewardship as part of its fundamental business proposition as most products will be sold to markets which require verification of legal origin and FSC certification.  The Company proposes avoiding and mitigating adverse environmental and social impacts through a proactive adaptation, deployment and strengthening of processing and woodland management practices which are well established in this region of Bolivia.

Project Name: Business Partners International Rwanda SME Fund
Company Name: BUSINESS PARTNERS INTERNATIONAL RWANDA SME FUND LTD
Project Description:
The proposed project is to establish an $8 million investment fund, Business Partners International Rwanda SME Fund ('BP Rwanda'), capable of delivering finance and technical assistance to local SMEs in a commercially sustainable manner and generating an acceptable return to investors in the Fund. 

BP Rwanda represents the fourth IFC investment in a local investment fund managed by Business Partners International ('BPI'). To date, IFC has invested $5.0 million in BP Kenya (IFC project no. 23826) and $3.7 million in BP Madagascar (IFC project no. 23825). A third fund, BP Mozambique (IFC project no. 26028, $1.6 million) is Board approved and expected to become operational in the second quarter of 2011.

The Fund aims to overcome the main obstacles in providing finance to smaller SMEs, namely: (i) lack of collateral and weak enforcement for debt providers; (ii) lack of upside opportunities for equity investors; (iii) high cost of appraisal; (iv) lack of controlling positions; and (v) limited exit potential.
Impact:
The Fund is expected to have significant development impact by:
-	Encouraging economic development of private sector by increasing the flow of risk capital to small and medium-sized companies in Rwanda.
-	Providing much needed growth and expansion capital and value-enhancing advice to companies located in Rwanda, which currently lack access to both. The resulting stronger companies are expected to generate above-average rates of job creation.
-	Improving companies' sustainable development by helping the Fund to introduce best pratice corporate governance and E&S standards.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.   During appraisal, IFC analyzed the funds expected portfolio and sectors of investment, which include SMEs providing business, manufacturing, tourism and trade related services with average transaction sizes between USD150, 000 and USD250, 000. S&E risks and impacts of SMEs typically financed by BP in other countries evolve around labor and working conditions, ensuring adequate occupational health and safety, and environmental issues such as effluents, waste and hazardous materials management. Based on the analysis of the potential social and environmental risks associated with the expected portfolio and considering IFCs investment, the IFC Exclusion List and the National laws and regulations have been determined as the Applicable Performance requirements for this project. IFC also reviewed the funds existing Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS), and capacity to implement the same. It was found that while BP Rwanda is a new Fund; both existing BP Funds in which IFC has invested are in compliance with all S&E requirements, including the development and implementation of a SEMS, which will be utilized by BP Rwanda. The quality of S&E due diligence undertaken and staff capacity at existing BP Funds were also found to be adequate, and the Funds are reporting regularly. As a category FI investment, and based on the review, the Fund will be required to (i) Provide a notification to IFC with regard to the adoption of the Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS), currently utilized by other BP subsidiaries, and the designation of the S&E Officer, prior to commitment; (ii) Commit to implement the SEMS to ensure that its activities are in compliance with the Applicable Performance requirements; (iii) Provide S&E training to investment staff; and (vi) Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor:
The sponsor is Business Partners International (BPI), established in 2004 as a joint venture between IFC and Business Partners Limited, a South African risk financier of SMEs. 

Based in Johannesburg, South Africa, Business Partners has made over 35,000 investments in SMEs in South Africa to the value of about $1.2 billion and has facilitated more than 500,000 employment opportunities.
Cost Nature: BP Rwanda has a target equity investment commitment of $8.0 million and IFC expects to invest up to $1.6 million in equity in the Fund.

Project Description:
SLV was established in Santa Cruz, Bolivia for the purpose of constructing and operating a state-of-the-art mill to produce hardwood tropical rotary veneer, plywood and its byproducts, mostly for exports.

Investments started in 2005. The plant was built within a 18 ha free-trade industry zone and includes a modern sawmill, veneer lathe and dryer. The Company currently has a total annual capacity to process 120,000 mt of logs/year, being one of the largest operations of its kind in Latin America. 

The purpose of the project is to support SLV to consolidate its operation and business model by: (i) improving plant efficiencies through diversified product mix and higher log recovery rates; (ii) increasing reliability and consistency of log supply; (iii) funding incremental working capital; and (iv) refinancing exiting short-term debt with local banks.
Impact: IFC involvement with the Company is expected to have a strong development impact in the economy by: i) supporting the development of an export oriented sector with deep roots in the economy and with extensive linkages throughout the value chain; ii) creating additional direct and indirect employment while helping to preserve 140 existing jobs; iii) improving living standards and climate change by promoting sustainable management of natural tropical forest through certification.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been categorized as an A project in accordance with IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures.  The proposed project involves the harvesting, extraction and processing of wood products from community-managed natural forests in Bolivias Guarayos and Chiquitania regions.  IFC conducted an extensive appraisal of the proposed project which included interviews with indigenous forestry associations and the Indigenous Territory leaders, government and industry representatives, contractors and suppliers, and local and international conservation NGOs active in Bolivia.  IFC reviewed the Companys management systems, compliance with Applicable Regulations and IFC Performance Standards, and assessed the Companys ability to meet and assist communities to meet internationally-recognized forestry practices and standards.  Environmental and social risks include the sustainability of wood production and potential impacts on biodiversity and ecosystem services, the direct engagement of communities and indigenous peoples, and the occupational health and safety of forestry and processing workforces including direct suppliers.  The Company proposes to mitigate such risks through a proactive environment and social management system and adherence to FSC forest management and chain-of-custody standards.
Sponsor: Today, on a fully diluted basis, SLV is owned by Ospraie (New York based private equity fund) with 57%; Fernando Campero with 29% (the 'Sponsor'); SLV management with 6.0%; and other local investors with 8.0% (no individual shareholder owning more than 5.0% of the shares).

Total Project Cost is estimated at $8.5 million. 

The proposed IFC investment is up to $6 million C loan for IFC's own account

Project Description:

The Bank provides a full range of banking services to SMES, retail, selected corporate clients, and alliance banking clients. Mercantile also aims at building a portfolio of SMEs / Mid Market clients which are energy efficient/cleaner production/ and renewable energy related subprojects in South Africa. IFC senior loan will assist the Bank to grow its SME / Mid Market clients lending and develop a portfolio of energy efficient related businesses.

Company Name: KONCERN FARMAKOM M.B. DOO - U STECAJU
Project Description: Farmakom MB ('Farmakom' or 'the Sponsor' or 'the Group') is a diversified group.  Its businesses include car battery manufacturing, metal smelting, dairy, foundry, heavy metal mining, and greenhouse-based agriculture. Since 2006, it has invested over 140 million for new equipment in order to add new capacity and improve the environmental standards of its factories, As a result, Farmakom's workforce doubled from 1,500 to 3,000 employees. The proposed IFC investment is to reduce the number of lenders Farmakom works with, improve banking relationships, and reduce administrative costs. Under the proposed structure, IFC financing will be extended to two or three of the main operating subsidiaries, including FAS (car battery), Zajaca (metal smelting), and Sabac (dairy), with a full guarantee from the ultimate holding company.
Review Scope: The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health, safety and social information submitted by the project sponsor, and field visits in December 2010. The environmental and social (E&S) appraisal team visited dairy/agribusiness factory, milk collection centers and livestock farms in Sabac, the FAS battery plant in Somber, smelter plant in Zajaca, foundry plant in Guca, lead/zinc mine sites in Lece, Serbia and the Lojane site in Macedonia. The E&S team held meetings with the corporate management team of Farmakom, and plant managers at Farmakom plants. The E&S appraisal team also visited communities and surrounding areas of key plant sites.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
All the project sites have operated for many years and will not be expanded under the terms of the Project, though there may be minor debottlenecking. Farmakom has invested to install new technology and equipment in its manufacturing sites in the past few years, with the results that air and water emissions are now much improved from previous conditions, and will meet IFC E&S requirements upon successfully implemented proposed mitigation methods which are defined in the attached Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP). The current operation at the Zajaca smelter site has no cross boundary impacts and has limited impact to nearby village. Farmakom is working with the Serbian government to propose mitigation methods for legacy contamination at Zajaca site. 

The potential adverse E&S impacts of this Project are therefore few in number and limited to project sites and may be readily mitigated.  This is therefore an E&S Category B project.
Sector: BA - Electrical Machinery, Equipment and Components (Electric Lighting, Motors, Batteries, Insulated Wires and Cables, Fiber Optic Cable, Carbon and Graphite Products, etc.)

Company Name: KONCERN FARMAKOM M.B. DOO - U STECAJU
Project Description: Farmakom is one of the largest exporters in Serbia.  Since 2006, the group has invested over EUR140 million in its operations in order to add capacity and improve productivity and environmental standards.  The IFC project involves both an investment component and a corporate governance advisory component.  The investment component seeks to (i) provide much needed financing to a leading private sector group in Serbia to restructure its debt, (ii) fund some capital investments, and (iii) finance additional working capital requirements in line with the projected growth in 2011-13 to increase utilization of completed investments.
Impact:
The Group will
- have access to liquidity in order to support its expansion in export markets generating hard currency for the country,
- strengthen existing linkages with local suppliers,
- provide value-added products & services to customer improving their living standards; and
- additional tax revenues to the local Government by increased operations.
Environmental Social Issues: This Category B project has limited impacts that can be resolved through the application of good international industry practices, the Environmental and Social Action Plan and IFC performance standards and applicable sections of EHS guidelines.  The key environmental and social issues for this project include the following: - Strengthening Corporate E&S Management,- Exemption of liability for legacy contamination and prevention measures of contamination risks -Strengthening Occupational health and safety controls, - Air emissions and abatement, - Cleaner production  and waste water treatment, - Hazardous and sanitary waste management, - Mitigations for community health risk - Road transportation and community safety, - Food safety and quality Management system.

Project Description:
MobiNetS Lebanon S.A.L. Offshore ('MobiNetS' or the 'Company') is a company specialized in providing professional services and software solutions to telecom operators and suppliers.  Its main product is a set of network planning optimization tools that enables mobile operators to optimize their networks, which can potentially result in substantial capital expenditures and operating expenditures savings. In today's environment, there is a rising need for operating efficiency in telecom operators as they experience a surge in data traffic volumes, combined with a downward pressure on tariffs and EBITDA margin, resulting from the increased competition. 

Created in 2003, MobiNetS is owned by its founder, Mr. Labib Shalak who is also the Chief Executive Officer ('CEO'). The Company is headquartered in Tripoli (Lebanon) and has 49 employees as of December 2010.
Environmental Social Issues: MobiNetS provides electronic services that save energy and other resources and lower carbon emissions. Due diligence at appraisal showed that environmental and social risks are low in this project, so the project is classified as Category C according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.
Sponsor: MobiNetS is 99% owned by its founder Mr. Labib Shalak, a 38-year old Lebanese-French national, who has been active in the Information, Communications and Technology ('ICT') sector since 1997. Prior to MobiNetS, Mr. Shalak worked as a system engineer and senior consultant with Mobile Systems International in the United Kingdom ('MSI-UK') and in the Research & Development department of France Telecom. He obtained a master degree from the Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Télécommunications (Paris, France) in 1997.
Cost Nature: Total Project Costs is estimated at $ 12.7 million over the next two years.  IFC's proposed equity investment of up to $2.5 million will mostly used to hire high level management as well as technical staff. The remaining financing will come from the Company's internal cash flows and potentially another co-investor.

Project Description: The project is to provide a subordinated loan, meeting the tier 2 capital requirement to ACLEDA. This subordinated loan aims to help ACLEDA to maintain a CAR/solvency ratio of more than 15% as required by the National Bank of Cambodia (NBC) and support the Bank's loan growth which is expected to be strong in 2011.
Impact:
Increase access to credit:  The proposed investment in ACLEDA is expected to improve access to credit in Cambodia as it will enable ACLEDA Cambodia to provide credit to underserved micro finance and SME and retail borrowers. 
Improving market confidence:  An IFC loan to a bank such as ACLEDA will enhance market confidence in the Cambodian financial sector and its perception in the international markets.  The proposed subordinate debt will not only strengthen the Bank's capitalization, but is also expected to enhance prospects of mobilizing additional equity and long term funding from private investors.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an investment with a repeat client which has an existing Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS), has appointed staff to oversee the SEMS implementation and has submitted annual reports to IFC. The review of the clients 2009 annual environmental performance report and the recent supervision visit by an environmental specialist in March 2011 have indicated that the client has implemented the SEMS in a satisfactory manner. The current ESRR rating is 2 (moderate). This new project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Considering the nature of activities supported, the client will be required to continue to ensure that its lending activities will comply with IFC Exclusion List, applicable Cambodian E&S laws and regulations and other requirements established in the existing SEMS. It will commit to take action to remedy any gaps in implementation on an ongoing basis and will continue to submit an annual performance report to IFC. The bank will also be required to continue to follow the principles established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions in its HR practices. IFC will continue to monitor the banks SEMS implementation and E&S performances.
Sponsor: Set up as a micro finance institution since 1998, ACLEDA has developed into one of the biggest commercial banks in Cambodia in term of asset and network, with 234 offices throughout the country and serves more than 267,000 clients of which over 50% are women. As of November 2010, the bank's total deposit reached USD 904 million while loan portfolio grew to more than USD 722 million. The Bank continues to serve micro segment and also goes up the market to serves SMEs segment as well, throughout Cambodia. ACLEDA also has a subsidiary in Laos. As of end 2010, ACLEDA Bank has a diversified shareholding structure, with ACLEDA NGO holding 32%, ASA 19% and a number of international development institutions including DEG, IFC, Triodos and JSH Asian Holdings Limited.
Cost Nature: The proposed project consists of a subordinated debt of up to USD 6 million with maturity of 7 years (grace period of 2 years) and meets tier 2 capital requirements in Cambodia. The sub debt aims to help ACLEDA: 1) maintain a CAR/solvency ratio of more than 15% as required by the National Bank of Cambodia (NBC), and 2) support its loan growth which has been picking up in 2010 more quickly than they have anticipated and is expected to remain strong in 2011.

Project Description: Mriya Agro Holding, an existing IFC client, is one of the largest Ukrainian primary agricultural producers with a proven track record of growing wheat, sugar beet, rape seed, corn, barley and potatoes. Its operations are concentrated in Western Ukraine in the Ternopil, Khmelnytskiy, Chernivtsi and Ivano-Frankivsk regions. Mriya operates grain storage silos, a seed plant (first stage development) and controls the operation of six sugar plants. The sugar plants are associated facilities to the Companys agricultural operations and are controlled in order to support cultivation of sugar beet, which improves crop rotation and is a source of additional value.This would be IFCs second investment in Mriya to support the expansion of its agricultural operations from 220,000ha land area under cultivation to 480,000 ha by 2014 and the construction of new silos. In 2011, the Company plans to add 80,000 ha to its cultivated land.
Review Scope: Mriya Agro Holding (the Company or Mriya) is an existing IFC client. In 2010, IFC invested in Mriya to support its efforts in expanding the scope of its agricultural operations (Project # 28632). Mriya demonstrated its commitment to continuous improvement of Environmental and Social (E&S) performance and completed, in due dates, the required action items included in the Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP).  The Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) and the ESAP for the first investment was disclosed locally and on IFCs public disclosure site on February 23, 2010 and is available at the following link: Project #28632In addition, IFC has provided to this client advisory services related to energy efficiency and cleaner production.Available information about the Companys E&S performance derived from the previous IFC investment was analyzed and taken into account during this appraisal. As such, the scope of this review was mainly focused on operations related to further expansion of crop growing and grain processing facilities being constructed.IFCs environmental and social (E&S) review of this project consisted of a field visit to the Companys local operational offices and selected facilities located in Western Ukraine; meetings and discussions with Mriyas corporate and local management (operational, environment, occupational health and safety, human resources, social) and review of key environmental, occupational health and safety and social documentation provided by Mriya. The field visit included observation of local operations and meetings with supervisors of selected grain storage silos, potato storage facilities and the seed plant. In addition, a visit to the selected sugar plant and meetings with plants management were undertaken. Sponsor-owned sugar plants are associated with Mriyas sugar business supply chain, but not funded as part of the Project.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Given the fact that the land proposed for the expansion of the Companys agricultural operations is either already converted idle farmland plots with modified habitats typical for agricultural areas, or consolidated agricultural and industrial land plots, it is deemed appropriate to classify this project as Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures. The Projects limited environmental and social adverse impacts can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to the International Codes of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO); national laws and regulations; IFCs Performance Standards and applicable WBGs general and sector-specific Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines.
Sector: AG - Diversified Edible Agricultural Crops Production

Project Description: The project consists of the construction, operation and maintenance of a 56.4 MW wind farm and associated transmission facilities in the Jhimpir area of Thatta District, Sindh Province, in south-eastern Pakistan, about 100 km east of Karachi (Project).  The Project site is within the Gharo air corridor and has an average wind speed of 7.8 m/s.  The Project will be an Independent Power Producer and will sell electricity to the National Transmission and Dispatch Company Limited (NTDC) under a 20-year Energy Purchase Agreement.  The Project is the first internationally financed wind power project in Pakistan.  The Project is being developed in two phases, with the 6 MW phase I already installed and phase II comprising the remaining 50.4 MW.  The inauguration of Phase I was made in April 2009 attended by the Prime Minister of Pakistan.  The five 1.2MW each wind turbine generators (WTGs) for phase I was procured from Vensys Energy and the twenty eight 1.8 MW each WTGs for Phase II are being procured from Vestas.  The 1.2 MW WTG will be placed at 69m height tower with its peak height of 100m.  The 1.8 MW WTG will be placed at 80m height with its peak height of 125 m.  All the 33 WTGs will be connected to a substation with an underground power cable.  The substation is planned to be connected to the national grid system of NTDC.  The Project has been developed by Zorlu Enerji Pakistan Limited (Zorlu Pakistan or the Company), a special purpose company incorporated in Islamabad.  Zorlu Pakistan is an almost wholly-owned subsidiary of Zorlu Enerji Elektrik Uretim A.S Zorlu Enerji or the Sponsor).  A subsidiary of Zorlu O&M Enerji Tesisleri Isletme A.S. (Zorlu O&M, wholly-owned by Zorlu Holding) will be responsible for the Projects operation and maintenance.  The Project is located in the operational jurisdiction of Hyderabad Electric Supply Company (HESCO), and the Project will be connected to the Zorlu Pakistans substation (20/132 kV) to be developed within the Project area by underground cable, and then, connected to the existing 132 kV transmission line network of HESCO.  An associated 2 km 132 kV transmission line from the Project area to the HESCO network will be developed by NTDC.
Review Scope: Documents reviewed:- Regional Environmental Assessment Study (REA) of the Gharo Wind Corridor in Pakistan,  prepared with assistance by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) of Pakistan, June 2009 This REA consists of (i) Section I (Environmental & Socio-Economic Baseline Report, (ii) Section II (Cumulative Impact Assessment & Alternatives), and (iii) Section III (Environmental Management Plan).  These are available at:http://www.wep.org.pk/05_reference_material/wep_publications.phphttp://un.org.pk/undpnew/images/publications/Sec02.pdfhttp://un.org.pk/undpnew/images/publications/Sec03.pdf- Wind Power Project  Sindh, Environmental Impact Assessment, Final updated Report, April 2010, Prepared for Zorlu Enerji- Decision on Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) for Zorlu Enerji Pakistan Limited 50MW Wind Power Project, Issued by Environmental Protection Agency of Government of Sindh, March 19, 2009Site Visits:  Visits to the project site, neighboring villages, transmission line route, phase I (6MW) operation, Keenjhar Lake, conducted by IFC staff in February 2010.Meetings and Discussions in February 2010.- Officers in charge of environmental, health and safety and social matters of Zorlu Pakistan- Environmental consulting firm (Elan Partners (Pvt) Ltd) that prepared the Projects EIA- Sindh Environmental Protection Agency- An environmental organization (WWF-Pakistan)
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The proposed investment in the Project is a Category B project because of a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The Project is located in a remote rural arid and rocky area and its access needed for the construction of the Project is possible through well established public roads and railway.  The distance to the closest residential receptors is about 3km, and environmental impacts typical to wind power generations (e.g. noise, shadow flickering) on affected communities are expected to be minimal.  The land will be sub-leased by the Government of Pakistan and no economic or physical relocation of people is needed.  There is a protected natural lake about 7.8 km from the Project site.  The Company is working with local environmental NGO (WWF-Pakistan) to conduct migratory bird monitoring programs.  The Company will manage its environmental and social performance in accordance with applicable local laws and regulations and international standards, including IFCs Performance Standards.  The Asian Development Bank, a co-financier to the Project, categorized the Project as B (Environment), C (Involuntary resettlement), and C (Indigenous peoples).  IFCs category is consistent with ADBs category.
Sector: BC - Wind Power - Renewable Energy Generation

Project Description: The project consists of the construction, operation and maintenance of a 56.4 MW wind farm and associated facilities in Jhimpir, Thatta District, Sindh Province, Pakistan, some 100 km east of Karachi (the Project). Outside of Turkey, besides Pakistan, the Sponsor is also developing power projects in Israel and Russia. Zorlu Enerji is listed on the Istanbul Stock Exchange, under the ticker ZOREN. 

The Zorlu Group, mainly through Zorlu Holding A.S., currently owns 84.9% of the Sponsor. The Zorlu Group is a leading Turkish business group with interests in a wide range of sectors, including energy, textile, electronics and real estate.

Project Description: The project involves providing a three-year renewable working capital facility to Mriya, a leading Ukrainian primary agricultural producer with a proven track record of growing wheat, barley, sugar beet, rapeseed, potatoes, and other crops. The three-year facility will provide financing of inputs needed for agricultural production to produce agricultural commodities for sale to local clients and international traders.
Impact: IFC''s financing will contribute to the development of a large-scale modern farming operation which will improve land productivity and have a demonstration impact on other neighboring farms.  Mriya''s land and operations are located in Western Ukraine in the Ternopil, Ivano-Frankivsk, Chernivtsi and Khmelnitsky regions.  These four regions are amongst the poorest regions in the country. Development impact of the project will be as follows:Employment: Mriya has approximately 1,002 permanent employees and 623 seasonal employees. The project is expected to increase permanent employment to about 1700 and seasonal employment to about 900. In the western Ukraine where Mriya operates, employment opportunities are scarce. In addition to creating new jobs, Mriya is setting new employment standards in the region by providing benefits to its farm workers such food and housing.Environmental and Social Standards: As part of the Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP), Mriya will implement an ESMS to provide a structured framework to identify and act on environmental and social risks and opportunities in the management of its agricultural operations as well as down-stream in the agricultural value chain, in the operations of the Sponsor-owned affiliated sugar beet processing plants.Private Sector Development: Mriya sells its products to a well diversified base of final customers and traders. Among them, there currently are about  55 MSME distributors of mainly potatoes, buckwheat, and corn, for final sales on the domestic market. On the purchasing side, Mriya relies on about 27 MSME suppliers, in addition to several large key ones, for deliveries of fertilizers, plant protection chemicals, and spare parts.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social (E&S) Review Procedures. IFCs E&S review has confirmed that the project must be managed consistent with the following IFC Performance Standards: PS1 (Social and Environmental Assessment and Management Systems); PS2 (Labor and Working Conditions); PS3 (Pollution Prevention and Abatement) and PS4 (Community Health, Safety and Security).Key E&S issues include: capacity of the E&S management system to address potential environmental, occupational health and safety risks associated with further expansion of Mriya agricultural operations; compliance with national laws and regulations; labour conditions and terms of employment of Mriyas permanent and short-time employees; implementation of Integrated Pest and Disease Management Plans; E&S aspects and occupational health and safety at the sugar plants that are the key in the sugar business value chain;  waste and wastewater disposal.Information about how these potential issues will be addressed by the Company is summarized in the Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS). Mriya is committed to implement all corrective actions identified in the E&S Action Plan (ESAP) to mitigate negative E&S impacts and risks associated with Mriyas and affiliated sugar plants operations.  Upon implementation of the ESAP, the proposed project will comply with the E&S requirements of host country laws and IFCs Policies, Performance Standards and industry specific guidelines.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is the Huta family (the Sponsors), who founded Mriya in 1992 and control it till this day. The head of the Huta family, Ivan Huta, a well-respected Ukrainian businessman, and his wife, Klaudia Huta, Ivan and Klaudia Huta established Mriya on 50 hectares of land, after having worked for eight years at a state farm. In 2002, Andriy and Mykola Huta, the sons of the founders, joined the family business after completing their education in Ukraine and abroad. Following a private placement on the Entry Standard of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange in 2008, the Sponsors collectively own 80% of Mriyas Cyprus-based holding company that fully controls all of Mriyas Ukraine-based operating companies, with the remaining 20% owned by over 20 institutional investors.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is $90 million. The Project will encompass financing of agricultural commodities grown by Mriya as well as the purchasing of seeds, fertilizers, CPPs, fuel and other costs related to work in progress.

Project Description: The proposed project consists in the launch of a greenfield reinsurance company ('Terra Brasis' or the 'Company') in Brazil.  Today the reinsurance market in Brazil presents a strong development potential for new domestic private owned reinsurance companies given: (i) the pipeline of investments  in logistic, energy and infrastructure; (ii) the events that the country will host in the next six years (the World Cup and the Summer Olympic Games); (iii) the discovery of important oil reserves in the so called pre-salt layer, which will bring significant investments in the oil exploration chain; and (iv) the growth of the economy as a whole, which creates necessity for more (re)insurance coverage. Terra Brasis will increase reinsurance capacity in the Brazilian market and will create a new reinsurance alternative for insurance companies operating in Brazil.
Environmental Social Issues: The Project consists of an equity investment in a greenfield reinsurance company and has been categorized as FI. During appraisal, IFC will analyze the expected portfolio of activities of the company and any existing E&S management capacity of the sponsors to determine the applicable E&S requirements, which may include a combination of the IFC exclusion list, the national E&S laws of Brazil and the Performance Standards. Given the potential E&S issues associated with some of the activities that will be supported by the new company, such as performance guarantees for infrastructure sub-projects, the client will be required to develop a Social and Environmental Management System tailored to identify and manage these risks. The company will also be required to comply with IFCs labor policy, Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions, and submit a periodic E&S report in a format agreed with the IFC.
Sponsor:
The project sponsors, Plural Capital (an asset management company) and Messrs. Rodolfo Riechert and André Schwartz, who today own Plural Capital and are former partners of Banco Pactual, which was one of the most successful Brazilian investment banks.   The company will be managed by Mr. Paulo Botti, a well known executive in the insurance sector.

The sponsors will hold (directly and indirectly) approximately 80% of the Company, IFC will hold approximately 14% and the management and other minority investors, 6%.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at BRL 100 million. The proposed IFC investment is approximately BRL 15 million in straight equity.

Company Name: MAGHREB PRIVATE EQUITY FUND III LLC
Project Description: Maghreb Private Equity Fund III ('MPEF III' or 'The Fund') is a private equity fund formed by Tuninvest-Africinvest ('Tuninvest') and managed by Evolia Limited (the 'Manager') with a target size of 200 million Euros, which will make equity and equity-related investments in small and medium-sized enterprises (SME) in Tunisia, Morocco, Algeria, Libya and, on an opportunistic basis, Egypt. Target sectors will include agribusiness, packaging, consumer products, distribution and retail, financial services, manufacturing, telecom, and transport.
Impact: The proposed Project is expected to have a high development impact as: (i) the Fund will target SMEs with clear growth prospects that can increase job creation, (ii) the Manager will adopt best practices for transparency and corporate governance of its investee companies, thus fostering knowledge and skills transfer, and (iii) the Manager will employ a hands-on value added strategy to help portfolio companies improve operational efficiency and competitiveness.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category "FI" project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.During appraisal, IFC analyzed the Fund''s pipeline, for types of transactions, size, and industry sectors and determined the Applicable Performance Requirements based on an analysis of the potential Social and Environmental risks associated with the Fund''s pipeline. Considering IFCs investment, the Applicable Performance Requirements are:- The IFC FI Exclusion List;- The applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and regulations; and- The IFC Performance Standards. IFC also reviewed the Fund''s existing Social & Environmental due diligence process and the current Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS). Company Name: Shanghai Pudong Development Bank Co., Ltd.
Project Description: IFC is in discussion with Shanghai Pudong Development Bank ('SPDB') to enter into a risk sharing facility ('RSF' or the 'Project'). This would be the first phase of CHUEE SME under which IFC intends to support energy efficiency ('EE') and renewable energy ('RE') projects with small and medium enterprises ('SME') in China through IFC RSFs with local financial institutions.  In this proposed project, IFC would take credit risk in a loan portfolio to be originated and funded by SPDB. The Project is expected to receive support from the Global Environment Facility.
Impact:
(i)	Environmental benefit: Annual reduction of 267,000 tCO2/year during 2015 to 2018
(ii)	SME access to finance: At least a total of 35 eligible loans will be disbursed by the end of 2014 from a baseline of zero loans as of December 2010
(iii)	 Demonstration effect: Encouraging the Chinese government at both central and local levels to participate in future public private partnership initiatives of this type; and 
(iv)	Capacity building: Promoting the development of industry specific loan underwriting criteria and improved risk management practices.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Considering the size and the EE technology applications of these subprojects, the Applicable Performance Requirements will include a combination of the IFC FI Exclusion List, the applicable Chinese social and environmental laws and regulations and applicable IFC Environmental, Health and Safety Guidelines. SPDB will be required to implement a social and environmental management system (SEMS) to properly assess and manage the E&S risks associated with the subprojects consistent with the Applicable Performance Requirements. A satisfactory SEMS will be a condition of the effectiveness of the risk sharing facilities. In addition, SPDB will be required to appoint designated staff to oversee the SEMS implementation and submit periodic reports per a form provided by IFC.
Sponsor: SPDB, approved by People's Bank of China, was incorporated in August 1992. It is a national joint-stock commercial bank headquartered in Shanghai and listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange.
Cost Nature: IFC is considering an investment of up to RMB330 million in the form of an unfunded risk sharing guarantee. The final amount will be decided by both IFC and SPDB after assessing the market demand.

Project Description: HPC Ukraina (the 'Company') operates the Odessa Container Terminal ('OCT') within the Odessa Port, the largest seaport in Ukraine and one of the Black Sea's biggest ports. The Project is to extend the existing OCT through the construction and operation of a new, adjacent container terminal (the 'Quarantine Mole Terminal', or the 'QMT').  These two terminals will have a combined capacity of 850,000 TEUs upon completion, increasing from the current capacity of 550,000 TEUs at OCT.  HPC Ukraina's portion of the QMT extension project includes: (i) land reclamation; (ii) construction of the access dam and pavement of the quay and access ways; (iii) purchase and installation of container handling and related equipment.  In addition, the Company will replace equipment and conduct maintenance civil work at OCT.
Impact: The Project will increase Ukraine's competitiveness, and indirectly drive trade growth, by providing modern efficient container handling capacity with deep draft to better serve the country's exports and imports.  The Project will help reduce the cost of transportation by serving larger vessels which have lower unit costs, therefore benefitting shippers, shipping lines, and consumers alike.  It will also strengthen the country's port sector by increasing competition in the market and encouraging other terminal operators to improve the efficiency and service standards of their own terminal facilities.  The Project's success will also have a demonstration effect for encouraging private infrastructure investments in Ukraine. In addition, the increased capacity is expected to result in more fiscal revenues to Ukraine when trade recovers.
Environmental Social Issues: The project is a category B investment according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The major environmental and social issues of this project are associated with construction activities and a risk of marine pollution from a terminals surface runoff or accidental release of hazardous substances during operation of the terminal. Application of standard construction environmental controls, mitigation measures recommended in the environmental impact assessment and specific measures agreed in the Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) will ensure compliance with national and IFC''s environmental and social Performance Standards. A summary of IFCs environmental and social review findings for the project including the rationale for the B categorization is publicly available in the Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) disclosed through IFCs external website: http://www.ifc.org/projects
Sponsor: HPC Ukraina is 100% owned by HPC Hamburg Port Consulting, which in turn is a fully owned subsidiary of Hamburger Hafen und Logistik Aktiengesellschaft (HHLA) from Germany.
Cost Nature: The Project cost is estimated at $119.1 million.  The proposed IFC investment comprises of an IFC A Loan of $32.0 million, for IFC's own account, and a B or a parallel loan from other financial institutions of $14.0 million.

Project Description: Emerging Markets Communications (EMC or the Company) provides mission-critical, end-to-end communications solutions to governments, non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and multinational corporations operating in remote regions of the globe. Specifically, the Companys services include voice, data, email, video and broadband internet access and applications.The project consists of (i) the scaling up and expansion, and (ii) the balance sheet strengthening, of EMCs VSAT telecoms network serving isolated areas of emerging markets.  EMC provides global satellite communication using a high quality, fully managed network.  The Company began its activities in 2002.
Impact: Improve productivity through connectivity:  The impact of increased and affordable access to communications and data services is widely acknowledged, with far reaching benefits in terms of private and public sector productivity, including market information, education, tele-medicine and extending financial services to the frontier.  Increased coverage: EMC has the capacity to deliver fully managed, end-to-end solutions in difficult countries and regions where satellite technology is the best or only alternative. Broader range of services:  Further to basic data and voice, EMC can support more sophisticated applications, processes and corporate software solutions such as SAP and Oracle.Enhance competition:  Often, EMC is the only viable alternative to the incumbent telecomsoperator.  Supporting EMC helps increase competition and provides comfort to many f its customers that sensitive communications will be handled with privacy. Reduction in travel/carbon footprint:   EMCs Video-on-Demand solution to be deployed in 2011 will allow customers to collaborate with their colleagues, clients and suppliers without the need to physically travel in and out of remote locations.Vulnerable ultimate beneficiaries:  Clients in main vertical (development agencies / NGOs, accounting for 54% of revenues), directly target the base of pyramid, especially in Africa.  These institutions reach would be limited without the services of specialized niche providers such as EMC. Quick deployments:  EMC has a custom-designed solution allowing fast, tactical implementation of communications links following natural catastrophes (i.e., most recently in the Haiti and Chile earthquakes). EMC''s personnel, a team of highly trained and experienced professionals, is available and ready to deploy and implement satellite services within 48 hours thanks to a stock of pre-staged equipment at regional offices across all continents. Business continuity:  Strategically located infrastructure ensures business continuity / disaster recovery through redundant links and ample data center capacity. Remaining operational during a disaster makes the difference between financial sustainability and extensive losses for any public or private corporation.
Environmental Social Issues: Less environmental and social (E&S) risk, more energy efficiency, and less carbon emissions are involved in EMC''s low-impact services than in services provided by typical telecommunications projects.  EMC has in place environmental and social policies and procedures that comply with IFC Performance Standards and it will be required to maintain those policies and procedures.  EMC''s low-impact services involve low E&S risk; therefore, the project is classified as Category C according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.
Sponsor: On an undiluted basis, the Company is owned by: Mr. Herbert Pardula (80%): He was the founder and President of SAT Corp., a provider of satellite communications monitoring systems, until its acquisition by Integral Systems in 2000.  Mr. Pardula was also the founder and VP of Systems Engineering for Automatic Test, a supplier of automated microwave test systems. Mr. Abel Avellan (20%): co-founded the Company and is chief architect of its business model. Prior to Emerging Markets Communications, Mr. Avellan was a Managing Director for ImpSat Fiber Networks, at one time South Americas largest VSAT operator.   Mr. Avellan is co-inventor of the Noise Reduction System (NRS) bandwidth optimization technology. Emerging Markets Communications has a number of share equivalent instruments, which when exercised, will partially dilute Mr. Pardula and Mr. Avellan.
Cost Nature: The Project consists of: -Capital expenditure and working capital financing  to secure, maintain and increase customer contract base; and -Resources for strengthening EMCs balance sheet by refinancing existing bank debt and other instruments and obligations.For the period 2011-2013, the total project cost is estimated at $60 million. EMC is seeking $19.5 million of long term financing from IFC, with the remaining needs to be covered by the Companys internal cash-flow generation and potentially with FMO.  IFCs financing will be in the form of a loan of up to $12 million and an equity investment of up to $7.5 million.  FMO will provide $7.5 million and a loan of up to $10 million
Investment: 22.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan12.0Equity10.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: EMC has a network of strategically located, wholly-owned support centers (mainly in Argentina and Kenya) and approximately 700 customer sites scattered throughout the World. It operates 3 teleport facilities (located in Germany, UK and Hawaii), as well as 120,000 sq feet of secure disaster recovery/business continuity data center infrastructure.  EMC has ample C-band spectrum (approximately 1,100 MHz) at below current market cost. Satellite capacity is a scarce resource for the medium term, thus acting as a barrier to entry.

Project Description:
Vivimed Labs Limited (Vivimed or the 'Company'), based in Andhra Pradesh, India is a leading manufacturer and exporter of specialty chemicals (for personal care and industrial segments) and pharmaceutical products. Vivimed is listed on both National and Bombay Stock Exchanges. The Company plans to invest about $42 million for the following projects:

Setting up a specialty chemical and pharmaceutical facility in a Special Economic Zone in Srikakulam, Andhra Pradesh, India
Setting up a facility for pharmaceutical formulations in Choutuppal
Modernization and enhancement of its existing facility in Jeedimetla to meet US FDA and MHRA standards
Maintenance capital expenditure at its plants in Bidar and Bonthapally

The proposed IFC investment is to part finance this capital expenditure plan with a mixture of long term debt and foreign currency convertible bonds.
Review Scope:
IFC's review of this project consisted of site visits to the specialty chemicals plant in Bonthapally, the pharmaceutical plant in Jeedimetla and the R&D Centre at Mallapur all of them located in the Hyderabad area. A site visit was conducted to the already acquired land in Srikakulam, Andhra Pradesh, where the Special Economic Zone (SEZ) including the green-field plant will be built. 

Documents reviewed include permits; licenses; monitoring records for air emissions, liquid effluents, ambient air, and workplace exposure; as well as E&S procedures, manuals, handbooks and programs for the existing operations. Documents regarding land acquisition and the prefeasibility report for the construction of the new manufacturing plant in Srikakulam were reviewed. At the time of this appraisal the Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) reports for Srikakulam and Choutuppal have not been prepared as the Terms of Reference from the national and state governments (SEAC: State Environment Appraisal Committee) have not been issued. 

Meetings were held with the corporate management team including Chief Executive Officer; Vice President for Quality Assurance, Health Safety and Environment and Regulatory Affairs; Operations Director; Production Manager; and Human Resources Manager.

Project Description: The proposed IFC investment of $15 million would support $40 million of capital expenditures over a 24-month period to develop 30 additional QSR outlets, of which 8 will be setup in select West African markets, and 22 in Nigeria; expand bakery capacity by 50%; and make a further investment into poultry backward integration through FRF in Nigeria (the 'Project'). The regional QSR expansion will be driven through Food Concepts Ghana.
Review Scope:
The environmental and social appraisal of this project included a site visit to the recently acquired and yet to be developed 250 hectare farmland in Abeokuta, Ogun State, the Globus chicken processing factory in Agbara, Ogun State, Chicken Republic restaurants, the Butterfield Bakery and First Blends, the suppliers of premix to the bakery, all of which are located in Nigeria. In addition, three other Chicken Republic restaurants as well as Sucatrade Limited, the sole suppliers of frozen chicken to Chicken Republic Ghana, in Accra, Ghana, were also visited. 

Through its wholly owned subsidiary, Free Range Farms Limited (FRF), Food Concepts plans to set up a semi-integrated poultry farm comprising of a broiler farm, poultry abattoir (processing plant), storage and distribution capacity, at the farmland referred to above. A Rendering Plant and Wastewater Treatment Plant will also be constructed on site to treat organic and effluent water from the operations respectively. The company has been granted a 99-year lease for this land which lies in the Abeokuta Agricultural Zone (AAZ) of Ogun State. The poultry project which will be implemented in phases will initially have capacity to process 2.6 million chickens per annum, increasing to 10.5 million chickens per annum by the fourth year. The main objective for this backward integration is to allow Food Concepts to secure chicken supply for its Quick Service Restaurants (QSR) operations.

The company currently operates a leading QSR chain in Nigeria, branded as 'Chicken Republic' with 63 outlets in Nigeria, 9 of which are franchised, and three in Accra, Ghana. Food Concepts also operates 11 bakeries in Nigeria, branded as 'Butterfield'.

The appraisal also involved reviewing environmental, health, safety, and social information, including the Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) Report for the FRF proposed poultry farm, submitted by Food Concepts.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
The key environmental, health, and safety and social (EHSS) issues associated with this investment are:

Environmental, social, food safety and quality management system and related issues,
Occupational health and safety (OHS) management during construction and poultry production, processing, storage and transport operations, 
Supply chain management, including child labor and contractors management,
Management of waste from poultry production, abattoir, and processing activities,
Bio-safety controls, including preparedness for avian influenza, and any other poultry disease,
Energy and water consumption and efficiency,
Community relationships, land acquisition and economic resettlement for FRF activities, and,
Standardization of EHSS management systems across the different countries.

For the FRF project, Food Concepts has teamed up with Innodis of Mauritius (www.innodis.mu) who is its technical partner. Innodis will offer technical services including site evaluation/assessment, design, specifications, planning, project supervision, training, recruitment of key personnel, installation and support, and continuous technical support.

In addition to its partnership with Innodis, Food Concepts has committed to an Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) to address the identified issues and meet the requirements of IFC's Performance Standards. As a result, based on the limited and site-specific E&S impacts which could be easily mitigated, the project has been classified as a Category B according to IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedures.

Project Description:
The Project is to extend the existing Odessa Container Terminal (OCT) through the construction and operation of a new, adjacent container terminal (the 'Quarantine Mole Terminal', or the 'QMT').  These two terminals will have a combined capacity of 850,000 TEUs upon completion, increasing from the current capacity of 550,000 TEUs at OCT.  HPC Ukraina's portion of the QMT extension project includes: (i) land reclamation; (ii) construction of the access dam and pavement of the quay and access ways; (iii) purchase and installation of container handling and related equipment.  In addition, OCSP would be responsible for building a breakwater, dredging and quay construction works to help complete the Project.  

The Company has been operating OCT under a set of contractual arrangements with OSCP and will execute the Project.    HPC Ukraina is a wholly-owned subsidiary of HPC Hamburg Port Consulting GmbH ('HPC'), which in turn is fully owned by Hamburg Port and Logistics Corporation (Hamburger Hafen-und Logistik Aktiengesellschaft, or 'HHLA'), one of the leading port logistics groups in Europe, and a major operator in the Hamburg port.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
The proposed project is an expansion within the Odessa Port, the largest seaport of Ukraine and one of the Black Sea's biggest ports. It is being developed in accordance with national regulatory requirements and modern industry standards. 

The existing container terminal is located on the southern end of Odessa bay and is spread over the area of 16.6 hectares.  The new terminal will be constructed on a reclaimed area of 19 hectares.
The Company's operations at the existing and new container terminals will continue to involve only the handling of containerized cargo and, therefore, potential E&S risks and impacts are limited.  The Company has demonstrated that it is able to control environmental, health and safety impacts from existing terminal operations.   Because the terminal expansion indicates no impacts related to Performance Standards 5, 7 and 8, and only readily mitigated environmental issues under Performance Standards 1 through 4 and 6, this project is a Category B project.

Project Description: Food Concepts ('FC' or the 'Company') is a leading Quick Service Restaurants (QSR) and bakery operator based in Nigeria.  QSR is branded as 'Chicken Republic' with 60 outlets in Nigeria, 9 of which are franchised, and three in Accra, Ghana. FC also operates 10 bakeries, branded as 'Butterfield'. The IFC investment would support capital expenditures and working capital over a 4 year period to develop approximately 40 additional QSR outlets; expand bakery capacity by approximately 100%, and make a further investment into poultry backward integration in Nigeria (the 'Project').
Impact: The Project's expected development impact includes (i) employment generation; (ii) gender promotion (QSR sector employs a high proportion of women); (iii) demonstration effect to the QSR/poultry market in West Africa; (iv) MSME reach; (v) develop efficient poultry industry in Nigeria; and (vi) introduction of best practice poultry using a technical partner with a proven track record.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure because the Environmental, Health & Safety, and Social (EHSS) impacts of the project can be managed through implementation of appropriate mitigation measures. IFCs review did not identify any significant adverse impacts or high risk exposures. The key EHSS issues associated with this investment are environmental, social, food safety and quality management system and related issues; occupational health and safety (OHS) management during construction and poultry production, processing, storage and transport operations; supply chain management, including child labor and contractors management; management of waste from poultry production, abattoir, and processing activities; bio-safety controls, including preparedness for avian influenza, and any other poultry disease; energy and water consumption and efficiency; community relationships, land acquisition and economic resettlement for FRF activities, and; standardization of EHSS management systems across the different countries.To address the above identified issues and meet the requirements of IFCs Performance Standards, Food Concepts has committed to an Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) covering all of its operations, including the Quick Service Restaurants (QSR), Butterfield Bakery and construction and operation of the proposed Free Range Farms (FRF) poultry production and processing facility. In addition, Food Concepts has teamed up with Innodis of Mauritius (www.innodis.mu) who is its technical partner for FRF project. Innodis will offer technical services including site evaluation/assessment, design, specifications, planning, project supervision, training, recruitment of key personnel, installation and support, and continuous technical support.
Sponsor: Food Concepts was founded in 1999 by Mr. Deji Akinyanju, and commenced operations in 2001.  It is a public company (though not listed on the Nigerian Stock Exchange) whose shareholders are Food Concepts International Limited or FCIL (63.7%), Employee Share Trust (1.9%) and other shareholders (34.4%). In turn, FCIL's main shareholders include Chief Dele Fajemirokun, Mr. Deji Akinyanju, Akinyanju Family, Mr. Sola Alabi, Mr. Jerry Chukwueke and Asaris Limited.
Cost Nature:
Total project cost is estimated to be $86 million consisted of: (i) QSR expansion; (ii) Bakery expansion; (iii) Setting up a poultry farm; and (iv) working capital.

The proposed IFC investment is an A Loan for IFC's own account of up to $ 10 million, and equity of up to $ 10 million, to be used for QSR and bakery expansion.
