Project Description: The proposed project is to provide a senior loan of up to $4 million to CJSC AccessBank Tajikistan ('ABTJ' or the 'Bank'). Proceeds of the loan will be used to finance the expansion of their lending to micro and small entrepreneurs (the 'Project'). ABTJ currently seeks long-term funding to continue its dynamic growth and offer new products to its target clientele.
Impact: The Project is expected to have the following development impacts: (i) increase access to finance for MSEs; (ii) contribute to employment creation and poverty reduction in Tajikistan; (iii) support the Bank's efforts to diversify and increase the volume of its funding; (iv) build market confidence in financial institutions and encourage more intermediaries to extend financial services to target segment; and (v) deepen the financial markets, stimulate competition in the microfinance sector and increase lending products and services available in the market.
Environmental Social Issues: The Project is with the existing IFC client to provide a senior loan to ABTJ to support the Banks on-lending to target microfinance clients and small entrepreneurs and has been classified as a Category FI project according to the IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The E&S appraisal will focus on reviewing ABTJs performance in terms of applying its current SEMS and labor practices, as well as on reviewing the Banks portfolio in terms of possible E&S risks. AMH is a commercial microfinance holding company that invests equity in newly-established and early stage microfinance institutions through a combination of equity finance, management and technical assistance services.

Project Description:
Salamander Energy plc (Salamander or the Company) is a rapidly-growing junior oil and gas company exclusively focused on Southeast Asia. The Company's strategy is to build a sustainable upstream business through leveraging its regional knowledge and relationships; maintaining a balanced portfolio of production, development, appraisal and exploration of assets; enforcing strict capital allocation discipline; and pursuing targeted acquisitions in addition to organic-led growth. Since its foundation in early 2005, Salamander has developed a broad set of assets, although the proposed refinancing is restricted to the producing and near-production interests in Indonesia and Thailand.  As of 1st January 2011, the Company reported net reserves of 66.3 million barrels of oil equivalent (boe) and average daily production of 20,300 boe. 

As with the 2008-2009 investments, the proposed refinancing is intended for the capital and operating expenditure needs of two existing Salamander-operated producing fields: 

 (i)   Glagah Kambuna  offshore north Sumatra, Indonesia.
 (ii)  Block B8/38 Concession (Bualuang) - offshore Gulf of Thailand;

Salamander also has minority interests (less than 10 %) in three fields operated by other companies but which are part of the borrowing base assets:

(iii) E5-N and EU-1 Concessions - onshore northeast Thailand;
(iv) ONWJ  offshore northwest Java, Indonesia;
(v) SES  offshore southeast Sumatra, Indonesia; and

The project will include the drilling of new wells in existing fields, the selective workover of existing wells and the construction of gas processing facilities and other field infrastructure. Salamander forecasts that the project will help it to increase its production to reach over 30,000 boe per day by 2013.

The following sections provide an update on the operation of the Salamander operated properties since IFC's 2010 disclosure.

Operated Assets

Kambuna - Indonesia  
Salamander now has 50% operatorship under a Technical Assistance Contract with Pertamina (the Indonesian oil and gas operator). Production commenced in August 2009 from a total of three offshore wells tied into an unmanned platform. No production processes, such as water separation, are undertaken on the platform.  In 2009 Salamander completed construction of a pipeline (42km offshore / 15km onshore) from the wellhead to an onshore  LPG asset and compressor station located on Pertamina's existing Pangkalan Brandan  facilities. Kambuna gas is exported south via the regional transmission system and is largely used for electrical power generation for Medan, Indonesia's second largest city.  

Bualuang  Thailand
Salamander now holds a 100% interest in the block and operatorship of the B8/38 Concession, the concession expires in 2025. Production patterns remain as described in the previous disclosure but a further phase of drilling on the field was completed in the first half of 2009, which included an exploration well, two horizontal producers and a water disposal well. The two horizontal production wells were tied into the production system and put on stream.  Within the existing footprint, a further six wells are planned for first half of 2011 (Phase 5) with drilling of three new horizontal wells and the sidetracking of three existing vertical wells with horizontal sections. With the completion of the Phase 5 development drilling, an expansion of production facilities is required. At the time of IFCs 2011 supervision visit, Salamander was preparing for an additional two phases of development drilling, with plans for a second wellhead.  Salamander will undertake an Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) in compliance with Thai Legislation and consistent with Performance Standards requirements for the installation of the Bualuang offshore production platform and drilling of new wells not covered under the existing field ESIA.
Review Scope:
Background

In 2008 IFC was requested by the management of Salamander to provide up to $75 million of corporate financing to help fund the company's planned 2008-2010 investment program. IFC provided senior and junior debt financing of $62.5 million to Salamander in 2008 and 2009, details of which were publically disclosed in June 2008, and redisclosed with updated information in March 2010. 

Following on from these current corporate investments in Salamander,  IFC has recently been requested by the management of Salamander to continue to support the Company's growth by providing a refinancing of up to $75 million in the forms of senior and junior lending facilities covering the same assets as the 2008/2009 investments. This corporate repeat financing, which is part of a broader refinancing package involving a number of other financial institutions, will help fund the Company's planned 2011-2013 investment program and refinance Salamander's existing debt. 

This review should be read in conjunction with the previously disclosed review of March 2010, updated information on the company's assets is provided below.

Overview of  IFC's Scope of Review

This investment is limited to the Borrowing Base Assets described below which cover the same footprint as the original investments which themselves covered exploration and pre-existing brownfield sites. This review provides an update of the original appraisal visit undertaken in 2008, ongoing annual site supervision visits to various Salamander assets and review of annual monitoring reports submitted to IFC.  Site supervision has included visits to Salamander's corporate office in Singapore, Salamander country offices in Jakarta and Bangkok supported by two visits to the Kambuna field (Indonesia) in 2010, and one visit to the Bualuang field (Thailand) in 2011.  The visits also included review of technical and policy documents, interviews with Salamander staff and contractors, members of local communities and local government officials. Salamander's commitment to environmental and social performance is evident and it demonstrates this through the continued development of corporate and project level environmental and social management systems and procedures.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
This is a refinancing of existing IFC investments in the Company which are all IFC Category B. Since the portfolio assets and footprint being refinanced has not changed and the scale of operations has not materially changed, the refinancing is also given a B Category. Category B projects according to IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedure are those that result in a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to industry recognized standards, guidelines and design criteria.  The existing Salamander operated portfolio consists of both exploration, development and production assets. 

Salamander has a Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) Policy and a Health, Safety and Environment (HSE) Policy which commit Salamander to conduct all its operations in compliance with applicable laws, recognized international standards and best practice which includes the safety and health of employees, protection of the environment and that the interests of the communities are respected in areas where Salamander operates.

Under the umbrella of the HSE Policy, the environmental or social impacts arising from current and planned assets are being, and will be mitigated and managed in accordance with national regulatory requirements and IFC's Performance Standards within Salamander's overarching corporate Health, Safety and Environment Management System (HSEMS) framework.  

The existing Salamander operated assets, which are the focus of this investment (the Borrowing Base Assets) are not anticipated to result in any significant adverse environmental and social impacts.  In 2008 Salamander presented plans to address the environmental and social impacts at its operated assets, and IFC has monitored progress through regular supervision. Implementation of the Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) which has been updated will ensure these assets continue to remain in compliance with IFC Performance Standards and its Environmental Health Safety (EHS) guidelines.

Salamander may wish to acquire additional assets and acreage in the future for inclusion in the Borrowing Base.  Salamander screens all prospective assets to establish the requirements for compliance with the IFC Performance Standards.  As required, IFC may undertake additional supplementary appraisal missions to further characterize the environmental and social risk of proposed asset acquisitions prior to giving approval for inclusion within the current BBA facility.  

Salamander will periodically review and update its CSR and HSE Policies commensurate with its operational risks and expanding portfolio. Prior to full field development and production of new assets where Salamander is the operator, Salamander will prepare and publicly disclose a full ESIA and an ESAP consistent with IFC's Performance Standards for all future assets where Salamander is the operator.

For the non-operated assets included in the BBA portfolio, the operators which include Hess and CNOOC have a good HSE Management Systems in place and conduct their operations in accordance with national laws, regulations and good international industry practice.
Sector: AB - Oil and Gas Production (Includes Development)

Project Description:
IFC will provide a $40 million facility to Banco Itaú Paraguay (Itaú Paraguay) to be on-lent to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and to Agricultural sector players in Paraguay. 

The Project will support an IFC existing client with a dominant position in the retail segment, but which intends to grow its SME portfolio. Furthermore, the Project represents an excellent opportunity for IFC to mobilize resources from other DFIs into Paraguay, not only reaching small farmers and Agri-SMEs which are key drivers of the economic activity in the country, but also generating a demonstration effect that will contribute to consolidate IFC's programmatic approach in the Country.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves IFC support for on-lending to farmers and agribusiness SMEs and has been classified as a Category FI project. During appraisal, IFC analyzed the E&S aspects of the Banks portfolio and the activities proposed to be supported with IFC finance and determined the following Applicable Performance Requirements that include (i) the IFC FI Exclusion List, (ii) applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and regulations, and (iii) specific measures to manage E&S risks in the agribusiness sector.IFC met with the Banks representatives from the Corporate Accounts, Risk and Agribusiness departments, and reviewed the Banks existing Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS), procedures and capacity. IFC and the Bank have agreed to additional measures and screening tools to be incorporated in the Banks existing practices, including enhancing E&S capacity and risk assessment tools prior to disbursement. The Bank will be required to submit a periodic E&S performance report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.IFC also met with the Banks representatives from the HR department, and reviewed the Banks existing HR policies, the code of Ethics and other relevant information. The Bank will be required to demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions.
Sponsor:
Banco Itaú Paraguay is owned by Itaú Unibanco S.A., which currently holds 99.99% of the total capital of the Bank, while the balance is owned by two minority shareholders, Estrel - Estudos Representacões e Administracão Ltda and Mario Miranda Ribeiro.

Itaú Unibanco, one of the largest conglomerates in the Southern Hemisphere, is the result of the merger between Banco Itaú and Unibanco in 2008. The holding employs more than 108 thousand people, has more than 50 million clients and 4.6 thousand branches spread throughout 1,100 municipalities and operates in 12 different countries. 

Itaú Unibanco is rated investment grade globally by Moody's (Baa3), Standard and Poor's (BBB-), and Fitch (BBB). As of December 2010, the holding reported assets of $455 billion, equity of $37 billion and net income of $7.6 billion.

Project Description:
Salamander Energy plc (Salamander or the company) is a rapidly-growing junior oil and gas company exclusively focused on Southeast Asia. The company's strategy is to build a sustainable upstream business through leveraging its regional knowledge and relationships; maintaining a balanced portfolio of production, development, appraisal and exploration assets; enforcing strict capital allocation discipline; and pursuing targeted acquisitions in addition to organic-led growth. Since its foundation in early 2005, Salamander has developed a broad set of assets, including producing and near-production interests in Indonesia and Thailand as well as exploration and appraisal properties in Indonesia, Thailand, Vietnam, Lao PDR and the Philippines. The company reported net proved and probable reserves of 66.3 million barrels of oil equivalent ('boe') and average daily production of 20,000 boe, of which about 34% is gas. 

Salamander is an existing client of IFC.  IFC supported its growth through both debt and equity investments over the last few years.  IFC has been requested to continue to support the Company's growth by providing up to $75 million debt financing in the forms of both senior and junior lending facilities. The financing will help fund the Company's planned 2011-2013 investment program that is primarily expected to cover the capital and operating expenditure needs of the following producing and near-production assets: 

-  the E5-N and EU-1 Concessions (Sinphuhorm) and the Block B8/38 Concession (Bualuang) in Thailand; and 
-  the Offshore North West Java (ONWJ), South East Sumatra (SES) Production Sharing Contracts, and the Glagah Kambuna Technical Assistance Contract in Indonesia. 

The project will include the drilling of new wells in existing fields, the selective workover of existing wells and the construction of gas processing facilities and other field infrastructure. 

The project will also include the refinancing of existing indebtedness and other general corporate uses. Salamander expects that the project will help it to increase its production to reach 30,000 boe per day by 2013.
Impact:
- Enhanced Availability of a Cleaner Fuel:  The Project will support the development of natural gas reserves. The increased availability of natural gas will promote the use of a cleaner fuel, given that natural gas has much lower carbon emissions than coal which is frequently the alternative fuel for power generation in Southeast Asia. 

- Preservation and Creation of Employment: The Project will have a sustaining impact on existing employment levels in producing assets and will contribute to the creation of new jobs in assets about to enter into production. Salamander staff positions are generally remunerated at a 25%-30% premium to other comparable employment. The percentage of nationals in managerial positions tends to be high, mostly above 75%. 

- Contribution to Central and Local Government Revenues: The project will increase production and generate significant fiscal receipts from a combination of royalties (8-12.5%), corporate taxes (41.5%-50.0%), production sharing (42%-73%) and obligations to supply domestic consumers at below-market prices. A material portion of these - approximately 15% of royalties in Thailand and 15-30% of total government payments in Indonesia - is expected to ultimately accrue to the regions where the oil and gas activities are undertaken. 

- Generating Additional Business for Local and National Suppliers: The project is expected to have a positive impact on national and regional economic activity through the purchasing of equipment, products and services.  For example, in 2009 contracts worth more than US$121 million were sourced from regional and national suppliers. 

- Promoting Competition and Development of Marginal Fields: The project promotes competition in the oil and gas sector through the growth of one of very few independent exploration and production companies exclusively focused on Southeast Asia. The participation of smaller privately-owned companies is important to the industry, as they often focus on reserves deemed too small to be of interest to the majors and the national oil companies which dominate the sector in Southeast Asia, and deliver production and recovery rates which tend to be above industry averages.

- Development in Frontier Regions: One of the Company's major assets, the Sinphuhorm Gas Field, is in the Northeast part of Thailand, a region that is by far the poorest and has been excluded from much of Thailand's growth.  Salamander's spending on local purchases is expected to have a positive impact on the regional economic activity, help to increase the income of the local people and promote an inclusive growth. 

Going forward, the following indicators will be tracked (i) gas production; (ii) employment; (iii) tax payments and other revenues to host governments; (iv) domestic purchase; (v) community development outlays.

Project Description:
Idavang currently has 8 large scale pig production facilities in Lithuania and one in Russia's Leningrad Oblast. The proposed project is to expand the current production capacity with additional, mainly greenfield, pig production facilities near Pskov in Western Russia. While all the current large scale pig production facilities are relying on feed stock from the commodity market, and manure handling through farmers off-take contracts, the Pskov facility will have its own crop production farm with sustainable internal balance in manure production and fertilizer needs for the crop production.

The new crop farm and pig production facility is based on re-farming of previously idle / brackish farmland that has not been under commercial production since the cease of the Soviet farms in early 1990ies, and the construction of a 3,450 sow pig production facility for production of 98,000 slaughter pigs per year in the midst of these fields, hereby establishing a sustainable balance between manure produced by the pigs and the ammonia and phosphate fertilizer needs of the land farmed for crop production.  The crop farm has a total of 4,000 ha of land available of which 3,500 ha will be used for the production of crops (mainly spring and winter crops of barley and wheat) for the pig farm feed mill. The new pig production consist of physically separated sections (sows w/piglet production section, small (weaner) pig section, finisher section for pigs getting ready for slaughtering, and a boar section for sperm production), as well as a feed mill and systems for manure handling in sealed lagoons capable of holding the manure for twice yearly application as fertilizer on the crop fields. The project does not include any slaughtering facility, as all Idavang's farms sell live pigs to the slaughter houses in Lithuania and the Leningrad Oblast of Russia. The primary market for the meat is the local markets in Lithuania and North West Region of Russia.
Review Scope: IFC's environmental and social review of this project included field visits by IFC's environmental specialist to selected Idavang A/S (Idavang) pig farms in Lithuania, the first Russian Idavang pig farm near Tosno, Leningrad Oblast and the crop farm for the planned new pig production operation near Pskov in Russia. The specialist also visited slaughtering facilities in both Lithuania and Russia to be able to inspect the quality of animal handling at these independent facilities and the animal corps after slaughtering to evaluate their health.  Documentation on pesticide and fertilizer management, medicine usage, handling of live animals and animal welfare, employee's Occupational Health & Safety (OHS), and production parameters were also reviewed. IFC has also reviewed Idavang's Annual CSR Status Report prepared for its current development institution investor (IFU/IØ).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The proposed project is being developed in accordance with national regulatory requirements and European Standards, by an experienced Sponsor committed to good environmental and social management practices. The expansion project is based on vertical integration of farm production from initial crop generation till final animal delivery to slaughtering facilities, with due respect for sustainability and animal welfare, will follow international labor standards, and has integrated farm waste utilization to avoid significant pollution. With no indication of impacts related to Performance Standards 5 through 8 and only readily mitigated environmental issues under Performance Standards 1 through 4, this is a Category B project, in accordance with IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedures.

Project Description: Idavang A/S ('the Company', previously named 'Danish Lithuanian Holding A/S') is a Danish holding company that has pig and crop farms in Russia and pig farms in Lithuanian.  The Project, located in Russia, is to: (i) build a green field pig farm in Pskov region; (ii) develop another pig farm in northwest region; (iii) complete the expansion of the pig farm in Leningrad region; and (iv) develop crop farms in Pskov and Leningrad regions. The total project cost is about EUR86.5 million. The Project is implemented in 2009-2014 and will increase production capacity by 6,450 sows and 185,000 finishers
Impact:
- Support Russia's under-developed pork sector to modernize, achieve self-sufficiency & international competiveness. 
- Support an efficient producer with solid track record to expand efficient production in Russia, introduce high European standards of livestock production, showcase clean production (CP) and energy efficiency (EE) to other pork producers. 
- Support the frontier Pskov region (per capita GDP about 60% below national average) to revitalize waste land, develop competitive pig and crop production, create jobs in remote rural area, contribute to local community.
    The Project will help alleviate insufficient domestic pig production, substitute imports, increase fresh meat supply (vs. frozen imported meat), and pass cost savings to consumers. The Project will rehabilitate the crop land that has not been cultivated for 15-20 year and create jobs in the rural area with high level of unemployment. As pork production remains highly supported by the Government (interest subsidized loans, tax benefits, import tariffs), additional domestic production will also result in losses for the Government and local tax payers, which is expected to be compensated by increased corporate tax payment, benefits to employees, local economy and communities. Overall, the medium to long term developmental impact can be expected as: (i) Russia has excellent long term fundamentals for pig production (feed availability, climate, large tracts of land for waste disposal); (ii) current production costs in the country are not globally competitive but can be improved with better technology and livestock management standards introduced by efficient producers; and (iii) the country is a net importer and may be able to compete on an import parity basis.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed project is being developed in accordance with national regulatory requirements and European Standards by an experienced Sponsor committed to good environmental and social management. The project will result in the implementation of a vertical integrated farm production from initial crop generation till final animal delivery to slaughtering facilities.  Due respect for sustainable animal/crop land balance and animal welfare according to future EU rules are included.  The project follows international labor standards, and has integrated farm waste utilization to avoid significant pollution. With no indication of impacts related to Performance Standards 5 through 8 and only readily mitigated environmental issues under Performance Standards 1 through 4, this is a Category B project. Project Description: The Project consists of the expansion of Digicel PNG Limited's cellular telephone network in Papua New Guinea, where it was granted a mobile license in 2007.  This Project will allow the Company to continue to expand geographic and population coverage throughout the country and expand its products and services (including 3G).
Impact:
The Project will improve access to reliable and affordable telecommunication services for consumers and businesses as well as introduce new value added services.  Since Digicel's initial launch in PNG in 2007, mobile penetration rate has grown from 3% to 31%.  The Company expects that mobile penetration will continue to grow over 40% by 2017.

The Project will expand mobile services to remote and rural areas where telecom infrastructure is currently poor or non-existent, thus increasing geographic and population coverage.  In addition, the Project will improve the speed and reliability of telecommunications services to the business segment, hence enhancing the efficiency and competitiveness of these companies.

The Project will create direct and indirect quality employment opportunities in PNG.
Environmental Social Issues: The key environmental and social risk in this project is in the siting and construction of new sites in the Western Highlands region, expected to be largely completed prior to IFCs investment.  This siting and construction are covered under the World Bank rural telecommunications project numbered P107782.   As a result, environmental and social risk in IFC''s investment is expected to be low, and the project is classified as Category C according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.
Sponsor: Digicel PNG is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Digicel Pacific Ltd ('DPL').  DPL and its founder, Denis O'Brien, are the sponsors. DPL is a holding company that in turn is 100% owned by Digicel Group Ltd. ('DGL'). DGL holds all of Digicel's assets in the Pacific Islands, the Caribbean and Central America and provides cellular services across 32 markets today for over 11.5 million subscribers.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at approximately $96.4 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a senior loan for its own account of up to $26.8 million.
Location: The Project is headquartered in Papua New Guinea, providing mobile telecommunication services to both urban and rural areas of the Country.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The key environmental and social risk in this project is in the siting and construction of new sites in the Western Highlands region, expected to be largely completed prior to IFCs investment.  This siting and construction are covered under the World Bank rural telecommunications project numbered P107782.   As a result, environmental and social risk in IFC''s investment is expected to be low, and the project is classified as Category C according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.

Project Description:
FV Argentina is embarking in an investment program of about $20 million comprising: (i) permanent working capital to maintain a well supplied wide portfolio of products to attend an exigent demand on a timely basis; (ii) improve operational efficiencies, including savings on a better use of energy resources; and (iii) completion of the environmental upgrades suggested by the IFC's action plan.

In that context, the Company has requested IFC financing of up to $10 million to support the Company's strategic plan. The proposed package would replicate the most recent investment in FV.
Review Scope:
FV Argentina (30686) follows from the FV Argentina II (27104) project approved in 2008. IFC's review included meetings with the FV S.A. ('FV' or the 'Company') management team (including General Director, Plant Managers for Villa Rosa and Florida, Environmental Manager, Maintenance Manager, Human Resources Manager, Health and Safety Officer, Security Manager) and staff of the environmental and human resources departments.  

A site visit to the FV plants in Villa Rosa and Florida was conducted. AMRs and update of current ESAP was reviewed during the visit together with the completed EHS Appraisal Questionnaire, as well as supporting information including workplace monitoring data, environmental permits, and documents on environmental management and procedures, human resources management, occupational health and safety policy and procedures, emergency preparedness protocols, training programs and the social responsibility program.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
IFC has closely supervised FV since the previous project was committed in 2008, and although the Action plan is not quite complete, the Company has been responsive in meeting IFC's E&S requirements.  Remaining Action Plan items reviewed during appraisal relate to completion of enhanced waste water treatment facilities, control of emissions to air and further work on the occupational health and safety management system.  

As a result of its due diligence, IFC has concluded that: (i) the potential adverse environmental and social impacts presented by the Project are few in number, site-specific and have been or can be readily addressed through mitigation measures; and (ii) the adverse environmental and social impacts caused by the existing operations have been adequately addressed and can be further reduced through a limited number of mitigation measures, already identified by the Company. It is therefore concluded that this is a Social and Environmental Category B project.
Sector: AF - Other Miscellaneous Fabricated Metal Products (Including Non-Wood Housing Products, Tanks, Cutlery, Kitchen Utensils and Handtools, etc.)

Project Description: Construtora Norberto Odebrecht S.A. (CNO or the Company) is Latin Americas leading engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) company. Founded in 1945 in the northeastern region of Brazil, CNO provides a variety of engineering, procurement and construction services in over 15 countries around the world. Through its subsidiaries, CNO engages in the construction of large scale infrastructure projects, such as highways, railways, power plants, bridges, buildings, subways, dams, as well as mining facilities and manufacturing plants, among others. CNO is fully owned by Odebrecht S.A. (ODB or the Sponsor), one of the largest private sector groups in Brazil.CNO approached IFC seeking support to structure a Partial Credit Guarantee Facility (the PCG Facility or the Facility) that would increase the supply capacity of surety bonds available for the Company.  These surety bonds will be used to guarantee CNOs performance in EPC infrastructure development contracts in Brazil and other Latin American and African countries (the Project).
Review Scope: IFC review of this Project involved meetings and discussions with CNOs management, including extensive meetings with CNOs Corporate Environmental, Social and Health and Safety (ESHS) Manager, and review of CNOs Integrated Corporate ESHS Management System (ESMS). IFC reviewed documentation evidencing ESMS application in four CNOs existing construction projects: (a) the Santo Antonio Hydroelectric project in the Madeira River which is one of the most important and visible infrastructure projects currently being built in Brazil, located in the Amazonia state of Rondonia, close to the Bolivian border, (b) Coral Concession in the Dominican Republic, (c) CONPAR, which involves the construction of eight new industrial-refinery facilities (five gasoline and three coke plants) within the 179,000 m2 Petrochemical Complex, Refinaria Presidente Getulio Vargas (REPAR) in the state of Paraná, Brazil, and (d) the Chaglla Hydroelectric project in Peru (See Annex 2 for summary of review). Other documents such as the 2009 Odebrecht Annual Report, Odebrecht Group Code of Ethics, CNOs Internal Sustainability Report for FY2010, the Manual for GHG Inventory, and the standard construction camp installation ESHS procedures called Kit Canteiro, were also reviewed. Once it is further defined which projects may come under this Facility, the IFC will visit a pool of sample projects to verify the application of CNOs ESMS.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category A investment primarily because the Company will likely be involved in constructing large-scale projects with potentially significant and diverse impacts  e.g. greenfield hydropower and thermal power developments, industrial plants, and transport projects.

Project Description: The project is a greenfield factoring company (the 'Company'), to be established in Brazil, that will offer domestic and cross border receivables financing and complementary services to Brazilian corporates and small and medium-sized companies.
Impact: (i) To promote SME financing, particularly for the lower-end SME segment that is less sophisticated and has more limited access to funding; and (ii) to improve the business enabling environment - factoring in Brazil is an unregulated industry with mostly unsophisticated players who, oftentimes, promote informal practices. The project will support the creation of a world-class factoring company that can become a highly visible industry player and an industry benchmark for best practices.
Environmental Social Issues: This project will support the establishment of a new company focused on factoring and forfaiting services and has been classified as a Category C project. The company will be required to review potential commitments to ensure that the underlying business does not involve any activity on IFC''s Exclusion List and to demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions. The project is required to inform IFC in the event of any change in nature or scope of its business or operations.
Sponsor:
FIMBank is a leading provider of trade finance and factoring solutions. Headquartered in Malta, its strategy is to further strengthen its global presence, with a focus on emerging markets, and enhancing the product range on offer, namely trade finance, structured commodity finance, factoring, forfaiting and support banking services.

Banco Industrial e Comercial S.A. ('BicBanco') is a leading Brazilian mid-sized bank, which has operated predominantly in the middle market niche since 1938. It is publicly traded at BM&FBovespa, and has a nation-wide presence with 45 outlets in all regions of Brazil. The project entails a corporate loan for which use of proceeds will be on-lending to small and medium enterprises.
Cost Nature: The Company will require capital of up to US$25 million to secure the roll out of its factoring operations in Brazil, over a period of 4 years. IFC's proposed investment in the Company would be up to US$5 million in the form of common shares representing up to 20.0% of the Company's equity.

Project Description:
Construtora Norberto Odebrecht S.A. (CNO or the 'Company') is Latin America's leading engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) company. Founded in 1945 in the northeastern region of Brazil, CNO provides a variety of engineering, procurement and construction services in over 15 countries around the world. Through its subsidiaries, CNO engages in the construction of large scale infrastructure projects, such as highways, railways, power plants, bridges, buildings, subways, dams, as well as mining facilities and manufacturing plants, among others. CNO is fully owned by Odebrecht S.A. (ODB or the Sponsor), one of the largest private sector groups in Brazil.
CNO approached IFC seeking support to structure a Partial Credit Guarantee Facility (the 'PCG Facility' or the 'Facility') that would increase the supply capacity of surety bonds available for the Company.  These surety bonds will be used to guarantee CNO's performance in EPC infrastructure development contracts in Brazil and other Latin American and African countries (the 'Project').
Impact: The Project aims to sustain the development of additional infrastructure projects when the insurance and surety industry is constrained and contribute to economic growth in Latin America and Africa. As a result, through the Project, CNO will be able to carry out additional projects in Latin America and Africa, creating employment opportunities for the base of the pyramid, generating taxes for different countries and improving critical logistics. The Company also promotes environmentally and socially sound construction projects. Finally, by supporting a company that has implemented sound corporate governance practices and a strong risk management policy, IFC will set a demonstration effect for other companies in the EPC sector. The Project's success will also encourage the Facility's replication within IFC and by other multilateral institutions.
Environmental Social Issues: With the understanding that  the  main areas of concern associated with this Facility are: (i) potential ESHS impacts and risks of underlying sub-projects in which the bond proceeds will be used; and (ii) IFCs exposure to reputation risks if ever associated with any negative press / media against CNOs existing and/or potential involvement with high profile environmentally or socially sensitive/visible projects, the IFC and CNO agreed on an Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) that includes the design and implementation of a Facility Environmental and Social Impacts and Reputation Risk Management Scheme (RMS) that will assure that all underlying projects ESHS impact and risk assessment and management is compliant with IFC Performance Standards. Since the risk of the Facility is that of CNO and the Surety Bonds will support underlying construction projects which potential ESHS impacts and risks are currently unknown but could certainly include large construction projects with significant ESHS issues, this is Categorize A operation. For further details please refer to the Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS).
Sponsor: ODB is the non-operating holding company of the Odebrecht Group (the 'Group'). It is one of the largest Brazilian private sector conglomerates. It employs directly over 120,000 people. The Group also controls Braskem, the largest private petrochemical company in Latin America. More recently, the Group has invested in other infrastructure development businesses including real estate, logistics, energy, water, and oil and gas services, among others.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC Facility is an up to US$75 million Partial Credit Guarantee for the benefit of surety bond providers. This Facility would have a multiplication effect, thus helping CNO obtain additional surety bonds for its expansion plans in Latin America and Africa.

Project Description: The proposed project involves supporting Bancolombia in providing financing for energy efficiency projects through a risk sharing facility.
Impact: IFC's involvement in this project would allow the Bank to make financing available to businesses committed to higher environmental standards that need longer term funding for their sustainability-related activities. It is also expected that the project will lead to the adoption of higher environmental standards across the banking sector.
Environmental Social Issues: As a Category FI (Financial Intermediaries) project, IFC''s E&S (Environmental and Social) appraisal of this project will focus on assessing Bancolombia''s capacity to manage the E&S risks associated with the eligible sub-projects, which may include energy efficiency, renewable energy, cleaner production, and green building. The Bank has an existing Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS), which will be reviewed in combination with the proposed activities to be supported by the facility in order to confirm SEMS adequacy to manage the E&S risks of sub-projects and to determine the applicable requirements, which may be a combination of: the IFC FI Exclusion List, the applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and regulations and/or the IFC Performance Standards.  During the appraisal IFC will also confirm compliance with the IFCs Performance Standards 2: Labor and Working Conditions. The client will be required to maintain or upgrade its existing SEMS, submit an annual E&S report to the IFC, deliver copies of the E&S due diligence reports for eligible sub-projects, and commit to apply the IFC Performance Standard 2.
Sponsor:
Bancolombia is the largest bank in Colombia. As of December 2010, it accounted for approximately 20% of total net loans and 19% of total net deposits within the entire local banking system. The bank, together with its subsidiaries, offers a wide array of products and services channeled through a regional platform that includes a leading bank in El Salvador. The bank's products and services include: investment banking; stock brokerage; leasing; factoring; consumer finance; asset management; fiduciary and trust services; and pension fund management.

Bancolombia, an existing IFC client, and the first local Equator Principles Financial Institution (EPFI) in the country, has a sustainability unit to spearhead its efforts in this area.  

Bancolombia is listed in the NYSE since 1995 through an ADR program. It is controlled by the Grupo Empresarial Antioqueño (GEA) through two of the group's companies:  Grupo de Inversiones Suramericana and Inversiones Argos. Together, these two companies hold almost 40% of Bancolombia's outstanding shares, followed by the ADR program that accounts for 22.6% of the bank's equity.
Cost Nature: The proposed transaction consists of a risk sharing facility with Bancolombia to cover an up to COP200,000 million ($100 million) portfolio of sustainable assets originated by the Bank. Under this facility, IFC and the Inter-American Development Bank ('IDB') will cover the risk of 50% of that portfolio (25% each), resulting in a maximum IFC exposure of COP50,000 million. The investment is expected to receive support from the Clean Technology Fund and will have a parallel advisory services component.

Project Description: The proposed project consists of a credit line of up to $50 million for up to 7 years to Banco General to be used to fund lending activity in the low income mortgage sector.
Impact: The proposed financing by IFC will support the growth of Banco General's low income mortgage portfolio.  It will also enable the Bank to reduce term mismatch.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed project consists of a USD50 million credit line to an existing client to provide middle and low income mortgages in Panama and has been classified as Category C according to the IFC Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  During the appraisal IFC reviewed the activities to be supported through the credit line and determined that they have low E&S risks. Banco General has implemented an Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS), reviewed by IFC, to assess sub-project/sub-client compliance with IFCs Exclusion list and host country E&S laws. As part of the continuing relationship, IFC and the client will consider enhancements in the existing ESMS to apply the IFCs Performance Standards. The client will be required to: (i) maintain its SEMS per the existing requirements under the outstanding loan; (ii) continue to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2:  Labor and Working Conditions; and (iii) continue to submit a periodic report to IFC per the requirements under the existing loan.

IFC has had a long standing relationship with Banco General that dates back to 2000. IFC and Banco General have co-participated in infrastructure financing in Panama.

Project Description:
Founded in 1921, FV S.A. ('FV' or the 'Company') is a second-tier family-owned and managed company and Argentina's leading producer of brass and metal fixtures for baths and kitchens. 

FV is well known to IFC, in 1998 IFC approved a $16 million financial package to FV, in 1999 IFC committed a $9 million financing package to FV Ecuacobre, and more recently in 2008, IFC committed another project with FV for up to $20.0 million.

FV will embark in an investment program of about $20 million for the next two to three years, that would mainly comprise: (i) permanent working capital to maintain a well supplied wide portfolio of products to attend an exigent demand on a timely basis; (ii) improve operational efficiencies, including savings on a better use of energy resources; and (iii) completion of the environmental upgrades suggested by the IFC's action plan.
Impact:
- Expansion of Argentine Export Base: FV's ability to continue developing its export base is dependent on the required permanent working capital needs to sustain an adequate and diversified level of stock to supply different markets abroad. The wide portfolio of products require FV to allocate larger amount of resources in order to better attend each market it supplies and enhance its competitive position abroad.

- Creation of Consumer Surplus: FV's cost optimization and energy efficiency improvements is expected to eventually translate into more competitive prices to end users, primarily within the construction sector. More competitive prices for building materials will benefit the housing sector.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Key environmental and social issues reviewed during the appraisal include the following: management of its environmental, health and safety performance in the operation facilities; safe and healthy working conditions at the Companys plant; labor issues in the Companys operations; management of emissions to air and water arising from the operation of its facilities; use of energy, water and resources; relations with the nearby communities. FV Argentina has provided information on its current practices and policies that seek to address environmental and social risks and impacts to ensure that the proposed project complies with or, will upon implementation of measures agreed upon as part of IFCs Investment documents, comply with host country laws and regulations and IFC''s Performance Standards (PS). IFCs review of this investment included a visit to the plant Argentina and meetings with key management personnel, including human resources, operational managers and support staff. A detailed description of IFCs environmental and social due diligence of this investment can be found in the Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS), which is also available on IFCs website at http://www.ifc.org/projects.
Sponsor: FV is privately owned by the Viegener family. Four brothers, descendants of the founder, control through holding Companies 70.7% of the shares of the Company. The balance is held by other members of the extended family.
Cost Nature: FV will embark in an Investment Program of about $20 million for the next two to three years. The proposed IFC Investment will comprise a corporate financing of up to $10 million to support the Company's strategic plan.

Project Name: Bangladesh SME Liquidity Facility (BSLF) I Southeast Bank
Project Description: This Project will provide a systemic solution to address the US dollar liquidity requirement of the recently established offshore banking units (OBUs) of Southeast Bank (SEBL).  Through IFC's support of this Project, OBUs of SEBL will provide short-term trade and working capital financing solutions for SMEs and export-oriented enterprises located in Export Processing Zones in Bangladesh.
Impact:
The key indicators for this Project will be the increase in number and value of short term transactions to finance SME working capital needs, number of SMEs financed, female employment, number of jobs created and supported.

The Project will help accelerate economic growth in Bangladesh by providing SMEs and exporters with the necessary liquidity to finance their trade and working capital needs.

The demonstration effect of the IFC funding will encourage the entry of international banks to finance the local banking sector and increase their range of funding options. 

IFC's loan will support job preservation in the small business sector that may otherwise have been forced to reduce staff  in the face of financing constraints.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  IFC will analyze the FI portfolio to identify high risk sectors and determine the Applicable Performance Requirements that would include a combination of: (i) The IFC Trade Finance Exclusion List; (ii) The applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and regulations; and (iii) Eligibility Criteria/E&S Checklist for high risk sectors. IFC will also appraise the FIs labor practices according to the IFCs Performance Standards 2: Labor and Working Conditions and review, if required, the capacity of the FI to manage social and environmental risks and to establish and maintain a Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS). Based on the review, the project will be required to: ·	Develop a Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS), to the satisfaction of IFC·	Identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the SEMS·	Commit to implement the SEMS, to ensure that its investments/activities supported by IFC financing are in compliance             with the Applicable Performance Requirements·	Demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions·	Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC
Sponsor:
The Project Company is Southeast Bank Limited (SEBL).  SEBL was established in 1995 by a group of professionals and industrialists. The Bank had its IPO in 1999 and is currently listed on the Dhaka and Chittagong Stock Exchanges.  

The Bank's shareholding is well-diversified with no individual shareholding exceeding 10%. The Bank had 66,898 Shareholders as of 31st December, 2010.  In addition to the 15 Non-Executive Directors, the Managing Director of the Bank also holds a seat on the Board as an Executive Director. 

At December 31, 2010, the Bank had total assets of $1.86 billion, total liabilities of $1.6 billion and Shareholder's Equity of $244 million.

Project Description: Fawaz Abdulaziz Al Hokair & Co. (ALH Retail or the Company), Saudi Arabias leader in the apparel retail franchise sector, is implementing a program to expand its domestic operations, as well as to grow its international presence, which currently spans Egypt, Jordan, Kazakhstan and the UAE. The proposed expansion program comprises the increase in the number of stores operated by the Company from approximately 1,028 to approximately 1,780 over a three-year period, and includes store openings in new countries of operations, such as Azerbaijan and Georgia.
Review Scope: IFCs project review comprised site visits to several of ALHs retail stores in Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Kazakhstan.  In addition, the review included a review of information provided by ALH on environmental and social management and performance including the Groups Human Resources policies and procedures, loss prevention program, security policy and procedures, and detailed questionnaires on each of its country operations; as well as meetings with ALHs management team in Riyadh and regional management team in Almaty.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The nature of ALHs operations involves the establishment of small (~180-465 square meters [m2]) retail outlets within exiting retail/commercial space (malls, shopping centers). As such, significant adverse E&S impacts are minimal. Based on site visits to ALHs corporate offices, a sample of retail stores in Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Kazakhstan, and discussions with ALH management, this project will have limited potential adverse environmental and social impacts that are site-specific, reversible and easily addressed through agreed mitigation measures. As a result, this is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.
Sector: BA - Retail (Including Supermarkets, Grocery Stores, etc.)

Project Description:
Oil and gas fields: The Company has 5 producing oil and gas fields (Aguada del Chivato, Aguada Bocarey, Cutral Co and Dos Picos and Medianera); and seven exploratory blocks in Neuquén and Rio Negro (Sierras Blancas, Loma Linda, La Tropilla I & II, La Via I & II, Puesto Roa, Aguila Mora and Tres Nidos Sur). Current average oil and gas production is 1,207 barrels per day (BPD) and 2,772 barrels of oil equivalent per day, respectively. 

Treatment plants: The Company owns and operates a gas treatment complex in Rio Negro Province (the 'Catriel Gas Complex'), which includes: (i) a gas compression plant (with a capacity to process 1,400,000 m3/day), (ii) a LPG and gasoline plant (255 tonnes per day 'Ton/D'), (iii) two gas sweetening plants (1,400,000 m3/day), and (iv) a network of feeding pipelines (78 km long).  In addition, Medanito operates three small oil treating/storage facilities in Neuquén Province (1,100 BPD); and a small gas sweetening plant in Santa Cruz Province. 

Forestry: Medanito owns 1,000 hectares of poplar plantations (800 in Veinticinco de Mayo in La Pampa Province and 200 in Rincon de Los Sauces in Neuquén Province). The forestry unit is a relatively small scale business, which is not included in the capital expenditure program. 

Medanito has requested IFC to provide financing to partially fund its 2011-2013 capital expenditure program which includes: (i) drilling programs ; (ii) expansion of oil & gas processing and storage facilities within existing footprint; and (iii) oil & gas exploration activities.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
The scope of this project covers a relatively small footprint of existing brownfield assets. The management of the company will be improved by IFC's investment as a result of the integration of IFC Performance Standards and EHS Guidelines into Medanito's existing EHS Management System. This project has thus been assessed as a category B project.

The Company's current activities consist of a) an oil and gas exploration and production program, including drilling programs, exploration activities in current assets, construction of new processing and storage facilities within existing areas and  small managed forests. Category B projects are those that according to IFC's Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects have a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to the applicable Performance Standards, guidelines and design criteria.

Company Name: S.A. SAN MIGUEL A.G.I.C.I. y F.
Project Description: The proposed investment in San Miguel is a corporate loan, which maximizes mobilization under IFC's umbrella with an A loan up to US$5 million and a B loan up to US$20 million. The funds from IFC will be utilized for a variety of purposes, including the replanting of older orchards with higher producing, more densely planted trees. A long-term IFC client, San Miguel has evolved its operations to comply with IFC's E&S requirements and applicable WBG's EHS Guidelines and to increase its sustainability in accordance with good industry's standards such as GlobalGAP; and, is nearing completion of a complex industrial wastewater management system. San Miguel, with the imprimatur of its internationally recognized food safety certifications in raw materials production and in processing exported diverse products, achieved 2009 revenue of US$207 million. San Miguel core operations are in Argentina, with more than 5,500 ha in plantations and downstream processing/packing facilities.
Review Scope: IFC's environmental specialist visited San Miguel's operations located in Tucuman and Famailla, Argentina. Famailla Industrial Plant area evaluations included the nursery and orchard at Monte Grande and the lemon processing plant. The fresh fruit packing operation located in the city of San Miguel de Tucuman was also evaluated. IFC participated in meetings with senior management, line management and staff responsible for operations and production. Of particular relevance to IFC's appraisal of this investment were the meetings with management and staff responsible for the environmental, occupational health and safety issues and social/community relations. Special attention was paid to the status of corrective actions addressing E&S performance in prior Environmental and Social Action Plans (ESAP) associated with previous IFC investments, namely San Miguel II (#23850) and Milagro (#26890). These included specifically the evaluation of the industrial plant's wastewater treatment operations, including the management of biosolids, OHS in both plants and orchards, and specific commercial and OHS-related management system certifications held by San Miguel. Company operations in Uruguay (ref. Milagro) were not visited as current reporting on E&S performance and completion of Milagro ESAP action items clearly demonstrates satisfactory overall environmental, social and OHS performance at these facilities. Previous Milagro ESAP action items completed were related to revision of human resources policies, the planning and implementation of a community engagement program, upgrades to the facility integrated pest and disease management program and planning and implementation of a water resources conservation program.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This investment is categorized as a B as there are no elements of the project with diverse, unprecedented or irreversible, negative social or environmental impacts. Company operations are well known to IFC since more than 12 years.  Previous E&S issues of concern, such as effluent management has been (and/or are being) addressed by San Miguel. This appraisal confirmed that many considerations are receiving appropriate management attention; and, that new initiatives and approaches to avoiding, managing or mitigating E&S impacts are in place and continue to drive improved performance. The Company does not engage with the community in other than in an ad hoc manner. Nevertheless, no serious social/community issues were observed or discovered related to industrial operational practices during the appraisal or have been reported in previous Annual E&S Monitoring Reports (AMRs).

Project Description: Scholz AG, based in Essingen, is one of the leading metal waste management and recycling company in Europe and Balkan countries with developing presence in Asia, Central America, Middle East and North Africa. The project of approximately US$ 120 million is to support operations of Scholz A.G. Germany ('Group' or the 'Sponsor') in Croatia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzagovina, Kosovo, FYR Macedonia, Romania and Albania (referred to as the 'Balkan' countries or the 'Region') over the next three years. The IFC investment will consist of a loan up to US$60 million in Euro equivalent. The investment will finance modernization and working capital needs of the Group in the Region. The project includes increase of processing capacity and product mix, installation of post-shredder technology in Croatia, investments in two new sites in Bosnia, restructuring of metal recycling company owned by Scholz in Albania and provision of maintenance capex in Albania, Croatia, FYR Macedonia, Montenegro and Romania.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
The key environmental, social and occupational health & safety issues reviewed with this investment include: Labor and working conditions including occupational health and safety considerations relating to Scholz' employees and within the supply chain, relevant treatment of vulnerable groups which may include underage workers, management of storm-water run-off from scrap metal collection and processing centers, soil and groundwater pollution control, handling and storage of hazardous materials, transportation safety, expansion of collection and processing capacity that may require land acquisition, avoidance of involuntary resettlement. 

The Project has limited potential adverse environmental and social impacts which can readily be addressed through effective implementation of good international industry practices and requirements of IFC's Performance Standards and Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) guidelines. This proposed investment is therefore a Category B project according to IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedures.

Existing and proposed measures to manage and mitigate these risks are described below and in the Environmental and Social Action Plan agreed with the Companies

Germany (Group or the Sponsor) in Croatia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, FYR Macedonia, Romania, Montenegro and Albania (referred to as the Balkan countries or the Region) over the next 4 years.  The investment will finance modernization and working capital needs of the Group in the Region.
Impact: An important aspect of this investment lies in the climate change element related to recovery of resources and creation of scrap as a raw material for steel making out of metal waste.  Production of steel out of scrap significantly reduces CO2 emission and lowers energy and water consumption as compared to the traditional method.  In addition to the environmental impact, metal waste management is vital for growth and sustainability of the Balkan economies, many of which are struggling with high unemployment and with management metal waste.  The Group''s operations and the Project address both issues by providing direct and indirect employment for collecting the waste metal and cleaning up the areas from the wasteAn important aspect of this investment lies in the climate change element related to recovery of resources and creation of scrap as a raw material for steel making out of metal waste. Project Description: The proposed project involves an equity investment by IFC in a new Non-Banking Finance Company (NBFC) being set up by the sponsors of Jain Irrigation Systems Limited (JISL) - an existing IFC client  subject to receipt of relevant regulatory approvals. The NBFC will finance the purchase of micro drip irrigation (MIS) and other agri-productivity tools in rural India. The project is intended to create a viable player in the rural financing space with support from an established industrial player that has significant rural presence.
Impact:
1.	Increased Access to Finance in Rural Areas: The project shall increase access to finance among smaller farmers who currently have limited access to credit in purchase of agricultural productivity tools.
2.	Improved Utilization of Water Resources: MIS and drip irrigation is capital intensive from the point of view of most small farmers. With improved credit access, it is expected that increased number of farmers would install MIS systems which would improve Water Use Efficiency which is a critical consideration as water resources start becoming scarce.
3.	Demonstration Effect: The proposed project shall demonstrate a commercially viable financing model for agricultural credit needs in rural India. This project brings together a strong sponsor and management team, institutional shareholders and an existing distribution set-up which improve its chances of creating a strong demonstration effect.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  The Applicable Performance Requirements include The IFC Exclusion List and The applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and regulations. Based on the review and the activities proposed to be supported, the project is required to: ·	Develop a Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS), to the satisfaction of IFC·	Identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the SEMS·	Commit to implement the SEMS, to ensure that its investments/activities are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements·	Demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions and ensure that the HR Policy and Procedures to be developed are consistent with the IFC PS 2 and National Requirements·      Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC
Sponsor: The new NBFC is being promoted by JISL and the sponsors of JISL. JISL, winner of IFC's 2010 Client Leadership Award, is one of India's largest integrated agribusiness players with manufacturing operations in micro irrigation systems (MIS), plastic pipes and sheets, dehydrated onions and processed fruits.
Cost Nature: IFC plans to make a minority equity investment of up to $ 5 million as part of the initial capitalization for the newly incorporated NBFC post receipt of relevant regulatory approvals.

Project Description: Medanito S.A. is a mid-size Argentinean company active in oil and gas exploration and production ('E&P'), liquefied petroleum gas ('LPG') production, and natural gas treatment services. The company's main assets are the Aguada del Chivato/ Aguada Bocarey E&P concession in the Neuquen Province, and the Catriel Gas Complex in the Rio Negro Province. The company holds three other exploitation concessions and seven exploration licenses in the Neuquen basin, as well as an early-stage forestry business.  Current oil and gas production net to Medanito is 1,185 barrels per day ('b/d') and 14,600 thousand cubic feet per day ('mcf/d'), respectively. The company also produces 177 tonnes per day ('T/d') of LPG, and 72 T/d of natural gasolines.  Medanito has a 2011-2013 capital expenditure program, consisting of: (i) drilling programs aimed to develop hydrocarbon reserves; (ii) expansion of processing and storage facilities; and (iii) exploration activities.
Impact:
The project will lead to further exploration, appraisal and development of primary energy sources in Argentina. The expected benefits will come in the form of:

1.	  Increased supply of hydrocarbons, particularly natural gas: IFC expects that Medanito's upstream production will increase from the current level of 3,600 boe/d. About 60% of this upstream production consists of natural gas.  Continued support for gas production and displacement of more carbon-intensive fuels is a key part of the World Bank Group's strategy, as natural gas is endorsed as a bridging fuel in the transition to a low carbon economy. The increased levels of gas production will also mitigate Argentina's dependence on gas imports. 

2. 	Contribution to Government revenues: the project will result in increased sales of natural gas, LPG, and crude oil. The associated provincial taxes, royalties, and federal income taxes will provide an important source of income to the Federal and Provincial Governments (incremental fiscal revenues are estimated at more than US$150 million over the next decade). 

3.  Creation/preservation of local employment and sourcing in Argentina: by extending the life of the Company's reserves, the project will help to secure direct and indirect jobs in the Provinces of Neuquen and Rio Negro. The project will also have an impact on regional economic activity through local purchasing. 

IFC plans to monitor the following indicators during supervision: (i) annual production of natural gas in Argentina (mcf); (ii) payments to governments (US$); and (iii) purchases of domestic goods and services (US$).

Governance risks assessment

It is expected that benefits from the project will accrue to different levels of government in Argentina in the form of taxes and royalties. Benefits to the local population are also anticipated in the form of direct and indirect employment. In coming to a view on whether to support this project, IFC has reviewed a range of governance and transparency metrics including, but not limited to, The World Bank Institute's Governance Indicators and Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index. The Government has committed to strengthening public sector performance within Argentina's federal system, with a view towards improving the effectiveness of basic service delivery and building transparency and trust, objectives that are supported by the World Bank Group. In addition, the Governments of Neuquen, La Pampa, and Rio Negro adhere to the 2004 "Ley de Reponsabilidad Fiscal", meant to promote fiscal discipline at the provincial level. Separately, IFC requires all its extractive industry clients to publicly disclose taxes, royalties and other payments made to governments.  On balance, given the governance situation in the country and the project's expected development benefits, IFC believes that this is a project which it should support.
Environmental Social Issues: The key social and environmental aspects to address in this project include:  i) adequacy of the Environmental, Social, Health and Safety Management System; ii)  the Companys assessment and management of potential ESHS impacts related to its activities; iii) Company and contractors ESHS performance; iv) Pollution prevention; v) Biodiversity; vi) Stakeholder engagement. The issues and their impacts are limited and can be managed through an Environmental and Social Action Plan and Medanitos ESHS Management System and Standard Operating Procedures.
Sponsor: Medanito was founded in 1993 by Tecna Proyectos de Ingenieria S.A and a group of private investors. Tecna is an engineering company that develops proprietary technology and engineering projects in the hydrocarbon, energy and petrochemical sectors in Latin America. The largest beneficiary shareholders of Medanito are the Carosio family (43%), and Messrs. Carlos Grimaldi (12.6%) and Ricardo Altube (12.6%).
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at $137 million. IFC is considering to invest equity for its own account and mobilize investments from third parties, for a total of up to $50 million.
Investment: 25.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity25.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: IFC's financing will be used to further develop Medanito's exploration and producing assets in the province of Neuquen (located in Southern Argentina). Funds may also be used to acquire new hydrocarbon assets. The areas where the company operates are sparsely populated and land generally belongs to the government or to large scale landowners. There are no small farmers or vulnerable households.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The key social and environmental aspects to address in this project include:  i) adequacy of the Environmental, Social, Health and Safety Management System; ii)  the Companys assessment and management of potential ESHS impacts related to its activities; iii) Company and contractors ESHS performance; iv) Pollution prevention; v) Biodiversity; vi) Stakeholder engagement. The issues and their impacts are limited and can be managed through an Environmental and Social Action Plan and Medanitos ESHS Management System and Standard Operating Procedures.

Company Name: S.A. SAN MIGUEL A.G.I.C.I. y F.
Project Description: San Miguel runs a capital intensive business as citrus trees take an average of 5-7 years to reach maturity. The proposed 6-year A loan (US$5 million) & B loan (US$20 million) would allow San Miguel to maintain an adequate balance sheet structure by replacing loans due in the coming 2 years with longer maturities.
Impact: The project would help to: (i) improve the debt structure of the Company by replacing financial debt maturing in the next two years with long term debt; (ii) assist the Company to continue its investment program in a frontier region in Argentina (province of Tucuman); (iii) support the final completion of an innovative waste water treatment designed to adress the specific and difficult effluent issue faced by San Miguel; (iv) provide economic benefits for Tucuman, a frontier region, and benefit local farmers, workers and affiliated enterprises; (v) maintain the financial flexibility of San Miguel in order to continue its South-South investments in Uruguay and South Africa.
Environmental Social Issues: A long-term IFC client, San Miguel has evolved its operations to comply with IFCs E&S requirements and applicable WBGs EHS Guidelines and to increase its sustainability in accordance with good industrys standards such as GlobalGAP; and, is nearing completion of a complex industrial wastewater management system. San Miguel, with the imprimatur of its internationally recognized food safety certifications in raw materials production and in processing, achieved 2010 revenue of US$207 million. Any updates or enhancements to production capacity will take place within the existing industrial plant footprint. No expansion is planned for orchards; production increases will come from replanting old orchards with a denser planting regimen; PS7: Indigenous Peoples  company operations are not conducted in areas that impact indigenous peoples; PS8: Cultural Heritage - not applicable. The operations are located either in industrial parks or other highly disturbed areas that have been used for farming and industrial purposes for many years. Orchards are long established and are not subject to expansion.
