Project Description:
Raffles Education Corporation Limited ('REC', 'Raffles' or the 'Company'), headquartered in Singapore, is the largest private education group in Asia-Pacific. Since establishing its first college in Singapore in 1990, the group has grown to operate 37 colleges in 34 cities across 14 countries in the Asia-Pacific region: Australia, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Mongolia, New Zealand, Philippines, Singapore, Sri Lanka, Thailand and Vietnam.  There are more than 28,700 students enrolled in Raffles' tertiary programs and the Company employs over 3,000 academic and administrative staff. Raffles also owns the Oriental University City ('OUC'), a self-contained campus in Langfang, China. Within this campus, OUC provides education services to 9 colleges with a total student population of over 27,000.  

The proposed IFC financing is a corporate finance facility to REC to support its continued expansion over the next four years. The expansion includes entry into new markets, scaling up Raffles' operations in select existing markets and on-going maintenance capex. The IFC financing is expected to be used to fund (i) the construction of a greenfield university in Greater Noida, India; (ii) the construction of a greenfield university in Iskandar, Malaysia; (iii) the establishment of vocational training schools in Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, the Philippines, India, Indonesia, Vietnam and Thailand; and (iv) the repayment of short-term debt.
Review Scope: The IFC review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information made available by the sponsor. The appraisal involved meetings with senior management of REC as well as review of the Company environmental and social systems and policies. Discussions were held with the Company Architect and Vice President regarding the approach to planning and designing new schools and campuses. In addition, visits were made to established campuses in Singapore and China, a vocational school in India and the construction site of the greenfield university in Greater Noida, in order to appraise how the Company manages environmental and social issues during construction and operation.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
The Project has been categorized as Category B according to IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The nature of REC's operations, which involve the provision of educational services, is such that adverse environment and social (E&S) impacts are minimal. Key environmental, social, health and safety impacts associated with the Project during construction and operation include: the sponsor's system to manage E&S issues during construction and operation of schools; land acquisition issues at campus sites; labor and working conditions; community and staff occupational health and safety issues; life and fire safety design and provisions; management and minimization of air, water and solid pollutants during construction and operation; energy and water usage efficiency; and community engagement.  

The Project may result in a limited number of specific adverse environmental and social impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. REC will manage its environmental and social performance in accordance with applicable local laws and regulations and international standards, including IFC's Performance Standards on Social and Environmental Sustainability and IFC's Environmental, Health and Safety General Guidelines.
Sector: AB - Colleges, Universities, and Professional Schools

Project Description: The project seeks to deepen and broaden financial services for small and medium enterprise ('SME') in sub-Saharan Africa by supporting the expansion of Alios Finance, S.A. ('Alios Finance'), a leasing, equipment rental, investment lending, and consumer finance group whose founders have over 50 years of experience in asset finance in the region.  The project aims to  support the expansion of Alios Finance into East Africa by providing a financing package of up to $10.2 million in combined senior debt and equity to its greenfield leasing subsidiaries in Tanzania and Kenya, and a proposed advisory services package to strengthen Alios Finance's operations as well as the business environment for leasing in the region.  To date, SMEs in sub-Saharan Africa have significant unmet demand for term financing for equipment and other assets.  The project proposes to support a seasoned leasing group that would be well positioned to respond to the demand for asset finance in the region.
Impact: By supporting the expansion of this strong vehicle and equipment leasing, long-term rental, and consumer finance company into new markets such as the Tanzania and Kenya, IFC will improve access to financing for SMEs and job-producing companies in both countries.  Participating in this expansion will enable IFC to add value to the project, based on its presence in the new markets, and its leasing experience in advisory services, legislative advisory services, and financial services in the region.  The project is expected to have a strong development impact in the following areas:  i.) Enhance Alios Finance's ability to deepen access to financial services for SMEs in Kenya and Tanzania; ii.) Increase Alios Finance's access to local currency financing; and; iii.) Subject to diagnostic work, strengthen the business environment for leasing in the region.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves IFC support for the leasing business and has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. During appraisal, IFC analyzed the FI portfolio for types of transactions, size, tenor and industry sectors and determined as Applicable Performance Requirements based on an analysis of the potential social and environmental risks associated with the FI portfolio and considering IFCs investment the IFC Exclusion list and the applicable national laws and regulations. IFC also reviewed the FIs existing social and environmental due diligence procedures, and capacity to implement the same, and appraised the companys labor practices. Alios Finance has an S&E policy for screening against the Exclusion List, which needs to be upgraded to comply with IFCs policy requirements, and each subsidiary has a designated S&E Champion. Based on the review the client will be required (i) to develop a Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS), that is satisfactory to IFC, and that ensures that all its activities are screened and processed to avoid supporting activities on the FI Exclusion List, and ensures that the use of the leased equipment complies with the applicable national S&E laws, prior to disbursement; (ii) Demonstrate commitment and resources to implementing the SEMS; (iii) When leasing to business activities with potentially significant environmental and social risks inquire and review S&E information available in the public domain and avoid leasing to businesses that have substantial unresolved environmental and social issues. In such cases, the Company will also need to satisfy itself that the activity is being undertaken in compliance with the applicable national laws; (iv) Develop a HR Manual, including a sexual harassment policy and grievance mechanism, and demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions; and (v) Submit a periodic report as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: Alios Finance, incorporated in France, has subsidiaries in Cameroon, Gabon, Zambia, and Cote d'Ivoire, and branches in Senegal, Mali, and Burkina Faso, which provide companies with vehicle leasing, long-term equipment rental, investment loans, and consumer finance services.  The group began in 1956 in Senegal as a single vehicle finance company SAFCA (Société Africaine de Crédit Automobile), established by Renault, Unilever, OPTORG, CFAO and SCOA.  In 1998, a holding company was formed to hold the interests of the main shareholders in the subsidiaries, and a new group of financial sector and development institution shareholders entered the holding company.  Today, Alios Finance's ownership includes the following main shareholders, a blend of automotive and equipment distributors, financial sector institutions, and development finance institutions:  CFAO (24%), AfricInvest (23%), FMO (18%), FinnFund (14%), OPTORG (12%), Tunisie Leasing (5%), Africa Financial Holdings (2%), and Gras Savoye (2%).
Cost Nature: IFC's investment will consist of a financing package with the following components for IFC's own account:  i.) a senior loan of up to $ 4 million available in USD or TZS to Alios Finance Tanzania, ii.) an investment of up to $400,000 in common shares (equity) of Alios Finance Tanzania, iii.) a senior loan of up to $ 5 million available in USD or KES to Alios Finance Kenya, and iv.) an investment of up to $800,000 in common shares (equity) of Alios Finance Kenya.

Project Description: Raffles Education Corporation Limited (REC, Raffles or the Company), headquartered in Singapore, is the largest private education group in Asia-Pacific. Since establishing its first college in Singapore in 1990, the group has grown to operate 37 colleges in 34 cities across 14 countries in the Asia-Pacific region: Australia, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Mongolia, New Zealand, Philippines, Singapore, Sri Lanka, Thailand and Vietnam.  There are more than 28,700 students enrolled in Raffles tertiary programs and the Company employs over 3,000 academic and administrative staff. Impact: The proposed investment is expected to increase the provision and access to quality education services. The Company''s expansion into new markets is not only expected to increase the supply of highly in-demand education services, but also improve the quality of service in those market given the strength of Raffles'' core programs. The establishment of Raffles'' schools in markets like India and Bangladesh for example will also offer another option for students seeking international curriculum, but who do not wish to leave their home country. In addition, the project will support the development of private education services in India through partnership with an established market leader.

The nature of RECs operations, which involve the provision of educational services, is such that adverse environment and social (E&S) impacts are minimal. The project may result in a limited number of specific adverse environmental and social impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. REC will manage its environmental and social performance in accordance with applicable local laws and regulations and international standards, including IFCs Performance Standards on Social and Environmental Sustainability and IFC''s Environmental, Health and Safety General Guidelines.
Sponsor: REC is listed on the Main Board of the Singapore Stock Exchange (SGX) with a current market capitalization of over S$660 million ($525 million) as of April 7, 2011. The main shareholders of Raffles are Mr. Chew Hua Seng, the Companys founder, Chairman and CEO, and his wife, Ms. Doris Chung Gim Lian, who combined own approximately 35% of the Company.

Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The project has been categorized as Category B according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Key environmental, social, health and safety impacts associated with the Project during construction and operation include: the sponsors system to manage E&S issues during construction and operation of schools; land acquisition issues at campus sites; labor and working conditions; community and staff occupational health and safety issues; life and fire safety design and provisions; management and minimization of air, water and solid pollutants during construction and operation; energy and water usage efficiency; and community engagement.  The project may result in a limited number of specific adverse environmental and social impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. REC will manage its environmental and social performance in accordance with applicable local laws and regulations and international standards, including IFCs Performance Standards on Social and Environmental Sustainability and IFC''s Environmental, Health and Safety General Guidelines.
Sector: AB - Colleges, Universities, and Professional Schools

Project Description:
Artha Capital S de RL de DV ('Artha' or the 'Sponsor') is a Mexican real estate fund, focused on buying and developing land to be used for affordable housing, retail, industrial and tourism projects in Mexico. Artha finances land and infrastructure investments consisting of the acquisition and development of land by the implementation of planned and sustainable urban projects and the implementation of basic infrastructure such as roads and water, electricity and sanitation utility services, and sale of land for the purposes of housing, tourism, industrial and commercial development.   
 
Artha has completed the raising of $200 million and has already built up a solid project pipeline. In its efforts to diversify its portfolio and complete the execution of its targeted projects Artha has invited IFC to invest up to $25 million equivalent in Mexican pesos in equity to finance the individual sub-projects. It is estimated that Artha will raise additional financing of $75 million.
Review Scope: IFC's E&S appraisal included a site visit to one of Artha's developments near the city of Querétaro in central Mexico, where environmental and social conditions were observed and discussed with project manager and other staff. In addition, discussions were held at Artha's office in Mexico City with Company executives regarding human resources policies and procedures, management of environmental and social matters during execution, and management of contractors. Company executives also provided information and documentation about Artha's organization, strategy, and portfolio.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
Key E&S issues reviewed at appraisal include: Artha's E&S project assessment processes as they apply to the land acquisition process, to ensure that all land acquisition is free and fair, avoids adverse impact on cultural heritage, and avoids or appropriately compensates any involuntary resettlement; and that construction activity within Artha's control is conducted with due regard to the environment and employee safety and working conditions.

This is a Category B project according to IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedure as the potential impacts of the project are readily manageable with recognized mitigation measures. Furthermore, the Company consistently applies appropriate energy efficiency and resource management measures to improve the sustainability of the project.

Project Description: The project involves an investment to expand the existing facilities of Paradeep Phosphates Limited ('PPL' or the 'Company'), an integrated manufacturer of complex phosphoric fertilizers such as di-ammonium phosphate ('DAP') and Nitrogen-Phosphate-Potash ('NPK'). The expansion includes: (i) a new 660,000 metric tonnes per annum (MTPA) sulfuric acid plant increasing its capacity by 90%; (ii) de-bottlenecking of its existing 250,000 MTPA phosphoric acid plant ('PAP') to increase its capacity by 150,000 MTPA.
Review Scope: The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health, safety and social information submitted by the project sponsor, and field visits in April 2011. The environmental and social (E&S) appraisal team visited the project site and surrounding areas in Orissa, India. The E&S team held meetings with the management teams for current operations, expansion projects design, EHS performances, HR policies, and community engagement. The E&S appraisal team also interviewed some employees and nearby residents.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
The expansion projects will be installed inside the current plant boundaries. The state regulatory agency confirms no natural protection area or protected species at or near the plant site. The findings in the environmental impact assessment and quantitative risk assessment indicate that the current and expansion operations will meet both local regulatory and IFC requirements upon successful implementation of the proposed mitigation methods. The normal operations have limited impacts to Paradeep colony and community to the southeast of the plant. Mitigation measures for the potential environmental and social impacts have been identified and are incorporated into an attached Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP).

The potential adverse E&S impacts of this project are therefore few in number and limited to the project site and may be readily mitigated.  This is therefore an E&S Category B project.

Company Name: VISHWA INFRASTRUCTURES AND SERVICES PRIVATE LIMITED
Project Description: IFC is considering a $5.5 million loan to Vishwa to be applied to the Khandwa water supply project and the Kolhapur STP. The Khandwa water supply project, Madhya Pradesh, is a public-private partnership between Khandwa Municipal Corporation (Khandwa MC) and Vishwa, under the Urban Infrastructure Development Scheme for Small and Medium Towns (UIDSSMT). The project will commence supplying 29 million L/day (MLD) to Khandwa (population 240,000) for domestic consumption, increasing to 43 MLD by the end of the concession period (2034), meeting the current shortfall by almost doubling the volume of water currently supplied. Under this build-own-operate-transfer (BOOT) scheme, Vishwa has a 25 year concession period (2 years construction, 23 years operation and maintenance). The project will pump water through an intake well on the Chhotitave River, a backwater of the Indira Sagar Reservoir, to the adjacent water treatment plant (WTP). The WTP (2.7 ha site) will treat water using water clarification / the application of alum for flocculation and chlorination, then pump it to Khandwa via a 50 km long 800 mm reinforced trunk pipeline. The pipeline will discharge into a 1,222 m3 ground level master balancing reservoir (GLMBR), from where it will be pumped to nine separate overhead tanks. Water will then be gravity fed to the township. The project includes the laying of 60 km of poly distribution pipeline through the streets of Khandwa. Project construction commenced in late 2010.The Kolhapur STP and allied works, Maharashtra, is a long-term public-private partnership between Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (Kolhapur MC) and Vishwa. The project, an initiative contributing to the Panchganga Action Plan (PAP), has the objective of preventing and controlling the discharge of sewage entering the Panchganga River via the four main nallahs (streams) that drain Kolhapur. The Ichalkaranji section of the Panchganga River was declared critically polluted by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB). The existing city STP (43 MLD treatment capacity) is limited to primary treatment (primary screening, grit removal and settling) and has inadequate capacity. As a result, treated sewage does not meet CPCB standards, and overflows from the existing STP plus partially treated and untreated sewage flow almost directly into the Panchganga River that serves as a potable water source for Kolhapur and other settlements. The project will intercept and pump untreated sewage from nallahs into the new STP. The STP will treat wastewater using: (a) primary treatment - conventional mechanical methods; and (b) secondary treatment - sequential batch reactor (SBR) technology that allows variable flows to be treated by this activated sludge method. A high quality effluent will be produced with low turbidity and low nitrogen levels. The STP will service Kolhapur city (population 493,000 in 2001) with a treatment capacity of 76 MLD, replacing the existing STP. The project consists of: the STP at Kasba Bawda; a sewerage pumping station and rising main at Bagat Camp and Line Bazaar; a rising main at Jayant Nallah; a discharge pipe between the STP and Panchganga River; and miscellaneous civil works. Under this design, finance, construct, operate and maintain scheme, Vishwa has a 15 year concession period (2 years construction, 13 years operation and maintenance). The STP site is located within an existing compound owned by Kolhapur MC, next to the existing STP operated by the Corporation. Project construction commenced in early 2011.
Review Scope: IFCs review of this project consisted of:-  reviewing technical, environmental and social information on the Kolhapur STP (Request for Proposal: Volume III  Technical Specifications and Volume IV  Project Information Memorandum; Draft Initial Environmental Examination; Social Safeguards Planning Document, May 2009).-  meetings with Vishwa management including: Director, Finance; General Manager, Human Resources; Manager, Health, Safety and Environment; Senior Project Manager, Khandwa; Project Manager  Hyderabad micro-tunnelling); - site visits to the Khandwa water supply project, Madhya Pradesh and an operational STP in Andhra Pradesh operated by Vishwa.- reviewing Vishwa corporate environmental, health and safety, and human resources policies and procedures.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The project is a Category B because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result from the Khandwa water supply project and the Kolhapur STP that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines and design criteria. Potential adverse construction impacts are likely to be limited to project sites, short term, able to be effectively managed and mitigated, and likely to have no or limited impact on environmentally sensitive features and sites. Project operational impacts can also be effectively managed by implementation of suitable engineering and management measures.The Khandwa water supply and Kolhapur waste water treatment projects will deliver significant environmental and community health benefits. The Khandwa project will provide a more reliable domestic water supply in terms of both volume and quality, thereby reducing the incidence of waterborne disease. The Kolhapur STP and allied works will improve sewage collection and provide additional sewage treatment capacity, safely treating sanitary effluent that currently poses a major health hazard and significantly degrades Panchganga water quality and the aquatic ecosystem, thereby improving social and environmental conditions in Kolhapur.

Project Description: The NSL Group was founded in 1973 as a seeds company -- Nuziveedu Seeds Limited (NSL), which has since become the largest in India.  Through NRPPL, NSL has diversified into renewable energy business with particular focus on wind and hydroelectric power (hydro) in India.  NRPPL is a holding company which has a pipeline of medium & small hydro and wind power projects under development. Typically, each project is developed under a special purpose company with NRPPL as the majority shareholder. IFC is considering an equity investment to support NRPPLs expansion plans.NRPPL has 112 MW of existing operating assets comprised of two 7.5 MW each biomass power plant and 2 wind power plants, the 50.4 MW wind power plant in Bhimasamudra and 47.5 MW wind power project in Jagalur, Anthiyur & Kappatgudda, both in Karnataka.  The Company has under development, 2 medium scale (100 MW and 44 MW) and 2 small scale (5 MW and 6 MW) hydro projects of which Tidong 1, a 100 MW hydro project is in the most advanced of construction.  Further, the Company is also planning to develop 7 wind power projects, which are in various stages of conceptualization and development.
Review Scope: IFCs review included interviews with NRPPLs key corporate staff (Chief Executive, business development, construction and operations, EHS, social responsibility, human resources) and numerous, relevant internal documents and records surrounding the Companys environmental and social (E&S) programs, procedures, and standards were discussed.  Among others, these included the: Corporate SEMS Framework; Corporate EHS Management Plans; Corporate EHS Staffing Plan; Corporate Human Resource (HR) Policy; and sample appointment letter and wage slip.  To benchmark the effectiveness of the Companys management system to promote E&S performance and its capacity to manage risks and impacts of its developments and operations, IFC staff also conducted visits to representative facilities -- two medium scale run of river hydro power projects under development (Tidong 1 and Tangnu Romai 1 in Himachal Pradesh), and one operational wind power project (Bheemasamudra in Karnataka).  Meetings at these selected sites were completed with members of the local community, members of the respective Panchayats (Village Councils), and State environmental authorities.  At Tidong 1 independently facilitated meetings were held with families who lost small parcels of land.  Discussions with these groups focused on project benefits, impacts, ongoing community engagement mechanisms, and ongoing project monitoring.  Its important to note that IFC undertook a relatively detailed review of Tidong-1, the 100 MW hydro project, since it is the most advanced of the under development projects and is also the one with highest risk amongst the under development projects.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a corporate investment as per IFCs Environment and Social Review Procedure since the proposed equity investment is in a holding company and not targeted at any of NRPPLs specific assets. In such investments, IFC expects that the Company will have in place social and environmental management systems to ensure that the holding companys operations, including the projects and operations of its subsidiary companies will be consistent with IFC Performance Standards.  While the existing operational assets of NRPPL (i.e. two 7.5 MW each biomass power plant and the 2 wind power plants viz  50.4 MW and the 47.5 MW wind power plants) have limited impacts, IFC is treating this investment as a category A project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects since the sector in which NRPPL is investing is potentially high risk, and the projects in the Companys current pipeline include medium and small scale hydropower developments.
Sector: BC - Wind Power - Renewable Energy Generation

Project Description: Continental Towers Holding Corporation (Continental or the Company) is a Central American telecommunications infrastructure sharing company created in 2008. The Project consists of the construction, operation and maintenance of towers in Central America, as well as the refinancing of its medium term debt. The Sponsor Terra Towers (Terra or the Sponsor), a Guatemalan company, founded Continental and together with a $70 million loan facility from Credit Suisse First Boston, started the Companys operations. Currently, the Company through its operating companies owns and operates about 500 towers in five Central American countries (Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, Panama, and Costa Rica). The Company is seeking $120 million of funding to: i) expand its operations by doubling its capacity, bringing its total portfolio of towers to about 1,000 by the end of 2012; and ii) refinance its existing medium term debt facility. The project also contemplates a possible geographical expansion with the penetration of other countries in the region.
Impact: -Improved mobile and broadband access: Access is one of the 3 pillars of IFC''s telecoms strategy, is achieved through overall business efficiency thanks to the co-location model, as the telecoms ecosystem benefits from tower costs spread amongst multiple carriers, leading to improved access (coverage, prices, provision of additional services, etc.). The other pillars i.e. mainstreaming of private and public services and the fostering of innovation, are also achieved by a more efficient telecoms industry.    - Reduced capex and lowers operating costs: For telecoms operators, the reduced costs can translate into lower cost of services for users. Potentially, operators can unlock cash from their balance sheets (in the case existing towers are sold to independent third party operators), critical in a region like Central America, where financing options are scarce. - Telecom sector growth Infrastructure sharing is critical in further fuelling the evolution of the telecoms market, indirectly assisting in the development of mobile broadband, and more indirectly, content and applications, mobile finance and mobile advertising, as several industry segments begin converging. -Increased competition: co-location allows smaller operators to have access to a well managed network and they can quickly roll out their network and compete more effectively. - Environmental benefits become evident, especially in reducing the visual burden of the explosion in tower masts (i.e., as a result of mobile telephony markets with as many as 5 operators). - The Project also assists in the creation of both direct and indirect employment opportunities.
Environmental Social Issues: The key environmental and social issues associated with the project are the company''s environmental, health, safety, and social (EHSS) management;  EHSS screening of new sites;  construction at new sites;  labor and working conditions (including contractor occupational health and safety);  and pollution prevention and abatement.  This has been classified as a Category B project according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.  As a condition of IFC''s investment, Continental Towers will commit to developing and implementing a Social and Environmental Management System for ensuring that all relevant social and environmental risks and impacts are managed as appropriate.  Specific information about how risks, impacts and opportunities will be addressed by Continental Towers is summarized in the Environmental and Social Review Summary for the project.
Sponsor: Continental is a British Virgin Island (BVI) registered entity with ownership interest in operating subsidiaries across Central America. The Company was established to provide mobile operators with infrastructure sharing solutions. The Sponsor, Terra, was started in 1998 in response to the needs of the mobile operators in the region. Terra currently operates 300 towers in Central America.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $160 million, of which $110 million will be used for Capex expansion and $50 will be used to refinance the Companys medium term loan facility. The proposed IFC investment is: i) up to $70 million on a senior long-term secured facility, of which IFC could provide up to $40 million for its own account; and ii) up to $50 million in the form of a medium term B loan or Parallel loan. IFC will invite other DFI to participate. The remaining funding needs will be injected by the Sponsor in the form of equity.

Project Description:
Paradeep Phosphates Limited (PPL or the Company) is a going concern engaged in the production of approximately 1.2 million metric tons per annum (MTPA) of fertilizers, including di-ammonium phosphate (DAP) ) and other complex phosphatic fertilizers representing a combination of multiple nutrients such as nitrogen, phosphorus, potash, and sulphur.  PPL also produces intermediary products like phosphoric acid and sulphuric acid, which are its critical raw materials. The plant, located in the port town of Paradeep in the district of Jagatsinghpur in Orissa, has an installed capacity of 720,000 MTPA of DAP, making PPL one of the largest integrated complex-fertilizer plants in India, with a strong market presence, especially in Orissa, and in the neighboring states of West Bengal, Jharkhand, Chattisgarh, eastern Uttar Pradesh, and Madhya Pradesh.  

PPL has been operating at over 100% capacity since 2003, and has now undertaken a three-year expansion plan requiring a capital expenditure of approximately $120 million to increase its current production capacity of di-ammonium phosphate (DAP) and nitrogen, phosphorus and potash NPK fertilizers by ~25% to 1.5 million MTPA to meet India's growing demand for fertilizers (the 'Project'). The Project entails the addition of incremental capacity as well as improvements to plant efficiency by improving raw material consumption, the material handling system, product quality and environmental standards.
Impact: The Project is expected to: (i) increase the domestic capacity of  DAP and other complex phosphatic fertilizers, and contribute to the growth of the agricultural sector in India; (ii) assist the Company in upgrading its environmental and operating performance to achieve international standards; (iii) help lower PPL's production costs which would benefit the farmers;  (iv) help mitigate the impact of climate change since the energy released during the sulphuric acid oxidation process will be used to power a significant part of the plant's operations; (v) create a number of direct and indirect job opportunities for local communities, including temporary employment to local labor during the construction phase of the Project assets.
Environmental Social Issues: This a Category B project. The potential adverse E&S impacts of this project are therefore few in number and limited to the project site and may be readily mitigated.  The key environmental and social issues for this project include the following:  - Wastewater treatment, recycling, and discharge- Air emission control- Solid waste management- Hazardous material management, operational hazards and emergency response- Occupational health/safety (OHS)- Community health and safety- Community engagement and development Paradeep has presented plans to address these impacts to ensure that the proposed project will, upon implementation of the specific agreed measures, comply with the environmental and social requirements - the host country laws and regulations and the IFC Environment and Social Performance Standards and the World Bank Group (WBG) Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) guidelines. Please refer to the Environmental and Social Review Summary for detailed information about E&S issues.
Sponsor:
PPL is majority owned by Zuari Industries Limited (ZIL), a K.K. Birla Group company, and Maroc Phosphore, SA, a Moroccan state-owned 100% subsidiary of Office Cherifien Des Phosphates (OCP).  Government of India (GoI) holds residual shares post-privatizetion.

ZIL: Zuari Industries Ltd, initially incorporated as Zuari Agro Chemicals Ltd. in 1967, is a member of the US$2.5 billion K.K. Birla Group, one of India's most well-respected business houses. Started as a partnership with the US Steel Corporation, the company now has four manufacturing facilities in Goa, which provide the neighboring markets with urea, DAP and NPK fertilizers. ZIL has now diversified into several other areas, including cement, hybrid seeds, engineering consultancy, financial services and oil tanking. ZIL is publicly listed and has a market capitalization of over US$400 million.

OCP: OCP was founded in 1920 and is based in Casablanca, Morocco. The OCP Group engages in mining, processing, exporting, and marketing phosphates. The company produces phosphate rock, phosphate derivatives, such as basic and purified phosphoric acid and phosphatic fertilizers.

Company Name: VISHWA INFRASTRUCTURES AND SERVICES PRIVATE LIMITED
Project Description:
Vishwa Infrastructures and Services Pvt. Ltd. ('Vishwa' or 'Company') was founded in 1992 by a group of technocrats with a focus to execute infrastructure projects. Vishwa is recognised as a turnkey contractor involved in developing integrated water supply and waste water projects which include:
Laying of water and waste water pipeline networks
Construction of water and sewage treatment plants
Construction of pumping stations
Management of NRW Projects
Construction of allied infrastructure including reservoirs, civil and electrical works projects

Vishwa has a team of about 600 employees with an experienced execution team with in-house design capabilities.  It has successfully manufactured and laid pipelines with aggregate length of over 1000 kms for various water supply and waste water projects. It has constructed water treatment plants (WTPs) ranging from 6 MLD to 84 MLD, and sewage treatment plants (STPs) with capacities ranging from 6 MLD to 60 MLD. Vishwa was recently awarded two water/wastewater projects to be executed on a PPP basis:

Khandwa Project: The Khandwa water supply project is a public-private partnership between Khandwa Municipal Corporationl (KMC) and Vishwa, under the Urban Infrastructure Development Scheme for Small and Medium Towns (UIDSSMT). The project will commence supplying 29 million L/day (MLD) to Khandwa (population 240,000) for domestic consumption, increasing to 43 MLD by the end of the concession period (2034), meeting the current shortfall by almost doubling the volume of water currently supplied. Under this build-own-operate-transfer (BOOT) scheme Vishwa has a 25 year concession period (2 years construction, 23 years operation and maintenance). The project will pump water through an intake well on the Chhotitave River, a backwater of the Indira Sagar Reservoir, to the adjacent water treatment plant (WTP). The WTP (2.7 ha site) will treat water then pump it to Khandwa via a 50 km long 800 mm reinforced pipeline. The pipeline will discharge into a 1,222 m3 Ground Level Master Balancing Reservoir (GLMBR), from where it will be pumped to nine separate overhead tanks. Water will then be gravity fed to the township via a network of distribution pipelines. The project includes the laying of 60 km of poly distribution pipeline through the streets of Khandwa. Project construction commenced in 2010. The Project is being executed by Vishwa Utilities Private Limited ('VUPL') which is 89% held by Vishwa.

Kolhapur Project: The Kolhapur STP is a long term public-private partnership concession between Kolhapur Municipal Corporation, Kolhapur, Maharashtra and Vishwa. The project will service apart from new STP of 7 area of Kolhapur and will have a sewage treatment capacity of 76 million L/day (MLD), the project involves construction of allied works such as new sewage pumping stations and new rising mains at Bapat Camp, Line Bazaar and Jayant Nallah, pipe laying for discharge into the Panchganga river and other miscellaneous civil works. Under this design, finance, construct, operate and maintenance scheme Vishwa has a 15 year concession period (2 years construction, 13 years operation and maintenance). Sewage will be pumped to the STP by the new pumping stations. The STP is a replacement of the existing STP operated by the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation and is located within the existing compound. The STP will utilise Sequential Batch Reactory (SBR) technology to treat the wastewater. Treated wastewater discharged from the site will either be utilised for industrial or agricultural consumption and/or discharged into the Panchganga river. The remaining organic residue will be applied to land as a fertiliser in an approved manner. Project construction commenced in early 2011.
Impact:
a) Improve sanitation and better water services to about 450,000 people in two mid-tier towns in India
b) Generate employment both during construction and operation
c) Demonstration Effect- Successful execution of the Project will help provide push for further replication of PPP based water infrastructure creation in the country
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed investment in the Company and the Project is a Category B project because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Potential impacts in construction activities besides being mitigable are likely to be limited to project site; short term; and likely to have limited impact on environmentally sensitive areas. Further, it is possible to readily design and implement engineering and management measures to mitigate adverse impacts during construction and operations. The Company will manage its environmental and social performance in accordance with applicable local laws and regulations, including IFCs Performance Standards on Social and Environmental Sustainability. Vishwas water and waste water projects deliver significant environmental and community health benefits. The Khandwa water supply project will provide a more reliable water supply in terms of both volume and quality, thereby reducing the incidence of waterborne disease. The Kolhapur STP will provide additional sewage treatment capacity, safely treating sanitary effluent that  currently poses a major health hazard.  Vishwa will formalize and ISO certify a Corporate EMS as part of the project.  Further details on the potential environmental and social impacts, corresponding mitigation measures, and guidance on how and where information about the Project can be obtained are provided in the IFC Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) .

Vishwa was founded in 1992 by Yerra Srinivas as a firm focused on construction related to water and water services. Over the years, it has transformed itself into an integrated water EPC player. Key Founders of the Company are Mr. Yerra Srinivas; Mr. M.L Sridhar Reddy; Mr. J. Vikram and Mr. K. Vijay Kumar. Founders together hold about 53.40% stake in the Company. Out of the balance 35.60% is held by Axis PE and 11% by NEA.

VUPL is held 89% by VISPL and balance 11% by Electrosteel Castings, Kolkata India.

The proposed IFC investment is an A loan of about $5 million for IFC's own account split across Vishwa and VUPL.

Project Description: The project involves an investment in an early stage company in the cleantech sector, Sunpreme Ltd. ('Sunpreme' or the 'Company').  The Company is still at the commercialization stage of development, and has no sales to date.  It has R&D facilities in China and Sunnyvale, CA, and plans to acquire capital equipment to scale up its R&D facilities, with potential to begin manufacturing silicon-based solar cells (6' to 8' wafers) in Jiaxing, China, with the goal of reaching 30MW in initial production capacity.  It is also considering new joint venture agreements that would possibly lead to new manufacturing lines in Brazil and similarly in India.
Review Scope: The review of this project consisted of a visit by IFC staff to the project site, to meet with and interview Sunpreme management and to have a first-hand look at operational activities.  IFC staff also appraised technical, environmental and social information submitted by Sunpreme.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project involves the establishment and operation of leased facilities for research, development, and design, and potential production of photovoltaic solar panels.  The nature of the Company's operations is such that no major adverse environmental or social impacts are expected to result from the Project, and that it will be possible to avoid or mitigate any limited adverse impacts that might result.  As a result, it has been classified as a Category B project according to IFC's Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.

Project Description:
Sunpreme Ltd. (the 'Company') is a global photovoltaic (PV) solar start-up company, based in Cayman Islands, engaged in the business of developing and commercializing its proprietary SmartSilicon® based solar cells to satisfy growing global needs for low-cost, high efficiency clean energy. 

The Company is raising up to $60 million to scale up manufacturing and R&D facilities globally, including China, other parts of Asia and Latin America.  Initially, the Company will be setting up a 30MW initial production capacity in Jiaxing, China, and build additional production facilities in other markets globally (the 'Project'). The financing will be deployed towards capital equipment expansion, building out R&D capacity, working capital and set up facilities and partnership agreements in key markets in Latin America, Asia and other geographies.
Impact: The Project will contribute to the transfer of technologies in the solar sectors to key emerging markets such as Latin America, Sub-Saharan Africa, China and India by combining the high technology innovation in the Company's US facilities, with the lower manufacturing base and target user markets in developing countries.  By supporting a technology innovator that focuses on reducing cost/watt at the module level and supplying modules to the large manufacturers, the Project will support the solar sector in its aim to reduce its cost to close to grid parity levels in key markets. In addition, the Company's green technology process sequence avoids toxic and/or exotic materials, aiming to eliminate the paradox of exporting clean technology globally while polluting the environment locally.
Environmental Social Issues: The key environmental and social issues associated with the Project are opportunities for greenhouse gas reductions, and risks in the Companys environmental and social management system, health and safety for workers and local communities, hazardous materials management, and emissions to air, water, and substrate.  This has been classified as a Category B project according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.  As a condition of IFC''s investment, Sunpreme will commit to developing and implementing a Social and Environmental Management System for ensuring that all relevant social and environmental risks and impacts are managed as appropriate.  Specific information about how risks, impacts and opportunities will be addressed by Sunpreme is summarized in the Environmental and Social Review Summary for the Project.
Sponsor:
The Company was founded by Dr. Ashok Sinha, a former Senior Vice President at Applied Materials (NAS:AMAT). Dr. Sinha, two co-founders and key employees own approximately 60% of the Company. The Company's leadership team is comprised of veterans from the semiconductor and silicon development industries.

Owning an approximate 40% currently, the existing investors Capricorn LLC ('Capricorn') and China Environment Fund III ('CEF'), are committing to invest additional monies in this round as well. Capricorn is a global investment group which focuses on early stage companies in the clean technologies sector. CEF is an IFC investee fund and active investor in the clean technologies space.
Cost Nature:
The Project cost amounts to approximately $60 million, including capital expenditures for fully integrated production facilities, installation and plant upgrades, pre-operational expenses and working capital, covering the Company's financial requirements till the end of 2012. IFC is considering to invest up to 
$25 million.

Project Description:
Founded in 1691 in Japan, Sumitomo Forestry Co, Ltd. ('SFC' or the 'Sponsor') is one of the most experienced companies in sustainable forest and plantation management, wood products and wood-based housing sectors.  SFC is planning to invest in a USD 93 million project to establish a greenfield particleboard plant with an annual capacity of 250,000 m3 near Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam (the 'Project'). 

The Project will increase Vietnam's particleboard production capacity, responding to the growth outlook of Vietnam's furniture and wood processing sector and current limited particleboard production capacity available in Vietnam.
Impact:
(i) Climate Change Mitigation: Through the Project, IFC will support positive climate change impact linked to sourcing of waste wood and use of bio-mass based power plant.
(ii) Employment: The Project will generate about 200 jobs at the Project site and also indirect employment through linkages to farmers who will supply part of the wood raw materials to the Project.  In the future, the Company is considering supporting farmers in sustainable plantation by working with local government agencies and research institutes and providing advice and seedlings.  
(iii) Development of Local Industry: The Project will support the development of local wood processing industry by establishing the first particleboard facility in Vietnam. From construction phase to operational stage, SFC will bring in its first class expertise and quality management system, which is expected to have demonstration effect to the local industry.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been categorized as a B project in accordance with IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures. The proposed project involves the development of a wood panel manufacturing and biomass generation facility using wood fiber from managed agriculture landscapes and forest plantations. The facility, located in an established industrial park [in the Southern Mekong Region], is expected to have isolated impacts which can be avoided through proactive management or mitigated through proven measures. The E&S themes identified during appraisal included: expansion of the management program to meet the sponsors corporate mandates for wood traceability and lifecycle assessment; labor and working conditions of wood assemblers; management of manufacturing wastes and hazardous materials; adaptation of processing and feedstock to climate change; and stimulation of vigorous replanting of forest/fruit trees through extension services.  During appraisal it was observed that the Company has substantial environmental, health and safety and quality assurance management systems and capacity which provided material demonstration of its commitment to corporate social responsibility, legal obligations, and sustainable natural resources management.  The Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) and Action Plan (ESAP) will characterize the results of the appraisal and the agreed upon measures to advance the Companys environmental and social performance.
Sponsor:
The new particleboard plant will be owned and operated by Vina Eco Board Co., Ltd. ('VECO' or the 'Company').  VECO was established in May 2010 by SFC and Sumitomo Forestry (Singapore) Ltd., SFC's wholly owned subsidiary in Singapore.   

Incorporated in 1947, SFC is a publicly listed company on the first section of Tokyo Stock Exchange and Osaka Securities Exchange. SFC's shares are widely held by institutional investors, financial institutions as well as individual investors.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated to be approximately USD93 million, and SFC plans to finance the Project with 50% in long term debt and 50% in equity. The proposed IFC investment is an equity investment of up to USD9 million for up to 20% of VECO's share capital.

Project Description: CJSC Credit Europe Bank Ltd (CEB) is a mid-size Moscow-based bank which operates in Russia since 1997. Initially set up as a corporate bank, CEB has gradually expanded its activities to consumer finance, retail and SME banking. As of today, CEB ranks among Russias top 50 banks with assets over $3 billion and equity in excess of $500 million. The Bank operates in 23 regions via 110 branches, 276 ATMs and 4500 point of sales, servicing about to 2.5 million retail customers, 10,000 SMEs and  900 corporate clients throughout Russia. The Project is aimed at supporting CEBs regional expansion plans and its lending activities to SMEs and consumer retail. In addition, IFCs participation in the Project will help CEB secure long-term and diversified funding, thereby enhancing IFCs role as a reliable partner in challenging times.
Impact: The Project is expected to have a demonstration impact as well as a developmental impact. The demonstration impact will be achieved by assisting a viable financial institution in accessing the syndication market and international investors in a challenging environment. IFCs support will contribute to bring additional stability and diversification to CEBs funding. On the developmental front, the Project will indirectly support the Russian SME sector, which suffers from a chronic shortage of funding options. This Project will also enable CEB to keep on growing its regional distribution channels and branch network, which in turn will generate new employment opportunities in regions where such opportunities are often limited.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Credit Europe Bank will be required to ensure compliance of the activities financed with the IFC Exclusion List, Russian environmental and social laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards, if applicable.  CES appraisal will focus on the clients portfolio risk and the Banks existing capacity to manage environmental and social risks.  In addition, due diligence will be carried out on the Banks HR policies and practices to determine compliance with IFCs Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions, and if needed to provide recommendations to address any gaps.   Final applicable requirements will be determined once IFC reviews the clients portfolio, labor standards, and existing E&S capacity.  The client will be required to develop a Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS), nominate staff responsible for SEMS implementation, and submit Annual Environmental Performance Reports (AEPRs) to IFC.
Sponsor: CEB is a subsidiary of Credit Europe Bank NV, which is registered and operates as a universal bank in the Netherlands. The latter is a subsidiary of Credit Europe Group NV, which is controlled by FIBA Holding AS, one of Turkeys largest private financial conglomerates with estimated total assets exceeding $15 billion. The ultimate beneficiary is Mr. Husnu Ozyegin, who owns 99.9% of FIBA Holding AS.
Cost Nature: The Project will consist of an IFC A Loan and a syndicated B Loan for a combined amount of up to $100 million; B Loan may  be increased in case of oversubscription from syndication participants. The funds will be used to expand CEBs loan portfolio, especially in the regions, and to grow its SME and retail loan portfolios. The EBRD may be joining the Project.

Project Description: Sound Global is a leading water/wastewater equipment, infrastructure, EPC and operations services provider for municipal and industrial clients in China. The Company has secured a number of Build-Operate-Transfer (BOT) concessions in China for municipal wastewater treatment facilities, and is looking to expand its business outside of China, including India, Vietnam and Saudi Arabia. IFC made a pre-IPO equity investment of US$10 million in August 2006 (Project No. 25046) to support the Company's core subsidiary in China, Beijing Sound Environmental Engineering Co. (Beijing Sound), as well as to assist Sound Global's initial public offering ('IPO') on the Singapore Stock Exchange ('SGX').  In September 2010, the company completed dual listing in Hong Kong in order to attract wider range of investors. IFC proposes aggregate financing support to Sound Global for four BOT projects of up to $36 million through an A loan. Proceeds from the proposed IFC financing will be used to support BOT concessions in the following project companies: Yantai Bihai Water Ltd., Yantai, Shandong Province; Xian Weiqing Water Company Ltd., Xi'an City, Shaanxi Province; Hongze Zeqing Water Company Ltd., Hongze County, Jiangsu Province; and Hanzhong Hanyuan Water Company Ltd., Yang County, Shaanxi Province.
Review Scope: The proposed investment is IFC's third corporate investment in the Sound Global Group. The scope of this review is an update to IFC's previous appraisal of the Company's operations. Additional to reviewing environmental, social, health and safety performance of the Company,  the scope of due diligence included visits to the Company's corporate offices, where meetings and interviews with key staff (business development, construction and operations, human resources, environmental, social, health and safety) were conducted, and numerous, relevant internal documents and records reviewed. Sound Global reports to IFC on an annual basis regarding the ongoing management of its environmental, social, and health and safety (ESHS) performance.  IFC's review of the Company's ESHS performance has confirmed that the Company is meeting the requirements of the original investment agreement and continues to demonstrate that its activities comply with applicable PRC laws and regulations, and IFC/World Bank requirements.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a repeat investment in one of China's leading equipment, infrastructure, EPC and operations services provider for the municipal and industrial water and wastewater market. IFC's proposed additional investment will result in no material change to Sound Global's operations. IFC's ongoing review and supervision of its existing investments in Sound Global has shown that the company continues to meet its ESHS compliance obligations, including relevant IFC Performance Standards and IFC/World Bank Group guidelines. The project has been classified as a Category B in light of the fact that the Company has already adopted IFC Performance Standards as part of its business requirements, and continues to implement these in its operations, mitigation measures where needed, and any adverse impacts are not expected to be diverse or irreversible and will be limited to project sit,. The current Environmental and Social Risk Rating (ESRR) for the project is B-2Average.

Project Description: Vina Eco Board ('VECO' or 'the Company') is a greenfield particleboard manufacturing facility being established in Long An Province through a joint venture between Japan's Sumitomo Forestry Co., Ltd. ('SFC' or 'the Sponsor') and Sumitomo Forestry (Singapore) Ltd. The proposed project is located on a 20 hectare parcel within the 1,007 ha Phu An Thanh Industrial Park adjacent to the Vam Co Dong River approximately 30 km from Ho Chi Minh City. The project includes an integrated particleboard line capable of producing 250,000m3 of particleboard from low value wood and development of an 11 MW biomass power plant. The manufacturing lines, biomass generation, and wood procurement systems are based on other SFC plants, including a comparable facility in Semarang Indonesia (PT. Rimba Partikel Indonesia: www.rpi.co.id) which was an earlier IFC investment and has been now operating for more than 20 years. VECO construction began in August2010 and is expected to be completed in November 2011. After production trials, the plant will begin full operations in March 2012 with the biomass power plant becoming operational in January 2013. The direct environmental and social (E&S) issues of the particleboard manufacturing facility are considered as are the indirect issues associated with the provisioning of wood fiber.
Review Scope:
During appraisal Vina Eco Board ('the Company') was assessed against IFC's Performance Standards, local regulatory requirements and applicable requirements of the World Bank Group (WBG), and IFC's General Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines and EHS Guidelines to Board and Particle-Based Products and Sawmilling and Manufactured Wood Products.  IFC reviewed the Company's current environment and social management systems and the likely impacts associated with the proposed project.  Review included a multi-day site visit to the Company's facilities currently under construction in Long An Province Vietnam. Observations at the plant site and of wood production and collection operations were supplemented by interviews with Provincial Government officials, Forestry and Agriculture Department (DARD) principals, Horticulture Research Institute (SOFRI) staff, and Industrial Park management authorities. The team also reviewed applicable environmental regulations and permitting procedures for wood processing facilities, harvesting, and associated logistics.  The review relied on documents and reports made available by the Company and interviews with key management personnel, including those responsible for as aspects of particleboard manufacturing and forestry operations. Key documents reviewed, some of which are on-line:

Environmental Impact Assessment of Veco Eco Board Plant. 2010. Green World Environmental technology Corp. Ho Chi Minh City
Environmental and Social Report  Sumitomo Forestry Company. 2011. http://sfc.jp/english/information/kankyo/2010/index.html
Statutes of Environmental Protection in Phu An Thanh Industrial Park. 2010. 
Assessment of water quality in the Lower Mekong Basin. MRC Tech Rpt No. 19. 2008. Mekong River Commission http://www.mrcmekong.org/
The Greater Mekong and climate change: biodiversity, ecosystem services and development at risk. 2009. WWF Regional Program

Through these activities, an assessment was made of the effectiveness of the Company's environmental and social management system for its proposed capital and operational expenditures and its ability to ensure and monitor compliance with applicable laws and regulatory requirements, IFC's Performance Standards, and internationally-recognized wood manufacturing and forest management practices during operations.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project has been categorized as a 'B' project in accordance with IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedures. The facility, under construction in an established industrial park adjacent to Ho Chi Minh City, is expected to have isolated operating impacts which can be avoided through proactive management or mitigated through proven measures. The key E&S issues reviewed during appraisal included the following:  the E&S management program and the sponsor's corporate commitments to  wood traceability and lifecycle assessment; labor and working conditions of construction workers and future wood suppliers; management of construction and operating air emissions and wastewater management; and replanting of forest/fruit trees through government and private extension services. During appraisal, it was observed that the sponsor has substantial environmental, health and safety and quality assurance management systems and internal technical capacity which provided material demonstration of its commitment to sustainability, including social responsibility, adherence to legal obligations, and sustainable natural resources management. The Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) and Action Plan (ESAP) characterize the results of the appraisal and the agreed upon measures to advance the Company's environmental and social performance.
Sector: FC - Wood Panels and Engineered Wood Products

Project Description:
China's wastewater sector is experiencing unprecedented growth, as major cities seek to meet national wastewater treatment standards. In order to raise funds and mobilize private sector expertise to meet the huge investment demands effectively, the Chinese government has sought private sector participation in the sector from the early part of this decade. In this context, the Build-Operate-Transfer (BOT) has become an important approach in bringing in much needed investment into the wastewater sector.

Sound Global Ltd. (Sound Global) provides water and wastewater treatment solutions in China. It started its wastewater business in late 2008 and since then, it has won several BOT concessions with total treatment capacity of 789,400 tons/day. The proposed project will provide financing support to the BOT projects.
Impact:
The project would have high development impact through IFC support of a growing private sector company in the following aspects:
i)   Support a key private sector investor who is playing a meaningful role to address water shortage and environment pollution issues;   
ii)  Support a private sector investor to expand business in the Frontier regions of China as 2 out of the 4 projects are located in one of the western provinces; and 
iii)  Help Sound Global free up cash for international business development and potential South-South cooperation opportunities.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects. Epure has provided information on its current practices and policies that seek to address environmental and social risks and impacts to ensure that the proposed project complies with or, will upon implementation of measures agreed upon as part of IFCs Investment documents, comply with host country laws and regulations and IFC''s Performance Standards (PS). The principal environmental and social risks identified for the project which will require additional mitigation measures by Epure include implementation of a comprehensive environmental and social management system, oversight of subcontracted labor, occupational health and safety, emissions to the environment, emergency response and community engagement. Going forward, as a condition of disbursement, the Company has adopted IFC environmental and social Performance Standards as part of the applicable legal and other requirements in its management system, including formal procedures for environmental and social screening of business opportunities and new projects into its marketing strategy, commercial planning, and project bidding processes. Project Description:
Med Life SA ('MedLife' or the 'Company') is a leading player in the Romanian private health care market.  It provides integrated medical services for corporate clients and individuals and operates a 120-bed private hospital in Romania (Life Memorial Hospital), 9 hyperclinics (large clinics providing an extensive range of high quality clinical services), 7 laboratories, 4 medical centers, and a pharmaceutical retail chain. MedLife also has one of the largest subscriber base in the Romanian corporate market.

MedLife is an existing IFC client and plans to invest up to approximately EUR 52 million in 2011-2015 to expand operations in Romania: (i) build new hospitals and hyperclinics in Bucharest and cities across Romania; (ii) develop laboratories; and (iii) target acquisitions of smaller outpatient clinics, laboratories and hospitals.

IFC made its first project with MedLife in 2006 and has considered this third investment given MedLife's commitment and good performance in social and environmental sustainability.
Review Scope: IFC's review of this project consisted of reviewing Environmental and Social's Annual Monitoring Reports from its previous investments from IFC, evaluating additional documentation provided by Medlife,  interviews with the senior management and technical team including quality, environment, occupational health and safety systems standardization, infection control, human resources, engineering and administrative management and architectural bureau commissioned for new developments. Site visits were performed to MedLife Memorial Hospital and MedLab laboratory in Grivita and to two operational hyperclinics as well as to the construction sites of current expansions in Bucharest, including an orthopedic and a pediatric hospital with a capacity of 50 beds and 120 beds respectively).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Key environmental and social issues for this project taken into account during appraisal include site selection, land acquisition and permitting; corporate environmental and social management systems, including management of construction and operation of the hospitals/clinics, management of solid and liquid waste, in particular hazardous medical wastes and water quality; air emissions control, occupational health and safety activities, prevention of nosocomial diseases; life and fire safety and consideration of seismic risks within the context of the protection of community health and safety. The appraisal concluded that any impacts will be limited, site-specific and can be addressed by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Therefore, this is a Category B project according to IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedures.

Project Description: United Water Corporation ('the Company' or 'United Water') is a holding company registered in the Cayman Islands that has invested in five water utilities and waste water treatment plants in China. The plants include  United Water (Suqian) Co. Ltd. in Jiangsu Province, United Water (Xianning) Co. Ltd. and United Yulong Water (Suizhou) Co. Ltd. in Hubei Province, Tongxiang Sanho Water Co. Ltd. in Zhejiang Province and Tuo Ke Tuo United Water Co. Ltd. in Inner Mongolia. The total contracted capacity of the plants is about 640,000 metric tons per day serving a total population of about 1.3 million residential users with potable water and 236 industrial clients with industrial wastewater treatment services in two industrial parks. United Water is seeking financing from IFC of US$20 million consisting of a loan of up to US$16 million and preferred shares of subscription of up to US$4 million. Proceeds from IFC financing will be used solely for projects in China.
Review Scope: The scope of review of the United Water project included visits to the Company's corporate offices, where meetings and interviews with key staff (business development, construction and operations, human resources, environmental, social, health and safety) were conducted, and numerous, relevant internal documents and records surrounding United Water's management capacity to provide adequate oversight of its environmental, social, health and safety performance in conducting its water and wastewater treatment businesses were discussed. The review relied on documents and reports made available by United Water, IFC technical consultant's report on sub projects, and interviews conducted by IFC staff during their site visits. The IFC team visited operational water and wastewater treatment facilities and also met with local city government officials where the performance of the projects proposed for IFC financing were discussed.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFC's Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because it may create a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria. Key environmental, health and safety, human resources and social issues that were reviewed included the following: environmental and social management system; quality and sustainability of water resources; emissions to the environment  air, water and subsurface; solid, and hazardous waste and materials management, including transportation; life and fire safety; community and occupational health and safety; energy use and efficiency; community engagement; cultural heritage and land acquisition. Water treatment, transmission and distribution services provided by United Water help in improving access to safe drinking water; and wastewater treatment services provided enhances environmental protection and public health through treatment before discharge.

Project Description:
The proposed Project involves two green-field grid-tied solar photovoltaic (PV) power plants located in Nakornratchasima and Loei provinces of Thailand (the 'Project') - namely, Solar Power (Korat 2) Company Limited ('SPKR2)') and Solar Power (Loei 1) Company Limited ('SPLO1') (together the 'Companies'). Both Companies are subsidiaries of SPC, which also owns the SPKR1 Solar PV Plant (previous IFC investment) located adjacent to proposed SPKR2 project site, which has been in operation since April 2010.

SPC was established in 1996 with the sole focus of developing grid-connected solar power projects. SPC will be both the engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) and also the operation, maintenance and monitoring (O&MM) contractor for each of the two Companies. 

Each of the Companies is designed to produce 6 MWp using Polycrystalline silicon PV modules and Inverters. The Companies will sell power to Provincial Electricity Authority ('PEA')  a state owned power distribution company under Thailand's Very Small Power Producer renewable energy program.

The SPKR2 project site is located in Don Chomphu sub-district of Non Sung district in Nakhonratchasima province.  The total area required for this project is approximately 22 hectares.  The SPLO1 project site is in Ban Nong Nor sub-district, Wang Saphung district of Loei province.  The area required for this project is approximately 14.7 hectares. Both the sites have high levels of solar irradiation, so are suitable for PV installations, and have easy access to transmission lines and a main highway along their site boundaries.
Review Scope:
IFC's review of this investment considered Solar Power Company Limited's ('SPC' or the 'Sponsor') social, environmental, health and safety management systems; the identification and mitigation of social and environmental impacts on account of its proposed solar power projects; land acquisition for the proposed projects; community consultation and engagement; and labor working conditions including occupational health and safety. 

Accordingly, the review consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information submitted by the Sponsor including: an Environmental Impact and Safety Assessment ('ESA') report for proposed projects in Korat and Loei, public hearing records, technical due diligence report for both the projects by independent engineer, applicable labor regulations and land purchase related data. The appraisal team also interviewed SPC's team in-charge of the proposed solar farms development. 

This is a repeat investment by IFC in the Company. The Environmental Social Review Summary (ESRS) for the previous IFC investment viz. Solar Power (Korat 1) Company Limited, (Project no. 28842), disclosed in March 2010, is available at:  
http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/2bc34f011b50ff6e85256a550073ff1c/81f9ccecbb88457a8525770b006a3bd6?opendocument. 

This review therefore, builds upon the previously disclosed ESRS.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
This is a Category B project because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. 

The key environmental and social aspects in the Project are the identification and mitigation of social and environmental impacts of the Companies; social, environmental, health and safety management systems; labor working conditions during construction and operation; pollution prevention and abatement during construction and operation; community health, safety and security;  and community consultation and engagement. 

Potential E&S impacts are mainly expected to be during the construction phase. These, besides being mitigable are likely to be limited to project sites; short term; and will likely not have any impact on environmentally sensitive areas. Further, it is possible to readily design and implement engineering and management measures to mitigate adverse impacts during construction and operations. 

SPC will manage its environmental and social performance in accordance with applicable local laws and regulations and international standards, including IFC's Performance Standards on Social and Environmental Sustainability.

Project Description:
Newcom Group ('NCG' or the 'Group'), is one of the largest investment holding conglomerates in Mongolia, with investments in the telecommunications, civil aviation, energy, and real estate sectors. NCG's flagship subsidiary company, Mobicom Corporation, is the largest wireless service provider in Mongolia, with more than one million subscribers. NCG also enjoys a leadership position with Eznis, the largest private airline in Mongolia that operates flights to 14 domestic destinations and to Hailar, China and Ulan-Ude, Russia. In the renewable energy sector, NCG has already started developing the first wind power plant in Mongolia. With over 12 investments and portfolio companies, Newcom Group employs around 2,000 people. NCG has entered into a joint-venture agreement with other Mongolian partners to construct a general hospital in UlaanBaatar.

The proposed project is to support NCG's expansion by providing loan financing for the capital expenditure program of its subsidiary and affiliate companies over the next few years. NCG's contemplated expansions include a 50 MW wind power project, a joint-venture out-patient hospital with four other Mongolian partners, a residential project in the outskirts of UlaanBaatar, as well as further investments in the group's commercial airline and property management businesses.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The Project has been categorized as Category B according to IFC's Environmental and Social (E&S) Review Procedure because it may create a limited number of specific adverse environmental and social impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.
