Company Name: Red Sea Energy Private Shareholding Company
Project Description:
IFC is considering an equity investment of up to US$ 15 million to acquire a minority stake in ENARA, owner of 51% of the Central Electricity Generating Company ('CEGCO'), Jordan's largest power generation company with an installed capacity of 1,500 MW. CEGCO's power plants currently sell power to NEPCO, the government owned transmission company and single buyer under long-term power purchase agreements ('PPAs'). IFC would invest alongside Acwa Power International ('ACWA Power'), one of the MENA region's premier power developers. 

In addition to running CEGCO's plants in accordance with the existing PPAs, ACWA Power's future plans also contemplate upgrading of existing sites and assets to add capacity at costs that are below the cost of greenfield capacity additions and/or extending the terms of the existing PPAs for certain plants based on technical and environmental feasibility.

CEGCO's existing thermal power plants include (i) Aqaba Thermal Power Station (Total 656MW, 130MW x 5 steam units plus 6MW hydro, Phase 1 started operation in 1985 & Phase 2 in 1996, Heavy Fuel Oil (HFO)-fired, but converted to run on imported gas from Egypt), (ii) Hussein Thermal Power Station (Total 363MW, 33MW x 3 HFO-fired steam units, 66MW x 4 HFO-fired steam untis, started operation in 1976/1977/1984), (iii) Rehab Power Plant (Total 357MW, 30MW x 2 gas-fired simple cycle gas turbine, plus 297MW gas-fired combined cycle gas turbine, started operation in 1994-2005), (iv) Risha Power Plant (Total 150MW, 30MW x 5 gas-fired simple cycle gas turbines, started operation in 1989-2005), (v) Marka Power Plant (Total 80MW, 20MW x 4 LFO-fired simple cycle gas turbines, started operation in 1978-1980), (vi) Amman South (Total 30MW x 1 LFO-fired simple cycle gas turbines, started operation in 1995), (vii) Karak (Total 20MW, LFO-fired simple cycle gas turbine, started operation in 1982).

In addition, CEGO has two wind power plants (i) Ibrahimiya Wind Power Plant (Total 0.32MW, 0.08MW x 4 wind turbines), and (ii) Hofa Wind Power Plant (Total 1.125MW, 0.225MW x 5 wind turbines).

ACWA Power is reviewing the upgrading and capacity addition to improve CEGCO's overall energy efficiency, environmental performance and power supply security.  Details are still to be developed.  ACWA Power will implement further upgrading and capacity addition in accordance with the agreed Environmental and Social Action Plan and IFC Performance Standards.
Review Scope:
Documents reviewed:

- CDM (Clean Development Mechanism) Project Design Document (PDD)  Fuel Switching Project of the Aqaba Thermal Power Station (ATPS), PDD Version No. 6, 15th August 2008

- ACWA Power International, Annual Report, Section on Corporate Responsbility, 2009
- Air emissions monitoring summary reports prepared by CEGCO for 2008, 2009 and 2010

Field visits in March 2011 to Aqaba Thermal Power Station (Total 656MW, 130MW x 5 steam units plus 6MW hydro), (ii) Hussein Thermal Power Station (Total 363MW, 33MW x 3 HFO-fired steam units, 66MW x 4 HFO-fired steam units), (iii) Rehab Power Plant (Total 357MW, 30MW x 2 gas-fired simple cycle gas turbine, plus 297MW gas-fired combined cycle gas turbine), (v) Marka Power Plant (Total 80MW, 20MW x 4 LFO-fired simple cycle gas turbines), and (vi) Amman South (Total 30MW x 1 LFO-fired simple cycle gas turbines).

Meetings in March 2011 with officers in charge of environmental, health and safety issues of both CEGCO and ACWA Power, and a representative from 5 Capitals (an environmental consulting firm who conducted environmental due diligence of CEGCO for ACWA Power).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: ACWA Power plans to operate CEGCO's thermal power plants in accordance with the existing PPAs and contemplates to upgrade existing sites and assets to add capacity, with limited environmental or social impacts.  ACWA Power will help improve the environmental and social (E&S) performance of CEGCO in various areas including its management system, and environmental, health and safety performance of existing thermal power plants.  Because of these, this investment was categorized as B.

Project Description: IFC has recently made an equity investment of about $45 million in Magma Fincorp Limited (Magma or the Company). Magma is a medium sized NBFC in India, headquartered at Kolkata, with a presence in 21 Indian states and a focus on the rural and semi-urban markets. The Company provides a wide suite of financing against - commercial vehicles (CV), construction equipments (CE), tractors, cars and multi-utility vehicles and also provides loans to small and medium enterprises (SME)  to address the needs of the financially underserved markets in rural and semi-urban India. The Company has invested significantly in a large branch network, efficient service and customer relationship management resulting in superior origination capacity in the market enabling sustained business growth. Magma is a listed entity with market capitalization of INR9.47 billion ($210 million) as on June 30, 2011. Magma has assets under management (AUM) of $2.1 billion as on March 31, 2007, and has shown consistent growth over the last 20 years. Magma now plans to leverage this financial infrastructure to drive the next phase of growth, by increasing its presence in rural and semi-urban areas, expanding within the low income states (LIS), as well as expanding its product line. Magma has raised fresh capital of about $100 million through new equity issuance. The infusion will enable Magma to provide for sufficient capital to address the following: (i) further expansion in rural, semi-urban areas with a focus on LIS; (ii) grow the new product portfolio (used CVs, tractors and SME); and (iii) meet capital adequacy requirement.  Note on Disclosure: This is a revised SPI published with the disclosure of the project companys name and other details, which were not disclosed in the earlier SPI released on May 16, 2011 because of risk of impacting market conditions. It is done pursuant to paragraph 9 (d) of IFCs Policy on Disclosure of Information, which requires a revised SPI to be published containing all standard SPI information after the disbursement of the proposed IFC investment (or earlier), when the information pending disclosure is no longer commercially sensitive.
Impact: IFC''s support to the NBFC will enable the Company to provide increased access to finance for the micro, small and medium entrepreneurs, who are mainly in the unorganized sector and do not have good access to the banking sector.Focus on rural and semi-urban areas and low income states: The Company''s growth strategy is focused on the rural and semi-urban areas. The Company is expected to increase its rural presence by deepening its existing branch network through the hub and spoke model.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Magma has developed a satisfactory Environmental and Social Management System (SEMS) to ensure the financing of commercial vehicles (CV), construction equipment (CE), and tractors, cars and multi-utility vehicles (MUVs) is in compliance with the applicable performance requirements of the IFC FI Exclusion List and the applicable Indian social and environmental laws and regulations.  The SEMS also includes a plan to finalize the S&E risk management procedures for financing small and medium enterprises (SME).  Magma has appointed an SEMS officer and is found to be in compliance with the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions.  Magma is required to (i) adhere to the plan to finalize the SEMS regarding the SME financing, (ii) develop a S&E risk management policy and procedure for its insurance business before it starts operation, and (iii) submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: Magma (formerly Magma Leasing Limited) was incorporated in 1988 and commenced operations in 1989. It was founded by Mr. Mayank Poddar and Mr. Sanjay Chamria. It is registered with the RBI as NBFC-ND (non-deposit taking NBFC). The Company has expanded through organic growth and acquisitions of companies operating in similar businesses. The Company entered into retail financing business for vehicles and construction equipment in 1996. During 2001-2002, Consortium Finance Ltd. was amalgamated with the Company, which resulted into Magma gaining access to the northern market for CVs. To further strengthen its business, Magma merged with Shrachi Infrastructure Finance Ltd., a retail NBFC with a strong presence in south India, to create Magma Shrachi Finance Ltd. On August 2008, it was renamed as Magma Fincorp Ltd. Magma is one of the few NBFCs to offer both CV as well as CE financing. Before the fresh capital infusion, the major shareholders in Magma included the Sponsors (as described below) with a 41.7 percent stake, foreign institutional investors with 42.3 percent stake, domestic institutional investors with 7.7 percent share holding and the balance 8.3 percent being held by the public.  The main Sponsors are: Mr. Sanjay Chamria, a chartered accountant, is one of the co- founders. He is the CEO and is responsible for policy, business strategy, planning and execution. Mr. Mayank Poddar is the co-founder and chairman of the Company. He is a commerce graduate and first generation entrepreneur. He contributes to policy formulation and provides overall guidance and support to the board and the management team.

Zend Mauritius has simultaneously subscribed to $55 million in common equity shares for an equity stake of up to 14.95%.

Company Name: Red Sea Energy Private Shareholding Company
Project Description: IFC is considering an equity investment alongside International Company for Water and Power Projects (trade name ACWA Power International (ACWA Power)) to collectively acquire a 65% stake in ENARA, 51% owner of the Central Electricity Generating Company (CEGCO). CEGCO is Jordans largest power generation company with a total installed capacity of around 1,500 MW representing circa 59% of Jordans installed capacity. It owns and operates seven power plants across Jordan playing a critical role in securing Jordans electricity supply capitalizing on the assets fuel flexibility. CEGCOs power plants currently sell power to the National Electricity Power Company, government owned transmission company and single buyer under the Power Purchase Agreements (PPAs). The acquisition of the 65% stake in ENARA will be subject to several conditions precedent, as is customary in a transaction of this nature, including a consent from the Government of Jordan.In addition to running CEGCOs plants in accordance with the existing PPAs, ACWA Power plans to improve overall assets efficiency whilst extending the terms of the existing PPAs. It will further contemplate re-powering selected plants based on the technical and environmental feasibility adding capacity at a relatively lower cost than a Greenfield power plant.
Impact: The Project is expected to improve CEGCOs power plants performance, both technically and environmentally, and enhance Jordans overall power generation efficiency and possibly increase total installed capacity. This will provide the government of Jordan with a quick, easy to implement and relative cheap solution to meet the expected increase in demand over the next few years enabling it to realize considerable savings.
Environmental Social Issues: IFCs investment in ENARA together with ACWA Power will help improve the Environmental and Social (E&S) performance of CEGCO, in various areas including its management system, and environmental, health and safety performance of existing thermal power plants.  ACWA Power retained an independent environmental consulting firm to carry out a detailed environmental due diligence of CEGCOs assets. ACWA Powers technical team reviewed the due diligence results and identified the areas in need of improvement to bring CEGCOs performance to good international industry practice. An ESAP was developed during IFC''s appraisal and agreed to with ACWA Power. The ESAP includes actions to strengthen a corporate level E&S management system to improve Jordanian environmental regulation compliance, to strengthen health and safety training programs, to reduce environmental impacts and risks of existing thermal power stations (fuel storage areas, air emissions and air quality management, hazardous waste management, noise impacts).
Sponsor: Incorporated in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, ACWA Power is a privately held developer, owner and operator of power generation and desalinated water production plants throughout the GCC. Its major shareholders include A.K. Al Muhaidib Group, the Abdullah Abunayyan Group and the MADA Group for Industrial & Commercial Investment (member of Al Rajhi Group of Companies of Saudi Arabia, an existing IFC client), all well renowned and highly reputed investors. To date, ACWA Power has been involved in a total of seven IPPs and IWPPs (6 of which are operational), 6 in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and 1 in Oman, with a combined capacity of 6,485 MW and 2.32 million m3/day for a total investment in excess of US$12 billion.
Cost Nature: IFC will be contributing up to US$15 million acquiring a minority stake alongside ACWA Power in the form of common shares equity in a project company to be established in Jordan

Project Description: UniCredit Bank Srbija a.d. Beograd (UniCredit Srbija or the Bank) is among Top 5 banks operating in the Serbian banking market.  UniCredit Srbija provides full range of banking services to retail and corporate/SME clients through a network of 70 branches employing 910 people.Investment in the form of the Senior Term Loan, aims to support a long standing partner of IFC by enhancing the capacity of UniCredit Srbija to provide: (i) term funding to agribusiness sector and (ii) access to finance to lower income population for mortgage financing.
Impact: The project is expected to have a high developmental impact by: (i) supporting bank operations within agribusiness industry, an underserved segment of Serbian economy, by providing term finance for agri producers. Agribusiness is one of the few sectors in Serbia where country has current account surplus and where Serbia can develop a sustainable long term competitive position (ii) access to finance to lower income population by providing long term housing finance that is currently not available in the market, and (iii) IFC investment will help banking sector sustain its recently built trust, significantly affected by the global economic crisis.
Environmental Social Issues: This project, which consists of a senior loan to UniCredit Serbia for on lending to agribusiness sectors and mortgage operations, has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. IFC''s existing investment in UniCredit Serbia consists of a senior loan which is intended to enable the Bank to expand its loan portfolio, particularly long-term lending to SMEs, mortgage operations, and lending relating to commercial and residential real estate development. The bank applies the UniCredit Group policy to screen the loans against the IFC Exclusion List, and applicable environmental and social national laws and regulations. UniCredit Serbia''s overall E&S performance is regarded as ''average''.For this particular project, IFC''s applicable requirements will be to ensure that loans to agribusiness sectors and mortgage operations are screened against the IFC Exclusion List, applicable environmental and social national laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards, if necessary. IFC''s appraisal will focus on local adaptation and implementation of the existing UniCredit Group Policy at the bank level by developing written guidelines and procedures. This will include a) screening against IFC Performance Standards, if necessary, and agribusiness related E&S risks, and b) an exclusion list that fully incorporates IFC''s Exclusion List.
Sponsor: UniCredit Srbija is 100% owned by UniCredit Bank Austria AG member of the UniCredit Group one of the Europes leading financial groups present in 22 European markets operating 9,617 branches and employing over 160,000 people.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at EUR 55 million to be solely provided by IFC.

Project Description: Emergia Contact Center S.L. ('Emergia') is a well established Business Process Outsourcing and Contact Center outsourcing company. The company started its operations in 2005 in Spain and, to date, has  over 4,600 employees in 3 countries, as follows: Spain (2,000 employees), Colombia (1,500 employees) and Chile (1,100 employees).  The Company is in the process of ramping up its operations in Latin America over the next 3 years by expanding its capacity in Colombia by 50% during 2011 and launching two new contact centers in Peru and Nicaragua in the period 2011-2013. Emergia has requested from IFC long term funding to help it finance this expansion.
Impact:
Positive social effects of Emergia are largely tied to increased employment opportunities, particularly in smaller university towns and for women, who represent 67% of Emergia's workforce.  Employees at Emergia benefit from childcare facilities, 24-hour on site medic and other  services largely unavailable locally.

Emergia is typically an "anchor employer" in the smaller towns where it operates, employing hundreds of people and providing to many their first job.  Some of these towns suffer from chronically high unemployment rates. A rise in employment and an ascending middle class has positive spillover effect in the local economic community. It is estimated that 4 indirect jobs are created from each direct job in the contact center industry.
Environmental Social Issues: Emergia engages with landlords of existing buildings to refit them for call center and business process outsourcing services.  The company has policies and procedures in place for managing the working conditions of its employees in compliance with IFC Performance Standards.  Emergia will be required to maintain compliance with IFC Performance Standards for the duration of IFC''s investment.  In case Emergia ever decides to have any new building constructed, it will be required to submit to IFC a plan for managing environmental and social risks in such construction.  There is no present plan for such construction, so environmental and social risks are expected to be low in this project, classified as Category C according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedures.
Sponsor:
The project sponsor is Mr. Albert Olle, a reputable Spanish businessman with over 20 years of experience in the sector. Prior to Emergia, Mr. Olle successfully launched a Spanish based contact center operation called DTG which was sold in 2000 to US-based Teletech. In addition to owning Emergia, Mr. Olle is founder of Presence Technology, a software company focused on solutions for the contact center industry. Mr. Olle is a member of Barcelona's Chamber of Commerce and of the Board of Directors of the bank La Caixa (one of the largest financial institutions in Spain). 

Mr. Olle owns in excess of 90% of Emergia through Corporación Financiera Valora, an established investment firm property of Mr. Olle.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at 21 million. IFC will provide a C Loan with an income participating feature of up to 7.5 million to fund this project, with the rest of the project funds to come from internal cash generation and additional debt/ subordinated shareholder loans.

Project Description: The proposed investment of up to $40 million would support Alpha (the Company), a subsidiary of Corporacion GEO S.A.B. de C.V. (Geo or the Sponsor), in the expansion of its prefabricated construction business for affordable housing in Mexico. With this investment, Alpha expects to achieve the capacity to build 40,000 - 45,000 houses per year. Alpha has an innovative process that will allow GEO to build all the pieces of a house in a production facility and assemble them on site using modern European technology.  Alpha production facilities include a factory in Tijuana which started production in 2010 and other three factories (Zumpango, Monterrey and Jalisco) that are in the process of being built.
Impact: The development impacts of the project include: (i) increase of housing supply for low income households - this project is expected to contribute to the alleviation of the current housing deficit in Mexico, increasing the supply of affordable entry level housing by 40,000 houses a year; (ii) GEO plans to leverage part of the efficiency gains by providing a larger house (more square meters) to its clients at the same low entry price (approximately US$15,000); (iii) enhanced supply linkages - the project will increase demand for construction and building materials in the country; (iv) job creation - the new facilities are expected to create 1,500 new jobs in 2011 and additional jobs in line with the Company's growth in the future; (v) demonstration effect - the project will lead the way to improve private sector development in this segment of the housing market; (vi) Green Building- the technology adopted by ALPHA will reduce the environmental impact building materials by saving of more than 70% of the traditional waste generation and reduction of the energy use in the construction process by 18%. The prefabrication will also allow for higher levels of insulation and integration of  water and energy efficient technology in the homes. The client is interested to work with IFC's Green Building Specialist to explore these opportunities.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria as is described in the following sections.Key environmental and social issues have been identified as follows: i) Alphas management of social, environmental, and health and safety matters during production and assembly of the houses, including the management of contractors; ii) Efficient use of energy, water and resources; iii) Air emission controls; iv) Waste reduction and disposal; v) Labor and working conditions for employees and contractors; and vi) Occupational health and safety conditions including construction safety during the assembly process on the housing developments.
Sponsor: Alpha is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Corporacion GEO S.A.B. de C.V (Geo or Sponsor), a leading housing developer in Mexico and one of the largest in Latin America. Geo is a fully integrated and highly diversified homebuilder engaged in all aspects of design, development, construction, marketing, sales and delivery of houses mainly in the low-income segment. The Sponsor was founded in 1973 and is now present in 57 cities and 18 states, selling more than half a million homes since its inception. GEO is listed on the Mexican Stock Exchange with a market capitalization of approximately $1.4 billion as of May 13, 2011.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $150-200 million.  IFC is planning to invest up to $40 million in equity or quasi-equity.

Project Description: The Intermultiservice packaging material project is to develop in Almaty, Kazakhstan, a subsidiary of the existing AA operations in Bishkek, transforming cardboard and paper into printed corrugated cardboard packaging and utilizing waste materials from this production for the production of egg trays.  The production will be limited to corrugation and gluing of cardboard and paper into packaging materials, printing these according to client needs, and preparing the final packaging shapes. Waste materials from this production together with locally collected waste paper will be utilized in a batch slurrying process to recover fibers for use in egg tray production.
Review Scope: The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental/social and occupational health and safety (OHS) policies, plans and procedures submitted by the project sponsor and an on-site field visit of both Altyn Ajydar''s (AA) existing operations in Bishkek, Kyrgystan and the site for the proposed new corrugated cardboard packaging and egg tray production plant in Almaty, Kazakhstan, to be established as a fully owned subsidiary under the name Intermultiservice, by an IFC E&S specialist. IFC has been involved in the financing of AA in Bishkek since 2002. As part of IFC''s involvement with AA the company has implemented several Environmental and Social Action Plans, has undergone a Labor Audit by external consultants and implemented the corresponding labor practices improvement measures, and is in the process of finalizing the implementation of a specific Occupational Health and Safety Plan. The previous Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) and Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) were disclosed by IFC on May 21, 2008, and can be found using this link: Project #26690
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedures for Environmental and Social Review because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, WBGs EHS guidelines or design criteria. The following environment, occupational health and safety and social impacts of the project were analyzed:- Parent company''s management of environmental and health & safety affairs;- Parent company''s adherence to existing action plans;- Sustainable raw material supply and utility connections;- Waste generation and recycling;- Effluent treatment and discharge quality;- Air emissions; and - Employment conditions.
Sector: AG - Paper Packaging Products (Including Boxes, Cartons, etc.)

Project Description: The proposed project involves a multi-level, multi-region engagement and partnership with SunEdison LLC (the Sponsor and North Americas largest solar energy services provider) which currently has a significant pipeline of grid-tied solar PV projects (many with signed Power Purchase Agreements) in India and Thailand, and ambitions for further expansion across South & South-East Asia and Sub-Saharan Africa, as declining solar prices and improved regulatory environments create new market opportunities.   SunEdison is a wholly owned subsidiary of MEMC Electronic Materials, Inc. (MEMC), a pioneer in the design and development of wafer technologies for 50 years.IFC proposes to provide a portion of the equity financing of the as yet unnamed regional Asian/Sub-Saharan solar development business based in Singapore and with operational teams in Chennai, Bangkok and elsewhere (the Development Company) as well as a portion of the debt financing required for five grid-tied solar photovoltaic plants (1 in India and 4 in Thailand). All of the projects will be built by SunEdisons EPC Company under a fully-wrapped EPC contract which is price and date certain and provides equipment and full-plant performance warranties for the first 2 years of operation.  Beyond this the Operation and Maintenance (O&M) will be provided by SunEdison O&M Services arm which will provide plant availability warranties and module supplier will provide degradation rate warranties.  IFC is proposing to make up to 15% equity contribution to the needs of the Development Company, equivalent to approximately US$55 million over the coming 12-18 months.  In addition IFC considers providing A Loans in the following amounts: US$20 million for 1 sub-project in India and US$26 million for the four small projects in Thailand. In India a 25MW facility is to be located in the newly announced Gujarat Solar Park (being built by Gujarat Power Corporation Ltd (GPCL)). The Solar Park is located near Charanka village, in Santalpur Taluka, in the Patan District of Gujarat. As for the Thai projects:  SunWat 1, an 9.6 MW facility will be in Saraburi;  Sunwat 2, a 7.2 MW facility in Sri Sa Ket; SunWat 3, a 9.6 MW facility in Sri Sa Ket; and SunWat 4, a 9.6 MW facility, will be located in Roi Et.The expected total project cost will be approximately in the range of US$300 - 450 million for the five grid tied projects being debt-financed by IFC. In addition, IFC is considering supporting these projects with financing from the IFC Earth Fund, a platform of the GEF Earth Fund, and the Clean Technology Fund (a fund under the World Bank administered Climate Investment Funds) for the Thai projects.
Review Scope: IFCs review included meetings with MEMC/SunEdisons management and staff in charge of environmental, social and health and safety (ESHS) issues based in India and Thailand; visits to a representative sample of solar power sub-projects in different stages of development; and interviews with representatives of  relevant communities in India (3 sub-projects totaling 20 MW located near the Village of Dhama, in the district of Surendranagar in Gujarat) and Thailand (SunWat-1 9.6 MW in Saraburi and SunWat-2 7.2 MW and SunWat-3 9.6 MW located in Sri Sa Ket). Numerous internal documents and records surrounding MEMC/SunEdisons and the Development Companys ESHS program, procedures, and standards that are applicable to global and local operations were discussed.  Among others, these documents included: MEMC/SunEdisons global ESHS corporate policies, manuals, and procedures; sub-project-level environmental and social assessments of multiple projects, including the 1 sub-project in India and 4 in Thailand being considered for direct investment; community engagement documentation; and key contractors ESHS management systems and procedures.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This equity investment in the Development Company and the direct financing of 1 sub-project in India and 4 sub-projects in Thailand are classified as Category B because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result of any related construction and operation activities, which can be avoided or mitigated by adequate site selection and by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines and design criteria. Potential impacts in construction activities of solar power sub-projects and ancillary facilities (i.e. transmission lines and access roads), besides being mitigable, are likely to be limited to sub-project site and short term, and highly unlikely to impact natural sensitive areas. The project is otherwise of obvious positive benefit as it will generate electricity from a renewable resource that will contribute to GHG abatement.

Project Description:
The proposed project involves a multi-level, multi-region engagement and partnership with Sun Edison LLC (the Sponsor and North America's largest solar energy services provider) which currently has a significant pipeline of grid-tied solar PV projects (many with signed Power Purchase Agreements) in India and Thailand, and ambitions for further expansion across South & South-East Asia and Sub-Saharan Africa, as declining solar prices and improved regulatory environments create new market opportunities.   

IFC proposes to provide a portion of the equity financing of the as yet unnamed regional Asian/Sub-Saharan solar development business based in Singapore and with operational teams in Chennai, Bangkok and elsewhere (the 'Development Company') as well as a portion of the debt financing required for five grid-tied solar photovoltaic plants (1 in India and 4 in Thailand). All of the projects will be built by SunEdison's EPC Company under a fully-wrapped EPC contract which is price and date certain and provides equipment and full-plant performance warranties for the first 2 years of operation.  Beyond this the Operation and Maintenance ('O&M') will be provided by SunEdison O&M Services arm which will provide plant availability warranties and module supplier will provide degradation rate warranties.
Impact: (i) Demonstration effect of early non-recourse financing of solar PV in India, Thailand and other regional markets; and (ii) support early stages of regulatory reform by helping the regulators, private sector and Government improve and ensure sustainability of regulatory structures supporting solar; (iii) directly increase power generation by 0.1 Million GWh per year; and (iv) promote renewable energy in line with climate change strategy by displacing approximately 115,000 tons CO2 per year.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed investment in the Development Company and the five project companies is a Category B project because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.While all Performance Standards are applicable to this investment, IFCs environmental and social due diligence focused on the Companys corporate-level ESHS management capacity and practices and issues related to the 2 sub-projects in India and 4 in Thailand to be directly financed under this operation in relation to the following Performance Standards: PS 1: Social and Environmental Assessment and Management System, PS 2: Labor and Working Conditions, and PS3: Pollution Prevention and Abatement. Further details on the potential environmental and social impacts, corresponding mitigation measures, and guidance on how and where information about the Project can be obtained are provided in the IFC Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) and the Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP).
Sponsor: Sun Edison LLC was founded in 2003 as a Delaware limited liability company and became a market leader in commercial scale roof-top PV installation under various state level solar regulatory support systems.  It was bought by MEMC in November 20, 2009 (for approximately $340million) and is now one of the leading solar power services companies in North America, with  global operations outside of North America, and has over 600 employees worldwide.  As of March 31, 2011, SunEdison has interconnected over 425 solar PV systems representing 287MWs of solar PV capacity and has approximately 1.9GWs of projects in its pipeline. SunEdison currently has more than 450+ plants under O&M contracts, with such plants in the aggregate operating at more than the independent engineers' expected capacity.  SunEdison is a wholly owned subsidiary of MEMC Electronic Materials, Inc ('MEMC'), a pioneer in the design and development of wafer technologies for 50 years. MEMC trades as 'WFR' on the NYSE and is part of the S&P500 Index. As of December 31, 2010, MEMC had total assets of $4.6 billion including $707 million of cash, and total liabilities amounting to $2.3 billion including $683 million of Short-term and Long-term debt. For the year ended December 31, 2010, MEMC generated revenues of $2.2 billion and realized a net income of $48 million. MEMC has Moody's rating of B and an S&P rating of BB, with a stable outlook.
Cost Nature: IFC is proposing to make up to 15 % equity contribution to the needs of the Development Company, equivalent to approximately $55 million over the coming 12-18 months.  In addition IFC considers providing A Loans in the following amounts: $20 million for the Indian project and $26 million for the four small Thai projects. The expected total project cost will be approximately in the range of $300 - 450 million for the five grid tied projects being debt-financed by IFC. In addition, IFC is considering supporting these projects with financing from the IFC Earth Fund, a platform of the GEF Earth Fund, and the Clean Technology Fund (a fund under the World Bank administered Climate Investment Funds) for the Thai projects.

Project Description: Altyn Ajydar (AA) is a leading producer of corrugated packaging in the Kyrgyz Republic and a long-term IFC client with sales of $5.4 million in 2010. AA's management has currently identified strong demand for packaging in Kazakhstan in line with the growth potential of the agribusiness, food processing, appliances and consumer goods sectors. AA now wishes to expand its production and sales to neighboring Kazakhstan closer to its main market and clients.  Through this investment, IFC will be able to: (i) provide longer term financing that is currently unavailable in the local market in sufficient amounts; (ii) support the expansion of an existing viable client in an IDA country to larger markets in Kazakhstan in the wake of the global financial crisis and economic contraction in the Kyrgyz Republic; and (iii) continue working with AA on implementing improved safety, labor, health, and environmental practices as well as provide advice on corporate governance in both Kyrgyzstan and Kazakhstan.
Impact: The proposed project will help AA expand into Kazakhstan and improve its competitiveness with the production of multi-layer packaging products through the use a new and more efficient corrugated packaging line in a location that is closer to its client base in Kazakhstan. Moreover, the project will have a demonstration effect for other SMEs, as AA has been a successful company in the region. Besides improving the company's competitiveness, the investment is expected to result in an estimated additional employment of 100 workers in Kazakhstan.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed project is with an existing Sponsor with which IFC has worked to increase environmental, social and health & safety management performance over the investment period.  The project has been evaluated on its own merits, but the appraisal also took into account the companys environmental, social, health and safety management of existing facilities and progress in implementation of corresponding action plans.  The proposed project will have minor, and easily mitigated environmental, social and health & safety impacts related to Performance Standards 1 through 4, and it has been given a B categorization. The proposed project will be required to comply with the applicable Kazakh environmental and social laws and regulations, the IFC Performance Standards and the applicable generic and sector-specific WBGs Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines.
Sponsor:
The majority of shares (53%) of Altyn Ajydar ('AA') are owned by Mr. Pavel Terekhov, President, and the rest of the shares are owned by his family members (the 'Sponsors'). IFC provided financing of $0.3 million to AA in 1999 for the modernization and expansion of its existing cardboard packaging facility and $1.4 million in 2005 to set up a new corrugated packaging line with a capacity of 10 million square meters near Bishkek.  In 2008, IFC committed a third loan of $1.6 million to finance the production of alucobond panels and insulated glass window units, which was partially disbursed and the remainder was cancelled in 2010 due to declining demand for building materials during the global economic slowdown. IFC projects were implemented successfully, as AA improved its operating performance, increasing its sales from $1.6 million in 2003 to $5.4 million in 2010, by more than 3 times. AA is currently the leader in the corrugated packaging industry in the local Kyrgyz market. AA now wishes to expand its production to neighboring Kazakhstan in order to be closer to its main market and clients. Production in 
Kazakhstan will be undertaken by Intermultiservices ('IMS'), AA's wholly-owned subsidiary in Kazakhstan.
Cost Nature: The total cost of the new project is estimated at around $4.5 million, which will be financed by an estimated contribution from the Sponsors and AA of $2.25 million and a senior IFC loan of $2.25 million for IFC's own account to finance the AA's corrugated packaging production in Kazakhstan.

Project Description: The project would involve a senior loan of up to EUR22.5 million to a newly established bank in Romania  Garanti Bank SA, Romania (the 'Bank') for the purpose of on-lending in small and medium enterprises market. The banking sector is short of supporting small and medium enterprises due to the effects of the financial crisis and lowered liquidity which deteriorated asset quality of the banks in Romania.
Impact:
- Increased access to finance: New loans and portfolio growth is expected for SMEs in the Country in an environment where funding resources are constrained.
- Supporting a new entrant to the market: Supporting competition in the market and signaling support to the SME financing.
- Enhancement in operational procedures: Bringing best practices in insurance and social and environment management systems to a newly formed bank.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure and will involve financing SME sectors including women entrepreneurs. IFC''s appraisal will focus on Garanti Romanias capacity to develop and implement a Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS) to comply with the IFC Exclusion List and national environmental and social laws. IFC will also appraise Garanti Romania''s labor policies against IFC''s Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working Conditions.
Sponsor:
Garanti Bank Turkey has been active in Romania as a branch of its Dutch subsidiary since 1998. In 2007, Garanti Bank Turkey decided to increase its presence in Romania through a direct subsidiary instead of a branch. The new bank license of the Bank was authorized by the National Bank of Romania in 2009, and the Bank became operational at the end of May 2010. As of year-end 2010, the Bank operates a network of 65 branches, 152 ATMs and more than 6,000 POSs. 

Garanti Bank, Turkey is Turkey's second largest private bank by asset size and largest lender. As of 2010, Garanti Bank Turkey has 9.8 million customers with close to $11.2 billion equity, serving its customers through a distribution network comprising 863 branches, more than 3,000 ATMs, call center and online banking. Garanti Bank is controlled jointly by Dogus Holding, Turkey and BBVA Bank, Spain.
Cost Nature: The financing will be comprised of a senior loan of up to EUR22,500,000 from its own funds.

IFC will also appraise Garanti Romania''s labor policies against IFC''s Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working Conditions.

Project Description: Orascom Construction Industries (OCI) is one of the largest construction groups in the Middle East and North Africa region.  The Company is also a leading global nitrogen fertilizer producer and distributor.  IFCs proposed investment is to support OCIs long term growth plans and operations as well as to extend the average life of the fertilizers Groups debt financing through investment in OCI directly.  IFC is also considering a possible additional direct investment in EFC (a subsidiary that is wholly owned by OCI). At the time of appraisal, OCI is the construction contractor on 38 active construction projects (35 in Egypt and 3 in Algeria).  Key projects include new power plant construction and existing plant upgrades, water and wastewater infrastructure improvements and new developments, transportation upgrades (roads and metro) and general building construction and civil engineering projects.  As part of the construction business, OCI also has operating companies involved with steel fabrication, piping and paint manufacture. In the nitrogen fertilizer business OCI has controlling ownership of two fertilizer plants and an ammonia export terminal in Egypt. The fertilizer plants include: EFC, which produces 1.3 million tons per annum (mtpa) of urea; and EBIC, which produces 0.7 mtpa of ammonia.  Both of these fertilizer plants are adjacent to one another at the Ein Sokhna industrial site, 140km southeast of Cairo and adjacent to the Gulf of Suez. OCI is constructing a fertilizer production plant in Algeria (Sorfert) that will have the capacity to produce 0.8 mtpa of ammonia and 1.2 mtpa of urea.  OCI will operate Sorfert under a joint venture with the Algerian state-owned oil and gas company, Sonatrach.  The plant is located within the existing industrial zone of Arzew in the north west of the country and has been under construction since September 2007.  It is expected to become operational in late 2011.  In the Netherlands, OCI controls one nitrogen fertilizer production plant producing 1.15 mtpa of calcium ammonium nitrate(CAN), 0.45 mtpa of ammonia, 0.2 mtpa of  UAN, , and 0.25 mtpa of melamine, as well as an ammonia storage terminal and a nitrogen distribution network. OCIs planned nitrogenous fertilizer production capacity by 2012 is 7.45 mtpa.
Review Scope: IFCs environmental and social (E&S) review of this proposed investment involved meetings and discussions with OCIs management team, including several meetings with the corporate directors for Health, Safety and Environment (HSE) and  Human Resources (HR) and the management teams for each of the fertilizer plants in Egypt and Algeria. During the review, IFC E&S specialists visited three of OCIs construction projects underway at sites in Egypt (Abu Qir gas fired power plant, a section of the Cairo-Alexandria Desert Road upgrade; and the New Cairo wastewater treatment plant), as well as two of OCIs operational fertilizer plants (Egyptian Fertilizers Company (EFC) and Egypt Basic Industries Corporation (EBIC)); and the largest of its National Steel Fabrication plants.The review also consisted of appraising HSE information submitted by the Company.  Key documentation reviewed included: the HSE management system manuals containing the Companys HSE Policy, standards, plans and procedures and instructions in relation to HSE management and control of the Companys construction activities, the management system manuals plans and procedures and safety guidelines for individual fertilizer plant operations in Egypt, HSE performance records; OCI Annual Reports; OCI HR policies and procedures, and the Environmental Impact Assessments (EIAs) for the EFC and EBIC fertilizer plants in Egypt and the Sorfert fertilizer plant under construction in Algeria.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category A investment primarily because of the E&S risks inherent during the operations of nitrogenous fertilizer facilities, in particular, workforce and community safety risks in the unlikely event of an accident.  In addition, OCIs construction business may, in the future include large-scale projects which could have the potential to result in significant and diverse impacts.  .

Project Description: IFC is considering a $350 million investment to be allocated to Orascom Construction Industries (OCI) and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Egyptian Fertilizers Company (EFC).  OCI is one of the largest construction and fertilizers groups in the Middle East and Africa region and is present in over 25 countries across the world. In its present form OCI acts as a holding and operating company. Collectively, the Groups companies (fertilizers and construction) employ more than 86,000 people. OCI, post disposal of the cement business to Lafarge at the end of 2007, became a leading global nitrogen fertilizer producer and distributor through acquisition of existing players and investment in Greenfiled projects. EFC, which was acquired by OCI in 2008, manufactures granulated Urea with a total production capacity of 1.3 million tons per annum. The majority of EFCs output is targeted for export. OCIs overall production and distribution capacity is expected to reach 7.45 mtpa by 2012.  IFC funds will go to support OCIs growth plans for the fertilizers and construction operations as well as restructure the Groups debt financing towards a longer term, more stable structure that is suitable for the nature of the Groups operations.
Impact: The proposed investment is expected to have the following development impacts: (1) revenue generation to the Egyptian government as both OCI and EFC through tax payments by OCI and EFC; (ii) contributing foreign currency income to the country through export revenues and dividends received from investments outside of Egypt; (iii) job creation, directly through a number of planned capacity expansions in the fertilizers sector, and indirectly through sub contracting parts of the construction works in many on the Group''s projects; and (iv) contribution to food security through increased availability of fertilizers to support supply growth in primary agriculture.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category A project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure. Key environmental, health, safety and social issues associated with this investment include the Companys ability to ensure that all assets and construction projects comply with national requirements and IFC Performance Standards recognizing that potential adverse E&S risks and impacts of individual construction projects will depend upon each specific projects characteristics.  IFCs review of this proposed investment included meetings and discussions with OCIs management team, including several meetings with the corporate directors for Health, Safety and Environment and Human Resources. IFC specialists visited three of OCIs construction projects underway at sites in Egypt as well as two of OCIs operational fertilizer plants and the largest of its National Steel Fabrication plants.  Key documentation reviewed included: the HSE management system manuals containing the Companys HSE Policy, standards, plans and procedures and instructions in relation to HSE management and control of the Companys construction activities, the management system manuals plans and procedures and safety guidelines for individual fertilizer plant operations in Egypt, HSE performance records; OCI Annual Reports; OCI HR policies and procedures, and the Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) for the Sorfert Algeria fertilizer plant.A detailed description of IFCs environmental and social due diligence of this investment can be found in the Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS), which is also available on IFCs website at http://www.ifc.org/projects.
Sponsor: OCI is the largest company listed on Egypt Stock Exchange (EGX), with GDRs listed on the London Stock Exchange and ADRs listed on the US Over-the-Counter (OTC) market. OCIs current capitalization is US$8.5 billion (based on May 15th share price). OCIs major shareholder is the Sawiris family with a 54.3% stake in the company (the Sponsor). Other shareholders with significant stakes include Abraaj Capital (6.2%) and Lazard (5.0%).
Cost Nature: IFC financing will be directed to support the Groups long term investment needs and replacing existing shorter term debt financing, previously raised in to partially fund the acquisition costs related to the Groups fertilizers assets. IFC is considering a total investment package of up to $350 million which will structured as corporate finance facilities.

The construction operations span most of Egypt, a number of countries in MENA including Algeria, UAE, Saudi Arabia and Qatar OCI construction Group also operates in Europe and the United States. For fertilizers, OCI plants are located in Egypt, Algeria and the Netherlands. The Group also includes fertilizers distribution channels in Western Europe, Dubai, Brazil and the United States.  EFC is located in the Suez Industrial Development Company, in Ain Sokhna, Suez Governorate on the Red Sea in Egypt.

Project Description: The Project would invest in Africa Railways Limited (ARL), a holding company established to hold a controlling stake in Rift Valley Railways (RVR).  RVR is the operator of the Kenya-Uganda railway line which was privatized under two substantially identical 25-year concessions in 2006.  The RVR concession covers the existing railway networks of Kenya and Uganda with the main line running from the port of Mombasa on Kenyas coast through Nairobi to Kampala in Uganda, a distance of approximately 1,330 km.IFCs Corporate Advisory Services acted as a financial advisor to the Government of Kenya for the 2006 privatization and, at that time, IFC made available an A Loan of $22 mn and C Loan of $10 mn (project #24766).  Given the long distances involved (530 km from Mombasa to Nairobi and 803 km from there to Kampala), rail transportation should have a significant cost advantage over road transportation by trucks.  However, following decades of under-investment the network is in poor condition.  The Project is part of a larger restructuring and investment program to put the railway back onto a sustainable footing with the goal of increasing cargo volumes from about 1.6 mn tons currently to over 5.0 mn tons by 2020.IFCs proposed investment is an equity investment of up to $15 million.  This would be used towards the Project cost which is estimated to be about US$366.5 million.  In addition, the following institutions, among others, are considering investments in the operation:  DEG, FMO, Proparco, AfDB, and the IFC-African Latin American Fund.
Review Scope: IFCs original review of the Rift Valley Railways (#24766) took place in 2006, the scope and results of which were made available on IFCs web site at that time (see link above).  Conducted in coordination with the World Bank (which is funding the retrenchment compensation of railway staff and the relocation of people who have encroached along the government-owned right-of-way), IFCs 2006 review relied upon visits, interviews with key staff, and documents prepared for the privatization and by the Project Sponsor.RVRs operations and facilities have subsequently been under continuous supervision by IFC, the most recent being visits conducted in September 2009 and September 2010.  Colleagues from the African Development Bank (AfDB), a potential new investor, also participated in the 2010 visit (see link to AfDBs website disclosure below).  This visit benefitted from the availability of an updated Environment, Health and Safety Audit (EHS Audit) carried out by the Companys consultant in 2010.  The September 2010 site visits incorporated key features of the railway network, including the main workshops, stations, rights-of-way, and encroachment areas around Mombasa, Nairobi (Kenya), Kampala and Jinja (Uganda).  A potential regional rail hub in Jinja was also visited.  The team met in Nairobi and Kampala with RVR management and with officials at the concessioning agencies, Kenya Railways Corporation (KRC) and Uganda Railways Corporation (URC) involved in resettlement and compensation issues for the Project.Also as a result of the 2010 visit, two resettlement action plans (RAPs) were prepared on the encroachments on the railway reserve covering the conceded network in Uganda and the majority of the conceded network in Kenya outside of the irregular settlements of Kibera and Mukuru, near Nairobi.  The resettlement action plan for Kibera and Mukuru prepared for the government of Kenya in 2005 was never implemented because a decision was taken to expand the scope of the resettlement beyond the original 10.4 m operations corridor due to safety considerations.  Supported as part of the World Banks East Africa Trade and Transportation Facility Project (EATTFP), this updated RAP was prepared in 2010 to cover 50 m corridor in these two areas.  IFCs site visit in September 2010 also covered these areas, and IFC has reviewed the updated RAP.IFCs scope of review has focused on those impacts and risks within the areas conceded to RVR under the concession agreements in both countries.  These conceded assets include the existing workshops, the station areas, the 10.4 m operational corridor, and some, but not all rolling stock.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The original 2006 IFC investment was categorized as B, which was consistent at the time with the World Banks categorization of its EATTFP project.  Involuntary resettlement, which was considered the main impact of the project, was limited to encroachment within the 10.4 m operational corridor identified in the concession agreements.  The social impact of the project has now expanded significantly as a result of the change in scope of the resettlement within Kibera and Mukuru irregular settlements and the additional encroachment that has taken place in other areas since 2006.  As a result, both IFC and the World Bank now consider this project to be Category A.

Project Description:
Assupol Life Limited is an insurance company in South Africa with a long history in providing insurance products to the police force. In the late 80's, it expanded its offering to all South Africans, particularly serving previously disadvantaged groups. Assupol's products include life, disability and accident cover; funeral cover; retirements products; and savings and investment products. Approximately 90% of Assupol Life Limited's 240,000 individual life policyholders are black, previously disadvantaged individuals.  A large portion of these individuals are from lower income segments.

On 09 December 2010, Assupol was formally demutualized, thereby transforming from a mutual society to a stockholding company majority-owned by its policyholders. It is now known as Assupol Life Limited.  The demutualization involved the creation of a holding company, namely Assupol Holdings Limited ('HoldCo') that owns 100% of the life company, and has issued shares to policyholders and employees.  In due course, Holdco will issue additional shares to new investors, including the IFC.  In terms of the demutualization scheme a structured process is being implemented to assist the policy holders who became shareholders and who have not elected to retain their shares but to redeem their shares for cash.  The redemption of shareholders would be made possible through the introduction of further strategic investors (other than IFC) over the next 18 months.  Key to management strategy is to ensure that the company continues to be black empowered.

Through this project, Assupol Life Limited is looking to raise ZAR170 MM (equivalent to approx. $24.3 MM) of capital from IFC following the demutualization. IFC's role in supporting this process is to: (i) lend credibility to the transformation of Assupol Life from a mutual society to a stockholder company; (ii) enhance Assupol Life's reputation in the marketplace; and (iii) provide Assupol Life with capital to expand its reach in South Africa and also selectively explore opportunities in other parts of Africa.
Impact: The project is expected to (i) expand the availability of insurance products (e.g. life, disability and accident cover, funeral cover, retirement policies and savings and investment products, etc.) to underserved populations in South Africa; (ii) highlight the potential of this market segment to other companies and the business model required to serve it; and (iii) increase the safety net protection for those who mostly need it.
Environmental Social Issues: This project will support Assupol, a company providing insurance to individuals (life insurance, burial policies, student loan policies, retirement policies, property insurance) and has been classified as a Category C project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The project will be required to demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions. No further review is required. The project is required to inform IFC in the event of any change in nature or scope of its present business or operations.
Sponsor: Assupol Life Limited is a former mutual insurance company that had approximately 240,000 individual life policyholders.  It in addition underwrites a large number of group scheme policies and products, giving it a national footprint in the Republic of South Africa.  Following demutualization, the shareholding structure includes former policyholders (85%) and management and staff (15%).
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC is an equity investment of up to ZAR 170 million ($ 24.3 million) for a stake of up to 18% in the Holding Company of Assupol Life Limited post demutualization. IFC's subscription will be in a proposed amount of up to ZAR 170 million or an amount such that IFC is not the single largest shareholder. Project Description: In the proposed project, IFC will establish a risk-sharing facility of up to $100 million with Deutsche Bank, AG (DB) to share the risk of credit losses resulting from certain corporate and financial institution credit risk events in emerging markets.  The facility will cover a pool of eligible transactions which include cross currency swaps and forwards and local currency interest rate swaps entered into by DB originated during a term of two years (the Facility).
Impact: The proposed Facility is expected to have a number of development benefits and should help IFC meet its Institutional Development Goals ("IDG"). First, it will increase the depth of local and cross-currency hedging products that are available to clients in emerging markets. Second, it will promote hedging transactions in markets where there are significant barriers to entry for many companies and financial institutions, by seeking to widen the circle of counterparts to include second-tier credits. Third, by improving access for emerging market clients to currency risk hedging products, it will facilitate financial risk management and planning, specifically in sectors that are key for the development of local economies such as microfinance, medium-sized enterprises operating in the manufacturing and agribusiness sectors, pension funds, and low-income housing. Broadening access to cross-currency hedging tools will enable clients in these key industries to better manage foreign exchange risk and strengthen their balance sheets and, through increased access to finance and more efficient use of capital, expand their businesses. Fourth, since only swap transactions with at least one local currency leg will be eligible for inclusion, the Facility will contribute especially to the development of local derivatives markets.
Environmental Social Issues: This proposed project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Eligibility criteria for counterparties to be included in the facility shall include the IFC Exclusion List and other requirements as established by IFC and agreed to by DB.  DB will implement procedures to screen counterparties in the Facility for the eligibility requirements and will identify person(s) to manage and implement the necessary procedures.  DBAGs treatment of its employees will demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions.  In addition, DB will submit a periodic report of exposures included in the facility to IFC as per a mutually agreed upon format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: Deutsche Bank, AG, a stock corporation organized under the laws of Germany with headquarters in Frankfurt, has become a leading global corporate and investment bank over the last two decades through organic growth and strategic acquisitions (such as that of Bankers Trust in 1999). With total assets of EUR 1,906 billion and equity of EUR 48.8 billion as of end-December 2010 it is ranked among the leading financial institutions worldwide. As of end-2010, DB employed over 100,000 people on a full-time equivalent basis and operated in over 72 countries out of 3,083 branches worldwide, of which 49% were in Germany.  DBs shares are widely held and listed in Germany and the U.S.; ratings include Fitch IDR at AA-/negative as at Dec 20, 2010; and S&P A+/stable as at Oct 19, 2010.
Cost Nature: The IFC Facility will be for up to $100 million.  The Facility will provide credit risk protection for a portfolio of local currency transactions such as cross-currency swaps and forwards, and local currency interest rate swaps.

Project Description: The Project would invest in Africa Railways Limited ('ARL'), a holding company established to hold a controlling stake in Rift Valley Railways ('RVR').  RVR is the operator of the Kenya-Uganda railway line which was privatized under two substantially identical 25-year concessions in 2006.  IFC's Corporate Advisory Services acted as a financial advisor to the Government of Kenya for the 2006 privatization and, at that time, IFC made available an A Loan of $22 million and C Loan of $10 million (project #24766).  Given the long distances involved (530 km from Mombasa to Nairobi and 803 km from there to Kampala), this should have a significant cost advantage over trucks.  However, following decades of under-investment the network is in poor condition.  The Project is part of a larger restructuring and investment program to put the railway back onto a sustainable footing with the goal of increasing cargo volumes from about 1.6 million tons currently to over 5.0 million tons by 2020.
Impact: By improving the railway's infrastructure and rolling stock, the Project would have a substantial development impact.  In particular, it would: (i) increase competition in the transport sector, reducing costs and leading to service improvements; (ii) shift traffic from road to rail (especially heavy bulk cargoes), slowing the deterioration of the road network and improving safety; (iii) increase regional integration in transportation, trade and economic development; (iv) by reducing transportation costs, facilitate economic growth particularly in Uganda and other landlocked countries in the region; and (v) by substituting trucks, reduce the emission of harmful greenhouse gases.
Environmental Social Issues: The key environmental and social aspects of the Project include:  environmental management program for system renovation and operation; the control of encroachment and railway safety management in key areas such as level crossings; liquid effluents and protection of water resources; solid and liquid waste management; risk assessment of the transportation and disposal of hazardous materials; vegetation management of the right-of-way; spill prevention and emergency response; and employee and public safety.Notwithstanding the fact that the Project involves the refurbishment of an existing railway with an established footprint, the social impacts of relocating significant numbers of people and businesses encroaching upon the right-of-way, particularly in Nairobi, as well as in other parts of Kenya and Uganda, cause this to be categorized as A.
Sponsor: RVR is controlled by Citadel Capital SAE, a leading MENA private equity house based in Cairo.  It is currently expected that DEG, FMO, IFC and Proparco will invest in the Project along with Citadel.  Other minority investors include Trans Century Limited (a Kenyan private investment firm), Primefuels Rail Investments Ltd. (a subsidiary of Primefuels, a Kenya based transport services company), Rail Tech (a civil contractor) and Bomi Holdings of Uganda.
Cost Nature: IFC's proposed investment is an equity investment of up to $15 million.  This would be used towards the Project cost which is estimated to be about $366.5 million.  In addition, the IFC-African Latin American Fund ('ALAC Fund'), managed by the IFC-Asset Management Company, is considering an up to US$25 million equity investment in ARL.

Project Description: The project is the development of a greenfield 80 MW Heavy Fuel Oil (HFO) fired power plant, including a 66kv interconnector and backup metering equipment on a 20 years build-own-and-operate basis along the Nairobi Mombasa highway in the Athi River area of Mavoko Municipality, Kenya (the Project). The Project will have a 20 year Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) with Kenya Power and Lighting Company (KPLC), the national transmission and distribution company. The PPA may be extended for 5 years based on mutual agreement between the Company and KPLC.The developer of the Project is Gulf Power Limited (GPL or the Company), a special purpose company incorporated in Kenya by a consortium of Kenyan investors with a view to enter the power generation business in Kenya. The Project is one of 3 Independent Power Projects (IPPs) for which KPLC had sought Expressions of Interests (EOI), in June 2009. These IPPs were expected to generate 60-80 MW each using medium speed diesel engines with HFO as the fuel.    The projects were awarded through a competitive bidding process based on the lowest electricity charges. GPL submitted an EOI to bid for the Project. In the final bidding held on December 15, 2009, GPL was the lowest bidder for the development of an 80 MW plant on the Mombasa Road, Athi River Site and on that basis was awarded the concession.
Review Scope: IFCs review included:- Field visit to the proposed project site near Athi River area of Mavoko Municipality.- Meetings with: Gulf Power management team; the area Chief and the village elders within a 5km radius of project site; the site hydro-geologist (from the Water Ministry);  the assistant sales administrator from Superior Homes residential development; the agency managing director and the sewerage superintendent of the Mavoko Water and Sewerage Company; the representative of the municipal planning department of the municipal county of Mavoko; the director of compliance enforcement and other representatives of the National Environmental Management Authority (NEMA).- Review of key documents such as Environmental and Social Impact Assessment for the power plant prepared by Nutek Solutions Ltd  April 2011; and Gulf Power human resources policy manual.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The Project is one component of a larger World Bank lending program to KP&LC that will support the creation of three IPPs.  The World Bank has categorized these IPPs collectively as Category A projects.  The IFC-supported project sponsored by Gulf Power will have limited environmental and social impacts that can be readily managed through mitigation measures.  Nonetheless and despite the modest E&S footprint, the proposed IFC investment has been categorized as A to maintain consistency with the World Banks categorization.
Sector: AC - Heavy Fuel Oil - Thermal Power Generation

Project Description:
The project is the development of an 80 MW Heavy Fuel Oil ('HFO') diesel power plant, including a 66kv interconnector and backup metering equipment on a 20 years build-own-and-operate basis in the Mombasa Road area of Nairobi, Kenya (the 'Project'). The project will have a 20 year Power Purchase Agreement ('PPA') with Kenya Power and Lighting Company ('KPLC'), the national transmission and distribution company. 

The developer of the Project is Gulf Power Limited ('GPL' or the 'Company'), a special purpose company incorporated in Kenya by a consortium of Kenyan investors with a view to enter the power generation business in Kenya. The Project is one of 3 Independent Power Projects ('IPPs') for which KPLC had sought Expressions of Interests ('EOI'), in June 2009. These IPPs were expected to generate 60-80 MW each using medium speed diesel engines with HFO as the fuel.    

The projects were awarded through a competitive bidding process based on the lowest electricity charges. GPL submitted an EOI to bid for the Project. In the final bidding held on December 15, 2009, GPL was the lowest bidder for the development of an 80 MW plant on the Mombasa Road, Athi River Site and on that basis was awarded the concession.
Impact:
The Project will be a significant step in assisting Kenya to achieve a more diversified energy mix and stability to its power generation. It will contribute to increasing the country's installed capacity in thermal generation as hydropower is frequently negatively impacted by drought and the creeping effects of climate change.

In addition, the Project presents a less expensive alternative to investments in emergency diesel fired plant and a strategic solution to Kenya's medium term power needs. 

The World Bank's Africa Infrastructure Country Diagnostic found that the lack of adequate, reliable electricity supply is Kenya's largest infrastructure challenge and a key constraint to economic growth (contributing to economic losses of 2% of GDP).
Environmental Social Issues: The Project consists of the development of an 80MW HFO fired power plant in a mixed used area where the land is leased through a private owner with no resulting economic or physical displacement. The key environmental and social impacts include air quality, noise, occupational health and safety, community health and safety, employment for local communities, traffic management, hazardous material and waste management, and access to water during both construction and operation. Please see ESRS for details on the environmental and social mitigations measures.
Sponsor:
The Sponsor of the Project is Gulf Energy Limited ('GEL'), with a 50% stake in the Company.  The other key shareholder is Multiple Hauliers Limited (a Kenyan surface carrier).  

GEL is a private oil and gas trading company based in Nairobi and that has operations in the East African region. The company was incorporated in 2006 in Kenya and has since expanded to become one of the top importers of crude and refined products to Kenya and the inland markets.

Project Description:
IFC is considering to invest up to EUR11 million to support the expansion of Patisen, a food processing and distribution company in Senegal. Patisen's main activity includes the production and distribution of bouillon cubes and chocolate and peanut spreads.

IFC's financing will be used to expand Patisen's production capacity to serve domestic and export markets, to build a new factory and warehouse facilities, support product diversification, and for working capital needs.
Impact:
-	Increase supply of food production domestically, thereby benefiting local consumers.
-	Support transformation of a local company into a regional champion.
-	Employment creation:  The Company has 250 full-time employees and 1,000 temporary employees. The Project will create additional jobs. 
-	SME development:  The Company assists small wholesalers with a professional Patisen sales force to distribute its products to consumers, thereby transferring marketing know-how and sustainability of local SME wholesalers.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves the expansion of Patisen''s production capacity and subsequent relocation to a new production facility. The investment will have impacts that must be managed in a manner consistent with the following Performance Standards: PS 1: Social and Environmental Assessment and Management Systems, PS 2: Labor and Working Conditions, PS 3: Pollution Prevention and Abatement, and PS 4: Community Health, Safety and Security.Environmental, social, food safety, occupational health and safety and community impacts associated with the expansion of production lines and the construction and operation of a new production center are predictable and, as such, can be managed with the appropriate provision of resources, commitment and capacity on the part of the Client. In summary, the proposed investment is provisionally categorized as a B as the project is thought to have potential limited social or environmental impacts that are few in number, generally site-specific, largely reversible and readily addressed through mitigation measures. Please see the ESRS for further information on proposed environmental and social mitigations measures.
