Project Description:
The Takoradi Thermal Power Plant ('TTPP') is located on the south-western coast of Ghana, approximately 15 km north-east of Takoradi.  TTPP was originally planned as two separate 330 MW combined cycle combustion units. Takoradi 1 ('T1') has been operating in full combined cycle mode since 1999. This unit is owned and operated by the Takoradi Power Company ('TAPCO'), a wholly owned subsidiary of the Volta River Authority ('VRA'), a state owned and operated power utility company.  In 2000, the Takoradi International Company ('TICO' or the 'company'), which is about 90% owned by the Abu Dhabi National Energy Company ('TAQA') and 10% by VRA, completed construction and began operating the second combustion unit, Takoradi 2 ('T2'), at TTPP.   These units have been operating in simple cycle mode and TICO currently propose converting T2 to operate in combined cycle mode with the addition of a 110 MW steam turbine and generator (hereafter referred to as the 'T2 expansion').  This would increase the capacity of T2 to 330 MW, and that of TTPP from 550 MW to 660 MW.  

Key features of the T2 expansion include the addition of two heat recovery steam generators, a 110 MW steam turbine generator, two 60 m stacks and a seawater desalination plant.  In addition, a once through cooling water system will be installed to support operations at both T1 and T2 thereby removing reliance of T2 on freshwater.  The cooling system will include a sub-sea intake structure located 2.5 km offshore, intake conduits, onshore works including a pump house and intake and discharge chambers, and sub-sea outfall conduits and diffusers situated approximately 1.2 km offshore.  This final phase of T2 will increase the generating capacity of the facility without any additional fuel requirements.  The total project cost is approximately $325 million and IFC is considering a loan of up to $70 million to TICO to support the T2 expansion.   

T1 and T2 use either LCO or gas to generate power.  LCO is transferred to on-site storage tanks via a mooring buoy located some 4 km offshore.  Gas is supplied directly to site via an existing off-take pipeline from the West Africa Gas Pipeline ('WAGP'), a regional gas pipeline that supplies gas from Nigeria to Ghana, Benin and Togo.  VRA is responsible for the fuel supply, along with the treatment and storage of fuel, water and the treatment of waste water. 
 
All power generated at the site will be transferred off-site via existing transmission lines that have sufficient capacity to accommodate the additional energy to be generated by the T2 expansion. 

In addition to the existing T1 and T2 operations and the planned T2 expansion, a further new unit is currently being constructed by VRA, termed Takoradi 3 ('T3').
Review Scope:
IFC's review of this project included:

A site visit which included the T1 and T2 operations, the proposed location for the cooling water intake and outfall, and the adjacent Aboadze village 
Meeting with representatives from the T2 environmental, health and safety ('EHS') team, the human resources department, VRA Hospital and management
Review of the respective Environmental Impact Statements ('EIS') compiled by Jacobs Engineering UK Limited ('Jacobs') for conversion of the plant from simple cycle to combined cycle and the once through cooling system that will serve both T1 and T2 (the T2 expansion)
Review of additional information as provided by Jacobs including the cumulative air quality study and Stakeholder Engagement Plan
Review of the independent environmental and social report as compiled by Mott MacDonald on behalf of various potential lenders
Discussions with representatives from Jacobs and Mott MacDonald
A review of documentation provided by T2 personnel related to human resources, on-site environmental management and occupational health and safety, and responses provided to the environmental and social questionnaire
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFC's Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. The T2 expansion will occur at an existing thermal power plant site and create additional generating capacity by increasing efficiency without combusting additional fuel. Potential impacts associated with the T2 expansion will be relatively insignificant, including those related to key issues such as noise and air quality.
Sector: AD - Light Fuel Oil - Thermal Power Generation

Project Description: The Project consists of the conversion of the Takoradi II (T2 or TICO) plant from its current 2x 110 MW simple cycle configuration to a 330 MW combined cycle plant through the addition of a 110 MW steam turbine (in addition to two heat recovery steam generators and other related equipment). T2 is currently being converted to dual fuel capability, to run both on natural gas and Light Crude Oil (LCO) -the plant has a 10-year history of successfully running on LCO only. The conversion of TICO to combined cycle operation will allow the plant to generate an additional 110 MW of power without any incremental fuel consumption.   TICO is the developer, owner and operator of the existing T2 plant. The Project is located in Aboadze, Takoradi, in the Western Region of Ghana, on a site adjacent to an existing 330 MW thermal power plant ("Takoradi I" or T1) owned and operated by the Volta River Authority (VRA).
Impact: The Project is expected to have a number of major benefits, including: (a) Increased supply of electricity to support Ghanas growing economy at a more efficient cost  the Project involves the increase of the existing plant capacity from 220MW to 330MW, with no additional fuel requirements (since a combined cycle operation utilizes waste heat from the simple cycle generation)- with the ultimate benefit of a lower cost of energy for the consumers.(b )Further diversification of Ghana electricity supply away from over-reliance on hydro power generation (with the attendant rainfall driven variations in supply), as well as utilization of gas resources from Ghana and the region, with the planned conversion of the plant to dual fuel mode  gas and LCO. (c) Supports the growth of private sector investment in Ghanas power sector, with positive signals for future investments.(d) Positive climate impact through avoided C02 emissions, by increasing the plants energy output capacity with no incremental fuel requirements.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project as the potential environmental and social (E&S) impacts and risks are limited in magnitude, site specific and can be mitigated with existing pollution prevention and control technologies and standard environmental management practices.  The project involves conversion of the current operations from single cycle mode to combined cycle mode.  In combined cycle mode, the exhaust gases generated in single cycle mode are used to make steam which drives a steam turbine to generate additional electricity. In this manner, the plants power generation efficiency is increased by approximately a third, with no increase in greenhouse gas emissions.    TICO commissioned a recognized consulting company with experience in the power sector to undertake the requisite E&S assessments for the project.  This included an assessment for conversion of the facility from single to combined cycle, and a separate assessment for the cooling water system.  These assessments were completed in consultation with the Ghana Environmental Protection Agency and are generally compliant with IFCs requirements.  They also included stakeholder engagement with the surrounding communities with whom TICO has good working relationships and formalized communication structures.   In addition, TICO / VRA have a community impact agreement with the project affected communities which facilitates the provision of certain social amenities.     Key potential issues include air quality and noise and the predicted change to the current situation is not considered significant.  In addition, the cooling system has been designed to comply with IFC EHS Guidelines for Thermal Power Plants and upon operation, marine monitoring programs will be implemented to confirm environmental impacts are in accordance with those predicted. The company is currently in the process of implementing recognized, certifiable quality, environmental and occupational health and safety (OHS) systems with time schedule for this defined in the project Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP).   In addition, TICO has robust policies and procedures for the management of labor which are compliant with IFCs requirements.  This similarly applies to occupational health and safety (OHS) with the company operating for over 8 years without a lost-time accident.  A Construction Environmental and Social Management and Monitoring Plan (CESMMP) will be compiled for the on and offshore works to ensure effective management of E&S issues, including OHS, during this phase.  In addition, TICO has sufficient internal capacity and experience to ensure adequate implementation of the CESSMP.  Whist the company is currently in general compliance with IFCs Performance Standards, E&S performance will be further enhanced via implementation of the project ESAP.
Sponsor: Project Sponsor:  The Project is sponsored by the Abu Dhabi National Energy Company (TAQA). Founded in 2005, TAQA is 51.1% owned by Abu Dhabi Water and Electricity Authority (ADWEA) and 21% owned by the Farmers Fund (a Government of Abu Dhabi owned fund). Collectively, ADWEA, the Farmers Fund and other Government of Abu Dhabi entities own 72.6% of TAQA. TAQA is listed on the Abu Dhabi Stock Exchange, with 27.4% of its shares being publicly held.  TAQA is gradually emerging as a global energy player with operations in Africa (Morocco and Ghana), Asia (India and UAE), and Europe (UK and The Netherlands) and has had operations in North America (Canada and United States).The Company:  TICO is 90% indirectly owned by TAQA and 10% by VRA.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated to be $440 million. The proposed IFC investment consists of a secured senior loan of up to $120 million, composed of up to $105 million A Loan for IFCs own account and up to $15 million in concessional funding from the Canada Climate Change Program.  .
Investment: 105.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan105.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Project is located in Aboadze, Takoradi, in the Western Region of Ghana, about 220 km southwest of the nations capital, Accra.  Takoradi is home to a major port, Takoradi Port, and is connected to the 678 km West Africa Gas Pipeline, which will supply gas from Nigeria. Takoradi is located about 140 km east of Bonyere, from where a gas pipeline is planned to transport gas from Ghanas recent off-shore discoveries. The Project will be developed on a brown-field site which currently houses the T1 and T2 plants. T2 is located adjacent to, and west of, T1. The site is easily accessible through existing roads.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project as the potential environmental and social (E&S) impacts and risks are limited in magnitude, site specific and can be mitigated with existing pollution prevention and control technologies and standard environmental management practices.  The project involves conversion of the current operations from single cycle mode to combined cycle mode.  In combined cycle mode, the exhaust gases generated in single cycle mode are used to make steam which drives a steam turbine to generate additional electricity. In this manner, the plants power generation efficiency is increased by approximately a third, with no increase in greenhouse gas emissions.    TICO commissioned a recognized consulting company with experience in the power sector to undertake the requisite E&S assessments for the project.  This included an assessment for conversion of the facility from single to combined cycle, and a separate assessment for the cooling water system.  These assessments were completed in consultation with the Ghana Environmental Protection Agency and are generally compliant with IFCs requirements.  They also included stakeholder engagement with the surrounding communities with whom TICO has good working relationships and formalized communication structures.   In addition, TICO / VRA have a community impact agreement with the project affected communities which facilitates the provision of certain social amenities.     Key potential issues include air quality and noise and the predicted change to the current situation is not considered significant.  In addition, the cooling system has been designed to comply with IFC EHS Guidelines for Thermal Power Plants and upon operation, marine monitoring programs will be implemented to confirm environmental impacts are in accordance with those predicted. The company is currently in the process of implementing recognized, certifiable quality, environmental and occupational health and safety (OHS) systems with time schedule for this defined in the project Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP).   In addition, TICO has robust policies and procedures for the management of labor which are compliant with IFCs requirements.  This similarly applies to occupational health and safety (OHS) with the company operating for over 8 years without a lost-time accident.  A Construction Environmental and Social Management and Monitoring Plan (CESMMP) will be compiled for the on and offshore works to ensure effective management of E&S issues, including OHS, during this phase.  In addition, TICO has sufficient internal capacity and experience to ensure adequate implementation of the CESSMP.  Whist the company is currently in general compliance with IFCs Performance Standards, E&S performance will be further enhanced via implementation of the project ESAP.
Sector: AD - Light Fuel Oil - Thermal Power Generation

Project Description:
The Emerging Africa Infrastructure Fund ('EAIF' or the 'Fund'), an existing IFC client, is a Public Private Partnership ('PPP') incorporated in Mauritius that provides long-term USD or EUR denominated debt or mezzanine finance on commercial terms to finance private infrastructure projects in 45 countries across Sub-Saharan Africa ('SSA'). 

Since the initial capitalization in 2002 with the Private Infrastructure Development Group 'PIDG' (a multi-donor organization formed by various European public development agencies)  as its sole equity investor and in response to a growing portfolio and financing needs of infrastructure projects in SSA, the Fund has undergone three rounds of additional funding reaching its current size of $600 million. IFC participated in the last round of financing closed in June 2010, committing a senior loan for $36.25 million and a standby liquidity facility for $12.5 million

The Project involves providing $150 million of net additional senior debt to EAIF in order to enable the Fund to invest in new projects through 2013.
Impact:
To close the infrastructure gap with other parts of the world, meet the Millennium Development Goals, and achieve national development targets in Africa within 10 years, an annual spending in infrastructure of US$93 billion (about 15 percent of the region's GDP) would be required. A funding gap equal to one third of this amount exists and the magnitude of the required investments places a premium on maximizing private sector investment flows that the proposed IFC investment will support.

The development impact of the project will be captured in terms of the Fund's performance, the Fund's additional investments in SSA infrastructure projects, the expansion of infrastructure capacity made available by project investments, the role of the Fund in extending appropriate environmental and social standards and the quality of those investments as follows: (i) Net Internal Rate of Return; (ii) Private sector involvement in infrastructure; (iii) Percentage of underlying investments with steady cash flows; (iv) Total infrastructure capacity (e.g. electricity generated, volume of export/import handled by a port etc.).
Environmental Social Issues: This second category FI investment in the Fund will not involve any material change in the way environmental and social risks are to be managed under the existing investment.  Under the terms of the first investment and to the satisfaction of IFC, the Fund developed a social and environmental management system to ensure that IFCs Performance Standards (PS) and applicable host country laws and regulations will be observed by each investee company.
Sponsor:
EAIF was initiated by the PIDG a multi-donor organization constituted in 2002. PIDG's objective is to encourage private infrastructure investment in developing countries that contributes to economic growth and poverty reduction. Since its establishment, the PIDG has developed project development facilities focused on improving project development and execution (InfraCo and DevCo) and project financing vehicles (GuarantCo and EAIF), aimed at addressing financial market failures that have created constraints to private investment in infrastructure service provision. GuarantCo which provides local currency guarantees to infrastructure projects in low-income countries to mitigate credit risks for local lenders is also managed by EAIF's fund manager. 
PIDG's current members include: the UK Department for International Development ('DFID'), the Swiss State Secretariat for Economic Affairs ('SECO'), the Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs ('DGIS'), the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency ('SIDA'), the Austrian Development Agency ('ADA'), Irish Aid and the World Bank. 
The PIDG members provide equity to EAIF through the PIDG Trust, a vehicle for the development of PIDG programs and the ownership of its investment vehicles.

EAIF is managed by Frontier Markets Fund Manager Limited ('FMFML'), also a special purpose company incorporated in Mauritius jointly owned by Standard Bank Group (70%), FMO (The Dutch Development Bank  18.4%) and Emerging Markets Partners (11.6%). FMFML in turn delegates most of the operational management to Frontier Markets Fund Managers ('FMFM'), a division of Standard Bank plc based in London and regulated by the U.K.'s Financial Services Authority ('FSA').
Cost Nature:
The total project cost of $150 million is equivalent to the net increase in the Fund size. The additional financing is needed in order to enable the Fund to meet its projected pipeline of projects through 2013. 
The proposed IFC investment is to provide an A loan of up to $45 million. IFC will also play a coordination role with other DFIs who will fund an additional $105 million.

Project Description: The Project is to refurbish and expand Tecon Salvador S.A.'s ('TSSA') container terminal inside the Port of Salvador, which is located in the state of Bahia in North East Brazil. The Project includes (i) the refurbishment of 2 berths with a combined total length of 617 meters; (ii) the installation of three Post-Panamax Ship-to-Shore cranes and six Rubber Tyred Gantries Cranes; (iii) the refurbishment of existing buildings and expansion of the container yard from 58.7 hectares to 95.2 hectares; and (iv) the development of supporting electrical infrastructure. Upon completion, the terminal's container handling capacity will increase from 250,000 twenty foot equivalent container units ('TEUs') to 500,000 TEUs.
Impact: The Project will help strengthen the port sector in Brazil by increasing container handling capacity at the Port of Salvador, which is critical to enabling further trade growth for Northeast Brazil and to strengthening Bahia's position as an investment destination. The Project will also create direct and indirect employment opportunities and increase revenues for the Government of Brazil through increased economic activity and higher tax payments, custom duties, and lease payments.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project, as environmental, social, labor, and health and safety (ESHS) impacts and risk expected are only incremental to existing ones, mostly associated to increased port capacity and activity, and can be managed via existing standard practices. TSSA is an existing IFC client with good ESHS track record. The only major works associated to the Project involve dredging of approximately 30 meters to the main port channel and strengthening the new berth. For further details on the Projects ESHS impacts and risks and TSSAs management strategies, please refer to the Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS).
Sponsor:
TSSA is 92.5% owned by Wilson Sons de Administracao e Comercio Ltda (Wilson Sons) and 7.5% owned by Intermarítima Terminais Ltda ('Intermarítima').

Wilson Sons is a Brazilian maritime group, founded in 1837. It has operations in port terminals, towage services, logistics, shipping assistance, support to offshore oil and natural gas platforms and shipyard. Wilson Sons comprises over 15 affiliate companies, employing over 3,000 people. Its parent Wilson Sons Limited is listed on the Luxembourg Stock Exchange and traded in BDR (Brazilian Depository Receipts) on the São Paulo Stock Exchange, BOVESPA. Intermaritima is a private owned inland and port logistics company with activities in the major ports of Bahia.
Cost Nature: The project is estimated to cost $117.2 million. The proposed IFC financing is expected to include an investment of $25 million for IFC's own account and up to $62.9 million in the form of a B Loan.

Project Description:
The Project is to support the expansion of Patisen ('the Company'), a food processing and distribution company in Senegal. Patisen's main activity includes the production and distribution of bouillon cubes and powder, spice mixing, chocolate-peanut spread, cocoa powder and margarine.

IFC's financing will be used to expand Patisen's production capacity to serve domestic and export markets, to build new processing and warehouse facilities, support product diversification, and working capital needs ('The Project').
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The key environmental and social risks from the Project include: occupational health and safety, food safety, liquid and solid waste management, fire and life safety; supply chain management and the land acquisition process along with construction phase risks such as occupational health and safety, community health and safety impacts, and management of construction waste for the proposed processing and warehouse facilities. As such, this Project is categorized as a B as it is anticipated to have limited potential environmental and social adverse impacts that are mostly reversible and readily managed through mitigation measures, project design and allocation of appropriate resources.

Project Description: MBAC Fertilizer Corporation, a Canadian company, through its local subsidiary Itafós Mineração Ltda (Itafós), is the Project Developer. The Project involves the development of a phosphate mine coupled to a new industrial complex that will produce fertilizers and other by-products for agricultural use, including 330,000 tons per annum of 28% P2O5 concentrate; 94,000 tons per annum of 15% P2O5 concentrate; 215,000 tons per annum of 98% w/w sulfuric acid; and 500,000 tons per annum of single superphosphate (SSP.) The Project is located in the municipality of Arraias, in the southeast of the State of Tocantins, Brazil; nearing the border with the State of Goiás.  However, the nearest community to the project,  located 7 km away, is Campos Belos (19,000 inhabitants) which  is in the  state of Goiás.  Arraias city in the State of Tocantins is located 22 km from the facilities.The Projects footprint occupies a total area of approximately 1,600 hectares (ha) including the industrial installations (approx. 45 ha), the mineral resources (approx. 490 ha); and a water dam (approx. 220 ha), and a tailings dam (approx. 740 ha) to be built.  The mining activities include open pit phosphate ore extraction, removal of overburden, and restoration of mining areas.  The mine plan developed for the Project anticipates processing a maximum of 3.5 M tons of ore per year at an average grade of about 5.0% P2O5, with a peak total material movement rate of 17.4 M tons per year. This scenario results in the production of approximately 330 K tons per year of phosphate concentrate at a grade of 28% P2O5.  The expected life of the mineral deposit is 15 years.The industrial activities comprise (a) phosphate rock processing including screening, crushing and grinding, then  water tank flotation to separate the phosphorous-rich phosphate rock from other minerals (waste) followed by filtration  and drying; (b) manufacture of sulfuric acid by melting sulfur and making it react with dry atmospheric oxygen to form SO3 and then through absorption of SO3 into water to produce sulfuric acid; the steam that is generated as by-product is used to produce electric energy;  (c) single superphosphate powder (SSP) production through the combination of phosphate rock and sulfuric acid; and (d) manufacture of ammoniate single superphosphate granulated (GSSP) by reacting ammonia with SSP in the granulation plant.  The project will use firewood as fuel for the phosphate rock drying process.  Itafos selected wood as fuel for environmental and economical reasons.  This renewable energy source is available closer to the project site than the nearest oil supplies which are more than 1,000 km from the project site.  Natural gas which was also considered in the selection process would have to also be transported from approximately 1,000  1,500 km from the project site. The construction phase of the project is planned to start within the second quarter of 2011, with an expected workforce of up to 1500 persons during peak period, and it is expected to begin operation in the third quarter of 2012. The project will manage the environmental and social impacts in accordance to international good practice.  In addition, the project will generate potential opportunities to the local communities by offering access to jobs, skills development, and business opportunities from providing services and products to Itafós as well as increased municipal tax revenue.
Review Scope: IFCs appraisal reviewed the effectiveness of the Companys Health, Safety, and Environment (HSE), social and labor management activities and the ability of the organization to ensure compliance with Brazilian regulatory requirements and IFCs Performance Standards during the construction and operation phases of the Project.  Specific items reviewed included: existing Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA), related Studies and Reports, and corresponding supplemental plans developed by Itafós (i.e., Stakeholder Engagement Plan, Resettlement Policy Framework, Study for the location of Water and Tailings dams (Relatorio do Projeto Conceitual das Barragens de Contenção de Rejeitos e de Captação de Agua Bruta do Projeto Fosfato Itafos.)  The IFC project team conducted a site visit to the project area, to the communities to be directly affected by the project and met with the local environmental authorities and had informal conversations with members of the communities affected by the Project.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category A project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure because although the Project is expected to bring economic and social benefits it has the potential to create significant and diverse adverse environmental and social impacts through the construction of water storage and tailing dams, the physical and/or economic displacement of approximately 49 households, industrial operation impacts such as emissions to air, and the risks associated with the mining activities, such as control of erosion and rehabilitation of drill roads, drill sites and trenches, safe disposal of oils, waste materials, dust control; surface and groundwater protection, drainage,  etc.

Project Description: MBAC is an integrated fertilizer company which is currently developing its main asset, Itafós or the 'Project', located in the state of Tocantins, central Brazil. The project consists of exploration, mining and processing of phosphate rock which will serve as the main feedstock to the Single Super Phosphate ('SSP') fertilizer plant that will be built. The SSP plant will process beneficiated rock and is expected to produce 500,000 metric tons of SSP fertilizer per annum which will be sold to farmers and fertilizer distributors in the nearby and expanding agricultural region of the Cerrado.
Impact:
The project will support the further intensification and expansion of agricultural production in North Eastern Brazil, the Cerrado, by making available SSP fertilizer closer to market. Given Brazil's already important role in supplying global agricultural markets and its significant potential for converting soil into arable land, the further development of the Cerrado plays an important role in promoting global food security, to which this project is making a contribution.

Specifically, the expected development benefits from the project will be in the form of:
Development of regional fertilizer capacity in a growing market that relies on imports and domestic supply from producers which are located at a distance.  Greater production and supply of SSP in the region supports the expansion and intensification of agricultural production and creates some degree of independence from imports with the positive effects overall of reduced transportation lag times and lower price volatility.
Expansion and intensification of agricultural production in the Cerrado, which has become the breadbasket of Brazil. Further intensification and expansion of agricultural activity depends on the availability of Single Super Phosphate ('SSP'), a source of sulfur and key ingredient to turning the sulfur deficient soils of the Cerrado into arable land.
Job creation in an isolated area in the poorer northeast of Brazil with few economic opportunities.
Revenues to government through corporate income taxes.

The following development indicators will be tracked throughout the project: i) payments to government, ii) jobs during construction and operational phase, iii) domestic purchase of goods and services, iv) community development outlays.
Environmental Social Issues: Key environmental, social, health and safety issues associated with the project include the construction of a water and a tailing dams, the resettlement of up to 49 families, industrial operation impacts, flora and fauna impacts, and the risks associated with the mining operations.  To assess the environmental and social impacts and identify mitigation actions, the Company commissioned an EIA and accompanying E&S management programs frameworks with which it obtained the construction license from the Brazilian environmental authorities.  As part of the Brazilian approval process, Itafos conducted a public hearing with the community of the municipality of Arraias to address concerns of the community regarding the project.  As part of this project, Itafos completed an upgraded Environmental and Social Impact Assessment where it addressed all known potential impacts during construction, operation and decommissioning phases in accordance to the IFC Performance Standards.  Itafos is committed to mitigating the additional potential impacts to be identified once the final project design is completed.    The construction program will also provide much needed positive benefits to the local population in relation to jobs and training.  Once in operation, the Project will be a state-of-the-art facility that will utilize best available technology.  Information about potential environmental and social impacts and how they will be addressed by the company is summarized in the Environmental and Social Review Summary.
Sponsor: MBAC is a publicly traded Canadian corporation listed in the Toronto Stock Exchange under the ticker MBC', and has a market cap of C$233 million ($239 million). MBAC was founded in 2009 and is currently engaged in activities relating to the mining, exploration, extraction and processing of phosphate rock.  MBAC's main asset is the Itafós project, where phosphate rock is currently mined, milled, processed and sold to local farmers for direct application. MBAC has also some smaller properties in the Brazilian coast focused on the production of potash.
Cost Nature: The total project is estimated to cost $257 million. IFC proposes an A Loan of $40 million to Itafos, as well as a $35 million investment in the shares of its parent, MBAC.

Project Description: The Project is to refurbish and expand Tecon Salvador S.A.s (TSSA) container terminal inside the Port of Salvador, which is located in the state of Bahia in North East Brazil. The Project includes (i) the refurbishment of 2 berths with a combined total length of 617 meters; (ii) the installation of three Post-Panamax Ship-to-Shore cranes and six Rubber Tyred Gantries Cranes; (iii) the refurbishment of existing buildings and expansion of the container yard from 58.7 hectares to 95.2 hectares; and (iv) the development of supporting electrical infrastructure. Upon completion, the terminals container handling capacity will increase from 250,000 twenty foot equivalent container units (TEUs) to 500,000 TEUs.
Review Scope: The IFC visited the project site, held meetings with TSSA personnel responsible for managing environmental, social, labor, and health and safety (ESHS) aspects of the operations, and reviewed TSSA environmental, social and health and safety policies, plans and procedures. In addition, the IFC assessed (a) the status of TSSAs environmental licensing renewal process for the existing facilities and the proposed expansion, (b) labor practices, agreements and status of the relationship with the different unions, (c) pollution prevention and emergency preparedness and response practices specially associated with dredging activities and fueling operations, and (d) any potential issues associated with the new construction and civil works in the coastal zone, as well as with the construction of a substation.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B operation, as environmental, social, labor, and health and safety (ESHS) impacts and risks expected are only incremental to existing ones and can be managed via existing standard practices. Project Name: AWI SME Finance Facility for the Middle East and North Africa
Company Name: AWI SME Finance Facility for the Middle East and North Africa
Project Description:
The project consists in the establishment of a regional MENA SME Initiative ('MSI' or 'Initiative') to scale up and support SME financing in the MENA region. MSI proposes to offer a comprehensive package to enhance SME access to finance in MENA in a systemic and sustainable manner.  It will consist of two core pillars: 
(a) A financial intermediation pillar, the MENA SME Facility ('SME Facility' or the 'Facility'), to enhance SME lending by local banks; and 
(b)   An advisory pillar, the MENA MSME Technical Assistance Facility ('MSME-TAF') to support capacity building in the micro and SME sector. The MSME TAF is a joint initiative between IFC and IBRD and would involve a strong collaboration between IFC, IBRD and other IFI partners.


The SME Facility will involve collaboration between IBRD, IFC, and partner DFIs/IFIs. Donor funding is expected to provide the first loss junior tranche complemented by IBRD contingent loan financing arrangements where governments of the targeted countries decide to allocate IBRD resources to back guarantees or risk sharing arrangements by the IFC-led SME Facility.  The initial target countries for the SME Facility are: Jordan, Tunisia, Lebanon, Egypt, and Morocco.

The SME Facility will be organized as a Facility and IFC would be the Facility Agent, helping to establish the SME Facility and to: identify PFI and originate PFI engagements, appraise PFI engagements, and to approve and supervise investments in accordance with IFC's operational/credit standards and processes. The SME Facility is expected to partner with banks and financial institutions engaged in SME lending and financial services in the targeted MENA countries.  In addition to risk sharing facilities with banks and financial institutions on a portfolio basis, the SME Facility may also offer term credit facilities to support working capital financing to SMEs and to finance machinery and equipment. The needs and the solutions in respect of SMEs are likely to be diverse among different markets and to change over time and evolve to adapt to country developments and new requirements that may emerge in the target countries changes.

The project is in response to the recent events in the region, which have amplified the importance of fostering broad-based and equitable growth and emphasized that private sector led, job-creating economic growth remains the cornerstone of any growth strategy for countries in the MENA region.
Impact: The project is expected to have the following development impact: (i) Improved access to finance for SMEs: SMEs in the MENA region account for 40% of GDP and 70% of employment. With this project, IFC would provide necessary funding and capacity building services to SMEs, including women entrepreneurs, enabling them to grow and expand their business and continue to play a major role in supporting the region's economic growth and job creation; and (ii) Improved financial infrastructure:  (a) The risk sharing structure of the SME facility aims to attract private sector investment flows and promote SME finance as a viable asset class. (b) The capacity building initiative would help build the capacity and increase the risk appetite of banks and lenders for the SME sector and enhance SME financing.
Environmental Social Issues: The project is a Category FI, according to IFC''s Environmental & Social review procedures. Activities supported by the SME Facility will need to meet the requirements of (i) IFC FI Exclusion List, (ii) the applicable national environmental and social laws and regulations, and (iii) to be consistent with a common set of E&S standards and procedures, which are to be developed, that will guide the Facility, incorporating the performance standards of IFC, the safeguards of IBRD and the policies applied by partner DFIs/IFIs.IFC will work with IBRD and other participating DFIs/IFIs to develop an Environmental and Social Risk Management Operations Manual (EOM) to guide participating banks of the RSF to properly manage E&S risks associated with the borrowers availing of the RSF. The EOM will require participating banks to develop and implement a social and environmental management system (SEMS) and maintain adequate capacities to achieve compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements. Specifically, each participating bank will be required to: - Develop an SEMS, which will be a condition of effectiveness for the RSF agreement and must be   satisfactory to IFC. Identify responsible, qualified persons to manage the implementation of the SEMS. - Implement the SEMS to ensure that its financing activities supported by the RSF are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements. - Commit to apply the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions. Submit periodic reports to IFC as per the format and timing to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor:
IFC will lead the initiative to develop the SME Facility in collaboration with IBRD, and partner DFIs/IFIs.  IFC will work jointly with the IBRD and partner DFIs/IFIs to develop the MSME-TAF. 

IBRD intends to collaborate with MSI as part of the Arab World Initiative Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise Facility' and will engage governments in promoting micro and SME development through intermediation and policy reforms that improve the business environment for the sector. IBRD funds could be accessed on a country by country basis for the SME Facility, if Governments choose to use IBRD loan funds to back IFC SME Facility guarantees. IFC and IBRD have agreed the financing modalities for this in principle, as presented in the World Bank MSME Facility Board document which will be presented to IBRD's Board.  Bilateral and donor funding is expected to provide first loss and to increase the leverage secured by MENA Governments through the SME Facility.
Cost Nature: The total size of the SME Facility will be up to $500-600 million.

Project Description: The proposed project consists of a combined equity investment of up to $ 10 million in newly issued common shares of Aseguradora Magallanes S.A. and Aseguradora Magallanes de Garantía y Crédito S.A. (both companies combined, 'AM').  The capital increase is expected to reinforce AM's capital base. The project will represent IFC's first insurance investment in the Southern Cone, which should act as a catalyst for more minority investors to come into the market, both in Chile and in the rest of the sub-region.
Environmental Social Issues: The Project consists of an equity investment in the insurance business and has been categorized as FI. During appraisal, IFC reviewed the portfolio of activities supported by the Company to assess their Environmental and Social risks. Given the nature of the insurance activities of Magallanes, the Company will be required to review potential clients to ensure that it does not provide cover to activities in IFCs Exclusion List and to develop a simple screening procedure to identify risks arising from E&S issues. The company is also required to comply with the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions and to inform IFC in the event of any change in nature or scope of its business or operations.
Sponsor: AM was founded in 1956 in Punta Arenas, Chile as a general insurance company. It is a private sector institution controlled by the Chilean group Nalac, which currently owns 68% of each of the companies. Inversiones Las Dunas S.A. holds 8% of each of the companies and the remaining 24% is owned by a fragmented group of local shareholders, none of which owns more than 5%. Nalac is a Chilean holding company which operates in the real estate, engineering and financial sectors and whose main asset is Aseguradora Magallanes.
Cost Nature: The proposed project is an equity investment of up to $10 million in common shares of Aseguradora Magallanes S.A. and Aseguradora Magallanes de Garantia y Credito S.A. for an up to 10% equity stake.

Project Description:
IFC is considering a corporate investment to provide a $50 million C Loan to Ecom. This would allow the Company to (i) increase the amount of working capital financing it can borrow to expand its operations or sustain volumes during periods of high commodity prices, (ii) provide further capital to cover unexpected financial needs; and (iii) support Ecom's internal financing needs to further maintain and grow its business (e.g. risk management systems, sustainability initiatives, provision of technical and financial services to farmers). By supporting Ecom through long-term quasi-equity financing, IFC would help the Company continue to further implement its sustainability business plan, improve its corporate and supply chain E&S performance, through increasing traceability of commodities, developing regional/country level data integrating knowledge of child or forced labor and natural/critical habitat to monitor supply chain and focus efforts to promote productivity intensification in areas with identified risks, and adopting agro-commodity voluntary standards in the cocoa and cotton sectors.

The Ecom Group's diverse operations involve trading and processing of agro-commodities including coffee, cotton and cocoa. Trading operations worldwide place ECOM 3rd in coffee, 5th in cotton, and 7th in cocoa, and has long-established relationships with top multinational buyers, such as Mars, Nestle, Starbucks, Sara Lee, Kraft, and Hershey. 

With regard to physical assets associated with processing, Ecom operates 25 coffee wet mills worldwide, 2 cocoa processing plants in The Netherlands, and Mexico, cotton gins in Mexico and Paraguay, and will operate a cotton gin to be built in Tajikistan. Other traded products, are grains, rape, and sunseed. Ecom operates an oilseed crushing factory in Paraguay. Ecom has a non consolidated investment in hog farms operating under the name of Granjas Carroll in Mexico (GCM), however Ecom does not trade hogs as such. GCM has been awarded the certification of Empresa Socialmente Responable' (Socially Responsible Enterprise) for four years in a row.

One of Ecom's core strategies is to procure as directly as possible from farmers. Ecom views the sustainability of the farmers who supply to the Company as critical to its own success. Ecom's goal of buying directly from farmers and adding value to their productionin terms of improved quantity, quality and farmer incomeis aligned with the farmer's and IFC's developmental interest. In terms of development impact, IFC's current projects with Ecom reached a total of 121,280 coffee farmers worldwide.
Review Scope: The scope of review of this corporate investment to Ecom (or the 'Company') included site visits to Ecom headquarters in Pully, Switzerland, and at field operations in Tajikistan. IFC's environmental and social review included the assessment of Company's technical documentation, regarding environmental, occupational health and safety, labor, and social performance and its supply chain (coffee, cocoa, and cotton). Further information on the Environmental and Social (E&S) risks associated with the supply chain of some of the commodities (coffee, cocoa, cotton) traded by Ecom was obtained at ILO and UNICEF websites, and through IFC's custom-made reports from recognized environmental and social consultancy firms. The due diligence of IFC environmental and social development specialists for this investment also benefited from a range of commodities' related activities, namely: a) participation to the World Cocoa Foundation Partnership Meeting in October 2010 where the need for engagement in a collaborative program with existing sustainability interventions to address social, environmental and productivity issues was recommended; b) establishment of a team of IFC's E&S specialists and investment officers to further define supply chain E&S issues and IFC Sustainability Performance Standard requirements to address investments for traders; c) preparation of an E&S sector risk analysis for cocoa production in West Africa and for cotton production in Central Asia; d) pro-active coordination with World Bank, Unicef, and IFC Advisory Services to address country, sector, and project level E&S issues.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
E & S Categorization Rationale: 

While the existing investments of IFC in Ecom for the coffee sector have limited E&S impacts, IFC is treating this corporate investment as a Category A project, according to its Environmental and Social Review Procedures. The rational underlying this categorization is based on the well documented significant adverse social or environmental issues related to cocoa in West Africa and cotton in Central Asia, as described in PS2 (child labor) and PS 6 (deforestation), and the associated E&S residual risks given the supply chain dynamics. In such category A investment, IFC will continue to monitor the implementation of Ecom's procurement policy, and how Ecom is making use of its social and environmental management system to ensure the inclusion of E&S issues into its supply chain management system, and that ultimately guarantee that the company's operations are consistent with IFC Performance Standards and World Bank Group Environmental, Health and Safety General Guidelines (WBG General EHS Guidelines) to avoid and mitigate impacts, and monitor progress in establishing better E&S practices across its supply chain. Despite this provision, it is likely that Ecom's ability to manage their supply chain in some geographical areas will be challenging, and that there will be instances of child labor at suppliers fields that will not be consistent with PS2.

Project Description: IFC is considering providing a $50 million long term subordinated debt facility to ECOM Agroindustrial Corp. Ltd ('Ecom' or the 'Company'), which would support Ecom's internal financing needs to maintain and grow its business (e.g. risk management systems, sustainability initiatives, provision of services to farmers). Ecom is active in sourcing from Latin America, Africa and Asia, and the proposed project will support Ecom's global efforts to continue to source from smallholders and assist smallholders adopt Voluntary Commodities Standards and, as such, improve their overall Environmental and Social performance.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category A project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review due to the well documented significant adverse social (child labour) and environmental (deforestation) supply chain risks associated with the production and trade of cocoa in West Africa and cotton in Central Asia and residual E&S risks. In such category A investment, IFC will continue to monitor the implementation of Ecoms procurement policy, and how Ecom is making use of its social and environmental management system to ensure the inclusion of E&S issues into its supply chain management to avoid and mitigate impacts, and monitor progress in establishing better E&S practices across its supply chain. The implementation of the agreed measures ultimately guarantees that the companys operations are consistent with IFC Performance Standards and World Bank Group Environmental, Health and Safety General Guidelines (WBG General EHS Guidelines). Information about how the potential impacts will be addressed by Ecom is summarized in the Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) and in the Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) agreed with the client.

Project Description: Bhilwara Energy Limited ('BEL' or the 'Company'), an IFC investee company (IFC holds a 5.24% stake in the Company), wants to develop, own and operate a 51 MW wind farm ('the Project'), in Village Kukudwad, located in the Satara district, in the Maharashtra State in India.  The Project will be built under a fixed all inclusive EPC contract with ReGen Powertech, an Indian company that designs, manufactures and installs gearless wind turbine generators using german technology licensed from Vensys AG. The project will utilize 34 ReGen Vensys 1.5 MW turbines. The Project output will be sold to the Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company utility under a 13 year Power Purchase Agreement (PPA). In addition, the Project will be eligible to receive Generation Based Incentives ('GBI').
Impact: 1) Providing long term local currency financing: IFC is able to provide long term fixed rate rupee loans in India which is difficult in this market. Indian banks typically provide variable rate loans which adversely affect power project's viability due to interest rate fluctuations; 2) Financing of wind Independent Power Producers (IPPs): Foreign banks have largely been absent from wind IPP financing except in some cases. IFC's participation in the Project is likely to significantly help Bhilwara Energy complete the financing of this Project as well as help it in future fund raising; and 3) IFC involvement with the Project will help Bhilwara Energy in adopting a structured framework to manage its social and environmental systems which will act as a benchmark for its subsequent wind projects.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed investment in the Company and the Project is a Category B project because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. While all Performance Standards are applicable to this investment, IFCs environmental and social due diligence indicates that the proposed investment will have impacts which must be managed in a manner consistent with the following Performance Standards: PS 1: Social and Environmental Assessment and Management System;PS 2: Labor and Working Conditions; PS 3: Pollution Prevention and Abatement; and PS 4: Community Health, Safety and Security.Further details on the potential environmental and social impacts, corresponding mitigation measures, and guidance on how and where information about the Project can be obtained are provided in the IFC Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS).
Sponsor:
BEL is a holding company which invests and develops all hydro and other renewable projects of the LNJ Bhilwara Group ('Bhilwara Group' or the 'Sponsor'). BEL is held:  83.12% by the Bhilwara Group (through family and group entities; Rajasthan Spinning & Weaving Mills (17.41%) and HEG (25.80%)), 5.24% by IFC, 7.87% by  India Clean Energy III, and the balance 3.77% is held by institutional investors Wachovia, Jacob Ballas and New York Life Investment Fund. For the year ended March 31, 2010, its revenues and net income were $37.9 million and $21.8 million respectively on a consolidated basis. During the same period, BEL had a total asset of $534 million and total liabilities amounting to $ 314.5 million including $283.5 3 million of Long-term debt. 

IFC has an existing relationship with the Bhilwara Group in the AD Hydro Project in which IFC has committed (IFC Investment Projects #11632 and #26500), to provide total debt of about US$67 million and equity of about US$15 million (for a 12% stake). In 2010, IFC made an equity investment of US$25 million (Project#29157) to acquire a stake of approximately 5.24% in the Company.

Project Description: BGEL is a part of LNJ Bhilwara Group (the "Group"). The Group has diversified from textiles into power, IT services and graphite electrodes. BGEL is developing the 51.0 MW wind power Project at Kukudwad in Satara District, Maharashtra. The project will consist of 34 x 1.5 MW wind turbine generators (WTGs) located on three ridges adjacent to one another. Each turbine will be mounted on an 85 m high tubular steel tower and the blade swept area will cover 77 m in diameter. The Project is being developed by ReGen ('Developer') on a turnkey basis, which involves securing land and all necessary planning approvals and permits, provision of all material and equipment, construction and commissioning. Further, the Project will be operated and maintained by ReGen under an O&M contract with BGEL for the first 13 years.Each WTG will have a separate transformer switchyard and be connected to other WTGs and the substation via an above-ground interconnecting 33 kV line, eventually connecting to the 33/220 kV Hiwarwadi substation that will service a total wind farm capacity of around 200 MW and be constructed by the Maharashtra State Electricity Transmission Company Ltd. (MSETCL). The interconnecting lines will be mounted on 11 m high steel poles. The Hiwarwadi substation will be connected to the grid by an 8 km long 220 kV line in  line out (LILO) transmission line to the 220 kV Vita - Pandharpur S/C line at Hiwarwadi, to be installed by MSETCL. Other Project facilities will include a central monitoring station (CMS), maintenance workshop, stores depot and staff quarters. The CMS will be the site of the O&M hub for the entire project. A total of 17 km of earth roads will be constructed under the Project to provide access to the WTGs.The total land area required for the Project is expected to be around 75 ha, consisting of 1.0 ha per WTG, 22.1 ha for the access roads (13 m wide right-of-way) and the remainder for associated facilities. Typically, each WTG occupies around 0.5 ha (70 m x 70 m), consisting of the WTG foundation (5.5 m diameter), foundation spoil disposal area, transformer switchyard (5 m x 10 m) and crane hard stands. However, 2.4 ha of land is usually purchased for each WTG site located on private land to ensure that any additional area that may be disturbed during turbine construction and maintenance is covered and all landowners immediately adjacent to the WTG are compensated to create good local relations. The footprint of the interconnecting 33 kV lines is 1 x 1 m per pole, with poles typically spaced at around 40 m. The Project WTGs will be located on relatively flat ridge tops at elevations of between 860-930 m above mean sea level (amsl), around 60-90 m higher than the intervening valleys. Site land ownership consist of Government Forest (19 WTGs) and private land (15 WTGs). Ground cover on the ridges is mostly grassland, although some areas of privately owned land may be occasionally cropped (rainfed only).
Review Scope: IFC is considering a project loan to Bhilwara Green Energy Limited ('BGEL' or the 'Company') to finance a 51.0 MW of wind power project (the "Project") being implemented by the Company in Maharashtra state in India. IFC's review of this investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information made available by BGEL, including the: Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) of the Project dated March 2011; the engineering design and operation and maintenance agreement (O&M) with ReGen (the engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) contractor and O&M operator for the Project); ReGen's corporate management systems; and Bhilwara's Human Resource (HR) policies. The appraisal team interviewed BGEL's corporate management and ReGen's site professionals. The team inspected the proposed project site a ReGen project under construction owned by another developer, and another project in operation for several years neighboring the proposed Bhilwara Project site.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The proposed investment in the Project is classed as Category B because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines and design criteria. Potential adverse construction impacts are likely to be limited to project sites, short term, able to be effectively managed and mitigated, and likely to have no or limited impact on environmentally sensitive features and sites. Project operational impacts are also manageable and generally mitigable through appropriate design and the implementation of suitable engineering and management measures. BGEL will manage its environmental and social performance in accordance with applicable national and local laws and regulations and international standards, including IFC's Performance Standards on Social and Environmental Sustainability.
Sector: BC - Wind Power - Renewable Energy Generation

Company Name: YAPI VE KREDI BANKASI ANONIM SIRKETI
Project Description: IFC proposes to purchase up to $75 million in bonds (up to 5 years) and act as one of the core investors to facilitate a successful issuance of a Diversified Payments Rights securitization by Yapi ve Kredi Bankasi A.S. in Turkey. The proceeds would be on-lent i) to small farmers and agribusiness companies and ii) sustainable energy financing -energy efficiency and renewable energy finance projects.
Impact:
- The Project would generate a range of social and economic benefits, including economic growth, higher productivity of farming and food & beverages processing, as well as enhance banking penetration in rural areas, which represent around 35 percent of Turkey's total population.
- The Project would directly support the renewable energy sector in Turkey by increasing access to long-term funding at attractive pricing levels for RE borrowers, and also contribute to a reduction of green-house gas emissions.
Environmental Social Issues: This project with a new IFC client has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure and will involve long-term investments in the Sustainable Energy and the agriculture sector. IFC''s appraisal will focus on YKB''s capacity to develop and implement a Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS) to comply with the IFC Exclusion List, national environmental and social laws, and the IFC Performance Standards, if necessary. IFC will also appraise YKB''s labor policies against IFC''s Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working Conditions.
Sponsor: Yapi ve Kredi Bankasi A.S. ('YKB') was established in 1944 as Turkey's first nationwide private bank.  The Bank took its present form as a result of the merger between YKB and Kocbank A.S. in 2006, which followed the partnership of UniCredit and Koc Holding in the form of a equal owned joint venture in 2002 through the parent company Koc Financial Services the first foreign partnership in Turkish financial sector. Koc Financial Services then acquired Yapi and merged two banks.  As of December 2010, it is the fourth largest private bank in terms of total assets with a market share of 10.4 percent in terms of loans.  With its 868 branches it has a wide geographical coverage throughout Turkey and is well represented in the regions outside major urban centers.
Cost Nature: The project's target amount is approximately $400 million of which IFC would consider investing up to $75 million from its own account.

Company Name: Nature Elements Asia Renewable Energy and Cleantech Fund LP
Project Description: The Nature Elements Asia Renewable Energy and Cleantech Fund, L.P. (the 'Fund') is a private equity fund that will invest in a diversified portfolio of clean energy and cleantech projects. The Fund will invest in China (estimated at approximately 80% of total investments) and other Asian countries including Vietnam, Thailand, Indonesia, and the Philippines (estimated at 20% of total investments).  The Fund is targeting $200 million in commitments and will be managed by Nature Elements Capital ('NECAP' or the 'Manager').
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI project under IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  As a start up Fund, the appraisal will focus on: management team selection and experience; investment eligibility criteria; approach to due diligence process, specifically on the identification, assessment and management of environmental and social risks to ensure compliance with applicable countries laws and regulations, IFCs Exclusion List, and the Performance Standards and approaches to portfolio management in both majority and minority stakeholder positions.  A Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS), appropriately scaled and resourced, will be required as a condition of IFCs investment.  This must include assignment of responsibilities and accountabilities for E&S issues, implementing procedures and processes, access to consultants and other technical expertise as needed, training, monitoring and review processes.  Additionally, IFC will review the implementation and performance of the SEMS for the first few sub-projects, prior to the Funds investment decision, to ensure that the SEMS is robust and has adequately addressed the environmental and social issues. The purpose of such notification and review is to ensure that sub-projects'' compliance with the applicable requirements can be demonstrated.

Nature Elements Capital ('NECAP' or the 'Manager') is a private equity firm in Hong Kong founded, solely owned, and led by Dr. KK Chan. NECAP's management team come with strong technical expertise in the climate change area, and members have worked together at a major cleantech investment firm prior to coming together for the proposed Fund.  

NECAP has raised a separate RMB fund in the amount of RMB 250 million, primarily from the Chinese local authorities.  The RMB fund invests in earlier stage, smaller scale venture capital projects in western China, primarily in the Chongqing region.

Project Description: The proposed project involves an equity investment by IFC in Vortex Engineering Private Limited (Vortex) which develops and installs low cost ATMs across rural and semi-urban areas. Vortex is a pioneer in the development of ATMs that have low capital and operational costs, have a lesser power consumption as compared to conventional ATMs and are more suited for rural usage possessing the ability for biometric authentication, dispensing soiled notes and the capability to run on solar power.
Impact: 1.	Increased access to finance in rural areas: The project is intended to increase access to finance; particularly basic banking services such as cash withdrawal and bill payment by installation of a large number of rural ATMs across India. These ATMs can potentially be used as a platform for transactions for other financial inclusion projects.2.	Greenhouse Gases savings impact: Vortex''s rural ATMs consume substantially less power than conventional ATMs and can be operated using solar power.3.	Demonstration effect: This project shall demonstrate a commercially viable model of domestically developed, technology enabled, low cost ATMs that can increase access to banking in previously unbanked areas through design of products tailor-made to suit the requirements of these areas and customer segment.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category C project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Key risks and issues related to this category C project include the Company''s capacity, staffing and management systems to ensure that its projects and operations meet IFC Performance Standards, in particular: Working conditions to ensure fair, safe and healthy working conditions for labor including employees and contract workers;Procedures to ensure contractor compliance with applicable labor and safety laws;Utilization of equipment and operational practices that maximize conservation of energy; andHandling, storage and disposal of hazardous materials and hazardous wastes (such as e-waste, batteries, oil, capacitors etc.).
Sponsor: Vortex is founded by Mr. L. Kannan (currently the Chief Technology Officer of Vortex) who is a leading technocrat and an expert on ATM design. Apart from the founders, other shareholders in Vortex include Oasis Fund, Raymond Stata, VenturEast, Aavishkaar and Vishal Bharat Comnet.
Cost Nature: IFC plans to make a minority equity investment of up to $2 million in Vortex Engineering Private Limited.

Project Description: IFC proposes to make an equity investment of up to approximately 5 million, not to exceed 20% of total commitments in Fonds Cauris Croissance II ('Cauris II').  IFC will be considered a subsequent investor contributing capital after first closing of the fund.  Cauris II is a private equity fund which will make equity and quasi-equity investments in small and medium enterprise (SME) companies in West Africa, primarily West African Economic Monetary Union (WAEMU) countries including Benin, Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Guinea Bissau, Mali, Niger, Senegal, and Togo.  The Fund has a committed capital target size of up to 60 million.
Impact: The Fund will achieve development impact by increasing access to financing for small and mid-sized companies in Francophone West Africa which are largely ignored by the larger funds; investing in frontier markets such as Benin, Burkina Faso, Guinea, Mali, Niger and Togo, supporting a local emerging Fund Manager in the region; investing in growth companies of a local emerging Fund Manager in the region; providing hands-on monitoring and guidance to the management of SME companies through board/management participation; sharing environmental and social international best practices with a local SME Fund Manager.  The investment is expected to create above average employment and accelerate economic growth across the region.  The investment will be across a diversity of sectors.  The Fund's investment in target companies will range from Euro 2-4.5 million and will consist mainly of strategic minority stakes, with board representation and shareholder right to influence the strategic direction of the company and conduct of management.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  During appraisal IFC analyzed the FIs potential portfolio pipeline and sectors of investment and determined the Applicable Performance Requirements based on an analysis of the potential social and environmental risks associated with the expected portfolio, and considering IFCs investment.  The Fund will target high-growth SMEs in the West Africa Economic Monetary Union (WAEMU) and neighboring countries such as Guinea, Mauritania, Ghana and Cape Verde.  The industry sectors of the pipeline investments analyzed are generally of a medium risk nature.  The Applicable Performance Requirements are the IFC Exclusion List, the applicable Social and Environmental Laws and Regulations of relevant countries, as well as the IFCs Performance Standards.  IFC also reviewed the Funds existing Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS), and capacity to implement the same. It was found that the Fund has an SEMS, and capacity to implement it, which needs be enhanced to ensure compliance with IFCs policy requirements.  Based on the Applicable Performance Requirements, and Fund SEMS and capacity review, the project will be required to: (i) Upgrade its SEMS prior to commitment; (iii) Provide IFC with the Social and Environmental Due Diligence for the first three investments, prior to the Funds investment, to enable IFC to review the implementation and performance of the clients SEMS; (iv) Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor:
The Fund will be domiciled in Mauritius and managed by Cauris Capital Partners II ('Cauris', 'Fund Manager' or 'Manager'), a local fund manager based in Lome, Togo with a track record managing SME investments in two previous funds in the same WAEMU region including challenging IDA countries.  The Fund Manager currently has three partners from Togo.

Noel Yawo Eklo, Togolese, joined Cauris in 1995 and was a co-founder of Cauris Management the fund manager in 1997.  He became CEO in 2002 and led changes in the fund's strategy which led to successful exits and the raising of a follow-on fund.  Prior to joining Cauris, Noel was deputy accountant at Hypermarche Auchan in France and auditor at FICAO in Lome, Togo.  He is a graduate of Ecole Supérieure d'Informatique et de Gestion de Paris and Ecole Supérieure de Gestion de Paris France.

Visseho Thierry Gnassounou, Togolese, joined Cauris in 2001 and is in charge of the Abidjan office.  Prior to joining Cauris, Thierry was auditor at Afrique Audit and Consulting in Lome, Togo.  He holds a Bachelor Degree in Economics and M.S. in Finance from the University of Montreal.

Lolo Kouassi Nolitse, Togolese, joined Cauris in 1996 and is among the co-founders of Cauris Management in 1997.  Prior to joining Cauris in 1996, Lolo was an analyst at a consulting firm in Lomé.  He holds a Master degree in Management from the University of Lomé.

In addition to the three partners, there are three investment staff as follows:  Constant Kouamé-Kra, Ivoiran, Associate, Schola Laban, Togolese, Analyst and Timothée Kokou Akodo, Togolese, Accounts  Manager. Company Name: FONDATION ARRAWAJ DE LA FINANCE INCLUSIVE
Project Description:
The proposed project is a MAD70  million ($9 million equivalent) partial credit guarantee facility (the ' Guarantee Facility') to allow Fondation pour le Développement Local et le Partenariat (FONDEP), an existing IFC client, to raise up to MAD210 million ($27 million equivalent) in local currency senior financing from the Moroccan banking sector. The Guarantee Facility will have up to 5 year tenor with up to 1 year grace period.

FONDEP is Morocco's third largest microfinance institution in Morcocco.  As of December 31, 2010, FONDEP had a loan portfolio $80 million equivalent and 132 thousand active clients.  FONDEP has been granting solidarity group loans and individual loans, primarily in semi-urban and rural areas.  As of December 2010, the portfolio was composed of 58% solidarity loans, 36% individual loans and 6% housing loans.  FONDEP has 176 branches and 870 employees.
Impact:
Job Creation and Poverty Reduction:   The proposed investment is expected to have a high impact in facilitating micro and small enterprises access financial services - an area of key strategic priority to IFC.  As IFC assists FONDEP with sourcing additional funding,  this project addresses the need to serve those segments of the population that lack the most access to credit; hence seeking to (i) reduce income disparities in the country, and (ii) contribute to job creation in underserved regions.

Demonstration Effect and Sector Development:  IFC's partial credit guarantee will help mobilize local currency financing for a microfinance institution in a post crisis context thus sending a strong signal to donors and commercial banks, which will help mobilize additional funding to the sector moving forward.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves IFC support for the business of Microfinance, and has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. During appraisal, IFC analyzed the FI portfolio, for types of transactions, size, tenor and industry sectors and determined the Applicable Performance Requirements based on an analysis of the potential Social and Environmental risks associated with the FI portfolio and considering IFCs investment. The Applicable Performance Requirements are: 	The IFC Microfinance Exclusion List; and	The applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and regulations.Based on the Applicable Performance Requirements and review of the FI''s existing Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS) and capacity, the project will be required to: 	Provide evidence of implementation of the existing SEMS, prior to commitment to the satisfaction of IFC.	Continue to retain a qualified person(s) to manage and implement the procedures, prior to commitment.	Demonstrate commitment and resources to implementing the SEMS procedures and ensure training is provided to staff.	Demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions.      Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: Founded by Mr. Mouatassim Belghazi, academic and entrepreneur, FONDEP began its operations in Rabat in 1996 as a non-government organization (NGO). It was among the first movers in the Moroccan market to establish a financial institution dedicated to providing credit services to micro and small enterprises. In 2000, FONDEP was granted its license to operate as a microfinance institution (MFI). FONDEP was founded on two main principles: to contribute to the integration of low-income households and individuals into the formal financial system and to contribute to the improvement of the livelihood of such households and individuals
Cost Nature: The Guarantee Facility is intended to cover up to 50% of up to MAD210 million worth of credit lines extended by local commercial banks.  The Guarantee Facility will partially cover the principal and interest payments and is expected to have a tenor of up to 5 years with 1-year grace period.

Project Description: The Project involves setting up a new non-banking finance company ('FinCo' or the 'Company'), focused on providing financing and advisory activities mainly to small and medium enterprises ('SME') in India that are engaged in businesses that have a positive environmental impact and fight climate change.  FinCo will offer debt financing and advisory services in areas such as cleaner production, energy efficiency, renewable energy, sustainable water and sanitation and waste management, environmental cleanup, carbon finance, emissions reduction, effluent disposal etc.
Impact:
- Demonstration Effect: This will be the first specialized green finance company in emerging markets; its success would encourage its replication in other markets with significant positive impact globally.

- Environmental Impact: Through the activities of the companies that FinCo finances and advises, FinCo is expected to have a significant positive impact on the environment.

- Wider Reach: Given the strong sponsorship of the Company by Tata Group, the support from IFC and other high quality partners, the Company will have the credibility and the network to create a wider reach across sectors and market segments in the environmental finance market in India.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  During appraisal, IFC will analyze FinCos proposed investment activities for types of transactions, size, tenor and industry sectors and determine the Applicable Performance Requirements, if any, that would include a combination of (i) the IFC Exclusion List; (ii) the applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and regulations; and (iii) the IFC Performance Standards. IFC will also appraise FinCos labor practices according to the IFCs Performance Standards 2: Labor and Working Conditions and recommend the capacity to FinCo to manage social and environmental risks and to establish and maintain a Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS). Based on the review, the project will be required to: Develop a SEMS to the satisfaction of IFC.Identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the SEMS.Commit to implement the SEMS, to ensure that its investments/activities are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements.Demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions.Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.

The key sponsor for the Project is Tata Capital Limited ('Tata Capital'), subject to the approval of its Board. Tata Capital is a subsidiary of Tata Sons Limited and caters to the diverse needs of retail, corporate and institutional customers, directly or indirectly through its subsidiaries through consumer finance & advisory services, corporate finance which includes commercial and infrastructure finance, securities business, investment banking and private equity. Tata Capital is headquartered in Mumbai and has a wide network of over 100 branches spanning all critical markets in India. Tata Capital is also setting its footprints in the overseas markets by setting up an international subsidiary  Tata Capital Pte Ltd. - headquartered in Singapore. 

IFC and other private investors propose to participate in the project through equity investment. Other private investors could include local and international institutions who will be identified shortly.
