Project Description:
The proposal is to create the Cleantech Innovation Facility (CTIF), a $60 million delegated authority facility which would include up to $15 million of concessional funding to invest equity or quasi-equity in early stage Cleantech companies.  The CTIF will extend IFC's reach to a group of innovative Cleantech companies (companies producing goods or services which deliver GHG emission avoidance) that have strong potential development impact in terms of environmental and social benefits, while also targeting IDA countries and/or Bottom of the Pyramid markets.  

The CTIF will target companies that are innovative in terms of technology or business models across a broad spectrum of sectors, including clean energy, transportation, water, waste, building and energy efficiency, and will contribute towards GHG emission avoidance and increased access to modern, healthy energy and water services, among others.
Impact: Impacts will vary investment by investment but tax receipts, job creation, and GHG emission avoidance will be indicators for all investments.  Other impacts may include increased access to water and energy for the underserved, recycling leading to reduced pressure on landfills, and technology transfer from the North to the South and from South to South.  Both directly and via demonstration effects, the CTIF aims to bring more capital and talent to Cleantech in development countries, and aims to support innovation in technology and business models.
Environmental Social Issues: Each proposed investment within the CTIF will undergo environmental and social appraisal, and is expected to involve environmental and social risk at a level between minimal and limited, in this facility classified as Category FI according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Depending on the level of environmental and social risk in each investment, a classification of Category C or Category B is expected for individual CTIF investments.  IFC will review all projects environmental and social performance from appraisal through supervision as needed.  Where a project is Category B, IFC will publicly disclose an Environmental and Social Review Summary.The Facility is expected to yield strong environmental and social benefits, particularly in terms of GHG emission avoidance.   As investments will be in early stage companies, they are expected more frequently than mainstream investments to have IFC provide guidance on establishing environmental and social management systems to comply with IFC Performance Standards.
Sponsor:
The project will be co-sponsored by the IFC and the IFC-GEF Earth Fund.  The IFC-GEF Earth Fund is the first operational platform under the GEF Earth Fund and comprises $10 million contributed by IFC and $30 million contributed by the Global Environment Facility (GEF).  The mandate of the IFC-GEF Earth Fund is to support, via advisory services and concessional finance, market transformation through testing or scaling up new technologies, new business models, or financial mechanisms which mitigate climate change or preserve biodiversity.   

Private sector innovation often arises through small, young companies and this type of companies will predominate in the CTIF portfolio, which will also aim to be geographically diverse.
Cost Nature:
The CTIF would be comprised of up to $45 million for IFC's own account, and up to $15 million of concessional funding from the IFC-GEF Earth Fund.   The CTIF will invest equity or quasi-equity in about 15 small Cleantech projects of earlier stage than 'business as usual' at IFC.  Blending concessional funds into the CTIF will partially mitigate the financial risks associated with this kind of investing and will therefore allow IFC to invest in earlier stage and more innovative Cleantech companies than it does today. 

CTIF investments will fund project costs such as capital equipment, land, working capital and operating expenses for companies which have not yet reached profitability.
Investment: 45.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity45.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: This is a global facility.  Investments may focus on any Part 2 country, most transactions will focus on IDA countries and frontier regions.

Depending on the level of environmental and social risk in each investment, a classification of Category C or Category B is expected for individual CTIF investments.  IFC will review all projects environmental and social performance from appraisal through supervision as needed.  Where a project is Category B, IFC will publicly disclose an Environmental and Social Review Summary.The Facility is expected to yield strong environmental and social benefits, particularly in terms of GHG emission avoidance.   As investments will be in early stage companies, they are expected more frequently than mainstream investments to have IFC provide guidance on establishing environmental and social management systems to comply with IFC Performance Standards.

Project Description: Tbilvino is the largest Georgian wine exporter by volume and procures from more than 300 small grape farmers located in the Kakheti Region. Tbilvino exclusively focuses on wine production and does not engage in any production or distribution of hard alcohol, which is an exception among Georgian wine producers. The Company is the result of privatization of a state wine company from the former Soviet Union period. The Company has gone through needed modernization over the course of the years.  The Company is now ready to undergo a new investment of around $3.0 million investment program in FY 2011-12 to improve product quality and safety standards and gain significant cost savings in order to improve its competitiveness and enter into new markets. IFC has been asked to provide $1.5 million A loan to support the Companys investment program. The planned investment program includes:1.) Developing grape collecting and crushing facilities, which will cost around $1.5 million. Currently the Company is renting primary facilities for grape collecting and crushing. Tbilvinos main winery (bottling lines, wine cellar,) is located in Tbilisi, where grape juice is transported from regions and wine is processed, bottled and preserved. Proposed investment in own primary production facilities will help to i)  improve  product quality; ii) strengthen internal control processes through each link of the supply chain; and iii) enhance the food safety management systems in order to penetrate new markets. 2.) Providing around $1.0 million incremental working capital. The company plans to increase sales by 40% next year and enter into new markets, which will require additional working capital. Incremental working capital will be mostly used to purchase grapes during the harvest season, which will transfer income to approximately 300 Georgian farmers.3.) Providing around $0.5 million for maintenance CAPEX for existing fixed assets including increasing capacity of wine holding refrigeration tanks.
Review Scope: The IFCs appraisal of this project included the following:Tbilisi facilities, three vineyards and rented crushing and fermentation units in Khakheti region were visited on 21-23th of June, 2011.Meetings were held with Tbilvino management; Executive director, department heads of winemaking, bottling and warehousing, chief engineer, project engineer, chief of laboratory and HR clerk in Tbilisi facilities and farmers in Kvareli village, Khakheti region. Review of available corporate environmental and social documents, including; employment contracts, records of trainings, safety instructions, ISO 9001-ISO 22000 Integrated management system procedures manual, ISO 9001-ISO 22000 Integrated management system policy manual, Hazard Analysis, HACCP Plan, Organization and Process Interaction charts, flow charts for wine production processes, bottling and packaging flow chart, IFC E&S Questionnaire, Ministry of Agriculture Food Safety Audit report, laboratory instructions and up to date calibration reports, Operation License, ISO 9001 and ISO 22000 certifications.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The key environmental, social and occupational health & safety issues reviewed with this investment include; quality, environmental and safety management systems, supply chain management, child labor, labor transparency, food safety programs and certification at processing and commercialization, organic and packaging waste, water consumption and waste water treatment, energy efficiency and air emissions, occupational health and safety, land acquisition, life, fire and traffic safety.The Project has limited potential adverse environmental and social impacts which can readily be addressed through effective implementation of good international industry practices and requirements of IFCs Performance Standards and Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) guidelines. This proposed investment is therefore a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures.

Project Description: Axis Bank (the Bank) is amongst Indias largest private sector banks with a network of 1,390 branches & extension counters, and 6,270 ATMs as of 31st March 2011. The Bank has a loan portfolio of $31.97 billion and a deposit base of $ 42.49 billion as of 31st March 2011.  The proposed investment involves a long term US dollar loan on IFCs own account and mobilization by IFC of parallel loans from international investors to the Singapore branch of Axis Bank. The proceeds of the IFC loan will be utilized by the Bank to on-lend to Indian companies as external commercial borrowings for projects relating to climate change projects. Such projects would include projects related to renewable energy, energy efficiency improvement, water management and related areas.
Impact: 1. Wider Impact: With a wide presence in India, Axis Bank has a natural advantage in terms of client reach which will allow it to expand rapidly in this area with IFC''s support. Through the proposed facility, Axis Bank can support a wider range of clients in the renewable energy and climate change space.2. Demonstration Effect: Axis Bank''s expansion in this space is likely to help attract other financial institutions to increase their risk appetite and invest more actively in Climate Change sectors.3. Greenhouse Gases (GHGs) savings: The proposed investment will result in substantial savings of GHG emissions as it will encourage investment in clean energy projects.4. Institution Building: IFC''s support to Axis Bank will help it to scale up its capacity to assess clean energy projects through sharing of its experience and knowledge of the sector worldwide.

During appraisal, IFC will analyze the FI portfolio and the activities proposed to be supported with IFC financing for types of transactions, size, tenor and industry sectors and determine the Applicable Performance Requirements, if any, that would include a combination of (i) The IFC Exclusion List; (ii) The applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and regulations and (iii) The IFC Performance Standards.IFC will also appraise the FIs labor practices according to the IFCs Performance Standards 2: Labor and Working Conditions and review the capacity of the FI to manage social and environmental risks and to establish and maintain a Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS). Based on the review, the project will be required to:Develop a Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS), prior to commitment to the satisfaction of IFCIdentify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the SEMSCommit to implement the SEMS, to ensure that its investments/activities supported by IFC financing are in compliance with the Applicable Performance RequirementsDemonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working ConditionsSubmit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC
Sponsor: Axis Bank is a listed on Indias National Stock Exchange (NSE) and Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE). Axis Bank was promoted jointly by the Unit Trust of India (UTI, now under the Administrator of the Specified Undertaking of the UTI -- SUUTI), Life Insurance Corporation of India (LIC), General Insurance Corporation Ltd., National Insurance Company Ltd., The New India Assurance Company, The Oriental Insurance Corporation and United India Insurance Company. The promoters cumulatively hold a 37.21% stake in Axis Bank with Foreign Institutional Investors (FIIs) holding an additional 37.68% stake as of 31st March 2011.

Project Description: Established in 1962, Tbilvino (the Company or Tbilvino) is one of the largest Georgian wine-makers and exporters, concentrates exclusively on wine production and procures grapes from more than 300 Georgian farmers, located in Kakheti Region of Georgia. The Proposed IFC loan will be will be utilized for: (i) construction of primary facilities for grape collecting and crushing, in Kvareli region of Georgia; (ii) working capital requirement and (iii) additional capital expenditures to increase capacity of wine holding refrigeration tanks (collectively the Project).
Impact: The project will have following development impact: i) Promotion of formal private sector abiding by rules, regulations and obligations; ii) Creation and preservation of  direct and indirect employment in rural areas of Georgia, where the job opportunities are scarce; iii) Linkage to farmers - IFC''s support will ensure the sustainability and growth of income for more than 300 Georgian farmers; iv) Improvement of product quality and food safety management systems, compared to uncontrolled producers; v) Contribution to the recovery of Georgia''s wine sector, helping to increase the Country''s export potential; vi) Generating additional amount of taxes paid by the Company to the Government.
Environmental Social Issues: This investment is a Category B project under IFCs Policy on Social and Environmental Sustainability because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized good international industry practices, guidelines, design criteria, local regulations and industry certification schemes. The key environmental, social and occupational health & safety issues reviewed with this investment include; quality, environmental and safety management systems, supply chain management, child labor, labor transparency, food safety programs and certification at processing and commercialization, organic and packaging waste, water consumption and waste water treatment, energy efficiency and air emissions, occupational health and safety, land acquisition, life, fire and traffic safety.
Sponsor: The Project Sponsors are Mr. Zurab Margvelashvi and Mr. George Margvelashvili, Georgian citizens. The Sponsors own 100% of the Company.
Cost Nature: The total Project cost is estimated at $3 million. The proposed IFC investment is a $1.5 million A loan for IFCs own account.

Kvareli is one of the main grape growing regions in Georgia and new facilities will be located close to the farmers, who are the main suppliers of Tbilvino.

Project Description: The proposed project is comprised of a senior loan investment in Alternatifbank A.S. (ABank or the Bank) of up to $25,000,000 which would be used to support women-owned small and medium enterprises (SME) and SMEs in general in Turkey.
Impact: The key development objective of this project is to increase financial inclusion in Turkey. The project is designed to improve access to finance for SMEs in Turkey, with a special focus on women owned businesses (at least 50% of the project amount will be used to on-lend to women owned SMEs). By working with ABank, a well-run, mid-tier bank with a particular focus on SMEs, this project is intended to demonstrate the business opportunity presented by women entrepreneurs as an under-served market.
Environmental Social Issues: This project, which consists of a senior loan to ABank has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. IFC''s existing investment in ABank consists of a subordinated loan. ABank has established a Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS) to screen on lending activities against the IFC Exclusion List, applicable environmental and social national laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards for high risk transactions. The Bank is in the process of developing guidelines for the implementation of the SEMS.For this particular project, IFC''s applicable requirements will be to ensure that loans to SMEs are screened against the IFC Exclusion List, and applicable environmental and social national laws and regulations.
Sponsor: The Sponsor, ABank, is a medium sized bank providing corporate and commercial banking services with a focus on SMEs through 63 branches in Turkey. The Bank is 96% controlled by Anadolu Group, with the balance publicly quoted at Istanbul Stock Exchange. Anadolu Group is a leading Turkish conglomerate, operating in various industries including beverages, automotive, financial services, energy, tourism, consumer durables, healthcare, IT and stationary.

Project Description: PROGIMMO S. A (Progimmo or the Company), a local property developer in Burundi, intends to build and manage a modern office/commercial building in Bujumbura (the Project).The Project will consist of two three story structures with about 7,000 m2 and adequate parking.  The design of the building will conform to international life, fire and safety standards.
Impact: - Contribute to filling the gap between supply and demand for quality office space in Bujumbura and provide much needed property infrastructure which is necessary to attract and retain investment in this post conflict country;-	Private sector development, an important engine for growth, in a post-conflict country;- Introduce new building standards to the market; - Have a demonstration effect on other local companies to pursue similar commercial property development projects;- Create opportunity for linkages and benefit to other sectors of the economy, from suppliers to tenants who will benefit from additional quality office space;-	Create employment (direct and indirect) for about 200 people during construction and about 100 post-construction;-	Increase in government revenues through taxes paid.
Environmental Social Issues: This is category B project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure due to the limited number of potential impacts and risks associated with the project.   The project is located in close proximity to the central business district of Bujumbura on land that was previously vacant and thus no resettlement was required.  In addition, the land was previously disturbed and no issues related to biodiversity were identified.  Key issues include the management of occupational health and safety during the construction phase, the supply and quality of potable water, disposal of waste water and compliance with recognized building standards, included that related to life and fire safety.  Adequate mitigation measures have been identified for these issues and via implementation of the project''s Environmental and Social Action Plan, the development will comply with IFC''s requirements upon commissioning.
Sponsor: The sponsor is Mr. Edouard Hicintuka, a 58 year old Burundian businessman and property developer.  He incorporated PROGIMMO in June 2005 to develop and manage commercial properties in Burundi.
Cost Nature: Total Project cost is estimated at $ 8.3 million.The proposed IFC investment is expected to consist of an A loan of up to $ 1.5 million and a C loan of up to $ 2.0 million on IFCs account.

Location: The Project will be located on a 8,250 m2 plot of land in a new neighborhood off Avenue du Large in Bujumbura.  The plot is close to Lake Tanganyika, about 2 km from the city centre, and is easily accessible to major roads.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is category B project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure due to the limited number of potential impacts and risks associated with the project.   The project is located in close proximity to the central business district of Bujumbura on land that was previously vacant and thus no resettlement was required.  In addition, the land was previously disturbed and no issues related to biodiversity were identified.  Key issues include the management of occupational health and safety during the construction phase, the supply and quality of potable water, disposal of waste water and compliance with recognized building standards, included that related to life and fire safety.  Adequate mitigation measures have been identified for these issues and via implementation of the project''s Environmental and Social Action Plan, the development will comply with IFC''s requirements upon commissioning.

Project Description: The Simandou iron ore project is located in South-east Guinea, approximately 600km from the Guinean coast.  The current phase of the project (the Project or Simandou III) entails the completion of a Preliminary Engineering Assessment (PEA), Definitive Engineering (DE), early construction works and advance ordering of long lead items at an estimated expenditure of more than $3.5 billion over the next eighteen months, and culminating in the formal decision to proceed with the full development of the operation (Decision to Mine).  A large high grade iron ore resource has been delineated and is expected to support a 95Mtpa mining operation for over thirty years.  Development of the mining operation would include development of new rail and port infrastructure to export the ore.  This infrastructure component is expected to account for around two-thirds of the total cost of the Simandou iron ore project.
Impact: Economic transformation for Guinea: At full production the Simandou iron ore project will be the largest mining and commercial project in the country and will make a large direct positive contribution to Guinea''s economy for decades. Annual taxes and royalties to the Government of Guinea have the potential, at full production and after tax holiday, to exceed US$1 billion p.a. (subject to iron ore prices) and will directly employ over 4,000 Guineans.Infrastructure development:  The Simandou infrastructure, particularly the rail, will open up the east of the country to new private sector development opportunities. Simfer has committed to the provision of a multi-use/multi-user facility, which will include passenger rail services.  The construction of the rail will also require the construction of a feeder road network along its alignment, further facilitating local movement and trade.  Emerging sustainable mining sector:  Guinea is an emerging iron ore producer and, based on its resource endowment, is expected to become one of the main global producers in the coming years. The Simandou iron ore project will be the first of several large projects and will set key benchmarks going forward in terms of standards of operation and E&S management.  In addition, Simandou''s infrastructure could in the future potentially be shared on a commercial basis with other emerging iron ore operations in the region.Community development:  Simfer will spend a minimum of 0.25% of project revenues on socioeconomic activities in affected prefectures (particularly Beyla and Forecariah), including investments in electricity, roads, water and sanitation, communication, and health and education.
Environmental Social Issues: While the IFC environmental and social categorization when IFC made its first investment in 2006 (i.e. Simandou I and II) was a B, consistent with the very early stage nature of the project at that time, this categorization has now been revised to A, on the basis that a proportion of the investments planned during Simandou III (through to Decision to Mine) will include initial development activities, including early construction works.The main E&S issues identified at this stage are: 1) biodiversity, 2) in-migration and 3) water usage. Numerous biodiversity studies have been completed (by Simfer and several reputable international consultants) for the mine site areas and similar studies will be undertaken for the rail and port sites. The mine site areas include various levels of protected forest, which are rich in biodiversity, and inter alia include endangered species, including West African chimpanzees.Significant in-migration has already occurred in towns and villages near Simandou (particularly Traorela, Beyla and Moribadou) and is expected to increase as the project progresses.  Studies to understand the in-migration dynamics have been completed and a number of activities have started as a result, including village planning for Moribadou and employment information centres. The Simandou mountain range is part of a key watershed at the head of a complex hydrographic system feeding the Niger and other important regional river systems.  A number of hydrological and climatological studies have been completed to assess potential impacts of mining at Simandou and a strategic plan to manage those impacts is in progress.Finally, although the precise alignment of the rail and location of the port are yet to be finalized, there may be as many as 2,000 economically or physically displaced households along the infrastructure corridor.  Simfer is committed to implementing the Simandou iron ore project in accordance with international best practices and IFCs Performance Standards.More details regarding the above can be found in the current Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS).GovernanceGovernance in Guinea has historically been weak.  In 2010 Transparency International ranked the country 164th of 178 countries and the World Banks Ease of Doing Business ranked Guinea 179th of 183.  Nonetheless, following successful Presidential elections in November 2010, the Government of Guinea has continued to show a strong commitment to strengthening governance and ensuring the country derives greater benefits from the mining sector.  The country has embarked on a process of reform that includes a review of all existing mining concessions. In this regard, the Government recently completed the review of the Simandou concession culminating in a revision of the convention terms.  Guinea has made an important stride forward by reaching out to the IMF regarding the management of the $700 million settlement sum (equivalent to approximately 15% of GDP) received under the revised convention terms. On transparency, Guinea became an EITI candidate country in 2007 but was (voluntarily) suspended in 2009 due to the political unrest in the country.  This suspension was lifted in March 2011 and Guinea has until mid-2012 to complete EITI Validation.  The country appears to be moving in the right direction and with the wide support of the international community following the recent advent of democracy, it is expected to complete the EITI validation process and to continue strengthen its governance structures.  Guinea is already working closely with the IMF and the World Bank on reaching Completion Point under HIPC.  Decision Point was achieved in 2000 when it was confirmed that around $2 billion in debt (of $3 billion) would be written off subject to meeting certain criteria on fiscal management and stability.  The success of a world class project such as Simandou will reinforce this reform process. For its part, Simfer recognizes that good corporate governance and transparency in the sector will enhance the developmental impact of the Simandou iron ore project and, in line with IFC requirements, will continue to disclose publicly all material payments made in the form of taxes, royalties, and fees to the Government.
Sponsor: The mining concession holder and project company is Simfer SA, which is owned 95% by Rio Tinto plc and 5% by IFC.  The Government of Guinea has a right to acquire up to a 35% interest in Simfer (under various option arrangements) and a 51% fully funded interest in the related Simandou infrastructure (port and rail).  Subject to satisfaction of certain completion requirements, Chalco (a subsidiary of Chinalco, a multinational Chinese state-backed holding company) will have an indirect participation in Simfer through a joint venture agreement with Rio Tinto plc. Rio Tinto plc is a diversified multinational mining and resources group with headquarters in London and Melbourne. It is the worlds largest bauxite, alumina and aluminum producer and second largest iron ore producer. It is an industry leader in sustainable mining and leads numerous mining sector initiatives on conservation, land rehabilitation, biodiversity, climate change and water and energy use.  Rio Tinto plc is listed on the London Stock Exchange and the Australian Securities Exchange.
Cost Nature: The total project cost for Simandou III (through to Decision to Mine) is currently forecast at in excess of $3.5 billion.  This amount includes the $700 million settlement sum (as agreed in the agreement recently signed between Simfer and the Government of Guinea, announced by Rio Tinto plc on 22 April 2011), technical studies and resource definition drilling through to the completion of the PEA and DE, as well as long lead item orders and early construction works.  The long lead item orders and early construction works will be necessary during this period in order to achieve the targeted first exported production deadline of June 2015. IFC is seeking board approval to invest an additional $150 million of equity in Simfer to contribute towards achieving the Decision to Mine milestone at the end of 2012.  IFC African, Latin American and Caribbean Fund, managed by IFC Asset Management Company LLC, may at a date yet to be determined participate in this investment.  In 2006 IFC obtained board approval to invest $5 million of equity in Simfer (Simandou I project) and a further $30 million in 2007 (Simandou II project), of which $32 million in total has been disbursed.

Project Description: The proposed investment involves an IFC equity, debt and advisory services package to help establish La Fayette Nigeria Microfinance Bank Limited (La Fayette Nigeria or the Company), a greenfield microfinance institution to be located in Oyo State, Nigeria (the Project). The Project is expected to address the severe lack of access to affordable financing in the region.
Impact: The Company is expected to help reduce unemployment and poverty in the western state of Oyo by: (i) increasing access to microfinance services; (ii) supporting the development and growth of the local MSME finance sector; and (iii) serving as a role model for good practices in the sector.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves IFC support for the business of microfinance and has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. During appraisal IFC analyzed the FI portfolio and determined the Applicable Performance Requirements, based on an analysis of the potential social and environmental risks associated with the financing provided by La Fayette Nigeria, the Microfinance Exclusion List. IFC also appraised the Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) proposed to be utilized by the client, the FIs capacity to implement the same, and its labor practices. The ESMS was found to be satisfactory, and the client is compliant with the PS2 requirements, except for the lack of an anti-sexual harassment policy. Based on the Applicable Performance Requirements and FI ESMS and capacity review, within six months after IFCs disbursement, the Project will be required to: (i) designate relevant E&S staff, (ii) adopt the Advans SA Environmental and Social Management System, (iii) develop an anti-sexual harassment policy, and (iv) provide reports on its E&S performance to IFC on an annual basis.
Sponsor: Advans S.A. SICAR (Advans S.A. or the Sponsor), an IFC strategic partner, is a Venture Capital Investment Company, created in August 2005 by Horus Development Finance together with several development financial institutions: Agence Française de Développement (AFD), the European Investment Bank (EIB), the Netherlands Development Finance Company (FMO), the International Finance Corporation (IFC), KfW Entwicklungsbank (KfW) and CDC Group plc (CDC). Advans SA is incorporated in Luxembourg on the official list of investment companies in risk capital (SICAR) and supervised by the Commission de Supervision du Secteur Financier (CSSF), Luxembourg''s financial supervision authority.Key shareholders in La Fayette Nigeria are expected to be: Advans S.A. 50.1% and IFC 17.5%, with an additional number of potential international investors.
Cost Nature: The investment is expected to comprise approximately $1.2 million in equity and $2.6 million in debt, on IFCs own account.

Project Description:
Granules - an existing IFC client - is a leading Contract Manufacturing Organization supplying high volume Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (APIs) and Pharmaceutical Formulation Intermediates (PFIs) to the bulk over-the-counter (OTC) drugs industry in the US, Europe, Latin America, Australia and India. Granules has three wholly-owned manufacturing plants near Hyderabad in India (Jeedimetla, Bonthapally and Gagillapur) and one plant in China through a 50:50 joint venture. 

The company is undertaking an investment program at its Gagillapur facility comprising of:  expanding the capacity of its multi-product tableting and PFI plants and its warehousing capacity with automated storage systems (the 'Project'). 

Granules is in compliance with all the E&S related requirements including the action plan developed for the previous IFC investments. The information about these previous investments can be found under project # 28199 (http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/1ca07340e47a35cd85256efb00700cee/4EDA7709DA6A618F85257597007AD9C3), and #25947 (http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/0/5B337ECFAB7EE746852576BA000E29F6).
Review Scope: IFC's review of this investment consisted of appraising information related to technical, environmental, occupational health and safety (OHS) and social matters submitted by Granules India Limited ('Granules' or the 'Company'), including regulatory approvals, technical information related to the proposed project, Human Resources (HR) policies, Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) management systems documents, Facilities' Environmental Management Plan, Environmental Statements submitted to local regulators, training plans and records, on-site Emergency Management Plan, environmental monitoring records, waste disposal records, etc. The appraisal also included a site visit to the Company's operational facility in Gagillapur near Hyderabad (which is also the location of proposed project). Interviews with Granules'  senior management and technical / EHS teams also took place.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
This is a category B project according to IFC's Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, procedures, guidelines and design criteria. 

Environmental and social issues associated with this Project include: social and environmental assessment of the impacts of the Project during both construction and operations; assurance of fair, safe and healthy working conditions during construction and operations; utilization of equipment and operational practices that maximizes conservation of energy, water and process materials including recycling and reuse initiatives; management of air emissions, wastewater treatment and discharge, and solid and other waste disposal; handling and management of hazardous materials and hazardous wastes; impacts of operations on local ambient environment; and impacts on transport infrastructure during construction and operations.

Project Description:
Granules India Limited ('Granules' or the 'Company') an existing IFC client is a leading Contract Manufacturing Organization supplying high volume Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients, Pharmaceutical Formulation Intermediates (PFIs) and finished formulations to the bulk over-the-counter drugs industry in the US, Europe, Latin America, Australia and India. Granules has three wholly-owned manufacturing plants near Hyderabad in India (Jeedimetla, Bonthapally, and Gagillapur) and one plant in China through a 50:50 joint venture.

The company is undertaking an investment program (the 'Project') estimated to cost about $22 million, comprising of: expanding the capacity of its multi-product tableting plant, expanding the capacity of its PFI plant and expanding its warehousing capacity.
Impact:
- The Project will significantly demonstrate how domestic companies use their strong comparative advantages of low cost of production and scale to exploit the opportunities that enable them to move up the pharmaceutical value chain in selling to more regulated markets.
- The Project will support the Company's expansion enabling wider availability of high quality, low cost drugs in developed and developing markets.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects. Key environmental and social issues associated with this Project include: adequate social and environmental assessment of the impacts of the Project during both construction and operations; assurance of fair, safe and healthy working conditions during construction and operations; utilization of equipment and operational practices that maximizes conservation of energy, water and process materials including recycling and reuse initiatives; management of air emissions, wastewater treatment and discharge, and solid and other waste disposal; handling and management of hazardous materials and hazardous wastes; the impacts of operations on local ambient environment; and impacts on transport infrastructure during construction and operations. Further details on the potential environmental and social impacts of the project, corresponding mitigation measures and guidance on how and where information about the project are provided in the IFC Environmental & Social Review Summary.
Sponsor:
Granules began operations in 1991 near Hyderabad, India. It is a public company that listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange in 2002 and the National Stock Exchange in 2005.  As of March 31, 2011 the shareholding was as follows:
Promoter Mr. C. Krishna Prasad and his Family - 40.57%
ISP Investco LLC - 11.02%
Ridgeback Capital Investments Ltd. - 10.87%
IFC - 10.26%
Others -27.28%

Project Description:
The project consists of the renovation and rebranding of the former 3-star 106 keys Novotel Hotel in Bujumbura, Burundi into a 4-star 138-room 'Double Tree by Hilton' hotel (the 'Project' or the 'hotel' or 'Hilton Bujumbura'). The Novotel Hotel commenced operations in late 1984 and since then has been the property of the Government of Burundi (GoB) through the Societe Hoteliere Nouvelle du Burundi (SHNB). 

In December 2010 Opulent (B) Limited ('Opulent' or the 'Company'), purchased all the shares in SHNB together with the hotel property and the land which is 14,300 m2. The Company will operate the hotel under a 22-year Franchise Agreement with the Hilton Group. Opulent is equally owned by Mr. Ayaz Ali Jivraj and Mr. Bashir Nathoo (together the 'Sponsors'). The Sponsors have already successfully developed two similar hotels in Tanzania (Dar es Salaam and Zanzibar). 

The hotel is located in the city center on Avenue du Stade  one of Bujumbura's major thoroughfares, approximately 9 km from the international airport, and situated adjacent to several commercial buildings and a couple of small sized hotel developments.

The facilities for the rebranded hotel will include food and beverage outlets, swimming pools, pool bar, stand alone bars, conferencing suites, administration area, staff housing, shops and other amenities. Renovation works have started and the hotel is scheduled to open in January 2013. The Hilton brand will facilitate the transfer of technical, training, marketing and reservation systems to the Group.
Review Scope: IFC's review of this project consisted of a site visit to the existing Novotel Hotel in Bujumbura in May 2011 to engage management of the hotel and to gain an understanding of the existing and proposed activities. In addition, technical, environmental and social information related to project activities, including design and construction standards, health and safety, emergency preparedness and response plans and human resources procedures were also reviewed.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
This project involves the renovation and rebranding and thereafter operation of the Double Tree by Hilton Bujumbura hotel. Environmental, health, safety, and social (EHSS) issues associated with the design and construction phases of the project include occupational health and safety (OHS) management during renovations, minimizing potential impacts on the occupants of neighboring properties; management of waste from the renovation activity; contractor working conditions (including employee and contractor occupational health and safety) and resource efficiency aspects of renovation design. In operation, key issues will be related to EHSS management, labor and working conditions including supply chain management, and control of child labor and contractors management; operational resource conservation measures (energy efficiency and water use); pollution prevention and abatement; food safety; and Life and Fire Safety (L&FS) provisions, and management of fire safety risks. 

Given the nature and scope of the project, IFC's review did not identify any significant adverse impacts or high risk issues and it will be possible to avoid or mitigate any adverse impacts that might result. Thus, this is a Category B project according to IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedure.

Project Description:
Estácio Participações S.A. and its subsidiaries ('Estácio' or the 'Company') is one of Brazil's largest private post-secondary education institutions with around 238,700, mostly undergraduate, students, spread over a network of 71 campuses with a significant presence in the  Southern, North and Northeast regions of the country. Estácio also operates a university in Paraguay.   Estacio is undertaking a corporate investment program to modernize its existing campuses, develop its distance learning platform, and expand into new campuses mostly through acquisitions (the 'Project').   

This would be IFC's second investment with Estácio.  The Environmental and Social Review Summary arising from IFC's 2010 due diligence is available for review at the following link:

http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/ProjectDisplay/ESRS28565
Review Scope: IFC's appraisal consisted of a review of Estácio Participacões and its subsidiaries ('Estácio ' or the 'Company') project information generated by the company since IFC's first environmental and social (E&S) appraisal in 2010, focusing on the company's progress toward implementation of the Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) which is a condition of IFC's very recent first investment.    Due to the recent nature of IFC's first investment, the appraisal for this second investment consisted of a one-day site visit of the headquarters in Rio de Janeiro, where the company provided IFC with an update of its activities to develop and implement a comprehensive Environmental and Social Management Program (ESMP), and a detailed site visit to the Tom Jobim Campus in Barra de Tijuca, Rio de Janeiro.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFC's Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social issues may have impacts which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Key environment, health and safety and social aspect of the project which were analyzed during IFC's review were: Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS); life and fire safety of building infrastructure; labor and working conditions of employees and subcontractors; energy conservation of building infrastructure; hazardous and non-hazardous solid waste management; and possible land acquisition for expansion activities.
Sector: AB - Colleges, Universities, and Professional Schools

Project Description: Cosmo, an existing IFC client, is one of the largest producers and exporters of bi-axially oriented polypropylene (BOPP) films in India and is the largest producer and exporter of thermal films in the world. The Company manufactures commodity BOPP films for print lamination and packaging and special value added products like high barrier film, synthetic film, high yield white opaque film, extrusion coated film, etc.  The Company has production facilities in Waluj near Aurangabad (Maharashtra) and Karjan, near Vadodara (Gujarat) with a total installed capacity of 122,200 metric tons per annum (MTPA) of BOPP and thermal films. IFC initially appraised Cosmo in June 2011 and at this stage the Company had proposed expansion of its manufacturing facility in Vadodara by installing a 40,000 tons per annum line, as well as the setting up of a facility overseas.  The Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) for this project was disclosed on 22nd August 2011.However, those plans were subsequently changed to install the new line (of 40,000 tons per annum) at a new location in Shendra SEZ in Aurangabad (the Project). Thus the ESRS has been updated to reflect the amendments. The nature of IFCs investment remains the same (project debt).The main operations at the Companys new facility will be similar to Cosmos existing facilities including extrusion of poly propylene films, thermal lamination, coating, cutting and packing. Major construction activity for the facility is already over (except external facilities like roads) and installation of machinery and equipment is in progress.
Review Scope: IFCs review of this investment consisted of appraising information related to technical, environmental, health and safety (EHS) and social matters submitted by Cosmo Films Limited (Cosmo or the Company) including: regulatory permits, quality, environmental and energy policies, Human Resources (HR) manual and records, organization chart, environmental monitoring reports, on-site emergency response plans etc. The appraisal included a site visit to the Companys operational facility in Vadodara (in Gujarat) and discussions with its senior management and the EHS team. This Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) primarily covers Cosmos capacity expansion project in India which was initially planned as a brownfield expansion at its Vadodara facility in Gujarat, India, by installing a new production line. Subsequently the Company decided to install the new production line at a Greenfield location in Shendra Special Economic Zone (SEZ) in Aurangabad, in Maharashtra, India (Shendra Facility or the facility).   In addition to the original appraisal visit, subsequent visits have been made to the Companys other facility in Waluj and the location of the proposed new Shendra facility.IFCs appraisal considered environmental and social management plans for the Project and gaps if any between these plans and IFC requirements. Where necessary, corrective measures, intended to close these gaps within a reasonable period of time, are summarized in the paragraphs that follow and in the agreed Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) disclosed in this review summary. Through implementation of these management plans and the ESAP, the Project is expected to be designed and operated in accordance with Performance Standards objectives.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards and guidelines. Environmental and social issues associated with this Project include: adequate social and environmental assessment of the impacts of the Project; the Companys capacity to manage its social, environmental, health and safety performance, and engage with local communities in accordance with local requirements, IFC Performance Standards and the World Bank Group (WBG) Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines; assurance of fair, safe and healthy working conditions during construction and operations; utilization of equipment and operational practices that maximize conservation of energy, water and process materials including recycling and reuse initiatives; management of air emissions, wastewater treatment and discharge, and solid and other waste disposal; handling and management of hazardous materials and hazardous wastes; impacts of operations on the local ambient environment; and impacts on transport infrastructure during construction and operations. The Shendra facility is being developed in a notified special economic zone (SEZ). The land has been acquired from the State Government. As such, issues relating to PS5: Land Acquisition and Involuntary Resettlement, PS6: Biodiversity Conservation and Sustainable Natural Resource Management, and PS8: Cultural Heritage are not applicable.  Also, there is no contact with Indigenous Peoples, therefore matters related to PS7: Indigenous Peoples are not applicable.
Sector: L-AC - Other Plastic and Rubber Products  (Including Polypropylene Bags, Housing Components, Containers, etc.)

However, those plans have been subsequently changed.

Project Description: SPSL, a wholly owned subsidiary of OSL, has been awarded a 17-year contract by Petronet LNG Limited ('Petronet') to provide port services at Petronet's upcoming LNG terminal at Kochi in the state of Kerala in southern India.  OSL is the leading Indian provider of comprehensive port management services such as harbor towage, mooring, pilotage, ship-to-ship transfer of cargo, and control tower operations. Ocean Sparkle operates a fleet of 81 vessels spread across 22 locations in India and  has been providing port management services at the Dahej terminal since 2004 (via a group company, Sealion Sparkle) where Petronet has an operating LNG Terminal. As part of its contract with Petronet, SPSL will: purchase and deploy 4 tugboats and 1 other marine craft at Kochi; and provide personnel for Petronet's port operation services including for operation and maintenance of tugs and marine craft, mooring crew, tug and marine craft crew, engineers, radio officers etc. ('Project'). IFC is considering providing a loan to part finance the Project.
Review Scope: The review of this Project builds upon the appraisal and supervision of IFC's previous investment in the Ocean Sparkle Limited ('OSL') and its subsidiary Sealion Sparkle (Sealion Sparkle Project # 23081, Ocean Sparkle II, Project # 25169, and Ocean Sparkle III Project # 27021). OSL reports to IFC regarding the ongoing management of its environmental and social performance, which has been satisfactory. IFC's appraisal mission in July 2011 confirmed that the company is meeting the requirements of the original investment agreement and continues to demonstrate that its activities comply with applicable Indian laws and regulations, and IFC requirements.OSL proposes to implement its existing social, environmental, health and safety management systems (SEHSMS) in Sparkle Port Services Limited ('SPSL' or the 'Company'), which is a 100% subsidiary of OSL. Accordingly, the review consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information submitted by OSL including a review of: OSL's Safety, Environment, and Quality System Manual; Human Resource Manual; Incident Monitoring Records; Safety Equipment (on board) inspection and testing logs including records also for mock drills, training, safety committee meeting, waste management; and SPSL's Port Services Agreement with Petronet LNG Limited ('Petronet').  The appraisal team interviewed the corporate and site operations managers of OSL.  Further, the appraisal included a site visit in July 2011, to the Company's existing operations at Kochi port in the state of Kerala, India.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: IFC's ongoing review and supervision of its existing investments in OSL has shown that the company continues to meet its environmental, health and safety, and social (EHSS) compliance obligations, including the relevant IFC Performance Standards and guidelines, and its EHSS performance has been satisfactory. Similar to the categorization of the earlier investments, this is also a Category B project because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Mitigation measures can be readily designed and any adverse impacts are not likely to be diverse; are not likely to be irreversible; and most likely will be limited to project site.  The key social, environmental, health and safety impacts associated with the project will include: Environmental, Health and Safety Management Systems; Labor working conditions, including occupational health and safety; Vessel safety and pollution control; and Oil spill containment and recovery.

Project Description: Sparkle Port Services Limited (SPSL) is a 100% subsidiary of Ocean Sparkle Limited (OSL), an Indian provider of port management services. SPSL has been awarded a 17 (15+2)-year contract by Petronet LNG Limited (Petronet) to provide services at Petronets upcoming LNG terminal at Kochi in southern India. Petronet is currently operating an LNG plant at Dahej in western India. Ocean Sparkle has been providing port management services at the Dahej terminal since 2004 (via a group company, Sealion Sparkle). As part of its contract with Petronet, SPSL will purchase and deploy 4 tugboats and 1 marine craft at Kochi, for a total cost of $31.5 million. IFC is considering providing an A loan of $11.5 million.
Impact: Support greater usage of an environmentally-friendly fuel, in the face of growing energy demand and limited domestic supply: The share of natural gas in the primary energy segment in India is only 8% currently. Natural gas supplies from domestic sources are expected to be constrained over the next few years; as a result, Indias reliance on imported LNG is expected to increase. SPSL is a key link in the logistics chain for Petronet as it seeks to ramp up LNG imports through the new terminal at Kochi. 	By supporting Petronets growth, SPSL will indirectly be contributing to the greater usage of an environmentally friendly fuel, and increasing the share of fuel that is bought and sold under free market conditions (Petronet and other newer market players are operating under new legislation that requires open access and unbundling of the supply chain). Higher Environmental, Social, Health and Safety Standards: IFC will work closely with SPSL to ensure that IFC performance standards are met, particularly those related to labor management and working conditions, as well as the management of effluents and waste-water. Employment Generation: As a result of the Project, direct employment is expected to be created for ~56 employees.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The Company has presented plans to address these impacts to ensure that the proposed project will, upon implementation of the specific agreed measures, comply with applicable environmental, health and safety and social requirements, including: international maritime standards under MARPOL, SOLAS, and IMO; Indian Merchant Shipping Rules and environmental, health and safety laws; and the IFC Social and Environmental Performance Standards. A discussion on the Companys plans to mitigate/minimize identified environmental and social impacts has been provided in the Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) and an Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP).
Sponsor: OSL is the leading Indian provider of comprehensive port management services such as harbor towage, mooring, pilotage, ship-to-ship transfer of cargo, and control tower operations.  OSLs principal sponsors are four first generation entrepreneurs, Mr P. Jairaj Kumar, Mr Sanjeev Dhawan, Mr A.K. Sawhney and Mr R.Virender Prasad. Other shareholders include IFC, SUUTI, Park Equity Holdings Limited, Infrastructure India Holding Fund LLC, West Coast Ports Limited and non-resident Indians. OSL was incorporated in 1995 and it along with its joint venture companies has a total fleet of 81 vessels operating in 22 locations in India. The companys headquarters are in Hyderabad in the state of Andhra Pradesh in India. It is unlisted.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is approximately $31.5 million primarily for the acquisition of the tugboats and marine craft. The proposed IFC investment is an A type Loan of up to $11.5million with a total tenor of 12 years.

Company Name: HOTELES CITY EXPRESS S.A.P.I. DE C.V.
Project Description: City Express is engaged in development and operation of business hotels for the middle and middle low income markets across Mexico and Latin America.  The project consists of the development of new hotels in both Mexico and latin America. This expansion will include up to 5 new hotels in Costa Rica and Colombia via a Joint-Venture with Hospiteum Corporation ('Hospiteum') one of the few established Central American hotel operators, ('the Central America Expansion'). The Project will also include an IFC and AMC/ALAC collaboration to support City Express expansion in other countries in Latin America including Chile (the 'Latin America Expansion'). Finally, the proposed project will also include a support to City Express expansion in Mexico (the 'Mexico project') with the implementation of two new properties in Mexico City and Monterrey (all together, the Project). The Project would help City express to consolidate its leading position in the budget business hotel sector, accelerate existing growth plans and initiate its expansion outside of Mexico.
Review Scope:
IFC's review comprised meetings and discussion of human resources, environmental and safety issues with corporate staff of Hoteles city Express, S.A.P.I. de C.V. ('City Express' or the 'Company'), site visits to a hotel in construction in Santa Fe, Mexico City, Manzanillo, Colima and to the construction site of the future hotel in Monterrey, Nuevo León, all in Mexico. The review included an assessment of the expansion plans; in particular regarding land acquisition policies and replication of the existing construction model outside Mexico and in alliance with other international partners.  The proposed projects will be designed, developed and administered by City Express; therefore, the E&S assessment has focused on City Express current practices.
IFC's review also considered environmental and social information available from ongoing supervision of existing IFC investments with City Express (project # 29520) and the current status of the agreed Environmental Action Plan. Earlier reviews for City Express are available on IFC's Disclosure Portal.

Company Name: HOTELES CITY EXPRESS S.A.P.I. DE C.V.
Project Description: Hoteles City Express, S.A.P.I. de C.V. ('City Express' or the 'Company') is engaged in development and operation of business hotels for the middle and middle low income markets in Mexico and Latin America.  City Express International (the 'Project') consists of the development of new hotels in Latin America and Mexico. This expansion will include up to 5 new hotels in Costa Rica and Colombia via a Joint-Venture with Hospiteum Corporation ('Hospiteum') one of the few established Central American hotel owner and operators, ('the Central America Expansion'). The Project will also include an IFC and AMC/ALAC collaboration to support City Express expansion in Latin America including Chile (the 'Latin America Expansion'). Finally, the proposed project will also include a support to City Express expansion in Mexico (the 'Mexico project') with the implementation of two new properties in Mexico City and Monterrey (all together, the Project). The Project would help City express to consolidate its leading position in the budget business hotel sector, accelerate existing growth plans and initiate its expansion outside of Mexico.
Impact: i) Increased business and tourism infrastructure: The Projects are expected to add to their region's business and tourism infrastructure by expanding and improving the existing base of accommodation facilities and business services; In addition, they should encourage increased tourism, business and meetings, incentives, conferences and exhibitions ("MICE") travel;(ii) Mid-market hotel development: The Projects will help the development of the domestic midmarket business hotel segment, thereby extending the product range in the targeted cities, where there is currently a shortage of supply; (iii)  Benefits to the local economy: The Projects will create opportunities for economic links (local and regional) between tourism and other sectors, both in the development phase (construction services and building supplies) and during on-going operations (employment and operating supplies);  in addition, the Projects will create both direct and indirect jobs, as well as provide training opportunities for employees. They will also contribute to maintain and increase foreign exchange and tax revenues;  spending by visitors would keep help support a wide range of local economic activities, restaurants, transportation, tours, entertainment, sports and leisure activity; and (iv) Climate change: In order to adopt sustainable green building design and construction, Hospiteum and City Express will continue to ensure high levels of energy efficiency and have various hotels achieve possibly compliance with LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) standards.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFC's Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria as is described in the following sections.Key environmental and social issues identified during the appraisal include the following:Corporate environmental and social management capacity;Permitting and licensing of new sites;Management of environmental impacts and occupational health and safety during construction;Structural considerations in the design of the hotels; Life and fire safety and emergency preparedness and response; Implementation of LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) criteria in the design and operation of the hotels;Use of energy, water and resources;Solid waste management; Land acquisition; andLabor and working conditions, including occupational health and safety.
Sponsor: City Express is Mexico's leading business hotel chain; it has contributed significantly to increase the competitiveness and standards of the industry, particularly in second and third tier cities, including some in five Mexican frontier states, namely Chiapas, Hidalgo, Michoacan, Veracruz, and Zacatecas. City Express owns and operates 59 hotels and was founded in 2002 by a management team with extensive experience in the hospitality industry. Today, City express shareholding includes: Morgan Stanley (through MSREF SSFIII), IFC-AMC/ALAC Fund, Wamex Capital and prominent businessmen from Mexico City and Monterrey, and the management of the Company. As of August 2011, City Express manages 6,519, rooms within three different brands: (i) City Express (ii) City Junior; and (iii) City Suites.  The Company has built a strong competitive advantage by having a wider coverage throughout the country, which enables it to maintain a central reservation system, a loyalty program, alliances with airlines and travel agencies, and corporate agreements. Hospiteum Corporation is one of the few established Central American hotel owners and operators.  Currently, it owns and operates four properties across Central America, namely in Guatemala, El Salvador, Nicaragua and Honduras. Hospiteum is collectively owned by a group of families/businessmen from Guatemala and El Salvador with the shareholding percentages of 74% and 26% respectively.
Cost Nature: The overall project cost is estimated at $157.5 million. IFC's investment for its own account will be of up to $52.5 million composed with: (i) an A loan of up to $15 million for the Central America Expansion or City Hospiteum JV with a $15 million mobilized loan; (ii) an up to $30 million A loan for the Mexico Project, and (iii) an up to $6.25 million equity investment for the Latin America Expansion with a similar investment from AMC/ALAC.
Investment: 44.55 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan38.30Equity6.25* These investment figures are indicative
Location: For the Central America and Colombia expansion the hotels will be located in San Jose, Costa Rica, Bogota, Cali and Cartagena in Colombia. The two properties in Mexico will be located in Santa Fe, Mexico City and Monterrey. The Latin America Expansion will include hotels in Chile, mainly in Santiago, Concepción, Antofagasta and cities in the north of the country.

Project Description:
The project involves construction of an office complex ('the complex or 'the project') in Bujumbura, the capital city of Burundi.  The complex is being constructed by Progimmo, a real estate holding company, owned by Mr. Edourard Hicintuka and his family.  Mr. Hicintuka is a Burundian businessman who has previously been involved in real estate developments in Burundi and is the largest importer and trader in fertilizer in the country.  

The site is 8,250 m2 and located on Avenue du Large within a new, low density and rise mixed use area (commercial, office, hotels) 2 km from Bujumbura's central business district, and some 100 m from the edge of Lake Tanganyika.  The complex will consist of two separate, yet similar, four storey office blocks with a total lettable area of about 7,000 m2.  Once complete, tenants would then be responsible for the final layout of the area being let.  Currently there are no construction activities on site, however the foundation for the office building on the site's northern boundary has been constructed, along with the first floor of the building.   This building is located at 90 degrees to the Lake and the second building will be located on the site's southern boundary.  The final orientation for this building is yet to be confirmed however, as opposed to being at 90° to the Lake, it may be angled so as to take advantage of the views afforded by the Lake.  

The remaining areas of the site will be occupied by parking for approximately 200 vehicles and landscaped gardens, though the latter will be limited due to space constraints.   There is a road on the site's eastern boundary between the site and the Lake, Avenue du Large forms the site's western boundary, to the south is an access road and further in this direction is a hotel, whist to the north is a vacant site.  The general area is characterized by commercial developments under varying stages of construction and the access roads are yet to be asphalted.  

The total project cost is approximately $8.7 million and IFC is considering a loan of up to $3.5 million, with Progimmo providing the remaining funds.
Review Scope: IFC's appraisal for this project consisted of a site visit attended by the municipal representatives including the Directors of Planning, Water Supply and Sanitation and Waste Management.  In addition, a subsequent site visit was also undertaken with IFC's engineer and the project architects and engineers.  Discussions were held with Mr. Hicintuka and meetings were held with the architects and engineers to review the conceptual designs.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
The project is located on previously vacant and disturbed land within a newly established development area within central Bujumbura.  The area is zoned for commercial use and the project is in accordance with the planned usage for the area and is of limited size. 

Progimmo has engaged the services of an experienced architect and similarly has a qualified Project Manager to ensure construction is undertaken in accordance with the original designs.  Municipal services are readily available and mitigation measures have been defined in the project Environmental and Social Action Plan ('ESAP') to address the limited potential impacts identified. Thus this is a Category B project in accordance with the IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedure.

Project Description: The proposed project is an early stage equity investment in a holding company in Albania (the Company) to be established by Enso Hydro GmbH (Enso or the Sponsor), an Austrian company specializing in investments in small hydro projects with up to 15MW capacity (the Project). IFCs investment will be an up to EUR 6 million equity investment for up to 20% of the share capital of the Company.  One 8.9MW hydro power plant on the river Lengarica has already been identified and the concession is signed and a concession for a cascade of 5 small hydro projects with a total installed capacity of 29.8MW on the river Mati has been awarded and ready to be signed. 1 to 2 further small hydro projects will be acquired and developed in the future, however these are not identified yet.Note:  Enso Hydro GmbH has a minimal staff as most of the services (including technical and environment) are being provided by Enso GmbH, which is different from Enso Hydro GmbH.  Lengarica hydropower project (a 8.9MW run-of-the-river type hydropower plant) will be built at the lower part of the Lengarica river basin in Permet district, Gjirokaster prefecture.  It will be situated in a hilly and mountainous terrain, in Banjas Canyon zone at the elevation of 410m above sea level, about 7 km from Vjosa river.  The project will consist of a regulator (side intake type, opening for ecological flow, about 13m height and 60m length), about 4 km tunnel (concrete lining, 2.4m width, 4m height), a forebay (concrete basin to collect the water coming from the tunnel), about 3.7 km penstock (6 river crossings), a power house (8.9MW), and about 6.5 km 35kV transmission line to Permet substation.  Mati hydropower project is a cascade of five small hydropower plants with a total capacity of 29.8MW :  2 diversion hydropower plants (5.9MW and 12.3MW) in the upstream area and 3 run-of-the-river type hydropower plants (4.5MW, 3.85MW, and 3.2MW) in the downstream area of Mati river basin in the Mat region.  This is still a concept stage without detailed design specifications.
Review Scope: IFCs review of this corporate-level equity investment included meetings with Enso GmbH management and staff  in charge of acquisition, design, construction and operation of hydropower projects and environmental, social and health and safety (ESHS) issues.  The review also included field visits in Albania to the two hydropower projects under consideration by Enso (Lengarica 8.9MW hydropower project, Mati 29.8MW hydro power project).Various internal documents associated to the Sponsors ESHS program were analyzed, including among others, the following:  Ensos internal Environmental Policy; Ensos draft environmental process manual; Ensos environmental standards for both direct impacts and indirect impacts of hydropower projects; Ensos environmental principles for four investment process stages; Ensos environmental, health and safety (EHS) requirements for contractors; Ensos design report for Lengarica hydropower project; Ensos preliminary feasibility report for Mati hydropower project; and Ensos environmental and social impact assessment report prepared for Lengarica hydropower project.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Enso focuses development of small to medium scale hydro power projects (focusing up to 15MW plants) in Albania, in general, with limited environmental and social impacts.  The first confirmed hydropower project that Enso plans to develop is Lengarica Small Hydropower Plant (8.9MW) with potentially limited environmental and social impacts.  The second hydropower project that Enso may develop is Mati River Project (29.8MW)  a cascade of five small hydropower plants, of which details and scheme are still to be designed.  Considering this, the project has been categorized as B according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures.
Sector: BB - Small Hydro (<10MW) - Renewable Energy Generation

Project Description: The proposed project is an early stage equity investment in a holding company in Albania to be established with the purpose of investing in small hydro projects with up to 15MW capacity (the Project). IFCs investment will be an up to EUR 6 million equity investment for up to 20% of the share capital of the company.
Impact: The Project''s development impact is as follows: (i) creating approximately 50MW additional renewable energy for the country, which in turn would improve sector sustainability and decrease reliance on imports; (ii) supporting power sector reform by increasing the share of private generation in Albania''s overall electricity generation; (iii) facilitating the move towards the creation of a regional energy market; and (iv) attracting international players to the Albanian market. Through the above, the Project will positively impact the fiscal and macroeconomic stability of Albania.
Environmental Social Issues: Key issues related to this investment include Ensos capacity to:  undertake adequate environmental and social impact assessments and manage the environmental, social, health and safety (ESHS) risks and impacts associated to the acquisition, engineering, construction and operation of hydropower projects and associated facilities (e.g. access road, transmission line), particularly those related to construction management, determination of ecological flow and biodiversity impact mitigation; and effectively consulting and engaging with project-affected communities.
Sponsor: The Project will be developed by Enso Hydro GmbH (Enso or the Sponsor), which is an Austrian company specializing in investments in small-scale (up to 15MW) and medium-scale hydropower plants (up to 50MW) and the company will be owned by Enso Hydro GmbH which is a limited partnership founded in Austria to raise private capital to invest in small hydroelectric power plants in South East Europe, Turkey, Alpine Regions (with a focus in Austria) and Scandinavia (with a focus in Norway). Enso GmbH is mainly controlled  by Dr. Gilbert Frizberg who is a well known businessman in Austria coming from a family which has been in the business of operating hydropower plants since 1902. He is also the Chairman of the Supervisory Board of Verbund AG and the CEO and owner of Hereschwerke GmbH which operates several hydropower plants in Styria (a state or Bundesland, located in southeast Austria).
Cost Nature: The target is to invest around EUR 100 million until 2015 in small hydro projects targeting a total installed capacity of up to 50MW. IFC will invest up to EUR 6 million in equity and the rest of equity contribution will come from Enso Hydro GmbH and potentially from local minority investors.

Project Description:
UABL Limited, an existing IFC client, is the largest barge operator on the Paraná-Paraguay river system in South America.  The company primarily transports: 
- soy products and iron ore from Paraguay, Bolivia and Western Brazil for final export markets in Europe and Asia, and 
- petroleum products into Paraguay for domestic consumption.  
UABL is expanding its 2011-2013 investment program to (i) accelerate the acquisition of dry bulk barges, (ii) modify and refurbish part of its existing barge fleet and (iii) repower existing pushboats and acquire new pushboats, tugboats and ancillary equipment to grow its river transport operations and to satisfy growing demand.  
The proposed project will allow UABL to further optimize its operations, increase fuel efficiency and expand the transport capacity in the River System (the 'Project or 'UBAL III').
Review Scope:
The environmental and social review consisted of a desk review of technical, environmental, social and health and safety (ESHS) information submitted by UABL Limited (the 'Company'). The review also included monitoring reports and other relevant documents from the existing IFC investments on the Company.  In addition, as part of IFC's standard supervision, in October 2010 an environmental and social specialist performed a site visit, which included an inspection of Ultrapetrol's shipyard in Punta Alvear, Argentina, an over-flight of the main barges route on the Parana river, a visit to UABL's Tres Fronteras Terminal in Paraguay, meetings and interviews with UABL's management, as well as well as technical discussions with staff in-charge of environment, social, health and safety and labor issues (ESHS), at the company's offices in Buenos Aires, Argentina.
IFC's review included (a) performance assessment against requirements in existing IFC investments, (b) ESHS management plans and procedure, (c) labor issues, (d) operation and maintenance of fleet (tugs, push boats and barges) including liquid, solid and hazardous waste management, (e) operations of on-shore terminals and shipyards, (f) spill prevention and emergency response, (g) cargo handling procedures, and (h) air emissions and fuel efficiency.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project is categorized as B.  IFC's previous reviews and supervision activities of existing investments in UABL showed the company met its environmental, social, and health and safety compliance obligations, including the at-approval applicable and relevant IFC policies, guidelines, and standards.  ESHS issues for this Project are only incremental to those identified for the previous financings and can be mitigated by adhering to generally recognized management practices. The project will finance a more efficient vessel fleet which is expected to reduce UABL's fuel consumption and associated air emissions per ton-mile. The investment program does not include expansion or construction of any on-shore facilities.
