Project Description: I&P Capital (III) Ltd ('I&P III' or 'the Fund') is a 10-year closed-end generalist private equity ('PE') fund targeting primarily control positions in small and medium-sized companies ('SMEs') in the Indian Ocean region as well as West Africa. The Fund is the successor fund to I&P Capital (II) Ltd. ('I&P II'), a EUR 37.3m fund in which IFC invested EUR 7m in 2008.
Impact: Fund is expected to have significant development impact by (i) encouraging economic and private sector development in local communities by providing much needed equity capital and management  advice for SMEs which will promote job creation; (ii) implementing best-practice corporate governance and social and environmental standards at the fund and investee level; and (iii) supporting regional integration by expanding investee companies into neighboring countries to build 'regional champions.'
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  During appraisal, IFC analyzed the Funds expected portfolio and sectors of investment and determined the Applicable Performance Requirements based on an analysis of the potential social and environmental risks associated with the expected portfolio and considering IFCs investment. I&P Capital III will primarily invest into tourism and hospitality, financial services, infrastructure and utilities, agro-businesses, and information technology and telecommunications sectors, with a regional focus on Madagascar, Mauritius, Comoros and Seychelles, and West Africa. For this project the Fund will therefore continue to be required to ensure all investments made are in compliance with the IFC Exclusion List, the national E&S laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards. IFC also reviewed the Funds existing Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) and capacity to implement the same. The Fund has dedicated staff for undertaking E&S due diligence, a satisfactory E&S Management System (ESMS), and is reporting regularly to IFC. Based on the Applicable Performance Requirements and Fund ESMS and capacity review, the project will be required to commit to continue to implement the ESMS to ensure that its investments are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements and submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: I&P Management ('I&P') was established in October 2002 as a limited liability private company incorporated in Mauritius. The company is majority-owned by the management team. I&P operates out of offices in Port Louis, Antananarivo and Accra.
Cost Nature: The fund is seeking to raise up to EUR 75 million by the end of 2012. IFC will make an equity investment of up to EUR 10 million ($ equivalent ca. 13.8m), not to exceed 20% of total fund commitments.

Company Name: FONDO PARA EL DESARROLLO, INC. - FONDESA
Project Description: The proposed investment (the Project) consists of a local currency loan of approximately DOP 190 million (up to $5 million equivalent) for Fondo para el Desarrollo, Inc. (FONDESA or the Company). With an average loan size of approximately $1,000, FONDESA is an NGO focused on providing financial services to micro entrepreneurs, low and middle income segments and rural populations in frontier regions and small provinces across the north and northwest of the Dominican Republic, where commercial banks have limited presence. The Dominican Republic still has a very unequal distribution of financial services: 76% of the financial system resources are concentrated in the Metropolitan areas, mainly the two largest cities, Santo Domingo and Santiago, leaving other areas with limited access to finance.
Impact: The Project is expected to: -Enhance FONDESA''s ability to support productive micro entrepreneurs and low income borrowers who will, in turn, stimulate growth, employment generation and poverty reduction. - Strengthen micro finance services in the Dominican Republic, covering a number of provinces across the country and outside urban areas with low banking penetration.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves IFC support for the business of microfinance and has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. FONDESAs does not have any type of E&S management system. Because its portfolio consists mainly of microfinance, the E&S risks are low and can be managed by screening borrowers against the IFCs Exclusion List and the E&S national laws. HR Policies and Procedures in place and appropriately conveyed to employees. Labor practices are consistent with national laws and IFCs policies.
Sponsor: FONDESA, as an NGO, has no shareholders; however, it is controlled by the Asociación para el Desarrollo - APEDI, which is also an NGO, established in 1961 with the objective of promoting the economic and social development of the Dominican Republic. APEDI has a long track record of creating several institutions that promote progress and development.
Cost Nature: The Project is estimated at around $5 million composed of a 5-year senior loan in local currency.

Company Name: JIANGXI JINYUAN AGRICULTURE DEVELOPMENT CO., LTD.
Project Description: With a growing customer preference for credible organic foods, larger and branded organic food companies are expected to further strengthen their market position. Jiangxi JinYuan Agriculture Development Co., Ltd (JinYuan or the Company) is planning to build an organic food processing facility in Tonggu county in Jiangxi Province (the Project), a neighboring county to Wanzai where the Companys existing facility is located, to expand its capacity. The Project is estimated to cost about $54 million.
Impact: 1.Rural growth and Employment: The Project supports a organic food company in the frontier region in China. The Company will have impact and rural reach by procuring from additional households, employing additional rural workers, and create business opportunities for MSMEs.2.Sustainability and Standards: By investing in JinYuan, IFC will be supporting a Company with a keen desire to contribute to the sustainable rural development and adopt higher food safety/quality standards.3.Demonstration Effect: The success of the Project is expected to have strong demonstration effect in the organic food industry in China and sets a good example for peers to improve their operational standards.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures. The Project will result in a limited number of environmental and social (E&S) impacts which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, procedures, guidelines or design criteria. Key environmental, health and safety, human resources and social issues that were reviewed included: environmental and social management system (ESMS); contractor and supply chain risk assessment and management; community engagement; labor and working conditions; occupational health and safety; water and energy use and efficiency; greenhouse gas emissions; air emissions, and water and solid waste management; community health and safety; land acquisition; and biodiversity preservation.
Sponsor: Established in 2004, JinYuan is now a leading processor and exporter of organic fruits and vegetables. Its major shareholders include Wanzai County Kangmei, SAIF Partners and DT Capital.  Currently the Wanzai County Kangmei owns about 61% of the Company, while SAIF Partners and DT Capital total owning rest about 38%.Mr. Chen Gengsheng, aged 48, is the Executive Chairman of the Board. Mr. Chen received PhD in law from Beijing University in China. Inspired by the provincial governments ambition to promote organic industry in Wanzai and Tonggu area and recognizing the opportunity in organic foods, Mr. Chen established JinYuan in 2004.

Company Name: JIANGXI JINYUAN AGRICULTURE DEVELOPMENT CO., LTD.
Project Description: JinYuan is a major manufacturer of processed organic fruits, vegetables, and rice in China whose products are sold in export and domestic markets. The Companys existing processing plant is located in Wanzai County, Yi Chun City, Jiangxi Province. Organic agricultural production in Wanzai County started around 1999 before the Company came into the area in 2004. This proposed Project consists of a greenfield processing and cold storage facilities in Tanggu County at about 100km away from Wanzai. JinYuan currently works locally with a number of third party organic growers, township organic procurement companies (typically affiliated with local governments), and grower cooperatives. It is continually developing procurement relationships with other growers in Tonggu and nearby countries to expand its organic farm base. IFC has been approached to provide loan and equity financing for the Project.
Review Scope: The scope of review of Jiangxi JinYuan Agriculture Development Co., Ltd (JinYuan or the Company) included the assessment of the Companys environmental and social (E&S) capacity to provide oversight and monitor compliance with IFCs Performance Standards as well as national environmental, social and occupational health and safety (OHS) regulatory requirements in the Peoples Republic of China. The review relied on documents made available by JinYuan and on interviews conducted by IFC during visits to the Companys processing facility as well as farm operations in Wanzai and Tanggu Counties, Yi Chun City, Jiangxi Province, China. IFC met with JinYuan representatives from the management, human resource, environmental, and farm production teams. IFC also visited a number of local rural townships where the organic farming operations of the Company and of third parties, such as farmer cooperatives and township agricultural procurement companies, were located.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures. The Project will result in a limited number of environmental and social (E&S) impacts which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, procedures, guidelines or design criteria. Key environmental, health and safety, human resources and social issues that were reviewed included: environmental and social management system (ESMS); contractor and supply chain risk assessment and management; community engagement; labor and working conditions; occupational health and safety; water and energy use and efficiency; greenhouse gas emissions; air emissions, and water and solid waste management; community health and safety; land acquisition; and biodiversity preservation. These issues are discussed in more detail in the following sections.

Project Description: The proposed transaction aims to support Financiera Creditos Arequipa S.A. (Crear or the Company), a strong microfinance provider in Peru, through a syndicated transaction which would facilitate resources for the Companys micro and small enterprise (MSE) portfolio expansion (the Project). Crear was recently acquired by Banco Compartamos S.A. (Compartamos), a strategic IFC partner whose core mission is to promote financial inclusion and increase access to financial services to MSEs in Mexico and is currently implementing a regional expansion strategy.  Financiera Crear is an Empresa Financiera which provides micro loans averaging $1,500 in size to micro entrepreneurs in the city of Lima and the South of Peru, primarily around Arequipa. Financiera Crear, which was incorporated as Edpyme in 1998, was transformed into Empresa Financiera in 2010. As of December 2010, Financiera Crear held a 4.1% market share in terms of MSE clients.
Impact: The development impact of the Project is expected to be high, as it will enhance the ability of Financiera Crear to support productive micro, small and medium enterprises which will in turn stimulate growth, employment generation and poverty reduction.  In addition, Financiera Crear will be able to increase its outreach and sustainability incorporating thousands of new entrepreneurs to the formal financial sector.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as Category FI according to IFC''s E&S Review Procedures Manual. During appraisal IFC reviewed the client''s portfolio of activities to assess the key E&S risks, which for this client can be considered low due to its focus on microfinance. IFC also reviewed Crear''s E&S risk management structure and labor standards. The client does not have an existing Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) and will be required to adopt the IFC Exclusion List prior to disbursement. Financiera Crear also does not have a fully developed grievance mechanism, although it is already adopting the one based on that of Compartamos, which would satisfy IFC''s labor policy upon implementation. Considering the nature of activities supported, the project will be required to: (i) implement an ESMS prior to disbursement and to the satisfaction of IFC; (ii) demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions; and (iii) submit a periodic report as per a format to be provided by IFC. The E&S requirements are comparable to those established for Compartamos, which agreed to update its exclusion list as part of the last IFC investment.
Sponsor: Financiera Crears main shareholder is Compartamos, with an 82.7% stake. Compartamos, an existing IFC client, is the largest microfinance provider in Mexico and the largest, in terms of number of active clients, in the LAC region. It has been highly successful in the market with a proven model to address the specific microfinance needs and thereby able to compete with larger consumer lending players in the country. Compartamos has recently begun expanding its operations in Central and South America; the acquisition of Financiera Crear is the first step in their expansion to South America.

Project Description: Located in Chisinau, Moldova, Glass Container Prim S.A. (GC Prim or the Company) is an early-stage flint glass investment, which was established as the sister company of the leading Moldovan glass packaging producer, Glass Container Company (GCC).  While GCC specializes in the production of colored glass packaging products, in light of the historical demand observed by the GCC management for flint (i.e. transparent) glass packaging products, and due to increased customer focus on quality, two of GCCs largest shareholders decided to launch a new investment in the high-quality flint glass segment under a new legal entity, that became GC Prim.  Construction process of GC Prim was finalized in May 2010, when GC Prim opened the new glass plant with a total capacity of 65,000 tones of finished goods per annum (rough equivalent of 130 million bottles). At this juncture, during the ramp-up stage of operations, additional financial resources are needed for GC Prim in order to strengthen the capital structure of the Company, to refinance part of its existing loans, to provide working capital and to fund capital expenditure requirements of the Company (the Project).
Impact: By providing financial support to GC Prim, IFC directly supports: -	the retention of jobs for local staff in an IDA country with limited alternative employment prospects;-	a sustainable local glass packaging industry player to continue its operations in a financially sustainable manner, that would also have positive effect on the beverage production sector in Moldova;-	the competitiveness of a successful exporter in an IDA country.Furthermore, by facilitating the partial reduction of the outstanding MAIB loan by proposed USD 5 million, IFC would enable MAIB to: -	comply with the recently tightened single-client exposure limitations of the Central Bank of Moldova;-	free-up additional capital to be redeployed domestically to a broader base of borrowers, including many SMEs.
Environmental Social Issues: Key environmental and social issues associated with this project are: - management of environmental, health and safety performance in manufacturing operations; compliance with national and local permitting requirements; - terms of employment and working conditions; - occupational health and safety; - emissions to the environment, particularly to air; - consumption of energy and other resources, control of greenhouse gas emissions.   This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure as the project has limited potential adverse social and environmental impacts that are few in number, site-specific, reversible and that can be  mitigated through existing measures and action plan items agreed with the Company. Further information is given in the Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) and the enclosed action plan (ESAP).
Sponsor: Horizon Capital (HC) is a private equity fund manager with over $600 million under management, focusing on mid-cap businesses in Ukraine, Belarus and Moldova.  Western NIS Enterprise Fund (WNISEF) is a $150 million fund managed by HC and funded by the United States government via the United States Agency for International Development (USAID).  WNISEF has a successful track record of 15 years of investments in the region.  The WNISEF fund currently holds a 90% ownership stake in GC Prim, with the remaining 10% split between Mr. Oleg Baban (GC Prims CEO) and Moldova-Agroindbank (MAIB).MAIB is the leading commercial bank in Moldova. It offers a wide range of banking services with a nationwide presence and has a history of over 20 years on the local market.  MAIB''s network included 69 branches and 22 representative offices at the end of 2010, having a national market share of 19.8% by total assets, 21.4% by total loans and 19.2% by total deposits.  MAIB provides services to corporates, SMEs and retail customers; corporate lending represented 58% of loans as of end-2009.  MAIB also owns 100% of MAIB Leasing (leading leasing company on the market) and has 8 minority participations in companies active in sugar / leather processing, glass production, agriculture.
Cost Nature: The Project Cost is estimated at $29.3 million and involves the recapitalization of GC Prims capital structure through the combination of partial refinancing of the Company''s existing indebtedness and a partial debt-to-equity swap by WNISEF and MAIB, as well as the provision of additional funds for capital expenditures and working capital needs of the Company.The proposed IFC financing entails a total of $13 million investment, which would be comprised of a senior secured A Loan and a C Loan with income participation component, both facilities having an 8-year tenor. Total financing amount is expected to be shared evenly by IFC with a parallel lender, which is being mobilized by IFC.

With a brand new melting furnace (supplied by Techglass, Poland) and two Emhart (Sweden) production lines put in operation in May 2010, GC Prims high quality flint glass production complements the range of bottles and jars produced by GCC in its production facility, which is located at the same industrial campus.

Project Description: IFC proposes debt and equity financing of Glass Container Prim S.A.(GC Prim or the Company). Located in Chisinau, Moldova, the Company is a manufacturer of flint glass containers, and has been operational since May 2010.  GC Prim was established as the sister company of the current Moldovan market leader in glass packaging production, Glass Container Company (GCC), which manufactures colored glass containers and has an annual production capacity of 110 million bottles per annum. GC Prim and GCC share the same premises.
Review Scope: The IFCs appraisal of this project included the following:Site visit to the container glass production plant of GC Prim and GCC located in the same campus in Chisinau;Meetings with the Companys management team, engineering, production and human resources staff;Review of available environmental and social documentation including the appraisal questionnaire submitted by the Sponsor, environmental monitoring reports, permits, human resources procedures.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The key social, environmental, health and safety (EHS) issues reviewed with this investment include; company''s capacity to manage EHS performance in its operations, compliance with national permitting requirements, terms of employment and working conditions, occupational health and safety (OHS), emissions to the environment (especially to air), consumption of energy and control of greenhouse gas emissions. The information about how these key issues will be addressed is summarized in the following sections of this Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) and in the attached Action Plan (ESAP) agreed upon with the Company.The Project has limited potential adverse environmental and social impacts, and those that do exist are site-specific and can be resolved through the effective implementation of good international industry practices and action items in the ESAP, which integrate the IFC requirements. This proposed investment is therefore a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures.Existing and proposed measures to manage and mitigate these risks are described below.

Project Description: The Project consists of an IFC equity investment of up to $15 million in India Knowledge-Manufacturing Company (IKMC or the Fund) or a maximum of 20% of total combined capital commitments in IKMC and all parallel entities.  With a target size of $150 million including commitments from parallel entities, the Fund is expected to invest in about eight to 10 primarily unlisted small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and mid-cap companies in India.  The Fund will focus on underserved sectors with high growth rates --such as healthcare, information and communication technology, engineering (including related manufacturing and services), and clean technology.  Some investments are expected to be made into companies located in Tier II and Tier III cities, thus creating jobs and driving growth and demand in these cities.  IKMC will invest through Forum Synergies India Trust (the Trust), a venture capital fund registered with the Securities and Exchange Board of India.  The Trust will be managed by Forum Synergies (India) PE Fund Managers Pvt. Ltd. (Forum Synergies or the Fund Manager), a well qualified first-time fund management team based in Bangalore, India.  The Fund Manager will use its strong operating experience and skills to bring high standards of corporate governance to portfolio companies, thus contributing towards the transformation and industry growth in these sectors.
Impact: The Fund is expected to have a strong impact for private sector development as follows:-- Private sector development:  The Fund will add value to its investee companies, by providing managerial, operational and strategic support to improve their competitiveness and sustainability-- Economic development:  The Fund is expected to invest in high-growth companies aiming to increase output, which in turn should lead to increased employment rates.-- Environmental practices:  The Fund Manager will adopt international best practices for environmental and social risk assessment and management, and improve transparency and corporate governance, thus transferring knowledge and skills to portfolio companies.-- Support of SMEs:  The Fund is expected to invest in SMEs and companies slightly above the SME scope.
Environmental Social Issues: The project involves an IFC investment in a private equity fund that will target investments in SMEs and mid-cap companies in India and has been classified as a Category FI according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  While the Funds expected sectors of investments appear to be of low to medium E&S risks, during appraisal IFC will assess in detail the the Funds expected portfolio to determine potential E&S risks.  IFC will also review the Fund Managers capacity to manage E&S risks as well as its E&S track record with other funds, if any.  Sub-projects financed by the Fund will need to comply with IFC FI Exclusion List, the applicable host country E&S laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards (the Applicable Performance Requirements).The Fund Manager will be required to: develop or upgrade an ESMS, prior to commitment and to the satisfaction of IFC and implement the ESMS to ensure that the Fund''s investments are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements and submit a periodic report to IFC.IFC will review the implementation and performance of the Fund''s ESMS for the first few sub-projects and all Category A projects, if any, prior to the fund''s investment, to ensure the ESMS adequacy and assess and manage E&S risks.
Sponsor: The sponsor of the Fund is Forum Synergies (India) PE Fund Managers Pvt. Ltd, a well qualified fund management group based in Bangalore, India.  The fund management team consists of four principals with complementary skill sets in sourcing, structuring/investing, and managing private equity transactions.  The principals have significant operations and management experience running the local arms of multinational companies as well as Indian companies.  Forum Synergies investment principals Mr. Samir Inamdar, Mr. Hemchandra Javeri, Mr. Prashant Goyal and Mr. Ishwar Subramanian, who collectively hold a significant ownership in the Fund Manager have held President, CEO, GM, country manager or similar high-level executive positions of Indian subsidiaries of GE, Tyco Electronics, Maruti (Suzuki), Nike, Madura Garments (Aditya Birla Group), 3M, Akzo Nobel, Ernst and Young, among others.  The investment committee is comprised of two Forum Synergies principals (Mr. Inamdar and Mr. Javeri) and two investment professionals (Mr. Francisco Velazquez and Mr. Allan Majotra) from Axon Capital, a Madrid-based fund manager to whom the Fund has a parallel investment relationship.  Outside of investment decisions, operational and strategic choices for the Trust and the Fund will be made entirely by the Forum Synergies team.
Cost Nature: It is proposed that IFC invest up to $15 million but not more than 20% of the total equity commitments of the Fund and its parallel vehicles.  The Fund has a target size of $150 million including commitments from parallel vehicles.

Project Description: The proposed project involves an unfunded risk participation where IFC will provide an unfunded guarantee of up to $100 million for up to 3 years to Wells Fargo Bank on a trade finance portfolio of up to $200 million that issuing banks in emerging markets (EMIBs) originate in Egypt, Tunisia, Algeria, Morocco and Turkey (Targeted Countries).  IFC will seek to obtain a counter-guarantee for up to 50% of IFCs exposure from other development/international finance institutions (Program Partners).The proposed project is a direct fit with the IFCs strategic focus to increase the access to finance for local EMIBs in Targeted Countries by risk-sharing in a portfolio of emerging market trade assets with a partner bank active in the MENA region.  The proposed investment is a timely response to the political instability in the MENA region at a time when EMIBs and international banks are seeking IFC support to maintain or increase their trade volume in the region.
Impact: The development impact is expected to be:(1)	Give emerging market issuing banks continued access to trade credit in MENA region and other IDA countries, which were hit hard during the financial crisis and the recent political instability; and(2)	Maintain the access to credit for the underlying exporters and importers.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves IFC support for the business of Trade Finance and has been classified as a Category C project according to IFC''s Environmental & Social Review Procedure. Each trade pool will be supported by underlying documentation with the designated bank. The agreement with Wells Fargo will specify that the underlying goods to the transaction will meet the requirements of the IFC Exclusion List and require the Bank to report on implementation on an annual basis. IFC will review the transaction portfolios to ensure compliance with the IFC Exclusion List.
Sponsor: About Targeted Countries The project will initially cover 5 targeted countries, namely Egypt, Tunisia, Algeria, Morocco and Turkey.  GDP growth in all targeted countries is expected lower in 2011 due to the recent events.  Going forward, the project could also extend to cover other IDA countries globally, tentatively Bangladesh, Vietnam, Honduras and likely some sub-Saharan countries.  About Utilization Bank (UB)Wells Fargo is a multinational diversified financial services company with operations around the world. Wells Fargos global trade finance business is managed by its International Group, with the majority of the staffing for the correspondent banking platform coming from the former Wachovia Bank, a leading bank in this business line.  The Bank has three representative offices in Cairo, Istanbul and Dubai for the MENA region, which are responsible for originating trade finance.
Cost Nature: The total project size is estimated at $200 million.  IFC would provide a risk participation of up to $100 million with up to 50% of this amount expected to be counter-guaranteed by a Program Partner.  IFC will act as the agent for the Program Partner.   The risk participation amount would support a trade finance portfolio in targeted countries, with a focus on the MENA region.

Project Description: The proposed IFC investment is in Ambit Pragma Fund II (the Fund), a growth capital private equity fund with a target size of $150 million. The Fund will finance Indian small and medium enterprises (SMEs) targeting fundamental market needs in second and third tier cities.  The Fund will focus on scaling up affordable models in the following sectors: healthcare and wellness, logistics, infrastructure services, branded consumer packaged goods, and entertainment services and leisure. The Funds investments in target companies are expected to generate significant employment, increase access to services across India, including in underserved regions and improve corporate governance practices in the portfolio companies. Ambit Pragma Ventures Private Limited will be the Manager of the Fund.
Impact: (i)	Support of SMEs: target investee companies will be SME''s(ii)	Private sector development, addition of value to portfolio companies by means of improved corporate governance and transparency(iii)	Providing advice and risk capital to enable faster growth in portfolio companies (iv)	Supporting high growth companies which will reach the bottom of the pyramid, and create jobs at a faster rate than the national average(v)	Contributing to sustainable economic development by incorporating environmental and social standards

In the context of the proposed fund, IFC will assess the potential E&S risks associated with the fund''s expected portfolio and further review the existing environmental and social management capacity to manage these E&S risks. The fund manager will be required to upgrade its Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS), prior to subscription to the satisfaction of IFC and commit to implement the SEMS to ensure that its investments/activities are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements; identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the SEMS; and submit a periodic report to IFC. Company Name: KENYA POWER AND LIGHTING COMPANY LIMITED
Project Description: The proposed investment supports the implementation of Kenya Power and Lighting Companys (KPLC or the Company) investment program aimed at the expansion of the electricity distribution network throughout Kenya (the Project).  Over the last few years, KPLC has invested over $200 million annually towards improving the quality of supply, expansion of the network, increase in connections and reducing systemic losses. To sustain and improve the gains achieved so far, the Company anticipates additional capital expenditure of up to $450 million over the next 5 years expected to be funded from internal cash generation as well as external resources, e.g. the World Bank, other multilateral agencies, Government of Kenya (GoK), IFC and commercial banks loans. The IFC loan proceeds are expected to be used primarily for investment in distribution infrastructure.
Impact: The proposed Project is expected to address some of the key challenges faced by the power sector in Kenya and have the following development impact: (i) increased coverage of electricity in the fast growing peri-urban as well as rural areas; (ii) reduction in commercial and technical losses; and (iii) improved quality of service.Despite the successful sector reforms, electricity supply remains unreliable and penetration rates low. The World Bank''s Africa Infrastructure Country Diagnostic found that the lack of adequate, reliable electricity supply is Kenya''s largest infrastructure challenge and a key constraint to growth. Unreliable electricity supply in recent years has led to an estimated economic losses of up to 2% of GDP or approximately 7% of the annual revenues of Kenyan firms, higher than that in other countries of similar economic development. Interruptions in electricity supply stem mainly from inadequate generation capacity and weak transmission and distribution networks, particularly in areas of high growth in electricity demand.
Environmental Social Issues: The Project involves the modernization, upgrading and expansion of existing electrical distribution infrastructure, thus this is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Key potential issues during the construction phase of capital improvements relate to land acquisition and occupational health and safety ("OHS"), whilst during the operational phase similarly OHS is also relevant, as is public safety and waste management.  Given KPLCs ongoing engagement with institutions such as the World Bank and African Development Bank, compliance with environmental and social standards that are in general alignment with IFCs Performance Standards is integral to their operations.   KPLC have a dedicated Environmental, Health and Safety Department staffed with qualified individuals and actively works towards continually improving environmental and social performance. The Company has clearly defined mitigation measures to address environmental and social issues, and these will be further supported via implementation of the projects Environmental and Social Action Plan.
Sponsor: KPLC is a limited liability company which was incorporated in 1922 as the East African Power & Lighting Company Limited after the merger of two private utilities in Nairobi and Mombasa.  KPLC is listed on the Nairobi Stock Exchange. It is majority owned by GoK (50.1%) and under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Energy.KPLC owns and operates the Kenyan electricity transmission and distribution network and had has 1,753,348 connections as of June 30, 2011.  KPLC aims to continue increasing its customer base by 250,000 annually and the reach 2 million customers by the end of fiscal year 2012. Until February 2009, KPLC was responsible for the construction of transmission lines as well.  However, subsequently the Kenyan Electricity Transmission Company (Ketraco) was formed to design, construct, operate and maintain new high voltage transmission lines.  Thus KPLC is no longer responsible for these functions, though it has retained ownership and responsibility for the operation of transmission lines existing prior to the establishment of Ketraco.  KPLCs distribution network consists of substations and primarily 66Kv, 33Kv and 11Kv transmission lines of about 43,754 kilometers.  In addition to the transmission lines, the Company is also responsible for the establishment and maintenance of 38 off-grid power generators in rural areas with individual installed capacity ranging between 64kW and 673kW.
Cost Nature: The total Project cost is estimated at $450 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a senior loan of up to $50 million.

Project Description: Leopard Haiti Fund, LP (the Fund) is a ten-year Cayman Islands based private equity fund established to help recapitalize the Haitian private sector following the January 2010 earthquake.  The Fund will make investments in small and medium enterprises (SMEs), targeting priority sectors such as affordable housing, renewable energy, food production, and tourism, while opportunistically considering investments in other basic sectors. The Fund aims to raise $75 million primarily from IFIs, foundations, impact investors and high net worth individual investors. A related $3 to $5 million Technical Assistance facility will be sought from donors to promote capacity development within potential target companies.
Impact: The Fund is expected to deliver strong development impact through: (i) supporting undercapitalized SMEs in Haiti with funding, managerial guidance and technical assistance; (ii) demonstrating successful private equity investing in Haiti, a priority IDA country, (iii) building confidence amongst institutional investors to invest in Haiti; and (iv) mobilizing co-investment from strategic international investors.  Private equity-sponsored companies often adopt management practices in financial control, cost accounting, quality control, corporate governance, formalized legal structure and tax reporting that are better than those used by their peers. If the Fund is successful and delivers developmental and financially positive returns for its investors, the investment manager may be able to launch successor funds.  Examples of successful and well run private enterprises will contribute to a vibrant and sustainable private sector, improving employment, trade balance and public finances in Haiti.
Environmental Social Issues: The project involves an IFC investment in a Private Equity fund that will target investments in SMEs in Haiti, and up to 25% in companies located in the Dominican Republic that have an interest in Haiti, and has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. During appraisal IFC will assess the potential Environmental and Social (E&S) risks associated with the Fund''s expected portfolio, and sectors of investment, which may include tourism, food processing, renewable energy, housing and agribusiness, some of which can potentially have high E&S risks. IFC will also review the Fund Manager''s capacity to manage such E&S risks and to establish and maintain an Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS). Sub-projects financed by the Fund will need to comply with IFCs Financial Intermediaries Exclusion List, the applicable host country E&S laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards (the Applicable Performance Requirements). The Fund Manager will be required to develop or upgrade an ESMS, prior to commitment and to the satisfaction of IFC, and implement the ESMS to ensure that the Fund''s investments are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements and submit a periodic report to IFC.  IFC will review the implementation and performance of the Fund''s ESMS for the first few sub-projects and all Category A projects, if any, prior to the Fund''s investment, to ensure the ESMS adequacy and to asses and manage E&S risks.
Sponsor: The General Partner of the Fund is Leopard Haiti Partners, L.P., and the Investment Manager is Leopard Capital Haiti Ltd.  Both are Cayman Islands based affiliates of Leopard Capital L.P. (Leopard Capital), a Caymans-based investment management group founded in 2007.  A subsidiary, Leopard Capital (Hong Kong) Ltd. is licensed by the Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission for Advising on Securities and for Asset Management activities.Leopard Capital was established in 2007 to invest in the worlds least developed countries, and to develop and replicate successful business models across them.  In 2008 Leopard Capital launched the first private equity fund for Cambodia, which has since made ten investments. It is now preparing a $75 million follow-on fund for Cambodia and Laos and a $100 million fund for Bangladesh.  Each fund will be managed by a separate, dedicated on-site investment team. Leopard Capitals Global Support team of experienced investment professionals and operations staff provides oversight and assistance to all country teams and promotes cross-border knowledge transfer across teams.The investment team managing Leopard Haiti Fund LP will combine local operational experience and deal sourcing capabilities with international financial expertise. Most or all of team will be based in Haiti and the team will include resident Haitians, members of the Haitian Diaspora, and long term expatriate residents.  The investment team will be supported and guided by (1) Leopard Capitals Global Support team; (2) a Technical Advisory Council (with industry experts); and (3) a Limited Partner Advisory Board representing strategic investors and IFIs.

Company Name: KENYA POWER AND LIGHTING COMPANY LIMITED
Project Description: This project involves an investment of up to $50 million to support the Kenya Power and Lighting Companys (KPLC or the Company) expansion program for the electricity distribution network throughout Kenya (the Project).   KPLC is under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Energy and 51% Government-owned, with the remaining owned by the private sector.  KPLC own and operate the Kenyan electricity transmission, distribution and supply network throughout the country, whereas the Kenya Electricity Generating Company (KenGen) is responsible for generating capacity.  The current generating capacity in Kenya is 1,200 MW and the intention is to increase this to 2,000 MW by 2016. Until February 2009, KPLC was responsible for constructing all new transmission lines.  However, as of this date, the Kenyan Electricity Transmission Company (Ketraco) was formed to design, construct, operate and maintain new high voltage transmission lines.  Thus KPLC is no longer responsible for these functions, though it has retained ownership and responsibility for the operation of transmission lines existing prior to the establishment of Ketraco. Over the last few years, KPLC has invested over $200 million annually towards improving the quality of supply, network expansion, increasing the customer base and reducing systemic losses. To sustain and improve the gains achieved so far, the Company anticipates additional capital expenditure in the order of $230 million over the next 2 years.  This will be funded with loans from the World Bank and other multilateral organizations, the IFC, the Government of Kenya, commercial banks and internal cash generation.  The IFC loan is expected to be used primarily for investment in distribution infrastructure.   KPLCs distribution network consists of substations and primarily 66, 33 and 11 kV transmission lines that span in excess of 43,000 kilometers.  In addition to the transmission lines, the Company is also responsible for the establishment and maintenance of all off-grid power generators.  These are all located in rural areas and currently number 38 in total and individually have an installed capacity of between 64 and 673 kW.  The total number of connections provided by KPLC increased from 505,951 to 1,753,348 in 2011.  The intention is to continue increasing the customer base by 250,000 annually and the target for 2012 is 2 million customers.
Review Scope: IFCs review for this project included:Discussions with KPLCs Chief Accountant - Projects, safety engineers and officers, the Project Manager responsible for the expansion program, representatives from the Safety Health and Environmental Department including the Manager and two environmental specialists, the Human Resources Development Manager and Principal Human Resource Officer for Training and Development. A site visit to a material storage depot, a vehicle storage and maintenance yard and a transformer repair and transformer oil recycling facility, all of which are located in Nairobi.  In addition, discussions were held with the respective managers and their assistants responsible for managing these facilities  A site visit to a construction project for a new substation and associated 66 and 11kV lines, including discussions with the construction personnelDocumentation review including KPLCs standards and guidelines for the design, construction and maintenance of projects, the staff regulations and procedures, the Environmental and Social Management Framework as applied to distribution and transmission activities, the Resettlement Policy Framework, the electrical safety rules, monthly reports from the Safety, Health and Environment Department, various Environmental Impact Assessments and associated Environmental Management Plans, Resettlement Action Plans and the company policy on HIV/AIDS.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Because it primarily involves modernization, upgrading and expansion of existing electrical distribution infrastructure, this is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Key potential impacts during the construction phase of capital improvements relate to land acquisition and occupational health and safety, whilst during the operational phase similarly OHS is also relevant, as is public safety and waste management.  KPLC has clearly defined mitigation measures to address these issues and these will be further supported via implementation of the projects Environmental and Social Action Plan.

Project Description: Cairo for Investment & Real Estate Development, SAE (CIRA or the Company) is a leading K-12 education business based in Cairo and currently operates 16 schools in Egypt, primarily under the brand name of Futures Schools.  CIRA was set up in 1992 and listed on Cairo Stock Exchange in 1998 and currently has over 13,000 students.  With a view to expanding it reach in Egypt from greater Cairo to other cities, CIRA is currently undertaking an expansion program over the next 5 years that entails setting up 9 new schools in Egypt with additional student capacity of 14,980 students (the Project).
Impact: - Increase access to high quality education services in the Egypt:  The Project will increase capacity of good quality primary and secondary education and improve its access, as CIRA is proposing to expand to upper Egypt and other frontier regions in the country. - Improve quality and operational performance:  IFC''s investment in CIRA will improve its quality of education through sharing of IFC global knowledge of education business.- Increase employment opportunities, especially for women: The Project will increase employment opportunities for skilled teachers to find good employment opportunities within their country. Traditionally, a greater proportion of the K-12 teachers are women, hence this may provide attractive employment opportunities for women.
Environmental Social Issues: The nature of CIRAs operations, which involves the provision of educational services, is such that adverse E&S impacts are minimal. Based on the site visits to all of CIRA premises in Cairo, and discussions with CIRA management, this project will have limited potential adverse environmental and social impacts which are site-specific, reversible and easily addressed through agreed mitigation measures as outlined in the Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) attached to this ESRS. As a result of the above this is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.The main issues include the E&S criteria for site selection of the future education facilities, the management of human resources, potable and waste water management, Life and Fire Safety design and operation of existing and to-be built school facilities and land acquisition procedures to provide land for the expansion program.

CIRA was founded by Dr. Hassan El Kalla, a prominent Egyptian national who was the first undersecretary of Curative Care Sector of the Ministry of Health and Population in Egypt.  Dr. El Kalla was one of the key members of the Health Policy Committee which laid the foundation for health sector reform and the re-engineering for the Ministry of Health and Population, where he successfully supervised the implementation of the Primary Health Care Benefit package for Egypt.  He is also founder and chairman of the Board of Futures Educational System (an education management company) and founder and president of the Egyptian Society for quality in Healthcare (ESQUA). Company Name: CAIRO FOR INVESTMENT AND REAL ESTATE DEVELOPMENT SAE
Project Description: CIRA is a leading K-Grade 12 education business based in Cairo and currently operates 16 schools, primarily under the brand name of Futures Schools.  Futures Schools targets primarily lower to middle income families. CIRA was set up in 1992 and currently has over 13,000 students with a goal to reach 14,000 students for this academic year (2011-2012).  IFC is proposing to fund their expansion program over the next 3-4 years to expand CIRAs reach in Egypt from greater Cairo to other cities in Egypt. The project aims to set up 8 new schools in Egypt (in Assiut, Menaya, Alexandria, Shorouk and Nasr City) with additional student capacity of 14,980 K-12 students.CIRAs goal is to have 170,000 students in Egypt, and to cover 10% of the private sector market in Egypt. CIRA has two types of school models. The first are schools that are directly owned by CIRA, and the second are schools that are owned by subsidiaries where CIRA owns at least a 70% stake. There are two license types for schools in Egypt. The first entails a license for K  Middle, the second is High School related Grade 9  Grade 12. CIRA currently has five schools in construction in Egypt, and 25 more schools are being scouted. Local Egyptian Schools take an average of 5 years to reach a 60-70% occupancy rate with international schools taking an average of 10 years to reach this rate of occupancy. CIRA has developed a free online resource designed to help students understand and explore key Science and Mathematics concepts using the online Skoool portal (a worldwide project that has been implemented in more than 25 countries).  The Skoool portal is an Education Systems International (ESI) initiative to promote e-learning and digital curricula and offers the Egyptian National Curricula exactly as offered by the Ministry of Education in both Arabic and English. CIRA is the first IT based school in Egypt, whereby the students get a CISCO certificate for IT knowledge.
Review Scope: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects as the nature of CIRAs operations involves the provision of educational services, and as such adverse E&S impacts are minimal. The review of this project consisted of appraising information provided by the Sponsor related to technical, environmental and social issues, as well as visits to all of the Sponsors existing school premises in Cairo, Egypt.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Based on the site visits to all of CIRA premises in Cairo, and discussions with CIRA management, this project will have limited potential adverse environmental and social impacts which are site-specific, reversible and easily addressed through the measures summarized below in addition to the agreed mitigation measures as outlined in the Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) attached to this ESRS. The main E&S issues include: the criteria for site selection of the future education facilities; the management of human resources; potable and waste water management; Life and Fire Safety; design and operation of existing and to-be built school facilities; and land acquisition procedures to provide land for the expansion program.

Project Description: Universidad Autonoma de Guadalajara, A.C. (UAG or the University) is implementing from year 2011-2013 a Project consisting of:  (i) the construction and renovation of existing facilities, with a specific focus on the Medical School, (ii) the expansion of UAGs community college network, (iii) investments in IT systems, and (iv) refinancing of short-term debt.  The Project investment amount is of around MXN 1,285 million (approximately $110 million).The proposed IFC investment, an A Loan of MXN 585 million (approximately $50 million) will finance items (i) through (iii) of the Project.
Impact: (i) Provision of quality education as the University refurbishes its existing facilities, improves its academic offerings and strengthens its balance sheet(ii) Increase in reach to other population segments beyond those traditionally served by UAG through the expansion of its community college (UNICO)(iii) Demonstration effect by enhancing the credibility of financing educational institutions in Mexico
Environmental Social Issues: UAG will have limited impact on the surrounding environment and has been classified as a Category B according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure, as issues can be addressed through known and accepted procedures and technologies to avoid or mitigate social and environmental impacts.  UAGs core business is the operation of universities, technical colleges, professional schools and K-12 schools in 3 cities in Mexico, but primarily in Guadalajara, Mexico.  Most of the assets are owned and operated by UAG.  The key social and environmental issues associated with the project as a whole include:  developing an environmental and social management system (ESMS), managing energy, water and waste effectively and efficiently, addressing life and fire safety issues in all of their facilities and ensuring any new build is in compliance with World Bank/IFC Guidelines before construction is completed, ensuring general human resource policies are in place, with no evidence of restriction of freedom of association/collective bargaining, formalizing procedures for grievance mechanisms for employees and neighbors, and managing short term construction impacts in neighborhoods where their facilities are located.

The University was founded in 1935 and has around 13,500 enrolled students in all levels of its educational system, with around 10,500 of them enrolled in UAGs higher education programs.  UAG offers K-12, bachelor and post graduate studies as well as professional degrees at its community college (UNICO).  UAG founded the oldest private medical school in Mexico, the UAG School of Medicine, which is very prestigious amongst Mexican and US students and which conforms around 45% of UAGs enrollments.  About 16,000 physicians in the US have graduated from the UAG School of Medicine.UAG also owns two hospitals, Hospital Angel Leaño and Hospital Ramon Garibay, which support the training of its School of Medicine students as well as its Programa de Medicina en la Comunidad (PMC).  PMC provides community health education and primary medical attention to underserved segments of the population in the Guadalajara metropolitan area.UAG is well recognized worldwide in the field of education because of its excellent academic level and active involvement in the most relevant international organizations. UAG has more than 100 cooperation agreements with universities in 18 countries, including North America, Latin America, Europe and Asia. Student and faculty exchanges are very active at UAG with close to 500 participants every year.

Project Description: Universidad Autonoma de Guadalajara (UAG or the University) was established in 1935 in Guadalajara, Mexico, and operates two types of educational establishments, the University itself, as well as community colleges known as UNICO.  The University also includes 2 teaching hospitals, an international medical school and several community clinics for general medicine and dentistry.  UAGs School of Medicine is highly recognized worldwide, with around 200 international students a year, and from where over 16,000 American physicians have graduated in the past 30 years.  The University also owns, as part of its holdings, three hotels, one sports team and some smaller business concerns, though these are excluded from the scope of the Project.The UAG project (the Project) consists of: the construction and renovation of existing facilities, with a specific focus on the international medical school, (ii) the expansion of UAGs community college network, (iii) investments in IT systems, and (iv) refinancing of short-term debt.  UAGs estimated investment for its Project is of around MXN 1,285 million (equivalent to $110 million), to be deployed over the next three years.  The IFC loan of MXN 585 million (equivalent to $50 million) will fund items (i) through (iii) of the Project.
Review Scope: IFCs environmental and social due diligence focused on the assets to be included in the Project, namely the educational and health facilities.  Consequently IFCs review included visits to UAG main campus (which included visits to the Arts, Sciences and Humanities undergraduate faculties, the Centro de Investigacion para el Desarrollo Industrial and the Departmento de Materiales y Mecanica de Suelos (CIDI), the Desarrollo Tecnologico de Alimentos (CITSIA), some of the sports facilities and their corporate headquarters) in Zapopan County, Guadalajara, Mexico City.  In addition, the review included an inspection of one of eight Pre-School to Grade 12 Schools run by UAG, the Santa Anita Preschool, Elementary, Junior and Senior High School in Tlajomulco County.  Also visited were the Faculty of Medicine, International Medical School and Instituto de Ciencias Biologicas, ICB (the Biological Sciences Institute of the School of Medicine) located in Guadalajara County; the Campus of UNICO, the Technical College and Continuing Education Programs in Zapopan County; and the largest hospital of two owned by UAG, Hospital Dr. Angel Leaño (HAL), which is located on the Tesistan Campus and also includes the 3rd/4th year Medical School Program and a short stay clinic.  Sites visited were chosen as representative examples of UAGs facilities in the metropolitan area of Guadalajara.  UAGs other facilities in Guadalajara, and in the cities of Nayarit, Tepic and Villahermosa, Tabasco were not visited.  Documents reviewed included the Universitys presentations made by the Universitys management team on various aspects of the business model, marketing, and future expansion plans.  Documents related to environmental and social matters, such as, Security, Fire and Life Safety, Human Resources, Energy Efficiency, and the Faculty of Medicines Community Medicine Program were also reviewed.  Meetings were held with the Chief Executive Officer (CEO), Directors of Development and Operations (COO), Human Resources, Security and Patrimonial Intelligence, Strategic Planning and Commercial, the CFO/CAO of the Community Medicine Program, Chair of the Health and Safety Committee, and the Chairs of the Centre for Renewable Energy.  Additional information was also provided after the appraisal visit on life and fire safety, water and waste treatment and disposal, and some of the other assets.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The key environmental and social issues for this project are: (i) development and implementation of a corporate environmental, health and safety management system, including national and local permitting requirements for the planned expansion, renovation and operation of existing property and related facilities; (ii) adherence to National labor laws, standards, terms of employment and OHS good practices during construction, renovations and operations (regarding employees, students, patients, contractors and nearby communities), including Life and Fire Safety (L&FS) provisions and emergency preparedness and response; (iii) safe storage and handling  of medical wastes; and (iv) engagement with local communities and the Universitys corporate social responsibility efforts.	Potential adverse impacts of the proposed developments are expected to have limited and site-specific impacts on the surrounding urban environment of the neighborhoods where the university and facilities are located.  In addition, construction impacts will be temporary in nature.  All identified impacts can be mitigated by adhering to recognized standards, procedures, guidelines or design criteria. Thus, this is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures.
Sector: AB - Colleges, Universities, and Professional Schools

Project Description: As part of IFCs strategic focus on addressing adverse climate change across the emerging markets, IFC is proposing to invest in a to-be-established investment vehicle (Climate Catalyst Fund) that will mobilize additional capital for co-investment alongside IFC in private equity funds (Climate Funds) focused on low-carbon and climate-friendly projects and companies globally across the emerging markets. The objective of the Climate Catalyst Fund is to stimulate the development of Climate Funds and climate friendly projects and companies which are expected to play a key role in accelerating the growth of investment in renewable energy and other low-carbon solutions.
Impact: The project is expected to deliver strong development impact by: (i) stimulating the development of Climate Funds and climate friendly projects and companies which are expected to play a key role in accelerating the growth of investment in renewable energy and other low-carbon solutions; (ii) mobilizing the additional capital needed to help fill the investment gap caused by the reluctance of institutional investors to invest in Climate Funds and climate friendly projects; (iii) reducing GHG emission and creating other positive environmental impacts; (iv) promoting the robust, inclusive economic growth needed to improve the lives of people impacted by adverse climate change; (v) transferring technology, best practices (including IFC Performance Standards) and innovative business models; and (vi) raising awareness of the commercial attractiveness of investing in low-carbon and climate-friendly projects and companies, and helping institutional investors to learn about these sectors in emerging markets.
Environmental Social Issues: IFCs participation in Climate Catalyst Fund will be a Category FI project. IFC''s E&S policies shall apply to the Climate Catalyst Fund and its investment activities. Portfolio investments of Climate Funds shall meet the requirements of IFC FI Exclusion List, applicable host country E&S laws and regulations and IFC Performance Standards (Applicable Performance Requirements). Each Climate Fund will be required to implement a social and environmental management system (SEMS) and maintain appropriate capacity, satisfactory to the Climate Catalyst Fund, to assess and manage the potential E&S risks associated with their investment activities consistent with the Applicable Performance Requirements.
Sponsor: IFC will seed the Climate Catalyst Fund.  Large global institutional investors are expected to invest alongside IFC.  The Climate Catalyst Fund will be managed by IFC Asset Management Company, LLC (AMC), a wholly owned subsidiary of IFC.  AMC mobilizes and manages third party funds for investment in developing and frontier markets.  It was created in 2009 to expand the supply of long-term capital to these markets by accessing IFCs global reach, investment approach and standards.
Cost Nature: IFC''s investment will be 20% of total commitments made to the Climate Catalyst Fund subject to an overall cap of $75 million.

Project Description: The project consists of the development, design, construction and operation of a Greenfield 87 MW Heavy Fuel Oil (HFO) diesel power plant on a 20 years Build-Own-Operate (BOO) basis in Thika, about 35 km from Nairobi, Kenya (the Project). The Project will have a 20 year Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) with Kenya Power and Lighting Company (KPLC), the national transmission and distribution company.  The projects prime movers will be medium-speed reciprocating diesel engines, using HFO as primary fuel with supplemental firing of light fuel oil (LFO), and a steam turbine bottoming cycle. The plant configuration will consist of five 18V48/60 MAN diesel generating units with one MAN Model Marc2 C01 steam turbine driven generator (approximately 7 MW). The steam turbine is powered by steam produced using the waste heat of the five reciprocating engines. The net output of the project will be approximately 87 MW. The heat rate of the Project is improved as engine exhaust energy is used to generate steam for the steam turbine.
Impact: The Project will be a significant step in assisting Kenya to achieve a more diversified energy mix and some stability to its power generation. It will contribute to the country''s installed capacity in thermal generation as hydropower is frequently negatively impacted by drought. In addition, the Project presents a less expensive alternative to investments in emergency diesel fired plant and a strategic solution to Kenya''s medium term power needs. The World Bank''s recently completed Africa Infrastructure Country Diagnostic found that the lack of adequate and reliable electricity supply is Kenya''s largest infrastructure challenge and a key constraint to economic growth (contributing to economic losses of up to 2% of GDP).
Environmental Social Issues: The key environmental and social issues relate to air quality, noise, occupational health and safety, community health and safety, traffic management, hazardous material and waste management, and access to water during operations. The Company has presented information on its planned policies and practices that will address environmental and social risks and impacts to ensure that the proposed project will, upon implementation of specific additional agreed measures, comply with host country laws and regulations and IFCs Performance Standards on Social and Environment Sustainability.  The Project is one component of a larger World Bank lending program to KPLC that will support the establishment of the three IPPs. The World Bank has categorized these IPPs collectively as Category A projects. The IFC-supported project related to Thika Power will have limited environmental and social impacts and can be managed via the existing project design, or via readily available mitigation measures    However, despite the limited impacts, the Project has been categorized as A to maintain consistency with the World Banks categorization.
Sponsor: The project will be developed by Thika Power Ltd. (the Company or Thika Power), a special purpose vehicle registered under the laws of Kenya, which is 90% owned by Melec PowerGen (BVI), (Melec) with the remaining 10%  owned by Africa Energy Resources Pte. Ltd. Melec PowerGen, an international company incorporated in the British Virgin Islands, is part of the Matelec Group of Companies (Matelec).  Matelec was formed in Lebanon in 1975 for the manufacturing of electrical products such as transformers, switchboards, control panels and packaged substations.  Matelec group is one of the few manufacturers of transformers in the Arab countries and a leader in its line of business at a regional level. The share ownerships of Melec and Matelec are privately owned by common shareholders.

Project Description: UT Bank (the Project) is focused on lending to the underserved SME sector in Ghana. Investment Services: IFC will offer UT Bank a suite of products:An equity investment up to $ 15mn (approximately GHS 22.5mn equivalent) in UT Bank Ltd. (the Company or the Bank). IFC together with the Funds managed by IFC Asset Management Company (IFC Funds) will invest up to $15mn Ghana Cedi equivalent. This will be done through a private placement of new common equity shares. Alternatively IFC and the IFC Funds will invest up to $15mn Tier 1 qualifying compulsory convertible subordinated debt in UT Bank to ensure the Bank meets the regulatory requirements for Tier 1 capital as set out by the Bank of Ghana. The combined shareholding of IFC and the IFC Funds would not exceed 30% on successful conclusion of the transaction. A Senior Loan Facility of up to $5mn. The loan will be denominated in US$. Proposed term is 5 years with a 2 year capital moratorium.A $ 10mn  Trade Finance Facility under the GTFP Delegated Program Authority. The Facility will guarantee trade transactions of up to 12 months. Advisory Services: UT Bank is committed towards developing a comprehensive partnership with IFC, and, under that same context, Bank management has also expressed interest in a parallel development of products from Advisory Services in order to strengthen both the operations and the corporate governance of the Bank.
Impact: The Project is expected to have high development impact in the following areas: (i)	Improved Access to Finance:  Injecting fresh capital into the Bank would allow for growth as the Bank would be able to further leverage itself to fund growth in the strategic focus area of SME and the currently unbanked rural populous. (ii)	Demonstration Effect:  IFC is helping to demonstrate the soundness and viability of the Ghana Banking Sector. It is expected that there will be new private sector entrants be it via new institutions or additional investment in existing enterprises, this will help to increase the reach of financial services and products in Ghana.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as Category FI according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. During appraisal, IFC analyzed the FI portfolio for types of transactions, size, tenor and industry sectors and based on an analysis of the potential Environmental and Social risks associated with the FI portfolio and considering IFCs investment, determined as the Applicable Performance Requirements the IFC Exclusion List, the National Environmental and Social laws and regulations and the IFC Performance Standards. IFC also appraised the FIs Environmental and Social Risk Management System and capacity to implement the same, as well as the Banks labor practices according to the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions. It was found that E&S assessments are undertaken during the loan review and approval and UT Bank is currently developing an E&S policy. No staff has been formally designated with the responsibility to oversee E&S risk management and an Environmental and Social Management System still needs to be developed. UT Bank was found to be largely in compliance with the PS2 requirements, except for the lack of an Occupational Health and Safety and Emergency Preparedness Plan. Based on the Applicable Performance Requirements and the review of the Banks ESMS and capacity, the project will be required to: (i) Identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the ESMS, prior to commitment, (ii) Develop an Environmental and Social Management System, prior to disbursement/investment to the satisfaction of IFC, (iii) Provide and implement a ESMS Training Plan to ensure relevant staff involved in implementation have adequate capacity, (iv) Commit to implement the ESMS, to ensure that its activities are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements, (v) Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC, and (vi) Develop an Occupational Health and Safety and Emergency Preparedness Plan.
Sponsor: UT Bank Limited was incorporated in April 1996 as Unique Trust Financial Services Ltd (UTFSL). The Bank of Ghana formally granted the company a license to operate as a non-bank financial institution and a certificate to commence business in April, 1997. UTFSL listed on the Ghana Stock Exchange (GSE) in November 2008 and by virtue of its acquisition of UT Bank in June 2010, the Bank was reverse listed. The shareholder of reference is UT Holdings Limited. UT Banks primary sponsor is UT Holdings Limited a private company which holds 60% of the issued equity in the Bank. UT Holding is owned by 2 founding entrepreneurs Mr. Prince Amoabeng (CEO of UT Bank) and Mr. Joseph Nsonamaoh (Non-Executive Chairman of UT Bank). Of the remaining shareholding 10.3% is controlled by Investec Asset Management Public Funds, 6.5% by Kura Capital and approximately 18.5 is % held by the general public none of whom control more than 5% of the Bank. UT Holdings has various other subsidiaries; these include UT Collections (Debt recovery services), UT Logistics (port clearance and warehousing services) and UT Properties (Real estate valuations and development consulting). The Holding Company has also set up lending institutions in Nigeria and Germany (targeting the Ghanaian Diaspora) expansion into Zambia and South Africa is at an advanced stage. The focus segment of UT Bank is the SME market. Growth in the SME sector had been unpredicted in recent past with UT having experienced compound annual growth of over 50% over the past 5 years. It is anticipated that growth will continue at the similar levels for the medium term. The SME focus and strategy to successfully expand operations into the unbanked segment justify the development role for IFC; the proposed investment will therefore provide the risk capital to enable UT bank to achieve its reach targets in a sustainable manner.
Cost Nature: The total Project cost will be up to $30mn comprised an Equity or Tier 1 qualifying investment of between $10$15mn. A Senior Unsecured Loan Facility of $5mn with a tenor of 5 years. A Trade Finance Facility of $10mn for trade transactions of up to 12 months.  The cost of the Advisory program will be determined once a full scope of the proposed Technical Assistance has been established and agreed with UT Bank.

No staff has been formally designated with the responsibility to oversee E&S risk management and an Environmental and Social Management System still needs to be developed. UT Bank was found to be largely in compliance with the PS2 requirements, except for the lack of an Occupational Health and Safety and Emergency Preparedness Plan. Based on the Applicable Performance Requirements and the review of the Banks ESMS and capacity, the project will be required to: (i) Identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the ESMS, prior to commitment, (ii) Develop an Environmental and Social Management System, prior to disbursement/investment to the satisfaction of IFC, (iii) Provide and implement a ESMS Training Plan to ensure relevant staff involved in implementation have adequate capacity, (iv) Commit to implement the ESMS, to ensure that its activities are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements, (v) Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC, and (vi) Develop an Occupational Health and Safety and Emergency Preparedness Plan.

Project Description: The project involves the design, construction and operation of an 87 megawatt (MW) heavy fuel oil power plant (the project) located 5 km from the town Thika which is some 38 km north-east of  Nairobi, the capital city of Kenya.  Electricity generated by the project will be supplied to the Kenya Power and Lighting Company (KPLC), the national transmission and distribution company.  The project is one of 3 Independent Power Projects (IPPs) for which KPLC sought Expressions of Interests in June 2009 and have been awarded based on a completive bidding process. The IPPs are expected to generate 60-80 MW each using heavy fuel oils (HFO) as the fuel source. The project is being developed by Thika Power (hereafter referred to the Company or Thika Power).  Thika Power is a special purposes company registered in Kenya and wholly owned by Melec PowerGen (BVI), which is part of the Matelec Group of Companies (Lebanon).  Construction commenced in June 2011 and is currently limited to earthworks. Commissioning of the project is expected in early 2013.    The project site was acquired by KPLC and will be leased to Thika Power. Adjacent to the site which occupies some 4 ha, KPLC are constructing a 132 kV substation which is similarly some 4 ha in extent.  The project will consist of a simple cycle power block with five engine powered generator sets, and one steam turbine.   The engines will have a combined generation capacity of 80 MW, while the waste heat from the exhaust gases emitted from the engine-generator sets will be recovered to generate steam for the turbine.  The latter will improve the projects efficiency by generating an additional 7 MW.  All electricity generated by the project will be fed into the adjacent KPLC substation.  The national Energy Regulator has approved a Power Purchasing Agreement (PPA) between Thika Power and KPLC which will come into effect on the first day of operations and extend for a period of 20 years.
Review Scope: IFCs review of the project included:A site visit including discussions with representatives from the Company, KPLC, IFCs Industry Specialist, the Independent Engineer appointed by the various lenders whose Terms of Reference included a review of environmental and social issuesDiscussions with the environmental and social specialists from the other lenders including the World Bank, African Development Bank and AbsaA review of the two separate environmental and social assessments undertaken for the project and the report compiled by the Independent Engineer
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The Project is one component of a larger World Bank lending program to KPLC that will support the establishment of the three IPPs. The World Bank has categorized these IPPs collectively as Category A projects. The IFC-supported project related to Thika Power will have limited environmental and social impacts and can be managed via the existing project design, or via readily available mitigation measures as defined in the management plans to be applied to the project. However, despite the limited impacts, the Project has been categorized as A to maintain consistency with the World Banks categorization.
Sector: AC - Heavy Fuel Oil - Thermal Power Generation

Company Name: La Positiva Vida Seguros y Reaseguros S.A.
Project Description: La Positiva Vida Seguros y Reaseguros (LPV or the Company) is Perus 5th largest life insurance company. The Company was founded in 2005 as a spin-off La Positiva Seguros y Reaseguros (LP) which holds an 89.5% equity stake.LPV product offering includes annuities, retirement pension insurance, occupational life & disability insurance, mortgage life insurance and family protection insurance. The Company has focused in the B, C, and D segments of the population and has a particularly strong presence outside the capital city of Lima.The proposed project consists of an equity investment in La Positiva Vida to facilitate the Companys expansion of its insurance business.
Impact: IFC''s participation in La Positiva Vida is expected to increase the availability of life insurance products in Peru, a country which presents one of the lowest insurance penetrations in the continent.  Given the Group''s target market, IFC''s investment would help increase access to insurance protection for the lower segments of the population.
