The company will be required to demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions and to review potential corporate clients, if any, to ensure that it does not support activities on IFC''s Exclusion List. The project is required to inform IFC in the event of any change in nature or scope of its business or operations.
Sponsor: La Positiva Vida is a subsidiary of La Positiva Seguros y Reaseguros which is the 3rd largest Peruvian Insurance Group, having more than 3 million policy holders. Its product offering includes: (i) compulsory automotive insurance (SOAT), for which it is the market leader; (ii) automotive insurance; (iii) fire insurance; and (iv) microfinance insurance among other. LP is highly innovative, having developed micro and climate insurance products, among other.

Project Description:
PT Wintermar Offshore Marine Services Tbk (the 'Company') is a company listed on the Indonesian Stock Exchange. The Company is one of the domestic market leaders in the Offshore Support Vessel (OSV) business in Indonesia with a 12% market share. The Company currently operates 66 vessels and in line with projected growth in demand for OSVs in Indonesia, the Company is looking to acquire 15 additional vessels worth $140 million over the next few years to continuing servicing its clients (the 'Project'). IFC is considering financing up to 8 OSVs as part of the expansion program for a total of up to $60 million. 

This current growth in demand for OSVs in Indonesia is driven by the increase in off-shore oil and gas exploration and production activities projected for Indonesia, particularly in the remote off-shore areas of Eastern Indonesia. These increased activities are the results of a strong increase in production sharing contracts awarded by BP Migas in recent years, now leading to an increase in exploration and field development activities by the oil and gas companies. The Company's expansion is estimated to capture its current market share of the projected total demand growth for OSVs in Indonesia.
Impact: With an increase in exploration and production activity, particularly in Natural Gas, expected in eastern parts of Indonesia, there is a greater need for marine services in these regions where incomes are significantly below the average national GDP. As one of the few businesses operating in the area, Wintermar will create employment opportunities and the associated multiplier benefits of increased incomes and tax revenues in the area.
Environmental Social Issues: Wintermar is a recognized operator in the marine, shipping and logistics service industry, an industry that is strongly regulated in relation to HSE management through international maritime standards and shipping codes. Compliance with these standards and codes is a pre-requisite for vessels using international ports and harbors. Consequently, this is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures as it may create a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally accepted good international industry practice.
Sponsor: The Company is publicly listed on the Indonesian stock exchange, with currently 36.23% owned by PT Wintermarjaya Lestari and 27.77% owned by PT Dwiprimajaya Lestari. The Layanto family which has operated the Company since the 1970s controls the majority of the company, and is partnered with the Sujipto family which is strongly reputed in the Indonesian shipbuilding industry in Indonesia.  The free float constitutes 25.11% of the company.
Cost Nature: The total Project Cost is estimated to be $155.5 million, including $15.5 million for general and corporate purposes. IFC is considering an investment in up to 5 off-shore services vessels not exceeding $60 million.

Location: The company maintains its headquarters and corporate office in Jakarta, Indonesia. Its vessels operate primarily in Indonesian waters, although vessels have on occasion, operated in Thailand and India.

Project Description: Wintermar, established in 1970 as a tug and barge operator providing domestic loading and transportation vessel chartering services, is currently the largest domestic operator of OSVs in Indonesia.  With an average vessel age of 9 years, compared to 14 years worldwide, Wintermar operates a diversified fleet of 66 owned vessels and operates an additional 11 vessels comprised of tug boats, landing crafts, crew boats, fast utility vessels, coal and oil transportation barges, anchor handling tugs, diving support vessels, harbor tugs and platform supply vessels, primarily servicing multi-national oil and gas exploration & production companies throughout Indonesia and the wider region.  The Company is planning to expand the existing fleet by 15 vessels at an estimated cost of $140 million, of which IFC is seeking to invest up to $60 million.  The proposed uses of the proceeds include the funding of up to 8 of these 15 vessels.

The scope of IFCs appraisal primarily included a review of Wintermars compliance with IFCs Performance Standards and management capacity to provide adequate oversight of environmental, social, health and safety aspects of its business.  The review relied on documents and reports made available by Wintermar, a visit to a Wintermar vessel and interviews conducted by IFC staff during meetings with Wintermars senior management team in Jakarta, Indonesia.  The interviews were focused toward the Wintermar Fleet Operations department, the Health, Safety and Environmental (HSE) department, the Human Resources department and individuals responsible for the community engagement aspects of Wintermars operations.

Project Description: The proposed project involves an equity investment in Saham Finances (Saham Finances or the Company). Saham Finances is an insurance holding company with operations in Morocco (through its majority owned subsidiaries CNIA SAADA and Isaaf), and Sub-Saharan Africa (through its wholly-owned subsidiary Colina).  CNIA SAADA is the third largest insurance company in Morocco in terms of premiums with a market share of 13.6% (as of 2010), offering life and non-life insurance products.  Isaaf Mondial Assistance is an assistance company (vehicle, medical and travel assistance) with a 46% market share (as of 2010).  Colina, acquired by the Company in 2010, is the third largest insurance group in the West and Central African region in terms of premiums, with a 13.2% market share (as of 2009), also offering life and non-life insurance products.  The project is intended to support Saham Finances in its expansion strategy for Colina in Sub-Saharan Africa.
Impact: Saham Finances currently operates in the two regions of the world which have the lowest insurance penetration globally. In sub-Saharan Africa, Colina is present in countries in West and Central Africa which significantly lag the rest of the region. This investment will allow Saham Finances to (a) consolidate its 2010 acquisition of Colina and leverage synergies with CNIA SAADA; (b) provide growth capital to Colina to further expand its insurance activities in Southern and Eastern Africa through targeted acquisitions, in countries that are markedly under-penetrated; and (c) meet the expected growing demand for insurance products in Morocco as a result of the "Contrat-Programme 2011-2015", a public-private partnership intended to boost penetration rates of non-life and life insurance.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves IFC support for the business of general insurance and reinsurance, and has been classified as a Category C project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Considering the nature of activities supported, the Company will be required to demonstrate commitment to apply the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions, and to develop a screening procedure to review potential corporate clients to ensure that they do not support activities on IFC''s Exclusion List. As a condition of commitment, the Company will be required to appoint responsible person(s) to oversee the implementation of the screening procedure and confirm annually on not extending services to activities on the exclusion list. The Company will also be required to inform IFC in the event of any change in nature or scope of its business or operations.
Sponsor: Saham Finances is 100% owned by Saham Group, which in turn is 95% owned and controlled by the founder of the Group, Mr. Moulay Hafid Elalamy, a leading Moroccan businessman and entrepreneur.  Saham Group is primarily active in insurance and financial services through Saham Finances, but also operates businesses in the pharmaceutical, health care and call center industries.
Cost Nature: The investment is expected to comprise up to $125 million equivalent in Moroccan Dirhams in new equity.

Project Description: Tribanco (the Company or the Bank) was created in 1990 to serve as the financial link in distribution chain of Martins Comércio e Serviços de Distribuição S.A. (Martins), the retail distribution arm of IMS (Integrated Martins System). Accordingly, it provides a full range of financial services to support the retailers (small and microenterprises) of IMS. This will be IFCs fifth project with Tribanco and aims to introduce the Bank to the international syndicated bank market (the Project). The Project is a natural continuation of IFCs relationship with the Bank.
Impact: The project will (i) increase access to finance to MSMEs; and (ii) introduce Tribanco to international funding markets for the first time. Additionally, the project will support a unique business model that promotes the sustainability of these MSMEs by delivering advisory and partnership support (through the Smart affiliate network).
Environmental Social Issues: This project consists of a $75 million A/B package to an existing client and has been classified as a Category FI.  Under three existing projects (#21922, #27488 and #29362) the client was required to develop a Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS) to manage impacts of its business. IFC has reviewed the FIs existing SEMS and labor practices and the client is in overall compliance. During appraisal IFC will review the client''s portfolio to confirm the applicable environmental and social requirements and may suggest additional upgrades. The project will also be required to continue to submit a periodic report to IFC and continue to comply with IFC''s Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions.
Sponsor: Tribanco is controlled through a series of family-member owned holding companies. Mr. Alair Martins do Nascimento is the individual controlling shareholder and holds 36.7% of the total common shares of the Bank. Together with his three sons (Juscelino, Alair Jr. and Renato), Mr. Alair controls 60.9% of the total common shares. Mr. Alairs brothers (Celson and Hélio) hold 29.1% of shares; and IFC holds the remaining 10.0% of the Banks shares.

Project Description: Microqual Techno Limited (Microqual or the Company) is a telecom equipment manufacturing and services company that caters to Original Equipment Manufacturers (OEMs), telecom operators and telecom passive infrastructure providers in India, SAARC countries and Africa. The Company presently provides turnkey active and passive network installation and active & passive network management services primarily in India with a strategy to expand its international footprint. Microqual also manufactures a range of passive components like RF cables & transmission kits, in-building products, repeaters etc. for RF/ microwave industry at its plants located in India. The Company is planning a foray into outdoor telecom leasing infrastructure business by installing mobile telecom towers on existing electricity grid network (Power Tower) for the first time in India. Microqual, through competitive bidding processes, has obtained 10-year exclusive rights to develop wireless telecom site solutions on selected power transmission towers from Powergrid Corporation of India (PGCIL) and State Transmission Companies (STC) for installing and operating mobile telecom equipments on these towers. Microqual intends to develop a portfolio of about 10,000  15,000 such towers across India and lease it out for use by various telecom operators. To enhance its technical and safety capabilities, Microqual has entered into a joint venture agreement with Buckley Cable Construction Co., United States, which has two decades of experience in deploying and managing telecom infrastructure including power solutions. Additionally, the Company is also developing a portfolio of in-building distributed antennae system across various properties in India. This will also be leased out to various telecom operators in India.
Impact: a)	The Project will have a strong development impact by the way of reducing the capital expenditure and set up time associated with installing new telecom infrastructure and thus facilitate expansion of telecom services in rural and remote corners of India. b)	Project will contribute to climate change mitigation by reducing the diesel fuel through the initial use of renewable based hybrid energy solutions and later on, direct tapping of electricity from transmission networks. c)	Deployment will result in employment opportunities in hilly states and rural areas. It will also contribute to government revenues by way of taxes and reduced use of subsidized diesel fuel.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed investment is a Category B project because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines and design criteria. Potential adverse construction impacts are likely to be limited to project sites, short term, able to be effectively managed and mitigated, and likely to have no or limited impact on environmentally sensitive features and sites. Project operational impacts are also manageable and generally mitigable through appropriate design and the implementation of suitable engineering and management measures.Microquals power tower projects will deliver significant environmental benefits. With permission to step-down power from power transmission lines to provide electricity to the telecommunication devices, the dependence on fossil fuels will be reduced. At the same time, due to infrastructure sharing model, the telecom industrys footprint on land will be considerably reduced, while the outreach will increase significantly in rural areas.
Sponsor: Microqual was set up in 1999 by Mr. Mahesh Choudhary with his family support and his cousin Mr. Varun Choudhary. The Company initially started manufacturing passive Radio Frequency components mainly for Wireless in Local Loop applications and kept expanding its product / service offerings. Key shareholders in the Company include Mr. Mahesh Choudhary, Mr. Varun Choudhary and their family members.Financial investors in the Company include PE firms Indo-US Venture Partners, JAFCO Asia, BTS Advisors and Headland Capital Partners.
Cost Nature: Microqual is planning to raise $55 million to roll-out of the first batch of towers. IFC is considering an investment of up to $25 million as a combination of debt (IFC A Loan) and equity/ quasi equity instruments.
Investment: 25.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan10.0Equity15.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The initial batch of transmission towers are in the several northern states of India. Microqual expects to expand its reach further by bagging rights over towers in other parts of India as well. The initial roll-out of Power Towers is expected to take place in the above mentioned states.

Project Description: Microqual was set up in 1999. The Company initially started manufacturing Radio Frequency components for Wireless in Local Loop applications and  expanded its product  and  service offerings to include:	Copper/Aluminium cored Radio Frequency (RF) feeder cables & transmission kits;	In building products and repeaters;	Turnkey Active and Passive Network Installation (turnkey service of telecom towers);	Active & Passive network management (mainly related to management of tower infrastructure); and	Leasing in-building sites.Microqual has manufacturing facilities in India in Aurangabad, Bangalore (R&D mainly), and Rudrapur. The Company offers the above products and services to major telecom companies such as Bharti Airtel directly and through their equipment / service providers, like Ericson, and also directly and indirectly to telecom companies for overseas operations, including in Bangladesh, South Africa, and Nigeria. Microqual's clients include Bharti Airtel, Vodafone, Ericsson, Huawei, ZTE, Nokia-Siemens-Network (NSN) and other service providers to telecom companies.Under the RF feeder cable manufacturing business, Microqual has a manufacturing unit in Aurangabad, Maharashtra where copper-core and Aluminum-core cables are sheathed for indoor and outdoor application. A second RF equipment facility is operational in Rudrapur (2 units) where active and passive RF components like repeaters, connectors, jumpers, antenna, splitters, couplers, combiners etc are manufactured. The company has an R&D laboratory in Bangalore, where product development and research work is done.Apart from being a manufacturer and material supplier, Microqual is also a Turnkey Service Provider (TSP) to telecom operators and tower companies. Microqual erects telecom towers (Ground Based Towers and Roof Top Towers) on small parcels of land (less than 0.25acre) procured and selected by the customer (telecom service provider).   Microqual also undertakes the operations and maintenance contract for telecom operators. Active Equipment maintenance is generally done by OEMs. Microqual was one of the first companies to win a contract for active maintenance from Huawei.Microqual is also engaged in the business of In-Building telecom Services (IBS) where it is involved in activities like RF planning and designing inside buildings (such as institutional areas, corporate campuses, shopping malls, hotels etc), leasing space from the builder/owner of the building, deploying RF infrastructure and then leasing out this RF network to telecom service providers to cater to the tenants /occupants of the building.The company is now proposing a new business line of installing mobile telecom infrastructure on existing grid electricity network towers (the power tower' business). This will involve utilising the existing infrastructure, i.e. power transmission towers of Power Grid Corporation of India (PGCIL) and State Transmission Companies (State Transco), for installing mobile radiofrequency equipments for telecom operators.The company will also deploy a hybrid system of diesel generator and renewable energy (wind and solar) to provide backup power to existing and new telecom towers. The project is thus expected to reduce the need to construct new telecom towers and thus the land footprint and once the step-down approval is received (and also through hybrid system), it is also expected to reduce the consumption of diesel, the primary fuel for backup power to conventional telecom towers.  IFC is considering a total of $25 million investment composed of part-quasi-equity investment and part senior loan to Microqual.To enhance its technical and safety capabilities, Microqual has entered into a joint venture agreement with Buckley Cable Construction Co, United States, which has two decades of experience in deploying and managing telecom infrastructure including power solutions. Thus far, the Company, through competitive bidding processes, has obtained 10-year exclusive rights to lease selected power transmission towers from PGCIL (for northern states of India) and, Himachal Pradesh State Electricity Board (HPSEB) for installing and operating mobile telecom towers on existing Power transmission towers.
Review Scope: IFC is considering an equity investment and a debt participation in Microqual Techno Limited, (hereafter 'Microqual' or the 'Company' and will include its operations and operating partners/JV partners in India, Bangladesh, Nepal, Middle East and African countries  and any other country where Microqual operates in future) in its telecommunication products, services and infrastructure solutions business. IFC's review of this investment consisted of:- appraising Microqual's corporate management system by interviewing management and assessing management systems and human resources;- reviewing the proof of concept' project site (for power tower) in Kolar, Karnataka;- visiting a manufacturing facility in Aurangabad, Maharashtra; - visiting Ground Based Telecom towers (GBT) and Roof top Telecom towers (RTT) sites and active and passive maintenance sites managed by Microqual; and - reviewing other technical, environmental and social information made available by Microqual.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The proposed investment is a Category B project because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines and design criteria. Potential adverse construction impacts are likely to be limited to project sites, short term, able to be effectively managed and mitigated, and likely to have no or limited impact on environmentally sensitive features and sites. Project operational impacts are also manageable and generally mitigable through appropriate design and the implementation of suitable engineering and management measures.Microqual's power tower' projects will deliver significant environmental benefits. With permission to step-down power from power transmission lines to provide electricity to the telecommunication devices, the dependence on fossil fuels will be reduced. At the same time, due to infrastructure sharing model, the telecom industry's footprint on land will be considerably reduced, while the outreach will increase significantly in rural areas.

Project Description: The Rio Grande Cu-Au-Ag porphyry early exploration project is located in the high Puna of NW Argentina, 450km west of the city of Salta. The main activities currently being undertaken are trench sampling and core drilling. The property has 77 drill holes (33,000 meters) which was completed as of year-end 2008 by Antares Minerals however no resource estimate has yet been prepared.   Previous work has focused on the near surface, oxidized mineralization which contains respectable grades of copper and gold, including large areas of low grade with variable areas of higher grade mineralization. With the economic slowdown in 2008 Antares Minerals focused on developing other assets and has in 2011 reinitiated activities at Rio Grande by initiating a drilling program for a total of 15,000 m utilizing two diamond drills. The exploration camp (3700 meters) is located in the camp facilities of the abandoned Mina Arita Onyx which has been closed down for several years. The camps hosts up to 70 people during drilling campaigns. The exploration area is located at 4700 meters. The area is arid with precipitation of 100-200 mm per year. The project has 12 full time staff with the balance being provided by contractors of which Boart-Longyear (drilling) is the largest.The project is located in an area with existing access roads. Other infrastructure available but less accessible includes a gas pipeline extending from Salta to Chuquicamata copper mine in Chile, with a branch line to the Hombre Muerto lithium mine 75 km east of Rio Grande. A high tension power line also extends from Salta to Chuquicamata, and this line lies about 200 km from the project site.
Review Scope: The review of this exploration project consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health, safety and social information submitted by the company, and assessing the companys operations through a field visit to the Rio Grande exploration site in April 2011, where meetings were held with field personnel and members of the nearest community, Tolar Grande. In line with similar previous investments, this Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) covers Regulus activities at the early exploration pre-feasibility and pre-development stageBackground: This project is related to an earlier IFC investment in Antares Peru disclosed in May 2009. Regulus is a new company that was spun out of Antares following their take-over by First Quantum in 2010 and as a result, IFC now owns 13.2% of the 36.2 million Regulus shares.  Regulus holds only one asset, which is a 50% interest in the Rio Grande Project.  Subsequent to becoming a shareholder of Regulus, IFC conducted an appraisal mission to the new property in order to assess the environmental and social performance of the project and in collaboration with the project sponsor developed an environmental and social action plan (ESAP) to ensure compliance with IFCs Performance Standards.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Environmental and Social Categorization and Rationale:This is a Category B project according to IFCs procedures for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because the project involves early exploration activates related to core sample drilling and trench sampling and therefore has limited adverse impacts and risks which are manageable.IFCs appraisal of this potential investment has identified the following environmental, social, health and safety issues as well as potential issues if and when mine development commences: (i)  Management of exploration activities  control of erosion and rehabilitation of drill roads, drill sites, safe disposal of oils, waste, etc. (ii)  Social issues - Management of community and stakeholder relations during on-going consultation and disclosure.(iii) Potential future impacts (if Regulus prospects are developed into mines) typical of those associated with open pit mining  community impacts, waste management, surface and groundwater protection, health & safety, hazardous materials exposure and management, emergency preparedness & response.

Project Description: Regulus Resources Inc. (Regulus or the Company) is a Canadian exploration company currently solely focused on the Rio Grande copper-gold exploration property located in Salta Province, Argentina (the Project). The Project falls under a 50%/50% JV with Pachamama Resources Ltd; Regulus is the managing partner of the JV. The current project activities include mainly exploration drilling, environmental and social studies and technical and economic assessments.
Impact: The proposed investment will be made before the completion of a full project feasibility study that would confirm the commercial viability of the Rio Grande project. The IFC investment will thus fund exploration and further studies and will not fund the development of a mine or result in any immediate incremental production. Development impacts from exploration activities are typically limited but nonetheless create local employment.Should Rio Grande be developed into a commercial mining operation, significant development impacts are likely to be realized during the construction and production phases, including employment opportunities, tax revenues and foreign exchange contribution to the national economy, purchase of local goods and services and associated economic development.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs procedures for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because the project involves early exploration activates related to core sample drilling and trench sampling and therefore has limited adverse impacts and risks which are manageable.IFCs appraisal of this potential investment has identified the following environmental, social, health and safety issues as well as potential issues if and when mine development commences: (i)	Management of exploration activities  control of erosion and rehabilitation of drill roads, drill sites, safe disposal of oils, waste, etc. (ii)	Social issues - Management of community and stakeholder relations during on-going consultation and disclosure.(iii)	Potential future impacts (if Regulus prospects are developed into mines) typical of those associated with open pit mining  community impacts, waste management, surface and groundwater protection, health & safety, hazardous materials exposure and management, emergency preparedness & response.The identified risks will be managed through the implementation of an Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) ensuring that the operations are compliant with the requirements of IFC Performance Standards. Prior to developing any mine activities a full Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) will be conducted in line with IFC Performance Standard requirements.Refer to the Environmental and Social Review Summary for more detail.
Sponsor: Regulus is a newly listed junior exploration company listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange (TSX V.REG). It was formed as a spin-off from Antares Minerals Inc. (Antares), a former client of IFC, in December 2010 and the Company continues to work under the directorship and close involvement of the original Antares management team. The Company currently has a market capitalization of C$45 million (as of August 5, 2011). The Company has several strategic partners, including Farallon Capital Management holding 25.2%, IFC currently holding 13.2% and First Quantum Minerals holding 9.9%. The management team and directors hold approximately 7.5% of the Company.
Cost Nature: The total project cost to fund the current exploration drilling program, which started in late June and will include approximately 15,000 meters of drilling, and associated exploration works and studies is estimated to approximately C$5 million, but will depend on exploration results. The proposed IFC investment consists of an equity investment of C$708,000 to increase IFCs equity interest in Regulus back to the 14.6% that IFC held in Antares prior to the spinout of Regulus from Antares in December 2010.
Investment: 0.74 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity0.74* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Rio Grande property is located in the high Puna of NW Argentina, 450km west of the city of Salta in high altitude. The main activities currently being undertaken are trench sampling and core drilling. The project is located in an area with existing access roads. Other infrastructure available but less accessible includes a gas pipeline extending from Salta to Chuquicamata copper mine in Chile, with a branch line to the Hombre Muerto lithium mine 75 km east of Rio Grande. A high tension power line also extends from Salta to Chuquicamata, and this line lies about 200 km from the project site.

Project Description: The proposed Project is an expansion of a greenfield plant in Egypt producing chemicals, primarily for export to large, international companies that manufacture home & personal care products in MENA, Europe & the Americas.  A majority of Galaxy Egypts sales will go to multinationals, many of which are currently supplied from the Sponsors existing operations in India.
Impact: (i) Setting up environment friendly world class facilities compliant with International Regulatory Standards.(ii) Employment Generation: The original project is expected to create nearly 110 jobs (including direct and indirect employment) with an additional 10 from the expansion.  Additional training opportunities for about 30 local engineers.(iii) IFC''s investment in the Company will have a significant number of direct and indirect development benefits such as linkages with local suppliers, upgrade of existing infrastructure, indirect employment creation through auxiliary businesses in the region.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review procedures because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.The project is located in a desert area inside the Suez Public Free Zone (SPFZ), which was established a few years ago by the local government. The key environmental and social issues for this project include: (i) water saving, wastewater treatment, and water reuse; (ii) operational safety and emergency response; (iii) Management of occupational health and safety during construction; and (iv) energy saving and energy efficiency. This is a repeat business with Galaxy. The latest environmental and social risk rating (ESRR) for the original investment is B2  Average.
Sponsor: The Project Sponsor is Galaxy Surfactants Limited (Galaxy or the Company), an Indian unlisted public company founded in 1986 that produces chemicals used by manufacturers of home & personal care (H&PC) products including shampoos, toothpastes, liquid soaps etc.  It is a prominent & established supplier in the Indian market & exports to over 90 countries.  Growth is expected in the BRIC and other developing countries as improved standards of living provide opportunity for increased demand for H&PC products.  Galaxys top customers include multinational producers of home and personal care products.The Company''s promoters and promoter group collectively have approximately 76% of the equity shares in Galaxy.
Cost Nature: The total Project cost is estimated to be about $41 million. The proposed IFC investment is a $8 million A Loan, thus bringing the total IFC investment to $20 million.

Project Description: The proposed project is intended to strengthen Latin America''s private pension fund management industry in a regionally integrated manner by supporting Grupo de Inversiones Suramericana S.A (GrupoSura) in its expansion plan.
Impact: IFC''s involvement in this project would allow it to positively impact the market place by contributing to the development of a strong local pension system in Mexico, Chile, Colombia, Peru and Uruguay. This is of the outmost importance as pension funds plays a critical role in terms of generating long term financial resources for investments in priority sectors of the economy such as infrastructure among others. At the same time, the development of pension systems and capital markets are closely interrelated. As pension funds grow, new financial instruments are developed to meet their needs and to fill perceived gaps in the market, facilitating the growth and modernization of the local capital markets.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category C according to IFCs E&S Review Procedure. While the E&S risks of the activities to be supported, pension administration, asset management, life insurance and annuities, are considered to be low, during appraisal IFC will review the company''s investment strategy to assess risks associated with the IFC exclusion list and other potential reputational risks. IFC will also review the companys labor practices according to the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions. The holding company will be required to apply the IFC exclusion list, to follow IFCs labor standards and inform IFC in the event of any change in nature or scope of its business or operations.
Sponsor: GrupoSura is a holding company with a portfolio of investments in leading Colombian companies as well as important stakes in other countries of the Americas. GrupoSuras portfolio is mainly concentrated in strategic investments in the financial, insurance and pension administration sectors; and is complemented by other investments in the: services, food, and cement sectors. GrupoSura is listed on the Colombian Stock exchange (GRUPOSUR:CB) and registered with an ADR-Level I program in the United States. The companys largest shareholders include Inversiones Argos and Subsidiaries and  Grupo Nutresa.
Cost Nature: The proposed transaction consists of an equity investment by IFC and the IFC African, Latin American and Caribbean Fund L.P., an IFC-sponsored fund that is managed by the IFC Asset Management Company LLC (a wholly-owned subsidiary of IFC) for up to $200 million in a newly created holding company. This holding company will own the assets that GrupoSura agreed to acquire from ING Group in July 2011 for a total acquisition cost of approximately $3,760 million.

Project Description: Galaxy Surfactants Limited (Galaxy or the Company) is an established supplier in India of performance and specialty chemicals used by manufacturers of home & personal care (H&PC) products including shampoos, toothpastes, liquid soaps etc.  The proposed Galaxy project is an expansion of a newly-established factory, located in the Suez Public Free Zone in Egypt to produce chemicals primarily for export to large, international H&PC companies in Middle East and North Africa (MENA), Europe and  the Americas.  Many of these multinational clients are currently supplied from Galaxys operations in India. The company has almost completed the construction of its new production facility in Egypt, which was supported by IFC, and this project will increase the sulfonation capacity by additional 32,000 metric tons per annum (MTPA). This capacity increase is in parallel with completion of the final stages of the existing project.
Review Scope: The review of this project consisted of a desk review of the environmental and social information available from ongoing supervision of the existing IFC investment with Galaxy (project # 29246).  This includes a review of the current status of the Environmental and Social Action Plan agreed with Galaxy for project #29246.  The previous Environmental and Social Review Summary for Galaxy is available on IFCs Disclosure Portal: HYPERLINK "http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/ProjectDisplay/ESRS29246"http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/ProjectDisplay/ESRS29246  Galaxy provided a written update of the current performance of the existing project through its annual monitoring report and through a written update of the Environmental and Social Action Plan. In the appraisal review of the first project, conducted in January 2010, IFCs team undertook a site visit and held meetings with technical and environmental representatives of Galaxy Chemicals Egypt. Additional information reviewed, as part of the new transaction, included the expansion plans; in particular changes regarding use of raw materials,  fuel/energy, and increase in the capacity of the wastewater treatment plant.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review procedures because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.The project is located in a desert area inside the Suez Public Free Zone (SPFZ), which was established a few years ago by the local government. The key environmental and social issues for this project include: (i) water saving, wastewater treatment, and water reuse; (ii) operational safety and emergency response; (iii) Management of occupational health and safety during construction; and (iv) energy saving and energy efficiency.

Project Description: Kosmos Energy (Kosmos or the Company) is an oil exploration and development company, listed in the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE). Kosmos current asset portfolio includes world-class discoveries and exploration prospects in Ghana, as well as exploration licenses with significant hydrocarbon potential in Cameroon and Morocco.The key elements of Kosmos business plan are: (i) to complete the development of the Jubilee oil field in Ghana which commenced oil production on November 28, 2010; and (ii) complete the appraisal and development of its other hydrocarbon discoveries offshore Ghana (the Project).  Over the longer term, Kosmos plans to conduct exploration work on its existing inventory of other licenses in West Africa and to replicate its exploratory success through new ventures in other regions of the African continent.To fund these activities, Kosmos launched a multipronged approach aimed at tapping the equity and debt markets.  This included first raising a US$2 billion debt facility to restructure its existing debt (including IFCs prior loan), then taking the Company public to access additional equity, and finally syndicating the debt facility.  Kosmos may also seek to increase the facility to US$3 billion, subject to market appetite, liquidity and timing of development activities.  The first phase of the debt facility and the IPO are now complete;  Kosmos and the bank underwriters are currently in the syndication phase for which they are seeking IFCs support and participation.
Impact: Development impacts include: (i)    generating substantial revenues for the Government;(ii)    stimulating economic activity through creation of demand for local goods and services; (iii)   providing opportunities to develop domestic energy sources such as gas to address the country''s energy needs; (iv)   promoting further foreign direct investments in the country and in the region, particularly in the hydrocarbon sector;(v)    helping expand the universe of lenders active for operators in the West Africa region and therefore play an important market-building role.
Environmental Social Issues: IFC previously carried out an appraisal of Kosmos'' operations in Ghana as part of the Company''s participation in the Jubilee Field.  IFC has maintained close supervision of the Jubilee project through IFC''s prior investment in Kosmos as well as Tullow, the Jubilee unit operator.  The Jubilee project is in full compliance with at-approval requirements of the original investment made in 2009 and Kosmos has completed the required actions that were part of the agreed-upon environmental and social action plan for the earlier IFC investment.  The proposed investments primary use of funds will be in the Jubilee Field, but the actual investment will be at the corporate level.  IFC''s review of the Project will therefore look at the management systems that the Company has in place to manage environment, health, safety and labor risks in its operations and to ensure that future developments, where IFC funds are used, meet the Performance Standards and WBG Environment, Health and Safety Guidelines.  The Project has been classified as Category A under IFCs Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability because some of the future activities could have significant associated risks that are currently not identified, particularly for the development of any discoveries from ongoing exploration activities.  The Environmental Impact Statement, which includes the preliminary Environmental Management Plan, for the Jubilee project has been publicly available since January 2010, and is disclosed on the Kosmos website, among other places.
Sponsor: Kosmos is led by a seasoned management and technical team with extensive experience implementing exploration and production projects and with a successful track record working together.  The team led Triton Energy Ltds (Triton) exploration and production success, prior to its sale to Hess Corp in 2001.  The Company is listed in the NYSE and its principal owners are Warburg Pincus (Warburg) and Blackstone Capital Partners (Blackstone), an affiliate of the Blackstone Group. Warburg and Blackstone are amongst the worlds leading private equity investors.
Cost Nature: The total cost of the project is estimated at US$3.8 billion. IFC is proposing to provide a loan of up to US$100 million in the facility.  The Company plans to finance the funding requirements through internally generated cash flow, the debt facility and shareholders equity.

Project Description: IFCs previous support for Kosmos Energy (Kosmos or the Company, IFC project # 27550) and Tullow Oil (#27918) helped Ghana achieve first oil production from the Jubilee oil field in Ghana at the end of 2010.  The key elements of Kosmos business plan are: (i) to complete the development of the Jubilee oil field in Ghana which commenced oil production on November 28, 2010; (ii) complete the appraisal and development of its other hydrocarbon discoveries offshore Ghana.  Additionally, Kosmos plans to appraise its portfolio of offshore exploration prospects in Ghana.  Over the longer term, Kosmos plans to conduct exploration work on its existing inventory of other licenses in West Africa and to replicate its exploratory success through new ventures in other regions of the African continent. To fund these activities, Kosmos has tapped the equity and debt markets.  This included first raising a US$2 billion bank facility to restructure its existing debts (including IFCs prior loan), then taking the Company public to access additional equity, and finally syndicating the bank facility.  The first phase of the debt facility and the IPO are now complete, and Kosmos and the commercial banks have launched the syndication phase for which they are seeking IFCs support and participation.  IFCs proposed investment would be a $100 million corporate loan, which is primarily targeted for Kosmoss capital expenditure in Ghana.  Kosmoss activities in other parts of West Africa are in the early stages of exploration, thus this ESRS will focus on the Ghana activities.
Review Scope: As part of its appraisal of the prior Kosmos Energy project, IFC met frequently with Kosmos staff responsible for environment, health, safety, human resources, and community relations.  As part of its ongoing supervision of the Jubilee Field, IFC has met with its Unit Operator, Tullow Oil, on a regular basis and carried out a site supervision of the floating production, storage and off-loading (FPSO) vessel.    As of March 2011 all of the action items previously agreed with Kosmos in the original projects Environment and Social Action Plan had been completedDocuments reviewed by IFC include:- Ghana Jubilee Field Phase 1 Development, Environmental Impact Statement, dated November 27, 2009, which is available on the Kosmos website: http://www.kosmosenergy.com/ghana_esia.html- Preliminary Environmental Report for the West Cape Three Points 2011 Exploration and Appraisal Program Offshore Ghana, November 2010.- Kosmos HSE Management System, Executive Summary, dated July 21, 2011.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The proposed project has been given an A categorization under IFCs Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability because some of the future activities could have significant associated risks that are currently not identified, particularly for the development of any discoveries from ongoing exploration activities.

Company Name: ASOCIACION LA NACIONAL DE AHORROS Y PRESTAMOS
Project Description: The proposed investment consists of: i) a local currency loan of approximately 190 million Dominican Pesos (up to $5 million equivalent); and ii) a Partial Credit Guarantee of up to a 400 million Dominican Pesos ($10.5 million equivalent) for Asociación La Nacional de Ahorros y Préstamos para la Vivienda (La Nacional or the Company) to be used to fund lending activity in the middle-low income mortgage sector (La Nacional or the Project).Asociación La Nacional operates commercially as mutual savings and loans focused on providing mortgage loans for middle-low income housing and, to a lesser extent, SME and consumer loans. The Company operates in urban and rural regions throughout 47 branches, 36% of which are located in provinces outside the two main urban areas where banking penetration is especially low.
Impact: - Provide long-term financing on terms not generally available: Long term funding is important to reduce term mismatch risk in mortgages. The IFC transaction is thus expected to provide long-term funding with a tenor and amount that is not generally available in the local capital markets.- Broadening Funding Source: The project will assist La Nacional to diversify its funding structure which is based on savings and term deposits.
Environmental Social Issues: This project will support exclusively middle-low income mortgages and has been classified as Category C according to IFC''s E&S review procedure. During appraisal IFC reviewed the client''s labor standards according to Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions and the portfolio of activities to be supported by the project. La Nacional will be required to commit to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions (PS2) and to inform IFC in the event of any change in nature or scope of its business or operations.
Sponsor: La Nacional is a financial intermediary operating as mutual since 1972; the company is privately owned but has no traded stock, instead, the depositors are associates who have the right to profits and votes. Asociaciones are fully regulated by the Superintendency of Banks in the same manner as commercial banks.
Cost Nature: The total Project size is estimated at around $15 million composed of a 5-year senior loan in local currency of up to $5 million and a Partial Credit Guarantee of up to $10 million.

Project Description: Delaware Consultoria S.L. (Delaware or the Company) is undergoing a $20 million 3-year plan that will increase its presence in Latin America and the Caribbean. These funds will be used in working capital needs required to expand the Companys existing operations centers in Colombia and Peru, the rollout of new operation centers in Brazil and Mexico and possibly other countries in Latin America (Delaware Group or the Project).Delaware is looking for institutional partners like IFC to participate in opportunities from an increased IT market demand, which after the global economic crisis, is rebounding.  The Company has invested for over two years in qualified human capital and now needs the financial resources to execute its future strategy.
Impact: Quality Employment: The Company''s expansion will increase the availability of direct and indirect jobs in those countries where it plans to expand.  Vocational and engineering students typically intern and land their "first job" at IT services companies, supplementing their income and tuition expenses. The industry increasingly employs more women and handicapped persons as IT fully jobs recognize their professional capabilities.Development of IT Sector in Latam: This project will promote the development of the IT services sector in Latam while fostering competition in those markets where the Company plans to expand.  An investment in Delaware would also support and enhance the competitiveness of the region''s as an attractive destination for outsourcing and offshoring.Technology Transfer: Delaware implements useful training programs for its employees in various technologies.  This project will enable the replication of these training programs to other countries. This technology transfer will increase the professional standards and technical knowledge throughout the region.Export/Economic Growth: Offshoring/Nearshoring generates significant export revenues. IT outsourcing helps organizations become more efficient and creates employment, which in turn contributes to economic growth.
Environmental Social Issues: The Delaware Group has implemented environmental and social policies and procedures that generally comply with IFC Performance Standards.  The company will be required to develop and implement Group-wide procedures to IFC''s satisfaction for managing any employee grievances, and for screening the ages of potential hires.  Otherwise, low level of environmental and social risk is associated with this project, as it will expand information services in leased office spaces.    As a result, the project is classified as Category C according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.
Sponsor: Delaware Consultoria S.L. (Delaware or the Company) is a Spanish company focused on delivering Information Technology and Business Process Outsourcing services. The Company started operations in 2000 and now employs over 715 employees across Latin America (265) and Europe (450).  Delaware is expanding its operations in Latin America and the Caribean.The Company is owned 90% by Sotavento Atlántico (100% owned by CEO, Mr. Luis Garma) and 10% by Mrs. Dolores Fernandez.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is $20 million and IFC will provide a financial package of $10 million. The remaining $10 million will be divided between Delawares internal cash generation and an additional co-investor.

Project Description: The proposed project is a $30 million loan to ACBA-Crédit Agricole Bank (ACBA or the Bank), the leading bank in Armenia in terms of assets.  The proceeds of the loan will used for on lending to local Micro and Small-and-Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) with a particular focus on agri-business.
Impact: High development impact on account of (i) continued MSE support in an IDA country and (ii) Sustained ability to lend to the agricultural sector which comprises 29% of its loan portfolio.The Project will generate a range of social and economic benefits, including economic growth and employment creation, as well as financial deepening with services and products tailored to low income populations, the Bank having a strong foothold in rural financing to micro and small enterprises and farmers.
Environmental Social Issues: The project is with the existing IFC''s client to extend a second loan for the amount of US$30 million to expand bank''s agri-business and accommodate its rural micro and small enterprises. The project has been classified as category FI-2 according to the IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure. IFC''s current E&S requirements to the bank are to comply with IFC Exclusion List, national E&S laws and IFC Performance Standards. ACBA Bank has developed a Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS) for the current IFC investment to make sure it meets the requirements.  The appraisal for the new project will focus on getting updates on the status of bank''s SEMS implementation and on portfolio to be financed from the IFC funds, as well as on how/to what extent that portfolio would be covered by the bank''s current SEMS. The bank would be required to extend current IFC E&S requirements, including annual E&S performance reporting, to cover the activities to be financed under the new loan, and to maintain compliance with IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions.
Sponsor: ACBA-Crédit Agricole Bank is the largest bank in Armenia with total assets of $526 million as of June 30, 2011.  The capital base is $110 million as of June 2011 and the bank enjoys a capital adequacy ratio of 22%.  ACBA was established in 1996 with help from the European Union and Crédit Agricole, the banks largest shareholder with a stake of 28%.  Remaining shares belong to agricultural village associations from all regions of Armenia.  The banks main focus is MSMEs.
Cost Nature: IFC will provide a $30 million senior loan with an expected maturity of 5 years.

Company Name: FINANCIAMIENTO PROGRESEMOS SA DE CV SOFOM ENR
Project Description: Progresemos III (the Project) will extend a Mexican peso (MXN) line of credit to support the microfinance loan portfolio growth and an equity investment in Financiamiento Progresemos, S.A. de C.V., SOFOM, ENR (Progresemos or the Company).  The Project will reach women micro-entrepreneurs in frontier regions and will (i) enhance micro lending competitiveness of the private sector; (ii) help deepening the financial sector since a high portion of the sub-borrowers served are outside the formal financial sector; and (iii) encourage a sustainable social and environmental development.
Impact: The development impact of IFC''s financing to Progresemos is expected to be high:(i)	Increase Access to Finance:  Progresemos provides financial services to low income segments of the Mexican population living in rural areas with limited or null credit opportunities.  Moreover it will contribute to build up a credit culture amongst this low-income population; and(ii)	Greater Commitment to Creating Opportunities to Disadvantage Groups:  This project will support productive low-income micro entrepreneurs which consequently will positively impact employment and income generation in the frontier regions where Progresemos operates.
Environmental Social Issues: As an existing IFC client, Progresemos, a non-bank multi-purpose financial institution specialized in microfinance, has developed an Environmental and Social Management System (SEMS) to comply with the IFC Exclusion List and has generally satisfactory labor practices.    Under this Category FI project, Progresemos will be required to: (i) maintain and/or upgrade an Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS) to ensure that all of its activities are in compliance with Applicable Requirements, which will likely be the IFC FI Exclusion List; (ii) maintain responsible, qualified persons to implement the SEMS; (iii) apply the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions; and (iv) submit an annual E&S report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: Progresemos is a non-bank multi-purpose financial institution (Sofom) specialized in microfinance that seeks to have a positive social impact at the base of the pyramid alongside financial returns.  The Company has been in business since September 2006.   Progresemos portfolio is comprised of micro loans to solidarity groups averaging approximately $475 per individual loan and payroll loans averaging approximately $877 per loan. Of the Companys total originated loans, 70% are microfinance loans granted through the solidarity group methodology and the balance 30% are individual payroll loans. The Company is an existing client.  IFC started a business relationship with Progresemos in 2007, when the Company was at the start-up phase.  In 2008, IFC extended a straight line of credit of 40 million Mexican peso to Progresemos to support the Companys loan portfolio growth.  As of to date, Progresemos has fully complied all its financial obligations. Along with the credit line, IFC also provided Advisory Services (AS) to the Company.  The objective of the AS program was to assist Progresemos in expanding its microfinance operations in Mexico by providing institutional strengthening capacities, including improved credit methodologies, a robust and unique IT platform, internal controls and operating efficiencies.   After finishing the AS program and consolidating the Companys operations, Progresemos is now entering into the growth phase.As of September 2011, Progresemos total assets and total equity amounted to $19.2 million and $10 million equivalent, respectively.  The Company is owned 100% by a group of investors who are seven private individuals.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment consists of a senior loan of up to 35 million Mexican peso (approx. $2.5 million equivalent) and an equity investment of up to 25 million Mexican peso (approx. $1.8 million equivalent) to support the Companys loan portfolio growth.
Investment: 4.30 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan2.51Equity1.79* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Progresemos is headquartered in Mexico City.  Through its delivery channels, the Company has presence in 27 Mexican states and 436 municipalities focused on Mexicos rural and least developed regions; such as Oaxaca, Veracruz and Chiapas, which have populations that are among the lowest in economic strata in Mexico, and with high potential for microlending to small entrepreneurs.

Company Name: PUBLIC JOINT STOCK COMPANY NBD BANK
Project Description: IFC and NBD Bank (the Company) shall realize a 1 billion Russian ruble program of expanding SME finance in frontier regions of the Central part of Russia (NBD SME Frontier or the Project). The proposed IFCs investment consists of a senior local currency loan of up to 500 million Russian rubles (approximately up to $17 million equivalent) up to 5 years to finance SMEs in frontier regions of the Central part of Russia. NBD shall match IFC funding by investing additional 500 million Russian rubles (approximately up to $17 million equivalent) from its own sources.
Impact: The Project is expected to have a high developmental impact on account of(a) providing access to finance to the Russian SME sector;(b) contribute to new employment generation in small towns of the Central part of Russia.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed investment has been classified as Category FI according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  NBD Bank is an existing IFC client.  Current IFC exposure to NBD Bank is $5 million, which consists of exposure under the SME and Energy Efficiency loan agreements.  NBD Bank has developed and is implementing an Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) and provided relevant documentation to IFC.  Environmental staff has been appointed.  The Bank will be required to continue implementation of its ESMS to ensure compliance of the activities financed with the IFC Exclusion List and Russian environmental and social laws and regulations.  IFC reviewed the Banks labor policies in order to verify compliance with IFCs Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions. CES will provide recommendations for NBD Banks labor policies enhancements.  The Bank will be required to continue submission of the Annual Environmental Performance Reports (AEPRs) to IFC.
Sponsor: NBD is a small private-sector regional bank, established in 1992 in Nizhny Novgorod, Russia.  The Bank strategic focus is on small and mid-sized enterprises.  NBD Bank is owned by its management (66.5%), the EBRD (25.0%) and Firebird Capital (8.5%). The participation of EBRD and a wide list of creditors such as DEG, FMO and IFC help to improve the Bank''s level of transparency and corporate governance relative to its peers.
Cost Nature: The total Project Cost is estimated at 1,000,000,000 Russian rubles ($34,000,000).The proposed IFC investment is a 500 million Russian ruble A loan for IFCs own account with 5 years maturity. NBD Bank committed to invest 500 million Russian rubles.
Investment: 15.52 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan15.52Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Project proceeds are targeted to reach SMEs in the most underserved and depressed areas in the central part of the Russian Federation, i.e. small towns and monotowns in Nizhny Novgorod, Ivanovo, Vladimir, Kirov, Penza regions, and Chuvash, Mari El republics and others, where NBD Bank operates.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The proposed investment has been classified as Category FI according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  NBD Bank is an existing IFC client.  Current IFC exposure to NBD Bank is $5 million, which consists of exposure under the SME and Energy Efficiency loan agreements. The Bank will be required to continue implementation of its ESMS to ensure compliance of the activities financed with the IFC Exclusion List and Russian environmental and social laws and regulations.  IFC reviewed the Banks labor policies in order to verify compliance with IFCs Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions. CES will provide recommendations for NBD Banks labor policies enhancements.  The Bank will be required to continue submission of the Annual Environmental Performance Reports (AEPRs) to IFC.

Project Description: The Greenfield project involves the construction and operation of a 3 star hotel in Takoradi Ghana (the Project) by Alliance Estates Limited (the Sponsor). The hotel will be branded as a Protea Select managed by Protea International.  Facilities will include 132 rooms and suites, a restaurant and bar, meeting space for 130 people, a workout room and 78 parking spaces.
Impact: (i) Absorb the unmet demand for quality hotel of international standards in a major business district of Takoradi.(ii) Standards: Improve hotel standards in the 3 star segment.(iii) Skill transfer: Encourage the transfer of skills and expertise in hotel management to the local workforce. (iv) South-South Investment: support a South/South investment in CAF region.(v) Employment: Direct and indirect employment for locals during construction and operations. (vi) Revenues: Government revenue source through tax collection.(vii) Local supplies: local procurement of construction supplies, food and services throughout construction and operations.
Environmental Social Issues: The environmental and social impacts of the Sponsors operations are relatively limited. IFCs review did not identify any significant adverse impacts or high risk exposures. Issues to address include those associated with construction of the hotel (specifically that of waste management, maintaining the health and safety of construction workers and avoiding impacts upon the local community) and those experienced during operations (energy and water usage and waste management and provision of appropriate rights to hotel employees). This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure because of the limited number of adverse impacts that may occur which are generally site specific and can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, procedures, guidelines or design criteria.  While all Performance Standards (PS) are applicable to this investment, IFCs environmental and social due diligence indicates that the investment may have impacts which must be managed in a manner consistent with the following Performance Standards:- PS 1: Social and Environmental Assessment and Management Systems- PS 2: Labor and Working Conditions- PS 3: Pollution Prevention and Abatement- PS 4: Community Health, Safety and Security
Sponsor: Capital Alliance Property Investment Company (CAPIC)   CAPIC is $165 million real estate private equity Fund sponsored by African Capital Alliance (ACA). ACA is an independent firm formed in 1997 to promote private sector invests in Africa. ACA is headquartered in Lagos, Nigeria and is an existing IFC client. CAPIC holds a 49% equity stake in the Project. The Mohinani Group of Companies (MG). MG was established in 1966 in Ghana. It is a private diversified family owned group with interests in packaging product manufacturing, distribution of electronics, property, chemicals trading and recently, quick service restaurants. MG has over 3,000 staff globally, with operations in Ghana, Nigeria and Hong Kong. It also has a presence in East Africa, South Africa and India. In 2010 it achieved a global turnover of $347 million, and held assets of $198 million. The group has won many local and international awards for CSR, quality and market leadership. The group holds a 51% equity stake in the Project.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is $21.8 million The proposed IFC investment is an A Loan of $5.45 million for IFCs own account.

Project Description: IFC is considering an A loan investment of up to $5.45M in Alliance Estates Limited (AEL or the Company) for the construction of a 3-star Protea Select brand hotel in Takoradi, Ghana (the Project).  AEL is a joint venture between CAPIC, (the Sponsor) an existing IFC client and a subsidiary of Africa Capital Alliance (ACA) also an IFC client and Mohinani Group (Co-Sponsor). The investment will be the first internationally branded hotel in Takoradi, a rapidly growing city in Ghanas western region that currently lacks sufficient business infrastructure. The hotel will consist of 132 rooms, a restaurant and bar, meeting space, a swimming pool and 78 parking spaces to be managed by Protea.
Review Scope: IFC''s review for this project included meetings in Accra, Ghana with representatives of the Company, Sponsor and Co-Sponsor, as well as from the construction contract management company. Conference calls also took place with other project suppliers.  In addition, a visit to the site of the proposed hotel development in Takoradi was conducted. The following information was also reviewed: Reponses to the IFC Environmental and Social Appraisal Questionnaire;The Preliminary Environmental Report  (PER), part of the environmental permit application process and various documents detailing the history of the projects interaction with the Ghana EPA (such as submission of Environmental Assessment Registration Form, evidence of submission of Preliminary Environmental Report (PER), evidence of payment of fees, etc. in conjunction with the application for an environmental permit;Various authority approvals including the lease agreement for the site and change of zoning application and approval, planning approval and building permit application approval;Proposed design for a waste water treatment digester which will produce biogas;A working draft of the contractual documentation between Alliance Estates and the construction companyAn IFC energy report detailing possible opportunities to maximize energy efficiency measures in the building design; and,Reports prepared by WSP (the electrical services design, fire strategy and wet services and HVAC design consultants), the architect-developed Materials and Specifications report and a Geotechnical report of the proposed site.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The key environmental and social issues of this project are those associated with construction of the hotel (specifically that of waste management, maintaining the health and safety of construction workers and avoiding impacts upon the local community) and those experienced during operations (hotel employees working conditions, energy and water usage and waste management and life and fire safety). This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure because of the limited number of adverse impacts that may occur which are generally site specific and can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, procedures, guidelines or design criteria.

Project Description: The proposed project involves an IFC investment of up to $12.5 million in Custodian and Allied Insurance plc (Custodian or the Company), a general insurance company located in Nigeria. Through Custodian and Allied Insurance Plc (or the Project), IFC will to support the Companys expansion plans within and outside Nigeria and into new products and market segments.  Custodian has operated on the Nigerian market since 1995, specializing in the marketing and provision of general insurance and special risk products predominantly to corporate clients.
Impact: 1. Insurance Sector Development: IFC''s support for Custodian will enhance the growth and development of the Nigerian insurance sector, thus improving the sector''s contribution to the Nigerian economy;2. Entrepreneurship and Employment: IFC''s involvement in the Insurance Sector through Custodian will promote growth of business activities and employment in Nigeria. Entrepreneurial activities will be encouraged by the availability of appropriate and effective insurance products for risk management; 3. Government Revenues: By enhancing the capacity of the insurance sector to support business activities and employment, IFC''s investment will also enhance the growth of government revenues from taxation of insurance and other business activities;4. Long-Term Funding Source: IFC''s support for Custodian will also facilitate the generation of long term funds through the growth of insurance premiums, thereby addressing the shortage of local currency financing for infrastructure development in Nigeria.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. During appraisal, IFC analyzed the FI portfolio for types of insurance provided and industry sectors, and analyzed the potential Social and Environmental risks associated with the companys activities.  Custodian is a general, non-life insurance company providing personal insurance (motor, accident) and corporate/commercial insurance.  Based on the review IFC determined as the Applicable Performance Requirements the IFC Exclusion List, the applicable national social and environmental laws and regulations as well as the IFC Performance Standards. IFC also assessed Custodians E&S risk management practices and capacity, and appraised the companys labour practices. Custodian has no ESMS in place and does not undertake E&S due diligence. Custodians labour and working conditions were found to be in compliance with the requirements of Performance Standard 2 except that anti-sexual harassment and grievance procedures are not in place. Based on the Applicable Performance Requirements and FI ESMS and capacity review Custodian, will be required to (i) Identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the ESMS prior to commitment, (ii) Develop an Environmental & Social Management System (ESMS), prior to disbursement to the satisfaction of IFC, (iii) develop an ESMS roll-out and training plan to ensure effective implementation of the ESMS, prior to disbursement (iv) Commit to implement the ESMS, to ensure that its activities are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements; (v) Undertake a review of its portfolio to determine if there are any Exclusion List activities; (vi) Finalize and provide for IFCs review an anti-sexual harassment and grievance policy for inclusion in the HR Manual and (vii) Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: Custodians shares are 100% listed on the Nigerian Stock Exchange and are widely held by Nigerian and international investors ( including Aureos Africa Fund LLC, a private equity fund), with no single investor having a controlling interest. The top 7 shareholders have less than 50% of Custodians total shares.  The Chairman, Chief Ade Ojo is the largest shareholder with a shareholding of 17%, while the Managing Director, Mr. Wole Oshin, has a shareholding of 13% in the Company. Aureos Africa Fund LLC holds 7% stake in Custodian.
Cost Nature: IFC will invest up to $12.5 million in a convertible debt.
Investment: 12.50 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan12.50Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Custodian is headquartered in Lagos and operates across Nigeria. The Company sources business essentially through brokers and its own sales force.

Project Description: Belcorp (the Company) is an international corporation with 40 years experience in the manufacturing and sale of cosmetics.  Belcorp is the third largest cosmetics company in Latin America after Natura and Avon, selling its products in 15 countries in LAC, as well as a small operation in the USA. The Companys main production facility is located in Colombia with a capacity of 500,000 products per day, from where it exports to most countries in the region. Belcorp employs over 8,920 people and operates through a direct sales model with a network of almost 1 million consultants who sell Belcorps brands (Ebel, Esika and Cyzone) across the region.IFC will support Belcorps investments plan for the period 2011-2013 that comprises the following main components: i. expansion of production capacity of the plant in Colombia; ii. construction of a new plant in Mexico; and iii. working capital to support the entrance of Belcorp in Brazil (the Project).
Impact: Strong development impact through the generation of 8,920 direct jobs across the region and 1 million of indirect jobs for women through the direct sales market model.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, procedures, guidelines and design criteria. Specific key environment, social, health and safety issues reviewed include: (i) Corporate environmental and social management capacity; (ii) Land acquisition process, planning, and permitting; (iii) Working conditions; (iv) Environmental considerations in the design of the new plants; which includes efficient use of resources and proper management of liquid and air discharges; and (v) Social impact derived from Belcorps direct sales model.
Sponsor: Belcorp, which was founded in Peru in late 1960s, is fully and privately owned.
Cost Nature: Total Project Cost is estimated at $265 million.The proposed IFC investment is an A/B Loan of up to $130 million, which includes $50 million on IFCs own account and a mobilization of $80 million.
Investment: 50.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan50.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Belcorps headquearters are located in Lima, Peru. Its main production facility is in Tocancipa, Colombia. The company has presence in 15 countries in Latin America. Investments will be made in Peru, Colombia, Mexico and Brazil.
