Project Description: Belcorp (the Company) is an international corporation with 40 years'' experience in the manufacturing and sale of cosmetics.  Its main production facility is located in Tocancipa near Bogota, Colombia with a capacity of 500,000 products per day, from where it exports 40% of its total production to most countries in the region.  Additionally, it sources from third party manufacturers (TPM) in Peru, Colombia, Ecuador, Brazil, and France. Belcorp is a multi-brand corporation that employs over 8,920 people across 15 countries in Latin America, operating through a direct sales model through a network of about 1 million women who offer Belcorps products in the region.  IFC will support Belcorps $265 mm investment program for the period 2011-2013. The IFC A/B Loan of $130 mm will finance the following components of the investment plan: (i) the construction of a production facility in Mexico; (ii) the increase in capacity of the production facility in Bogota; and (iii) working capital to enter the Brazilian market.
Review Scope: IFCs due diligence for this proposed investment consisted of a review of environmental and social (E&S) documents provided by Belcorp, which included written replies to an E&S questionnaire submitted by IFC, reviews of technical information related to the proposed project and current operations, human resources (HR) policies and environmental and occupational health and safety (OHS) procedures, plans and records. The appraisal included site visits to Belcorps manufacturing plant in Tocancipa near Bogota, Colombia, the proposed land for the expansion project in Colombia and a site visit to a Third Party Manufacturer (TPM) in Lima, Peru.  Meetings were held at corporate and plant level with the managers and teams responsible for the environmental, human resources, occupational health and safety and social responsibility operations of the company.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, procedures, guidelines and design criteria. Specific key environment, social, health and safety issues reviewed include:Corporate environmental and social management capacity to undertake the project and operations in a manner consistent with IFC Performance Standards;Environmental and social assessment of the impacts of the Project during both construction and operations;Land acquisition process, planning, and permitting;Working conditions, including those relating to occupational health and safety  for employees and contractors during both construction and operation of the project;Belcorps  relationship with the independent beauty consultants who distribute Belcorps product under the direct sales business model;Use of hazardous chemicals during the production processes;Efficient use of energy, water and resources;Wastewater reduction, treatment and disposal; Social impact derived from Belcorps direct sales model.

Company Name: AUREOS SOUTH-EAST ASIA FUND II LP
Project Description: Aureos South-East Asia Fund II (the Fund or the Company) is a closed-end private equity fund which will make equity and quasi-equity investments in a balanced and diversified portfolio of small to medium-sized enterprises located in South-East Asia (Aureos SEAsia II or the Project). The Fund intends to make investments in Thailand, Philippines, Indonesia, Malaysia, Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos, collectively the Target Countries.
Impact: (1)	Support the Development of SMEs. The Fund is expected to invest in small and medium-sized enterprises in the Target Countries. The Fund will address a major constraint faced by SMEs by providing access to finance through equity and quasi-equity instruments. In addition to its capital investment, the Manager expects to provide hands-on support to strengthen the management capacity, develop new information systems, improve accounting and financial systems, and play an active role in identifying new market opportunities and potential acquisition targets. (2)	IDA countries. The Fund intends to invest in SMEs located in IDA countries such as Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam.  (3)	Promote Private Sector Development and Create Jobs. The Manager is expected to source quality SMEs that can generate employment and accelerate growth enabling them to become local and regional market leaders. Furthermore, the successful execution of the Manager''s strategy will attract additional funding sources from the private sector to help narrow the funding gap experienced by most SMEs.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Aureos Capital Limited is an existing IFC client and has developed and implemented an organization-wide SEMS.  Outstanding environmental and social issues with the existing funds in which IFC invests should be followed up prior to the disbursement for this project.  IFC analyzed the proposed portfolio for types of transactions, size, tenor and industry sectors and determined the Applicable Performance Requirements as: the IFC FI Exclusion List, the applicable national social and environmental laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards.  IFC is also reviewing, the capacity of the FI to implement a Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS) and manage social and environmental risks.  If required, IFC will suggest Supplemental Actions to address any gaps in the SEMS.  Based on the review, the project will be required to: (i) upgrade, if necessary, any existing Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS), prior to disbursement to the satisfaction of IFC; (ii) identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the SEMS; (iii) commit to implement the SEMS, to ensure that its investments are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements; and (iv) submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: Aureos was established in 2001 as a joint venture between CDC and the Norwegian Investment Fund for Developing Countries (Norfund). In December 2008, Aureos employees completed a management buyout of Aureos from the two founding shareholders, CDC and Norfund.  Aureos currently has over 90 investment professionals with experience in industry, consulting, corporate finance, investment banking, accountancy and private equity located throughout a network of 28 offices focused on investing across Asia, Africa and Latin America.  The Fund will be managed by Aureos South-East Asia II Managers Limited which will be advised by local investment professionals (Investment Team) with operational and technical support from staff in their Mauritius, London and Singapore offices.
Cost Nature: Aureos South-East Asia Fund II seeks to raise $200 million and held a first closing in March 2011 with $86.2 million in commitments.  IFC proposes to invest equity of up to $25 million in the Fund in a second closing.

Project Description: Lidl, a chain of discount grocery stores owned by the Schwarz Group (the Group or the Company) is implementing a long-term expansion plan in Romania by opening new Lidl discount stores (Lidl Romania or the Project). The Group, one of the largest European food retail discounters, has requested IFC to provide a long-term loan to its Romanian subsidiaries to partially finance the Project.
Impact: Improvement in green building standards: As one of the few global retailers in the food discount stores segment in Romania, the Sponsor will, through the Project, contribute to the improvement of local green building standards by applying the highest level of energy efficiency measures, in line with the ones prevalent in its home market of Germany; which would help the new Lidl stores exceed IFC''s Green Building standardFood Supply chain development: Schwarz''s expansion will (i) increase the number of its local suppliers, (ii) provide additional sales channels for local fresh and dry food producers in Romania, and (iii) contribute to improvements in food security and availability, as well as in efficiency and operating standards throughout the supply chain.Benefits to low income consumers: By expanding the modern discount format in frontier regions and secondary and tertiary cities of Romania, Schwarz will be able to improve access of local low income customers to a more affordable diverse selection of high-quality food products.Employment generation: The Project will create significant local direct employment (mostly women who represent more than 60% of Lidl employees), and indirect employment in the retail value chain.

Project Description: African Eagle Resources ("AFE" or the "Company") is a junior mining company with several exploration properties in Tanzania and Zambia. Its main focus is the advanced stage Dutwa nickel laterite project in north central Tanzania (Dutwa or the Project).At Dutwa, the Company has delineated a JORC-compliant resource of 98.6 metric tons at 0.93% nickel and 0.02% cobalt making it the 6th largest nickel deposit in Africa. AFEs plan is to develop a nickel mine and concentrating plant at Dutwa and to export its product to international markets.AFE is seeking an equity investment from IFC to help finance the ongoing Dutwa feasibility study. IFCs engagement will also help AFE develop the Project in line with industry best practices in environmental and social sustainability.
Impact: The proposed investment will contribute to the completion of a full project feasibility study to confirm the commercial viability of Dutwa. Thus IFC''s current investment will be used for further exploration and studies, and not for the development of a mine. Development impacts from exploration activities are typically limited and at this stage mainly limited to local employment.If Dutwa is developed, significant development impacts will be realized, including: (i) diversification of Tanzania''s mining industry beyond gold and gemstones into base-metals; (ii) Government revenue generation and increased foreign exchange earnings; (iii) Significant linkages of Dutwa with other domestic economic activities; especially transportation and logistics; (iv) employment opportunities; and (v) Dutwa could become a long-term base-load customer of the Tanzanian central rail system.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure because the Environmental, Health & Safety, and Social (EHSS) impacts of the project are limited, site specific and therefore manageable through implementation of appropriate mitigation measures. IFCs categorization of this project is based on the impacts of exploration activities, which currently have a small footprint. The drilling activity is focused on the two target hills - Wamangola and Ngasamo. The hills, whilst fairly preserved, already have access roads that were developed by Telecom companies for the base stations that are currently on the hills. There has therefore been limited need for African Eagle to construct new access roads.  The key environmental and social issues associated with the exploration drilling currently ongoing in Dutwa are: (i) management of exploration activities (specifically rehabilitation of the drill roads, and drill sites, safe disposal of oils, proper solid waste management, water and effluent management at the proposed exploration campsite); (ii) occupational health and safety; (iii) handling of hazardous materials, principally fuel; (iv) public safety and emergency preparedness & response; (v) temporary use of small fractions of communal land for drill pads, that has limited impacts on community use of the land  livestock grazing, collection of firewood and medical plants; (vi) community safety resulting from increase in vehicular traffic; (vii) potential project-induced in-migration and influx of job seekers and small scale service providers; (viii) adequate consultation with the potentially affected communities to manage expectations vis-à-vis potential project benefits, community development programs and understanding of mining activities; and (ix) implementation of appropriate control measures (eg. screening, for prevention of communicable disease transmission).To address the above identified issues and meet the requirements of IFCs Performance Standards, AFE has committed to an Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) covering its exploration activities, feasibility and potential future mine development.Any IFC investment in potential future mine development undertaken by the company will be assessed as a new project and its categorization would be determined after the necessary due diligence. As an equity holder, IFC would require any future mine development to follow the approved ESIA which will be undertaken as part of this investment and to develop and implement a robust and auditable Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS).
Sponsor: AFE was established in 1996 and in 2003 listed on the London Alternative Investment Market (ticker AFE). In 2007 it made a secondary listing on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange (ticker AEA). The Company is headquartered in London, United Kingdom.AFEs largest shareholders are two London-based resources funds: MWB Capital at 11.11% and Anglo-Pacific Group at 7.34%. Directors own 1.97% of the Company. The Company is widely held with approximately 62% of the Company in free-float.
Cost Nature: The Companys 2012 budget estimate is up to 16 million Great British pounds (approximately $26 million), of which approximately 13 million Great British pounds (approximately $21 million) will go towards feasibility and trial studies at its Dutwa project in Tanzania. The feasibility study for the Dutwa project is already in progress and due to be completed in late 2012. IFC proposes to make an initial equity investment of approximately 3.1 million Great British pounds (approximately $5.0 million) in the Company, primarily to finance Dutwa feasibility study activities, and the balance for other corporate activities.

Project Description: African Eagle Resources (AFE or the Company) is a publicly listed British junior mining company, which has early-stage and advanced exploration projects in Tanzania (nickel and gold) and Zambia (copper). 	IFCs main interest is the Companys Dutwa nickel laterite project located in north-central Tanzania, approximately 100km east of Mwanza and 1100km northwest of Dar es Salaam, near Dutwa, a large village and administrative centre within Bariadi District.A total IFC equity investment of around 3.1 Great British pounds (approximately $5.0 million) is proposed to contribute to the financing of the Bankable Feasibility Study (BFS) of the project and for other corporate purposes. AFE has commissioned baseline studies which will lead to the Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) as part of the BFS. The baseline studies will commence in November 2011 and the consultants are currently finalising the scope of work for the studies. IFC will assist AFE in reviewing the scope of work to ensure that the company can develop the project in line with international best practice in environmental and social sustainability. This Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) covers AFEs activities at the early exploration stage including feasibility studies.
Review Scope: IFCs review of the Dutwa project consisted of a three-day appraisal visit conducted in April 2011 to assess the Companys operations, review environmental, health, safety, and social information submitted by the Company and understand their plans and commitments for the future development of the prospect. The trip to site was undertaken by road to gain an impression of the logistics challenges related to raw materials and product transportation should the project proceed to development. In addition, as part of the preliminary logistics assessment, a jetty on Lake Victoria in the fishing village of Nyamikoma was also visited. Whilst in its early stages, the project could also draw water from this point. A potential groundwater abstraction area on the Duma River was also visited to gain an appreciation of potential water sources the company could consider for production.The project area lies thirty to forty km west of the Serengeti National Park; to determine the possibility of adverse impacts on the Park, the IFC team drove east along a gravel road which runs from Dutwa towards the Park and also to the Ndabaka Gate of the Park on the main Mwanza to Musoma trunk road. The gravel road ends approximately 7  10 km from the Maswa Game Reserve which forms a buffer zone between Serengeti National Park and the surrounding communities. The land outside the Park is settled and used for agriculture (crops and animal husbandry  cattle, sheep and goats), and there was no evidence of wildlife migratory routes in this area.Meetings were held with representatives of the community at Dutwa, the Director of Environment and senior representatives of Bollore Africa Logistics in Dar es Salaam. The communitys views on the exploration project were discussed including the communitys interactions with the Company to date. The purpose of the meeting with the Director of Environment was to engage with the relevant central government authorities at an early stage of the investment to solicit their views on the project and understand the directorate sector general views on environmental issues and their management. The meeting with Bollore Africa Logistics sought to strengthen the teams appreciation of logistics related issues in Tanzania including hazardous materials transportation and associated spill, emergency preparedness and response plan requirements. The meeting also touched on Lake Victoria Barging as a potential option for transfer of both raw materials and finished product should the project progress to development.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure because the Environmental, Health & Safety, and Social (EHSS) impacts of the project are limited, site specific and therefore manageable through implementation of appropriate mitigation measures. IFCs categorization of this project is based on the impacts of exploration activities, which currently have a small footprint. The drilling activity is focused on the two target hills - Wamangola and Ngasamo. The hills, whilst fairly preserved, already have access roads that were developed by Telecom companies for the base stations that are currently on the hills. There has therefore been limited need for African Eagle to construct new access roads.  There is currently no exploration campsite as the African Eagle staff resides in rented accommodation in Dutwa village. The key environmental and social issues associated with the exploration drilling currently ongoing in Dutwa are: (i) management of exploration activities (specifically rehabilitation of the drill roads, and drill sites, safe disposal of oils, proper solid waste management, water and effluent management at the proposed exploration campsite); (ii) occupational health and safety; (iii) handling of hazardous materials (e.g. fuel); (iv) public safety and emergency preparedness & response; (v) temporary use of small fractions of communal land for drill pads, that has limited impacts on community use of the land  livestock grazing, collection of firewood and medical plants; (vi) community safety resulting from increase in vehicular traffic; (vii) potential project-induced in-migration and influx of job seekers and small scale service providers; (viii) adequate consultation with the potentially affected communities to manage expectations vis-à-vis potential project benefits, community development programs and understanding of mining activities; and (ix) implementation of appropriate control measures (screening, for prevention of communicable disease transmission).Any IFC investment in potential future mine development undertaken by the company will be assessed as a new project and its categorization would be determined after the necessary due diligence. Even without an additional investment, as long as IFC remains an equity holder, IFC would require any future mine development to follow the approved ESIA which will be undertaken as part of this investment and to develop and implement a robust and auditable Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS). AFE will ensure that the ESIA is consistent with IFC Performance Standards and EHS Guidelines and be publicly available and consulted upon in accordance with IFCs disclosure policy prior to the start of construction.To address the above identified issues and meet the requirements of IFCs Performance Standards, AFE has committed to an Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) covering its exploration activities, feasibility and potential future mine development. The above issues will also be managed via the companys Health, Safety and Environment and Corporate Social Responsibility (HSEC) Policy described below.

Project Description: Sama Resources Inc.s (Sama or the Company) objective is to build a successful exploration and mining company in Côte dIvoire with a focus on nickel and copper sulphides, nickel and cobalt laterites, as well as platinum and palladium. Samas primary asset is an option to earn a 60% stake in the Samapleu polymetallic project (Samapleu or the Project) in Côte dIvoire.   The Project is relatively early on the development curve, but has the potential to host multiple deposits given its location in a new and prospective district in Côte DIvoire.   Samas strategy is to first build a small operation to produce nickel and copper concentrate based on an initial resource of 10 to 15 million tonnes. They would then use the cash flow to scale up their operation based on the discovery of additional resources.  Sama also has a grassroots exploration project (Lola) in Guinea, but the Companys focus is on the development of Samapleu in Côte dIvoire, where IFCs proceeds will be spent.
Impact: This is an early-stage, exploration project in a post-conflict, IDA country which is set to attract investment to develop its mineral resource sector.   During exploration and prior to commercial resource discovery, the Project will have limited, immediate development impact.  Nonetheless, even at its early stage, the Project provides local permanent employment to 35 people in an area with no formal employment opportunities and poverty levels of 80%.   Should exploration lead to mine development and production, the developmental impacts will be notable.   Key expected benefits will include taxes and other payments to government, the generation of direct employment and indirect jobs through linkages into the community as well as the improvement of local transportation and other infrastructure that will support local economic development.   Successful resource discovery and development are also likely to attract more foreign investment into the sector.
Risk Assessment: Governance is weak in the country, as captured by various governance metrics, including the World Bank Governance Indicators and Transparency International.   However, given the early stage nature of the project and the limited benefits to be generated at this point, especially in terms of fiscal revenues, any potential governance risks to them are deemed limited.   In addition, the current Government is actively engaged with the WBG to further improve governance and transparency of the sector, including a renewed commitment to successful EITI implementation.  Côte dIvoire is expected to become EITI compliant in 2012.   In addition, the client is bound by IFCs requirement to make public any material payments made to the government

The drilling activity is focused on target areas identified through ground geophysics and in some cases, soil sampling.  The key environmental and social issues associated with the exploration drilling and trenching currently ongoing are: management of exploration activities (specifically rehabilitation of the drill roads, and drill sites, safe disposal of oils, proper solid waste management, water and effluent management at the exploration campsite); occupational health and safety; handling of hazardous materials (e.g. fuel); public safety and emergency preparedness & response; awareness and assessment of biodiversity issues associated with the proximity to the Mount Nimba UNESCO World Heritage Site for the Lola project; adequate consultation with the potentially affected communities to manage expectations vis-à-vis potential project benefits, programme and consistency of EHSS management across Côte  dIvoire and Guinea.To address the above identified issues and meet the requirements of IFCs Performance Standards, Sama has committed to an Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) covering its exploration activities, feasibility and potential future mine development. In addition, IFC will assist Sama in developing a comprehensive Health, Safety, Environment & Community (HSEC) Policy which will contain management plans for the exploration stage with commitments relating to any future mine development and implementing a comprehensive management system adequate for the exploration phase of the project.Any IFC investment in potential future mine development undertaken by the Company will be assessed as a new project and its categorization would be determined after the necessary due diligence. Even without an additional investment, as long as IFC remains an equity holder, IFC would require any future mine development to follow an ESIA which will be undertaken as part of this investment in parallel to the BFS should an economic resource be defined. Management, directors and advisors hold approximately 22% of the Company.

Project Description: Sama Resourcess (Sama, or the Company) objective is to build a successful exploration and mining company in Côte dIvoire with a focus on nickel and copper sulphides, nickel and cobalt laterites, as well as platinum and palladium. Samas primary asset is an option to earn a 60% stake in the Samapleu polymetallic project (Samapleu or the Project) in Côte dIvoire.   The Project is relatively early on the development curve, but has the potential to host multiple deposits given its location in a new and prospective district in Cote DIvoire. Samas strategy is to first build a small operation to produce nickel and copper concentrate based on an initial resource of 10 to 15 million tonnes. They would then use the cash flow to scale up their operation based on the discovery of additional resources.  Sama also has a grassroots exploration project (Lola) in Guinea, but the Companys focus is on the development of Samapleu in Côte dIvoire, where IFCs proceeds will be spent. Samapleu is located in the Dix Huit Montagnes region approximately 600 km north west of Abidjan, Cote dIvoire.The Lola project, which was not visited during appraisal, is located approximately 1,000 km south east of Conakry near the Liberian border. The concession lies in the forest region of Guinea immediately adjacent to (and surrounding) the Mount Nimba UNESCO World Heritage Site. Exploration at Lola in Guinea is at an early stage of identifying targets (of which the closest is 10 km outside the Mount Nimba Biosphere Reserve buffer zone  see below) and involve site reconnaissance and trenching. Sama plan to undertake diamond core exploration drilling in its Lola concession before the end of this year. The company has established a camp in each country to support the exploration activities. An initial IFC equity investment of up to 1.3 Canadian dollars million is proposed to contribute to the financing of continued exploration and a scoping study of the project. Sama is interested to have IFC on board as a shareholder before the full Bankable Feasibility Study (BFS) for Samapleu. The BFS is a fundamental and key part of the process of development of the mining project which would follow project resource definition and scoping studies, and prefeasibility studies. One of its main purposes is to define the project, its scope, quality, cost and schedule. Should the Samapleu project get to this stage an ESIA meeting IFC Performance Standards will be commissioned and will run parallel to the BFS.In line with similar previous investments, this Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) covers Samas activities at the early exploration pre-feasibility stage. Sama has engaged an environmental consultant to conduct environmental baseline studies. A meteorological station and five surface water data acquisition stations have already been procured and installed on site.
Review Scope: The project consists of a nickel and copper sulphides, nickel and cobalt laterites, platinum and palladium exploration in Côte dIvoire (Samapleu) and a nickel laterite grassroots exploration in Guinea (Lola).IFCs review of the project consisted of an appraisal visit in July 2011 to the companys Samapleu concession area in Côte dIvoire. The appraisal reviewed environmental, health, safety, and social information submitted by the Company and identified their plans and commitments for the future development of the prospect. The appraisal team have also undertaken desk studies on plans and data submitted by the company in respect of their Lola concession in neighbouring Guinea. Informed opinions were also obtained from biodiversity specialists with knowledge of the Lola area.During the site visit to Samapleu, meetings were held with the local communities of Yorodougou, Gangbapleu, and Samapleu, and with the companys labour lawyer and environmental consultant, in Abidjan. The communitys views on the exploration project were discussed and information obtained on the overall community condition, development needs and expectations. The purpose of the meeting with the company lawyer was to gain an understanding of the requirements of the Ivorian labour law for contractors in the context of casual labourers the Company hires from time to time in its exploration programme. The objective of the meeting with the environmental consultant was to assess the consultants capacity to deliver an IFC Performance Standards compliant Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) in the event that an economic resource is identified at Samapleu based on the current exploration activity.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure because the Environmental, Health & Safety, and Social (EHSS) impacts of the project are limited, site specific and therefore manageable through implementation of appropriate mitigation measures. IFCs categorization of this project is based on the impacts of exploration activities, which currently have a small footprint. The drilling activity is focused on target areas identified through ground geophysics and in some cases, soil sampling.  The key environmental and social issues associated with the exploration drilling and trenching currently ongoing are: management of exploration activities (specifically rehabilitation of the drill roads, and drill sites, safe disposal of oils, proper solid waste management, water and effluent management at the exploration campsite); occupational health and safety; handling of hazardous materials (e.g. fuel); public safety and emergency preparedness & response; awareness and assessment of biodiversity issues associated with the proximity to the Mount Nimba UNESCO World Heritage Site for the Lola project; adequate consultation with the potentially affected communities to manage expectations vis-à-vis potential project benefits, programme and consistency of EHSS management across Côte  dIvoire and Guinea.To address the above identified issues and meet the requirements of IFCs Performance Standards, Sama has committed to an Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) covering its exploration activities, feasibility and potential future mine development. In addition, IFC will assist Sama in developing a comprehensive Health, Safety, Environment & Community (HSEC) Policy which will contain management plans for the exploration stage with commitments relating to any future mine development and implementing a comprehensive management system adequate for the exploration phase of the project.Any IFC investment in potential future mine development undertaken by the Company will be assessed as a new project and its categorization would be determined after the necessary due diligence. Even without an additional investment, as long as IFC remains an equity holder, IFC would require any future mine development to follow an ESIA which will be undertaken as part of this investment in parallel to the BFS should an economic resource be defined. Sama will ensure that the ESIA demonstrates that the project is consistent with IFC Performance Standards and EHS Guidelines and will be publicly available and consulted upon in accordance with IFCs requirements prior to the start of mine construction.

Company Name: India Mortgage Guarantee Corporation Private Limited
Project Description: This proposed project (IMGC India or the Project) is an important part of IFCs financial sector engagement in India, and involves an equity investment in Indias first mortgage guarantee company, proposed to be named as India Mortgage Guarantee Company (IMGC or the Company). IMGC is proposed to be established as Mortgage Guarantee Corporation to provide credit risk coverage to residential mortgage lenders in the event of a borrowers default.
Impact: This product is expected to enhance accessibility to affordable housing finance across income segments and regions through the provision of guarantees and support to the lenders. The proposed project will have development impact in the following areas:- Increased home ownership for middle income households  and first time buyers, and deepening the financial market for housing finance - Increased activity in the housing sector- Knowledge transfer to the company and the sector from the various sponsors of the company in helping develop the mortgage finance and guaranty market in India- Risk Transfer: The mortgage guarantee product is expected to allow the banking system an new and effective avenue for risk diversification and would allow the institutional investors to participate in the very large mortgage market which would otherwise be closed to them.-It will also lead to a standardization of lending practices.
Environmental Social Issues: This project entails IFC support for a mortgage guarantee company and has been classified as a Category C project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. No further review is required. The project is required to inform IFC in the event of any change in the nature or scope of its contemplated business or operations.
Sponsor: The proposed company will be established as a public and private sector partnership (PPP) between four partners  National Housing Bank (NHB), IFC, Asian Development Bank (ADB), and Genworth Financial International Holdings (GFIH).  The main Sponsors of the project are NHB and GFIH . NHB was established in 1988 under an Act of Parliament as a wholly owned subsidiary of the Reserve Bank of India (central bank of the country) for developing a sound, healthy, viable and cost effective Indian housing finance system.  GFIH is the international Mortgage Insurance holding company of Genworth Financial, Inc.  a diversified US  financial services company involved in providing  Life Insurance, Wealth Management, Lifestyle Protection and Mortgage Insurance products.
Cost Nature: IFC proposes to invest up to 800 million Indian rupees ($ 17.4 million equivalent) over the next 4-5 years for up to a maximum 19% equity stake to establish a mortgage guarantee corporation in India- India Mortgage Guarantee Company (IMGC).
Investment: 8.60 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity8.60* These investment figures are indicative
Location: IMGCs operations will be headquartered in the National Capital Region of Delhi. Offices in other locations may be opened depending upon the business needs of the Company.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project entails IFC support for a mortgage guarantee company and has been classified as a Category C project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. No further review is required. The project is required to inform IFC in the event of any change in the nature or scope of its contemplated business or operations.

Project Description: Matco Rice Processing (PVT) Ltd. (the Company) is a private-family owned limited company engaged in rice processing and export business. The Company has three rice processing plants, two in Karachi (Matco 1 & Matco 2) and one in Sadhoke. Rice is procured from Punjab and Sindh provinces and stored in warehouses in Karachi and Lahore. The production activity in Karachi comprises mainly of re-processing  include polishing, length grading, color sorting, and packing lines of 5 and 25 tons per hour (tph) capacity respectively whereas Sadhoke has paddy drying, storage and milling processing line of 10 tph capacity. The project is to construct a modern rice paddy drying, husking and parboiling plant at Sadhoke, Punjab and storage capacity in Sadhoke (the Project).
Impact: The expected development impact includes the following:(i)	Employment: The Project will generate 300 new rural jobs and about 200 seasonal employees in Punjab in 2 years;(ii)	Farmers reach: The Project will create additional backward linkages which are expected to generate benefits to approximately 1,500 farmers in the region;(iii)	Improved agri-infrastructure: The Project will increase  automatic drying capacity by 45,000 MT and automated silo capacity by 30,000 MT thus improving food storage in the Punjab region and reducing losses and bottlenecks; and(iv)	Better quality product: The company will expand the production of its high quality branded rice products in Pakistan.
Environmental Social Issues: The potential adverse effects of the project are limited, site specific and reversible and can be readily mitigated.  It is therefore concluded that this is an Environmental Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures.The key environmental and social issues associated with the project include: companys capacity to manage and implement its health, safety, and environmental (HSE) policies and procedures in accordance with IFC Performance Standards and Environment, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines, utilization of equipment and operational practices that maximizes conservation of energy, water and process materials including recycling and reuse initiatives; monitoring and management of air emissions, wastewater treatment and discharge, solid waste disposal; and management of any child labor in the supply chain as well as other issues (e.g., pesticide/fertilizer provision to suppliers) associated with the supply chain.
Sponsor: The Project sponsor is the Ghori family (Sponsors) which own 100% of Matco Rice Processing. The Sponsors are a well established family which has over 45 years of experience in basmati rice business.  Mr. Jawed Ali Ghori, is Matcos Chief Executive Officer and Managing Director. Mr. Ghori has led Matco through various phases which included the construction and operation of Pakistan''s largest rice processing plant with the capacity of 25 MT/hour.  Four additional members of the Ghori family play front-line roles in Matco as sponsors and managers.
Cost Nature: The total Project cost is $17.8 million investment program. IFC is considering an equity investment up to $5 million in the Company.
Investment: 5.06 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity5.06* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Project is located at Sadhoke, a village of Gujranwala, Punjab of Pakistan.  As a result of the Project, the Company will procure paddy directly from farmers and paddy trader which is expected to reduce supply bottlenecks and translate into additional margin opportunities for Matco.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The potential adverse effects of the project are limited, site specific and reversible and can be readily mitigated.  It is therefore concluded that this is an Environmental Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures.The key environmental and social issues associated with the project include: companys capacity to manage and implement its health, safety, and environmental (HSE) policies and procedures in accordance with IFC Performance Standards and Environment, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines, utilization of equipment and operational practices that maximizes conservation of energy, water and process materials including recycling and reuse initiatives; monitoring and management of air emissions, wastewater treatment and discharge, solid waste disposal; and management of any child labor in the supply chain as well as other issues (e.g., pesticide/fertilizer provision to suppliers) associated with the supply chain.

Project Description: Matco Rice Processing (PVT) Ltd. is a private-family owned limited company engaged in rice processing and export business. The Company was founded in 1964 as a trading company and supplier of machinery to the Government of Pakistan (GoP). In 1990, GoP allowed the private sector to export rice, and Matco established Pakistans first fully automated, modern rice processing plant supplied by Satake Corporation of Japan to produce and export well cleaned, graded and textured Basmati and IRRI rice. Almost 95% of the companys products are exported to over 40 countries. The Company has three rice processing plants, two in Karachi (Matco 1 & Matco 2) and one in Sadhoke. Rice is procured from Punjab and Sindh provinces and stored in warehouses in Karachi and Lahore. The production activity in Karachi comprises mainly of re-processing  include polishing, length grading, color sorting, and packing lines of 5 and 25 tons per hour (tph) capacity respectively whereas Sadhoke has paddy drying, storage and milling processing line of 10 tph capacity. Matco is undertaking a US$17.8 million investment program to (i) construct a 45,000 metric tons (MT)  per annum  modern rice paddy drying, husking and parboiling plant at Sadhoke, Punjab; (ii) build up 12 silos with 30,000 MT storage capacity in Sadhoke; and (iii) fund additional working capital requirements. The Company has already commissioned a 22,500 MT capacity (of the 45,000 MT plant capacity) production line of the drying, husking and parboiling plant and has installed 3 (of 12) silos for paddy storage (Phase I) in the Sadhoke plant. The Project is expected to be financed by US$8.3 million of long term debt, US$4.7 million of cash generation and US$4.8 million of IFC equity which is required to finance the remaining silos construction and some of the permanent working capital requirements. For Further information about IFC financing of this project, please refer to the Summary of Proposed Investment (SPI) published on IFC website.
Review Scope: IFCs review of this proposed investment consisted of reviewing technical, environment and social information submitted by Matco Rice Processing (PVT) Limited (Matco or the Company) including:Health, Safety and Environmental policiesHealth, Safety and Environment (HSE) manual, HSE management plan, risk assessment tools, and certificates;Food Safety and Hygiene policy; Emergency response plan;Human Resources policies and procedures including organization charts and training records; Technical specifications of equipment and utilities;Relevant permits and legislative authorizations;Environmental monitoring reports; and Corporate social responsibility (CSR) and Community Welfare report. The appraisal included site visits to Matcos processing plants and warehouse in Karachi and discussions with Matcos senior management, technical and HSE team at the corporate office in Karachi.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The potential adverse effects of the project are limited, site specific and reversible and can be readily mitigated.  It is therefore concluded that this is an Environmental Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures.The key environmental and social issues associated with the project include: companys capacity to manage and implement its health, safety, and environmental (HSE) policies and procedures in accordance with IFC Performance Standards and Environment, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines, utilization of equipment and operational practices that maximizes conservation of energy, water and process materials including recycling and reuse initiatives; monitoring and management of air emissions, wastewater treatment and discharge, solid waste disposal; and management of any child labor in the supply chain as well as other issues (e.g., pesticide/fertilizer provision to suppliers) associated with the supply chain.
Sector: AA - Grain Processing (Milling, Starch, Flour, Malt)

Project Description: The proposed project, comprised of an investment in a subordinated loan in Bank Muscat SAOG (BM or the Bank or the Company), is designed to strengthen the Banks capitalization and support its lending program to low to middle-income housing households and small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Oman (the Project).Bank Muscat, a client of IFC since 2006, is the leading bank in Oman. The Bank is a universal bank providing corporate, retail, investment, treasury, private banking and asset management services to over one million clients through the largest branch network in the country.  The Bank also has international presence through its branches in Riyadh (Saudi Arabia), Kuwait and Representative Offices in Dubai (UAE) and Singapore. In addition, BM currently owns 49% of BMI Bank B.S.C, an independent bank with banking interests in East Africa; a 43% stake in Mangal Keshav Group, one of the oldest securities houses in India; a 98% stake in Muscat Capital LLC, a newly created brokerage and investment banking entity in Saudi Arabia; besides a minority stake in Silkbank Ltd. in Pakistan. This new investment is aimed at supporting a bank committed to fulfill the funding needs of segments that play an important role in Omans economic growth and job creation as well as strengthening its capitalization for future growth.
Impact: The project is expected to achieve a significant development impact as it will allow IFC to enhance access to finance for job creation sectors such as SME and low-middle income households in Oman partnering with a strong bank with an established distribution capacity and reach.  Specific positive developmental impacts are expected to be:-	Job Creation: Through this project IFC will increase access to finance for SMEs and housing finance  in Oman that play an important role in generating employment and economic growth.-	Enhance access to finance for SMEs: The project will support the underserved SME segment which in turn helps the industry diversification efforts.-	Enhanced Access to Affordable Housing and Social Impact: The project will promote the primary mortgage market enhancing the level of access to viable housing finance and the ability of the population to purchase their homes. The increased level of home ownership will also contribute to improve living standards in the country;-	Positive Signaling to the Market:  IFC''s continued engagement at a time of global turmoil is expected to send a positive signal to markets.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  During appraisal, IFC will analyze the FI portfolio, and the activities proposed to be supported with IFC financing for types of transactions, size, tenor and industry sectors and determine the Applicable Performance Requirements, if any, that would include a combination of: The IFC FI Exclusion List(s), andThe applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and regulations IFC will also review, if required, the capacity of the FI to manage social and environmental risks and to establish and maintain an Environmental & Social Management System (ESMS).Based on the review, the project will be required to: Identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the ESMS, prior to IFC commitment.Develop an Environmental & Social Management System (ESMS), prior to disbursement to the satisfaction of IFCCommit to implement the ESMS within an agreed time frame, to ensure that its investments/activities supported by IFC financing are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements.Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: BM is listed on Muscat Securities Market, Bahrain Stock Exchange and London Stock Exchange through GDRs.  As of June 2011, the Bank has approximately 7,500 shareholders and GDR holders and has over 40% free float. The main shareholders are the Royal Court Affairs, Dubai Financial Group, Omani Pension Funds and Muscat Overseas Company LLC.
Cost Nature: The proposed investment consists of a subordinated loan of up to $170 million and is expected to be made by the IFC Capitalization Fund, which is managed by IFC Asset Management Company, LLC, a wholly-owned subsidiary of IFC.
Location: BM is headquartered in Muscat, Oman. The Bank also operates through its branches in Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and representative office in Dubai (UAE) and Singapore, and has further international presence through its associates in Bahrain, India and Saudi Arabia.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  During appraisal, IFC will analyze the FI portfolio, and the activities proposed to be supported with IFC financing for types of transactions, size, tenor and industry sectors and determine the Applicable Performance Requirements, if any, that would include a combination of: The IFC FI Exclusion List(s), andThe applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and regulations IFC will also review, if required, the capacity of the FI to manage social and environmental risks and to establish and maintain an Environmental & Social Management System (ESMS).Based on the review, the project will be required to: Identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the ESMS, prior to IFC commitment.Develop an Environmental & Social Management System (ESMS), prior to disbursement to the satisfaction of IFCCommit to implement the ESMS within an agreed time frame, to ensure that its investments/activities supported by IFC financing are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements.Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.

Project Description: Desarrollo Agricola del Paraguay S.A. (DAP or the Company) is one of the leading farming companies in Paraguay. IFC started its relationship with DAP in 2009 with a short term facility followed by an equity investment to support its operations. DAP currently owns more than 26,000 hectares and leases another 8,000 hectares in Paraguay to cultivate soybean, corn and sunflower with a social-inclusive and sustainable approach. It outsources farming operations to local specialized service providers such as seeding, fertilizing, harvesting, storage, and transportation operators.   Desarrollo Agricola del Paraguay LT Financing (the Project) consists of providing a corporate long term facility to DAP for the financing of permanent working capital needs to sustain its farming activities in Paraguay.
Impact: DAP is having a significant developmental impact by supporting a more productive farming business model in Paraguay, which is expected in turn to make significant contribution to Paraguay''s rural economic development as well as to global food security. DAP''s main impacts include:(i) DAP''s innovative approach to establish trust-based relationships with the local peasant communities. DAP''s initiatives help rural families to improve their farming practices, triggering a virtuous circle of development. (ii) DAP is partnering with leading NGOs and local community organizations to develop outreach programs for rural farmers to improve their access to new markets by (a) capacity building on good agricultural practices, (b) advise on product diversification (e.g. organic products), and (c) improve access to roads and logistic services. (iii) DAP has contributed to the development of a new class of agricultural service companies and SMEs agri-contractors in frontier rural areas that provide various services and inputs to the Company.  DAP supports indirect employment for 850 persons working for more than 44 SMEs agri-contractors, which DAP promotes through trainings, workshops, and social activities. (iv) DAP contributes to food security by promoting soil conservation agriculture expertise (no-till farming), sustainable pest management (IPM) and world-class farm technology and management, increasing the yields and sustainability of owned and leased farms.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that may be avoided or mitigated by adhering to good international industry practices, IFCs performance standards, and applicable sections of IFCs EHS guidelines or design criteria.
Sponsor: DAP is a private Paraguayan Company owned by (i) Paraguayan and Argentine investors (39.1%), (ii) The Rohatyn Group (15.2%), (iii) Berkley International (26.1%), (iv) JP Morgan (10.6%), and IFC (9.1%).  The Company is owned by its shareholders through two holding companies: Mercosur Agro Frontiers Fund LLC (MAFF) and NFD Agro Limited (NFD).
Cost Nature: The Project consists of financing permanent working capital needs to sustain the Companys farming activities in Paraguay. The proposed IFC investment is an up to $8 million A loan for IFCs own account.
Investment: 7.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan7.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Company is headquartered in Asunción, Paraguay and its farms are mainly located in rural areas in the States of the San Pedro and Concepcion of Paraguay.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that may be avoided or mitigated by adhering to good international industry practices, IFCs performance standards, and applicable sections of IFCs EHS guidelines or design criteria.

(DAP or the Company) is an existing IFC client and the environmental and social aspects of the Companys operations were initially evaluated by IFC in 2009.  IFCs initial appraisal, at that time, indicated that the Company was in compliance with the majority of   IFCs Performance Standards requirements applicable to its operations and also identified areas of improvement which were captured in an Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP).  Based on the appraisal of the initial loan and additional information received during the monitoring phase, the Company is considered to be a good performer on environmental and social matters. Project Description: The project is for IFC and other development finance institutions, DFIs and commercial banks (Program Participants) to assume a funded  risk participation for up to $250 million in the  trade finance portfolio of the critical agri and energy inputs of Société Générale SA (SocGen, SG or the Bank), structured under IFC Critical Commodities Liquidity Program (CCLP) initiative. CCPL is a public-private partnership (PPP) initiative that is part of IFCs multi-faceted rapid global financial crisis response. It is a funded program of up to $4 billion that will be mobilized and disbursed in phases to provide IFC with a flexible platform from which to support the extension of liquidity to clients globally. The proposed total IFC investment would be up to $1 billion, which will be leveraged with resources from other DFIs as well as several international banks with an established footprint in emerging markets. Without this support, the risk of disruption in essential commodity flows to Africa is real.
Impact: The CCLP-Bank facility is expected to have the following specific development impacts:- Increase Liquidity: The Facility will ensure continuing and additional funding to the major agricultural and energy sectors in Emerging Countries, especially in Africa and IDA countries. This Facility will contribute to the Bank maintaining its level of business in commodity finance. Among other things, the Facility will enable traders to purchase from and finance agricultural producers, the mainstay of most economies in Africa, and ensure food security and income for the public at large, but especially to farmers. - Strong Demonstration Effect by catalyzing other IFIs to Support Agri and Energy Finance: By supporting commodity backed finance and outreach in partnerships with banks, the facility will have a significant demonstration impact on other banks, especially local /regional banks to participate in funding the agricultural and energy sectors.  This would ultimately help increase access to finance for critical economic sectors.-  A steady supply of critically needed refined oil products through regular channels will keep prices in check, remove parallel market incentives, improve affordability for the vulnerable poor and contribute to sustaining local economic activities.
Environmental Social Issues: This Project involves support for agricultural commodities, agricultural (e.g. fertilizers, crop protection) and energy inputs, and has been classified as Category FI. In addition to applying IFC''s Exclusion List as an applicable requirement, IFC will review the environmental and social (E&S) risks associated with the agricultural and energy commodities portfolio to be supported by the project.  IFC will review the project by applying its own standards and applicable methodology, especially as it relates to harmful child/forced labor and biodiversity risks associated with the conversion of natural and critical habitats.  This process will allow to exclude counterparts involved in agricultural and energy commodities that have significant E&S concerns in the countries where they are sourced/produced.  IFC will review the Banks  internal processes in respect of the proposed commodity portfolio.
Sponsor: Established in 1864, Société Générale (the Bank) is one of the largest banks in France and in the European zone. Its three main divisions are Retail Banking & Specialized Financial Services, Corporate and Investment Banking and Global Investment Management & Services. The Bank is currently rated A+ by S&P, Aa3 by Moody''s and A+ by Fitch.
Cost Nature: As part of IFCs Critical Commodities Liquidity Program, the funding to the Bank will be for up to $250 million for a trade portfolio of up to $500 million aimed at supporting both agricultural commodities/inputs globally and exports/imports of crude oil and  refined oil products in and out Emerging Countries, primarily IDA countries.

Company Name: TIRYAKI AGRO GIDA SANAYI VE TICARET ANONIM SIRKETI
Project Description: IFC considers an investment up to $50 million A Loan to Tiryaki Agro Foods (Tiryaki or the Company), which is an integrated supply chain manager with activities in sourcing, logistics, processing, storage and marketing of agricultural products (the Project). The Company is headquartered in Istanbul, has a substantial presence in Turkey by operating plants across the country, including processing facilities in the southeast Turkish city of Gaziantep, and has international trade presence. Tiryaki is a family owned private company which is engaged in sourcing, processing, storage and trading of conventional and organic grains (wheat, barley and corn), Pulses (lentils, chickpeas, peas, beans, rice and bulgur),  Oil seeds (sunflower, sesame, kanola and soybean) and  Nuts (pistachio, almonds, walnut and peanuts)  across Europe, Africa, the Middle East, CIS countries, Indian subcontinent and America.
Impact: -Supply Chain Linkages and Access to Farmers: Tiryaki sources directly from 40 farmers in Turkey through contract farming arrangements, providing them seeds and pre-financing in the process. In addition, the Company works with third-party logistics and service companies. The Project will increase the impact of the Company on SMEs along its supply chain.-Job Creation and Increased Tax Revenues for the Government: Profitable growth of Tiryaki''s business would create new jobs and increase the tax revenues to the Government.-Supporting a Regional Player: The Project will strengthen the Company`s market position, which has substantial room for consolidation, and improve its competitiveness in agribusiness sector regionally.
Environmental Social Issues: The Project has limited potential adverse environmental and social impacts, and those that do exist are being site-specific and can be resolved through the application of good international industry practices. This corporate-level investment is therefore a provisional Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.Key environmental and social risks for this project include;- Quality, Environmental and Safety Management systems, Food Safety programs- Management of  E&S Risks and Impacts of Agro-Commodity Supply Chains, risk mapping, child and forced labor risks for direct suppliers and traders, significant adverse impact potential for natural and/or critical habitats by primary suppliers-Occupational Health and Safety risks for direct employees and contractors/third parties - Energy efficiency and air emissions (special environmental and safety measures are required for fryers and roasters if exist)-Water use efficiency at the supply chain- Life, fire and traffic safety- Labor transparency typically require strengthening
Sponsor: The Company is privately owned. The main shareholders are Tiryaki Holding A.S. with 80% shareholding and Gulf Investors Agro S.A.R.L., a fund managed by Investcorp from Manama, Bahrain , with 20% shareholding. Established in 1965 by the Tiryakioglu family and headquartered in Istanbul, the company has successfully expanded to become an integrated supply chain manager sourcing from over 15 different countries with storage and processing facilities in Turkey and exporting to more than 40 countries. Tiryakioglu family has only been focused on Tiryaki and does not have ownership in other businesses.
Cost Nature: IFC considers an A loan up to $50 million to finance working capital needs of the Company.

The Company has two operational plants in Turkey in the cities of Gaziantep and Bandirma. Third plant in Mersin is currently at the construction stage. The Company also has three storage facilities located in Gaziantep, Trabzon, Mersin.

Project Description: Candax Energy Inc. (Candax or the Company) is a small independent oil and gas company mainly focused on Tunisia, and listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Candax owns an interest in five oil and gas fields in Tunisia, consisting of the El-Bibane (73.8% net interest), Ezzaouia (31.4%), Robbana (80%), Belli (50%), and Al-Manzah (75%) fields, and one exploration license in Madagascar. Candax seeks to raise funds in order to finance its investment program in Tunisia which aims to enhance production from its mature asset base (currently approximately 320 barrels of oil per day (bopd) on average) by improving reservoir understanding, drilling new wells, and executing other recovery techniques (the Project).With the proposed development program, the Company is expecting to increase production to approximately 700 bopd by the end of 2012, and keep growing at a similar trend over the following years from its existing base, in addition to any acquisition the Company may make.
Impact: The Project is expected to have the following development impacts:1.	Value extraction out of mature, marginal fields: The Project involves investments aimed at prolonging the life of mature fields which, given their marginal nature, would otherwise see production decline quickly and be abandoned within the next few years. 2.	Contribution to government revenues: The Project will generate fiscal receipts in the form of royalties, corporate taxes and participation in the production through the Tunisian national oil company ("ETAP").  3.	Demonstration effect: The Project supports a junior oil and gas company with assets in Tunisia. Increase in     production and positive returns to shareholders should incentivize more investors to supply capital for similar ventures in the country that focus on marginal and mature field development. 4.           Preservation and creation of employment: By sustaining production for a longer period in the Company''s mature fields, the Project will maintain current employment levels. Approximately 140 families rely on their income from jobs sourced on these fields. Furthermore, the Company is committed to create managerial positions in its Tunisian offices as well as operating positions for the development of the fields.5.	Generating additional business for local and national suppliers: Candax''s local procurement will have a positive impact on regional economic activity through the purchase of equipment, products and services.6.            Improve Tunisia''s energy account trading balance: Tunisia currently has a negative energy account trading balance. Production from the Project will help alleviate the energy trade deficit and raise foreign exchange earnings. The following indicators will be tracked throughout the life of the Project: (a) Annual output levels; (b) Tax and other payments made to government; (c) Employment; and (d) Domestic purchases (US$).
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project because a limited number of specific E&S impacts may result, that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to industry recognized standards, guidelines, design criteria and IFC Performance Standards. Candaxs facilities are well established and the Company follows good international industry practice through the implementation of the standards and internationally recognised procedures contained within their comprehensive health, safety and environmental management system. The management system will be further strengthened through the adoption and integration of IFCs Performance Standards and applicable EHS Guidelines.Information about potential environmental and social impacts and how they will be addressed by the company is summarized in the Environmental and Social Review Summary.
Sponsor: The Project sponsor is Geofinance N.V. (Geofinance), the holding vehicle of the Rebilly family. The Geofinance group, through various entities, has been active in the oil and gas exploration and production business since 1993, with a portfolio of assets in France, India, Vietnam and Yemen. With its investment in Candax, Geofinance seeks to expand its activity in the E&P business in the Middle East and North Africa.Geofinance owns an 80.2% stake of the Company, Actis LLP (a private equity fund specialized in emerging markets) owns 6.6% and the remaining 13.2%  is free float held by more than 4,000 private investors (mostly retail).
Cost Nature: Total Project costs are estimated at $50.5 million, and comprise several appraisal and development activities across the Companys assets. In particular: Following the resumption of production of Robbana 1 well  in August 2011, the Company will foresee the redevelopment of Robbana field through potential drilling of infill wells and will evaluate the implementation of a waterflood program;On El Bibane, a 3D seismic acquisition campaign will be implemented if the planned reprocessing of existing 2D seismic data and additional 2D seismic lines do not provide adequate detail.  Following the full seismic studies, the Company will drill up to two new wells to develop this offshore field;A review of the development of Ezzaouia together with the other partners in the field, which could lead to a campaign of workovers and a sidetrack in the Ezzaouia field. The field has been producing for the past 20 years and recovery could be improved by carefully managing the asset; andRe-drilling or side-tracking an existing well in the Belli field.IFCs proposed investment consists of an initial equity investment in the Company of up to 10 million Canadian dollars. The investment will be in the form of common shares and warrants. The exercise of these warrants would generate additional proceeds of up to 14 million Canadian dollars for the Company.
Investment: 23.56 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity23.56* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Candaxs main oil and gas assets in Tunisia are mature oil and gas fields that were first brought into production 10-20 years ago. None of the assets involve a greenfield development.The El-Bibane field is located 18km offshore in the Gulf of Gabes, in water depths of 2-7 meters. The field has been developed by installing three unmanned production platforms with 18km underwater pipelines to the shore. The onshore Ezzaouia field is located in southern Tunisia, 12km north of the city of Zarzis in an agricultural area.The central processing facility of the El Bibane field, as well as the storage and export terminal of the Ezzaouia field, are located in the area of the industrial port of Zarzis.Robbana is an onshore field located on the island of Djerba, and production has been resumed in August 2011 following a successful workover of the well.  The field is in an agricultural area.The non-producing Belli and Al-Manzah fields are located in the Cap Bon Peninsula of northern Tunisia, approximately 60km from the city of Tunis.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project because a limited number of specific E&S impacts may result, that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to industry recognized standards, guidelines, design criteria and IFC Performance Standards. Candaxs facilities are well established and the Company follows good international industry practice through the implementation of the standards and internationally recognised procedures contained within their comprehensive health, safety and environmental management system. The management system will be further strengthened through the adoption and integration of IFCs Performance Standards and applicable EHS Guidelines.Information about potential environmental and social impacts and how they will be addressed by the company is summarized in the Environmental and Social Review Summary.
Sector: AB - Oil and Gas Production (Includes Development)

Project Description: The proposed IFC transaction is an equity investment of up to $25 million in PT Medco Power Indonesia (MPI or the Company), an independent power producer (IPP) in Indonesia (Medco Power 2011 or the Project or the Investment). The Investment is part of a $112 million equity package to be arranged by a consortium of financial investors to acquire majority of MPI and provide growth capital to MPI.MPI is currently owned 100% by PT Medco Energi Internasional tbk (MedcoEnergi), an oil and gas exploration company in Indonesia.  In line with MedcoEnergis strategic re-focusing on its hydrocarbon business, MedcoEnergi has decided to invite a financial investor into MPI to facilitate its further growth in the domestic IPP market, which is poised for significant growth in response to growing electricity demand in the country.The power grids in Indonesia comprise a large, interconnected Java-Bali grid and several other smaller island grids, most of which are isolated.  Given growth in electricity demand of over 9% per annum, the Indonesian power sector has struggled to meet its required investment needs over the past decade. In light of these factors, MPI has focused on developing, owning and operating small- to medium-scale IPPs tailored to smaller islands and isolated grids with unmet demand for electricity. MPI has developed six gas power projects with a total gross installed capacity of 189MW. MPI also provides Engineering, Procurement and Construction (EPC) and Operations and Maintenance (O&M) services to other power producers in the country. Given the increasing awareness of the climate change agenda in the country, MPIs future strategy is to pursue small- to medium-IPPs in the clean energy sphere. The growth capital provided by IFC and its co-investors is to be used for: i) the expansion of MPIs existing gas plants from simple-cycle to combined-cycle, thereby improving their efficiency; ii) developing small scale hydro projects; and iii) new gas fired power projects.
Impact: The Project is expected to have the following developmental impacts:a) Climate Change Mitigation: The Project is expected to displace coal and oil fired power generation that would otherwise be developed and to have demonstration effect in facilitating the development of small-to medium -sized domestic IPPs using domestic gas or hydro resources, a market segment that has been under-served thus far. b) Private Sector Development: The Project would also have a demonstration effect in facilitating the development of local IPP players, in a market that remains dominated by foreign IPP investors. The development of local players is important in supporting the growth of a competitive IPP market and would further broaden the local private-sector base.c) Infrastructure Development: The Project is expected to add power generating capacity for over one million people, a substantial number in a country where approximately 1/3 of the population lives without regular access to the electricity network.d) Rural Development & Employment: Investments in small scale hydropower projects are expected to stimulate job creation and economic growth in rural communities.e) Taxes: The project is expected to increase the tax base of the Government of Indonesia.
Environmental Social Issues: Existing gas-fired thermal power assets are considered to have limited environmental and social impacts.  MPIs medium-term growth strategy is focused toward the development of additional gas fired power generation on Batam Island, Indonesia, and the development of small hydro (less than 10MW per asset) power activities, which are expected to have limited environmental and social impacts.  Consequently, this is a Category B corporate investment as per IFCs Environment and Social Review Procedure.
Sponsor: The group of financial investors in which IFC would participate is led by Saratoga Capital.  Founded in 1998 by Messrs. Edwin Soeryadjaya and Sandiaga Uno, Saratoga is an investment management firm focused on Indonesia. Saratoga has invested about $600 million to date in various industries. Saratoga Asia II raised funds primarily among institutional investors, including IFC. Saratogas portfolio companies are valued in excess of $ 2 billion and currently employ over 20,000 people.The Soeryadjaya family was the founder of Astra International, a large Indonesian automotive manufacturer, and an IFC client in the 1990s. The family exited from Astra International in the late 1990s and has refocused its business activities into investment through Saratoga which is now among the best regarded investment firms in Indonesia. Established in 1980 by Arifin Panigoro as a drilling company, MedcoEnergi is now an integrated oil & gas exploration company with operations in Indonesia as well as the United States, the Middle East, and North Africa. Listed on the Jakarta Stock Exchange (owned 50.7% by Encore Energy; 37.6% the public; and 11.7%, the treasury stock), MedcoEnergi reported $929.9 million in revenues and $222.5 million in EBITDA for FY2010.
Cost Nature: Total project costs required for undertaking MPIs expansion, acquisition and green-field projects are estimated at about $430.5 million. This is to be funded through a debt to equity ratio of approximately 70:30 with $283.5 million in loans at a project level and $147 million in equity, of which MPI is to contribute $112 million and the other equity holders of the projects are to contribute the remaining $35 million, as summarized below:Table 3:  Sources and Uses of fundsSources of funds ($ mill)Uses of funds ($ mill) Total Equity $147 Committed Projects Gross Capital Expenditure$398.7 Subscription of MPIs new shares $112 Of which the IFC Investment$25 Working Capital, EPC, Acquisitions$31.8 Equity from minority shareholders in MPIs subsidiaries$35 Total Debt (to be borrowed at a project level) $283.5 Total$430.5 Total$430.5
Investment: 25.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity25.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The bulk of MPIs current operations are located on the southern shore of Batam, an island located between Singapore and the Indonesian island of Sumatra, adjacent to the entry point of the undersea gas pipe-line from a gas field in Sumatra to Singapore.  They are at an industrial site on a hill overlooking the narrow strait between Sumatra and Batam, with no residential or other non-industrial developments in close proximity. In line with its business model, MPIs future operations will be located across various locations in Indonesia.

MPIs medium-term growth strategy is focused toward the development of additional gas fired power generation on Batam Island, Indonesia, and the development of small hydro (less than 10MW per asset) power activities, which are expected to have limited environmental and social impacts.  Consequently, this is a Category B corporate investment as per IFCs Environment and Social Review Procedure.
