Project Description: Komercijalna Banka ad Beograd (KBB or the Bank or the Company) is the largest locally owned bank in the Serbian banking sector, ranking the 2nd by total assets in the country. Operating since 1971, KBB is a universal bank offering a full range of banking services to its more than 750,000 clients in retail, corporate, SME, and municipal sectors. Headquartered in Belgrade, KBB has developed a strong domestic franchise and expanded to Bosnia & Herzegovina and in Montenegro. The Bank currently employs more than 3,000 staff. KBB SubDebt (the Project) supports an existing client of IFC, a systemic bank in the Serbian banking sector, with long-term financing which is currently unavailable in the market. This partnership will further support private sector development and sustainable economic growth as it would enhance the Banks capacity to serve clients.
Impact: By providing the Bank with the sub-debt, IFC/AMC will help Komercijalna to strengthen its capital base at a time where Basel II capital requirements are to be adopted in Serbia. This will consequently allow the Bank to further strengthen its position in the market and bolster its financial services and products to Serbian enterprises and individual consumers, supporting economic activity and job protection in the country.
Environmental Social Issues: This project which consists of a sub-debt has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. IFCs existing investment in Komercijalna Banka consists of an equity investment. Komercijalna Banka has established a Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) to screen on lending activities against the IFC Exclusion List, applicable environmental and social national laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards for high risk transactions. For this particular project, IFC''s applicable requirements will be to ensure compliance against the IFC Exclusion List, applicable environmental and social national laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards. IFC''s appraisal will focus on Komercijalna Banka progress in implementing the ESMS.
Sponsor: The Banks shares are listed on the Belgrade Stock Exchange. The Government of Serbia is the largest shareholder with 43% direct ownership in KBB. European Bank of Reconstruction and Development is the second largest shareholder of the Bank with a minority 25% stake. Remaining shares of the Bank are owned by small shareholders individually holding less than 5% of the Bank. In December 2009, the Bank was recapitalized by the IFIs resulting in IFC Capitalization Fund holding preference convertible shares, which would be approximately 10% shareholding if converted.
Cost Nature: The proposed investment consists of up to $75 million 6-year sub-debt which is expected to be funded by IFC Capitalization (Subordinated Debt) Fund, L.P (the AMC), or directly by IFC in  equivalent.

Company Name: TIRYAKI AGRO GIDA SANAYI VE TICARET ANONIM SIRKETI
Project Description: IFC considers an investment up to $50 million A Loan to Tiryaki Agro Foods (Tiryaki or the Company), which is an integrated supply chain manager with activities in sourcing, logistics, processing, storage and marketing of agricultural products. The Company is headquartered in Istanbul, has a substantial presence in Turkey by operating plants across the country, including processing facilities in the city of Gaziantep, and has international trade presence. Tiryaki Agro Foods, a family owned private company which is engaged in sourcing, processing, storage and trading of conventional and organic grains (wheat, barley and corn), pulses (lentils, chickpeas, peas, beans, rice and bulgur), oil seeds (sunflower, sesame, canola and soybean) and nuts (pistachio, almonds, walnut and peanuts) across Europe, Africa, the Middle East, CIS countries, Indian subcontinent and North America.
Review Scope: IFCs review consisted of appraising environmental, occupational health and safety (OHS), and social information submitted by the Client as well as site visits to the Tiryaki facilities, silos and warehouses in Gaziantep and head office in Istanbul from October 10-13, 2011. Interviews were conducted with Tiryakis CEO, Finance Director, Treasury Director, OHS Consultant, Quality Manager, Human Resource (HR) Manager, Production Manager, Technical Manager, Warehouse officers, Trading Managers.Key documents reviewed include the IFC E&S appraisal information sheet submitted by the Company, as well as its Quality Manual, Food Safety Manual, HR Manual, relevant permits, ISO 22001 on food management safety procedures, instructions and forms; employment data, forms and statistics, examples of the labor contracts, documentation on trainings; information on waste production, environmental parameters monitoring data and energy consumption figures. Supply chain risk assessment and management procedures of the Company have also been reviewed.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The Project has limited potential adverse environmental and social impacts, and those that do exist are being site-specific and can be resolved through the application of good international industry practices, the effective implementation of the action items in the attached Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP), which integrate IFCs Performance Standards requirements and applicable World Bank Group (WBG)s Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) guidelines. This corporate-level investment is therefore a Category B project according to IFCs Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability.Key environmental and social risks include: 1) Quality, Environmental and Safety Management systems, including Food Safety programs; 2) Management of E&S Risks and Impacts of Agro-Commodity Supply Chains; 3) Occupational Health and Safety risks for direct employees and contractors/third parties; 4) Air emissions; 5) Deforestation risks in its supply chain; 6) Life, fire and traffic safety; and, 7) Labor transparency. The information about how these potential impacts will be addressed is summarized in the following sections of this Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) and in the attached ESAP agreed upon with the Company.
Sector: AG - Diversified Edible Agricultural Crops Production

Project Description: Founded in early 2004, MPI is a developer of Indonesian IPP projects. MPI is currently 100% owned by PT Medco Energi Internasional tbk (MedcoEnergi), an integrated energy company. MPI is focused on small to medium sized IPPs, with a portfolio consisting of six operating gas-fired power plants. The current MPI operated production portfolio stands at 189 MW.  Three of these power generation assets are located at one site on Batam Island, Indonesia, representing a total gross capacity of 158 MW.  The Company also has a non-operating 5% equity holding in a gas fired power generation asset located in South Sulawesi.  The Company has a power plant services (PPS) business which encompasses Engineering, Procurement, Construction (EPC), project management and O&M services. IFC is considering an equity investment of up to $25million in MPI to finance the company''s current expansion plans. The proceeds of this financing will be used for additional capacity expansions of around 200MW through a series of upcoming projects. These include capacity expansions at the existing assets on Batam Island (Batam Operational Assets), construction of an additional, separate, gas fired power plant on Batam Island, and entry into the small, run of the river, Indonesian hydro-power market with current activities focused on concession acquisition and feasibility development.
Review Scope: IFC has reviewed technical information provided by PT. Medco Power Indonesia  (MPI the Company), an Indonesian Independent Power Producer (IPP).  The scope of IFCs appraisal primarily included a review of MPIs compliance with IFCs Performance Standards and the Companys management capacity to provide adequate oversight of environmental, social, health and safety aspects of its business.  The review relied on documents and reports made available by MPI, along with various visits by IFCs technical team to MPIs largest power producing assets  a 158 MW gas fired power asset - located on Batam Island, Indonesia.  Interviews were conducted by IFC staff during meetings with MPIs senior management team in Jakarta, Indonesia.  Interviews also included the Operations and Maintenance (O&M) department, various projects teams, health safety and environment representatives of two subsidiary companies and the MPI Human Resources department.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B corporate investment as per IFCs Environment and Social Review Procedure.  Existing gas-fired thermal power assets are considered to have limited environmental and social impacts. MPIs medium-term growth strategy is focused toward the development of additional gas fired power generation on Batam Island, Indonesia, and the development of small hydro (less than 10MW per asset) power activities, which are expected to have limited environmental and social impacts.
Sector: IA - Electric Power Other (Including Holding Companies)

Project Description: Candax Energy Inc. (Candax or the Company) is a junior oil and gas company listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange with assets in Tunisia. IFC is considering an equity investment of up to CA$24 million in Candax to be used in order to finance its investment program which aims to enhance production from its mature asset base, consisting of (1) the operational shallow water offshore field El-Bibane, (2) the operational onshore fields Ezzaouia and Robbana, and (3) two additional shut-in onshore fields Al-Manzah and Belli (the Project). Candax is the operator of the El-Bibane, Robbana and Al-Manzah fields whereas Maretap, an equal partnership between Candax and the Tunisian national oil company ETAP, operates the Ezzaouia and Belli fields. The Companys current production volume averages around 320 barrels of oil per day. Assets in Tunisia include:El-Bibane (73.8% working interest): Candax is the field operator.  The field consists of three offshore unmanned well tower platforms, some 18 km offshore of Zarzis, south east Tunisia in the Gulf of Gabes in water depths of 7 m.  Current production of liquids is from one well, one well is shut-in and the third well is used for gas injection for the optimization of reservoir liquid recovery.  Liquids are sent to a central processing facility based in the industrial area of Zarzis port via an 8 subsea pipeline.  Processed oil is transferred to a terminal operated by Maretap (a 50/50 joint venture between the Candax subsidiary, Ecumed and the Tunisian state owned oil company, ETAP) for export.  The terminal is adjacent to the central processing facility.  Final export is by ship from the Zarzis port.  High pressure gas separated at the El-Bibane processing facility is recycled and sent back offshore for gas lift via a subsea 6 pipeline.Ezzaouia (31.4% working interest): Maretap is the field operator.  An onshore field with 13 wells of which currently six are producing.  Liquids are transferred to a central processing facility approximately 12 km north of Zarzis.  Processed oil is transferred via a 10 pipeline to the Maretap terminal adjacent to the El-Bibane central processing facility.Robbana (80% working interest): Candax is the field operator.  An onshore field located on the island of Djerba and consisting of one well with minimal above ground support facilities.  Production resumed in early August 2011.Al-Manzah (75% working interest): Candax is the field operator.  An onshore field located approximately 60 km from Tunis.  The field was shut-in in 2007.Belli (50% working interest): Maretap is the field operator.  An onshore field located adjacent to Al-Manzah.  The field was shut-in in 1999.  This investment is limited to these assets. Potential future work programs in Tunisia may include implementation of a waterflood program in the Robbana field, well work-overs and sidetrack drilling in the El-Bibane, Ezzaouia and Robbana fields and a 3D seismic acquisition campaign at El-Bibane.
Review Scope: IFCs environmental and social (E&S) review of this proposed investment consisted of appraising technical and health, safety and environment (HSE) information submitted by the Company. Key documentation included: the HSE management system manual containing the Companys HSE Policy, standards, procedures and instructions in relation to HSE management and control of the Companys activities in Tunisia, various environmental impact assessments conducted for Candax activities in Tunisia, the oil spill contingency plan for the El-Bibane field, emergency response procedures, health and safety reports and the Companys personnel policy handbook.During the review, the IFC team, including an environmental specialist, met Candax management and operational staff in Paris and Tunis and visited current operations in Tunisia.  These visits included the El-Bibane offshore field and onshore central processing facilities in Zarzis, the SEEB power plant at Zarzis, the Ezzaouia central processing facilities north of Zarzis, the oil storage and export terminal adjacent to El-Bibane, well intervention activities at Ezzaouia and, the Robbana field on the island of Djerba. Existing field activities and operations as well as facilities, equipment and infrastructure were assessed during the field visits.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The Project has been assessed as an E&S Category B investment.  Category B projects according to IFCs E&S Review Procedure are those that result in a limited number of specific E&S impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to industry recognized standards, guidelines and design criteria.  Key findings of the appraisal that defined categorization included:The scope of the Project covers a small footprint of existing brownfield assets. Candax operations are small-scale, pre-existing and potential E&S impacts and risks are typical for small-scale oil and gas activities.  Impacts and risk can be readily identified and avoided or reduced by following good international industry practice.  Candax has a strong commitment to effective E&S management and have a comprehensive HSE management system in place.  Adherence to good international industry practice is achieved through the implementation of the standards and internationally recognized procedures contained within the management system and the system will be further strengthened through the adoption and integration with IFC Performance Standards and EHS Guidelines.Existing central processing facilities at the El-Bibane and Ezzaouia fields are well established.  The El-Bibane facility started operations in 1998 and is located within the industrial area of the Zarzis port zone.  First oil at the Ezzaouia facility was back in 1991 and the facility is located in a rural environment north of Zarzis.  There will be no need to increase the existing facility footprints at either of these facilities as the existing supporting infrastructure is adequate and any processing upgrades or alterations required will take place within the existing fence-line.  Candaxs onshore assets Al-Manzah and Belli are all not producing at present, whereas production at Robbana resumed in August 2011. All have been in place for many years and are small sites consisting of minimal above ground facilities and located in remote agricultural areas.  Current future plans indicate that increases to Candaxs onshore footprint including around the onshore wells for Ezzaouia will be limited. The offshore footprint is insignificant consisting of three small unmanned tower platforms in shallow water (7m) and two subsea pipelines.  There are no production processes carried out at these platforms and no effluent discharges.  All drilling wastes are collected and brought to shore for disposal.  There are no fishing activities specific to the offshore platform area. The offshore wells and pipelines are designed to avoid accidents that may result in oil spills to sea through the implementation of internationally accepted oil spill prevention measures that are regularly tested and maintained.  In the unlikely event of a spill, Candax has regularly practiced oil spill response arrangements and procedures in place to contain and respond to potential spill risks.Future activities can be assessed on a case by case basis before the activities begin and E&S management measures commensurate with the identified impacts and risks can be readily developed and implemented where necessary.
Sector: AB - Oil and Gas Production (Includes Development)

Project Description: Agricover Credit (the Project) would involve a senior loan of up to 12.5 million to Agricover Credit IFN S.A. (the Company) for on-lending to qualified small and medium sized farmers in Romania. The proceeds of the sub-loans would be used to finance working capital expenses, equipment and machinery purchases by farmers.The Company is the financing arm within the Agricover Group and is the only financial institution in Romania aimed exclusively at agriculture financing.
Impact: This project generates multiple developmental impacts:(i)	Increases Access to Finance for Farmers: Romanian farmers would be able to access to long-term debt to finance their investments in agriculture sector, resulting in higher productivity and economic growth.(ii)	Job Creation and Increased Tax Income for the Government: With IFC financing, the Company will be able to grow its business, creating new jobs and resulting in higher revenues and taxable income.(iii)	Support to a Domestic Agriculture Group: The Project will strengthen the Company''s and the Sponsor''s market position and improve its competitiveness in agriculture sector.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure and will involve financing SME sectors with agribusiness activities. IFC''s appraisal focused on Agricover Credit IFNs capacity to develop and implement an Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) to comply with the IFC Exclusion List; the national environment, occupational health and safety, and social regulations; and IFCs Agribusiness/Food Production Guidelines and the agribusiness related Environmental & Social risks. IFC also appraised Agricover Credit IFN''s labor policies against IFC''s Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working Conditions.
Sponsor: Agricover (Agricover or the Group) is an integrated agricultural group whose main operations include: (i) grain sourcing, trading and logistics services; (ii) distribution of agricultural inputs to farmers; (iii) provision of financing to farmers; (iv) fuel distribution to agriculture; and (v) trading of meat and livestock. It is the 3rd largest grain trader in Romania and has the 2nd largest logistics network across the country with 32 silos for a total storage capacity of 700,000 tons.The Companys shareholders are Agricover S.A. (87%) and Agricover S.R.L. (13%) while the ultimate majority owner of the Group is Mr. Jabbar Kanani.
Cost Nature: The financing will be comprised of a senior loan of up to 12,500,000 from IFCs own funds.
Investment: 16.47 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan16.47Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Company is headquartered in Bucharest, Romania. Investments can be made throughout the country.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure and will involve financing SME sectors with agribusiness activities. IFC''s appraisal focused on Agricover Credit IFNs capacity to develop and implement an Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) to comply with the IFC Exclusion List; the national environment, occupational health and safety, and social regulations; and IFCs Agribusiness/Food Production Guidelines and the agribusiness related Environmental & Social risks. IFC also appraised Agricover Credit IFN''s labor policies against IFC''s Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working Conditions.

Project Description: CCLP Rabo (the Project) is for IFC and other development finance institutions, DFIs and commercial banks (Program Participants) to assume a funded  risk participation for up to $250 million in the  trade finance portfolio of the critical agri and energy inputs of Cooperatieve Centrale Raiffeisen Boerenleenbank B.A. (Rabobank, Rabobank International, Rabobank Group or the Bank), a bank incorporated in the Netherlands, with the statutory seat in Amsterdam, the Netherlands and located at Croeselaan 28, 3521 CB Utrecht, the Netherlands, structured under IFC Critical Commodities Liquidity Program (CCLP) initiative. CCPL is a public-private partnership (PPP) initiative that is part of IFCs multi-faceted rapid global financial crisis response. It is a funded program of up to $4 billion that will be mobilized and disbursed in phases to provide IFC with a flexible platform from which to support the extension of liquidity to clients globally. The proposed total IFC investment would be up to $1 billion, which will be leveraged with resources from other DFIs as well as several international banks with an established footprint in emerging markets.
Impact: The project is expected to have a significant development impact by increasing funding for trade of critical agri and energy inputs, including fertilizers and crop protection as well as energy products that cover daily needs (e.g., refined fuels, kerosene), to/from the emerging markets. Project Description: Asia Pacific Medical Group (APMG or the Company) is a leading medical service provider founded by Michael Choy, a US-trained surgeon, and a group of US-based physicians and surgeons in 1992. APMGs hospitals and clinics offer a range of primary care and specialty services, with focuses including neurology, oncology, cardiovascular, maternity, pediatrics and dermatology. The hospital facilities are located in Beijing, Shanghai and Tianjin. The Company also recently entered a joint venture agreement with a healthcare clinic chain with operations in Singapore, Malaysia and Hong Kong. APMG aims to help Chinese patients to access quality specialty healthcare services.
Impact: This project is expected to increase access to high quality medical services, promote dissemination of best operational and clinical practices, provide community health services per the China health care reform blueprint, and generate high quality employment opportunity for medical professionals in China.
Environmental Social Issues: Based on the site visit to three operational hospitals in Beijing and Shanghai, a clinic in Beijing and the new acquisitions in Tianjin and Beijing, discussions with the client and review of client information by IFCs Environment and Social Specialist, this project will have limited potential adverse environmental and social impacts. The project has been classified as Category B according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The key social and environmental aspects associated with the project include: environmental, health, safety, and social management  including waste water management, health care waste management; labor and working conditions, employee and contractor occupational health and safety, including training and housekeeping; disinfection, sterilization, hygiene and implementation of good hospital management practices required to prevent infections among patients and employees; community health, safety and security during construction and operational phase  including radiation hazards, traffic management, and security services; and life and fire safety, including emergency response. The project may result in a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. APMG will manage its environmental and social performance in accordance with applicable local laws and regulations and international standards, including IFCs Performance Standards on Social and Environmental Sustainability, IFC''s Environmental, Health and Safety General Guidelines and Guidelines for Health Care Facilities.
Sponsor: The Founder, Chairman and CEO of APMG is Dr. Michael Choy (the Sponsor). Prior to starting APMG, he formed healthcare joint ventures including outpatient surgery centers and MRI imaging facilities, etc. He is a Diplomat of the American Board of Podiatric Surgery and a Fellow of the American College of Foot and Ankle Surgery.  The largest shareholders of APMG include Cathaya Funds, a U.S. based private equity fund, and Dr. Choy.

Project Description: The IFC investment consists of a proposed loan of up to $2.5 million equivalent to Jamaica National Small Business Loans Limited ('JNSBL', the 'Company'), a microfinance company in Jamaica.  JNSBL is the largest microfinance company in Jamaica with an estimated 75% of the micro-loans supply in Jamaica.  IFC's funding is intended to support JNSBL's growing portfolio of microfinance loans (the Project).   IFC will have equity warrants.
Impact: FORMTEXT The development impact of IFCs financing to JNSBLL is expected to be high, as it will support productive microenterprises and foster employment generation. Sponsors such as Jamaica National Building Society are good partners for IFC, as they are committed long-term players in Jamaica and to expand to areas such as providing the so much needed financial services to low income households and helping address the inequality that exists within the different segments of society. The beneficiaries of these loans will be low-income micro-entrepreneurs in Jamaica.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves IFC support for a nascent microfinance company, Jamaica National Small Business Loans Limited (JN SBLL) and classified as a Category FI project.  JNSBLL is a new client.  During appraisal, IFC reviewed the client''s portfolio, capacity to manage environmental and social risks relevant for its business, and labor standards, and determined the applicable requirements as the IFC exclusion list and the E&S laws of Jamaica.  The client would be required to: (i) develop a Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS), prior to disbursement to the satisfaction of IFC; (ii) identify qualified persons to manage and implement the procedure; (iii) apply the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2; and (iv) submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: JNSBL is a wholly owned subsidiary of Jamaica National Building Society (JNBS).  JNBS is a mutual organization, incorporated in Jamaica under the Building Societies Act.  Its principal activities are comprised of granting home loans, operating savings accounts, trading in foreign exchange and bill payments, which it conducts through its subsidiaries and associate companies.

Project Description: Etileno XXI (the Project) consists of the development, construction and commercial operation of a petrochemical complex in Mexico, composed of one cracker facility to produce ethylene from ethane, integrated to three polyethylene plants with an aggregate nominal capacity of 1,050,000 tons per year.Etileno XXI, which is located in Nachital de Lazaro Cardenas a frontier region of Coatzacoalcos, represents the largest investment in Mexicos petrochemical sector in the last 20 years.  Access to competitively priced feedstock will make the Project one of the most competitive in the Americas.  The Project seeks to serve the Mexican polyethylene market, which is rapidly growing and currently being supplied in part by imports.
Impact: The Project is expected to have a significant development impact by (i) adding value to a natural resource which would otherwise be used as natural gas, (ii) creating forward linkages that would develop the downstream industry, (iii) improving the position of Mexican downstream converters, such as savings on inventory, reduced foreign exchange exposure, local access to a PE supplier that could provide services and new solutions, (v) providing inclusive growth for an economically underdeveloped southern region of Mexico, (iv) creating employment and training opportunities.
Environmental Social Issues: The Project has been designated as Category A according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.   Specific key environmental and social issues associated to the Project include: environmental and social management capacity, operational safety, air emissions, liquid effluents, handling, storage, and transportation of hazardous materials, biodiversity aspect, occupational health and safety, emergency response, community and stakeholders engagement, potential population influx, and potential cumulative impacts.   The sponsors conducted a comprehensive assessment of the impacts and mitigations for all phases of the Project.  The sponsors also consulted and engaged the public and community.   During construction the sponsors will implement sound practices as per the IFC requirements, and once in operation, the Project will be a state-of-the-art facility that will utilize best available technology fully complying with local and IFC requirements.   Information about potential environmental and social impacts and how they will be addressed by the company is summarized in the Environmental and Social Review Summary as well as in the Environmental and Social Impact Assessment conducted for the Project.

(the Company), to house the Project.  Braskem and Idesa will hold shareholding interests of up to 65% and up to 35%, respectively, in the Company.   Braskem is a listed Brazilian company and leading thermoplastic resin producer in the Americas.   Idesa is a privately owned Mexican petrochemical company dedicated to the production and distribution of a variety of petrochemical products.
Cost Nature: The total Project cost is estimated at $4.3 billion.  The proposed IFC investment consists of a loan of up to $300 million for IFCs own account and the mobilization of a B Loan.

Project Description: Fundacion CardioVascular (FCV) is building a 468 bed high quality complex in the outskirts of Bucaramanga (Floridablanca) as part of a 10 year expansion plan. This hospital will increase FCVs current health offering; they operate 623 beds in 4 different cities of Colombia (Bucaramanga, Manizales, Ibague and Santa Marta). This new hospital will not replace the existing one but rather add new beds and medical specialties to FCV. The design of the hospital will be at the level of the best hospitals in Latin American and worldwide, and will have the latest technology in medical equipment.  The project fit with IFCs LAC strategy to support health care in the region through increasing access to high-quality health (especially for lower income groups), improving standards of quality and efficiency, facilitating the exchange of best practices, and creating jobs for skilled professionals. Aside from fulfilling these requirements, this project also fits with the Government of Colombias (GoC) priority to increase the provision of health services.
Impact: (i) High quality health coverage in an underdeveloped region: Colombia overall has 10 beds per 10,000 inhabitants, low as compared to Argentina and Brasil.  This low coverage is even less in remote regions, such as the ones FCV is targeting; Santander, coffee region and the Atlantic coast.(ii) Availability of hospital infrastructure for population for some frontier regions of Colombia (Norte Santander, Guajira, Magdalena, Cordoba, Choco), (iii) Best practices redeployment in a network of smaller hospitals: FCV has JCI accreditation for its main hospital in Bucaramanga and plans to expand this standard to the new project as well to the hospitals under management.(iv) Improving coverage: FCV has a track record of operating 4 hospitals in different cities of Colombia and plans to continue expanding its network.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Specific key environment, social, health and safety issues reviewed include:- Corporate environmental and social management capacity to undertake the project and operations in a manner consistent with IFC Performance Standards;- Land acquisition process, site location, planning, and permitting;- Working conditions for employees and contract workers during both construction and operation of the hospital; - Occupational health and safety (OHS);- Management and control of nosocomial and blood-borne infections;- Life and fire safety;- Efficient use of energy, water and resources;- Wastewater reduction, treatment and disposal, in particular discharge of treated effluents to surface water;- Management of hazardous materials and hazardous health care wastes; and- Management of impacts on nearby communities regarding safety and security risks during construction and operations.
Sponsor: Fundacion Cardiovascular (FCV) was established in 1986 in Bucaramanga (Colombia) as a non-for profit health services provider with emphasis on cardiovascular care. It was the first hospital in Colombia to receive JCI accreditation in November 2009. During 2010, they performed close to 13,000 surgeries and 76,000 outpatient visits in the network, making them one of the largest hospitals in Colombia (considering both public and private sector ones). Its main focus is cardiovascular and neurosurgery, being strong in transplants and high risk obstetrics as well. FCV also has a hospital products division, for supplies to other Colombian hospitals (telemedicine equipment, gowns, and sutures among others). It also operates a telemedicine division, by which FCV doctors remotely track and follow patients in low income frontier regions, as a social responsibility by FCV. Additional to its JCI accreditation, FCV was the first Latin-American hospital certified by NTC ISO 9001:2000 and is also a Green Hospital.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at $100 million for the construction of Hospital Internacional de Colombia. The proposed funding consists of $30 million.
Investment: 30.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan30.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located within a green area protected by natural barriers that ensure the environmental quality of the project. Thanks to its privileged location, the project will provide excellent conditions for the patients, as well as an optimal working environment for the medical group and its partners. The Hospital will be built in the municipality of Piedecuesta, located 9 miles from the center of the city of Bucaramanga. Its neighbors are Universidad Pontificia Bolivariana and private residential condominiums. Key environmental factors in the project will be the conservation and improvement of the current network of river water sources, respecting and applying local and international legislation. The low population density of the area helps to maintain natural green areas, as well as those areas to be created by the project. Impact on existing ecosystems will be minimal, through the implementation of a regulator plan during construction.

Project Description: Etileno XXI (the Project) is the result of a joint venture between Brazilian (Braskem) and Mexican (Idesa) chemical companies incorporated as Braskem Idesa S.A.P.I. (B-I, the Company) for the development, construction and commercial operation of an integrated petrochemical complex in the state of Veracruz in Mexico.  The project includes the construction and operation of the following facilities:an ethane cracker, with a nominal capacity of approximately one million tonnes per annum (tpa) of ethylene production, a high density polyethylene (HDPE) plant with a capacity of approximately 400 thousand tpa,a HDPE plant with a capacity of approximately 350 thousand tpa, anda low density polyethylene plant (LDPE) with a capacity of approximately 300 thousand tpa.The ethylene to be produced at the cracker will be used as raw material for the three polyethylene plants. The facilities will be located in the municipality of Nanchital de Lázaro Cárdenas del Rio, in the state of Veracruz (southeast Mexico) 3.5 km east of the city of Nanchital (27000 inhabitants)  approximately 2.5 km south of the PEMEX Cangrejera Petrochemical Complex; in close proximity to the PEMEX Pajaritos Maritime Terminal, on the shore of the Gulf of Mexico; and 7 km southeast of the city of Coatzacoalcos (305,000 inhabitants) in the municipality of Coatzacoalcos, which is the main petrochemical producing region in Mexico.    There are several other petrochemical and chemical plants in the area such as PEMEX Petroquímica Morelos, Celanese Mexicana, Grupo Petroquímico Beta, Clariant Mexico, IDESA, INNOPHOS, IQUISA and others. Seven small rural communities are located within 5 km radius).  The members of these communities are familiar with industrial installations as they are in municipalities whose primary economic activity is derived from petrochemical industries.The size of the project land parcel is 192 ha, of which, the project will use 61%.  9% of the area will be used during construction and then revegetated, with a further 16% (30 ha) set aside as a permanent conservation area.  The remaining 14 % is already used by right of ways of PEMEX pipelines located within the project site but not related to the project. Out of the total 180,000 barrels per day (b/d) of ethane that PEMEX currently produces, all in the Coatzacoalcos area, it only uses 88,000 b/d in its own petrochemical facilities.  The remaining ethane is reinjected back into its gas production operations to be sold as fuel.  However, with this project, PEMEX will provide Etileno XXI with 66,000 b/d (36%) of the ethane currently sold as fuel for the production of ethylene and ultimately polyethylene.  The project is strategically located in close proximity to the PEMEX installations to facilitate the access to ethane.  PEMEX will install an 800 m underground pipeline to furnish the 66,000 b/d of ethane needed for the Etileno XXI project. The following additional infrastructure will be built to support the Projectan underground 3.7 km pipeline to source water from the PEMEX La Cangrejera water system located to the north of the project site; an underground 1.6 km pipeline for ethylene from a distance less than 1 km from the site fence line; as alternate ethylene supply from the PEMEX facility, to the polyethylene plants;an underground  1.6 km pipeline for natural gas to be supplied from PEMEX at a connecting pipeline located  1 km distant to the south of the project  site; and a 5 km electricity transmission line from the substation that will furnish 400 MW.  Ethane cracker technology is licensed from Technip, a worldwide leader in engineering, project management and technologies, serving the chemical, oil & gas industry for more than 50 years. HDPE technology is from INEOS, one of the largest chemical companies in the world; while LDPE technology is licensed from LyondellBasell, the worlds third-largest independent chemical company.   The company has also hired Odebrecht-ICA Fluor as the contractors for the site preparation and construction phases.  The EPC contracting for the construction and installation will be conducted by a joint venture between Technip and Odebrecht-ICA Fluor.The construction phase of the project is planned to start during the second quarter of 2012 and last for about three years with an expected workforce of up to 8,000 people during the peak period.  The plant is expected to begin operation in 2015. The project will manage the environmental and social impacts in accordance to international good practice.
Review Scope: IFCs appraisal reviewed the Companys Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS), social and labor management capabilities (i.e., assessment, planning, implementation, etc.) and its ability to ensure compliance with Mexican regulatory requirements and IFCs Performance Standards during the construction and operation of the Project.  Specific items reviewed included: (a) existing Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA), related Studies and Reports, and corresponding Environmental and Social Management Plan (ESMPs) Frameworks; (b) human resources policies and management of the Company, its contractors and subcontractors, (c) the Stakeholder Engagement Plan. IFC conducted a site visit to the proposed project site in October 2011. The visit included interviews with the Companys project management team including EHS staff, with the site preparation and construction management Contractor, representatives of the nearby Jaguaroundi National Preserve Natural Park, PEMEX representatives in charge of raw materials supply and E&S aspects related to the project, and representatives of the SEMARNAT (Mexican environmental authorities).  During the site visit, the team visited the site, Jaguaroundi National Preserve Natural Park, and nearby locations.  The team also met with representatives of the two key municipalities and approximately 200 members of the 5 communities closest to the project.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category A project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Although the Project is expected to bring economic and social benefits it will be a source of significant diverse environmental and social impacts during the construction and operational phases; the loss of highly modified critical habitat;  as well as social impacts  arising from labor sourcing during the construction phase, and possible unintended influx of job seekers to the area.

Project Description: Fundacion Cardiovascular  de Colombia (FCV) is building a 468 bed high quality complex in the outskirts of Bucaramanga (Piedecuetsa) as part of a 10 year expansion plan. This hospital will increase FCVs current health offering; they operate 623 beds in 4 different cities of Colombia (Bucaramanga, Manizales, Ibague and Santa Marta). This new hospital will not replace the existing one but rather add new beds and medical specialties to FCV.  The new hospital will have one wing dedicated to pediatric care and another for general hospitalization.  Each wing will have near 160 beds and shared 148 ICU, sharing 20 operating rooms.  Focus will be on cardiovascular surgery, transplants (heart, lung, liver, kidney and pancreas), orthopedics and trauma, endocrinology, ophthalmology, neuroscience, pneumology, urology, and gastroenterology.
Review Scope: IFCs appraisal of the project included meetings with the social, financial, and technical team of Fundacion Cardiovascular de Colombia (FCV) and, visits to the site of the new hospital,  FCV - Hospital Internacional de Colombia,  and to the existing hospital Instituto del Corazon in Floridablanca, Santander, Colombia. Environmental and social conditions of the project were assessed through documentation review; meetings with the current social and environmental team; meetings and presentations with the current environmental, social and technical consultants for the project; and information submitted by FCV.  Issues evaluated included the land acquisition process, labor and working conditions including occupational health and safety, design features for the new Hospital Internacional de Colombia, strategy to manage the environmental and social aspects of the project both during construction and operation, including but not limited to storage and disposal of hazardous materials, liquid effluents, use of energy and water, control of nosocomial infections and emergency preparedness and response.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria as is described in the following sections.Specific key environment, social, health and safety issues reviewed include:Corporate environmental and social management capacity to undertake the project and operations in a manner consistent with IFC Performance Standards;Land acquisition process, site location, planning, and permitting;Working conditions for employees and contract workers during both construction and operation of the hospital; Occupational health and safety (OHS);Management and control of nosocomial and blood-borne infections;Life and fire safety;Efficient use of energy, water and resources;Wastewater reduction, treatment and disposal, in particular discharge of treated effluents to surface water;Management of hazardous materials and hazardous health care wastes; andManagement of impacts on nearby communities regarding safety and security risks during construction and operations.

Project Description: The Project ('IXcellerate') is an early stage equity investment in a holding company named IXcellerate Ltd. (the 'Company') established in the United Kingdom with the purpose of developing a 6,200m2 greenfield data center ('DC') in Moscow through a 100% owned operating company named OOO IXcellerate (the 'Operating Company' or 'IXcellerate Moscow') established in the Russian Federation.The facility will be designed and constructed on par with the leading North American and European DC co-location facilities and the current design has been reviewed and approved by Ove Arup and Partners, which is a leading consulting firm in this field.  This will be one of the first independent high quality pure-play DC co-location service providers in the Moscow market.
Impact: The Project is expected to have the following impacts:i) Expanding availability of IT infrastructure, services and solutions: IXcellerate fills a gap in the market for high quality/high availability systems hosting which is, in turn, needed for business continuity and disaster recovery service offerings.  ii) The Company's association with Guy Willner, who co-founded one of largest global providers of vendor neutral data centers, brings best practice in operational procedures, design, and business model to the country. iii) Improved private sector connectivity and public sector competitiveness: This Project will help provide cost-efficient and energy-efficient IT infrastructure and services.
Environmental Social Issues: At appraisal, IFC assessed environmental and social risks and impacts in this project, in particular the key issues of environmental impacts of the company''s facilities, and working conditions of employees. IXcellerate plans to refit an existing leased building, and to adapt its human resources policies and procedures developed for other European operations to Russia.  Environmental and social risks and impacts in this project are expected to be low, so the project has been classified as Category C according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.
Sponsor: The Company was founded by Guy Willner, Cliff Gauntlett and David Cologne who jointly own about 80% of the Company (the 'Founders').  The Project is developed and backed by Guy Willner, an entrepreneur with a demonstrated track record of building, operating and exiting from DC companies, who is also a co-investor with IFC in the South African DC Teraco (Project # 29767). Approximately 20% of the Founders' shares are owned by IDC-G which is a company owned and controlled by Guy Willner.  Prior to the formation of IXcellerate Cliff Gauntlett held the position Senior Vice President in leading Russian telecommunications provider Golden Telecom, and David Cologne was a Project Director at Ove Arup and Partners.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at approximately $55 million with $50.8 million being capital expenditures. IFC's investment will be an up to $15 million equity investment in form of redeemable convertible preferred shares for up to 20% of the share capital of the Company to be invested in two stages, and up to $25 million in long-term debt consisting of an A-Loan of up to $15 million and a B loan of up to $10 million.
Investment: 30.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan15.0Equity15.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The DC will be constructed in an existing warehouse building, which was built 6 years ago. The building is located in the Dmitrovskoe/Altufievskoe shosse area, which is located in an industrial zone in Northern Moscow. As a relatively new warehouse it is an ideal location for data center services and a lease agreement has been signed with the landlord on October 31, 2011. In the first phase, approximately 1500m2 of raised white flooring with perimeter white walling will be constructed within this existing structure and therefore the amount of construction works that are expected to be required are very limited.

Project Description: Based in Dushanbe, the Tajero Group of Companies ('the Group') is composed of three related but separate companies:  Tajero LLC, Tajero-Sugd and Amal Industry.  It is the leading nationwide importer and distributor of food and beverages with exclusive contracts from 16 International Fast Moving Consumer Goods ('FMCG') companies.  Tajero distribution currently covers 70% of sales points in Tajikistan.Tajero is exposed to volatility in global prices as a distributor of imported food, which makes up 80% of food in Tajikistan.   Increasing food prices coupled with currency depreciation have limited Tajero's ability to further expand the operation, particularly as access to affordable capital has diminished in Tajikistan. To sustain stable volumes and further grow the business, Tajero seeks more affordable sources of financing and has approached IFC to reduce refinancing risks.   Tajero has approached IFC for a 3-year working capital line to refinance a current loan and reduce financing costs (the 'Project'). This would be IFC's second investment with Tajero.
Impact: Through this Project, IFC will be supporting a local sponsor that has built a distribution business in a challenging environment.  The project will have strong development impact:  i) in the business community where Tajero will serve as an example of the benefits to be gained through improved transparency and corporate governance; ii) for consumers, as  the affordable financing that Tajero will obtain from IFC will help mitigate the price increases it is passing on to its customers, which are also as a result of global food price increases; and iii) for investors and exporters to the region, as IFC's involvement with Tajero adds comfort in identifying potential partners in Tajikistan,  a country with few foreign investors outside the resource sectors and microfinance.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social (E&S) Review of Projects. The Company presented relevant environmental and social information, which was reviewed and discussed with its management.  An Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) has been agreed to ensure performance in compliance with IFCs Performance Standards and Guidelines.
Sponsor: The three Tajero group companies are all owned 100% by Mr. Abdurakhmon Gaibullozoda, the Project Sponsor. Mr. Gaibullozoda started in sales at a local grocery in Dushanbe in 1992, which he purchased in 1995. Since then, Mr. Gaibullozoda transformed this business into the largest FMCG distributor in Tajikistan for perishable and non-perishable products with suppliers from Ukraine, Russia, Kazakhstan, the US and Brazil.  IFC has an existing outstanding loan of $1.3 million loan to Amiri LLC, a chocolate confectionary company in Tajikistan, 100% owned by the Sponsor.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $2.9 million. The proposed investment is an IFC A working capital facility of up to $1.7 million for IFC's own account.
Investment: 1.70 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan1.70Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Company is located in the Rudaki district of Dushanbe, Tajikistan. The site used to be an old storage facility which Mr. Gaibullozoda purchased in 2005 and fully renovated into modern storage and production complex including a 1,000 sq.m. modern refrigerated warehouse and  a 2,300 sq.m. dry warehouse. Throughout Tajikistan, Tajero owns and leases warehouse facilities of approximately 7,360 sq. m in total including warehouses of 1,850 sq. m. for frozen products and refrigerated warehouses of 1,160 sq. m.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social (E&S) Review of Projects. The Company presented relevant environmental and social information, which was reviewed and discussed with its management.  An Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) has been agreed to ensure performance in compliance with IFCs Performance Standards and Guidelines.
Sector: AA - Wholesale (Including Grocery and Farm Products)

Project Description: Tajero Group of companies ('Tajero' or the 'Group'), established in 2002 in the city of Dushanbe, the capital of the Republic of Tajikistan, is the leading nation-wide importer and distributor of food (confectionary, frozen poultry and raw meat products, oils, milk products, pasta, etc.) and beverages (juices and tea) with exclusive contracts from leading foreign Fast Moving Consumer Goods companies.  The Group also manufactures sausages and chocolate. Tajero's distribution network covers Dushanbe, Region of Republican Subordination and Khatlon region through its central office in the city of Dushanbe. Sogd region of the northern Tajikistan is served through a subsidiary in the town of Khojand.  The Group owns and leases warehouse facilities of 7360 sq. m in total including warehouses of 1850 sq. m. for deep-frozen products and refrigerated warehouses of 1160 sq. m. Total vehicle fleet consisted of 46 small size lorries including12 vehicles in Khojand to serve in the city and suburb. Tajero has approached IFC for a 3-year working capital line to refinance a current loan and reduce financing costs. This would be IFC's second investment with Tajero. In 2010, IFC initially invested in a new production of chocolates (Project ID 29630). Information about the project was disclosed on the IFC's site and locally, and may be viewed on IFC's disclosure portal at the following link:  HYPERLINK "http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/ProjectDisplay/ESRS29630" http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/ProjectDisplay/ESRS29630
Review Scope: IFC's environmental and social (E&S) review of the project consisted of a site visit to the Group's facilities including dry and refrigerated warehouses, chocolate production facilities, a vehicle park and repair workshop areas; a building recently acquired for accommodation of new office premises after overhaul; discussions with Tajero managers and specialists on operational, human resources, occupational health and fire safety, environmental, security and product quality matters; and a meeting with a local consultant commissioned for development of the HACCP/ISO 22000 based management system. The appraisal also included review of environmental, health, safety (EHS) and social documentation available in the Annual Monitoring Report and the Report on the E&S Action Plan Status of the current project between IFC and Tajero.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to the IFC's environmental and social review procedure. The Project's limited environmental and social adverse impacts can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to national laws and regulations, generally recognized performance standards and guidelines. Key EHS and social impacts/issues of the project include:-  EHS and food quality management system capacity to address current and future risks;-  Labor and working conditions, including occupational health and fire safety;-  Refrigerants used;-  Staff safety due to a location within a seismic active region.
Sector: AA - Wholesale (Including Grocery and Farm Products)

Project Description: Banco Atlantida S.A de C.V ('Bancatlan' or 'the Bank') is the largest bank in Honduras in terms of assets, loan portfolio, deposits and capital, as of October 2011.  The Bank is very active in the agribusiness, commerce, tourism and infrastructure sectors and has the largest retail distribution network in the country. Bancatlan is an existing IFC client through a trade line and advisory services projects.Bancatlan is interested in supporting the renewable energy sector in Honduras and has already built a pipeline of projects.  The Bank is also willing to support its corporate and SME clients in improving their energy efficiency and cleaner production initiatives. The Bank is seeking to fund this potential portfolio growth with long-term funding since it allows for a proper maturity matching. The proposed investment seeks to support the Bank's loan origination activities through a Senior Loan to be complemented with a potential sustainable energy finance advisory services project (the 'Project' or 'Atlantida Loan').
Impact: - The Project expects to address climate change by reducing GHG emissions through the use of alternative energy sources and cleaner technologies.- It will help transform the energy matrix and reduce dependency on volatile imported fuel prices and subsidies for costly thermal energy power sources; ultimately will help alleviate public budget constraints.  - IFC will contribute to the creation of new direct and indirect jobs during the design, construction and operation of the sub-projects.- Consumers will have improved access to more reliable and less costly sources of energy; - Implementation of clean technology projects will facilitate the transfer of modern production techniques to Honduras which may be followed by new entrants into the sector.
Environmental Social Issues: This Project will support the expansion of Bancatlan''s portfolio of renewable energy sub-projects and has been classified as Category FI (Financial Intermediary). The main E&S risks are related to the Bank''s investments in hydro and other renewable energy sub-projects, which could have potentially high E&S impacts. As such, IFC reviewed the pipeline of potential sub-projects to be supported through this transaction as well as the Bank''s existing capacity to manage their E&S risks. As part of this investment, Bancatlan will conduct an E&S due diligence of sub-projects to determine compliance with the applicable national E&S laws and regulations of Honduras and  IFC''s Performance Standards, requiring corrective actions as necessary to ensure that the sub-projects meet these requirements. Furthermore, the Bank will be required to: develop an E&S review procedure, to the satisfaction of IFC, to ensure that the investments/activities under this Project are in compliance with the IFC Exclusion List, the applicable E&S laws and regulations of Honduras, and the IFC Performance Standards (the applicable requirements), identify responsible and qualified persons to conduct the E&S due diligence based on the applicable requirements, require corrective actions as needed to ensure that sub-projects meet the applicable requirements, and submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC. In addition, Bancatlan will embrace IFC''s Performance Standard 2 (PS2) on Labor and Working Conditions to follow international labor best practices.
Sponsor: Banco Atlantida is 87.18% owned by Inversiones Atlantida S.A de C.V. ('INVATLAN'), which at the same time is controlled by four prominent Honduran families Bueso, Vinelli, Goldstain and Mendoza, and the Bank's employee pension fund (Fondo de Retiro Bancatlan) and Fundaciones Iris Ulargui. INVATLAN is a financial conglomerate that also includes an insurance company (Seguros Atlantida) and six other companies.
Cost Nature: The proposed investment consists of a 7-year secured Senior Loan for up to $50 million to fund the origination of long-term energy efficiency, renewable energy and cleaner production sub-loans.  The total amount will be composed of a $45 million A Loan for IFC's own account and a $5 million Canada Climate Change Program Loan.

Project Description: Vonpar Alimentos S.A. ('Vonpar Alimentos' or the 'Company') has an investment program for 2011-2013 to the relocation and expansion of its chocolate manufacturing plant, to be located in the city of Arroio do Meio, Brazil and the expansion and modernization of the Company's dairy and candy businesses.
Impact: IFC's investment in Vonpar will have a direct and significant impact in the region's development:  (i) The company works together with about 1,133 farmers that produce milk for Vonpar, and Vonpar provides technical assistance to the farmers it sources raw milk from, with dedicated staff, and will support the farmers in  improving the quality of milk in light of the new milk safety regulations that are expected to come to effect in 2012; and (ii) although the production staffing needs will decline in the new chocolate factory due to increased automation and efficiencies gained from co-locating the candy and chocolate plants, increased employment is expected in the transportation, sales and promotion staff as sales of the company continue to increase.

Project Description: The Project is the extension of a funded facility for IFC and funding partners (development finance institutions and international financial institutions) to provide trade financing of up to $500 million to Citibank N.A. ('Citibank' or the 'Bank') headquartered in the United States, as part of IFC's Global Trade Liquidity Program ('GTLP') Extension. IFC's premiere crisis response initiative, Global Trade Liquidity Program, is a unique global public-private partnership (PPP) collaboration with 20 partners, public and private, that brings together governments, development finance institutions, and private sector banks to support trade in developing markets in order to address the shortage of trade finance resulting from the global financial crisis.  Significant achievements have been made to date: 5 global deal of year awards, total program disbursements almost $4 billion (DFIs $1.3 billion, IFC $0.6 billion, and banks $1.9 billion) financing over $17 billion of trade transactions financed with zero losses, over 80 percent benefiting SMEs, and nearly 40 percent supporting low-income and lower middle income countries.  Funding for this crisis response program came from development institutions and governments, and it worked through over 200 global and regional banks to extend trade finance ultimately to SMEs.  GTLP provides IFC and its partners with a proven foundation of experience, a partnership platform, and lessons that can be leveraged to develop other innovative solutions to tackle global strategic priorities such as supporting the financial sector, SMEs and agriculture.  As part of  IFC's multi-faceted global financial crisis response , GTLP is being extended in order to address the current liquidity needs in the market which is affecting  the availability of trade finance funding for emerging markets.  Under this project, IFC is considering an investment of $1-2 billion, which will be match-funded with resources from other development finance institutions (DFIs) and international financial institutions (IFIs) as well as several international banks with an established footprint in emerging markets trade finance.
Impact: The project is expected to have a significant development impact by increasing funding for trade of consumer goods, intermediate goods, smaller machinery and commodities demanded by emerging market enterprises.
Environmental Social Issues: This project is the extension of the $250 million GTLP to Citi and has been classified as a category FI-3 according to the IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. As a GTLP project, the applicable requirement is the IFCs Exclusion List. Citibank is an existing client; each trade pool will be supported by underlying documentation with the designated banks.  The agreement with Citibank will specify that the underlying goods to the transaction will meet the requirements of the IFCs Exclusion List and require the Bank to report on implementation on an annual basis.  IFC will also review the details of the underlying trade transactions.
Sponsor: Citibank is a global financial institution with some 200 million customer accounts and does business in more than 100 countries, providing consumers, corporations, governments and institutions with a broad range of financial products and services, including consumer banking and credit, corporate and investment banking, securities brokerage, and wealth management.  As of November 30, 2011, it operated 1400 branches and 3800 ATMs in 46 countries. The company was founded in 1812 and is based in New York, New York. It is a widely held company by the public.
Cost Nature: As part of IFC's Global Trade Liquidity Program Extension, IFC is considering providing funding for up to $500 million to Citibank with the objective of channeling liquidity for funded trade financing to clients of Citibank.

Project Description: Vonpar Alimentos, a company created with the acquisition by the Vonpar Group of three companies in Rio Grande do Sul, has an investment plan of $100 million to relocate, modernize and double the production capacity of a recently acquired chocolate manufacturing company and for expanding its financial and technical support to an estimated 1,200 small milk producers supplying the Company ('the Project'). IFC proposes to provide up to $50 million A-Loan to Vonpar Alimentos to support this Project.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is category B project according to IFC's Policy on Social and Environmental Sustainability because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, EHS general and sector-specific guidelines or design criteria as is described in the following sections.

Project Description: The Project (CPLF-Mryia) involves providing a long-term financing to Mriya Agro Holding Public Limited (Mriya or the Company), a leading Ukrainian primary agricultural producer with a proven track record of growing wheat, barley, sugar beet, rapeseed, potatoes, and other crops. The long-term loan will provide financing to improve the operational processes and resource efficiencies at the sugar plant companies.
Impact: IFC''s financing will support resource and energy efficiency improvements at the sugar plants. The implementation of the project will achieve significant reductions in energy consumption, water use and CO2 emissions. As a result, Mriya will realize direct economic benefits and enhance its competitiveness.
Environmental Social Issues: The main environmental effect of this Cleaner Production Project will be reduced consumption of energy and water.  Potential adverse impacts arise from construction activities within Mriyas existing footprint, and are expected to be minimal.  This is, therefore, an Environmental & Social (E&S) Category C Project.Mriya is an existing client and is fully compliant with IFCs at-approval environmental and social requirements which were defined for the earlier IFC investment.  IFC already does and will continue to monitor Mriyas E&S operations and will continue to require Mriya to report annually on its E&S performance in the Annual Monitoring Report.  IFC will also undertake periodic site-based supervision visits.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is the Guta family (the Sponsors), who founded Mriya in 1992 and control it to this day. The head of the Guta family, Ivan Guta, a well-respected Ukrainian businessman, and his wife, Klaudia Guta established Mriya on 50 hectares of land (124 acres) after having worked for 8 years at a state farm. In 2002, Andriy and Mykola Guta, the sons of the founders, joined the family business after completing their higher education in Ukraine and abroad. Following a private placement on the Entry Standard of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange in 2008, the Sponsors collectively own 80% of Mriyas Cyprus-based holding company that fully controls all of Mriyas Ukraine-based operating companies, with the remaining 20% owned by over 20 institutional investors.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is $12.5 million, a portion of which will be financed using IFCs Cleaner Production Loan Facility (CPLF). Mriya will use the funds to implement IFCs cleaner production team recommendations at four out of six sugar plant companies to bring about a reduction in energy consumption, water use and CO2 emissions. IFC investment will consist of a five-year senior loan of up to US$ 5 million.

Project Description: The proposed project is a senior loan of up to $10 million equivalent to Sasfin Bank Limited (Sasfin or the Group or the Company) to provide the Group with capital to finance eligible SME energy efficiency lending (Eligible Transactions) in South Africa (the Project). Eligible Transactions include energy efficiency, renewable energy and cleaner production projects that result in material improvement in energy use by SME companies in South Africa.
Impact: The Project is expected to generate a range of environmental and economic benefits related to the development of sustainable energy finance and a stream of energy efficiency project investments. Specifically, the Project will i. facilitate energy efficiency investments by Sasfin''s small industrial and SME sub-borrowers; ii. build Sasfin capacity to finance energy efficiency projects and iii. improve the local and global environment through reduced emissions of greenhouse gases and other conventional pollutants while reducing South Africa''s dependence on fossil fuels.
Environmental Social Issues: This project is a senior loan of up to $10 million for energy efficiency financing and it has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Sasfin is an existing client and the Applicable Performance Requirements for the existing investments are the IFC Exclusion List and the applicable national social and environmental laws and regulations. During appraisal, IFC analyzed the FI portfolio for types of loans provided and industry sectors covered, and analyzed the potential Social and Environmental risks associated with the Bank''s activities. Sasfin is a non-retail bank which provides office equipment finance, trade finance, debtor finance and capital equipment finance typically to SMEs in South Africa. Sasfin has an Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) and undertakes Environmental and Social Due Diligence (ESDD) as part of its loan review process. The appraisal focused on the Companys implementation of its ESMS and the quality of the ESDD conducted. The Companys E&S performance was found to be satisfactory, the ESMS procedures are being followed and E&S checklists are completed for all loans (except office equipment finance). The Applicable Performance Requirements for this project remain the Exclusion List and the applicable national environmental and social laws. Recommendations for improvement on E&S risk management have been made to the client and the client has started implementing these recommendations.
Sponsor: The sponsor of the proposed project is Sasfin Holdings Limited. Sasfin Holdings is a mid-tier specialist banking and financial services group focusing on entrepreneurial corporate, commercial small and medium enterprise (SME), and private clients. Established in 1951, the Group has over the years grown to become a solid and reputable mid-sized financial services group in South Africa. Sasfin Holdings is a publicly held company listed on the Johannesburg Securities Exchange (JSE) since 1987. Sasfin Bank is the flagship subsidiary of Sasfin Holdings.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a senior loan of up to $10 million equivalent, with a tenor of up to 7 years, of which up to $7.7 million equivalent is for IFCs own account and up to $2.3 million is provided by IFC in its capacity as the implementing entity of the Canada Climate Change Program. In addition, IFC may provide advisory services for capacity building which will include a training program for Sasfins equipment finance vendors.
