Project Description: The project is to lend up to $75 million to TSKB, Turkey's first privately-owned development and investment bank.  Loan proceeds will be used to finance energy efficiency and renewable energy investments in Turkey.
Impact: The project is expected to generate a range of environmental and economic benefits related to the development of the sustainable energy finance and stream of SE project investments. Specifically, the Program would: (i) develop SE investment projects across all sectors; (ii) improve the competitiveness of the Turkish economy by increasing the SE of end-user's operations; and (iv) improve the local as well as the global environment through reduced emissions of greenhouse gases and other conventional pollutants and reduce the country's dependence on imports of fossil fuels and natural gas.
Environmental Social Issues: The Project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. IFC''s existing investment in TSKB consists of a subordinated loan to strengthen banks capital and augment the availability of long-term funding for on-lending to borrowers in Turkey. The Bank has implemented an Environmental & Social Management System (ESMS) to screen the loans against the IFC Exclusion List and applicable environmental and social national laws and regulations. For this particular project, IFC''s applicable requirements will be to ensure that loans to energy efficiency and renewable energy projects are screened against the IFC Exclusion List, applicable environmental and social national laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards. IFC''s appraisal will focus on TSKB''s ongoing implementation of the ESMS in particular environmental and social due diligence. IFC will also appraise TSKB''s labor policies against IFC''s Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working Conditions.
Sponsor: TSKB is owned 50% by Isbank (Turkey) and 8.4% by Vakifbank (Turkey). Free float is 41.6%.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is $75 million, to be used entirely for renewable energy and energy efficiency lending in Turkey.
Investment: 75.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan75.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Projects to be financed are located in Turkey.  TSKB's head office is in Istanbul.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The Project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. IFC''s existing investment in TSKB consists of a subordinated loan to strengthen banks capital and augment the availability of long-term funding for on-lending to borrowers in Turkey. The Bank has implemented an Environmental & Social Management System (ESMS) to screen the loans against the IFC Exclusion List and applicable environmental and social national laws and regulations. For this particular project, IFC''s applicable requirements will be to ensure that loans to energy efficiency and renewable energy projects are screened against the IFC Exclusion List, applicable environmental and social national laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards. IFC''s appraisal will focus on TSKB''s ongoing implementation of the ESMS in particular environmental and social due diligence. IFC will also appraise TSKB''s labor policies against IFC''s Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working Conditions.

Project Description: PT. Bank Tabungan Pensiunan Nasional Tbk ('BTPN' or the 'Bank') is emerging as a regional leader in microfinance in Asia and has been a valued IFC client since 2009.  It uses an innovative business model that combines access to finance with access to training to reach micro, small and women entrepreneurs with the objectives of improving their lives and businesses.  The Project ('BTPN Loan II') builds on this successful and growing relationship and intends, through loans in Indonesian Rupiah, to help BTPN to: (i) expand its micro-banking business to serve mass market and low-income customers; and (ii) strengthen its funding base in order to reduce asset and liability mismatch with a longer tenor financing package.
Impact: 1) Increased Access to Finance to the Underserved Population: The proposed project will significantly increase access to finance for large populations at the bottom of the pyramid.2) Women's Empowerment:  The proposed project will help to increase access to finance for women borrowers and will enable them grow their businesses and support their families financially.3) Job Creation:  The Project will directly create employment opportunities within the Bank as well as create broader employment opportunities arising from the creation and expansion of microfinance enterprises that the Bank supports.  BTPN currently employs about 13,000 staff and expects to employ more people to support the growth of its business.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as Category FI. Applicable requirements include IFC FI Exclusion List and applicable Indonesian laws and regulations. The client will be required to have a functional Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS) approved by IFC, and appoint an Environmental and Social officer to ensure sound execution of the SEMS. The client will need to submit annual environmental performance reports to IFC according to an IFC-approved reporting format.
Sponsor: BTPN is publicly traded and its shareholding structure is as follows: TPG Nusantara (59.68%), the public (39.45%) and the Bank's board and management (0.87%).  TPG Nusantara is a consortium comprised of Texas Pacific Group ('TPG') and Northstar Pacific ('Northstar'), an affiliate of TPG. TPG Capital is a well-regarded private investment partnership that was founded in 1992 and currently has more than $48 billion of assets under management. TPG Capital's investments span a variety of industries including financial services.  Northstar, the local affiliate of TPG, was founded in 2003 by Patrick Walujo and Glenn Sugito as a Jakarta-based merchant bank engaged in principal investment as well as corporate finance advisory.
Cost Nature: The proposed project will consist of: (i) a revolving loan of up to $100 million equivalent in local currency; and (ii) $150 million in local currency including up to $25 million in the form of an IFC A loan and up to $125 million in the form of an IFC B loan and parallel loans.
Investment: 250.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan250.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: BTPN is headquartered in Jakarta, Indonesia and has 1, 096 outlets located throughout Indonesia. Over 464 outlets are dedicated to the pension business, over 569 are dedicated to the microfinance business and over 63 are dedicated to funding business. BTPN plans to open several more microfinance outlets nationwide over the next three years.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project has been classified as Category FI. Applicable requirements include IFC FI Exclusion List and applicable Indonesian laws and regulations. The client will be required to have a functional Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS) approved by IFC, and appoint an Environmental and Social officer to ensure sound execution of the SEMS. The client will need to submit annual environmental performance reports to IFC according to an IFC-approved reporting format.
Sector: AC - Commercial Banking - Microfinance and Small Business

Project Description: IFC is considering an investment to finance Laureate Education Inc.'s ('Laureate') expansion in several countries in Latin America.  The two sub-projects currently under consideration entail the expansion of Laureate's operations in Peru and Panama.  Subsequent sub-projects will be disclosed independently when they materialize.In Peru, IFC is considering an investment of up to $40 million to finance Universidad Peruana de Ciencias Aplicadas ('UPC'), a Peruvian institution in the Laureate network.  The specific purpose of the Project is to finance UPC' expansion plans in Peru in order to provide better quality facilities and higher quality education to students in middle income segments, as well as working adults.   In Panama, IFC is considering an investment of up to $25 million to finance Universidad Interamericana de Panamá S.A. and Universidad Latinoamericana de Ciencia y Tecnologia, two Panamanian institutions in the Laureate network.   Through the proposed project in Panama, Laureate aims to expand the capacity of its university operations and provide better quality facilities and higher quality education to students in middle and low income segments, as well as working adults.
Review Scope: The review of Laureate Latin America (the 'Project') comprised meetings with Laureate Education Inc. (the 'Company') management team, at their HQ office in Baltimore MD, and site visits at the Laureate facilities in Panama City and in Lima, Peru, where IFC staff inspected three Company sites and interviewed management, administration and academic staff. Staff also reviewed the EHS Appraisal Questionnaire completed by the Company, as well as relevant supporting information regarding:  workplace monitoring, environmental permits, environmental management and procedures, human resources management, occupational health and safety policy and procedures, emergency preparedness protocols, training programs and corporate social responsibility.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFC's Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria as is described in the following sections.Social and environmental issues include: Laureate's management systems and assessment of prospective investments in education installations, including constructors' capacity to manage environmental and social issues; site selection and land acquisition; sustainable building design and construction; operation, including life and fire safety, water and wastewater management, use of sustainable materials and appliances; labor and working conditions, occupational health and safety during construction and operation.
Sector: AB - Colleges, Universities, and Professional Schools

Project Description: IFC is considering an investment to finance expansion projects at Laureate Education Inc.'s ('Laureate') network institutions in several countries in Latin America.  The two sub-projects currently under consideration entail the expansion of Laureate's operations in Peru and Panama.  Subsequent sub-projects will be disclosed independently when they materialize.In Peru, IFC is considering an investment of up to $40 million to finance Universidad Peruana de Ciencias Aplicadas ('UPC'), a Peruvian institution in the Laureate network.  The specific purpose of the Project is to finance UPC' expansion plans in Peru in order to provide better quality facilities and higher quality education to students in middle income segments, as well as working adults.   In Panama, IFC is considering an investment of up to $25 million to finance Universidad Interamericana de Panamá S.A. and Universidad Latinoamericana de Ciencia y Tecnologia, two Panamanian institutions in the Laureate network.   Through the proposed project in Panama, Laureate aims to expand the capacity of its university operations and provide better quality facilities and higher quality education to students in middle and low income segments, as well as working adults.
Impact: (i) Expand access for middle income students to high quality post-secondary education; (ii) Improve quality of education and access to the job market, through better academic standards; (iii) Demonstration effect in the country regarding the viability of privately-run education institutions.
Environmental Social Issues: Projects in Panama and Peru are both Category B project according to IFC's Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Social and environmental issues include: Laureate's management systems and assessment of prospective investments in education installations, including constructors' capacity to manage environmental and social issues; site selection and land acquisition; sustainable building design and construction; operation, including life and fire safety, water and wastewater management, use of sustainable materials and appliances; labor and working conditions, occupational health and safety during construction and operation.Laureate has provided information on its current practices and policies -both in Peru and Panama- that seek to address environmental and social risks and impacts to ensure that the proposed project complies with or will, upon implementation of measures agreed upon as part of IFC's Investment documents, comply with host country laws and regulations and IFC's Performance Standards (PS). Subsequent sub-projects in other countries in Latin America will be appraised separately and with separate implementation measures to be agreed upon as part of the corresponding IFC Investment documents.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Laureate Education Inc., which provides higher education programs and services to students through a global network of more than 55 campus-based and online universities offering undergraduate and graduate degree programs to more than 600,000 students around the world. Laureate operates in 22 countries throughout North America, Latin America, Europe, Australia and New Zealand, and the Middle East and North Africa region and offers more than 130 career-focused, undergraduate, master's, and doctoral degree programs in fields including architecture, art, business, culinary arts, design, education, engineering, health sciences, hospitality, information technology, law, and medicine.Laureate is owned by large private equity and investment companies through a Canadian limited partnership called Wengen Alberta LP, along with a group of individuals, including Douglas Becker, Chairman and CEO.

The proposed IFC investment comprises an A loan for IFC's own account of up to $40 million.In Panama, the total project cost is estimated at $52 million. The proposed IFC investment comprises an A loan for IFC's own account of up to $25 million.

Project Description: The Project ('BBVA P SR Loan') involves supporting Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria Panama S.A. ('BBVA Panama' or the 'Bank' or the 'Company') in providing long-term financing to SMEs in the agribusiness sector.The primary objective of the Project is to increase access to finance for Panama's farmers and agribusiness SMEs, with an emphasis on expanding opportunities for the bottom of the pyramid ('BOP') population in rural areas, and supporting the whole agricultural supply chain. This will be achieved by leveraging BBVA Panama's strong brand positioning and distribution capacity.
Impact: The Project will provide SME funding to a systemic bank in Panama, generating a range of social and economic benefits which include promoting economic growth and raising productivity, as well as increasing banking penetration in rural areas. The anticipated development impacts of the Project are to:(i)	Enhance access to finance for SMEs.  The Project will allow the Bank to provide its clients access to funding with longer maturities, enabling them to undertake investment projects with more appropriate financing structures;(ii)	Generate a demonstration effect.  The Project is expected to create a demonstration effect for other banks and further enhance IFC's developmental impact in Panama; and(iii)	Assist in the deepening of Panama's financial sector by increasing access to finance for low-income groups and other priority sectors;
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as Category FI according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Because the key S&E risks of the project are associated with BBVA Panamas SME portfolio, which include sectors with potential E&S risks such as agribusiness and manufacturing, IFC will review the Bank''s portfolio and capacity to manage S&E risks in order to determine the applicable requirements, which may include a combination of the IFC Exclusion List, the national S&E laws and regulations as well as the Performance Standards. IFC may recommend specific measures to manage S&E risks in certain sectors where E&S risks are perceived to be higher. IFC will also assess the Banks labor practices according to IFCs labor standards. The Bank will be required to: Develop, upgrade or maintain a Social and Environmental Management System to ensure compliance with the applicable requirements;Demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2:  Labor and Working Conditions; and Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: BBVA Panama is fully owned by Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, a Spanish financial institution which heads the group of entities that give form to Grupo BBVA.Grupo BBVA is a global financial holding which provides a wide array of both wholesale and retail financial services in 32 countries around the globe.
Cost Nature: The proposed project consists of a long-term credit facility for up to $25 million for on-lending to farmers and agri-SMEs.

Project Description: The project is to support Grupo Canopus ('Canopus' or the 'Company'), to expand its focus on low-income housing developments under the Minha Casa Minha Vida or any follow on governmental program. Canopus, one of the largest real estate developers and construction companies in the state of Minas Gerais, Brazil, has invited IFC and the IFC African, Latin American and Caribbean Fund, LP, managed by IFC Asset Management Company LLC (ALAC Fund) to make an equity investment to support its corporate capital expenditure plan for the expansion of its footprint in the affordable housing segment specially in the 0 to 10 minimum wages segment (including underdeveloped regions such as Brazilian North and Northeast), as well as the consolidation of its current position in the mid-high income and commercial segments (the 'Project').
Impact: The stability of the Brazilian macro economy during the last seven years coupled with the Government's agenda to prioritize the housing sector in a countercyclical effort, have boosted the demand for lower- and middle-income housing.  The proposed Project will support a reputable domestic housing company to undertake its growth plan in response to increasing demand for quality and affordable entry level lower-income houses in Brazil, thereby helping to reduce the current housing deficit in the country  particularly among lower-income families. Consumers will benefit from the expanded supply of residential units, while such housing developments will contribute to urban infrastructure development and community development around them, such as roads, electricity, hospitals, recreation areas, and so forth, thus also improving living standard of the population in the surrounding area.  Finally, in addition to promote significant job creation, the Project will also enhance local supply linkages through increased demand for construction and building materials in the country. Once construction is completed, the housing units will stimulate the use of local supplies of goods and services, supporting maintenance, retailing and wholesale operations.  In addition, local employment will be generated during and after construction.
Environmental Social Issues: The Companys core business activities in the construction of commercial and residential real estate take place in urban and peri-urban land. Land is acquired on a willing-buyer willing-seller basis and the Company has an informal policy not to get involved in negotiations of land with informal occupants. Project design takes account of relevant health and safety requirements including L&FS, the capacity and connections with municipal systems providing services and utilities, etc. Necessary licenses, permits and approvals are secured from relevant municipal authorities prior to the start of construction, the latter involving both Company construction workforce and contractors. A well established construction process is defined, with project construction teams involving construction managers, technical staff and trades people being supported with OHS staff, etc.This is therefore a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Further detail on environmental and social matters is provided in the projects Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS).
Sponsor: Headquartered in Belo Horizonte and with a focus on the medium/high income residential and commercial buildings segments and most recently on the low income housing segment through its wholly owned subsidiary Emcasa, Canopus is an integrated homebuilder involved in acquisition of land, planning, development and construction of residential and commercial buildings as well as sales.  The Company enjoys of more than 40 years of expertise in the real estate industry, mainly in the Southeast region of Brazil, but has been currently expanding its footprint in other underdeveloped regions such as the Brazilian North and Northeast. The Company was created in 1971 by Mr. Adgar Mattos, a reputable and well-known entrepreneur. Since 1992, CANOPUS has been controlled by the second generation of the Mattos Family, represented by Mr. Lucas Mattos and Mr. Tulio Mattos (50% stake each).
Cost Nature: IFC will provide an equity investment in the newly created company Canopus Holding S.A. for an amount to be determined. In addition, the ALAC Fund is also considering a similar investment in Canopus Holding S.A.
Investment: 25.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity25.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Housing and commercial projects will be developed in various states of Brazil, including frontier regions such as the Brazilian North and Northeast.

Project Description: Previously known as Elektrostopanstvo na Makedonija (ESM), EVN Macedonia AD (EVN Macedonia or  the Company) is the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonias (FYR Macedonia) sole electricity supply and distribution company serving more than 640,000 customers and a population of 2 million people. In order to finance the Companys investment program, in 2008 each of IFC and EBRD provided a long term loan of 35 million (IFCs project number #26093). The loans will be repaid in 18 equal installments that started in July 2011 and will be ending in January 2020.In line with the EU Energy Policy, following the new Energy Law that was enacted in February 2011 and the new secondary regulation, EVN Macedonia and the Macedonian energy market is going through a major reform and liberalization process. Due to the ongoing unbundling of its distribution, supply and generation businesses and the changes to market mechanics the Company is expected to require additional working capital by the beginning of 2012. In order to finance this working capital need and capital expenditures of the Company IFC will provide a long term loan up to 7 million. EBRD also considers participating in the financing. If EBRD, decides to participate the IFC loan amount will be reduced to 3.5 million.  The Companys capital expenditure includes items for high voltage lines, substations, low and medium voltage lines, connections to customers, transformers, meters, telecommunications, and some generation (investment in a new small hydropower project of 1.1MW in 2012).  The potential environmental or social impacts of these items are similar to those supported by IFCs previous investment made in the Company in 2008.  The main business of the Company is electricity distribution with about 26,360 km distribution lines.  The Company has 11 small hydropower plants (in total 46MW capacity).
Impact: The Project''s expected development impacts are as follow: (a) Supporting the Company during the power sector deregulation by providing long term financing,  (b) Continue supporting EVN with their turnaround strategy that essentially focuses on increasing bill collection rates and reducing energy losses that will lead to significant electricity savings for FYR Macedonia, and (c) Promoting proper sector reform and the development of a competitive power market in the country.
Environmental Social Issues: The previous project (ESM Macedonia #26093) has been supervised by IFC and its Environmental and Social Risk Ratings have been "Satisfactory" in 2008 - 2011.  As part of this previous project, Environmental Action Plan (EAP) was agreed and covenanted in the Loan Agreement. The EAP included various actions typical to electricity distribution sector such as screening and monitoring of PCBs contaminated oils and equipment, handling of wooden poles, monitoring of soil and groundwater contamination, occupational health and safety management.  A health and safety action related to the Company''s existing small hydro power plants were also included in the EAP.  Some actions of the EAP were delayed but the overall implementation status has been satisfactory to IFC.  Since the new project is to provide financial support to meet the company''s working capital needs, no additional environmental or social risks beyond the findings of the previous project''s due diligence are expected.  IFC will update the Environmental and Social Review Summary based on the latest information obtained through IFC''s supervision activities of the previous project and will continue to monitor the implementation of the EAP.  This new project is also a category B project, to be consistent with the category of the previous project.
Sponsor: The Project Sponsor is EVN AG, Austria''s second largest integrated utility company providing electricity, gas, heating, water, and waste incineration services in Austria and 20 other Central Eastern European countries and Russia, reaching over 3.6 million customers. EVN was partially privatized in 1990 and is currently owned 51% by the Province of Lower Austria, 32.5% by the German electricity supplier EnBW and 16.5% free float. As of October 17th, 2011, EVN AG has a market capitalization of EUR1.9 billion. 90% of EVN Macedonia (the Project Company) is owned by EVN AG, and 10% is still state-owned. The privatization took place in 2006, where EVN purchased 90% of the Company.

Thus the long term tenor will enable the Company to replace part of its current short term loans with long term financing resulting in a more sustainable balance sheet.No mobilization is envisaged.

The Company is active throughout the country, and its supply territory has an area of around 25,713 km2 and about one third of the distributed electricity is supplied in the Skopje area. Project Description: The proposed project is to provide a $4 million senior loan (or local currency equivalent) to CJSC FINCA MicroCredit Company ('FMCC' or the 'Company'), a leading microfinance company in Kyrgyz Republic. Proceeds of the loan will be used to finance the expansion of their lending to micro and small entrepreneurs (the 'Project 'or 'Finca Kyrgyz 2'). The Company currently seeks long-term funding to continue its dynamic growth and offer new products to its target clientele.
Impact: The developmental impact is expected to be high:- 	The Project would provide funding for the underserved segments of the society in an IDA country, more specifically women entrepreneurs, and would help create jobs and reduce poverty in Kyrgyz Republic.- 	The Project would support the efforts of FMCC to diversify and increase the volume of their funding and to better manage their assets and liabilities at a time of limited funding opportunities.- 	In Kyrgyz Republic, the provision of term funding in the local financial market would have a very strong demonstration effect and build market confidence. This is extremely relevant in a post-conflict environment.
Environmental Social Issues: The Project is with IFCs existing client to provide a senior loan to support its microfinance activity and has been classified as Category FI-3 according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The appraisal will focus on evaluating the Companys SEMS implementation and progress in implementation of SEMS Action Plan for the current project. According to the nature of IFCs investment and FMCCs operations the Company will be required to comply with the IFC Exclusion List, national E&S laws, IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions and submit Annual Environmental Performance reports according to the format provided by IFC.
Sponsor: FMCC has been active in the country since 1995 and was funded with a USAID grant. In 2003, FMCC was incorporated as a closed joint stock company and licensed by the National Bank of Kyrgyz Republic as a non deposit taking commercial micro credit company.FMCC has been primarily targeting underserved clients in remote, mostly rural areas with no or poor access to credit, as well as very small entrepreneurs in semi-urban and urban communities, who due to very small business size and lack of collateral had no access to credit from the formal financial system. FMCC is owned by FINCA Microfinance Holding Company, LLC ('FINCA'), a commercial holding company, headquartered in Washington, DC and one of the largest microfinance networks in the world. FINCA serves approximately 765,000 micro entrepreneurs, 70 percent of which are women. The shareholders of the holding company are FINCA International, Inc., IFC, KfW, FMO, Triple Jump and responsAbility.
Cost Nature: The proposed project involves a senior loan from IFC's own account to the Company in either US Dollar or Kyrgyz Som, in an amount not to exceed $4 million (equivalent).
Investment: 4.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan4.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: FMCC is headquartered in Bishkek, Kyrgyz Republic. It is currently present in all seven regions of the country and runs a network of 18 branches and 49 outlets thus having a nation-wide coverage.

Project Description: The Project ('IMON Senior Loan 2') is to support Micro Lending Organization IMON International LLC (the 'Company' or 'IMON'), Tajikistan's largest microfinance company, founded in 2005. IFC's debt financing to a strong financial intermediary like IMON with a successful track record of providing funding to local micro entrepreneurs would help the company expand its lending to micro and small entrepreneurs. The Company seeks long-term funding to continue its dynamic growth and offer new products to its target clientele.

Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at $5 million (or local currency equivalent) to IMON. The proposed investment would be on IFC's own account. The proposed project would be IFC's first project in Tajikistan denominated in Tajik Somoni.

Project Description: The project is to support Grupo Canopus (Canopus or the Company), to expand its focus on low-income housing developments under the Minha Casa Minha Vida or any follow on governmental program. Canopus, one of the largest real estate developers and construction companies in the state of Minas Gerais, Brazil, has invited IFC to make an equity investment to support its corporate capital expenditure plan for the expansion of its footprint in the affordable housing segment specially in the 0 to 10 minimum wages segment (including in underdeveloped regions such as Brazilian North and Northeast), as well as the consolidation of its current position in the mid-high income and commercial segments (the Project).  The low income housing segment is managed by the Company under the brand name Emcasa.
Review Scope: IFCs review included visits to Grupo Canopus (Canopus or the Company) administrative offices in Belo Horizonte, State of Minas Gerais, Brazil, as well as field visits to projects under construction at the time of the appraisal. IFC met and interviewed key staff (corporate and operational management; new projects development; occupational health and safety engineers; and human resources management) and reviewed numerous, relevant internal documents and records surrounding the Sponsors environmental and social (E&S) performance.  Among others, these included environmental licenses for a representative set of projects; health and safety procedures; employee manuals defining the Sponsors human resources policy; sample employment contracts; and presentation materials about the Sponsor business activities.  IFC staff also conducted inspections of representative projects under construction including: a low income housing project in the State of Minas Gerais; a middle income residential project near Campinas, State of Sao Paulo; and a high-rise commercial office building near the City of Sao Paulo.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because Sponsors business in residential and commercial real estate development presents a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Furthermore, the Sponsor is presently demonstrating the ability to effectively manage potential environmental and social risks from its business activities through the application of national legislation which will be complemented with additional actions defined as part of IFCs investment conditions.

Project Description: EVN Macedonia AD (the Company) is the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonias (FYR Macedonia) sole electricity supply and distribution company serving more than 640,000 customers and a population of 2 million people. In order to finance the Companys investment program, in 2008 each of IFC and EBRD provided a long term loan of  35 million (IFCs project number #26093). The loans will be repaid in 18 equal installments that started in July 2011 and will be ending in January 2020.In line with the EU Energy Policy, following the new Energy Law that was enacted in February 2011 and the new secondary regulation, EVN Macedonia and the Macedonian energy market is going through a major reform and liberalization process. Due to the ongoing unbundling of its distribution, supply and generation businesses and the changes to market mechanics the Company is expected to require additional working capital by the beginning of 2012.  In order to finance this working capital need and capital expenditures of the Company IFC will provide a long term loan up to  7 million.  EBRD also considers participating in the financing.  If EBRD decides to participate, the IFC loan amount will be reduced to  3.5 million.The Companys capital expenditure includes items for high voltage lines, substations, low and medium voltage lines, connections to customers, transformers, meters, telecommunications, and some generation (investment in a new small hydropower project of 1.1MW in 2012).  The potential environmental or social impacts of these items are similar to those supported by IFCs previous investment made in the Company in 2008.  The main business of the Company is electricity distribution with about 26,360 km distribution lines.  The Company has 11 small hydropower plants (in total 46MW capacity).
Review Scope: This is a repeat investment for an original project (ESM Macedonia # 26093) that was appraised in 2007 and committed in 2008.  The original project was the loan financing of an investment program to upgrade Macedonias electricity supply and distribution company, Electropanstvo na Makedonija AD (ESM) which was privatized in April 2006 and was acquired by EVN, Austrias second largest power utility.  ESM is now called EVN Macedonia AD (EVN Macedonia or the Company).  After IFCs investment in the Company, IFC has conducted periodic and ongoing supervision of the Companys environmental, health and safety and social performance by reviewing Annual Monitoring reports for the year 2008, 2009 and 2010.  In addition, IFC conducted a regular environmental supervision visit in March 2011.  The appraisal of this new investment in the Company was conducted by a desk review of the accumulated and updated information about the Companys environmental and social performance obtained through IFCs supervision activities as described above.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Because it primarily involves the modernization and upgrading of aging electrical transmission and distribution infrastructure that is already in place, this repeat category B investment will not result in any material change in the management of limited environmental and social risks.  New investment activities also include constructing and operating a relatively small-scale hydro power facility in confined (and already disturbed) areas by an existing IFC client who has demonstrated it can effectively operate similar facilities.  The current Environmental and Social Risk Rating for the original investment is Satisfactory.

Project Description: Pran Group ('Pran' or the Company') is seeking IFC's assistance to finance the expansion of its food processing operations. The proposed expansion project has been incorporated as a new private limited company, Natore Agro Limited.  Pran is a diversified group involved in the production and sale of a wide product range covering beverages, snacks, culinary products, confectionery, dairy products, rice and tea.  The Project ('Pran Natore Agro') consists of an investment of approximately $25 million for the expansion of Pran's food processing and manufacturing capacity with the goal of introducing new packaged food and spice/condiment products to the Company's product line for both local and export markets.
Impact: Agriculture accounts for 21% of Bangladesh's GDP, whereby 55% of the country's population derives its income from the sector.  Private sector involvement will ensure continued growth in income-generating agriculture activities, particularly by integrating small farmers into formal supply chain linkages such as those that Pran's operations have established. In addition to creating over 1,200 new jobs, the proposed Project will positively impact the livelihood of several thousand farmers and their communities by ensuring consistent demand and fair pricing for their produce. Further, Pran's unparalleled distribution network will enable the Company to reach under-served, impoverished communities and provide them with affordable, essential food products of high quality.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects. Key environmental and social (E&S) issues associated with this Project include: development and implementation of integrated management systems covering quality, environment, health and safety and food safety; assurance of fair, safe and healthy working conditions in compliance with local regulatory requirements and relevant Performance Standards; resource efficiency of the operations (water, energy); monitoring and management of air emissions, wastewater treatment and discharge, solid and other waste disposal; the impacts of operations on local ambient air quality; and safety management including emergency preparedness and response. Further details on the potential environmental and social impacts of the project, corresponding mitigation measures and guidance on how and where information about the project are provided in the Environmental & Social Review Summary.
Sponsor: The Sponsors are Mr. Amjad Khan Chowdhury, Mrs. Sabiha Amjad, Mr. Ahsan Khan Chowdhury, and Ms. Uzma Chowdhury who control the seven Pran Group companies engaged in the food processing sector: AMCL Ltd., PRAN Agro Ltd., PRAN Foods Ltd., Bango Agro PRAN Ltd., PRAN Beverage Ltd., PRAN Dairy Ltd., and PRAN Natore Agro Ltd.  All of these companies are fully privately-owned, with the exception of AMCL, which is listed in the Dhaka Stock Exchange.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $25 million.  The proposed IFC investment consists of an A Loan of up to $15 million.
Investment: 10.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan10.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project will support the expansion of Pran's existing food and confectionary lines in Natore in northern Bangladesh.

Further details on the potential environmental and social impacts of the project, corresponding mitigation measures and guidance on how and where information about the project are provided in the Environmental & Social Review Summary.

Project Description: Pran is the leading food processing company in Bangladesh, which produces and distributes beverages, such as fruit juices, cola, bottled water; snacks, confectionery (candies, biscuits), culinary products, dairy and soft drinks. It enjoys a strong brand reputation in the country and exports its products to 70 countries. The proposed IFC investment is for the expansion of its food processing and fruit pulping operations within its existing Pran Agro Industrial Park in Natore, located around 200 km north-east of Dhaka, and will include construction and commissioning of: 6,500MT noodle line, 4,000 MT spice line, 12,000MT sauce/ketchup line, 4,500MT mustard oil line, 42,000MT fruit pulping line, 2,000MT papad (traditional South Asian crackers) line, and 4,500MT fortified cereal bar line and associated utilities, such as water and wastewater treatment plants, boiler and diesel generators for captive power generation (Project).
Review Scope: IFCs review of this proposed investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental, occupational health and safety (EHS) and social related information submitted by Pran Group (Pran or the Company) including, Environment, Health and Safety (EHS) and Human Resources (HR) related corporate level policies and procedures; food safety management system policies and procedures, overall organization chart, including E&S team; reports of external/third-party audits (related to HR, resource efficiency/cleaner production); environmental monitoring reports; detailed report for the proposed project under this investment. The appraisal included supervision site visits to the existing food processing facilities, including progress status of ESAPs, and to the construction site of the proposed investment at Pran Agro Industrial Park in Natore; and discussions with Prans senior management, technical and EHS teams  at each facility as well as at the corporate office in Dhaka. Further information on the Environmental and Social (E&S) risks associated with the supply chain of agro-commodities in Bangladesh was obtained at US Department of Labor and ILO websites. The due diligence for this investment also benefited from IFCs internal guideline on the E&S risk assessment and management of agro-commodities for traders and processors and IFC Performance Standard requirements (PS2 and PS6).This is third investment by IFC in the Pran Group. The Environmental Social Review Summaries (ESRS) for the previous IFC investments are available at:PRAN, Project no. 27005), disclosed in June 2008, is available at: http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/ProjectDisplay/ESRS27005PRAN DAIRY, Project no. 30568), disclosed in April 2011, is available at: http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/ProjectDisplay/ESRS30568 The Company has, to this date, successfully implemented the Environmental and Social Action Plans (ESAP) action items for these investments. A summary status of the implementation is disclosed herewith.Considering the nature of the proposed investment (ref. new processing plant next to the existing processing facility in Natore), this review thus, builds upon the previously disclosed ESRSs and ESAPs, and the information collected during IFCs engagement with Pran over the past three years; and covers specific EHS and HR aspects related to the new processing facilities at Natore.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Key environmental and social (E&S) issues associated with this Project include: development and implementation of integrated management systems covering quality, environment, occupational health and safety, and food safety; assurance of fair, safe and healthy working conditions in compliance with local regulatory requirements and relevant Performance Standards; resource efficiency of the operations (water, energy); monitoring and management of air emissions, wastewater treatment and discharge, solid and other waste disposal; the impacts of operations on local ambient air quality; and safety management, including emergency preparedness and response.The Project may result in limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards and guidelines. On this basis, this project is therefore classified as a Category B project according to IFCs Policy and Social and Environmental Sustainability.

Project Description: Shanghai Fosun Pharmaceutical (Group) Company Ltd. ('Fosun Pharma', or the 'Company'), an existing IFC client, is a leading healthcare company in China with presence in the entire healthcare value chain from manufacturing to distribution and provision of healthcare services. Fosun Pharma plans to pursue strategic acquisitions, strengthen its research and development capability, expand and upgrade existing manufacturing capacity, strengthen its distribution network and optimize its capital structure (together, the 'Project').
Impact: 1. Support frontier region development. The Project will provide support to some of Fosun Pharma's subsidiaries in the frontier provinces. The Project will send a positive signal to the market in terms of the region's capabilities in carrying out relatively high value-add pharmaceutical manufacturing.2. Support development of anti-malaria drugs. One of Fosun Pharma's subsidiaries has the exclusive right to manufacture artesunate, a treatment for malaria, in China and export artesunate-related products to 37 countries. The Project will support the expansion and upgrade of the manufacturing capacity of these anti-malaria drugs.3. Increase access to quality and affordable medicines. Through the expansion of the Company's distribution network, the Project will increase the availability of quality and affordable medicines addressing rising demand. The Company is also expected to bring more facilities acquired through acquisitions into compliance with the Chinese GMP standards.4. Employment creation and local linkages. The Project is expected to create a number of employment opportunities for the local communities as well as spur the growth of local suppliers of goods and services.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Fosun Pharma has provided information on its current practices and policies that seek to address these risks and impacts to ensure that the proposed project complies with or, will upon implementation of specific additional agreed measures, comply with host country laws and regulations, IFC Performance Standards on Social and Environment Sustainability and applicable environmental, health and safety guidelines. Environmental, social and health and safety issues that require ameliorative measures will be addressed by Fosun Pharma as part of IFCs investment agreements. Key issues that will require mitigation measures include (i) Adoption of IFC environmental and social Performance Standards as part of applicable requirements in its management system; (ii) establishment of emission standards consistent with international best practice, and (iii) improve resource efficiency (energy and water).
Sponsor: Fosun Pharma has been listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange (ticker: 600196) since 1998. Fosun Pharma is 51.95% owned by the public and 48.05% owned by Shanghai Fosun High Technology (Group) Co., Ltd., which is a wholly owned subsidiary of Fosun International Limited ('Fosun International'). Fosun International is a company incorporated and listed in Hong Kong and had revenues and profits of US$7 billion and US$945 million respectively in 2010.
Cost Nature: IFC is considering a financing package of up to US$75 million.

Project Description: Laxmi Organic Industries Ltd (LOIL or the Company) is an Indian company producing specialty chemicals used in diverse end-user industries. The Company is undertaking an expansion (the Project), comprising brown field expansion of ethyl acetate (ETAC) and diketene derivatives (DD) products capacities, a coal fired co-generation facility and a greenfield facility to produce acetic anhydride.
Impact: -	IFC''s proposed investment will help LOIL become a leader in adopting latest practices to ensure clean production. This is significant, especially in an industry where most medium-scale chemical manufacturers tend to follow polluting processes with minimal investment in waste effluent handling. LOIL has designed a zero discharge ETP for additional effluents generated from expansion projects where processed effluent will be used as feed water.-	The proposed investment in a thermal co-generation power plant will provide the most efficient âEnergy and Product Integration'' solution between steam intensive ETAC plant and power intensive DD plant. -	LOIL is in the process of carrying out R&D for cost effective thermal solar panels which has potential to integrate with co-generation unit in DD plant. This pioneer design will mitigate LOIL''s reliance on fossil fuels and reduce its greenhouse gas footprint.-	The proposed expansion is expected to create nearly 70 jobs over the next two years and result in other indirect development benefits such as linkages with local suppliers, upgrade of existing infrastructure, and indirect employment creation through auxiliary businesses in the region and during construction phase.-	Considering that 70% of India''s current requirement for DD products is being imported, the proposed investment will facilitate self sufficiency and conserve foreign exchange.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because it may create a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria.Key environmental, health and safety, human resources and social issues that were reviewed included: air emission, wastewater treatment and discharge, solid and hazardous waste management, operation hazard and hazardous material management, employee health and safety, fire protection and emergency response, community health/safety, and community relationship and development.LOIL has presented plans to address these impacts to ensure that the proposed project will, upon implementation of the specific agreed measures, comply with the environmental and social requirements - the host country laws and regulations and the IFC Environment and Social Performance Standards and the World Bank Group (WBG) environmental, health and safety guidelines.Please refer to the disclosed Environmental and Social Review Summary for the details of environmental and social issues.
Sponsor: LOIL is an unlisted company and the promoter family holds 100% of its share capital. The Company was promoted by Mr. Vasudev Goenka and is currently being managed by his sons, Mr. Ravi Goenka and Mr. Rajiv Goenka.
Cost Nature: The estimated Project cost is approximately US$43.6 million and IFC is proposing a financial investment to fund a part of the expansion. The balance will be funded from other financing institutions and internal accruals of the Company

Location: The project site is Mahad, Maharashtra, India, where the Companys existing plant is located.

Project Description: Shanghai Fosun Pharmaceutical (Group) Company Ltd. ('Fosun Pharma' or the 'Company') is an existing IFC client in good standing. The Company is a leading healthcare products company in China with presence in the entire healthcare value chain from manufacturing to distribution and provision of healthcare services. IFC is expected to provide a financing package of up to USD 75 million. The financing will be used by the Company to pursue strategic acquisitions, strengthen its research and development capability, expand and upgrade existing manufacturing capacity, strengthen its distribution network and optimize its capital structure (together, the 'Project').
Review Scope: The scope of review comprised assessment of the effectiveness of the Company's management system to provide robust oversight of environmental and social issues, ensure continued compliance with local regulatory requirements, and its ability to achieve and consistently maintain compliance with IFC's Performance Standards and applicable environmental health and safety guidelines. IFC's review consisted of meetings and document review related to the Company's environmental and social management policies and procedures, human resources management, and monitoring and reporting systems and data at the Corporate and subsidiary level. Environmental monitoring data was also reviewed, which included among others an environmental audit of Fosun Pharma's operational manufacturing sites, which contains site descriptions and data describing emissions to air and water. This report is available on EPA web site at the following link:  HYPERLINK "http://wfs.mep.gov.cn/gywrfz/hbhc/hcpx/201107/t20110715_215054.htm" http://wfs.mep.gov.cn/gywrfz/hbhc/hcpx/201107/t20110715_215054.htm; HYPERLINK "http://www.mep.gov.cn/gkml/hbb/bh/201109/t20110902_216902.htm" http://www.mep.gov.cn/gkml/hbb/bh/201109/t20110902_216902.htm. The review relied on documents and reports related to E&S performance made available by the Company, and interviews conducted by IFC staff during their site visits which included manufacturing facilities of Shine Star (Hubei) Biological Engineering Co., Ltd. ('Shine Star') in Hubei province, Chongqing Yaoyou Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd. ('Yao Pharma') in Chongqing province, Jiangsu Wanbang Biochemical Pharmaceuticals Co., Ltd. ('Wanbang') in Jiangsu province, and Shanghai Chemo Wanbang Biopharma Co., Ltd. ('Chemo Wanbang') in Shanghai.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFC's Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because it may create a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria. Key environmental, health and safety, human resources and social issues that were reviewed included: environmental and social management system (scope and implementation); quality and sustainability of water resources; emissions to the environment  air, water and subsurface; solid, and hazardous waste and materials management, including transportation; life and fire safety; community and occupational health and safety; energy use and efficiency; community engagement; and land acquisition. The key E&S issue related to this proposed investment is effectiveness of Fosun Pharma's E&S management system at the corporate level and at the level of its subsidiaries which are geographically diverse, for a wide range of products which are manufactured and distributed through various subsidiaries. The current E&S management system used by the Company includes effective oversight of risk identification, labor practices, and integration between policies and procedures the corporate level with those of its subsidiaries. The Company has an actively engaged management program and has presented specific plans to address key issues and gaps to ensure continued compliance with local regulatory requirements as well as consistency with IFC Performance Standards and applicable Word Bank Group (WBG) Environmental, Health and Safety guidelines.

Project Description: Laxmi Organic Industries Limited (LOIL) is an Indian company manufacturing specialty chemicals (ethyl acetate or EATC at Unit 1 and diketene derivatives or DD at Unit 2, which cater to diverse industries including pharmaceuticals, paints, dyes, pigments, flexible packaging, agrochemicals, aluminum foil, and adhesives. The proposed investment is for (i) brownfield expansion of ETAC capacity from 60,000 tonnes per annum (tpa) to 100,000 tpa; (ii) building a 7.5MWe  turbine installed capacity coal fired co-generation facility with about 4.8MWe power available for utilization from Unit 1; (iii) brownfield expansion of DD products with capacity increasing from 9600 tpa to 22,100 tpa; and (iv) setting up 13,000 tpa capacity to manufacture acetic anhydride (AAH) at Unit 2.  IFC is considering supporting the Project through an equity stake in LOIL.The main specialty chemical manufacturing facilities, Units 1 and 2, are located in Mahad, Maharashtra State, India, which account for approximately 95% of LOIL revenue. LOIL has a molasses fermentation/ethanol distillation facility in Satara, Maharashtra. Besides the chemical business, LOIL has two wind turbines of total capacity 2.5 MW located at a large wind farm and operated by the wind farm company. LOIL also plans to install water turbines at existing dams with total capacity of 7 MW.
Review Scope: The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health, safety, and social information submitted by the project sponsor, and undertaking a field visit in October 2011. The environmental and social (E&S) appraisal team visited projects sites in Mahad and Satara, Maharashtra State, India. The E&S team held meetings with the company's management team and also interviewed some employees.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: All the manufacturing facilities are located in industrial areas and there are no communities near the facilities. Moreover, all the expansions are located within the existing properties, and all the wastewater generated from these expansions will be treated and recycled. Air emission rates for both traditional pollutants and carbon dioxide will be reduced due to new technologies adopted in this project. Water and energy specific consumption rates for unit products will also be reduced due to process optimization. Mitigation measures for the potential environmental and social impacts have been identified and are incorporated into an attached Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP).The potential adverse E&S impacts of this project are therefore few in number and limited to project sites, and may be readily mitigated. This is therefore an E&S Category B project.

Project Description: The Project (OCB SME Loan) consists of a senior loan of up to $25 million, including $15 million from IFCs own account, of which $ 5 million is allocated towards women-owned SME financing, and $10 million from participant lenders, to support Orient Commercial Joint Stock Bank (OCB or the Bank or the Company) expanding its SME lending program.
Impact: As a large segment of the private sector, particularly SMEs, remains un- or underserved this project is expected to directly expand credit access to SMEs, provide liquidity for exports and indirectly improve market perception to commercially-priced long-term funding for SME lending, which could catalyze similar funding from commercial sources for further SME-lending activities. It is also expected to promote market development with the introduction of syndication for this type of funding.
Environmental Social Issues: This new project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. During appraisal IFC will analyze the banks portfolio/pipeline activities proposed to be supported by the new IFCs facility for types of transactions, size, tenor and industry sectors and determined the Applicable Performance Requirements that would include a combination of the IFC FI Exclusion List, the applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and regulations and IFC Performance Standards. IFC will also appraise the labor practices of the client according to the IFCs Performance Standards 2: Labor and Working Conditions. Based on the review, the project will be required to: 	Develop an, or upgrade, if necessary, any existing Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS), prior to disbursement, to the satisfaction of IFC	Identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the SEMS	Commit to implement the SEMS, to ensure that its financing activities are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements	Demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions	Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC
Sponsor: OCB was established in June 1996 with an initial paid-in capital of 70 billion Vietnamese dong (approximately $6 million). In 2003, the Bank integrated with Tay Do Bank, a rural commercial bank, to increase its footprint in the Mekong Delta region. The Bank offers a wide range of banking services primarily to SMEs, households and individuals. As at end of September 30, 2011, the Bank had an asset base of 26,263 billion Vietnamese dong ($1.3 billion), a loan portfolio of 12,791billion Vietnamese dong ($614 million) supported by a capital base of 3,639 billion Vietnamese dong ($175 million).  The Banks ownership structure is diversified, consisting of BNP Paribas (20%), CEO Trinh Van Tuan and his family members (14.84%); Ben Thanh Corporation (6.87%) and its affiliate, Savico (3.75%); financial management board of Ho Chi Minh City''s Communist Party Committee (5.95%) and Vietcombank (5.06%). The remaining 43.53% are held by other 2,800 local shareholders.
Cost Nature: The proposed dollar denominated loan to OCB is $25 million, of which a $15 million A loan from IFCs own account, of which a $5 million allocated towards women-owned SME financing, and a $10 million from participant lenders. The loan will have a tenor of 2 years with an option to extend by another 2 years if conditions necessitate.

Company Name: TMB THANACHART BANK PUBLIC COMPANY LIMITED
Project Description: The Project (TMB flood relief) consists of the provision of a loan of up to $100 million to TMB Bank Public Company Limited (TMB) with a 3-year maturity to be used for immediate flood relief purposes by extending sub-loans to SMEs in flood-affected areas of Thailand. TMB is a wholesale bank with focus on corporate, SMEs and retail clients, and a growing presence outside of Bangkok.
Impact: Support the economic recovery: The worst flooding in Thailand in half a century is expected to reduce the country''s economic growth rate by 1-1.5%. The Project will support the country''s disaster responses by providing a source of emergency liquidity.Financial sector deepening: The Project will enable a local bank to access foreign currency funding and provide a level playing field with foreign banks that have the benefit of parent funding.Increase financing to sub-borrowers: The project will contribute to an increase of TMB''s loan portfolio.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  During appraisal, IFC will analyze the FI portfolio and determine the Applicable Performance Requirements, if any, that would include a combination of: the IFC FI Exclusion List, the applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and regulations and the IFC Performance Standards. During appraisal IFC will also review the clients capacity to manage the environmental and social risk and if required, to establish and maintain an environmental and social management system (ESMS). Based on the review, the project will be required to:Develop an, or upgrade, if necessary, any existing Environmental & Social Management System (ESMS), within a timeframe agreed with IFC Identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the ESMSCommit to implement the ESMS, to ensure that its financing activities are in compliance with the Applicable Performance RequirementsDemonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working ConditionsSubmit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC
Sponsor: TMB was established in Thailand in 1957 as Thai Military Bank to offer financial services to members of the Thai military.  In 1973, TMB became a full commercial bank and expanded its customer base to include the general public. The Bank was listed on the Stock Exchange of Thailand (SET) in 1983 and transformed into a public limited company in 1994. Project Description: The IFC investment will support Vegpro Ghana (VGL or the Project), a Ghanaian company associated with Vegpro Kenya Limited (VKL or the Company), Kenyas largest vegetable producer, processor and exporter.  The Project consists of: (1) setting up of a 1,070 hectares (ha) commercial farm to produce vegetables on land leased from the Government of Ghana on a 50-year renewable lease; (2) development of 768 ha equipped with 12 Centre Pivot Irrigation Systems each covering 64 ha; (3) procurement of farm equipment and refrigerated vehicles and (4) construction of a bespoke pack house on the farm for packing and processing vegetables for export to UK and EU markets.
Impact: The proposed Project will help a) create employment for up to 1500 people; b) develop the horticulture industry in Ghana; c) develop a network of suppliers of goods and services (inputs, transportation, maintenance; equipment, etc) which has industry-wide benefits; d) provide access to export market for 200 smallholder farmers which should improve their incomes and e) contribute to food security through the production of maize for the local market and increased incomes of employees and smallholders.
Role: IFC will provide: (i) funds at a longer tenor and grace period than generally available in the market which is critical for this Greenfield project; (ii) the company with political risk mitigation in its South-South investment; (iii) advisory capacity building to small farmers as needed and (iv) assist Vegpro to implement environmental and social standards that will form a benchmark for projects in the horticulture sector in Ghana. Vegpro is also keen to work with IFC ti improve Corporate Governance and to establish a more efficient corporate structure.
Sponsor: The Company is Vegpro Kenya Limited while the major shareholders are James Cartwright and Bharat Patel who each own 50 percent of VGL.  Bharat Patel co-founded Vegpro Kenya Limited in 1979 and is the Managing Director of VKL.  James Cartwright is the Business Development Director of VKL and has over 36 years of experience in horticulture; joined VKL in 1995.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is $14 million. The proposed IFC investment is a $7 million secured A loan to VGL to support the Project.

Project Description: The proposed investment involves supporting Banco Regional S.A. ('Banco Regional' or the 'Bank' or the 'Company') in providing long-term financing in Guaranies to crucial sectors of the economy such as SME's, and in facilitating increased mortgage lending especially for affordable housing.The Project will be sourced through IFC's recently signed master swap agreement with the Central Bank of Paraguay.
Impact: The Project is expected to have a high development impact as it will help an IFC client to bolster its financial services and products to Paraguayan companies and individuals, supporting economic activity and job creation in Paraguay.On an institutional level, by providing access to longer-term local currency financig, IFC will help Banco Regional to introduce new products in the financial system limiting foreign currency risk.  On a sector level, the introduction of longer-term financing in the market will supply more options to SME's and individual borrowers, therefore generating a range of social and economic benefits which include promoting economic growth and raising productivity, as well as increasing banking penetration in rural areas. The anticipated development impacts of the Project are to:-	Enhance access to finance for SMEs.  The Project will allow the Bank to provide its clients access to funding in Guaranies with longer maturities, enabling them to undertake investment projects with more appropriate financing structures;-	Generate a demonstration effect.  The Project is expected to create a demonstration effect for other banks and further enhance IFC's developmental impact in Paraguay; and-	Assist in the deepening of Paraguay's financial sector by increasing access to finance for low-income groups and other priority sectors such as affordable housing.
Environmental Social Issues: This Project has been classified as Category FI according to IFCs E&S review procedure. Under the existing project with Banco Regional - #29679, the Bank was required to upgrade its Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) to ensure compliance of all applicable operations with the IFC Exclusion List, the Paraguayan E&S laws and regulations, and to develop specific criteria for the financing of agribusiness companies. In addition, the client agreed to implement a grievance policy and mechanism. The same requirements would apply to this new project and implementation of existing requirements will be a condition of commitment. The client will be required to: (i) finalize implementation of its ESMS and ensure its continuous operation; (ii) submit a periodic report to IFC; and (iii) implement the grievance mechanism and maintain compliance with the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions.
Sponsor: Banco Regional was established in 1991 by a group of Paraguayan entrepreneurs, with the purpose of promoting the development of the productive and industrial sectors in the department of Itapua. Soon after its constitution, the Bank expanded its activities to other locations in the department of Alto Parana and other productive regions near Asuncion.In January 2008, the Rabobank Group acquired a 40% stake in the Bank as part of the initiative of the Rabobank Development Program to support banks in developing countries through minority equity investments. In November 2009, Banco Regional completed the merger with the Paraguayan subsidiary of ABN AMRO Bank, becoming the largest player in the local financial system in terms of assets.The Bank has been an IFC client since June 2008, when it joined IFC's Global Trade Finance Program.
Cost Nature: The Project consists of a 5-year Guarani-denominated A-Loan for an equivalent of up to $15 million to Banco Regional.The Project will enhance access to finance for SMEs with a marked presence in the domestic market (a key driver of the economic activity in Paraguay), and will enable IFC to consolidate and foster its programmatic approach in the local financial sector initiated by the end of 2007, by reaching to relevant productive sectors which couldn't be served due to the former structural barrier to lend in local currency.In addition, the Project will enable IFC to gradually enter into a relevant but yet unexplored segment such as the Paraguayan housing finance sector.

Project Description: IFC is considering a loan of up to $7 million to VGL to enable them to establish a greenfield horticulture project in Ghana. The Vegpro Group, which includes VGL, is a leading exporter of vegetables and flowers to the UK and Europe from its Kenya operations, to market leading clients, such as Marks & Spencer, Tesco and Sainsburys. Vegpros flower growing operations in Kongoni are subject to an existing IFC investment. E&S management at that operation has been reviewed a number of times since the investment was committed and has always been judged to be meeting IFCs requirements with regards to the Performance Standards and at-commitment E&S requirements. VGL has entered into a 50-year lease on 1070 hectares (ha) of land to grow baby corn, chilies and butternut squash, under centre pivot irrigation, primarily for export. Maize will be used as a rotation crop and to supply the local market, ensuring food security. The investment plan also includes growing rice and soya beans if proposed trials prove successful. VGL will also source vegetables from a large number of local smallholders. The Vegpro Group selected Ghana for expansion of its operations due to: (i) a good investment incentive and business climate; (ii) good land and water availability; (iii) excellent logistics and proximity to Europe, and; (iv) favorable climatic conditions.
Review Scope: IFC environmental and social specialists visited the site of the proposed Vegpro Ghana (VGL or the Project) farm in Torgorme, in the North Tongu District of the Volta Region of Ghana. The team toured existing buildings (offices and warehouses) that were being rehabilitated to prepare for the on-site processing of vegetables, the farmland that had been cleared and the 4 centre pivot irrigation systems. The team also visited the two villages that are directly affected by the farming operations. In addition, the team reviewed the Environmental and Social Impact Assessments (ESIAs), Resettlement Action Plans (RAPs) and other documents developed for both the project itself, and the broader Torgorme Irrigation Project (TIP) being completed by the Millennium Development Authority (MiDA) on behalf of the Government of Ghana and the Millennium Challenge Corporation (MCC). This latter project includes the development of infrastructure (roads, water conveyance canals) to irrigate a total area of 2000ha (which will supply water to irrigate VGLs fields).Finally, the team met with the World Bank regarding the Ghana Commercial Agriculture Project (GCAP), which include an investment component located on the right bank of the Kpong River with similar issues to address. The environmental specialist also visited the Vegpro Groups operations in Kenya, which is an existing IFC client, including three irrigated farms in the Lake Naivasha area and pack-house operations located at Jomo Kenyatta International Airport to assess how the company manages its environmental and social (E&S) issues associated with its existing industrial scale farming and vegetable processing.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability because the limited number of specific impacts that may occur are generally site specific and those impacts can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, procedures, guidelines or design criteria.
Sector: AG - Diversified Edible Agricultural Crops Production

Project Description: The CI-202 block offshore Cote dIvoire is a key asset of Rialto Energy Ltd (Rialto or the Company) in which it has an 85% working interest and is also the operator. On CI-202, two main hubs (Gazelle and Hippo) have been identified based on previous drilling and 3D seismic. The blocks contingent resources on a 2C basis are estimated at 35.9 million barrels of oil (mmbo) and 355 billion cubic feet (bcf). The Project (Rialto Energy) consists of drilling 2 wells on the Gazelle area and one exploration well on a prospect in the Hippo cluster. A rig contract has been executed and long-lead items for this program are being acquired. The success of this appraisal and exploration drilling will allow the Company to make the final investment decision and proceed with the field development plan agreed with the Government of Cote dIvoire. Once developed, hydrocarbon production from the field, particularly gas from Gazelle, will help address significant shortage of gas supply currently existing and projected in order to serve the countrys power needs.
Impact: The project offers strong development impacts.Develop Cote d''Ivoire''s energy sector: By financing CI-202 appraisal, the project will help increase gas availability, which is crucial for the country''s power sector. The country currently suffers from power outages.Increase government''s revenues: Oil and gas production will increase the country''s exports and the government''s fiscal revenues.Provide local employment: the project will generate local employment directly through direct hiring and its local contractors, and indirectly by improving the power sector''s economics.
