Project Description: Rialto Energy is an oil and gas exploration and production company headquartered in London. The CI-202 block offshore Cote dIvoire is Rialto Energys (Rialto or the Company) key asset in which it has an 85% working interest and is also the operator. On CI-202, two main hubs (Gazelle and Hippo) have been identified based on previous drilling and 3D seismic. The blocks contingent resources on a 2C basis are estimated at 35.9 million barrels of oil (mmbo) and 355 billion cubic feet (bcf). The project consists of drilling 2 wells on the Gazelle area and one exploration well on a prospect in the Hippo cluster. A rig contract has been executed and long-lead items for this program are being acquired. The success of this appraisal and exploration drilling will allow the Company to make the final investment decision and proceed with the field development plan agreed with the Government of Cote dIvoire. Once developed, hydrocarbon production from the field, particularly gas from Gazelle, will help address significant shortage of gas supply currently existing and projected in order to serve the countrys power needs.IFCs proposed investment consists of an equity investment in the Company of up to $20 million coupled with a warrants package. IFCs investment will help finance the Companys drilling campaign, i.e. drilling the two appraisal wells in the Gazelle gas field area which is scheduled to continue for 120 days for the 3 wells (i.e. if the additional well is also drilled) and will commence in mid-February 2012. Cote dIvoires power sector is dominated by gas-fueled plants (Azito and CIPREL) which provide majority of the power supply for the country. Rialtos CI-202 block has significant gas resources complemented with oil resources. It is expected that the gas from Rialtos CI-202 Block will supply the power plants.
Review Scope: IFCs environmental and social (E&S) review of the Rialto Energy Ltd (Rialto or the Company) project consisted of an appraisal visit conducted in November 2011. This visit was to assess the Companys organizational capacity and commitment, their operations and to review the technical, health, safety, environmental, (HSE) and social information submitted by the Company and understand their plans and commitments for the future development of the block. During the appraisal, IFC team also held meetings with Rialtos management in London and with the E&S consultants working on behalf of Rialto in Abidjan. The site visit included the CI-202 offshore block (currently, there are no installations or any other physical infrastructure on the block).The review of key documentation included the Health, Safety, Environmental and Quality (HSEQ) Management System manual, the HSEQ policy statement, policies and procedures, the environmental impact assessment reports prepared for the seismic and drilling campaigns, the environmental audit report for the seismic exploration, draft bridging documents, management of change, emergency management response and the human resources manual among others.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The proposed investment has been assessed as a Category A project because of the inherent sector risks associated with oil and gas offshore exploration and production and the project location in an ecologically sensitive area. The project is at late stages of exploration and appraisal and is likely to progress to development of the fields. The detailed design aspects associated with the development phase are yet to be determined. The detailed environmental and social documentation will be prepared for the development phase of the project. It is envisaged that the ESIA will commence early next year and it will be fully consulted upon and disclosed in accordance with IFCs requirements

Company Name: BUSINESS PARTNERS INTERNATIONAL SOUTHERN AFRICA SME FUND
Project Description: The proposed investment involves an equity investment by IFC of up to $8 million in the Business Partners International Southern Africa SME Fund (the 'Project' or the 'Company'). The Fund is seeking to raise $40 million and will provide commercially sustainable financing and technical assistance to local SMEs in Malawi, Zambia, Zimbabwe and Namibia. The Fund will seek to invest in entrepreneurs who are building businesses that provide steady income for their families and serve unmet market demand in their local communities. Targeting this group of entrepreneurs maximizes the reach of the Fund, supports business growth in the selected countries, creates and sustains jobs, and helps to develop the local communities that family entrepreneurs are serving. These businesses must demonstrate viable business plans, sustainable market demand, and value-added management and operational capabilities.
Impact: The Fund will achieve developmental impact via:1) Providing investment options for SMEs to diversify and boost economic and social development;2) Encourage economic and private sector development in local communities, providing much needed equity capital for SMEs, and promoting job creation;3) Building institutional capacity of local companies through technical assistance programs; 4) Implementing best-practice corporate governance and social and environmental standards at the Fund and Investee level.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.   During appraisal, IFC analyzed the funds expected portfolio and sectors of investment, which include SMEs diversified across industry sectors and with transaction sizes between $50,000 and $1 million. E&S risks and impacts of SMEs typically financed by BP in other countries evolve around labor and working conditions, ensuring adequate occupational health and safety, and environmental issues such as effluents, waste and hazardous materials management. Based on the analysis of the potential social and environmental risks associated with the expected portfolio and considering IFCs investment, the IFC Exclusion List and the National laws and regulations have been determined as the Applicable Performance requirements for this project. IFC also reviewed BPIs existing Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS), and capacity to implement the same. It was found that while BP Southern Africa is a new Fund, existing BP Funds in which IFC has invested are in compliance with all E&S requirements, including the development and implementation of a ESMS, which will be utilized by BP Southern Africa. The quality of E&S due diligence undertaken and staff capacity of the existing BP Funds are also adequate, and the Funds are reporting regularly. As a category FI investment, and based on the review, the Fund will be required to (i) Provide a notification to IFC with regard to the adoption of the Environmental and Social Management System and the designation of the E&S Officer prior to commitment; (ii) Commit to implement the ESMS to ensure that its activities are in compliance with the Applicable Performance requirements; (iii) Provide E&S training to investment staff; and (vi) Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: The Sponsor is Business Partners International, established in 2004 as a joint venture between IFC and Business Partners Limited, a South African risk financier of SMEs. Based in Johannesburg, South Africa, Business Partners has made over 35,000 investments in SMEs in South Africa to the value of over $1.2 billion and has facilitated more than 500,000 employment opportunities.
Cost Nature: The Fund has a target equity investment of $40 million, of which IFC expects to invest up to $8 million in equity.

Project Description: IFC is considering a loan of up to $30 million to Armajaro Trading Group Limited (ATGL or Armajaro).  ATGL is an intermediary holding company and owns 100% of Armajaro Trading Limited (ATL), which was founded in 1998 and is an integrated supply chain manager of soft commodities including cocoa, coffee and, more recently, sugar. ATL aims to be partner of choice in the Agri-commodity supply chain. The proposed investment will scale up ATLs upcountry sourcing capabilities in the origin countries, improve its funding flexibility, strengthen its balance sheet and assist more farmers achieve sustainable farming practices.
Impact: The project''s development impact includes direct benefits to rural populations in many developing countries in Africa and Asia and a demonstration impact on sustainability and traceability initiatives. Some key impacts will be: 1)  increased number of farmers reached/trained, 2) improved E&S practices in the traceable portion of the supply chain 3)  improved farmers'' income through certification, training and improved access to market.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category A project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review due to the well documented significant adverse social (child labor) and environmental (conversion of habitat) supply chain risks associated with the production and trade of cocoa in West Africa and residual E&S risks. In such category A investments, IFC will continue to monitor the implementation of Armajaros procurement policy, and how Armajaro is making use of its environmental and social management system to ensure the inclusion of E&S issues into its supply chain management to avoid and mitigate impacts, and monitor progress in establishing better E&S practices across its supply chain. The implementation of the agreed measures ultimately guarantees that the companys operations are consistent with IFC Performance Standards and World Bank Group Environmental, Health and Safety General Guidelines (WBG General EHS Guidelines). Information about how the potential impacts will be addressed by Armajaro is summarized in the Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) and in the Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) agreed with the client.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is ATGL. It was incorporated in England in 2010 as an intermediary holding company to own 100% of ATL, which was founded in 1998. Armajaro Holdings Limited (AHL) is the group holding company. The majority of AHLs equity is owned by Mr. Anthony Ward (51%) and Mr. Richard Gower (44%). Both persons are co-founders and directors of AHL. The rest of the shares (5%) are owned by the staff and widow of the deceased former Chairman.
Cost Nature: IFC is considering a corporate loan up to $30 million. The proposed investment will scale up ATLs upcountry sourcing capabilities in the origin countries, improve its funding flexibility, strengthen its balance sheet and assist more farmers to achieve sustainable farming practices. In addition, the IFC African, Latin American and Caribbean Fund, managed by the IFC Asset Management Company, is also considering a $25 million corporate loan to ATL.

Company Name: ACWA POWER CF KARAD PV PARK EAD
Project Description: The Project (Karadzhalovo SPP) involves the development, construction, operation and maintenance of a 60.4 MWp solar photovoltaic power plant at Karadzhalovo in the municipality of Parvomay, Plovdiv District, Bulgaria. All of the output generated by the Project will be sold to the national electricity company, Natsionalna Elektricheska Kompania EAD (NEK), a 100% subsidiary of the Ministry of Energy, Economy and Tourism under a 20-year PPA that will provide for a fixed Feed In Tariff (FiT), expected to be BGN 485.6/MWh (equivalent to 248.3/MWh).
Impact: 1. Increasing Bulgaria''s renewable energy output, and helping the country meet its renewable energy targets, including by diversifying its renewable energy mix; 2. Associated displacement of thermal power, resulting in avoidance of carbon emissions; 3. Demonstration effect, showing the viability of financing a large SPP on a limited recourse basis, and proving the ongoing viability of the Bulgarian RE sector, given recent changes to the RE Law.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed investment in ZBE Partners EOOD is a category B project, reflecting a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that may result from the construction and operation of the of the photovoltaic power plant, and the short associated transmission line. However, these can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to recognized performance standards, guidelines, design criteria and specific mitigation measures recommended by the environmental assessment. The project site is located in the Maritsa Parvomay Natura 2000 protected zone. Detailed assessment of impacts on the protected zone was conducted. While the project site is located in the Maritsa Parvomay Natura 2000 protected zone, it is of no significant conservation or habitat value because (i) the project site (about 100 ha) is a small portion of the entire protected zone (about 1%), (ii) the project site had been converted to industrial use two (2) years before the establishment of the protected zone, and (iii) the environmental assessment shows that no sensitive species of fauna (avian or terrestrial) or flora will be affected.  Various parties, including environmental NGOs active in the conservation of protected zones in Bulgaria, were consulted during the environmental assessment, and no concerns were raised.  The hosting municipality is strongly supportive for the project. The Company will conduct a biodiversity monitoring program to confirm the result of the assessment.  An Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) listing key E&S mitigation measures and monitoring programs in line with IFC Performance Standards was agreed with the Company, the implementation of which IFC will monitor.

Project Description: IFC is considering providing a $30 million, 5-year unsecured corporate loan with warrants to Armajaro Trading Group Limited (ATGL or Armajaro).  ATGL is an intermediary holding company, which owns 100% of Armajaro Trading Limited (ATL), was founded in 1998, and is an integrated supply chain manager of soft commodities, including cocoa, coffee and, more recently, sugar. ATL aims to be the partner of choice in the agri-commodity supply chain. The proposed investment will scale up ATLs upcountry sourcing capabilities in the origin countries, improve its funding flexibility, strengthen its balance sheet and assist more farmers in achieving sustainable farming practices.In addition, the IFC African, Latin American and Caribbean Fund, managed by the IFC Asset Management Company, is also considering a $25 million corporate loan to ATL.
Review Scope: The scope of review of this corporate investment in Armajaro (or the Company) included site visits to Armajaro headquarters in London, England and at field operations in Ghana, Côte dIvoire and Vietnam. IFCs environmental and social review included the assessment of the Companys technical documentation regarding environmental, occupational health and safety, labor, and social performance of its direct operations and of its most relevant supply chains (coffee, cocoa, and sugar). Further information on the Environmental and Social (E&S) risks associated with the supply chain of key commodities (coffee, cocoa, sugar) traded by Armajaro was obtained from ILO and UNICEF websites, and through third party reports from a recognized environmental and social consultancy firm responding to IFC criteria. The due diligence of IFC environmental and social development specialists for this investment also benefited from a range of commodities related activities including participation in the World Cocoa Foundation Partnership Meeting in October 2010 where the need for engagement in a collaborative program with existing sustainability interventions to address social, environmental and productivity issues was recommended as well as  ongoing work by a team of IFC E&S specialists and investment officers to further define supply chain E&S issues and IFC Performance Standard requirements to address investments for traders.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: IFC has categorized this corporate investment as a Category A project, according to its Policy on Social and Environmental Sustainability. The rationale underlying this categorization is based on the well documented significant adverse social or environmental issues related to cocoa farming in West Africa, as described in PS2 (child labor) and PS 6 (conversion of natural/critical habitats leading to biodiversity loss), and the associated E&S residual risks given the characteristics of the supply chain. In such an investment, where the environment and social risks are largely in the supply chains, IFC will monitor the implementation of Armajaros business strategy with respect to commodity traceability and certification, review how Armajaro is making use of its environmental and social management systems in its supply chain management efforts, and monitor the companys performance against IFC Performance Standards and World Bank Group (WBG) General Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines. Notwithstanding IFCs ongoing monitoring and Armajaros own commitments, Armajaros ability to manage aspects of their supply chain in some geographical areas will be challenging and there can be no absolute guarantee that harmful child labor will not be present at the supplier level.Armajaros own operations have environmental and social risks and impacts that are limited in number, site specific, and addressable through known technology and/or procedures. Potential issues related to Armajaros direct operations include: labor practices and working conditions; occupational health and safety; effluent control; truck fleet safety and emissions management; pest management associated with storage of commodities; and food safety.

Company Name: ACWA POWER CF KARAD PV PARK EAD
Project Description: The project involves the development, construction, operation and maintenance of a 60.4 MWp (50MW-AC effective) solar photovoltaic power plant at Karadzhalovo in the municipality of Parvomay, Plovdiv District, Bulgaria (Karadzhalovo SPP or the Project).  The Project is owned by ZBE Partners EOOD (the Company), a special purpose vehicle that is ultimately 100% owned by SunEdison LLC, a leading global developer, EPC contractor and operator of utility scale, commercial and small size solar power systems.  All of the output generated by the Project will be sold to the national electricity company, Natsionalna Elektricheska Kompania EAD (NEK), a 100% subsidiary of the Ministry of Energy Economy and Tourism under a 20-year PPA.  IFC investment would be an IFC A Loan of 45 million and an IFC B Loan of up to 45 million which will be participated by UniCredit Bank Austria AG.The Project will have 42 photovoltaic blocks of variable capacity, and each block consists of a number of photovoltaic modules (solar sub-arrays) grouped in strings and connected to an AC/DC inverter transformer station.  Photovoltaic modules will be crystalline silicon (c-Si) based modules. The modules will be made up of a number of solar cells, with cell types either mono-crystalline or polycrystalline, both suitable and proven for large photovoltaic power plants. The 42 inverter stations will be connected through an internal 20kV underground network in a ring configuration which leads to a new 20/110kV substation to be built within the project site. The generated power will be transferred through a 7.5km 110kV underground transmission line (to be built as part of the Project) to NEKs existing Borisovgrad substationThe Project site is a 100 hectare land, formerly owned by the Parvomay Municipality and used for agricultural purposes in the past. The agricultural status of the project site was re-zoned under the Municipalitys Master Plan and the land was converted to industrial use in 2006. Through a public tender procedure initiated by the Parvomay Municipality, this land was transferred to INTERZONA Ltd. Plovdiv.  In September 2011, the land was sold to the Company for the Project.  The site is about 160 km southeast from the capital city Sofia, or about 9km east from the town center of Parvomay. The site is flat and easily accessible from Karadzhalovo Village. There is a railway passing adjacent to the site border (southside), but sufficient distance is kept to avoid any possible shading influence on the solar modules. The closest residence is about 500 m south from the project site. The construction of the Project started in September 2011 and is expected to finish by the spring of 2012.
Review Scope: Documents reviewed:- Report for Ecological Assessment, Detailed Development Plan for Change of Permanent Use of Regulated Land Plot I to Regulated Land Plot XXVII, Quarter 119 (Property #000119, According to the Map of Restored Ownership) in Karadzhalovo Village, Municipality of Parvomay, Plovdiv District with the Objective of Constructing a Photovoltaic Power Plant with Capacity of up to 50MW, Investor:  INTERZONA Ltd. Plovdiv, Contractor:  General partnership Hidroecostroy  Grozev and Partners, Plovdiv, March 2011- Report for Assessment of the Degree of Impact on Protected Zone Maritsa Parvomay by Detailed Development Plan for Change of Permanent Use of Regulated Land Plot I to Regulated Land Plot XXVII, Quarter 119 (Property #000119, According to the Map of Restored Ownership) in Karadzhalovo Village, Municipality of Parvomay, Plovdiv District with the Objective of Constructing a Photovoltaic Power Plant with Capacity of up to 50MW., Investor:  INTERZONA Ltd. Plovdiv, February 2011- Ecological Assessment Statement issued by RIEW on May 4, 2011- SunEdisons environmental and social due diligence documents for the Karadzhalovo Photovoltaic Power Project- SunEdisons corporate environmental and social management system information (obtained from IFCs earlier, related investment in SunEdison -- #28053)Site visits:  Visits to the project site, access road, connecting transmission line route, conducted by IFC staff in November 2011Meetings and Discussions in November 2011:- SunEdisons project team officers in charge of environmental and social assessment and management, including energy and environmental lawyers from Wolf Theiss law firm in Bulgaria (who conducted environmental legal due diligence at the request of SunEdison)- Karadzhalovo Photovoltaic Power Station construction management team officers (SunEdison, Sienit, ABB)- Municipality of Parvomay officials (including the Mayor and an officer in charge of land zoning)- Sienit Holding, the main EPC subcontractor and an affiliate of Interzona Ltd. Plovdiv, which initially handled environmental assessment and community engagement- Bulgarian Photovoltaic Associations representatives- Regional Inspectorate of Environment and Water  Plovdiv (RIEW Plovdiv)- An environmental organization (Green Balkans)- Lenders technical advisor (Fichtner GmbH + Co KG)
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project because only a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result from the construction and operation of the photovoltaic power plant and the short associated transmission line.  However, these can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to recognized performance standards, guidelines, design criteria and specific mitigation measures recommended by the environmental assessment.  While the project site is located in the Maritsa ParvomayNatura 2000 protected zone, it is of no significant conservation or habitat value because (i) the project site (about 100 ha) is a small portion of the entire protected zone (about 1%), (ii) the project site had been converted to industrial use two (2) years before the establishment of the protected zone and (iii) the environmental assessment shows that no sensitive species of fauna (avian or terrestrial) or flora will be affected.  The routing of the underground transmission line is mainly along the existing municipality roads with minimal environmental or social impacts.  One of the largest solar power plants in Europe, the Project will generate solar electricity contributing to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.

Project Description: The Project (SRLL) is a financial investment of up to $25 million in Super Religare Laboratories Limited (SRL or the Company). SRL, a leading provider of medical diagnostics services in India, was established in 1995 by Dr. Parvinder Singh. The Project will help SRL to optimize its capital structure by repaying existing debt and also support its expansion plans of opening new laboratories across India and, potentially, across several lower middle-income countries in Asia and Africa.
Impact: - SRL''s expansion plans include opening new laboratories across India including laboratories in several Low Income States and Tier II and Tier III cities, which will help improve the standard of medical facilities by providing advanced, high quality diagnostics services. - The Project will provide additional direct employment to more than 800 technically qualified professionals apart from generating indirect employment for close to 2,000 people through its collection centers and other allied downstream facilities. - The Project will provide standardized high quality diagnostics services in a fragmented industry, where the quality of diagnosis has a critical impact on the health of the population. - The Project will create new business opportunities for local companies, including small and medium enterprises that will be franchise partners and through training and development of franchise partners, help improve the overall quality of healthcare services.- SRL also plans to expand its laboratory network across several lower-middle income countries in Asia and Africa.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects. The key social and environmental issues associated with the Project include: adequacy of the social and environmental assessment of the construction and operations phases of the Project; implementation of social, environmental, health and safety management systems; assurance of fair, safe and healthy working conditions during construction and operations; efforts to minimize energy and water consumption; life and fire safety of the laboratories and clinics and management of wastes and emissions - especially the biomedical / hazardous waste disposal.  Further details on the potential environmental and social impacts of the project, corresponding mitigation measures and guidance on how and where information about the project is provided in the Environmental & Social Review Summary.

Mr. Malvinder Singh, Mr. Shivinder Singh (sons of Dr. Parvinder Singh) and family own 81.5% economic interest in Fortis Healthcare (India) Limited.

Project Description: SRL is the largest organized medical diagnostics service provider in India.  SRLs services include 1) pathology services; 2) radiology / imaging services; 3) wellness services; 4) clinical trial testing and 5) international operations.  As at September 2011, SRL operated a network of 8 reference laboratories, 168 pathology network laboratories, 18 radiology network centers, 19 wellness centers and 1,061 collection centers. IFC is considering a financial investment in SRL which will help SRL optimize its capital structure by repaying existing debt and also help finance the expansion of its radiology and pathology laboratories network across the country, over the next five years (Project).    SRLs expansion plans are relatively asset light with expansion through franchising and tapping the Fortis hospital network.
Review Scope: IFCs review of this investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety (EHS) related information submitted by Super Religare Laboratories Limited (SRL or the Company) including the Standard Operating Principles (SOPs), Human Resources Policies and Procedures, operational manuals and practices at a number of laboratories, regulatory permits including biomedical waste disposal agreements and monitoring records for liquid effluents. IFCs review also included discussions with the senior management and technical team at the Companys headquarters in Mumbai and site visits to reference, network, and specialized laboratories and  sample collection centers in Mumbai, Delhi and Gurgaon.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The operations of the Company involve a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. This is, therefore, a Category B project.

Project Description: Byblos Bank Armenia (the 'Bank' or the 'Company') has asked IFC for a long-term senior loan of up to $10 million to support its loan program for housing finance with particular emphasis on financing energy efficiency (EE) upgrades for households in Armenia. IFC shall provide advisory services to the Bank for technical training of credit officers and risk specialists in EE lending and training on E&S issues.Bank was originally established in Armenia in 1992 by a local group. In 2007 the Byblos Bank S.A.L (Byblos Lebanon) became 100% shareholder, renaming the bank into Byblos Bank Armenia Closed Joint Stock Company.
Impact: The project envisages partnering with a capable financial intermediary to provide residential energy efficiency loans to Armenian residents. Energy-efficiency improvements can play a critically important role in Armenia - a country without indigenous fossil energy resources and thus very dependent on imported fuel. IFC will also provide advisory support to Byblos Bank Armenia for development of energy efficiency product and related training.
Environmental Social Issues: This project consists of a senior loan to Byblos Armenia to be used for financing energy efficiency (EE) upgrades of residential households in Armenia. It has been classified as a Category C project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure with no further E&S requirements from the client.
Sponsor: In 2008, EBRD and OFID (The OPEC Found for International Development) acquired minority stakes in Byblos bank Armenia (EBRD- 25%, OFID-10%) while majority 65% stake remained with Byblos Bank S.A.L. (Lebanon).Byblos Bank S.A.L (Lebanon) is an international banking group established in 1950. It is the third largest bank in Lebanon with a market share of 12% in terms of total assets.  Its core business is commercial banking, followed by retail and investment operations.  Byblos has a strong domestic branch network with over 76 branches and located overseas in Luxembourg, France, UK, Cyprus, Sudan, Syria, Armenia, UAE, Iraq, Nigeria, and Congo. International expansion is an integral part of Byblos's strategy which aimed to help the bank to be a leading Lebanese bank with an interregional presence.  Byblos is an IFC client since 1993 and IFC currently holds equity in the Bank with a stake of 8.4%.

Project Description: The proposed project is an investment in Pragati India Fund Limited, an SME focused fund that will focus on the economically under-developed low income states ('LIS') of India such as Bihar, Jharkhand, Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh and Orissa. IFC's support to the company will help Pragati to partner with existing businesses, entrepreneurs and managers who have demonstrated execution ability. Pragati's investment strategy is to expand into low income states and rural regions where changing political, social and economic development dynamics offer new opportunities that are largely untapped. The regional orientation provides opportunities in early stage investments which leverage ideas that are successful elsewhere in the Indian context and adapt them to suit local conditions.
Impact: The team expects high development in the following areas:1. Flow of private capital to LIS - Focus of the Fund's investments will be for the benefit of companies and projects in LIS2. Support of SMEs - The target investee companies will be small to medium enterprises3. Private sector development - The target companies will benefit from value-added practices that include increased corporate governance, environmental and social standards and transparency.4. Accelerated growth - Providing advice and risk capital to enable faster growth in portfolio companies. 5. Job creation - Supporting high growth companies which will reach the bottom of the pyramid and create employment at a faster rate than the national average.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves IFC investment in a private equity fund and has been classified as Category FI. The likely environmental and social (E&S) risk of this project is that the impacts of sub-projects are not always adequately identified and managed. The Applicable Performance Requirements for the sub-projects financed by the fund includes: IFC FI Exclusion List, the applicable host country E&S laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards.  As a new IFC client, the fund managers E&S management capacity is not fully known.  IFC understands that the fund has adopted the CDCs toolkit on ESG for Fund Managers, but the same has not come into implementation yet. As part of IFC''s investment, the fund will be required to upgrade the current E&S risk management process (EGS Toolkit) to be benchmarked to the requirements of IFC Performance Standards, including enhancing the existing environmental and social management capacity, to manage these E&S risks.The Fund Manager will be required to: develop a Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS), prior to subscription to the satisfaction of IFC and commit to implement the SEMS to ensure that its investments/activities are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements; identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the SEMS; and submit a periodic report to IFC.  IFC will also review the implementation and performance of the fund''s SEMS for the first few projects and all Category A projects, if any, prior to the fund''s investment, to ensure the fund''s SEMS is adequate to assess and manage E&S risks.

The Investment Manager will enter into an investment advisory agreement with Pragati Equity Advisors Pvt. Ltd. ('Investment Advisor' or the 'Company'), a company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, 1956.
Cost Nature: Pragati India Fund has a target fund size of $75-100 million. IFC is proposing an equity investment of up to $20 million or 20% of the Fund's total committed capital.

Project Description: The project entails an IFC revolving loan to Finsch diamond mine in South Africa ('Finsch' or the 'Project'),  which is 74% owned by Petra Diamonds Limited ('Petra' or the 'Company'). The financing, that will be provided jointly by IFC and a South African Bank (Rand Merchant Bank), will enable Petra to: (i) finance the Finsch mine expansion program; (ii) strengthen Petra's overall liquidity position following its move to the London Stock Exchange ('LSE') main-board; and, (iii) fund other general corporate requirements (through repayment of intercompany loans) (collectively, the 'Project').On January 21, 2011, Petra entered into an agreement to acquire Finsch from De Beers Consolidated Mines Limited for 1.425 billion South African Rand (about $210 million), that was fully financed by a 205 million Great British pounds (about $325 million) equity-raising. The transaction was completed on September 14, 2011, with Petra assuming management (including production, revenues and cash flow) at the mine.Finsch is one of the world's major diamond mines with a resource base of 43.3 million carats ('Mcts'), of which 25.8 Mcts are in the reserve category. Finsch produced an average of approximately 2 Mcts per annum over the five years to 2010, from a combination of underground mining and tailings retreatment and has produced 126 Mcts in its 40-plus year life to date. The mine has a new order mining right valid until 2038. Finsch is expected to more than double Petra's annual production, contributing about 1.5 Mcts per annum to Petra's production, rising to nearly 2 Mcts per annum by 2018. Finsch adds an eighth producing mine to the Petra group, consolidating Petra's position as London's largest quoted diamond mining group and provided a strong platform for the company's  move to the LSE main-board in December 2011.Petra will implement a development plan to increase production from 1.5 Mcts per annum to 2 Mcts per annum by 2018, by gradually opening up Block 5 below the current Block 4 operations, supported by a surface tailings treatment program. Production levels from underground will be maintained during the transition from Block 4 to Block 5 by developing smaller sub-level caves within the Precursor ore body (adjacent to the main ore body) at Block 4 and within Block 5 itself. Petra foresees a long life for the operation and has a current mine plan of 18 years, though the ore body remains open-ended at depth.The Finsch capital expenditure over the next six years for the underground and infrastructure development program is estimated to be approximately $330 million and is expected to be financed by a combination of debt and internal cash generation. The proposed revolving loan facility will allow Petra to fully fund the projected capital expenditure programs for the next two years and withstand unfavorable variations in cash flows.
Impact: A strategic priority of South Africa's Medium Term Strategic Framework (2009-2014) is the creation of employment opportunities. The framework also specifically recognizes the economic contributions from mineral extraction and processing, and the need for support for continued expansion in the sector. The Finsch expansion, which contemplates the long-term and economic sustainability of a 44-year old mine, will support this government objective, by increasing production from 1.5 Mcts per annum to 2 Mcts per annum and extending the mine life from three to 18 years, thereby promoting sustainable development in a frontier region of South Africa. More specifically, the development impact from the Finsch expansion is expected to include:(i) Employment: Successful implementation of the Finsch expansion will help maintain the aggregate number of direct and indirect jobs and potentially create opportunities for further employment.(ii) Fiscal Contributions: Petra anticipates Finsch to start generating royalty payments immediately and become a tax paying entity by 2014. As per IFC requirements, Petra has agreed to publicly disclose all material revenue payments made to the South African government.(iii) Community Development: Finsch already contributes directly towards community development through the provisioning of social, commercial and industrial infrastructures.(iv) Support to Local SMEs: A large proportion of Finsch's procurement is expected to be from South African suppliers, of which a significant percentage is expected to be from local and regional suppliers. Finsch is committed to supplier development and training, and expects to allocate a portion of its community development expenditure to such initiatives.
Environmental Social Issues: Petra is an existing IFC client with good environmental and social performance. The company is committed to meeting good international industry practice through compliance with the IFC Performance Standards as well as adherence to the strong, well enforced South African environmental laws, regulations and requirements. In particular, the Mineral Resources and Petroleum Development Act (MPRDA) of 2002 and the National Environmental Management Act (NEMA) of 1998 are both used to guide practice, as well as various international best practice standards.Finsch, like all other Petra operations, has in place an Environmental Management plan (EMP), which has been developed based on regulatory requirements and the site specific conditions at Finsch. The EMP is a legally binding document for which performance is regularly reviewed. Finsch is also IS14001 and OHSAS 18001 certified. Finsch operations were found to be broadly in compliance with the IFC Performance Standards from observations during the pre-appraisal visit and data provided by the company.Finsch is an existing brownfield mine and the IFC investment will only fund deeper underground development within the same surface footprint. Thus the investment will not result in any significant new impacts. Pre-existing Environmental, Health and Safety and Social (EHSS) management issues associated with the Finsch project include dust control, waste management; water management; public safety, hazardous materials management and mitigation of transportation risks on roads leading to the site. The appraisal considered any impacts the expansion may cause, especially with regard to sustainability of water resources, mining and mineral processing waste handling and occupational health and safety though any such impacts are expected to be minor and therefore relatively easily mitigated as part of the environmental management plan.Thus, this is a Category B project according to IFCs procedures for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because the project only involves underground expansion of an existing brownfield site, within the same footprint, by an existing IFC client with good EHSS performance and therefore has limited adverse impacts and risks which are manageable.
Sponsor: Petra is a producer of rough diamonds, with a gross resource base of circa 300 Mcts. Petra's operations comprise a number of diamond mines acquired in recent years from De Beers, S.A. and the company is one of only a handful of publicly-traded pure-play diamond producers worldwide. Petra has interests in seven producing South African mines (Cullinan, Finsch, Koffiefontein, Kimberley Underground, Helam, Sedibeng and Star), one Tanzanian mine (Williamson) and one Botswana exploration project (Kalahari). Petra was previously quoted on the Alternative Investment Market (AIM), which is the LSE's international market for smaller growing companies, but moved to the LSE main-board in December 2011.Petra's 74% stake in Finsch is held through a subsidiary, Afropean Diamonds (Proprietary) Limited ('Afropean'). Petra is the Sponsor of the Project and Afropean is the borrower. The remaining 26% stake in Finsch is held by Petra's Black Economic Empowerment partners, including: Senakha Diamonds Investments (Proprietary) Limited ('Senakha' 21%) and the Petra Diamonds Employee Share Trust (5%). Senakha is a shelf company set up specifically to house Petra's BEE partners on the Finsch transaction, and its shareholders are: Sedibeng Mining (Proprietary) Limited (81%), Namoise Mining (Proprietary) Limited (9.5%) and Lexshell 844 Investments (Proprietary) Limited (9.5%).Petra has undertaken to work only in countries that are members of the Kimberley Process. The Kimberley Process is a joint government, industry and civil society initiative to stem the flow of conflict diamonds. The Kimberley Process Certification Scheme imposes extensive requirements on its members to enable them to certify shipments of rough diamonds as 'conflict-free'. As of December 2009, the Kimberley Process has 49 members, representing 75 countries.
Cost Nature: The estimated total project cost (excluding financing costs) is $170 million and reflects Petra's budget for its expansion program at Finsch in South Africa to be implemented over the next two years. The proposed IFC investment of up to $25 million, is a senior secured two-year revolving loan to Finsch, through Afropean, Petra's 74% owned subsidiary. The revolving loan facility will be used to fund Finsch's mine expansion program, strengthen Petra's overall liquidity and fund other general corporate requirements, through repayment of intercompany loans.
Investment: 25.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan25.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Finsch mine is situated approximately 165 km North West of Kimberley in the Northern Cape Province of South Africa. It is a fully-staffed operation and the associated assets include over 800 housing units in a well-established town. The mine is an underground block cave diamond mine with state-of-the-art mining infrastructure, including a modern processing plant which was recently upgraded at a total cost of about $100 million.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Petra is an existing IFC client with good environmental and social performance. The company is committed to meeting good international industry practice through compliance with the IFC Performance Standards as well as adherence to the strong, well enforced South African environmental laws, regulations and requirements. In particular, the Mineral Resources and Petroleum Development Act (MPRDA) of 2002 and the National Environmental Management Act (NEMA) of 1998 are both used to guide practice, as well as various international best practice standards.Finsch, like all other Petra operations, has in place an Environmental Management plan (EMP), which has been developed based on regulatory requirements and the site specific conditions at Finsch. The EMP is a legally binding document for which performance is regularly reviewed. Finsch is also IS14001 and OHSAS 18001 certified. Finsch operations were found to be broadly in compliance with the IFC Performance Standards from observations during the pre-appraisal visit and data provided by the company.Finsch is an existing brownfield mine and the IFC investment will only fund deeper underground development within the same surface footprint. Thus the investment will not result in any significant new impacts. Pre-existing Environmental, Health and Safety and Social (EHSS) management issues associated with the Finsch project include dust control, waste management; water management; public safety, hazardous materials management and mitigation of transportation risks on roads leading to the site. The appraisal considered any impacts the expansion may cause, especially with regard to sustainability of water resources, mining and mineral processing waste handling and occupational health and safety though any such impacts are expected to be minor and therefore relatively easily mitigated as part of the environmental management plan.Thus, this is a Category B project according to IFCs procedures for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because the project only involves underground expansion of an existing brownfield site, within the same footprint, by an existing IFC client with good EHSS performance and therefore has limited adverse impacts and risks which are manageable.

Project Description: The project entails an IFC revolving loan to Finsch Diamond Mine in South Africa (Finsch), which is 74% owned by Petra Diamonds Limited (Petra). The financing, that will be provided jointly by IFC and a South African Bank (Rand Merchant Bank), will enable Petra to: finance the Finsch mine expansion program; strengthen Petras overall liquidity position following its move to the London Stock Exchange (LSE) main-board; and, fund other general corporate requirements (through repayment of intercompany loans) (collectively, the Project). Petra was publicly listed on the Alternative Investment Market (AIM), which is the LSEs international market for smaller growing companies, but moved to the LSE main-board in December 2011.Finsch was acquired by Petra from De Beers Consolidated Mines Limited (De Beers) in September 2011 after which Petra assumed full management of the mine. The acquisition of Finsch increases Petras mines to eight (Cullinan, Koffiefontein, Kimberley Underground, Finsch, Sedibeng, Star and Helam in South Africa, and Williamson in Tanzania). Petra is an existing IFC client and IFC was involved in financing Petras Williamson Diamond Limited expansion programme in Tanzania and exploration concessions in Botswana. Petra will implement a development plan at Finsch to increase production from 1.5 million carats (Mcts) per annum to 2 Mcts per annum by 2018, by gradually opening up Block 5 below the current Block 4 operations, supported by a surface tailings treatment program. Production levels from underground will be maintained during the transition from Block 4 to Block 5 by developing smaller sub-level caves within the Precursor ore body (adjacent to the main ore body) at Block 4 and within Block 5 itself. Petra foresees a long life for the operation and has a current mine plan of 18 years, though the ore body remains open-ended at depth.Finschs expansion programme entails deeper underground development within the same surface footprint and with no increase to this footprint. One of the challenges related to this expansion programme is securing sufficient water resources to supply the proposed expansion without impacting negatively on the needs of the local (predominantly farming) communities. Any impacts that may arise as part of the mine expansion project will be addressed through the EMPR amendment exercise that the mine commissioned in July 2011. Finsch is situated in the Kgatelopele Local Municipality within Siyanda District Municipality in Northern Cape Province of South Africa. The mine is located approximately 165 km northwest of Kimberley, with Lime Acres approximately 3.5 km to the northeast, Danielskuil 30 km to the north-northeast and Papkuil 31 km to the southeast. The majority of Finsch workforce lives in Lime Acres and Danielskuil; Lime Acres was built and is run for the employees of Finsch and Pretoria Portland Cement (PPC) which is situated adjacent to the mine. Danielskuil also houses employees from PPC. According to the 2001 census, Lime Acres had a population of nearly 7 000 and Danielskuil had nearly 9 000 against a total of almost 21 000 for Siyanda District Municipality. The Northern Cape has the smallest economy of the nine provinces in South Africa for which Siyanda District Municipality accounts for about 30%. The major economic activities and sources of employment in this frontier region of South Africa are mining and agriculture; tourism is the fastest growing sector. Unemployment is high and economic opportunities limited.The mine is surrounded by several farms and the PPC Lime operations. There are no perennial surface water systems located or traversing the mine property and the pre-mining land capability is classified as extensive grazing land. Soil depth limits most of the areas agricultural potential and when combined with the erratic and unpredictable rainfall, the land is considered most suited to conservation/wilderness land. Thus with the acquisition of Finsch and surrounding properties in 1962, De Beers initiated a wildlife conservation policy, which resulted in sections of properties being enclosed by a game fence and the areas being managed as game farms.Diamonds were first discovered at Finsch in 1930. Mining commenced in 1964, when a treatment and recovery plant was erected at the pipe. Initial operations were by means of open pit mining to a depth of 430m in 1992, where-after an open stoping underground method was used to a depth of 530m. The current method is by means of block-caving technology. The mine has one main shaft in which two 28-ton skips are used solely for ore hoisting, while two personnel elevators also operate in this shaft. The treatment process used at Finsch consists of three basic stages: ore preparation by crushing, washing and screening; concentration of the sized material and preparation by means of Dense Media Separation; and sorting. Old residue deposits are also reprocessed to recover residual diamonds. Diamonds extracted from Finsch are generally 60% of industrial quality and 40% of gem quality.Finschs current surface operational areas consist of a processing plant area, headgear infrastructure, workshops, administration infrastructure, waste rock dumps, two coarse residue deposit facilities (CRDs) and three fine residue deposit facilities (FRDs). There are four residential areas in the town, a clinic, shops and schools. This infrastructure is linked with Eskom power lines, tar and gravel roads, a local airstrip, and the Kimberley/Sishen railway line which passes about 1.5 km to north of the mine.
Review Scope: The review of this Project consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health, safety and social information submitted by the company, and assessing the companys operations by a field visit conducted by the project team. Key focus was a review of management systems and organization, including review of Finsch Diamond Mines approved Environmental Management Programme Reports (EMPRs) - the South African equivalent of an Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) for mining projects, and their associated Performance Assessments Reports; approved Social and Labour Plan (SLP); Rehabilitation and Closure Plans; and key monitoring data. The team visited the mine on the 10th of November 2011, and met key mine representatives. Field visits were organized to different parts of the mining areas as well as to ancillary infrastructure. Various discussions were also held with key representatives from Petra Diamonds Limited.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Petra has good environmental and social performance (ESRR 2 on both IFC existing investments). The company is committed to meeting good international industry practice through compliance with the IFC Performance Standards as well as adherence to the strong, well enforced South African environmental laws, regulations and requirements. In particular, the Mineral Resources and Petroleum Development Act (MPRDA) of 2002 and the National Environmental Management Act (NEMA) of 1998 are both used to guide practice, as well as various international best practice standards.Finsch, like all other Petra operations, has in place an Environmental Management System (EMS), which was developed by De Beers based on regulatory requirements and the site specific conditions at Finsch. The EMPR is a legally binding document for which performance is regularly reviewed. Finsch is also ISO 14001 and OHSAS 18001 certified. Finsch operations were found to be already broadly in compliance with the IFC Performance Standards from observations during the site visit and data provided by the company. Finsch is an existing brownfield mine and the IFC investment will only fund deeper underground development within the same surface footprint. Thus, the investment will not result in any significant new impacts. Pre-existing Environmental, Health and Safety and Social (EHSS) management issues associated with the Finsch project include dust control, waste management, including management of mine residue deposits; water management; public safety, hazardous materials management and mitigation of transportation risks on roads leading to the site. The existing and approved EMPR is in the process of being recompiled in line with updated legal requirements and will identify and manage any environmental aspects that may arise as part of the mine expansion project. The most significant direct social impact associated with this project is positive and involves the protection of employment for the workforce for an expected further 18 years as well as their dependents and people employed by businesses supporting the mine. Whilst difficult to quantify at this stage, there will be new job opportunities during the expansion programme although a large part of the expansion project can be outsourced from the local area. The Siyanda District Municipality and the communities in the Kgatelopele Local Municipality area will benefit from the employment, vocational training and community development potential, which will be implemented through the Finsch expansion. Petra has a strong commitment to achieve demonstrable socio-economic improvements in the communities in areas where it operates.Thus, this is a Category B project according to IFCs procedures for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because the project only involves underground expansion of an existing brownfield site, within the same footprint, by an existing IFC client with good EHSS performance and therefore has limited adverse impacts and risks which are manageable. The project requires a public disclosure period of at least 30 days prior to consideration by the IFC Board.

Project Description: The proposed IFC support ('Grameen Phone V' or the 'Project') is a financial package of up to $300 million, comprising an A Loan and Parallel Loans to finance the medium term capital expenditures program of GrameenPhone Limited ('GP' or the 'Company') for the 2012-2014 period. The capital expenditure program includes network and capacity expansion, technological advancement, energy efficiency initiatives and improvement of services.
Impact: Bangladesh is an IDA country with nominal GDP per capita of around $550 for 2009. The country has one of the lowest teledensities (only 42%) and highest subscriber growth in the world.  Since 2006, total number of subscribers has increased from 20 million to more than 65 million, with a significant impact on the economy in terms of aggregate investment, employment and productivity levels, particularly in rural areas. By further investing in network development, offering improved connectivity and additional services, GP will continue to assist Bangladesh to build its competitive strength. The Project will also enhance competition in the sector, leading other mobile operators to invest further in their networks, thereby increasing availability and improving the quality of cellular services and lower tariffs.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects. Key risks and issues related to this Project include the Company''s systems, capacity and staffing to ensure that its operations are undertaken in a manner consistent with IFC PSs; fair, safe and healthy working conditions for the Company''s staff as well as the contractors'' workforce; utilization of equipment and operational practices that maximizes conservation of energy, water; management of air emissions, and solid and electronic/hazardous waste disposal; and mitigation of risks and impacts on community health, safety, security and transport infrastructure during construction and operation. Further details on the potential environmental and social impacts of the project, corresponding mitigation measures and guidance on how and where information about the project are provided in the Environmental & Social Review Summary.
Sponsor: GP is the largest mobile phone operator in Bangladesh, with 35 million subscribers and a market share of approximately 44% as of October 2011.  It operates a GSM digital network in the 900MHz and 1800MHz frequency bands. GP has been a market leader in introducing new products and services in Bangladesh, including the installation of approximately 5,000 kms of optical fiber alongside railway and highways.  This fiber ensures nation-wide transmission backbone (the largest in the country) as well as technological redundancy. GP is publicly listed on the Dhaka and Chittagong stock exchanges.GP's largest shareholders are Telenor AS with 55.8% shareholding and Grameen Telecom with 34.2% shareholding. Telenor is the Norwegian state-owned carrier, with more than 135 million mobile subscribers in Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Hungary, Serbia, Montenegro, Thailand, Malaysia, Pakistan, India and Bangladesh, and 93 million mobile subscribers in 19 markets through its ownership in VimpelCom Ltd.  Grameen Telecom is a non-profit organization, wholly owned by Grameen Bank, the internationally acclaimed microfinance pioneer in Bangladesh. Both shareholders have a deep commitment to GP and its mission to provide affordable telephony to the entire population of Bangladesh.  The remaining 10% shares of the Company are owned by the general public and other institutional shareholders.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at around $1.1 billion. The proposed IFC investment is a financial package of up to $300 million, comprising of a senior A Loan and Parallel Loans.

Project Description: The A&C Square is an existing one-stop mixed-use concept consisting of a shopping mall, a fuel station, fitness centre, two multi-purpose office buildings, a pool area and a childrens play ground.  The mixed-use development has an ongoing expansion program. IFC has been approached to provide a loan that will be used to fast track the completion of the expansion program comprising the construction of an additional office block and the refurbishment of the existing retail area (the Project) in Accra, Ghana.
Impact: i) Development of necessary business infrastructure:  The Project will alleviate the country''s critical lack of class A office space and it will improve retail services to meet the country''s growing population; ii)  Job creation: The new office building will create new direct and indirect employment both during the permanent stage and during construction; iii) Benefit to local suppliers:  Local procurement of construction supplies, food and services throughout construction; andiv) Skills transfer: there will be the transfer of skill and expertise in the construction and renovation of the mall and office building to the local workers

Project Description: The Project ('Continental Automotive Thailand Ltd') is a green field manufacturing facility in Thailand, with a production capacity of 500,000 high pressure pumps and 2,500,000 injectors per year. These pumps and injectors are used in Continental's high-precision Piezo common rail systems, which in turn are used in its diesel-based Powertrain engine systems. Continental sells the complete system, which consists of the Piezo injector, the pump, the fuel rail, and the engine control unit, to Original Equipment Manufacturers. Diesel engines consume about 30% less fuel than gasoline engines do. Further, Piezo technology produces fuel savings of up to 5% relative to other diesel engines, reduces particulate and nitrogen emissions and makes engines quieter without any loss of performance. These components fulfill EURO 6 emission standards which will apply in Europe from 2014 onwards. The Project aims at supplying injectors for passenger with diesel engines. The Project is an important step taken by the Sponsor to expand its manufacturing base in Asia in order to support the growth of its clients' fuel efficient vehicle sales in the region.
Impact: 1.	Climate change: The Project involves the manufacturing of high pressure pumps, a key component of the Piezo common rail system. Continental is a pioneer of diesel technology and is the market leader for Piezo Common Rail Technology, which will promote adherence to EURO 6 emission standards, which will be mandatory from 2014. This new technology will lower carbon dioxide emissions by over 15% relative to regional standards, and by 5% relative to world-class standards. Assuming that half of the CO2 savings are attributable to the injection system , the Industry Specialist calculates CO2 emissions reduction of 17 g/km per vehicle attributable to the use of the Piezo common rail technology. With an annual mileage of 30,000 km, a lifetime of 10 years per vehicle and a production of 145,030 vehicles in 2011, total estimated CO2 savings is 739,650 tons in 2011.2.	Technology transfer and enhancing Thailand's competitiveness: The Project will increase the competitiveness of the Thai automotive sector through the transfer of best practices and managerial and technological know-how. Innovation and high-tech manufacturing processes will support Thailand's transition to a developed country status. Historically, the development of the auto sector, including the export of high-value components, has played a significant role in the economic transformation, as exemplified by Japan, Korea and Taiwan.3.	Generation of highly skilled labor: The Project will generate approximately 780 jobs. Continental is committed to developing and strengthening its employees' technical expertise. All newly recruited engineers from Thailand attend a one year training program at its headquarters in Germany. 4.	Support of local suppliers: This Project will require local suppliers to improve their quality and will generate around EUR40 million of local purchases annually by 2014. We estimate that over 1,000 employment opportunities could also be created within the local supply chain. Continental is situated close to its supply base and provides regular inputs to improve quality through internal audits and supplier evaluation.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects. Key E&S risks and issues related to project include: assessment and mitigation of the impacts of the Project; the Companys capacity to manage its social, environmental, health and safety performance, and engage with local communities in accordance with local requirements and IFC Performance Standards and applicable guidelines; assurance of fair, safe and healthy working conditions; utilization of equipment and operational practices that maximizes conservation of energy, water and process materials including recycling and reuse initiatives; management of waste emissions and discharge; handling and management of hazardous materials and hazardous wastes; and the impacts of operations on local ambient environment. Further details on the potential environmental and social impacts of the project, corresponding mitigation measures and guidance on how and where information about the project are provided in the Environmental & Social Review Summary.
Sponsor: The Project Sponsor is Continental AG, a worldwide automotive supplier of a broad range of electronic systems and components, tires and non-tire rubber products, founded and headquartered in Germany. Continental AG generated revenues of about 26 billion in 2010 and has approximately 164,000 employees across 45 countries globally.Continental AG indirectly holds 99% of the shares of the Continental Automotive (Thailand) Co., Ltd (the 'Company'). In compliance with Thai law, which requires a minimum of three shareholders, the remaining 1% is held by three individuals, all employees of Continental Group.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated to be about 180 million, to be funded via 87 million in equity from the Sponsor, 13 million in intercompany loans, a 10 million working capital loan and the proposed IFC investment. The proposed IFC investment consists of a  35 million A loan for IFC's own account and a 35 million B loan syndicated facility.

Project Description: The Project Sponsor is Continental AG ('Sponsor'), a worldwide automotive supplier of a broad range of electronic systems and components, tires and non-tire rubber products, founded and headquartered in Hanover, Germany. Continental AG generated revenues of about 26 billion in 2010 and has approximately 164,000 employees across 45 countries globally.The Project involves development of a green field manufacturing facility in Thailand with a production capacity of 500,000 high pressure pumps and 2,500,000 injectors per year ('Continental Automotive Thailand Ltd'). These pumps and injectors are used in Continental's high-precision Piezo common rail systems, which in turn are used in its diesel-based Powertrain engine systems. Continental sells the complete system, which consists of the Piezo injector, the pump, the fuel rail, and the engine control unit, to Original Equipment Manufacturers (OEMs). IFC is considering a debt financing for this Project.The Project is located in Amata City Industrial Estate near Rayong on the eastern seaboard of Thailand, strategically located 27 kilometers from Laem Chabang Deep Sea Port and 114 kilometers from Bangkok. Established in 1995, Amata City is known as a premier industrial estate in Thailand that functions as a complete town  housing both residential and industrial areas. Amata City has implemented Environmental Management Systems certified compliant with ISO 14001.  The Company purchased the fully developed industrial land for this project in Amata City in 2007. The facility has a built-up area of 25,400 sqm on the total land area of 50,000 sqm. The Project became operational in June 2009.
Review Scope: IFC's review of this proposed investment consisted of appraising technical, environment, safety, security, health (ESH) and social related information submitted by  Continental Automotive (Thailand) Co., Ltd. (hereinafter referred to as 'Continental' or 'Company') including its ESH policy, organization chart, ESH management system manual, management system audit report, human resources (HR) policies and procedures; training records; environmental monitoring reports; hazardous materials manifests; emergency action plan, etc. The appraisal also included site visit to Continental's operational manufacturing facility in Rayong, Thailand and discussions with Continental's senior management, technical and EHS team.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFC's Procedure for Environmental and Social (E&S) Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards and guidelines.Key E&S risks and issues related to project include: assessment and mitigation of the impacts of the Project; the Company's capacity to manage its social, environmental, health and safety performance, and engage with local communities in accordance with local requirements and IFC Performance Standards and applicable guidelines; assurance of fair, safe and healthy working conditions; utilization of equipment and operational practices that maximizes conservation of energy, water and process materials including recycling and reuse initiatives; management of waste emissions and discharge; handling and management of hazardous materials and hazardous wastes; and the impacts of operations on local ambient environment.

Project Description: A&C Development Company Limited (A&C Development or the Company) is a privately held real estate development company based in Accra, Ghana. The A&C Square was conceived as a one-stop mall concept consisting of a shopping mall, a fuel station, fitness centre/office block building, a pool area, two multi-purpose business plazas and a childrens play ground.  The first phase of the project comprising the shopping mall and an adjacent fuel station was built over 4 years (commissioned in 2006). The second phase, or the expansion, which started in 2007 included fitness center/office block, pool block, childrens playground area and Business Plaza I (an office block) all of which were completed by May 2010. The proposed IFC loan will be used to fast track the completion of the third phase or expansion program of the A&C Mixed Use Complex (A&C Square) comprising the construction of an additional office blocks (Business Plaza II) and the refurbishment of the existing retail area (A&C Mixed Use or the Project).
Review Scope: IFC''s review for this project included meetings with the management team of A&C Development Co; the executive team of the property management company in charge of the existing A&C Square development; and the design team, including representatives from the architects and the refrigeration and air conditioning engineers. In addition, a visit to the existing A&C Square which includes the site of the proposed project was conducted. The following information was also reviewed: (i) responses to an IFC environmental and social appraisal questionnaire; (ii) existing operation licenses including Fire and Safety inspections by local authorities; (iii) contractual documentation between A&C Development and the management company and other contractors; and (iv) A&C Developments human resources policies and procedures. The proposed project is in an early planning stage; therefore, detailed information on the design and environmental assessment of the project will be reviewed as the information become available.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure because of the limited number of possible adverse impacts,  the site specific nature of these possible impacts, and that these potential impacts can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, procedures, guidelines or design criteria.  Key environmental and social issues of this project include impacts during both construction and operation of the project; the following potential impacts were analyzed: (i) site location in an urban setting; (ii) identification of environmental and social impacts; (iii) life and fire safety aspects of project design and operation; (iv) management systems in place to address environmental and social issues; (v) labor and working conditions, including occupational health and safety of employees and construction contractors; (vi) solid waste management and disposal; (vii) tenants and visitors health and safety issues such as potable water and emergency response;  and (viii) refrigerant selection.

Project Description: The Project ('ENDA II') consists of IFC providing support to an existing client in the form of local currency financing to ENDA Inter-Arabe ('ENDA' or the 'Company'). ENDA is Tunisia's only private sector microfinance institution, having more than 190,000 clients, of which 70% are women as of November 2011. Average loan size is $600. ENDA's micro credit operations commenced in 1995.
Impact: - Access to Finance for Micro-Entrepreneurs:  This project will also allow ENDA to increase the outreach of its lending operations.  With an existing average loan size of US$600 and an average maturity of eleven months, this project would enable ENDA to provide over 45,000 such loans during the tenor of the credit line expected to be up to five years.- Improved Economic and Social Livelihoods:  The planned expanded outreach of ENDA's credit activities is expected to have a significant and positive impact on its clients' livelihoods.  The provision of credit services empowers micro-entrepreneurs to take a proactive approach to improving their economic well-being.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. During appraisal, IFC analyzed ENDA''s portfolio, for types of transactions, size, tenor and industry sectors and determined the Applicable Performance Requirements based on an analysis of the potential Social and Environmental risks associated with the portfolio and considering IFCs investment. The Applicable Performance Requirements are: - The IFC Microfinance Exclusion List. This is a repeat project with ENDA, IFC also reviewed the existing Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS), and the capacity to implement the same. As a result of the latest supervision visit, it was found that the Environmental and Social Risk Rating is "F2-Average" and the client demonstrated satisfactory capacity to manage E&S risks according to the applicable requirements in previous investment.Based on the Applicable Performance Requirements and capacity review, the project will be required to: (i)  Prior to commitment, finalize the internal approval of the Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS) to the satisfaction of IFC;(ii) Prior to commitment, notify IFC of the identified responsible, qualified person to manage and implement the SEMS;(iii) Prior to disbursement, provide evidence of implementing the SEMS, to ensure that its investments/activities are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements;(iv) Demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions; and(v) Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: ENDA is an international and foreign NGO member of the ENDA Tiers-Monde network which is present in more than 20 countries and based in Dakar, Senegal.  Established in 1989, ENDA started to provide microcredit to the poor in Tunisia in 1995. It now has an established network of 65 branches/outlets throughout the northern, southern and central parts of Tunisia.  ENDA is a founder member of Sanabel, the Network of microfinance in the Arab countries.
Cost Nature: The total project consists of a local currency loan of up to 10 million Tunisian dinar ($7 million) of up to 5 years to support its microfinance activities. An Advisory Services package with ENDA is also underway, focusing on Risk Management and institution building.
