Project Description: The proposed project is to provide a senior loan of up to $3 million equivalent to Microcredit Organization Arnur Credit LLP (the Company), one of the leading commercial microfinance institutions in Kazakhstan. Proceeds of the loan will be used to finance the expansion of the Companys lending activities to micro and small entrepreneurs (the Project). Arnur Credit currently seeks long-term funding to continue its dynamic growth and continue offering existing and new products to its target clientele. Arnur Credit is one of the leading microfinance organizations operating in the southern region of Kazakhstan and serves more than 6,000 clients, of which 40% are women, through its network of 38 branches. Arnur Credit provides a range of products to its clients with rural loans for agricultural purposes accounting for more than 40% of portfolio and number of clients. Arnurs average loan size is about $2,000.
Impact: The developmental impact is expected to be high:- Open up more financial channels to the underserved segments of the society in remote and rural areas of Kazakhstan through supporting lending operations of Arnur Credit. Through access to finance, local micro and small entrepreneurs, more specifically women owned borrowers, would be able to expand their business activities and subsequently finance their day to day consumer and family needs.- Contribute to the employment creation and improvement of life at the base of the pyramid through the strengthening of the microfinance industry in the frontier regions of Kazakhstan.- Create a demonstration effect for MFIs in the country to upgrade their practices in different areas including risk management and social and environmental risk management.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed project is with the new IFC client to provide a senior loan of up to US$3 million equivalent to Microcredit Organization Arnur Credit LLP to finance the expansion of the Companys lending activities to micro and small entrepreneurs. The project has been classified as category FI according to the IFC Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Arnur Credit will be required to update the Exclusion List it currently applies to include items on IFC Exclusion List, to develop and operate an Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS), and to appoint an ESMS officer to run the system. The ESMS shall be commensurate with the level of E&S risks in its portfolio and prospective business activities and ensure screening operations of borrowers against the IFC Exclusion List and, where they present E&S risks, for compliance with environmental and social laws and regulations of the Republic of Kazakhstan, where they exist and are applicable. Arnur Credit will also need to demonstrate ongoing compliance with IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions in its employment practices and regularly report to IFC its E&S performance in accordance with the format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: Arnur Credit was founded in 2001 as a Rural Credit Partnership and in 2004 it was transformed into a limited liability partnership and registered as a Micro Credit Organization (MCO). In 2006 Arnur Credit was sold to credit cooperative ORDA Credit LLP which is currently the sole owner of Arnur Credit.ORDA Credit is a credit cooperative headquartered in Shymkent, southern Kazakhstan, and is one of the largest credit cooperatives in Kazakhstan. ORDA Credit was founded in 1999 and provides limited number of banking services to its members, such as lending, payment transactions and investment, in accordance with the Credit Partnerships Law.
Cost Nature: The proposed project involves a senior loan from IFCs own account to Arnur Credit in an amount up to $3 million equivalent. The proposed loan would be denominated in the Kazakh Tenge.

Location: Arnur Credit is headquartered in Shymkent in southern Kazakhstan and has 38 branches and sub-offices in the southern region.

Project Description: Snowman Logistics Limited (Snowman or the Company) is a company providing Temperature Controlled Logistics (TCL) solutions. Its primary business lines are:Storage: Snowman provides temperature controlled storage services to a number of industries. It has an aggregate capacity of over 18,000 pallets spread over 16 locations.Transportation: Snowman offers temperature controlled transportation services for both long distance transportation and for regional distribution to individual retail hubs, with its fleet of over 109 reefer vehicles.Consignment Agency:  Snowmans offerings under this division include a range of supply chain services from inventory management, order collection etc. As part of this project, Snowman proposes to expand its storage facilities at existing and new locations (Snowman III or the Project.
Impact: This repeat investment will have a strong development impact by helping build efficient agriculture supply chain solutions in India. Additionally, the investment will help in (a) building competitiveness as the development of an efficient supply chain will help reduce waste and losses as well as reduce logistics costs, (b) providing an opportunity to local businesses to outsource their distribution functions and lower their distribution and inventory costs. Further, IFC''s repeat investment will provide a strong demonstration effect, signaling IFC''s faith in the TCL sector. This should aid the sector and Company in attracting new private capital in future. Finally, this expansion is expected to create additional jobs.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Further, it is possible to readily design and implement engineering and management measures to mitigate the limited adverse impact.The key risks and aspects associated with this provisional category B investment are: effective deployment of its current social and environment management system including the ISO 14001 certified EMS during construction and operation of the facilities proposed under this investment; enhancement of corporate capacity and as required staffing to implement the projects in accordance with the Performance Standards and to engage with communities in the vicinity of the facilities; ensuring fair, safe and healthy working conditions (for employees, drivers and those engaged through contractors); appropriate vehicle safety and maintenance; emergency preparedness and response; driver and employee training on health and safety; conservation of energy, water and avoidance of ozone depleting substances in design, construction and operation of facilities; management of air emissions, wastewater discharges and solid and other waste disposal; handling and management of hazardous materials and hazardous wastes; vehicle (new and existing) emissions and energy efficiency; community health, safety and security with regard to construction and operation of cold storage facilities, waste management/disposal, vehicle operations and emergency response; and site selection and fair and transparent purchase of land for new facility construction.Snowman will implement its existing SEHSMS and HR Policies in the proposed new facilities as well. Accordingly, the Company has presented plans to address the relevant impacts of its operations and to ensure that the proposed Investment will, upon implementation of the specific agreed measures, comply with the environmental and social requirements - the host country laws and regulations and IFC Performance Standards.  The detailed discussion about how these potential impacts will be addressed by the Company is summarized in the Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) also disclosed together with this document.
Sponsor: Snowman was initially promoted by Amalgam group in 1997. Subsequently, three Japanese companies viz. Mitsubishi Corporation, Mitsubishi Logistics Corporation and Nichirei Logistics Group acquired a significant stake in Snowman. In November 2006, Gateway Distriparks Ltd. (GDL) acquired a majority stake in Snowman. Today, GDL has the management control and the Sponsor and holds 53% stake in Snowman. The other major shareholders - Mitsubishi Corporation (MC), Mitsubishi Logistics Corporation (MLC) and Nichirei Logistics Group together hold approx 26% of Snowman. IFC holds 19.9% equity stake by virtue of its equity investment in 2010.
Cost Nature: Snowman has drawn up a capital expenditure plan of about $ 28 million for expansion of its storage facilities in various locations in India. The major costs of expansion are civil work, lease costs, refrigeration systems, material handling equipments, electrification, fleet and IT augmentation, furniture and fixtures etc. Snowman proposes to implement the expansion plan over the medium term. IFCs proposed contribution to the same will be about $ 6.5 million by way of long term debt.
Investment: 6.64 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan6.64Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Snowman is headquartered in Bangalore, India and its present temperature controlled storage infrastructure is spread across 16 locations including Delhi, Mumbai, Bangalore, and Chennai. As a part of the Project Snowman intends to expand in some of these existing and new locations in India.

Project Description: Snowman Logistics Limited (Snowman or the Company) formerly known as Snowman Frozen Foods Limited (SFFL), headquartered in Bangalore, India, is one of the largest organized temperature controlled logistics (TCL) service providers in India with an aggregate cold storage capacity of over 18,250 pallets spread across 16 locations. Snowman through its 109 refrigerated (reefer) trucks (49 deployed on long route and 60 on short route) also offers temperature controlled pan-India transportation and distribution services. The Company currently serves over 150 customers across 11 industry segments.  It commenced operations in 1994 as SFFL. Snowmans services include primary transportation, storage, inventory management, documentation and distribution of frozen and chilled foods. Snowman has the capability of providing TCL services to the entire spectrum of products including processed foods, fast foods, seafood, meats, ice creams apart from fruits and vegetables. Pursuant to IFCs 2009 equity investment, Snowman has increased capacity to 18,250 pallets. The Company is now considering to further increase its storage capacity to ~ 46,410 pallets in the medium term (Investment) within the next 2-3 years. IFC is considering providing a corporate loan to Snowman to partially fund the expansion.
Review Scope: The review of this corporate investment builds upon the appraisal and supervision of IFCs previous investment in Snowman Frozen Foods Limited Project (conducted in 2009 and 2010 for project # 26688). Snowman reports to IFC regarding the ongoing management of its environmental and social performance, which has been satisfactory. IFCs recent review in December 2011 consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information submitted by Snowman including a review of: the Companys social, environmental, health and safety management system (SEHSMS); Human Resource Manual; incident monitoring records; records for mock drills, training, waste management; certificates; and copies of permits.  The appraisal team interviewed the corporate and site operations managers and the Corporate Human Resources (HR) Manager. Appraisal team also visited the Companys existing operational cold storage facility at Bangalore, Karnataka, since at this facility an expansion with significant construction activity is also currently underway.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Further, it is possible to readily design and implement engineering and management measures to mitigate the limited adverse impact.

Project Description: Mediterra Capital Partners I, LP (the 'Fund') is a closed end private equity fund that will make investments in small to midsized private Turkish enterprises. The target fund size is  200 million, and the first closing of 100 million was held on May 27, 2011, therefore the final closing is on May 27, 2012 (with a potential 6 month extension subject to LP Advisory Board approval).  The Fund expects to make 10 to 15 investments in various sectors, including: retail, education, healthcare, industrials, automotives and logistics. Approximately 60-70% of investments will be in Istanbul and Marmara, approximately 30-40% will be in Anatolian cities, where SMEs are often underserved for equity capital. The Fund will allocate a minimum of 20 million, or 16.7% of its commitments (whichever is greater) to SMEs.
Impact: (i)  Support for SMEs: IFC experience has shown that small to midcap companies can achieve higher job creation rates than large cap companies. IFC would support job creation in Turkey since Mediterra's midcap growth strategy is in full alignment with IFC's development impact goals.(ii) Access to long-term equity/risk capital is limited in Turkey. SMEs usually access short term bank loans in the absence of equity investors. IFC's investment would support Turkish companies by providing liquidity and depth.(iii) Private Sector Development: Mediterra will employ a hands on, value added strategy with portfolio companies. Through this knowledge sharing, new management techniques and growth strategies are incorporated by investee companies, leading to improved competitiveness and sustainability.(iv) The Fund will seek to make investments in Anatolian cities where SMEs are often underserved for equity capital.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a new investment in Mediterra Capital Partners I, LP a closed end private equity fund which will make investments in small to mid-sized private Turkish enterprises. The project has been classified as "Category FI" according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedures. The expected portfolio will likely comprise medium Environmental and Social risk investments.The Fund has a documented Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS) as per EBRD guidelines, ensuring compliance with national law and EBRD''s Environmental and Social Exclusion and Referral List. The Fund has also designated two SEMS officers.
Sponsor: Mediterra Capital Management Limited, a Guernsey company, is the manager of the Fund ('the Manager').  It is advised by Mediterra Private Equity Limited as its sole Investment Advisor. The team consists of six investment professionals with private equity investment experience and a CFO, with offices in Istanbul, Turkey.
Cost Nature: The proposal is to make an equity investment of 15 million (USD 21 million) to Mediterra Capital Partners I LP, a closed end private equity fund which is targeting a total of  200 million in commitments.

Project Description: Lombard Asia IV L.P. (Lombard Asia IV or the Fund), a Cayman Islands exempted limited partnership, is a private equity fund seeking $400 million in capital commitments to build a portfolio of equity and equity-linked investments in middle market, growth-oriented companies formed and operated in Southeast Asia.
Impact: The Fund would help its portfolio companies create jobs, potentially covering the rural areas and increasing female employment.  The Fund would help private sector development through supporting growth and operational improvement of its portfolio companies.  The Project would support private equity investments in the Fund''s target markets, helping develop the financial markets in its target countries.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an investment with a repeat client which has a good commitment to manage Environmental & Social (E&S) risks associated with its activities consistent with IFCs E&S requirements, including mechanisms to screen existing and potential portfolio investees against IFC Performance Standards.  Discussions with the client and review of the clients 2010 annual environmental performance report of their previous funds in which IFC invested indicated that although the Fund Manager has adopted IFC''s E&S requirements as its E&S policy, an updated formal SEMS would need to be developed before commitment.  This has been agreed to by the client.This project has been classified as Category FI.  Applicable requirements include the IFC FI Exclusion List, national legal requirements and IFC Performance Standards.  The client will be required to prepare a SEMS, including a mechanism to receive and review regular E&S reports from investees classified by the SEMS as category A or B.
Sponsor: The Fund will be managed by Lombard Investments, Inc. (Lombard or the Manager) who has offices in San Francisco, USA; Bangkok, Thailand; and Hong Kong SAR, China. Lombard Asia IV is the fourth Asia-focused private equity fund managed by Lombard.  IFC previously committed in Lombard Asia III L.P. and the Thailand Equity Fund.
Cost Nature: IFC proposes to make an equity investment of up to $25 million in the Fund, not to exceed 20% of the total commitments of the Fund.

Project Description: The proposed project is to provide a $6 million senior loan (or local currency equivalent) to Kompanion Financial Group Microfinance CJSC (Kompanion or the Company), which would use the loan to expand lending to micro and small entrepreneurs (the Project). The Company seeks long-term funding to continue its dynamic growth and offer new products to its target clientele.Kompanion was founded in October 2004 as a Limited Liability Micro Credit Company through the consolidation of five separate micro-credit agencies. In April 2009 the Company was reorganized into a closed joint stock company and licensed by the National Bank of Kyrgyz Republic as a non-deposit-taking commercial microfinance company.Kompanion has an extensive country-wide geographic footprint with representation in all regions. It provides micro- and small-business credit in rural and urban areas throughout Kyrgyzstan. Currently, the Companys primary products are women solidarity group loans (approximately 84% of the customer base) and secured small business loans to entrepreneurs and individuals in agriculture and rural areas. Kompanion is targeting primarily the rural areas and lending to individuals in poor rural villages, fostering the growth of these less developed areas. With its active clients base of over 137,000 as of December 2011, Kompanion is the largest credit provider by outreach in the country.
Impact: The developmental impact is expected to be high:-	 The Project would provide funding for the underserved segments of the society, more specifically women entrepreneurs and individuals in poor rural areas.-	 In Kyrgyz Republic, the provision of term funding in the local financial market would have a strong demonstration effect and build market confidence. -	 Strengthening the microfinance sector in Kyrgyzstan will allow to prop up economic growth in the country through generation of new jobs and improvement of life at the base of the pyramid.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed project is with a new IFC client to provide a senior loan to Kompanion to expand lending to micro and small entrepreneurs. The project has been classified as category FI according to the IFC Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Kompanion has internal procedures to manage its E&S risks.  The company screens its investments against the Exclusion List and a set of E&S criteria, which are taken into account in pricing its loans. The client will be required to formalize its procedures in a formal Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS), adjust its Exclusion List to include items on the IFC Exclusion List, and incorporate reviewing borrowers operations for compliance with environmental and social laws and regulations of the Kyrgyz Republic where they exist and are applicable. Kompanion will also be required to demonstrate ongoing compliance with IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions in its employment practices and regularly report to IFC its E&S performance in accordance with the format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: The sole owner of Kompanion is Mercy Corps, a US-based international NGO established in 1979 with a mission to alleviate suffering, poverty and oppression by helping people build secure, productive and just communities. Mercy Corps has a broad experience in microfinance.
Cost Nature: The total project cost consists of a proposed senior loan of $6 million equivalent in either Kyrgyz Som (desired) or US Dollar to Kompanion for IFCs own account to support the growth of the Companys microfinance operations in Kyrgyz Republic.

Project Description: The proposed engagement with Equity Bank Limited (EBL or the Bank) is aligned to IFCs strategy for the East African financial sector. The Project consists of a US$100 million senior loan to EBL, to help the Bank grow its lending to Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSME), women entrepreneurs and the agricultural sector, and to support its regional expansion in East Africa. EBL is a commercial bank providing inclusive financial services with a specific focus on the underserved populations in Kenya, Uganda and South Sudan, with a customer base of 6.3 million majority of them small savers and an asset base of close to US$ 2 billion as of June 30, 2011.In addition to traditional brick and mortar outlets the bank has rolled out multiple delivery channels including ATMs, cash back services and POS to increase access to financial services. The bank recently rolled out mobile banking and agency banking which will take banking services to the remote areas and further increase access.
Impact: The project is expected to:i) Support Lending and Growth in the East African Market:Equity Bank has a wide distribution network in East Africa with subsidiaries in Uganda and South Sudan, offering financial services to the large unbanked population. The Project will support the Banks continued growth ultimately contributing to renewed economic activity in East Africa.(ii) Increased Access to Finance for SMEs:SME''s are a key growth sector for EBL. IFC will assist with SME development beyond financing to include advisory services for key aspects of its SME operations including lending to the agricultural sector and women entrepreneurs. The expected improvement in access to finance for SMEs will help to generate employment at the grass roots level and further facilitate regional trade which is expected to grow rapidly following the economic integration of the East African Community.(iii) Support regional Expansion and integrationIFC''s engagement with EBL will its regional expansion strategy and contribute to increased competition and service in the regional banking sector. This will strengthen the regional economy and contribute to the success of the newly created economic community.(iv) Increased Financial Inclusion at the bottom of the pyramidEquity Banks has a clear focus and commitment to increasing financial inclusion at the bottom of the pyramid through new and innovative products and services. IFCs investment will support the Banks growth strategy and allow it to reach even more customers at the bottom of the pyramid.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.During appraisal, IFC analyzed the FI portfolio and the activities proposed to be supported with IFC financing for types of transactions, size, tenor and industry sectors and determined as the Applicable Performance Requirements, based on an analysis of the potential Social and Environmental risks associated with the FI portfolio and considering IFCs investment, the IFC Exclusion List, the host country laws and regulations and the IFC Performance Standards.IFC also appraised the FIs existing Environmental and Social Risk management practices, capacity to implement the same, and reviewed the Banks labor practices. It was found that Equity Bank already has an E&S policy to ensure financing provided is compliant with the national laws and regulations. The policy will need to be enhanced to ensure screening against the IFC Exclusion List and the Performance Standards, and an Environmental Management System (ESMS) be developed. Based on a preliminary review the Banks labor and working conditions were found to be in compliance with the requirements of Performance Standard 2.Considering the Applicable Performance Requirements and FI E&S Policy and capacity review, the project will be required to: (i) Upgrade the existing E&S Policy and develop a Environmental &Social Management System (ESMS), prior to disbursement to the satisfaction of IFC, (ii) Identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the ESMS and ensure all staff involved in ESMS implementation are adequately trained to implement the revised policy and procedures, (iii) Commit to implement the ESMS, to ensure that its lending activities are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements, (iv) Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: EBL was incorporated in Kenya in 1984 as a building society and converted to a fully fledged commercial bank in 2004. It was listed on the Nairobi Stock Exchange in 2006 and the Uganda Securities Exchange in June 2009. The Bank has over 28,000 shareholders. Major owners are as follows: Helios EB Investors (24. 5%), British-American Investment Company (Kenya) Limited (11.0%), Equity Bank Employees Share Ownership Plan (4.2%), James Njuguna Mwangi (3.45%) and Leah Wanjiku Muguku ( 3.3%).
Cost Nature: The proposed investment will be in the form of a senior loan of up to $100 million for IFCs own account.
Investment: 180.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan100.0Equity80.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: EBL is based in Nairobi, Kenya, and has existing operations in Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda and South Sudan. Total number of branches as of Dec. 31, 2011 was 180, and the investment is expected to support the Banks operations throughout its network.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.During appraisal, IFC analyzed the FI portfolio and the activities proposed to be supported with IFC financing for types of transactions, size, tenor and industry sectors and determined as the Applicable Performance Requirements, based on an analysis of the potential Social and Environmental risks associated with the FI portfolio and considering IFCs investment, the IFC Exclusion List, the host country laws and regulations and the IFC Performance Standards.IFC also appraised the FIs existing Environmental and Social Risk management practices, capacity to implement the same, and reviewed the Banks labor practices. It was found that Equity Bank already has an E&S policy to ensure financing provided is compliant with the national laws and regulations. The policy will need to be enhanced to ensure screening against the IFC Exclusion List and the Performance Standards, and an Environmental Management System (ESMS) be developed. Based on a preliminary review the Banks labor and working conditions were found to be in compliance with the requirements of Performance Standard 2.Considering the Applicable Performance Requirements and FI E&S Policy and capacity review, the project will be required to: (i) Upgrade the existing E&S Policy and develop a Environmental &Social Management System (ESMS), prior to disbursement to the satisfaction of IFC, (ii) Identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the ESMS and ensure all staff involved in ESMS implementation are adequately trained to implement the revised policy and procedures, (iii) Commit to implement the ESMS, to ensure that its lending activities are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements, (iv) Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.

Project Description: CLN Group, and Proma Group, two Italian automotive suppliers (the Sponsors) have decided to jointly invest in Serbia in a Greenfield metal stamping factory (the Project). The Project will be located in Grosnica, a supplier park dedicated to FIATs new plant in Kragujevac.FIAT current production capacity in Kraguievac is 20,000 car/year and is expecting to grow to 140,000 car/year by 2013 and potentially 300,000 car/year by 2015. The Project will produce for FIAT, seat structure, safety component and system, suspension and car jacks, with manufacturing processes including press, assembly and painting. The plant is expected to create 367 skilled jobs.
Impact: Sustainable employment creation - The Project is expected to create at least 367 skilled jobs in Sumadija District, a frontier region of Serbia.Support FDI in Serbia - Channeling foreign direct investment is a priority for Serbia. The project will contribute to balancing Serbia''s large current account deficit. Support export oriented industry - the project will sell its product to FIAT assembly plant in Kragujevac, which will export 90% of the production.Technology transfer - MA and Proma are FIAT trusted suppliers and have state-of-the-art technologies and efficient processes. Local staff will be trained to new, highly competitive standards.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed project is being developed in accordance with national regulatory requirements and international standards by a Sponsor committed to good environmental and social management.  The project has primarily local and international raw material supply, will follow international labor standards, and will have minimal of emissions and discharges from controlled sources. As documented further in the Environmental and Social Review Summary there is no involuntary resettlement.  With no indication of impacts related to Performance Standards 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 and only readily mitigated environmental issues under Performance Standards 1 through 3 this is a Category B project.
Sponsor: Simest: Società Italiana per le Imprese allEstero (Simest) is a financial institution which provides financial instruments and services to support Italian companies in foreign markets.  Simest is owned by the Italian Ministry for Economic Development, whose participation includes leading Italian banks and Confindustria, which is the General Confederation of Italian Industry.  Simest will participate as a minority equity holder in the Project. CLN: Founded in 1949, CLN is an Italian company which operates in three business segments: Steel Service Centers (SSC), Steel Wheel Manufacturing, and Steel Metal Stamping (MA). CLN is the preferred steel stamping and wheel supplier of many OEMs. CLN is 65% owned by Perris-Magnetto family and 35% by Arcelor Mittal. In 2011, CLNs consolidated expected revenue is EUR1.8 billion, with an EBITDA of EUR169 million and total assets of EUR 1.5 billion. The Automotive division, MA, is CLNs most profitable division and will directly invest in Project.Proma: Proma SpA, the operating holding of Proma Group, is the legal entity investing in the JV. Founded in 1980 with its first plant specialized in steel cold stamping, Proma Group is controlled by the Pino Family, and is a long standing metal stamping part manufacturer, part of FIAT suppliers group. It has 9 plants in Italy, one in Morocco, Poland, Spain and France. It employs globally 1,750 staff. Proma is the leader in the car seat frame area, stamping and metal assemblies for the vehicles of the main European car-makers. Proma Group offer to its customer (automotive) a complete service, consisting of product Engineering, industrialization, production, assistance and logistic.
Cost Nature: The total Project cost is EUR 37 million.  It will be financed by Senior Debt, equity and shareholder loans. The sponsors will inject in equity plus quasi equity an amount of approximately EUR 15 million (paid in cash) representing 40% of the Project cost. IFCs is contemplating providing a loan of up to EUR 20 million.
Investment: 26.88 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan26.88Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is a greenfield, located in Grosnica, a supplier park less than a kilometer from FIATs plant in Kragujevac, Serbia.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The proposed project is being developed in accordance with national regulatory requirements and international standards by a Sponsor committed to good environmental and social management.  The project has primarily local and international raw material supply, will follow international labor standards, and will have minimal of emissions and discharges from controlled sources. As documented further in the Environmental and Social Review Summary there is no involuntary resettlement.  With no indication of impacts related to Performance Standards 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 and only readily mitigated environmental issues under Performance Standards 1 through 3 this is a Category B project.

Project Description: Yes Bank Ltd. (Yes Bank or the Bank) is a private sector bank, established in November 2003. Yes Bank was granted a license by the Reserve Bank of India to commence banking operations in May 2004. The Bank has a pan India presence with 331 branches across 225 cities (as on December 31, 2011). Approximately 25 percent of the branches are present in the low income states of Rajasthan, M.P, U.P and Chhattisgarh.  The Bank plans to expand its branches network to 750 branches by FY 2015, targeted towards expanding its SME, agriculture and retail franchise. Yes Bank plans to primarily expand in smaller cities and centers where it expects to tap SME and agriculture business. Much of the expansion will be in the states of Maharashtra, NCR, Gujarat, Rajasthan, Haryana, UP and MP.
Impact: The market segments focused on by Yes Bank overlap with some of IFC''s top priorities. Through this investment IFC will initiate and develop a relationship with a potentially important development partner. IFC will help refine the focus and strengthen the capabilities of the Bank in effectively addressing SMEs and agriculture customers as it expands its network and increases its exposure in these market segments.Access to finance: The proceeds of IFC''s funding will be utilized by Yes Bank to finance its customers in the SME and agricultural sectors. IFC''s investment will thus ensure continued and increasing access to finance to the SME sector in increasingly challenging credit environment.Supporting a private sector bank in the growth years:  Yes Bank is a recently established private sector bank with 7 years of operations, and has demonstrated consistently good performance. Yes Bank was also the regional (Asia Pacific) winner of the 2011 FT/IFC Sustainable Finance awards. The Bank has ambitious plans to expand its branch network, broaden its footprint in smaller cities and grow its SME franchise. This project will support the long-term growth strategy of Yes Bank and improve its financial fundamentals.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.During appraisal, IFC analyzed the bank''s portfolio for types of transactions, size and industry sectors and determined the Applicable Performance Requirements based on an analysis of the potential Social and Environmental risks associated with the bank''s portfolio and considering IFCs investment which is 15-year subordinated debt (Upper Tier II instrument). The Applicable Performance Requirements are (i) The IFC FI Exclusion List(s); (ii) The applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and regulations; and (iii) The IFC Performance Standards.IFC also appraised the Banks labor practices and reviewed its existing Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS) and the capacity to implement the same. It was found that the bank has a SEMS and some capacity. The labour practices of the bank were found to be satisfactory. However, the following Supplemental Actions apply:The bank will upgrade its existing SEMS to enable the bank to identify, assess and manage the social and environmental risks in respect of banks operations in accordance with the Applicable Performance Requirements which includes IFC Performance Standards.The bank will nominate a person(s) responsible for implementing the SEMS;The bank will commit to implement the SEMS, to ensure that its investments/activities are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements; andThe bank will submit periodic reports to IFC as per a format(s) to be provided by IFC.IFC will also review the implementation and performance of the Bank''s SEMS for the first few projects to ensure that the Bank''s SEMS is adequate to assess and manage E&S risks.
Sponsor: Mr. Rana Kapoor, the Banks founder is a graduate from the University of Delhi and an MBA from Rutgers University, with more than two decades of experience in the banking sector. In 2003-04, Mr. Rana Kapoor and his partner, the late Mr. Ashok Kapur, established Yes Bank along with Rabobank International. The sponsor group as on December 31, 2011 has a 26.21 percent stake in the Bank. Other major shareholders include (percent share in parenthesis): American Funds Insurance Series Growth Fund (4.85), HSBC Bank (4.77), Rabobank International (4.75), Titiwangsa Investments (4.17), Smallcap World Fund Inc. (2.56), Citigroup (1.03), JP Morgan (1.39) and LIC of India (2.39).
Cost Nature: The project involves a 15-year subordinated debt (Upper Tier II instrument or UT2) of US$75 million to Yes Bank. The project is intended to support the Bank in (i) augmenting its capital base and to prepare it for Basel III implementation (ii) improving the Banks maturity mismatch position, and, (iii) growing its assets, increasing its reach and improving its market share especially in the SME and agricultural space.
Investment: 75.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan75.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Yes Bank is headquartered in Mumbai. The Bank plans to expand its branches to 350 by the end of FY2012 and to 750 branches by FY 2015. The expansion will help in the Bank in increasing its reach, particularly in the targeted sectors (SME and agriculture), and to increase savings mobilization.

Project Description: The proposed IFC investment will help OOO Ava Peter (Ava Peter or the Company) to finance the construction of a new multi-functional medical center in St. Petersburg (the Project).
Impact: - Improved access to quality healthcare: the Project is expected to increase availability of modern inpatient and outpatient health care services for local population and reduce pressure on public health infrastructure - Demonstration effect: the local private provider''s expansion into advanced segments of care, together with potential new PPPs with local health authorities building on success of the existing PPP in Kazan will raise awareness and increase attractiveness of healthcare for private investors and financiers- Job creation and retention: the Project is expected to create 450 new jobs, including 350 for medical personnel, contributing to retention of qualified staff in the sector
Environmental Social Issues: The project is a category B investment according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The major environmental and social issues of this project are associated with construction impacts and a risk of fire occurrence in the company''s clinics. Application of standard construction environmental controls and internationally recognized life and fire safety standards during construction and operation will ensure compliance with national and IFC''s environmental and social Performance Standards. A summary of IFCs environmental and social review findings and proposed mitigation measures for the project is publicly available in the environmental and social review summary disclosed through IFCs external website: http://www.ifc.org/projects
Sponsor: Ava Peter was founded in 1996 by Dr. Ralph Ashorn and Mr. Gleb Mikhaylik. Current shareholders are Scanfert Oy (54%), NMC Holding Oy, (40%), both controlled directly and indirectly by Mr. Ashorn; and Mr. Gleb Mikhaylik (6%). The Company is operating a network of clinics in St. Petersburg, consisting of Scandinavia, a multi-functional medical center with a maternity hospital, an infertility clinic and 10 primary care outpatient clinics; an outpatient clinic in Vologda; an infertility clinic in Kazan established under a Private Public Partnership (PPP) with the Government of the Republic of Tatarstan. The Company is completing construction of a diagnostic center with outpatient, inpatient and maternity clinic in Kazan. Ava Peter is a client of IFC since 2008.
Cost Nature: The Project is expected to cost US$34 million and will be part of the general corporate investment program for 2011-2014 with estimated cost of US$58 million. The proposed IFC investment will be in the form of an equity investment in the Company of up to US$14 million.

Project Description: Proteak Uno S.A.P.I.B de C.V. (Proteak or the Company)  is a mid-sized publicly traded Mexican company engaged in the sustainable management of teak plantations.  The proposed Project consists of the Companys expansion plan, which includes the financing of the recent acquisitions of teak plantations in Central America and Colombia; as well as the establishment of new teak plantations in Mexico.
Impact: Climate change mitigation: IFC financing will support the Company in establishing teak plantations and supporting the growth of the existing planted area, which will directly result in a significant carbon sequestration. Moreover, since land reserves and land to be acquired comprise mainly ranch lands that have been degraded due to over-grazing of livestock, the Project will have a considerable impact on soil regeneration.  Employment generation: The Project is expected to create direct and indirect employment (number of jobs to be created and wage levels) and contribute to poverty reduction in remote rural areas.Strong demonstration effect:  Successful implementation of the Project will demonstrate the long term viability of sustainable forestry projects in regions with favorable weather and soil conditions for forestry, and degraded land available.Frontier regions: The Project involves direct investment and job creation in remote rural areas of Costa Rica and Colombia, and frontier regions in Mexico such as the states of Nayarit, Tabasco and Chiapas.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project in accordance with IFCs Policy on Social and Environmental Sustainability.  The E&S risks and impacts associated with the proposed project can be prevented or mitigated through the combined use of a proactive environmental and social management system, application of established EHS safeguards and mitigation measures proven effective by other companies in the region, and use of internationally-recognized and externally-verified forestry practices.  Environmental and social issues reviewed during appraisal included:   - Current status of the companys environmental and social management systems;- Proposed OHS management practices of the Company and its contractors;- Identification and conservation of natural and critical habitats and protection of ecosystem services; - Prevention, detection and suppression of fire in plantation operations;- Energy use, efficiency and GHG emissions associated with all aspects of project development;- Management of hazardous materials, including all agrochemicals and operational petrochemicals;- Proposed approach and tools for community engagement during plantation establishment and operations.The Company proposes avoiding and mitigating environmental and social impacts by establishing clear operational procedures and management systems for the screening of land acquisitions or leases to ensure compliance with each countries environmental requirements as well as compliance with WBG EHS requirements and conformity with Forest Stewardship Councils Principles & Criteria.
Sponsor: As of December 31, 2011, Proteak  had 4,408 ha planted with teak trees located in the Mexican states of Jalisco, Nayarit, Tabasco and Chiapas. The Company has also acquired 1,956 ha of established plantations in Colombia and Costa Rica as well as in Mexico to improve its inventories profile by adding older plantations to its portfolio. The Company established 1,000 ha of new plantations in 2011 and plans to continue adding an average of 1,000 ha/year over the next few years.
Cost Nature: The total project cost amounts US$ 113.6 million. The proposed IFC investment consists of a US$ 15 million A Loan and a US$ 15 million B Loan.

Project Description: Aqualyng Holding AS (the Company) is a Norwegian water company that designs, builds, finances, owns, and operates seawater reverse osmosis (SWRO) desalination plants with its own proprietary energy recovery technologies and equipment. The proposed IFC investment is to support the Company's expansion into the Chinese market by funding investments into new desalination projects in China as well as in the establishment of a manufacturing base for its proprietary technology and equipment sales.In 2008, the Company was awarded a 30-year Build Own Operate Transfer (BOOT) desalination project with a product capacity of 50,000 cubic meters per day in the Caofeidian Industrial Zone, one of China's 13 pilot Eco-Cities with a planned area of 310 km2 in Tangshan City, Hebei Province. The plant will be one of the first commercial seawater reverse osmosis larger-scale plants in China to be in operation, and is planned to be expanded to 700,000 cubic meters per day. Water will be supplied to domestic and industrial customers within the industrial zone. The Company has also formed a joint venture with Beijing Enterprises Water Group Limited (BEWG), one of the top tier water companies in China in order to exclusively work on desalination projects in China and other Asian countries. Aqualyng will also form a separate joint venture for its technology and equipment manufacturing with a leading desalination contractor in China. This partnership will serve to commercialize and market the Company's energy recovery device for SWRO and other technology.
Impact: 1. Address the severe water scarcity in China; out of the 663 cities in China, 400 are short of water and 110 are facing serious shortages.2. Assist the government in establishing a technology that reduces energy consumption, especially with the growing environmental pressure that is increasingly being stressed by the national government and the international community.3. Demonstration effect to grow this infant industry through the success of the project, in particular the Caofeidian plant as the model desalination project for China.4. Adoption of environmentally sustainable practices in a water sector that requires careful planning of the waste (brine).5. Enable knowledge transfer and technology transfer by supporting a company that is shifting its research and manufacturing to China, and planning to expand into other emerging markets.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects. The proposed IFC equity investment in Aqualyng will support the Norwegian Company''s entry into the rapidly growing water desalination market in China. As part of the environmental and social review process, the Company''s corporate environmental and social management system, policies and procedures were reviewed as well as its performance to date on the Caofeidian SWRO project. The scope of review included environmental, safety and health and social risks and impacts of the project and the Companys management capacity to undertake such projects in the future, including how environmental and social consequences are taken into account, from screening of opportunities to planning, design, construction and operation phases.Because the proposed equity investment may be used to support future, but as yet, undefined projects in addition to those identified, the principal environmental and social risks identified for the project which will require additional mitigation measures by the Company include implementation of a comprehensive environmental and social management system; and adoption of IFC environmental and social Performance Standards as part of the applicable legal and other requirements in its management system, including formal procedures for environmental and social screening of business opportunities (including any joint ventures) and new projects into its marketing strategy, commercial planning, and project bidding processes.
Sponsor: Aqualyng Holdings AS was incorporated in 2007 in Norway. The Company specializes in planning, developing, financing and operating seawater desalination plants. Aqualyng has also established its own technology in energy recovery device for SWRO and other technology. Aqualyng has four major Norwegian shareholders, Staur Aqua AS, a Norwegian industrial developer, the Lyng Group AS, Aqua Venture AS, and Pareto Energy Solutions AS. The Company was also joined by Clean Resources Asia Growth Fund, L.P. (CLSA), a leading Asia focused private equity fund under CLSA Asia-Pacific Markets as of 2010. IFC plans to co-invest alongside CLSA and other leading private equity fund(s).
Cost Nature: The total project cost defined in this round of financing is estimated at US$65 million. IFC is considering an investment of up to US$17 million, in the form of equity, warrants and/or debt.
Investment: 12.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan12.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Aqualyng's first plant is located in the Caofeidian Industrial Zone, Tangshan, Hebei Province, China, and the Company looks to expand to other coastline cities in China. Desalination plants may include supplying water to Beijing.

Project Description: The Project represents construction of a greenfield multi-functional clinic comprising a diagnostic center and a 96-bed general hospital. The new facility will strengthen the Companys position as a leading private health network in St. Petersburg and will create additional capacity to serve patients needing specialized care (including inpatient care) and referred by primary care satellite clinics. The existing inpatient clinic at Scandinavia hospital (currently operating at close to 100% capacity) will focus on delivery and maternity services while general surgery and inpatient services will be provided at the new clinic.  The new clinic will located in Primorsky district of St. Petersburg, a large residential area with population of 500,000 and insufficient existing outpatient and inpatient capacity at public facilities. The Project is expected to cost US$34 million and will be part of the general corporate investment program with estimated cost of US$40 million. The proposed IFC investment will be in the form of an equity investment in the Company of up to US$14 million.
Review Scope: IFCs review of the proposed investment in OOO AVA-Peter (Ava-Peter or the Company), an existing IFC client, to finance the construction of a new multi-functional medical center in St. Petersburg (the Project) consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information submitted by the Company, including:   -	Minutes of public hearings held in St. Petersburg on March 23, 2006;-	Minutes of public consultations on a city planning decision held on April 12, 2006.   -	A specimen employment agreement;-	The Companys response to IFCs E&S questionnaire (11/8/2011)-	The Companys Annual Monitoring Report for 2010. A site visit to the companys facilities was carried out by IFCs environmental specialist in December 2011 to get the latest update on E&S matters associated with the existing operations and ongoing construction. In addition, IFC review used the conclusions of the Life and Fire Safety due diligence carried out by the independent consulting company, FPC (Belgium), in December 2011.  To date, IFC has concluded 2 transactions with the company. In 2003, IFC has provided a US$2.1 million loan to NMC Holding Oy (NMC project, # 10407) to finance the construction of the Scandinavia clinic in St. Petersburg. The loan was fully repaid in September 2011.  In 2008, IFC committed a US$12.5 million loan (NMC II project, #26119) to finance the expansion of a satellite network of primary care clinics in St. Petersburg and construction of a greenfield maternity hospital in Kazan. The satellite clinics program was completed with 10 clinics operational. Completion of Kazan hospital is expected in 2012. The Environmental and Social (E&S) reviews of the earlier investments (Project ID #10407 and ID #26119) were disclosed on the IFCs site and locally. The company is in compliance with the requirements of IFC loans and has demonstrated a commitment and capacity to effectively manage environmental and social (including life and fire safety) matters. The most recent monitoring visit to the Companys facility was undertaken in June 2011, when an independent Life and Fire Safety Consultant conducted a site visit to the companys new property in Kazan to monitor a proper implementation of the Life and Fire Safety Master Plan during a construction phase.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Similarly to the previous IFCs investment with the company, this proposed investment is classified as a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review procedures, because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized design criteria, construction and operational standards. The major environmental and social issues of this project are associated with construction impacts and a risk of fire occurrence in company''s clinics.

Project Description: Proteak Uno S.A.P.I.B de C.V. (Proteak or the Company) is a mid-sized publicly-traded Mexican company engaged in development of teak forest plantations and primary processing facilities in Mexico, Central America and Colombia. The Company has planted or acquired approximately 8,000 hectares of plantations in Mexico, Costa Rica and Colombia and also conserves some 3,000 hectares of natural forest in areas within and adjacent to its plantation holdings.  All of the Companies forest assets are managed in material compliance with applicable forestry codes, environmental and labor regulations, and IFCs Performance Standards on Environmental and Social Sustainability.  In addition, all Company plantations are managed in conformance with the Forest Stewardship Councils (FSC) Principles & Criteria for sustainable forest management and plantations older than five years have been certified by the Rainforest Alliances SmartWood Program. The Company has a valid FSC Chain of Custody (CoC) certification for its operations, including sawmills, indicating that the Company is able to track the legality and sustainability of its wood supply.
Review Scope: During appraisal, IFC assessed Proteaks forestry and wood processing practices against IFCs Performance Standards, local regulatory requirements and applicable requirements of the World Bank Groups General and sector-specific Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines (Forest Harvesting Operations and Sawmilling and Wood Based Products, 2007).  IFC reviewed the environment and social risks and impacts associated with the proposed project through site visits to Company plantations, nurseries, and wood milling facilities in Mexico, Costa Rica and Colombia. The team conducted interviews with field staff, contractors, and consultants at each location and reviewed Company policies, procedures and actual practices. For some plantations which were being acquired during appraisal prior management practices and FSC audits were reviewed and documentation of labor and occupational health and safety (OHS) practices examined to the extent possible. The appraisal relied largely on documents and reports made available by the Company and publicly disclosed audits of forest and financial performance, including:  - Environmental permitting and licensing documentation; - Spatial and cartographic information about plantations and natural forest assets;- National Forest Management Policies; - Company Forest Management Practices and Procedure Specifications;- FSC Assessment and Surveillance Reports (SW-FM-002110; SW-FM/COC-000098; SW-FM/COC-004221);- Contract agreements with principle contractors and suppliers; and- Workplace safety procedures and accident reports.  Through this review process, an assessment was made of the effectiveness of the Companys environmental and social management system and its ability to ensure and monitor compliance with regulatory requirements and IFCs Performance Standards.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project in accordance with IFCs Policy on Social and Environmental Sustainability.  The E&S risks and impacts associated with the proposed project can be prevented or mitigated through the combined use of a proactive environmental and social management system, application of established EHS safeguards and mitigation measures proven effective by other companies in the region, and use of internationally-recognized and externally-verified forestry practices.  Environmental and social issues reviewed during appraisal included:   - Current status of the companys environmental and social management systems;- Proposed OHS management practices of the Company and its contractors;- Identification and conservation of natural and critical habitats and protection of ecosystem services; - Prevention, detection and suppression of fire in plantation operations;- Energy use, efficiency and GHG emissions associated with all aspects of project development;- Management of hazardous materials, including all agrochemicals and operational petrochemicals;- Proposed approach and tools for community engagement during plantation establishment and operations.The Company proposes avoiding and mitigating environmental and social impacts by establishing clear operational procedures and management systems for the screening of land acquisitions or leases to ensure compliance with each countries environmental requirements as well as compliance with WBG EHS requirements and conformity with Forest Stewardship Councils Principles & Criteria.

Project Description: Aqualyng Holding AS (the Company) is a Norwegian water company that designs, builds, finances, owns and operates seawater reverse osmosis (SWRO) desalination plants with its own proprietary energy recovery technologies and equipment. In 2008, the Company was awarded a 30 year Build Own Operate Transfer (BOOT) desalination project with a product capacity of 50,000 cubic meters per day in the Caofeidian Industrial Zone, one of Chinas 13 pilot Eco-Cities with a planned area of 310 km2 in Tangshan City, Hebei Province. The plant will be one of the first commercial SWRO larger-scale plants in China to be in operation, and is planned to be expanded to 700,000 cubic meters per day. Water will be supplied to domestic and industrial customers within the industrial zone. The Company has also formed a joint venture with Beijing Enterprises Water Group Limited (BEWG), one of the top tier water companies in China in order to exclusively work on Chinese desalination projects. Aqualyng will also form a separate joint venture for its technology / equipment manufacturing with a leading desalination contractor in China. This partnership will serve to commercialize and market the Companys energy recovery device for sea water SWRO and other technologies. The proposed IFC investment is to support the Companys expansion into the Chinese market by funding investments into new desalination projects in China as well as in the establishment of a future manufacturing base for its technology and equipment sales in China.
Review Scope: The scope of review of Aqualyngs compliance with IFCs Performance Standards included assessment of Aqualyng''s management capacity of its environmental, social, health and safety performance in relation to IFC Performance Standards, national (PRC) regulatory requirements and relevant Environmental Health and Safety guidelines. The review relied on documents and reports made available by Aqualyng, IFC technical experts report, and interviews conducted by IFC staff. Meetings and interviews with key staff (business development, operations, human resources, environmental, social, health and safety) were conducted, and numerous, relevant procedures demonstrating the Companys management capacity to provide adequate oversight of its environmental, social, health and safety performance in conducting its business were discussed. The IFC team also visited the Companys first water desalination concession in China (Caofeidian) which is anticipated to begin commercial operations in the second quarter of 2012.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because it will create a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that can be minimized, avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria. The project has a very limited footprint, and is collocated with other industries in an exclusive industrial zone located on a purpose built manmade island. The Company''s desalination project at Caofeidian complies with all regulatory requirements and is subject to strict environmental oversight by local regulatory agencies.

Project Description: The proposed investment consists in the construction of a greenfield integrated medical complex (Binaria) in northern Monterrey that focuses on addressing the need for quality medical infrastructure in northern Monterrey through the construction of a secondary care hospital (Hospitaria) and ancillary services. The area of northern Monterrey significantly lacks quality health care services although the area has been growing substantially. The integrated medical complex includes the construction of (i) a 50 bed hospital, (ii) a consultation tower, and (iii) adjacent commercial space for specialty clinics, medical services and other related services. IFC proposed investment consists in financing the construction of Hospitaria, its medical equipment, and the pre-operating expenses related to the opening of the hospital.
Impact: Provision of quality health care services to an underserved area: Both Ambar Capital and Ginequito are committed to providing quality health care services to an area which continues to grow substantially, without access to quality healthcare. The hospital will represent the first secondary care hospital in the area, thus improving the quality of health care to the local population.   Demonstration effect: The envisioned Project is innovative in comprising a fully integrated medical complex and designed with energy efficient systems. This is expected to have a demonstration effect for further health care projects in Mexico. IFC will assist in implementing and encouraging further "green" construction. Strong social commitment: Ginequito has historically shown a strong commitment towards the community. The expansion will allow for Ginequito to continue its contribution to the community.Urban frontier: The hospital will be constructed in an area of Monterrey, which does not have quality medical services readily available. The local population living in the northern part of Monterrey will benefit significantly from the planned hospital building and adjacent medical facilities.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure, because of the limited number of adverse impacts that may occur which are generally site specific and can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to IFCs Performance Standards, good international industry practice, guidelines or design criteria.  Identified Applicable Performance StandardsWhile all Performance Standards are applicable to this investment, IFCs environmental and social due diligence indicates that the investment will have impacts which must be managed in a manner consistent with the following Performance Standards:PS1: Social and Environmental Assessment and Management Systems PS2: Labor and Working ConditionsPS3: Pollution Prevention and AbatementPS4: Community Health and SafetyThe WBG EH&S General Guidelines, as well as the EH&S Guidelines for Health Care Facilities also apply. Issues related to the following IFC Performance Standards were not identified during IFCs review:PS5: Land Acquisition and Involuntary Resettlement: the land for the development was obtained from a housing developer a number of years ago under a willing buyer-willing seller scenario; no one was living on, or making a living from the land at that time. PS6: Biodiversity Conservation and Sustainable Natural Resource Management: Hospitarias proposed new medical center will not have impacts upon biodiversity or natural resources due to the site being located within an established industrial/commercial area located in the north of Monterrey.PS7: Indigenous Peoples: No Indigenous People are impacted by the location of the proposed project.PS8: Cultural Heritage: No sites of cultural heritage are impacted by the location of the development.
Sponsor: Hospitaria Tenedora, S.A.P.I. de C.V. (the 'Company') has two Sponsors, namely Ambar Capital (financial partner) and Ginequito (operational partner).Ambar Capital is a Mexican family fund (the 'Fund') based in Monterrey, which was incorporated in 2009, and owns 50% of Hospitaria and 100% of Binaria. The Fund focuses on the education, health and technology sectors, and has a portfolio of around $25 million in nine companies. Ginequito owns 50% of Hospitaria and represents one of the leading hospitals in Monterrey. The hospital has over 35 years of experience and specializes in gynecology and obstetrics. It is a private hospital and is owned by 95 doctors.
Cost Nature: The total Project cost is approximately $32 million. The proposed IFC investment consists of an approximately $5.5 million A Loan and an approximately $5.5 million C Loan in Mexican Pesos for IFC's own account.

Project Description: IFC plans to provide an approximately US$11 million loan for the construction of a greenfield hospital in Monterrey, Mexico. IFC will finance the SPV that will own the hospital building, of which Ambar Capital and Ginequito are 50/50 owners. The Project consists of the construction of a medical complex in the northern part of the city, that will include (i) a 50 bed hospital, (ii) a consultation tower, (iii) specialty clinics, to include amongst others, rehabilitation, hemodialysis, chemotherapy, and (iv) adjacent commercial space for medical care products and services, such as diagnostics and imagery laboratories, cafeteria, and banks. The hospital will be operated by Ginequito, who will replicate its operating model developed over 35 years
Review Scope: IFC conducted a field appraisal of a greenfield hospital development (Hospitaria, already under construction) in Monterrey, Mexico. The appraisal included a visit to the construction site, a tour of the building, interviews with project management and a review of construction plans including those pertaining to life and fire safety. In addition, an existing hospital operation (Ginequito) in downtown Monterrey was visited to understand the operating companys ability and willingness to put in place systems to manage the environmental and social risks and impacts associated with a new hospital development of this type.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an E&S category B project because, on the basis of information reviewed by IFC, this investment will have limited adverse social and environmental impacts that are few in number, are generally site specific, largely reversible and readily addressed through mitigation measures, as outlined in the Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) attached to this ESRS. The main issues include the replication and staffing of a management system, of the same standard reviewed in the existing hospital operation, to assess and manage environmental, occupational health and safety and community issues related to operations. Specific attention will be required to ensure Life and Fire Safety systems are constructed and operated according to relevant national and international standards.

Project Description: Trivon AG ('Trivon' or the 'Company') is a broadband service provider operating in Russia. The Company operates with the brand name of Virgin Connect, under a brand license agreement with Virgin. The Company provides broadband services to both business and residential customers through a combination of wireless and fiber-optic solutions and has acquired both regional operating licenses and regional frequencies. The project consists of the expansion of the Company's services through investment in network optimization followed by the acquisition and integration of small broadband operators in Russia and growing them organically through the Company's operating skills and expertise. The Company was founded in 2004 by a group of senior telecom executives and is headquartered in Zug, Switzerland. The Company had 300 employees as of October, 2011, with all but a handful located in Russia.
Impact: 1. Increase Access to Broadband: The Company mainly operates in fifteen regions of Russia. The Company's strategy is to acquire operators in these regions lacking the necessary cash resources to invest in their own infrastructure and then invest in the required infrastructure to increase broadband penetration.2. Increase Competition: Currently 82% of the broadband market is captured by six operators with the remaining 18% spread between several dozens of smaller operators. As the Company expands, offering high quality broadband services with exceptional customer service, incumbent operators will start investing in infrastructure to increase their service levels, resulting in a more competitive market in which broadband prices are expected to decline, benefiting customers.3. Employment Creation and Skills Transfer:  As the Company expands local jobs will be created and with the Company's commitment towards providing high quality training to all their staff, local talent and skills deployment will be enhanced in frontier regions of Russia.
Environmental Social Issues: Environmental and social risks and impacts in this project are expected to be low, so the project is classified as Category C according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.
Sponsor: Trivon has a varied shareholder base with the executive founders, Mr. Markus Mueller (CEO Acquisitions and Finance) and Mr. Istvan Kovacs (CEO Operations) holding 6.3% and 3.1% shareholding respectively.  Both Mr. Mueller and Mr. Kovacs have over 20 years experience in the telecom and information technology industry. Prior to founding Trivon, Mr. Mueller was Chief Financial Officer at a Swiss private family office managing assets in excess of US$1bn. Mr. Kovacs spent his earlier career at Lockheed Martin Intersputnik in various roles, the last of which was VP Central Europe of Lockheed Martin Global Telecom. Other shareholders in the project are Virgin (16.6% shareholding), Delta Partners (15.2% shareholding), and Eurasia Capital (13.5% shareholding) while the remaining shareholding of 45.3% is held by a number of high-net-worth individuals. Virgin is a leading branded venture capital organization and is one of the world's most recognized and respected brands. Delta Partners is a leading integrated management advisory and investment firm specialized in emerging telecom and technology markets, while Eurasia Capital is a fund management firm focused on investing and advising in emerging markets including Russia, Central Asia and Mongolia.Trivon operates in the Russian market under the brand name 'Virgin Connect'. The Company has the right to use the Virgin brand name in the Russian market under a long term franchise agreement with Virgin.
Cost Nature: Total Project Costs is estimated at US$131 million. IFC's proposed equity investment of up to US$25 million will mostly be used for network optimization of current operations, and for partial funding of the Company's expected acquisitions.  The remaining financing will come from existing investors as well as potential co-investors.
Investment: 25.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan0.0Equity25.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Trivon is nominally headquartered in Zug, Switzerland and has its main office in Moscow with sales offices  in fifteen regions across Russia.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Environmental and social risks and impacts in this project are expected to be low, so the project is classified as Category C according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.

Project Description: The proposal is to invest equity and debt, along with strategic partners, to create a platform to acquire and service a distressed asset (DA) portfolio of Rizal Commercial Banking Corporation (RCBC), the 5th largest bank in the Philippines in terms of asset size.Through the proposed project, IFC will play a critical role to (i) help re-activate the DA market in the Philippines; (ii) mobilize funding from the private sector, helping address the limited capital currently available in the current local NPL market; and (iii) provide a major bank with an attractive mechanism for NPL resolution.
Impact: (i) Market development: The successful implementation of the project could spark the interest of other market players and evolve into a common practice.  Furthermore, this could become an important stabilization mechanism for the Philippine financial sector and help IFC to address the current NPLs issues of the bank;(ii) Best practices: As part of the project IFC would promote international insolvency standards, creditors'' rights and collection practices for the resolution of the distressed assets; and(iii) Market transparency: Through this project, IFC would be helping to assign a market value to a NPL portfolio.  If successful, the proposed project has the potential to be replicated by other entities in Asia.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves creating a SPV to purchase and service a pool of non-performing assets and has been classified as a Category FI according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. During appraisal, Altus or the servicer will need to provide information pertaining to the pool''s exposure to the activities on IFC''s FI Exclusion List as well as information on any unresolved social and environmental issues or high risk projects in the pool. If the review indicates that the pool is broadly in compliance with IFC E&S requirements, the SPV servicer will be required to follow international best collection practices and to establish a Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS), satisfactory to IFC and prior to IFC commitment, to work with the borrowers and (the bank where needed;  the bank is in the process to develop and implement its own SEMS) to achieve compliance with the IFC Exclusion List, applicable national E&S laws and regulations, and where necessary IFCs Performance Standards. The asset service company is also required to submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be prescribed by IFC.
Sponsor: The majority of the Banks shares are owned by a conglomerate, and the balance of the Banks shares are owned by various shareholders.
Cost Nature: The project will consist on the acquisition and resolution of a non-performing asset (NPA) portfolio of face value of around US$85 million, for a total purchase price of US$55.0 million.
Investment: 32.41 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan32.41Equity0.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Bank is headquartered in Metro Manila, Philippines and the assets of the DA portfolio are located in Metro Manila, Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao, Philippines.
