Company Name: AMETHIS MAGHREB FUND I SICAV-SIF S.C.A.
Project Description: The project consists of up to 10 million equity commitment not to exceed 20% of total commitments in Capital North Africa Venture Fund II ('CNAV Fund II' or the 'Fund'), a private equity fund which will make equity and quasi-equity investments in small and mid-size enterprises ('SMEs'). In terms of regional focus, the Fund will primarily focus on companies in Morocco but will also target investments in Algeria and Tunisia. The Fund will also make opportunistic investments in Egypt and West Africa. The Fund has a committed capital target size of 70-100 million and will be managed by Capital Invest Group, a fund management company to be established in Luxembourg.
Impact: Supporting SMEs: The Fund's strategy is to target SMEs with high upside potential but that lack access to finance due to limited resources in the market. Private Sector development: The Fund will provide not only capital but also managerial support and expertise to SMEs in North Africa region to improve their competitiveness and sustainability.Implementation of best practice for corporate governance in portfolio companies: The Fund will adopt international best practices for corporate governance and management, as well as transparency, thus fostering knowledge and skill transfer, and encouraging best practices across the industry.Job creation: Unemployment constitutes one of the greatest barriers for poverty alleviation and economic development in the region. The Fund's target countries including Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia and Egypt exhibit high unemployment rates. The Fund's strategy is to target high growth companies, which will make a positive contribution to job creation and economic growth.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category "FI" project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.During appraisal, IFC analyzed the Fund''s pipeline, for types of transactions, size, and industry sectors and determined the Applicable Performance Requirements based on an analysis of the potential Social and Environmental risks associated with the Fund''s pipeline. Considering IFCs investment, the Applicable Performance Requirements are:- The IFC FI Exclusion List;- The applicable National Social and Environmental Laws and regulations; and- The IFC Performance Standards. IFC also reviewed the Fund''s existing Environmental & Social due diligence process and identified gaps in the current Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS). Based on the Applicable Performance Requirements and the ESMS capacity review, the project will be required to:-	Upgrade, as a condition of IFC commitment, the ESMS to outlines screening against the Applicable Performance Requirements to the satisfaction of IFC;-	   ensure continuous appointment of a qualified person(s) to manage and implement the ESMS and notify IFC in case the appointed person is replaced;-	commit to implement the ESMS, to ensure that its investments/activities are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements;-	take action to remedy any gaps in ESMS implementation on an going basis; and-	submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC. IFC will review the implementation and performance of the Fund''s ESMS for the first few projects; prior to the Fund''s investment, to ensure that the SEMS functions properly. The Fund will also notify IFC for any investment in Category "A" project.
Sponsor: Capital Invest Group will be sponsored by its two principal investment executives namely Mr. Mehdi Tahiri and Mr. Omar Chikhaoui.  Mr. Tahiri is the Chairman of Argan Invest, fund management arm of FinanceCom group. He joined BMCE Capital in 1999 and launched the FinanceCom group's private equity activities. He remained CEO of Capital Invest until 2006 when FinanceCom group decided to launch ARIF after which he moved to Argan Invest. During 1995 to 1999, Mr.Tahiri was a Senior Consultant at Arthur Andersen (Paris). Mr. Tahiri is an engineering graduate of the Ecole des Mines in Paris. Mr. Chikhaoui is the Chairman of Capital Invest, the manager of the investment funds - Capital Morocco and CNAV Fund I. He has more than 15 years of experience within the domain of Expansion Capital and Buyouts and initiated the first leveraged buyout transactions in Morocco. Mr. Chikhaoui was previously the chairman of the Moroccan Venture Capital Association and is also the President of Club Invest. Previously, he was a business manager in the venture capital companies Asma Invest and Fayçal Finance. Mr. Chikhaoui has an M.B.A. in Finance and a Master's Degree in Management (International Finance) from University of Dallas, and is a certified Chartered Financial Analyst (CFA).

Company Name: COMERCIAL CITY FRESKO, S. DE R.L. DE C.V.
Project Description: This project is proposed under the Global Trade Supplier Finance program (GTSF or the Program) approved by the IFC Board in September 2010. (Original Project Link #28723).Controladora Comercial Mexicana (CCM or Comerci or the Company) is the fourth largest retailer in Mexico with 227 retail stores, 74 restaurants and 5 distribution centers under operation as of December 31 2011. It is listed on the Mexican Stock Exchange (BMV) and, as of January 20 2012, had a market capitalization of approx. US$2.1 billion. It has 4 business lines (retail, restaurants, real estate management, and a 50-50 JV with Costco) with retail being the largest one as it represents 75% of its revenues (mainly food). Comerci has supplier finance (SF) program in place with NAFIN providing SF to 700 of its suppliers, the large majority of which are small of medium enterprises (SMEs).The Project will establish a Supplier Finance (SF) program and make financing available to the suppliers of Commercial Controladora Mexicana (Comerci or CCM or the Company), through the discounting of receivables of the suppliers payable by Comerci.  The SF program will have an IFC-funded, uncommitted credit line of US$100mn to be split in: i) US$85 million equivalent denominated in Mexican Pesos (MXN) and targeted to CCMs Mexican SME suppliers and ii) US$15 million denominated in USD and targeted to CCMs foreign suppliers based in emerging markets. The program will be implemented through PrimeRevenue, a Supply Chain Finance platform, and its local re-seller, E-Factor Network (EFN), and it is expected to reach 700 Suppliers  the large majority of which will be SMEs.
Review Scope: IFC reviewed CCMs information publicly available including the current Company structure, Comercis 2010 corporate social responsibility (CSR) and Sustainability Report and supplemental information provided by the Companys Deputy Procurement Director, who acts as CSR and Sustainability lead for Comerci. Of CCMs business lines Tiendas Comercial Mexicana represents 75% of its revenues, and similar percentage of its suppliers, which mainly involve food companies, but also home goods, apparel and footwear manufacturers. Potential adverse E&S impacts of the GTSF project arise at the level of the Suppliers.  All Performance Standards are applicable to operations of potential suppliers to be supported by the Project.  In supplier financing programs of this nature, IFC assesses environmental and social (E&S) risk at Suppliers to Buyers (such as Comerci in this proposed transaction) by assessing the Buyers systems for management of E&S performance of their Suppliers.  Therefore the Buyer (Comerci) assessment reported in this Environmental and Social Review Summary considers the application by Comerci of PS1 Social and Environmental Assessment and Management Systems as described below.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: E&S risks associated with Comercis food suppliers are related to the production of raw materials, initial processing in situ, further manufacturing at industrial level, and distribution. Production of raw material, depending on the foodstuff, and the size and characteristics of the farm, commonly involves issues of labor and working conditions, pollution from fertilizers and pesticides, and management of agricultural waste. On occasion, there may also be impacts related to land acquisition and resource management (especially water). Food processing may also involve issues pertaining labor and working conditions including occupational health and safety, pollution prevention and resource management. A key issue for food production and distribution is food safety, including traceability.The most common E&S risks associated with the apparel and shoe manufacturing sector relate to labor and working conditions, whilst potential adverse environmental impacts can arise from failure of adequate treatment for process or sanitary waste effluents.The above issues are readily manageable and site specific: this is therefore considered to be an E&S Category B project. CCM will be subject to satisfactory CES assessment of their supply chain and supplier compliance with IFC Performance Standards
Sector: BA - Retail (Including Supermarkets, Grocery Stores, etc.)

Project Description: The project entails a risk sharing facility ('RSF' or 'the Facility') to support a portfolio of up to US$70.6 million of Energy Efficiency (EE) and Renewable (RE) loans of generated by the Bank of the Philippine Islands ('BPI' or the 'Bank').   IFC will guarantee 50% of the portfolio for a maximum risk amount of up to US$35.3 million.  The Bank is the third largest universal bank in the Philippines in terms of total assets and the country's largest bank in terms of market capitalization. The Bank is a publicly listed domestic universal bank offering a wide range of financial services that include corporate, consumer, overseas and investment banking as well as asset management and insurance.The proposed project, which is a repeat project and builds on the success of IFC's and BPI's partnership in the first Sustainable Energy Finance (SEF) RSF, fits into IFC's strategic objectives because it increases access to finance to EE and RE projects in the Philippines.  The project is part of the Philippine Sustainable Energy Program (PSEFP) which aims to establish partnerships with local banks using financial products and technical advisory to increase funding to RE and EE projects.
Impact: The project is expected to contribute to the development and diversification of the financial sector by assisting in the development of new markets and product lines in sustainable finance with significant growth potential.  This in turn will continue to have positive demonstration effect in the commercial mainstreaming of RE/EE finance among other commercial banks.  Lastly, the project will contribute to pollution reduction by increasing usage of more energy efficient and renewable energy technologies.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Portfolio activities of the proposed new project shall be consistent with the IFC FI Exclusion List, applicable national E&S laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards. Under the existing project (SEF RSF I), BPI has developed a social and environmental management system (SEMS), appointed staff to oversee the SEMS implementation and submitted annual reports to IFC.  A recent review of SEF RSF Is annual report assigned an E&S risk rating of F2 (average). During the appraisal for the new project, IFC will further assess SEF RSF I existing portfolio and new pipeline activities E&S risks, and may suggest supplemental actions to address any gaps in its SEMS implementation if needed. In addition, the client will be required to retain qualified person(s) to manage and implement the SEMS, submit periodic reports to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC and to apply the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions to its HR practices.
Sponsor: The two main shareholders of BPI are Ayala Corporation and Development Bank of Singapore. Ayala Corporation ('AC')AC is the flagship company of the Ayala family, a successful business group in the country. AC's four core businesses are real estate (through Ayala Land Inc.), financial services (through BPI), telecommunications (through Globe Telecom, Inc.) and a portfolio of other investments.Development Bank of Singapore ('DBS')DBS, established in 1968, is a full service bank and an integral part of DBS Group Holdings Ltd. The group is one of the largest banking groups in Asia-Pacific.
Cost Nature: The total size of the Facility is estimated to be US$70.6 million. Under the proposed terms of the Facility, BPI would be responsible for generating a portfolio of loans that satisfy certain criteria set by the Bank and IFC. Project Description: IFC proposes to invest up to US$75 million (up to 7 years) in ZAO Raiffeisenbanks (the Bank or RBRU) Diversified Payment Rights (DPR) securitization. IFC will play the role of a lead investor, which will significantly contribute to the deal reaching the issuance amount of up to US$250 million. The proceeds from IFCs investment would be directed towards on-lending to subnational entities to support their investment in the essential economic and social infrastructure, and SMEs.
Impact: The proposed Project is expected to have a number of the development impacts:1. Capital market development: As the first DPR securitization out of Russia since the crisis, this would provide an important signaling effect to the market and could set the stage for subsequent Russian DPRs.2. The deal would create a long-term funding source for the Bank.3. The Project is expected to positively impact private sector development by increasing access to finance for SMEs.  Long-term financing is crucial for the sustainable development of the private sector across the country that would result in improved economic development and improved living conditions. 4. The Project would contribute to the objective of commercial long-term lending without sovereign guarantees to well-performing subnational entities to support their investment in the essential economic and social infrastructure.5.    Demonstration effect: A succesful closing with the participation of other IFI''s could be used as a model for replication with other Western European banks with emerging market subsidiaries.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed project has been classified category FI according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure and involves purchase of a DPR securitization bond.  Under the DPR investment, IFC will direct up to US$75 million of financing towards investment in economic and social infrastructure projects, such as water, heating, and municipal finance and provide financing for SME lending.  CES appraisal focused on e&s risks of the infrastructure projects proposed for financing and on the Banks existing capacity to manage such risks.  The applicable performance requirements for the Banks lending activities include the IFC Exclusion List, Russian social and environmental laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards.  The Bank will be required to make revisions to its existing Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS), appoint staff responsible for SEMS implementation, and submit an Annual Social and Environmental Performance report to IFC.  In addition, due diligence will be carried out on the Banks HR policies and practices to determine compliance with IFC''s Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions.
Sponsor: ZAO Raiffeisenbank is a subsidiary of Raiffeisen Bank International AG (RBI). The Bank has been operating in Russia since 1996 and offers a full range of services to retail and corporate customers.  RBRU ranks 10th among the Russian banks in terms of assets, 5th in terms of private deposits and 11th with regard to lending to non-banking sector as of 31/12/2011 according to  ranking information published by  Interfax CEA on the basis of annual 2011 results according to Russian accounting standards.RBI is a leading universal bank in Central and Eastern Europe (CEE) and one of the foremost providers of corporate and investment banking services in Austria. RBI originated from the merger of the spun-off principal business areas of Raiffeisen Zentralbank Österreich AG (RZB) with Raiffeisen International Bank-Holding AG. The transaction was legally completed in October 2010. RBI is a fully-consolidated subsidiary of RZB, which owns around 78.5 per cent of the banks common stock. The remainder is in free float, with the shares listed on the Vienna Stock Exchange.
Cost Nature: The targeted issuance amount in RBRUs inaugural DPR securitization is up to US$250 million of which IFC would consider investing up to US$75 million from its own account.

Project Description: The proposed project is a risk sharing facility ('RSF') with CREDIT AGRICOLE BANK (the 'Bank'), a 99.9955%-owned Ukrainian subsidiary of Credit Agricole S.A, on portfolio of receivables generated by Bayer in connection with sales of crop-protection products to private sector farmers in Ukraine. The RSF will cover a portfolio of seasonal receivables (with maturities less than 1 year) with a total portfolio amount of up to US$35 million equivalent in local currency. IFC will share 50% of credit losses in the portfolio with the Bank up to a maximum IFC exposure of up to US$17.5 million equivalent in the local currency. IFC will enter into agreement with Bayer in order to complement the risk sharing arrangement with the Bank.CREDIT AGRICOLE BANK is a medium-size universal bank ranked ?32 in the Ukrainian banking system with ca. US$800 million of total assets and total equity of approximately US$100 million. It serves around 400,000 clients via its network of 200 branches and outlets covering all regions of Ukraine. CREDIT AGRICOLE BANK is universal bank with specific focus on the agricultural sector. The Bank has defined agriculture as priority sector for their operations in Ukraine. Its exposure to agri-sector reached US$157 million and constituted 26% of the Bank's loan portfolio as of mid-2011.The proposed project will be IFC's second engagement with Bayer Ltd, main supplier of plant protection products in Ukraine with revenues of approx. US$150 million. The Company's clients are mainly represented by small and medium size farmers.
Impact: IFC involvement through this transaction is expected to have a strong development impact, through:(i)	increased and improved access to financial services for agricultural SME's and farmers;(ii)	improved productivity through the provision of certified, top quality crop protection products and know-how to SME farmers;(iii)	improvement of Bayer's and farmers' integrated pest and disease management (IPM/IDM) approach, coordinated use of pest and environmental information along with available pest control methods, including cultural practices, biological, genetic and, as a last resort, chemical means to prevent unacceptable levels of pest damage.
Environmental Social Issues: This repeat investment remains a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Sustainability Policy because IFCs review and supervision of the Companys activities indicates no changes in Bayers business operations, therefore this investment will not result in any material change in relation to the associated environmental and social risks and impacts. Given the fact that transportation and storage are carried out by Bayers contractors, the Project has limited environmental and social adverse impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to Ukrainian laws and regulations and generally recognized good industry practices and guidelines.
Sponsor: The Project is cosponsored by CREDIT AGRICOLE BANK and Bayer Ltd. CREDIT AGRICOLE BANK is 99,9955%-owned by Credit Agricole S.A. France ('CA'), one of the largest financial banks in Europe in terms of income from retail business. CA is represented in more than 70 countries serving 54 million customers worldwide. The Group's long-term ratings are: A+ Stable Outlook (Fitch); Aa3 Negative Outlook (Moodys); A Stable Outlook (S&P). In Ukraine, CA has two subsidiaries: (i) CA, and (ii) a corporate investment bank, CIB Credit Agricole, in operation 18 years. CA plans to strengthen its position at the Ukrainian market through consolidation of the two subsidiaries in 2012-2013.  After consolidation, the bank would have US$1.3 billion in total assets and be ranked ?21 in Ukraine.Bayer Ltd. is a Ukrainian entity wholly owned by Bayer AG, a Germany-based pharmaceuticals, polymers and agrochemicals conglomerate with sales of approximately 35 billion and EBITDA of approximately of 6.3 billion in 2010. The group's structure consists of three divisions: (i) Bayer Healthcare, (ii) Bayer CropScience, and (iii) Bayer MateriaScience. Bayer CropScience, with revenues of approximately 6.8 billion in 2010, manufactures herbicides, insecticides, fungicides, seed treatment and seeds.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $17.5 million for IFC's own account, to be provided as a risk sharing facility on the portfolio of up to $35 million of receivables generated by Bayer Ltd. to its existing and new farmer clients. The CAB will provide a guarantee to farmers which will allow them to buy on credit from Bayer.
Investment: 17.50 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuarantee17.50LoanEquity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Bayer and the Bank are headquartered in the capital of Ukraine, Kyiv. Credit Agricole Bank operates around 200 outlets located in big cities, provincial and district centers across Ukraine. Bayer Ltd. covers the entire territory of Ukraine via the chain of local distributors.

Given the fact that transportation and storage are carried out by Bayers contractors, the Project has limited environmental and social adverse impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to Ukrainian laws and regulations and generally recognized good industry practices and guidelines.

Project Description: The proposed project is a risk sharing facility (RSF) with CREDIT AGRICOLE BANK (the Bank), a 99.9955%-owned Ukrainian subsidiary of Credit Agricole S.A, on portfolio of receivables generated by Bayer in connection with sales of crop-protection products to private sector farmers in Ukraine. The RSF will cover a portfolio of seasonal receivables (with maturities less than 1 year) with a total portfolio amount of up to US$35 million equivalent in local currency. IFC will share 50% of credit losses in the portfolio with the Bank up to a maximum IFC exposure of up to US$17.5 million equivalent in the local currency. IFC will enter into agreement with Bayer in order to complement the risk sharing arrangement with the Bank.The Project is designed to improve access to finance for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) that purchase or would purchase, should they have access to credit, certified and top quality crop protection products from Bayer Ltd., Ukraine (the Company or Bayer Ukraine). Bayer Ltd., Ukraine, a fully owned subsidiary of Bayer AG, offers products in three business areas: CropScience (crop protection and non-agricultural pest control), HealthCare (pharmaceutical and medical products) and Material Science (high-tech polymers and materials). The Company is a main input supplier of crop protection products, mainly insecticides, herbicides and fungicides in Ukraine and the Project will support the Companys plans to extend its reach to a larger pool of farmers who currently lack access to credit and are using fewer and lower quality products for their agricultural production.
Review Scope: The proposed project is a repeat IFCs risk sharing facility with Bayer Ukraine and Raiffeisen Aval and extension of IFCs commitment with Bayer through risk sharing facility that will entail partnering with Credit Agricole in Ukraine. The environmental and social (E&S) review of the existing project (Project # 30595) was conducted in March 2011. The summary of the review (ESRS) and the Action Plan (ESAP) can be found at the following link: http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/ProjectDisplay/ESRS30595 To determine the compliance of the existing project with at-approval agreements and evaluate the new proposed Project, the scope of the appraisal included a site supervision visit to Bayer Ukraine in January 2012. The site visit has focused on key updates and changes in Bayers quality, health, safety and environment (QHSE) policies and procedures, Ukrainian legal framework, incident statistics, local regulatory product certification, Bayers communications with farmers on safe use of crop protection products (CPP) and promotion of Integrated Pest/Disease Management (IPM/IDM) plans. The E&S appraisal of this new project consisted of discussions with Bayers senior management, including the QHSE manager; the occupational health and safety (OHS) specialist; representatives of human resources, logistic, legal, supply chain, marketing, business development, customer services and sales departments. Also, the implementation progress of the ESAP agreed upon under project #30595 and actions to enhance Bayers E&S performance were discussed during this site visit. These actions will be implemented in the framework of the existing ESAP, which is also applicable for the proposed project.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This repeat investment remains a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Sustainability Policy because IFCs review and supervision of the Companys activities indicates no changes in Bayers business operations, therefore this investment will not result in any material change in relation to the associated environmental and social risks and impacts. Given the fact that transportation and storage are carried out by Bayers contractors, the Project has limited environmental and social adverse impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to Ukrainian laws and regulations and generally recognized good industry practices and guidelines.
Sector: AG - Diversified Edible Agricultural Crops Production

Project Description: Titan Cement Company S.A. (Titan Group, the Group or the Sponsor), an existing IFC client and Greeces leading private cement company, is seeking to expand its cooperation with IFC by inviting IFC to invest in its Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM), Kosovo, and Serbia operations.  These operations mainly consist of three entities: Cementara Kosjeric (TCK),  Cementarnica Usje (TCU), and SharrCem (TSC) (together, the Companies) that have a combined production capacity of about 3.5 million tons per annum (mtpa) and are engaged in an investment program which also  includes environmental improvements and various debottlenecking investments in all plants (the Project).
Impact: (i)	Contributing to further improving infrastructure development and strengthening the capacity of the construction sector and related activities, a key growth and local sustainability area for the Balkans in the long-term(ii)	Supporting employment and enabling entrepreneurial opportunities through increased operational efficiencies at energy consumption, resource utilization, etc.(iii)	Contributing and safeguarding income to the Governments through taxes as a result of the plants'' operations and continuous performance improvement(iv)	Supporting and strengthening local SMEs by promoting  sub-contracting at local level and investing in their continuous performance improvement
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed project is to invest in environmental, energy efficiency and debottlenecking upgrades to existing cement plants that have been under the Titan Group''s control for some years. The upgrades are being developed in accordance with national regulatory requirements and international standards by a Sponsor committed to and with a long track record of good environmental and social management.  The project will follow international labor standards, will only have emissions and discharges from controlled sources in compliance with local regulations and World Bank Group (WBG) guidelines, and will include sustainable quarry operation planning including progressive quarry rehabilitation. As documented further in this document there is no involuntary resettlement.  With no indication of impacts related to Performance Standards 5, 7 and 8 and only readily mitigated environmental issues under Performance Standards 1 through 4 and 6 this is a Category B project.
Sponsor: Titan Group is an independent cement and building materials producer with over 100 years of industry experience. Based in Greece, Titan Group owns 14 cement plants in 9 countries, with half of these plants being in emerging markets. Titan is listed on the Athens Stock Exchange and is a core member of the World Business Council for Sustainable Development. In 2011, Titan Group sold 15.3 m. tons of cement and cementitious materials and had revenues of EUR1.1 billion and EBITDA of EUR243 million.
Cost Nature: IFC is considering a potential investment in the company which will consolidate the Groups operations in FYROM, Kosovo and Serbia, in the form of a minority equity stake.  Total Project cost is estimated to be EUR 75 million for the period 2011-2016.

TCU  Titan Cementarnica Usje A.D. is located in Skopje and has an annual production capacity of about 1.7 mtpa of cement. TSC-SharrCem SH.PK is located in Hani Elezit, Kosovo and has an annual production capacity of about 1.0 mtpa of cement.

As documented further in this document there is no involuntary resettlement.  With no indication of impacts related to Performance Standards 5, 7 and 8 and only readily mitigated environmental issues under Performance Standards 1 through 4 and 6 this is a Category B project.

Project Description: Tonicorp is one of the largest agribusiness companies in Ecuador.  Through its subsidiary Industrias Lacteas Toni SA (ILT), Toni is the leading dairy company in Ecuador.  The Group processes milk purchased from +2,400 farmers into a wide range of dairy products (UHT milk, flavored milk, cream, butter, cheese and yogurt) and produces bottled water, energy drinks and fruit beverages from concentrate under the licensed Tampico brand.  In all product categories Toni commands between 50-70% market share.  The Group also owns Plasticos Ecuatorianos SA (Plasticos), a packaging plant that supplies the dairy business and sells to 3rd parties, and Dipor SA (Dipor), which distributes all of ILTs products.With a production capacity of ~200,000 liters of milk/day, Toni operates a plant located in an industrial area of Guayaquil.  This plant, originally designed in the early 1970s to produce 7,000 MT/year of yogurt, is currently producing +30,000 MTs. Although the Group has managed to grow its capacity over time in order to keep up with increasing demand, the plant is currently cramped, having reached a point where there is no more space to grow, or changes to the layout would derived in loss of efficiencies.  Therefore, ILT is currently planning to move the plant to a new site (the Project). This will allow increasing production capacity, generating efficiencies through better layout, newer equipment and improving E&S management.
Impact: IFC will be supporting the continued growth of one of Ecuador''s leading agribusiness companies in terms of employment and linkages through the value chain and one of the most important staple food producers in the country.  The Project will contribute to improve Toni''s competititveness in the production and commercialization of dairy products, and help the Company extend its reach toward the interior of Ecuador.  Toni has a strong base of the pyramid focus as it services more than 90,000 small shops, and sources milk from approximately 2,300 small and medium-size farmers, most of them located in rural frontier regions where employment opportunities are scarce.  Its activities therefore have a considerable reach in the local economy and impact on livelihood of local population.There are specific developmental impacts associated with the Project, which are summarized below:Product Safety: consumption of raw milk is still very popular in Ecuador, in particular in the interior of the country. This is considered a health hazard as the product does not meet minimum health and safety standards. On the contrary, Toni''s products conform with high quality and safety standards, and therefore reduce public health risks for consumers.  Toni''s growth strategy in the interior of Ecuador will displace consumption of raw milk with high quality and safe products.Employment: Toni''s improved performance and increased production capacity will result in higher employment opportunities at the plant, and in rural areas througout the country.Farmers linkages: Toni sources milk from direct and indirect farmers througout the country.  As a consequence of the Project, Toni will further develop milk production and tehrefore enhance and stabilize farmers'' income and increase hired employment on dairy farms.
Environmental Social Issues: This is category B project according to IFCs Policy on Social and Environmental Sustainability because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, EHS general and sector-specific guidelines or design criteria.
Sponsor: Founded in 1978 by Mr. Francisco Alarcon, Toni is mainly owned by the Alarcon family: Mr. Francisco Alarcon Alcivar (58.3%), Ms. Barbara Alarcon Alcivar (20.9%), Mr. Jaime Patricio Alarcon (4.7%), Ms. Maria del Carmen Alarcon (3.6%), and Ms. Maria Gloria Alarcon Alcivar (1.5%).  The rest is floating in the Quito stock exchange.
Cost Nature: Total project cost over the 2011-2014 period is estimated at US$60 million. IFC is considering providing the Company with a US$30 million A-Loan for IFCs own account.
Investment: 30.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan30.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: ILTs existing plant is located in an industrial area of Guayaquil, Ecuador. The new plant will be built in a new site in the Guayaquil area as well.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is category B project according to IFCs Policy on Social and Environmental Sustainability because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, EHS general and sector-specific guidelines or design criteria.

Project Description: The proposed modernization Project entails the replacement of obsolete equipment with more efficient machinery at Nile Kordsa Company for Industrial Fabrics S.A.E (the Company). Based in 10th of  Ramadan City, Area No. 7, Industrial Zone B1 Egypt, the Company is a joint venture between Kordsa Global Endustriyel Iplik ve Kord Bezi Sanayi ve Ticaret A.S. (Kordsa or the Group) and the Egyptian Partners focusing on tire cord fabric processing. The Project will increase the Companys production capacity and enable it to expand its product offering. The total Project cost is estimated at US$11 million. The proposed IFC investment entails an A-Loan for IFCs own account of US$11 million.
Review Scope: Social and environmental issues reviewed during the appraisal mission for this Category B investment included: Nile Kordsas social and environmental assessment and management systems; labor relations and working conditions at the Cairo plant including particularly workplace air quality, occupational health and safety; hazardous materials management; emissions to air and water; hazardous materials management; solid waste disposal; resource efficiency including potential to improve energy and water efficiency and recycling of waste; relations with the nearby communities. Kordsa Global corporate programs were also reviewed through a visit performed to Kordsa Global in Turkey where the corporate Research and Development Center; Environmental, Health and Safety Management, and Human Resources Management Teams are located.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria as is described in the following sections.Key environmental and social issues reviewed during the appraisal include the following:Management of environmental, health and safety performance; Occupational health and safety conditions; Human resources policy and practices, labor relations;Hazardous materials and waste management; Management of emissions to air and water arising from the operation of its facilities; Use of energy, water and other resources; Relations with the nearby communities.
Sector: BB - Other Textile Products (Including Industrial and Medical Products)

Project Description: The proposed project consists of an IFC senior loan of US$50 million equivalent denominated in RMB to Fullerton Credit (Sichuan) Ltd ('FCSC'),  Fullerton Credit (Chongqing) Ltd ('FCCQ'),  and Fullerton Credit (Hubei) Ltd ('FCHB') (together, the 'Companies').  The proposed investment is consistent with all aspects of IFC's China Strategy and Global Microfinance Strategy, particularly in increasing access to finance for the underserved - the micro and small business enterprises and the self-employed mass market.  The project would facilitate a stable source of long-term funding which would help the Companies grow their business in Western and Central China.
Impact: Expanding Access to Finance for MSEs : Micro and Small Enterprises ("MSEs") play an important role in creating employment and contributing to local economy particularly in less developed regions. Nevertheless, MSEs are under-served by traditional financial institutions.   The expansion of the Companies will help address this issue by increasing credit supply accessible and affordable by MSEs; Supporting Economic Growth in Frontier Regions: Frontier regions in China have experienced much  pronounced difficulties in access to finance for MSEs, which hinders the economic growth in these regions. The Companies, operating in three large frontier provinces, i.e., Sichuan, Chongqinq and Hubei, will expand access to credit in these regions, specifically to MSEs, thereby supporting the continued growth of the local economy;Demonstration Effect of Setting Best Practice in the Burgeoning Chinese Microfinance Sector:    The Companies have potential to become model institutions in China in serving the MSEs with a novel business model.  The success of the Companies is likely to attract other MCCs to emulate, with a demonstration effect to stimulate the healthy development for the entire sector.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as Category FI according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. All of these micro credit companies supported by IFC financing will be required to implement an environmental and social management system (ESMS), satisfactory to IFC and prior to IFC disbursement, to ensure their lending activities will be consistent with IFC FI Exclusion List and the applicable Chinese E&S laws and regulations. These companies will also be required to comply with IFCs Performance Standards 2: Labor and Working Conditions for their own labor practices. In addition, these companies will need to appoint a senior officer to oversee the ESMS implementation and to submit an annual environmental and social performance report to IFC according to an IFC-approved reporting format.
Sponsor: Fullerton Financial Holdings (International) Pte. Ltd.  ('FFH' or 'the Sponsor')  The three Companies, FCSC, FCCQ, FCHB are all fully owned by AF Management Service Pte. Ltd.  ('AFM').  AFM is incorporated in Singapore and further 100% owned by Fullerton Financial Holdings (International) Pte. Ltd.  ('FFH' or 'the Sponsor'), a fully-owned subsidiary of the Government of Singapore's Temasek Holdings ('Temasek') that invests in various financial sector entities in Asia.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$50million equivalent.  The proposed project will consist of a long-term loan facility denominated in RMB.

All of these micro credit companies supported by IFC financing will be required to implement an environmental and social management system (ESMS), satisfactory to IFC and prior to IFC disbursement, to ensure their lending activities will be consistent with IFC FI Exclusion List and the applicable Chinese E&S laws and regulations. Project Description: The proposed project is to provide long-term financing in the form of a senior loan to PT Bank CIMB Niaga Tbk (CIMB Niaga or the Bank), to support the Banks mortgage lending business.CIMB Niaga was incorporated in Indonesia in 1955 under the name of Bank Niaga, and was listed on the Indonesia Stock Exchange in 1989. In 2002, CIMB Group acquired a majority control stake in the Bank. CIMB Niaga is today Indonesias 5th largest bank in terms of assets and operates a full-fledged universal platform offering retail, SME and corporate banking services. In addition to traditional banking products, the Bank also has a growing franchise in microfinance and Sharia banking.
Impact: (i)	Development of the housing finance sector: By providing long term funding, this project will enable CIMB Niaga to grow its mortgage loan portfolio and thereby further develop the housing finance sector in Indonesia. (ii)	Increase availability and the affordability of mortgage loans: Further growth of CIMB Niaga''s mortgage loan portfolio will increase the availability and access to affordable mortgage loans.(iii)   Support a Government of Indonesia initiative: The project will support the government''s efforts to increase access to housing financing.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves IFC support for the business of housing mortgages. Given the minimal environmental and social impact associated with this investment, the project has been classified as a Category C according to IFC''s Environmental & Social Review Procedure and therefore there are no environmental and social requirements.
Sponsor: CIMB Niaga is a public company controlled and majority-owned by CIMB Group with a 97.9% shareholding, with the remaining 2.1% publicly listed. CIMB Group (the Sponsor) is Malaysias second-largest financial services provider, as well as one of the largest regional financial service institutions in Southeast Asia. CIMB Group is listed on the Bursa Malaysia and operates as a universal bank offering a full range of financial products and services, covering corporate and investment banking, consumer banking, treasury, insurance and asset management. CIMB Group offers products and services on a dual banking basis, giving customers a choice of both conventional and Islamic solutions. With a presence in 11 Southeast Asian countries, at present CIMB Groups main markets are Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore and Thailand.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a senior loan of up to US$75 million.
Investment: 75.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan75.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: CIMB Niaga is headquartered in Jakarta, Indonesia, with 845 branches and 1,510 ATMs across the country as of June 30, 2011.

Given the minimal environmental and social impact associated with this investment, the project has been classified as a Category C according to IFC''s Environmental & Social Review Procedure and therefore there are no environmental and social requirements.

Project Description: Triada is a Colombian homebuilder and integrated housing developer in different market segments.   Operations include land acquisition, planning, design, construction, management and sales.  Triada develops projects on its own and in partnership with other developers in order to leverage the Companys capacity and participating in more projects. IFC will provide up to US$10 million in mezzanine financing to invest alongside Triada in the purchase of land and development of urban infrastructure for further development of approximately 6,000 low income housing units for a total cost of approximately US$105 million (the Project).
Review Scope: IFCs environmental and social review of Triada included: (i) meetings with Triadas management team in Bogota; (ii) site visits to Triadas low income housing land bank and developments in the municipality of Soacha, near Bogota and in Cali, both in Colombia, and; (iii) review of internal policies and procedures including human resource policies, occupational health and safety (OHS) procedures, land acquisition principles, sample of permits for construction of projects, sample contracts with sub-contracting companies, and environmental management guidelines. Environmental and social conditions were observed during the site visits and discussed with project managers, quality officials and other Triada staff.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure as the potential adverse environmental and social impacts presented by the project are few in number, site-specific and have been or can be readily addressed through mitigation measures.The key environmental and social (E&S) issues have been identified as: (i) Triadas ability to provide systematic and consistent management of E&S issues across different projects including the adoption of necessary mitigation measures; (ii) assessment processes applied to the land acquisition process, to ensure avoidance of adverse impacts on cultural heritage, biodiversity when these are encountered in developments; (iii) the avoidance of involuntary resettlement; (iv) management of occupational health and safety risks during construction, and (v) ensuring adequate services and utilities (electricity, safe water and sanitary facilities) associated with project development.

Project Description: The Project consists on the development of approx. 5-10 Low Income Housing (LIH) projects in Colombia. Triada S.A.S (Triada or the Company) will be responsible for developing all housing projects under this investment.
Impact: (i) Address housing deficit: Colombia''s current deficit stands at 1.3 mm units that grows at 140,000 units per year.  The Project will contribute to address the increasing deficit by supporting the development of 5 to 10 projects in a five period; (ii) Address shortage in housing supply: Colombian homebuilders face constraints in obtaining medium- to long-term financing, especially equity to finance land acquisition. This issue constraints the ability for homebuilders to develop larger projects and is one of the main reasons why the number of housing units built every year is not enough to address the increasing deficit.  The Project will help Triada to develop larger scale projects; (iii) Alignment with Government''s priority:  Housing is one of the strategic pillars of the government.  President Santos is setting up the framework and designing the incentives to increase the stock of new units by 250,000 per year.  The Project will be aligned with the government''s strategic priorities for the period 2012-2014 and will benefit of the incentives that the government will make available to foster housing supply.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure as the potential adverse environmental and social impacts presented by the project are few in number, site-specific and have been or can be readily addressed through mitigation measures.
Sponsor: TriadaIs a Tier II Colombian family owned company. T riada will be in charge of developing and managing all housing projects under this investment.  Promotora 3Is a family owned company that owns 35% of Triada. Promotora 3 is the Sponsor of this investment.
Cost Nature: Total Project Cost is estimated at $100 mm.The proposed IFC Investment is up to $10 mm mezzanine financing for IFCs own account.

Location: The development of the subprojects will take place in Colombia with focus in Bogota and Cali. Sites for each subproject are still to be determined.

Project Description: Merec Industries Ltd. (Merec or the Company), an existing IFC client and a leading Mozambican grain miller, is seeking financing for: i) a 250 tons/day greenfield flour mill to be constructed in Nacala, in Mozambiques northern region; and ii) a grain handling terminal with a 20,000 ton silo capacity to be constructed on the premises of the port of Maputo under the jurisdiction of the Port Authorities.  IFCs previous investments have supported the upgrading and expansion of Merecs milling, warehousing and distribution capacity at its existing Machava and Socimol plants in Maputo.  Merec is a member of the Charania Group of companies (charaniagroup.com/group/index.html), a major East African corporation established in 1995.
Review Scope: IFCs environmental and social review of the projects included: site visits to Merecs existing milling operations and food processing (pasta plant, biscuit factory and animal feed plant) in Maputo; discussions with Companys senior management regarding the construction, management and operations of the proposed new facilities; and a review of the Terms of Reference for the Environmental Impact Assessments (EIAs) of those facilities.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability.  Grain milling and processing are typically low impact operations with few environmental and social issues.  Milling waste that had previously been disposed is now processed as animal feed in a new feed mill commissioned on the grounds of the Companys Machava plant in 2011.  Process waste water is recycled into milled grain. Solid waste from operations consists predominantly of office and packaging paper waste and spent lubricants from vehicle maintenance, both of which are recycled.
Sector: AA - Grain Processing (Milling, Starch, Flour, Malt)

Project Description: Merec Industries Lda (Merec) was established in 1998 and is today the largest wheat miller in Mozambique. IFC provided partial guarantees for the establishment of the companys first mill in 2000 and for the acquisition of a second mill in 2003 followed up by a US$7 million loan in 2008 to finance the establishment pasta plant in FY2008The proposed project would allow Merec group to expand and optimise their operations through the establishment of:a new wheat mill in the north of the country in Nacala; and  a port based discharge and storage facility at the port of Maputo.
Impact: (i) Strengthening the wheat procurement logistics and improving the group''s production infrastructure; (ii) Employment creation; (iii) SME development as the company''s new projects would entail increased demand for locally produced maize and increased business for retailers; (iv) Increase domestic food production in Mozambique; (v) import substitution which will save the country foreign currency outflows; and (iv) Increased tax revenues to government
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability. Grain milling and processing are typically low impact operations with few environmental and social issues. The proposed greenfield flour mill in Nacala will be constructed within an existing commercial development zoned for industrial use on a plot leased by the Company from a private owner.  The proposed grain handling terminal in Maputo with a 20,000 ton silo capacity will be constructed on the premises of the port of Maputo under the jurisdiction of the Port Authorities.  As such, neither of the two proposed facilities will have significant adverse impacts.  The key environmental and social issues identified during IFCs appraisal relate to worker occupational health and safety (OHS) in all operations and food safety management in the Companys food processing operations.
Sponsor: Merecs main sponsor is Mhamud Charania, CEO of the company. Mr. Charania is a mechanical engineer with specialization in manufacturing with over 15 years of experience in trading, manufacturing and leasing. Mr. Charania founded Africom Lda in 1995, which is now Mozambiques leading distributor of soft commodities and Merec Industries Lda in 1998 which he grew to be the largest wheat miller in Mozambique in less than 10 years. Merec is a 100% family owned company.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated to be $58 million consisting of: (i) pasta production plants; (ii) milling expansion; (iii) storage capacity expansion; and (iv) working capital.The proposed project consists of a corporate facility of up to $25 million that will be used to finance Merecs expansion project.

Location: Merecs operations are located in Maputo, Machava and Beira with the new project in Nacala. The expansion projects will take place on Merec owned and leased properties.The project sites have good access to road network.

The proposed greenfield flour mill in Nacala will be constructed within an existing commercial development zoned for industrial use on a plot leased by the Company from a private owner.  The proposed grain handling terminal in Maputo with a 20,000 ton silo capacity will be constructed on the premises of the port of Maputo under the jurisdiction of the Port Authorities.  As such, neither of the two proposed facilities will have significant adverse impacts.  The key environmental and social issues identified during IFCs appraisal relate to worker occupational health and safety (OHS) in all operations and food safety management in the Companys food processing operations.

Project Description: Until recently, foreign exchange (FX) liquidity funding for banks in Bangladesh was provided only by Bangladeshs Central Bank  Bangladesh Bank (BB) - through the countrys robust reserves.  However, since the beginning of 2011, as part of the pre-conditionality for a US$1 billion program from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), BB has ceased to provide direct FX liquidity support to banks.  This development has resulted in an acute systemic FX, mainly US Dollar (US$), liquidity squeeze in the banking system.  The lack of FX liquidity has negatively impacted the timely issuance of L/Cs by banks, particularly for small and medium enterprise (SME) clients.  Since the bulk of the Bangladesh economy is value-added (imports, processed then re-exported), the ability to issue L/Cs on a timely basis is critical to the well-functioning of the economy.  Hence, to mitigate the adverse impact of the US$ shortage on the countrys trade flows and the SME sector, BB is now permitting select local banks with licensed offshore branches, to meet their short-term FX requirements from the international market. The proposed project is a direct response to the prevailing FX liquidity crisis and is in line with the World Banks and IFCs strategy of promoting economic growth by providing access to finance to underserved market segments and promoting international trade. The Project consists of a short-term loan and a participation in IFCs Global Trade Finance Program (GTFP) to The City Bank Ltd.s (City Bank or the Bank) offshore unit to support foreign currency trade and working capital financing for the Banks SME clients.
Impact: The Project is expected to have the following specific development impacts:-     Financial Market Deepening: By providing local banks with much-needed FX liquidity and facilitating their access to the commercial loan market, the Facility will help deepen the financial sector by establishing a level playing field between local banks and foreign banks operating in the local market that have an advantage due to support of parent funding.  -	     Demonstration Effect: The demonstration effect of the IFC funding will encourage international banks to finance the local banking sector and increase the range and availability of funding options in the market. -  	Economic Growth Acceleration: The Facility will help accelerate economic growth in Bangladesh by providing SMEs and exporters with trade finance solutions to finance their working capital needs and pay for critical value chain imports. -	      Job Creation and Job Loss Prevention: By providing much needed working capital support to SMEs, the Facility will help create new jobs and also prevent job losses resulting from business interruption, particularly in an economy where the poor are mainly employed as daily wage workers.
Environmental Social Issues: This Project involves a short term loan and a trade finance guarantee from IFC to support trade and FX working capital needs of SMEs and has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.
Sponsor: City Bank is a first generation bank in Bangladesh, i.e. it is one of the oldest private commercial banks operating in Bangladesh and was established in March 1983.  Ranked among the top 15 banks by asset size in the country, the Bank conducts all types of commercial banking activities and is also a leader in retail banking, particularly in credit cards, and the remittances business.  The Bank currently has 90 branches, 15 SME service centers and 2 SME Agro centers spread across Bangladesh.City Bank is listed on both the Dhaka and Chittagong Stock Exchanges.  As of December 31, 2011, 90.85% of the Banks shares were in the hands of sponsors and the general public, and financial institutions held 9.15% City Bank shares.  The Managing Director, Mr. K. Mahmood Sattar, has been heading the bank since 2007.  He is a well-respected banker with a proven track-record and experience in working for a multinational bank.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a package of a US$25 million short-term loan and a US$30 million guarantee under the GTFP.
Investment: 25.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan25.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The bank is headquartered in Dhaka and has branches across Bangladesh with Chittagong being the Banks second most important location.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This Project involves a short term loan and a trade finance guarantee from IFC to support trade and FX working capital needs of SMEs and has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.

Project Description: Brunswick Rail Holding Limited (BRHL or the Company) is a leasing company providing freight railcars to corporate clients in the Russian Federation.  It generally provides the railcars on an operating lease basis (where the residual value of the railcars remains with BRHL).  It is a wholly owned subsidiary of Brunswick Rail (Brunswick or the Group), one of the largest privately-owned freight railcar leasing companies active in the Russian Federation with a fleet of over 22,000 railcars.  The Group is looking to expand its fleet to optimize its operations and achieve the critical mass it needs to thrive in the sector.IFC has previously provided two loans to this Company and has recently provided a loan to another subsidiary of the Group (Brunswick Wagon Leasing) and has an equity stake in Brunswick.
Review Scope: IFCs review of this repeat investment relied on discussions with technical and human resources staff as well as the ongoing supervision of Brunswicks environmental and social performance.  This included a review of Brunswicks most recent Annual Monitoring Report for the 2010 reporting period (dated April 2011) and updated information provided by the Company.  IFC Staff also visited senior management, inclusive of those individuals responsible for E&S activities.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This remains a category B project because IFCs ongoing review and supervision of the Companys railcar leasing activities indicates that this additional investment will not result in any material change in the associated environmental and social risks and impacts.  The current Environmental and Social Risk Rating for the existing investments is Excellent.  Finally, and in the context of their prospective investment, EBRD also considers this a category B project.

Company Name: POWER GRID CORPORATION OF INDIA LIMITED
Project Description: POWERGRID is a state-owned electric transmission utility. It wheels about 51% of the total power generated in India on its transmission network  comprising around 90,000 circuit-km of transmission network and 145 Extra High Voltage Alternating Current (EHVAC) & High Voltage Direct Current (HVDC) sub-stations with a total transformation capacity of around 100,000 MVA. The World Bank has supported POWERGRID since its inception in 1989 during which time the company has become one of the world''s largest electricity transmission system operators. In addition to electric power transmission (including grid management, grid operation and maintenance activities), which forms its core business, the Company has also diversified into: (a) telecom, utilizing right of way on its Extra High Voltage Power Transmission Network infrastructure in the country. The telecom operation includes putting in place overhead optic fiber network using OPGW (Optical Ground Wire) on power transmission lines. POWERGRID is managing an all India Broad Band Telecom Network of about 25,000 Kms as well as intra city access networks across India; (b) electric power transmission engineering, procurement and construction consultancy services both within and outside India to governments and other utilities. POWERGRID has so far been assigned more than 300 consultancy assignments by national and international clients in construction of transmission lines, substations, load dispatch centers, distribution and rural electrification. The Company has undertaken/is executing 40 international consultancy assignments including in Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, Dubai, Kenya Nepal, Nigeria and Srilanka; and (c) provision of O&M services to transmission utilities in India and other countries. POWERGRID has an Rs 100,000 crores (around US$ 22 billion) capital investment plan to be implemented over the next 5 years. In the next 12 months the Companys investment plans include transmission systems for various generation projects including UMPPs, IPPs and grid-strengthening schemes across several states namely, Jharkhand, Orissa, Chhattisgarh and North-East. In order to generate resources to meet its capital expenditure program, POWERGRID is desirous of accessing international commercial financing. In this regard, POWERGRID has approached IFC to facilitate achieving its objective.IFC is considering  partly finance, with a mix of A Loan and syndicated B loan, POWERGRIDs capital investment plan for the above referred investment (the Investment).
Review Scope: IFC is considering an A loan and a syndicated B loan to partly finance Power Grid Corporation of India Limiteds capital investment program. IFC has undertaken an environmental and social review in the context of this proposed corporate investment in POWERGRID, and this document is a summary of review findings. Review of this proposed IFC investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information submitted by the Company including POWERGRIDs: investment plan; Environment and Social Policies and Procedures (ESPP); Human Resource Policies and Procedures; Sample ESA documents; standard procedures pertaining to projects, operation and maintenance; crop and tree compensation related documentation; sample internal and third party audit reports; and sample project contract documents. The appraisal team also interacted with POWERGRIDs corporate and operations professionals. The appraisal included a site visit to the Companys existing operations and projects at Bhiwadi in Rajasthan state of India.  The Team has also reviewed The Safeguards Diagnostic Review report prepared by The World Bank. The World Bank has been working with POWERGRID in development and implementation of the Companys ESPP since 1998. IFCs review has relied and drawn upon the work already done by The World Bank over the years and most recently as part of the Fifth Power System Development Project (# P115566) towards ensuring that POWERGRIDs ESPP is consistent with The World Bank Groups Safeguard Policies. The World Bank has determined, per its SDR, that this ESPP is equivalent to the Objectives and Operational Principles in relation to the requirements of World Bank Operational Policy 4.00.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: While POWERGRIDs individual transmission line projects typically have limited social and environmental impact (typically Category B), several of the projects to be implemented by POWERGRID have a large geographical spread, voltages above 400 kV, large substations, and it is reasonable to assume that some of the project transmission lines may pass through forest areas. Due to the broad scope of the proposed corporate investment, it cannot be completely ruled out that implementation of some of the projects by the Company may result in potentially significant adverse social and environmental impacts. Hence, IFC is treating this as a category A investment according to IFCs procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects. This is consistent with the categorization of the Fifth Power System Development Project (# P115566) by The World Bank. The proposed loan is not targeted at any of POWERGRIDs specific assets but is being provided to the Company to partly fund its capital investment program. In such investments, IFC expects that the Company will have in place social and environmental management systems to ensure that the Companys projects and operations, including the projects and operations of POWERGRID controlled subsidiary companies will be consistent with IFC Performance Standards.

Project Description: Brunswick Rail Holding Limited (BRHL or the Company) is a leasing company providing freight railcars to corporate clients in the Russian Federation.  It generally provides the railcars on an operating lease basis (where the residual value of the railcars remains with BRHL).  It is a wholly owned subsidiary of Brunswick Rail (Brunswick or the Group), one of the largest privately-owned freight railcar leasing companies active in the Russian Federation with a fleet of over 22,000 railcars.  The Group is looking to expand its fleet to optimize its operations and achieve the critical mass it needs to thrive in the sector.IFC has previously provided two loans to this Company and has recently provided a loan to another subsidiary of the Group (Brunswick Wagon Leasing) and has an equity stake in Brunswick.
Impact: The Project would: (i) support the continued development of a key private sector player in the relatively new Russian railcar leasing sector; (ii) contribute to the development of the transportation and logistics sectors in the Russian Federation, facilitating economic growth particularly in the economically disadvantaged hinterland; and (iii) facilitate a Eurobond issue which will be used to finance the construction of additional railcars and help avoid a supply crisis over the next 5-10 years as the majority of RZhD''s fleet reaches the end of its useful life. The majority of the Group''s fleet is unrelated to the oil sector and thus helps facilitate the diversification of the economy. Brunswick''s new, more reliable railcars also help mitigate the risk of trucking replacing railways which would result in an increase of harmful greenhouse gases.
Role: Consistent with IFC''s crisis response objectives, IFC would be supporting one of our strongest infrastructure partners in Russia in a countercyclical environment and in a time of limited liquidity. Because of the euro zone crisis and subsequent closing down of the public debt markets, Brunswick has postponed issuing a Eurobond in Q1''12, which was intended to repay the BRHL facility and the bullet due in August 2012. IFC would thus be providing a short-term solution to facilitate the repayment of the BRHL facility in a difficult market environment, as well as enable a Eurobond issue at a later stage. As a key existing investor in Brunswick, and an existing lender to BRHL more specifically, IFC''s participation would provide significant comfort to other lenders enabling the mobilization of additional funds. In the absence of IFC''s involvement, Brunswick would likely not be able to raise the requisite financing or would do so on unfavorable terms, limiting Brunswick''s ability to issue a Eurobond and making it harder for Brunswick to grow the business and eventually IPO.
Sponsor: Brunswick is a holding company incorporated in Bermuda which is in turn is owned 24.1% by its two founders Mr. Martin Andersson and Mr. Gerard de Geer, 13.0% by IFC, 12.0% by Sumitomo, 14.9% by Macquarie Renaissance Infrastructure Fund, 6.9% by VTB Capital, 5.5% byUFG and the balance by other shareholders and management.
Cost Nature: The total cost of the project is estimated at US$250 million. IFCs proposed investment is an A loan of up to US$100 million and a B loan of US$150 to 200 million depending on the amount of the A loan.

Company Name: POWER GRID CORPORATION OF INDIA LIMITED
Project Description: Power Grid Corporation of India (POWERGRID) is the national power transmission company of India responsible for planning, coordination and undertaking high voltage inter-state transmission in the country. The mission of the corporation is establishment and operation of a national power grid to facilitate transfer of electric power within and across the regions with reliability, security and economy, on sound commercial principles. This project represents POWERGRIDs investment program for the next 12 months aimed at enhancing electricity transmission infrastructure in India to ensure (a) ability to handle increasing power load to meet growing demand; (b) ability to increase inter-regional transmission capacity to optimize efficient generation and utilization of power; (c) ability to provide reliability and economy in doing so.
Impact: The key development impacts of the Project are (a) supports increasing investments in the Indian power sector - a critical bottleneck for economic growth and poverty alleviation.   In particular, the power transmission sector requires urgent investments to ensure efficient transfer to power from generation to load centers; (b) supports increased private sector investment in the power generation sector by allowing new generation projects to access users across the country due to the development of the National Transmission Grid by POWERGRID ; (c) helps mitigate climate change impacts by supporting development of renewable energy projects which need the National Grid to optimize utilization of the power they produce.
Environmental Social Issues: While POWERGRIDs individual transmission line projects typically have limited social and environmental impact (typically Category B), several of the projects to be implemented by POWERGRID have a large geographical spread, voltages above 400 kV, large substations, and it is reasonable to assume that some of the project transmission lines may pass through forest areas. IFC is treating this investment as a category A project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects since some of the projects to be implemented by the Company may result in potentially significant adverse social and environmental impacts. This is consistent with the categorization of the Fifth Power System Development Project (# P115566) by The World Bank.
Sponsor: The Government of India (GoI) is the single largest shareholder of POWERGRID, with approximately 69.4% of equity. The Company is listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange and the National Stock Exchange of India. Institutional and Non-Institutional investors hold approximately 30.6% of the total equity in the Company.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated to be US$2.3-3.5 billion over the next 12 months proposed to be 70% financed with debt and remaining from internal accruals.  IFC financing of upto US$400 million  an A Loan of US$100 million and B Loan of upto US$300 million  is expected to finance approximately 15% of the project cost on corporate finance basis. The balance debt will be raised including from multilaterals namely World Bank and ADB, and through issuance of domestic bonds. The proceeds from IFC is intended for financing transmission projects to be undertaken by POWERGRID and shall not be used for EPC consulting and/or O&M services and/or Joint-venture projects.

Project Description: The project consists of a senior loan facility of up to US$30 million to Fibabanka A.. (Fibabanka or the Bank). The proposed investment would be used to finance the Banks lending operations to women-owned SMEs (at least 50% of the facility amount) and the remaining 50% will be on-lent to other SMEs. IFC is working to mobilize funds from parallel lenders to increase the total financing package to the Bank to increase up to US$70 million.
Impact: The key development objective of this project is to increase financial inclusion in Turkey. The project is designed to improve access to finance for SMEs in Turkey, with a special focus on women owned businesses (at least 50% of the project amount will be used to on-lend to women owned SMEs). By working with Fibabanka, a well-run, mid-tier bank with a particular focus on SMEs, this project is intended to demonstrate the business opportunity presented by women enterpreneurs as an under-served market
Environmental Social Issues: This project, which consists of a senior loan to Fibabanka for on lending to the SMEs (particularly women-owned SMEs) in Turkey, has been classified as a Category FI-2 project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure.
Sponsor: Credit Europe Group (CE) has acquired Fibabanka in December 2010. Currently, CE holds 98% of the Bank. Fibabanka has a growth strategy in Turkey and will be positioned as a universal bank, with a particular focus on SMEs. The number of branches has increased from 18 to 22 following the acquisition, and number of employees increased to 470.
Cost Nature: The project consists of a senior loan facility of up to US$30 million to Fibabanka from IFCs own account.
