Company Name: ALTA GROWTH CAPITAL MEXICO FUND II LP
Project Description: Alta Growth Capital Mexico Fund II, L.Ps (the Fund) investment strategy is to invest equity and to provide technical and management expertise to Mexican SMEs poised for growth, specifically in primary sectors: Health, Education, Financial Services and Logistics. It is proposed that IFC invests the lesser of $15 million and 20% of the total committed capital in the Fund.  The Fund is targeting $150 million in equity commitments from investors. The Fund will target investments ranging from $10-15 million in several funding rounds.  Investments will be equity or equity-like structures and may be minority or along with like-minded investors secure a majority ownership interest. The Fund may generate co-investment opportunities for investors. The Fund is launched as a follow-on fund to Alta Growth Capital, Mexico Fund, L.P. Fund I, (Project No. 25352), a $75 million private equity fund of vintage 2007, and in which IFC committed $18.7 million.
Impact: Alta Growth Capital Mexico Fund II, L.P. is targeting equity investments in 10-15 SMEs that will be supplemented with environmental, managerial and technical value addition.  Private equity-sponsored companies often adopt management practices (in environment and social, financial control, cost accounting, quality control, corporate governance, legal structure and tax reporting) that are better than those used by their local peers. If Alta Growth is successful and delivers developmental and financial results for its investors, it may be able to launch successor funds. Examples of successful, well-run private enterprises will contribute to encourage foreign investment in Mexico. The Fund is expected to contribute to a vibrant and sustainable private sector that will improve employment, trade balance, and public finances in Mexico. Finally, by attracting new investors to the private equity asset class âlocal pension funds, insurers and investment companies, the Fund will help these companies to achieve higher risk adjusted returns as well as the implied benefits that private equity brings into their overall portfolio. The IFC team will measure and report on the following developmental impact indicators: 1) percentage of funding disbursed, 2) net/gross financial return, 3) number of jobs created, 4) annual growth sales, 5) annual growth EBITDA, 6) launching of follow-on funds, 7) tax paid to local governments, among other indicators.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Under "Fund I"  (Project No. 25352)  the Fund Manager was required to develop an Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) to ensure sub project compliance with IFCs Exclusion List,  host country Environmental and Social (E&S) laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards (the Applicable Requirements).  During appraisal IFC assessed the potential E&S risks and impacts associated with the new Fund''s expected portfolio and sectors of investment, which may include Healthcare, Logistics, Consumer Goods, Food, Financial/Business Services, Education, and Housing, some of which may have moderate to significant E&S risks.IFC also reviewed the Fund Manager''s capacity to manage the expected E&S risks under IFC''s existing E&S risk management framework for private equity funds. As part of the investment in Fund II, IFC will suggest adjustments to the ESMS to address the gaps identified during appraisal as well as the new E&S requirements that came into effect since the investment in Fund I.The Fund will be required to:  enhance its existing ESMS to ensure that its investments/activities are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements; identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the ESMS; and submit a periodic report to IFC.IFC will review the implementation and performance of the Fund''s ESMS for the first three projects and all Category A projects prior to the fund''s investment, to ensure the fund''s ESMR is adequate to assess and manage E&S risks.
Sponsor: IFC supported the creation of Alta Growth Capital Management (the Fund Manager) in 2007 as a partnership comprising members of the former Baring Mexico Private Equity Partners (Mexico, Project No. 9357, 4594 ) S.C. and  vSpring Capital.  In the past five years the Alta team has worked cohesively and raised $135 million in capital commitments distributed in three funds: i) $75 million in Alta Growth Capital, Mexico Fund, L.P. (2007);  ii) $60 million in an  early-stage funds (2011), Alta Ventures Mexico Fund, L.P. (Project No. 28086) which includes the Kickstart program, a seed capital facility that supports innovation.  The Alta team has also created a strong network that brings together industry experts, executives, entrepreneurs, and capital sources behind the funding and mentoring of seed, venture and growth investments. The Alta Growth team is based in Mexico City, and is composed of the following senior professionals: Erik Carlberg (Managing Director), Scott McDonough (Managing Director), and Rafael Payro (Managing Director). Other team members are: Burton Flynn, Roberto Henriquez, and David Oscos. The Fund is proposed as a Canadian limited partnership formed under the laws of Ontario. A first close is expected to bring $85-105 million from new and recurring investors.
Cost Nature: The target fund size is $150 million. It is proposed that IFC be an early equity investor with up to $15 million.

Project Description: The project consists of a direct equity investment of up to RUB 2.90 billion in CREDIT BANK OF MOSCOW (CBM), a medium-sized universal bank, well known to IFC from earlier projects. CBM was established in Moscow in 1992 and now ranks among the top-25 banks of Russia in terms of assets. CBM operates in Moscow and the Moscow region, offering both corporate and retail banking services to a wide range of clients. The main purpose of the project is to improve access to finance for clients of the Bank, mainly represented by mid-sized companies and to strengthen the capital of the bank in view of its regional expansion and its preparation for an initial public offering (IPO) in the mid-term.
Impact: The proposed investment seeks to (i) help Credit Bank of Moscow grow and serve its small-and-medium enterprise client base; (ii) expand its operations to new regions outside of Moscow; (iii) strengthen and diversify its capital base; (iv) mobilize additional investors to enter the Bank''s capital in light of a future initial public offering (IPO); and (v) promote best practices in terms of corporate governance and business and risk management, enabling the Bank to become one of the key platforms for sector consolidation.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed investment has been classified as Category FI according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. CREDIT BANK OF MOSCOW is an existing IFC client. CBM has developed and is implementing an Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) and appointed environmental staff.  For this equity investment project the client will be required to screen all loans against the IFC Exclusion List, the Russian E&S laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards. CES environmental specialists will work with the client to enhance CBMs E&S capacity and to apply all applicable requirements to entire portfolio. E&S specialists conducted a follow-up site supervision visit in November, 2011 focusing on portfolio review. Key findings were communicated to the client. IFC reviewed CBMs labor policies in order to verify compliance with IFCs Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions. CES will provide recommendations for CBMs labor policies enhancements.  The client will be required to continue submission of the Annual Environmental Performance Reports (AEPRs) to IFC
Sponsor: CREDIT BANK OF MOSCOW is a well-established privately-owned mid-sized universal Bank and has been a reliable client of IFC since 2004. The Bank currently operates in Moscow and the Moscow region with a network of 74 points of sale, over 600 ATMs and over 4,000 payment terminals. The Banks sole shareholder is Mr. Roman Avdeev.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at RUB 2.90 billion (approximately US$ 100 million), consisting of equity from IFCs own account.

Project Description: The proposed project is to provide up to $50 million IFC A loan and, depending on market conditions, up to $50 million IFC B loan, backed by a CELT-type guarantee from Societe Generale, to Rusfinance Bank (Rusfinance or Bank). The loan is intended to help Rusfinance launch its Green Car lending product for environmentally friendly vehicles, including hybrid, electric, gas and low emission petrol engines with CO2 emission lower than 150g/km. LLC Rusfinance Bank is the consumer/auto lending subsidiary of Société Générale in Russia. The Bank was acquired in 2005 and as of end-2011 ranked #41 in Russia with over $3.4 billion in assets*. Rusfinance is one of the leading players in the Russian retail banking market: was ranked #1 in the car loan market in 1H2011** and is among the top-five banks in the point-of-sales lending market***. The Bank operates in 67 regions in Russia reaching approximately 93 % of the Russian population, with over 17,559 active points of sales**** reaching more than two million customers.*Source: the RBC rating of Top500 banks on net assets** Source: the RBC rating of banks on CAR loan market*** Source: Frank Research Group, The CBR, Rusfinance**** where at least one loan per quarter is granted
Impact: 1.	Development of sustainable "green products" in Russia, and particularly financing of CO2 efficient vehicles compliant with current noxious emissions standards or better, that directly contributes to the protection of the environment and human health. 2.	Given that Rusfinance will be financing eco-friendly vehicles, including those manufactured in Russia, which meet the CO2 and other emissions criteria (such as GAZ and YO-mobile), it would further strengthen the development of the Russian economy and local employment outside of raw materials sector.3.	Using global best practices and in close cooperation with the WB experts, including Societe Gererale Group, IFC would develop and pioneer a new "green" car lending product that is in demand in numerous developing and developed markets, thus building this solid platform for product replication worldwide.
Environmental Social Issues: Proposed project consists of a ruble-denominated senior loan to Rusfinance Bank, SocGens consumer/auto lending subsidiary in Russia.  The loan is intended to help Rusfinance launch its Green Car lending product for environmentally friendly vehicles, including hybrid, electric and gas engines.  The proposed project is provisionally classified category C.  The client will be required to put in place a mechanism to ensure that IFC financing is used exclusively for auto lending.  The client is in compliance with PS2 requirements except for the grievance mechanism that is currently under development.
Sponsor: Rusfinance Bank is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Rosbank, Russias largest privately-owned banking group, which is in turn 82.3956 % owned by the international publicly traded banking group Société Générale. Other shareholders in Rosbank include two legal entities beneficially owned by Vladimir Potanin (6,5%), VTB Bank (9.95%) and free floating shares (1.16%)

Company Name: MICROFINANCE INITIATIVE FOR ASIA (MIFA) DEBT FUND SA, SICAV-SIF
Project Description: The project consists of the establishment of a facility that will increase access to finance to micro-borrowers and low-income households in the Asia region, including East Asia, South Asia, and Central Asia.  The proposed facility, the Microfinance Initiative For Asia Debt Fund (MIFA Fund or the Fund) will: i) offer market-based debt financing  with an emphasis on local currency and longer-term financing  to financial entities serving micro businesses (microfinance institutions or MFIs), with a focus on reaching smaller and less developed MFIs; ii) help establish microfinance as an asset class with mainstream investors and leverage donor funds with private capital; and iii) support capacity building among financial entities serving micro entities.The project is directly in line with IFCs microfinance strategy to reach large but underserved markets, including India, Indonesia, Pakistan, and the Philippines.  A parallel TA facility will provide capacity building support to the MFIs.
Impact: i)	Poverty reduction: The project is in line with the IFC microfinance strategy for increased outreach in South, East and Central Asia, especially in large countries like India and China, home to 40% of the world''s population.  Microfinance penetration rates in this region remain among the lowest globally. By supporting the expansion and sustainability of well performing MFIs, the project will improve access to finance for thousands of micro and small borrowers. This in turn will stimulate growth, employment generation and poverty alleviation in the region.ii)	Access to local currency commercial longer-tenor funding for MFIs: By lending in local currency, the Fund will facilitate the access of Asian emerging market MFIs to commercial funding that is better tailored to their needs. It will reduce the volatility of MFI loan portfolios, as currently most MFIs are unable to properly address the currency mismatch risk.  Further, the Fund aims to provide longer tenor funding and subordinated debt products, a clear need for MFIs currently.iii) Mobilization: the Fund will mobilize resources from local and private partners to promote microfinance as a viable asset class.iv) Capacity-building: the TA Facility will aim to build the capacity of microfinance institutions, with a focus on business and finance skills, MIS development, and corporate governance.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves IFC support for the business of microfinance and has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  The envisaged fund manager under this project will have capacity for environmental and social risk management relevant for microfinance.  Considering the nature of activities supported, the fund manager will be required to: (i) develop and implement a procedure relevant to its business process, prior to disbursement, that is satisfactory to IFC, and that ensures that all its investments are screened and processed to avoid supporting activities on the Microfinance Exclusion List; (ii) identify qualified persons to manage and implement the procedure; (iii) ensure that the MFIs it supports establish a similar screening process to avoid supporting activities on the IFC Microfinance Exclusion List; (iv) apply the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions; and (v) submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: The Fund will be managed by an experienced global investment manager which specializes in microfinance.  The Fund is being structured jointly by IFC, KfW and BlueOrchard Finance. The MIFA Fund will be funded by issuing up to 3 classes of shares.  Initially, the investors are expected to be IFC, KfW, and Bundesministerium für wirtschaftliche Zusammenarbeit und Entwicklung (German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development, BMZ).
Cost Nature: The Fund has a target size of $100 million, including up to $25 million in donor-funded concessional funding.  IFCs investment in the Fund is proposed to be up to $20 million in mezzanine shares.

Project Description: The project involves an equity investment by IFC of up to $20 million to support Russian Towers plan to build a nationwide network of towers and lease the tower space to the Russian mobile phone operators.  The Company is still in early stages of development, operating about 140 towers. Most of its existing and new towers are or will be sited in rural areas and on railway rights of way, by agreement with the national Russian Railway.  By offering opportunities to co-locate telecommunications equipment owned and operated by several companies on a single tower, this project reduces the amount of land and other resources devoted to telecommunications in Russia.
Review Scope: The review of this project consisted of a visit by IFC staff to the project site, to meet with and interview management of Russian Towers (or the Company), and to have a first-hand look at operational activities.  IFC staff also reviewed technical, environmental and social information obtained from previous investors in Russian Towers, namely from the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development and from Macquarie Renaissance Infrastructure Fund  as well as information submitted by Russian Towers.  The reviewed information included draft human resources policies and procedures; samples of contracts for design, construction, and maintenance of towers; annual environmental and social reporting information; guidelines for operations of antennas/towers published by the Russian Ministry of Communications; Russian Towers guidelines on general safety, fire safety, safety in electrical work, and emergency safety; a list of sites; checklists; a sample of positive conclusions of government reviews at a Russian Towers site; and permits.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: As this project involves the development of towers mainly on existing railway rights of way or on land owned by local authorities, no major adverse environmental or social impacts are expected to result.  As a result, it has been classified as a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.
Sector: AD - Other (Including Satellite Telecommunications, Radio and Television Broadcasting, etc.)

Project Description: The project is to support the development of Russian Towers (the Company), an emerging independent tower operator in Russia, which is building a nationwide network of telecommunication towers to lease the tower space to Russian mobile phone operators. The privately-owned Company was established in 2009 and is in an earlier stage of development, currently operating about 140 towers. As an independent tower operator, the Company would allow multiple mobile operators to share tower space, creating significant economic and other benefits.
Impact: The project is expected to have a number of development impacts including the following: (i) improve access to mobile network in rural areas due to a decreased time to market and improved economics of accessing more sparsely populated areas; (ii) enhance the coverage and quality of service in rural areas; (iii) facilitate more economically efficient use of resources, including land and capital investments, due to the reduced need in the number of towers; (iv) reduce the visual burden of multiple towers as well as the carbon footprint (through reduced and/or more efficient use of diesel generators to supply power in rural locations); (v) encourage more competition that, together with lower capital costs and operating expenses of operators, would translate into the lower cost of services to users, and (vi) assist in the creation of direct and indirect (through subcontracting) employment opportunities.
Environmental Social Issues: Environmental and social risks and impacts in this project are expected to be limited, so the project is classified as Category B according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.
Sponsor: The project is sponsored by a group of founding shareholders with extensive experience in the telecommunication sector in Russia that includes: (i) Mr. Peter Owen Edmunds, a UK national; (ii) Mr.  Garth Self, a US national, (iii) Mr. Yuri Dombrovski, a Russian national, and (iv) Mr. Evgeniy Roitman, a Russian national. Collectively the founders control about 14.4% of the project company. The institutional investors, after the first round of the equity investment, include: (i) UFG Private Equity Fund II, an investment fund focusing on Russia and the CIS (61.1%), and (ii) EBRD (24.4%).
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$300 million. The proposed IFC investment is in the form of equity of up to US$20 million.

During appraisal IFC will review the portfolio of activities to be supported by the project as well as the client''s capacity to manage E&S risks in order to determine the applicable requirements, which may include a combination of the IFC Exclusion List and the national E&S laws and regulations. IFC will also review compliance with the IFCs Performance Standards 2: Labor and Working Conditions. The client will be required to commit to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working conditions (PS 2) to apply the Exclusion List and to inform the IFC in the event of any change in nature or scope to its business operations.

Project Description: TTS and its subsidiaries (collectively known as TTS Group) are leading providers of integrated logistics, freight forwarding and shipping services in Romania and an existing IFC client. The proposed project is an equity investment of up to EUR 12.0 million for 10% of newly issued shares in the Company. TTS Group is expanding its inter-modal operations across the Danube River System and in Constanta Port in the Black Sea. Proceeds from the investment will be mostly used to fund capital expenditures for TTS subsidiaries: - CNFR Navrom S.A. (Navrom)  river shipping on the Danube - Canopus Star S.R.L. (Canopus)  grain terminal in Constanta Port - Trans Europa Port S.A. (TEP)  river port terminals on the DanubePart of the proceeds will be used to fund various other corporate expenses, including enhancements to the IT systems.
Review Scope: This project is an investment in an existing client. Two previous projects were:  TTS I (Transport Trade Services, #24082, 10-year EUR 14 million A Loan) and TTS II (S.C. Transport Trade Services S.A., #26203, 10-year EUR 10 million C Loan).  S.C. Transport Trade Services S.A. (TTS, or the Company) and its subsidiaries and affiliates (TTS Group) are leading providers of integrated logistics and freight forwarding services in Romania. The first project (#24082) financed the investment program to upgrade and expand the fleet of vessels operating on the Danube River.  It was approved and committed in 2005.  The second project (#26203) provided additional funding for the TTS Groups expansion plan which included constructing a grain handling terminal, purchasing equipment and refurbishing / acquiring propelled vessels.  It was approved and committed in 2008.  Since 2005, IFC has conducted periodic and ongoing supervision of TTS Groups environmental, health and safety performance by reviewing Annual Monitoring Reports (2005-2010) prepared for Navrom, TTSs major subsidiary and the actual borrower in the first project, and by having a supervision visit to TTS and selected subsidiaries in June 2010.  The appraisal of this third investment in TTS was conducted by a desk review of the accumulated and updated information about the Groups environmental and social (E&S) performance obtained through IFCs supervision activities described above, and an appraisal visit in September 2011 to major facilities of the Group likely to be supported by IFCs third investment including:  CNFR Navrom (Navrom), TransEuropa Port (TEP), Canopus Star SRL (Canopus) and some additional facilities to review E&S risk mitigations (Navroms passenger transport operations at Galati and Danube Delta  Navrom Bac S.R.L and Navrom Delta S.A. Tulcea).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Issues of this repeat category B project are essentially the same as those identified for the previous two investments and include:- environmental, health and safety management systems of the TTS Group;- river fleet safety and pollution control at Navrom;- oil / hazardous cargo spill prevention and control at Navrom;- maintenance / repair yard pollution control and hazardous materials and waste management at Navrom; and- employee health and safety of TTS Group.IFCs ongoing review and supervision of the existing investments shows TTS Group continues to ensure that its operational facilities and subsidiaries comply with applicable environmental, health and safety (EHS) requirements, including:  international navigation standards under International Safety Management (ISM) code of the IMO, the Danube Commission recommendations, Romanian shipping-related rules and EHS laws, and IFC Performance Standards.  IFCs current Environmental and Social Risk Ratings (ESRRs) for the two previous investments are Good.

Project Description: The project consists of a new syndicated facility to Banco Itaú BBA, S.A, (Itaú BBA or the Bank), the wholesale subsidiary of Itaú Unibanco Holdings (IUH).  IUH is an existing partner to IFC and one of the largest banks in Brazil.  It offers a wide range of financial services including banking services to individuals, micro, small and medium enterprises, and large corporate clients through Itaú BBA.This above Project will support Itaú BBAs lending operations in the frontier regions of Brazil, especially in the North and Northeast, assisting the Bank to grow its credit portfolio and presence in those regions.
Impact: 1)	Increase access to finance in frontier regions with focus on smaller and middle sized companies.2)	Assist in  the development of companies located in frontier regions of the country which are still underserved by the domestic financial markets.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed project has been classified as Category FI according to the IFC Environmental and Social Review Procedures.  During the appraisal IFC will review the client''s portfolio and the project structure to determine E&S requirements applicable to the Project, as well as review the Banks labor practices according to IFCs standards. The client has an existing Social  &  Environmental Management System (SEMS), which IFC will review and may recommend adjustments, if needed regarding the Project. The client may be required to; (i) maintain and/ or upgrade the SEMS concerning the Project; (ii) demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established  by  the  IFC  Performance  Standard  2:  Labor andWorking  Conditions; and (iii) continue to annually submit  The Social and Environmental Performance Report for Financial Intermediary Client to IFC
Sponsor: IUH is a private company, with publicly traded shares on São Paulo Stock Exchange, New York Stock Exchange and Buenos Aires Stock Exchange. IUH shareholders are: Itaúsa (listed holding company with other investments and controlled by Egydio family; 19.6%), IUPAR (holding company controlled by Moreira Salles family and by Itaúsa; 25.9%) and the remaining is Free Float (53.7%).  IUH has operations in 18 countries spanning the Americas (mainly Latin America), Asia, Africa and Europe and it employs nearly 105,000 people, of which 98,000 in Brazil. As indicated above IUH is an IFC existing partner.

The A loan will be up to US50 million for IFCs own account and the B loan will be of up to US$200 million  to be provided by other financial institutions. Company Name: CONVERGENCE PARTNERS COMMUNICATIONS INFRASTRUCTURE FUND LLC
Project Description: The Project consists of an IFCs equity commitment of up to US$45 million in Convergence Partners Communications Infrastructure Fund LLC, an up to US$500 million investment vehicle, which is being raised and will be managed by Convergence Partners Management Limited (Convergence Partners), a South Africa based investment management firm.The Funds strategy is to invest in the opportunities presented by current underdeveloped state of Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) infrastructure in Africa.  In IFCs experience, funding is often not the only requirement for successful ICT infrastructure investments.  Other critical components include project conceptualization, design, development and implementation.  Over the past few years, Convergence Partners have demonstrated the capacity, knowledge and skills, as well as proven investment track that position the firm to successfully capitalize on the opportunities in Africa ICT infrastructure sector.
Impact: - Further Development of ICT Sector in Sub-Saharan Africa:  Based on substantial expertise in ICT sectors and hands-on, value added approach to investees, the Fund Manager will continue to proactively source investment opportunities with significant socio-economic and developmental impact.- Provision of Critical Funding and Expertise to Emerging Market Companies:  The Fund will address critical funding needs by emerging market companies that due to their business stage or scale might face capital access constraints.  The Fund''s investments will support entrepreneurship, innovative business models and technologies, and generate employment.  The Fund Manager will provide operational, technical and managerial advice to its investees.- Development of Africa Private Equity Sector: The importance of private equity for development of emerging market private sector, nurturing entrepreneurship and supporting business innovation is well recognized, and IFC''s commitment to the Fund will serve as a vote of confidence for Africa''s growing private equity industry.
Environmental Social Issues: This transaction involves a Tier-II equity investment and the overall portfolio risk is considered medium.  Therefore, the project has been categorized as FI-2 in accordance with IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Convergence Partners Communications Infrastructure Fund s a dedicated private equity fund focusing on communication infrastructure and associated activities.  The majority of the potential pipeline investments entail limited environmental and social (E&S) risks and impacts that can be readily addressed.  The investments will focus primarily on the establishment of terrestrial communication networks and, to a more limited extent, marine networks.  For this project, the client will be required to screen projects against IFCs Exclusion List, national laws and IFCs Performance Standards.
Sponsor: Founded in 2006, Convergence Partners is an investment management and advisory firm focused on the ICT sector in emerging markets, with a principal focus on Africa.  Since inception, the firms investment and research activities have been covering the full spectrum of industry sectors, across various phases of the investment cycle, including early stage/venture capital, expansion capital, private equity and project equity.  In the recent years, Convergence Partners have been closely involved in the development phase of new communication infrastructure projects, bringing critical bandwidth to the African market and serving rapidly evolving communication needs of African businesses and consumers.The management team comprises professionals with a solid track record of sourcing, structuring and managing investments in the ICT sector.  The team has an on-the-ground presence and over the years has developed relationships with key business players and regulators in the region.  All senior partners are significant shareholders in the business.  The team is led by Andile Ngcaba, Chairman, Brandon Doyle, Chief Executive Officer, Idan Segal, Chief Investment Officer, and Stefan Ferreira, Chief Financial Officer.
Cost Nature: IFCs investment will consist of an equity commitment of up to US$45 million in Convergence Partners Communications Infrastructure Fund LLC.  Total IFCs exposure to the Fund will not exceed 15% of the Funds total final commitments.

Project Description: The project is to finance Eastcomtranss expansion of its railcar fleet operations from currently close to 6,000 wagons progressively to reach around 13,500 units by the end of 2013.  Eastcomtrans is a significant rail car provider in the Kazak market, with oil tank cars (77%), LPG tank cars (15%) and open wagons (8%).  The Kazakh rail transport market is significant as the country covers 2.7 million square kilometers resulting in long distance transportation being needed for most goods, and a significant extractive industry sector, covering mainly oil, gas and coal.  As a result close to 75% of the freight turnover in Kazakhstan (not including pipelines) is carried out by the important rail sector.  Eastcomtrans supports the bulk transport sector (oil, gas, and bulk raw materials/coal) and most of their cars are in back-to-back lease arrangements with the main oil and gas producers in Kazakhstan, while a smaller number of cars are available for short term lease/rent through dispatcher arrangements.
Review Scope: IFCs review of this investment relied on documentations presented by Eastcomtrans Management and discussions with technical and human resource staff.  This included the review of a 200 page documentation folder prepared by Eastcomtrans.  IFC staff also visited operations where Eastcomtrans'' wagons were used.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project because the Companys railcar lease and rental activities do not involve actual operations or maintenance of the wagons, which are designed and maintained according to local and international standards as appropriate for their operational usage, and therefore the company''s activities will not result in any material environmental and social risks and impacts.

Project Description: The Project would invest in Eastcomtrans LLP (ECT or the Company), the largest private railcar leasing company in Kazakhstan with a fleet of about 8,350 wagons.  It provides railcars to major Kazakh and Russian companies on an operating lease basis (where the economic value of ownership remains with ECT).  The Company also provides transshipment and rail forwarding services.  A significant portion of its fleet are oil tank cars with the balance being open gondola wagons and Liquid Petroleum Gas (LPG) railcars.  IFCs investment would be part of a larger financing to fund the Companys 2012 expansion program (the Project).  This would enable the Company to diversify its fleet and client base while also allowing it to continue to grow its proprietary freight forwarding business.
Impact: The project would: (i) support the continued development of a key player in the still nascent private Kazakh rail sector; (ii) promote competition and the role of the private sector in a state-dominated industry; (iii) contribute to the development of the transportation and logistics sectors in Kazakhstan; and (iv) help renew Kazakhstan''s aged railcar fleet, helping avoid a supply crisis over the next 5-10 years as about half of the existing fleet needs to be retired.  The availability of new, more reliable railcars would also help sustain the competitiveness of Kazakhstan''s railway sector, mitigating the risk of trucks displacing the railway with attendant increases in harmful greenhouse gases.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project because the Companys railcar lease and rental activities do not involve actual operations or maintenance of the wagons, which are designed and maintained according to local and international standards as appropriate for their operational usage, and therefore the company''s activities will not result in any material environmental and social risks and impacts.
Sponsor: Founded in 2002, ECT is currently wholly owned by Mr. Marat Sarsenov (a Kazakh national), 60% directly and 40% through Steinhardt Holding B.V.
Cost Nature: IFCs proposed investment is an equity investment of up to US$20 million and a convertible loan of up to US$30 million.  This would be used to finance part of the Companys proposed 2012 investment program totaling US$120 million.
Investment: 50.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan30.0Equity20.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Eastcomtrans is headquartered in Almaty, Kazakhstan.  Its railcars, while registered in Kazakhstan, can operate throughout the Former Soviet Union and, in particular, some of its wagons are regularly interchanged from Kazakhstan into the Russian Federation.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project because the Companys railcar lease and rental activities do not involve actual operations or maintenance of the wagons, which are designed and maintained according to local and international standards as appropriate for their operational usage, and therefore the company''s activities will not result in any material environmental and social risks and impacts.

Project Description: The proposed project consists of the runway overlay of Sangster International Airport (SIA) and other safety investments (the Project). SIA is the larger of the two international airports in Jamaica and is operated under a 30-year concession granted by the government of Jamaica (GOJ) to the project company, MBJ Airports Limited (MBJ). As the principal gateway for tourists visiting Jamaicas major resorts, SIA is of particular importance to the countrys tourism infrastructure. The GOJ has made its expansion and modernization a high priority. The Projects rapid implementation is essential to the continued safe operation of the airport.
Impact: a) The Project involves much needed investments for the continuous maintenance of SIA''s infrastructure in order to improve safety and ensure operations at the highest levels of service to all stakeholders (carriers, tenants and users).  b) The safety improvements at SIA are essential for the airport to continue supporting tourism in Jamaica, a critical source of revenues for the country''s economy. c) The continued success of a high profile project like SIA will encourage other foreign investments and further private sector participation in infrastructure concessions in Jamaica.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project because the investment activity has minimal incremental environmental and social impacts and risks; no further appraisal or disclosure will be necessary. IFC will continue to supervise performance under the framework established by the original investments. IFCs ongoing review and supervision of the existing category B investments in MBJ confirms the company is continuing to meet its environmental, health and safety, and social compliance obligations, including compliance with the applicable and relevant IFC Performance Standards. MBJs most recent Annual Monitoring Report provided adequate assurance of environmental and social performance, and there are no outstanding follow-up actions. The current Environmental and Social Risk Rating (ESRR) for the project is B  1  Good.
Sponsor: MBJ is a private company incorporated in Jamaica in 2002 with its registered office at the Sangster International Airport, Montego Bay, Jamaica. MBJ is a 74.5% subsidiary of Desarrollo de Concesiones Aeroportuarias S.A. (DCA), which holds stakes in a number of airports around the world. DCA is controlled by Abertis Infraestructuras, S.A., an international infrastructure group incorporated in Spain. The remaining 25.5% of MBJs shares are owned by Vantage Airport Group (formerly YVR Airport Services Ltd. or YVRAS), incorporated in Canada. YVRAS is a leading airport operator majority-owned by Vancouver International Airport Authority which operates Vancouver International Airport, Canadas second busiest airport.
Cost Nature: The cost of the Project is US$22.4 million. IFC is considering providing up to US$7.5 million through an A loan for IFCs own account and up to US$7.5 million in additional mobilization. The proposed financing would be IFCs fourth investment in SIA since MBJ took over the airport operation in 2003. IFC provided MBJ with A and B loans to finance the construction of a new terminal in 2003, the refurbishment of the original terminal buildings in 2005, and check-in related equipment in 2008.

Location: SIA is located on 232 hectares on the tourist-oriented northwest coast of Jamaica, approximately 6 km east of the country''s second major city, Montego Bay.

MBJs most recent Annual Monitoring Report provided adequate assurance of environmental and social performance, and there are no outstanding follow-up actions. Project Description: The Company, listed on the New York Stock Exchange, is a major educational provider in China.  As of end-2011, it operated one university college and two career enhancement campuses, 25 career enhancement centers, 138 tutoring centers, and five K-12 schools throughout China. The Company plans to develop two new career enhancement campuses in Beijing and Guangzhou, expand its campus Kunshan, Suzhou, and continue to complete its campus in Dalian, Liaoning (together, the Project), and IFC has been approached to provide financing of up to US$50 million to support this expansion.
Review Scope: The scope of review of the operations of Ambow Education Holding Ltd (Ambow or the Company) in China included assessment of its management system and capacity to oversee and monitor compliance of its operations with IFCs Performance Standards as well as national environmental, social and safety regulatory requirements.  IFCs review relied on documents made available by the Company and interviews by IFC during its visit to Ambows career enhancement campus, university college, Kindergarten through twelfth grade (K-12) schools, and tutoring centers in Suzhou, Dalian, and Beijing. IFC staff met with Ambow personnel from its management, administrative and facility maintenance, investor relations, and human resource teams.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific and reversible environmental and social impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Key environmental, health and safety, human resources and social issues that were reviewed included: environmental and social management system; labor and working conditions; occupational health and safety; air, water, and solid emissions or discharges to the environment and their management; life and fire safety and emergency preparedness and response program; community health and safety; water, energy and resource use and efficiency; land acquisition; and community engagement.
Sector: AB - Colleges, Universities, and Professional Schools

Project Description: Founded in Treviglio, Italy, in 1927, SDF is an integrated manufacturer of tractors, combine harvesters, specialist harvesters, diesel engines and farm machinery. Its products are marketed under the brands SAME, DEUTZ-FAHR, LAMBORGHINI, HÜRLIMANN and GRÉGOIRE.  Currently SDFs production is based in four plants in Europe (Italy, Germany, France and Croatia), one in Croatia, one in Russia and one in China.  Furthermore, in Bandirma, Turkey, the production of tractors from 50 to 70 HP has started in co-operation with a local partner.SDF Croatia, located in Zupanja (south eastern Croatia), was acquired by SDF in 2005. This facility produces harvester / combines and is the only facility in Group to manufacture these products. Almost all production is exported to neighboring EU countries  mainly Germany and France. Since the acquisition, SDF revamped the Companys operations by modernizing its machinery and operations, consolidating SDFs European combine production on its site, introducing new products, and making it one of SDFs main logistics centers. The proposed Project in Croatia involves further capacity expansion and modernization of manufacturing operations (including machine modernization, debottlenecking and refurbishment in existing industrial buildings) to support SDFs growth plans (the Croatia Project).
Review Scope: IFCs review of this investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety (EHS) related information submitted by SAME DEUTZ-FAHR Group (SDF or Sponsor) and the SAME DEUTZ-FAHR ZETELICE d.o.o. (SAME Croatia or Company) facility including: regulatory permits and approvals, site layout plan, technical specifications, quality, environmental, occupational health and safety policy,  organization chart, human resources (HR) procedures, safety and waste management rule books, safety statistics and records, environmental monitoring reports, etc. The review also included site visits and discussions with the respective senior management and EHS team for SAME Croatias facility in Zupanja in Croatia and SDFs corporate headquarters and main manufacturing facility in Treviglio, Italy.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards and guidelines. Key environmental and social issues associated with this Project include: SDF''s corporate approaches to management of environmental, occupational health and safety and social issues, SAME Croatias management of environmental and occupational health and safety during the manufacturing and assembly operations, labor and working conditions including workplace air quality and noise, energy efficiency, emissions to air, use, treatment and discharge quality of liquid effluents and management of solid and hazardous waste.
Sector: DA - Agriculture, Construction, and Mining Machinery

Project Description: Founded in Treviglio, Italy, in 1927, SDF is an integrated manufacturer of tractors, combine harvesters, specialist harvesters, diesel engines and farm machinery. Its products are marketed under the brands SAME, DEUTZ-FAHR, Lamborghini, Hürlimann and Grégoire. SDFs production is based in four plants in Europe (Italy, Germany, France and Croatia), one in India, one in Russia and one in China (under development). In addition, it has established an industrial agreement with a local company for the assembly of tractors in Bandirma, Turkey.The proposed project in India involves expansion of manufacturing operations (including machine modernization and refurbishment) and setting up a research and development (R&D) and testing center in existing industrial buildings to support (i) SDFs strategy of making India as the engine manufacturing center for all its manufacturing facilities in the group, (ii) aligning the Companys production with European emission standards, and (iii) growth in the domestic market as well as export markets that cover neighboring countries, Turkey and east Africa (the Project).
Review Scope: IFCs review of this investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety (EHS) related information submitted by SAME DEUTZ-FAHR Group (SDF or Sponsor) and SAME DEUTZ-FAHR INDIA (P) LTD  (SAME India or Company) including: regulatory permits and approvals, site layout plans, technical specifications, organization chart, human resources (HR) procedures, health and safety policies and procedures, safety statistics and records, environmental review reports, waste management system designs, monitoring reports, etc. The review also included site visits and discussions with the respective senior management, HR and EHS teams for SAME India facility in Ranipet in South India and SDFs corporate headquarters and main manufacturing facility in Treviglio, Italy.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards and guidelines. Key environmental and social issues associated with this Project include: SDF''s corporate approaches to management of environmental, health and safety (EHS) and social issues; SAME Indias management of occupational health and safety and environmental aspects during the manufacturing operations; labor and working conditions including workplace air quality and noise; efforts to minimize wastes and emissions and enhance resource efficiency; emissions to air; use, treatment; discharge quality of liquid effluents and management of solid and hazardous waste and impacts of transportation to and from the facility on the nearby communities.
Sector: DA - Agriculture, Construction, and Mining Machinery

Project Description: SAME DEUTZ FAHR Zetelice d.o.o. is a producer of combine harvesters, located in Zupanja, Croatia.  It was privatized in 2005 when it was acquired by the Italian producer of agricultural machinery, SAME DEUTZ FAHR Group SpA (SDF).  Since the acquisition, SDF revamped the Companys operations by modernizing its machinery and operations, consolidating SDFs European harvest combine production on its site, introducing new products, and making it one of SDFs main logistics centers.  The project consists of introduced leading edge harvesting technology into the Croatian company and gearing it to become a major exporter and distribution center for Europe and the CIS.
Impact: 1.	Contribution to food security. Based on competitive cost structure, quality, efficient distribution network and service, the projects are expected to increase the availability of tractors and harvest combines in their regions. This, in turn, should help improve the agricultural productivity and thus output, and contribute to food security. 2.	Contribution to rural development: Increased mechanization of the agriculture in the region is expected to lead to higher farmer income as well as development of small businesses that provide spare parts and maintenance/ repair services for the agricultural machinery. 3.	Job preservation in a frontier region.  By supporting the continuation of the Croatian Company''s post-privatization restructuring, IFC''s investment is expected to ensure the preservation of at least 300 jobs at the plant, and help increase indirect employment in the supply chain and distribution network of the SDF group in the region through the Company''s growth.
Role:
1. Counter cyclical role. Current market conditions in Europe magnifies IFC''s countercyclical role as most of the European banks, especially the Italian banks that are active in eastern Europe, have been limiting their exposure to emerging markets due to funding and capital constraints. In this regard, IFC would be supporting a second tier European company within the context of IFC response to the European crisis.
2. Longer term flexible financing structure. The proposed loan structures fits well with the needs of SDF, which is not available from other sources especially during the current market conditions. In the context of the evolving European crisis, access to long term finance has been limited especially for second tier European companies.

Its products are marketed under the brands SAME, DEUTZ-FAHR, LAMBORGHINI, HÜRLIMANN and GRÉGOIRE.  SDF currently employs approximately 2,800 staff. Project Description: Ambow Education Holding Ltd (Ambow or the Company) is a major educational provider in China.  As of end-2011, it operated one university college and two career enhancement campuses, 25 career enhancement centers, 138 tutoring centers, and five K-12 schools throughout China. The Company plans to develop two new career enhancement campuses in Beijing and Guangzhou, expand its campus Kunshan, Suzhou, and continue to complete its campus in Dalian, Liaoning (together, the Project)
Impact: (i)	Improve students'' employability: The Project will provide the infrastructure for college students, high school graduates, and working adults to improve their technical skills and employability prospects through hands-on IT training and other soft skills training;(ii)	Reduce youth unemployment: By bridging the skill gap between college and high school students and their first job, the Project will reduce unemployment among youth; (iii)	Enhance education outcome: The Project will enhance education outcomes by offering vocational training services that mobilize quality teachers, online learning tools, and innovative systems that track students'' progress as well as provide guidance on their career prospects; and(iv)	Support innovative model of education: The Project will provide support to an innovative model of education delivery: large career enhancement campuses located in close proximity of potential employers, with courses designed closely with these potential employers and content providers.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific and reversible environmental and social impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Key environmental, health and safety, human resources and social issues that were reviewed included: environmental and social management system; labor and working conditions; occupational health and safety; air, water, and solid emissions or discharges to the environment and their management; life and fire safety and emergency preparedness and response program; community health and safety; water, energy and resource use and efficiency; land acquisition; and community engagement. Refer to the Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) of this Project for more details.

Dr. Huang holds a bachelor''s degree in Computer Science, a master''s degree in Computer Science and a Doctor of Philosophy (Ph.D.) in Electronic Engineering from the University of Electronic Science & Technology of China. Between 1990 and 1993, Dr. Huang was doing research at the University of California, Berkeley while completed her Ph.D. dissertation.The Company is listed on the New York Stock Exchange and it is currently owned by the Sponsor and the management team (29.1%), institutional and other shareholders (45.5%) and public (25.4%) as of February 2012.

Project Description: The proposed project by AHEL, which is among the largest integrated healthcare groups in India, involves an investment of upto US$394 million over the next four years to add about 2,900 beds to its hospital network and for equipment purchases of its existing hospitals (Project). The funds will be used to implement AHELs strategy for growth which includes: (i) expansion in existing facilities that are reaching full capacity; (ii) setting up new facilities in larger cities with growing and unmet demand; and (iii) expanding its network of Reach hospitals, which include smaller, simpler facilities in less developed population centers.
Review Scope: IFCs review of this investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety (EHS) related information of Apollo Hospitals Enterprise Limited (AHEL or the Company) including EHS policies and procedures at group Level, facility management systems, environment, health and safety (EHS) performance and reports of Apollo Reach Hospitals, construction contract documents, site checklists, waste management authorizations and waste and emissions monitoring data for existing hospitals. The appraisal also included site visits to AHELs flagship hospital in Chennai and Apollo Reach Hospital in Karaikudi, and discussions with senior management and the project team in-charge of design and development of Apollo Hospitals.This is third investment by IFC in AHEL. The Environmental Social Review Summaries (ESRS) for the previous IFC investments are available at:Apollo Equity (Project #24406) disclosed in July 2005, is available at: http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/ProjectDisplay/ERS24406 Apollo Loan (Project #25969) disclosed in April 2009, is available at: http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/ProjectDisplay/ESRS25969This review thus, builds upon the previously disclosed ESRSs and ESAPs, and the information collected during IFCs engagement with AHEL over the past years.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Key risks and issues related to this project include: adequate social and environmental assessment of the impacts of the Project; the Companys capacity to manage its social, environmental, health and safety performance, and engage with local communities in accordance with local requirements and IFC Performance Standards and EHS Guidelines; assurance of fair, safe and healthy working conditions; management of wastes (particularly biomedical waste) and emissions; impacts of transport infrastructure on nearby communities during construction, life and fire safety management for all public use buildings in accordance with international  fire safety codes and impacts of land acquisition as applicable.The Project will result in a limited number of potentially adverse environmental and social impacts which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria. On this basis, this project is therefore classified as a Category B project according to IFCs Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability and Performance Standards.

Project Description: Apollo Hospitals Enterprise Limited (AHEL or the Company) is among the largest integrated private healthcare groups in India.  The proposed project by AHEL involves an investment of upto US$394 million over the next four years to add about 2,900 beds to its hospital network and for equipment purchases of its existing hospitals (the Project). The funds will be used to implement AHELs strategy for growth which includes: (i) expansion in existing facilities that are reaching full capacity; (ii) setting up new facilities in larger cities with growing and unmet demand; and (iii) expanding its network of Reach hospitals, which include smaller, simpler facilities in less developed population centers.
Impact: -	AHEL''s plans to set up new hospitals and expand facilities will enhance the country''s medical infrastructure and improve access to high quality healthcare services. The Company''s facilities in larger cities will act as centers of excellence for tertiary healthcare, while its new facilities in second and third tier cities and in Low Income States (LIS) will bring affordable quality healthcare closer to populations in these locations and reduce the need for people to travel long distances to seek medical care.   -	The Project will help raise the overall quality of private medical service delivery in India, thereby also having a strong demonstration effect.-	The Project, upon completion, will provide additional direct employment to more than 9,000 people in the healthcare sector, apart from generating indirect employment. -	AHEL is incorporating aspects of green buildings into the design and construction of its facilities while also taking steps to increase energy efficiency of existing operations.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects. Key risks and issues related to this project include: adequate social and environmental assessment of the impacts of the Project; the Companys capacity to manage its social, environmental, health and safety performance, and engage with local communities in accordance with local requirements and IFC Performance Standards and EHS Guidelines; assurance of fair, safe and healthy working conditions; management of wastes (particularly biomedical waste) and emissions; impacts of transport infrastructure on nearby communities during construction, life and fire safety management for all public use buildings in accordance with international  fire safety codes and impacts of land acquisition as applicable. Further details on the potential environmental and social impacts of the project, corresponding mitigation measures and guidance on how and where information about the project are provided in the Environmental & Social Review Summary.

AHELs shares are listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange and the National Stock Exchange. Dr. Reddy and family members own 33.1% of the shares. Other significant shareholders include Apax Group (12.7%) and Integrated Healthcare Holdings (Mauritius) Ltd (11.2%). IFC holds approximately 0.9% of AHELs shares

Project Description: The Project consists in the development, construction and operation of a 305 MW hydropower generation plant in the Reventazón river basin located in Siquirres, province of Limón, one of poorest regions in CR.  It would be the largest hydropower project in CR (and Central America) when it starts operations in 2016.  The Project involves a relatively long construction process of 4-5 yrs (medium size hydro projects are usually built in around 3 years) which has already started (15-20% advance according to ICE).  It comprises an 8.8m diameter /2 km tunnel, and a 535 meter long / 125 meter high dam, with a reservoir area of approximately 690 ha.
Sector: V-BA - Large Hydro - Renewable Energy Generation

Project Description: The proposed Project entails investment of debt and equity to support future expansion of the Persianas Group (the Group or Persianas).  Persianas currently owns and sub-contracts operation of The Palms Shopping Mall in Victoria Island, Lagos; is completing construction of the Polo Park mall in Enugu; has construction underway at the Kwara Mall site in Ilorin and has acquired land upon which a mall will be developed in Ibadan.  Persianas also expects to develop additional mall projects during the lifetime of IFCs proposed investment, and may also acquire existing buildings for redevelopment and subsequent letting.
Review Scope: IFCs review comprised meetings with key staff of the Persianas Group, i.e.: the Chairman and Managing Director, the Chief Investment Officer who is also Managing Director of the Groups real estate asset management company, and the Head of Project Development.  The review also included visits to the existing, operational The Palms Shopping Mall in Lagos, the under-construction malls in Ilorin and Enugu and the site of the future mall in Ibadan.  Supporting documents reviewed included environmental impact assessment reports for The Palms and Ilorin malls, the construction contractors safety management manual and a Persianas environmental management plan for the construction phase of the Enugu mall.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The key environmental and social (E&S) issues for this multi-site property development and operation transaction relate to Persianas assessment of potential adverse environmental and social impacts ahead of site acquisition, development of appropriate plans to mitigate such impacts in construction and operation.  Future issues of  concern are the manner of land acquisition, so as to minimize or mitigate possible economic or physical displacement; engagement with communities adjacent to mall sites, if any; environmental issues such as noise, dust and erosion control during construction; safety in construction; and in the operational phases, provision of safe and fair working conditions, occupational health and safety, energy efficiency and management of greenhouse gas emissions arising from energy use and release of refrigerants, solid waste management, and life and fire safety.  These issues may all be readily mitigated and are relatively minor and reversible. This is therefore an environmental and social Category B project.

Company Name: SOCIETE IVOIRIENNE DE PRODUCTION ANIMALE SA
Project Description: Project descriptionLa Societe Ivoirienne de Productions Animales (SIPRA or the Company) was created in 1976 and is the largest poultry operator in Cote dIvoire and in Francophone West Africa region. SIPRA has vertically integrated operations established in three key business entities, namely 1) Ivoire Poussins, which encompass seven (7) parent stock farms and hatchery for production of one day-old chicks, with a production capacity of 18 million chicks per year, and commercial farming facilities (intégration) composed of four (4) egg laying farms, and 34 broiler chickens farms, including 9 under SIPRAs management and 25 contracted farms with a production of 5.5 million birds/year; 2) Ivograin, a feed mill unit with installed production capacity of 100,000 tons/year located in Yopougon. Ivograin also sells its products through a network of 22 retail outlets throughout Ivory Coast; and, 3) CoqIvoire, a slaughtering unit with a processing capacity of 2,000 chicken/hour and 43 retailing outlets for fresh chicken and eggs. Ivograin and CoqIvoires activities also encompass logistical/distribution activities, including third-party contracted fleet of 75 trucks for corn sourcing and feed mills delivery and SIPRAs own fleet of 6 one day-old chick delivery trucks, 6 livebird delivery trucks, 15 CoqIvoire delivery (refrigerated) trucks respectively.   The proposed investment from IFCs is up to 7M and will fund SIPRAs 22M expansion project (the Project) over the next 3 years. The Project includes: (i) expand broiler production to 8 million birds/year; (ii) expand egg production to 70 million eggs p.a. (from current 20 million eggs); (iii) increase poultry & egg retail outlets to 80 (from current 43); (iv) debottlenecking of feed mill to increase capacity; and (v) others (working capital, etc.).
Review Scope: IFCs environmental and social (E&S) appraisal included two-day site visits to SIPRAs corporate office and selected production facilities, including: - Meetings with SIPRAs senior management, including Mr. Jean-Marie Ackah, President, Mr. Sylvain Gotta, Managing Director, Mr. Aboya Koffi, Director of Human Resources, Dr. Latyr Faye, Veterinarian and Director of the hatchery and commercial farms, Mr. Alphonse Coffi, Director of Ivograin, Mr. Patrick Yace, Director of CoqIvoire. Meetings with the quality management officers in Ivograin and CoqIvoire also took place; - Review of key technical documentations provided by SIPRA, including operational permits (agréments from sector ministries), review of the internal human resource management regulations (Règlement Intérieur) and Code of Good Conduct, Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs), SOPs implementation status and technical capacity, internal and external environmental and occupational health and safety (OHS) audits/inspections, life and fire safety (L&FS), resource consuption effiency (water, energy), social performance;- - Site visit to Ivoire Poussin parent stock farm and hatchery unit, situated in Bingerville (suburd of Abidjan), SIPRAs associated broiler farm in Abobo, CoqIvoire slaughtering unit in Abobo and Ivograins feed mill plant in Yopougon.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This proposed investment is expected to have limited environmental and social impacts which are expected to be site-specific, temporary and none are expected to be significant. Those impacts can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to recognized performance standards, procedures, guidelines and design criteria as described in the following sections. Thus, this is a Category B project in accordance with IFCs Environmental and Social Sustainability Policy. This categorization is in accordance with other similar type of projects within the sector. The project is designed to avoid, minimize and manage environmental and social risks and impacts of the Companys operations in compliance with applicable IFCs Performance Standards and World Bank Group (WBG) General and sector-specific (Poultry production and Poultry processing) Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines. IFCs Good Practice Note on Animal Welfare and its applications to SIPRAs operations have also been assessed.  Key E&S issues applicable for this investment are: (i) operational licenses of SIPRAs facilities; (ii) environmental, occupational health and safety (OHS), food safety and social management system, including Hazard Assessment and Critical Control Point (HACCP) and ISO 22000 certification; (iii) adherence to Ivorian labor law, working conditions, standards and OHS risk prevention and management, including SIPRAs employees, contractors and nearby communities; (iv) Life and Fire Safety (L&FS) provisions and emergency preparedness and response; (v) use of public utilities (water supply and energy), optimization of water and energy use through project design and resource conservation measures and greenhouse gas emissions; (vi) food safety and biosecurity protocol and procedures; (vii) land acquisition and expansion planning procedures; (viii) wastewater collection and treatment, solid waste disposal, air emissions from generators and boilers, potable water quality, treatment and monitoring, hazardous material handling, management and control of pest and rodent; (ix) food and transport safety, and (x) engagement with communities on EHS, food and traffic safety and social performance.

Project Description: CCFP (Critical Commodities Finance Program) is part of IFCs multi-faceted rapid response to the current financial crisis. As a crisis response initiative, CCFP will address eminent needs in terms of liquidity and unfunded guarantees and help avoid disruptions in the supply chain of commodities to and from emerging markets. The CCFP would be a portfolio-based program with total funding from IFC up to US$1 billion, Developmental Financial Institutions/Governments (DFIs) up to US$1 billion, and commercial banks up to US$2 billion that will be mobilized and disbursed under separate facilities for each participating bank in the program.The proposed project with ING Bank N.V. (ING or the Bank), a bank incorporated in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, under CCFP, CCFP-IFC facility, will provide ING with a funded risk-sharing facility of up to US$250 million for a trade portfolio of up to US$500 million aiming at supporting both agri globally and energy sectors only in IDA and IDA-blend countries. The portfolio will consist of funded trade transactions originated by ING through its wide network of Emerging Market Issuing Banks (EMIBs) and corporate customers.  Trade transactions will be subject to certain eligibility criteria.
Environmental Social Info: ING will not have direct exposure to primary agro-commodity supply chain issues through this type of facility and is therefore not subject to IFC''s supply chain requirements outlined in the IFC''s Performance Standards.
Impact: The project is expected to have a significant development impact by increasing funding for trade of critical agri and energy commodities to/from the emerging markets. CCFP is aimed at helping to address this current liquidity constraint faced by both financial institutions and real sector businesses.
Role: IFC''s global franchise in financial markets will be critical to the project''s success in leveraging trade volumes, expanding new markets, and providing liquidity that will enable the financing of agri and energy commodities.
Sponsor: ING was founded in 1991 by the merger of Nationale-Nederlanden (Insurance) and NMB Postbank Group. ING is one of the top five European banks by net profit and is the 15th largest bank by total assets and by market capitalization. The Bank is rated A+ by S&P and Aa3 by Moodys. In the field of trade and commodity finance, ING is one of the top tier banks in the world, operating out of 25 countries. Apart from its Western European core markets, ING has an especially strong presence in the Europe & Central Asia (ECA) Region. ING offers a wide range of trade & commodity related financial services to SMEs, mid-corporate and corporate clients directly or indirectly via financial institutions. ING brings its trade finance expertise to its more than 1,300 core clients that are playing a major role in the global commodity trade flows.
Cost Nature: As part of IFCs Critical Commodities Finance Program, the IFCs investment to ING will be up to US$250 million to support the extension of trade and commodity financing to INGs clients.

Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project has been classified as Category FI in accordance with IFC''s Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability. The applicable E&S requirements for this project will include a combination of IFC''s Exclusion List and portfolio eligibility criteria on the applicable country/commodity E&S risk matrix associated with the production and trade of agro-commodities, especially as it relates to harmful child/forced labor and biodiversity risks associated with the conversion of natural and critical habitats, and E&S counterparty assessment, as appropriate. Specifically, for the imports of energy inputs, adoption of best practices on safety and handling risks during storage, transportation and sale will be assessed.
Risk Impact: ING will not have direct exposure to primary agro-commodity supply chain issues through this type of facility and is therefore not subject to IFC''s supply chain requirements outlined in the IFC''s Performance Standards.
Mitigation Measures: ING will be required to implement a methodology for screening transactions based on the applicable country/commodity E&S risk matrix associated with the production of agro-commodities, especially as it relates to harmful child /forced labor and biodiversity risks associated with the conversion of natural and critical habitats.  This process will allow excluding project supporting agro-commodities that have known significant E&S issues in the countries where they are sourced/produced. IFC will also pre-qualify the universe of agri and energy integrators above a certain credit rating, and will rely on ING to monitor and carry out supervision of the beneficiaries; however, IFC will retain the right to drop any beneficiary from the Program at its sole discretion. In addition, IFC will have further analysis of the impact of the proposed financing along the value chain including producers and importers.

Project Description: HSBC Bank Armenia is subsidiary of HSBC Group. The bank was established in Armenia in 1996, originally under the name Midland Armenia Bank and has been renamed into HSBC Bank Armenia in 1999. The bank is one of the leading banks in Armenia, offering a wide range of products and services to individual as well as corporate customers in Armenia and abroad.The IFC will provide a financial facility to HSBC Bank Armenia (the Bank) to finance projects for investment in renewable energy (RE) and energy efficiency (EE) technologies (RE/EE) in Armenia. IFC is considering supporting the project with financing from the Canada Climate Change Program, a donor-funded facility for climate change friendly projects. IFC shall also provide advisory services to the Bank for technical training of credit officers and risk specialists, as well as training and transaction support for the sustainable energy finance projects.The facility will be used for financing investments in projects that will result in increase of energy efficiency or generation of renewable energy in Armenia. The project builds on IFCs first renewable energy finance loan in Armenia to finance small hydropower plants, complemented by advisory services. In Armenia, RE producers are supported by favorable legislation, a guaranteed feed-in tariff and 15 year power purchase agreement. Survey of 100 Armenian enterprises undertaken by IFCs Energy Efficiency Survey Project in 2008 found, that there is significant potential for EE financing and the industry could be saving up to 14.5% of energy costs by further improving energy efficiency. The proposed facility would support the Bank in expanding the volume of financing for EE and RE projects.
Impact: The development impact is expected to be high, as the Project provides the needed long term funding for investments in renewable energy and energy efficiency sub-projects in an IDA country through an experienced and capable bank and contributes to the deepening of financial intermediation in Armenia. It will also help Armenian companies to improve their competitiveness and overcome the consequences of the economic crisis as well as support job generation. Estimated volume of greenhouse gas emissions that can be avoided as a result of the project implementation stands at 15,000 tons.
Environmental Social Issues: This project, classified as Category FI according to IFCs Environmental and Social (E&S) Review Procedure, consists of an IFC senior loan to HSBC Bank Armenia (HBAM), a new IFC client, to finance energy efficiency and renewable energy in Armenia. Preliminary information provided by HBAM indicates that as a subsidiary of HSBC Group, the bank subscribes to international standards such as the Equator Principles and also follows the Groups sustainability policies and operational procedures.As part of IFCs appraisal, IFC reviewed the potential E&S risks associated with financing projects involving energy efficiency (such as upgrade of general/auxiliary and industry-specific energy equipment in industry sectors such as food processing, chemical industry, building material production, metal-processing and mining) and renewable energy (such as small hydro power plants, wind and solar energy). IFCs appraisal also focused on assessing HBAMs capacity to identify and manage these risks, including the banks experience to date with similar types of projects as well as the extent to which HSBC Group-level E&S procedures are implemented at the subsidiary level as part of the banks lending procedures. IFC has also appraised HBAM''s labor practices against IFC Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working Conditions.As a condition of IFC commitment, HBAM will need to designate an ESMS Officer and demonstrate that E&S risk management procedures will be revised and integrated with the banks lending procedures to meet IFCs standard for an acceptable Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS). As a condition of IFC disbursement, HBAM will need to provide evidence that adequate E&S due diligence and monitoring procedures have been developed and implemented to ensure that the E&S risks associated with energy efficiency and renewable energy projects are assessed against the IFC Exclusion List, applicable social and environmental laws and regulations of Armenia, and IFC''s Performance Standards.
Sponsor: HSBC Bank Armenia is a joint venture between the HSBC Group, which has a 70% ownership, and Wings Establishment, a company controlled by a UK-Armenian business with 30% ownership.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$30 million. IFC is considering supporting the Project with financing from the Canada Climate Change Program, a donor-funded facility for climate change friendly projects administered by the IFC.
