Location: Proceeds of the loan facility will be on-lent by HSBC Bank Armenia to its customers in Armenia through its 8 branches operating in Armenia.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project, classified as Category FI according to IFCs Environmental and Social (E&S) Review Procedure, consists of an IFC senior loan to HSBC Bank Armenia (HBAM), a new IFC client, to finance energy efficiency and renewable energy in Armenia. Preliminary information provided by HBAM indicates that as a subsidiary of HSBC Group, the bank subscribes to international standards such as the Equator Principles and also follows the Groups sustainability policies and operational procedures.As part of IFCs appraisal, IFC reviewed the potential E&S risks associated with financing projects involving energy efficiency (such as upgrade of general/auxiliary and industry-specific energy equipment in industry sectors such as food processing, chemical industry, building material production, metal-processing and mining) and renewable energy (such as small hydro power plants, wind and solar energy). IFCs appraisal also focused on assessing HBAMs capacity to identify and manage these risks, including the banks experience to date with similar types of projects as well as the extent to which HSBC Group-level E&S procedures are implemented at the subsidiary level as part of the banks lending procedures. Project Description: Persianas Group (the Company or Persianas) is the developer of the first, internationally specified, purpose-built mall (The Palms Shopping Mall) in Nigeria. The Companys existing portfolio comprises the Palms Shopping Mall and Polo Park Mall in Lagos and Enugu State respectively which are in operation and two other malls in Kwara and Oyo States that are under development. The Companys vision is to develop and list Nigerias first investment grade real estate portfolio. The Nigerian real estate sector is expected to produce high growth in the medium term driven by the recovering economy, and other high growth sectors of commerce, construction, telecommunications, and a recovery in the financial services sector. This is expected to lead to demand for real estate product in all sectors in an environment where there is a dearth of quality stock of real estate and the market is undersupplied. To address Nigerias vastly underserved commercial property, Persianas is undertaking a restructuring and expansion of its operations which involves the: i) building and development of new retail and mixed used centres; ii) establishment and development of a professional asset management company; and iii) restructuring of the Companys balance sheet (The Project). At completion, the new Project is expected to provide at least approximately 140,000 square meters of business infrastructure.
Impact: The Project is expected to have the following impacts: i) Improvement of food security - rollout of modern food retailing as planned anchor for every development.ii) Direct and indirect employment - retail and service jobs; possibility for linkages. iii) Tax revenues will accrue to the government.iv) Development of critical business infrastructure in Africa''s second largest market, and most populous nation.v) Elevation of commercial real estate standards - throughout the country.vi) Better aesthetic environment, particularly states outside Lagos undergoing redevelopment.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an environmental and social (E&S) Category B project because potential E&S risks and impacts are limited in scope to construction and operation of malls, and are readily mitigable.The key environmental and social (E&S) issues for this multi-site property development and operation transaction relate to Persianas assessment of potential adverse environmental and social impacts ahead of site acquisition, development of appropriate plans to mitigate such impacts in construction and operation.  Issue of particular concern are the manner of land acquisition, so as to minimize or mitigate possible economic or physical displacement; engagement with communities adjacent to mall sites, if any; environmental issues such as noise, dust and erosion control during construction; safety in construction; and in the operational phases, provision of safe and fair working conditions, occupational health and safety, energy efficiency and management of greenhouse gas emissions arising from energy use and release of refrigerants, solid waste management, and life and fire safety.
Sponsor: Mr. Adetayo Amusan is the primary sponsor/ promoter of the Project. He currently serves as executive chairman of Persianas Limited (Mauritius), Persianas Properties Limited (PPL), Persianas Investment Limited (PIL) and all other related mall development subsidiaries which will eventually come under one holding company  The Persianas Group. PPL (a.k.a the Palms Mall) is the premier asset in the Group and it is wholly owned by the founder, Mr Adetayo Amusan, while PIL is owned by himself and his wife, Mrs Ayodeji Amusan. The Company has entered into joint venture with a number of state governments for the development of retail and commercial real estate. These state governments own between five to thirty percent shareholding in the respective joint venture company. Mr Amusan also holds majority ownership in the Groups asset management company, Africa Real Estate Investment and Asset Management Company Limited (ARIA), while the remaining shareholding is held by Mr. Michael Williams  the groups chief investment officer.
Cost Nature: The project cost is estimated at approximately US$400 million and will be financed with a combination of debt and equity. Of this amount IFC and IFC African, Latin American and Caribbean Fund, LP (ALAC) have proposed to invest up to US$74 million in equity and IFC providing an additional financing of US$50 million A-Loan.
Investment: 87.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan50.0Equity37.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Project will be implemented in different states within Nigeria. Some project sites have been identified and are in various stages of development and operation. These include:Lagos Sate: The Project will be located on approximately 69,000 square meters of land at the Oniru Chieftaincy Family Private Layout, Victoria Island Annex, Lekki-Pennisula, Eti-Osa Local Government Area.Oyo State: The Project will be located on approximately 77,210 square meters of land along M.K.O Abiola Road, Ibadan in Ibadan South West Local Government Area of Oyo State.Enugu State: The Project is located on approximately 83,000 square meters of land at Polo Park grounds in GRA, Enugu, along the Abakaliki Expressway, Enugu State.Kwara State: The Project will be located on approximately 32,240 square meters of land at Fate Road/ Alhaji Tunde Mohammed Road, by Nigeria Television Authority Station, Ilorin, Kwara State.Persianas expects to develop additional mall projects during the lifetime of IFCs proposed investment, and may also acquire existing buildings for redevelopment and subsequent letting.

Company Name: SOCIETE IVOIRIENNE DE PRODUCTION ANIMALE SA
Project Description: IFC is considering to invest up to 7 million to support the expansion of La Societe Ivoirienne de Productions Animales (SIPRA or the Company), a leading poultry operator based in Cote dIvoire.  SIPRA has vertically integrated operations established in three key business units, namely 1) Ivoire Poussins, which encompass parent stock farms and hatchery for production of one day-old chick, and commercial farming facilities composed of 4 egg laying farms, and 34 broiler chickens farms, including 9 under SIPRAs management and 25 contracted farms; 2) Ivograin, a feed mill unit. Ivograin is also selling its products through a network of 22 retail outlets throughout Ivory Coast; and, 3) CoqIvoire, a slaughtering unit and 43 retailing outlets for chicken and eggs.IFCs financing will be used for SIPRAs 22 million expansion project (the Project) over the next 3 years. The Project includes: (i) expand broiler production to 8 million birds p.a.; (ii) expand egg production to 70 million eggs p.a. (from current 20 million eggs); (iii) increase poultry & egg retail outlets to 80 (from current 43); (iv) debottlenecking of feedmill to increase capacity; and (v) others (working capital, etc.).
Impact: (i)	Contribution to the Development of the Ivoirian Poultry Industry:  IFC investment will support the Company''s efforts to promote higher efficiency, quality, and best practice biosecurity standards.  These best practices would spread throughout the country, and contribute to development of Ivorian poultry industry.(ii)	Benefit to the supply chain:  SIPRA operates in a post conflict country with significant linkages to farmers and MSMEs.  SIPRA works with 25 poultry outgrower farms.  Also, SIPRA sources maize locally reaching small farmers, and sells its feed and day-old chicks to poultry meat and egg farmers.  The Company indirectly contribute the growth of small service-oriented businesses (transporters, restaurants, etc.).  (iii)	Employment creation:  The Company has 523 full-time employees and 217 temporary workers. The Project is estimated to create approximately 200 additional jobs.(iv)	Increased Tax Revenue For Government. (v)	Demonstration effect:  IFC investment in Cote d''Ivoire will raise confidence of other investors.
Environmental Social Issues: The potential adverse impacts of this project are limited, site specific and reversible and can be readily mitigated. As such, this investment is classified as a Category B in accordance with IFC''s Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability. The key environmental and social issues associated with this project include: SIPRA''s management capacity to implement an integrated environmental, occupational health and safety (EHS) management systems, in accordance with IFC Performance Standards and applicable World Bank Group General and sector-specific (poultry production and processing) EHS guidelines, appointment of a full-time and qualified E&S officer to ensure the effective implementation and continuous improvement of the EHS system; corrective action plan of the OHS and life and fire safety performance at all SIPRA''s facilities; and, management of waste water, solid wastes and air emissions at all sites.
Sponsor: Mr. Jean-Marie Ackah, the president of SIPRA, owns 78% of SIPRA.  Rest of the ownership is held by the Companys employees (2%), BICICI (subsidiary of BNP Paribas in Cote dIvoire) (10%), and COLINA (an insurance company) (10%).
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at 22 million. IFCs proposed financing is equity and loan of up to 7 million.
Investment: 10.67 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan6.67Equity4.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: SIPRAs facilities are located in the greater Abidjan area.  Ivoire Poussins facilities are situated in Bingerville (isolated from communities, for biosafety reasons), slaughtering unit is in Abobo (surrounded by commercial and residential areas), and Ivograins feed mill plant in Yopougon (an industrial area).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The potential adverse impacts of this project are limited, site specific and reversible and can be readily mitigated. As such, this investment is classified as a Category B in accordance with IFC''s Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability. The key environmental and social issues associated with this project include: SIPRA''s management capacity to implement an integrated environmental, occupational health and safety (EHS) management systems, in accordance with IFC Performance Standards and applicable World Bank Group General and sector-specific (poultry production and processing) EHS guidelines, appointment of a full-time and qualified E&S officer to ensure the effective implementation and continuous improvement of the EHS system; corrective action plan of the OHS and life and fire safety performance at all SIPRA''s facilities; and, management of waste water, solid wastes and air emissions at all sites.

Project Description: DOSHION Pvt Limited, (DOSHION or Company) provides water and wastewater treatment and transmission EPC services for industrial and municipal applications in India. The Company also has limited manufacturing operations, primarily in making GRP pipes and specialty chemicals for use in the water treatment industry. Services provided by the Company include undertaking EPC and turnkey contracts, and Build-Own-Operate-Transfer (BOOT) concessions for industrial and municipal customers. The Company currently has four concessions  a 24x7 water supply concession in Shivpuri, Madhya Pradesh; an industrial water supply/wastewater treatment BOOT for Nagarjuna Oil Corporation Limited (NOCL) in Cuddalore, Tamil Nadu; a desalination concession in TWAD and a brackish water desalination DBOOT for Rajasthan Mines and Minerals in Rajasthan. The proposed IFC investment is equity / quasi equity investment of INR equivalent of up to USD 24 million to finance capital expenditure and upcoming BOOT based water and wastewater projects, water transmission projects involving bulk water supply and cross country pipelines.
Review Scope: The scope of review of Doshions compliance with IFCs Performance Standards included assessment of Doshion''s management capacity of its environmental, social, health and safety performance in relation to IFC Performance Standards, national (India) regulatory requirements and relevant Environmental Health and Safety guidelines. The review relied on documents and reports made available by Doshion, and interviews conducted by IFC staff. Meetings and interviews with key staff (business development, operations, human resources, environmental, social, health and safety) were conducted, and numerous, relevant procedures demonstrating the Companys management capacity to provide adequate oversight of its environmental, social, health and safety performance in conducting its business were discussed. The IFC team also visited various facilities, including manufacturing (Ahmedabad), EPC projects (Baroda and New Delhi) and a municipal BOOT concession (Shivpuri).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because the projects currently undertaken by the Company will create a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that can be minimized, avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria. Projects undertaken by the Company in the future typically will likely have a limited footprint, and help in providing access to clean potable water for water treatment projects, and reduce pollution from discharge of effluents in wastewater treatment projects.

Company Name: BANQUE INTERNATIONALE POUR LE COMMERCE ET L'INDUSTRIE DE LA COTE D'IVOIRE
Project Description: The proposed project is for an up to XOF 20 billion Risk Sharing Facility to support SME lending in post conflict Côte dIvoire for Banque Internationale pour le Commerce et lIndustrie de la Côte dIvoire (BICICI or the Bank), a subsidiary of BNP Paribas.  BICICI is the fifth largest bank in the country banking sector in terms of loans (9.9%) and deposits (9%), with a network of 27 branches in 9 cities. Created in 1962, the Bank operates a universal bank business model servicing the retail, SME and corporate business segments.
Impact: This project is expected to have significant development impact by: (i) Supporting the resumption of lending in CDI and helping spur economic growth through the increase in lending to SMEs;(ii) Promoting lending to viable SMEs in a post-conflict environment where it has been increasingly difficult to access financing.
Environmental Social Issues: During the appraisal, IFC determined that this Category FI project is considered medium risk based on the potential E&S impacts associated with SME operations in Cote d''Ivoire, which would be targeted under IFC''s proposed risk sharing facility to support the SME sector. However, this project is also considered to carry a reputational risk to IFC given the Bank''s existing exposure to clients active in the cocoa sector with associated labor and forestry risks. Therefore, the key issue in this project is whether the Bank can develop adequate capacity for conducting the necessary E&S risk management of SME clients and to identify clients with exposure to the cocoa sector. The Bank will be required to ensure compliance of the activities financed with the IFC Exclusion List and the national E&S laws and regulations of Cote d''Ivoire. The Bank will also be required to demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions. Based on IFC''s appraisal of the project, the Bank currently does not have any E&S risk management practices in place including qualified E&S staff and E&S due diligence procedures. The Banks current HR policies and practices were found to be largely in compliance with the PS2 requirements. In addition to IFCs usual E&S requirements for FI investments (designation of qualified E&S staff, development and implementation of an ESMS, and annual E&S reporting) and to mitigate the reputational risk to IFC from the Bank''s exposure to clients in the cocoa sector, the Bank would need to further enhance its capacity to mitigate risks associated with clients in the cocoa sector if these types of clients were to be considered for financing under the proposed project.
Sponsor: The project sponsor, and majority shareholder of BICICI, is BNP Paribas (BNPP), a leading French-based banking group with key positions in its three core businesses: Retail banking, Corporate & Investment Banking and Investment Solutions.  Listed on the Paris stock exchange, BNPP stock  is widely held.   The Group is currently rated AA- by Standard & Poors, Aa3 by Moodys and A+ by Fitch.  As of December 2011, BNPPs shareholders equity stood at EUR 75.3billion and total assets EUR 1,965 billion. The Group has over 200,000 employees and a presence in 80 countries.
Cost Nature: The total size of the Risk Sharing Facility is estimated to be XOF20 billion.  Under the proposed terms of the Facility, BICICI would be responsible for generating a portfolio of loans that satisfy certain criteria set by the Bank and IFC.  IFCs participation would involve sharing the risk on up to 50 percent of the Facility.

Project Description: DOSHION Pvt LIMITED, (Doshion or Company) is engaged in the business of complete water cycle management for the past 35 years. Doshion offers the complete gamut of technologies, manufacturing capabilities, engineering & project management, infrastructure and assets management solutions. Doshion provides total water management solutions including supplying custom-made Water Treatment Plants and Waste Water Treatment plants used in industries like power, refineries, pharmaceuticals, SEZs, airports, ports, metals, chemicals, textiles, etc. depending on the source of water, quality and quantity of water and the end use of water including recycling / reuse and zero liquid discharge. The Company also supplies Packaged Water Treatment Plants and Sewage Treatment plants to its customers. The Company also has a manufacturing unit for manufacturing different types of Ion Exchange Resins and chemicals used for treatment and purification of water. The Company also undertakes turnkey contracts and Build-Own-Operate-Transfer (BOOT) contracts for its customers. Its customers include municipalities and leading industrial players across India and overseas.The Company plans to expand its reach in India and develop several new EPC and BOOT projects in India.
Impact: a)	Create projects for water distribution and transmission thus increasing access to clean waterb)	Create projects for treatment of waste water thus reducing water pollutionc)	Generation of employment both during construction and operation stage.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects. The proposed IFC equity investment in Doshion will support the Company''s capital expenditure and upcoming BOOT projects. As part of the environmental and social review process, the Company''s corporate environmental and social management system, policies and procedures were reviewed as well as its performance to date on ongoing projects. The scope of review included environmental, safety and health and social risks and impacts of the project and the Companys management capacity to undertake such projects in the future, including how environmental and social consequences are taken into account, from screening of opportunities to planning, design, construction and operation phases.Because the proposed equity investment may be used to support future, but as yet, undefined projects in addition to those identified, the principal environmental and social risks identified for the project which will require additional mitigation measures by the Company include implementation of a comprehensive environmental and social management system; and adoption of IFC environmental and social Performance Standards as part of the applicable legal and other requirements in its management system, including formal procedures for environmental and social screening of business opportunities (including any joint ventures) and new projects into its marketing strategy, commercial planning, and project bidding processes.
Sponsor: Doshion was incorporated in 1978 by Mr. Dhirajlal Shivlal Doshi as a partnership in the business of manufacturing resins. Since then, the Company has expanded itself into a full-fledged water cycle management company.The current shareholders of the Company include  a) key directors including Mr. Dhirajlal Shivlal Doshi, Mr. Ashit Dhirajlal Doshi, Mr. Rakshit Dhirajlal Doshi, Mr. Amit Dhirajlal Doshi, Mr. Sujit Dhirajlal Doshi  and their families; and b) IDFC Private Equity Fund.The Company has a subsidiary called Doshion Veolia Water Solutions Limited, which is a Joint Venture with Veolia Water Solutions and Technologies, France.
Cost Nature: IFC is considering an equity/quasi-equity investment of the INR equivalent of up to US$24 million to finance expansion related capital expenditure, long term working capital and upcoming BOOT based water projects, Cross Country Pipelines and other EPC projects.

Company Name: Urbi Desarrollos Urbanos, S.A.B. de C.V.
Project Description: URBI has requested IFC to support its Low Income Housing (LIH) construction and development efforts through a corporate loan of up to US$50 million. The objective of the IFC financing to Urbi is to allow them to continue to complement the Mexican Government affordable housing program which through their several programs provides housing financing solutions to lower income families, and promotes the development of large scale sustainable affordable housing communities, like Valle San Pedro. Urbi is planning on constructing almost 50,000 housing units in the first stage of this development.
Review Scope: IFC conducted an appraisal of the corporate management systems in place at Urbi, used to identify and manage environmental and social risks and impacts associated with the companys low income housing development activities. Examples of environmental and social assessment practices and ongoing management and oversight of company-based and contracted activities were reviewed at an active development site, the Urbi Valle San Pedro development in Valle Las Palmas Baja California, a major housing project on the outskirts of Tijuana. Large scale housing developments require considerable land, appropriate assessment and ongoing biodiversity conservation where such exists and consideration of protection of cultural heritage as applicable. Construction materials, adequate energy and water supply, sanitary and storm water treatment and disposal systems, control of impacts during construction related to erosion, dust, chemicals and waste management and the efficiency of the housing units and common services themselves are all of importance when considering housing such development; these were therefore reviewed during the site visit and discussed with management at company headquarters as they relate to the overall planning and design process used by Urbi in developing their projects. Due diligence of the companys labor practices was also conducted, both in terms of conditions of employment of its own staff and the management processes used to promote good occupational health and safety practices in construction activities.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an E&S category B project because, on the basis of information reviewed by IFC, this investment will have limited adverse social and environmental impacts that are few in number, generally site specific, largely reversible and readily addressed through mitigation measures, as outlined in the Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) attached to this ESRS. The main issues of concern include the following: ensuring the client works with relevant local and national authorities to obtain the required planning consent and ensuring developments are conceived so as to support overall development objectives at the municipal, state and federal levels and meet IFC environmental and social requirements. Further, ensuring that measures to protect the occupational health and safety of construction contractors are enforced, that hazardous and non-hazardous materials and waste management during construction of the houses and other infrastructure meets regulatory and IFC requirements, that measures to protect any biodiversity that may be present are in place and that other practices to avoid or minimize erosion and dust generation and the resources (materials, energy and water) that will be used in the construction and consumed during occupancy of the houses are  expended as efficiently as possible are also of importance.

Project Description: The Project is a proposed investment program of around Euro 90 million comprising expansion of production capacities. Alutech is aiming to expand the present production capacity of 22,000 tpa of extruded products and 53,000 units of door systems to 45,000 tpa and 150,000 units respectively (the Project). Production of extruded products (Alumin Techno) will be increased by construction of new workshops for foundry and anodizing works. Door systems production (Alstrong and Alutech Doors System), which is now operating at rented premises, will be also relocated to the new production facility. The Project will be implemented at two land plots neighboring Alutechs existing site near Minsk, within the industrial zone Shabany.
Review Scope: The proposed Project is with the Alutech group of companies (the Company, Alutech or the Group), the only producer of roller shutters accessories, sectional doors and aluminum extruded products in Belarus and an IFC client in good-standing since 2010.  The Environmental and Social (E&S) review of the earlier investment (Project ID # 28684), as well as a short description of Alutech manufacturing facilities in Belarus, were disclosed on the IFCs site and locally. The existing investment is regularly supervised and its E&S performance has been determined to be in material compliance with at-approval agreements. The Group has completed all actions agreed with IFC in the Environmental and Social (E&S) Action Plan. The most recent monitoring visit by the IFCs E&S specialist to Alutechs manufacturing enterprises in Minsk was conducted in December 2011. Meetings with the Groups specialists were held to get the latest update on the current environmental and social performance; and to understand E&S implications of Alutechs expansion project.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This Project is a Category B project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure. Alutechs environmental and social performance is in material compliance with the regulatory requirements of the Belarus and relevant IFCs Performance Standards and World Bank Groups (WBG) Environmental, Health and Safety Guidelines. It is expected that Alutechs environmental and social performance will be further improved as the result of the Project implementation. This is because the existing operations will be relocated to new facilities, which will be fully equipped with appropriate emission and effluent discharge control. The existing anodizing and foundry workshops of AluminTechno will be phased-out. Construction impacts associated with the Project are limited and can be readily mitigated by applying standard protection measures during construction.

Project Description: The proposed Project is with the Alutech group of companies (the Company, Alutech or the Group), the only producer of roller shutters accessories, sectional doors and aluminum extruded products in Belarus and the IFC good-standing client since 2010.  Alutech was founded in 1996.  It operates four manufacturing enterprises (Alutech, AluminTechno, Alutech Industrial Doors Systems and Alstrong) in Minsk, Belarus, and one in Kyiv, Ukraine, as well as over 20 trading companies and local warehouses in Belarus, Ukraine, Russia, and Czech  Republic (jointly referred to as the Group).  The implementation of the Project would allow Alutech to further reduce its production cost, strengthen its leading market position and penetrate new geographic markets, predominantly in the growing former CIS region and European Union through the expansion of its production capacities for sectional doors and aluminum profiles.
Impact: The Project will further increase the supply of high quality extruded aluminum products and panels, which are important components for the construction industry, and are used in infrastructure, housing amd industrial real estate developments across the region.  The Project will help Alutech grow its share in the regional market, substituting imports and providing adequate quality products at competitive price.  It will also help the Company to increase its exports to the European markets.  Key development impacts to the local economy include employment generation and benefits to the consumers.  The Project has a significant demonstrational effect.
Environmental Social Issues: The Project is a Category B project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure. Alutechs current environmental and social performance is in material compliance with the regulatory requirements of the Republic of Belarus and relevant World Bank Groups Environmental, Health and Safety Guidelines. It is expected that Alutechs environmental and social performance will be further improved as the result of the Project implementation  the existing anodizing and foundry workshops will be phased-out, and new facilities will be fully equipped with appropriate emission and effluent discharge control. Construction impacts associated with the Project are limited and can be readily mitigated by applying standard protection measures during construction. The summary of IFCs environmental and social review findings for the project is publicly available in the Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) disclosed through IFCs external website: http://www.ifc.org/projects.
Sponsor: The Group is owned by several individuals, all are citizen of the Republic of Belarus.

Company Name: Urbi Desarrollos Urbanos, S.A.B. de C.V.
Project Description: Urbi Desarollos Urbanos SAB de CV (Urbi or the Company) has requested IFC to support its Low Income Housing (LIH) construction and development efforts and in particular the macro projects, through an investment of up to US$50mm either in US$ or equivalent Mexican Pesos (the Project). IFC is also considering providing a US$20 million loan from the Canada Climate Change Program to support eligible green building projects in addition to mobilizing up to US$35mm equivalent in local currency through syndication.
Impact: The Project''s strong development impact includes: (i) job creation; (ii) addressing the housing deficit; (iii) integrated and sustainable urban developments; (iv) transfer of knowledge and best practices on green building in Mexico, and E&S sustainability; and (v) contribution to equitable economic growth and community development.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an E&S category B project because, on the basis of information reviewed by IFC, this investment will have limited adverse social and environmental impacts that are few in number, generally site specific, largely reversible and readily addressed through mitigation measuresIdentified Applicable Performance StandardsWhile all Performance Standards (PS) are applicable to this investment, IFCs environmental and social due diligence indicates that the investment will have impacts which must be managed in a manner consistent with the following Performance Standards:- PS1: Social and Environmental Assessment and Management Systems- PS2: Labor and Working Conditions.- PS3: Pollution Prevention and Abatement.- PS4: Community Health, Safety and Security.Issues related to PS5, Land Acquisition and Involuntary Resettlement are not encountered because, as a practice, land acquisition by Urbi is done on a willing-buyer-willing-seller basis, which would not impinge on individuals or local communities rights. There are no current issues with regard to the potential displacement of occupants and/or users of land that is banked by the company (approximately 5,500 ha which is equivalent to 7 years of future housing developments). Land acquired for such future projects is regulated by state and local development plans. When an area designated for urban development is under communal ownership (ejidos), which may have been formerly used for limited agricultural production, it is legally subdivided and sold to developers under a willing seller-willing buyer arrangement. Land whose use is changed from agriculture to urban development rapidly increases in value, which amply compensates for any improvements the ejidatario might have made and is paid at the market price. Issues related to PS6, Biodiversity Conservation and Sustainable Natural Resource Management are not encountered in general, as by law, housing developments in Mexico cannot be located in protected areas or areas with natural habitats. In the case of the San Pedro development, small pockets of vegetation with biodiversity interest were identified through the corresponding ESIA as being in need of preservation and were appropriately incorporated in the master plan as such. Issues related to PS7, Indigenous Peoples (IPs) were not identified by IFCs due diligence because IPs are not currently affected by Urbi developments and have not been involved in prior land sales. As noted above, land acquisition by Urbi is done in practice on a willing-buyer-willing-seller basis. Issues related to PS8, Cultural Heritage may apply on a case by case basis; issues of cultural heritage have not been experienced in the San Pedro development. In order to ensure appropriate management of cultural heritage issues, however, the company will be required to prepare and implement a chance finds policy regarding cultural heritage.
Sponsor: Within the Mexican context, Urbi is one of the largest, most established and profitable homebuilders (despite having lowest prices in the sector), with presence in 39 cities and municipalities, including the main metropolitan areas. Urbis innovative approach has resulted in it being a pioneer in initiatives targeted to positively impact segments of the population that were not benefiting from access to government programs and consequently housing. Through this, Urbi has been ahead of the curve, having the first mover advantage by tapping new segments of the market, which has strengthened its credibility, brand as well as market positioning. During over 30 years of operations, Urbi has built more than 400,000 housing units.Some of Urbis initiatives, that support and differentiate its operations, include: (i) UrbiNet, a sophisticated information technology platform, (ii) UrbiNova, Companys proprietary construction technology, and (iii) Alternativa Urbi, a unique program in the industry to attend the non-traditional population segments (low-income workers, non-wage earners, and those not affiliated to the housing agencies). Through the City Licensee Manager (CLM) program, the company has managed to rapidly diversify into new Mexican geographies with lower working capital requirements, almost doubling its geographic coverage in three years. These tools have allowed the Company to increase its operating efficiencies and obtain profitable growth.Furthermore, Urbi was the first company to develop a Sustainable Integral Urban Development project (DUIS) in Mexico. These macro projects are comprehensively planned areas of development that contribute toward improving the quality of life of the residents and the territorial organization of the states and municipalities. The Company is in the process of developing additional DUIS projects, which would continue putting it on the front line of innovation.  In addition to the housing development business line, URBI also has a housing-related line of business, which includes commercial land sales, Urbis Casa Capital Program and housing equipment and services.Urbi has been listed on the Mexican Stock Exchange since May 2004 with a market capitalization of US$1.3bn as of 1/16/2012. 54.5% of the shares is public and traded on the exchange. ~40% of the shares belong to the Pérez Román  brothers (co-founders and members of the current management team). Companys credit rating in Mexican market is Moody A3 and Fitch A- as well as an S&P B+ in the international bond market.
Cost Nature: An investment of up to US$50mm either in US$ or equivalent Mexican Pesos (the Project) is intended to be made in Urbi in the form of a senior secured corporate loan (the IFC A Loan). In addition, IFC would pursue a mobilization (the Mobilization or the IFC B Loan) which would result in an increase of the funding to Urbis environmentally sustainable affordable housing projects by another US$35mm equivalent in local currency. IFC is also considering providing a US$20 million loan from the Canada Climate Change Program to support eligible green building projects.

Project Description: Founded in 1998 and headquartered in Bangalore, India; Kalkitech is a technology company providing products, services and solutions that monitor, manage and optimize energy generation and transmission assets for public utilities and industrial clients across the world. Kalkitech has a suite of hardware and software products that provide intelligent decision support system for energy utilities for optimizing their performance leading to reduced operational energy losses. The Company also provides consulting, engineering, systems integration and software Services.  The Company does not manufacture any hardware in its own premises, as it is sub-contracted.  IFC is considering an investment in Kalkitech to support its plans of new product development and to grow the Companys business development capabilities in new and existing markets (the Project).
Review Scope: IFCs review of this investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety (EHS) related information submitted by Kalki Communication Technologies Limited (Kalkitech or the Company) including: company details, regulatory permits & licenses, technical details about the Companys products and services, EHS related policies and procedures etc. In particular, the appraisal included review of an Environment and Social Due Diligence (ESDD) report prepared by an external consultant. The appraisal also included discussions with Kalkitech senior management and technical personnel responsible for EHS management and ESDD consultants.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Key E&S issues associated with the Companys activities include: environmental and social (E&S) impacts of office areas such as solid waste (particularly e-waste) management, energy conservation, human resources management, and worker health and safety and security issues. The Companys activities have limited adverse EHS risks and impacts. This investment is therefore, categorized as B, since it will result in a limited number of potentially adverse environmental and social impacts which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria.

Company Name: CoreCo Central America I Limited Partnership
Project Description: The project consists of an IFC equity investment of up to $10 million or a maximum of 20% of total capital commitments in CoreCo Central America Fund I, L.P. ('CCAF I' or the 'Fund'), a private equity fund that will invest in small- and medium-sized enterprises ('SMEs') in Central America.  With a target size of $65 million, the Fund will focus on underserved sectors with high growth rates, such as healthcare, IT, retail, financial and business services.  The Fund will invest in 8-12 regional services-based businesses with an investment allocation of $1 million to $5 million per company.  Managed by CoreCo Management, Inc., a well-qualified fund management with presence and business networks across Central America, the fund management team sees an opportunity in the region considering: (i) there is an underserved private equity market in the region with growing demand; (ii) the region is attractive in terms of size and consumption; and (iii) there is a favorable competitive landscape where strong demand for independent capital with good corporate governance and financial standards are required.  The Fund's investment thesis and exit strategy anticipate regionalization and cross-border exits.

Project Description: Kalkitech is a technology company providing products, services and solutions that monitor, manage and optimize energy generation and transmission assets for public utilities and industrial clients across the world. The Company was founded in 1998 and is headquartered in Bangalore.The Company operates in the IT services and system integration space but also generates revenues from sales of its SYNC and ELTRIX hardware and software product lines. In addition to selling these products directly to utilities, Kalkitech also provides ELTRIX and SYNC solutions to OEMs who bundle these products with their systems to implement solutions for utilities.
Impact: The Project is expected to have strong development impact by way of the following:(a)	Improve energy efficiency: Kalkitech''s integrated software and hardware technology solutions for the T&D segment will contribute significantly to optimize energy efficiency by providing technologically advanced solutions to utilities and other industrial customers in a market characterized by acute energy transmission and distribution inefficiency. (b)	Improvement in quality of electricity to consumers: The key benefit expected to be delivered to end-consumers is the significant improvement in grid performance and delivery of electricity through fewer power outages, improved power quality and better management of load and electricity. (c)	Support changes in regulatory environment: There is significant traction developing in the power sector in terms of regulations such as Availability Based Tariff, Merit Order Dispatch, Open Access and power trading; sales of Kalkitech''s ELTRIX products will help ensure better compliance with this new regulatory environment.(d)	Creating employment opportunities: New applications of advanced communication and information technologies will provide employment opportunities to the large and growing pool of software and technology professionals in India.
Role:
a) Financing and signaling: Small-cap technology-focused companies operating in the electricity transmission and distribution segment are relatively new to the Indian market and fund-raising from conventional sources is likely to be challenging. IFC equity participation will send a strong signal supporting both the industry segment and the company; this will likely help complete financing of this project, as well as assist with any future fund-raising.
(b) Access to IFC resources: The Company is essentially an early stage technology-driven SME operating in the power and gas utility space. The IFC will provide the Company access to resources that will help to support its growth, including specific value-added knowledge in the Power and IT sectors, as well as resources that have recently been developed by the organization in the still nascent emerging market smart-grid sector.
(c) E&S: IFC involvement with the Project will help Kalkitech adopt a structured framework to manage its social and environmental systems, which will act as a benchmark for its projects and the broader private T&D segment which is still in its infancy in the region.
Sponsor: The sponsor is a public limited company. Its key promoter and management personnel are:Prasanth Gopalakrishnan  Co-Founder & CEO: He has more than 16 years of experience in the Communication System Research and Product Development. His areas of specialization are standards based communication and optimization technology leadership for the energy and utilities space.Sushil Cherian  Co-Founder & CTO: Mr. Sushil Cherian, has more than 16 years of experience in Control and Automation Systems, especially in the Power and Oil & Gas Industries. His areas of specialization are Dynamic Controls and Non-linear Systems.George Punnoose  COO: Mr.George Punnoose has more than 27 years of experience in the Power Industry. He is responsible for the Companys operations.Sunil Vargis Mathew  President: Mr. Sunil Vargis Mathew has more than 16 years of experience in the Electrical Industry in implementing Sub-Station Automation, Energy Management and Control and Automation solutions.Sreeni T S  VP Sales and Marketing:  Mr. Sreeni T S has more than 12 years of experience in different positions, the last 6 years of which has been with Kalkitech.The ownership of the Company is closely held by the promoters & management along with their family and friends.
Cost Nature: The total equity financing required by Kalkitech is US$4.5 million for new product development and to grow the Companys business development capabilities in new and existing markets. The IFC proposes to provide US$1.35 million in the form of a quasi-equity or convertible instrument. The GEF South Asia Clean Energy Fund, L.P. (GEF SACEF) has proposed to invest US$3.15 million alongside the IFC. The IFC is currently invested in GEF through its US$10 million commitment to the Fund. Additionally, IFC & GEF SACEF may finance a second round of US$ 2 million and third round of US$ 5 million equity for use in further business development activities.

Project Description: IFC will be the lead arranger for a US$125 million debt facility to fund a project by WM Gaza to expand a cellular network started by Wataniya in the West Bank.  The project will include construction and maintenance of cellular tower sites, laying and leasing of a fiber connection for the Companys main hub sites, and leasing of retail outlets.
Review Scope: The review of this project consisted of a visit by IFC staff to the project site, to meet with and interview management of Wataniya Gaza (or WM Gaza or the Company), and to have a first-hand look at operational activities.  IFC staff also appraised technical, environmental and social information submitted by WM Gaza, including a including Civil Acceptance Technical Sheets, a Human Resources Policies manual, and a Security Guard Services contract.  IFC staff also reviewed Wataniyas operations in the West Bank under IFCs previous investment, and E&S performance was determined to be satisfactory but with improvements still expected.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: As this project involves a second investment by IFC, with expansion of Wataniyas operations into Gaza following the Companys development of operations in the West Bank under IFCs first investment, and new sites will be chosen only in developed areas where no high risk exists, no major adverse environmental or social impacts are expected to result.  As a result, it has been classified as a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.

Project Description: CCL Products India Limited (CCL), an instant / soluble coffee processor in India was established in 1995. CCL exports instant coffee to second tier brands and private labels in 58 countries. It has a processing plant with annual production capacity of 15,000 MT in Andhra Pradesh, India and a granulation cum packaging plant of 3,000 MT per annum capacity in Switzerland.NCL, CCLs subsidiary was established in 2009 as an instant coffee manufacturer in Dak Lak province of Vietnam. NCL has recently completed the construction of a green field instant coffee manufacturing facility with an annual processing capacity of 10,000 MT. It now plans to add packaging lines, ancillary and line balancing equipment and also secure financing for its working capital requirements (the Project).The project cost is estimated at US$50 million. IFC proposes a loan of up to US$20 million for its own account.
Review Scope: IFCs review of this investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety (EHS) related information submitted by Ngon Coffee Company Limited, Vietnam (NCL or Company) including: Company details (building plans, manufacturing process), Environment Impact Assessment for coffee manufacturing (EIA), regulatory permits & licenses, Projects technical details on coffee manufacturing, third party reports on Vietnam country risks, existing Environmental Health & Safety (EHS) policies and procedures, Human Resource (HR) policies, procedures and practices, organizational charts,  production and EHS data from the Sponsor companys (CCL Products India Limited) Quality Management System. The sponsor company is not having a 3rd party certified EHS management system.The appraisal included site visit to NCL coffee processing facility in Vietnam, discussions with NCL senior management and technical teams and interaction with key stakeholders, such as employees, community, local NGO, contractors and suppliers. A site visit was also made to the Sponsor Companys corporate office in Hyderabad and existing coffee processing facility in Duggirala, Guntur district, Andhra Pradesh, in India.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The proposed investment is expected to have limited environmental and social impacts which are expected to be site-specific, temporary and none are expected to be significant. Those impacts can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to recognized performance standards, procedures, guidelines and design criteria as described in the following sections. This is a Category B project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Sustainability Policy.  This categorization is in accordance with other similar type of project within the sector. The project is designed to avoid, minimize and manage environmental and social risks and impacts of the Companys operations in compliance with applicable Vietnamese legal and regulatory requirements, IFCs Performance Standards and WBGs EHS Guidelines.Key E&S issues applicable for this investment are: social and environmental assessment impacts of the Project; NCL and Sponsors social, environmental, occupational health and safety and food safety management system and performance, adherence to Vietnameses labor laws, working conditions and OHS risk prevention and management, including NCLs employees, contractors and nearby communities; utilization of equipment and operational practices that maximizes conservation of energy, water and process materials, including recycling and reuse initiatives; management of air emissions, liquid effluents, and solid/hazardous wastes from its proposed processing facility; impacts of transport and warehousing infrastructure, and EHS issues associated with the supply chain - especially related to procurement of green coffee from traders & wholesale dealers in Vietnam.

Project Description: Ngon Coffee Company Limited, Vietnam (NCL) was established in 2009 as an instant coffee manufacturer in the Dak Lak province of Vietnam. NCL has recently completed the construction of a greenfield instant coffee manufacturing facility with a processing capacity of 10,000 MTPA. It now plans to add ancillary equipment and utilities at the facility and also secure financing for its working capital requirements.
Impact: Economic value addition and employment generation in VietnamExpansion of a mid-scale Indian company in Vietnam will have a demonstration effect for other Indian companies considering similar avenues for growth. Positive environmental impact: Ngon Coffee recycles solid waste generated during the production of instant coffee to be used as biomass fuel, thus conserving scarce fossil fuel and reducing environmental pollution
Role:
Long term partner: With presence in both India and Vietnam, IFC can act as a long term partner as NCL establishes itself in a new geography / market.
Expertise: NCL can leverage IFC''s knowledge, experience and relationships in the industry. Further, there is a potential to help the company improve environment, safety and quality standards.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is CCL Products (India) Limited (CCL), an instant / soluble coffee processor in India set up in 1995. NCL is a wholly owned subsidiary of Jayanti Pte Limited, Singapore, which in turn is a wholly owned subsidiary of CCL. CCL exports instant coffee to second tier brands and private labels in over 58 countries.  It has a plant with processing capacity of 15,000 metric tons per annum (MTPA) in Andhra Pradesh, India and a granulation-cum-packaging plant with a capacity of 3,000 MTPA in Switzerland.CCL is promoted by Mr. Challa Rajendra Prasad, who together with his family, holds a 35.25% stake in CCL. The remaining stake is held by foreign collaborators (13.4%), institutional investors (15.91%) and other public shareholders (35.43%).
Cost Nature: The Project cost including the greenfield plant which is already completed, the proposed expansion and working capital requirements, is estimated at US$50 million. IFC proposes an A loan of up to US$20 million for its own account.

Project Description: Wataniya Palestine Mobile Telecommunications PLC (the Company), an existing IFC client and second mobile licensee in West Bank and Gaza, has asked IFC to assist it in arranging a US$125 million debt facility to finance the Companys continued expansion in the West Bank and Gaza along with refinancing an existing debt facility (the Project).  The Company launched its operations in the West Bank in November 2009 and has reached 465,000 subscribers, as of December 31, 2011.  The project would result in the Companys capacity to serve more than 2 million subscribers and could result in 3G services being offered for the first time in the West Bank and Gaza.
Impact: The Project will have the following development impacts:-	Improve access to telecommunications services:  The Project will improve the availability of reliable and affordable communications for consumers and businesses in the West Bank and Gaza.  Access to reliable, high quality voice and data services is key for economic activity and for personal and family lives, especially given the many restrictions on mobility currently in place throughout the territories.-	Spur competition:  Mobile sector in West Bank and Gaza is highly dominated by the incumbent operator. As the Company will expand in the market, it is expected to improve the quality, coverage and cost for the mobile users. -	Increased employment:  The Project will create quality employment opportunities at both the Company and the distributor level in the West Bank and Gaza, which suffer from 15% and 26% unemployment rates respectively.  The Company has approximately 410 employees as of December 31, 2011 in the West Bank and plans to hire an additional 160 in Gaza, by the end of 2013.
Environmental Social Issues: Environmental and social risks and impacts in this project are expected to be limited, so the project is classified as Category B according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.
Sponsor: The Company is 48.5% owned by National Mobile Telecommunications Company (NMTC) of Kuwait which is 52.5% owned by Qatar Telecom (Qtel); 36.5% by the Palestinian Investment Fund (PIF) and the remaining 15% of the Company is publicly traded on the Palestinian Stock Exchange.  Qatar Telecom (Qtel) has ultimate control of NMTC as a result of its 52.5% shareholding therein; 24% of NMTC is owned by the Government of Kuwait and 23.5% is publicly traded on the Kuwait Stock Exchange.   Qtel is a multinational telecom operator based in Qatar with operations in 16 countries and with a customer base of over 82 million.  The State of Qatar owns 55% of Qtel, and approximately 22% of Qtels shares are publicly traded on the Doha Stock Exchange.  PIF is a Palestinian state owned investment fund with over $850 million under management.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$408 million equivalent, which will include capital expenditures, license payments, loan repayment and financing costs.  The proposed IFC investment is a US$50 million A Loan for IFCs own account.  IFC will also assist in arranging US$75 million with a combination of parallel loans from local and regional banks and/or IFC B loan.

Project Name: COMPAGNIE HOTELIERE DE LA LAGUNE S.A.
Company Name: COMPAGNIE HOTELIERE DE LA LAGUNE SA
Project Description: The proposed Project consists of a loan to the Azalai Abidjan (the Company) a subsidiary of Azalai Group for the construction and operation of a new hotel in Côte dIvoire. IFC has a current investment with Azalai Group.  For more information on financial structure of the investment please refer to the SII.
Review Scope: As the Abidjan asset is not yet developed and its at an Environmental Impact Assessment stage, IFCs review included the Azalai Groups other assets to get a better context and sense of the management system in place in existing hotels. The review included: Review of the Companys existing Environmental and Social (E&S) management system and its implementation  at the hotel level following onsite visits in Mali, Burkina Faso, Guinée Bissau,  the new hotel construction site in Benin, and the site in Côte dIvoire.  The hotels in Burkina Faso, Guinée Bissau and Benin are not part of this investment; they were appraised as part of the assessment of the Companys E&S risk management practices. Supervision information of existing investments was also reviewed.Interviews with:Technical Manager at each hotel operated by the Company with regards to E&S management at hotel level and relationship at the Group level. The interview focused on life and fire safety aspect; occupational health and safety training; food safety; hazardous material storage and handling; solid and liquid waste handling, storage, treatment and disposal, pest management, potable water sources and treatment measures; pool maintenance procedures; energy efficiency measures; monitoring and reporting; and housekeeping.Construction site Supervisor: the interview focused on fire and life safety measures; electrical installations; liquid and solid waste management measures; construction site safety; onsite labor and working conditions; and land acquisition process. Human Resource Supervisor: interview focused on labor and working conditions at the hotel level particularly human resource policy; hiring process; compensation and benefits; code of conduct; performance evaluation system; and grievance mechanism.Workers Representatives: the interview focused on labor and working conditions (similar to interview with HR Supervisor); type of grievances as well as the effectiveness of the grievance mechanism in place.Health and Safety Committee (HSC): interview focus on understanding of their role and verifying their awareness of the regulatory requirements of a HSC.Onsite Nurse: the interview focused on understanding their role; the most common type of illnesses/incident reported by staff and action undertaken by the Company to resolve root cause;  health awareness campaigns undertaken; adequacy of the infirmary and pharmacy; and incident reporting framework.Head Chef: the interview focused on kitchen and food safety management including food procurement process and pest management.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B investment according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review because the potential adverse social and environmental impacts of the proposed investment are limited, site-specific and reversible and may be mitigated by adhering to the IFC Performance Standards, generally recognized guidelines or design criteria.

Project Description: OCI Construction Group provides international engineering and construction services primarily on infrastructure, industrial and high-end commercial projects in Europe, the Middle East and North Africa for public and private clients. OCI Construction Group is comprised  of (i) OCI and Orascom Construction (OC or the company) with core markets Egypt, Algeria, Saudi Arabia, Abu Dhabi and Iraq, (ii) Besix, a Belgium based construction company in which OCI owns 50% and core markets are Gulf Council Countries, select African & European markets, and (iii) Contrack, a US based wholly owned subsidiary of OCI mainly active in construction in Afghanistan and Qatar. OCI is currently restructuring the group by demerging its operations into two legally independent entities: (i) a fertilizers company to own and manage the fertilizers-related companies under the existing entity-OCI; and (ii) a construction company which would be fully dedicated to own and manage the construction-related part of the business. All OCI current policies and procedures as well as track-record will move to Orascom Construction (OC). OCI filed for the restructuring in Jan. 2012 and at time of appraisal is still waiting for clearance from the relevant national authorities. At the time of appraisal, OCI / OC is the construction contractor on around 56 active construction projects (50 in Egypt , 5 in Algeria and one in UAE).  The Groups consolidated backlog is roughly distributed as follows: 60% infrastructure, 30% commercial and 10% industrial construction. Key projects include new power plant construction and existing plant upgrades, water and wastewater infrastructure improvements and new residential developments, transportation upgrades (roads and metro) and general building construction and civil engineering projects.  IFCs proposed investment is to support OCs working capital needs over the course of the next three years through a revolving loan facility.
Review Scope: This is a follow-on investment to Orascom Construction Industries (OCI) (project #30974) in 2011. IFCs environmental and social (E&S) review of this second proposed investment consisted of meetings and discussions with OCIs corporate directors for Health, Safety and Environment (HSE) and Human Resources (HR). During the review, IFC E&S specialist visited two of OCIs construction projects underway at sites in Egypt (6th of October power plant, and National Post complex in Cairo) in addition to the ones reviewed under the recent investment. The review also consisted of reviewing technical, environment and social information submitted by the Company including:Health, Safety and Environmental policiesHealth, Safety and Environment (HSE) plan, risk management procedures, accident and investigation procedures, training records and ISO certificates;Environmental program including environmental protection plan, evaluation of environmental aspects, monitoring and measurement procedures, environment and quality communication procedures;Emergency preparedness and response;Human Resources policies and procedures including organization charts; HSE Audit reports for Mechanical and Rebar workshops.Waste handling contracts;Sample of HSE site audit reports,Environmental measurement files for a number of projects; andSample of HSE project closure report.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: IFC''s review of OC''s existing contracts indicates that the construction activities described above will have potential limited adverse environmental or social risks and/or impacts that are few in number, generally site-specific, and readily addressed through mitigation measures. It is therefore concluded that this is an Environmental Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures.

Project Description: The Simandou Project is a world-scale mining project comprising: (i) an open pit iron ore mine in the Simandou Range in southeastern Guinea, approximately 600 km south east from the Guinean coast,   (ii) a trans-Guinean railway of approximately 670 km in length to transport the ore from the mine to the Guinean coast; (iii) a new Port facility located south of Conakry in the Forécariah prefecture; and (iv) various associated developments providing utilities and infrastructure to the project including construction workforce facilities, roads, quarries, power generation and distribution and water supply. First ore is anticipated in 2015, with the production expected to increase over the following years to an estimated 95 million tonnes per annum.The mining resource is located in the southern part of the Simandou Range and covers deposits at Pic de Fon and Ouéléba.  The main geological units are known technically as hematite and goethite (iron ore), itabirite and phyllite.  These minerals extend up to 500 m below the surface and the two orebodies are estimated to contain more than two billion tonnes of high grade iron ore.  The Simandou Project is being developed by Simfer, a Guinean-registered company.  Simfer is a subsidiary of the international mining group Rio Tinto, and holds a mining concession to explore and mine iron ore in the southern part of the Simandou Range.  Simfer is owned 5% by the International Finance Corporation (IFC) and 95% by a company owned jointly by the Rio Tinto Group (53%) and a consortium led by Aluminium Corporation of China, Chalco, (47%).  In April 2011, the Republic of Guinea and Simfer signed a Settlement Agreement pursuant to which a modified mining concession covering the southern part of the Simandou range was issued to Simfer.  The Settlement Agreement also provides inter alia, for the separation of the mining activities from the principal infrastructure activities (the railway and port).  The mine will continue to be held by Simfer whereas the rail and port infrastructure will be held by an infrastructure company to be established between the Republic of Guinea and Simfers other shareholders (Rio Tinto, Chalco and the IFC).The total project financial commitments for Simandou III activities currently forecast at approximately $4.0 billion.  This amount includes the $700 million settlement sum (as agreed in the agreement signed between Simfer and the GoG, announced by Rio Tinto plc on 22 April 2011), technical studies and resource definition drilling through to the completion of the PEA and DE, as well as long lead item orders and early construction works.  The long lead item orders and early construction works will be necessary during this period in order to achieve the targeted first production in 2015.IFC received board approval on May 24, 2012 to invest an additional $150 million to contribute towards achieving the Decision to Mine milestone at the end of 2012.  In 2006 IFC obtained board approval to invest $5 million in equity to Simfer (Simandou I project) and a further $30 million in 2007 (Simandou II project), of which $32 million in total has been disbursed.
Review Scope: IFC owns a 5% equity interest in Simfer SA (Simfer), a Guinean-registered company and holder of an iron ore mining concession (the Simandou Project) in the Simandou mountains of South-East Guinea. Simfer SA is 95% owned via Simfer Jersey Limited which is jointly owned by the Rio Tinto Group (53%) and a consortium led by Aluminium Corporation of China, Chalco,(47%).  Simfer has undertaken extensive iron ore exploration work in Guinea since 1996 and IFCs long relationship with the Simandou Project has developed since 2005.  IFC has visited Guinea and the Simandou Project area numerous times with a team of environmental & social and technical staff between August 2005 and May 2012.Since exploration started in 1996, Simfer has conducted several environmental and social studies.  Since IFCs first investment in the Simandou Project (Simandou I), it has monitored the implementation of its Action Plan (AP) through the review of Annual Monitoring Reports, monthly conference calls and site visits.The current phase of the project (the Simandou III) encompasses the completion of a Preliminary Engineering Assessment (PEA), Definitive Engineering (DE), early construction works and advance ordering of long lead items with total financial commitments, including the US$700 million payment as part of the Settlement Agreement with the Government of Guinea (April 2011), estimated at approximately US$4.0 billion up until end of 2012.  IFCs most recent Environmental and Social (E&S) due diligence for the Simandou III investment took place in September 2011 when a visit to the project area was conducted with the objective of site familiarisation and gauging the level of community support for the project. The visit included a reconnaissance flyover of the Simandou ridge, the furthest east 50 km of the railway, potential biodiversity offset areas and the location of a potential hydropower dam (Lolema). There was also an inspection of the facilities at the workers camp, Canga East which serves as the hub for all exploration activities associated with the mine component of the project. Meetings were held with local authorities and representatives from the local communities of Beyla, Moribadou, Nionsomoridou Waterferedou II, Lamandou and Kerouane. The World Bank Group Board of Directors approved the Simandou III project on May 24, 2012. Since the due diligence visit, IFC personnel have visited the proposed Port area and flown the entire length of the rail corridor, and the mine site as part of the supervision of the project. Additionally, IFC have attended numerous meetings with Simfer and their consultants to provide guidance in the development of the Social and Environmental Impact Assessments (SEIAs), the resettlement and compensation approach, review the technical, environmental and social documentation and generally discuss the status of the project. The project finalized the Social and Environmental Baseline studies (SEBs) for the mine in 2009 and the railway and port in 2012.  Four early works SEIAs were approved by the Government of Guinea in the PEA phase (late 2011 and early 2012). During the Definitive Engineering (DE) Phase the project completed the SEIAs for the main components (Volume I, Mine;Volume II, Rail; and Volume III, Port), undertook an extensive consultation programme and submitted them to the Government of Guinea for approval. A separate volume (Volume V) containing  the Social and Environmental Management Plans for all of the SEIA components was also submitted to the GoG.  Several construction phase Environmental and Social Management Plans are under development.The PARC Framework agreement has been completed and agreed with the IFC and the project has been declared a Project of National Importance (PIN) by the State (4th October 2012). The Framework is currently under Government review and is pending approval. Once approved by the GoG, IFC will disclose the Framework. Detailed Resettlement and Compensation Plans (PARCs) will be required for the rail, port and mine components and the project has committed to the preparation of these prior to any resettlement activities taking place.Simfer continues to work to ensure that a successful resettlement programme will be delivered according to IFC principles, standards and PARC Framework.  Through the identification and implementation of project avoidance criteria, engineering designs are adjusted to minimise potential resettlement and socio-economic impacts.Since its appraisal of the three investments in Simandou (Simandou I, II and III), IFCs input on E&S issues has included the following: (i) review and provision of comments on the Terms of Reference (ToR) for the different components of the project SEBs and SEIA, (ii) review and provide comments on several other key documents including: Public Consultation and Disclosure Plan (PCDP), PARC Framework, local climatological studies, biodiversity critical habitat assessment, health impact baseline studies, grievance mechanisms etc.; (iii) contribute to the development of the biodiversity strategy for the Pic de Fon and Oueleba areas; (iv) assess opportunities for social and economic development (v) review and endorse four early works SEIAs (Camps, Marine Offloading Facility, Roads and Quarries),(vi) reach agreement on the early works Environmental and Social Action plan (ESAP) and (vii) review and endorse the SEIAs for the main project.

Project Description: IFC is considering a debt investment of up to US$100 million to Orascom Construction (OC or the Company), the Egypt based construction arm of Orascom Construction Industries (OCI). OCI is one of the largest construction and fertilizers groups in the Middle East and Africa region and is present in over 25 countries across the world. On December 21, 2011 OCI announced the demerger of its construction business from its fertilizer business. Once demerged, OC will form a leading engineering, procurement and construction contractor targeting large industrial, commercial and infrastructure projects for public and private clients primarily in the Middle East, North Africa, and Europe.OCIs construction activities operate under three distinct and separate brands.  Orascom Construction which includes OCI and OC targets large industrial and infrastructure projects principally in Egypt, North Africa, Saudi Arabia, UAE and Iraq. Contrack International pursues institutional projects in Afghanistan, Qatar and other markets in the Middle East and Central Asia.. OCI also owns a 50% stake in the Besix Group which specializes in large-scale commercial, industrial and infrastructure projects throughout Europe and the Middle East primarily. The construction group currently employs around 70,000 people.The proposed investment is intended to support the working capital needs of the Company.
Impact: The proposed investment is expected to have the following development impacts: i) employment preservation and creation as the Company''s construction activities increase; ii) SME support through local procurement by the Company and through channeling of funds to subcontractors; iii) revenue generation to the Egyptian economy through payment of taxes by the Company and its subcontractors; and iv) promotion of better E&S standards in Egypt''s construction sector as the Company enforces its E&S standards on local subcontractors.
Role: The proposed investment is expected to have strong additionality through: i) providing a strong vote of confidence to the Egyptian construction sector despite the recent crisis, a critical sector given its direct and indirect contribution to employment; ii) playing IFC''s traditional counter-cyclical role by extending working capital financing to the Company at a time when local, regional, and international banks are reducing financing limits to Egyptian corporates while European banks are deleveraging worldwide; and iii) building a risk and insurance management framework within the Company to help it minimize risks.
Sponsor: OCI is the largest company listed on Egypt Stock Exchange (EGX), with GDRs listed on the London Stock Exchange and ADRs listed on the Over-the-Counter (OTC) NASDAQ market in the US. OCIs current market capitalization is US$8.8 billion (based on March 19th share price). OCIs major shareholder block is the Sawiris family with a 54.3% stake in the company (the Sponsor). Other shareholders with significant stakes include Abraaj Capital (6.0%), Genesis Investment Management (5.2%) and Lazard Asset Management (4.8%). IFC currently holds close to a 0.6% stake in OCI. Once the construction business is demerged from the fertilizer business, both entities will continue to be listed on EGX. OCs main shareholder currently is OCI.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a US$100 million A loan from IFCs own account which will be directed to support the working capital needs of the Company and other Orascom Construction companies in Egypt and in other MENA countries including Saudi Arabia and Iraq.

Project Name: COMPAGNIE HOTELIERE DE LA LAGUNE S.A.
Company Name: COMPAGNIE HOTELIERE DE LA LAGUNE SA
Project Description: The proposed project consists on the construction of a 180-key 4-star hotel in Abidjan, Cote dIvoire, as part of  the expansion plan of the Groupe Azalai Hotels S.A (Azalai or the Group), a Mali-based holding company operating 7 business hotels in 4 IDA countries in West Africa.
Impact: - South-South investment;- Job creation and skills development; - Benefits to the local economy through both downstream and upstream local supply linkages; - Government revenues through tax collection; and - Environmental and Social standards improvement including life & fire safety and green building components.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B investment according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review because the potential adverse social and environmental impacts of the proposed investment are limited, site-specific and reversible and may be mitigated by adhering to the IFC Performance Standards, generally recognized guidelines or design criteria.  Key E&S issues associated with this investment are corporate environmental and social management capacity; management of environmental impacts (i.e. air emissions, spills, noise), and occupational health and safety during construction; labor and working conditions; food safety; fire and life safety, efficient use of energy and water resources; solid and liquid waste management; and permitting and licensing of new site. Please refer to the ESRS for further information on the environmental and social risk and mitigation measures.

(Azalai, the Group or the Holding).  The 40% remaining belong to SIFCOM group operating in Cote dIvoire.Azalai is headquartered in Bamako and is 70.91%-owned by Mr. Mossadeck Bally and 21.87% by his family.Mossadeck Bally has been partnering with IFC since 1994 when he entered into the tourism industry.  He is a Malian national with an MBA from San Francisco (CA).
Cost Nature: Project cost is estimated at EUR22.7 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a EUR6 million A loan for IFCs own account.
