Project Description: The Project is to finance the construction of a portion of the SWB i.e. from the junction with the road Podgorica - Cetinje to the junction with the road Podgorica - Podgorica airport (approx 3,6 km) including 160 meters long bridge over the Moraca River and 38 meters long overpass in the vicinity of aluminum smelter (KAP), and is expected to cost approximately EUR 19 million. Once the total length of 6, 6 km SWB is completed it will connect to the existing road Podgorica  border with Bosnia on the Northwest and with the Adriatic highway Podgorica - port of Bar on the Southwest.  Portion of the funds will also be used to re-finance the existing loan, which was used to construct a bridge over the River Ribnica ( i.e. Ribnica Bridge, Underpass and Approaching/Connecting Lanes) a key component of the Eastern Bypass.
Review Scope: The E&S due diligence of the Podgorica Roads project (the Project) involved appraisal site visit on 14/15th November 2011 and desk review of available project documentation. The site visit included a visit to an already constructed bridge over the river Ribnica, a key component of the Eastern Bypass already co-financed by IFC in 2010, and (ii) visit to a corridor along which the South West Bypass (SWB) will be constructed. Desk review included a review of (i) Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) for a section of the SWB that will be financed by IFC, (ii) expropriation plan and operational permit for Ribnica Bridge (i.e. Ribnica Bridge, Underpass and Approaching/Connecting Lanes).  Due diligence also included discussions/meetings with the City Management representative.In December 2010, IFC signed and fully disbursed its first infrastructure project  (#30009) in the country i.e. the completion of the Podgorica Eastern Bypass - Section I and part of Section IV. IFCs environmental and social review of the 2010 agreement can be viewed on IFCs website at the following link http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/ProjectDisplay/ESRS30009.  IFC also reviewed a number of relevant documents associated with that earlier investment, e.g. (i) the Expropriation Law (2008); (ii) the City Environmental Management Plan for 20102014, (iii) several examples of willing buyer/willing seller contracts between the City and affected land owners and expropriation plans for all sections of the Eastern Bypass.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: For the construction of a 3,6 km section of SWB only minor economic resettlement is expected: there will be no physical resettlement as the alignment of the SWB section is positioned within the existing public corridor already reserved for infrastructure development as per Podgorica Urban Plan. Other aspects of the Project related to the construction of a section SWB that can have potential adverse environmental and social impacts are few in number, site-specific, largely reversible and readily addressed through mitigation measures. This is therefore an environmental category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social.

Project Description: The proposed IFC investment would help the City of Podgorica finance the construction of the first phase of the South-Western Bypass from the junction with the Podgorica-Cetinje Highway to the junction with the Podgorica- Petrovac Highway. A portion of the IFC loan would be used to re-finance existing debt that the City contracted in the midst of the 2009 crisis for other capital expenditures.
Impact: Given the central location of Podgorica along the main road axes connecting different cities within Montenegro and providing access to neighboring countries, a targeted investment in the roads sector is expected to improve national and international connectivity, reduce travel times and vehicle operating costs and contribute significantly to local economic growth. By keeping transit traffic out of the city, the Project is also expected to help reduce air and noise pollution and road crashes along the existing network. The first tranche of IFC investment will allow the City to refinance expensive existing debt, thus reducing the cost of financing its capex and improving its debt servicing capacity.
Environmental Social Issues: For the construction of a 3,6 km section of the South West Bypass only minor economic resettlement is expected: there will be no physical resettlement as the alignment of the South West Bypass section is positioned within the existing public corridor already reserved for infrastructure development as per Podgoricas Urban Plan. Other aspects of the Project related to the construction of section 1 of the South West Bypass that can have potential adverse environmental and social impacts are few in number, site-specific, largely reversible and readily addressed through mitigation measures. This is therefore an environmental category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Performance Standards.
Sponsor: Podgorica is the capital and largest city of Montenegro with an estimated population of 187,000. It is also the administrative, financial, telecommunications and university center of the country with a strong economic base focusing on the aluminum, construction and tourism sectors. The municipal annual budget for 2011 was approximately $56 million.
Cost Nature: The total investment program of the City of Podgorica for 2012-2014 amounts to nearly $94 million, of which approximately $25 million is the estimated cost of phase-1 the South-Western Bypass. IFC is considering a senior loan to the City of Podgorica for an amount of up to EUR 25 million.

Project Description: The Vino Zupa AD project includes a corporate loan of up to EUR 12.5 million for: (i)  capital investments, including additional bottling capacity for fruit juices and investment in the energy block (EUR 3 million); (ii) E&S wastewater treatment improvements to bring the Company into compliance in accordance with  IFC Performance Standards and applicable World Bank Groups Environmental, Health and Safety Guidelines and EU standards (EUR 1.5 million); (iii)  re-financing a portion of its existing short / medium term debt facilities (with up to 2 year maturities) on a longer term basis (EUR 6 million); and (iv) provision of additional, permanent working capital (EUR 2 million) (the Project). The Project will enhance the Companys E&S standards and overall performance, reduce funding risk and strengthen the Companys liquidity position. During appraisal, IFC has also explored possible AS work with regard to supply chain linkages, inclusive business opportunities and sustainable business practices.
Review Scope: The IFCs review of this project included:Site visits to Vino Zupa fruit juice and wine production plants, Brus frozen vegetable plant located in Serbia and Povarderie wine and fruit concentrate production plants in Negotino, Macedonia;Meetings were held with General Director, Technical manager, Energy manager, Quality Insurance Manager, Laboratories manager, Environmental Consultant, HR manager and OHS Specialists;Review of available corporate environmental and social documents, including purchase  contract with farmers, Employee Training records on Occupational Safety and Health (OSH), and Life and Fire safety, including inspectors report on Companys activities on fire prevention and evacuation, manual procedures  for fire and explosives protection, Plan for fire protection and evacuation, certificate delivered from Government''s Directorate for Prevention and Evacuation onacceptance of the Company''s manual procedures  for prevention of fire and explosions, Company''s assessment of the natural disasters and other accidents, OSH manual, Collective Agreement between Povardarie and Agro Sindikat (Agro union) on the rights and obligations of the workers and the employer "Povardarie" Negotino.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Key environmental and social issues for this provisional category B project include: (i) Quality, Environmental and Safety Management systems; (ii) Supply chain E&S management; (iii) Labor conditions and working conditions; (iv) Occupational health and safety management, including during construction; (v) Food Safety programs and certification at processing and commercialization; (vi) Organic and packaging waste; (vii) Water consumption and waste water treatment; (vii) Energy/ Water Use efficiency, including cleaner production, and air emissions; (viii) Land acquisition; (ix) Life, fire and traffic safety.The entire operations of Vino Zupa will be required to meet both local and IFC environmental and social requirements. The due diligence has allowed IFC to identify compliance gaps against the Performance Standards, which are  indicated in the attached Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP)with the establishment of performance reporting requirements.The information about how these potential impacts will be addressed is summarized in the following sections of this Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) and in the attached ESAP agreed upon with the Company.The Project has limited potential adverse environmental and social impacts, and those that do exist are being site-specific and can be resolved through the effective implementation of the action items in the ESAP, which integrate the IFCs Performance Standards requirements and good international industry practices as defined in World Bank Group (WBG)s general and applicable sector-specific (Food and Beverage Processing) Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) requirements. This corporate-level investment is therefore a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Sustainability Policy.Existing and proposed measures to manage and mitigate these risks are described below.

Project Description: Zambeef Products PLC (Zambeef or the Company) is one of the largest agri-business companies in Zambia and the Southern African Development Community (SADC) region, involved in the production, processing, distribution and retailing of beef, chicken and eggs, pork, dairy products, edible oils, stock feed, flour and bread. The Company, which continues to grow through organic expansion and acquisitions, was successfully listed on the Alternative Investment Market of the London Stock Exchange in June 2011. In the same year, the Company acquired Mpongwe Farm in northwestern Zambia. Zambeef has also been listed on the Lusaka Stock Exchange since February 2003. The Company continues to roll out its West Africa expansion in Nigeria and Ghana, as well as developing its palm oil project in Mpika, Zambia.The IFC investment (the Project) is to assist Zambeef with its three year developmental capital expenditure plan, including: 1) upgrading and expanding the Zamanita edible oils plant; 2) post acquisition expansion and upgrading of Mpongwe farm, including conversion of at least 500ha of rain-fed to irrigated to increase soya & wheat production; 3) expansion of processing capacity at Masterpork, dairy plant and poultry; and, 4) a new ruminants plant at Novatek feed mill in Lusaka. Zambeefs operations include: Farming Division  Huntley, Sinazongwe, Chiawa and Mpongwe, and Palm oil plantation in Mpika; Meat and Dairy  beef feedlots and abattoirs, chicken broilers and abattoirs, chicken layers, Kalundu dairy farm, and piggery and pig abattoir; Manufacturing/Processing Division  Zamanita edible oils plant, Novatek stock-feed plant, leather and shoe plant, flour mill and bakery, and meat and dairy processing plants;Retail Division  Zambeef outlets, Shoprite butcheries, Zamchick Inns, wholesale depots, and transport and distribution. During the appraisal, the following Zambeefs Zambia operations were visited: Mpongwe Estate in Ndola; Zambeef retail outlets in Kapiri, Kabwe and Lusaka; Huntley (Chisamba) Farm  the Companys largest agro-processing complex - and Kalundu dairy farm; Zamanita  edible oils processing plant and Novatek stock feed plant in Lusaka; and Masterpork slaughter and processing facility on the outskirts of Lusaka.
Review Scope: The first appraisal of Zambeef operations took place in 2009 in support of the initial investment (#29013). The main environmental, occupational health and safety, and social (EHSS) issues identified during that initial appraisal included: (i) weak internal controls to assess and manage environmental impacts and comply with national environmental, occupational health and safety (OHS) and food safety standards; (ii) food safety issues from weak implementation of Good Manufacturing Processes and microbiological contamination; (iii) hazardous materials transportation, storage, and use; and, (iv)  resettlement and relocation issues. To mitigate these issues, Zambeef, with technical and financial assistance from Deutsche Investitions- und Entwicklungsgesellschaft mbH, Cologne, Germany (DEG), embarked on the development and implementation of a comprehensive Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) based on IFCs Performance Standards requirement and World Bank Group (WBG) Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines. In addition to this ESAP, a supplemental ESAP was produced after IFCs due diligence process and agreed upon with the Company.The environmental and social due diligence of this follow-on investment project focused mainly on evaluating progress made by Zambeef in implementing its ESAPs under DEG and IFCs loan agreements. The scope of the due diligence for this repeat investment also comprised review of available corporate and project-level environmental and social documents, including ESAP implementation progress reports produced by independent consultants.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The project has been categorized as a Category B according to IFCs Environmental and Social Sustainability Policy because the Project is a follow-on investment for an existing IFC client who is fully committed to successfully complete the implementation of its ESAP requirements for the initial investment, thereby achieving compliance with national legal and regulatory requirements as well as with the IFCs Performance Standards. IFC is satisfied that Zambeef continues to make good progress in implementing the agreed upon ESAP. Specifically, since the first investment, Zambeef has established a fully functional Environmental, Food Safety and Technical Services department. This department is responsible for the implementation of the ESAP. There is a high level corporate commitment and resourcing which is clearly demonstrated by the fact that more than 75% of the ESAPs Action Items from the combined DEG and IFC ESAP items have been successfully completed. The next phase of Zambeefs full compliance with international and national requirements is the actual implementation of international standards as regards to Food Safety, especially ISO 22000 Food Safety Management System (FSMS). The Company is currently concluding discussion with an identified Development Finance Institution (DFI) for Technical Assistance to part fund this phase which is expected to be completed by December 2014.

Project Description: The Project is an expansion (Azito Phase III) of the Azito Power Plant by converting the plant to combined cycle operation. This conversion essentially involves addition of two heat recovery steam generators (HRSG) and a 139 MW steam turbine, to the existing 2 x 144 MW simple cycle natural gas-fired turbines. The Project is expected to generate about 50 percent more power without using additional gas (gas turbines exhaust heat generates steam in a boiler to power a steam turbine) and with zero incremental emissions. This switch from simple-cycle power generation to combined cycle will increase energy efficiency of the Azito Power Plant from approximately 29.5 percent to approximately 44 percent (Gross HHV).Azito Power Plant, as planned in the initial project design in 1998, consists of building, owning, operating and eventually transferring to the State, a gas-fired power station with a total capacity of approximately 420 MW, to be implemented in three phases. In the first phase 144 MW simple cycle gas turbine operation was commissioned in January 1999 and in the second phase the second 144 MW simple cycle gas turbine  was commissioned in February 2000. Expansion of capacity through conversion to combined cycle, which was originally planned in the third phase (in 2002) has been delayed but is being undertaken now. The existing gas turbines are designed to operate with natural gas (mainly) and distillate oil (back-up only). However, since initial commissioning of the Plant in 1999, the turbines have  exclusively operated on gas. The distillate oil storage tanks (2 x 6000 m3) and related facilities will continue to be maintained for back up operation. Gas for the Plant comes from three sources in CÔte d Ivoire: the Devon fields (Lion/Panthèere), the Foxtrot field; and the CNR fields (Espoir/Baobab), with Foxtrot field as the primary gas supplier.Azito Power Plant is located on a 5 ha plot of land near the Azito village in Yopougon District, approximately six  kilometers West of the port of Abidjan in CÔte d Ivoire . The Plant premises are located alongside the Western arm of the Ebrié lagoon and the finished ground level (±0.00 level) in the Plant is +4.5 m above mean sea level. Béago, a second village is located about 300 m North East from the Plant boundary. The Plant premises are bordered (along the Northern fence) by a gas treatment unit, independently operated by Foxtrot, which provides condensate-free feed gas to Azito Power Plant, and by an electrical switchyard operated by the Compagnie Ivoirienne dElecticité (CIE  national electricity distribution company) on its Western fence. The existing transmission line (T-Line) is adequate to evacuate power from the expanded capacity.The Project involves construction of: steam turbine installation and building; HRSG installation; air-cooled condenser installation; control and electrical building; water treatment building/de-mineralization plant; administrative building; and warehouse. The duration of the construction works will be approximately 27 months. The Project does not require any land acquisition, since the facilities will be built over land which is already part of the Azito Power Plant concession. The temporary lay down areas and workers accommodation camps during the construction phase may occupy land outside of the site limit but these will also be within the existing 300 m exclusion zone around the existing power plant. The Project site can be accessed by an existing road. Much of the construction material, and construction and project equipment will be transported on this access route but there is a possibility that construction and project equipment may be transported by barges from Abidjan port.
Review Scope: The review of this Project builds upon the supervision, undertaken since the year 2000, of IFCs previous investment (IFC project # 8503) in Azito Power Plant (the Plant). Azito Energie S.A, (Azito or the Company) is owner of the Plant and also the Project proponent. Up until early 2011 Azito reported to IFC regarding the ongoing management of environmental and social performance at the Plant, which had been satisfactory. IFCs recent review in February 2012 consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information submitted by the Company including: Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) for the Phase III expansion Project of the existing Azito Power Station in Abidjan, CÔte dIvoire dated March 5th, 2012 prepared by Environment Resources Management, including the Environmental and Social Management Plan (ESMP);Azito Phase 3 Expansion Project Environment and Social Impact Assessment: Scoping Study dated November 2010 prepared by Environment Resources Management;Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) of Combined Cycle Gas Turbine (CCGT) Power Plant Project in Abidjan, CÔte dIvoire dated April 1998 prepared by Environment Resources Management;Noise Abatement Plan for the Azito Power Plant Project in Abidjan, CÔte dIvoire dated December 1998 prepared by Environment Resources Management; andEnvironmental Impact Assessment (EIA) of Azito - Abobo Transmission Line and Substation (Addendum to the EIA of CCGT Power Plant Project) dated April 1998 prepared by Environment Resources Management;The review also included a discussion with: the technical and management professionals from Azito Energie and Azito Operation and Maintenance S.A. (Azito O&M, the power plant operator); Agence Nationale de lEnvironnement (National Environmental Agency or ANDE); Cabinet dEtudes, Conseils dAssistance et de Formation (CECAF - the in country consulting firm involved in the ESIA process); and Environment Resource Management (ERM) team involved in the ESIA process. Further, the review included a visit to the Project site and the Attiéké factory at Azito village, all in Yopougon District of Abidjan city in the Republic of CÔte dIvoire.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The Project involves capacity expansion through conversion of an existing simple cycle power plant to combined cycle through installation of above mentioned facilities within the existing power plant premises. The Project impacts will be time limited (short term during construction) and site limited (within immediate plant area) and it is not expected to result in any new significant long term impacts.  Accordingly, this is a Category B project because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Further, it is possible to readily design and implement engineering and management measures to mitigate the limited adverse impact.

Project Description: The Vino Zupa AD project includes a corporate loan of up to EUR 12.5 million for capital investments, including additional bottling and fruit concentrate capacity and investment in the energy block (EUR 3 million); (ii) E&S wastewater treatment improvements to bring the Company into compliance in accordance with IFC Performance Standards and applicable World Bank Groups Environmental, Health and Safety Guidelines and EU standards (EUR 1.5 million); (iii) re-financing a portion of its existing short / medium term debt facilities (with up to 2 year maturities) on a longer term basis (EUR 6 million); and (iv) provision of additional, permanent working capital (EUR 2 million) (the Project). The Project will enhance the Companys E&S standards and overall performance, reduce funding risk and strengthen the Companys liquidity position. During appraisal, IFC has also explored possible AS work with regard to supply chain linkages, inclusive business opportunities and sustainable business practices.

Project Description: The Project consists of the expansion of the existing 2x 144MW natural gas-fired open cycle Azito power plant in Côte dIvoire by adding 139MW steam cycle capacity, converting it into a combined cycle operation (the Project).  The Project, expected to enhance the efficiency of the existing plant by generating 50 percent more power without the use of any additional gas, will be developed, designed, constructed and operated under a 20-year Build-Own-Operate-Transfer (BOOT) arrangement.  The Project will sell its power to Government of Côte dIvoire (GOCI) through Compagnie Ivoirienne dElectricité (CIE), the private transmission and distribution company.
Impact: IFC''s involvement in this Project is expected to: * Support the provision of least cost, reliable and clean base load power to help reduce the country''s power shortage, and support its economic recovery; * Displace expensive emergency thermal power being rented today, thus reducing costs to Ivoirian consumers;* Stimulate the entrance of new IPPs and the use of combined cycle technology, making efficient use of the country''s natural gas resources (as the Project does not use additional gas); * Provide a strong signalling effect to the broader investment community to support CÃ´te d''Ivoire''s economic growth.

Globeleq is owned by Actis Infrastructure 2 LP (AI2), a fund managed by Actis LLP, a leading equity investor in emerging markets which is majority owned by the UKs CDC Group. Today, Globeleq owns five operating power projects globally, three of which are in Africa and has an extensive development pipeline of projects.Industrial Promotion Services (West Africa) (IPS (WA)) is the industrial development arm of the Aga Khan Fund for Economic Development (AKFED) with operations in Côte dIvoire since the mid-1960s.  IPS, 15percent owned by IFC, has a longstanding experience in the power sector with projects in Kenya, Uganda and Mali. Project Description: IFC is considering supporting the portfolio growth of BBVA Banco Continental (the Bank or Continental)  through (i) a US$75 million non-revolving credit line, and (ii) up to US$100 million non-revolving syndicated credit line subject to market conditionsThe proceeds from this facility will be used mainly to support the Banks growth in renewable energy projects, mortgages, and other medium-term needs.
Impact: (i) Expand access to housing finance, while stimulating demand for labor, materials and other supplies for the housing industry; and (ii) indirectly support the construction and development of small hydropower plants, which will increase the availability of clean energy in the country;
Environmental Social Issues: This project is considered to be a Category FI according to the IFC''s E&S review procedure. Under two previous investments (25360 and 26661) BBVA Continental has implemented E&S review procedures to manage E&S impacts of SME and sub-national infrastructure finance. This project will support renewable energy sub-projects, primarily small hydropower plants, which can have potentially high E&S impacts and risks. During appraisal IFC assessed in detail the Bank''s existing capacity to review, identify and manage the E&S risk of such sub-projects, including examples of E&S due diligence. As a subscriber to the Equator Principles, BBVA Continental has procedures in place to review its project finance activities against the IFCs Performance Standards and the Peruvian national laws. For each sub-project financed as part of the IFC loan, the Bank will conduct an E&S due diligence to identify the applicable E&S risks and require corrective actions as needed to ensure that these risks are managed according to the Performance Standards and applicable laws. As part of supervision of this project, IFC will review the implementation and performance of this procedure for the first few projects and all Category A projects, if any, prior to investment. IFC also reviewed BBVA Continental''s labor practices and concluded that the Banks labor policies are aligned with Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions. The client will be required to: maintain its Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) and conduct E&S due diligences of all renewable energy sub-projects, to the satisfaction of IFC, to ensure that activities associated with the project are in compliance with the E&S requirements; Identify responsible, qualified staff  to manage and implement the ESMS; maintain its commitment to applying the labor standards established by PS2; and submit a periodic report to IFC in a format to be provided by IFC.

Project Description: The Project consists of providing a 1 year Short-Term Loan in the amount of upto US$8 million (up to 12 months, renewable up to two times at IFCs option for an additional 12 months, for a maximum aggregate period of up to 3 years) to Bank of Kathmandu (Bank or BoK) to support the foreign currency needs of SMEs in Nepal. Impact: Financial Sector Deepening: The Project will enable BoK to access foreign currency funding and compete on a level-playing field with foreign banks that have the benefit of parent funding. The IFC funding will also encourage other international banks / FIs to lend to local banks in Nepal eventually increasing the access to market funding.Supporting Trade: Support to SMEs (via trade financing) is critical as trade in Nepal contributes 41% to the GDP. The project will have a positive impact on economic activity in Nepal

Project Description: The proposed project is an investment in BanyanTree Growth Capital II (BanyanTree II or the Fund), focused on financing fast growing small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in relatively neglected sectors of the Indian economy.  These include areas such as manufacturing and niche industrial segments, which have traditionally received a very small portion of private equity capital in comparison to their total contribution to the Indian economy.  BanyanTrees core proposition centers around its ability to find companies that are growing and capital constrained but reluctant to dilute to the extent a traditional private equity financing would require. BanyanTree has positioned itself as a provider/arranger of hybrid capital based on the teams long experience of structured finance. The proposed project is a successor fund to BanyanTree Growth Capital I (BanyanTree I) which raised about US$100 million in 2008-2009. BanyanTree I has invested in eight companies with one partial exit.
Impact: 1)	Jobs: Like with all the SME growth fund investments, the provision of expansion capital to companies at a crucial inflexion point in their development is the most effective way to impact job creation. This funds ability to reach companies that would not ordinarily access PE capital on account of dilution fears makes their capital even more impactful   2)	Private sector development: An investment in this fund will serve to enhance IFC''s mandate of developing the ecosystem for private enterprise to thrive by promoting SMEs, their suppliers, customers, providers of capital and potential acquirers. This is particularly relevant given the fund''s focus on the manufacturing and industrial segments of the Indian economy
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves IFC investment in a sector agnostic private equity fund and has been classified as Category FI. The fund''s will primarily make equity investment in fast growing SMEs which could include IT, manufacturing and engineering sectors among others. These sectors are likely to have Environmental and Social concerns mainly around Occupational Health & Safety (OHS), Labor, air & water pollution and waste management.The Applicable Performance Requirements for the sub-projects financed by the fund will include: IFC FI Exclusion List, the applicable Indian E&S laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards.  The fund manager has been backed by FMO and DEG and hence has an operational SEMS in place. The fund manager is aware of IFC E&S requirements and has agreed to upgrade the SEMS to IFC''s satisfaction. The fund manager will be required to: 1) upgrade the existing Social and Environmental Management System (SEMS) satisfactory to IFC prior to subscription and commit to implement the SEMS to ensure that its investments/activities are in compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements; 2) identify responsible, qualified person(s) to manage and implement the SEMS; and 3) submit a periodic report to IFC in the format to be provided by IFC.  IFC will also review the implementation and performance of the fund''s SEMS for the first few projects, and all Category A projects if any, prior to the fund''s investment, to ensure the fund''s SEMS is adequate to assess and manage E&S risks.

The Fund Manager will enter into an investment advisory agreement with BanyanTree Finance Private Limited (Fund Advisor), a company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, 1956.
Cost Nature: BanyanTree Growth Capital II has a target fund size of US$150-175 million. IFC is proposing an equity investment of US$25 million or 20% of the Funds total committed capital.

Project Description: UAP Properties Limited (the Company) is seeking financing to support the construction of a green field mixed-use property to be known as Equatoria Tower (the Project) in Juba, the national capital and commercial center of South Sudan, and the capital of the countrys Central Equatoria State.  The Project is a joint venture initiative between UAP Insurance South Sudan Ltd., a subsidiary of UAP Holdings, one of the leading insurance and financial services companies in East Africa, and the state governments Central Equatoria Investment Corporation (CEIC).  The Equatoria Tower will be a 12 storey complex comprising 7,700 m2 of total built up space providing approximately 6,500 m2 in retail space (ground floor), conference facilities and office space.
Review Scope: IFCs assessment of the Project consisted of a review of project documentation and meetings with key members of the Project team including: the Managing Director and Finance Manager of UAP Insurance South Sudan Ltd., the developers Project Manager and Architects, the Projects builder, China National Aero-Technology International Engineering Corporation (CATIC), and representatives of the governments Ministry of Environment.  The review also included site visits to the Equatoria Tower building site in Juba and another UAP development  UAP Plaza Apartments, a five storey 3,000 m2 residential development  also in Juba.  In addition, IFC visited the site of CATICs construction of the new international terminal at Nairobis Jomo Kenyatta International Airport, a World Bank supported project.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Equatoria Tower is a category B project according to IFCs Policy and Performance Standards on Environmental and Social Sustainability because a limited number of specific environmental and social risks and possible impacts that may result from its construction and operation can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.

Project Description: MK Group d.o.o. (the MK Group, or the Group), a leading vertically-integrated agro-industrial conglomerate with vast the majority of its operations in Serbia, has embarked on a 87 million investment plan which comprises: (i) the acquisition of Carnex AD Meat Industry (Carnex), the Serbian brand leader in processed meat products; (ii) the upgrade and expansion of Carnexs vertically-integrated operations; (iii) the expansion and modernization of the Groups primary agriculture operations; and, (iv) permanent working capital to support the growth of the Group''s operations (the Project).  The Project will enable the Group to further diversify and expand its operations vertically and horizontally in sectors where it already operates as well as adjacent industries, namely livestock and meat production. Thereby, the Project is expected to increase the size, strength and sustainability of MK Groups operations. With offices in Belgrade and Novi Sad, the Project funds will support MK Groups agriculture-related operations which are concentrated in the northern Serbian province of Vojvodina. Carnexs operations are located in the municipality of Vrbas, also in the Vojvodina province. The Vojvodina region is home to Serbias most fertile land and most of its economy revolves around agribusiness activities.
Review Scope: IFCs appraisal of this project included the following:Site visits to MK headquarters in Belgrade as well as the Carnex meat processing facilities, Vitamix feed mill, crop fields and pig farms in Vrbas, Sunoko sugar plants in Vrbas and Kovacica, and grain export loading/unloading terminal in Pancevo, all of which are in Serbia. Site visits to Agroinvest headquarters and slo complex, cattle farms, and warehouses in Ukraine. Meetings with the MK Chief financial Officer (CFO), Plant Production Managers, Operation Managers, Quality Managers, Technical Managers, Human Resources (HR) Director, Occupational Health and Safety (OHS) Specialists, Environmental Coordinators, Agriculture Managers, and Plant Engineers. In addition IFC reviewed available corporate environmental and social documents, including Environmental & Social (E&S) questionnaires; internal Human Resources (HR), quality, environment and safety procedures and reports; emission and discharge permits; drinking and waste water analyses; emission measurements; plant maintenance programs; groundwater usage permissions; ISO 9001 and HACCP   management system certificates; and  seasonal employees contracts and collective bargaining agreements.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Key environmental and social risks for this project include:Quality, Environmental and Safety Management systems including supply chain, Food Safety programsLabor and Working conditionsOccupational Health and Safety risks for direct employees, seasonal employees and contractors/third partiesManagement of Dust Explosion risks in silosConstruction SafetyEnergy and Water Use EfficiencySolid waste and by-products disposal and re-use, and air emissionsManagement of refrigeration agents and other hazardous materialsTreatment of High BOD (organic pollution load)  content process waste waterLand acquisitionLife, fire and traffic safety interaction with the surrounding communities relating to traffic and emergency preparedness and response.The Project has limited potential adverse environmental and social impacts, and those that do exist are site-specific and can be resolved through the application of good international industry practices. This corporate-level investment is therefore a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.
Sector: AG - Diversified Edible Agricultural Crops Production

Project Description: The Project is a corporate loan to AEGEA Saneamento S.A. (AEGEA or the Company), a leading private provider of water and sanitation services in Brazil that is looking to expand its operations, including into frontier regions in the North and Northeast of Brazil.
Review Scope: IFCs review included visits to AEGEA (AEGEA, or the Company) offices in the Brazilian States of Sao Paulo, Mato Grosso do Sul, and Rio de Janeiro where IFC held meetings and interviews with key staff  (management, technical, human resources) and where IFC reviewed numerous, relevant internal documents and records surrounding the Companys environmental and social (E&S) performance.  Among others, these included environmental licensing processes; human resources management documentation; water and wastewater management and monitoring information; and presentation materials about the Company business activities.  IFC staff conducted inspections of representative operating facilities  water treatment and wastewater treatment plants serving the City of Campo Grande (known as Aguas Guariroba) in the State of Mato Grosso do Sul and the regional water and wastewater company (known as Prolagos) of the Cabo Frio / Buzios / Sao Pedro da Aldeia region in the State of Rio de Janeiro.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  AEGEAs core business activities in water and wastewater treatment provide essential environmental services with proven public health benefits.  AEGEA is presently demonstrating the ability to effectively manage potential environmental and social risks from its business activities through the application of international accepted practices to protect soil, water and air resources.

Project Description: The Project is a corporate loan to AEGEA Saneamento S.A. (AEGEA or the Company), a leading private provider of water and sanitation services in Brazil that is looking to expand its operations, including into frontier regions in the North and Northeast of Brazil.
Impact: The Project is expected to increase water and sewerage service coverage in AEGEA''s service area, which is expected to expand throughout Brazil, including frontier regions. This increased coverage leads to positive health impact for the population, especially the poor. Diseases associated with poor sanitation decreased by 34% between 2005 and 2009 in Campo Grande, after AEGEA increased sewage collection and treatment there. This reduction of diseases results in lower absenteeism of students and workers, as well as reduced health expenditures, with substantial positive impact in the economy.The Project will also lead to increase in population that receive water and sanitation services from a private operator and to reduced water losses and energy consumption. Indicators to be tracked will include: (i) total number of individual residential customers receiving new or improved water services; (ii) volume of sewage treated; (iii) volume of freshwater saved (reduced physical water losses); (iv) reduction in water losses (NRW - including commercial losses); and (v) reliability of water services (average hours of service per 24 hour period).
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  AEGEAs core business activities in water and wastewater treatment provide essential environmental services with proven public health benefits.  AEGEA is presently demonstrating the ability to effectively manage potential environmental and social risks from its business activities through the application of international accepted practices to protect soil, water and air resources.
Sponsor: AEGEA Saneamento is part of Grupo Equipav, a family owned group that has more than 50 years of history operating in various sectors in Brazil.  Currently, its main business lines are: (i) water and sanitation, through two fully owned subsidiaries, Aguas Guariroba and Prolagos; (ii) transportation, with a 75% stake in the Univias road consortium, which operates three road concessions (Convias, Sulvias and Metrovias) in the State of Rio Grande de Sul and two bus terminals (Terminal Rodoviário Ramos de Azevedo in Campinas and Terminal Rodoviário Antonio Mendes Canale in Campo Grande); (iii) agribusiness, holding a 41% stake in Renuka do Brasil, a sugar/ ethanol mill; and (iv) engineering and construction, through Equipav Engenharia, Minerpav and Sarpav.
Cost Nature: The project is expected to cost BRL270 million, and consists of investing mainly in brownfield municipal water concessions, but also in acquisition of existing private concessions and sub- concessions. The proposed IFC Loan amount is BRL100 million. A parallel loan of an additional BRL 100 million is expected to be provided by other source of funding, while the remainder will be sourced from own resources of the Company.

Project Description: JISL is Indias one of the largest integrated agribusiness players with operations spanning the agricultural value chain including: provider of micro-irrigation systems; production of plastic sheets, pipes and fittings; and processed fruits and vegetables (JISL is the largest mango puree producer in the world and the 2nd largest dehydrated onion producer). While the Companys headquarters are located in Jalgaon in the western Indian state of Maharashtra, JISL and its subsidiaries operate 25 production facilities for MIS, plastic pipes, plastic sheets, dehydrated vegetables and processed fruits in India, USA, UK, Spain, Turkey, Chile, Brazil and Israel.To meet the demands of its growing business, JISL is implementing an investment program during 2012-2014, which includes: expansion of the Companys Indian production of MIS, food processing, and plastic pipes; and expansion of its MIS plant in Turkey (the Project). IFC is considering investment in JISL to finance this Project.
Review Scope: IFCs review of this investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information submitted by Jain Irrigation Systems Limited (JISL or the Group) and Jain Sulama Sistemleri San. ve Tic. A.S. (Jain Turkey or Company) including: regulatory permits; management system documentation, such as quality, environmental, health and safety policies, and operational procedures; recent emission and discharge monitoring records; accidents and incidents register; training records and various documents related to the compliance against existing Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) agreed by JISL as a condition of the prior IFC investments; JISLs corporate sustainability report, etc.The appraisal also included site visits to JISLs Plastic Park which houses manufacturing of micro irrigation, systems (MIS), plastic sheets, pipes, fittings) and Jain Valley Food Park (processed fruit & vegetable product manufacturing facilities) at Jalgaon, in Maharashtra, India; Jain Turkeys MIS manufacturing facility in Adana, Turkey and discussions with JISLs senior management as well as operational staff in-charge of quality, environment, and occupational health and safety at respective facilities.This is IFCs fourth investment in JISL. The disclosure documents for the previous IFC investments are available at:Jain Irrigation, Project # 24485 disclosed in August, 2007http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/ProjectDisplay/ESRS24485 Jain II, Project # 27624 disclosed in December, 2008http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/ProjectDisplay/ESRS24485 Jain NBFC, Project # 30598 disclosed in April 2011http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/1ca07340e47a35cd85256efb00700cee/C2C1AC97CE1B4D4385257892004EF74B JISL has satisfactorily complied with all the E&S requirements for the previous IFC investments (as above). A status summary of the implementation of ESAPs for past investments is attached herewith. The Company has been submitting regular updates on its environmental and social (E&S) performance, as well as status of implementation of the action plans. This review thus also builds upon the information collected during IFCs engagement with JSIL over the past years.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Sustainability Policy because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards and guidelines. Key E&S issues related to this project include: adequate social and environmental assessment of the impacts of the Project during both construction and operations; implementation of social, environmental, health and safety management systems; assurance of fair, safe and healthy working conditions during construction and operations; utilization of equipment and operational practices that maximize conservation of energy, water and process materials including recycling and reuse initiatives; management of air emissions, wastewater treatment and discharge, and solid and other waste disposal; the impacts of operations on local ambient environment; and impacts on transport infrastructure during construction and operations.

Project Description: Jain Irrigation Systems Ltd. (JISL or the Company) is Indias largest provider of micro-irrigation systems (MIS). In addition to MIS, the Company is also a leading producer of plastic sheets and pipes, agro processed products, tissue culture and green energy. Its headquarters are located in Jalgaon in the western Indian state of Maharashtra. IFC is considering financing part of its capital expenditure project with the total cost of about US$257 million.
Impact: Raising farmer incomes:  The adoption of MIS is expected to result in reduced risk from weather, lower cost of farm inputs and an increase in farm yields due to better utilization of inputs.  This is expected to improve farmer income and have a direct impact on poverty reduction.Improved water management: India has 16% of the world''s population and only 4% of the water resources.  MIS improves water use efficiency from the average 30-40% in India to 80-85%, leading to improved water management resulting in more sustainable growth for the country.   Supporting the development of a modern food processing industry:  A very low proportion of fruit and vegetable produce is currently processed in India and growth in processed foods is likely to be constrained by lack of a reliable supply chain.  JISL is expected to play a key role in not only supplying some of the inputs but in setting the benchmark for other players that enter the market.Employment: Additional employment is expected in India.
Role:
IFC''s role and additionality include:

- Continuing financing the growth of a leading local MIS company which promotes the use of more efficient and water-saving agricultural practices in India;
- Providing a financing package as JISL''s long term partner with a range of different products (loan, equity/quasi-equity, mobilization) that are not easily available locally;
- Supporting the Company''s expansion in overseas market such as Turkey; and
- Mobilizing funds from other international financial institutions for the Project.
Sponsor: JISL is listed on the National Stock Exchange of India and the Bombay Stock Exchange. The sponsor, the Jain family from Jalgaon, currently owns about 31% of the Companys shares as of June 30, 2012. The Jain family has been involved in agriculture and plastics businesses since 1960s.
Cost Nature: Total project cost over the next two years is estimated to be around US$ 257 million including: capital expenditure for expansion of the Companys production of MIS, food processing, plastic pipes, tissue culture, and solar products in India; capital expenditure for expansion of a MIS plant and working capital requirement for the Companys operation in Turkey and other region; reduction of short term loans and refinancing of an existing loan.  IFC proposes an investment of up to US$ 60 million and mobilization of up to US$ 65 million to part finance this capital expenditure plan.

Company Name: MNT SAGLIK HIZMETLERI VE TICARET ANONIM SIRKETI
Project Description: IFC plans to provide up to US$30 million financing package, including an equity investment of up to US$15 million, to MNT Salk Hizmetleri ve Ticaret A.S. (MNT). MNT is a leading molecular imaging and oncology services provider in Turkey, specialized in diagnosis and oncology treatment services within public and private hospitals. MNT also owns a proprietary oncology clinic in Istanbul, Neolife, which provides outpatient diagnosis and treatment services both to private patients and those covered under the countrys Social Security Institution insurance. The proposed financing will support MNT in the continued expansion of its services in Turkey, and in the region, mainly in Eastern Europe and the Middle East.
Review Scope: IFCs review of this project consisted of following site visits:the nuclear medicine and radiotherapy departments operated by MNT at six selected public and private hospitals located in Istanbul, Kahramanmaras and Sanliurfa cities in Turkey; the nuclear medicine and radiotherapy clinic Neolife which is owned and operated by MNT in Istanbul;the manufacturing facility of Eczacibasi-Monrol which is the sister company under Bozlu Group and supplier of radiopharmaceutical products for nuclear medicine to MNT, located in Kocaeli, Turkey.Documentation provided by MNT about regulatory permits and licenses, inspections by the authorities; quality management documentation and certifications; building design and construction; contractor and supplier control programs; equipment and area verification and maintenance programs; transportation and handling of hazardous chemicals and wastes; emergency management schemes, occupational health and safety risk assessments; radiation safety; exposure monitoring records for the employees; training materials and records, as well as other information on human resources policy and practices; community engagement activities. Interviews were held with the corporate management team including Vice President, General Manager, Business Development Manager, Nuclear Therapy Group Medical Manager, Radiotherapy Group Medical Physics Manager, Corporate Quality Coordinator, Corporate Supply Chain Manager, Corporate Human Resources Manager, team members from Engineering and Information Technologies departments,  medical staff and technicians in the operational centers, officials from Eczacibasi-Monrol and GLOBUS, the sister company under Bozlu Group undertaking construction of MNT services.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: While all Performance Standards are applicable to this investment, IFCs environmental and social due diligence indicates that the investment may have impacts which must be managed in a manner consistent with the following Performance Standards:PS1: Social and Environmental Assessment and Management Systems;PS2: Labor and Working Conditions;PS3: Pollution Prevention and Abatement;PS4: Community Health, Safety and Security;No issue related to PS5 Land Acquisition and Involuntary Resettlement has been identified in relation with current expansion projects as MNT provides services at existing buildings/areas provided by the hospitals. Clinics owned by MNT are developed either as greenfield projects or at existing buildings rented or purchased based on willing buyer/willing seller basis.  MNT facilities are located within urban areas, therefore, there is no issue in relation to PS6 and PS7 namely biodiversity conservation, sustainable natural resource management and indigenous people. No adverse impact has been identified on cultural heritage with regard to PS8. MNT will incorporate all IFC Performance Standards on Social and Environmental Sustainability into its management system and will accordingly evaluate future expansion projects to ensure operation in full compliance with IFC requirements. The key environmental and social issues related to this project include regulatory compliance; structural design and safety; radiation safety; life and fire safety; hazardous materials and waste management; human resources policy and practices; engagement with communities. The appraisal concluded that any impacts will be limited, site-specific and can be addressed by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Therefore, this is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.

MNT also owns a proprietary oncology clinic in Istanbul, Neolife, which provides outpatient diagnosis and treatment services both to private patients and those covered under the countrys Social Security Institution insurance. The proposed financing will support MNT in the continued expansion of its services in Turkey, and in the region, mainly in Eastern Europe and the Middle East.
Impact: MNT''s expansion in Turkey and in the region will increase availability and quality of molecular imaging and oncology treatment services in Turkey and in the target countries; where oncology is an area still hugely underserved and facing a strong increase in patient demand. MNT''s unique model of providing outsourced services within public and private hospitals enables the company to reach to a wide spectrum of patient base including the lower income segments. The project will enable creation of a regional healthcare player with high quality, ethical and corporate governance standards, attracting further foreign investor interest to the region''s healthcare sector.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.The key environmental and social issues related to this project include permits, regulatory compliance; environment, health and safety during construction and restructuring; structural design and safety;  radiation safety; life and fire safety; hazardous materials and waste management; employee health and safety monitoring and management; emergency preparedness and response; control of air emissions from combustion and other operations; energy and water conservation;  treatment and disposal of liquid effluents; hazardous materials management; occupational health and safety including employee training and monitoring programs; human resources policy and practices; community health, safety and security; engagement with communities. The appraisal concluded that any impacts will be limited, site-specific and can be addressed by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Further details on the potential environmental and social impacts of the project, corresponding mitigation measures and guidance on how and where information about the project are provided in the Environmental & Social Review Summary.
Sponsor: MNT was established in 1990 by a renowed nuclear medicine specialist, Dr. Sukru Bozluolcay, and is the first and the flagship company of Bozlu Group, which encompasses 13 companies mainly operating in healthcare services and technologies.  Dr. Sukru Bozluolcay is the majority owner of MNT with 96 percent share.
Cost Nature: MNT has an expansion plan spread in the next four years and expected to cost around US$70 million, depending on the opportunities in the target markets.  MNT has invited IFC to consider a financing package of up to US$30 million to support its expansion in Turkey and in the regional markets. The proposed IFC financing package is expected to include equity and quasi-equity products to strengthen MNTs capital structure during this expansion.

Project Description: The Project consists of the construction and operation of two greenfield concentrating solar power (CSP) projects near the towns of Upington and Pofadder, in South Africas Northern Cape Province, by Abengoa Solar, through its affiliates Abengoa Solar South Africa (Pty) Ltd (ASSA) and Son Revieren (Pty) Ltd, in partnership with the Industrial Development Corporation (IDC). Abengoa Solars parent company, Abengoa S.A. (Abengoa) is a leading developer of renewable energy projects. CSP is a general term used to describe a variety of technologies by which solar energy is concentrated onto a receiver with the subsequent concentration of heat used to power applications such as the generation of electricity by a steam-driven turbine.  The 100 MW plant (!KaXu Solar One, or Pofadder Solar Thermal Plant) will utilize parabolic trough (PT) CSP technology. PT technology involves a field of pivoting concave mirrors tracking the sun, and concentrating the reflected sunlight onto a closed circuit network of piping that contains synthetic oil. The heated oil cycles through a generator creating steam to drive a 100 MW net capacity turbine. The electricity generated is transmitted through a high voltage substation for dispatch to the grid. The plant design includes a molten salt thermal energy storage (TES) system that allows for extended electricity generation of up to 2.5 hours for controlled dispatch during cloud cover or to meet evening electricity demand. The 50 MW plant (!Khi Solar One, or Upington Solar Thermal Plant) will utilize a central receiver, also known as solar power tower technology. The tower technology captures solar radiation in a field of dual axis mirrors that track the sun, and concentrate the reflected sunlight onto receivers (steam generators) located on top of a single 200m tower. Superheated steam is piped to a 50 MW net capacity turbine that generates electricity, which is transmitted through a high voltage substation and dispatched to the grid. The plant design includes a high pressure steam storage system, which like the molten salt TES of the !KaXu plant, allows for controlled dispatch during cloud cover or to meet evening electricity demand.Each of the CSP power plants will be owned by a special purpose project company (the Company and together the Companies).The actual footprint of the !KaXu and !Khi power plants are 300 ha each.  Infrastructure components for both plants are similar and include: a solar field equipped with mirrors; a power island/tower housing a steam generator, steam turbine, power generator, transformer, auxiliary boilers and associated equipment (including thermal storage); an overhead power line feeding to an on-grid substation; a water abstraction point, supply pipeline and reservoirs to provide water for steam generation and mirror cleaning and storage of blow down water; and access roads and service buildings.
Review Scope: IFCs environmental and social review of the Project included a review of the complete environmental impact assessment (EIA) documentation for each power plant; a review of the licenses issued by the environmental authorities for each power plant; visits to each of the power plant sites and discussions with representatives of the Sponsors regarding the management of potential environmental and social impacts of the two CSP plants.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Each of the proposed CSP plants are category B according to IFCs Policy and Performance Standards on Environmental and Social Sustainability because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that may result from their construction and operation can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.

Project Description: The Project consists of the construction and operation of two greenfield concentrating solar power (CSP) projects near the towns of Upington and Pofadder, in South Africas Northern Cape Province, by Abengoa Solar, through its affiliates Abengoa Solar South Africa (Pty) Ltd (ASSA) and Son Revieren (Pty) Ltd, in partnership with the Industrial Development Corporation (IDC). Abengoa Solars parent company, Abengoa S.A. (Abengoa) is a leading developer of renewable energy projects. CSP is a term used to describe a variety of technologies by which solar energy is concentrated onto a receiver to heat steam for use in industrial or electricity generation applications.  !Ka Xu will use a parabolic trough CSP design and !Khi will use a power tower CSP design.  The power plants will sell electricity to the state owned utility, Eskom, under twenty year power purchase agreements.  !Ka Xu is a 100 MW parabolic trough CSP plant, with approximately 2.5 hours of molten salt storage, located 40 km from the town of Pofadder with an estimated total cost of ZAR 7.5 billion (approximately US$860 million). The solar plant will be located on the land of farm Scuit Klip 92 and will feed power into the Eskom Paulputs substation located approximately 1 km from the site. It will be structured as a special purpose vehicle and the project company is !Ka Xu CSP South Africa (Pty) Ltd.!Khi is a 50 MW steam receiver power tower CSP plant, with approximately 2.0 hours of steam storage, located 15 km from the town of Upington with a total provisional estimated cost of ZAR 3.9 billion (approximately US$445 million). The solar plant will be located on the land of farm Mc Taggarts Camp 453 and will feed power into the Eskom 132kV transmission line located approximately 5 km from the site. It will be structured as a special purpose vehicle and the project company is !Khi CSP South Africa (Pty) Ltd.
Impact: 1.	Increasing South Africa''s renewable energy output and helping the country meet its renewable energy targets, including by diversifying its renewable energy mix.  South Africa is facing electricity supply and demand imbalances that risk power cuts and the increased generation capacity from the Project will help to address this.2.	Associated displacement of thermal power, resulting in avoidance of carbon emissions and local air pollutants (Sox and NOx) associated with South Africa''s predominant coal-fired power.3.	Demonstration effect, as one of the first private sector renewable energy projects in South Africa and the first CSP projects in sub-Saharan Africa, proving the viability of financing a large CSP project on a limited recourse basis, demonstrating the suitability of solar power to South Africa given its excellent solar resources, and supporting the successful role out of the first projects under South Africa''s new renewable energy independent power producer program.4.	Job creation/community development: the local communities will benefit through (i) significant sourcing of labor from local communities during the construction period, and overall job creation during the construction and operation periods; (ii) community development programs undertaken as a result of direct ownership in the power plant companies by Community Trusts.
Environmental Social Issues: Each of the proposed CSP projects are category B projects according to IFCs Policy and Performance Standards on Environmental and Social Sustainability because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that may result from their construction and operation can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.
Sponsor: For the Kaxu project, the shareholders will be Abengoa Solar South Africa (Pty) Ltd (ASSA) (holding 51%), Industrial Development Corporation of South Africa Ltd (IDC) (holding 29%) and a respective community trust backed by Broad-Based Black Economic Empowerment (BBBEE) funders (holding 20%).For the Khi project, the shareholders will be will be Son Revieren (Pty) Ltd (SR) (holding 51%), Industrial Development Corporation of South Africa Ltd (IDC) (holding 29%) and a respective community trust backed by Broad-Based Black Economic Empowerment (BBBEE) funders (holding 20%).ASSA and SR are wholly owned subsidiaries of Abengoa Solar S.A which, in turn, is a wholly owned subsidiary of Abengoa S.A. (http://www.abengoa.com) (Abengoa or the Group).  Abengoa is a global company founded in 1941 and headquartered in Spain, with 26,000 employees and a presence in 85 countries. The company is focused on: (i) engineering and construction, including solar-thermal plants, solar-gas hybrid plants, conventional generation plants, transmission lines and water infrastructures; (ii) infrastructure concessions, through the operation of solar plants, transmission lines, co-generation plants and desalination plants; and (iii) industrial production, which includes commodity risk products, such as biofuels, and recycling steel dusts. Abengoa Solar has 392.7MW of solar power capacity in operation (including CSP and photovoltaics) and 1,010MW under construction in Spain, US and the Middle-East. As of Annual Report 2011, Abengoa had total assets of 18.8 billion and total equity of 1.6 billion, with a total market value of 1.72 billion.  The company had total revenues of 7 billion, EBITDA of 1.1 billion and net income of 257 million for the year. Abengoa is publicly traded on the Madrid and Barcelona Stock Exchanges.The IDC (http://www.idc.co.za) is a self-financing, South African state-owned development finance institution that provides finance to promote industrial and entrepreneurial development. It was established in 1940 to promote economic growth and industrial development in South Africa focusing on the importance of a dynamic private sector in securing and stimulating rapid and sustainable economic growth, creating employment and reducing poverty. The IDC had capital and reserves of approximately ZAR 79 billion as of March 2010 and has equity interests in over 250 companies across diverse economic sectors. In financial year 2010, IDC funding approvals amounted to above ZAR 9.4 billion more than 75% of which is to expansion and start up projects. The IDC has publicly committed to investing ZAR 60 billion over the next 5 years of which ZAR 11.7 billion is targeted towards green industries.!Ka Xu Community Trust and !Khi Community Trust : The Sponsors are committed to enabling BBBEE ownership in the Projects and facilitating local economic development through their implementation. In order to achieve these objectives the Sponsors are targeting the allocation of approximately 20% of the shareholding in each project company to a Community Trust. Dividends flowing to the Community Trusts over the life of the Project will be applied towards local economic development beneficiary projects. The IDC is coordinating the establishment of the Community Trusts and arranging the required equity funding.
Cost Nature: The total Project cost for both CSP plants is estimated at ZAR 11.4 billion (approximately US$1.3 billion).  Individually, !Ka Xu has an estimated cost of ZAR 7.5 billion (approximately US$860 million) and !Khi has an estimated cost of ZAR 3.9 billion (US$445 million).The proposed IFC investment includes separate loans to each of the CSP project companies:to !Ka Xu CSP South Africa (Pty) Ltd:An A Loan of up to ZAR 1000 million (approximately US$ 125 million) for IFCs own account;Mobilization of a senior loan from the Clean Technology Fund of up to US$26.5 million;to !Khi CSP South Africa (Pty) Ltd:An A Loan of up to ZAR 600 million (approximately US$ 75 million) for IFCs own account;A C Loan of up to ZAR 125 million (approximately US$ 15 million) for IFCs own account;Mobilization of a loan from the Clean Technology Fund of up to US$15.0 million to be structured either as a senior or a subordinated loan.
Investment: 160.54 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan160.54Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Both plants will be located in the Northern Cape province of South Africa which is characterized by flat, desert type landscapes with high solar irradiation, making it suitable for CSP generation. Both plants will be located close enough to the Orange River to access water required for steam generation and mirror cleaning. !Ka Xu will be  located on a 300ha parcel of land on the Scuit Klip 92 farm, which is 40 km from the town of Pofadder on the R64  and R358 roads in the Khai Ma municipality.  The site coordinates are Latitude 28.9S and Longitude 19.6E. !Khi will be located on a 300ha of the Mc Taggarts Camp 453 farm, which is 15 km from the town of Upington on the N14 highway in the Kai Garaib municipality.  The site coordinates are Latitude 28.5S and Longitude 21.0E.

Company Name: SUPER FILM AMBALAJ SANAYI VE TICARET ANONIM SIRKETI
Project Description: The Project is related to the investment programs of Sanko Holdings two subsidiaries. Superfilm is a manufacturer of packaging film, while Sanko Tekstil  is a vertically-integrated textile operation. The Project includes proposed investment by Superfilm in new production lines which will increase capacity and expand its product mix, and by Sanko Tekstil which will increase the production capacity in Gaziantep and Corlu facilities.Project cost is composed of Superfilm and Sanko Tekstils investments and associated working capital needs. The project cost is estimated to be US$156 million. IFC will provide an A loan up to US$70 million to finance the project.
Review Scope: IFCs review included:Site visits to Sanko Holding headquarters, the Superfilm plant, and the following Sanko Textile facilities:  Baspinar cotton and viscose fiber knitting and spinning mills), Organized Industrial Zone (OIZ) (composed of various kinds of textile, food processing, chemicals and plastics production plants.)  and Central Waste Water Treatment Plant in Gaziantep, Adiyaman cotton knitting and spinning mills, Isko Denim Fabric mill in Inegol and the cotton knitting, fabric dyeing and finishing mill in Corlu Meetings were held with the Supply Chain Director, Plant Production Managers, Operation Managers, Quality Managers, Technical Managers, Human Resources (HR) Managers, Occupational Health and Safety (OHS) Consultants, Environmental Consultants, and Technicians, Plant Managers, Quality Engineers, and the Gaziantep OIZ Treatment Plant Manager Review of available corporate environmental and social documents, including; completed Environmental & Social (E&S) questionnaires for each plant, risk assessment studies, training plans and programs, Emergency Response Plans and Fire Safety Procedures, emission and discharge permits, ambient noise level permits, drinking and waste water analyses, emission measurements, maintenance programs, groundwater usage permissions, fire safety reports, ISO 9001 management system certificates, work permission forms, human resources (HR) policy and procedures
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Key environmental and social issues for this proposed project include: EHS management systems and capability; air emissions control (including VOC-Volatile Organic Compounds) and monitoring; highly polluted wastewater/ sludge treatment and disposal for the textile business; water and energy use reduction programs, occupational health and safety (OHS); and fire safety measures. The Project has limited potential adverse environmental and social impacts, and those that do exist are site-specific and can be resolved through the effective implementation of the action items in the ESAP, which integrate IFCs Performance Standards requirements and good international industry practices as defined in World Bank Group (WBG)s general and applicable sector-specific (Metal, Plastic, Rubber Products Manufacturing & Textiles Manufacturing) Environmental, Health and Safety requirements. This corporate-level investment is therefore a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures.The information about how these potential impacts are and will be addressed is summarized in the following sections of this Environmental and Social Review Summary (ESRS) and in the attached Action Plan (ESAP) agreed upon with the Company.

Project Description: The project consists of a straight senior loan to Ameen s.a.l one of the leading and well-managed commercial microfinance institutions in Lebanon. Proceeds of the loan will be used to finance the expansion of the Companys lending activities to micro and small entrepreneurs (the Project). Ameen s.a.l seeks long-term funding to continue its growth and continue offering existing and new products to its target clientele. Ameen s.a.l is one of the leading microfinance organizations operating in all regions in Lebanon and serves more than 14,400 clients, of which 27% are women. Ameen s.a.l mainly operates through branches of three partner banks that fund and book their share of originated loans on their books. By end December 2012, Ameen s.a.l served its clients through 73 branches of partner banks and offers a range of products to its clients with an average loan size of about US$1,190.
Impact: (i) Funding: IFC will provide medium/long term funding, that is not available in the market, to enable the Company to continue supporting and further grow its client base. The loan would also assist the Company to diversify their funding and better manage their asset and liability position at the time of limited funding opportunities. (ii) Access to finance: The proposed Project would support AMEEN Lebanon, one of the main microfinance providers, expand its outreach and serve a larger number of low-income people in Lebanon.(iii) Job creation: MSMEs are key contributors to job creation in the Country. Developing a vibrant MSME sector, with reliable access to finance, can play a significant role in private sector led economic growth, generating employment and providing opportunities to the poor and under-served groups. (iv) Demonstration effect: Through this project, IFC is expected to act as a catalyst by encouraging other investors, especially local banks, to fund the microfinance sector and bridge the financing gap facing this sector. Furthermore, the fact that IFC''s first microfinance investment project within Lebanon is with one of the only two microfinance players in the market that adopt best practices and are regulated by the Central Bank, would amplify the value and credibility derived from adopting best practices and falling under the supervision of the Central Bank, hence encourage other players to apply best practices and convert to NBFIs, thereby developing the microfinance market.
Role: IFC''s additionality will come from providing medium/long term funding, which is not available in the market especially to microfinance institutions that would support the Company in growing its portfolio and extending its reach during its current expansion phase. The long term nature of the loan represents a stable source of funding and accordingly would facilitate better liquidity management and enhanced ability to reach out to the targeted underserved segments. An Advisory Services package has been provided to the Company, which has addressed critical functions including MIS and internal audit, and assisted in developing the Company''s HR Department. Other Advisory Services are yet to be extended, which would address RM, product development and marketing, setting up a compliance department, and inturn would reflect positively on the Company''s efficiency and competitiveness in the market.
Sponsor: Ameen s.a.l was founded in 2003 as a joint stock service company to continue a USAID-funded microfinance program (Access to Microfinance and Enhanced Enterprise Niches) initiated by CHF International in October 1998.  The Company transformed into commercial for profit company regulated by the Central Bank in October 2007, thereby becoming a licensed financial institution amongst the Lebanese microfinance providers and the first MFI supervised by the Lebanese Central Bank.Since establishment, Ameen s.a.l was part of CHF International network of 9 subsidiaries in the Middle East, Latin America, Sub-Saharan Africa, and Southern & Eastern Europe. It was transferred to be part of CHF Development Finance International LLC in July 2011 that currently owns 99.99% of Ameen s.a.l shares. CHF Development Finance International LLC was established in the US to strengthen and grow CHF Internationals network of microfinance institutions into non-deposit taking, commercial institutions. CHF International is a US-based non-governmental organization with the mission to be a catalyst for long-lasting positive change in low- and moderate- income communities around the world, helping them improve their social, economic and environmental conditions.
Cost Nature: The proposed project involves a senior loan from IFCs own account to Ameen s.a.l in an amount up to US$ 2 million.

Project Description: INFUSE Capital ('INFUSE' or the 'Fund') is a sustainable energy and cleantech focused incubation and early stage fund aimed at seeding and supporting scalable ventures in India through equity investment up to US $ 1.5 million per venture. INFUSE is housed at Indian Institute of Management Ahmedabad's business incubator  the Centre for Innovation Incubation and Entrepreneurship ('CIIE') - and currently backed by BP Ventures (BP's corporate venturing arm) and Government of India's Ministry of New and Renewable Energy (MNRE) & Technology Development Board (TDB).INFUSE aims to raise a US$25 million fund that will invest in technology and business model innovation based entrepreneurial solutions across the cleantech vertical. INFUSE will bridge the early-stage equity gap in this sector and simultaneously build an enabling ecosystem for eco-ventures in India.
