As part of IFC''s investment, the fund will be required to upgrade the current SEMS to be benchmarked to the requirements of IFC Performance Standards to manage the E&S risks.
Impact: 1) Environmental impact: India is currently the third largest CO2 emitter and by 2030, India's share of global emissions is expected to increase 60%, which represents the largest expected percentage increase of any nation. Because of India's existing energy infrastructure is insufficient and inefficient, there exists an opportunity to shift development away from the model of fossil-fuel centric generation & old technologies to clean technologies. Demonstrating that cleantech investment is profitable in India may spur the type of widespread private sector adoption that could help alter India's emerging carbon emissions footprint. 2) Narrowing the Gap of funding of Early Stage Cleantech Companies: Despite presence of affordable, globally proven technologies, there exists a gap in funding for early-stage cleantech companies in India, with no major VC actively investing them in an ongoing basis. Demonstrating that investment in early-stage companies in cleantech sector is profitable and may lead to increased inflow of much needed private capital for the sector.
Role:
1) Catalyst Effect: Supporting India's first early-stage cleantech dedicated fund will send a positive message to the fund investment community on attractiveness of the sector.

2) Expertise: IFC's global expertise in cleantech will enhance the quality of investments for the Fund and have an impact on the early stage cleantech ecosystem where our activities are limited.

3) Advisory: The technical assistance program of CTIF can be utilized to benefit the fund and its underlying portfolio companies.

4) Standards: Having IFC as an investor and a potential co-investor will ensure a tight adherence to and propagation of E&S & corporate governance standards at the fund and portfolio company level.
Sponsor: INFUSE Capital is an India domiciled venture fund.CIIE Initiatives Private Limited ('Investment Advisor'), a company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, 1956 will provide deal scouting, portfolio management and administrative support to INFUSE.

Project Description: Investment Services: IFC will offer BOA Ghana (the Bank) a suite of products namely, an equity investment up to US$ 8mn (approximately GHS 13mn equivalent) in BOA Ghana Ltd. (the Bank) for a shareholding of up to 19.9% through a private placement of new common equity shares, a Senior Loan Facility of up to US$ 10mn. The loan will be denominated in US$ with a proposed term of between 5-7 years and lastly a US$ 10mn Trade Finance Facility under the GTFP Delegated Program Authority. The Facility will guarantee trade transactions of up to 360 months.
Impact: The Project is expected to have high development impact in the following areas: (i)	Improved Access to Finance:  Injecting fresh capital into the Bank would allow for growth as the Bank would be able to further leverage itself to fund growth in the strategic focus area of SME and the currently unbanked rural populous. (ii)	Demonstration Effect:  IFC is helping to demonstrate the soundness and viability of the Ghana Banking Sector. It is expected that there will be new private sector entrants be it via new institutions or additional investment in existing enterprises, this will help to increase the reach of financial services and products in Ghana.
Environmental Social Issues: The project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The Applicable Performance Requirements for this project are the Exclusion List, the applicable National Laws in Ghana and the Performance Standards. BOA Ghana is a new client and during appraisal IFC analyzed the FI portfolio for types of loans provided and industry sectors covered. IFC also analyzed the potential social and environmental risks associated with the bank''s activities, and the banks environmental and social risk management procedures. BOA Ghana is a universal bank which provides retail, SME, corporate and project finance to clients in Ghana across a number of industry sectors with the highest exposures to construction, finance and service sectors. The bank has no Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) and does not conduct Environmental and Social Due Diligence (ESDD) as part of its loan review process. The banks E&S compliance measures are limited to requesting for applicable government permits and licences. The Bank will be required to develop an ESMS which includes detailed ESDD procedures to cover E&S risk assessments for all lending activities. The ESMS needs to include screening against the Exclusion List, National Laws and IFCs Performance Standards.    BOA Ghanas compliance with PS2 on labour and working conditions was also reviewed during appraisal and the bank was found to be compliant.  The bank will be required to: (i) Nominate an E&S Officer and notify IFC prior to commitment; (ii) Develop an ESMS in line with the applicable requirements to cover all lending activities and submit to IFC prior to disbursement; (iii) Provide training to staff on the implementation of the ESMS and commit to implementing the ESMS to ensure that its lending activities are in compliance with the Exclusion List, applicable National Laws in Ghana and the Performance Standards; and (iv) Submit an annual report on E&S performance in the format to be provided by IFC.
Sponsor: BANK OF AFRICA  GHANA (BOA-GHANA) commenced operation in Ghana in 2011 after BANK OF AFRICA Group (BOA Group) acquired majority interest in Amalgamated Bank (Amalbank) on 2nd of February 2011. With this acquisition, the BOA Group has consolidated its presence within the West African region and is therefore strategically well placed to facilitate cross  border trade within the larger West African region. The BOA Group has presence in 14 African countries namely Benin, Burkina Faso, Burundi, Democratic Republic Of Congo, Djibouti, Ghana, Ivory Coast, Kenya, Madagascar, Mali, Niger, Senegal, Tanzania and Uganda.  Additionally, the BOA Group owns three leasing companies, a housing finance company, a stock brokerage company, two investment companies and an Information Technology subsidiary.  BOA Groups majority shareholder, is Bank Maroccaine du Commerce Exterieur (BMCE Bank). BMCE Bank is Africas twelfth (12th ) largest bank and is actively involved in Capital Market, Asset Management, Stock Brokerage, Consumer Credit, Asset Leasing, Credit Insurance, Custody and Advisory services.BOA-GHANA is a commercial bank, offering a wide range of financial products and services that covers sectors of Retail, SME and Corporate Banking. The Bank has 19Branches around Ghana, with about 383 Staff members.
Cost Nature: The total Project cost will be US$ 28mn comprised of : An Equity investment of US$8mn through a subscription of new common shares of the Bank. A Senior Unsecured Loan Facility of US$ 10mn with a tenor of 5 years for on-lending the SME sector in Ghana. A Trade Finance Facility of US$ 10mn for trade transactions of up to 12 months to support Trade Finance Transactions of SME in Ghana.

Company Name: SUPER FILM AMBALAJ SANAYI VE TICARET ANONIM SIRKETI
Project Description: The Project is related to the investment programs of Sanko Holdings two subsidiaries. Superfilm is a manufacturer of packaging film, while Sanko Tekstil  is a vertically-integrated textile operation. The Project includes proposed investment by Superfilm in new production lines which will increase capacity and expand its product mix, and by Sanko Tekstil which will increase the production capacity in Gaziantep and Corlu facilities.
Impact: 1)Preservation of employment in frontier region of the country: Combined Superfilm and Sanko Tekstil have around 6,000 employees most of which work in the frontier regions of Turkey. The increased capacity at Superfilm and Sanko Tekstil will enable the Borrowers to be more competitive and retain the existing work-force.2)Exports: Superfilm and Sanko Tekstil are exporters. The investments will enable them to improve their standings in the export markets and help increase export activity and hard currency inflows into Turkey.3)Environmental Benefits: New machines will be more energy-efficient which will increase overall energy efficiency of Superfilm and Sanko Tekstil.
Environmental Social Issues: Key environmental and social issues for this category B project include: EHS management systems and capability; air emissions control (including VOC-Volatile Organic Compounds) and monitoring; highly polluted wastewater/ sludge treatment and disposal for the textile business; water and energy use reduction programs, occupational health and safety (OHS); and fire safety measures. The Project has limited potential adverse environmental and social impacts, and those that do exist are site-specific and can be resolved through the effective implementation of the action items in the ESAP, which integrate IFCs Performance Standards requirements and good international industry practices as defined in World Bank Group (WBG)s general and applicable sector-specific (Metal, Plastic, Rubber Products Manufacturing & Textiles Manufacturing) Environmental, Health and Safety requirements. This corporate-level investment is therefore a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures.
Sponsor: Sanko Holding is the main shareholder of Sanko Tekstil and Superfilm. Based in Gaziantep, Sanko Holding is a major conglomerate of Turkey with operations in energy, cement, textile, packaging, heavy industrial machines, hospital, yacht manufacturing, white-goods, financial sector, IT, education, water bottling.
Cost Nature: Project cost is composed of Superfilm and Sanko Tekstils investments and associated working capital needs. The project cost is estimated to be US$156 million. IFC will provide an A loan up to US$70 million to finance the project.

Project Description: The project consists of the acquisition, building and maintenance of two telecommunication tower networks by Eaton Uganda.  Existing tower sites will be acquired from Orange Uganda Limited and Warid Telecom Uganda Limited in a negotiated sale.  Towers will also be built-to-suit over the next two years to support additional demand.
Review Scope: The review of this project consisted of a visit by IFC staff to the project site, to meet with and interview management of Eaton Towers Uganda Limited (the Company or Eaton Uganda), and to have a first-hand look at operational activities.  IFC staff also appraised technical, environmental and social information submitted by Eaton Uganda, including an environmental and social management plan, an employee manual, and a sample employee contract.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Because this project involves the acquisition of existing towers and new ones will be built only at non-sensitive sites where no high risk exists, no major adverse environmental or social impacts are expected.  As a result, it has been classified as a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.

Project Description: The project consists of the acquisition of two tower networks in Uganda by Eaton Towers Uganda Limited (the Company, Borrower or Eaton Uganda) for a total project cost of US$153 million (the Project).  The Company will use the proposed debt financing from IFC and other lenders along with equity and internal cash generation to fund the acquisition of existing tower sites from Orange Uganda Limited and Warid Telecom Uganda Limited in a negotiated sale, in addition to supporting its plans to add build-to-suit towers over the next two years to support additional demand.
Impact: (i) Expand mobile telecommunication access: With the improvements to current networks and construction of additional tower sites, existing mobile phone operators will be able to expand the reach of their services both in terms of geographic coverage and network traffic capacity.  In addition, collocation reduces the incremental cost of expanding service for all carriers thereby allowing them to service remote and economically less developed areas where average revenues per user and minutes of use tend to be lower. (ii) Increased competition: The entry of Eaton Uganda will add a second player in the tower sharing market which will lower barriers to entry for smaller and newer mobile phone operators through access to leased towed facilities compared to building their own.  (iii) Expand access to other ICT technologies: Eaton Uganda will be building a tower network capable of not only supporting mobile network traffic but also wireless broadband, backhaul and broadcast networks, which would increase the penetration levels of these technologies. (iv) Contribute to mitigating environmental impact and Climate Change: The Company''s constructed network and services offered will provide a cost effective opportunity for operators to lower their carbon emission as well as physical footprint by sharing infrastructure.  Significant benefits of tower sharing arise from the material, energy and emissions savings incurred from building only one tower compared to each operator building their own site to cover the same terrain.
Role: (i) Knowledge Sharing: IFC has developed good relationships with major telecom operators in Sub-Saharan Africa and will make its experience available to the Company.  (ii) Establish and Maintain Good Social and Environmental Standards, Anti-Corruption and Anti-Money-laundering practices: IFC will work with Eaton Uganda to ensure that it develops and implements related policies and procedures that address these critical issues as the Company expands its operations in Uganda.  (iii) Enhanced Opportunity to Provide Long-Term Funding: Given that the acquisition and expansion of shared telecommunication infrastructure is capital intensive, IFC''s ability to mobilize long term capital for operations of the Company in Uganda is essential. (iv) Long Term Partnership:  Given Eaton''s plans to expand across the African continent, IFC''s ability to partner with the Sponsor to invest and mobilize additional financing across such a wide geographic area is an attractive proposition to the Sponsor.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is with ETW Africa Holdings UK Limited ("ETWH" or the "Sponsor").  The Sponsor operates across three business segments: (i) tower building; (ii) tower ownership; (iii) tower maintenance; and (iii) information technology services in both ICT and telecommunication environments.  ETWH was formed in 2009 through the merger of Q-Venture and Eaton Telecom Infrastructure Ltd. Currently the Sponsor is owned by Capital International Private Equity Funds VI LP (77.3%), ADP 1 Holding 1 (18.8%); Eaton Partner Investments II LLP (2.1%), Kingsbridge Investment Holdings (NR) (0.3%), and Kingsbridge International Investments Inc. (1.4%).
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$153 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a senior loan for IFCs own account of up to US$35 million.

Project Description: Kenya Airways Ltd. (Kenya Airways, KQ or the Company), an IFC client and a leading African airline, is seeking financing from IFC to support the implementation of a five year expansion plan for national, regional and transcontinental passenger and cargo services.  The Company was founded in 1977, and was wholly owned by the Government of Kenya until 1996 when it was privatized through a public private partnership arrangement.  KQs head office is located in Embakasi, Nairobi, with its hub at Nairobis Jomo Kenyatta International (JKIA).  The Company currently operates 33 aircraft servicing 55 domestic, regional and transcontinental destinations. Kenya Airways is now in the midst of implementing a comprehensive network and fleet expansion plan focused on growing its passenger network and diversifying its fleet to match the network needs as well as launching a dedicated freighter division.
Review Scope: IFCs environmental and social review of the project included: i) meetings with Kenya Airways management and senior operational staff responsible for environmental, health and safety of flight and ground operations, procurement and supply chain management, human resources management, staff training and quality assurance; ii) inspection of the Companys aircraft and ground equipment maintenance facilities, pilot and crew training facilities, and ground handling operations; and iii) review of documentation, including safety manuals, environmental assessments and audit reports, and operating licenses related to the various functions of the Companys Corporate Quality, Safety and Environment division.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability.  Air transport is a highly regulated industry that has well established policies and procedures for managing the environmental, health and safety performance of accredited carriers such as Kenya Airways.

Project Description: Metito Holdings Limited (the Company or Metito), an existing IFC client, is the largest Middle Eastern-based privately-owned water group with operations in developing markets. The Company has asked IFC to assist it in arranging up to a US$120 million debt facility to finance the Companys future projects (including expansions of existing facilities) and consolidate existing medium term facilities (the Project) from its subsidiaries into a single longer term corporate loan. The Company is well situated in the water deficient Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region and in China, where it is further expanding its presence. The Project would provide the Company with a longer term, consolidated financing package better adapted to its growth plans.
Review Scope: This is a follow-on investment to Metito (#25043, 2007) and Metito II (#29325, 2010). IFCs Environmental & Social (E&S) review of this third proposed Metito investment consisted of: Metitos performance against previous IFC Environmental & Social Action Plans; the implementation status of Metitos Environmental & Social Management System (ESMS); E&S impact assessment documentation pertaining to Metitos newest Chinese projects; updated Metito staffing and greenhouse gas emissions data and recent (2011) E&S performance data. The review relied on documents and reports made available by MHL, IFC technical experts report, and discussions with key Metito staff at the Metito Head Office in Dubai in March 2012.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: IFC''s review indicates that the Metito operations have potential limited adverse environmental or social risks and/or impacts that are few in number, generally site-specific, and readily addressed through mitigation measures. It is therefore concluded that this is an Environmental Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures. This is consistent with categorization for Metito II, disclosed in 2010 and Metito, disclosed in 2007.

Project Description: Kenya Airways Ltd. (Kenya Airways, KQ or the Company), an IFC client and a leading African airline, is seeking financing from IFC to support the implementation of its  strategic fleet and network expansion plan focused on growing its passenger network and diversifying its fleet to match the network needs as well as launching a dedicated freighter division (the Project).  Having reached a critical mass and achieved a solid financial position, KQ finds itself well positioned to capitalize on the growth prospects and opportunities that the African region and the international market presents. KQs strategic intent is to establish its brand and its presence in the most important intra African markets as well as become a significant player in long haul origin-destination city pairs that are expected to grow over the next few years. To implement the Project, the Company has already placed firm orders to aircraft manufacturers in connection with the acquisition of nine Boeing 787 Dreamliner aircraft and ten Embraer 190 aircraft. KQ will also incur additional capital expenditures such as spare engines and hangar construction related to its fleet expansion.
Impact: IFC''s support of Kenya Airways expansion plan will have significant development impact.  From a social and labor point of view, the Company estimates that the number of employees will nearly double after five years (currently 4,400 employees) most of which are of a technical/qualified labor nature.  At the regional level of Sub Saharan Africa ("SSA"), the launch of the freighter division coupled with the opening of new intra-Africa destinations will contribute to markets integration and will reduce the transactional costs of trade, an aspect that is extremely important to promote the economic development of the SSA economies. Finally, KQ''s entry into new international markets will promote competition as well as provide a key transportation link between growing economies in the Middle East and Northern Africa ("MENA") region and Asia promoting international trade, South South Investments and tourism to and from Africa.
Role: A growing airline faces an array of capital needs that includes financing the aircraft they operate but also investing in inventory of spares parts and engines, making pre delivery payments associated to their aircraft orders and investing on training as well as in new management systems. While senior debt for 85% of the aircraft purchase price should be available under Export Credit Agency cover, IFC''s role in the proposed transaction is: i) to provide scarce PDP financing to an airline that is undertaking an expansion to open underserved markets within Africa. This type of financing is currently not readily available in the market from financial institutions that are reluctant to increase their exposures to the airline sector, except for export credit agency backed financing for the purchase of aircraft.  ii) Demonstration effect: KQ is undertaking a significant expansion that requires the support of many investors. IFC''s equity investment will play its demonstration role by providing its stamp of approval to the expansion plan, with a potential facilitation effect of the Company''s upcoming Rights Issue and iii) IFC will also contribute its technical, market, industry expertise and lessons learned by leveraging its investment experience in similar sized and situated carriers.
Sponsor: Kenya Airways, originally established in 1977 following the break-up of East Africa Community, was privatized in 1996 and since then it has achieved many firsts in the aviation sector in Sub Sahara Africa including, 1st carrier to be certified under the International Air Transportation Associations (IATA) Operational Safety Audit (IOSA), and Safety Audit for Ground Operations (ISOGA) as well as been the first Sub Saharan Airline to achieve Sky Team alliance membership.  KQs operational and financial track record in the last 10 years is a stellar one marked by rapid growth and consistent profitability.  Since the beginning of the past decade, the company focused on modernizing its fleet, transitioning part of its wide-body fleet from Airbus A310 to the then recently launched Boeing B777 and its narrow-body fleet from Boeing 737 classics to Boeing 737 New Generation while at the same time investing in operating systems and training its labor force. The fleet modernization and growth from 16 planes in 2002 to 31 in 2011 resulted in revenue growth from US$320 million to over US$1 billion while at the same time maintaining healthy load factors, improving productivity and achieving extremely solid margins.KQ is a public company with shares listed on the Nairobi Securities Exchange (NSE), the Uganda Securities Exchange (USE) and the Dar-Es-Salaam Stock Exchange (DSE). KQs largest shareholder is KLM (Dutch airline) with 26.0% of the shares. Approximately 40% of the ownership is held by foreign shareholders and the largest Kenyan shareholder is the Government of Kenya with 23.0%.
Cost Nature: The total Project cost is estimated at more than US$3 billion, which will be funded by a combination of equity, internal cash generation, Pre-delivery Payment (PDP) facilities and Export Agency Aircraft term loans over more than five years. The equity will be provided through a Rights Issue Offer which began on April 2 and is scheduled to conclude on or about June 30 2012.The proposed IFC investment is a US$80 million senior secured PDP facility in the form of an A Loan and an equity investment to complement the Rights Issue Offer in amount up to US$25 million.

Project Description: Metito Holdings Limited (the Company or Metito), an existing IFC client, is the largest Middle Eastern-based privately-owned water group with operations in developing markets. The Company has asked IFC to assist it in arranging up to a US$120 million debt facility to finance the Companys future projects (including expansions of existing facilities) and consolidate existing medium term facilities (the Project) from its subsidiaries into a single longer term corporate loan. The Company is well situated in the water deficient Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region and in China, where it is further expanding its presence. The Project would provide the Company with a longer term, consolidated financing package better adapted to its growth plans.
Impact: 1) Support for a Regional Player in the Water Sector by putting in place a more suitable capital structure to support its growth plans.2) Increase in Access to Services by helping Metito to pursue new projects and expand capacity at existing plants, and thus to widen service access significantly. 3) Promotion of Water Reuse in Africa and Asia. 4) Enhancement of Competition and demonstration of the benefits of private sector participation by investing in private sector water projects in MENA and China, which are areas that have relatively few private sector players.5) Development of Emerging Markets by supporting the Company to further grow its presence in MENA, Asia and Sub-Saharan Africa and, to contribute to balanced rural and urban development in developing countries with increased investment.
Role:
1) Extending Long-Term Funding: to provide the Company with greater operational flexibility as long-term funding is very limited in the MENA region following the Global Financial Crisis and the Arab Spring.
2) Mobilization: As a global coordinator and co-arranger for the Company''s financing package, IFC will assist Metito in mobilizing up to US$80 million of financing from regional and international commercial institutions which are willing to extend proposed maturities if they come under the IFC B-loan umbrella.
Sponsor: Metito was founded by Farouk Ghandour and later joined by his brother Mutaz Ghandour, two Lebanese entrepreneurs, in 1958 as the first company in the Middle East to specialize in water and wastewater treatment services. In November 2006, the Ghandour family sold a majority stake of the Company to Gulf Capital PSJC, a private equity group based in the United Arab Emirates. In October 2007, IFC purchased an equity stake in the Company. The current shareholding structure is: 56% Gulf Capital, 38% the Ghandour Family and 6% IFC.

The proposed IFC investment is up to a US$40 million A Loan for IFCs own account. IFC will also assist in arranging up to US$80 million through an IFC B Loan.

Project Description: The proposed project is to provide a US$5 million straight senior loan to Forus Bank (Forus or Bank). The loan is intended to support the Banks micro-lending operations in the European part of Russia.Forus Bank is a unique specialized microfinance institution, located in Nizhny Novgorod. The Bank was formed by FORA Fund, a non-banking microfinance organization in Russia, part of Opportunity International Microfinance Network. Since then Forus has gone through a transformation into a commercial bank and managed to build a sustainable business model and a recognized brand. IFC has been engaged with the Bank since 2006.At the moment Forus is the only commercial bank in Russia specialized on lending to micro enterprises. The Bank operates through 6 regional branches and 34 satellite offices located in 26 regions of Russia, which translates into the market share of about 2.5% of the total microfinance market in Russia.
Impact: The development impact of the Project is expected to be high. The Bank already has a locally recognised franchise and a loyal customer base in servicing micro- and small businesses, including those in the remote regions, small towns and rural areas.  This segment is underserved and especially lacks access to quality financial services, on both lending and savings sides.

Forus Bank has designated an SEMS Officer and submitted its AEPRs on time since 2006.  In November 2010, IFC environmental specialists met with a number of Bank''s representatives and discussed implementation of the Banks E&S procedures. Last ESRR score (based on 2010 AEPR review) is F2  Satisfactory (July 13, 2011).  As a follow up to 2010 AEPR review, the client was asked to use new AEPR reporting format. Project Description: SinoGreen Fund L.P., (SinoGreen or the Fund), a Cayman Island exempted limited partnership, is an eight-year private equity fund seeking to raise $150 million to invest in the cleantech sector in China.  The Fund will invest in early- and growth- stage companies focusing on renewable energy, energy efficiency, cleaner transportation, non-energy related climate change mitigation technologies and other technologies that have direct contribution to climate change mitigation and adaptation.
Impact: IFC''s investment in the Fund is expected to have the following quantifiable development impact:(i)	Reduction of GHGs through adoption of clean technologies and more environmentally sustainable practices: indicated by potential reduction of CO2 emissions directly and indirectly by the Fund''s investees;(ii)	Private sector development: indicated by improved revenue and profitability of the Fund''s investees;(iii)	Economic sustainability: demonstrated through the Fund''s ability to help its investees grow sustainably and generate employment growth faster than the national average;(iv)	Financial success: evidenced by the Fund''s investment return (net IRR) and the Manager''s ability to raise successor fund.
Environmental Social Issues: SinoGreen has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Portfolio activities of the proposed new fund shall meet the requirements of the IFC FI Exclusion List, applicable Chinese E&S laws and regulations, and the IFC Performance Standards. As a condition of IFC investment, the Fund is required to appoint a senior officer and implement an environmental and social management system (ESMS) to ensure its portfolio activities will meet the above performance requirements. IFC will have the rights to review the first three and all Category A investments of the Fund prior to their investment decisions to ensure the Fund''s ESMS is operating adequately in identifying and managing E&S risks. Project Description: RP Global (the sponsor) is proposing to develop the 43.7 MW Danilo Wind Farm straddling three locations covering a total area of approx 210 ha that together will produce 97.5 GWh per year. Specifically, the wind farm consists of three sets of turbines -- 9 turbines on Velika Glava site, which is approx 3 km apart from two adjacent sites Bubrig with 8 turbines and Crni Vrh site with 2 turbines -totaling 19 turbines in all.  The Project will have its own power substation, and will include 7,3 km double overhead 110 kV transmission line. The Danilo Wind Farm is located in the Dalmatia region about 15-16 km southeast of the town ibenik in the area that is administratively split between municipalities Sibenik, Drnis and Ugresic. The distance to the Adriatic Sea is about 15 km. The wind farms sites are located on hills ridges with an elevation of about 420 to 540m meters above sea level. The wider plain area around the project location is open and mostly used for agricultural purposes and livestock grazing. The Project will be developed by RP Global, a renewable energy company that currently has several hundreds of MW of wind power under development in Portugal, France, Poland, Chile and Croatia.  RP Globals project management team will implement the Project through a multi-contract structure. Both supply and installation agreement and service agreement with EPK (Enercon Partner Konzept) for a duration of 15 years is being negotiated. The scope of supply includes delivery and installation of 19 Enercon E-82 E2 2,3 MW with 79 steel tower height and 82m rotor diameter. The wind farm will be connected to the grid through a 7,3 km double 110 kV overhead transmission line to the Podi industrial zone.  Start of construction is scheduled for June 2012, while the commercial operation is expected to start by May 2013. This Project presents a first stage of the larger development (88 MW), for which RP Global has obtained the Location Permit from MofEnv of Croatia.
Review Scope: IFCs review of this investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information made available by the sponsor including the following documents:-Environmental Impact Study for Velika Glava wind farm, prepared in 2005;-Environmental Impact Study for Bubrig and Crni Vrh and Transmission Line 110 kV wind farm, prepared in 2007;-Ornithological Studies for Crni Vrh and Bubrig wind farm locations, prepared in 2007, by Croatian Ornithological Society; -The Elaborate Revision of EIAs due to the change of the wind turbines specification i.e. installed power and diameter of blades;-The Location Permit for Velika Glava, Bubrig, Crni Vrh and Transmission Line 2x110kV, issued by Croatian Ministry of Environment, Spatial Planning and Construction (MoEnv) in July 2011; andSupplemental Report to EIAs, prepared in March 2012, as per IFC request following the field appraisal, to cover (i) potential information deficiency related to the baseline bird/bat assessment studies prepared in 2007, and (ii) stakeholders engagement related to the project development. The integral part of the Supplemental Report is Environmental Management and Monitoring Plan (EMMP).The appraisal team also met with and interviewed: the sponsors consultants who prepared the Projects original EIAs from 2005 and 2007; representatives from the Croatian Ornithological Society; relevant Sibenik municipal officials; and representatives from the local Danilo community.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The proposed investment in the Project is a Category B project because of a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that may result from it, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Potential impacts in construction activities besides being mitigable are likely to be limited to project site; short term; and likely to have limited impact on environmentally sensitive areas. Further, it is possible to readily design and implement engineering and management measures to mitigate adverse impacts during construction and operation.
Sector: V-BC - Wind Power - Renewable Energy Generation

Project Description: The Project, also referred to as the Umm Qasr Logistics Center (UQLC), involves the development, construction and joint-operation with the Iraqi Ports Authority (IPA) of an inland container depot and logistics center on a 750,000 m2 plot of land a short distance from Gulftainers existing container and cargo terminal operations at Umm Qasr Port. The Logistics Center will be fully secure and will encompass the entire range of logistics and freight forwarding services, an inland container depot, cold stores and areas to be utilized by other major logistics providers.  The UQLC is located outside of the security fence of the port northward on a surface area of 75 ha. There is no community population within immediate surroundings of the facilities. Ground preparation and engineering design for the Project have begun and operations are expected to commence in the 3rd quarter of 2012.  UQLC will effectively serve as an extension of the Umm Qasr Port operations, and Gulftainer would be the only company with such a facility that would also contain customs clearance facilities. The Project is being implemented under a 10 year concession that is being is expected to cost approximately US$ 40 million and is intended to cater towards the significant amount of economic activity that is currently taking place and is expected to continue over the next several years as Iraq continues to develop its substantial hydrocarbon reserves.  In addition, the Project will also benefit from the increased container traffic and non-containerized cargo that is expected to be handled by the Umm Qasr Port as the rebuilding of Iraq gains momentum.
Review Scope: IFCs E&S due diligence of this follow-on investment with the Company involved meetings with key members of Gulftainers management team at the Companys corporate offices in Sharjah, UAE, and desk review of available project documentation including:  (i) current E&S performance of Gulftainers container and cargo operations at Umm Qasr Port (#28819) ; (ii) status of implementation of Gulftainers corporate QHSE management system and HR Manual; and (iii) detailed maps and photographs to document the location and surrounding areas for each of its existing or proposed facilities.  IFC also reviewed a number of relevant documents associated with the earlier investment, e.g. (i) progress in implementing the Environmental Social Action Plan (ESAP) and (ii) Annual Monitoring Report (AMR) 2010. Security issues prevented visiting either Gulftainers existing operations in Iraq or the proposed site for new facility.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The location for the proposed developments is situated adjacent to the existing port facilities in Port Umm Qasr.  Aspects related to the development of the project that can have potential adverse environmental and social impacts are few in number, site-specific, largely reversible and readily addressed through mitigation measures. This is therefore an environmental category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social.

Project Description: Gulftainer Company Limited (Gulftainer or the Company), a UAE Limited Liability Company founded in 1976, is developing port and logistics activities in Iraq since 2009 where it operates since August 2010 a multipurpose terminal at Umm Qasr port, southern Iraq. Gulftainer has now decided to expand its container, cargo and logistics operations at Umm Qasr. It plans to develop and operate a 750,000 m2 bonded dry port north of Umm Qasr port (Umm Qasr Logistics Center or UQLC), which is expected to serve not only the container traffic at the port, but also the transport and logistics needs of the oil and gas industry in Southern Iraq (the Project). Gulftainers objective is to establish a first class logistics and oil field supply facility in the Basra region based on two main activities:A fully fledged dry port (inland container depot) targeting general traffic; andAdditional services targeting specifically oil and gas companies looking for integrated and secured facilities to operate in Southern Iraq including (i) rental offices and accommodation, (ii) field support rental of equipment and transport, and (iii) long- and short-term rental of serviced but undeveloped plots for hazardous, fabrication, commercial, and oil and gas industry clients.The Project is expected to have a significant contribution towards the redevelopment of the logistics and transport infrastructure in Iraq which is essential for the economic development of the country as well as its integration into the global economy.
Impact: Once regarded as having one of the Middle East''s most comprehensive transportation systems, Iraq''s transport and logistics infrastructure has suffered from more than two decades of neglect and underinvestment. Rehabilitation of such infrastructure is a major national and regional trade issue. Gulftainer investments in Umm Qasr Port should help solve this issue and thus contribute to Iraq integration in the regional and global economy.Iraq relies heavily on imports for its consumer goods and for its reconstruction program. Cost effective transport of imported goods is therefore critical to Iraq''s economy. The 2012 Doing Business indicators however show that Iraq''s is lagging behind other countries in the region in terms of logistics performance. Gulftainer''s investments to modernize one of Umm Qasr berth combined with its experience to efficiently manage container terminals is expected to improve the situation.At present, a substantial portion of goods coming into Iraq are off-loaded at ports in the neighboring countries such as Kuwait, Turkey and Jordan and are then transported into the country by road, which tends to increase the time and cost of delivering the goods to the end consumer. The Project should have a significant impact on reducing these impediments to trade in Iraq and foster the country''s reconstruction efforts along with its economic growth and development. Efficient and well-developed transport and logistics infrastructure is an essential component for the expected growth in Iraq''s oil and gas production and export-related activities and the Project would play a strong role in facilitating these improvements.In addition to its direct impact on trade, the Project should also contribute towards socio-economic development through the creation of several hundred jobs, reduction in the cost of goods paid by the end consumer (through reduction of costs incurred in the transportation process) as well as substantial royalty payments to the Government of Iraq.Through its involvement at Umm Qasr port, Gulftainer will also play a strong role in training and improving the skills of the employees of the Iraq Port Authority, help introduce industry best-practice and contribute its valuable know-how in managing ports and logistics operations, which should improve the overall efficiency of the sector.
Role:
IFC is in a position to offer a facility which tenor (10 years) is needed by Gulftainer to develop its Iraqi ventures in a phased and sound manner, and which cannot be matched by commercial banks (usually 5 years) especially in the current market situation

Although the investment is structured as a corporate loan at UAE level, IFC is willing to take some Project and Iraqi risk, which other institutions cannot do.

IFC will also improve the environmental and social standards of Gulftainer''s activities, as a result of the introduction of IFC''s Performance Standards.

IFC''s presence at such early stage of Gulftainer''s international development should help the group i) structure its emerging market activities in a way that could facilitate its future fundraising and ii) mobilize international sources of financing a later stages.
Sponsor: An existing client of IFC since September 2010, Gulftainer Company Limited, based in Sharjah, United Arab Emirates (UAE), and founded in 1976, is a well established company whose core business consists of the operation and management of two container terminals in the Emirate of Sharjah: the Sharjah Container Terminal (SCT) operating since 1976 at Port Khalid in Sharjah city, and the Khorfakkan Container Terminal (KCT) since 1986 on the eastern side of the Straits of Hormuz. In addition to these historical activities, the Company has developed container-related transport and logistics activities (such as trucking, warehousing, freight forwarding, etc.) in the UAE and has started to export its know-how since 2004 with its first significant overseas investment in Iraq in 2010 (rehabilitation and operation of two terminals at Umm Qasr port) and Brazil (operation of one multi-purpose terminal at Recifes port). The Company handled total traffic of over 3 million twenty-foot equivalent (TEU) in the UAE in 2011.The Company is owned by two shareholders: HH Sheikh Sultan Al Qassimi, the Ruler of Sharjah and Mr Hamid Dhia Jafar.

IFCs proposed investment is in the form of a C-loan to Gulftainer, up to an amount of US$ 30 million, and with a condition that the IFC funds will be exclusively used towards the development of the Project in Iraq and other projects eligible for IFC financing.

Sibenik WPP is wholly-owned by RP Global Danilo d.o.o, a limited liability Company incorporated under Croatian Law. Construction is expected to commence in the second half of 2012 and commercial operations are expected to begin by the end of 2013.

To date the Group developed close to 200 MW in 25 different projects focusing on small hydro power plants (Chile, Spain and Portugal) and wind farm projects (France and Poland). At the moment RP Global operates a portfolio of 6 wind power projects in Poland and France with total installed capacity of 86 MW.

Company Name: COOPERATIVA NACIONAL DE PRODUCTORES DE LECHE
Project Description: Cooperativa Nacional de Productores de Leche (Conaprole or the Company) is Uruguays leading dairy producer and one of the lowest cost producers in the world. Conaprole has eight production plants that produce a wide range of dairy products including liquid milk, milk powder, yogurt, cheese, butter, ice cream, and milk by-products. The Project entails capacity expansion at two production plants.  At the Villa Rodriguez plant (VR or Plant 8), the existing powdered milk capacity of one 6 tonnes/hour spray drier with associated evaporator will be progressively expanded by the addition of a second evaporator, then a second spray drier and finally a third evaporator, to develop capacity to produce 12 tonnes /hour of whole or skim milk powder, with supporting investment in milk reception and processing and in utility systems.  At the Montevideo plant (CIM), the Project will expand production capacity for ice cream, desserts and yoghurt production, again with supporting investment in factory infrastructure.  The Project will increase raw milk reception from farmers by about one third.
Review Scope: Conaprole has been an IFC client since 2002, with IFC support previously assisting the establishment of the CIM plant in Montevideo and the installation of the first powder line at VR.IFCs environmental and social (E&S) review of the Project included examination of routine E&S reporting to IFC over the last two financial years, visits to the VR and CIM processing plants, and to two dairy farms supplying milk to Conaprole, and discussions of technical aspects of existing and proposed future operations with Conaproles Engineering Manager, and Technical, Innovation and Environmental Manager, and the Head of the Occupational Health and Safety department.   Where available, specifications for the major capital items to be purchased were also reviewed.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The key environmental and social issues related to this proposed project are related to the manufacturing activities at the two sites to de developed, and are assessment of potential adverse environmental and/or social impacts arising from the projects, labor and working conditions, including occupational health and safety considerations, use of energy and water, emissions to air and to surface waters, and management systems to assure food hygiene.  These risks and impacts are commonly encountered in this industry are site specific and may be readily mitigated.   This is therefore an environmental and social Category B project.

Project Description: There is at present no dedicated port terminal in Pakistan for non-food dry bulk cargo (e.g., coal, cement and clinker).  The volume of coal, cement and clinker handled by Pakistan ports grew by more than 15% between 2007-08 and 2008-09. These volumes are currently handled primarily by small privately managed facilities at various Pakistan ports, none of which is equipped with adequate equipment or storage capacity.  To respond to Pakistans need for a dedicated bulk terminal, the Port Qasim Authority (PQA) in 2008 launched an international competitive bidding process for private sector operators to develop and operate such a facility in Port Qasim, located approximately 50 km southeast of Karachi.  In August 2009, Pakistan International Container Terminal Ltd. (PICT) won the bid. PICT has created a fully-owned special purpose subsidiary, Pakistan International Bulk Terminal Limited (PIBT or the Project Company) to develop and operate the project.  PICT currently operates a container terminal in the Port of Karachi under a 21-year agreement signed in 2002 with the Karachi Port Trust. Since 2003 IFC has provided four loans to PICT to support the development and expansion of the Karachi Port container terminal.  The project consists of the construction and operation of the referenced bulk terminal under a 33-year agreement between PIBT and PQA.  The bulk terminal will primarily handle coal, cement and clinker and will have a total capacity of approximately 8 million tons in the initial phase, which can be increased to over 12 million tons at a later stage.  The project will be developed on a parcel of reclaimed land totaling 25 hectares (ha) in size. It will include five concrete silos of 10,000 tons capacity each located at the western side of the storage area. The development also includes a jetty of up to 460 meters (m) in length to allow the simultaneous operation of two vessels. The jetty will have two coal ship unloading cranes and one clinker and ship loading crane and be connected to the storage area via a 2.5km trestle bridge. The trestle will have two covered conveyors, one for coal imports and the other for cement exports.
Review Scope: As a long-term IFC client the project sponsor, Pakistan International Container Terminal Limited, reports annually on the management of its environmental and social (E&S) performance. Its performance has been strong over the eight years of IFCs multiple investments in its container terminal at the Port of Karachi.  The company regularly submitted thorough and detailed Annual E&S monitoring reports (AMRs) that confirm compliance with IFC requirements. In addition, IFC has carried out supervision visits to the Port of Karachi facility twice in the last few years (2008 and 2010). The most recent visit (March 2010) confirmed that the company is meeting or exceeding the requirements of the investment agreement and continues to demonstrate that its activities comply with applicable Pakistan laws and regulations, IFCs Performance Standards (PSs) and World Bank Group environmental, health and safety (EHS) guidelines. As part of the due diligence for the subject investment, IFC met with the project team in Karachi in December 2010 to review the plans for the proposed bulk terminal at Port Qasim, and toured the project site with both the project sponsor and the independent consultants, Environmental Management Consultants (EMC), who prepared the Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) for the project, in accordance with both the  requirements of the Pakistan Environmental Protection Act of 1997 and IFCs PSs. IFC also reviewed the ESIA Final Report (dated July 2011 and included as an attachment to this Environmental and Social Review Summary) and held several follow up meetings and other communications with EMC to discuss their findings. IFC also attended the public hearing on the ESIA for the project conducted by the Sindh Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) on October 15, 2011.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The onshore facilities for the proposed project are located on heavily modified land that was allocated by the Government of Pakistan for port and associated industrial and commercial activities 40 years ago. Offshore developments, including a 2.4km trestle bridge and 460m jetty will be located in the Kadiro creek system and contiguous mudflats, which have also been heavily modified as a result of other PQA developments over the past decades. In light of the fact that adverse impacts are not expected to be diverse or irreversible and will be limited to the project site, and mitigation measures can readily be designed to address these impacts, the project has been classified as a Category B.

Project Description: Under an Implementation Agreement (IA) signed with Port Qasim Authority (PQA), Pakistan International Bulk Terminal Ltd. (PIBT or the Company) has been awarded a 33 year concession to develop and operate a multi-purpose terminal on Build-Operate-Transfer (BOT) basis at Port Mohammad Bin Qasim in Karachi for handling and storage of non-food dry bulk cargo. Under a phased development, the terminal will be capable of handling total cargo of around 15.7 MTPA along with requisite on-shore storage facilities (the Project).The Project represents Pakistans first multi-purpose non-food dry bulk cargo terminal, offering state of the art fully automated handling and storage of clinker, cement and coal in compliance with international environmental and safety standards. The proposed terminal is expected to maintain high level of operational efficiency leading to significant cost savings in handling, storage and transportation of non-food dry bulk cargo. With 3 years of construction time, the Project is expected to be in operation by July 2015.PIBT was incorporated under the laws of Pakistan in 2010 as a special purpose company to undertake the development and operations of the Project. It was originally organized as a wholly owned subsidiary of Pakistan International Container Terminal Limited (PICT), however following reorganization in 2011; PICT transferred its entire shareholding in PIBT to the then shareholders of PICT. As a result, PIBT was converted into a public limited company and is now in the process of listing on the domestic stock exchanges in compliance with local laws and regulations.
Impact: The Project will: (i) facilitate overall economic growth by further augmenting Pakistan''s transport and logistics infrastructure through development of the country''s first multi-purpose non-food dry bulk cargo terminal; (ii) significantly improve overall efficiency in handling, storage and transportation of non-food dry bulk cargo by way of  faster turnaround of vessels at the port as well as increased efficiency in inland transportation of cargo through road and rail networks; (iii) enable handling and storage of imported coal in Pakistan in an environmentally responsible manner while ensuring high level of safety as per international standards; (iv) provide requisite infrastructure to local cement producers for export of cement in bulk form thus facilitating access to new markets; (v) generate additional revenue for the Government through taxation and royalty and lease payments to Port Qasim Authority (a government owned entity); and (vi) send an important signal of support to local sponsors for development of sustainable businesses in Pakistan during a challenging economic environment.
Environmental Social Issues: The onshore facilities for the proposed project are located on heavily modified land that was allocated by the Government of Pakistan for port and associated industrial and commercial activities 40 years ago. Offshore developments, including a 2.4km trestle bridge and 460m jetty will be located in the Kadiro creek system and contiguous mudflats, which have also been heavily modified as a result of other PQA developments over the past decades. In light of the fact that adverse impacts are not expected to be diverse or irreversible and will be limited to the project site, and mitigation measures can readily be designed to address these impacts, the project has been classified as a Category B.
Sponsor: Sponsors: The Project Sponsors include i) Premier Mercantile Services (Pvt.) Ltd. (PMS), a locally incorporated company wholly owned by Captain Haleem A. Siddiqui and his family members; and ii) individual members of Captain Haleem Siddiquis family including Aasim A. Siddiqui, Sharique A. Siddiqui, Danish A. Siddiqui, and Saba H. Siddiqui. The Sponsors have over 40 years of experience in ports and shipping sector wherein they have successfully developed, operated and managed a number of companies including PICT, which is the 3rd largest container terminal operator in Pakistan.Shareholders: PIBTs ownership prior to IFCs investment will comprise of 62.90% shareholding held by the Sponsors, 21.07% shareholding by Jahangir Siddiqui & Company Ltd, a local investment company, while the balance 16.03% shareholding will be held by general public including institutional portfolio investors and individuals (the Shareholders).
Cost Nature: Total Project cost is estimated at around US$ 186 million. The proposed IFC investment consists of i) A Loan for IFCs own account of up to US$ 26.5 million; and ii) an equity investment of up to US$ 19.1 million. In addition, IFC will also mobilize US$ 20 million as a Parallel Loan.

Project Description: IFC proposes to provide Diamond Bank Plc (Diamond Bank or the Bank) with a subordinated convertible loan of up to US$70 million to support its expansion strategy, strengthen its capital base and enhance its corporate governance and risk management practices. Furthermore, it is expected to send positive signals to the market, aimed at improving confidence within the Nigerian financial sector, as well as with international investors. The Project will also provide the Bank with significant and stable long-term financing to help it grow its business.
Impact: IFC will be providing and mobilizing long term funding and support at times of adverse market conditions. In addition, it will be providing an integrated advisory program that will assist the institution to strengthen its corporate governance.
Environmental Social Issues: The project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  The banks portfolio includes substantial lending to corporate clients in high risk sectors with potential significant adverse environmental or social risks and impacts. The Applicable Performance Requirements for the project are the Exclusion List, the applicable National Laws in Nigeria and the Performance Standards.
Sponsor: Diamond Bank Plc was incorporated on December 20, 1990, and opened for business in March, 1991 as a Private Limited Liability Company. In February 2001, the Bank became a universal bank. In January 2005, following a successful Private Placement and an Initial Public Offer, the Bank became a Public Limited Company and was subsequently listed on the Nigerian Stock Exchange in May 2005. In October 2005, the Bank acquired former Lion Bank of Nigeria Plc. The Bank was also listed on the Professional Securities Market of the London Stock Exchange in 2007, following a successful US$500 million GDR offering.In addition to its banking activities in Nigeria, the Bank established Diamond Bank, Benin in the Republic of Benin in September 2001 as a first step towards expanding activities into French-speaking West Africa. Project Description: This project is proposed under the Global Trade Supplier Finance program (GTSF or the Program) approved by the IFC Board in September 2010. (Original Project Link #28723).Desarrolladora Homex (Homex or the Company), one of the two largest homebuilders in Mexico with a network of approximately 5,000 suppliers. Homex is a vertically-integrated home development company that engages in the development, construction, and sale of entry-level, middle-income, and tourism housing in Mexico, as well as entry-level housing in Brazil.The Project will establish a Supplier Finance (SF) program and make financing available to selected suppliers of Homex, through the discounting of receivables of the suppliers payable by Homex. The SF program will have an IFC-funded, uncommitted credit line up to US$75mn. The program will be implemented through PrimeRevenue, a Supply Chain Finance platform, and its local re-seller, E-Factor Network (EFN), and it is expected to reach 200 Suppliers the large majority of which will be SMEs.
Review Scope: In supplier financing programs of this nature, IFC assesses environmental and social (E&S) risk at supplier level by assessing the Buyers systems for management of E&S performance of their Suppliers. IFC due diligence involved: (i) a review of publicly available information describing Homexs approach to suppliers, which included Homexs sustainability report, ethics code, website, and public information on Corporate Social Responsibility initiatives with suppliers in which the Company has had a significant participation; (ii) a review of internal documents provided by the Company including the procedure for selection of suppliers, contracts with sub-contractors, and assessment questionnaires for the certification of materials and suppliers; (iii) telephone interviews with Homexs team in charge of procurement, research and development and sustainability initiatives; (iv) a review of public information concerning labor, environmental and social conditions in Mexico and in the sectors where the potential suppliers of Homex operate (such as construction materials and construction companies that provide mainly labor services).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Suppliers under this transaction provide a variety of services and goods to Homex including construction materials such as tiles, plumbing, lighting and water fixtures, concrete, windows, appliances, etc and specialized construction labor force (e.g. electrician services, finishing services, etc). Most of the suppliers are small Mexican enterprises.The potential risks, where encountered, are both manageable and site specific. This is therefore considered to be an E&S Category B project.

Project Description: Kongo Coffee Limited (KCL or the Company) is a local Arabica coffee processor and exporter of high quality green bean and small quantities of roasted/ground coffee based in the Highlands of PNG, and has been in operation for over 15 years. KCL is seeking financial support from IFC to improve their working capital position and capital structure, so that they are able to increase their processing volumes and further satisfy strong customer demand.
Review Scope: IFCs environmental and social (E&S) review included the assessment of the Companys technical documentation, regarding environmental, occupational health and safety (OHS), labor, and social performance. Meetings were held in Goroka and in Chuave, Papua New Guinea (PNG), with the CEO/owner, Companys Senior Management, and engineering staff. The scope of the due diligence encompassed: a) Kongo Coffee Limited Head Office and coffee processing facilities in the Chuave district; b) coffee farmer fields in the Mount Elimbari area; c) discussions with the Companys staff working in Extension Services and Environmental Health and Safety (EHS).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This proposed investment is expected to have limited number of environmental and social impacts which are expected to be site-specific, temporary, and none is expected to be significant. Those impacts can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, procedures, World Bank Group (WBG) General EHS Guidelines, and design criteria as described in the following sections. This is therefore a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Sustainability Policy.

Project Description: The proposed Project consists of an equity investment in new shares in National Bank of Vanuatu  (NBV or the Bank) of up to 15% of the Banks share capital following the new shares issuance. Co-investors Asian Development Bank  and Vanuatu National Provident Fund are targeting also to acquire up to 15% each of the Banks share capital following the new shares issuance.  NBV is serving rural and urban clients, both retail and commercial, through its 25 branches across the country.The purpose of the Project is to assist NBV increase its capital base and diversify the Bank''s shareholding to support its future growth and new financial products and services.
Impact: i) Increasing Access to Finance: NBV expects to open new rural branches and expand its microfinance program in 2012, which should further drive access to finance for Vanuatu''s rural population. It is estimated that approx. 80% of Vanuatu''s total population lives in rural areas.  Given high travel costs to access bank branches, only approx. 13% of Vanuatu''s rural population has bank accounts.  Increased access to finance would increase inclusive growth for the larger population.  ii) Promoting Competition: The banking market is dominated by four commercial banks. The strengthening of NBV''s lending capacity will improve its competitiveness in the market. Strengthening of NBV would serve to promote competition within the sector, which would benefit the people of Vanuatu.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social (E&S) Review Procedure. IFC analyzed the FIs portfolio and determined applicable performance requirements to include the IFC FI Exclusion List, applicable national laws and regulations and the IFC Performance Standards (PS).IFC also appraised the FIs labor practices according to the IFCs PS 2: Labor and Working Conditions and reviewed the FIs capacity to manage E&S risks and to establish and maintain a Social & Environmental Management System (SEMS). Based on the review, the project will be required to: ·	Develop or upgrade, if necessary, any existing SEMS, prior to disbursement to the satisfaction of IFC;·	Identify responsible, qualified persons to manage and implement the SEMS (SEMS officer);·	Commit to implement the SEMS, to ensure that its investments/activities supported by IFC financing are in 	compliance with the Applicable Performance Requirements;·	Demonstrate commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: 	Labor and Working Conditions;·	Submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be provided by IFC
Sponsor: Sponsor:Vanuatu Ministry of Finance and Economic Management (MFEM): NBV is currently 100% owned by the Government of Vanuatu. The MFEM is the sole shareholder on behalf of the government and is responsible for the formulation of national economic and finance policies. Co-investors:Asian Development Bank (ADB): ADB is an international development finance institution whose mission is to help its developing member countries reduce poverty and improve the quality of life of their people. Headquartered in Manila, and established in 1966, ADB is owned and financed by its 67 members, of which 48 are from the region and 19 are from other parts of the world. Vanuatu National Provident Fund (VNPF): The VNPF is a compulsory savings scheme for employees who receive a salary of Vatu 3,000 (approximately USD 32) or more per month, to support them financially at retirement. VNPF is responsible for managing members retirement funds.
Cost Nature: ADB, VNPF and IFC are expected to acquire a total of up to 45% of NBVs share capital following the new shares issuance.

Project Description: This proposed project involves an equity investment in a medium sized financial sector company in Bangladesh. The Companys primary business is general insurance providing insurance services to both corporate and retail clients in most large districts of Bangladesh.
Impact: IFC''s support to the Company will enable it to provide increased access to finance for the micro, small and medium entrepreneurs, who are mainly in the unorganized sector and do not have good access to insurance products. The Company is also expected to diversify its product base to have a healthy mix of corporate and retail business.Focus semi-urban areas and targeted products for retail clients: The Company''s growth strategy is focused on the retail sector and semi-urban areas. The Company is expected to increase its semi-urban presence by deepening its existing operations and having a wider network. It intends to reach a larger retail client base through products specifically designed to cater to their needs.
Environmental Social Issues: This transaction involves an equity investment for up to 10% in a Company, which is a leading private sector property and casualty primary insurance provider headquartered in Dhaka, Bangladesh. The company offers a full range of non-life products including fire, property, business interruption, marine cargo, automobile, bankers blanket insurance; cash in transit, and workers personal accident and compensation. Majority of its existing client base is commercial in nature.The project has therefore been categorized as FI in accordance with IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. For this project the client will be required to screen its insurance decisions against the IFC Exclusion List and the Bangladeshi E&S laws and regulations.
Sponsor: The project is a listed entity, and has as shareholders the Sponsor group, FIIs, Corporates, individuals and the public.
Cost Nature: The Company is keen on having an organization of international repute onboard as a shareholder and to support their growth strategy. IFC with its global experience in the insurance sector proposes to acquire upto 10% of the company for a value of upto USD10 million.
Investment: 9.99 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity9.99* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Company has pan Bangladesh operations with a large branch network spread across the country. The Company plans to increase its branch network to have a deeper penetration in the semi-urban areas of the country.

Project Description: The proposed transaction involves a credit enhancement facility to a local bank, which is expected to be in the form of an unfunded partial credit guarantee. IFC will support (a) the PNG Kina 9 million (approximately US$4.25 million equivalent)  renewable annual working capital need for Kongo Coffee Limited to purchase parchment from local coffee growers and (b) the PNG Kina 6 million (approximately US$ 2.84 million equivalent) long term facility for capacity enhancements, overall technology improvements along with processing capacity expansion.IFC will provide an unfunded partial credit guarantee to a local bank, which may result if called upon in a potential direct exposure to Kongo Coffee Limited. It is expected that the level of guarantee will gradually decrease over time. Kongo Coffee Limited is the only coffee processing company based in PNG Highlands. It operates out of its existing processing facilities in Chuave, Chimbu province.
Impact: 1. Income generation for small holder coffee growers: Expanded processing capacity will generate increased demand and therefore income for growers. Growers will have access to a local, price competitive coffee buyer who has capacity to demonstrate a consistent buying pattern, thereby promoting security of income.2. Job creation and upskilling: Additional employees will be required as processing volumes increase, many of which are roles undertaken by women. New machinery and technology will provide the opportunity for the local labour force to develop of new skills.3. Small holder sustainability: The investment is expected to impact up to 500 coffee growers. This may assist in encouraging younger people to continue participating in local businesses, thereby contributing to industry sustainability.4. Rural development: approximately 100, 000 people in  the Chimbu region are heavily reliant on the coffee industry. Growth of KCL''s business will create additional downstream business opportunities for MSMEs including buyers and other related businesses.5.  Improved financial management and corporate governance: IFC''s involvement will provide an opportunity to improve internal systems and broaden management capacity6. Skills training for growers: opportunity for IFC technical assistance such as enabling business training and accreditation courses.
Environmental Social Issues: The project has been categorized as category B according to IFCs Environmental & Social review procedure. This proposed investment is expected to have limited number of environmental and social impacts which are expected to be site-specific, temporary, and none is expected to be significant. Those impacts can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, procedures, World Bank Group (WBG) General EHS Guidelines, and design criteria as described in the following sections. This is therefore a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Sustainability Policy.
Sponsor: Kongo Coffee Limited, a privately held company incorporated under the laws of Papua New Guinea, established in 1990. The company is owned by Jerry and Lilly Kapka.
Cost Nature: The project involves an annual revolving working capital facility of PNG Kina 10.0 million (US$4.73 million equivalent) and a long term loan of PNG Kina 6.0 million (US$2.84 million equivalent) which will be funded by a local bank. IFC will provide an unfunded partial credit guarantee which will gradually decrease over time.

Location: The investment will be located at Portion 1004C, Milinch Goroka, Fourmil Karimui, Wawi Coffee Mill, Okuk Highway, Chuave, Simbu Province, Papua New Guinea

This proposed investment is expected to have limited number of environmental and social impacts which are expected to be site-specific, temporary, and none is expected to be significant.
