Project Description: This project is proposed under the Global Trade Supplier Finance program (GTSF or the Program) approved by the IFC Board in September 2010. (Original Project Link #28723).Tenedora Nemak S.A. de C.V. (Nemak or the Company),  is the worlds leading producer of high-technology aluminum components for the automotive industry.  The companys product lines include cylinder heads, engine blocks, and transmission parts.  Nemak has 27 plants around the globe in Asia (China), Europe (Germany / Hungary / Austria / Slovakia / Czech Republic / Poland), and North (Mexico / USA / Canada) and South America (Brazil / Argentina), producing approximately 43 million units annually. Its clients include some of the largest car manufacturers in the world.  Nemak has over 18,000 employees and is a subsidiary of Alfa S.A.B de C.V.The Project will establish a Supplier Finance (SF) program and make financing available to selected suppliers of Nemak , through the discounting of receivables of the suppliers payable by Nemak. The SF program will have an IFC-funded, uncommitted credit line of US$50mn. The program will be implemented through PrimeRevenue, a Supply Chain Finance platform, and its local re-seller, E-Factor Network (EFN), and it is expected to reach 100 Suppliers the large majority of which will be SMEs.
Review Scope: In supplier financing programs of this nature, IFC assesses environmental and social (E&S) risk at supplier level by assessing the Buyers systems for management of E&S performance of their Suppliers. IFC due diligence involved: (i) a review of publicly available information describing Nemaks approach to suppliers including Alfa, S.A.B. de C.V. (Grupo Alfa)s sustainability report and Nemaks sustainability website; (ii) a review of procurement, human resources, and environmental documentation pertaining to Nemaks requirements of its suppliers; and (iii) a review of public information concerning labor, environmental and social conditions in Mexico and in the sectors where the potential suppliers of Nemak operate (such as raw materials, freight and machinery).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Suppliers under this transaction provide a variety of services and goods to Nemak including logistics, machinery, food services and goods such as raw materials, cylinder liners, tooling and equipment among others. Most of the suppliers are small Mexican enterprises. The potential risks, where encountered, are both manageable and site specific. This is therefore considered to be an E&S Category B project.

Project Description: Equity investment to support business expansion plans for a pan-African banking group.
Impact: The Project is expected to make a significant contribution to the financial sector and economic development in SSA. The Project''s expected development impact in countries and regions where the Group is present is summarized below:(i)	Increase Access to Credit:  The proposed investments in the Group are expected to improve access to credit in SSA as they will enable the bank to maintain and/or grow credit provision to the domestic economies where it operates, including to underserved market segments (e.g., agribusiness, climate change, SMEs and microenterprises); (ii)	Develop the Financial Sector in IDA and Conflict-Affected Countries:  the Group has demonstrated its commitment to IDA and post-conflict countries by strengthening and/or establishing operations in some of the most difficult environments, making it a pillar of financial sector stability in those countries and a link between them and their more stable neighbors;(iii)	Create/maintain employment :  By helping the Group to better serve its clients in the countries within which it operates, the Project will also help generate job opportunities for the bank''s clients thereby creating or maintaining employment opportunities for more  people in the region.
Environmental Social Issues: The project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  The banks portfolio includes substantial lending to corporate clients in high risk sectors with potential significant adverse environmental or social risks and impacts. The Applicable Performance Requirements for the project are the Exclusion List, the applicable National Laws in the countries where the groups subsidiaries are located and the Performance Standards.
Sponsor: Listed entity with multiple shareholders
Cost Nature: IFC Africa Capitalization Fund, Ltd., IFC Capitalization (Equity) Fund, L.P. and IFC ALAC Holding Company II, managed by IFC Asset Management Company LLC, potential investments in the group would be up to US$100 million in equity.
Location: The group operates across Africa with presence in Europe and the Middle East.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  The banks portfolio includes substantial lending to corporate clients in high risk sectors with potential significant adverse environmental or social risks and impacts. The Applicable Performance Requirements for the project are the Exclusion List, the applicable National Laws in the countries where the groups subsidiaries are located and the Performance Standards.

Project Description: Alliance Tire Group (ATG or the Company) manufactures off-highway tires that are used in agricultural, forestry, construction and earth-moving equipment. ATG has a 48,000 tonnes per annum (tpa) plant in India in a Special Economic Zone (SEZ) near Tirunelveli, India that is in the process of being expanded to 61,000 tpa and 35,000 tpa plant near Hadera, Israel. The Company plans to expand its Indian operations via: (i) the construction of a greenfield plant with a capacity of 50,000 tpa in Jhagadia Kharchi Extension in Gujarat; (ii) a further expansion of 29,000 tpa in Tirunelveli; and (iii) the installation of a cogeneration plant at Tirunelveli comprising boiler with 35 tonnes per hour capacity for steam generation and 4.5 MW turbine (the Project).
Review Scope: IFCs review of this investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety (EHS) and social related information submitted by Alliance Tire Group (ATG or the Company) for its operational facilities in India and Israel including: technical details related to its facilities, regulatory permits, organization charts, human resources (HR) policies, training records, safety policies and procedures, safety audit reports, environment, health and safety (EHS) management system manuals, audit reports and certificates and monitoring records including environmental statement submitted to regulatory authorities. The appraisal also included a visit to ATGs operational facility in Tirunelveli in Southern India, and discussions with ATGs senior management, technical and EHS teams  at Tirunelveli site and at the corporate office in Mumbai.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards and guidelines.Environmental and social issues associated with this Project include: adequacy of social and environmental assessment of  construction and operational risks and impacts of the Project; the Companys capacity to manage its social, environmental, health and safety performance, and engage with local communities in accordance with local requirements and IFC Performance Standards and World Bank Group (WBG) environmental health and safety (EHS) Guidelines; assurance of fair, safe and healthy working conditions during construction and operations; utilization of equipment and operational practices that maximize conservation of energy, water and process materials including recycling and reuse initiatives; management of air emissions, wastewater treatment and discharge, and solid and other waste disposal; handling and management of hazardous materials and hazardous wastes; the impacts of operations on local ambient air quality, and impacts on transport infrastructure during construction and operations.

Project Description: Alliance Tire Group (ATG or the Company) manufactures off-highway tires that are used in agricultural, forestry, construction and earth-moving equipment. ATG has a 48,000 tonnes per annum (tpa) plant in India in a Special Economic Zone (SEZ) near Tirunelveli, India that is in the process of being expanded to 61,000 tpa and 35,000 tpa plant near Hadera, Israel. The Company plans to expand its Indian operations via: (i) the construction of a greenfield plant with a capacity of 50,000 tpa in Jhagadia Kharchi Extension in Gujarat; (ii) a further expansion of 29,000 tpa in Tirunelveli; and (iii) the installation of a cogeneration plant at Tirunelveli (the Project).
Impact: 1. Technology transfer and enhancing India''s competitiveness: Innovation and technological ability are critical to the development of off-highway tires, a high-value niche segment of the global tire industry. The Project will increase the competitiveness of the Indian OHT manufacturing sector as a result of shared R & D and technology between ATC India and its associate companies, Alliance Tire Company Ltd., Israel and Alliance Tire Americas Inc., USA.2. Employment generation: The Project will create direct employment for about 850 people. ATG is committed to developing and strengthening its employees'' technical expertise and engineers from each of its Israel and India facilities are often sent to the other location to conduct training. In addition, the Project will create temporary employment during its construction phase.3. Agricultural productivity: Almost 60% of ATG''s sales are to the agriculture equipment sector, where increasing productivity is critical to meet increasing food demand. ATG invests significant resources in its research and development and conducts extensive testing to ensure its tires are designed to increase the productivity of the equipment on which they are used.

ATG is promoted by private equity firm Warburg Pincus, which has a majority stake in the Company and Mr. Ashok Mahansaria and his son, Mr. Yogesh Mahansaria.

Project Description: The proposed investment would support the implementation of the Chuvashias capital expenditure program in the preschool education sector 2012-2014, which includes construction and reconstruction of preschool education facilities (kindergartens) in major cities and smaller settlements. Implementation of the project will increase the coverage of children (1 to 7 years old) by quality preschool education up to 77% from current 68% in the Republic. The proposed IFC investment is a senior loan of up to RUB1.000 million (approximately US$33 million) to the Chuvash Republic.
Review Scope: The Chuvash Republic is an existing IFC client. To date, IFC has concluded 3 transactions with Chuvash Republic (Project ID 24582, ID 25835 and ID 27786). The Environmental and Social (E&S) reviews of the earlier investments were disclosed on IFCs Disclosure Portal. The existing investments are regularly supervised and their E&S performance has been determined to be in material compliance with at-approval agreements. IFCs review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information submitted by Chuvash Republic (the client) in relation to the Project, including:List of preschool education centers (kindergartens) to be (re)constructed in 2012-2013 with identified locations and occupant loads;Design documentation for sample kindergartens;The clients response to IFCs E&S questionnaire.  In March 2012, IFCs E&S specialist conducted a visit to Chuvash Republic, where a number of meetings with Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Construction and Ministry of Education were held to discuss E&S aspects of the Project.Particular attention was given to comparison of local Life and Fire Safety (LFS) construction standards with World Bank Group (WBG) Environmental Health and Safety General Guideline requirements. A meeting with representatives of major Chuvash design contractors was organized to discuss local regulations and design practices. Also IFC has engaged with an independent international LFS consultant to understand principal gaps between local standards and the NFPA requirements, which are used as an example of an internationally-accepted fire safety code.  These gaps should be addressed in the Projects design. As part of appraisal visit, the E&S specialist also visited two kindergartens - one of which is under construction in the City of Tsivilsk (240 children) and the other has been recently reconstructed and put in operation in the City of Cheboksary (210 children), to get an impression on practical implementation of local construction and operation standards.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The potential adverse environmental, health and safety (EHS) impacts of construction and operation of preschool education centers are limited and can be largely mitigated and, hence, this Project is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.

Project Description: The privately owned Farmsecure (Farmsecure or the Group) was formed in 2004 to provide scientific farming, insurance risk mitigation, working capital and marketing services to grain farmers. Since then, the Company has continued to grow both organically and through acquisitions and currently contracts and or partners with farmers on approximately 140 000 hectares on which they farm about 650 000 tons of grains and oilseeds (approximately 7% of South Africas grain production), raise 100 000 heads of cattle and farm 3 200 hectares of fruit across the nine provinces of South Africa. The Company is currently considered to be an innovative participator and service provider in the areas of, agri-inputs, primary agriculture and agri-outputs through its contracting of and partnerships with large-scale farmers in South Africa.Farmsecure operations can be mainly broken down as follows: Farmsecure Fruit and Fruit Growers; Farmsecure Grains and Livestock; Farmsecure Technologies (Farmsecure Carbon, Pro Gas Solutions, Kynoch Fertilizer, etc); and Farmsecure Global Markets. Farmsecure has recently entered the fruit sector in own production and packaging. It manages about 15 million cartons of fruits a year (of which own production accounts for 6 million cartons). Under the grain contract-farming model, Farmsecure provides pre-harvest working capital through a Contract Farming agreement with selected farmers. Through this Contract Farming agreement, Farmsecure establishes conditions for scientific implementation of the production, working capital, insurance, including weather risk cover, and marketing of the grains to be produced. The Company agrees with the farmer, among other parameters, on farming practices (including scientific farming) to be applied to ensure maximization of the yields (under the supervision of Farmsecure Agri Science). Under the livestock contract-farming model, the Company provides selected farmers with working capital towards purchasing young animals to raise/fatten-up for sale to a slaughter house. As with crops, Farmsecure agrees with the farmers on best veterinary practice to be applied to ensure maximization of the weight of the animal at slaughter (under the supervision of Farmsecures animal scientists).In 2011, Farmsecure introduced Farmsecure Optimized Farming (FOF) an enhanced variant of the original grain contract-farming model. FOF, which is the Companys preferred model going forward, currently covers 55 farmers compared to 352 farmers in the contract farming model. In this model, Farmsecure signs a long term farming and lease contract with the farmer (as opposed to the annual contract under contract farming). Farmsecure takes over the farming operations and the farmer is employed to farm on behalf of Farmsecure. Thus, Farmsecure is more hands-on in terms of monitoring farming operations and as a result has a better control over the application of best farming practice.Farmsecure Carbon, which is 100% owned by Farmsecure Technologies  a subsidiary of Farmsecure, is a project development and consultancy Company for greenhouse gas emission mitigation and renewable energy in the agricultural sector and on farm level. Farmsecure Carbon currently has a portfolio of more than 20 waste-to-energy projects, which include processing of by-products into fertilizer, in various stages of development.. Kynoch Fertilizer is a leading importer, blender and retailer of a complete range of granular, liquid and specialty fertilizers in Southern Africa. Kynoch is the exclusive distributor of Yara Internationals premium products in Southern Africa and sells around 400 000 and 100 000 tons of fertilizer annually in South Africa in the rest of Southern Africa respectively. Pro Gas is an inputs supplier of Nitrogen in the form of direct ammonia application in South Africa and in the Southern Africa region. Pro Gas is estimated to sell 4 000 tons of liquid ammonia annually.The IFC investment (the Project) consists of an up to 500 million South African Rands ($64mn) funded risk participation in Standard Chartered Bank South Africa (SCB or the Bank) financing facility to Farmsecure. The Project will enable SCB to increase its exposure to Farmsecure while the Group expands its operations in and potentially outside of South Africa
Review Scope: The IFCs environmental and social due diligence of this project included the review of available Farmsecures corporate and operations specific environmental and social documents, including review of Coastal & Environmental Services Environmental and Social Scoping/Due Diligence for Agro-Industries Services South Africa, Final Report, August 2011, prepared for Deutsche Investitions- und Entwicklungsgesellschaft mbH, Cologne, Germany (DEG). Site visits were undertaken to Kynoch Fertilizer dry blending plant, Novo Fruit Packhouse and Theewaterskloof Fruit Farm in the Western Cape province, and to a Farmsecure Optimized Farming grain farmer in Bethlehem in the Free State province. Several meetings were also undertaken with Farmsecure Senior Management Team at the Companys head office in Cape Town, Farmsecure Grains/Farmsecure Livestock head office in Bethlehem, and with Standard Chartered Bank (SCB) in Johannesburg.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The project has been categorized as a Category B according to IFCs Environmental and Social Sustainability Policy because none of the impacts are regarded to be significant. Any impacts arising as a result of the project can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to the well enforced relevant South African national legal and regulatory requirements. A number of acts, such as the National Environmental Management Act (NEMA), National Water Act, Conservation of Agricultural Resources Act, Occupational Health and Safety Act, and Labor Relations Act, are used to guide practice, as well as various international best practice standards which are in line with IFCs Performance Standards. Impacts will also be managed through Farmsecures ESMS which will incorporate a comprehensive environmental and social due diligence procedure to evaluate prospective farming operations to ensure their compliance with host country national legal and regulatory requirements, IFCs Performance Standards and relevant World Bank Group (WBGs) Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines.

Project Description: The proposed investment would support the implementation of the Chuvashias capital expenditure program in the preschool education sector 2012-2014, which includes construction and reconstruction of preschool education facilities (kindergartens) in major cities and smaller settlements. Implementation of the project will increase the coverage of children (1 to 7 year olds) by quality preschool education up to 77% from current 68% in the Republic.
Impact: The project is expected to improve access to essential pre-school education services in the Republic by increasing the number and capacity of the centers for preschool education. The project is also expected to improve the quality standards of pre-school education in the Republic available to local population.
Role: The proposed investment will provide the Republic with long-term (up to 10 years) local currency financing that is currently not available from commercial banks and capital markets. IFC financing will enable the Republic to speed up its investments into essential social infrastructure, which otherwise would be significantly delayed or downscaled.
Sponsor: The Chuvash Republic is IFCs existing client. It is one of the 83 regions in the Russian Federation, located approximately 650 kilometers east of Moscow with a population of 1.25 million people. The Republics Gross Regional Product per capita is approximately twice below of national average. The Republic is classified as frontier region by IFC. Chuvash economy is fairly diversified with significant importance of agricultural sector. Local industry includes machinery and metalworking, chemical manufacturing, electrical engineering, and food processing. The Republic has an international credit rating from Moodys of Ba2, the current outlook is stable. The Republics total revenues demonstrate moderate growth and reached RUB30.8 billion (US$1.05 bn) in 2011.
Cost Nature: The total capital investment program of the Chuvash Republic in preschool education sector 2012-2014 is estimated at RUB 3 173 million (approximately US$ 105 million).The proposed IFC investment is a senior loan of up to RUB1 000 million (approximately US$33 million) to the Chuvash Republic. The maturity of the loan is up to 10 years, including 2-year grace period. IFC loan will help the Republic to finance an important part of its overall capital expenditure program in 2012-2014 related to the preschool education. IFC financing would cover up to 32% of the capital investment program of the Chuvash Republic in construction of preschool education centers and about 10% of the Republics total capital investment program in 2012-2014.
Investment:
30.17 million (USD)

Risk Management

* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Project investments will be implemented in the Chuvash Republics capital Cheboksary and a number of other cities and small city settlements within the Republic.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The project is a category B investment according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The key issue for the proposed investment is an adequate level of Life and Fire Safety (LFS) at newly constructed kindergartens. World Bank Group (WBG) Environmental Health and Safety General Guideline requires that all new buildings accessible to the public should be designed, constructed and operated at full compliance with both local codes and regulations; and in accordance with an internationally accepted LFS standard. To meet this requirement, Chuvash Republic will incorporate additional features in building design, where international standards are stricter, to better protect building occupants in case of emergency. A summary of IFCs environmental and social review findings for the project including the rationale for the B categorization is publicly available in the ESRS disclosed through IFCs external website: http://www.ifc.org/projects.

Company Name: FAWRY FOR BANKING AND PAYMENT TECHNOLOGY SERVICES SAE
Project Description: Fawry for Banking and Payment Technology Services SAE (Fawry, the Company), is the first and largest electronic bill payment platform (EBPP) in Egypt. The Company was established in 2008 with the objective of facilitating payments on a ubiquitous electronic platform. Its extensive network footprint with more than 10,000 points of presence allows (a) consumers to pay bills or top-up their mobile phones and (b) businesses to pay for goods and services.  Fawry has invited IFC to invest up to [US$6.0] million in equity to finance the Companys growth and help support the Company in (i) continued expansion of its network within Egypt, (ii) service and product development and (iii) sales and marketing (together the Project). The Project would result in 16,000 additional points of presence and number of new products offerings, including business to business (B2B) payments.
Impact: The project will have the following development impacts:- Create an efficient, reliable collection infrastructure for billers;- Provide consumers with a convenient, reliable and secure payment option;- Facilitate trade by reducing transaction costs and overcoming geographic barriers; - Extend financial inclusion by reaching unbanked populations with limited access to traditional banking services; and- Signal to the market, that Egypt has viable and innovative early stage companies that can attract venture funding.
Role:
IFC''s additionality in the proposed investment will be as follows:
- Supporting the growth of the nascent Electronic Bill Processing sector in Egypt during a period of political uncertainty;
- Providing Fawry with global industry knowledge by drawing upon experience in a wide range of industries that depend on payments;
- Offering guidance on Fawry''s expansion strategies as the Company looks to scale up operations in other markets;
- Investing as a strategic partner in an early stage venture company in a market with limited financing options as other commercial financiers withdraw or reduce their exposure to Egypt;
- Leveraging IFC''s extensive relationships in the market with financial institutions, retailers, and other corporate clients to build the Companies network.
Sponsor: The Company is 29.1% owned by Raya Holding (Raya); 25.3% by Technology Development Fund II (TDF II) (together the Sponsors).  16.0% of the Company are owned by prominent commercial banks in the country (HSBC, Bank of Alexandria and Arab African International Bank); 14.1% by Fawry management; 6.6% by System Engineering of Egypt. The remaining 8.8% are owned by individuals.  Raya is one of the largest IT services company in Egypt with over 3,000 employees and branches in Saudi Arabia, the Gulf, Algeria, Nigeria and the USA. 49% of Rayas shares are publically traded on the Egyptian Stock Exchange (EGX) and 51% are owned by individuals and investment funds.   TDF II is a US$ 50 million venture capital investment fund managed by Ideavelopers, subsidiary of EFG-Hermes.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$15.5 million equivalent for the expansion of the distribution network through new points of presence, authorized dealers and retail stores.  The proposed IFC investment is a [US$6.0 million] in equity for IFCs own account.

Project Description: The Project consists of an up to R500mn (~$65mn) funded risk participations in Standard Chartered Bank South Africa (SCB or the Bank) financing facilities to the Farmsecure group of companies (Farmsecure or the Group), for the provision of pre-harvest working capital to contracted farmers in grains and livestocks and own production in fruits. The facilities also cover other working capital needs of the Group. Among others, the financing facility will be used for input financing (e.g. seeds, fertilizer, agrochemicals), purchase of weaner calves/lambs for rearing and payment of insurance premiums and other marketing expenses.
Impact: Farmsecure is having a significant developmental impact by promoting a more productive and sustainable agri-business model in South Africa. The Project is expected in turn to make a significant contribution to South Africa''s rural economic development, as well as to global food security by increasing access to sustainable and profitable farming structures for farmers.This means that Farmsecure''s focus includes the empowerment of farmers with scientific farming skills, agricultural knowledge and technologies, and hands-on support to assist farmers in fulfilling their maximum potential both in terms of yield and revenues, positioning the Company ahead of the field in the region''s agricultural development.Farmsecure works on a commercial farming basis with a long term goal to further develop small scale farming supported by the infrastructure of sustainable commercial farming.
Environmental Social Issues: The project has been categorized as a Category B according to IFCs Environmental and Social Sustainability Policy because none of the environmental and social impacts are regarded to be significant. Any impacts arising as a result of the project can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to the well enforced relevant South African national legal and regulatory requirements. A number of acts, such as the National Environmental Management Act (NEMA), National Water Act, Conservation of Agricultural Resources Act, Occupational Health and Safety Act, and Labor Relations Act, are used to guide practice, as well as various international best practice standards which are in line with IFCs Performance Standards. Impacts will also be managed through Farmsecures Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) to be developed as part of IFCs investment. The ESMS will incorporate a comprehensive environmental and social due diligence procedure to evaluate prospective farming operations to ensure their compliance with host country national legal and regulatory requirements, IFCs Performance Standards and relevant World Bank Group (WBGs) Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines.
Sponsor: Farmsecure is an active participant and specialized agribusiness service and input provider operating in South Africa. Its core business is development and optimization of farming enterprises through its contracting and farmer partnership schemes which include the provision of services for the mitigation of climatic risk (through insurance) and price risk (through hedging). Farmsecure also provides farmers with technical advice and crop marketing. Farmsecure''s main business segments are: (i) grain production, (ii) livestock, (iii) own fruit production and fruit exports, (iv) distribution of fertilizers, and (v) provision of technical services.Farmescure is owned by four shareholders: (i) The Jerogene Trust, a trust related to the Yazbek founder family (40,95%), (ii) The Trio Farms Trust, a trust related to the three founder executives: Schalk Lubbe, Johnny Maass, and Erick de Klerk (20,25%), (iii) the Sameer Group (28,8%), a major Kenya based conglomerate with interests in agriculture, banking, construction and IT sectors controlled by Mr. Naushad Merali; and (iv) Deutsche Investitions- und Entwicklungsgesellschaft mbH (DEG), a subsidiary of the German promotional bank KfW a German investment and development company focusing on investments in  emerging markets (10%).
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC funded risk participation in SCBs financing is capped at R500 mn. IFCs maximum participation would not exceed 50% of SCBs total facilities to Farmsecure. The IFC participation will have tenor of one year and be renewable up to two times.

Project Description: The proposed project comprises an IFC investment in a subordinated convertible bond to be issued by Banca Transilvania S.A. (BT or the Bank)  a long standing client of IFC. BT is the third largest bank in Romania with total assets of EUR6 billion, equity of EUR537 million, and net income of EUR54 million as of the end of December 2011. This new IFC investment is aimed at supporting a bank committed to fulfill the funding needs and  is designed to strengthen the Banks capitalization.
Environmental Social Info: The bank applies Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) to screen the loans against the IFC Exclusion List, and applicable environmental and social national laws and regulations.  During the appraisal, IFC analyzed the Banks pipeline and portfolio, and review the capacity of the bank to manage social and environmental risks and to undertake E&S due diligence in line with IFCs policy requirements. Based on the analysis of the potential social and environmental risks, the bank will be required to ensure compliance with the IFC''s Exclusion List, Host Country Laws and Regulations, and IFC Performance Standards for high risk projects.
Impact: Specific positive developmental impacts are expected to be:(i) Strengthen the capital base and adequacy of a systemically important bank in Romania, and do so in a more efficient manor than raising Tier I capital. In light of the difficult economic context, a strong capital base is very important, not only because it will reduce the solvency risk for the Bank, but it allow the Bank to consolidate its position on the market.(ii) Allow the Bank to continue to grow its loan portfolio. In the absence of this investment, the Bank could be required to reduce its loan portfolio growth, reduce its exposure to riskier asset classes or increase Tier I capital, which would be costly at this stage. (iii) Demonstrate the ability of a domestic Romanian bank to attract investments from international investors in difficult financial times; and bolster depositors'' confidence in the banking sector of Romania by signaling IFIs'' continuing support and commitment to the Romanian banking sector.

Project Description: The proposed project will likely consist of IFC loan financings in RMB to Jiangsu Financial Leasing Co., Ltd (JFLC or the Company) to support its business growth and improve its financing structure.  JFLC, established in June 1985, is a leading financial leasing company in China and an existing IFC client.
Environmental Social Info: The main E&S risks and impacts of the project derive from the E&S risks of the companys leasing activities, the capacity and systems in place to manage these risks, and the companys practices with regard to labor and working conditions. Under the requirements of the existing IFC investment, the company has appointed an E&S officer and developed an E&S policy that is commensurate with its leasing activities. The policy also requires the company to heighten its E&S review and monitoring when providing leasing to businesses of potential high E&S risks such as large infrastructure development projects, although its portfolio doesnt appear to have exposure to such activities. To improve the implementation of its E&S policy, the company is suggested to incorporate in its operations manual an E&S screening procedure and to conduct training for its staff. The companys labor management was found to be consistent with the requirements of IFC Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working conditions.
Impact: Expanding access of finance to SMEs: SMEs contribute significantly to China''s GDP growth but have been under-served by commercial banks.  The growth of JFLC, an SME focused leasing company, can help address the SMEs'' financing difficulty by providing flexible alternative channels;Supporting economic growth in frontier regions: Frontier regions have much lower financial service penetration in China. In light of the credit tightening in China, leasing addresses the local demand for funding, supports the continued growth of local economy, and thus mitigates widening gap between frontier regions and coastal regions;Promoting the development of the leasing sector: Leasing penetration is only 3.8% in China. IFC''s further investment in JFLC will have a strong development impact in promoting the development of leasing sector in China.  JFLC has maintained a sound business record and is expected to further improve its risk management capability. JFLC could become a model institution for other leasing companies to emulate, with a demonstration effect to stimulate the healthy development for the entire leasing sector.
Role:
Local currency funding: IFC can provide long-term local currency funding to the Company, which is not easily accessible locally but critical to the sustainable growth of leasing companies;

Strategic long-term partnership: IFC acts as a critical strategic investor that can provide both equity investment and long-term debt financing to the Company, the latter is particularly important to the company in light of the current macro environment;

Stamp of approval: IFC''s further investment to the Company can help the Company raise long-term funding from local banks by setting a model case and enhance the Company''s image in the investment community.

Project Description: The Project is to provide a senior loan to Prasac MFI Ltd. (Prasac/ the MFI), a growing MFI in Cambodia, to support them in providing micro finance solutions to over 126,000 small businesses and individuals (over half which are women) in Cambodia. Through this project, we aim to support the MFIs the long-term fund raising strategy and also set a positive demonstration impact for other lenders to do the same. The proposed project consists of a senior loan of up to US$5 million with maturity of up to 7 years (grace period of up to 3 years). The loan aims to help Prasac support its loan growth which has been steadily increasing.

Company Name: RENEWGEN ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION KOTTE PVT LTD
Project Description: RenewGen Enviro Ventures India Pvt. Ltd. is a developer focused on the waste disposal market in and around South Asia. In order to facilitate the development and operation of such projects in the region, the decision has been taken to establish a holding company, as the Sponsor, in Singapore. The Sponsor would hold a portfolio of waste disposal and waste to energy projects in South Asia. The developer has secured the first competitively awarded Waste to Energy concession in Sri Lanka from the Waste Management Authority of the Western Province in Sri Lanka (WMA). The project is a 25 year concession to build own and operate a 10MW waste to energy project in the Western Province of Sri Lanka. The project will process up to 580MT/day of municipal solid waste (MSW) and will generate up to 10MW of electricity which will be sold to the grid. The concession will be undertaken by Renewgen Environment Protection Kotte Pvt Ltd ('Renewgen Kotte' or 'Company'), a company incorporated in Sri Lanka.  The Ceylon Electricity Board will off-take the power generated from the plant. The project will use a highly proven (deployed in over 400 plants worldwide) grate based mass incineration technology that is suitable for unsorted MSW in conjunction with advanced emission control systems. The Company will use grate based mass incineration technology (suitable for unsorted MSW) and has tied up with Hitachi Zosen to be the technology partner. The technology is the most widely deployed and commercially proven globally (60% global market share) and Hitachi Zosen is a global leader in the WTE segment with a strong presence in both Europe and Asia having executed more than 450 WTE plants worldwide. The project consultant is Ramboll AG, a leading European engineering firm with experience in over 50 WTE plants, and will be responsible for advisory (concept to commissioning) and project management during execution. The EPC turnkey contractor is Hyquip Technologies Ltd., an Indian EPC company based in Hyderabad, India, which has extensive experience in working on power plants using biomass as feedstock.The total project cost is estimated at US$ 29 million. IFC is considering providing a financing package of up to US$ 9 million consisting of equity (IFC Project #31944) and debt (IFC Project #32295) at both the Sponsor and Company level.
Review Scope: The scope of review of RenewGen's compliance with IFC's Performance Standards included assessment of RenewGen's management capacity of its environmental, social, health and safety performance in relation to IFC Performance Standards, national (Sri Lanka) regulatory requirements and relevant Environmental Health and Safety guidelines. The review relied on documents and reports made available by RenewGen, and interviews conducted by IFC staff. Meetings and interviews with staff focused on business development, operations, human resources, environmental, social, health and safety aspects of the business. Since this is RenewGen's first venture, the need for the Company to develop relevant procedures to augment the Company's existing management capacity to provide adequate oversight of its environmental, social, health and safety performance in conducting its business were discussed. The IFC team also had meetings with the Waste Management Authority (WMA), visited local government offices, various Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) handling and sorting facilities, and the site for the proposed MSW Waste to Energy (WTE) facility at Kaduwela, Western Province in Sri Lanka.Discussions with government officials on the environment and social impact assessments focused on scope and processes for establishing community acceptance of WTE projects; baseline health monitoring and communication of potential risks to human health from WTE projects (in addition to compliance with regulatory standards for air quality) as part of the community consultation process was also discussed. MSW incineration and WTE has been used interchangeably in the review, but refer to the same basic process of mass burning of municipal solid waste with an added energy recovery component. Hitachi Zosen Inova (HZI), which is the technology provider for the project has provided confirmation that the proposed WTE project at Kaduwela can achieve emission performance standards established by the European Union (Directive 2000/76/EC and relevant Annexes/Amendments), applicable IFC/WB guidelines for incineration of MSW, and  relevant national emission standards established by the Central Environment Authority, Sri Lanka (Nov 2011), as well as ESIA approval requirements for the operation of the project facility at Kaduwela.The scope of this review includes IFC's proposed equity investment (IFC Project #31944) and debt (IFC Project #32295) in RenewGen Enviro Ventures India Pvt. Ltd. and the Kaduwela project company Renewgen Environment Protection Kotte Pvt Ltd.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFC's Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because the projects currently undertaken by the Company will create a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that can be minimized, avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria. Waste treatment services provided by the Company help in the management of municipal solid waste using contemporary technology that meets performance standards established by the European Union (Directive 2000/76/EC and relevant Annexes/Amendments), and applicable IFC/WB guidelines for incineration of MSW. Additionally, the Company will work with the local government on a best effort basis to help establish a relevant baseline, and develop a community heath monitoring program for long term exposure to byproducts of MSW incineration.
Sector: V-BI - Waste to Energy - Renewable Energy Generation

The project will process up to 580MT/day of municipal solid waste (MSW) and will generate up to 10MW of electricity which will be sold to the grid. The concession will be undertaken by Renewgen Environment Protection Kotte Pvt Ltd (Renewgen Kotte or Company), a company incorporated in Sri Lanka.  The Ceylon Electricity Board will off-take the power generated from the plant. The project will use a highly proven (deployed in over 400 plants worldwide) grate based mass incineration technology that is suitable for unsorted MSW in conjunction with advanced emission control systems. The Company will use grate based mass incineration technology (suitable for unsorted MSW) and has tied up with Hitachi Zosen to be the technology partner. The technology is the most widely deployed and commercially proven globally (60% global market share) and Hitachi Zosen is a global leader in the WTE segment with a strong presence in both Europe and Asia having executed more than 450 WTE plants worldwide. The project consultant is Ramboll AG, a leading European engineering firm with experience in over 50 WTE plants, and will be responsible for advisory (concept to commissioning) and project management during execution. The EPC turnkey contractor is Hyquip Technologies Ltd., an Indian EPC company based in Hyderabad, India, which has extensive experience in working on power plants using biomass as feedstock.The total project cost is estimated at US$ 29 million. IFC is considering providing a financing package of up to US$ 9 million consisting of equity (IFC Project #31944) and debt (IFC Project #32295) at both the Sponsor and Company level.
Review Scope: The scope of review of RenewGens compliance with IFCs Performance Standards included assessment of RenewGen''s management capacity of its environmental, social, health and safety performance in relation to IFC Performance Standards, national (Sri Lanka) regulatory requirements and relevant Environmental Health and Safety guidelines. The review relied on documents and reports made available by RenewGen, and interviews conducted by IFC staff. Meetings and interviews with staff focused on business development, operations, human resources, environmental, social, health and safety aspects of the business. Since this is RenewGen''s first venture, the need for the Company to develop relevant procedures to augment the Companys existing management capacity to provide adequate oversight of its environmental, social, health and safety performance in conducting its business were discussed. The IFC team also had meetings with the Waste Management Authority (WMA), visited local government offices, various Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) handling and sorting facilities, and the site for the proposed MSW Waste to Energy (WTE) facility at Kaduwela, Western Province in Sri Lanka.Discussions with government officials on the environment and social impact assessments focused on scope and processes for establishing community acceptance of WTE projects; baseline health monitoring and communication of potential risks to human health from WTE projects (in addition to compliance with regulatory standards for air quality) as part of the community consultation process was also discussed. MSW incineration and WTE has been used interchangeably in the review, but refer to the same basic process of mass burning of municipal solid waste with an added energy recovery component. Hitachi Zosen Inova (HZI), which is the technology provider for the project has provided confirmation that the proposed WTE project at Kaduwela can achieve emission performance standards established by the European Union (Directive 2000/76/EC and relevant Annexes/Amendments), applicable IFC/WB guidelines for incineration of MSW, and  relevant national emission standards established by the Central Environment Authority, Sri Lanka (Nov 2011), as well as ESIA approval requirements for the operation of the project facility at Kaduwela.The scope of this review includes IFCs proposed equity investment (IFC Project #31944) and debt (IFC Project #32295) in RenewGen Enviro Ventures India Pvt. Ltd. and the Kaduwela project company RenewGen Environment Protection Kotte Pvt Ltd.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because the projects currently undertaken by the Company will create a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts that can be minimized, avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria. Waste treatment services provided by the Company help in the management of municipal solid waste using contemporary technology that meets performance standards established by the European Union (Directive 2000/76/EC and relevant Annexes/Amendments), and applicable IFC/WB guidelines for incineration of MSW. Additionally, the Company will work with the local government on a best effort basis to help establish a relevant baseline, and develop a community heath monitoring program for long term exposure to byproducts of MSW incineration.
Sector: V-BI - Waste to Energy - Renewable Energy Generation

Company Name: VIETNAM TECHNOLOGICAL AND COMMERCIAL JOINT STOCK BANK
Project Description: The purpose of the project is to support Technological Joint Stock Commercial Bank (Techcombank or the Bank) in providing USD liquidity to its trade-oriented SME clients. The proposed investment is an IFC A loan of up to US$30 million with a maturity of up to 12 months, renewable twice (3 year life in total) upon the Bank fulfilling conditions of renewal. The IFC financing will further support the Bank to provide financing to trade-oriented SMEs in Vietnam for their exports, imports and working-capital needs.
Environmental Social Info: The main E&S risks and impacts of the project derive from the E&S risks of the Banks lending activities, the capacity and systems in place to manage these risks, and the Banks practices with regard to labor and working conditions. Under the requirements of the existing IFC investment, the company has appointed an E&S officer and developed an environmental and social management system (ESMS). The ESMS, among other things, requires the company to screen all investments for E&S issues and to undertake a more thorough E&S due diligence for projects with potential medium to high E&S risks and impacts. The companys labor management was found to be consistent with the requirements of IFC Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working conditions.
Impact: The Facility is expected to have the following specific development impacts:(i) Increased Access to FCY Financing for SMEs: Limited access to finance is considered a key constraint to private sector growth. Increased access to finance is indispensable to grow the competitiveness of SMEs. By directly financing the short term USD liquidity needs of Techcombank, the Facility will support trade-oriented SMEs for their exports, imports and working capital needs, eventually support the sustainable economic growth of Vietnam.(ii) Job Preservation in an IDA Country:  The Facility is expected to have a positive impact on job preservation by partially bridging the foreign currency liquidity gap in trade-oriented businesses. This is especially important in an environment where a large number of SMEs have been severely affected by the continuing financial crisis. Financial support to SMEs is thus critical to employment preservation in adverse market conditions.  Hence, the Facility will have a direct impact on job preservation and employment generation through Techcombank''s financing provided to private companies.
Role:
(i) Market Stability: Similar to other local banks, Techcombank has seen increasing need for short-term USD funding as international banks have been cutting down on their exposure to Vietnam. The State Bank of Vietnam ("SBV") has been enforcing administrative measures in an attempt to enhance the availability of USD for export oriented businesses. Therefore, IFC''s intervention will be to contribute to and support the Government''s effort in bringing stability to foreign currency borrowing by enterprises for foreign trade-related purposes.
(ii) Mobilization Effect: In addition to the strong signaling effect of this Facility, IFC potentially can play a mobilizing role by bringing other financial institutions to participate in the financing.
Sponsor: Techcombank, is the second largest private joint stock bank (JSB) by assets as of December 2011, operating through a network of 307 branches and transactional offices. It offers a comprehensive range of banking services primarily to SMEs, households, and individuals. Techcombanks total loans and assets grew fast during 2005  2010, which was fueled by Vietnams strong economic growth. The bank has slightly slowed down its loan portfolio growth since 2011 due to the high interest environment and the cap of credit growth of 20% by State Bank of Vietnam.  Techcombanks financial strength is rated D- by Moodys and D+ by S&P.	As of December 31, 2011, Techcombanks total assets amounted to $8.7bln, representing a growth of 20% (in VND terms). The net loan portfolio grew 19.6% (in VND terms) to approximately $3bln equivalent. Techcombanks major shareholders are Masan Group (19.7%), HSBC - Techcombanks strategic partner (19.6%); Eurowindow Holding JSC. (4.8%), PetroVietnam Finance Company (PVFC) (3.1%), Vietnamairlines (2.7%) and Eurofinance Joint Stock Company (2.6%). Techcombank is an issuing bank under IFCs Global Trade Finance Program (GTFP) since 2007.

Project Description: This greenfield project consists of approximately US$20 mn investment to construct a steel fabrication plant in the state of Gujarat, near Halol, 45 km north of Vadodara, with an annual capacity of 25,000 tons. The plant will manufacture in roughly equal quantity for transmission & distribution (T&D) projects and metallic support structures for the cylindrical parabolic solar collectors (CPC) and heliostats in concentrated solar power (CSP) projects that will be developed in India. Eucomsa and Comemsa, both existing Abengoa companies with steel fabricating plants in Spain and Mexico, will provide expertise and know-how, taking advantage of synergies between Inabensa Bharat Pvt. Limited (IBPL or the Company) and existing operations.
Review Scope: For the environmental and social appraisal of this project, IFC specialist undertook interviews with senior executives of IBPL and visited the site of the proposed plant near Halol in the state of Gujarat. The Company completed IFCs environmental and social questionnaire and furnished additional information and documentation to supplement the data provided
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Key E&S issues reviewed during appraisal include: management of environmental, health and safety performance at ongoing operations and during the construction of the new production lines; water and energy efficiency of the production processes; air emissions from combustion facilities and metal cutting, forming, welding and finishing processes; waste management; treatment and discharge of liquid effluents; and life and fire safety, including emergency preparedness and response. Labor conditions, occupational safety and community safety were also reviewed as is described in the following sections.

Project Description: The greenfield project is to construct a steel fabrication plant in the state of Gujarat, near the city of Vadodara with an annual capacity of 25,000 tons. The plant will manufacture in roughly equal quantity steel structures for transmission & distribution (T&D) projects and metallic support structures for the cylindrical parabolic solar collectors (CPC) and heliostats in concentrated solar power (CSP) projects that will be developed globally, including in India and neighboring countries.
Impact: Inabensa Bharat''s operations will support the construction of solar energy plants globally by providing a necessary component in the form of the solar panel structure, thereby encouraging the use of clean energy and reducing CO2 emissions through the implementation of clean energy plants.  In addition, Inabensa Bharat will support improvements in the infrastructure supply chain through the increased manufacture and sale of transmission towers across Asia, the Middle East and Sub-Saharan Africa to meet growing demand.  As a result of increased focus on transmission capability in India, energy access is expected to improve.   Finally, the project will support job creation in India, both during the expansion and operation of the facility, a key objective for the Indian government.
Role: IFC will support Inabensa Bharat through the provision of long term finance to support development of a greenfield manufacturing plant in India and the acquisition of technology and equipment to improve its delivery of components along the renewable energy and infrastructure supply chains in India and other countries in Asia, Africa and the Middle East.  This expansion will enable Inabensa Bharat to establish a stronger presence in India, allowing it to bid for and win turnkey projects in India with companies such as Power Grid. The India plant will also be able to supply solar steel structures to Abengoa''s solar projects globally. IFC will provide technical support to Inabensa Baharat to ensure compliance with IFC''s Environmental & Social Performance Standards.   IFC''s support of a subsidiary of Abengoa SA, a leading global player in the area of sustainable energy, will reinforce IFC''s long term strategic partnership with Abengoa SA, supporting the group''s growth plans in emerging markets both in the manufacturing space as well as the downstream implementation of clean energy. While Abengoa is a large group with good banking relationships, Abengoa is relatively highly leveraged and growing in areas IFC would like to encourage and support.  As such, the Group will continue to require long-term funding sources in Emerging Markets, providing an opportunity for further collaboration between IFC and Abengoa in the future.
Sponsor: Inabensa Bharat Private Limited (Inabensa Bharat) is a 100% owned subsidiary of Abengoa S.A. (the Sponsor), a Spanish infrastructure conglomerate operating since 1941, and one of the top global players focusing on technology and engineering solutions for sustainable development.  The group has 5 core businesses: Solar, Bio-energy, Environmental, IT and Engineering & Construction

Project Description: Recaudo Bogota, S.A. (the Company or Opportunity) is Bogotas Fare Collection and User Information and Service Systems concessionaire (SIRCI) for the new Integrated Public Transportation System (SITP). It is responsible for the integration and implementation of the system as well as for the commercialization of the Contact-less Smart Cards that will support the systems fare collection. Recaudo will also provide real time data to support monitoring and control of the systems bus fleet and real time transportation and fares information to users, bus operators and TransMilenio.  Bogotas bus-based transportation system is undergoing a massive overhaul. The ownership structure of the privately provided transport service is changing to allow 13 operators to take over from over 14,000 owner-operators of buses in an effort to introduce better quality standards, uniformity, transparent and adhered-to schedules and higher safety. The change can only be made possible by a further consolidation of fare collection and logistics through a common platform provided as a service by Recaudo Bogota starting July 2012. The common platform will allow the ultimate manager of the service, city-owned Transmilenio, to better manage this large and complex system that will comprise of multiple fleets of over 16,000 buses running 500+ routes and carrying over 4.5 million passengers daily.
Impact: a. Reduce the number of buses in the system by about 7500 buses, all of which old, below safety and environmental standards; b. Reduce accidents and death-by accident rates related to buses; c. Reduce congestion and traffic gridlocks; d. Improve labor conditions for most of today''s driver-owners. Reduce working hours from 13-14 / day to 8 per day, receive stable income, social security, health insurance and other benefits; e. Improve quality of service in the public transportation system of Bogota. Provide predictable, scheduled service, run buses that are of superior quality than the ones currently in use. f. Increase transparency in the system which will result in better cost and remuneration allocation;  g. Recaudo will make a system of transfers possible, reducing total cost of ridership to all those users of the system that today transfer from bus to bus and pay multiple fares for each destination; h. Recaudo will make it possible for Transmilenio to manage the systems more efficiently by providing live information on traffic conditions, bus unavailability, break-downs, maintenance schedules, etc; i. Recaudo will help improve the security in the transit system by allowing Transmilenio to better monitor key stations and by availing bus drivers with an SOS system for all emergencies.j. Recaudo''s fare and recharge infrastructure will take cash out of the transport system, eliminating all the other inefficiencies that come with it - waiting lines, slow bus mounting procedures, pilfering, etc.
Role:
a. SITP is very politically sensitive, therefore potentially unstable operating environment. IFC presence will alleviate some political risk.
b. IFC has an important role providing needed long term financing and mobilization for a project that is key to the success of the new public transportation system in Bogota. Local Commercial banks have participated in the financial closings of SITP bus operator concessions for an estimated US$ 1.2 billion. The collection concession was awarded after the bus operator concessions and local banks feel they have enough exposure to the SITP and do not have appetite to increase it substantially. The Company was pursuing lenders separately (including ECAs). IFC''s suggestion to help arrange the entire financing was welcomed, especially given the timeframe pressures.
d. IFC will support new foreign investors in the country that are doing South-South expansion (Korean and Chilean investors).
e. IFC has the local flavor and knowledge in transport to understand the SITP underlying risks and the global expertise in evaluating payment systems, that will provide comfort and a stamp of approval for B lenders.
d. IFC has deep experience with payments systems outside transport. Given the enormous user base, IFC is hopeful that the system can be converted into a major sustainable business outside the concession. IFC will help conceptualizae and set up an executable base for this endeavor.
Sponsor: The Project''s sponsors are GPS group, citymovil, LG CNS and Land Developer. The project''s shareholders are citymovil colombia, whose majority shareholder is citymovil chile (60%), LG CNS (20%) and Land Developer (20%). The sponsors and shareholders bring a good mix of financial and technical skills, and critical elements of success such vast experience in concessions, transport systems, and fleet management. LG CNS, a AA+ rated subsidiary of LG Holding of Korea, is Recaudos technological partner responsible for the system implementation and operation.
Cost Nature: Project cost is estimated at US$278 million including: (i) the construction of the technology platform, (ii) the integration with the existing Bus Rapid Transit Systems collections system and (iii) financial expenses during implementation period.  IFC has been retained to secure the total financing of US$175 million including an A loan of up to US$35 million and a C loan of up to US$25 million, equivalent to 22% of total project cost. The remainder of the funds is expected to come from a mix of B/parallel loans, export credit agencies (ECAs) and local or international commercial banks.

Project Description: The IFC will provide a financial facility to Credins Bank (the Bank) to finance projects for investment in energy efficiency (EE) and renewable energy (RE) in Albania. IFC is considering supporting the project with financing from the Canada Climate Change Program, a donor-funded facility for climate change friendly projects. IFC also provides advisory services (AS) to the Bank in financing of housing EE renovations in Albania and will consider enhancing its existing AS support with this project.
Environmental Social Info: During the appraisal, IFC analyzed Credins Banks portfolio, and reviewed its capacity to manage social and environmental risks and to undertake E&S due diligence in line with IFCs policy requirements. IFC also appraised Credins Banks and labor policies against IFC''s Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working Conditions. The key challenge in this investment  will be for Credins Bank to manage the E&S risks associated with the activities of its borrowers in line with IFCs policy requirements, and to screen borrowers against the activities on the exclusion list. Credins Bank will be required to develop and implement an Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) that screens against the IFC Exclusion List, ensures compliance with national environmental and social laws, and meets the requirements of IFC''s Performance Standards for high risk projects.
Impact: The Project is expected to generate a range of environmental and economic benefits related to the development of sustainable energy finance and related investments. The development impact of the Project is expected to be significant in the following areas:* improving the competitiveness of the Albanian economy by increasing the efficiency of energy use across sectors,* facilitating the development of energy efficiency investments among residential and potentially SME clients and targeting to generate a minimum decrease in per unit energy consumption >15% (kWh/unit (m2, production).* increasing lending for RE projects in Albania, with specific focus on small hydro power plants, provided that at least EUR 15 million would be financed, and app. app.15 MW newly installed* improving the local and global environment through decreased emissions of greenhouse gas and other conventional pollutants while reducing the country''s dependence on energy exports.
Role:
IFC''s main role in this project is to build strong partnership with leading local bank. using combination of IS and AS in order to develop financing climate change positive investments in Albanian economy. IFC will provide essential advisory support to client to build EE/RE lending expertise and offer tools for RE project evaluation, monitoring and tracking energy savings and GHG emissions. By the dedicated term funding IFC will support growth of bank''s portfolio in energy efficient and renewable energy projects. IFC''s additionality in this project includes:
* Providing long term funding at commercial rates supplemented by donor funds in order to facilitate entry of the bank into sustainable energy finance business in Albania.
* Sharing global expertise in climate change investments which would further add upon Credins''s experience in this sector, with particular focus to Small Hydro Power Projects.
* Strengthening focus to EE/RE finance on Albanian market with strong demonstration effect on overall banking sector.
Sponsor: Credins bank is one of the leading banks in Albania, offering a wide range of products and services to corporate, SMEs as well as retail customers in Albania.  Credins Bank was founded in 2003 as the first 100% local-owned bank in Albania. The Bank remains to be largely owned by local shareholders. In 2008, two foreign shareholders namely, Balkan Financial Sector Equity Holding B.V., represented by Development Financial Equity Partners (DFE) and State Secretariat for Economic Affairs (SECO), acquired stakes in the Bank.

Project Description: As part of IFCs multi-faceted global financial crisis response, Global Trade Liquidity Program (GTLP) is being extended in order to address the current liquidity needs in the market which is affecting the availability of trade finance funding for emerging markets.  Under GTLP, IFC is considering a total investment of up to $1 billion, which will be match-funded with resources from other development finance institutions (DFIs) and international financial institutions (IFIs) as well as several international banks with an established footprint in emerging markets trade finance.IFCs premiere crisis response initiative, GTLP is a unique global public-private partnership (PPP) collaboration with 20 partners, public and private, that brings together governments, development finance institutions, and private sector banks to support trade in developing markets in order to address the shortage of trade finance resulting from the global financial crisis.  Significant achievements have been made to date: 5 global deal of year awards, total program disbursements almost $4 billion (DFIs $1.3 billion, IFC $0.6 billion, and banks $1.9 billion) financing over $20 billion of trade transactions financed with zero losses, and over 80 percent benefiting SMEs, and more than 30 percent supporting low-income and lower middle income countries.  Funding for this crisis response program came from development institutions and governments, and it worked through over 200 global and regional banks to extend trade finance ultimately to SMEs.  GTLP provides IFC and its partners with a proven foundation of experience, a partnership platform, and lessons that can be leveraged to develop other innovative solutions to tackle global strategic priorities such as supporting the financial sector, SMEs and agriculture.  The Project is the extension of a funded facility for IFC and funding partners (DFIs and IFIs) to provide trade financing of up to $500 million to Standard Chartered Plc (SCB or the Bank) headquartered in London, United Kingdom, as part of IFCs GTLP Extension.
Impact: The project is expected to have a significant development impact by increasing funding for trade of consumer goods, intermediate goods, smaller machinery and commodities demanded by emerging market enterprises.
Role: IFC''s global franchise in financial markets will be critical to the project''s success in leveraging trade volumes, expanding new markets and facilitating the growth of south-south trades.
Sponsor: Founded in 1853 and formed through the merger of the Standard Bank of British South Africa and the Chartered Bank of India, Australia and China, SCB operates in 71 countries and has been present in Hong Kong, China, Korea, Singapore, India and other key financial markets for more than 150 years.  SCB has over 1,500 branches and over 86,000 employees.  SCB has made a strong commitment to the trade finance sector and has integrated this business into its core business model.  Formal organizational arrangements for strategy development, marketing, credit risk approval and workouts have been established.
Cost Nature: As part of IFCs Global Trade Liquidity Program Extension, IFC is considering providing funding for up to $500 million to SCB with the objective of channeling liquidity for funded trade financing to clients of SCB.

Project Description: IFC proposes to invest in Ujjivan Financial Services Private Limited (Ujjivan or the Company), which is a leading Microfinance Institution (MFI) in India.Ujjivan is amongst the few large MFIs that focus on providing micro loans to women borrowers in urban and semi-urban areas. Its target customers include self-employed women working as vegetable or fruit vendors, small shop owners, sari sellers, tailors etc; salaried women working in garment factories, hospitals, cooks, house maids, and piece rate workers involved in incense stick rolling, tailoring etc. Ujjivan today has about 1.1 million members and a loan portfolio of about US$140 million equivalent. Ujjivan has over the years, established itself as one of the most customer centric institutions with a strong emphasis on responsible lending and good HR practices. The proposed project intends to help Ujjivan fund its expansion and  carry out strategic & operational changes in order to cope with the changed regulatory and business environment, and meet its regulatory capital adequacy requirements for the next 3-5 years.
Impact: 1.	Increasing access to finance in low income states in India, including states in the northern and eastern parts of the country which have amongst the highest population densities and poverty rates in the country2.	Promoting a more balanced growth of microfinance by supporting an institution that been a front-runner in adopting technology, is a pioneer in focusing on consumer service and responsible financing and offers customized products for various financial and non financial needs of its members
Role:
1. Institution Building: IFC''s assistance would help Ujjivan to strengthen and expand its operations, diversification of product offerings, strengthening management capacity and corporate governance practices. IFC is a leading global provider of funding in microfinance and will play a key role by leveraging its relationships with other MFIs and MFI networks around the world to transfer knowledge of microfinance and introduce microfinance sector best practices to Ujjivan.
2. Demonstration Effect: IFC''s entry is expected to build confidence in the MFI sector post the AP crisis, and have a demonstration impact by catalyzing other investors, network partners and stakeholders to support Ujjivan''s expansion over the medium term. IFC''s investment would underline the faith in the sustainability of the microfinance business post the changed regulatory investment in addition to building investor confidence in the low income states towards provision of financial services to the BoP.
3. Diversification of Funding: IFC''s investment will help the Company diversify sources of funding by providing comfort to potential lenders and investors.
Sponsor: Ujjivan was founded by Mr. Samit Ghosh who has been an international banker for over thirty years and was part of the pioneering team which launched consumer banking in India at Citibank in 1985. He led the launch of retail banking for Standard Chartered in the Middle East and South Asia, and for HDFC Bank in India. His last assignment, before starting Ujjivan was as CEO of Bank of Muscat. He is an alumnus of Jadavpur University and the Wharton School of Business, USA. Apart from Mr. Samit Ghosh, his friends and professional colleagues, other shareholders include foreign individual investors, Bellwether, AW Holdings, Michael and Susan Dell Foundation, India Financial Inclusion Fund, Unitus, Elevar, Sequoia Capital, Lok Capital Group, FMO and Wolfensohn Capital Partners.

Project Description: Virgin Mobile Latin America (VMLA or the Sponsor) has Mobile Virtual Network Operator (MVNOs) licenses in Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru, and has filed for license in Uruguay, Bolivia, Brazil and Argentina. VMLA has recently launched operations in Chile.  IFC will be providing up to US$11 million C loan to fund Virgin Mobile Chile SpA (VMC or the Company).  VMC will be offering mobile phone services targeting the youth segment with a targeted offering that will expand mobile broadband usage with attractive data packages.
Impact: The Project is expected to have the following development impacts: i. Greater availability, affordability & accessibility of mobile services: Mobile Virtual Network Operators ("MVNOs") contribute towards expanding reach, lowering the cost and increasing competition in mobile telephony. Besides voice services, VMLA''s product offering will support further expansion of mobile broadband, particularly in niche markets that have not been successfully served by traditional Mobile Network Operators ("MNOs"). Particularly, VMLA will target the youth market which has more limited purchasing power than other population segments.  In this regards, VMLA is positioning itself as the first pan-LAC MVNO, targeting the youth sector with highly segmented and tailored voice and data offerings.ii. Efficiency gains in the telecom industry through the sharing of infrastructure: The concept behind MVNOs is the sharing of telecoms infrastructure with existing mobile network operations (i.e, VMC will use Movistar''s network to provide its services). The specialization enables the use of existing spare capacity for niche markets through the sharing of infrastructure, ultimately contributing to generate greater efficiencies of the telecom industry overall.iii. Greater availability of broadband services (mobile in this case) and innovation: Greater access to mobile broadband is expected to contribute towards improving productivity and generate economic efficiencies. The contributions of broadband connectivity to economic growth, and as a kick-starter of other innovative business models (e-health, e-education, e-commerce, etc.), are widely accepted.
Role:
i. Long term financing: IFC support of Chile''s VMLA greenfield operation in the form of long term is critical, as the company is embarking on rolling out multiple operations across the region in an international context of high financial volatility. Success in Chile, its first launch, is important in terms of eventually rolling out in other countries.

ii. Stamp of Approval: MVNOs are common in Europe and US, but the concept is still largely untested in LAC. As such, new entrants face difficulties in raising non-recourse financing for greenfield operations. Furthermore, traditional financiers do not fully understand the MVNO business model. IFC involvement in the project will assist in validating the business model for other investors, allowing future mobilization of resources to this industry segment.

iii. Knowledge sharing/replication: VMLA sees value in a financial partner who understands the mobile sector and recognizes the potential of MVNO business model viability in LAC. In addition, IFC will provide sector expertise and regional knowledge.
Sponsor: VMLA is a privately-owned company. The Virgin Group, one of the worlds leading MVNO brands,  provides VMLA and its subsidiaries with the use of the Virgin Mobile brand name, as well as close support from current and former Virgin Mobile senior executives in business strategy, product design, marketing, sales distribution, customer support, technology, wholesale agreement negotiations and public relations. The Virgin Group has pioneered the MVNO business model with over 15M customers in 7 countries (UK, US, Canada, France, India, South Africa and Australia). The shareholders of VMLA are Virgin Group with 10.6%, ePlanet Capital with 19.3%, Hermes Growth Partners with 14.8%.  The remainder is held by individual investors and the founding partners (i.e., Tribe Mobile executives).
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is in the form of a C Loan of up to US$11 million.  Together with Sponsor equity, IFC funds will help the Company to roll-out operations across Chile.  Additionally, the Sponsor has raised approximately US$28.5 million following 2 rounds with institutional investors which more than funds the Chile peak funding of $22 million.
