Project Description: The proposed project envisages an equity investment in Equitas Holdings Private Limited (Equitas or the Company) which is the holding company for a leading microfinance institution, Singhivi Investment and Finance Private Limited (Equitas Microfinance) headquartered in Chennai, India and amongst the top 10 MFIs in India. Equitas Microfinance has a borrower base of 1.2 million across 5 states and 1 union territory including the Low Income States of Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh.  Equitas has also started recently businesses in the areas of affordable housing (Equitas Housing Finance Private Limited) and used commercial vehicle financing (Equitas Finance Private Limited) to cater to the relatively unbanked population in these financial services segments with a view towards financial inclusion. Equitas is widely acknowledged for following best practices in responsible financing and corporate governance.  Equitas also has a strong focus on using technology and process innovation to increase operational efficiency through implementation of a scalable system for IT infrastructure. The proposed project intends to help Equitas fund its geographical expansion, scale up new businesses and meet its regulatory capital adequacy requirements for the next 3-5 years
Impact: 1.	Access to Microfinance by expanding the outreach of Equitas in several of the poorer states in India, where the Company would scale up in the next few years. 2.	Access to Finance for Affordable Housing and Used Commercial Vehicle Financing to people engaged in the informal sector for affordable housing and used commercial vehicle financing, several of whom are currently underserved by the formal banking system.   Clients who avail finance for purchase of second hand commercial vehicles would be able to open up a livelihood opportunity for themselves and their families and turn from being a driver to an owner.  The housing finance company helps people who run businesses in the informal sector to plan for and buy a house at current prices.  Typically such people are almost fully excluded from the formal financial sector.3.	Promoting a more balanced growth of microfinance by supporting an institution that has been a front-runner in adopting technology, is amongst the pioneers in best practices on responsible financing, takes a very active part in sector development and is working to provide varied financial services to customer segments which have limited access to formal sources of finance.
Role:
1. Institution Building: IFC''s assistance would help Equitas in its expansion in the low income states and help the company to further reduce cost of intermediation, achieve higher client outreach, offer diversified products as well as build best practices in the areas of risk management and responsible financing.
2. Demonstration Effect: IFC''s entry is expected to build confidence in the Microfinance sector and have a demonstration impact by catalyzing other investors, network partners and stakeholders to support Equitas''s expansion over the medium term. IFC''s investment would underline the faith in the sustainability of the microfinance business post the changed regulatory environment in addition to building investor confidence in the low income states towards provision of financial services to the BoP.
3. Diversification of Funding: IFC''s investment will help the Company diversify sources of funding by providing comfort to potential lenders and investors. This investment is expected to help the company broad base its profile of investors with long term perspectives.
Sponsor: Equitas was founded by Mr. P.N. Vasudevan who has been involved in consumer financing for over 20 years in Cholamandalam Finance where he was a VP and the Business Head.  His last commercial assignment, before starting Equitas, was as Executive Vice President and Head of Consumer Banking at Development Credit Bank.Apart from Mr. Vasudevan, other shareholders include SIDBI, Sequoia Capital, Bellwether, Aavishkaar Goodwell, IFIF, Microventures, CLSA, Canaan, Aquarius and Helion.

Project Description: SRF Limited (SRF or the Sponsor), is a large company with three main businesses: 1) Technical Textiles (Nylon and polyester tire cord fabric, belting coated and laminated fabrics); 2) Chemicals (Refrigerant gases, Chloromethanes, fluorospecialities); and 3) Packaging Films, is setting up a greenfield plant, SRF Flexipak (South Africa) (Pty) Ltd (hereafter referred to as SRF Flexipak, in eThekwini, South Africa to manufacture 26,000  ton per annum (TPA) bi-axially oriented polypropylene (BOPP) with a  5,700 TPA metallizer. SRF Flexipak will import or purchase polypropylene chips locally and extrude/stretch polypropylene to manufacture BOPP film. The total investment is about US$67 million.  The Sponsor has requested IFC to provide a loan of US$40 million to fund the Project.
Review Scope: The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health, safety, and social information submitted by the project sponsor, and undertaking a field visit in March 2012. IFC reviewed the proposed production processes and environmental and social impact assessment. The environmental and social (E&S) appraisal team visited the proposed project site located in eThekwini Metropolitan Municipality, Cato Ridge, KwaZulu-Natal province, South Africa. The E&S team also held meetings with the companys E&S advisor and management teams.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The proposed project site is located inside an abandoned airport within an area that has been designated an industrial zone by the local government. There is no farmland or residential area near the proposed project site. There are no areas of biodiversity value at or near the project site. The environmental and social impact assessment (ESIA) predicts that air emissions and wastewater effluents can meet both local regulatory requirements and World Bank Group (WBG) Environmental Health/Safety (EHS) Guideline limits upon successful implementation of the proposed mitigation methods. Mitigation measures for the potential environmental and social impacts have been identified and are incorporated into an attached Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP).The potential adverse E&S impacts of this project are therefore few in number and limited to project site and may be readily mitigated. Thus, this is an E&S Category B project.
Sector: G-CB - Man-Made Fibers (Including Nylon, Polyester, Rayon, etc.)

Project Description: SRF Limited (SRF), a large Indian producer of packaging films, is setting up a greenfield 26,000 ton per annum (TPA) bi-axially oriented polypropylene (BOPP) and 5,700 TPA metallizer plant in Durban, South Africa, to produce packaging films catering to various industries including food production and distribution, at a cost of about US$67 million (Project).
Impact: (i) Import substitution: Currently, South Africa imports around 20,000 TPA BOPP plain films.  The BOPP films produced by this Project will lead to import substitution and eventually facilitate the growth of the local economy.  (ii) Job creation: The Project is expected to create more than 200 new jobs during construction and operation.  Furthermore, additional jobs will be created through auxiliary services, through the life of the Project.(iii) Environmental and social best practice: A successful implementation of IFC''s Environmental & Social (E&S) standards will serve as an example which other chemical companies might emulate.(iv) Knowledge transfer: SRF''s experience in India and IFC''s technical advice will allow the Sponsor to transfer knowledge of efficient plant management and operations to Africa.
Role:
(i) Demonstration effect of a South-South investment: The Project will facilitate a South-South investment and its success could encourage other Indian companies expand overseas and in Africa in particular.
(ii) Long-term foreign currency loan: SRF values IFC''s ability to offer long-term US$ financing, which is not available from local banks.
(iii) Long-term partnership opportunities: The success of this Project could lead to other mutual investment opportunities as the Sponsor further expands overseas.

It is listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) and National Stock Exchange (NSE) in India. 50% of the company is held by the Bharat Ram family, while 50% is owned by the general public including Foreign Institutional Investors, Mutual Funds, Banks and DFIs.

Project Description: The Trans Oil group of companies (T-O), a leading integrated agro-industrial group focused on grain origination trading and oilseed crushing in Moldova, is seeking financing to support (i) its capital expenditure program, including capacity expansion, energy efficiency investments and environmental upgrades; (ii) its acquisition of five additional elevators and an 88.9% stake in Moldovas leading oilseed processor, Floarea Soarelui (FS, and together with T-O, the Group); and (iii) refinancing of short term debt to strengthen its capital structure (collectively, the Project).  The Project cost is US$110 million. IFC is considering an investment up to US$70 million in the Group to involve a combination of A, B and C Loans. The balance of the Project will be financed with equity from the Sponsor, and internal cash generation.Agro-industrial activities of the Group include farming, grain handling and storage, flour and vegetable oil production, as well as international grain trading. The Group is presently the largest grain trader in Moldova in the following commodities: corn, wheat, sunflower, and barley. More than 90% of the grain volume collected in Moldova by the Group is exported to Turkey, Middle East, North Africa and European Union.
Review Scope: IFCs technical review included meetings with Trans Oil senior management, including corporate Human Resources Manager and general coordinator, plant managers and engineers, facilities environmental and occupational health and safety (EHS) officers. Site visits to Trans Oil group of companies headquarters in Chisinau, newly acquired Floarea Soarelui Oil Seed Crushing Plant and Refinery in Balti, Trans Oil Refinery and Aur Alb Grain Elevator (80,000 MT) in Ciadir Lunga, Trans Cargo Terminal in Giurgiulesti and Elevator Kelley Grains (135,000 MT) in Causeni.E&S documents reviewed during the appraisal process included the following: environmental certifications, technical authorization documents for industrial safety, sanitary authorizations, employment data and permanent/contractor worker contract samples, job descriptions and specific work permits and instructions, waste and wastewater contracts, laboratory accreditation certificates/lab rules and instructions, air emission authorizations, fire, safety and emergency reports, ISO 9001 certificate for Floarea Soarelui, environmental and social audit report and action plan prepared by independent third party - Mott Mac Donald for EBRD, September, 2011), dust explosion risks /audit reports prepared by Mica Environmental Ltd for Elevator Kelley Grains - Causeni and Trans Cargo Terminal - Giurgiulesti (May, 2011).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The Project has limited potential adverse environmental and social impacts, and those that do exist are site-specific and can be resolved through the effective implementation of the action items in the ESAP, which integrate the IFCs Performance Standards requirements and good international industry practices as defined in World Bank Group (WBG)s general and applicable sector-specific (Vegetable Oil Processing) Environmental, Health and Safety requirements. This corporate-level investment is therefore a Category B project according to IFCs Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability.

Company Name: KIPAS KAGIT SANAYI ISLETMELERI ANONIM SIRKETI
Project Description: Kipas is a well-known business group in Kahramanmaras Province, Turkey, with interests in textiles, cement, energy and agribusiness. In order to take advantage of the growth of the packaging industry in Turkey, Kipas is currently planning to invest in a EUR260 million recycled fiber based greenfield corrugated paper and cardboard facility with a capacity of 450,000 to 480,000 tons per annum depending on the product mix (Project).  Kipas Kagit (Company), a Kipas subsidiary, will undertake the project.  The Project will use 100% wastepaper as raw material.  The Project will use recovered paper (RCP), old corrugated containers (OCC) and mixed waste paper, as raw material.  The Project includes installation and operation of (i) Paper Machine (PM) - 1,536 ton/day gross, efficiency 85%, 350 days/year - corresponding to annual production capacity of 450,000 to 480,000 ton per year,   (ii) Recycled Fiber (RCF) Plant - 1,500 bone dry tons/d - corresponding to Paper Machine production of 450,000 to 480,000 tons per year, and (iii) 50 MW (gross) coal-fired Circulating Fluidized Bed (CFB) boiler Combined Heat and Power (CHP) plant.The CHP plant will be a captive plant providing heat and power to the paper mill operation with high energy efficiency.  The net electricity output of the CHP plant will be around 45 MW, of which about 33 MW of electricity will be provided to the Project, and 7.5 MW of electricity for the forthcoming expansion of the Paper Machine expected to be developed within a few years with additional 150,000 ton per year production capacity, resulting in the total electricity demand of 40.5 MW.  The remaining generation capacity represents contingency over these initial estimates, to allow for production peaks and future capacity expansion from paper machine development.  The CHP plant will also supply about 132 MW heat for the Project and the forthcoming expansion of the Paper Machine.  The CHP plant will be fueled by a mixture of local coal procured from Turkish coal market and imported Russian coal.  Being the combined heat and power operation, the overall energy efficiency of the CHP plant is estimated to be around 70%, much higher than the electricity only CFB boiler power plant.  The ash and the flue gas treatment by-products will be 100% utilized by Kipass cement factory.  The CFB boiler will have limestone injection plus flue gas desulfurization system to control sulfur dioxide emissions.  The Project will be located in a small town of Kilili in the Turkoglu County of Kahramanmaras Province.  The nearest village of Kilili is about 500 m from the site.  The area of 328,000 m2 has been reserved for the Project and future forthcoming expansion.  Out of 328,000 m2 land, 128,000 m2 of the land is owned by the Company, and 200,000 m2 of the land is currently leased from Kipas Holding subsidiary Maren Maras Elektrik Uretim A.S.  The Company plans to purchase this plot at a later stage of the Project development.  No physical relocation or economic displacement of people will be involved.The raw materials and products will be transported by about 350 trucks (owned and operated by third party service providers) to and from the Project site, which is located right next to the major highway (D825).The Project is expected to employ around 400 people during the construction phase and 300 people for the operational phase.
Review Scope: Documents reviewed:- Kipas Kagit Uretim Fabrikasi Ve Enerji Santrali (50MW) Entegre Projesi, CED Raporu, Ekim 2011 (EIA for Integrated Project of Kipas Kagit Production Plant and 50 MW Power Plant) (in Turkish)  - Viability Assessment of Kipas Papers Containerboard Investment Plan in Turkey, March 23, 2012- Kipas Paper Industry Enterprises Inc.  Paper Production Plant Feasibility Report (PM1), January 16, 2012- Kipas Paper Industry Enterprises Inc.  Paper Production Plant Feasibility Report (PM2), January 16, 2012Site visits:  Visit to the project site and its surrounding areas, conducted by IFC staff in February 2012.Meetings and discussions in February-April 2012:- KipasKagits General Manager about the overall environmental and social strategy and the Project.- KipasKagits officers in charge of technical, environmental, health and safety (Chemical Engineer, Environmental Engineer and Assistant Coordinator) about the environmental assessment, resource efficiency and pollution prevention measures, and health and safety management.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The Project to use recycled paper to produce corrugated paper and cardboard will contribute to the countrys overall recycling rate of wastepaper.  The Project involves a 50MW captive lignite-based CHP plant.  The CHP plant will have high energy utilization efficiency.  The Company plans to adopt various best available techniques to minimize environmental impacts of the paper production including the CHP plant.  Based on this, the Project has limited potential environmental adverse impacts and is a category B project in accordance with IFC Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability.

Project Description: The proposed project involves a funded risk participation of up to US$250 million where IFC with support from bilateral and multilateral organizations, and governments and government/development agencies (collectively the Program Partners) will participate in a portfolio of up to $500 million in eligible RMB trade assets originated by multiple Chinese issuing banks (mostly private sector) and confirmed or discounted by Standard Chartered Bank (SCB). This Project will cover eligible import and export trade transactions between China and mostly other emerging markets (the Project), with a two-year maturity and one year renewal option. The proposed project is a direct fit with IFC China strategy of facilitating trade and investments between China and emerging markets, supporting SMEs by providing exporters and importers from developing countries, a new currency option to manage their trade flows and promoting South-South collaborations. The project is part of IFCs Global Trade Liquidity Program (GTLP) and seeks to broaden the scope and impact of the program while contributing to developing a strong mitigation mechanism to current and future disruptions to trade finance stemming from currency volatility and availability.
Impact: The Project is expected to have strong development impacts. First, it will contribute to the development of more market driven solutions for RMB-based trade settlement, with a stronger focus on small private sector Chinese banks (importer-side) and emerging markets (exporter-side). Second, it will contribute to increasing currency availability and reducing volatility risks in international trade, especially at times of crisis like the ongoing Euro-zone crisis, by diversifying the options available to both importers and exporters. Finally, the Project will help attract other global players to the RMB-based trade settlement markets with emerging markets.
Role: IFC''s additionality in the Project lies in: (i) the strength of IFC''s trade finance programs including the GTFP and the GTLP programs; (ii) IFC''s investment experience in China''s financial markets; and (iii) IFC''s strong partnerships with potential Program Partners and other global financial institutions that places it in a unique position to contribute to the sustainable development of the RMB-based trade finance markets.
Sponsor: Standard Chartered Bank is a leading international banking group operating for over 150 years in some of the world''s most dynamic markets and earning more than 90 per cent of its profits in Asia, Africa and the Middle East. With 1,700 offices in 70 markets, the Group offers exciting and challenging international career opportunities for nearly 87,000 staff. It is committed to building a sustainable business over the long term and is trusted worldwide for upholding high standards of corporate governance, social responsibility, environmental protection and employee diversity as expressed in its brand promise, Here for good. Standard Chartered PLC is listed on the London and Hong Kong stock exchanges as well as the Bombay and National Stock Exchanges in India.http://www.standardchartered.com
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $250 million, of which IFC is providing funded risk participation for up to $250 million backed up by an unfunded guarantee by potential Program Partners of up to $150 million.  The proposed project would support a trade finance portfolio of $500 million.

Company Name: KIPAS KAGIT SANAYI ISLETMELERI ANONIM SIRKETI
Project Description: Kipas Kagit A.S, a subsidiary of the Kipas Group, is embarking on a new project to set up a recycled fiber based greenfield corrugated paper and cardboard facility,  with a capacity of 450,000- 480,000 tons per annum (tpa) in Kahramanmaras, Turkey. Through its corrugated cardboard investment, Kipas intends to take advantage of the growth of the packaging industry in Turkey, in particular in the South and Eastern parts of the country.
Impact: The project will create additional employment through 300 additional jobs in Kipas and indirectly in related fields, notably waste paper collection in a frontier region of Turkey. The project will increase the use of recycled paper and in turn improve the domestic waste paper recovery rate, especially in a frontier area. Moreover, the project will result in the production of high quality cardboard through the use of the most recent technology in the industry that will help substitute for imports. Kipas Kagit will also supply corrugators in the food packaging container business that contribute to improved efficiency in food distribution and ultimately lower costs, thereby helping with food security.The project will also be integrated with an on-site co-generation plant. It is expected that the waste ash from the co-generation plant will be used in the cement operations of Kipas.
Role: By providing long-term financing for a sizeable project at a difficult time in global markets, IFC will be assisting in the growth of the corrugated paper industry and the development of a competitive business group in a frontier region of Turkey. Kipas could also benefit from IFC''s industry expertise as it diversifies into a new sector and IFC''s environmental and social (E&S) guidelines and performance standards, which encourage more robust E&S assessment and management system and best practice to achieve higher resource efficiency.
Sponsor: The Kipas Group (the Sponsor or Kipas) is a well-known business group in Kahramanmaras, Turkey with operations in textiles, cement, energy, agribusiness and education with an estimated total turnover of USD 750 million. Kipas was set up in the mid-1980s by the Oksuz (58% shareholding) and Gumuser (42% shareholding) families, which have since maintained a strong partnership, enhanced by the formation of Kipas Holding A.S. in 1985. The Group employs approximately 6,000 people and is the largest tax payer in Kahramanmaras.  Kipas has several companies ranking in the top 500 and the subsequent 500 corporations in Turkey, including Kipas Mensucat AS, Kipas Denim A.S. and KCS K.Maras Cimento A.S.. With demand for corrugated paper and cardboard in Turkey rising steadily, Kipas Group has decided to diversify into corrugated cardboard production. Kipas has formed a new company, Kipas Kagit A.S. (or the Company), which will be the operating entity for the project. Kipas Kagit is owned by various Kipas Group companies as follows: Kipas K.Maras Iplik Pamuk Tic.A.S.(35%), Erdem Tekstil Tic.A.S (30%), Kipas Mensucat Isletmeleri A.S. (15%), Kipas Holding A.S. (10%), KCS K.Maras Cimento A.S. (10%). Erdem Tekstil is a joint venture between Kipas and the Buyukerzurumlu family, also from Kahramanmaras.

The Company''s diversified product offerings would also lead to increased access to affordable housing finance across India which has a much lower penetration of mortgage finance as compared to other emerging markets.

Project Description: Muyuan Foodstuff Co, Ltd is a large-scale, integrated, farrow-to-finish intensive pig breeder and hog producer located in Neixiang County, Henan Province, China. Since the establishment of the first hog farm in 1992, the business has seen progressive expansion.  IFC previously made an equity investment in Muyuan in 2010. Currently Muyuan operates 17 farms, including two boar station, breeder farms (great grandparent, grandparent and parent farms) and hog farms. The farms occupy a total area of 427.55 ha, with individual farm sizes ranging from 0.43 ha to 109.5 ha. In addition, Muyuan operates one feed mill in Guanzhang Town with an annual production capacity of 400,000 tons.  Eight facilities are currently under construction; two feed mills and six farms (including those at Wolong and Dengzhou). Muyuan previously partnered with Shandong Longda Group Limited (Longda) to establish a slaughter house with a processing capacity of 1 million hogs per year (i.e., 3,000 hogs/day). The slaughter house is a dedicated facility designed to process mainly Muyuan pigs with Muyuan owning a 40% stake. Individual farms are located away from local communities in rural areas in the agricultural Neixiang County. The majority of the land area of each farm is occupied by housing for the pigs.  Pigs are provided with on-demand feed and water, the former deriving from silos located outside each unit.  Pigs are provided with slatted floors allowing for the collection and storage of solid waste and urine below the unit with subsequent flushing or gravity flow to biogas digestors. Summer cooling is provided through ceiling or wall fans and opening of shutters: buildings are designed to maximize air flow through the unit.  Winter heating is provided by water heated by small coal-fired boilers and pumped through a ground level piping system. Farms also have offices, accommodation and a canteen.IFCs proposed loan investment of $20M can be considered a corporate loan but it is understood that the proceeds will primarily support the development of the Wolong commercial hog farm facility to allow for annual production of 300,000 hogs. Upon completion, this Project would expand Muyuans annual hog production capacity to 1.35 million.
Review Scope: The IFC Environmental and Social (E&S) Review of Muyuan included a review of E&S policies, procedures and practices managed by the Muyuan Foodstuff Co, Ltd (Muyuan or the Guarantor) and a field visit to the pig farm of Wolong Muyuan Breeding Co., Ltd (Wolong or the Borrower), which is being built to allow for the rearing of 300,000 pigs (the Project). The review included: (i) interviews with key management staff responsible for project development, production, environment, human resources, and occupational health and safety (OHS); (ii) review of documents and reports made available by Muyuan,  including site screening procedures, environment management manual and procedures, human resource manual, OHS policy and manual, worker contracts, emergency response procedures, the results of a comprehensive safety report of the feed mill operation and other selected inspection/ monitoring records, and (iii) a site visit to two  operating hog farms (Farm 11 and 17) to oversee the operations and in particular to review a biogas generation facility.  The appraisal included a review of the progress of E&S commitments made by Muyuan in conjunction with a previous IFC investment. Biosecurity practices restricted close-up access to farms and employees. These above activities however allowed for an assessment to be made of the effectiveness of the Companys environmental and social management system for the proposed project and its ability to ensure and monitor compliance with Chinese regulatory requirements, IFCs Performance Standards and IFC General, Mammalian Livestock and Meat Processing Environmental, Health and Safety Guidelines
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The key environmental and social issues have been identified as: (i) the continuous development and implementation of the environmental and social management system (ESMS); (ii) management of the development of whole-farm environmental and social impact assessments and relevant local permitting; and, (iii) on-going development of an appropriate standardised E&S monitoring framework applicable to operations.  Specific concerns with regard to waste management typical of operations in this sector are addressed through construction and operation of biogas facilities.The potential adverse environmental and social impacts associated with this investment, and in particular the development of the project site, are relatively few in number, site-specific and can be readily addressed through mitigation measures the likes of which are utilized elsewhere in Muyuan operations as standard practice. This is a Category B project in accordance with IFCs Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability.

Project Description: The proposed investment would support Kuibyshevazot Open Joint Stock Company (KuAz) in implementation of its energy efficiency and cleaner production program. The program is expected to result in significant energy savings and reduction of greenhouse gases emissions.
Impact: Investment to be financed under the proposed project will help KuAz implement its energy efficiency and clean production program, and ultimately achieve reduction of greenhouse gases emissions and reduction in energy consumption.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed loan will support three projects, each individually small in the context of KuAz which is a large chemical manufacturing complex spread over approximately 300 hectares. The projects are replacement of :an old alkaline waste incinerator, with a new unit with modern air pollution control equipment, and heat recovery equipment.  The new unit will have much lower emissions to air and deliver energy savings to KuAz;steam reducing valves by steam turbo-generators; andseveral old low concentration nitric acid production lines, with a new energy efficient unit. The new unit will have lower emissions and deliver energy savings to KuAz;The aggregate annual reduction in GHG emissions attributable to these projects is estimated at around 110,000 tonnes CO2 equivalent.  Simple payback on energy cost savings will be less than four years.  In addition to energy and cost savings, the projects will reduce KuAzs pollutant discharges to air and water.Potential adverse E&S risks arising from the Project relate to safety in construction.   In the context of KuAz, a major chemicals manufacturing site with continuous ongoing construction and maintenance activity these risks are considered minimal.  The only offsite impact of the Project will be to reduce conventional pollutant and GHG emissions.  Kuaz is a long-standing IFC client, and has progressively improved its environmental performance in the course of the 8 years relationship with IFC.  The proposed project will substantially correct outstanding non-compliances with IFCs EHS guidelines, and one other outstanding item is under management. Due to the minimal potential adverse E&S impacts of the proposed investment, this is considered an E&S Category C project.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Kuibyshevazot Open Joint Stock Company, existing IFC client. Located in Togliatti, Samara region, KuAz is the leading Russian manufacturer of caprolactam (the raw material for synthetic fibers, engineering plastics, automotive and other downstream products) and one of the top Russian producers of nitrogenous fertilizers.

Project Description: The Project involves an IFC equity investment in Aqualia Capital (the Company), an investment holding company which the Sponsor intends to incorporate to acquire, build, own and operate water treatment and transmission and wastewater treatment projects across emerging markets.  Subject to the proposed IFC investment and after obtaining relevant approvals, Aqualia S.A., a leading Spanish water production and management company and the key shareholder in Aqualia Capital, will contribute the two desalination plants it currently owns in Algeria (one which has started operations recently, Mostagenem, and another in Cap Djinet  which is under construction); two water treatment and transmission projects in Mexico (Queretaro II which recently began operations and one near Sao Luis de Potosi which will soon begin construction); and one sanitary wastewater treatment plant under construction near the city of New Cairo, Egypt.The Company is expected to continue to leverage the Sponsors resources for the development of water projects, including in relation to all environmental and social aspects of the projects, until the time that each project reaches financial close, at which point it will be transferred to the Company.  Given Aqualias expertise in the construction and operation of water projects, it is expected that the Company will largely contract these activities for each project with Aqualia itself or affiliates of the Company.  Therefore, the review of Aqualias E&S performance is relevant, not only as providing insight into the track record of the projects to be contributed to the Company but also because the Company will continue to use the Sponsors E&S resources and will apply Aqualias E&S policies and procedures, as relevant to each project.
Review Scope: IFCs review included visits to Aqualia (the Sponsor)  a wholly owned subsidiary of FCC S.A.   offices in Madrid, Spain, where meetings and interviews with key staff (management, technical, human resources) were conducted, and numerous, relevant internal documents and records surrounding the Sponsors environmental and social (E&S) performance were analyzed.  Among others, these included environmental health and safety policies; quality management program; health, safety and environmental management program and procedures; environmental impact studies for a representative set of projects; environmental, health and safety audit checklists; environmental, health and safety monitoring reports; and presentation materials about the Sponsor business activities.  IFC staff also conducted inspections of representative operating facilities including a water treatment and transmission project in Queretaro, Mexico; the proposed location of the water treatment and transmission project in near San Luis de Potosi, Mexico; and a sanitary wastewater treatment plant under construction near Cairo, Egypt.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The Companys current and potential future business activities in water and wastewater treatment provide essential environmental services to the public.  The Sponsor, as owner of the assets to be contributed to the Company, is generally demonstrating the ability to effectively manage potential environmental and social risks from its business activities through the application of international accepted practices to protect soil, water and air resources.  The results of IFCs evaluation of the Sponsors environmental and social management programs are described below.

Project Description: Aqualia Gestion Integral del Agua S.A. (Aqualia or the Sponsor), a leading company in the global water management business, has been engaged in public-private water projects in developing countries since 2005. Aqualia currently has five projects under construction and operation in Algeria, Egypt and Mexico, including the: (i) Mostaganem (capacity: 200,000 m3 per day) and Cap Djinet (capacity: 100,000 m3 per day) desalination projects in Algeria; (ii) New Cairo (capacity: 250,000 m3 per day) wastewater treatment project in Egypt; and (iii) Queretaro (capacity: 129,600 m3 per day) and El Realito (capacity: 86,400 m3 per day) aqueduct projects in Mexico. Subject to IFCs proposed equity investment mentioned below, Aqualia intends to form a new investment holding company (Aqualia Capital or the Company) which will be responsible for the development, financing, ownership and operation of water projects in developing countries, except in Eastern Europe where it is already pursuing similar opportunities through an existing investment company, Aqualia New Europe B.V. Aqualia plans to transfer its ownership interests in the abovementioned five projects into Aqualia Capital after obtaining relevant approvals for such transfers. The Sponsor is currently considering bidding for water projects in Latin America, North Africa and South Asia.
Impact: The Sponsor has been actively participating in and expanding its business presence in developing countries. In the context of rapidly growing demand for reliable water and wastewater treatment services in developing countries, public sector financing constraints and generally lack of quality service delivery by the public sector, private sector participation can play an important role in serving the growing demand, financing the required infrastructure expansion and rehabilitation works, and improving sector efficiency and quality of service delivery. Aqualia has significant operational experience, technological know-how and managerial competencies that it can leverage and share to contribute to the development of the water sector in its developing country target markets.  Water scarcity has become a matter of serious global concern and it has become especially pronounced in the Middle East and North Africa region, where the Sponsor is currently active. In Mexico, the Sponsor is building aqueducts to deliver water to communities which are facing growing water scarcity as nearby aquifers have been over-exploited. The Sponsor''s desalination projects in Algeria and aqueducts in Mexico are expected to serve around 2.8 million people.  The Company is expected to develop new projects in the future that will help significantly expand the number of customers to whom it will deliver clean drinking water. Rapid urbanization and industrialization in developing countries has also meant that governments need to aggressively address the issue of wastewater treatment in a sustainable manner. Projects like the Sponsor''s New Cairo wastewater treatment plant will be important in proper management of wastewater and the re-use of treated wastewater for purposes such as irrigation. By contributing to enabling increased access to clean drinking water, improving efficiency in water management and supporting best practices in wastewater management, the proposed Project will support sustainable economic development.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The Companys current and potential future business activities in water and wastewater treatment provide essential environmental services to the public.  The Sponsor, as owner of the assets to be contributed to the Company, is generally demonstrating the ability to effectively manage potential environmental and social risks from its business activities through the application of international accepted practices to protect soil, water and air resources.
Sponsor: Aqualia is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas S.A. (FCC), a leading Spanish conglomerate engaged in a broad range of businesses, including infrastructure services (water and waste management, transport), construction, cement and power generation. FCC is listed on the Madrid Stock Exchange, with a 36.5% float. Aqualia manages FCCs global activities in the integrated water management sector, including water treatment, desalination, transport, distribution, sanitation, wastewater treatment and irrigation services. The Sponsor is primarily engaged in the management of public water services, based on long-term service contracts with over 1,100 municipalities, primarily in Spain, the Czech Republic and Italy. With an employee base of over 7,000, Aqualia currently serves around 27 million people worldwide, of which around 13 million are in Spain. In terms of number of customers served, Aqualia ranks second in Spain and fourth in the world. Aqualia Infraestructuras S.A., a wholly-owned subsidiary of Aqualia, is engaged in the design and construction of water infrastructure projects.
Cost Nature: IFCs proposed equity investment in the Company is for up to US$50 million. Proceeds from IFCs subscription will contribute to funding the Companys existing projects under construction and future projects that the Company expects to undertake. In addition to contributing capital from its own resources, the Sponsor may seek additional investor participation in Aqualia Capital.
Location: Aqualia currently has ownership interests in projects under construction and operation in Algeria, Egypt and Mexico, which will be transferred into the Company. In Algeria, the two desalination projects are located in Mostaganem and Cap Djinet. In Egypt, the wastewater treatment plant is located in the city of New Cairo. In Mexico, the two aqueduct projects are located in the states of Queretaro and San Louis Potosi.

Project Description: The project entails an investment in equity and debt, along with strategic partners, to create a platform to acquire and service a Distressed Asset (DA) portfolio of Planters Development Bank (Plantersbank or the Bank). The portfolio will be acquired through a to-be-formed Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV).  The DA portfolio contains non-perfoming loans (NPL) and real and other properties owned or acquired (ROPOAs) with a face value of around US$71 million.Through the proposed project, IFC can play a critical role to help re-activate the DA market in the Philippines, mobilize funding from the private sector to help address the limited capital currently available in the local NPL market, and provide Plantersbank with a mechanism for NPL resolution which will allow it to increase lending to its customers.  The proposed project is part of IFCs Debt and Asset Recovery Program (DARP), a crisis response initiative approved by the Board in August 2009, which focuses on DAs, roll-over risk and restructurings.  DARPs strategy is to revitalize financial systems through investments in DA and servicing companies / platforms.
Impact: (i) Market development: The successful implementation of the project could spark the interest of other market players and evolve into a common practice.  Furthermore, this could become an important stabilization mechanism for the Philippine financial sector and help IFC to address the current NPLs issues of its existing clients; (ii) Best practices: As part of the project IFC would promote international insolvency standards, creditors'' rights and collection practices for the resolution of the distressed assets; and(iii) Replication: Through this project, IFC would be helping to assign a market value to a NPL portfolio.  If successful, the proposed project has the potential to be replicated by other entities in the EAP region.
Environmental Social Issues: This project involves creating a SPV to purchase and service a pool of non-performing assets and has been classified as a Category FI according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Plantersbank or the servicer will provide information pertaining to the pool''s exposure to the activities on IFC''s FI Exclusion List as well as information on any unresolved social and environmental issues or high risk projects in the pool. If the review indicates that the pool is broadly in compliance with IFC E&S requirements, the SPV servicer will be required to follow international best collection practices and to establish an Social & Environmental Management System (ESMS), satisfactory to IFC and prior to IFC commitment, to work with the borrowers to achieve compliance with the IFC Exclusion List, applicable national E&S laws and regulations, and where necessary IFCs Performance Standards. The asset service company is also required to submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be prescribed by IFC.
Sponsor: IFC has three partners in the Project: (1) Plantersbank, the largest privately-owned and managed development bank in the Philippines, with majority of shares controlled by the Tambunting Family of the Philippines; (2) Altus Transaction Services (Altus), a Manila-based DA advisor and servicer; and (3) OSK Investment Management Pte. Ltd. (OSK), a Malaysia-based fund management company that is wholly owned by OSK Holdings Berhad.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$31.8 million.  IFCs portion is around 75% of the total project cost, comprised of a US$19.4 million loan and a US$4.4 million income-participating subordinated loan.
Investment: 24.33 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan24.33Equity* These investment figures are indicative

The asset service company is also required to submit a periodic report to IFC as per a format to be prescribed by IFC.

Company Name: Urbi Desarrollos Urbanos, S.A.B. de C.V.
Project Description: This project is proposed under the Global Trade Supplier Finance program (GTSF or the Program) approved by the IFC Board in September 2010. (Original Project Link #28723).Urbi, Desarrollos Urbanos, S.A.B. de C.V (Urbi or the Company) is a Mexican developer present in 35 cities across 20 states.  The Company focuses primarily on affordable entry-level and low middle-income housing while also operating in the high-middle and upper income housing sector.  The Project will establish a Supplier Finance (SF) program and make financing available to selected suppliers of Urbi, through the discounting of receivables of the suppliers payable by Urbi. The SF program will have an IFC-funded, uncommitted credit line of US$50mn. The program will be implemented through PrimeRevenue, a Supply Chain Finance platform, and its local re-seller, E-Factor Network (EFN), and it is expected to reach 200 Suppliers the large majority of which will be small and medium enterprises (SMEs).
Review Scope: In projects under the Global Trade Supplier Finance program (GTSF), IFC assesses environmental and social (E&S) risk at supplier level by assessing the Buyers systems for management of E&S performance of their Suppliers. IFCs supplier due diligence is based upon IFCs review of Urbis Corporate Social Responsibility management systems and procurement practices. IFCs due diligence involved: (i) a review of publicly available information describing Urbis approach to suppliers including Urbis 2010 and 2011 Corporate Responsibility Reports, Urbis ethics code and the companys policy for selection and assessment of suppliers; (ii) a review of the internal processes and policies for the selection, assessment and accreditation of suppliers (both for materials and services); (iii) due diligence materials and the Environmental and Social Review Summary of the proposed transaction Urbi Verde I between Urbi and IFC, which is publicly available at: http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/651aeb16abd09c1f8525797d006976ba/ade822e677b11851852579c700511939?opendocumentand (iv) a review of public information concerning labor, environmental and social conditions in Mexico and in the sectors where the potential suppliers of Urbi operate (such as construction materials and sub-contractors, providing services).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Suppliers under this transaction provide a variety of products and services to Urbi including construction materials (e.g. plumbing and electric fixtures, windows, appliances, etc) and specialized construction labor (e.g. electrician services, finishing services, etc). The most common E&S risks associated with these suppliers include labor management and working conditions, in particular occupational health and safety.

Project Description: The proposed Project aims to support the investment plan of the Metropolitan Municipality of Izmir (the "City"), focusing specifically on the following two Project components:1. Traffic management system, including the construction of a new traffic control center and the installation of an intelligent traffic signal system to replace the current outmoded and unconnected signal controllers, thereby reducing the congestion of the urban road network.2. Emergency response vehicles: a substantial part of the loan proceeds will be used for strengthening the Citys fleet of fire trucks and other emergency response vehicles to meet the needs of a growing city and provide a more effective response to its citizens.
Impact: The installation of an Intelligent Traffic System infrastructure will contribute to the City''s efforts to create a more efficient road transportation system in Izmir, reducing travel times and fostering higher productivity and economic growth. Moreover, there will be a number of environmental and social benefits due to reduced air pollution, traffic accidents, noise and congestion in the City center. In addition, strengthening its fleet of fire trucks and other emergency vehicles will enable the City to provide a more effective response to its citizens in case of emergencies.
Environmental Social Issues: This project will support a new traffic management system and replacement of emergency response vehicles, which will have no or minimal environmental impacts respectively. Thus, the project has been classified as Category C according to the IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The client will be required to commit to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working conditions (PS 2).
Sponsor: The project sponsor is the Metropolitan Municipality of Izmir, the 3rd largest metropolitan area of Turkey serving a population of nearly 4 million inhabitants. Izmir has a diversified economy and a strong socio-economic profile with a GDP per capita 30% above the national average. Given its favorable geographic location as the main port on the Aegean coast, Izmir has been one of the most vibrant cities in Turkey and a preferred destination for international trade and foreign direct investment. The Metropolitan Municipality of Izmir has received a BB+ rating from Fitch, in recognition of its strong revenue base, prudent financial management and stable political administration.  It derives most of its revenues from the share of national taxes collected within its metropolitan area (80% in 2011). Operating margins have averaged 57% since 2006 and are projected by rating agencies to remain above 40% over the next 3 years. Capital expenditures represent the bulk of Izmirs budget and are primarily associated with the large investments needed to modernize the Citys public transportation system. Including off-balance sheet liabilities, total debt was 93% of revenues and debt service coverage ratio was at 2.5 as of 2011.The Mayor, Mr. Aziz Kocaoglu, is in the middle of his second term in office. The next elections are due in 2014. He belongs to the Republican Peoples Party (CHP), the main opposition party in the national parliament, which holds an absolute majority in the Municipal Council in Izmir.
Cost Nature: The total Project cost is estimated at EUR 68 million. The proposed IFCs investment is a EUR 45 million long-term A loan for IFCs own account.
Investment: 58.53 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan58.53Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Project is located in the metropolitan area of Izmir, the main port city on the Aegean coast of Turkey.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project will support a new traffic management system and replacement of emergency response vehicles, which will have no or minimal environmental impacts respectively. Thus, the project has been classified as Category C according to the IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The client will be required to commit to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working conditions (PS 2).

Project Description: The proposed project entails financing of approximately US$25 million to Banco BHD (BHD or The Bank), a longstanding client and partner of the IFC, in Subordinated Debt through the IFC Capitalization Fund. The loan, structured to qualify as Tier II capital under Dominican regulations, is aimed to support the growth of BHDs loan portfolio which contains an important component of Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) and a new portfolio of EE projects.  The project is consistent with IFC''s Strategy in the Dominican Republic by emphasizing and strengthening linkages with existing clients in order to support their sustainability and expansion.
Impact: Increase access to financeThe Project will enhance BHD''s capital structure maintaining its ability to continue growing and supporting the SME segment which will increase access to finance in a market with low banking penetration. Greater access to finance is expected to stimulate the growth of businesses and, in turn, employment generation. Resource MobilizationThe capacity to mobilize other investors through the AMC to provide a significant amount of funding at a time of global instability.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFC''s E&S review procedures. Under existing projects (#11147 and #26142), Banco BHD is required to assess its clients according to the IFC Exclusion List and the DR''s environmental and social laws and regulations. More recently, under the Energy Efficiency (EE) credit line (#30732), the Bank has agreed to apply the IFC''s Performance Standards to high-risk EE sub-projects, if any. BHD has satisfactorily implemented an Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) and has trained E&S staff that conducts E&S assessments and frequently engages IFC to discuss the E&S issues.During appraisal IFC confirmed implementation of the ESMS and the risks of the Bank''s portfolio, which can be considered moderate, although a few sub-projects that can be potentially high-risk. As part of this investment, the Bank will be required to roll out the application of the Performance Standards to its corporate and project finance portfolio in addition to select projects under the EE credit line. IFC also reviewed Banco BHD''s labor policies, finding that they are generally consistent with IFC''s Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions.The client will be required to continue implement the ESMS to ensure that its investments are in compliance with the applicable E&S requirements, adjusting its procedures to expand the applicability of the Performance Standards; to continue its commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2; and submit a periodic report to IFC.
Sponsor: Banco BHD is the second largest private commercial bank in the Dominican Republic. The Bank is a subsidiary of Centro Financiero BHD, a diversified financial services company whose activities include commercial banking, consumer and micro finance, pension funds, insurance, remittances and private banking. Centro Financiero BHD is owned by four shareholders: Grupo BHD (51%), Popular International Bank Inc. (20%), Banco Sabadell of Spain (20%) and IFC (9%).
Cost Nature: The proposed investment consists of a subordinated loan of up to $25 million and is expected to be made by the IFC Capitalization Fund, which is managed by IFC Asset Management Company, LLC, a wholly-owned subsidiary of IFC.
Location: Banco BHD is headquartered in Santo Domingo and has 91 branches across the Dominican Republic.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project has been classified as a Category FI project according to IFC''s E&S review procedures. Under existing projects (#11147 and #26142), Banco BHD is required to assess its clients according to the IFC Exclusion List and the DR''s environmental and social laws and regulations. More recently, under the Energy Efficiency (EE) credit line (#30732), the Bank has agreed to apply the IFC''s Performance Standards to high-risk EE sub-projects, if any. BHD has satisfactorily implemented an Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) and has trained E&S staff that conducts E&S assessments and frequently engages IFC to discuss the E&S issues.During appraisal IFC confirmed implementation of the ESMS and the risks of the Bank''s portfolio, which can be considered moderate, although a few sub-projects that can be potentially high-risk. As part of this investment, the Bank will be required to roll out the application of the Performance Standards to its corporate and project finance portfolio in addition to select projects under the EE credit line. IFC also reviewed Banco BHD''s labor policies, finding that they are generally consistent with IFC''s Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions.The client will be required to continue implement the ESMS to ensure that its investments are in compliance with the applicable E&S requirements, adjusting its procedures to expand the applicability of the Performance Standards; to continue its commitment to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2; and submit a periodic report to IFC.

Project Description: This project is proposed under the Global Trade Supplier Finance program (GTSF or the Program) approved by the IFC Board in September 2010. (Original Project Link #28723).Under the terms of this proposed investment, IFC will risk-participate with BNP Paribas in the latter''s credit facility issued to Utexam Logistics Limited (a subsidiary of BNP Paribas Ireland).  Utexam Logistics Limited uses the credit facility to purchase guar from Indian suppliers for sale on a just in time to Rhodia, the internationally-known specialty chemicals company.Guar is an annual, leguminous plant, from the seeds of which guar gum and other derivatives are manufactured. These products are used in the food processing industry and also have a number of industrial applications.  Worldwide, India is the largest grower of guar. Rhodia sources guar from selected companies in India, and Rhodia has a fifty percent (50%) equity interest in the largest of these suppliers (the JV).
Review Scope: In supplier financing programs of this nature, IFC assesses environmental and social (E&S) risk at Supplier level by assessing Buyers management system and procedures of assessing E&S performance of their Suppliers. IFC due diligence for this proposed transaction involved: (i) a review of publicly available information describing Rhodias approach to assessment and management of Suppliers sustainability performance:  this included a review of publically available materials describing the Rhodia Way which is described later in this document (ii) a telephone call with Rhodias sustainability team, to better understand how Rhodias guar supply chain structure operates and how the Rhodia Way is applied to raw materials purchases of the type anticipated in this transaction; (iii) review of additional materials provided by Rhodia. In addition, IFC undertook some background investigation of guar farming in India.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The key issue considered in IFCs review was Rhodias management of E&S practices among its guar suppliers.Guar is primarily grown in north-western India in semi-arid modified habitats not associated with ongoing loss of biodiversity.  In addition, guar is not included in the US Department of Labor 2011 List of Goods Produced by Child Labor or Forced Labor. Rhodias guar suppliers are industrial companies processing guar to produce the derivatives at specific manufacturing locations, and includes the JV which is Rhodias main guar supplier.  It is therefore concluded that potential E&S risks, where encountered, are reversible, may be readily mitigated and are site specific. This is therefore considered to be an E&S Category B project in accordance with IFCs Policy on Environment and Social Sustainability.
Sector: G-BD - All Other Basic Inorganic Chemical

Company Name: PATRIA CREDIT INSTITUTIE FINANCIARA NEBANCARA S.A.
Project Description: The proposed Project is to provide of a local currency senior loan in Lei of up to US$11 million equivalent to Patria Credit (the Company), the largest microfinance institution in Romania. Proceeds of the loan will be used to finance the expansion of the lending to micro and small entrepreneurs. The Company currently seeks long-term funding to complete its funding plan for 2012 and 2013, continue its loan portfolio growth by extending loans to its target clientele and to diversify its funding sources.
Impact: - The development impact of IFC''s financing is expected to be high, as it will enhance the MFI''s ability to support productive MSEs which will in turn stimulate growth, employment generation and poverty reduction.- Create a demonstration effect for MFIs in the country by bringing best practices in insurance and social and environment management systems to Romania''s largest MFI.- Improve asset quality of the portfolio through IFC''s global knowledge of microfinance and rural products.
Environmental Social Issues: This project, which consists of a senior loan to Patria Credit for on lending to micro and small entrepreneurs in Romania, has been classified as a Category FI-3 project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure.
Sponsor: Patria Credit was established in 1998  under the name of Capa Finance and was acquired in 2007 by Romanian American Enterprise Fund (RAEF) ; Capa Finance was rebranded to Patria Credit in 2009. Immediately after the acquisition, RAEF invited another private equity fund Balkan Accession Fund (BAF) to participate in the MFIs capital increase. Currently, the MFIs main shareholders are: RAEF with a 56.5% stake, EECAP UA (BAF) with a 43.2% stake, and Chindris Adrian Petru with 0.3%.Romanian-American Enterprise Fund (RAEF) is a private equity fund established in 1994 by the U.S. government to support the development of the private sector in Romania through direct equity investments and loans. Since its inception in 1994, RAEF has invested more than US$80 million and attracted another US$140 million from partners such as IFC, EBRD, DEG, FMO and the Black Sea Trade and Development Bank (BSTDB). Balkan Accession Fund is a EUR 110 million private equity fund created in 2005 by lead investors such as RAEF, EBRD, DEG, FMO and BSTDB. It was designed to take advantage of investment opportunities related to the 2007 EU accession of Romania and Bulgaria but also to selectively invest in other countries in the Western Balkans and Ukraine. BAF''s portfolio includes market leaders in: retail, logistics, refrigeration, microfinance, leasing, consumer finance, equipment rental, ice-cream production and IT&C operated in Romania, Bulgaria, Moldova, Albania and Turkey. Axxess Capital is an investment manager of two private equity funds RAEF and BAF with more than 15 years extensive investment experience in the region and US$250 million equity invested. Axxess Capital is fully engaged in maximizing the value of the investment by improving the performance of the investee company over the holding period. Patria Credit has been a portfolio client of Axxess Capital since 2007, when the Company was acquired by RAEF and BAF. Since then, Axxess Capital team has been sitting on the Board of Directors of Patria Credit.
Cost Nature: The proposed project involves a senior loan from IFCs own account to the Company in Lei, in an amount not to exceed US$11 million (equivalent).
Investment: 11.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan11.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Patria Credit is headquartered in Bucharest, Romania. It is currently present in 27 rural and 15 urban locations and runs a network of 42 branches, thus having a nation-wide coverage.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project, which consists of a senior loan to Patria Credit for on lending to micro and small entrepreneurs in Romania, has been classified as a Category FI-3 project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure.
Sector: O-HA - Microfinance and Small Business - Non Commercial Banking

Company Name: THE CO-OPERATIVE BANK OF KENYA LIMITED
Project Description: The proposed investment consists of a US$60 million 7-year senior loan to Cooperative Bank of Kenya (Coop Bank or the Bank) to support its long term lending business and in particular to enable the Bank to expand its SME and Agribusiness lending programs (the Project). In addition to the senior loan, a further US$5 million trade line will be made available by IFC to the Bank under IFCs Global Trade Finance Program (GTFP).  The primary objective of the Project is to support the Banks growth, address its balance sheet maturity mismatch, and help it meet its US$ funding needs. Coop Bank is the 3rd largest bank in Kenya and accounts for 8.2% of total assets in the banking system.  The Bank was publicly listed in 2008 and trades on the Nairobi Securities Exchange (NSE) under the symbol COOP.  Coop Bank has its roots in the cooperative movement having been established in 1965 by agricultural cooperative marketing societies.  Over the last 15 years, the Bank has transformed into a strong universal bank catering to all market segments including public sector, corporate, SMEs, micro-entrepreneurs and the Cooperative sector.
Environmental Social Info: The key risk is the ability of Coop Bank to identify and manage the environmental and social risks associated with its lending activities particularly to the agribusiness sector, and farmer co-operatives. Additional E&S risks and impacts of the Project derive from the capacity and systems in place to manage these risks, and the Banks practices with regard to labor and working conditions. At present Coop Bank does not have an  Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) outlining the procedures, responsibilities and tools for undertaking E&S risk management of its lending activities and, apart from assessing compliance with national environmental permitting requirements,  E&S related due diligence is not yet part of the Banks loan review process. No staff/department has been assigned responsibility for E&S due diligence and monitoring, and training needs to be provided to all staff involved in ESMS implementation.
Impact: By providing long term US$ financing and a trade line, IFC expects to deliver strong development impact through its partnership with Coop Bank.  Long term funding to address the existing maturity mismatches will offer a lower risk funding approach to the Bank''s business and consequently allow for increased reach in terms of broader access to finance for various market segments.  In summary, the provision of long term finance is expected to have strong development impact in the following areas:i) Access to Finance - SME: IFC''s long-term funding will allow Coop Bank to grow its SME lending business and enable it offer affordable long term finance to its clients;ii) Access to Finance - Agriculture: access to long term funding will enhance the Bank''s ability to grow its agribusiness lending portfolio and increase the tenor of its loans;  andiii) Access to Finance - Trade: the trade line under GTFP will allow the Bank to ramp up its trade activities and more importantly offer affordable trade finance to SMEs.
Role:
Through its proposed partnership with Coop Bank, IFC will play a unique role in:

i) providing long-term US$ financing, currently in limited supply in the market, to help the Bank address maturity mismatch and grow its long term lending business in a sustainable way; and
iii) providing additional institutional endorsement to support the Bank''s regional expansion and future capital-raising efforts.
Sponsor: Coop Banks largest shareholder is Coop Holdings Cooperative Society Limited, which holds a 65% stake in the Bank on behalf of over 3,800 cooperative societies and unions who were shareholders of the Bank prior to its listing on the NSE. The lending provided entails limited adverse E&S risk and impacts that are few in number, generally site-specific, largely reversible and readily addressed though mitigation measures. For this Project the Bank will be required to screen loans against the IFC Exclusion List, the Kenyan E&S laws and regulations and the IFC Performance Standards.
Risk Impact: The key risk is the ability of Coop Bank to identify and manage the environmental and social risks associated with its lending activities particularly to the agribusiness sector, and farmer co-operatives. Additional E&S risks and impacts of the Project derive from the capacity and systems in place to manage these risks, and the Banks practices with regard to labor and working conditions. At present Coop Bank does not have an  Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) outlining the procedures, responsibilities and tools for undertaking E&S risk management of its lending activities and, apart from assessing compliance with national environmental permitting requirements,  E&S related due diligence is not yet part of the Banks loan review process. Project Description: The project consists of an IFC loan to Bank of Georgia (BoG or the Bank) aimed at improving access to finance to Georgian SMEs, with special emphasis on SMEs owned by women.  The project will provide term financing for the Bank to expand its lending to women-owned SME segment. IFC will look into mobilizing additional funds from partner financial institutions as syndicated or parallel loans for the same purposes.  Bank of Georgia, established in 1994, is the largest bank in Georgia with more than a third of the market share based on total assets, total loans, total deposits and total shareholders equity.  The Bank is a universal commercial bank engaged in corporate and retail banking and wealth management.
Environmental Social Info: BoG has procedures for assessing and managing E&S risks, which have been recently amended to incorporate requirements to comply with IFC Performance Standards. However, there is a lack of implementation guidelines to ensure the due implementation of the procedures. BoG has a 4% cap for financing Exclusion List items (alcohol tobacco and gambling), and reports current exposure to this items at 1.6%.
Impact: The project is expected to support the SME business in Georgia through provided much needed long-term financing to boost the recovery of the economy after the negative consequences of the global financial crisis. The project will have an opportunity to encourange lending to women-owned SMEs. The Project is expected to have a strong demonstration effect and support mobilization of international funding for Georgian market.
Role: IFC is expected to play a catalyst role in providing medium/long-term resources. The Project will support provision of much-needed medium/long term finance in the IDA-blend country. The facility will have an opportunity to broaden IFC''s value proposition for the Bank through improving its brand and increasing its lending to the women-owned SME segment.
Sponsor: Bank of Georgia is a privately owned joint-stock company incorporated in Georgia. The holding company of the Bank, Bank of Georgia Holdings Plc (BGH), incorporated in the United Kingdom, which owns 98.35% of the Banks shares is listed on the premium segment of the London Stock Exchange (LSE) and has a widely distributed shareholder base. Management and employees hold 2.6%, with the remainder held by various institutional investors and individuals.  IFC and EBRD each hold 4.58% of BGH shares.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$50 million. The proposed IFC investment is a US$25 million A loan for IFCs own account. Additional US$25 million is expected to be mobilized by the IFC from the parallel or syndicated lenders.

Project Description: Headquartered near Delhi and listed on Indian stock exchanges, SRF Limited (http://www.srf.com) has three main business verticals: 1) Technical Textiles - such as nylon and polyester tire cord fabric, belting, coated and laminated fabrics; 2) Chemicals  such as refrigerant gases, chloromethanes, fluorospecialities; and 3) Packaging Films - viz. bi-axially-oriented polyethylene terephthalate (BOPET) and bi-axially oriented polypropylene (BOPP) films (which is in the process of being set up in South Africa). SRF, through its subsidiary SRF Thailand, proposes to set up a facility for the production of BOPET packaging films in Thailand with a capacity of 28,500 ton per annum (the Project). The proposed Project is located in Hemaraj Eastern Seaboard Industrial Estate (HESIE) approximately 30 kilometers from the Laem Chabang deep-sea container port and Sri Racha city and approx 110 kilometers from Bangkok. The Company purchased 22 acres (54 Rai) of fully developed industrial land for this project in HESIE in September 2011. The Project is expected to become operational in May 2013.
Review Scope: IFCs review of this proposed investment consisted of appraising technical, environment, health safety, security (EHS) and social related information submitted by SRF Limited (SRF or the Sponsor) and its subsidiary company SRF Industries (Thailand) Ltd ( SRF Thailand or the Company) including its EHS policies, organization charts, EHS management system manual, human resources (HR) policies and procedures; training records; accident/incident records, environmental monitoring reports; emergency action plan, annual reports, etc. The appraisal also included a site visit to SRF Thailands operational nylon tire cord manufacturing facility in Maptaphut, Thailand; visit to the site of the proposed packaging film manufacturing facility near Sri Racha city in Thailand and discussions with SRFs & SRF Thailands senior management, technical and EHS teams.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Key environmental and social (E&S) issues and risks related to project include: assessment and mitigation of the impacts of the Project; the Companys capacity to manage its social, environmental, health and safety performance, and engage with local communities in accordance with local requirements and IFC Performance Standards and applicable World Bank Group (WBG) Environmental Health and Safety (EHS) Guideline; assurance of fair, safe and healthy working conditions; utilization of equipment and operational practices that maximizes conservation of energy, water and process materials including recycling and reuse initiatives; management of waste emissions and discharge; handling and management of hazardous materials and hazardous wastes; and the impacts of operations on local ambient environment.The potential adverse E&S impacts of this project are few in number and limited to the project site; and can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards and guidelines. This is therefore a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social (E&S) Review of Projects.
Sector: G-CB - Man-Made Fibers (Including Nylon, Polyester, Rayon, etc.)

Project Description: SRF Limited (SRF), a producer of bi-axially-oriented polyethylene terephthalate (BOPET) in India, and a market leader in Nylon 6 tire cord as well as belting fabrics, proposes to set up a facility for the production of BOPET packaging films in Thailand (the Plant).  The Plant having a capacity of 28,500 tonnes per annum will be set-up in the SRFs subsidiary SRF Industries (Thailand) Ltd (SRFIT). The project is expected to cost around US$71 million including working capital requirements , of which IFC is considering financing up to US$ 45 mm. The balance will be financed by SRF contribution and loans through local banks.
Impact: (i)	Improving Local Supply Chain:  Local procurement of about US$10 million is expected during construction.  During operational phase, business for local supply chain will increase.(ii)	Job creation: The Project is expected to create about 300 direct jobs and 1500 indirect jobs in ancillary units and supply chain. In addition, there will be temporary jobs created during construction phase and during life of the project.(iii)	 Food Security:  The Project supports the expansion of the food packaging industry, thereby reducing food spoilage and enhancing availability of processed foods. (iv)	 Enhanced Financial Sustainability through Product Diversification:  The BOPET plant expands the company''s product base in Thailand (currently producing Nylon 6 tire cord), thus providing an additional revenue source, and access to new markets and customers.(v)	Demonstration Effect of a South-South Investment: The project will facilitate a South-South investment and its success could encourage other Indian companies to expand in emerging markets.
Role:
(i) Global Knowledge: IFC''s global presence and expertise enables IFC to offer the Sponsor advice and comfort, as SRF expands its footprint overseas.

(ii) Long-term Partnership Opportunities: This project will be a part of IFC''s endeavor to establish a long-term partnership with SRF. IFC is currently looking at another investment with SRF in South Africa, where IFC is requested to provide US$40 million dollar denominated loan.

(iii) The project is large in relation to the size of the Company along with gradual ramp up, hence requiring longer tenor financing which is not easily available in the local market. IFC''s ability to offer long-term dollar denominated loans are important for the financing of a project of this nature.

(iv) Environmental and Social Good Practice: IFC''s support of the Project will ensure E&S good practice in accordance with IFC''s Performance Standards.
Sponsor: Headquartered in Gurgaon, India- SRF is a large company with three main businesses: 1) Technical Textiles (Nylon and polyester tire cord fabric, and belting fabrics); 2) Chemicals (Refrigerant gases, Chloromethanes, fluorospecialities); and 3) Packaging Films. It is listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) and National Stock Exchange (NSE) in India. 50% of the company is held by the Bharat Ram family, while 50% is owned by the general public including Foreign Institutional Investors, Mutual Funds, Banks and DFIs. SRFIT is a wholly-owned subsidiary of SRF.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated to be about US$71 million. The proposed IFC investment is a US$ 45 million A loan for IFCs own account. The balance will be funded as equity or sponsor loans by SRF, as well as loans from local banks.
