Project Description: Founded in November 1981, RKFL manufactures forged and machined transmission and axle components for medium and heavy commercial vehicles, and is currently one of the market leaders in this space in India. RKFL is headquartered in Kolkata, India, and has its three operational manufacturing plants at two sites in Jamshedpur, Jharkhand, India and one unit at Liluah, Howrah.In order to increase its market share in a growing domestic market, and improve its operating efficiency, RKFL has undertaken an expansion program in Jamshedpur requiring a capital expenditure of approximately US$97 million. The expansion program will include brownfield expansion and technology upgrades in its existing facilities (such as replacement of oil fired furnaces with induction furnaces) and construction of a greenfield facility in Jamshedpur to manufacture front axle beams for commercial vehicles, with machinery imported from Germany (the Project).
Review Scope: IFCs review of this proposed investment consisted of appraising technical, environment, health and safety (EHS) and social related information submitted by  Ramkrishna Forgings Limited (RKFL or the Company) including its EHS policy, organization chart, quality and EHS management system manual, human resources (HR) policies and procedures; training records; environmental monitoring reports; emergency response plan, etc. The appraisal also included site visits to RKFLs operational manufacturing facilities and discussions with senior management, technical and EHS teams in Jamshedpur, India.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social (E&S) Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards and guidelines.Key E&S risks and issues related to project include: the Companys capacity to manage its EHS performance, and engage with local communities; assurance of fair, safe and healthy working conditions during construction and operation; utilization of equipment and operational practices that maximizes conservation of energy, water and process materials including recycling and reuse initiatives; management of wastes, emissions and discharges; handling and management of hazardous materials and wastes; and the impacts of operations on nearby communities and local ambient environment.

Project Description: Ramkrishna Forgings Limited (RKFL or the Company) is headquartered in Kolkata, West Bengal, India, and its manufacturing units are located in Jamshedpur, Jharkhand, India.  Founded in November 1981, RKFL manufactures forged and machined Transmission and axle components for medium and heavy commercial vehicles, and is currently one of the market leaders in this space in India.  In order to increase its market share in a growing domestic market, and improve its operating efficiency, RKFL has undertaken an expansion program in Jamshedpur requiring a capital expenditure of approximately US$97 million. The greenfield expansion program will include a new Front Axle Beam manufacturing line, with machinery imported from Germany, and will be installed near the Companys existing plant in Jamshedpur.
Impact: This investment will have a strong development impact in the form of (a) direct employment generation for about 390 people in the state of Jharkhand and (b) enhance global competitiveness and capabilities of the Company as it embarks on its journey to become a player of scale in the auto-components sector.
Role:

He is a Mechanical Engineer from Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani and has more than 20 years experience in this industry. Mr. Jalan has worked with Orient Paper Mills Limited, Spinning Accessories Limited, Shalimar Wires Limited and Calicut Engineering Works Limited. His first entrepreneurship was as Managing Partner of Tribeni Steel Forgings in the year 1974. His son Mr. Naresh Jalan, Managing Director of RKFL is actively involved in running the business with his core strength being in marketing and finance. The Company listed in April 2004. Project Description: Ozyegin University (OzU or the University) is undertaking a project to build a state-of-art campus in Cekmekoy, Istanbul (the Project). The Projects first phase, which was completed in the summer of 2011, comprises an academic building with 3,000 student capacity, a dormitory building with 400 student capacity, laboratories, student center, library, dining hall, auditorium and open sports and recreational activities.  The second phase of investments, which IFC will be financing, will include a new faculty building, a new dormitory, car parks, energy facilities and power center with distribution system and a closed-area sports center.
Review Scope: IFCs review of this Project consisted of visits to the existing academic, social and technical facilities of Ozyegin University at Cekmekoy, Altunizade and Camlica and to the construction site at Cekmekoy of the on-going expansion project, all located in Istanbul.Documentation provided by Ozyegin University about land acquisition, processing of regulatory permits and licenses, building design and construction, inspections by the authorities, quality and environmental management documentation and certifications; contractor and supplier control programs; equipment and area verification and maintenance programs; emergency management schemes, occupational health and safety; training materials and records, human resources policy were reviewed.Interviews were held with the management team of Ozyegin University, including Administrative Manager, Construction Projects Manager, members of the technical and administrative staff responsible of facilities management and EHS, project management team members and engineers from FIBA Group (sponsor of the University) and BERKO, one of the main contractor companies undertaking the expansion projects at Cekmekoy Campus.  Members of the academic staff from the Energy, Environment and Economics Center of Ozyegin University were also interviewed.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The key environmental and social issues related to this project include; structural design and safety; occupational health and safety for construction operations; life and fire safety; hygiene and sanitation management; energy efficiency; and land acquisition. The appraisal concluded that any impacts will be limited, site-specific and can be addressed by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Therefore, this is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.
Sector: T-AB - Colleges, Universities, and Professional Schools

Project Description: Ozyegin University (OzU or the University) is a private foundation university in Turkey, founded in 2007, and started education in 2008-2009 academic year with 210 students admitted to its Undergraduate Business Administration Program. Today, the Unievrsity has in excess of 1,700 students in its 4 faculties, 2 vocational schools and 2 graduate schools. The vision of the University is to be a financially accessible, entrepreneurial research university. Until 2011, the Unievrsity operated out a rented building in Altunizade, Istanbul. In 2010, the University embarked on a project (the Project) to build a state-of-art campus in Cekmekoy, Istanbul (the Campus). The Campus is designed by international architects, and its first phase, which was completed in summer of 2011, has received the internationally acclaimed LEED certificate granted to environmentally friendly buildings. The University has started education in the Campus in 2011-2012 academic year, in addition to its existing site in Altunizade, Istanbul. The Projects first phase, which was completed in the summer of 2011, comprises an academic building with 3,000 student capacity, a dormitory building with 400 student capacity, laboratories, student center, library, dining hall, auditorium and open sports and recreational activities.  The second phase of investments, which IFC will be financing, will include a new faculty building, a new dormitory and closed-area sports center. The University aims to obtain LEED certification for most of its buildings upon completion.
Impact: (i) Incerased access to higher education. (ii) Through its focus on enterprenurial research and application and industry-oriented education, support its students in establishing the SMEs of the future or taking their place in the work force with the right skill sets.(iii) Create a demosntration effect by being the first environmentally friendly university campus in Turkey, with international accreditation. (iv) Create a center of excellence for computational finance, enterpreneurship and energy efficiency through its research centers.
Role:
- Provide long-term financing to support the campus investment
- Help strengthen financial and operational discipline in the University
- Share IFC''s global knowhow and network to contribute to the University''s aim to become a high quality education institution and a center of excellence.
- Provide guidance on high standards of quality, corporate governance, and environmental and social considerations, which the University gives high importance to.
Sponsor: Ozyegin University is owned by Husnu M. Ozyegin Foundation, which was founded in 1990 by Mr. Husnu Ozyegin (the Sponsor) as a private foundation dedicated to improving the lives of individuals through social investments in education, health, cultural heritage and rural development. The Sponsor has also founded Fiba Group in 1987, which houses about 40 companies operating in financial services, real estate, energy, retail, port management and shipping industries, which are consolidated under Fiba Holding A.S. and Fina Holding A.S. Fiba Group companies are the sole benefactor of Husnu M. Ozyegin Foundation.
Cost Nature: The Project is expected to cost more than US$100 million, the second phase of which is expected to be completed by August 2012. IFCs proposed investment consists of an A-Loan of up to US$35 million for IFCs own account.

Project Description: The proposed project consists of an A-Loan denominated in Russian Rubles at IFCs own account of up to US$30 million (approximately equivalent to RUB882.2 million) for up to five years, and a B/parallel-Loan of up to US$30 million. The loans are intended to support the Banks onlending to small and medium enterprises in the Far East and Siberia Federal Districts of Russia.ATB is the largest regional bank in the Russian Far East and Siberia, headquartered in Blagoveshchensk. The Bank is focused on retail lending, but has a significant corporate loan and SME loan portfolios. IFC has been engaged with the Bank since 2008 and is a shareholder with a 7% stake. The Bank operates through a branch chain including 221 offices, located in 18 regions of Russia, 60% of which are frontier regions.
Impact: The Project is expected to have a significant development impact as it will enhance the Bank''s ability to lend more to SMEs and households in frontier regions of the Eastern Russia.  Such financing will be crucial for the sustainable development of the private sector and diversification of the regional economies where the Bank operates (including 9 frontier regions, defined as having per capita income 80% or less of the national average). Additional developmental impact lies in the introduction of the Bank and its unique business model to the international wholesale funding market, by possibly marketing its debut syndication.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed project is with an existing IFC client to provide debt investment for financing MSMEs sector and the overall portfolio risk is considered to be medium. The project has been categorized as FI in accordance with IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Asian Pacific Bank (ATB) is focused on retail banking, and also provides corporate, SMEs finance and leasing services. The Banks corporate and SME lending accounts for approximately 33% of the total portfolio, the key sectors of lending mainly entail limited adverse E&S risk and impacts that are few in number, generally site-specific, largely reversible and readily addressed though mitigation measures. Applicable requirements for this project are IFC Exclusion List, the Russian E&S laws and regulations and the IFC Performance Standards.

These businessmen hold stakes in a number of gold and iron ore mining, financial services, IT and retail companies. Swedish asset management company East Capital Fund owns an 18% stake through East Capital Explorer Financial Institutions Fund, a closed-end fund focused on investments into financial service companies in the Central and Eastern Europe. Yevgeny Aksenov, the chairman of the management board of the Bank, holds a 5% stake, while IFC owns a 7% stake. The remaining 2.7% is owned by various minority shareholders.

Project Description: The proposed investment consists of a debt package of up to US$65 million to Banco Interamericano de Finanzas (BanBif or the Bank), comprising an IFC A Loan of up to US$15 million and a B Loan package for the balance. The B Loans are expected to be funded mainly by commercial banks.The proposed project is expected to help BanBif continue accelerating the growth of its SME portfolio, access longer term financing.  It will also help the Bank diversify its funding sources by opening up new relationships with international commercial banks.
Impact: - Without the Project, it would be much harder for BanBif to raise the amount of medium-term funding it is seeking from diversified sources and at competitive market conditions.  If fully deployed, the loan could help make financing available for over 3,000 SME loans during the life of the project.  - The income derived from the financing activity made possible by the investment would be widely distributed helping reduce the income gap prevailing in Peru.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been classified as a Category FI project. (50.05%) and Britton S.A. (49.95%)).

Company Name: Shanghai F-Road Commercial Service Co., Ltd.
Project Description: The proposed project will likely consist of IFCs equity investment of up to RMB50 million (US$8 million equivalent) in Shanghai F-Road Commercial Service Co., Ltd. (F-Road or the Company).  F-Road, founded in Shanghai in 2008, is a financial service provider specialized in providing financial access to customers of small financial institutions through mobile devices. The project represents an opportunity for IFC to support a leading mobile banking service provider in China which serves a large number of rural population and micro-business sector through partnering with small financial institutions, with high potential of scaling up its outreach and impacts in rural and frontier regions. By using mobile devices, the underserved rural population and micro businesses would be able to access basic banking services including money transfer, remittance, bill payment, card operations, lending, account inquiry, account management, and cash-in/out through mobile payment platform established by F-Road.
Impact: The Project will achieve strong development impact and demonstrate IFC''s commitment to support financial inclusion and the development of frontier regions in China:(i) Improve Access to Financial Services: lack of access to financial services in rural areas and frontier regions has been a challenge for China.  By using mobile networks effectively, access to financial services will no longer be limited to areas in which a bank is physically present or there is access to the Internet.  Through easier access to the financial services visa mobile devices, underserved population will experience higher financial efficiency and capture more business opportunities, leading to increased income and improved livelihood. (ii) Promote Financial Sector Innovation: access to banking and payments services through the mobile phone is new in China.  By assisting the pioneering mobile banking service provider at this important stage and by helping develop it into a model company, IFC is expected to have demonstrative impacts and accelerate adoption.(iii) Enhance Institution Building: through F-Road, IFC could potentially improve the operating efficiency, scale and financial transparency of small financial institutions and enable these financial institutions to reach out to their clients.
Role:
(i) Sector knowledge: IFC''s combined expertise in both financial markets and payments will help F-Road enhance its capacity in serving small financial institutions. Moreover, IFC has a strong AS presence in China. The AS team has accumulated solid experience in the microfinance industry, and has gained credibility with relevant government agencies and stakeholders. The ongoing good cooperation with People''s Bank of China, the leading government agency in the mobile banking sector enables IFC to assist the development of the Company, especially in the areas of strategy planning, business model refinement and network expansion.
(ii) Global experience: IFC has made a number of successful investments in the electronic payments and remote banking services in countries such as India, Vietnam, South Africa, Brazil, Argentina, Central America, Nigeria etc. F-Road is particularly interested in IFC''s global experience and hopes to learn from IFC''s other clients. The Company is also looking beyond China for potential opportunities in emerging markets. With global IS and AS experience, IFC is well positioned to assist F-Road in improving its industry knowledge and connections to the international markets.
(iii) Stamp of approval: IFC''s reputation and credibility will upgrade F-Road profile in the market and facilitate potential funding initiatives of the Company in the future.
Sponsor: F-Road was co-founded by Mr. Su Huidong and Mr. Qiu Qi in 2008.  They worked previously for China Construction Bank for 4 years, and served as senior managers for 11 years of EasyCon, an IT services company.  The Company''s current shareholders include:  (i) Jiangsu Hongji Investment Co. Ltd. (33.38%); (ii) Taisys Technologies (Beijing) Co. Ltd. (16.72%); (iii) HTC HK Limited (14.21%); (iv) Mr. Su Huidong, Co-Founder and CEO (9.17%); (v) Mr. Qiu Qi, Co-Founder and VP (7.98%); and (vi) a number of private companies and individual shareholders with total shareholding of 18.54%.

Company Name: Stora Enso Pulp And Paper Asia AB
Project Description: The Project is to build plantation-based integrated board and pulp mills at Beihai city in Guangxi, southern China. The mill site will initially include a 450 000 tons per year state-of-the-art paperboard machine and pulp capacity of 900 000 tons per year, including necessary energy plant and auxiliary facilities. In a unique set-up, the board and pulp mills will be self-sufficiently integrated with wood supply from 120 000 hectares of self-managed eucalyptus plantations. The ultimate target is to expand the paperboard capacity to 900 000 tons at a later stage. The project will serve the fast-growing market for liquid packaging board and other premium consumer board grades. The project investment will be approximately EUR 1.6 billion. The project will be financed through a combination of debt and equity on an approximately 60/40 basis. The debt financing is expected to be a mix of export credit agency, multilateral and commercial bank debt. The investment is subject to regulatory approvals, the signing of final documentation and other customary conditions precedent.  Construction at the industrial site will commence when the mentioned preconditions have been fulfilled, which is expected to be in the second half of 2012. Production is scheduled to start in the fourth quarter of 2014. Stora Enso Pulp & Paper Asia AB (the Company) will implement the Project through three subsidiaries: two will be 85% owned by the Company and 15% owned by the Guangxi Forestry Group, a state-owned company under the Guangxi provincial government. Stora Enso Oyj is the Sponsor and Guarantor of the Project.

SLH is a diversified conglomerate which started operations in 1991 as an information and communication technology (ICT) company and has since expanded into healthcare, retail, leisure/ tourism and financial services. SLH is listed on Colombo Stock Exchange. Under its healthcare business, SLH owns the largest private hospital network in Sri Lanka with five hospitals and 12 diagnostic laboratories supported by 350 collection centers. IFC has an investment in SLHs hospital business (Project #28555 disclosed in February, 2010: http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/0/B9F14C11EE96B7E2852576CD00604BF5). SLHs retail business primarily focuses on consumer electronics with some share from branded apparel, furniture and automobile dealerships. SLH has a travel agency and is now diversifying into tourism business by building hotels. The proposed project involves an investment over the next two to three years to (a) expand its network of retail stores from about 124 to up to 280 as well as increase its geographical reach to smaller cities by 2015; and (b) rebuild and expand an acquired beach hotel to a total of 166 keys in Bentota, 60 km south of Colombo (the Project).  This will be implemented through subsidiaries of SLH.The retail business expansion will involve opening of new stores  primarily for consumer electronics and a few for branded textiles and apparels  in urban commercial areas. Almost all the existing as well as proposed stores will be built in leased or rented premises, with average area varying from 750-1,000 square feet (sqft). The layout and design of the stores is governed by the specifications of the respective brand (e.g. Nokia, Samsung, Panasonic, NEC, Levis, Nike, Giordano, Mango etc.). For its leisure/tourism project, SLH has purchased Hotel Ceysands in Bentota as its first acquisition. This property was a part of Bentota National Holiday Resort (NHR) developed by Sri Lanka Tourism Development Authority (SLTDA) in 1969. NHR is spread over 100 acres with a long beach front, and comprises of about 600 guest rooms of various star categories in five hotels. SLTDA manages NHR and provides the supporting infrastructure  including a central wastewater treatment plant - for this entire resort complex.After refurbishment the Company plans to upgrade the existing hotel into a 4-star plus rated resort on par with international standards. The Company has signed a management agreement with a well known hotel and resorts management group, Centara Hotels and Resorts (Centara) from Thailand.
Review Scope: IFCs review of this investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety (EHS) related social information submitted by Softlogic Holdings PLC (SLH or the Company) including: regulatory permits, human resources (HR) policy, design documents (such as site layout plans), Occupational Health and Safety policy, organization chart, design details for the proposed hotels etc. The appraisal also included site visits to the Companys retail outlets and site for one of its proposed hotels and discussions with its senior management and EHS teams in its corporate headquarters in Colombo, Sri Lanka.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards and guidelines. Key environmental and social (E&S) risks and issues related to this project include: adequate assessment of the E&S impacts of the Project; implementation of social, EHS management systems; engagement with local communities in accordance with local requirements and IFC Performance Standards and World Bank Group (WBG) environmental, health and safety EHS Guidelines; assurance of fair, safe and healthy working conditions; resource efficiency; management of emissions, wastes and discharges; and life and fire safety management of all the public access buildings.
Sector: Q-BA - Retail (Including Supermarkets, Grocery Stores, etc.)

Project Description: Softlogic Holdings Plc (Softlogic or the Company),  is a Sri Lankan conglomerate with existing operations across retail, information and communication technology, healthcare and financial services sectors. The proposed project by Softlogic involves an investment of up to US$67.7 million over the next three years to (a) expand its network of retail stores from about 124 to up to 280 as well as increase its geographical reach to smaller cities; and (b) to rebuild and expand an acquired hotel to a total of 166 keys (the Project).  The Project will be implemented through subsidiaries of Softlogic.
Impact: (i) Job creation: The project is expected to generate 930 direct jobs, with a significant part of the workforce drawn from the local community. In addition, the project will also generate indirect employment related to the supply chain of the tourism sector.(ii) Best practices in hotel management: The hotel is expected to be managed by a global hotel chain and will bring best practices in the sector to Sri Lanka.(iii) Increase access to high quality consumer products: The project will increase the number and geographical reach of retail products for Sri Lankan consumers and also make the products available to lower income segment of the population in smaller cities.
Role:
(i) Provide long-term tailored capital to support Softlogic''s growth in the tourism and retail sectors in Sri Lanka. The tenors provided by IFC are not readily available in Sri Lanka.
(ii) IFC will share its experience and expertise in the tourism and retail sectors which is expected to contribute to an improved capital structure, efficiency of operations and risk management, especially in the hotel sector which is new to the Company.
(iii) Forge a long term strategic partnership which will be leverage to support Softlogic''s broader growth plans across the other sectors as well.
(iv) IFC''s investment will function as a stamp of approval for the Company which is expected to help the Company attract other potential debt and equity investors.
Sponsor: Founded in 1991, Softlogic has been publicly listed company on the Colombo Stock Exchange since July 2011. Its largest shareholder is Mr.Ashok Pathirage who holds 43.4% of the shareholding. Other significant shareholders include Mr. H.K.Kaimal (8.3% shareholding), Mr. R.J.Perera (7.8% shareholding) and Mr.H.U.Gunawardena (7.3% shareholding).
Cost Nature: The total project cost is US$67.7 million. The proposed IFC investment of up to US$30 million (or equivalent in local currency) will include A Loan(s) for IFCs own account and equity/quasi equity in Softlogic and/or its subsidiaries. The proceeds of IFCs financing will be used to partially fund the planned expansions in retail and tourism sectors.

Project Description: Azure Sun Energy Private Limited (Azure Sun) is a 100% subsidiary of Azure Power India Private Limited (AZI), an existing IFC client. Azure Sun has been awarded a 25-year concession to construct and operate a 2.5 MW rooftop solar power (Project) in Gandhinagar by the Government of Gujarat. This concession was awarded through a process of competitive bidding. The power generated under the Project will be sold at a pre-agreed tariff to Torrent Power Limited (TPL), a privately owned distribution company that holds the license for electricity distribution in Gandhinagar and several other cities in Gujarat. About 80% of the roof top solar panels will be installed on the roofs of government buildings, while the balance 20% will be installed on the roofs of privately-owned buildings.
Impact: 1. Demonstration effect: The Project will serve as a role model for rooftop generation of solar power. It is expected that after implementation of the Project, the Govt. of Gujarat will roll out larger rooftop programs in Gandhinagar as well as other cities in the state. Other states such as Rajasthan are also expected to follow suit.2.Private Sector Development in Solar Rooftop Energy Generation: The Project is first public private partnership (PPP) for rooftop solar generation. IFC support to a roof top solar project will help to attract other potential sponsors to such nascent clean energy program.3. Contribution to Climate Change Mitigation: The Project helps mitigate adverse climate change impacts by tapping in to clean and renewable energy source.
Role:
1. Provision of Long Local Currency Financing: : IFC will provide a long-term local currency loan that will make the project more viable. Although funding for renewable energy project is available in India, but such long term funding, which makes the renewable energy project more viable, are not available yet. IFC''s debt will help the Project in managing appropriately the uncertainties associated with variations in currency exchange rates

2. Catalytic role in attracting other Financiers: The rooftop solar program is at a very early stage in India. While IFC has previously provided financing to NDPL for its rooftop project in Delhi, the business model there was very different as NDPL was essentially supplying to itself. This Project is a true public private partnership (PPP) that involves a government concession to a private sector company for generating and supplying electricty to a power offtaker. IFC''s financing will show viability for such clean energy projects that will attract other financiers to provide funding for future rooftop solar PPPs. Without IFC''s financing, the Company would run the potential risk of not raising planned capital in a timely manner, thereby delaying the execution of a high development impact project
Sponsor: Azure Sun is 100% owned by AZI, an Indian solar power company incorporated in 2008.AZI develops, constructs, owns and operates solar power plants. Currently, it has 17MW of solar power projects operational and another 40MW under development. AZI carries out all engineering and construction related work for its projects through a subsidiary. AZI was founded by an Indian resident, Mr. Inderpreet Wadhwa. Other shareholders of AZI include Foundation Capital, Helion Ventures, DEG and IFC.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$ 6.2 million. The IFCs proposed investment is an A Loan of Indian Rupee equivalent of US$4.6 million for a period of up to 15 years.

Project Description: The Project involves up to US$50 million under a funded risk participation by IFC in the Banks supplier finance program for Goodyear. In the first phase of the Project, IFC expects to support over 10 Suppliers of natural rubber originating from Indonesia. In later phases, the Project may be expanded to include Thailand and Malaysia. Further due diligence and development of separate documentation by IFC will occur when and if such expansion is considered.  Citibank is a global financial institution, headquartered in the United States, with presence in 160 countries. The Bank currently operates multiple supplier finance programs in North America and around the world. Supply chain finance is a core product of Citibanks overall trade business under Global Transaction Services (GTS).
Review Scope: This project is proposed under the US$ 500 million Global Trade Supplier Finance program (GTSF or the Program) approved by the IFC Board in September 2010. (Original Project Link #28723). Under GTSF, IFC will support short-term financing to Suppliers (Suppliers) in emerging markets selling to large companies (Buyers) on open account terms. Under this project, IFC will enter into a funded risk participation arrangement with Citibank N.A. (Citibank or the Bank) for financing Suppliers to selected Buyers that are clients of the Bank and for whom Citibank operates supplier finance programs in emerging markets. The Buyers under the supplier finance structures are expected to have management systems and processes to develop the necessary assurance of good Environmental and Social (E&S) performance among their Suppliers. IFCs supplier due diligence will be based upon IFCs review of the Buyers management systems and procurement practices applicable to their supply chain that are relevant to E&S practices among their Suppliers, usually as a component of the companys approach to Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR).The proposed investment is the first project with the Bank under this participation arrangement and it involves provision of financing Suppliers to Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company (Goodyear).  IFC due diligence under the proposed project has involved: (i) consultations with Goodyear staff to understand procurement of natural rubber in Indonesia, the structure of Goodyears supply chain, including the use and role of traders and/or processors to source rubber and Goodyears Supplier Code of Conduct that encompasses E&S standards for suppliers; (ii) a review of Goodyear documentation pertaining to E&S standards, trade of rubber, etc; (iii) a review of publically available information describing Goodyear traders and/or processors; (iv) a review of secondary information concerning the state of rubber production in Indonesia and key aspects of the rubber supply chain, and; (v) consultations with key Indonesian actors, including rubber industry associations and conservation NGOs.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is considered to be an E&S Category B Project.The most common potential E&S risks associated with production of natural rubber include labor management and working conditions, chemical use and disposal, and conversion of natural/critical habitats. The common E&S risks associated with rubber processing include labor and working conditions (including OHS) and management of effluents. Risks associated with production of natural rubber are manageable although the supply chain for Indonesian rubber is fragmented and has many layers of consolidation, as further described below. Where risks are encountered in processing, they are both manageable and site specific.

Project Description: IFC is considering an equity investment and a loan to Sakr Energy Solution FZCO (SES or the Company), a multiregional power rentals and emergency power solutions provider serving temporary and short to medium term energy needs across the MENA region and in Africa.  Headquartered in Jebel Ali free zone in Dubai, the Company is capable of serving both small short-term clients with power generation needs starting at 50 kVA and large long-term utilities, governments and companies with power requirements of up to 60 MW. As of March 2012, the Company owns more than 157 MW of gensets fabricated in either 20 ft or 30 ft containers.  The Companys existing fleet operations are distributed in Tanzania, Qatar, Saudi Arabia,   Yemen, Saudi Arabia and UAE.  The Company has a workshop to conduct maintenance of gensets in Jebel Ali in Dubai.
Review Scope: - Review of the Companys documentation of its policies and practices, including: environmental assessment framework; environmental performance specifications for rental power gensets; procedures for noise control, environmental, health and safety (EHS) arrangement during delivery, installment, commissioning and decommissioning of rental power gensets; EHS training programs; emergency response and preparedness arrangements; environmental monitoring arrangement; and energy efficiency and greenhouse gas emissions.- Meetings and discussions with the Companys officers in charge of EHS management in March 2012; and- Site visit to the Companys existing rental power genset operations in Tanzania in March 2012.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The Companys business activities is to provide a small scale diesel-fired rental power generation equipment for a short period of time, delivered and installed in most of the cases in remote areas.  Key environmental and social issues are air emissions and noise from gensets, environmental, health and safety management and performance during delivery, installation, operation of rental gensets.  Such business activities have limited potential adverse environmental or social impacts and risks and therefore, the Project is a category B project in accordance with IFC Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability. Upon application of the measures described below, the Companys business activities will meet the requirements of the IFC Performance Standards. **Information On IFCs Policy and Performance Standards on Environmental and Social Sustainability can be found at www.ifc.org/sustainability
Sector: V-AE - Multi Fuel - Thermal Power Generation

Project Description: IFC is considering and equity investment and a loan to Sakr Energy Solution FZCO (SES or the Company), a multiregional power rentals and emergency power solutions provider. SES is a regional provider of power generation solutions to serve temporary and short to medium term energy needs across the MENA region and in Africa, headquartered in Jebel Ali free zone in Dubai. The Company is capable of serving both small short-term clients with power generation needs starting at 50 kVA and large long-term utilities, governments and companies with power requirements of up to 60 MW. This Company is a provider of power generation solutions to serve temporary and medium-term energy needs across the MENA region and Africa. By investing in the Company, IFC would be supporting the expansion of a business which addresses the power supply-demand imbalance in these difficult emerging countries and give them the time to implement efficient permanent solutions. This Project fits well with IFCs strategic priorities in the MENA region by catalyzing South-South investments and promoting investments in the frontier countries and sectors and improving infrastructure services.
Impact: 1. The project is expected to alleviate the demand-supply deficit in MENA and Africa and mitigate the negative impact on economic growth. 2. Through investing IFC will help capitalize a player with the technical expertise and risk appetite to invest in frontier countries.3. SES'' additional capacity is expected to be deployed to also alleviate disaster induced power shortages.4. The project will help to facilitate economic growth by making available short term capacity to large scale industrial projects, overcoming supply bottle-necks.5. The deployment of units to remote areas that are not yet connected to the national grid increases rural access to electricity.
Role:
1. Non-financial risk mitigation: IFC, with its reputation and relationship with governments, would provide SES with protection from certain political risks.
2. Stamp of approval: IFC''s investment would provide the Company with both comfort and greater credibility to pursue its development and attract other investors to secure further financing, and in particular debt financing to fund its investment plan.
3. Environmental and social standards/implementation: IFC will help the Company improve its capacity in the many areas of environmental and social management, in particular social and environmental assessment and management systems. IFC will also introduce policies, provide guidance, and where needed will help to establish standards in these areas.
Sponsor: Gulf Capital is an alternative asset management company focusing primarily on late-stage control buy-outs, growth capital, real estate development and credit business, based in the United Arab Emirates. Its Private Equity strategy is to acquire strategic stakes in profitable and fast growing companies in select industries. It is an active investor with a particular focus on operational improvements and regional or product expansion.
Cost Nature: IFC is to invest up to US$17 million in equity and debt for IFCs own account to support the Companys capital expansion plan.

Project Description: BB Energy, an international trading company with main trading centers in Dubai and London, has been awarded a 2-year contract to supply refined oil products in Mauritania. The proposed financing consists of a short term trade facility, set up together with Société Générale, DFIs and other commercial lenders, to finance BB Energys importation of refined energy products into Mauritania. The funding will be used by BB Energy to purchase various liquid fuels from world markets and store the fuels at two fuels storage terminals located in Nouakchott and Nouadhibou, Mauritania, respectively. Both terminals are owned by Government of Mauritania and managed by professional management companies. The Nouakchott terminal is managed by Mauritanienne dEntreposage des Produits Pétroliers (MEPP) and the Noudhibou terminal is managed by Société de Gestion des Installations Pétrolières (GIP), which is mainly owned by Société Nationale Industrielle et Minière (SNIM), the largest state owned company in Mauritania. SNIM has obtained ISO 14000 for its operations in mining operations.
Review Scope: The review of this financing consisted of appraising technical, environmental, occupational health and safety, and social information submitted by BB Energy (Gulf) DMCC (the Sponsor) and an independent consultant. The environmental and social (E&S) team reviewed the Sponsors environmental and engineering management plans and desk review of corporate E&S risk assessment provided by independent consultants. The E&S team met the Sponsors management representatives and fuel storage terminal management team and visited the fuel storage terminal and jetty in Nouakchott, Mauritania in May 2011.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: BB Energys main business is refined energy products trading. BB Energy will mainly purchase liquid fuel from international spot markets for this project. Both fuel storage terminals are located at port industrial areas and built a few kilometers from the shore. The tank farms have sufficient secondary containment systems. The fuel tanks are installed with floating roofs to prevent vapor emissions. Both terminals have established EHS procedures for operations. The potential adverse E&S impacts of this project are therefore few in number and limited to project sites, and may be readily mitigated. This is therefore an E&S Category B project in accordance with IFCs Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability.
Sector: G-AC - Other Petroleum and Coal Products

Project Description: The proposed project consists of a revolving secured short term trade facility, with a significant funding mobilization factor, to support key private sector operators (the international energy trader and domestic oil marketing companies) in their access to finance the import, purchase and marketing of refined fuel products in Mauritania. The proposed project would lend in parallel along with Societe Generale, DFIs and other commercial lenders to BB Energy- the successful bidder under Government of Mauritanias oil import tender arrangement.  BB Energy, an international trading company domiciled in the United Arab Emirates, has been awarded a 2-year contract to supply refined oil products to Mauritania for 2012-2014.  The funding will be used by BB Energy to finance: (i) purchase of oil products imported into Mauritania and related storage expenses; (ii) as well as related receivables against local oil product marketing companies, and major domestic industrial entities which are consumers of refined fuel products.
Impact: The proposed investment will have significant development impacts as follows:(a)	Maintain the availability of trade finance for trade businesses in Mauritania. The Project is expected to finance in excess of US$1.5 billion of energy commodity trade flows to Mauritania over two years by providing much needed liquidity.  This will protect an IDA economy against the risk of energy shortages, the risk of being cut off from suppliers as commercial banks have reduced their emerging market exposure.(b)  Ensuring availability of energy products in the local economy, critical for consumption, power and other energy needs.  A steady supply of critically needed fuel through regular channels will keep prices in check, remove parallel market incentives, and improve affordability particularly for the vulnerable poor and is necessary to sustain economic activities.  (c)	SME Development -  By supporting the private sector companies in the country''s downstream oil sector, the project will provide business opportunities to local private companies involved in transportation, distribution, and retail of refined oil products
Role:
(a) With the help of IFC, Mauritania can access commercial and official sources of funding to finance the import of refined energy products essential for the working of its economy, covering the country''s entire energy needs over the next two years. Due to the continuous constraints on banks traditionally active in the trade finance space, including European banks, and the increased cost of US funding, the proposed facility will allow continued importation of energy products into Mauritania. Without this facility, all sectors and economic agents, such as power generation, transportation, agriculture, industrial and commercial entities and households will be negatively impacted, hurting economic activity. There is also a risk that the current successful tendering and private sector involvement would stop, forcing the State to get again involved in the trade of fuel products, use scarce foreign exchange reserves for energy rather than food imports, and potentially resorting to barter trade if state financing were not available. This will be a setback to Mauritania''s reform program of private sector development and devolving the importation and marketing of energy to private companies.

(b) IFC''s presence enables the mobilization of financial resources from other development financial institutions and also commercial lenders. In the current market environment, Mauritanian risk is hard to finance, notwithstanding the security structure from pledged oil and confirmed L/Cs from international banks, and currently importers have difficulty accessing discounting facility of commercial banks, an arrangement needed to finance their trading operations.
Sponsor: BB Energy (Gulf) DMCC, domiciled in the United Arab Emirates, is part of the BB Energy Group of companies  (the Group).  The Group is mainly active in the oil trading business for crude oil, refined petroleum products and bitumen.  It is ultimately controlled by members of the Bassatne family.  Established in 1969, BB Energy Group is well represented through trading and services companies in London, Singapore, Dubai, Beirut and Athens with over 200 employees.  The Group trades around 7-10 million metric tons of crude oil and petroleum products annually.
Cost Nature: The facility size will be up to $500 million two year arrangement to finance the importation of refined energy products into Mauritania.  Out of the total  $500 million facility, IFC and Société Générale are each considering an exposure of up to $150 million for their respective accounts and both institutions together plan to mobilize up to $200 million from commercial banks and DFIs.

IFC would support job creation in Russia since Elbrus' midcap growth strategy is in full alignment with IFC's development impact goals.(ii)	Access to Finance: Long-term equity/risk capital is limited in Russia. Project Description: The Reventazon Hydropower Project (PHR) comprises the construction and operation of a dam and 305.5 MW hydroelectric power plant (HPP) on the Reventazón River, Province of Limón, located at 8 kilometers southeast of the city of Siquirres (Caribbean side of Costa Rica). The Project design includes the construction of a 130-m high dam, a 6.9 km2 reservoir with a volume of 118 MM m3, a 700-m long diversion tunnel, and hydroelectric generation facilities. In addition, the construction of the PHR also requires about 20 km of new internal access roads, a 1.8 km long Transmission Line, spoils disposal and construction materials extraction sites, and a construction camp. Project construction started in 2009 and is expected to end in 2015. The excavation of the temporary diversion tunnel for the construction of the dam and the river diversion infrastructure have been completed, construction of the spillway has started, and all of the ancillary infrastructure (e.g. access roads, construction camp, borrow pits) are completed and operational. The river diversion took place in April 2012, and dam construction has commenced. The PHR is the third hydroelectric dam project the Instituto Costarricence de Electricidad ('ICE' or 'Client') will construct in the Reventazón River and will be the hydroelectric project with the highest energy production in the Country.  ICE currently operates three other HPPs on the Reventazón River: Cachi HPP has been in operation since 1966, it is the most upstream facility, with a capacity of 108 MW; Angostura, currently the most downstream hydropower plant, has operated since the year 2000 and has a capacity of 177 MW; and La Joya, which is operated by ICE under a BOT agreement, started operations in 2005 and is the smallest of the three with a capacity of 50 MW. The PHR is located about 38 km downstream of Angostura tailrace.
Review Scope: IFC's environmental and social appraisal consisted of:Review of Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) documents and process and additional studies prepared by ICE to complement the ESIA, including but not limited to those disclosed at the early stages of IFC's appraisal Reventazon HPP Early DisclosureVisits in March and April 2012 to the Reventazón HPP site and project area of influence. IFC also visited two of the existing upstream ICE's HPP projects, and the downstream portion of the Reventazón River to the confluence with the Parismina River and the Tortuguero National Park areas; Meetings in San Jose with ICE's environmental, social,  and occupational health and safety teams; and Interviews with property owners affected by existing ICE HPPs in the upper Reventazón watershed, communities located in the project's direct area of influence, communities located downstream of the project; families directly affected by land acquisition, and one of the main White Water Rafting (WWR) operators, as well as representatives of the tourist boat operators at Barra de Parismina. Meetings were also conducted with the Mayor of the Municipality of Siquirres.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: PHR is a Category A project because of the potential significant and irreversible impacts on the Mesoamerican biological corridor which is considered critical habitat, the ecological integrity of the Reventazón River, and on the complex and ecologically sensitive downstream Reventazon  Parismina  Tortuguero hydro-biological system.
Sector: V-BA - Large Hydro - Renewable Energy Generation

Project Description: IF C proposes to purchase up to US$75 million in bonds (up to five years) issued via a Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV) under a Diversified Payment Rights (DPR) securitization structure by Finansbank in Turkey. The proceeds will be used to finance Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs).
Environmental Social Info: As an existing client, Finansbank has implemented an ESMS to screen against the IFC Exclusion List, applicable national environmental and social laws, and the IFC Performance Standards; and maintained its exposure to the IFC Exclusion List within the agreed upon 3% cap of total portfolio. During the appraisal, IFC analyzed the Banks pipeline and portfolio, and reviewed the capacity of the bank to manage social and environmental risks and to undertake E&S due diligence in line with IFCs policy requirements. Based on the analysis of the potential social and environmental risks, the bank will be required to ensure compliance with the IFC''s Exclusion List, and Host Country Laws and Regulations.
Impact: 1. Provide & mobilize term financing: the Project will provide a significant amount (US$150-200 million) of long-term funding to the bank, which would otherwise be difficult to obtain under current market conditions. 2. Access to finance for the underserved markets: the Project will increase access to finance for MSMEs, thereby supporting economic growth and job creation.
Role:
1. Anchor investor and fund mobilizer: as one of the lead investors in the DPR transaction, IFC will play a key role in allowing the transaction to reach a minimum targeted issuance size.
2. MSME funding: the proceeds of IFC''s investment in the DPR structure will be channeled to financing MSMEs.
3. Support a strategic subsidiary of a main Greek bank amidst the challenges of the Greek banking sector crisis.
Sponsor: Finansbank is a universal bank that provides a variety of corporate, retail and investment banking products and services. The Bank was established in 1987 by Mr. Husnu Ozyegin. In 2006, National Bank of Greece (NBG) acquired the bank from the Fiba Group. As of March 2012, Finansbank was the eighth largest bank in Turkey with total assets of US$26 billion and a branch network of 522 branches.
Cost Nature: The Project targets a bond issue of US$150-200 million of which IFC will consider investing up to US$75 million.

Project Description: The project consists in the development, construction and operation of a 305.5 MW hydropower generation plant (the 'Project') in the Reventazón river basin located in Siquirres, province of Limón, Costa Rica.  The construction process has started and the Project is expected to start operations in 2016.  The Project is expected to generate around 1,400 GWh annually, on average, once operational; representing around 10% of the energy expected to be produced in Costa Rica by then.The Project will be developed through a special purpose vehicle (Fideicomiso Reventazón or the 'Trust', a Costa Rican trust).  The Trust is expected to lease the Project to Instituto Costarricense de Electricidad ('ICE') when operational.
Impact: The Project is expected to have high economic and developmental impact in the following ways: 1) provision of critical infrastructure to support economic growth: the Project is expected to generate around 1,400 GWh of base-load power generation annually, or about 10% of the country's total generation, helping to meet increasing power demand driven by economic growth; 2) decreasing carbon emissions through the displacement of fossil-fuel powered generation.
Role: 1) Providing longer term financing than otherwise available in the commercial bank market, which is critical given the long-term nature of hydropower assets; 2) jointly with IADB, ensuring that the Project will be developed and operated in accordance with best Environmental & Social industry practices.
Sponsor: The Project's sponsor is ICE, a 100% state-owned company founded in 1949 and dedicated to the provision of power and telecom services in Costa Rica.  In the electricity sector, the ICE group currently generates or offtakes around 95% of the energy produced in the country.  In the telecom sector, ICE is the incumbent operator and currently provides all related services in the country (fixed, mobile voice, data and broadband internet).  The company faces competition from several private sector operators mainly in the mobile and broadband segments.
Cost Nature: The Project cost is expected to be around US$1,400 million.  The proposed IFC investment consists in a US$100 million A Loan.   The remaining debt financing for the Project is expected to be provided by the Interamerican Development Bank ('IADB') and a group of international institutional investors.

Project Description: The proposed project (the Project) involves an investment of up to US$55 million in Educomp Solutions Limited (Educomp or the Company). Educomp is one of the largest education companies in India, with over 17,000 employees reaching 29,000 schools and approximately 19 million learners around the world.Educomp has four business segments: (i) School Learning Solutions which includes SmartClass, a comprehensive learning management system blending content and technology, and EduReach, a business that provides computer-aided learning systems and content to Government K-12 schools; (ii) K-12 Schools which includes pre-schools and brick and mortar K-12 schools; (iii) Higher Learning Solutions which focuses on vocational training through a JV with Pearson, university education through a JV with Raffles Education, and teacher training; and (iv) Online, Supplemental & Global, which includes various other initiatives including assessments and counseling, tutoring, and test preparation.  The Companys offerings span a range of pricing options that make them affordable to both middle and lower income learners.The project will help the Company refinance debt to optimize the capital structure and allow more of its cash flow to be used for capital expenditures to support Educomps growth and further domestic and international expansion. IFC is considering providing both equity and debt facilities to this Project.
Review Scope: The IFC review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information made available by the Sponsor. The appraisal involved meetings with senior management of Educomp as well as a review of the Companys environmental and social systems and policies and the approach to planning and designing new schools. In addition, visits were made to an established Millennium School, the JRE University in Noida, and two Universal Academy schools in Haryana, in order to appraise how the Company manages environmental and social issues.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The Project has been categorized as Category B according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The nature of the Companys operations, which involve the provision of educational and IT services, is such that adverse environment and social (E&S) risks and impacts are limited, site specific and may be readily mitigated. Key environmental, social, health and safety issues associated with the Project during construction and operation include: the Sponsors system to manage E&S issues during construction and operation of schools; land acquisition issues at school sites; labor and working conditions; life and fire safety design and provisions; resource efficiency; and community engagement.  The Project may result in a limited number of specific adverse environmental and social impacts that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. The Company will manage its environmental and social performance in accordance with applicable local laws and regulations and international standards, including IFCs Sustainability Framework and World Bank Group (WBG) Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) General Guidelines.

Project Description: The proposed project (the Project) involves an investment of up to US$55 million in Educomp Solutions Limited (Educomp or the Company).  Educomp is one of the largest education companies in India, with over 17,000 employees reaching 29,000 schools and approximately 19 million learners around the world.Educomp has four business segments: (i) School Learning Solutions which includes SmartClass, a comprehensive learning management system blending content and technology, and EduReach, a business that provides computer-aided learning systems and content to Government K-12 schools; (ii) K-12 Schools which includes pre-schools and brick and mortar K-12 schools; (iii) Higher Learning Solutions which focuses on vocational training through a JV with Pearson, university education through a JV with Raffles Education, and teacher training; and (iv) Online, Supplemental & Global, which includes various other initiatives including assessments and counseling, tutoring, and test preparation.  The Companys offerings span a range of pricing options that make them affordable to both middle and lower income learners.The Project will help the Company refinance debt to improve the capital structure and allow more of its future cash flow to be used for capital expenditures to support Educomps growth and further domestic and international expansion.
Impact: - Expanding equitable access to quality basic and secondary education.  Educomp is one of the largest K-12 education services providers in India.- Improving quality education in India, both in public and private schools and in tertiary education, through its learning management systems and technology products, tutoring, assessments / test preparation, and teacher training services. - Promoting innovation, knowledge transfer and scalability in the Indian education sector, given the Company''s role as a market leader and the fact that many competitors may become followers of successful business and academic practices.- Bringing about a significant demonstration effect that the use of technology in education can effectively help improve learning outcomes.- The Project will support the growth of the Educomp''s employee base in key business segments over the next four years.  - Potential for South-South investments, as the Company has expansion plans in other developing countries including some in Africa.
Role:
- IFC has a long term investment horizon and will be a long-term capital provider. The IFC investment would help to refinance debt, and provide new capital that better fits the Educomp''s cash flow profile as it allows for the Company to utilize more of its cash flows for expansion purposes. IFC would also provide longer tenor financing than is typically available to the Company.
- The project will help create a strategic partnership between Educomp and IFC. IFC''s extensive contacts in the industry can help facilitate the Company''s expansion in the region, as well as into new regions, and into new business lines over time. IFC expects to share both industry contacts and knowledge of best practices over the course of the partnership with Educomp.
- IFC would come in at a strategic time for Educomp, and the investment will help with investor confidence at a challenging time for the education and information technology sectors in India''s capital markets.
Sponsor: The sponsor is Educomp founder and current Managing Director, Shantanu Prakash.  As of 12/31/11, Mr. Prakash owned 46.2% of the Company, while his wife, Ms. Anjlee Prakash owns 3.4%.  Most of the remaining portion of Educomps share capital is publicly traded on Indias two most significant stock exchanges: the Bombay Stock Exchange and the National Stock Exchange, where the Company has been listed since January 2006.

Project Description: The proposed investment is to provide financing to the Company in the form of an A loan to Astarta (Astarta or the Company), a leading primary agriculture producer in Ukraine to support the (i) construction of the soybean crushing facility to process locally grown soybeans into meal for the local market and oil, potentially for export, (ii) construction of the biogas facility, (iii) expansion of agricultural land, (iv) purchase of supporting farm machinery, storage and dairy infrastructure to increase production volumes of crops and (iv) further modernization of sugar production and storage (the Project).Astarta is an integrated agricultural company with strategic focus on the sugar manufacturing and sugar by-products from eight sugar plants in operation and sales, cultivation and sale of grains and oilseeds. Also, the Company produces milk.IFC may be able to contribute advisory services related to energy efficiency and cleaner production concerning opportunity for manufacturing bio-plastic from sugar molasses and introduction of fieldlook project, satellite based instrument for precision agriculture of sugar beet.
Review Scope: IFCs environmental and social review of this project included a visit to Astarta office located in Kyiv, Ukraine and the following facilities located in the Poltava region, Northeastern Ukraine: a selected sugar plant, a site for a future soybean crushing plant, a construction site for a biogas facility located in the vicinity of the town of Globino; a seed treatment plant, a local agricultural laboratory, and a machinery yard located near the settlement of Shishaki.  The appraisal also included meetings and discussions with Astarta senior management and specialists (operational, financial, business development, environmental, health and safety, human resources, agricultural, standardization and certification, internal audit) and review of key environmental, health, safety and social documentation provided by Astarta, including a) project design documents related to environmental and social prevention and mitigation measures, b) relevant approvals and permits of the state supervisory authorities; c) corporate human resources policy and procedures; d) labor terms and working conditions, including occupational health and safety; e) pesticide handling practices;  f) land acquisition and leasing procedures, and g) stakeholder engagement plan. Though dairy cattle operations are not within IFC Project scope, a cattle dairy farm was visited and cattle farming activities were overviewed to evaluate potential environmental and social risks and impacts associated with the proposed financing to the Company.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Sustainability Policy. The Projects limited environmental and social adverse impacts can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to national laws and regulations, generally recognized performance standards and WBGs EHS guidelines.

Project Description: The Project will support LLC Astarta-Kyiv (the Company or Astarta), a leading primary agriculture producer in Ukraine with 240,000 ha of land under cultivation.  Astartas principal activities include (i) production of sugar beet and sugar processing, and (ii) production of other crops including wheat, barley, corn, sunflower, and soya. The Company owns and operates 8 sugar plants across 7 business units and 4 operational regions in Ukraine. IFC''s financing will support one of the leading grain and sugar producers in Ukraine. IFC financing will support the (i) construction of a 700 tpd soybean crushing facility to process locally grown soybeans into meal for the local market and oil, potentially for export, (ii) construction of a biogas facility, (iii) expansion of agricultural land, (iv) purchase of supporting farm machinery, storage and dairy infrastructure to increase production volumes of crops and (iv) further modernization of sugar production and storage capacity. IFC''s financing will also support a viable economic activity and create new jobs in some of the poorest frontier rural regions of Ukraine (Vinnytsya, Khmelnytsky, among others).
Impact: The project is to support the growth and diversification of one of the leading farm enterprises in Ukraine, engaged in the production of crops, sugar and milk. The corporate investment program will include in particular: (i) a cost reduction program for sugar production; (ii) a biogas capture component that will both reduce GHG emissions and improve energy efficiency in processing; and, (iii) a soybean processing project that will add value to the local production of soybeans while serving the needs of the fast developing livestock and poultry sector. This program will contribute to the growth of the Ukrainian economy, to global food security by increasing production of key crops exported from Ukraine, while supporting direct and indirect employment in rural areas where alternative job opportunities remain scarce.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Sustainability Policy. The Projects limited environmental and social adverse impacts can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to national laws and regulations, generally recognized performance standards and WBGs EHS guidelines.
Sponsor: 36.99% of Astarta is owned by Viktor Ivanchyk and 25.99% by Valery Korotkov, with the remaining 37.02% floated on the Warsaw Stock Exchange.
Cost Nature: IFC will provide corporate financing to the Company in the form of an up to US$50 million long-term loan to support Astartas on-going modular investment program aimed at providing value addition and diversification to its main business units.  The IFC long-term loan will partly finance the Companys FY2012-2013 capex program of approximately US$175 million. The remaining portion of the capex will be financed from long term loans from other financial institutions and internal cash generation.

Project Description: IFC is proposing an equity investment of up to US$15 million in PetroNova Inc., a TSXV-listed oil and gas exploration company with operations in Colombia. The Company has working interests in five onshore exploration blocks in Colombia. Two blocks are operated by PetroNova namely the PUT 2 Block (The Company has 100% working interest) and the Tinigua Block (The Company has 90% working interest) both located in the Caguan-Putumayo Basin. Three blocks are operated by Tecpetrol namely CPO6, CPO7 and COP8 (The Company has 20 % working interest in all three) located in the Llanos Basin, In the period 2011-2012 2D and 3D seismic was aquired in the blocks operated by PetroNova: PUT 2 Block: 2D and 3D seismic completed Tinigua Block: 3D seismic 90% completed.    For these seismic activities the development of access roads was not required due to the seismic techniques applied which reduced the overall footprint of the activities. IFCs investement will  be used to finance the first phase of an exploration campaign (2012) including drilling of exploration wells and additional seismic acquisition if required (it is expected that IFCs financing will include about 12 exploration wells). The exact location of the exploration wells will be defined on the basis of the interpretation of the seismic information already acquired.
Review Scope: IFCs review included visits to PetroNovas (PetroNova or the Company) offices in Bogota, Colombia, where meetings and interviews with key staff (management, technical, human resources, environmental and social) and external environmental and social consultants were conducted. In addition, numerous documents related to the Companys environmental and social (E&S) management and performance were analyzed.  These included environmental health and safety policies; the integrated health, safety and environmental management program and procedures; environmental and social impact assessments; environmental, health and safety audit checklists; environmental, health and safety monitoring reports; stakeholder consultation methodology and outcome, as well as documentation of the consultation process with Indigenous Peoples in line with Colombian requirements for consultation (Consulta Previa). IFC also met with E&S representatives from PetroNovas joint venture partner, Tecpetrol (an Argentinean mid-size independent oil and gas company with operations across Latin America and the United States) the operator of three blocks where PetroNova has minority participation. A visit was conducted to an exploration well operated by Tecpetrol in the Llanos Basin. In addition, meetings were conducted with representatives from two communities of Indigenous Peoples who have been involved in a process of consultation (Consulta Previa) for seismic activities with PetroNova and Tecpetrol.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project as the impacts related to the establishment of temporary exploration wells and potential additional seismic activities are site-specific, largely reversible and adverse impacts if any, are temporary and can be readily mitigated through the mitigation measures identified in the ESIA. The Company has an environmental and social team in place with adequate capacity and a solid E&S Policy and management system to address the level of impacts related to the exploration activities to be financed by IFC. The E&S policies and management systems are in line with national legislation, good international industry practice and IFC Performance Standards. Some of the seismic activities which had already taken place prior to IFCs involvement were located on the land of Indigenous Peoples. Prior to initiating these seismic activities the Company engaged with the Indigenous Peoples in a process of consultation in line with the Colombian requirements for consultation (Consulta Previa) as well as the principles of Free, Prior, Informed Consent. In case any of the future exploration activities are located on the land of Indigenous Peoples the Company has committed to engage in a process of Free, Prior and Informed Consent. This will ensure a robust consultation process where potential impacts and adequate mitigation measures are identified and implemented if the Indigenous Peoples agree to the planned activities.  For the three blocks in the Llanos Basin that are not operated by PetroNova, the operator Tecpetrol has a solid E&S management system in place as well as competent staff to manage their operations in line with national legislation and good international industry practices. PetroNova has procedures in place to ensure that Tecpetrol is managing E&S issues adequately on an ongoing basis.

Project Description: PetroNova Inc., is a small independent oil and gas exploration company with operations in Colombia and listed on the TSX Venture Exchange.  The company has interests in five exploration blocks located in the Caguan-Putumayo Basin and the Llanos Basin, namely the PUT-2, the Tinigua, CPO6, CPO7 and CPO13.   According to its business plan, the company is carrying on an exploration program that includes acquisition of seismic and drilling of exploration wells. The Project consists of the exploration program for 2012 and first quarter of 2013.
Environmental Social Info: Having considered the Project''s benefits and assessed potential governance and other risks to these benefits, IFC has come to the view that the project should be supported.  In coming to this view, IFC has examined various governance and corruption indexes for Colombia, including the World Bank Institute''s Governance Indicators as well as Transparency International''s Corruption Perception Index and ranking of ease of doing business by Doing Business Report. Relative to its peers in Latin America, Colombias governance indicators show relatively strong and improving performance. Both Transparency International and the World Bank Groups Doing Business Report rank the country in the top of the region (3rd in terms of ease of doing business in the Doing Business 2012 Report; 4th in the CPI 2011).The National Hydrocarbons Agency (ANH) administers Colombias hydrocarbon resources, and is responsible for granting hydrocarbon concessions for exploration and production; evaluating the hydrocarbon potential of the country; and collecting royalties on behalf of the Government.  ANH publicly discloses royalty revenues statistics and concession terms on its website.
Impact: IFC''s investment will be used for early exploration activities.  Development impacts for exploration activities are typically limited and at this stage mainly limited to some local employment and procurement. If the exploration efforts are successful, significant development impacts are expected to be realized, including:i) Creation of local employment opportunities through direct hiring and indirectly through PetroNova''s contactors.  ii) Fiscal benefits to the Government of Colombia through royalties and income taxes. iii) Procurement of oilfield services and supplies from local and regional sources, thus fostering local economic development.
Risk Assessment: Having considered the Project''s benefits and assessed potential governance and other risks to these benefits, IFC has come to the view that the project should be supported.  In coming to this view, IFC has examined various governance and corruption indexes for Colombia, including the World Bank Institute''s Governance Indicators as well as Transparency International''s Corruption Perception Index and ranking of ease of doing business by Doing Business Report. Relative to its peers in Latin America, Colombias governance indicators show relatively strong and improving performance. Both Transparency International and the World Bank Groups Doing Business Report rank the country in the top of the region (3rd in terms of ease of doing business in the Doing Business 2012 Report; 4th in the CPI 2011).The National Hydrocarbons Agency (ANH) administers Colombias hydrocarbon resources, and is responsible for granting hydrocarbon concessions for exploration and production; evaluating the hydrocarbon potential of the country; and collecting royalties on behalf of the Government.  ANH publicly discloses royalty revenues statistics and concession terms on its website.
Role:
(i) Provision of risk capital: PetroNova is still at an early exploration/appraisal stage and does not generate material revenues, thus it depends on external funding to finance its capex program. As an anchor equity investor with global expertise in upstream oil & gas and local knowledge, IFC is well positioned to provide long-term support for the company''s plans.
(ii) Mobilization: IFC investment is expected to play a catalyst role in the market, attracting further equity investments, especially at a time when exploration companies find it increasingly difficult to attract market investors due to the current financial turmoil and flight to quality trend.
(iii) Environmental and social sustainability: PetroNova is committed to adopt best international standards on environmental and social management. With IFC''s support, PetroNova will enhance its environmental, social, health, and safety management systems, which will be fully compliant with the IFC''s Performance Standards.
Sponsor: Founded in 2009, PetroNova was formed by the Inelectra Group, one of the largest engineering and construction groups in Latin America dedicated to providing services to the energy sector.  PetroNova was spun off from the Ineletra Group in 2009 and listed in TSXV after its IPO in 2010.  The company''s shares are widely held by a diverse range of institutional and individual investors. The main shareholders are two families, who collectively hold close to 25% of the outstanding shares.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at US$73 million.  IFC is considering an equity investment for its own account and mobilizing investments from third parties for a total amount of up to US$27 million.
