Project Description: Edilar, S.A. de C.V. (Edilar or the Company) provides training materials, books and electronic media and on-going education financing to public sector teachers in 27 states of Mexico. Edilar supports teachers from the public sector by facilitating the access of teachers to training and training materials. Edilar has a large geographic presence and reaches public sector teachers in rural areas. The project will finance the Companys working capital needs for the next three years, as it expands its client base to further cities and states within Mexico. Edilar has additional offices in 23 states, each office serves as regional distribution center. In addition, Edilar has mobile distribution centers that distribute the materials to remote areas in Mexico.
Review Scope: IFCs Environmental and Social due diligence of the project comprised site visits to Edilars main offices in Mexico City, the main Distribution Center (warehouse) in Mexico City and a distribution center in the city of Queretaro, state of Queretaro where environmental and social conditions were observed. In addition to site visits, discussions were held with Edilars management team regarding human resources policies and procedures and management of environmental and social matters in Edilars operations. Meetings with representatives of the Secretariat of Public Education of Queretaro (Secretaría de Educación Pública de Querétaro - SEP) and the local section of the Mexican National Educational Workers Union  (Sindicato Nacional de Trabajadores de la Educación-SNTE) were held to discuss the conditions of Edilars agreements with those entities. IFCs team observed promotional activities carried out by Edilar representatives with its clients (public sector teachers).Documents reviewed included Edilars policies and manuals for recruitment and management of personnel, samples of contracts with commission agents (sales representatives) and employees, sample of agreements with education authorities and teachers union, life and fire safety inspections, and records of maintenance of vehicles.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, procedures, guidelines and design criteria. **Information On IFCs Policy and Performance Standards on Environmental and Social Sustainability can be found at www.ifc.org/sustainability

Impact: Provision of quality education material: Edilar plans to expand its product offering and geographic reach further. This will have a strong development impact by providing public sector teachers with books, teaching material and ongoing training financing and thus enhancing the quality of the Mexican public education system. Strengthening Corporate Governance: Edilar is in the process of institutionalization and could benefit from IFC''s experience in working with family-owned companies, especially given the stage in which Edilar is and the need for succession planning.

Stamp of approval: Edilar seeks iFC''s participation since the Company plans to tap debt and equity markets in the medium-term. IFC''s investment in Edilar will give potential investors comfort in the Company''s financial and operational performance.

Project Name: Housing Finance Co. of Kenya - Green Financing
Company Name: HOUSING FINANCE COMPANY OF KENYA LTD
Project Description: The proposed project is a senior loan of up to $16 million for IFCs own account and a senior loan of up to $4 million by IFC in its capacity as the implementing entity of the Canada Climate Change Program (CCCP) to Housing Finance Company of Kenya Limited (HFCK or the Company) to support the Companys funding base and help it grow its mortgage and property development finance business, with an added incentive to develop a green housing portfolio (the Project).
Environmental Social Info: The key risk is the ability of HFCK to identify and manage the environmental and social risks associated with its lending activities particularly lending to project developers, and to ensure consistency in E&S performance between its own property developments, and those to which it provides finance. Additional E&S risks and impacts of the Project derive from the capacity and systems in place to manage these risks, and the Companys practices with regard to labor and working conditions. At present HFCK does not have an  Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) outlining the procedures, responsibilities and tools for undertaking E&S risk management of its lending activities and, apart from assessing compliance with national environmental permitting requirements, E&S related due diligence is not yet part of the Companys loan review process. No staff/department has been assigned responsibility for E&S due diligence and monitoring, and training needs to be provided to all staff involved in ESMS implementation.
Impact: The Project is expected to generate a range of social and economic benefits related to mortgage lending. With CCCP funds complimenting IFC''s own funds, it is expected that the Project will also generate environmental benefits through the development of energy efficient green housing projects. The Project may also have a strong demonstration effect in Kenya and beyond - to financial institutions seeking to build their green housing business and to property developers seeking to green their portfolio. Specifically, the Project will: (i) increase access to affordable housing in Kenya through growth in mortgage lending; (ii) help to grow housing supply in Kenya through on-lending to property developers; (iii) facilitate energy efficient housing developments and therefore introduce and promote a new sustainable housing product into the Kenyan market; (iv) enhance environmental and social (E&S) management capacity of HFCK and therefore help the Company to improve E&S and sustainability standards for property developers; and (v) help abate green house gas emissions as a result of construction of green buildings.
Role:
Financial Risk Mitigation: IFC will provide long-term funding of up to 7 years that is not readily available in the market.
Standard Setting: IFC will introduce E&S standards to help HFCK to better manage E&S risks of lending to property developers.
Knowledge and Innovation: IFC will apply and share its global expertise in sustainable housing to help HFCK introduce an innovative housing product in the Kenyan market.
Mobilization: IFC will help arrange donor funding which, subject to HFCK satisfying certain performance criteria, will qualify for certain concessional terms.
Sponsor: HFCK is listed on the Nairobi Stock Exchange and has approximately 29,000 shareholders. The Companys major shareholders (above 5%) include Equity Bank Limited (24.9%), British American Insurance Company (Kenya) Limited (12.5%), Equity Nominees Limited (8.14%), and the National Social Security Fund (6.8%). The Government of Kenya, through the Permanent Secretary Treasury, has a shareholding of 3.7%.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a senior loan of up to $16 million for IFCs own account and a senior loan of up to $4 million by IFC in its capacity as the implementing entity of the CCCP, in each case with a tenor of up to 7 years. In addition, IFC may provide advisory services to HFCK for capacity building in the area of green housing

Project Description: Hidrovias do Brasil S.A. (HDB) is developing a barge operation in the Paraguay-Parana river system in South America through a wholly owned Uruguay-based subsidiary. The Project consists of the acquisition, operation and maintenance of a push boat and barge fleet for the transport of iron ore from Corumbá in Brazil down the river system for export. The Project is expected to deploy 8 convoys in the river system with an estimated annual capacity of over 3 million tonnes.
Review Scope: IFCs review included meetings and interviews with Hidrovias do Brasil (HDB or the Company) key staff involved in the development of the project, including its recently hired Environmental, Health, and Safety (EHS) manager, and review of relevant internal documents including the technical description of future project activities, equipment design specifications, and the Sponsors development of Environmental and Social (E&S) programs.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This Project has been classified as Category B according to IFCs E&S Review Procedure. The Projects principal risks and impacts will be associated with the operation and maintenance of the Companys pushboats and barges, including but not limited to: management of fuels and lubricants; solid and liquid wastes; effluents and emissions; occupational health and safety; navigational safety and collision prevention; human resource policy and working conditions of employees; and emergency preparedness and response planning. These risks and impacts can be readily addressed through well established mitigation measures.

Project Description: Hidrovias do Brasil S.A (HDB) is developing a barge operation in the Paraguay-Parana river system in South America through a wholly owned Uruguay-based subsidiary. The Project consists of the acquisition, operation and maintenance of a push boat and barge fleet for the transport of iron ore from Corumba in Brazil down the river system for consumption and export. The Project is expected to deploy 8 convoys in the river system with an estimated annual capacity of over 3 million tons.
Impact: The proposed IFC investment will help to:(i)	increase the supply of efficient, low emission transport services on the Parana-Paraguay River System;(ii)	increase competition in the barging sector, encouraging operators to improve efficiency and reliability of service;(iii)	 create additional employment for the region;(iv)	foster South-South investments; and(v)	improve supply chain management and support the development of the iron ore and steel industries in the region with follow-on benefits for construction and industrial sectors.

Project Description: Galnaftogaz PJSC (GNG or the Company) is the third largest petroleum distribution company in Ukraine and a long-standing IFC client. GNG has created a joint-venture (ADM JV) with another IFC client, ADM CEECAT Fund (ADM), to build/purchase and operate about 80 modern fuel retail stations in four eastern regions of Ukraine (Luhansk, Donetsk, Dnipropetrovsk, Zaporizhia), where GNG currently has little presence.  GNG will be responsible for building and operating the stations under a management contract and under its flagship OKKO brand. The proposed IFC investment is a corporate long-term financing and EBRD, a joint lender for the previous GNG project, is being offered the option to match the IFC financing.
Review Scope: The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health, safety, and social information submitted by the project sponsor. The environmental and social (E&S) team reviewed the implementation of Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) for the existing project with the sponsor. Engineering designs for the renovation of the existing fuel storage terminals are also reviewed by the E&S team. The E&S team also held meeting with the sponsors management team and visited the project sites in March 2011.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: GNG currently operates 350 gas retail stations, of which 319 are its OKKO brand stations. The remaining stations will also be refurbished to OKKO brand gradually. All the new retail stations in this project are OKKO brand stations. The OKKO brand stations are refurbished or built according to European Union (EU) standards, in which the underground fuel tanks have double steel layers and leak detection devices. Fuel tanks in main terminals have vapor recovery installation. The land acquisition for the new gas stations will be strictly on a willing buyer / willing seller basis. GNG has established EHS procedures for operations. Mitigation measures for the potential E&S impacts have been identified and are incorporated into an attached Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP).The potential adverse E&S impacts of this project are therefore few in number and limited to project sites, and may be readily mitigated. This is therefore an E&S Category B project.
Sector: G-AC - Other Petroleum and Coal Products

Project Description: The Project is to raise capital for IHH Healthcare Berhad (IHH or the Company), a Malaysia-based healthcare and medical education company with operations in eight countries across Asia and CEEMENA. The capital is being raised to strengthen the Companys balance sheet for future growth, and to fund working capital requirements. The global healthcare network of IHH operates, directly and indirectly, about 4,800 licensed beds in 30 hospitals, as well as medical centers, clinics and ancillary healthcare businesses across 8 countries including in India, China, Vietnam, Hong Kong, Brunei, Macedonia, Turkey, as well as Singapore and Malaysia.
Review Scope: The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety related information related to IHH and two of its key subsidiaries: Parkway Pantai Limited (PPL) and Acibadem Holding (a former IFC client) as well as Apollo (an existing IFC client).  The Environmental and Social Review Summaries for IFCs previous investments in subsidiaries of this group are available at: (3 for Apollo; 2 for Acibadem).  This review builds on previously disclosed ESRSs and ESAPs and the information collected during IFCs engagement with these companies over the past years.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Based on the site visit to two operational hospitals in Singapore and two in Malaysia as well as a visit to a new hospital in Singapore due to open in July 2012, IFCs previous experience in the healthcare sector and with other parts of IHH, and review of client and IFC information by IFCs Environment and Social Specialist, this project will have limited potential adverse environmental and social impacts. The project has been classified as Category B according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The key social and environmental aspects associated with the project include: the ability to implement rigorous and systematic management systems such as JCI, management of solid and liquid wastes, particularly biomedical wastes, and life and fire safety.   Potential adverse impacts arising from the issues mentioned above are limited, site specific and can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized industry performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.

Company Name: ACWA GUC ELEKTRIK ISLETME VE YONETIM SANAYI VE TICARET ANONIM SIRKETI
Project Description: The purpose of the Project is to finance a greenfield approximately 835 MW natural gas fired combined cycle gas turbine power plant investment with an estimated project cost of USD 900 million located 50 km east of Ankara, near the city of Kirikkale, Turkey (the 'Project'). The Project is sponsored by International Company for Water and Power Projects ('ACWA Power') and Eser Holding Anonim Sirketi ('Eser Holding') (together the 'Sponsors').  The Project will be developed by Farcan Enerji Uretim Anonim Sirketi ('Farcan Enerji' or 'the Company'), which is currently owned 70% by ACWA Power, and 30% by Eser Holding.  As part of the Project, the Company will also build 380 kV transmission lines from the plant to the national grid (about 63km).  Natural gas will be supplied from the existing natural gas pipeline (Samsun-Ankara gas pipeline) owned by BOTAS Petroleum Pipeline Corporation which passes through the border of the plant site.  The Company selected a closed wet cooling system to limit water usage.  Water will be extracted from 9 Caisson wells to be established at the riverbed of Kizilirmak River, which is located about 100 to 150 m from the Project site. The 835 MW plant called 'ESER Natural Gas Combined Cycle Power Plant' will be developed on land of approximately 22.7 ha located within the boundaries of Kiliclar Municipality of Yahsihan District in Kirikkale Province.  The 22.7 ha site is owned by the Treasury of the Government of Turkey, and will be leased to the Company.  The site is a hilly natural meadow and is not presently used for any purposes.  The exact routing of the connecting transmission lines will be determined after a joint site visit by the Company and TEIAS (Turkish Electricity Transmission Company).  Based on the available information, the first transmission line is from the Project site to the future Kayas Substation, which will be constructed by TEIAS (30km), and from the Kayas Substation to the existing Golbasi Substation (25km).  The second transmission line is planned to be from the Project site to the new Kirikkale Natural Gas Combined Cycle Power Plant under development (8km).  The routing of these lines is not expected to pass any urban or ecologically sensitive areas.  About 3km of existing road from the national Ankara-Kirikkale highway to the Project site will be used as an access road to the Project site.  This existing 3km roadfrom the national highway to the Project site will be widened to allow transportation of heavy equipment.  The Company is expected to sign the Engineering, Procurement and Construction ('EPC') agreement with Samsung C&T Corporation, and to start construction late in 2012.  The construction period will be about 30 months, and the Generation Licence to be issued by Energy Market Regulatory Authority (EMRA) will allow the Company to operate the plant for 49 years.  The plant will be operated by ACWA Power's subsidiary company called NOMAC, an Operation and Maintenance (O&M) operator.
Review Scope: Documents reviewed:- ESER Natural Gas Combined Cycle Power Plant Project, Environmental and Social Impact Assessment, July 2012- ESER Natural Gas Combined Cycle Power Plant Project, Stakeholder Engagement Plan, September 2011- ESER Natural Gas Combined Cycle Power Plant Project, Non-Technical Summary, September 2011- ESER Natural Gas Combined Cycle Power Plant Project, Environmental and Social Management and Monitoring Plan, September 2011- Farcan CCPP, Technical Feasibility Report, 26th of Aug, 2011- ACWA Power's E&S management system documents and corporate presentation file, presented to IFC in July 2012- ESER's E&S management system documents and corporate presentation file, presented to IFC in July 2012- NOMAC's E&S management system documents and corporate presentation file about O&M Overview presented to IFC in July 2012Interviews in July 2012:- Officers of ACWA Power and ESER in charge of the Farcan Enerji project development and E&S assessment and management- Environmental Project Manager of ESER Project and Engineering CompanySite visit in July 2012:- Proposed project site- Kizilirmak River and its riverbed where Caisson wells will be installed to supply water to the Project- Existing gas pipeline point where gas will be supplied to the Project- Possible transmission line routes from the Project site to the Golbas substation of TEIAS- Nearest village (Hacibali), about 2km from the Project site
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The Project is to develop a new large scale natural gas fired combined cycle plant (835MW) in an unused meadow land about 50 km east of Ankara and the key environmental and social issues are: (i) water supply and effluent discharge; (ii) air quality impacts; (iii) management of spoil from excavation activities during the construction phase, (iv) E&S impacts of associated transmission line construction and (v) conversion of natural habitat.  Due to the potential significant adverse environmental and social impacts and risks, this Project is a category A project according to IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedures.

Company Name: ACWA GUC ELEKTRIK ISLETME VE YONETIM SANAYI VE TICARET ANONIM SIRKETI
Project Description: The purpose of the Project is to finance a greenfield approximately 835 MW combined cycle natural gas fired power plant ('CCGT') investment with an estimated project cost of about USD900 million located 50 km east of Ankara, near the city of Kirikkale, Turkey (the 'Project'). The proposed investment is an A Loan of up to USD125 million and a B Loan of up to USD75 million to Farcan Enerji Uretim Anonim Sirketi ('Farcan Enerji' or the 'Company'), a special purpose vehicle incorporated in Turkey.
Impact: Turkey Country Partnership Strategy FY2012-2015 outlines strategic objectives for fast, sustainable, equitable and inclusive growth that respects the environment. In line with this strategy, the World Bank Group aims to contribute to improved supply of reliable and efficient energy, increased use of renewable energy and climate actions under implementation. The Project will have a significant development impact as it will: (i) increase Turkey's electricity output and help meet the country's growing energy demand and provide power supply security; (ii) in doing so, reduce Turkey's reliance on coal and lignite, thereby reduce carbon emissions in electricity generation; (iii) support power sector reform by increasing the share of private generation in Turkey's overall electricity generation in order to move towards possible EU accession and the creation of a regional energy market; and (vi) by size and nature of the transaction, influence Turkey's ability to continue to attract foreign investment in the energy sector. Through the above, the Project will positively impact the fiscal and macroeconomic stability of Turkey.
Role:
The Sponsors are seeking to raise project finance on a limited recourse basis from the local and international financial markets when there is (i) reduced funding availability due to the spillover from the European Debt Crisis and (ii) higher risk perception related to the Turkish merchant power market that is still in transition into a fully competitive market model.

IFC's role and additionality in this Project will include: (i) supporting a reputable regional investor entering to Turkey's power generation market, which is in transition and in strong need of private sector investment given the looming power deficit in generation (South-South investment); (ii) providing long term financing that commercial banks currently cannot provide at sufficient scale without IFC B loan umbrella; (iii) sharing IFC's extensive know-how of deregulated power markets; (iv) advising on contractual and financial structuring issues considering the merchant risk embedded in the Project; (v) IFC's comfort to participants under its B-loan umbrella and other parallel lenders in a major energy financing with merchant risk in the transitioning electricity market in Turkey; and (vi) ensuring the implementation of adequate environmental and social standards in line with World Bank Group standards, which are not required under Turkish legislation.
Sponsor: The Project is sponsored by International Company for Water and Power Projects ('ACWA Power') and Eser Holding Anonim Sirketi ("Eser Holding") (together the 'Sponsors'). The Project will be developed by Farcan Enerji Uretim Anonim Sirketi ('Farcan Enerji'), which is currently owned 70% by ACWA Power, and 30% by Eser Holding.Founded in Saudi Arabia in 2004, ACWA Power is the largest independent power producer ('IPP') developer in the Middle East and North Africa ('MENA') and one of the fastest growing companies in Saudi Arabia. The ACWA Power focuses on power generation and desalinated water production in the region. ACWA Power holds both majority and minority equity ownership in a portfolio of contracted assets comprising 8,000 MW of power plants, of which 3,170 MW is composed of CCGTs, and 2.3 million m3/day of desalinated water production plants, with a total investment value of over USD 12 billion.Eser Holding is a local construction company operating in Turkey and the near region. Eser Holding is a private company. Eser Holding completed numerous projects in Saudi Arabia, Sudan, Afghanistan, and other countries in Central Asia, Eastern Europe, Middle East and Africa. Eser Holding has experience in all stages of construction and project cycles, with know-how from design to construction and commissioning to operation. Eser Holding has a power generation pipeline of nine hydro power plants with an estimated total installed capacity of 102MW.

Company Name: KENYA TEA DEVELOPMENT AGENCY HOLDINGS LTD
Project Description: Kenya Tea Development Agency Holdings (KTDA (H)) is seeking IFC financing for the construction of a 200,000ft2 warehouse in Mombasa.  Kenya Tea Development Authority was established in 1964 as a government agency to promote tea growing in small farms. In 2000, Kenya Tea Development Agency Limited was incorporated as a private company, becoming one of the largest private tea management agencies in East Africa. KTDA is owned by 54 individual tea companies that operate 65 tea processing factories across Kenya. Each tea company is owned by a number of smallholder tea farmers; there are approximately 562,000 smallholders supplying tea leaves to KTDA companies. Smallholders are farmers with plots close to their homes, used for small scale cash crop farming, subsistence farming and stabling of farm animals. Tea smallholders in Kenya typically own 0.5 to 2 acres of land used primarily for tea farming; each farmer produces an average of 1500 kgs of tea (green leaf) per year.KTDA (H) operates through a number of subsidiaries:KTDA Management Services (KTDA-MS) - provides management services to KTDAs tea factories; Chai Trading Company Limited (CTCL) - provides warehousing and logistics services to KTDAs tea factories;Kenya Tea Packers (KETEPA) - packages and brands tea produced by KTDA factories  for the local market; Majani Insurance Brokers - provides insurance brokerage services to KTDA and other clients; Greenland Fedha - provides microfinance services to KTDA farmers; Kenya Tea Power Company (KTPC) - a power development company that  focuses on renewable energy; and KTDA Tea House Ltd  a tea lounge in Nairobi.IFC funds will be invested exclusively into the warehouse project. The construction of the warehouse will be managed by KTDA-MS through a civil contractor (contract yet to be awarded) and the operation of the warehouse will be managed by CTCL.
Review Scope: IFCs environmental and social review of the project included: (i) meetings with senior management of KTDA Holdings and KTDA subsidiaries, and with operational staff responsible for environmental, health and safety for two subsidiaries, Chai Trading and KTDA Management Services, and one factory - Makomboki Tea Factory; (ii) inspection of Chai Tradings Miritini Warehouse in Mombasa; (iii) inspection of the site for the proposed warehouse in Mombasa; (iv) inspection of a KTDA tea factory  Makomboki Tea Factory, Thika  and nearby tea collection centre and farmstead; and (iv) review of KTDAs and its subsidiaries environmental policy documents, environmental assessment reports and audit reports, and human resources (HR) documents.  IFC also reviewed the E&S issues associated with KTDAs supply chain i.e. KTDA tea factories and farm operations and processing plants that make up the supply chain.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability. The environmental and social risks and impacts associated with the construction and operation of the warehouse are limited, site-specific and can be readily addressed through generally accepted mitigation measures.

Project Name: Loan to LAPO Microfinance Bank, Nigeria
Project Description: The proposed project will support the expansion of LAPO Microfinance Bank (LAPO MFB), which was created by the transformation of the microcredit activities of Lift Above Poverty Organisation into a regulated financial institution in 2010. LAPO MFB provides credit and savings services to its target market of micro entrepreneurs, most of whom are small-scale traders in urban and peri-urban areas. LAPO MFB also works with partners to provide insurance coverage and health and educational services to its clients. It currently serves over 500,000 clients across more than half of Nigerias 36 states and is expected to reach more than 2 million clients during the life of the project.
Impact: The project will have a high development impact considering that microfinance has been shown to play a major positive role in sustainable reduction of poverty and unemployment in developing countries. It will deepen financial inclusion in Nigeria, where access to finance remains extremely limited for low-income populations. IFC''s support to LAPO MFB is expected to have a strong demonstration effect and encourage the professionalization of locally-sponsored institutions, especially NGOs seeking to transform into microfinance banks.
Role: IFC brings along extensive microfinance expertise and a relatively unique combination of investment and advisory services. These contributions will support the bank''s ability to initiate operations, effectively scale up and build local staff/management capacity. IFC will promote LAPO MFB''s ongoing transformation into a regulated, commercial financial institution, improving its governance and risk management structures while funding its expansion and enabling it to develop new products, including on-demand savings accounts. The long term nature of IFC''s participation, which is generally not available to microfinance institutions in Nigeria, will support LAPO MFB''s ability to provide longer tenors to its clients.
Sponsor: The sponsor of the project is Lift Above Poverty Organisation, which created LAPO MFB in 2010. Lift Above Poverty Organisation was registered in 1993 as a non-governmental organization (NGO) dedicated to poverty reduction. The NGO was the vehicle for the microcredit activities transferred to LAPO MFB for many years and has developed several other programs during this time. Since 2010, it has focused its activities primarily on health, education and womens empowerment programs, which are conducted by its staff of 100 and through partnerships.
Cost Nature: The total cost of the project is NGN 800 million (~US$5.0 million) to be offered in local currency over a period of 4-5 years. IFC is also considering providing advisory services to enable LAPO MFB to expand and improve its product range and to enhance the effectiveness of its management systems.

Project Description: The proposed investment is to support Agrofusion Group (the Company), a tomato paste and industrial tomato producer in Ukraine, by strengthening its capital base through refinancing existing short term debt and financing incremental permanent working capital.Established in 2007, Agrofusion is the largest vertically integrated tomato paste producer in Ukraine, marketing its products mainly to large FMCG (Fast Moving Consumer Goods) companies in Ukraine, Russia, other CIS countries, and to a lesser extent Western European markets. The Companys operational assets include:  (i) two tomato paste plants with total processing capacity of approximately 300,000 metric tons of tomatoes per season (6,000 tons of tomatoes a day); (ii) two seedling green-houses; and (iii) 12,000 hectares of irrigated leased land in Mykolayiv and Kherson regions, as well as modern farming equipment.

The Project has limited potential adverse environmental and social impacts, and those that do exist are site-specific and can be resolved through the effective implementation of the action items in the attached E&S Action Plan (ESAP), which integrate IFCs Performance Standards (PS) requirements and good international industry practices as defined in World Bank Group (WBG)s general and applicable sector-specific (Annual Crop Production, Food and Beverage Processing) Environmental, Health and Safety requirements. Company Name: BANK OF AYUDHYA PUBLIC COMPANY LIMITED
Project Description: The proposed investment is a US$ 200 million credit line to Bank of Ayudhya Public Company Limited (BAY) to be used for flood relief purposes by extending sub-loans to SMEs in Thailand.
Impact: Support the economic recovery: The worst flooding in Thailand in half a century is expected to reduce the country''s economic growth by 1-1.5%. The Project will support the country''s disaster responses by providing source of emergency liquidity.Financial sectors deepening: The Project will enable a local bank to access foreign currency funding and provide a level playing field with foreign banks that have the benefit of parent funding.Increase financing to sub-borrowers: The project will contribute to an increase of BAY''s loan portfolio.

Project Description: Grupo Calidra S.A. de C.V. (Calidra or the Company); Mexicos leading producer of lime, construction hydrated lime, quicklime, dolomitic lime, chemical hydrated lime, and calcium carbonate products; operates twenty plants across Mexico and one in Honduras.  Nine of its plants comprise quarrying, calcination, hydration and packaging, 11 plants are combined hydration and packaging operations, and Calidra also has one paper bag manufacturing plant.  Its products are used in the construction, steel, chemical, mining, agricultural, waste treatment industries, amongst other industries.  The proposed project with IFC includes: Operations in Mexico.  Strategic capital investments in Mexico including:  Purchase of equipment to increase production capacity as follows:Installation of 400 tons per day (tpd) Maerz kilns at its Sonora and Minorte plantsInstallation  of hydration operations at Calidra de Occidente  Santa Cruz site (25 tph), Cal de Apasco (11 tph) , and Cal Quimica Mexicana (25 tph) Installation of a dry mortars plant at Calidra de Oriente, Upgrade of the packing operations at various facilities as follows: (a) automatic packing at Calidra de Occidente Santa Cruz and semi-automatic packing at Zapoltiltic sites, (b) Cal Quimica Mexicana, (C) Cal de Apasco (increase existing capacity by 50%)Installation of crushing and screening facilities at Minorte Durazno quarry, Cal de Apasco and Calhidra de Sonora plants;New quarry and quicklime plant in CampecheQuicklime handling facility at Arcelor Mittal in Lazaro Cardenas to support a long term contract Joint venture with two existing lime producers located in central Mexico to implement the following projects:A greenfield project that includes installation of crushing and screening operations, a 250 tpd Maerz kiln, a quicklime handling facility, and solid fuel installations at the Cal Los Arcos plant located in Vizarron, QueretaroA 150 tpd Maerz kiln at the Cal Muro facility located in MichoacánAdaptation of two production sites, Calidra de Oriente and Calidra de Occidente, to use biomass as a substitute fuelOperations in Peru. Construction of two lime facilities in Peru. The Company is establishing a greenfield operation in Peru by associating with the owner of the concessioned quarry, and is planning to open a second facility later in 2013Operations in Colombia. A 50% joint venture with Cementos Argos in Colombia to set up and operate two quicklime plants in the countryMexicoThe proposed upgrades to Calidras existing operations began in 2012 and will be complete by 2014.  For the proposed biomass project, Calidra has already acquired a biomass collection center at approximately 120 km from the Calidra de Oriente Plant.  Calidra has established a subsidiary, Plantaciones Comerciales Forestales (PCF), to handle biomass related activities.  Initially, PCF will acquire waste from wood processing facilities and will coordinate with plantation owners to acquire the discarded biomass resulting from plantations maintenance and clean-up.  Ultimately, PCF will acquire land to establish its own operations.  Calidra de Oriente is the first plant in Mexico to begin fuel replacement (18 % biomass) and Calidra de Occidente (36% biomass) will be the second Calidra plant by mid 2014.  To ensure biomass quality and quantity, the Company has set up a biomass collection and preparation center located 120 km from the plant, in Chignahuapan, Puebla, from which it sends the biomass to the Calidra de Oriente plant.  For the Calidra de Occidente plant, it is considering to use mainly (90%) Agave bagasse with the remaining 10% from wood processors and forestry clean ups.  Currently, the Company is developing a Planting and Harvesting Manual intended to identify the suitable species and establish the needed practices a plantation owner should apply aiming to establish a business model whereby plantation owners become PFC business partners and are in compliance with the IFC requirements.  A copy of this Plan will be submitted to IFC as indicated in the Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP). PeruCalidra anticipates building two greenfield plants in Peru.  The land acquisition and environmental permitting process for Calquipa, the first of these two plants, has been completed.  The plant will be located in the Callalli district, at approximately 188 km from Arequipa, Perus second largest city and at 3800 m altitude.  Calidra anticipates it will install the second plant by the end of 2012. The two plants will operate in full compliance with local as well as IFC E&S requirements.The Peruvian government has granted a 400 ha quarry concession which will be associated to Calquipa.  This quarry located 21 km from the plant and at 4880m altitude, will be operated by Calidra.   The plant will install a 400 tpd Maerz kiln to produce between 350-420 tons of quicklime per day.  Initially, the plant will use anthracite and pet coke; however it expects to begin using natural gas once the Peruvian government installs a proposed nearby gas pipeline by 2014. The anthracite will be transported by ship from the northern part of the country to the Matarani port where it will be temporarily stored. The anthracite and the pet coke will be transported by railroad respectively from the port and the Matarani Petroperu storage areas to the Chasquipampa station and from there by truck to the plant.  The electricity needed will be obtained from the power grid. Water needs will be supplied by the nearby Pulpera River, located 30 m from the project site.  In addition to the plant installation, the Company will also build needed internal access roads, a 1.7 km transmission line, and a 2.5 MW electrical substation.Calidra assessed three different sites prior its final site selection for the Calquipa plot based on environmental, technical, and socio economical aspects as indicated in the Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) developed for the project.ColombiaCalidra anticipates building two greenfield plants in Colombia.  The first plant is expected to be built near the town of Victoria in the department of Caldas (between Bogota and Medellin). It is planned that this facility will have a 400 tpd capacity kiln. A second plant is being evaluated, mainly to attend the export market, and could to be located in the Caribbean coast, near the town of Tolu, in the Sucre department.
Review Scope: The review of this project consisted of appraising environmental, health, safety and social information submitted by the Company, and assessing the Companys operations.  This was done through a field visit conducted by the project team in February 2012.  The environmental and social (E&S) appraisal team visited the proposed Company operations in Mexico, the proposed project site for one of the plants in Peru and conducted discussions in Colombia with Calidras joint venture partners related to the E&S issues for the proposed project.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project, according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review procedures because the environmental and social impacts that may result can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. The following potential environmental, health and safety, and social issues were analyzed:-	Corporate E&S capabilityRaw materials and resource managementAir emissions and wastewater managementQuarry exploitation and reclamation programsSolid waste management and disposalBiodiversity aspectsFire protection and emergency responseOccupational health and safetyLogistics and transportCommunity engagement and development initiativesUpon implementation of this project along with the mitigation measures summarized below and included in the attached ESAP, the project is expected to comply with IFCs E&S requirements, namely the laws and regulations of the relevant countries, IFCs Performance Standards (PSs) on Social and Environmental Sustainability and the applicable elements of the following World Bank Group (WBG) Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines: (i) General EHS Guidelines, (ii) Cement and Lime Manufacturing, (iii) Construction Materials Extraction, and (iv) Forest Harvesting Operations.

Project Description: Hummingbird Resources PLC is an AIM-listed mining company with exploration licenses in Liberia covering some 7,000 square kilometres. Dugbe F/Tuzon gold project is Hummingbirds main asset. The Dugbe project site is located in Sinoe County in the southeast of Liberia, inland of the port of Greenville. The project area is rainforest degraded by slash-and-burn subsistence agriculture, bush-meat hunting, selective logging, artisanal gold mining and recent gold exploration activities. There are several small villages in the area, many associated with active artisanal mining.The Dugbe F/Tuzon project has identified an inferred/indicated mineral resource and is currently continuing early exploration work. Dugbe exploration camp has been established on the west bank of the Jubo River and is the main centre of field operations. It houses about 80 staff and includes workshops for vehicle maintenance, woodwork, etc., a basic clinic, communications equipment and the core shed. Exploration drilling around this area has identified gold deposits hosted in Birimian rocks typical of this region of West Africa.A number of other smaller licenses are owned by Hummingbird, such as Kana Hills, Ba, Zia, Jubabli, Nemo Creek and Tiehnpo, with exploration work limited to stream sediment sampling, soil sampling and preparation for trenching and future drilling. IFC investment will finance continuing early exploration work at Dugbe to be undertaken prior to pre-feasibility study of potential future mine development.
Review Scope: IFCs review of the project consisted of an appraisal visit to Hummingbird Resources PLC (Hummingbird or the Company) prospects in Dugbe in southern Liberia. The appraisal reviewed environmental, health, safety, and social information submitted by the Company and identified their plans and commitments for the future development of the prospect. The IFC team held discussions with Hummingbirds management and technical staff, reviewed environmental health and safety documents, visited the drill sites, and conducted a meeting with the local community members in the village of Tuzon. The team also held a meeting with the Liberian Ministry of Lands, Mines and Energy in Monrovia.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFC''s Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability  because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts, at this early stage of mineral exploration, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to the applicable IFC Performance Standards, relevant guidelines and design criteria.IFCs categorization of this project is based on the impacts of exploration activities, which consist primarily of construction of access roads and drill pads for exploration drilling, construction of a base camp for worker accommodation and site office, limited temporary land acquisition, emissions of dust and water, and waste streams from camp activities and machinery maintenance. Any IFC investment in potential future mining development in Dugbe would be assessed as a new project and its categorization would be determined after the necessary due diligence.  Even without an additional investment, IFC would require any future mine development with major impacts to follow PS 1 in its requirements for independent monitoring of project social and environmental performance and informed consultation and participation with project affected people.  Hummingbird will ensure that social and environmental assessment documents associated with such a development will be consistent with the IFC Performance Standards and EHS Guidelines and be publicly available and consulted upon in accordance with IFCs disclosure policy prior to the start of any possible future mine development in Dugbe.

Department: CNGS7 - Gbl Infrastructure & Natural Resources/Infrastructure - LAC
Project Description:
The proposed transaction will finance the development, construction, operation and maintenance of a 50 MW greenfield wind power plant and related facilities. It entails an up to US$30 million A Loan, a client risk management product (i.e., interest rate swap) with a loan equivalent exposure of up to US$2 million, and a subordinated loan of up to US$17 million from the blended finance component from the Canada Climate Change Program (CCCP), which is a program financed by the Government of Canada and administered by IFC to support IFC's climate change mitigation projects. The total project cost is estimated at US$132.8 million. The project is being developed by Parques Eólicos del Caribe S.A ('PECASA' or the 'Company'), a Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV), in the City of Guayubin (Montecristi Province), in northwestern Dominican Republic. Akuo Energy ('Akuo' or the 'Sponsor') owns 90.5% of PECASA.
      
      
        The project is under construction and has a total capacity of 50MW, consisting of 25 Gamesa G114-2.1 MW, 80m hub height ('HH') and 114m rotor diameter ('RD') Wind Turbine Generators ('WTGs'). The WTGs will connect to a new substation also located in Guayubin that will increase the voltage from 34.5kV to 138kV. To facilitate the connection of the wind power plant, the Balance of Plant ('BoP') Contractor will build a new 138kV 14km overhead line (OHL) that will tee into an existing 138kV OHL. Ownership of the new OHL and the substation will be transferred to the Grid Operator, Empresa de Transmisión Eléctrica Dominicana ('ETED') upon commissioning. The project also involves the opening or improvement of 25 km of access roads. It is estimated that the construction period for the project will last 18 months. The nearest communities (El Copey and Los Limones) are located more than 2 km away from project's boundaries.
      
      
        Akuo has contracted the construction works under three main agreements: (i) with Akuo Energy including development services, construction management, and operations services; (ii) the Turbine Supply Agreement ('TSA') with Gamesa covering the engineering, supply, delivery, installation, and commissioning of the WTGs, and (iii) the BoP for the civil and electrical works with Sociedad Española de Montajes Industriales S.A. ('SEMI'). Maintenance of the WTGs will also be contracted to Gamesa under an Operation and Maintenance ('O&M') contract. The electricity generated by the project will be purchased by Corporación Dominicana de Empresas Eléctricas Estatales ('CDEEE') acting as off-taker under a Power Purchase Agreement ('PPA') with a 20 year duration starting at the Commercial Operations Date (COD).
Review Scope: IFC's first disclosure of this project was in August 2012. The project was approved by the Board of the World Bank Group in January 2013. As the project was sold to another company, and  years have passed since the first evaluation, an update appraisal was undertaken consisting of a desk review of environmental, social, health and safety, and labor (ESHS) information provided by the company, including: an environmental and social impact assessment (ESIA); complementary assessments consisting of a bat study and avian monitoring surveys; ESHS management plans and procedures; environmental license; Environmental Compliance Reports - ICA (Informe de Cumplimiento Ambiental); as well as Akuo's and PECASA's policies and procedures that will be applied to the project.  In addition, in May 2017 IFC conducted a visit to the site where the wind farm will be constructed, visited the nearby communities Los Limones and El Copey, interviewed some of the land owners that will be affected by the project, traveled through the roads expected to be used for transportation of towers, blades and turbines, met with the Mayor and advisors of Villa Vasquez (where is the port and the main road from which the wind turbines will be transported until Guayubin), held technical meetings with Akuo's and PECASA personnel and consultants in charge of deploying the project and managing ESHS issues, and met with the Director of Environmental Quality in the Ministry of Environment (MIMARENA).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFC's Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability because potential limited adverse environmental or social risks and/or impacts are few in number, generally site-specific, largely reversible, and readily addressed in mitigation measures. The main environmental, social and occupational health and safety (ESHS) impacts and risks related to the project, are those typically associated with the construction and operation of wind farms. Construction impacts and risks include: (i) land acquisition, (ii) clearing of soil and vegetation during excavation and construction, (iii) traffic safety and nuisance noise and dust, and (iv) health & safety risks for construction workers. Operation impacts and risks may include: (v) potential bird and bats mortality, (vi) turbine noise and shadow flicker, (vii) health & safety risks to O&M workers, and (viii) visual impact. All these risks and impacts are considered of limited magnitude and significance, and will be managed with established pollution prevention and control technologies and with standard environmental and social management practices, such as those described in relevant sections of IFC's General EHS Guidelines (e.g. Section 1.7 and Table 1.7.1 Noise Level Guidelines, and Section 2.0 Occupational Health and Safety - Working at Heights), and of the Wind Energy EHS Guidelines
Sector: V-BC - Wind Power - Renewable Energy Generation

Project Description: Hummingbird has successfully assembled a total of 14 exploration licenses (13 gold and 1 iron ore) covering 7,000 km2 of prospective ground in Liberia. Hummingbirds most advanced project is the Dugbe One Project (Dugbe or the Project) located in southeast Liberia about 275 km from Monrovia. The Companys focus is on the development of Dugbe.  The Dugbe exploration license (450 km²) was first granted in November 2005 to Hummingbird and was renewed in October 2009. The Dugbe exploration license would normally have expired on 24 October 2011.  As required by the license an application for a Mineral Development Agreement (MDA) was submitted prior to the expected expiry of the Dugbe exploration license, and on 14 September 2011 the Minister for Lands Mines and Energy of the Republic of Liberia wrote to Hummingbird to confirm that whilst the exact timings of the MDA application process were unforeseeable, all licenses controlled by Hummingbird are in good standing regardless of when their due date occurs.  Negotiations with the Government of the Republic of Liberia in relation to this MDA application are ongoing.Dugbe has a total mineral resource of 3.8 Moz (96 Mt grading 1.24 g/t ) including 1.4 Moz indicated and 2.4 Moz inferred. The resource is contained in the Dugbe F and Tuzon deposits. Dugbe is still very much at the advanced exploration stage and Hummingbird is looking to start a Preliminary Economic Assessment (PEA) of the Project, which will be followed by a prefeasibility study and a bankable feasibility study as quickly as all factors allow.
Environmental Social Info: Historically, governance has been weak in the country as captured by various governance metrics, including the World Bank Governance Indicators and Transparency International.   However, governance has been consistently improving since President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf took over in 2006. According to the World Bank Institute, governance in Liberia has consistently been improving over the last several years. Liberia became the first African country to be EITI compliant in 2009. Mineral Development Agreements have to be ratified by parliament and publicly disclosed. The World Bank Mining Policy Team and the International Monetary Fund Fiscal Affairs department have been assisting the government of Liberia on improving the legal and regulatory framework for mining. Further, given the early stage nature of the project and the limited benefits, especially in terms of fiscal revenues, any potential governance risks are deemed limited in the near to medium term.  The Government is actively engaged with the WBG to further improve governance and transparency of the sector.
Impact: Generally, exploration projects have limited development impact but even at this early stage, the proposed investment has shown tangible benefits to the surrounding communities by generating local employment for people in poor parts of eastern Liberia. Key expected benefits during development and operation will include notable social contributions by Hummingbird. Once developed, the Project will also bring revenues to the national government through royalties and taxes, notable local economic development in a poor part of a post-conflict IDA country through the generation of direct and indirect employment opportunities.

Role: Hummingbird has invited IFC to contribute to the financing of the Company and expects IFC to play an important role in various areas. Specifically, IFC is expected to: (i) provide environmental and social expertise, particularly as it relates to biodiversity management, resettlement and artisanal mining issues; (ii) provide a stamp of approval to the Project facilitating raising of additional funds for further exploration, and in due course development of a mining operation; and (iii) be a long-term shareholder.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Hummingbird Resources plc (the Company, Hummingbird or HUM), a mineral exploration company incorporated in England and Wales and headquartered in London.  The Company was founded in November 2005 by the Betts family (Stephen Betts and his son Daniel Betts) and a business partner Matthew Idiens, to explore for gold in Liberia. Hummingbird listed on the London AIM (symbol: HUM.L) in December 2010.  The Company has a market capitalization of GBP 48 million (53,500,565 shares at GBP0.90 per share) as of July 30, 2012.  The stock is widely held; major shareholders include: (i) Mark Hillery (11.3%); (ii) Capital Research & Management (7.8%); (iii) JP Morgan Asset Management (7.1%); (iv) BlackRock (6.5%); (v) Resource Capital Funds (5.1%). Management and directors hold approximately 16.7% of the Company.
Cost Nature: The next 18 months of project cost, which will include further exploration, a scoping study / PEA and environmental and  social studies, is estimated to be US$20million dependent on various as yet unknown factors, such as drilling of new targets.The proposed IFC investment consists of an initial equity investment of up to GBP 3 million. IFC will also receive warrants to subscribe to additional shares in the Company.

Project Description: Parques Eólicos del Caribe S.A (PECASA or the Company) is currently developing a 50 MW greenfield wind power plant.  The plant will consist of:  i) installation of 25x 2 MW Gamesa G97 wind turbine generators, ii) construction of a 14 km 138 kV transmission line; and iii) construction of access roads, a substation, and foundations/ platforms for the WTGs (the Project). The Project is located  near the town of Villa Vasquez in the province of Montecristi, in the northwestern part of the Dominican Republic (DR). The Project is being developed pursuant to a 20 year concession awarded by the Comisión Nacional de la Energía (CNE) of the DR  The Project is expected to produce approximately 156 Gwhs annually and will sell 100% of power produced to Corporacion Dominicana de Empresas Electricas Estatales (CDEEE) under a 20 year power purchase agreement (PPA).  The Project construction is expected to commence in November 2012 and be completed and commissioned by year end 2013.
Impact: (i) Diversifying the power generation mix in the DR: Currently the DR relies primarily on imported, expensive fuel to generate power.  The Project would enable local wind resources, rather than imported fuel, to generate power; furthermore, the cost of the Project''s power is significantly less than current wholesale power prices in the DR, so the country will add lower cost power to the energy mix; (ii) The Project is expected to generate approx. 156 GWh per annum of clean, non-fossil fuel dependent electricity generation that will displace an estimated 110,000 tCO2e per annum, leading to improved air quality and climate change mitigation.
Role:
IFC''s role and additionality in the financing of the Project include:

(i) The DR has a crucial need for additional generation capacity, but the commercial banking sector is hesitant to finance projects due to the perceived risks in the DR power sector. IFC''s financing would enable this Project to obtain the additional financing it needs in order to proceed; and

(ii) Successful completion of the Project would have an important demonstration effect, as it is expected to be the first long-term project financing of a wind power project in the DR. This should provide a strong signal to global power developers and commercial financial institutions that the DR provides a viable framework for successful development of renewable energy projects.
Sponsor: PECASA is 57% owned by Gamesa  Energía S.A.U. (Gamesa or the Sponsor).  Gamesa Energía S.A.U., a subsidiary of  Gamesa Corporacion Tecnologica SA, a Spanish holding company that trades on the Madrid Stock Exchange. Its largest shareholder is Iberdrola, with a stake of 19.62%. Gamesa is the fourth largest wind turbine manufacturer globally, with a market share of 11% and 8,000 employees worldwide.  It has installed more than 24,000 MW of its wind turbines in 20 countries and has a pipeline of more than 3,000 MW of wind power projects in Europe, the U.S, Asia and Latin American. The additional shareholders in PECASA are Promociones KEOPS (25%), a Spanish holding company focused mainly on real estate development and construction, and local shareholders Aquiles Mateo-Flaquer (9%), Miguel Angel Muniz (5%), and Vientos Alisios SRL SPV (4%).
Cost Nature: The total Project cost is estimated at approximately US$133 million. IFC is considering providing financing for up to US$ 32.5 million through an A Loan for IFCs own account. Co-financing in the form of parallel long term senior debt is expected to come from other international financial organizations, such as the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB).

Project Description: Stone Apple Solutions Pte. Ltd (Stone Apple or the Company) is a pan-Asian information technology (IT) services company founded in Singapore in 2009. The Companys main IT services include consulting and project implementation (installing and configuring of software and/or hardware); managed services (monitoring and maintaining of software, hardware and network); and software application development and testing. The proposed IFC financing to Stone Apple will be used to expand the Companys existing facilities in South East Asia and fund expansion into other emerging countries.
Impact: Employment: The Company''s expansion will increase the availability of direct and indirect jobs in the target countries where it plans to expand. IT services companies are usually the "first job" for many school graduates. The industry is also a source of employment for women as they allow them a job that recognizes their professional capabilities.Development of IT sector: The implementation of this project will promote the development of the IT services sector in South East Asia and in other emerging markets in the long-term fostering competition in the markets where it plans to expand. An investment in Stone Apple will also enhance the competitiveness of these markets as attractive destinations for outsourcing and offshoring.Export/ Economic Growth: Outsourcing/ offshoring generates significant export revenues helping organisations become more efficient and creating local employment thereby contributing to economic growth.Human Capital Development: Stone Apple implements useful training programs for its employees in various technologies. This project will enable the replication of these training programs to new markets where the Company is expanding.
Role:
Demonstration Effect: IFC''s involvement will continue reinforcing the position of South East Asia as an ideal destination for IT Services companies. IFC''s funding will also help to increase IT sector competition and improve service quality.

Global Knowledge and Expertise: Stone Apple will benefit from IFC''s global knowledge and expertise from investing in similar companies throughout the world. As the Company plans to expand within and outside of South East Asia, IFC''s guidance will add value to the Company.

Access to Finance: Debt financing is limited due to the Company''s limited hard assets to post as collateral and traditional lenders'' limited understanding of the IT sector. IFC''s investment will help the Company strengthen its balance sheet so it can focus its efforts on expansion and integration efforts. Without IFC''s funding, the Company will have difficulties in completing the financing plan and achieving its expansion goals.
Sponsor: The Company was founded by Mr. Madhujeet Chimni, Mr. Bharadwaj Chivukula and Mr. Rajeev Nair. The founders jointly hold a controlling stake in the Company. Mr. Chimni is the Chief Executive Officer of the Company. Other major shareholder in Stone Apple is Cambridge Anchorage, a privately held fund based out of Singapore.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is around US$25 million. IFC will provide a financial package of up to US$10 million and the remaining will be divided between Stone Apples internal cash generation and additional investors.

Project Description: China Flooring Holding Co., Ltd. (the Company or Nature) is one of the largest flooring manufacturers in China. The Company, which was established in late 2007 based on the restructuring of its fully owned onshore wood flooring business in China, has solid wood flooring and engineered flooring manufacturing sites and lumber mills in China and in Peru.  In China Nature owns and operates six manufacturing sites while another 13 are operated by Authorized Manufacturers (AMs: previously referred to as original equipment manufacturers or OEMs) who supply exclusively to Nature.  In Peru, Nature owns and operates one natural forest concession, one lumber mill, while one other concession (Majeryja), two further mills and a flooring factory are AMs.  Nature listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in mid 2011.IFCs first investment with Nature was made in 2008.  Since that time, Nature has acquired forest concession assets, specifically the Nature America Peru SAC natural forests concession in Yurimaguas, Peru (46,347ha) and the Ninglang (4,445ha) and Yingjiang (3,718 ha) mixed woods concessions in Yunnan Province, China.  Nature America is operational, the Yunnan assets are both pre-operational (i.e. at the time of this disclosure, no harvesting has taken place.  An AM-like entity in Peru holds the Maderera del Rio Yaverija (Maderyja) concession (49,556 ha) in Madre de Dios.  All of the Peruvian concessions are certified to the Forest Stewardship Council Forest Management (FSC-FM) standard and all the owned and operated lumber and finished flooring mills are operating under valid FSC COC certifications.  Further details on these aspects are provided in the PS6 analysis.   As the Company grows it seeks to develop plantation resources which it can control and which hedge against future wood price increases.  Specifically, Nature is seeking for a potential acquisition plantation forests in the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region of China (the Project).  At the time of this disclosure, the consideration of the Project by the Company is at early stage and there is no certainty of completion. The Company has not signed any letter of intention or any legally binding agreement for the Project.  IFC is proposing a $40m financing package to support the development of forest resources business of the Company, including the Project. The Environmental and Social Review Summary for the original investment details Natures group level operations: where relevant to the proposed new financing, updates have been captured in this document.  The proposed 33,000ha plantation in Jiangxi described in the original ESRS did not go forward.Further details of the project are provided in the Summary of Investment Information (SII).
Review Scope: Given IFCs existing investment with Nature , much of the information and analysis presented in this ESRS was originated through ongoing supervision activities, which has included visits to forestry concessions/operations in Peru and Yunnan, regular E&S review meetings (Shunde and Hong Kong) and visits to a number of production facilities in China.  For the proposed new financing, the review comprised visits to:- the initial target plantation area in Guangxi, China- the Ninglang concession in Yunnan, China.  The purchase of the Yingjiang concession in Yunnan was concluded shortly after the visits took place- the Peru operations, specifically the (1) Nature Wood SAC green lumber mill (Puerto Maldonado); (2) the Universal Flooring SAC finished flooring mill (Lima); (3) the Maderera del Rio Yaverija lumber mill; (4) Maderyja concession (Inapare); and (5) the Comunidade Belgica (a supplier to the Maderera Rio Yaverija)- three production plants in China (Kunshan, Zhengjiagang and Shunde)which manufacture engineered, solid wood and laminated flooring- an Authorized Manufacturers engineered flooring production plant in Shunde, China- worker accommodation in Shunde, China- Nature HQ in Shunde, where discussions were held the Natures legal advisors and other corporate functions.As IFCs proposed financing is at the holding company level, the E&S performance of all of Natures operations was considered relevant to the review.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The key environmental and social issues from the currently known plantation targets relate to land acquisition, including the potential for physical or economic displacement; land use change, including the potential to impact biodiversity or ecosystem services; development of supporting infrastructure (e.g. roads) and the potential to impact indigenous groups (referred to as ethnic minority groups in China).  Key issues from Natures broader operations center on concession management (Peru and Yunnan) and related assurance processes; third party wood sourcing and related assurance processes and operational management with particular reference to occupational health and safety, pollution control and community outreach and development.   The proposed use of IFC new financing and Natures underlying operations are considered to hold potential significant adverse social and/or environmental impacts that are diverse, irreversible or unprecedented and as such, the project has been classified as category A according to IFCs 2006 Environmental and Social Review Procedure.

Project Description: Alliar is a health imaging diagnostic company and a result of the merge of four companies in January 2011. After the initial merger, Alliar acquired other brands, and today sums ten different brands: Axial, Di imagem, Uni imagem, CSD, Plani, Cedimagem, Sonimed, Unic Ideal and Sabedotti. Altogether, the Company has 29 outpatient service centers across 14 cities throughout 5 States in Brazil, mainly focused on MRI and CT, serving a population of approximately 7 million people.  IFC is providing adequate long-term financing in support of the Company''s expansion plan, allowing sustainable growth.
Review Scope: IFCs review of the Alliar project consisted of a five-day appraisal visit conducted in March 2012 to assess the Companys operations, review environmental, health, safety, and social information submitted by the Company and understand their plans and commitments for the future development of the prospect. Five facilities of Alliars subsidiary (Axial) in Belo Horizonte MG, were visited as well as two facilities (Campo) in Belém, PA. In Belo Horizonte, Axial has two facilities integrated to existing hospitals as well as standalone Imaging Diagnostic Centers. Both types of facilities offer Magnetic Resonance Image (MRI), Tomography, X ray and Mammography diagnostic services.  In addition to that, Campo also offers clinical laboratory diagnostic and nuclear medicine with active contrast diagnostic.Meetings were held with local managers and operational directors.  This provided a good view of the current stage of development of the project, existing E&S practices and their strategies to conduct environmental and social management programs.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is category B project according to IFCs Policy on Social and Environmental Sustainability because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, EHS general and sector-specific guidelines or design criteria as is described in the following sections.

Project Description: Alliar Medicina Diagnóstica, through the legal entity Centro de Imagem Diagnósticos S/A and subsidiaries, (collectively Alliar or Company), is one of the largest imaging diagnostic companies in Brazil, offering, mainly for the private sector, imaging exams from magnetic resonance imaging and computed tomography to ultrasound, x-rays, mammography among others. The Company resulted from the consolidation of existing and renowned brands of the segment in Brazil. As of Mar12, Alliar summed 8 brands, 28 outpatient service centers across 16 cities throughout Brazil. (iv) Economic development: In addition to job creation, tax generation through the opening of new patient service centers will also contribute to direct economic development in less developed regions of Brazil.
