Project Description: The proposed project (the Project) is a $12 billion investment to develop a copper and gold mine at Oyu Tolgoi in the Southern Gobi region, Mongolia. The Project owner and developer is a Mongolian company, Oyu Tolgoi LLC (the Company) indirectly owned 66% by Ivanhoe Mines Ltd  (Ivanhoe),  a Canadian public company listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange and 34% by Erdenes Oyu Tolgoi LLC, a Mongolian State owned company. The deposit, which was acquired by Ivanhoe from BHP Billiton in 2000, consists of a near surface (Southern Oyu) copper/gold orebody together with a high grade deposit (Hugo North) suitable for underground mining discovered in 2002. With resources of almost 80 billion pounds of copper and 45 million ounces of gold, Oyu Tolgoi is one of the worlds largest known copper/gold deposits. The Project is being developed in phases starting with construction of a copper concentrator and associated infrastructure to support production of 100,000 tonnes per day of ore, to be sourced predominantly from the Southern Oyu open pit mine development. In parallel underground infrastructure and mine development is ongoing for the Hugo North deposit. Commercial operations from the initial open pit mining development are expected to start in mid-2013. Underground production from Hugo North is expected to commence in 2016. A potential expansion of concentrator capacity (subject to required regulatory approvals and the identification and permitting of additional water resources) to 160,000 tonnes per day of ore, is currently being studied.  Mine output, in the form of copper concentrate, will be trucked along a dedicated new road to the China border, to reach the Companys primary target market of Chinese copper smelters.  Power for the initial years of operations will be sourced from China, to be replaced by an on-site captive coal fired plant, which is currently in the advanced planning phase, with initial earth site work expected to start in Spring 2013.
Environmental Social Info: Mining currently accounts for 70% of exports and more than 30% of Mongolian government revenues and will continue to be the mainstay of economic growth for Mongolia as the Project and other large scale mining projects come on stream in coming years. Following a sharp cyclical correction in metals prices in 2008/2009, the Government of Mongolia, supported by the IMF and World Bank, passed a Fiscal Sustainability Law and an Integrated Budget Law in 2010. These provide a legislative framework to support financial management of mineral revenues and to plan and execute public investment.  The World Bank also has a longstanding engagement with the Mongolian government including advice with the Minerals Law in 1997 and 2006,  technical assistance programs for the Ministry of Mines and state owned mining companies, and  support to  achieve compliance with the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI) in December 2010. Furthermore, the  Investment Agreement (October 2009), the Shareholders Agreement (October 2009), and the Revised Shareholders Agreement (June 2011) which describe the royalty, tax and legal framework for the Project together with other material information are available for review by the public under Ivanhoe Mines at the Canadian Securities Administrators public information website  http://www.sedar.com and on the  Companys website at http://www.ot.mn.  The Company will also commit to disclosure of all payments to government. Given: (i) the existing legal framework and commitments of government of Mongolia with respect to macro-economic management and sector governance and transparency; (ii) the continued engagement of the World Bank and the IMF and (iii) the engagement, resources, and strong record of commitment of the Project owners to transparency and best industry practice,  IFC believes that the governance risks for the Project are adequately addressed.
Impact: Macro-economic impacts:  The Oyu Tolgoi project is expected to make a significant contribution to Mongolia''s economic growth, increasing GDP by more than 30% at full production and providing a catalyst for additional private sector investment in Mongolia''s fast growing mining sector. Fiscal impact: The Project is expected to generate significant revenue streams to the Mongolian Government. In addition to a 34% equity stake, the Government will receive: (i) a royalty of 5% of sales for the life of the mine; (ii) taxes on profits; (iii) other taxes and duties, including customs duties, value added, excise and immovable property/real estate taxes and payments for mining licenses; (iv) dividends on its equity ownership stake.  Employment: At peak construction the Project employs 14,800 workers, of whom 10,000 are Mongolians.  During operations the Company is expected to have 3,500 direct employees, of whom 90% will be Mongolian. The Project is also expected to generate significant indirect employment in the supply chain including service companies, construction, mining equipment contractors, transport and maintenance operations.Regional impacts: The Project is expected to be a catalyst for investment in infrastructure including housing for company employees, utilities and services in the the Khanbogd soum and regional cities. The Project will also develop the road, air transport and and electric grid in the South Gobi region and will provide investment and support for university education and vocational training for mining and technical graduates across Mongolia.
Risk Assessment: Mining currently accounts for 70% of exports and more than 30% of Mongolian government revenues and will continue to be the mainstay of economic growth for Mongolia as the Project and other large scale mining projects come on stream in coming years. Following a sharp cyclical correction in metals prices in 2008/2009, the Government of Mongolia, supported by the IMF and World Bank, passed a Fiscal Sustainability Law and an Integrated Budget Law in 2010. These provide a legislative framework to support financial management of mineral revenues and to plan and execute public investment.  The World Bank also has a longstanding engagement with the Mongolian government including advice with the Minerals Law in 1997 and 2006,  technical assistance programs for the Ministry of Mines and state owned mining companies, and  support to  achieve compliance with the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI) in December 2010. Furthermore, the  Investment Agreement (October 2009), the Shareholders Agreement (October 2009), and the Revised Shareholders Agreement (June 2011) which describe the royalty, tax and legal framework for the Project together with other material information are available for review by the public under Ivanhoe Mines at the Canadian Securities Administrators public information website  http://www.sedar.com and on the  Companys website at http://www.ot.mn.  The Company will also commit to disclosure of all payments to government. Given: (i) the existing legal framework and commitments of government of Mongolia with respect to macro-economic management and sector governance and transparency; (ii) the continued engagement of the World Bank and the IMF and (iii) the engagement, resources, and strong record of commitment of the Project owners to transparency and best industry practice,  IFC believes that the governance risks for the Project are adequately addressed.
Role:
Long-term Partner, Mobilization and Risk Management: IFC has played a lead role with the arranging bank syndicate and the Company to help structure Mongolia''s largest ever private sector financing, which will provide long tenor partial recourse debt financing meeting the complex requirements of a capital intensive, very long mine development; the evolving needs of IFI and commercial bank participants, the Company and its owners. IFC''s participation helps mitigate risk for both Project owners who are providing very significant capital for this very long life investment as well as for international commercial banks and co-lenders in the project debt financing.

Management of E&S Risks: The Project is a very large scale and long life mine being developed in a remote location. IFC has lead the environmental and social due diligence for the arranging bank syndicate, working over an extended period to advise on and help the Company prepare a comprehensive Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) of the potential environmental and social impacts on the biophysical and human environments in the Project''s area of influence. The ESIA draws upon on Environmental Impact Assessments prepared under Mongolian requirements between 2002-2008 as well as on numerous supplementary studies undertaken to accommodate continuously evolving Project design. The ESIA also builds upon extensive fieldwork, baseline data gathering, inputs from specialized consultants and experts and an extensive stakeholder engagement process to develop measures through all Project phases to avoid, minimize, mitigate and manage potential adverse impacts to meet Mongolian regulatory requirements, IFC Performance Standards, European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) Performance Requirements as well as the corporate commitments to environmental protection and social responsibility of Ivanhoe Mines and Rio Tinto.

Community Development: IFC is providing assistance to the Company in formulating their community development strategy, providing training using financial valuation methodologies to prioritize between investment options as well as broader strategic advice. IFC also expect to work with the Company over time on external initiatives addressing regional priorities, with focus areas likely to include stakeholder engagement and awareness around water issues.
Sponsor: Ivanhoe Mines is an international mining company focused on mineral exploration and development primarily in the Asia Pacific region. In addition to its ownership in OT which is its primary asset, Ivanhoe owns 58% of Mongolian coal producer SouthGobi Resources; 59% of Ivanhoe Australia  and 50% of Altynalmas Gold, a private company developing the Kyzyl Gold Project in Kazakhstan. Ivanhoes majority shareholder is international mining major Rio Tinto Group (Rio Tinto). In 2006 Rio Tinto entered into a strategic partnership with Ivanhoe to develop and fund the Project and, since December 2010, to manage OT LLC.  In January 2012 following a series of equity injections used primarily to fund the development of the Project, Rio Tinto became 51% owner of Ivanhoe.  Rio Tinto is a diversified multinational mining and resources group with headquarters in London and Melbourne. Rio Tinto is the worlds fifth largest copper supplier and is an industry leader in sustainable mining practice, conservation, land rehabilitation, biodiversity, climate change and water and energy use. Erdenes Oyu Tolgoi LLC is a state-owned holding company established for purpose of representing the Government of Mongolia with regard to its ownership into OT LLC as provided for under an Investment Agreement between the Government, OT LLC, Ivanhoe Mines and Rio Tinto signed in October 2009.
Cost Nature: The estimated total Project cost is $12.0 billion. IFCs proposed investment is a $300 million senior A Loan together with a B Loan of up to $600 million loan to be syndicated to international commercial banks, as part of a proposed $4billion project debt financing.  Co-arrangers of the proposed debt financing are European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), Export Development Canada (EDC), Standard Chartered Bank, BNP Paribas, US Export Import Bank (US EXIM), and Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA). The balance of the funding for the Project is expected to come from Sponsor equity, shareholder loans and Project generated cash flows.

Location: The Project is located in the southern Gobi region of Mongolia, approximately 600 km South of the capital city Ulan Bataar and 80 km North West of the border post and rail head with China at Gashunn Sukhait. The nearest town, the regional soum capital Khanbogd, is 45 km away. The area is very sparsely populated with a total population in the regional Khanbogd soum of 3,500 of whom some 1450 are resident in Khanbogd town.   The Project area is characterised by a very dry, continental desert climate with very high summer and very cold winter temperatures. Vegetation in the Project area is limited and largely comprises low-growing drought- and cold-tolerant shrubs, perennial grasses and annual plants.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The Oyu Tolgoi development is a very large scale mining operation with significant impacts on the environment and way of life in the Southern Gobi including on water resources, biodiversity and local communities. An international standard ESIA demonstrating compliance with Mongolian Law and IFC Standards is being disclosed along with the Environmental and Social Review Summary and this SII. Future Project components including expansion phases or other major infrastructure will also have international standard ESIAs completed. All ESIAs are subjected to full consultation and disclosure meeting IFC standards.Internal and external auditing of environmental, health & Safety and social parameters is being undertaken. Periodic external monitoring post IFC-investment conducted by qualified independent consultants will also be undertaken with reports publically disclosed.

Project Description: IAS is an aviation operator and a maintenance company registered with the Ivory Coast Civil Aviation Authority. Created in 2002, IAS is one of three aircraft services companies independently owned and managed by the Moreau family. IAS (the Company) provides helicopter air transport services to the Oil and Gas industry in Cote dIvoire and to the Mining industry in the region. The Company owns 13 helicopters and employs 25 pilots. Its main base is located at the Felix Houphouet Boigny International Airport in Abidjan and it maintains satellite bases in Accra and Takoradi, Ghana. IAS headquarters in Abidjan comprises 1,400 m2 of administration offices, waiting rooms, maintenance and paint shops, and 2,940 m2 of hangars for helicopters. IAS provides helicopter transport for offshore oil platforms, mining projects, private charters, medical evacuation, cargo and heavy equipment transport, geophysical surveys, and other services.   IAS is seeking to acquire three secondhand Dauphin N3 helicopters (the Project) to modernize its fleet with newer generation helicopters to meet the specific requirements of a five-year renewable contract currently being negotiated with leading oil exploration and production firm Canadian Natural Resources International. As per standard contractual terms, the Company is expected to provide around the clock, on-demand services and therefore has to have dedicated helicopters available for each long term contract. One of the newly acquired helicopters will serve as main helicopter and the second as back up. The third one will be used for upcoming contracts.
Review Scope: IFCs environmental and social (E&S) appraisal included a site visit on July 3, 2012 to IASs corporate office and aircraft handling facilities at the Felix Houphouet Boigny International Airport in Abidjan, a review of technical documentation and interviews with IAS senior management and technical staff including: the Deputy Manager Quality, Safety, and Environment (QSE), the  Quality Assurance Officer, the Maintenance Manager,  the Radio and Radar Engineer, the Storekeeper, the Paint Shop Supervisor, the Fuel Manager, the Runway Officer, the Sales Manager, the Human Resources Manager, and the Finance Manager;Review of key technical documents included: the draft Environmental Management Manual (Manuel de Gestion Environnementale - MGE), IAS Internal Regulations (Règlement Intérieur), Canadian Natural Resources International Response to Tender for Provisions of Helicopter Services, and IAS Financing Proposal (IAS Dossier de financement), and the Cote dIvoire Labor Law (Code du Travail).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This proposed investment is expected to have limited environmental and social impacts that are expected to be site-specific and temporary, and none are expected to be significant. Those impacts can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to recognized performance standards, operating procedures, guidelines and design criteria as described in the following sections. Thus, this is a Category B Project in accordance with IFCs Sustainability Policy.Key E&S Issues and Mitigation Key E&S issues applicable for this investment are: aircraft operations safety, including pilot and crew training programs; aircraft maintenance and servicing, including mechanic training and the management of hazardous materials and wastes; environmental protection and safety at ground sites; aircraft noise and emissions controls; employee health, safety and fair working conditions; and general passenger safety.  The Project is designed to avoid, minimize and manage environmental and social risks and impacts of the Companys operations in compliance with applicable IFCs Performance Standards and World Bank Group (WBG) General and sector-specific (Airlines) Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines.
Sector: E-BD - Other Support Activities for Transportation (Grain Terminals, Cargo Terminals, Airport Operations)

Project Description: The project involves a proposed equity investment by IFC of up to $4 million early stage investment in a $10 million equity round for Organica to expand in India, China, Indonesia, Turkey, Russia, and the Ukraine.  The Company seeks new financing for recruiting sales and marketing resources, establishing new distribution partners, funding new product development, and for some general corporate purposes.  Organica sells a package of products and services for wastewater treatment facilities, up to and including the management of turnkey projects to establish or rehabilitate such facilities.  Organicas technology enhances the natural processes of complex ecosystems by creating more diverse biology than would normally exist.  Its wastewater treatment reactors are arranged in a cascade fashion, with pretreatment steps in the beginning and final polishing at the end, depending on influent characteristics and effluent use.  The sub-ecosystems provide for enhanced removal efficiency while utilizing less energy and producing less sludge. Organica operates a laboratory, technology center, and offices in leased facilities in Hungary.  It has offices in New Delhi and Singapore, and plans to open ones in China, Turkey, Russia, and the Ukraine.  Offices will generally be located in leased spaces.
Review Scope: The review of this project consisted of a visit by IFC staff to the project site, to meet with and interview management of Organica Water (or Organica or the Company) and to have a first-hand look at operational activities.  IFC staff also appraised technical, environmental and social information provided by Organica.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The project involves research, development, design, operations, and management by Organica of wastewater treatment products and services.  No major adverse environmental or social impacts are expected to result from the project, and it will be possible to avoid or mitigate any limited adverse impacts that might result.  As a result, it has been classified as a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.

Project Description: InterEnergy Holdings IEH is one of the largest private sector power operators in the Dominican Republic ("DR"), with exposure to approximately 1,000MW of existing generation capacity. IEH has both direct and indirect interests in this generation capacity through three operating companies.  These subsidiaries include: i) Consórcio Energético Punta Cana Macao S.A. (CEPM) and Compañía de Electricidad de San Pedro de Macorís S.A. (CESPM) in which it has a controlling stake, and ii) a non-controlling interest (25.66%) in La Empresa Generadora de Electricidad Haina S.A. (EGE Haina) through a 51.3% indirect economic interest in Haina Investment Company Ltd (BVI), the private sector investor which owns 50% of EGE Haina. The Government of the DR holds the remaining 50%.The project consists of a proposed US$ 50 million IFC equity investment to support IEHs future power and energy sector developments, the principal focus of which will be the co-development of a new LNG terminal and an associated gas pipeline to allow conversion of its existing power generation assets to cleaner-burning natural gas fuel. IFCs investment will come in parallel to a proposed equity investment by the IFC African, Latin American and Caribbean Fund (ALAC or the ALAC Fund), managed by the IFC Asset Management Company (AMC). Among other development outcomes, the investment will contribute to the eventual reduction of the greenhouse gas footprint of the Dominican Republics energy generation matrix, which currently relies on liquid fuels, especially on Heavy Fuel Oil (HFO).Projects currently under consideration by IEH include: (i) a flagship LNG terminal and gas pipeline network in the DR: (ii) an expansion of the companys existing portfolio of renewable energy projects in the DR, including solar and wind power; (iii) an expansion of its generation park focused on gas-fired capacity; (iv) a transmission line interconnecting the DR with Haitis power grid; and (v) acquisition of certain power assets in the region to diversify the Companys geographic exposure. All of these potential projects/assets are at the conceptual stage of development and are not amenable for a full E&S due diligence at this point in time.
Review Scope: An equity investment in IEH (the Project), exposes the IFC to three different types of assets: (a) existing controlled assets, namely CEPM and CESPM, (b) future assets or projects to be directly developed by IEH, and (c) existing and future assets under EGE Haina, where IEH has a non-controlling interest as well as limited operational exposure and control. The first two sets of assets are also referred to as IEH Controlled Group throughout this document.IFC reviewed documents for both IEH Controlled Groups  and EGE Hainas environmental, social, and health and safety management (ESHS) policies, practices and supporting procedures, including documents developed by IEHs predecessor, Basic Energy Ltd (Bahamas) (BEL). IFC also interviewed the IEH Controlled Groups and EGE Hainas management and their corresponding ESHS teams. To further understand how the companies currently manage ESHS performance, IFC visited the two facilities under IEH control, namely CEPM and CESPM power generation complexes. In addition, the IFC also visited La Sultana power plant (owned and operated by EGE Haina). Since there are no IEH controlled assets currently under construction, the IFC also performed a site visit to the construction site of Quisqueya I and II, two greenfield 215 MW HFO currently under construction and to be commissioned in 4Q2013.  Quisqueya I is being built by Barrick Gold Corporation to supply energy to the Pueblo Viejo Gold mine, and will be operated by EGE Haina. Quisqueya II, is being built and will be owned and operated by EGE Haina.  (Neither Quisqueya I or II will be part of the CAPEX to be financed by the IFC.)  In addition IFC also reviewed the most recent environmental compliance reports (Informes de Cumplimiento Ambiental  ICA) from all facilities in which IEH is a shareholder, mainly focusing on CESPM and CEPM, but including also those facilities belonging to EGE Haina.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category A investment because of the potentially significant and diverse environmental and social impacts and risks associated with IEHs CAPEX program: a Greenfield LNG marine terminal and an associated 30-40 km gas pipeline to connect the LNG terminal to its various power generation assets; a power transmission line to interconnect the DR with Haiti; and potential additional solar and wind generation projects, among others.
Sector: V-IA - Electric Power Other (Including Holding Companies)

Project Description: InterEnergy Holdings (the Company or IEH) is one of the largest private sector power players in the Dominican Republic (DR), commanding approximately 1,000MW generation capacity through its indirect interest in three operating companies. IFCs investment will come in parallel to a proposed equity investment on similar terms by the IFC African, Latin American and Caribbean Fund (ALAC or the ALAC Fund), managed by the IFC Asset Management Company (AMC). Together, these equity contributions will support the Companys expansion of its existing businesses and new possible power and energy sector investments. It will focus on renewable energy development and natural gas diversification, while not excluding other selective opportunities in the electricity sector in the Caribbean and Latin America, such as Haiti. Pipeline projects include (i) a flagship LNG terminal and gas pipelines network in the DR: (ii) an expansion of the companys existing portfolio of renewable energy projects in the DR, including solar and wind power; (iii) an expansion of its generation park focused on gas-fired capacity; (iv) a transmission line interconnecting the DR with Haitis power grid; and (v) acquisition of certain power assets in the region to diversify the Companys geographic exposure.
Impact: Development impact from the proposed IFC/ALAC equity investment is manifold. The Company is among the few domestic/regionally based IPP companies in the Caribbean region and considers "high developmental impact" synonymous with "long-term commercial success" as its core strategy. IEH through BEL invested in the sector when others were exiting, and has successfully turned around then-problematic companies (e.g. EGE Haina and CESPM) or started out distribution utilities in remote places where there was no electricity supply to support tourism development (e.g. CEPM and CEB) Thus, the Company''s  success is hoped to help catalyze more generation investments and companies following a similar long-term developmental perspective in the DR and the region. The projects within the pipeline, if successful, could alter the energy map of the DR region with a profoundly positive economic impact - a significant reduction in electricity generation costs and an alleviation of balance of payment problems.
Role: IFC has closely collaborated in the past with BEL.  BEL relied on IFC for long term loans for financing one of its operating subsidiaries, CEPM- an 8.25 MW wind power project in 2005 and a transmission project in 2007. IEH will leverage on IFC''s sector and country-specific knowledge and will work together with the IFC in determining potential projects to invest in.   IFC''s equity participation in the Company would be a natural evolution of this close working relationship between IFC and a private sector company, whose focus is to achieve higher commercial returns through investments facilitating economic development in frontier regions/countries.  In this context, the proposed IFC investment would contribute to: (i) supporting a DR-based, second-tier sponsor to grow regionally (i.e. south-to-south transactions), (ii) promoting power sector investment in countries with challenging sector environments, (iii) enabling IEH to mitigate the risk of its investment through IFC''s international sector experience and World Bank relationships.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is IEH, owned 88.33% by an investment vehicle (the InterEnergy Fund) managed by InterEnergy Partners  Ltd. (InterEnergy) and 11.33% by investment vehicles managed by Portland Private Equity (Portland). InterEnergys majority and controlling shareholder is Basic Energy Ltd. (Bahamas) (BEL), which is also an anchor investor in the InterEnergy Fund. InterEnergys minority shareholder is InterBolsa Investments Ltd. (BVI). BEL is led by Mr. Rolando Gonzalez Bunster, an Argentinean entrepreneur who was the pioneer in the independent power producer (IPP) industry of the DR. Portland is a firm founded and led by Mr. Michael Lee-Chin, a prominent Jamaican born Canadian citizen.IEH owns interests in three operating companies: (i) Consórcio Energético Punta Cana Macao S.A. (CEPM), which is 100% owned through its holding company CEPM Energy Ltd. (Cayman); (ii) La Compañía de Electricidad de San Pedro de Macorís S.A (CESPM), which is controlled by IEH through an aggregate 60% interest in its parent company CESPM Holdings Ltd (Cayman) controlled by IEH; and (iii) La Empresa Generadora de Electricidad Haina S.A. (EGE Haina) through a 51.3% indirect economic interest in Haina Investment Company Ltd. (BVI), the private sector investor in EGE Haina with 50% interest.
Cost Nature: IFC will invest up to $50 million in equity. In addition, ALAC is considering an up to US$50 million equity as well. IEH will use the proceeds from the IFC/ALAC Fund equity investment to fund its pipeline projects.

Project Description: Organica Water Inc. (Organica or the Company) is a Budapest, Hungary based wastewater treatment (WWT) technology company that is developing and deploying a next-generation, biological wastewater treatment technology. The Organica technology utilizes proprietary algorithms to create engineered ecosystems that efficiently treat and recycle the same quality wastewater in significantly less space, using less energy and generating less sludge than conventional treatment plants, and done in an aesthetically appealing way that integrates seamlessly into urban environments.   The Organica WWT technology was originally conceived in 1998 and the Company has since completed 28+ installations operating worldwide, including in Hungary, France, China, and Poland.  The technology is designed to enhance the natural processes of complex ecosystems by creating considerably more diverse biology than those already in use in the industry.  Since 2008, Organica has signed over 20 contracts for its technology deployment, including 11 projects in France, 5 projects in China, and its first 80,000 m3/day retrofit plant in Hungary using its second generation technology.  The Company is currently seeking to expand its commercialization efforts in emerging markets such as India, China, Indonesia, Turkey and Eastern Europe, focusing on municipal and industrial WWT opportunities in the 1,000-100,000 m3/day hydraulic capacity.
Impact: 1.	Improving Water Sanitation and Wastewater Reuse in Emerging Markets:  Organica''s wastewater treatment (WWT) technology offers a highly cost competitive, space saving, and decentralized solution to customers.  This technology application is particularly attractive in the chosen emerging markets that Organica operates in, where a) urbanization and water quality issues are prevalent; b) WWT infrastructures are relatively new and stakeholders are relatively more open to adopting new WWT solutions; and c) increasing urban population density requires WWT solutions that minimizes footprint whilst aesthetically pleasing/ecosystem-like solutions allow for preservation of land value in the vicinity. 2.	Promoting a Decentralized and Distributed Wastewater Solution:  In addition to driving resource efficiency on every level- lower energy usage, lower geographic footprint and lower infrastructure costs; Organica''s WWT solution is comprised of botanical garden like structures which blend into the urban landscape with no resemblance to traditional facilities. The sustainable look and feel as well as the smaller infrastructure footprint promote a decentralized and distributed approach towards WWT and contribute to a drive towards urban sustainability in emerging markets.3.	Improving Effectiveness of Wastewater Treatment Solutions: Organica''s utilization of plant roots andits patented artificial media as a special biofilm carrier creates a more diverse and complex biological treatment system that improves treatment efficiency by maximizing oxygen transfer. This ultimately enhances the resilience of the WWT infrastructure against variations in treatment volume and wastewater quality variability. 4.	Stimulating Water Technologies Innovation and Resource Efficiency:  Organica''s innovative biological treatment solution generates substantial savings in capital cost, operating cost, energy use and physical land use compared to conventional WWT technologies.  IFC''s investment will stimulate technological innovation in WWT solutions that addresses energy and resource efficiencies, thereby strengthening its target market''s ability to delivery key infrastructure services and offer decentralized solutions.

Role:
1) Early Stage Equity & Mobilization: The Company''s early-stage profile, its plans to grow in emerging markets, and its unconventional base in Hungary, makes it challenging to raise venture capital funding. IFC''s support can play a mobilizing role by leading growth financing for the Company''s expansion.

2) Technical and Industry Knowledge Sharing: IFC can aid the Company as it seeks to do business in India, China, Indonesia, Turkey, Russia and Ukraine. In particular, IFC can leverage its public and private sector contacts in the water industries in these countries and provide significant industry and technical expertise and potential advisory services to the Company.

3) Stamp of Approval: IFC''s investment will enable an innovative wastewater treatment technology to scale up and reach more end users as IFC''s participation will positively influence the perception of the market and public of Organica''s technology and its brand in the markets. In particular, Organica will deploy its solution in emerging markets, where the need for efficient wastewater solutions is the most acute.

4) Introducing Client to New Markets: The Company''s potential customer base is expected to be primarily municipalities, industries and private commercial developers located in emerging markets. IFC has a history of working within the water sector in these countries and can facilitate the Company''s access to such customers particularly in its key strategic markets such as China, India and Indonesia. In particular, IFC see significant opportunities for Organica''s decentralized WWT solutions for many of its private sector clients in Mexico, Caribbean and South America where Organica''s has yet to establish a presence.

5) E&S and Corporate Governance: IFC''s involvement will help this early stage Company to adopt a structured framework to manage its environmental and social policies as the Company expands. In addition, the Company can leverage IFC''s best practices in corporate governance.
Sponsor: Organica, a Delaware incorporated Company, was originally founded in 1998 as a traditional design and build company focused on the water sector in Hungary.  From 2000-2006, the Company achieved EUR8 million in revenue annually and constructed over 75 WWT plants.  During this period, the Company invested its free cash flow into R&D which would later become the first generation Organica WWT technology.  In 2007, Organica sold its traditional design-build business to Veolia Water Solutions, the largest global water company, in order to focus exclusively on the global commercialization of the Organica technology.  Veolia currently holds the exclusive license of the Organica WWT technology for deployment in France. The Company was originally founded by Mr. Atilla Bodnár and Mr. István Kenyeres.   In 2008, it received its first round of institutional investment from two private equity Funds Cleanwater Partners and Gamma Venture Partners.
Cost Nature: The Company is seeking to raise up to US$10 million in a Series B equity round of financing. The proceeds of the financing are intended to accelerate the Companys growth primarily in emerging markets by (i) hiring sales and marketing resources and establishing distribution partners in emerging markets, (ii) fund new product development, and (iii) for general corporate purposes.  The proposed IFC investment in Organica is up to US$4 million in equity (the Project).

Project Description: Peak Reinsurance Company Limited (Peak Re or the Company), owned 100% by Peak Reinsurance Holdings Ltd. (PeakRe Holidngs), is a newly established reinsurance company, headquartered in Hong Kong SAR, China and operates across Asia.
Impact: Market Development: The Project will help create market alternatives for Asian based primary insurance companies which are today dependent on European or North American based reinsurance groups or inadequate local, nationally based reinsurers.  As an Asian based reinsurer, Clipper aims to differentiate itself from established multinational reinsurance companies in terms of its pricing and capital allocation, and also avoid the often inadequate portfolio diversification found in single-country reinsurance companies.    Local Capacity Enhancement: In partnership with local primary market operators, the Project will improve the availability of technical expertise and reinsurance underwriting capacity in key product areas such a micro-insurance, natural catastrophe and agricultural crop insurance.
Role:
- Long-term Strategic Partnership: IFC''s participation will support the Project Sponsor to diversify into reinsurance business and build a sustainable and profitable operation;
-Stamp of approval: having IFC as a shareholder since its inception is an important indication of the Company''s commitment to governance practices;
- S&E policies: IFC may help a greenfield company to develop adequate S&E policies and procedures from scratch;

Project Description: The project consists of a straight senior loan to Middle East Micro Credit Company MEMCC, one of the leading and well-managed commercial microfinance institutions in Jordan. Proceeds of the loan will be used to finance the expansion of the Companys lending activities to micro and small entrepreneurs (the Project). MEMCC seeks long-term funding to continue its growth and continue offering existing and new products to its target clientele. MEMCC is one of the leading microfinance organizations operating in all regions in Jordan and by end June 2012 served more than 17,500 clients, of which 65% are women, with a credit portfolio of US$25 million. MEMCC serves its clients through its well established network of 15 branches and staff of 172 people.
Impact: - Access to finance: The Project would support MEMCC''s lending activities and expand its outreach to serve more of the low-income active poor and the SME sector in Jordan, including women entrepreneurs who currently represent more than 65% of the Company''s borrowers;- Job creation: MSMEs are contributors to job creation in the Country. Supporting the development of the sector with reliable access to finance would play an important role in economic growth, generating employment, and providing opportunities to the underserved groups.-Demonstration effect:  Through this Project, IFC is expected to act as a catalyst to encourage local banks and FIs to lend for longer periods and support MFIs growth. Further, it will enable MEMCC to better manage its risks and such, by which, setting an example in the market.
Role:
- First, provide medium/long-term funding that is otherwise difficult to mobilize locally. Limitations on term funding poses risks and place constrains on MEMCC''s ability to design longer-term products. In addition, longer maturities allow the Company to match its assets and liabilities and allow for multiple use of the funds.
- Second, provide local currency funding to the Company to reduce its foreign currency exposure, better manage assets and liabilities and improve its risk profile.
-Third, support the commercialization of microfinance that is critical for the sustainability of the operations. This would allow MEMCC to continue and further improve access to finance to the MF and SME target clientele.
Sponsor: As a continuation to the CHF/USAID project (JACP), Middle East Micro Credit Company was established in 2003 as a limited liability, not-for-profit company registered with the Ministry of Industry and Trade with a paid up capital of JD50,000 (US$70,000). Since establishment, MEMCC received several grants to support its microfinance activities. MEMCC is fully owned by CHF International and accordingly is part of CHF Internationals network of microfinance subsidiaries in the Middle East, Latin America, Sub-Saharan Africa, and Southern & Eastern Europe.
Cost Nature: The proposed project involves a senior loan from IFCs own account to MEMCC in an amount up to US$4 million.

Project Description: bKash Limited (bKash or the Company) is a mobile payment joint venture in Bangladesh between BRAC Bank (51% shareholding) and Money in Motion (49% shareholding). The Company intends to leverage the distribution network of its partners and work with mobile network operators to offer a mobile payment platform that would enable financial services across rural and urban areas in Bangladesh. The Company launched operations in July 2011 and currently has a subscriber base of around 443 thousand customers. IFC is considering a potential equity investment of up to US$10 million in bKash.
Impact: The project will have the following development impacts:- Increased access to finance through mobile payment: The project is intended to increase access to finance through mobile payment/banking to broader segments of the country including the unbanked and the base of the pyramid.-Enabling integration into the formal banking system: The project will help develop a track record of banking transactions for the bKash customers and aid their eventual integration into the formal banking system and access other financial services such as credit and insurance- Facilitating commerce: The Project will help create a mobile banking/payment platform that will reduce transaction costs and overcome geographic barriers, helping to facilitate commerce in the country amongst broader segments of the population.
Role:
IFC''s additionality in the proposed investment will be as follows:

- Global industry knowledge and expertise: The Company will benefit from IFC''s knowledge and expertise in the payments and mobile banking space gained from investment and advisory experience and also from IFC''s network of portfolio clients including telcos, financial institutions, and service providers.

- Capital facilitation and demonstration effect: By investing in a nascent business model as a long-term strategic partner in a market with limited financing options, IFC will not only fill the financing gap but also will provide comfort to other potential providers of capital.
Sponsor: bKash is a joint venture between BRAC Bank Ltd. (51% shareholding) and Money in Motion LLC, USA (49% shareholding). BRAC Bank, headquartered in Dhaka, Bangladesh, was formed by BRAC, the largest non-government organization in the world, with the aim to serve the small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the country. Money in Motion LLC is an investment company based in the United States, founded by globally renowned telecom entrepreneurs.

Project Description: Komercijalna Banka ad Beograd (KBB or the Bank or the Company) is the largest locally owned bank in the Serbian banking sector, ranking the 2nd by total assets in the country. Operating since 1971, KBB is a universal bank offering a full range of banking services to its more than 750,000 clients in retail, corporate, SME, and municipal sectors.The Project consists of a Senior Loan of EUR 50 million up to 7 years, including 2 years grace period, to support an existing client of IFC, a systemic bank in the Serbian banking sector, in its growth in housing finance for low income population.
Impact: By supporting its portfolio client, IFC will bolster mortgage finance for low-income clients by providing more liquidity at the retail level for low income housing, besides helping bank to increase its market share in the mortgage sector. Access to mortgage finance will inherently boost the historically strong construction sector- one of the key catalysts of sustainable growth in the local economy.
Role: IFC''s additionality in this project is the extension of its role initially played back in 2009 when IFC/AMC along the other IFIs made equity investment in Komercijalna Banka and have been supporting the bank in various domains of funding and technical assistance. IFC is expected to play a unique role of not only providing a long term funding which has been scarce in the ongoing crisis, but also augmenting the Bank''s strategy, operations and other operational areas to further improve the sustainability of business and opportunities for the growth which resulted in the proposed IFC funding.

Project Description: The proposed Project involves a EUR50 million Loan to Societe Generale Splitska d.d. Split, Croatia (the SGSB or the Bank) for on-lending to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and to companies operating within Agri-sector.
Environmental Social Info: The key issue in this project is to ensure the Bank has adequate capacity to manage the E&S risks associated with the activities of its borrowers in line with IFCs policy requirements, and to screen borrowers against IFC Performance Standards, the host country laws and regulations and the Exclusion List. SGSB has a system in place for reviewing operational risks (including evaluation of compliance with local environmental laws) which needs to be updated in line with IFC''s applicable requirements. Role: Long-term Funding: IFC would provide long-term funding to SGSB. Banks and companies are experiencing difficulties sourcing even shorter tenor funds in the markets. Project Description: IFC is considering an investment in Auchan Ukraine, who is planning on building and operating a hypermarket in Odessa as well as other hypermarkets and shopping centers in other cities in Ukraine (the Project). Auchan has shown interest in obtaining a USD 75M corporate loan to fund this development.Auchan Ukraine hypermarkets are large stores selling a wide variety of food and non-food goods. The company has been in Ukraine since 2007 and currently owns and/or operates a total of 10 stores. The Auchan parent company is based in France and operates 616 hypermarkets in 12 countries, had a 2011 turnover of 44.4 billion Euros and employs 235,000 people worldwide.
Review Scope: IFC visited the Auchan Ukraine corporate headquarters (HQ) located in Kyiv, an adjacent hypermarket and another hypermarket located in Berko in Kyiv. Meetings at HQ involved senior management including those responsible for sustainable development for the Ukraine operations. The visit to the hypermarkets included both shop floor and back-of-the-house operations to see firsthand a typical Auchan store in Ukraine.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This investment is classified as a Category B project in accordance with IFCs Policy on Environment and Social Sustainability. Based on information reviewed by IFC, this investment will have limited adverse E&S impacts that are few in number, are generally site specific, largely reversible and readily addressed through mitigation measures, as outlined in the Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) attached to this ESRS. The main E&S issues include the management of impacts during construction (particularly protecting the occupational health and safety of those engaged in building the stores), the life and fire safety design of the stores themselves, the management of human resources and natural resources consumed in the operation of the stores.
Sector: Q-BA - Retail (Including Supermarkets, Grocery Stores, etc.)

Project Description: The proposed project will support Accessbank in providing access to finance for MSMEs operating in Azerbaijan. The project consists of a senior loan of up to US$15 million.
Environmental Social Info: The key risks and impacts of the project are associated with the banks agenda to further increase its presence in the market and target the micro and SME segments, which will require wider application of E&S due diligence in lending, more resources and training for staff on ESMS implementation, and closer monitoring of the process by management. Accessbank has developed and maintains an ESMS in line with the IFC E&S requirements. The Exclusion List therein needs to be upgraded to meet the Accessbanks E&S portfolio requirements. The Bank has staff in place to implement the ESMS, and was found to be in compliance with PS2 on labor and working conditions.
Impact: The development impact of the Project is expected to be significant in the following areas:(i) Support the growth of the Bank''s MSME portfolio and increase access to finance for MSMEs.(ii) Stimulate growth in the non-oil sector and make a positive impact on employment generation and economic development in Azerbaijan.(iii) Potentially create positive spill-overs in the banking sector by supporting a strong partner with good risk management and corporate governance practices.
Role:
IFC has a strong role and additionality in this project as IFC''s financing would:
(i) Provide long-term financing to a strong partner bank in a market where there is limited liquidity and no commercially viable sources that are willing to lend to banks for MSME financing.
(ii) Help the Bank improve its funding maturity mismatch by providing funding at longer maturities, which is not easily available in the market.
(iii) Signal confidence in the Bank and gain support from other IFIs.
Sponsor: Accessbank was founded with the support of IFC and other IFIs including EBRD, DEG/KfW and Black Sea Trade and Development Bank as well as technical partners AccessHolding AG and LFS in 2002. Since then, Accessbank has become the largest financial institution to reach out to micro clients, providing financial services to the poor, contributing significantly to expanding the frontier of the financial sector in Azerbaijan. Accessbank is now one of the most profitable microfinance organizations in the region and is the leader in micro and small business finance in Azerbaijan.
Cost Nature: The total project cost consists of a proposed US$15 million loan to Accessbank to support the growth of the Banks microfinance and SME portfolio.

Company Name: NSL WIND POWER COMPANY (SATARA) PRIVATE LIMITED
Project Description: NSL Renewable Power Private Limited (NRPPL), an existing IFC investee company (# 29912), is a subsidiary of NSL Group established for implementation of renewable power projects across the country. NRPPL intends to set up a wind power project of 75 MW in Chilarwadi village of Man Tehsil, Satara District of Maharashtra, India (the Project) through a subsidiary NSL Wind Power Company (Satara) Private Limited (NSL Wind or the Company). The Project will be implemented in two phases with 25.5 MW to be implemented in the first phase. Construction period for each phase is expected to be [6] months from start of construction. IFC is considering providing a loan to NSL Wind to part finance the Project.The Project involves supply, erection, testing, commissioning, operation and maintenance of 50 wind turbines, with a unit generating capacity of 1.5MW to be supplied by ReGen under a supply, erection and commissioning contract with NSL Wind. Further, ReGen is also the O&M operator of this Project under an O&M contract with the Company. Transformers will be located near the turbine within an access controlled area. Underground cables will connect each turbine-transformer and overhead conductor will connect the transformer to the pooling substation. ReGen has constructed a 220 kV Transmission Line from Pooling Substation to the Maharashtra State Electricity Transmission Company Limited  (MSETCL), the state transmission utilitys interconnection point. The pooling sub-station, 220 kV T-Line and monitoring station will be shared with 125 MW capacity ReGens other existing and future projects for other project owners.The Project area falls in three villages viz. Chilarwadi, Puklewadi and Virli of Man & Khatav tehsil in Satara District of Maharashtra State of India. The wind farm will be located on a table top plateau and will require a total area of 62 ha. However, at each turbine location only about 1 ha land is required. Typically, each turbine is located in the center of a 50-80 m diameter land plot, which includes also the transformer and switchyard for the turbine. However, 2.5 acres of land is usually purchased for each turbine location. The additional land over and above the 80 m diameter is used as lay down area during construction and is required for use by cranes during both turbine installation and maintenance work. The balance 12 ha land is for access roads and internal roads between turbines. 62 ha of land is comprised of 33.4 ha private land purchased on a willing seller-buyer basis and 28.6 ha government revenue land to be transferred/leased to the Company. The Company has availed the services of a land agency to purchase the private land. 33 of the 50 turbines will be located on private land and the balance on government revenue land. There is an operating 42 MW project about 1 km from the Project site and a further 100 MW of existing wind power project located at about 5 km or more from the Project site. Additionally, 31.5 MW of projects are proposed of which 16.5 MW is within 1 to 5 km of the Project site. There has been no diversion of government land or sale of private land from Virali village to any other project. Further, 5 and 3 turbines from other proposed projects are planned in Chilarwadi and Puklewadi villages requiring about 6 and 3.5 ha of land respectively.
Review Scope: The review of this project also draws upon the supervision of IFCs previous investment (# 29912) in NSL Renewable Power Private Limited (NRPPL). NRPPL reports to IFC regarding the ongoing management of its environmental and social performance and their progress has been satisfactory.IFCs review consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information made available by NRPPL including the: Social and Environment Impact Assessment Study (ESIA) dated August 2012 for the 75 MW wind power project being set up near Chilarwadi village by NSL Wind Power Company (Satara) Private Limited; Rapid Biological Assessment of Chilarwadi Wind Farm Site, July 2012;  sample supply, erection & commissioning and Operation and maintenance agreements (O&M) with ReGen Powertech Private Limited (ReGen or the O&M operator); NRPPLs Human Resource (HR) policies; and NRPPLs social, environmental, health and safety (SEHS) management system procedures (SEHSMS) as applicable to the Project. The appraisal team also interviewed NRPPLs corporate and project management as well as environment, occupational health, safety and human resources professionals. The appraisal also included visits by IFC staff to NRPPLs other operating wind farm at Bheemasamudra in Karnataka and the proposed Project site at Chilarwadi, district Satara, Maharashtra state of India.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The proposed IFC loan to the Project is a Category B project because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Potential impacts in construction activities besides being mitigable are likely to be limited to project site; short term; and not expected impact environmentally sensitive areas. Further, it is possible to readily design and implement engineering and management measures to mitigate adverse impacts during construction and operations. The Company will manage its environmental and social performance in accordance with applicable local laws and regulations and international standards, including IFCs Performance Standards on Social and Environmental Sustainability.
Sector: V-BC - Wind Power - Renewable Energy Generation

Project Description: The project involves a US$10 million equivalent debt facility for FINCA's African affiliates in DRC, Tanzania and a proposed greenfield in Nigeria. The proposed loans will be denominated in local currency in Tanzania and Nigeria and will support the expansion of lending activities to MSMEs in Tanzania, DRC and Nigeria. FINCA's strategy in Africa is to focus operations on underserved markets and groups, namely rural areas and women.
Impact: It is anticipated this project will have a high developmental impact by:i)	providing funding to underserved segments in IDA countries, particularly women and youth. Over 95% of FINCA's clients in Africa are women and this funding will support portfolio growth and geographic expansion.ii) diversifying funding sources for FINCA's affiliates in Africa, and iii) increasing the tenor of local currency financing available in the local markets.
Role: IFC's additionality will come from providing medium/long term funding, which is not available in the market especially to microfinance institutions, to support companies in IDA countries to grow their portfolios. The long term nature of the loan represents a stable source of funding and accordingly would facilitate better liquidity management and enhanced ability to reach out to targeted underserved segments, mainly youth and women. IFC has a multi facility relationship with FINCA  as a shareholder of the holding company, and provider of technical assistance, local currency debt financing to local affiliates.
Sponsor: FINCA DRC s.a.r.l, is a company limited by shares, licensed and regulated by the Central Bank of the Democratic Republic of Congo. FINCA Tanzania is a company limited by shares; Both companies are fully owned by FINCA Microfinance Holding (FMH).FMH owns and operates 21 microfinance institutions globally. Shareholders of the holding company include: FINCA International 66.33%; IFC 14.99%; KfW 7.18%; FMO 6.71%; responsibility 2.39%;  and Triple Jump 2.39%.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a US$10 million equivalent facility, which will be split and committed directly to FINCA DRC, FINCA Tanzania and potentially to the FINCA Greenfield in Nigeria. Loans will have a maturity of 5 years. IFC will also consider an Advisory Services package to help strengthen internal capacity in pivotal areas, such as product development and risk management, which are key to successful growth.

Project Description: The project involves KKS Group (KKS), an independent utility providing space heating and hot water to customers in the Tula and Kemerovo regions of Russia. The project consists of: (i) improving the efficiency of existing KKS assets through capital expenditures; (ii) expanding KKS activities through acquisition and leasing of municipal heating assets; and (iii) developing and operating a combined heat and power plant (CHP plant) for an international industrial customer located in the Tula region. Currently, more than 80% of KKS heat sales is produced at the gas-fired assets, while the rest is produced at the coal-fired heat stations in Kiselevsk (Kemerovo oblast), where the use of coal is widely spread due to the geographical proximity of coal mines. The company will not increase its use of coal beyond 25% of total fuel consumption within the lifetime of the Project. IFC investment will provide a total of up to RUB 810 million (approximately US$25 million) in financing, or about 24% of the total project cost.
Review Scope: IFCs Environmental and Social (E&S) review of this project is based on: Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Audit of KKS Group (KKS or the Company), commissioned by the request of EBRD, and performed in June 2012 by the consulting company Dekonta (in cooperation with the local consulting company Shaneco);Review of available Company documentation related to environmental and social impacts and risks; IFC specialist meetings and interviews with the Companys corporate offices in Tula and site visits to the Companys operational facilities in the city of Plavsk, in May 2012.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Primarily intended for replacement/upgrading of heat networks and rehabilitation of obsolete boilers to improve operating efficiency and reduce heat and water losses in the system, this is a Category B project. The Groups planned efficiency improvements are expected to result in lower fuel and electricity consumption, and, consequently, will reduce emissions of multiple air pollutants, including carbon dioxide (CO2), per unit of energy generation.  Further reduction of emissions will be achieved through closure of inefficient equipment and installation of particulate matter (PM) emission control on operational coal-fired boilers.

Project Description: The purpose of this project is to increase the access to finance to the lower segment of the population in Colombia by supporting Credivalores-Crediservicios S.A.S (CV, the "Company" or "Credivalores"), a non-banking financial institution ("NBFI") focused on lending to low and middle income households in medium and small cities of the country. IFC will provide a Pesos-linked loan of up to US$25 million equivalent.Credivalores is a NBFI that resulted from the merger of two sister companies in 2009 (Crediservicios S.A. and Credivalores S.A), which were established in Cali  Colombia in 2003 with the purpose of lending to individuals and small companies. The Company focuses on payroll-deduction loans, consumer lending collected through public utility bills, discount of checks and financing of insurance policies to low and middle income individuals.
Impact: Colombia continues to have a low banking penetration (Loan penetration to GDP 33%), especially in low-income segments of the population. Consumer loans that are billed and collected through Public Utility companies are an attractive channel to provide financing solutions at effective costs to the underserved individuals.The Project is expected to have a significant development impact as it will allow middle and low income households to have access to formal sources of financing in medium and small cities of Colombia,  instead of going to loan sharks at interest rates as high as 280% per annum and therefore promoting a better income distribution in the Country.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed investment consists of a Senior Loan of up to $ 25 million to Credivalores, a non-banking financial institution (NBFI) focused on lending to low and middle income households in medium and small cities in Colombia. The loan will be earmarked at originating consumer loans that are billed and collected through Public Utility (PU) companies in several cities of Colombia, allowing increased funding for individuals that otherwise may not have access to credit. Credivalores focuses on four financial products: payroll deduction 66%, consumer lending through public utilities 14%, financing of revocable insurance policies 11%, and payroll deduction loans 11%. As the project will only support consumer lending at the base of the pyramid, there are no environmental and social risks associated with the investment. The project has therefore been categorized as FI-3 in accordance with IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The client will be required to enhance its Grievance Mechanism Procedure and commit to applying the labor standards established by the IFC Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions (PS2).
Sponsor: Credivalores is controlled by Mr. David Seinjet and his family through several companies holding 57% of the Company. Mr. Seinjet is a recognized business man and industrialist with interests in the sugar mill business.In 2010, ACON Investments, invested in Credivalores acquiring up to this date 33% of its equity. ACON is an international private equity investment firm managing capital through varied investment funds and special purpose partnerships. ACON focuses on investing in companies where it can add value as an active shareholder, while providing support and additional resources to management. The fund was created in 1996 and has managed over US$1.5 billion in investments in the United States, Europe and Latin America. The fund maintains offices in Washington DC, Los Angeles, Mexico City, and Sao Paulo. Among ACONs investors are the French, Dutch and German development banks, Proparco, FMO and DEG, respectively.
Cost Nature: The proposed project involves a senior loan from IFCs own account to the Company as a Peso-linked loan, in an amount not to exceed US$25 million (equivalent).

Project Description: The proposed project will provide access to financial services to small and medium-size companies in Nigeria through an investment package aimed at supporting the scale-up of the SME banking operations of Access Bank Plc (Access Bank or the Bank) by providing a risk sharing facility, on a portfolio of SME distributor loans, for primarily women-owned businesses.
Environmental Social Info: The main E&S risks and impacts relate to the Banks ability to identify and manage the risks associated with its lending activities. Access Bank is an existing client. The Bank has an E&S Officer and an ESMS in place. The implementation of the ESMS is however considered inadequate and needs improvement. The Banks ESMS also needs to be revised to reflect all the clauses in IFCs Exclusion List. The Banks compliance with PS2 on labor and working conditions was also reviewed during appraisal and the Bank was found to be compliant except with regards to not having a sexual harassment policy and a formal grievance mechanism.
Impact: The project is expected to make a contribution to the financial sector and economic development in Nigeria. The expected development impact is summarized below:1) Increase Access to Finance for underserved SMEsThe project will increase Access to Finance for SMEs, including women-owned businesses that are currently underserved in Nigeria.  2) Capacity Building of SMEsThe RSF project will assist the distributors to professionalize their businesses by providing relevant financial and non-financial training that will cover areas such as (a) financial management, (b) business planning, (c) inventory management as well as (d) soft skills / people management skills.3) Demonstration EffectThe Bank''s increased lending to underserved segments has the capacity to contribute to market transformation through continued lending to the target segments beyond the life of the project and demonstrate to the market that these segments can be banked profitably in Nigeria.4) Job CreationThe project will support job creation as they will provide financing to small and medium enterprises, which play a key role in economic development and employment5) Replication PotentialThe RSF project has significant replication potential as the large retailing company will use this as one of its pilot projects for distributor financing, with the potential to expand the distributor partnership with banks to other countries in Sub-Saharan Africa.
Role:
(i) Provide long-term funding for on-lending to key SME sub-segments
IFC will support the Bank''s increase in long-term lending to key sub-segments of the SME market, including women-owned firms.
(ii) Mobilization of Funding
IFC will mobilize Department for International Development (DFID) funding to support the project (Advisory Services and RSF), which will support the Bank''s expansion into high impact SME subsectors.
(iii) Leverage Global Expertise
IFC will add value through global knowledge of SME finance and best practice sharing, particularly as the Bank undertakes the strategic expansion of its SME portfolio.
(iv) Support Sustainability
IFC will play a key role in advising the Bank as its strives to improve its corporate governance and environment and social standards to global best practice levels, and as such support long-term sustainability.

Project Description: Ecolibrium Energy Pvt. Ltd. (Ecolibrium or the Company) is an early stage company providing a technology platform to monitor and control electricity usage for commercial and industrial customers, thereby achieving energy efficiency, with plans to extend to power grid infrastructure management and renewable project energy monitoring. The Company began operations in August 2010 and currently has 15 employees. The Company is looking to raise equity capital to expand its presence in the energy efficiency space by strengthening its product capabilities and reaching out to a larger customer base.

IFC equity participation will send a strong signal supporting both the industry segment and the company; this will likely help complete the current financing round, as well as assist with any future fund-raising.

Sponsor: Ecolibrium is promoted by Chintan Soni and Harit Soni, who are majority stake holders and also key management personnel in the Company. CIIE is also a stake holder in the Company.

Project Description: Headquartered in Zagreb, Croatia, Atlantic Grupa d.d. Project Description: IFC is considering a loan of up to $75M in Euro equivalent in Group Victoria to provide the Group working capital and to refinance existing short term loans. The IFC funds are expected to be used within the three core companies, namely Victoria Oil, Sojaprotein and Victoria Logistics. The oil and protein businesses are crushing operations (primarily sunflower and/or rapeseed and soy beans and meal, respectively) to produce foods and oils for animal and human consumption. The logistics business manages commodity transfer (from farms to production plants) and also its storage in a network of buying sites and large warehouses and silos.
Review Scope: IFC visited the Victoria Group corporate headquarters (HQ) located in Belgrade, Serbia and also several of the Groups operating company sites; sites visited included the production plants of Victoria Oil and Sojaprotein, a silo complex located in Crepaja belonging to Victoria Logistics, the Group Laboratory (SP Laboratory), the fertilizer mixing plant operated by Fertil and the adjacent Danube dock/port operation. Meetings at the company sites were held with production managers and those responsible for site-based environmental, occupational health and safety (OHS), legal and management system certification. A comprehensive walk-through of each site was undertaken. A meeting was also held with a representative of one of the largest farming cooperatives (Agro Promet, which represents approximately 3,000 farmers) to discuss Victoria Logistics relationship and interaction with these contributors to the Companys supply chain. Meetings at HQ involved senior management; the Chief Operating Officer (COO), Chief Financial Officer (CFO), Human Resources (HR) Director, members of the Board and other individuals responsible for operations.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This investment is classified as a Category B project in accordance with IFCs Policy on Environment and Social Sustainability. Based on information reviewed by IFC, this investment will have limited adverse E&S impacts that are few in number, are generally site specific, largely reversible and readily addressed through mitigation measures, as outlined in the ESAP attached to this ESRS. The main environmental and social (E&S) issues include the ongoing management of E&S impacts associated with the production plants and how the Group is planning on developing its corporate E&S management program to better coordinate this activity and promote performance improvements. The movement of commodities and products (and their impact upon matters of resource efficiency and pollution prevention) and ensuring OHS of those engaged in industrial operations is provided for through adequate systems and resources.
Sector: A-AC - Other Vegetable Oil Crops (Coconut, Rapeseed, Peanut, Sunflower, etc.)

Project Description: IFC is considering an investment up to US$75 million in Euro equivalent in Victoria Group a.d. (Victoria, or the Group). Victoria is a leading agro industrial group in Serbia with a primary focus on processing of soybean and sunflower oilseeds and grain trading. The Group employs over 1,800 people.IFCs loan proceeds will be used to finance the Groups permanent working capital financing needs and restructure the Groups debt financing towards a longer term, more stable structure that is suitable for the nature of the Groups operations. The long-term facility will be used partially to provide input financing to farmers needed to produce oilseeds for processing on the Groups plants. Thereby, IFCs investment is expected to strengthen the support to farmers and increase the sustainability of the Groups operations.
Impact: The development impact of the Project is expected to include:(i) Strengthening of agribusiness linkages and support to farmers:  given the strong linkages of Victoria Group with farmers, provision of longer term permanent working capital will help ensure stable access of pre-harvest financing to farmers;(ii) Job preservation:  the Group employs about 1,800 people across its operation and collaborates with about 400 partners which in turn supply the Group from over 25,000 farmers; (iii) Increase tax revenues:  IFC''s investment will contribute to the growth of government revenues from taxation; and(iv) Addressing food security concerns: IFC''s investment will contribute to food security and in meeting the challenges of increasing demand and food crisis.
Role:
IFC''s expected additionality includes: (i) Crisis response and countercyclical support: In light of the fluid economic situation in Serbia in the context of the Eurozone crisis, the local banking sector has cut liquidity on the domestic market. Through the Project, IFC is stepping up its presence on the local market, helping to restore confidence and increase investment in Serbia;
(ii) Provision of long-term financing: Provide long-term financing otherwise not readily available on the market; and
(iii) Diversified funding base: At a time of financial strain for local banks, IFC is starting its relationship with Victoria, a new partner which will benefit from a further diversified funding-base as a result of IFC''s presence.
Sponsor: Victorias  shareholders consist of: (a) three Serbian businessmen (who are also the founders of the business) Mr. Zoran Mitoric, Mr. Milija Babovic and Mr. Stanko Popovic (22.5% each); (b) EBRD (21.4% share) and, (c) Apsara Limited (11%), a Cyprus domiciled holding company.
Cost Nature: IFCs financing will be directed to support the Groups permanent working capital needs and replacing existing shorter term debt financing. IFC is considering an A loan investment up to 60 million for IFCs own account which will structured as a corporate finance facility.

Project Description: IFC is in discussion with Bank of JiangSu (BOJS or the Bank) to enter into a risk sharing facility (RSF) to support energy efficiency (EE) and renewable energy (RE) projects with private enterprises in JiangSu province (the Project).  In this proposed Project, IFC would take credit risk in a loan portfolio to be originated and funded by the Bank. The Project is expected to receive support from the China Clean Development Mechanism Fund (CDM Fund), JiangSu Provincial Government and Chinese central Government.
Environmental Social Info: The main E&S risks and impacts of the project derive from the E&S risks of the RSF target loans, the capacity and systems in place to manage these risks, and BOJSs practices with regard to labor and working conditions. At present BOJS does not have an  Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) outlining the procedures, responsibilities and tools for undertaking E&S risk management of its lending activities and a full scale E&S due diligence is not yet part of BOJSs loan review process. No staff/department has been assigned responsibility for E&S due diligence and monitoring, and addressing the training needs of all staff involved in ESMS implementation. BOJS was found to be in compliance with China relative labor laws and regulations and in line with the requirements of IFC Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working conditions.
Impact: Environmental benefit: Upon fully utilization of the RSF, 257,000 ton CO2/year GHG emission is estimated to be reduced per year; Access to finance: About 30 EE or RE projects will be financed under this project and most of the borrowers are expected to be SMEs. During the course, the Bank is expected to change its risk perception of EE and RE loans and would be willing to extend more credits to address EE  and RE demand; Capacity Building: The Project will help the Bank establish its internal capacity in indentifying and assessing EE/RE projects and  get ready to expand the  EE/RE products offering in the future ; and Demonstration effect: The success of the Project will encourage more banks in JiangSu to provide the much needed EE findings to local manufacturers. The Project, as an innovative PPP ( Public Private Partnership) initiative to address China''s climate change agenda, will also set a role model for other provinces across China.
Role:
IFC''s proved records in EE and RE financing through CHUEE model in China enables IFC to mobilize the first loss funding from Chinese central government, JiangSu provincial government to support the Bank''s initiative to promote EE and RE lending in JiangSu province; and
IFC, with its advisory services team and strong global technical expertise, could support the Bank to build its internal capacity to implement EE and RE lendings;
Sponsor: BOJS was established in 2007 through merging 10 city commercial banks in JiangSu province. BOJSs top 5 shareholders are Jiangsu International Trust Co., Ltd, Huatai Securities, Jiangsu Phoenix Publication Medium Group,Wuxi City Construction Development Investment Company  and China Oriental Asset Management Co.
Cost Nature: It is proposed that IFC invests up to RMB 462 million in the form of an unfunded risk sharing facility for a portfolio of up to RMB924 million comprised of EE and RE loans originated by BOJS.
