Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This transaction involves an unfunded RSF aimed to support small to medium energy efficiency and renewable energy loans and the overall environmental & social risk is considered to be limited. The project has therefore been categorized as FI-2 in accordance with IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The key sectors of RSF target loans entail limited advance E&S risk and impacts that are few in number, generally site-specific, largely reversible and can be readily addressed through mitigation measures. For the project BOJS will be required to screen and monitor the RSF target loans against the IFC Exclusion List, applicable Chinese E&S laws and regulations, and PSs for corporate/project finance if supported.
Risk Impact: The main E&S risks and impacts of the project derive from the E&S risks of the RSF target loans, the capacity and systems in place to manage these risks, and BOJSs practices with regard to labor and working conditions. At present BOJS does not have an  Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) outlining the procedures, responsibilities and tools for undertaking E&S risk management of its lending activities and a full scale E&S due diligence is not yet part of BOJSs loan review process. No staff/department has been assigned responsibility for E&S due diligence and monitoring, and addressing the training needs of all staff involved in ESMS implementation. BOJS was found to be in compliance with China relative labor laws and regulations and in line with the requirements of IFC Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working conditions.
Mitigation Measures: ActionTime Line (Proposed) and DeliverableDescriptionsNominate ESMS Officer/ ManagerOn or prior to commitmentDeliverable: Notification to IFC on the appointment of ESMS Officer/manager to serve as a point of contact on E&S issues and ESMS progress.A staff from senior management level should be assigned as an ESMS officer/manager for overall responsibility on development and implementation of the ESMS (for the target lending services of the RSF). The assigned ESMS officer/manager should have sufficient authority to ensure all affected departments and entities are involved and adequately cooperate for the ESMS development and implementation processes. The main departments and entities probably will need to involve for BOJ include (but are not limited to) Risk Management and Compliance Department, Credit Management department and Plan & Finance Department at headquarter, Corporate and Small Enterprise Finance Departments, Credit Appraisal Department and relevant review/approval committees at both headquarters and branches for corporate and small loans.Establish ESMS documentationOn or prior to the date the RSF is effective Deliverable: All ESMS documentation developed should be submitted to IFCs satisfactory.The ESMS should be established with necessary documentation to ensure consistency of E&S risk management across offices/locations of BOJ's operation.  The ESMS documentation could be either as stand-alone documents or as specific procedure steps in the BOJs existing system (e.g. the credit manual/policy). The ESMS documentation should include, among others: (i) an E&S policy, (ii) E&S due diligence procedure, (iii) E&S risk control measures, (iv) E&S monitoring and reporting procedures, (v) responsibilities of ESMS operation, (vi) mechanism to address external E&S concerns. The ESMS shall be supported with necessary guidance notes/tools for its implementation. Examples of these guidance notes/tools include E&S risk categorization tool, E&S due diligence forms, E&S Action Plan templates, E&S monitoring/supervision check list, E&S reporting form and etc. The ESMS and its supporting tools should be designed to address the specific E&S risks of the target loans in compliance with IFC exclusion list and China applicable environmental and social laws and regulations, and PSs for corporate/project finance if supported under the RSF.ESMS Trial-Run PhaseWithin 3 months after  the date the RSF is effectiveA trial run period may or may not be imposed before ESMS's formal rolling out depending on the need.  If a trail run period is imposed,  a comprehensive review of ESMS' effectiveness should be performed to assess and make decisions on any needed revisions, improvements or adjustments of the ESMS.     ESMS Implementation and TrainingOn or prior to the date the RSF is effective for submission of the plan Within 3 months after  the date the RSF is effective for completion of the implementationDeliverable: An ESMS implementation plan should be submitted to IFCs satisfactory.The ESMS implementation should be facilitated with a pre-defined ESMS implementation plan. The plan should specify the "to-be-taken" actions along with the time schedules and assigned responsibilities.  One the key item in the plan is the ESMS staff training which often to be the first step of ESMS implementation.  The plan should be approved by the senior management and communicated with all relevant departments and entities.The ESMS staff training may be tailored to accommodate the necessary levels of need-to-know for different audiences in applying the ESMS requirements. The ESMS training should at least be provided to:  i) the ESMS officer/manager; ii) the managers and staffs in the line of risk management at both headquarters and branches; iii) the members of Credit Appraisal Committees at headquarters and branches; iv) account managers/loan officers involved in processing loans and monitoring portfolios. ESMS Implementation Reporting3 months after the date the RSF is effectiveDeliverable: An ESMS Implementation Report should be submitted to IFCs Satisfactory.After implementing the ESMS, an implementation report can be prepared in due course to summarize the execution of the plan including some key data such as the ESMS staff training records/results (e.g. the number of staffs trained, types of training undertaken...), the ESMS operation results (number of projects went through ESMS requirements) and etc.ESMS Continue Operation On-going after the implementation Deliverable:ESMS performance Reports should be submitted annually according to the format provided by IFC.The ESMS is applied to process and supervise/manage all RSF target loans.

It will also add much needed competition to a banking sector dominated by state-owned banks.

Project Description: The proposed investment consists of 2-year convertible loan of up to US$ 2 million to ACLEDA Bank Plc. (ACLEDA Cambodia) in Cambodia, which may be converted into 1.2 million common shares in a greenfield microfinance institution, ACLEDA MFI Myanmar Co., Ltd. (ACLEDA Myanmar), as ACLEDA Cambodia expands its activities into Myanmar, following the successful model of its expansion into Lao PDR through ACLEDA Bank Lao Ltd. (ACLEDA Laos). It is expected that ACLEDA Myanmar will be established in late 2012-early 2013, and if the IFC loan is converted it would represent an equity participation of up to 15% of the capital of ACLEDA Myanmar. The conversion of the loan would be at IFCs option.
Impact: (i) Contribute to the development of the financial sector in Myanmar.(ii) Respond to unmet demand for microfinance.(iii) Development of new financial services in Myanmar.

(i) IFC has a broad range of institutional and financial sector building experience in emerging markets, and can give direct guidance in expanding into a new untapped market. In this regard IFC is planning as its first engagement in Myanmar an integrated program of support to the microfinance sector in coordination with the World Bank to strengthen the regulatory and institutional framework of the microfinance sector.
(ii) IFC has had a long relationship with ACLEDA, and this project will provide additional support to a strategic partner that has become a platform to provide microfinance in the region.
Sponsor: ACLEDA Cambodia was established in 1993 in Cambodia as a national NGO for micro and small enterprises development and credit, and gradually evolved from an NGO to a microfinance institution and to a commercial bank since 2003. It is now largest bank in Cambodia in terms of assets and loan portfolio.  In 2008, ACLEDA Cambodia launched its operations in Lao PDR through its subsidiary, ACLEDA Laos. Project Description: The MCS Group of companies (MCS Group or the Sponsor), IFCs repeat client and one of Mongolias leading business groups active in (i) distributing fast-moving consumer goods; (ii) beverage manufacturing; (ii) mobile communications and information technologies; (iii) civil engineering and infrastructure development, (iv) mining, as well as in a number of other industry sectors, is expanding the scale of its property development operations, which are currently focused on a large-scale affordable housing development in Ulaanbaatar (UB). MCS Groups property-focused subsidiary MCS Properties Holdings Ltd (BVI) (MCS Property, MCSP or the Company) has requested a long-term IFC loan of up to US$60 million, which will be used (i) to complete the Companys affordable housing development Shine Ger in UB; (ii) to build an affordable housing residential complex in the vicinity of the Ukhaa Khudag (UHG) mine site, 500 kilometers to the south of UB, as well as (iii) to develop an office tower, which will be an important contribution to the Mongolian capital business infrastructure, and a school building in UB (the Project).

As such, they have a direct and immediate development impact with respect to improvements in living standards and inefficiency of doing business in Mongolia''s capital. Project Description: The proposed project will assist Center Invest Bank in southern Russia in providing finance to small and medium enterprises located in the region.  The project will consist of a three-year senior loan in the amount of RUB 900 million (approximately US$28 million).
Environmental Social Info: The main E&S risks and impacts of the project derive from the E&S risks of the Bank''s lending activities, the capacity and  systems in place to manage these risks, and the Bank''s practices with regard to labor and working conditions.  Center Invest Bank has developed an Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) outlining the procedures, tools, and responsibilities for undertaking E&S risk management of its lending activities and E&S related due diligence is a part of the Banks loan review process. E&S staff has been assigned.  Center Invest Bank was found to be in compliance with the requirements of the PS2 regarding Labor and Working conditions.
Impact: The project is expected to have a significant development impact as it would enhance the Bank''s ability to lend to small and medium enterprises.  The project would enable Center Invest Bank to offer a wider range of financing instruments to underserved SMEs and encourage continued development of its SME lending with matched funding that would be available with IFC''s proposed loan.  Long-term financing is crucial for the sustainable development of the private sector across the country that would result in improved economic development and improved living conditions.
Role:
IFC will play a strong developmental role in the project by:
(i) providing funding in local currency with longer maturity and better amortization patterns not readily available in the market;
(ii) ensuring access to finance for small and medium enterprises, especially in financing of equipment and capacity expansions which typically require long-term financing;
(iii) supporting a well-run, privately-owned bank operating in the frontier regions of Russia; and
(iv) fostering competition in the Russian financial sector.

Company Name: VIRGIN MOBILE COLOMBIA S A S
Project Description: Virgin Mobile Latin America (the Sponsor or VMLA) has Mobile Virtual Network Operator (MVNOs) licenses in Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru, and has filed for license in Uruguay, Bolivia, Brazil and Argentina.  IFC will be providing a financial package of up to US$14 million to fund Virgin Mobile Colombia (VMCO or the Company).  VMCO will be offering mobile phone services primarily to the youth segment, with a targeted offering that will expand mobile broadband usage with attractive data packages.
Impact: 1) Innovation/Demonstration Effect: MVNOs are relatively new in LAC. Through this innovative business model the whole mobile ecosystem benefits (i.e., MVNOs, MNOs, technology providers, and most importantly, the consumer). The MVNO model allows for a deeper penetration of services (i.e., including mobile broadband, etc.) as poorly attended client niches (i.e. youth in the case of Virgin) obtain a well targeted service offering more aligned to its needs and expectations.2) Broadband / Productivity enhancement: VMLA offers a data centric service offering. Broadband directly contributes towards improving productivity. The contributions of broadband connectivity to economic growth, and as a kick-starter of other innovative business models (e-health, e-education, e-commerce, etc.), is widely accepted. 3) Infrastructure Sharing: Infrastructure sharing (i.e., including towers) is a key theme in IFC''s TMT sector strategy. The concept behind MVNOs is the sharing of existing telecoms infrastructure, thus maximizing efficency, increasing competition and reducing prices. The owner of the core infrastructure (i.e., MNOs) also benefits as it revenues increases by selling additional minutes and data wholesale. Moreover, the fact of leveraging on existing infrastructure makes this investment a "climate friendly" project. MVNOs have no substantial infrastructure or facilities, so they are unlikely to create E&S risk. 4) Availability, Affordability & inclusion of underserved markets: MVNO contributes to expending the reach of underserved population segments, lowering the cost and increasing competition in mobile telephony.5) Youth: VMLA directly targets the youth segment. Youth in general have a lower purchasing power than other population segments, and thus, a targeted and relevant service offer contributes directly to attending this segment''s needs.
Role:
1) Long term financing across the region: MVNOs entrants face difficulties in raising non-recourse financing for Greenfield operations. Traditional financiers do not fully understand the MVNO business model. IFC support is critical, as fundraising is particularly challenging in the current context of global financial volatility.
2) Stamp of Approval: Sponsor sees significant value in IFC''s involvement, as a way of further validating the business model after IFC''s involvement in its first regional launch (Chile). IFC participation will provide comfort to other investors.
3) Support an existing client to expand across LAC: VMLA has already launched in Chile and plans to deploy its MVNO business in 7 additional countries, including Colombia and Brazil.
4) Mobilization: Funding of Colombia operations might imply attracting co-investors. IFC capability of mobilizing financial institutions will help to achieve financial plan completion.
Sponsor: VMLA follows a branded venture capital model, with independent private investors funding a venture supported by a well-known consumer brand.   Main shareholders of VMLA are ePlanet Capital with a 19.3% stake, Hermes Growth Partners with 14.8%, followed by several other institutional investors, founding partners (i.e., Tribe Mobile executives) and management.The Virgin Group, one of the worlds leading MVNO brands,  provides VMLA and its subsidiaries with the use of its brand name, as well as close support from current and former senior executives in business strategy, product design, marketing, sales distribution, customer support, technology, wholesale agreement negotiations and public relations.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is in the form of a C Loan of up to US$14 million.  Together with Sponsor equity, IFC funds will help the Company to roll-out operations in Colombia.  Additionally, the Sponsor is in the process of raising a new round of equity financing, for which it has invited, and IFC is presently evaluating, an investment of approximately $10 million.

Project Description: FC proposes to make an equity and subordinated debt investment package of up to USD 2.1 million in MicroEnsure (ME), a leading micro-insurance facilitator with operations in Africa and emerging Asia. ME is highly innovative in the provision of micro-insurance through mass distribution channels such as MFIs and telecom companies (telecoms).The project supports ME transformation process from a donor-funded NGO business model to a for-profit company focusing on reaching financial sustainability. IFCs investment would be part of a USD 7 million investment package, which aims to make the company commercially sustainable by: (i) expanding MEs client base through a partnership with a leading telecom and innovator in mobile financial services, which would initially focus on 4 Asian markets, (ii) strengthening the Companys equity base, and (iii) expanding the Companys shareholder base to incorporate more commercially minded investors.IFCs initial disbursement of the investment would be for approximately USD 1.7 million for approximately 17.6% stake in ME. And a second tranche disbursement is planned for approximately USD 0.4 million one year after the first disbursement, for a cumulative total of 19% equity share in ME.  MicroEnsure is a leading micro-insurance facilitator that offers a range of affordable insurance solutions to the low income market.  ME currently operates in five countries and currently offers insurance products to 4 million people.  ME is a three-time winner of the Financial Times/IFC Sustainability Award. ME provides a range of services along the insurance value chain, including: product design, intermediation, administration, claims management services and third party administration (TPA).
Impact: Essential Protection of the Less-privileged: Unpredictable events, such as illness, loss of assets, death or accidental disability of breadwinner, bring devastating consequences to the poor, particularly in developing countries. Natural disasters such as windstorm/cyclones, floods and earthquakes constantly represent a threat to poor households and small enterprises. It is currently estimated that the current penetration of microinsurance is close to 2% of the potential market worldwide and that up to 4 billion people at the ''bottom of the pyramid'' could potentially benefit from microinsurance to mitigate their vulnerabilty against risks and disasters. Insurance can prevent people from lossing the achievements of their whole life and from falling back into abhorent poverty.The Project is expected to increase the availability of micro-insurance products to low-income people in Sub Saharan Africa and Emerging Asia, markets that have very low insurance penetration rates. Based on conservative projections, MicroEnsure (ME) expects an increase of more than 7 million low-income people accessing micro-insurance in the next 5 years, however there is a potential for this outreach to be much higher. ME is actively engaged in the provision and development of weather index insurance, a new and innovative product, currently in several countries and reaching tens of thousands of low-income farmers. As ME continues to develop the technology and management of this product, it has the potential to be rolled out on a mass scale.IFC expects the project to have a strong demonstration effect in the micro-insurance space by establishing the viability and profitability of a micro-insurance platform that can successfully deliver tailored products and utilize innovative distribution channels to reach the low income segment.
Role:
In addition to IFC''s financial support in the form of equity, IFC brings broad experience in and knowledge of the insurance sector, unique experience in the relatively underdeveloped micro-insurance sub sector and a vast network of risk carriers, MFIs, telecommunications companies, and other potential partners for ME. IFC''s involvement will provide a "stamp of approval", but also credibility to a concerted push into the microinsurance space. IFC''s best practises in corporate governance, E&S, AML/CFT and responsible finance are seen a tools to mitigate the risks inherent in a fledgling market such as micro-insurance.

Specifically, IFC''s additionality in supporting ME operations is given by (i) strengthening ME''s capital base, allowing ME to expand its operations, and therefore the offering of micro-insurance products, (ii) facilitating ME''s entrance into new markets through IFC''s client network and relationships, and (iii) advising ME on the implementation of corporate governance best practices.
Sponsor: Currently ME is 100% owned by Opportunity International (OI). Founded in 1971, OI is one of the first non-profit organizations to recognize the benefits of providing small business loans to those working their way out of poverty.  OI provides micro credits, savings, insurance and training to clients in over 20 countries and works with fundraising institutions in the United States, Australia, Canada, Germany and the United Kingdom to help create a sustainable approach to help fighting global poverty.  Contributions from individuals, governments, corporations and foundations are leveraged through commercial borrowings and client savings to significantly increase the size of OIs loan pool.
Cost Nature: IFCs investment would be part of a USD 7 million investment package, which aims to make the company commercially sustainable by: (i) expanding MEs client base through a partnership with a leading telecom and innovator in mobile financial services, which would initially focus on 4 Asian markets, (ii) strengthening the Companys equity base, and (iii) expanding the Companys shareholder base to incorporate more commercially minded investors.

(Navix or the Company) a  specialty non-bank, non-regulated financial intermediary focused on lending to local SMEs in the oil, gas and energy sectors in the southern states of Mexico. IFC will provide a loan of up to US$10 million equivalent. Navix is a Mexican multi-purpose financial institution established in 2007. Navix provides financing to small and medium-sized enterprises in the Country through structured debt facilities. Navixs two main business lines are project finance, which include structured loans to oil & gas and energy contractors and portfolio finance which include payroll financing, microfinance and loans to companies in other sectors of the economy.

By increasing its source of funding, contractors can secure a larger share of contract bidding as well as remaining as service providers in an industry were contracts are typically awarded to multinationals.

Project Name: Shandong Changlin Deutz-Fahr Machinery Co., Ltd.
Company Name: SHANDONG CHANGLIN DEUTZ-FAHR MACHINERY CO., LTD.
Project Description: The proposed investment is to support CDF to build a greenfield plant in Shandong province to manufacture four-wheel tractors in China (the Project).  CDF is a joint venture (JV) by SDF, an Italian agri-machinery manufacturer and IFCs global client, and a Chinese machinery manufacturer, Changlin.Founded in Treviglio, Italy, in 1927, SDF is an integrated manufacturer of tractors, combine harvesters, specialist harvesters, diesel engines and farm machinery. Its products are marketed under the brands SAME, DEUTZ-FAHR, LAMBORGHINI, HÜRLIMANN and GRÉGOIRE.  Currently SDFs production is based in four plants in Europe (Italy, Germany, France and Croatia), one in Russia and one in India.  Furthermore, in Bandirma, Turkey, the production of tractors from 50 to 70 horsepower (HP) has started in co-operation with a local partner.Changlin manufactures agricultural machinery, construction machinery, single cylinder diesel engines, hydraulic systems, machining parts and foundry products in the special economic zone located close to the city of Linyi in the Shandong province.
Review Scope: IFCs review of this investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety (EHS) related information submitted by SAME DEUTZ-FAHR Group (SDF or Sponsor),  Shandong Changlin Machinery Group (Changlin) and Shandong Changlin Deutz-Fahr Machinery Company (CDF or the Company) including: regulatory permits and approvals, site layout plans, technical specifications and reports, quality, environmental, occupational health and safety policies, organizational chart, human resources (HR) procedures, Changlins safety management regulation manual, minutes and reports of EHS committee meetings, safety statistics and records, environmental monitoring reports, Cleaner Production audit reports etc. The review also included a site visit to the proposed greenfield facility as well as Changlins operational facilities near Linyi city in Shandong province of China, and discussions with the Changlin and CDFs senior management and EHS teams.This is third investment by IFC with SDF. The Environmental Social Review Summary (ESRS) documents for the previous IFC investments are available at:SAME DTZ Croatia (Project #31911) disclosed in March 2012, is available at: http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/ProjectDisplay/ESRS31911 SAME Deutz India (Project #32007) disclosed in March 2012, is available at: http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/ProjectDisplay/ESRS32007Through past engagement for the projects in Croatia and India, IFC is well aware of the commitment and capacity for managing environmental and social (E&S) issues on the part of SDF.  The E&S due diligence for this proposed investment in China therefore focused mainly on Changlin''s management of environmental, occupational health and safety and social aspects of its operations.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for E&S Review of Projects because a limited number of specific E&S impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards and guidelines. Key E&S issues associated with this Project include: SDF and Changlin''s corporate approaches to management of EHS and social issues, adequate social and environmental assessment of the Project impacts during both construction and operations; assurance of fair, safe and healthy working conditions during construction and operations; resource efficiency efforts for the proposed Project, management of air emissions, wastewater treatment and discharge, and solid and other waste disposal; the impacts of operations on the local ambient environment; and impacts on transport infrastructure during construction and operations.
Sector: M-DA - Agriculture, Construction, and Mining Machinery

Project Description: IFC proposes to provide a loan up to Euro 10 million (approx. US$13 million) to support Shandong Changlin Deutz-Fahr Machinery Co., Ltd. (Changlin-SDF) to build a greenfield plant in Shandong province to manufacture four-wheel tractors in China. The Project will have significant contribution to efficient use of farm land and higher productivity through supply of four wheel tractors that offer higher technology and horsepower by manufacturing close to 200,000 tractors and reaching that many farmers during the life of the IFC loan. (ii)	Development of downstream food industry. Higher crop output resulting from large scale farming with four-wheel tractors will help develop downstream industries such as food processing and packaging. (iii)	Inclusive business. The Project will help the development of SMEs along the value chain, including the dealers/distributors, suppliers, logistics and service providers. A significant portion of these SMEs, especially the distributors, are based in frontier regions and rural areas. (iv)	Job creation. The Project is expected to create more 700 direct jobs in its facilities, as well as significant level of indirect jobs along the value chain and downstream industries.

(i) Long-term Financing. IFC offers longer term loan and grace period to the greenfield project, This allows the company to have more flexibility in managing its cash flow especially in case of longer than expected ramp up period. (ii) Stamp of approval/catalyst role. IFC''s investment in the Project is expected to provide comfort to other lenders and improve the Company''s ability to access long term financing.
(iii) E&S advice. As the project is in implementation stage, IFC could provide timely advice for the Company to establish best E&S practices, as well as input on efficient use of energy and water.

Project Description: The Project will involve an  equity investment into  HMH to assist with its corporate needs, including the following investments: (i) increase its softwood timber processing capacity and efficiency in South Africa, (ii) expansion of its  European Union (EU) fruit marketing and distribution, and (iii) expansion of its avocado orchards in South Africa and Latin America to achieve consistent year round supply of 50% of products marketed in the EU markets. In the medium term, HMH intends to expand into other avocado markets, including Latin America. The project will enable the HMH to implement its strategy to further develop its forward integration in the supply chain in South Africa, pursue global trading opportunities in wood products, and ensure it increases its ownership / control of sustainable commercial plantations.
Review Scope: IFCs review of the Baobab project ( the Project) consisted of a three weeks appraisal visit conducted in August 2012 to assess the Company (Hans Merensky, HMH) operations, review environmental, occupational health and safety, and social information submitted by the Company and understand their policy, plans and commitments for the future development of the Project. The forests operations and milling are located in Limpopo, Kwa-Zulu (Singisi and Weza), Eastem Cape (Langeni), and Mpumalanga provinces in South Africa. The avocado orchards and processing facilities are located in Limpopo, Everdon, Adelaide and Paarl in South Africa, as well as in Huanta, Perus Ayacucho Province. Under Hans Merensky Holding, there are two main subsidiaries that run its forests operations and processing (Merensky) and its avocado production and processing (Westfalia). A sample of their forests operations, wood milling facilities avocado orchards and processing plants, workers accommodations, field camps, and local offices were visited.  Meetings were held with local business units managers, forest managers, avocados farms managers, environmental staff and social/community liaison. This provided an overview of Hans Merensky Holding E&S performance and existing stakeholder engagement practices.  Meetings were also held with the CEO and senior management to better understand the Companys commitment and approach to key environmental and social aspects.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is category B project according to IFCs Policy on Social and Environmental Sustainability because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, EHS general and sector-specific guidelines or design criteria as is described in the following sections.

Company Name: INDORAMA ELEME FERTILIZER AND CHEMICALS LTD
Project Description: The Indorama Corporation (Indorama) is an Indonesian based multinational company operating in 19 different countries and a leading manufacturer of petrochemicals and associated downstream products such as polyethylene, polypropylene, polyester fiber, filament, spun yarns and fabrics.  In 2006 the Government of Nigeria privatized the Eleme Petrochemicals Company located in Port Harcourt, the capital city of Rivers State.  At the time IFC provided an investment to Indorama to acquire a 75% equity stake in the Company which was renamed Indorama Eleme Petrochemicals Limited (Eleme or the Company). The current shareholding is:  the Indorama Group 65%, Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC) 10%, Rivers State Government 10%, Host Communities 7.5%, the Nigerian Federal Government 5%, and Employees 2.5%.IFC is no longer invested in Indorama and is currently considering a $300 million loan to Eleme to support development of a new urea-based fertilizer plant.  The current operations are located on a 360 hectare site west of central Port Harcourt.  Approximately 50% of the site is developed and thus there is sufficient space to accommodate the new plant. Existing operations on the site include an Olefins Plant that produces 330,000 tons of ethylene and 126,000 tons of propylene annually.  The primary feedstock for the Olefins plant is Natural Gas Liquid (NGL) which is supplied by the Nigerian Agip Oil Company (NAOC), a joint venture between Agip and the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation, via an 84 kilometer pipeline from a gas collection and separation plant (gas plant)  located in OBIAFU /OBRIKOM.  The ethylene is used in the Polyethylene Plant to produce high and low density polyethylene with a total combined capacity of 320,000 tons per year. Propylene is used in the Polypropylene Plant to manufacture 120,000 tons of polypropylene polymers per year; these are used in the various applications including the production of materials associated with packaging and labeling, textiles and plastics amongst others. The facility also has two nitrogen plants that produces 4,400 Nm3 of nitrogen gas and 10 metric tons (MT) of liquid nitrogen per day. Power for the facility is generated via two out of four available natural gas turbines with a total power generation capacity of 132 megawatts (MW) and there are 3 steam turbines for the Olefins Plant. The new fertilizer plant will be located within the confines of the existing site and occupy some 38 hectares.  The main project components involve an Ammonia Plant, a Urea Plant and Urea Granulation plant. The Ammonia Plant will produce 2,300 tons of ammonia per day that will be transferred to the Urea Plant, though in the event that the Urea Plant is not operational, the ammonia would be fed to a storage tank.  The Urea Plant will produce 4,000 tons of granulated urea which will either be exported via the port or sold in the domestic market.  With the exception of natural gas that will be transported to the site via a new pipeline to be constructed, all the utilities required for the operations such as power, air  and nitrogen will be supplied via existing on-site facilities.The new gas pipeline for the fertilizer plant will be constructed by Eleme within an existing 15 m Right of Way (RoW) in which there are currently two existing gas pipelines; both of these traverse the RoW between Eleme and the gas plant at OBIAFU /OBRIKOM. The new gas pipeline will be operated by NAOC to ensure synergy in overall operations of all the three pipelines (the new gas pipeline and two existing pipelines within the same RoW). In addition, a new Port Terminal (jetty) will be built at Onne Port on a plot of land some 6 ha in extent and owned by the Nigerian Port Authority (NPA). The land has been leased to Oil Industrial Service Limited (OIS) for a period of 25 years commencing November 2005, and the lease is renewable for a further 25 years.  Eleme and OIS will form a Joint Venture Company (JVC) with a shareholding ratio of 51% retained by Eleme, and 49% by OIS; Eleme will provide the investment for construction of the jetty. The jetty operations will be managed by JVC and will include a quay with a water front measuring 320 m comprised of two berthing sections. Berthing Section-1 will measure 180 m and be suitable for accommodating urea vessels with a length overall (LOA) of up to 180 meters to serve Eleme.  Berthing Section-2 will measure 105 meters and serve OIS; this will be suitable for vessels with a LOA of up to 105 meters and accommodate break bulk, pipes and containerized cargoes. In addition to the quay, there will be terminal infrastructure including all material handling facilities necessary for urea and a urea storage facility with a capacity of 45,000 MT.  Other facilities as required for operation of the jetty will include a site office, generators, a control room, parking areas, a weighbridge and fire fighting facilities.  The transfer of urea from the fertilizer plant will be by road via an existing road network.Construction of the new fertilizer plant will commence in early 2013 with commissioning in late 2015.  The start dates for construction of the jetty and gas pipeline are still to be confirmed, however given the need to be operational once the fertilizer plant is commissioned, construction of the jetty and gas pipeline are expected to commence in 2013.
Review Scope: IFCs view of this project included:A site visit inclusive of the existing operations, the site for the new fertilizer plant and the location of the new jetty; Meetings with Elemes Financial Director, the Project Head who is also responsible for Environment, Health and Safety, Quality Control and Assurance Manager, Safety Manager, Fire Safety Manager, Human Resources Manager, Training Manager, Security Manager and Medical Doctor. A meeting was also held with community representatives;Review of the respective environmental impact assessments (EIA) undertaken for the fertilizer project and jetty, various documentation related to the environmental management and occupational health and safety systems, human resources documentation, responses to IFCs environmental and social questionnaire and presentations by the Company on the project and current operations; andReview of a comprehensive Environmental and Social Due Diligence report of the project undertaken on behalf of various lenders, including IFC, by an experienced international consultancy against IFCs Environmental and Social Sustainability Framework and the Equator Principles.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  The Project is expected to have limited environmental and social impacts that will be site-specific and temporary, and none are expected to be significant. The new plant will be located within the confines of an existing petrochemicals site and the cumulative impacts and risks of operating the new the plant, allied to the existing operations, will not pose significant risk to the surrounding environment or communities.  Those risks can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to recognized performance standards, operating procedures, guidelines and design criteria as described in the following sections. Key environmental and social issues relate to; i) ensuring the contractors comply with the environmental and social management system and associated plans for construction including aspects related to occupational health and safety; ii) contractor compliance with Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions; iii) extension of Elemes existing Integrated Management System to include the fertilizer plant and jetty operations; iv) ensuring adequate emergency response for all the project components; v) operation of the pipeline in accordance with accepted industry practices and; vi) updating various aspects of the project component EIAs to ensure adequate assessment of specific issues such as noise and dredging.  Eleme have robust management systems allied to effective infrastructure and in-house resources to ensure adequate management of project related impacts and specific actions to ensure compliance with IFCs Performance Standards have been defined in the ESAP.

Project Description: The proposed project involves an equity investment of LKR 495Mn (approx. US$3.84Mn) to acquire up to 10% shares in a Greenfield Licensed Commercial Bank, Cargills Agriculture & Commercial Bank (CACB or The Bank) and a senior loan of up to US$7 Mn to support the Banks debt funding requirements. In September 2011, the Central Bank of Sri Lanka granted CACB provisional approval to set up operations subject to fulfillment of routine terms and conditions.
Environmental Social Info: Main E&S risk and impacts of the project emanates from the corporate, project and SME finance. These includes impacts like occupational health & safety concerns, labour and working conditions, fire and life safety, construction related E&S risks, waste and pollution management and possibly land and biodiversity impacts depending on the nature and location of the investments to be made by the bank. Additionally, there is a likelihood of social risks and impacts in case of agriculture related projects in the country. At present the bank does not have an E&S risk management system in place. The bank was found to be in gross compliance with IFC''s requirements of PS-2 on Labour and Working Conditions.
Impact: Access to Finance - The Bank will increase access to finance to MSMEs especially in the unbanked agrifinance sector. The project is expected to contribute to IFC''s IDG on Access to Finance to SME/Micro clients. Expansion in North and East - The Bank is expected to have significant operation in the underserved N-E region of the country which is also part of the farming, fisheries, dairy production area of Sri Lanka. Build investor confidence - IFC''s participation can help build foreign investor confidence and help channel future FDI in the country which is critical for the growth of the economy and specifically for the reconstruction and development of the war affected N E regions. A niche Banking model - The Bank will be built on a unique business model with a bias towards serving the underserved MSMEs and underpenetrated regions of the country. Its strategy of serving the agriculture and linked communities will take its operations outside of the well banked western provinces. The Bank will use mobile banking technologies and take advantage of the extensive Cargills supermarket footprint and its links to the agriculture community to implement its differentiated banking strategy. This project will add a new dimension to the banking sector in Sri Lanka. Employment in the rural regions - The Bank plans to hire graduates as loan officers from the local communities to work in its branches creating job opportunities for young people in the rural regions of the country.
Role:
IFC''s association to this project will add further credibility to the proposal amongst investors, rating agency and regulators.

Development of best in class SME banking business model - As a new player in SME Banking the Bank will need support and advice in building the best practice operational processes and standards in order to built a profitable franchise given the difficulty to assess the risks inherent to SME financing as well as the higher transaction costs. IFC with its global expertise in this area, strong on the ground advisory capabilities and its successful track record in investing in greenfield banks will be critical to the Bank''s success.

Strategic Partner - As an equity partner, IFC wll instill good governance and help the Bank in strenghtening capacity at the board level. IFC will be able to work with like minded investors in fulfilling this objective.

International Strategic Partner - As requested by the sponsors, IFC will help to introduce a strategic partner with a strong track record in SME/Rural/Agriculture Banking to be an investor/technical partner in the project.

Financial Additionality- IFC plans to provide long term debt financing to the Bank along with its equity investment which would be beneficial for the Bank to manage its funding during the initial years of operations.
Sponsor: The proposed shareholding structure is as follows: Cargills (Ceylon) PLC (sponsor): 15%; CT Holdings (sponsor): 15%; IFC: 10%; An International Development Finance Institution: 10%; Employees of CACB: 5%; Local Corporate/HNI/Foreign investors: 45%CT Holdings PLC (formerly Ceylon Theatres PLC): is one of the diversified conglomerates listed on the Colombo Stock Exchange (CSE). The group has over 30 subsidiaries and associate companies and operates in the retail space, food processing, property development, financial services, ceramic and tiles, entertainment, packaging and plantations. CT Holdings had a market capitalization of US$201Mn as at 29th June 2012. Cargills (Ceylon) PLC: The operations of Cargills (no relation to Cargill USA) started off as a general warehouse, import and wholesale business in Colombo under an establishment named the ''House of Cargills''. A successful bid by Sir Chittampalam A. Gardiner saw the House of Cargills being incorporated as a Public Limited Liability Company on 1 March 1946. In 1981 Ceylon Theatres acquired controlling interest of the Company, and in 1983 Cargills established the first supermarket chain in Sri Lanka. Currently, Cargills is the largest modern retailer in Sri Lanka, with 45% market share. Cargills is a publicly listed Company on the CSE with a market capitalization of US$243 million as on June 27, 2012. Cargills had a revenue and net profit of US$ 293 Mn and US$9.1 Mn as of close financial year March, 2012. Cargills is a 70% owned subsidiary of CT Holdings PLC.
Cost Nature: IFCs proposed investment subject to IFC Management and Board approval: (i) an equity investment of LKR 495 Mn (approx. US$3.84 Mn) to acquire a 10% stake (44 Mn shares) of CACBs initial share capital; (ii) US$7 Mn, 7 year tenor, senior loan.

Company Name: INDORAMA ELEME FERTILIZER AND CHEMICALS LTD
Project Description: The Project (Eleme Fertilizer) consists of the construction of a nitrogenous Fertilizer Complex at the existing Eleme Petrochemicals site in Port-Harcourt, Nigeria. The project will include an Ammonia plant, a Urea production plant, supporting boundary infrastructure, and an 84km gas pipeline from the gas suppliers facilities. Total plant capacity will be 2,300 metric tons per day (MTPD) of ammonia, and 4,000 MTPD of granulated urea. A new port terminal will also be constructed at the nearby Onne Port to support the fertilizer complex; however the port is not being financed by the IFC. With exception of the external natural gas facilities, all main associated off sites and utilities necessary to make the fertilizer plant self-supporting are already in existence at the Eleme Petrochemicals Complex. At completion, Eleme Fertilizer will supply the domestic fertilizer market in Nigeria, and also export directly into the international urea market. The plant is expected to be completed and commence operations by early 2016.The IFC plans to support the project by providing senior debt, mobilizing 3rd party funding, and potentially making an equity investment.
Impact: The expected development benefits from the project are:(i) Food Security:  Contribution to the development of the agricultural sector and unlocking its potential, thereby reducing Nigeria''s dependence on imports. The project will increase fertilizer production which promotes intensive agricultural production, and will improve crop yields.(ii) Economic Diversification:  Increased value addition to a natural resource in Nigeria (i.e. natural gas), and advancement of the downstream chemicals sector. The project supports regional fertilizer capacity in Sub-Saharan Africa, which is a growing market heavily reliant on imports.(iii) Employment: Creation of significant direct and indirect employment opportunities.(iv) SME Development:  Removal of obstacles that prevent farmers with small land holds from efficiently optimizing their crop yields and maximizing their incomes.(v) Current Account Impact: Foreign exchange savings by import substitution.(vi) Demonstration Effect: The project is expected to have a positive signal for other foreign investors on the government''s commitment for economic diversification and agricultural transformation project
Environmental Social Issues: This is Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  The Project is expected to have limited environmental and social impacts that will be site-specific and temporary, and none are expected to be significant. The new plant will be located within the confines of an existing petrochemicals site and the cumulative impacts and risks of operating the new project components allied to the existing operations will not pose significant risks to the surrounding environment or communities.  Further, the identified risks and impacts can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to recognized performance standards, operating procedures, guidelines and design criteria.
Sponsor: The project company is Indorama Eleme Fertilizer & Chemicals Limited (IEFCL), which is owned 51% by Indorama Eleme Petrochemicals Limited (or Eleme Petrochemicals), and 49% by the Indorama Group. Eleme Petrochemicals is the largest producer of polyolefins in West Africa, and the 2nd largest in Africa. It is owned by the Indorama Group 65%, Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC) 10%, Rivers State Government 10%, Host Communities 7.5%, the Nigerian Federal Government 5%, and Employees 2.5%.Indorama Group is a leading manufacturer of petrochemicals and associated downstream products shipped to over 100 countries across the globe. Indorama employs over 21,600 personnel, and has 40 manufacturing sites in 20 countries. Indorama is wholly controlled and beneficially held by Mr. S. P. Lohia and his family.
Cost Nature: The Fertilizer complex will cost US$1.2 billion. Details of the proposed investment are as follows (i) An  A-loan of US$150m for IFCs own account (ii) A mobilization tranche of US$150m comprising of an IFC B-loan and parallel loans (under IFCs Master Corporation Agreement - MCA) ,  and (iii) a potential equity investment

Project Description: Hans Merensky Holdings Proprietary Limited (HMH or the Company) is a South African vertically integrated natural resource company with over 60 years operating history in the forestry and sub-tropical fruit industries. The Company is the largest grower and exporter of avocados out of Africa, and a leading player in South Africas timber industry through its timber plantations and sawmilling operations. HMH is embarking on a capital expenditure program that will expand and upgrade its timber processing capacity and increase the production of avocados in existing markets as well as new markets.
Impact: The development impact of the project is expected to include: Employment creation:  The Company has about 4,300 employees. The expansion of its operations and market position in South Africa and South America is expected to lead to the creation of more jobs.Rural Development: The project will make significant contribution to the development of rural communities in South Africa. Women Inclusion: The project will enhance inclusion as a significant number of the Company''s business units employ largely women.Increased tax and export revenue for government.
Environmental Social Issues: This is category B project according to IFCs Policy on Social and Environmental Sustainability because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, EHS general and sector-specific guidelines or design criteria as is described in the Environmental and Social Review Summary.
Sponsor: HMHs majority shareholder is the Hans Merensky Foundation (HM Foundation) with a 50.1% shareholding. The HM Foundations primary mandate is to promote science by driving the Companys research and development strategies. The second largest shareholder with 37% shareholding is Industrial Development Corporation of South Africa Limited, a government-owned development finance institution whose objectives include the development of the South Africas industrial capacity and implementing the Countrys industrial policy. The other shareholders are Vuka (5.1%), WIPHOLD (4.1%) and an HMH Employee Share Option Plan (3.7%) which are Broad-Based Black Economic Empowerment (BBBEE) shareholders.

IFC is contemplating a minority equity investment of up to 20%, which will contribute to financing the Companys capital expenditure over a five year development period. Project Description: IFC is considering providing a loan to OCL, an existing IFC client, to part finance establishment of a 1.35 million tons per annum (mtpa) stand alone cement grinding plant at Kulapachuria village, Salboni Block, West Medinipur in the Indian State of West Bengal (the 'Project').The Project will utilize clinker from OCL's existing cement plant at Rajgangpur, Orissa. The plant will manufacture 100% Portland Slag Cement (PSC) to suit the market needs with an option to manufacture Portland Pozzolana Cement (PPC) or Ordinary Portland Cement (OPC) at a later stage depending upon market demand. Clinker will be transported by rail from Rajgangpur while coal/slag/fly ash/gypsum will be transported by road. Cement will be dispatched both by road and rail. The Project is expected to take 27 months to construct and thus be operational by January 2014. The Project includes construction, installation, operation and maintenance of various facilities including: a vertical roller mill; coal fired hot air generator; coal crusher; cement packing machine; a cement loader; clinker silo; slag stockpile with stacker and reclaimer; covered coal storage; cement silos; fly ash silos; gypsum storage; utilities (a water treatment, wastewater and sewage treatment plant, diesel generator for backup power and fire fighting system). In addition, a1 km access road is required along with a 6.25 km transmission line for the supply of power from the grid and a proposed township with about 50 houses for employees.
Review Scope: The review of this Project loan builds upon the appraisal of OCL India Limited  (OCL or the Company) conducted in 2006 for IFC's existing debt to the Company, (IFC project # 24668 ) and ongoing supervision thereof, most recently completed in April 2012.  This project involved the establishment of an additional clinker unit at the existing plant located in Rajgangpur, Orissa, a standalone cement grinding plant at Kapilas in Orissa and increase in lime stone production from the Company's existing mines, all in India. OCL regularly reports to IFC regarding the ongoing management of their environmental and social performance which is currently considered satisfactory. OCL has undertaken an Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) dated February 2009 for the Project based on the baseline data collected in the winter months in 2008-2009.  In addition, a Social Impact Assessment (SIA) was completed for the Project in August 2012.  IFC's review of this investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety (EHS) related information submitted by OCL including the detailed project report, EIA, SIA, human resources policies and procedures, operational manuals and practices and regulatory permits including the Environmental Clearance and Consent to Establish from the West Bengal Pollution Control Board (WBPCB). Further, the appraisal included a site visit to the proposed Project site at Kulapachuria village in the Salboni Block of West Medinipur district, West Bengal in India.  In addition, interactions with representatives of the affected communities and discussions with the senior management and the technical team were conducted at OCL's headquarters in Delhi and at Rajgangpur.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The Project has been categorized as A given it may result in significant adverse environmental and social risks and impacts that are diverse and irreversible which are associated with various applicable Performance Standards.  More specifically, these relate to; i) land acquisition of 154 acres (62 ha apprx) with the resulting economic displacement affecting 321 households; (ii) economic displacement of 113 Scheduled Tribe (ST) households that are defined as Indigenous People (IP) as per PS 7; and (iii) potential impacts on communities immediately neighboring the Project site due to an increase in traffic, an influx of labor and emissions and noise during construction and operations. IFC based this categorization on a site visit to the proposed Project site and surrounding areas, meetings with OCL management and Company representatives responsible for environmental and social assessment and management, meetings with communities impacted by the Project and a review of environmental and social documentations prepared for the Project. The Company will implement measures to mitigate the identified impacts in a manner consistent with the Performance Standards including those as defined in the Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP).

Project Description: OCL India Limited (OCL or the Company) is an existing IFC client and a leading cement producer in eastern India with a capacity of 3.8 million tons per annum (MTPA). The Company started manufacturing cement in 1952. OCL also manufactures refractories.	OCL proposes to setup a 1.35 million tons per annum (MTPA) greenfield cement grinding unit at Medinipur, West Bengal (the Project).
Environmental Social Info: While all Performance Standards (PSs) are applicable to this investment, IFCs environmental and social due diligence indicates that the investment will have impacts which must be managed in a manner consistent with the following: Performance Standards.PS 1  Assessment and Management of Environmental and Social Risks and Impacts; PS 2 - Labor and Working Conditions; PS 3 - Resource Efficiency and Pollution Prevention; PS 4  Community Health, Safety and Security; PS 5  Land Acquisition and Involuntary Resettlement; PS 7  Indigenous People; PS 8  Cultural Heritage.The 154 acre (62 ha approximately) Project site is largely barren with some parcels of cultivated land and includes scattered parcels of forest land that total 4 ha. This project will not have adverse impacts on Bio-diversity and Natural Resources and thus PS6: Bio-diversity Conservation and Sustainable Management of Living Natural Resources is not applicable to this Project
Impact: -	The Project will lead to the creation of 150 direct and 120 sub-contracted jobs upon Project implementation. It will also create 10-15 managerial jobs & ~500 construction jobs during its peak construction. -	The Project would produce Portland slag cement, which due to its low clinker-cement ratio would result in savings of 84,000 tons of annual CO2 emissions.-	The project will contribute an estimated US$7 million per annum of tax revenues to the exchequer.
Role:
IFC will play a significant role in the Project by:
(i) Providing a long term finance, well suited to project & difficult to obtain under current market conditions for mid-sized companies. ;
(ii) Partnering with an existing client in a difficult frontier market,
(iii) Offering IFC''s Advisory Services to strengthen the clients'' supply linkages,
(iv) Enhancing the Project''s technical, environmental and social review and practices and ensuring compliance with IFC Performance Standards and reduce the Project''s carbon footprint.
Sponsor: OCL is a part of the Dalmia Group and is publicly traded on the Bombay Stock Exchange and the National Stock Exchange. Dalmia Cement (Bharat) Limited, the flagship company of the Dalmia Group, is the largest shareholder in OCL with a 45% stake & the Dalmia family collectively controls 70% in OCL. The remaining 30% is owned by the general public and institutional investors.
Cost Nature: The investment cost for the Project is estimated at US$102 million and IFC is evaluating an A-Loan of US$40 million to part finance the project. The balance funding requirement will be met through rupee debt and internal accruals.

Project Description: The proposed project aims to support existing or establish new national exchanges in Africa (and potentially outside of Africa) through a partnership with Eleni & Associates LLC, a newly established company with expertise in designing, building and supporting core operations of scalable commodity exchanges in Africa.  E&A will develop a full suite of technology necessary to operate a commodities exchange, including logistics management, electronic payments, market data, trade, reporting, surveillance, and warehouse receipt systems. Other co-investors are expected to join this undertaking.
Impact: The proposed Project is expected to have a strong development impact by improving the functioning of commodities markets in Africa (and potentially in a broader emerging markets context) through price formation, market transparency, regional trade, and logistics management.  It is also expected to improve access to credit.
Role: IFC''s investment is expected to facilitate the Company''s efforts in attracting other investors.  IFC will also help the Company establish best practices related to corporate governance and Environmental & Social standards.
Sponsor: Eleni & Associates LLC (the Company) was established in 2012 with the objective of designing, building and supporting core operations of commodity exchanges, primarily in Africa but also in other regions.  The Companys founding shareholders include Dr. Eleni Gabre-Madhin (70%); Keith Thomas (15%); and Jawad Ali (15%).  This team has built a solid track record in designing, building and supporting core operations of scalable commodity exchanges in the African context and is highly qualified.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated to be up to US$5.0 million. IFCs investment would be up to US$2.5 million for its own account, in the form of equity.  It is expected that the remaining US$2.5 million equity capital will be provided by co-investors.

Project Description: Brunswick Rail (Brunswick or the Group) is a Bermudian holding company which provides freight railcars to corporate clients in the Russian Federation primarily on an operating lease basis via its railcar owning subsidiaries. Brunswick is one of the largest privately-owned freight railcar leasing companies active in the Russian Federation with a fleet of over 22,000 railcars.  The Group is looking to expand its fleet to optimize its operations and achieve the critical mass it needs to thrive in the sector.IFC has an equity stake in Brunswick and has provided loans to several of its subsidiaries, inclusive of OOO Brunswick Rail Leasing, OOO Brunswick Rail Service, Brunswick Rail Holding Limited, and Brunswick Wagon Leasing. The proposed financing is a significant next step for Brunswick to finance its stage of growth and increase the company''s transparency and corporate governance discipline.
Review Scope: IFCs review of this repeat investment relied on discussions with technical and human resources staff as well as the ongoing supervision of Brunswicks environmental and social performance.  This included a review of Brunswicks most recent Annual Monitoring Report for the 2011 reporting period (dated April 2012) and updated information provided by the Company.  IFC Staff also visited senior management, inclusive of those individuals responsible for E&S activities under the previous investment (February 2012).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This remains a category B project because IFCs ongoing review and supervision of the Companys railcar leasing activities indicates that this additional investment will not result in any material change in the associated environmental and social risks and impacts.  The current Environmental and Social Risk Rating for the existing investments is Excellent.

Project Description: Brunswick Rail (Brunswick or the Group) is a Bermudian holding company which provides freight railcars to corporate clients in the Russian Federation primarily on an operating lease basis via its railcar owning subsidiaries. Brunswick is one of the largest privately-owned freight railcar leasing companies active in the Russian Federation with a fleet of over 22,000 railcars.  The Group is looking to expand its fleet to optimize its operations and achieve the critical mass it needs to thrive in the sector.IFC has an equity stake in Brunswick and has provided loans to several of its subsidiaries, inclusive of OOO Brunswick Rail Leasing, OOO Brunswick Rail Service, Brunswick Rail Holding Limited, and Brunswick Wagon Leasing.
Environmental Social Info: Key issues for this repeat investment are essentially the same as those previously identified and include: environmental and social organization and management of leased railcars, including relationships with manufacturers and lessees; employee working conditions, including health, safety and training programs; and pollution control and waste management activities associated with railcar maintenance.  IFCs ongoing supervision of the Companys railcar leasing activities indicates that this new investment will not result in any material change in the management of environmental & social impacts and risks associated with the project.
Impact: The Project would: (i) support the continued development of a key private sector player in the relatively new Russian railcar leasing sector; (ii) contribute to the development of the transportation and logistics sectors in the Russian Federation, facilitating economic growth particularly in the economically disadvantaged hinterland and (iii) enable Brunswick Rail to access the debt markets in the future to finance the purchase of additional railcars, foster the introduction of new casting technology improving efficiency on the Russian rail network and participate in the consolidation of the Russian rail sector.  Rail transportation is vital to the Russian economy and Brunswick Rail''s strategy to expand its fleet with new, modern railcars will improve the quality of railcars used in Russia. The majority of the Group''s fleet is unrelated to the oil sector and thus helps facilitate the diversification of the economy. Brunswick Rail''s new, more reliable railcars also help mitigate the risk of trucking replacing railways which would result in an increase of harmful greenhouse gases.
Role: The investment builds on IFC''s relationship with Brunswick Rail, which began in 2006, and contributes to IFC''s strategy in Russia to support private sector development and encourage economic growth. As one of Russia''s more experienced rail sector lenders and as an existing lender to Brunswick Rail, IFC''s continued support would help enhance further the company''s standing in the investment community.
Sponsor: Brunswick is a holding company incorporated in Bermuda which is in turn is owned 25% by its two founders Mr. Martin Andersson and Mr. Gerard de Geer, 14% by IFC, 9% by Sumitomo, 16% by Macquarie Renaissance Infrastructure Fund, 7% by VTB Capital, 6% by UFG and the balance by other shareholders and management.
Cost Nature: Brunswick Rail regularly considers different funding options, and in the event the company were to pursue a capital markets transaction (subject to market conditions), IFC would provide up to US$50 million for its own account (subject to the size of the transaction).
