Project Description: MHP is a vertically integrated poultry and grain producer. It owns and operates the key steps of the chicken meat production process, starting from crop growing; grain processing; fodder production; egg incubation; poultry processing; distribution and sales. Associated agricultural and processing operations include sunflower oil, sausages and cooked meat production; fruit growing and sell; cattle breeding; meat processing.MHP has requested IFC for a working capital loan to support MHPs strategy to increase its presence and grow including financial support to increase the land under cultivation up to approximately 500,000 ha by year 2016 in connection with the Companys expansion plan in farming and poultry operations. Once the first phase of the Vinnytsia new poultry facilities comes online in 2013, MHPs working capital requirements are expected to increase to be financed through internal cash generation and IFC debt.This would be IFCs fourth investment in the MHP. In 2003, IFC initially invested in MHP to support its efforts in chilled poultry distribution and sunflower feed technology (Project ID 21071). IFC followed-up with an equity investment and a loan in 2005 (Project ID 24011) for further expansion of existing facilities and construction of new ones in Mironivskys complex of integrated operations. Information about these projects was disclosed on the IFCs website and locally. In 2010, IFC invested in MHP to support its efforts in expanding the scope of its agricultural operations. E&S performance for this last investment is satisfactory and ESAPs action items have been effectively implemented. Information on the E&S aspects of the current Project (Project ID 29204) can be found at the IFC website through the following link:http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/ProjectDisplay/ESRS29204.
Review Scope: MHP Mironivsky Hliboproduct (MHP or the Company), one of the leading Ukrainian agricultural and consumer companies, is an existing IFC client. Available information about the Companys E&S performance derived from the previous IFC investments was analyzed and taken into account during this appraisal. As such, the scope of this review was mainly focused on operations related to further expansion of crop production areas and new poultry production facilities being constructed.IFCs environmental and social (E&S) review of this project consisted of a field visit to the Vinnytsia facilities located close to the town of Ladyzhin, Vinnytsky region, Central Ukraine; meetings and discussions with MHP corporate and local management (operational, environment, occupational health and safety, social) and review of key environmental, occupational health and safety and social documentation provided by the Company. The field visit included observation of hatchery facilities, rearing sites, a slaughter house and a meat processing plant, construction sites of a sunflower crushing plant and a fodder plant, and silos operating since 2011.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: IFCs environmental and social review reveals that this investment will have impacts that must be managed in a manner consistent with the IFC Performance Standards (PS) on Social and Environmental Sustainability listed above. Impacts related to PS5: Land Acquisition and Involuntary Resettlement, PS6: Biodiversity Conservation and Sustainable Management of Living Natural Resources, PS7: Indigenous People and PS8: Cultural Heritage are not expected with this investment for the following reasons. Any future land acquisition will only be done through willing seller / willing buyer negotiations. Project operations will not have direct adverse impacts on biodiversity as crop production is located on consolidated agricultural areas; the local population is not known to include indigenous people communities; the likelihood of finding of unknown cultural heritage, particularly archeological resources, within the existing agricultural and industrial zones is low. This proposed investment is expected to have limited and site-specific environmental and social impacts and none is expected to be significant. Those impacts can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to recognized performance standards, procedures, guidelines and design criteria as described in the following sections. Thus, this is a Category B project in accordance with IFCs Environmental and Social Sustainability Policy. This categorization is in accordance with other similar type of projects within the sector. The project is designed to avoid, minimize and manage environmental and social risks and impacts of the Companys operations in compliance with applicable IFCs Performance Standards and World Bank Group (WBG) General and sector-specific (Crop production; Poultry production and Poultry Processing; Mammalian Livestock Production; Vegetable Oil Processing; Meat Processing) Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines.

Project Description: BML is a leading electronics and home appliance retailer in Bangladesh selling mainly refrigerators, televisions and air conditioners. BML is the sole distributor of LG products in Bangladesh and also sells two major Chinese brands (Hisense and Kelon) as well as its own brands (Butterfly and Eco Plus) through its retail stores and dealership outlets. BML is in the process of establishing an assembly operation for their three main products, that is - refrigerators, room air conditioners and TVs and intends to complete this facility in the next 24 months.BMLs current and planned operations are summarised as follows: Current operations:BML is operating 200 retail stores and 455 dealer outlets across Bangladesh in owned, rented or leased premises in well established urban commercial areas. 19 retail stores are directly owned by BML and the average floor space of the retail stores and dealer outlets ranges from 230-280 m2.    BML is operating 9 warehouses across the country in owned, rented or leased premises. 5 warehouses are directly owned by BML and the average area per warehouse is 2600 m2. SKD (semi knocked down) assembly of CRT (cathode ray tube) and LCD (liquid crystal display) TVs for Hisense and LG brands. The TV assembly factory production capacity is 150,000 per annum with commercial operations having commenced in February 2012. The main operations for this factory involve assembly, testing, packing and dispatch.  Planned operations (Project):Addition of around 150 new retail stores and dealer outlets in 2 years in Bangladesh.CKD (completely knocked down) assembly of refrigerators for Butterfly, Eco Plus, Kelon, and Hisense Brands. The production capacity for a one shift operation is 200,000 refrigerators per annum and it is expected to start production in December 2012. Main operations in the plant will include cutting, punching, bending of pre-painted sheet metal, polyurethane (PU) foaming for insulation, assembling, testing and quality control and dispatch. Most of the materials like compressors, sheet metal, copper tubes and; chemical for PU foaming; etc. will be imported. There will be no painting operation required as pre-painted sheets will be procured. SKD assembly of room air conditioners and refrigerators for the LG brand. The production capacity will be 200,000 refrigerators per annum and 30,000 air conditioners per annum based on single shift operations. The production expected to start from June 2013.   The Project consists of equity and a debt investment by IFC.
Review Scope: IFCs review of this investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety (EHS) and social related information submitted by Butterfly Marketing Limited (BML or the Sponsor) including: regulatory permits, human resources (HR) policy / Employee Handbook, design documents (such as site layout plans), Occupational Health and Safety Policy, Waste Management Policy, Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) Usage Policy, organization chart, etc. The appraisal also included site visits to a sample of Sponsors retail outlets and warehouse facilities in Dhaka, a television (TV) assembly factory in Gazipur and a refrigerator and air conditioner assembly factory in Bhaluka, near Dhaka which is currently under construction.  Brummer & Partners Frontier PE Fund (FPE), an IFC-portfolio private equity fund is a co-investor in BML. A review of an environmental and social (E&S) due diligence for BMLs retail operations conducted by Brummer & Partners FPE team and a report on actions taken as submitted by BML was also completed.    Discussions were also held with BMLs senior management and operational teams at their corporate headquarters and assembly factory sites, Brummer & Partners management and their E&S and legal compliance unit, and with senior management from LGs -white goods division (a key supplier of BML for last 16 years) in Dhaka.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards and guidelines. Key environmental and social (E&S) risks and issues related to this project include: adequate assessment of the E&S impacts of the Project and implementation of associated mitigation measures; implementation of effective EHS management systems; engagement with local communities in accordance with local requirements and IFC Performance Standards; assurance of fair, safe and healthy working conditions; resource efficiency; management of emissions, wastes and discharges; and life and fire safety management of all the public access buildings (retail stores and dealer outlets).The retail stores and dealer outlets will be located in authorized commercial areas. The TV assembly factory and refrigerator and air conditioner assembly factory are located in designated and well established industrial areas of Gazipur and Bhaluka near Dhaka. The land for assembly units was purchased by BML from the Bhaluka industrial authority in 2010. The Project thus does not involve any new land acquisition and there are no forest lands, ecologically sensitive areas, indigenous people or cultural heritage in the vicinity of any of the Project sites. Accordingly, the findings of the Project review indicate that there are no impacts related to Land Acquisition and Involuntary Settlement (PS5), Biodiversity Conservation and Sustainable Management of Living Natural Resources (PS6), Indigenous Peoples (PS7) or Cultural Heritage (PS8).
Sector: M-BC - Household Appliances (Including Refrigerators, Laundry Machine, Dishwashers, etc.)

Project Description: This is an equity investment in Klabin SA to support the design, construction and operation of the Puma Pulp Mill (the Project), a greenfield mill that will produce 1.5 million tons of softwood and hardwood pulp per year located in a rural area in the Municipality of Ortigueira, Paraná State, Brazil, about 20 km from the cities of Ortigueira and Telêmaco Borba. The Project will consume 2.3 million cubic meters (m3) of pinus and 4.4 million m3 of eucalyptus per year approximately, which will be supplied from Sponsors own and leased forest plantations (totaling about 106.494 ha already under production) as well as third party suppliers who will provide about 28% of Eucalyptuswood requirements and approx. 11% of Pinus wood requirements during the first several years of the plants operation. The Project will also generate approximately 330 megawatts (MW) of electrical energy output through the plants chemical recovery boiler and a biomass boiler that will use pinus and eucalyptus bark as fuel, exporting in excess of 150MW of electrical energy output for use by the Sponsor at its nearest Monte Alegre Pulp and Paper Mill in Telêmaco Borba and for sale to the grid, through a substation located at the Monte Alegre site.   To operate, the project will further require the following ancillary facilities some of which are still in the feasibility or pre-feasibility stage as indicated below:Approximate 56,5km of 230-kilo volts (kV) high voltage transmission line;Dedicated water intake and wastewater discharge pipelines from the Project site to the Tibagi River (approximately 4km each); 4 temporary construction worker camps to house about  4500 workers to be located in or immediately adjacent to the cities of Ortigueira and Telêmaco Borba (currently in the feasibility study stage);Approximate 22km railway spur to connect the Project to the Central Paraná Railway system (currently in a pre-feasibility stage);Approximate 37km dedicated main access roads (currently in a pre-feasibility stage)Approximate 22km internal road with bridge over Tibagi River as a dedicated connection between the Project and Klabins existing Monte Alegre pulp and paper mill located in Telêmaco Borba (currently in a pre-feasibility stage)Approximate 35km road connection between the municipalities of Telemaco Borba and OrtigueiraThe Sponsor has started first phase of 3-year construction process at the approximate 188,5 ha site of the future pulp mill in Jully 2013, beginning with site clearing and earthworks activities to prepare for the start of civil construction works.
Review Scope: IFC Environmental and Social Due Diligence of this project included two field appraisal missions conducted in July, 2012 and October, 2013.  IFCs due diligence scope included a review of environmental, health, safety and social documentation provided by Klabin S.A. (Klabin or the Sponsor), consisting mainly of an Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) for the proposed new construction of a greenfield cellulose plant known as the Puma Project (the Project); the Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) for the proposed railroad spur; the Rapid Environmental Assessment of a new transmission line; Supplemental Social baseline study, Indigenous People baseline, impact assessment, and consultation report; Air, Noise and Water dispersion Models; Archeological Programs and Reports; Environmental Licenses; Management Programs;  meetings with Klabin representatives responsible for the management of environmental and social aspects of the project; meetings with third party consultants responsible for the preparation of the ESIA, as well as an independent consultant responsible for cultural protection and archeological recovery activities; meetings with elected officials from the City of Ortigueira and community representatives from the village of Lageado Bonito; meeting with a selection of families directly affected by the project; meeting with representatives from the Environmental Institute of Paraná (the State of Paraná environmental regulatory agency responsible for the environmental licensing process); meetings with IP Kaingang leaders; and field visits to the following locations: Proposed future construction site for the Project;Existing network of access roads near the Project site; Potential locations of new proposed access roads and railway lines;Cities of Telêmaco Borba and Ortigueira, the towns which will host worker camps during the construction phase; Queimadas and Tibagi/Mococa Indigenous Reserves, respectively located within the Project Area of Influence;Communities of Campina dos Pupos and Lageado Bonito, two small rural settlements located nearby the proposed Project site and associated components; andKlabins forestry plantations in the vicinity of Telêmaco Borba.  IFC appraisal considered environmental and social management plans for the Project and gaps, if any between these plans and IFC requirements. Where necessary, corrective measures, intended to close these gaps within a reasonable period of time, are summarized in the paragraphs that follow and in the agreed Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) disclosed in this review summary. Through implementation of these management plans and the ESAP, the Project is expected to be designed and operated in accordance with Performance Standards objectives.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category A according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure (ESRP) due to a number of potential significant and irreversible impacts of the Project which include:Social and economic and cultural effects on living conditions for nearby rural settlements and towns due to the influx of over 4,500 workers during the construction phase of the project which is expected to last 3 years.  This  includes risks of impacts to the IP population within the Projects direct area of influence and potential effects of construction employment on worker availability for other local agro-industrial activities;Permanent change to the landscape from its current rural characteristic into an industrial setting;Temporary increase in traffic risks from increased flow of heavy trucks, personnel and machinery during the 3-years construction period and permanent increase in traffic risks from the increased flow of trucks to and from the facility for the delivery of raw materials during operations;Changes to air and water quality in the vicinity of the project site during the operational phase; andPotential impacts to archeological resources.

Project Description: AMERRA Capital Management, LLC, (AMERRA) is an investment fund manager, focused on providing customized agriculture-focused and commodity-based finance solutions throughout the Americas to producers, processors, distributors and traders.  AMERRA has about US$600 million in assets under management across five funds and accounts.After successful deployment of investor capital through several funds during 2009-2012, AMERRA is in the process of raising additional equity for the AMERRA Agri Fund II, LP (AMERRA Fund II) which will provide a broader range of finance solutions to its existing and new clients, especially longer loan maturities than it has not been able to provide up until now. The proposed project entails IFC making about US$50 million of credit available to AMERRA Fund II for up to 5 years, leveraging the capital it will have to lend (the Project).
Impact: Despite their contribution to food supply and rural livelihoods, smaller and medium-sized agribusiness companies (and the farmers that supply them) have historically had insufficient access to finance from private sector sources, in particular finance that extends for more than one crop season.  Recently, the unfavorable supply-to-demand dynamics for financing to this segment has deteriorated as working capital needs have risen across the agribusiness supply chain with higher commodity prices at a time when the commercial banks who had been operating in some parts of the supply chain have come under increasing pressure to strengthen their capital ratios.  The IFC project supports the expansion of an innovative firm whose business model includes providing financing into this segment by intermediating capital from an institutional investor segment in developed countries that has not historically invested significantly in these agribusiness segments from the emerging markets.

Role:
(A) IFC is helping Amerra design and implement an Environmental & Social Management System (ESMS) to identify and manage potential environmental and Social risks. The system will include the following. (i) an initial screening for every transaction, and an environmetnal and social (E&S) due-diligence for long-term finance transactions. (ii) When applicable, the preparation of a plan to mitigate E&S risks or strengthen client E&S practices. And (iii), monitoring and enforcement of the plan. Improved E&S evaluations systems are expected to make Amerra: (i) among the few finance firms in its and related financing niches with a formal ESMS, which in turn (ii) helps disseminate better E&S practices among its clients in the agricultural commodity supply chain.

(B) Agribusiness sectors generally do not enjoy good access to finance and financing that extends beyond a given crop year is especially limited for smaller and medium-sized companies. Through this project, IFC is supporting a financial intermediary serving the sector as it moves toward providing longer tenor finance to its clients (earlier up to about 3 years, now up to 5 years).

(C) Although Amerra is proving its business model works, its role in intermediating funding from institutional investors to medium-sized agribusiness companies in emerging market countries and companies that purchase commodities from emerging market countries has not tapped all the funding that such intermediaries could efficiently deploy given unmet finance needs of medium-sized agribusiness companies. IFC''s support for the Project represents an important diversification of funding sources and may have a demonstration effect to help catalyze the mobilization of funding from new sources for this financial intermediary and others in similar niches.
Sponsor: AMERRA is a partnership which is 50% owned by Craig Tashjian and Nancy Obler (its two founding principals) along with Pat Morabito (its Chief Operating and Risk Officer).  The balance is held by M.D. Sass-Macquarie Financial Strategies, L.P. (25%) and Macquarie Group Limited (25%). The founding principals and COO had long and successful careers in banking before AMERRA.  M.D. Sass-Macquarie Financial Strategies, L.P. is a joint venture focused on investing in alternative strategies private equity fund managers and is equally owned by M.D. Sass and Macquarie Group Limited.  M.D. Sass was founded in 1972 and is a well-established investment management firm. Today, the M.D. Sass organization has approximately US$8 billion in assets under management and employs over 100 people. Macquarie Group Limited (Macquarie) is a global provider of banking, financial, advisory, investment and funds management services. Founded in 1969, Macquarie employs more than 15,000 people in over 28 countries. Macquarie has approximately US$340 billion of assets under management and is listed in Australia (ASX:MQG).
Cost Nature: The proposed project entails making up to US$50 million of credit available to extend and leverage the funds AMERRA Fund II has available.  The IFC investment is expected to be made in support of a sub-fund of AMERRA Agri Fund II, LP, which when it has deployed all of its resources to finance its clients, would consist of US$50 million lent directly from (or guaranteed by IFC) and at least US$150 million funded by equity for a total portfolio of US$200 million or more.

Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The Funds proposed pipeline consists primarily of loans to agribusiness companies at a producer-, trader-, processor- and/or distributor-level, located in the Americas in countries such as Brazil, Mexico and others in Central and South America. Transactions range from short- to medium-term finance. While sub-projects in this sector and these countries could have potentially significant environmental and social risks, the Project will not invest in high-risk projects, therefore this project has been classified as Category FI-2.
Risk Impact: The main risks associated with sub-projects in the region that involve primary production and/or processing, distribution or trading are related to labor and working conditions, resource efficiency and pollution prevention, land acquisition and/or resettlement, impacts upon biodiversity and possibly impacts upon indigenous peoples and cultural heritage. Some sub-projects involving food processing may have OHS risks, resource efficiency and pollution prevention and community health, safety and security risks; primary suppliers to processors, distributors and (depending on the proximity in the supply chain) traders may have risks associated with child and forced labor, OHS of workers and impacts upon biodiversity that would need to be addressed by the processors.The above can be managed and/or mitigated by the Fund: (i) Developing an E&S Management System (ESMS) and capacity to review all sub-projects per the E&S laws and regulations of the sub-project''s country and the Performance Standards, to be in place by commitment; (ii) conducting E&S due diligence (ESDD), with the help of qualified professionals, to identify the applicable E&S risks of each sub-project and require corrective actions as needed to ensure that these risks are managed according to the Performance Standards and applicable laws; (iii) implementing a monitoring framework to supervise the E&S risks of all sub-projects and report to IFC. In addition, the Fund will not support any Category A projects and IFC will review the first three ESDDs prior to the Funds investment to support the implementation of the ESMS.

Project Description: The project consists of the development of a 1.5 million ton per annum (mtpa) greenfield pulp production facility, with associated forest plantations, infrastructure and logistics, near Ortigueira, Brazil.  The plant will produce a mix of hardwood and softwood pulp, which will serve the domestic and export markets.
Environmental Social Info: Please refer to the Environmental and Social Review Summary.
Impact: 1. Employment: The project is expected to employ over 5,000 workers during construction, and following the start of operations, is expected to employ around 1,000 employees in the pulp mill and forestry operations.  Along with Klabin''s existing paper mill in nearby Monte Alegre, the project will be the largest employer in this part of the state.2. Taxes: The project is expected to pay over US$50MM annually in taxes, once it reaches steady state.  Under a scheme that was developed through Klabin''s initiative, in conjunction with local governments, the tax receipts will be shared with the neighboring municipalities, all of which are among the poorest municipalities in Parana.3. Carbon Sequestration: The project will include a forestry base of 106,500 ha, which will be under FSC certification.4. Renewable Energy:  The project includes a biomass-based co-generation plant with a capacity of 260MW.5. Import Substitution: The project will be the first fluff producer in Brazil, and one of the few softwood producers in the country.  By replacing imports that currently meet demand for these products, the Project will enable domestic proeduction in these segments in Brazil.

1. Anchor Investor: IFC would play the role of an early investor, which would help Klabin to raise more external equity financing for the project.
2. Environmental and Social Considerations: IFC''s involvement will help Klabin incorporate environmental and social best practices, learned through IFC''s involvement in landmark investments in the sector in Latin America and Asia.
3. Corporate Governance: IFC is working with Klabin to incorporate best practices in the Board structure of the project.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Klabin S.A., Brazils largest producer, exporter and recycler and exporter of paper. Project Description: The project entails a straight senior term loan to Jordan Micro Credit Company Tamweelcom, a leading and well-managed microfinance institution in Jordan. The purpose of the loan is to provide Tamweelcom with the needed financing to continue serving and grow its strong client base.
Impact: (i)Access to finance: The proposed Project would support Tamweelcom, one of the largest and well managed MFIs focusing on women, expand its outreach and serve a larger number of low-income people in Jordan. Through its well established network of 23 branches in the different areas of the Country, the project would be supporting the company is reaching out to more of the underserved segments of the society and thus expand their business activities and subsequently finance their day to day consumer and family needs.(ii) Job creation: MSMEs are key contributors to job creation in the Country and accordingly developing a vibrant MSME sector, with reliable access to finance, can play a significant role in private sector led economic growth, generating employment and providing opportunities to the poor.
Role: IFC''s additionality would be in supporting a viable financial institution in Jordan to further improve access to finance to the targeted microfinance segments of the market that will result in a high development impact, especially that women clients represent 96% of Tamweelcom''s borrowers. Building on IFC''s long standing experience in microfinance, IFC will be able to support Tamweelcom to further penetrate the Jordanian microfinance market by providing the needed term funding and help the company to diversify its funding mix. In addition to the loan, IFC will also be providing AS to strengthen Tamweelcom''s risk management capabilities that is key for successful growth. Moreover, this will have a strong demonstration impact as IFC''s presence will (i) encourage local banks, who usually shy away from extending long-term funding, to provide loans for longer periods to MFIs; (ii) provide comfort to other investors given IFC experience in financing MFIs in such markets; and (iii) provide Tamweelcom with the international best practices in microfinancing through the loan and the planned advisory services.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Tamweelcom, a leading MFI in Jordan that was established in 1999 as a non-profit Limited Liability Company fully owned by Noor Al-Hussein Foundation. Tamweelcoms vision is to enable low-income earners and productive poor to improve their social and living standards through micro and small-sized enterprises. Tamweelcom has about 32% market share and as June 2012, it had more than 73,000 loans (of which 96% were loans to women) and an outstanding portfolio of US$28.6 million. Tamweelcom serves its clients through 23 branches in Jordan and employs 279 people. Tamweelcom provides its clients a range of products addressing their needs in addition to non-financial services to enhance their marketing and production skills.
Cost Nature: The proposed project involves a senior loan up to US$2 million from IFCs own account to Tamweelcom

Project Description: The project is to assist Myronivsky Hliboproduct (MHP or the Company), a vertically integrated and the leading poultry producer in Ukraine, expand its production capacity. In line with its strategy of vertical integration, the Company plans to strengthen its grain growing segment by cultivating up to an additional 120,000 ha of land.
Environmental Social Info: Not applicable
Impact: The investment program will help MHP expand its domestic and export sales. The proposed Loan will support the Company''s working capital requirements for the successful implementation of MHP''s growth plans, which will have a significant impact on the local economy. Benefits include:- SMEs: MHP supports a network of 2,600 SMEs, a franchise network of small shops selling MHP branded poultry, which will significantly increase with the implementation of the Vinnytsia project. Significant number of these SMEs operate in rural locations often underserved in terms of basic food retail reach. - Employment: The Company currently employs 24,800, including 9,000 females. As a result of the investment program, employment will increase by an additional 8,000 workers. - Food security: MHP''s competitive cost structure will help the company provide competitively priced chicken in Ukraine as well as in importing countries in Africa, Middle East and Asia, thereby contributing to food security in those regions.
Role:
(i) Long-term partnership with IFC which would facilitate its growth through continued advice while facilitating the renewal of its bond in 2015;
(ii) IFC''s political and country risk cover in the context of political and economic volatility would encourage MHP to proceed with its investment plans;
(iv) IFC''s advisory services in resource efficiency and IFC''s assistance in certification of MHP farms to Global Good Agricultural Practice would set the standard for more environmentally friendly farming operations in Ukraine.
Sponsor: The project is sponsored by MHP. Mr. Yuriy Kosyuk, a local entrepreneur, who owns 100% of WTI Trading Ltd, which in turns owns approximately 66% of MHP. A remaining 34% is floated on the London Stock Exchange. Mr. Kosyuk graduated from the Ukrainian Food Institute in 1991 and established MHP in 1998. Prior to launching his poultry business, Mr. Kosyuk was involved in various business activities, including grain and retail trading, food processing.

Project Description: The Project involves financing the ongoing capital expenditure of Butterfly Marketing Limited (BML or the Company) to facilitate its backward integration into the assembly/manufacturing of some of its key imported white goods. The Company is in the process of setting up two manufacturing plants, Butterfly Industries Limited (BIL) and Butterfly Manufacturing Company Limited (BMCL) in an effort to manufacture its products locally, thereby giving it better competitiveness. The Project Company is BML, which is setting up the two manufacturing plants. It is one of the leading consumer electronics/white goods retailers in Bangladesh.
Impact: The Project is expected to: (i) Job creation: BML''s various projects are expected to create 90 jobs during the construction stage of the plants and 367 permanent jobs in the factories post-construction. The company will be creating 200 new dealerships across the country in the next three years to expand its distribution network, which will create additional indirect jobs; (ii) Technology transfer: BML will be leveraging the technical expertise of LG and Hisense to set up its manufacturing plants, adopting manufacturing best practices, which is expected to improve the overall quality of BML and, in due course, of other companies in the industry; (iii) Diversify Bangladesh''s export basket: BML plans to export Hisense (and possibly other branded) products once operations have stabilized. This would help Bangladesh diversify its export basket and improve the country''s over dependence on the textile sector; (iv) Increase domestic consumption: By selling branded household appliances at lower prices, BML will make these aspirational goods affordable to a much larger section of the country''s population, promoting domestic consumption; and (v) Reduce trade deficit: BML''s backward integration will help reduce Bangladesh''s total import bill and will lead to foreign currency savings, which will help shore up the country''s foreign exchange reserves.
Role: (i) Industry: IFC''s industry expertise in retail and manufacturing have yielded a set of recommendations, which have already been incorporated into the Company''s future plans. Very much welcomed and valued by the Company, IFC will seek to add value through its expertise going forward as a long-term partner; (ii) Demonstration effect: IFC''s equity investment will positively influence the perception of Bangladesh''s undeveloped manufacturing sector, potentially encouraging more investments that could improve the overall scale and competitiveness of the sector; (iii) Corporate governance expertise: Through the proposed investment, IFC/FPE will be able to appoint two to three independent directors to the board of the Company between themselves, which will help promote adoption of corporate governance best practices and increased financial transparency and accountability. IFC is also exploring an engagement of the Corporate Governance Advisory team with the Company; and (iv) Long-term financing: Through the provision of A and B loans, IFC will provide long-term financing to facilitate the growth of the Company, that is not currently available in the local market.
Sponsor: BML currently has 23 shareholders, representing 11 groups of friends and family. The Sponsor, Mr. M.A. Mannan, who set up the Company in 1987, is also the chairman of the Company. The Chairman and his immediate family manage the business and own 35% of the shares, while an additional 20.5% stake is held by his extended family and close friends - thus the Sponsor Group exercises control over approximately 55.5% of the shareholding.
Cost Nature: The proposed investment from IFC is a financing package of up to US$ 42 million consisting of an A loan, a B/parallel loan and an equity purchase. The A and B/parallel loans would be used to part-finance capital expenditure towards setting up the manufacturing plants while the equity investment would help the company streamline its share holding structure to support its future growth and expansion plans.

Project Description: Plato is a Turkish private education provider which started operations in 2009 with two vocational education institutes: Plato College for Higher Education in Istanbul, Turkey and Plato University of Management and Design (PUMD) in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan. Plato has grown from 70 students in academic year (AY) 2009-2010 to 1900 students in AY 2012-2013. Plato currently has eleven vocational training centers in Turkey and one university in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan. Of these eleven in Turkey, six are operational and the remaining will be functional in the coming few months.Plato is implementing its 2012-15 expansion plan which constitutes: (i) expansion of its vocational learning network across Turkey, (ii) introduction of new programs in its existing university in Bishkek and establishment of vocational training centers in Kazakhstan, and (iii) entrance into the Middle East and North Africa region with offering of post secondary vocational education programs. Their physical expansion of facilities will be mainly carried out through existing structures that will be renovated and restored, but may also include construction of new facilities in the future.  Turkey InstitutionsIn Turkey, Plato has 3 facilities in Istanbul, and another 8 facilities outside Istanbul in state premises as described below.  Among the Istanbul facilities the largest and main campus is known as the Balat Campus, which is composed of 9 buildings of 4500m2 closed spaces and 1000m2 of open spaces that are scattered around in an old historical neighborhood of Istanbul. Most of the buildings are at least 150-200 years old. Each building has been restored and renovated to fit the criteria of the institution according the Law of Renewal in Turkey. Balat in Istanbul's Fatih district is among the city's oldest neighborhoods, dating back to well before the Byzantine period. Part of the district is included on the UNESCO World Heritage Site of the historic areas of Istanbul, within the Golden Horn harbor area. UNESCO is regenerating the area to retain the old heritage of these historical sites. Plato in conjunction with the municipality is restoring these buildings for the expansion of the Balat Campus in this area. Most of the employees of the Balat Campus are employed from this area. The second facility is known as Fatih Campus which is composed of 1 building of 1000m2 of closed space in a commercial area that is more modern in Istanbul focusing on IT services and education with a student capacity of 200. The third facility is known as Althunizade Campus which is composed of 1 building of 800m2 of closed space in a residential area in the Asian side of Istanbul. This campus has a student capacity of 250 students but is still not yet operational. Plato has entered into a cost sharing agreement with state-owned vocational institutions to use the state's premises to deliver Plato's educational services. This model is currently functioning in 8 cities outside Istanbul including Ankara, Adana, Trabzon, Bursa, Izmir, Antalya, Konya, and Samsun.  Of these 8 cities, Izmir, Samsun, Konya and Antalya are near completion whilst the rest are operational.Central AsiaThe Group currently has 1 facility in Central Asia, one in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan, Plato University of Management and Design (PUMD) which is operational.  PUMD is 1 building in Bishkek of 800m2 of closed space and 100m2 of open space. The building capacity can withstand 200 students, and offers vocational based Bachelor of Arts (BA) programs in Bishkek. Plato is in the process of establishing a regional learning center in Chimkent, Kazakhstan that delivers PUMD programs through face-to-face and distance learning modules.
Review Scope: The review of this project consisted of appraising information provided by the Sponsor related to technical, environmental and social issues, as well as visits to the Sponsor's existing education premises in Istanbul and Adana, Turkey as well as Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan during September 2012. IFC's review also included meetings with top Management including the CEO and CFO, as well as the HR director, HSE and Maintenance officers and Quality assurance supervisors at Plato Group's headquarters in Balat, Turkey. IFC reviewed relevant documents pertaining to the HR Policies and Procedures, Emergency Response and Management System, and Security system.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Based on the site visits to Plato's premises in Turkey and Kyrgyzstan, and discussions with Plato management, this project will have limited potential adverse environmental and social impacts which are site-specific, reversible and easily addressable through the measures summarized below and outlined in the Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) attached to this ESRS.  This is, hence, a category B Project.
Sector: T-AB - Colleges, Universities, and Professional Schools

The Fund would help private sector development through supporting growth and operational improvement of its portfolio companies.  The Project would support private equity investments in the Fund's target country and thus it would help develop the financial markets in the Philippines.

Project Description: Plato is a Turkish private education provider which started operations in 2009 with two vocational education institutes; Plato College for Higher Education in Istanbul, Turkey and Plato University of Management and Design in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan. Plato has grown from 70 students in academic year (AY) 2009-2010 to 1900 students in AY 2012-2013. Plato currently operates six vocational training centers in Turkey (additional five to be operational in the coming months) and one university in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan. Plato is implementing its 2012-15 expansion plan which constitutes: (i) expansion of its vocational learning centers across Turkey, (ii) introduction of new programs in its existing university in Bishkek and establishment of vocational training centers in Kazakhstan, and (iii) entrance into the Middle East and North Africa region with offering of quality post secondary vocational education programs relevant to labor market needs, thereby contributing to the goals of IFCs e4e Initiative for the Arab Youth (e4e). The total Project cost is estimated at US$ 12 million and IFC is proposed to fund a portion of this investment program.
Environmental Social Info: The main E&S issues related to Plato are land/building acquisition, cultural heritage, permits, regulatory compliance; environment, health and safety during construction/renovation/restructuring; building structural safety, life and fire safety, emergency preparedness and response; energy and water efficiency; hazardous materials, wastes, emissions and effluents management and minimization, human resources policy and practices; safety and hygiene control mechanisms both for personnel and students, supply of food and drinking water, engagement with communities.
Impact: - Expansion of access to vocational education thereby increasing number of youth that have skills relevant to the job market, including soft skills.- Increase access to quality higher education and internationally accredited programs to lower income students and to remote communities.- Demonstration of financial viability and replicability of a vocational education model that could be applied to various markets across regions, including to post-conflict regions. - Project is an example of south-south investments and will serve to strengthen regional communion.
Role:
- Provision of long term financing to support expansion of vocational education facilities across three regions.
- Enhancing sustainability of the Project by bringing financial and operational discipline during the extensive expansion plan.
- Sharing IFC''s sectoral knowledge and global network to assist the client in expansion in new territory.
- Providing guidance on high standards of corporate governance and environmental and social considerations.

Project Description: Umeme Ltd. (Umeme, the Company) is a regulated electricity distribution company in Uganda, supplying over 500,000 customers mainly located in the semi-urban corridor linking Kampala, Entebbe and Jinja.  In March 2005, Umeme was awarded a 20 year concession to manage and operate the assets of Uganda Electricity Distribution Company (UEDCL).  The award of the concession was part of Ugandas broader privatization of its power sector, which also involved the unbundling of transmission, distribution and generation, and the awarding of concessions for the operation of its existing generation assets.  Ugandas power sector privatization was fully supported by the World Bank Group, and the Umeme financing structure includes both MIGA insurance and a partial risk guarantee from IDA.  Umeme is wholly owned by the UK based Actis Infrastructure 2 Fund (AI2).As at 31 December 2011, Umeme invested approximately US$ 134 million in the rehabilitation and development of its network (the Project), making additional connections, implementing a new customer billing system, rolling out a customer call center and work management centers, and expanding its environmental, health and safety management capacity.   In 2009, IFC committed $25 m in debt financing to support Umemes expansion.  The proposed investment involves IFCs participation in an Initial Public Offering by Umeme to support Umemes capacity to raise the financings for its ambitious capex expansion program.
Review Scope: IFCs review of the project involved: an assessment of the Companys environmental and social performance since IFCs original investment in the Company (2009); meetings with Company management and staff responsible for environmental, health and safety as well as human resource management; and site visits to a representative sample of key infrastructure, i.e. various types and ages of sub-stations, medium- and low-voltage distribution networks and the main operations depot/engineering center in Kampala.  Umeme currently has an IFC Environmental and Social Risk Rating of Satisfactory, which reflects the Companys ability to manage the environmental, health and safety risks associated with its operations in compliance with IFC requirements.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Policy on Environmental and Social Sustainability.  The Companys operations have limited environmental and social impacts, and these are site-specific, temporary and not significant.  Impacts associated with an expansion of existing operations can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to recognized performance standards, operating procedures, guidelines and design criteria as described in the following sections.

Project Description: The proposed transaction is an equity participation by IFC in the IPO of Umeme Limited (Umeme, or the Company), a Ugandan electricity distribution company.   Umeme holds a concession for electricity distribution in Uganda until 2025 and the company is presently approximately 98% indirectly owned by Actis Infrastructure 2 LP (AI2), an investment fund under the management of Actis LLP, UK-based emerging market Private Equity firm.  The IPO consists of the sale of existing shares and subscription of new shares in Umeme.
Environmental Social Info: The Companys operations have limited environmental and social impacts, and these are site-specific, temporary and not significant.
Impact: The IPO is the first step of a new development and investment phase for the Company, which is expected to (i) allow the connection of additional customers to the grid; (ii) reduce technical and commercial distribution losses; (iii) improve the quality of services to end users; (iv) through the improvement of distribution network, contribute to mitigate climate change impacts; As such, this Project represents an important next step in ensuring the long-term reach and reliability of electricity supply in the country.
Role: Since its involvement in the Company in 2009, IFC has played an important and continuous role of support to Umeme, not only by financing them in the time of the financial crisis but also as an active support in the dialogue with the Government and the Regulator. By becoming a shareholder, IFC''s investment will contribute to the IPO success and the development of local capital markets. Finally, it will enhance the Company''s capacity to raise further financing which is much needed for its investment program.
Sponsor: Umeme was incorporated on 6 May 2004 and was subsequently awarded a 20 year concession of the Ugandan Electricity Distribution Company Limiteds (UEDCL) distribution assets, as a result of an international bidding process. Umeme is a wholly owned subsidiary of Umeme Holding Limited, a Mauritian based holding company, which in turn is owned indirectly 98 % by AI2 and 2 % by Actis co-investment vehicles.
Cost Nature: The Company plans to raise UGX 171.1 billion (circa US$ 66.73 million) through the IPO.  IFC intends to participate in the IPO.

Company Name: GLOBAL HEALTH INVESTMENT FUND I, LLC
Project Description: The project being proposed is a US$10mm equity investment in a mezzanine fund, the Global Health Investment Fund, LLC ('GHIF' or the 'Fund'), sponsored by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. GHIF is seeking to raise approximately US$100mm for the purpose of  improving global health. The Fund would support the development of drugs, vaccines, preventatives, diagnostics and other related technologies aimed at infectious diseases that cause significant morbidity and mortality in developing countries (e.g. neglected infectious diseases), as well as those that provide solutions for maternal, neonatal and child-health challenges.
Environmental Social Info: The environmental and social risks in this investment are those associated with the Funds investments in the companies developing the health care products previously described.  The main risks anticipated in these companies are related to labor and working conditions, including occupational health and safety for the companies staff, control of emissions to air and water, and the design and conduct of clinical trials according to international best practices
Impact: Given the Fund's focus on the late stage in the development of many of the drugs, vaccines and diagnostics in the pipeline, it is reasonable to expect a large development impact on several fronts: (i) possible replication of the business model and scale-up of the flow of additional funding into late stage development of drugs for neglected diseases; (ii) millions of patients, and especially those in vulnerable population (children and pregnant women) will benefit from the drugs that will be commercialized through this vehicle; (iii) by demonstrating the commercial viability of the proposed funding structure, this could prove to be an important catalyst for the development of drugs that otherwise would not be developed; and(iv) demonstration effect to other charitable foundations that their money could be multiplied and effects of their charitable giving amplified through this funding mechanism, which is expected to bring positive financial return to investors.
Role:
(i) By participating in the first close, IFC's presence signals the confidence in a novel funding model for the development of drugs targeting neglected diseases and the poorest in the emerging markets;
(ii) IFC's will endeavor to make its emerging markets experience and expertise available to the Fund; and
(iii) The recipients of mezzanine funding may be beneficiaries of IFC's direct co-funding in certain cases, which could further expedite the commercialization of these drugs.
Sponsor: The Fund will be managed by the Global Health Investment Corporation, a Delaware nonprofit nonstick corporation, which has mandated LHGP Asset Management LLP, the affiliate of Lion's Head Global Partners LLP, as the designated Investment Manager.
Cost Nature: The proposal is for IFC to make an equity investment of up to US$10 million in the Fund, which aims to total US$100 million.

Project Description: The proposed investment consists of a US$ 40 million 7-year subordinated debt to ACLEDA Bank Plc. (ACLEDA Cambodia or the Bank), which is expected to be funded fully through the IFC Capitalization Fund (the Cap Fund), as the proposed project is fully consistent with the Cap Funds objective of supporting a systemic bank that is capable of providing credit to emerging economies but is facing significant challenges to raise capital in international capital/credit markets, due to the global financial crisis. The proposed investment will support ACLEDA Cambodias growth plan of further expanding its branch network in Cambodia and regionally, and continuing to move up market to better serve larger medium SMEs.
Environmental Social Info: The main E&S risks and impacts of the project derive from the E&S risks of the Banks lending activities, the capacity and systems in place to manage these risks, and the Banks practices with regard to labor and working conditions. Under the requirements of the existing IFC investment, the company has appointed an E&S officer and two E&S coordinators and developed an environmental and social management system (ESMS). The ESMS, among others, requires the Bank to screen projects against the IFC Exclusion list and to ensure compliance with Cambodian national E&S laws and regulations.  The Bank is however in the process of upgrading the current ESMS and in particular to enhance its capacity to assess and manage potential E&S risks associated with the Banks investment activities. The Banks labor management was found to be consistent with the requirements of IFC Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working conditions.
Impact: (i) Improve access to credit as it will enable ACLEDA to continue providing credit to microfinance and SME clients.(ii) Improve market confidence, as it will enhance prospects of mobilizing additional long term funding from private investors.
Role:
(i) Play a catalytic role in resource mobilization by mobilizing resources from the Capitalization Fund.
(ii) Provide long term tier 2 capital which is scarce in Cambodia.
(iii) Continued support of a strategic partner.
Sponsor: ACLEDA Cambodia was established in 1993 in Cambodia as a national NGO for micro and small enterprises development and credit, and gradually evolved from an NGO to a microfinance institution and to a commercial bank since 2003. It is now largest bank in Cambodia in terms of assets and loan portfolio.  In 2008, ACLEDA Cambodia launched its operations in Lao PDR through its subsidiary, ACLEDA Laos. The shareholding structure of both ACLEDA Cambodia and ACLEDA Laos is diversified, and includes other DFIs.ACLEDA Cambodia has been a long term client of IFC since an initial equity investment in ACLEDA Cambodia in 2000, and an equity investment in ACLEDA Laos in 2009. IFC now holds 12.25% of the capital of ACLEDA Cambodia, and 15.9% of the capital of ACLEDA Laos. The Bank is now planning to expand into Myanmar, and IFC is preparing a project to support this expansion.
Cost Nature: The proposed investment consists of a US$ 40 million 7-year subordinated debt to ACLEDA Cambodia.
Location: ACLEDA is headquartered in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, and has a network of 260 branches in Cambodia and Lao PDR. The Bank is also planning to expand into Myanmar.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This transaction involves a Tier-II debt investment and the overall portfolio risk is considered to be low to medium. The project has therefore been categorized as FI-2 in accordance with IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. ACLEDA''s main business areas are microfinance and SME and 50% of the loans in the Bank''s portfolio are between US$10,000 and US$100,000. The sector exposure is mainly focused on trade (40% of the Banks loan portfolio), services (20%), and agriculture (18%). For this project the Bank will be required to screen loans against the IFC Exclusion List and the Cambodian E&S laws and regulations. In the event that the Bank expands its business to provide project or corporate finance, the Bank will be required to ensure that those borrowers comply with IFC''s Performance Standards.
Risk Impact: The main E&S risks and impacts of the project derive from the E&S risks of the Banks lending activities, the capacity and systems in place to manage these risks, and the Banks practices with regard to labor and working conditions. Under the requirements of the existing IFC investment, the company has appointed an E&S officer and two E&S coordinators and developed an environmental and social management system (ESMS). The ESMS, among others, requires the Bank to screen projects against the IFC Exclusion list and to ensure compliance with Cambodian national E&S laws and regulations.  The Bank is however in the process of upgrading the current ESMS and in particular to enhance its capacity to assess and manage potential E&S risks associated with the Banks investment activities. The Banks labor management was found to be consistent with the requirements of IFC Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working conditions.

Project Description: BI-Gender Inclusion (Project # 32605), consists of an A/B syndicated loan of up to US$ 65 Million to Banco Industrial do Brazil (BIB, Banco Industrial or the Bank), a midsized SME bank in Brazil, and an existing IFC client.   The above loan will support BIBs lending operations to the SMEs, with at least 50 percent of the total funds earmarked to funding women-owned businesses. Therefore, the above Project will assist BIB to promote financial inclusion of women entrepreneurs in Brazil.  The Project would include eligibility criteria on the use of proceeds related to the profile of the sub-borrowers (women entrepreneurs), as similarly done in other IFC projects in Brazil.
Environmental Social Info: The main E&S risks and impacts related to the Project derive both from the banks capacity to maintain the required procedures to manage E&S risks as well as to maintain practices with regard to labor and working conditions. As an existing client, the Bank has implemented an Environmental and Social Management System that as part of the proposed investment will be upgraded. SME loans account for over 51% of BIB portfolio, with transaction size averaging USD 450 thousand and tenor of 9.8 months. BIB focus majorly in services and retail clients (61%), in addition to manufacturing, most specifically suppliers of highest growing sectors in the local economy such as Auto industry, Construction & Engineering and large retailers mostly in the food and beverage segment (39%).
Impact: The expected development impacts of this project are:i)	The key development objective of this project is to increase financial inclusion for SMEs in Brazil with a special focus on women-owned business ( at least 50 % of the project amount will be used to on-lend to women-owned SMEs ). ii)	This project is intended to have a demonstration effect of the business opportunity presented by women entrepreneurs as an under-served market in Brazil.iii)	Foster competitive environment in the Brazilian banking sector.  Furthermore, given that the project targets financial inclusion which gives people the opportunity to escape poverty and improve their lives.  Furthermore, World Bank Group research shows that focusing on access to finance for female entrepreneurs has the following benefits:a)	Increasing opportunities for women entrepreneurs is key if the global economy is to have sustained and more equitable growthb)	Women entrepreneurs create jobs that are more likely to employ other women c)	Women are more likely than to men to contribute additional income to household poverty reduction and improved nutrition and schooling for their children; andd)	Giving women entrepreneurs access to credit and increasing their economic power will translate into improve livelihoods for a wide cross-section of society.

Role:
The Project is expected to create the following benefits:
i) The senior loan facility would have a target of at least 50% for on lending to women owned SMEs, thereby enabling the Bank to increase the reach to this underserved market, with the remaining funds financing SMEs in general;
ii) With the proposed project, Industrial would promote women-owned enterprises as a separate sub-segment with the SME space.
iii) Access to International Banking Markets: without the Project, Industrial would not be able to raise 2 to 3 year funding from international financial institutions in the current market conditions. In volatile moments such as the current one, IFC''s stamp of approval and preferred creditor status are critical elements to attract international lenders.

Mr. Mansurs business experience roots are in the agribusiness sector.  Prior to owning the Bank, Carlos Mansour owned and ran successfully one of the largest dairy products companies in Brazil called Vigor. He then sold Vigor to Bertin (former IFC client) in 2007 and used part of the sales proceeds to capitalize Banco Industrial.  The Bank is today Mr. Mansurs main business concern.

Project Description: Ananta Apparels Limited ('AAL', 'Ananta' or the 'Company') is one of the leading apparel exporters of Bangladesh. The company specializes in denim products with monthly production capacity of 2.7 million woven bottoms across five factories employing about 18,000 workers. Key processes include design, manufacturing (sewing lines) and washing. The 'Wash' division includes 'wet process' options such as bleaching and enzyme, resin and ozone washes; and dry processes such as high intensity laser etching, 3D whiskering, oven wrinkling and grinding. AAL has undertaken an expansion plan to be developed in two phases:  Phase I, will primarily involve the relocation of its existing casual woven bottoms factory to a new custom built facility. Initially, the plan was to construct the facility in Kanchpur, south of Dhaka, however, shortly after the IFC investment in October 2013, AAL was informed by the Bangladesh Export Processing Zone Authority ('BEPZA') that it has been awarded a 30-year lease on a 3-acre unbuilt plot within the Adamjee Export Processing Zone (AEPZ). Considering the better infrastructural and administrative facilities available in an EPZ as well as other fiscal and non-fiscal incentives, the company decided to construct the new facility in AEPZ  (the 'Project'). The Project is therefore, greenfield in nature. Also, initially the plan was for the new facility to replace the one of AAL's existing facilities in downtown Dhaka, however, in June 2016, the company decided to continue its existing facility as well as operate the new facility. The reasons for this are explained in detail in the section on PS2.The second phase (Phase II), which would involve further capacity expansion, will be undertaken at a future date once Phase I is fully implemented and operational.  IFC will provide a financing package at the corporate level and will help mobilize parallel funds.
Review Scope: This is an update to the originally disclosed ESRS dated 12 th   November 2012 due to several changes in the project description as described below.   IFC's original environmental and social due diligence of the project in August 2012comprised site visits to Ananta's main offices in Dhaka, Bangladesh and the production facilities of DNV Clothing Ltd., Ananta Denim Technology and Ananta Apparels Ltd. in the cities of Dhaka and Narayanganj. A site visit to the proposed expansion site (next to Ananta Denim Technology) was also undertaken.  Meetings were held with Ananta's management team regarding human resource policies and procedures, and management of environmental and social matters in the operations.   Documents reviewed included Ananta's policies and manuals for human resources, environment, fire safety and occupational health and safety.  In addition, records on the performance of the liquid effluent treatment plant, results from client's audits and initial designs of the proposed expansion were also reviewed. Information collected by IFC during subsequent supervision visits and discussions with the company between 2013 and 2016 has been used to update the relevant sections of this document to explain the changes in the project description, any associated changes in E&S risks and impacts and company's action plans. An update of the action plan is attached with this updated ESRS.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedure for projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, procedures, guidelines and design criteria. Key environmental and social issues identified during the appraisal include adequate environmental and social management capacity in the current operations and in the new projects; labor and working conditions; fire safety protection; water, energy and resource efficiency; wastewater treatment and discharge; solid waste disposal; and management of contractors including occupational health and safety elements. As identified in the project Environmental and Social Action Plan ('ESAP'), the company will implement actions to address the identified issues.
Sector: K-CA - Garment and Apparel  (Without Fabric , Excluding Footwear)

Project Description: The Sponsor i.e. Dawood Group ('DG'), has obtained Letter of Interest ('LOI') from Alternate Energy Development Board ('AEDB') under the RE Policy to develop a 50MW wind power project. The LOI was awarded in the name of Tenaga Generasi Limited ('TGL'), who has already been awarded a license by the National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA). TGL intends  to develop a 50 MW wind farm on total rented area of over 19.75 km2 , located about 30 km southwest of Gharo town, Thatta District of Sindh Region. The project involves engineering, design, procurement, construction, turbine erection, grid tie-in, commissioning, and operations management over the 20 year concession period. The project site and land identified and allocated by Alternative Energy Department Board (AEDB), a central government agency,  is close to the national grid. The total Project cost is approximately US$130 million. As the developer, TGL will contract with CMEC EPC contractors for construction and O&M contractor GE for operations and maintenance services. The National Transmission and Distribution Company (NTDC) will be in charge of T-line construction and operations; the T-line will be designed and constructed by giving due consideration  to Sindh EPA's  environmental specifications and timeline to be able to off-take power from other wind projects in the area that are planned for development in future.
Review Scope: IFC's review of this investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information made available by the sponsor including the following documents:Regional Environmental Assessment Study ('REA') of the Gharo Wind Corridor in Pakistan, prepared with assistance of the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) of Pakistan, June 2009. This REA consists of (i) Section I (Environmental & Socio-Economic Baseline Report, (ii) Section II (Cumulative Impact Assessment & Alternatives), and (iii) Section III (Environmental Management Plan); Initial Environmental Examination (IEE) 49.5 MW Wind Power Project  Gharo, Sindh, prepared by Tekcellent, a TGL's EHS consulting firm, dated October 2009;Supplemental Report to IEE, prepared in December 2011 as per IFC request following the field appraisal, that contained a record of additional round of consultation on the project environmental and social development aspects held with Coastal Forest Division of Sindh Forest Department, IUCN, Sindh Wildlife Department (SWD), Zoological Survey Department and WWF;Faunal Baseline Environmental Study, prepared by Tekcellent in February 2012;Study "Sindh - State of Environment and Development", prepared by IUCN Pakistan in 2004. The Study presents the list and locations of (i) protected areas of Sindh under Sindh Wildlife Protection Ordinance, (ii) Ramsar Sites and other important Wetlands, mangrove forests, arid areas, and irrigation system of Sindh;Decision on IEE i.e. Environmental Approval for 49.5 MW Wind Power Project, Issued by Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) of Government of Sindh, October 25th 2010;Sindh Wildlife and Protection Areas Act dated 2010.The appraisal team visited the project site in July 2011 and interviewed: environmental consulting firm that prepared the Project's IEE, Sindh Wildlife Department (SWD), Secretary Environment and Alternative Energy , Government of Sindh  and Environmental Protection Agency of Government of Sindh, International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Pakistan).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Potential impacts are those primarily associated with construction activities, are likely to be limited to the project site; are short term; and likely to have limited adverse impacts because of the remote location and sufficient distance from sensitive environmental areas.
Sector: V-BC - Wind Power - Renewable Energy Generation

Project Description: Founded in 1992, Ananta Apparels Limited (AAL or the Company) is one of the leading apparel exporters of Bangladesh (top 10 position among woven product manufacturers). The Company specializes in denim products with monthly production capacity of 1.8 million woven bottoms across three factories comprising 850,000 square feet and employing about 13,000 workers. AAL recently re-structured into a group holding company with five manufacturing subsidiaries: Ananta Casualwear Limited (99% shareholding), Ananta Denim Technology Limited (99%), Ananta Fashion Limited (99%), DNV Clothing Limited (75%), and Universal Menswear Limited (51%; a joint-venture company with Romanian suit manufacturer Time Trade International).  Major customers include top retail brands such as H&M, GAP and Bestseller Group. AAL has undertaken an expansion plan to be developed in two phases:  Phase I, costing approximately US$24.4 million, will primarily involve the relocation of its existing casual woven bottoms factory to a new custom built facility in Kanchpur, south of Dhaka thereby replacing its original factory in downtown Dhaka (the Project). The Project is brownfield in nature. The second phase (Phase II), which would involve further capacity expansion, will be undertaken at a future date once Phase I is fully implemented and operational.
Environmental Social Info: Key environmental and social issues identified during the appraisal include adequate environmental and social management capacity in the current operations and in the new projects; labor and working conditions; fire safety protection; water, energy and resource efficiency; wastewater treatment and discharge; solid waste disposal; and management of contractors including occupational health and safety elements. Full details on how this risks are mitigated are in the Environmental and Social Review Summary.
Impact: - Job Creation: Approximately 1,500 new jobs expected over both Phases I and II. - Technology Transfer: AAL intends to adopt global best practices in terms of lean manufacturing concepts, factory efficiency, worker productivity and energy efficiency standards of the overall industry.- Local Supply Chain Linkages: The Project will generate incremental business for MSMEs in the value chain, including accessory and package suppliers, service providers and logistics support.- Benefits to the Government: The Project will generate tax revenues, which is expected to contribute to Bangladesh''s Annual Development Program budget, enabling the Government to execute a greater number of developmental activities.- Demonstration Effect: The Project will support a Company that has committed to adopting best practices in corporate governance, E&S compliance, labor standards, and energy efficiency in Bangladesh''s RMG industry.
Role:
- Provide longer tenor foreign currency financing, otherwise difficult to secure in Bangladesh, to support a strategic, private equity portfolio client expand its core business.
- Integrate the Company into various textile/RMG-focused IFC advisory programs such as environmental assessment of 250 factories, effluent treatment plant study, Cleaner Production program across 12 pilot factories, Buyer''s Forum and the planned Water Resource Efficiency and Better Works programs, which are geared towards improving compliance, competitiveness, energy efficiency, and labor welfare at the firm and industry levels (more on slides 11-12).
- Resource mobilization from other DFIs (FMO is already on board).
Sponsor: Mr. Sharif Zahir, Managing Director of  AAL , owns 47% of the Company while his younger brother, Mr. Asif Zahir, owns 30%.  Their mother Mrs. Qamrun Nahar, with 9% shareholding, is the Chairperson of AAL.  Frontier Fund (FPE), a Bangladesh-focused IFC-portfolio private equity fund managed by Swedish hedge fund Brummer and Partners, owns the remaining 14% of AAL.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated to be US$24.4 million. IFC will provide a financing package for up to US$8 million.

Project Description: The proposed investment consists of a senior loan package of US$10million to Root Capital, Inc. (Root Capital or the Company).  Founded in 1999, Root Capital is a nonprofit development financier that provides loans and financial training to farmer aggregators, cooperatives and agricultural SMEs in Africa and Latin America. The proposed financing package will be supported by the Private Sector Window of the Global Agriculture and Food Security Program (GAFSP).GAFSP funding plays a catalytic role to create opportunity to support innovative private sector investments and deliver a level of additionality and impact beyond what is possible through IFCs regular operations. The financing package will support Root Capital to scale its Sustainable Trade Fund operations, its core lending arm, in order to become a financially sustainable business, while addressing the funding needs of the missing middle in the agricultural finance space; i.e. rural businesses that are too large to access credit from microfinance institutions but considered too remote to secure financing from commercial banks.
Environmental Social Info: The main E&S risks and potential impacts of the project derive from the E&S risks of the Root Capitals lending activities to producers of agricultural products. Root Capital has a sound E&S Management System in place that includes: 1) rigorous screening of potential clients, 2) policies for financing select commodities; 3) clear definition of E&S roles and responsibilities for loan officers, 4) sound system of internal verification of E&S due diligence, and 5) an on-going training for E&S coordinators as well as all investment staff. There is, however, a need to upgrade the system to enable: a proper screening through IFC''s Exclusion List and enhance monitoring of long term transactions. Root Capital labor policies are aligned with requirements of the Performance Standard 2: Labor and Working Conditions.
Impact: 1) Expected to reach approximately two million farmers over the next five years.2) Significantly enhances Root Capital''s lending volume targets as stipulated in its five-year business plan.  This is expected to positively impact the "missing middle," which is the gap between microfinance and commercial banking, especially in pronounced rural areas in Africa.3) Sends a strong market signal regarding the business case for sustainable and climate friendly agriculture in difficult markets.
Role:
1) IFC''s investment will catalyze private sector funding to fill the identified funding need to support Root Capital as it gradually transitions itself to become a more financially sustainable institution
2) IFC''s investment will support an innovative financial intermediation business model that targets underserved market segments including bottom-of-the-pyramid clients and small scale rural farmers. This is expected to have strong demonstration effect and replication potential to other institutions serving this market segment
3) IFC''s knowledge and experience in corporate governance and environmental and social standards will play a key role in supporting the Company in it''s corporate governance and E&S standards practices, and as such support long-term sustainability.
Sponsor: Root Capital is currently registered as an U.S. 501(c)(3) non-profit organization and thus does not have any shareholders.  The Company is capitalized with philanthropic contributions and borrowings from financial institutions, foundations, individual investors and corporations.Notable contributors and lenders include, among others, Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, Skoll Foundation, Overseas Private Investment Corporation, Inter-American Development Bank and Starbucks Corporation.
Cost Nature: IFC, with GAFSP support, will provide the proposed US$10million financing package.  In addition, GAFSP funding will be made available to private sector investors who intend to invest in Root Capital.
