Project Description: Tenaga Generasi Limited (TGL or the Company) is developing a 49.5MW wind power project located over 19.75 km2 area in Gharo, District Thatta, Sindh province, Pakistan. The project involves engineering, design, procurement, construction, turbine erection, grid tie-in, commissioning and operation & maintenance of the 49.5MW wind power generation facility (the Project).  The Project will be an independent power producer and will sell electricity to the National Transmission and Despatch Company Limited (NTDC) under a 20-year Energy Purchase Agreement (EPA). NTDCs payment obligations under the EPA will be guaranteed by the Government of Pakistan. The Projects site area has favorable wind resources, expected to generate an annual average of 156 GWh of electricity at 36.0% plant factor (based on the independent engineers estimates).
Impact: The Project will i) promote the use of renewable energy sources for power generation in Pakistan by providing zero emission power; ii) contribute to diversification of the existing generation mix by reducing the use of fuel oil; iii) help channelize local investment in the development of renewable energy in Pakistan as the Project is one of the first to be developed by a large local business group; iv) generate Carbon Emission Reductions (CERs) through the Clean Development Mechanism of the Kyoto Protocol; and v) help develop local expertise to aid future development of renewable energy in Pakistan.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Potential impacts are those primarily associated with construction activities, are likely to be limited to the project site; are short term; and likely to have limited adverse impacts because of the remote location and sufficient distance from sensitive environmental areas.
Sponsor: TGL is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Dawood Lawrencepur Limited (DLL or the Sponsor). DLL is listed in the Karachi and Lahore stock exchanges with a 34.5% public float and has been principally engaged in the manufacture and sale of yarn fabrics. Currently, the Sponsor is winding down its textile related business through the sale of assets and focusing on developing its renewable energy business. The Dawood family, through Dawood Corporation and other entities, has a majority ownership interest in DLL. The Sponsor owns a 16.2% shareholding in Dawood Hercules Corporation Limited (DHCL), a holding company, which in turn holds direct or indirect interests in Engro Corporation Limited, Dawood Hercules Fertilizer Limited, Hub Power Company Limited and Sui Northern Gas Pipelines Limited.
Cost Nature: The total Project Cost is estimated at US$128.7 million and is proposed to be funded with a debt to equity ratio of 75:25. Of the total US$96.5 million in debt, IFC is considering providing an IFC A Loan of up to US$24 million and mobilizing up to US$50 million. The balance of the debt will be provided by local Pakistani banks. IFC is also considering an equity investment of up to US$8 million. This Project will be IFCs second wind investment in Pakistan.

Project Description: As part of IFCs Critical Commodities Finance Program Phase II (CCFP II), IFC is proposing the following project: 1) an expansion of the funded  risk-sharing facility (CCFP SocGen, Project No. 34955)  with Société Générale SA (SocGenor the Bank); 2) an extension of the maturity of the facility  from March 2014 to  January 2015. The US$150 million increase would supplement IFCs existing US$250 million investment in the facility, bringing up IFCs total participation up to US$400 million in SocGens  trade and commodity finance portfolio of the critical agriculture and energy commodities/inputs. CCFP program is a public-private partnership (PPP) initiative that is part of IFCs multi-faceted rapid global financial crisis response. It is aiming at mitigating disruptions in two critical commodity value chains: (i) exports and imports of agricultural commodities and inputs globally; and (ii) imports of energy products into IDA or IDA- blend countries.
Environmental Social Info: The proposed project supports agro-commodities and energy trade portfolio. As it relates to agro-commodities, the portfolio of funded trade transaction will be agro-commodity traders, importers/exporters, and processors, largely in the Africa region. Type of agro-commodities the existing CCFP SocGen facility has financed includes cocoa, coffee, wheat, soybean, corn and cotton. The applicable E&S requirements include a combination of IFC Exclusion List and portfolio eligibility criteria based on the applicable country/commodity E&S risk matrix (ref. Global Mapping of E&S risks associated with agro-commodity production - GMAP) associated with the production of agro-commodities, especially as it relates to harmful child/forced labor and biodiversity risks associated with the conversion of natural and critical habitats, and E&S counterparty assessment, as appropriate. Societe Generale will not have direct exposure to primary agro-commodity supply chain issues through this type of facility. Therefore, it is not subject to IFCs supply chain requirements outlined in the IFCs Performance Standards.
Impact: The CCFP-Bank facility is expected to have the following specific development impacts:- Increase Liquidity: The Facility will ensure continuing and additional funding to the major agricultural and energy sectors in Emerging Countries, especially in Africa and IDA countries. This Facility will contribute to the Bank maintaining its level of business in commodity finance. Among other things, the Facility will enable traders to purchase from and finance agricultural producers, the mainstay of most economies in Africa, and ensure food security and income for the public at large, but especially to farmers. - Strong Demonstration Effect by catalyzing other IFIs to Support Agri and Energy Finance: By supporting commodity backed finance and outreach in partnerships with banks, the facility will have a significant demonstration impact on other banks, especially local /regional banks to participate in funding the agricultural and energy sectors. This would ultimately help increase access to finance for critical economic sectors.- A steady supply of critically needed refined oil products through regular channels will keep prices in check, remove parallel market incentives, improve affordability for the vulnerable poor and contribute to sustaining local economic activities.
Role: The IFC Facility will provide additional dollar liquidity for a pre-agreed period to the Bank. This extra funding source will allow the Bank to apply it to its business plan in regards to the funding of critical commodities as targeted by the CCFP, particularly in Africa, where the Bank is one of the foremost players.
Sponsor: Established in 1864, Société Générale (the Bank) is one of the largest banks in France and in the Eurozone. Its three main divisions are Retail Banking & Specialized Financial Services, Corporate and Investment Banking and Global Investment Management & Services. The Bank is currently rated A by S&P, A2 by Moody''s and A+ by Fitch.
Cost Nature: As part of IFCs Critical Commodities Finance Program Phase II,  IFCs funding to the Bank will be up to $150 million for a trade portfolio of up to $300 million, aimed at supporting both agricultural commodities/inputs globally and exports/imports of crude oil and refined oil products in and out of emerging countries, primarily IDA countries.

Type of agro-commodities the existing CCFP SocGen facility has financed includes cocoa, coffee, wheat, soybean, corn and cotton. Global Mapping of E&S risks associated with agro-commodity production - GMAP) associated with the production of agro-commodities, especially as it relates to harmful child/forced labor and biodiversity risks associated with the conversion of natural and critical habitats, and E&S counterparty assessment, as appropriate. Societe Generale will not have direct exposure to primary agro-commodity supply chain issues through this type of facility. Therefore, it is not subject to IFCs supply chain requirements outlined in the IFCs Performance Standards.
Mitigation Measures: SocGen has an Environmental and Social Sustainability Policy. This policy applies to all its banking and financial operations. Sector-based (e.g. mining, oil and gas) and cross-cutting policies define the specific standards that SocGen applies to its corporate and project-based lending operations. SocGen is developing an agri-business sector policy which it is expected to be completed in 2013. This E&S framework is operationalized through internal corporate procedures for the E&S review process of project-based lending activities. SocGen is presently developing and implementing an approach for corporate level E&S assessments of clients E&S performance, including reputational and credit risks. SocGen has been an Equator Principles Financial Institution (EPFI) since 2007. Societe Generale will provide to IFC corporate E&S risk screening review done for sub-borrowers selected under #31754 and pro-actively under this investment (#32944) as part of the clearance process of eligible agro-commodity related obligors. Societe Generale complies with IFC Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working Conditions. IFC will make the GMAP available to Societe Generale, starting in January 2013, for its use as part of a pilot project under review for 2013.Internal risk screening procedure for trade finance will be reviewed, and might be enhanced, including application of the Global Map for E&S risk assessment and management of agro-commodity production (GMAP); On or prior to commitmentSubmission of counterparty assessment for orange and red combinations and periodic (annual) report for all supported transaction as per the format to be provided by IFC.On-going basis during project implementation

Project Name: Almaz Capital Russia Fund II, LP
Project Description: The proposed project is an investment of up to US$25 million in equity, not to exceed 20% of total fund commitments, in Almaz Capital Fund II, L.P., a Cayman Islands exempted limited partnership (the Fund), a venture capital fund sponsored by Almaz Capital Partners Ltd. (Almaz). Almaz is seeking to raise about US$175 million of aggregate commitments for the Fund, with initial closing targeted at US$100 million. This is the second fund to be managed by Almaz. Almaz successfully raised $72 million for the Almaz Russia Fund I in 2008/2009.The Fund will make venture capital investments in information technology (IT) companies in Russia and Commonwealth of Independent States ("CIS") with a focus on (i) proven technologies for global markets, developed in Russia/CIS; and (ii) proven business models targeted at Russian/CIS consumers. Target sectors include: (i) internet, software, and systems; and (ii) semiconductors and optoelectronics. The Fund aims to invest in 15-18 portfolio companies, each in the range of $7-16 million over the life of the investee company. The Fund plans to invest in 7-8 early stage companies; 5-7 mid-stage companies; and opportunistically invest in 2-3 late stage, pre-IPO deals. Finally, the Fund will allocate $5 to 10 million for early seed investments only to be invested with select angel investors (typically experienced technology entrepreneurs) as well as in cooperation with incubators and accelerators.
Impact: There is limited access to Western-style venture funding and support, a much needed ingredient for a successful telecoms, media, and related technology ("TMT") industry in Russia and Commonwealth of Independent States ("CIS"). The Fund will act as a catalyst to support the development of the technology sector and the growth of local entrepreneurship and innovation. It will facilitate the capacity development as well as sector knowledge and skill transfer while using global industry best practices in portfolio companies thereby enhancing their competitiveness and sustainability. In addition, the Fund will support the creation of new jobs as investee companies expand.
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed project involves an equity investment of up to US$25 million in Almaz Capital Fund II (the Fund), a Russian/CIS venture capital fund with a target size at US$175 million focused on the telecoms, media, and related technology projects. The proposed portfolio entails mainly potentially limited adverse E&S risks and impacts that are generally site-specific, largely reversible and readily addressed through mitigation measures. The project has therefore been categorized as FI in accordance with IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. According to the nature of IFC''s investment and client''s operations, the Fund will be required to comply with the IFC Exclusion List, national E&S laws and the IFCs Performance Standards.
Sponsor: Almaz Capital Partners II, LLC, (Almaz) will sponsor and manage the Fund.
Cost Nature: The target Fund size is US$175 million, and can go up to US$200 million. IFC proposed to make an equity commitment of up to US$25 million, not to exceed 20% of the Funds total commitments.

Project Description: The proposed project involves project financing of  a 24 MWp solar photovoltaic power project on an 82.5 ha barren area  in the Ugras village at approximately 35 km from the Phalodi Tehsil village in the district of Jodhpur, Rajasthan state, India.  The project will be developed by a joint venture between Astronergy Solar Korea (ASK) and SunEdison Energy Holding (Singapore) Pte Ltd.  The solar panels to be installed will convert sunlight to DC (Direct Current) electricity. The DC power will be sent to an Inverter to convert the DC power into AC (Alternate Current) power which will then be fed into the utility power grid.  As part of the project, the Company will install an approximately 12 kilometers transmission line (33 kV) to transport the generated electricity to the main grid.  The routing of the transmission line, which will be so selected as to remain within the right of way of existing roads, is being finalized.  Since the project site is located in an area already accessible to the state highway, there will not be a need to open access roads.  The nearest population settlement is approximately 2 km from the project site.
Review Scope: IFC's appraisal reviewed the Sun Edison (the 'Company')'s Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS), and Social capabilities and its ability to construct and operate the project in accordance with the Indian regulatory requirements and IFC's Performance Standards.  Specific items reviewed included: (a) Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) and (b) Site Specific Safety Plan.  IFC conducted a visit to the proposed project site and conducted interviews with the Company's project management team including EHS staff in October 2012.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The proposed investment is a Category B project because the potentially limited environmental and social impacts that may result from constructing and operating the solar power generation and transmission facilities can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized good practices and design criteria.The Company has presented information and plans that will seek to address environmental and social risks and impacts in accordance with the Indian laws and regulations, the IFC Performance Standards on Social and Environment Sustainability, the applicable elements of the World Bank Group (WBG) General EHS Guidelines, and the attached Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP.)

Project Description: Value and Budget Housing Corporation (VBHC or 'the Company') is a real estate company which develops and offers affordable entry level houses near the industrial clusters in major metros in India. VBHC has a pipeline of projects in Chennai, Hyderabad, Mumbai, Bangalore and National Capital Region that will get executed in the coming years. IFC will invest in VBHC as equity and as compulsorily convertible debentures in a Special Purpose Vehicle ('Project SPV' or the 'Project'). The Company has successfully completed the first phase of its first project comprising 1800 apartments in the outskirts of Bangalore, of which the first phase of 392 apartments has been completed. VBHC is in the process of setting up an expansive network of integrated housing projects nationwide, applying industrial engineering to the construction process and building scale through standardization, employing the latest construction technology.
Review Scope: IFC's environmental and social review of VBHC included: (i) meetings with VBHC's management team in Bangalore, India; (ii) a site visit to a VBHC's affordable housing project in the outskirts of Bangalore; (iii) review of internal policies and procedures regarding human resources, occupational health and safety (OHS), and land acquisition; (iv) review of sample contracts with sub-contracting companies and permits and; (v) review of a sample of geotechnical engineering studies, hydro geological investigations, infrastructure surveys and environmental impact assessments among other environmental studies relevant for the planning and execution of the projects. Environmental and social conditions were observed during the site visits and discussed with project managers, sustainability officials and other VBHC staff.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedure as the potential adverse environmental and social impacts presented by the project are few in number, site-specific and have been or can be readily addressed through mitigation measures.The key environmental and social (E&S) issues have been identified as: (i) VBHC's ability to provide systematic and consistent management of E&S issues across different projects including the adoption of necessary mitigation measures; (ii) VBHC's E&S assessment of prospective projects including land acquisition processes to ensure that land acquisition is the result of voluntary transactions, avoids adverse impact on cultural heritage, and considers the biodiversity value of the areas;  (iii) pollution control measures during planning and operations including access to public services (water and electricity) and management of liquid effluents; and (iv)  management of labor conditions and occupational health and safety risks during construction.VBHC has presented information on how its current practices and policies address the identified impacts and how it will ensure that the proposed project, upon implementation of the specific agreed measures, comply with the environmental and social requirements, which include the Indian laws and regulations and IFC's Performance Standards (dated January 01, 2012).  The information about how these potential impacts will be addressed by the project is summarized in the paragraphs that follow. Additional actions are summarized in the attached Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP).
Sector: U-AE - Other (Including Restaurants, Amusement Parks, etc.)

Project Description: Value and Budget Housing Corporation (VBHC or the Company) is headquartered in Bengaluru, Karnataka, India. The Company was incorporated in 2008, with a focus on building affordable and entry level housing in India. VBHC has projects under various stages of development and construction across Bengaluru, Chennai (state of Tamil Nadu) and Mumbai (state of Maharashtra). Further, the Company is in various stages of identification and procurement of land for developing affordable housing in the states of Rajasthan, Gujarat, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu and Uttar Pradesh (the Project). VBHC is in the process of raising capital from IFC for part-financing the development of the above affordable housing projects.
Impact: This investment will have the following development impact: (a) provide essential residential infrastructure to support the ongoing rapid urbanization in India, resulting in improved sanitation and health conditions; (b) demonstration effect for attracting private capital to the affordable housing sector in India; and (c) demonstration effect with regard to use of construction technology to shorten delivery times as well as eco-friendly practices. Compared to conventional constructions, the Project is expected to use 35% less water and meet IFC''s green building standards that results in at least a 20% lower energy consumption.
Role:
(1) This investment in the Company lends IFC''s stamp of approval to VBHC for the governance practices adopted by Company.
(2) This investment will make available long term equity capital which is not readily available for the the affordable housing segment in particular, thereby providing financial flexibility to VBHC.
(3) VBHC will benefit through access to expertise across IFC''s network in Latin America and other markets where IFC has financed such affordable housing projects.
(4) This investment will provide access to IFC''s knowledge base in the field of green buildings/construction as the Company plans to adopt green building practices in the design of its projects.
Sponsor: VBHC was established in 2008 by Mr. Jaithirth Rao and Mr. P.S.Jayakumar with the aim of providing affordable homes coupled with buyer friendly practices and strong governance. Together, Mr. Rao and Mr. Jayakumar hold about 34% of VBHCs equity stake. Mr. Jaithirth Rao has over 20 years experience in the banking industry. In the past, he served Citibank, and its parent Citicorp Incorporated, United States of America, in various capacities across Asia, Europe, South and North America. He was Country Manager for India at Citibank. He developed the consumer business of Citibank in India, Middle East, Eastern Europe and the United Kingdom. He was head of Citibank''s Global Technology Development Division and Global Electronic Cards Division. He co-founded Mphasis in 1998 - a software company based out of California - which was later bought over by EDS, a division of HP.Mr. P.S. Jayakumar has about 24 years experience in the banking industry. He worked with Citibank and held several senior management positions. He was the head of Citibanks retail banking division in India.The other investors in VBHC are Housing Development Finance Corporation Limited (HDFC), First Carlyle Growth IX (a fund managed by The Carlyle Group), and India Financial Inclusion Fund (a fund managed by Caspian Advisors Private Limited).
Cost Nature: The total Project cost is estimated at over US$24 million and IFC proposes to invest equity to part finance the Project.

Project Description: The project is to develop, construct, own and operate a 24MWp greenfield solar PV power plant (the Project). The Project is being executed as a joint venture between SunEdison Energy Holding (Singapore) Pte. Ltd (SingCo) an IFC investee and Astronergy Solar Korea Co. Ltd. (ASK) a subsidiary of Chint Solar (Zhejiang) Co., Ltd, a CHINT Group company. The Project was competitively awarded under the second batch of first phase of Indias Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar Mission (JNNSM).The total output of the Project will be sold to the state owned power trading company, NTPC Vidyut Vyapar Nigam Ltd, (NVVN or the Offtaker), under a year 25 PPA signed on January 2012. NVVN is a wholly owned subsidiary of NTPC Ltd - the largest Indian state-owned generator of thermal power based in New Delhi. The deadline for commissioning is February 2013.
Impact: The project will: (i) increase generation of renewable power; (ii) the project will help a Chinese private Company expand its business in India; and (iii) create job.
Role: (i) IFC is able to provide long term fixed rate rupee loans in India which is difficult in this market; and (ii) IFC''s participation in the Project is likely to help mobilize additional funding to complete the Project financial plan. (iii) Knowledge sharing: IFC has previous investing experience in the solar sector in Asia and India in particular; and (iv) Demonstration effect for a South-South project.
Sponsor: The Project Company is SEI Solar Power Pvt. Ltd. (the Borrower), a company incorporated in India. The Borrower is held by ASK and SingCo in the equity proportion of 51:49.  ASK is a firm based out of South Korea, which in turn is 100% owned by Chint Solar (Zhejiang) Co., Ltd, a Chint Group Company. SingCo is 15% held by IFC and 85% by MEMC/Sun Edison LLC.Sun Edison LLC (SunEdison) and Chint Solar (Zhejiang) Co., Ltd (Astronergy) or together are the ultimate Sponsors. SunEdison is one of the leading solar power system integrators/installers in North America and globally. SunEdison is a wholly-owned subsidiary of MEMC Electronic Materials Inc (MEMC), a leading manufacturer of silicon wafers for semiconductor devices and solar manufacturers. MEMC is listed on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol WFR and is included in the S&P 500 Index. Chint Solar (Zhejiang) Co., Ltd, a China-based private Company, is the solar panel manufacturing arm of CHINT Group Corporation, Chinas leading player in the electrical industry. Astronergy was founded in 2006, as a member of the Group. Chint Solars total revenue amounted to $762 million in 2011, which represented a 155% increase compared with $298 million in 2010.
Cost Nature: IFC is considering providing a combination of A/B Loans amounting to up to $34.3 million in Indian Rupees equivalent to support the Project with total investment of around $49 million (INR 2,705 million).

Project Description: The proposed project involves establishing an unfunded risk sharing facility with BTMU for a trade and commodity finance portfolio of up to US$200 million (with IFC investment of up to US$100 million) aiming at supporting both agri and energy sectors (Project).  The Project will enable BTMU to continue to fill the gap in financing the commodity trade that keeps critical food and energy supplies available in emerging markets, including IDA countries in Asia.
Environmental Social Info: The applicable E&S requirements include a combination of IFC Exclusion List and portfolio eligibility criteria based on the applicable country/commodity E&S risk matrix (GMAP) associated with the production and trade of agro-commodities, especially as it relates to harmful child/forced labor and biodiversity risks associated with the conversion of natural and critical habitats, and E&S counterparty assessment, as appropriate. BTMU will not have direct exposure to primary agro-commodity supply chain issues through this type of facility. Therefore, it is not subject to IFCs supply chain requirements outlined in the IFCs Performance Standards.
Impact: The CCFP-BTMU facility is expected to have the following development impacts:  i) increased access to finance for agriculture globally and energy in IDA countries; ii) demonstration impact on local market development, promote commodities as an asset class, and encourage local /regional banks to participate in funding the agricultural and energy sectors; and reduce poverty by providing access to clean energy for urban and rural poor.
Role: IFC''s risk participation will provide a guarantee to a portfolio originated by BTMU to expand its trade finance in critical commodities as targeted by the CCFP, and will enable it to meet increasing demand from emerging markets.  IFC''s support would encourage greater activity in IDA countries and also support smaller traders and processors.
Sponsor: The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ (BTMU) is the largest bank in Japan and was established in 2006 with the merger of the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, Ltd. and UFJ Bank Ltd.  The bank serves as the core retail and commercial banking arm of the Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG), one of the largest and most diversified financial groups in Japan.  The group comprises five primary operating companies, including The Bank of Tokyo- Mitsubishi UFJ, Ltd., Mitsubishi UFJ Trust and Banking Corporation, Mitsubishi UFJ Morgan Stanley Securities Co., Ltd., Mitsubishi UFJ NICOS Co., Ltd. and Mitsubishi UFJ Lease & Finance Company Limited.

Project Description: The project is to provide FIMbank (or the Bank), with a trade finance facility of up to $30 million to support the Banks trade finance activities in MENA and Sub-Sahara Africa. The Facility will be funded as part of IFCs Global Trade Liquidity Program (GTLP) which was created as part of IFCs extended commitment to support global trade finance in order to increase the reach to some of the enterprises in emerging markets by addressing the liquidity constraint that they are as well as some of the financial institutions are still facing.
Impact: (a) Channeling liquidity for trade financing in the Africa, and MENA regions which is vital to the survival of SMEs in those regions, thereby preserving jobs at such SMEs and the FIs; (b) Strong demonstration effect to support trade finance activities - a main artery to economic health and recovery, especially in emerging markets - through providing longer tenor sources of financing.
Role: IFC''s global franchise in financial markets will be critical to the project''s success in leveraging trade volumes, expanding new markets and facilitating the growth of ''south-south'' trades.
Sponsor: FIMBank was created in 1994 as a niche trade finance Bank. FIMBank is a major international player in the trade finance industry. Listed in Malta, it has a global presence, serving customers in more than 50 countries across four continents. It operates through a wide network of offices, subsidiaries, associate companies and joint ventures, which are spread across the globe, including the UK, the US, Dubai, Egypt, Brazil, Singapore, India, Russia and other key hubs of international trade. FIMBank itself concentrates mainly on conventional and structured trade transactions whereas forfaiting is done through its wholly-owned subsidiary in the UK, LFC, and factoring is carried out by its various factoring affiliates and subsidiaries.  The Groups shareholders include a number of private Middle Eastern shareholders that have invested in the business since inception, and a large and growing retail shareholder base, in addition to IFC which became a strategic shareholder in 2005. The main shareholders in FIMBank are Massaleh Investments K.S.C.C with 38.52%, IFC 5.84%, Astrolabe General Trading & Contracting Company 5.69% and the balance is publicly traded.
Cost Nature: As part of IFCs Global Trade Liquidity Program, the funding to FIMBank will be for up to $30 million to channel liquidity to ultimately support trade finance in sub-Saharan Africa and MENA.

Project Description: IFC will provide a senior loan of up to US$65 million to finance the Companys acquisition of a 3G license, capital expenditures to roll-out the 3G network and community facilities, and capital to make debt repayments.  Social responsibility is built into many parts of the overall business model.
Review Scope: The review of this project consisted of a meeting and interview by IFC staff with management of the Telecom Development Company Afghanistan (Roshan or the Company), and appraisal by IFC of technical, environmental and social information submitted by submitted by Roshan, including documentation on Site Acquisition and Negotiation and Site Owner Issues Handling, an Employee Handbook, and a Construction Contract.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: As this project involves sites to be chosen only where no high risk exists, no major adverse environmental or social impacts are expected to result.  As a result, it has been classified as a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.

Project Description: Concord Medical Services Holdings Limited ('CCM' or the 'Company'), which is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, has 133 centers located in 52 cities across 25 provinces. The Company operates the largest network of radiotherapy and diagnostic imaging centers in China. Most of the centers in Concord's network are operated under lease and management or similar agreements, where Concord leases the radiotherapy equipment to the hospital and operates the equipment. The Company also acquired a 52% interest in Chang'an Hospital, a private hospital in Xi'an, Shaanxi province, in the second quarter of 2012. Over the next five years, Concord plans to open an additional 50 radiotherapy centers, an oncology focused hospital (the 'Guangzhou Oncology Hospital') and a proton beam therapy hospital (the 'Beijing Proton  Center') (together, the 'Project').
Review Scope: IFC's review of this investment consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety ('EHS') and social related information submitted by Concord Medical Services Holdings Limited including: a sample of regulatory permits and licenses from Ministry of Health ('MOH'), Ministry of Environment ('MOE'), Government of China and Environmental /Radiation Impact Assessment report of the hospital partners, CCM organization chart and human resource ('HR') procedures. The Company's oncology centers in Zhengzhou, Beijing and Shanghai and Chang'an Hospital in Xi'an were also visited as part of the appraisal.     Discussions were also held with CCM's senior management in Beijing and operational teams at their oncology centers in Zhengzhou, Beijing and Shanghai and Chang'an hospital in Xi'an.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFC's Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards and guidelines. Key environmental and social (E&S) risks and issues related to this project include: adequate assessment of the E&S impacts of the Project and implementation of associated mitigation measures; implementation of effective EHS management systems; engagement with local communities in accordance with local requirements and IFC Performance Standards; management of construction and operations of the new hospitals and selection of facilities in which to locate oncology centers; employee occupational health and safety activities, including prevention of nosocomial diseases; management of solid and liquid waste, in particular hazardous and biomedical wastes and wastewater; and life and fire safety management of all the public access buildings (including Chang'an hospital, the Beijing Proton Center and the Guangzhou Oncology Hospital).

Project Description: The Project comprises an equity investment of up to 20% in Bhutan National Bank (BNB or the Bank).  The Bank was established in 1996 by the Government of Bhutan as the second commercial bank in the country, to promote growth and competition in the financial sector.  BNB is currently the largest of Bhutans five banks in terms of credit market share.  As of September 30, 2012, BNB had assets of US$442 million, outstanding portfolio of US$ 306 million, and capital fund of US$82 million.The proposed project will be IFCs first equity investment in Bhutan.  The proposed investment is strongly aligned with IFCs South Asia regional strategy, as it involves expanding outreach and financial inclusion as well as promoting sustainable and competitive private sector development in a frontier market in South Asia. Through this investment, IFC will provide BNB with access to international best practices in operational areas and help the Bank develop a more robust and scalable business model.  In parallel, IFC is also proposing an Advisory Services engagement to build the Banks capacities in risk management, strategy and business planning for the micro, small and medium enterprise (MSME) sector, as well as IT business integration and MIS strategy.
Environmental Social Info: Main E&S risk and impacts of the project emanates from the project finance, corporate and SME exposure and housing finance portfolio.  These includes impacts like occupational health & safety concerns, construction safety, fire and life safety, waste and pollution management and possibly land and biodiversity impacts depending on the nature and location of the project.  At present the Bank does not have an E&S risk management system in place.  The Bank was found to be in gross compliance with IFC''s requirements of PS-2 on Labour and Working Conditions.
Impact: (i) Access to finance: increasing access to finance in Bhutan, a frontier market, by enabling BNB to expand and enhance lending to an underbanked largely rural population. (ii) Best practices and implementation of strategy: as a shareholder, IFC will provide BNB with access to international best practices in the areas of IT, risk management, SEMS and governance, and help the Bank implement its new growth strategy and expand into new underserved market segments, not only benefiting Bhutan''s society, but also allowing the Bank to attain higher profitability.(iii) Demonstration effect: as new commercial banks enter the market, BNB can prove to be an example of both success and public impact.  The guidelines and norms that IFC will introduce can serve as an important precedent in the newly developing financial market and can strengthen the country''s investment climate.  Further, IFC''s investment is expected to provide a stamp of approval and increase the interest of other foreign investors to invest in Bhutan.(iv) Strengthening the Bhutanese banking sector. Stronger equity capital footings of a key player such as BNB will help to reduce systemic risk, and enable BNB to play a strong role in increasing and improving financial intermediation in BNB and promoting the competitiveness of the banking sector.
Role:
(i) IFC will strengthen a systemic bank in an IDA country by providing needed long-term capital.
(ii) IFC will support institutional transformation of the Bank by transferring know-how and expertise in corporate governance and risk management, through a new Advisory Services program (IFC has already completed one Advisory Services program with the Bank) as well as through representation on the Bank''s Board of Directors.
(iii) Since specialized services to micro enterprises and SMEs are practically non-existent in the country, IFC will also be able to help the Bank develop products to serve these segments; and
(iv) IFC will facilitate further reduction of effective government ownership in the Bank, thereby supporting the transition of Bhutan''s banking system to majority private sector participation.
Sponsor: BNB is listed on the Royal Securities Exchange of Bhutan and 50.44% of its shares are free float shares.  The Banks single largest shareholder is the National Pension and Provident Fund (NPPF), an organization created by the Royal Government of Bhutan to manage the retirement plans of Civil servants and the Armed Forces.  The NPPF owns 25.77% of the Bank.  The other key shareholders are: Druk Holding & Investment (DHI)  13.67%, Bhutan Trust Fund (BTF)  7.31%, Mr. Kunzang Dechen (Board Chairman) - 6.5%, Royal Insurance Corporation of Bhutan Ltd (RICB)  2.11%.  Mr. Kunzang Dechen is the largest private individual shareholder of the Bank.  He is a well-known businessman in Bhutan and is currently the Chairman of the Board of Directors of BNB.
Cost Nature: IFC proposes to invest an estimated amount of US$28.8 million in common shares of BNB, for a 20% shareholding. The endeavor is to complete the investment within 2012 subject to approval by respective authorities.

Project Description: Concord Medical Services Holdings Limited (Concord or the Company), which is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, has 133 centers located in 52 cities across 25 provinces. The Company operates the largest network of radiotherapy and diagnostic imaging centers in China. The Company also acquired a 52% interest in Changan Hospital, a private hospital in Xian, Shaanxi province, in the second quarter of 2012. Over the next three years, Concord will further expand its network by opening 50 new oncology and diagnostic centers, invest in a proton center in Beijing, and invest in an oncology hospital in Guangzhou (together, the Project).
Impact: 1. Increase access to quality healthcare services. The Project will support an established healthcare service provider to move down-market to frontier provinces, to reach middle- and lower-income households, providing affordable basic radiotherapy services that are not readily available to those populations.2. Enable knowledge transfer. Successful operation of the Proton Beam, one of the most advanced technologues in radiotherapy, would enable knowledge transfer amongst radiotherapy practitioners both within and outside the Company3. Demonstration effect. This will be achieved in terms of improving standards and corporate governance in healthcare management, and in sending a positive message to other private sector investors about potential market opportunities in the healthcare sector.4. Promoting health care reform and the public private partnership model. Concord''s success should help to enhance China''s health authorities'' confidence in private health care providers and increase willingness to further relax the regulatory barriers for private investment in the sector. 5. Create skilled employment opportunities. The Project will provide training and create employment opportunities for a number of specialty healthcare positions, including those of radiologists, which are currently in short supply in China.
Role:
1. Long term financing that suits the Project''s cash flow cycle. IFC will provide a long-term financing package with sufficient grace period and tenor that suits the Project''s cash flow. Such financing is not readily available in the domestic market.

2. Global industry expertise. IFC will share its experience in other emerging markets with the Company who will become part of IFC''s global network of healthcare clients. IFC has already introduced the Company to a prominent US healthcare institution, and also plans to introduce the Company to some of IFC''s other clients in the healthcare sector in Asia.

3. Environmental and Social best practices. IFC will share with the Company international best practices in Environmental and Social management and will work with the Company to improve its Environmental and Social standards.
Sponsor: Dr. Jianyu Yang is the current Chairman and CEO of the Company. Prior to joining Concord, Dr. Yang held senior management posts in a number of private companies, including Eguard Resource Development Co., Ltd., a company listed on Shenzhen Stock Exchange, and Beijing Sound Environmental Group Co. Ltd., an existing IFC investee company.Concord was formed by the merger of  Shenzhen Aohua Medical Services Co., Ltd. (Aohua) and Medstar (Shanghai) Leasing Co., Ltd. (Medstar) in 2008. Concord is 31% owned by institutional shareholders, 20% owned by the founders (and their families) of Aohua and Medstar, 10% owned by management with the rest owed by the public.

Project Description: Telecom Development Company Afghanistan (TDCA, Roshan or the Company) is the leading mobile telephone operator in Afghanistan with approximately 34% market share and 6 million subscribers. The Company began commercial operations in July 2003. The Company has asked IFC to provide a senior loan of up to US$65 million to finance the Companys acquisition of a 3G license, capital expenditures to roll-out the 3G network and make debt repayments (the Project).
Environmental Social Info: The key environmental and social (E&S) issues associated with the project are construction of new facilities; health and safety for workers and community members; pollution prevention and abatement; security services; and community engagement.  Details are contained in the Environmental and Social Review Summary for this project.
Impact: (i) Enhance use of telecommunication services in a low income country, through the roll-out of a 3G network, which will enable more people to access to broadband data services especially given Afghanistan's low fixed line penetration of less than 0.2%.(ii) Expand geographic coverage: While approximately 60% of the population is within reach of its network, Roshan is planning to extend service further to rural and untapped areas, with a population coverage target of 80% in five years.(iii) Extend economic opportunity and financial inclusion to all Afghans: Roshan's M-Paisa service has provided, since 2008, the Afghan population with mobile banking services, such as money transfers, bill payments and salary payments to the unbanked population in the country.  There are approximately 130,000 M-Paisa users and with the introduction of better quality 3G technology, the number of users is expected to grow to approximately 1.3 million by the end of 2016.(iv) Improve the well-being of people in Afghanistan through its corporate social program, Roshan Community: Roshan will continue to develop and financially support a wide range of programs aimed at improving the well-being of the people of Afghanistan that are focused on six main areas: healthcare, education, commerce, social welfare, arts & culture and the environment. (v) Provide political risk mitigation: In view of the increasing challenging security situation in Afghanistan coupled with the planned withdrawal of troops in 2014, country risk and security concerns continue to be the primary barriers to foreign investment in Afghanistan. By supporting this project, IFC is expected to send a positive signal to potential investors that it is possible to finance infrastructure projects in Afghanistan.
Role:
(i) Financial support to a priority post-conflict country: Due to decades of war and complete lack of foreign investment, Afghanistan is today one of the world's poorest countries with a per capita GDP of about US$500. About 97% of the population is unbanked and access to finance for large corporate remains extremely difficult. In this context, IFC will play a key role in providing financial support to a growing company with limited access to funding from private commercial banks.
(ii) Long-term financing: Long-term funding from private sources is extremely limited in Afghanistan. IFC's provision of long-term debt is critical for Roshan to help finance the 3G license acquisition and capital expenditures required for the network roll-out. As well, extending the tenor of Roshan's debt will provide the Company with greater operational flexibility.
Sponsor: Incorporated under the laws of Afghanistan and headquartered in Kabul, Roshan is 100% owned by Telecom Development Company Afghanistan B.V. (TDCA B.V.), a company incorporated in the Netherlands. TDCA B.V. is itself 51% owned by the Aga Khan Fund for Economic Development (AKFED), 36.75% by Monaco Telecom International and 12.25% by TeliaSonera AB. AKFED is part of the Aga Khan Development Network which encompasses a number of non-profit agencies, active in sectors such as rural development, microfinance, health and education services, cultural development, as well as its for-profit agency, AKFED, which makes long-term investments in developing countries. AKFED is a private company.Monaco Telecom International is a 100% subsidiary of Monaco Telecom Group, which itself is 55% owned by Cable & Wireless Communications Plc and 45% owned by the Principality of Monaco. Monaco Telecom is a private company.TeliaSonera AB is a leading telecommunications operator in the Nordic and Baltic regions. TeliaSonera is a public company and is listed on the Stockholm Stock Exchange.
Cost Nature: The total Project cost is estimated at US$147 million, which includes the acquisition of a 3G license, capital expenditures to roll-out the 3G network and loan repayments. The proposed IFC investment is an A Loan of up to a $65 million for IFCs own account.

Company Name: ALD AUTOMOTIVE UKRAINE LIMITED LIABILITY COMPANY
Project Description: IFC proposes to provide up to US$5 million senior loan (up to 4 years) to First Lease LLC (First Lease or the Company), fully owned by ALD International, a leasing subsidiary of Societe Generale Group. The proposed project (the Project) would support the post-crisis growth of the Companys leasing portfolio aimed to provide high-level car lease and fleet management services throughout Ukraine.
Impact: The project is expected to have a significant development impact as it would:(i) support Ukrainian financial (non-banking) sector after the recent crisis and in the current fragile economic environment;(ii) enhance further development of the leasing industry in Ukraine, which is still at an early stage;(iii) enable the Company to expand its client network throughout Ukraine, including frontier regions;(iv) facilitate access to finance via leasing services to result in more job creation;(v) strengthen the Company''s capacity in environmental and social management standards, creating a demonstration effect for other companies in the country to upgrade.
Role:
IFC will play a strong developmental role in the project by:

(i) providing much needed longer term funding to one of the key players in Ukrainian leasing sector;
(ii) supporting the long standing Partner at times of market turbulence and strengthen the strategic partnership with Societe Generale Group in Central and Eastern Europe;
(iii) sending positive signal to the market and to existing or potential investors and thus, increasing confidence in the Ukrainian leasing sector.
Sponsor: First Lease is 100% owned by ALD International, leasing subsidiary of Societe Generale Group (SocGen).SocGen is one of the leading international financial institutions, operating in 77 countries with over 160,000 staff. The Group consists of 5 business divisions: French networks, international retail banking, corporate and investment banking, specialized financial services and insurance and global investment management and services. It is financially sound, with shareholders equity of 49 billion and Core Tier 1 capital adequacy ratio (Basel 2.5) at 9.9% as of June 30, 2012, which is above European Banking Authority 9% minimum requirement. As of October 30, 2012 SocGens long term ratings were A2 by Moody''s, A by S&P and A+ by Fitch.

Impact: (i) Provision of growth capital to small and medium sized healthcare providers, thus expanding much needed healthcare infrastructure in emerging markets. (ii) An investment by IFC could be a demonstration of successful private equity investing in healthcare in emerging markets countries. Project Description: The proposed IFC financing is a loan package on its own account to support a group of Indonesian companies in undertaking an expansion project, including (i) to expand beverage product lines based on PET (polyethylene terephthalate) bottle under PT Tirta Alam Segar  PT TAS (Jakarta), (ii) to expand fruit flavored beverage in plastic cups under PT Murni Alam Segar  PT MAS (Surabaya), (iii) to commission a greenfield coffee mix production under PT Harum Alam Segar  PT HAS (Surabaya), and (iv) to increase the capacity of existing detergent business under PT Sayap Mas Utama  PT SMU (Jakarta), all targeting low-middle income segments in the domestic market (the Project). IFC will also try to syndicate a B loan subject to market conditions. The balance of the financing will be  through shareholder loans / equity.
Review Scope: IFCs environmental and social (E&S) review included site visits to PT HAS and PT MAS in Surabaya as well as to PT TAS and PT SMU in Jakarta, including: - Meetings with President Director of PT. Wings Surya, Finance & Human Resource Director; Engineering Department, PT SMU; General Manager, PT TAS; Plant General Manager, PT MAS, Surabaya; Plant General Manager, PT HAS, Surabaya. Meetings with the Quality Assurance and Control (QA/QC) and the Environmental, Occupational Health and Safety (EHS) Officers at each of the four (4) facilities also took place;- Review of technical documentations provided at each plant, including detailed responses to IFCs E&S Questionnaire, plants operational permits, management systems Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs), SOPs implementation status and technical capacity, internal and external environmental and occupational health and safety (OHS) audits/inspections, review of HR regulation, life and fire safety (L&FS), resource efficiency (water, energy), and social performance.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This proposed investment is expected to have limited environmental and social impacts which are expected to be site-specific and none is expected to be significant. Those impacts can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to recognized performance standards, procedures, guidelines and design criteria as described in the following sections. Thus, this is a Category B project in accordance with IFCs Environmental and Social Sustainability Policy. This categorization is in accordance with other similar type of projects within the sector. The project is designed to avoid, minimize and manage environmental and social risks and impacts of the Companys operations in compliance with applicable IFCs Performance Standards and World Bank Group (WBG) General and sector-specific (Food and Beverage processing) Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines. Key E&S issues applicable for this investment are: (i) operational licenses of the four  facilities; (ii) environmental, occupational health and safety (OHS), food safety and social management system and related procedures, including Hazard Assessment and Critical Control Point (HACCP) Principles and ISO 22000 certification; (iii) EHS organizational structure and internal capacity; (iv) adherence to Indonesian labor law, working conditions, standards and OHS risk prevention and management, including each facilitys employees, contractors and nearby communities; (v) Life and Fire Safety (L&FS) provisions and emergency preparedness and response; (vi) use of public utilities (water supply and energy), optimization of water and energy use through project design and resource conservation measures and greenhouse gas emissions; (vii) wastewater collection and treatment, solid waste disposal, air emissions from generators and boilers, potable water quality, treatment and monitoring, hazardous material handling, management and control of pest and rodent; (viii) food and transport safety, and (vix) engagement with communities on EHS, food and traffic safety and social performance. PT TAS is an existing IFC client and its E&S performance to date has been satisfactory.

Project Description: The proposed investment is to support the Wings Group of Nigeria (Wings or the Group) with the development of a greenfield detergent manufacturing facility in Nigeria (the Project). In addition, the Group is also planning to develop a greenfield food manufacturing facility (food facility) in Nigeria.  The Wings Group is headquartered in Indonesia where it has various operations and the Group commissioned its first powder detergent facility in Nigeria in September 2007. This facility is located at Igbessa in the OPIC Industrial Estate situated in Ogun State some 40 kilometers from central Lagos.  The Project is being constructed on an adjacent 3.6 ha site and is expected to be commissioned in August 2013. This facility is being implemented under a Nigerian registered company, Natural Prime Resources Nigeria Ltd. (Natural Prime) which is majority owned by Wings. The Group is still in the preliminary stages of designing the food facility with limited information on the project currently available. However, Wings has extensive experience in such operations in Indonesia and is assessing various possible locations for this facility.   While all Performance Standards are applicable to this investment, IFCs environmental and social due diligence indicates that the investment will have impacts which must be managed in a manner consistent with the following Performance Standards (PS) dated April 2012:PS 1: Assessment and Management of Environmental and Social Risks and ImpactsPS 2: Labor and Working ConditionsPS 3: Resource Efficiency and Pollution PreventionPS 4: Community Health, Safety and SecurityPS 6: Biodiversity Conservation and Sustainable Management of Living Natural ResourcesThe Project is located within an established industrial area and the land was acquired on a willing buyer-willing seller basis. In addition, this land had been previously cleared and developed. Thus PS 5: Land Acquisition and Involuntary Resettlement, PS 6: Biodiversity Conservation and Sustainable Management of Living Natural Resources and PS 8 Cultural Heritage do not apply to the Project.   The land for the new food facility is still to be identified. Thus PS 5, PS 6 and PS 8 may all, or individually, apply to this project.  Once the land has been identified, Wings will engage with IFC to confirm the approach to the assessment of this facility and the extent to which the PSs apply to this component will determined at that time.   Palm oil will likely be required in the manufacturing process for the food facility and thus there is the potential that such oil could be sourced from areas contributing to significant conversion of natural and/or critical habitats. Mitigation measures have been defined to address this issue, however in such an event, PS 6 would apply. There are no Indigenous Peoples in Nigeria, thus PS 7: Indigenous Peoples is not applicable to either of the developments.
Review Scope: IFCs environmental and social (E&S) review of this project included the following:A site visit to the existing detergent manufacturing facility and the Project;Discussions with management representatives, including the Plant Managing Director, Production Manager and Human Resources Manager;Responses to IFCs environmental and social questionnaire and subsequent related queries;A review of documentation, including the Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) for the existing detergent facility.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The proposed investments are expected to have limited environmental and social impacts which will be site-specific with none anticipated to be significant. Further, the impacts can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to recognized performance standards, procedures, guidelines and design criteria as described in the following sections. Thus this is a Category B project in accordance with IFCs Environmental and Social Sustainability Policy. Following implementation of the attached Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP), the project will be in compliance with applicable IFCs Performance Standards and the World Bank Group (WBG) General and sector-specific (Food and Beverage Processing) Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines. Key environmental and social issues applicable for this investment are: (i) environmental, occupational health and safety (OHS), food safety and social management systems and related procedures, including Hazard Assessment and Critical Control Point (HACCP) Principles at the food facility; (ii) EHS organizational structure and internal capacity; (iii) adherence to Nigerian labor law, working conditions, standards and OHS risk prevention and management, including each facilitys employees and contractors; (iv) Life and Fire Safety (L&FS) provisions and emergency preparedness and response; (v) wastewater collection and treatment, solid waste disposal, air emissions from generators and boilers, hazardous material handling and management; and (vi) food and transport safety, Specific actions have been defined in the attached Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) to ensure these issues are adequately addressed.

Project Description: Project Description: Muyuan Foodstuff Co., Ltd. (Muyuan Foodstuff) is a pig breeder and hog producer located in China. IFCs proposed loan investment of $20M will primarily support the development of a Project of the Company to allow for annual production of 300,000 hogs. Upon completion, this Project would expand further Muyuan Foodstuffs hog production.
Environmental Social Info: Social and Environmental Assessment:All facilities currently under construction have been subject to an EIA. Documents reviewed associated with the EIA process (the EIA approval and comment document from the relevant government authority) provided for Muyuan Foodstuff to begin construction of the projects; they also highlight the E&S issues that are expected to be of the greatest importance and hence prioritized by Muyuan Foodstuff for management. Issues such as wastewater management, for example, are singled out. Management programThe operational requirements of Muyuan Foodstuff farms are managed by a central corporate office. Through 2009, Muyuan Foodstuff operated an informal environmental and social assessment and management system. This has now been formalized culminating in the system being independently certified in 2010 to ISO 14001:2004 with a scope that includes operating farms, feed mill production and associated management activities.  The Environmental Management Manual (a key part of the ISO 14001 EMS) is a high level structural document that makes reference to a variety of procedures which are applied, as needed, at each facility. Muyuan Foodstuffs current plans do not include obtaining an OHSAS 18001 management system certification; however, Muyuan Foodstuff has developed a policy and various operating procedures for the management of OHS issues within its operations. All operating farms are certified to the Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points (HACCP) standard; in addition the feed mill is certified to ISO 22000. The production department is responsible for animal welfare. Muyuan Foodstuff  is judged to have exemplary standards for the vast majority of animal welfare issues, including animal handling, feeding systems, nutrition, animal health and transport. The housing of sows, however, is the one area that could be subject to a change in practice to better align it with contemporary practices in the industry elsewhere in the world. In recognition of this opportunity, the company has been piloting a new approach based upon the use of Electronic Sow Feeding (ESF) systems supplied from Europe and designed to provide more room for the animals while providing them individually tailored nutrition that promotes productivity. This pilot scheme is in keeping with other pig producers in the country who are trying out this approach and, as noted above, is a practice already adopted in other countries. Organizational capacityThe Service Department assumes responsibility for environmental management; occupational health and safety; maintenance, construction and development; electricity and water utilities; landscaping; and, catering.  The Environmental Management Unit within this department comprises 24 employees who oversee the work of full time farm-level environmental coordinators (3 to 5 persons per farm depending on the farm size).  The OHS Unit has  6 staff who oversees health and safety management within the company from the corporate level.  At the farm-level, there are 25 individuals who, amongst other duties, are tasked with coordinating OH&S management. These coordinators are also involved in the monthly safety inspections at the farms (a comprehensive company-wide undertaking). They also conduct daily and weekly safety inspections. The mill manager is ultimately responsible for OHS matters at that operation; a safety supervisor (a group leader position) provides day to day implementation support.  Muyuan Foodstuff has dedicated farm/project-level safety personnel for the construction sites who are trained by the local authority on construction site safety; they are managed from the Construction Unit within the Service Department. Monitoring and ReportingThe Company uses pre-qualified and licensed consultants to collect environmental data from various operations. This data is used internally to understand existing operations but is also used in the EIA process to characterize proposed projects. A previously developed Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) project involved building biogas digesters for the farms; this required the Company to monitor emissions from bio digesters so as to manage their operation. Data collected as part of that project has since been used as a basis for subsequent biogas developments at all other farms.  PS2 Labor and Working ConditionsOrganizational capacityThe total workforce is thousands of which approximately 80% are farm workers located on the pig breeding and production farms. The Human Resource Department is managed by 9 staff responsible for application of HR policy, procedures and administration.  Activities of the Department are guided by a HR Manual. This manual is currently being updated to include sections on working hours, benefits, staff grievance mechanism, staff training and development, safety, and a code of conduct. Worker Welfare The majority of farm workers are recruited from the local population in the immediate vicinity of the farm. The minimum age for employment is 18 years. All workers sign a standard written contract with Muyuan Foodstuff. Workers are essentially paid on a production basis; average monthly wage is more than 2,000 RMB. In addition, all employees receive social insurance (which covers pension, unemployment, medical, injury, and maternity) and 11 days of public holidays in accordance to the regulatory requirements.  Given biosecurity concerns and lengthy quarantine periods associated with gaining access to and working in the farms, farmers are provided with no-cost accommodation on the farm and subsidized meals in the canteen. Farm workers are required to work irregular hours determined by the pig production cycle (i.e., farrowing, weaners, growers).  Worker Health and Safety Muyuan Foodstuff uses third party contractors for the construction of new farms. Contractors recruit workers from local villages for construction work. Health and safety issues are jointly managed by the Company and Contractor personnel. The workers receive training for health and safety requirements related to construction activities from Muyuan Foodstuff safety personnel as well as the contractor.  Construction operations are regularly inspected for adherence to required health and safety practices by local authorities. Muyuan Foodstuff conducts annual health check up of all farm workers in accordance with standard international practice. Fire safety control measures are required for the feed mill under Chinese regulation.  Biogas facilities are constructed with fire safety precautions built-in such as water seal containers.  PS3 Pollution Prevention and AbatementEach farm is equipped with a bio digestion system to treat manure and preclude the need for effluent discharge to surface waters. Solid waste from the bio-digestion process is provided free-of-charge to farmers for use as fertilizer.  The Company utilizes coal as fuel for hot water boilers, steam boilers, and cooking activities in the dormitory/ canteen.  The hot water boilers at the farms are equipped with cyclones for dust removal from the coal burning process. Muyuan Foodstuff  has begun development of procedures to manage centralized and farm-level facilities for storage of medicines and chemicals; this procedure will be enhanced to include reference to better storage practices, hazards to be identified and emergency measures to be determined. This is addressed in the ESAP.  Used syringes, needles and vaccine containers used for animal care are centrally managed and disposed of by high temperature disinfection and land disposal. The company will maintain records on types and amounts of waste disposal going forward, as set forth in the ESAP.       PS4 Community Health, Safety and SecurityMuyuan Foodstuff farms are located in rural areas throughout Neixiang County. Muyuan Foodstuffs site selection and screening criteria are used to identify sites located on poor quality agricultural lands distant from settlements. Muyuan Foodstuff has implemented strict biosecurity procedures on all its farms.  Farms are fully fenced and gated thereby restricting access. All vehicular access to and movement within farms requires passage through dips. Muyuan Foodstuff has developed various emergency response plans to address potential emergencies including fire and biogas leakage.The feed mill located in Neixiang County is surrounded by commercial and residential establishments.  Previously, fire protection/ control measures within the mill was observed to be minimal, including the lack of fire alarm system and appropriate dust control.  Muyuan Foodstuff since conducted a comprehensive safety assessment/ review for its feed mill operation. Whereas most of the recommended corrective actions have now been completed, those remaining regarding prevention of explosions and some fire prevention requirements remain to be finally closed out; the completion of these recommended items is addressed in the ESAP.
Impact: mployment: The Company''s operations are located in Province - a frontier region in China. It provides stable employment opportunities for thousands, including  female employees.Farmers reached: Currently, a significant number of rural households supply the Company with raw materials such as corn, barley and silage.   SMEs reached:  Company sells its breeds to rural pig farms for further fattening for sale to market. Food Safety:  The Chinese hog sector is still very fragmented, leading to poor hygiene standards, inadequate bio-security, poor nutrition, and over-use of antibiotics. By creating a larger enterprise with greater focus on efficiency and food safety, the Company supports the improvement of breeding techniques, quality standards as well as the production efficiency of the industry.
Role:
Long-term partner: Muyuan Foodstuff is keen to attract financing from credible/knowledgeable partners such as IFC who have a long-term investment horizon and can add value to the operations through our industry knowledge and enable the Company implement a properly designed strategic plan.
Credibility and Positioning: Muyuan Foodstuff expects the signaling from IFC''s direct investment will enhance its reputation with investors and other partners.
Adoption of Best-Practice Operational Standards: By supporting the deployment of environmentally friendly, energy-efficient pig farms yielding quality pigs, Muyuan Foodstuff can have a positive, visible demonstration effect for improving the operational management standards in the Chinese pig industry.
Sponsor: The Company is privately held.
Cost Nature: The total Project cost is estimated to be RMB300 million (approx. US$48 million equivalent). IFC is considering to provide a senior debt to Wolong Muyuan Breeding Co., Ltd. (Wolong Muyuan, a subsidiary of Muyuan Foodstuff) in an amount of up to US$20 million on its own account.

Project Description: Ser Educacional S.A. (Maurício or the Company) is a for-profit higher education company providing undergraduate, graduate and technical education to students in the North and Northeast regions of Brazil. The Company has approximately 55,000 students mainly from the middle and low income social classes. Maurício currently runs fifteen campuses in ten different states. Mauricio is undertaking a 2-year investment program to (the Project): (i) modernize and improve its existing campuses; (ii) open 2 new campuses in the Northeast of Brazil; and (iii) make new acquisitions.
Impact: i. Raise quality standards: Strengthening the Company''s position as a leading education company in North and Northeast regions of Brazil will pressure other institutions to raise the quality of their services in order to remain competitive;ii. Improve access to services: the Company''s plan to expand its network in the Brazilian North and Northeast will enhance the country''s education infrastructure and improve access to quality, affordable post-secondary education services for lower income students; iii. Rationalize the market: The expansion of the Company through growing market share and selective acquisitions may help to consolidate the still fragmented education sector, potentially leading to rationalization and quality improvement in the industry.
Role:
i. Provide longer-term financing in a still relatively difficult market environment for the Company;
ii. Support the enhancement of the Company''s education services by sharing industry contacts and best practices;
iii. Provide a strong signal to the market in terms of the attractiveness of the post secondary Education market in the North and Northeast; and
iv. Help improve environmental and social management systems at the Company.
Sponsor: Maurício is majority owned by Janguie Diniz (87.7%), a Brazilian lawyer and professor who founded the Company. The balance is owned by Cartesian Capital Group (11.3%), a private equity group based in New York and Janyo Deniz (1%), brother of the founder and the CEO of the Company.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is expected to cost US$ 80 million. The proposed IFC investment is an A Loan of up to US$40 million equivalent.  The remaining portion of the project cost is expected to be financed with internal cash generation.

Project Description: Equatorial Energia S.A. (EQTL, the Company), a holding company with investments in Brazils electricity sector and an existing IFC partner, is seeking financing from IFC to support (i) the turnaround and expansion of Centrais Electricas do Para S.A. (CELPA) and (ii) the potential future acquisition and turnaround of other power distribution companies in Northern and Central Brazil (together, the Project). CELPA is the distribution company of the State of Para, covers a service area of 1.25 million square kilometers (the size of France, the UK and Spain combined) and serves close to 1.8 million customers representing a population of nearly seven million people as of end of 2011. CELPA was privatized and acquired by Rede Enérgia S.A. (Rede) in 1998. Since then, CELPA has been underperforming and filed for Brazils Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in February 2012 as it was unable to meet its debt obligations. In June 2012, EQTL presented a buyout proposal to Rede, acquired Redes 61.4% ownership of CELPA and formally took over on November 1, 2012. The remaining stake is held by Brazils federal, integrated power utility, Elétrobras (34.2%) and others (4.4%).
Environmental Social Info: There may be potentially complex environmental and social considerations given that CELPAs concession area is located entirely within the Amazon Biome. There is also the risk of potentially high operational safety and accident rates given the sizeable rural concession area and poor network automation and communication systems currently in place.
Impact: The current operational condition of CELPA is uncertain and the provision of reliable electricity to the population is severely compromised. Once the Project reaches financial close, a knowledgeable and experienced partner will step-in to restructure and undertake significant investment to improve and expand CELPA''s power network, increase operational efficiencies and achieve productivity gains. In turn, the quality and reliability of the service will improve and should, over time, translate into better access to electricity for one of the poorest and most underserved regions of Brazil. In addition, industrial and commercial activities in the region, particularly agricultural activities, will directly benefit from reliable and good quality electricity.Overall, IFC''s financing will support greater private sector participation in Brazil''s power sector as a means to improve its efficiency and long-term development and is expected to benefit directly the State of Para, a frontier region, and support the development of its infrastructure.
Role:
IFC''s role and additionality in the proposed transaction is to (i) provide confidence and a "stamp of approval" to the equity market and other investors by serving as an "anchor" investor to support EQTL''s ambitious equity fundraising plan under current challenging public equity market conditions; (ii) leverage IFC''s understanding of turnaround efforts in power distribution in Brazil after having supported several operators (including CPFL: Project# 11575, CEMAR: Project# 26370, and Endesa Brasil: Project# 11600; and (iii) further strengthen the Company''s environmental, social and corporate governance policies/practices.

IFC also plans to explore with EQTL and CELPA management the potential to leverage IFC Advisory Services to support their turnaround plan and rural electrification efforts.
Sponsor: Established in 1999, EQTL, was initially created to participate in the auctions during the privatization of Brazils distribution companies in the late nineties. In 2004, the Company acquired a 65.1% stake in Companhia Energetica do Maranhão (CEMAR), then the financially distressed distribution company of the State of Maranhão. EQTL successfully turned around CEMAR through operational efficiencies, loss reduction and large improvements in quality of service. Other assets include Geradora de Energia do Norte (Geramar, formed of two thermoelectric plants in Maranhão) and Equatorial Soluções (services related to electrical energy, telecom, receivables collection and technical and O&M services). EQTL is also the sponsor of IFCs US$80 million equivalent local currency loan to CEMAR (Project# 26370) committed and fully disbursed in 2008.  EQTL was listed in 2006 on Bovespas Novo Mercado. The Company is indirectly controlled by Fundo de Participação Pactual Capital Partners Limited (FIP PCP) with a direct ownership of 12% and an indirect ownership of 41.5% via Pactual Capital Partners Latin America Power Fund Limited (PCP Latin) itself 100%-owned by FIP PCP. Both entities are Brazilian private equity funds managed by Vinci Partners, a Brazilian asset management and private equity firm with over US$3 billion in assets under management.
Cost Nature: EQTL plans to raise R$1.15 billion (US$567 million equivalent) through a follow-on public offering of newly issued EQTL shares combined with potential new funding of approximately R$150 million (US$74 million equivalent) for a total of R$1.3 billion (US$640 million equivalent). R$800 million (US$394 million equivalent) will be used to fund the turnaround of CELPA. The remaining R$500 million (US$246 million equivalent) in equity and debt proceeds will be reserved for future acquisitions and contingencies.IFCs proposed equity investment of R$200 million (US$99 million equivalent) would account for 15% of the contemplated financial plan.
