Project Description: This project comprises an investment in Rizal Commercial Banking Corporation (RCBC or the Bank), a bank in the Philippines, into which IFC, through the IFC Capitalization (Equity) Fund, LP is proposing an equity investment of up to US$100 million in the form of common shares.  RCBC provides a wide range of banking and other financial products and services, including commercial and retail banking, credit cards, asset management and treasury. IFCs proposed investment will strengthen the Banks capital in anticipation of higher regulatory capital requirements of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) and support the Banks growth. This project fits in with IFCs strategy to support the Philippine financial markets through equity type investments in local financial institutions that play a key role in providing access to finance to underserved sectors such as SMEs and housing.
Environmental Social Info: The main E&S risks and impacts of the project derive from the E&S risks of the Banks lending activities, the capacity and systems in place to manage these risks, and the Banks practices with regard to labor and working conditions. Under the requirements of the existing IFC investment, the company has appointed an E&S officer and developed a satisfactory environmental and social management system (ESMS). The ESMS, among others, requires the Bank to screen all projects against the IFC Exclusion list, to ensure compliance with the national E&S laws and regulations and the IFC performance Standards. At present however the Bank has not yet started to implement the ESMS and therefore no E&S due diligence or other procedures are yet in place to address the risks and mitigations associated with the clients portfolio. The Bank was found to be in compliance with the requirements of PS2 on Labor and Working conditions.
Impact: (i)	Continuing to strengthen the Philippine banking sector by providing long term capital, following IFC and IFC Cap Fund''s investment in BDO Unibank, Inc. in 2010  and RCBC in 2011, particularly in light of the higher capital requirements of Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas;(ii)	Increasing access to finance to underserved segments in the Philippines such as SMEs, microenterprises, and homebuyers and women entrepreneurs, including in frontier regions outside Metro Manila;(iii)	Promoting and expanding better corporate governance and risk management practices in the Philippine banking sector; and(iv)	Contributing to the strengthening of environmental and social management practices in the country''s banking system.
Role:
IFC''s additionality comes from its leadership and unique track record in providing comprehensive financing and advisory services support to help large financial institutions transition to leaders and provide inclusive access to finance in their markets. In this project, IFC''s additionality stems from:
(i) Providing significant amounts of equity capital by mobilizing partners (e.g. through the AMC) which is otherwise not available to the Bank;
(ii) Supporting increased access to finance for SMEs and microenterprises especially in frontier regions of the country that are currently underserved; and
(iii) Using its presence in the Board of the Bank to bring best practices in the areas of corporate governance, risk management, and environmental and social management.
Sponsor: The majority of the Banks shares are owned by the Yuchengco Group, and the balance of the Banks shares are owned by various shareholders.
Cost Nature: The investment is up to US$100 million in RCBCs common equity.
Location: RCBC is headquartered in Metro Manila, Philippines and its network is comprised of branches and ATMs throughout the country.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This transaction involves an equity investment and the overall portfolio risk is considered to be high. The project has therefore been categorized as FI-1 in accordance with IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The Bank provides retail, SME and corporate services. The Banks corporate lending accounts for approximately 70% of the total portfolio while SME lending, consumer, residential mortgage and other loans account for approximately 30%. The Bank''s outstanding exposure to long term corporate loans in sectors regarded as high risk, such as real estate including development, manufacturing and electricity, gas and water, is greater than 20% of the total loan portfolio. For this project the client will be required to screen loans against the IFC Exclusion List, the national E&S laws and regulations and the IFC Performance Standards
Risk Impact: The main E&S risks and impacts of the project derive from the E&S risks of the Banks lending activities, the capacity and systems in place to manage these risks, and the Banks practices with regard to labor and working conditions. Under the requirements of the existing IFC investment, the company has appointed an E&S officer and developed a satisfactory environmental and social management system (ESMS). The ESMS, among others, requires the Bank to screen all projects against the IFC Exclusion list, to ensure compliance with the national E&S laws and regulations and the IFC performance Standards. At present however the Bank has not yet started to implement the ESMS and therefore no E&S due diligence or other procedures are yet in place to address the risks and mitigations associated with the clients portfolio. The Bank was found to be in compliance with the requirements of PS2 on Labor and Working conditions.

Project Description: The proposed project consists of a subordinated debt investment of US$ 75 million which will strengthen the Tier 2 capital base of CBC, a systemically important bank in Sri Lanka.
Environmental Social Info: Main E&S risk and impacts of the project emanates from the corporate, project and SME finance. These includes impacts like occupational health & safety concerns, labour and working conditions, fire and life safety, construction related E&S risks, waste and pollution management and possibly land and biodiversity impacts depending on the nature and location of the investments to be made by the bank. Additionally, there is a likelihood of social risks and impacts in case of agriculture related projects in the country. The bank has an E&S risk management system in place. The bank was found to be in compliance with IFC''s requirements of PS-2 on Labour and Working Conditions.
Impact: Market Signal: JBIC''s involvement in the Project sends an important market signal to international investors endorsing Sri Lanka as an investment target. This will have a key impact on FDI flows particularly at a time when the country is emerging from a 26 year civil war and there is ongoing uncertainty in global financial markets.Strengthen Systemic Impact: A stronger capital base will enable CBC to enhance its systemic contribution to finance the post-conflict reconstruction efforts in the North and East of the country and infrastructure projects identified as a national priority to accelerate economic growth.Increased Access to Finance: CBC is a major SME lender in Sri Lanka, comprising nearly a third of its portfolio. The Project will provide additional funding for the SME sector, which is a key driver of economic growth, and the tangible development outcome of this financing will be monitored through the incremental increase in the Bank''s SME portfolio.Promote Regional Integration: The Project will help promote regional economic integration by supporting the expansion of CBC''s expansion of its regional presence.Optimize Capital Structure of Banks: The Project meets a key priority of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka in raising Tier 2 capital to optimize the capital structure of key domestic banks. Tier 2 capital is relatively new in Sri Lanka and nor widely prevalent since weak market conditions have precluded banks from readily accessing subordinated debt.
Role:
Address Market Failure: There is a clear role for IFC/AMC in addressing market failure by providing large ticket equity funding otherwise unavailable from commercial investors due to limited absorptive capacity in domestic capital markets and global investor uncertainty in the aftermath of the recent financial crises.

Introduction of a new Investor: The introduction of JBIC as an indirect new investor consequent to the AMC funding will be beneficial for the Bank. JBIC sees investment prospects in Sri Lanka in other sectors as well making it a potentially attractive strategic partner and co-financier for projects funded by CBC.
Sponsor: Established in 1969, CBC is Sri Lankas largest private sector commercial bank with approximately 12% market share (in terms of loans and advances). CBC has the largest delivery network amongst private sector banks with 227 branches and service points and over 500 ATMs countrywide. Due to its dominant role in the market, it is expected to pitch its share of support in the future growth in the country, especially in infrastructure, tourism, agriculture, retail financing in the North and East. It also has banking operations in Bangladesh. CBCs asset book is diversified across retail, SME, corporate and project finance. As a strategic client of IFC, with investment and advisory relationships dating back to 2003, CBC is the ideal partner with regard to IFCs priority initiatives for Sri Lanka which range from supporting the growth of SMEs to the reconstruction and development of the Northern and Eastern provinces of the country.The Bank is listed on the Colombo Stock Exchange. The top shareholders in the Bank include DFCC Bank - a specialized bank in Sri Lanka, the Government of Sri Lanka via Sri Lanka Insurance Corporation (SLIC) and Employees Provident Fund (EPF), Aberdeen Asset Management, Janus Overseas Fund, IFC and SBI Venture Holding Pvt. Ltd - a Venture Capital/Private Equity group based in Japan.
Cost Nature: IFC proposes to invest US$75 million 10-year, bullet maturity subordinated loan (Tier 2 capital). The Project will be entirely funded through the IFC Capitalization Fund via its sub-debt funds. This fund has been created by investments from IFC and JBIC (Japan Bank for International Corporation).
Location: The head office of CBC is located in Colombo but the Bank has a wide branch network across the country.
Risk Impact: The key E&S risks and impacts derive from the bank's capacity to manage the potential environmental and social risks associated with its operations. The typical risks and impacts in SME segment are limited and site specific (e.g. related to occupational health & safety, emergency response, waste-water discharge, air emissions, labour, etc.). The bank is an existing IFC client and thus the bank has appointed an E&S specialist and is implementing an adequate E&S risk management system (ESMS) including an external communications mechanism. The existing ESMS will continue to be implemented for this project as well. The bank has adequate HR policies in line with IFC Performance Standard - 2 requirements for its operations in Sri Lanka and is in the process of upgrading its HR policies for Bangladesh. The bank will ensure that the upgrades are in line with IFC Performance Standard -2 requirements.

Project Description: IFC is in discussion with Bank of Shanghai (BOS or the Bank) to enter into an unfunded risk sharing facility (RSF) to support energy efficiency (EE) and renewable energy (RE) projects with small and medium enterprises (SME) in China (the Project, or CHUEE SME BOS). In this proposed Project, IFC would take credit risk in a loan portfolio to be originated and funded by the Bank. The Project is expected to receive support from the Global Environmental Facility (GEF) and Chinese Central Government.
Environmental Social Info: The main E&S risks and impacts of the project derive from the E&S risks of the RSF target loans, the capacity and systems in place to manage these risks, and BOSs practices with regard to labor and working conditions. At present BOS does not have an Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) outlining the procedures, responsibilities and tools for undertaking E&S risk management of its lending activities. No staff/department has been assigned responsibility for E&S risk assessment and monitoring, and addressing the training needs of all staff involved in ESMS implementation. BOS was found to be in compliance with China relative labor laws and regulations and generally in line with the requirements of IFC Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working conditions.
Impact: (i)	Environmental benefit:  Upon full ramp-up of CHUEE SME BOS, 132,000 tCO2 GHG emission is estimated to be reduced per year; (ii)	SME access to finance:  Upon full ramp-up of CHUEE SME BOS, approximately 25 SME borrowers will be financed;(iii)	Demonstration effect:  Encouraging governments to participate in future public private partnership initiatives of this type, both within and beyond China; (iv)	Capacity building:  Promoting the improvement of industry-specific loan underwriting criteria and strengthening risk management practices; and
Role:
(i) With more than a decade experience in supporting EE financing globally, especially in China through CHUEE, IFC is in the leading position to continue innovation to address major market gaps for SMEs to access funding for EE and RE projects and activities;

(ii) Using global and China-specific knowledge and expertise in EE/RE financing, unique to IFC and unavailable in the local market, IFC will leverage public and private sources of capital to increase development impact;

(iii) IFC''s advisory services will be delivered through established platform which has great experience in building banks'' capacity to do EE/RE lending and SME finance;

(iv) IFC is helping partner banks to focus on SMEs, especially those in frontier regions where EE/RE funding is still at an early stage; and

(v) In the absence of IFC''s participation, it will be very difficult to raise funding for first loss and advisory services, both critical for the success of the program.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Bank of Shanghai. Founded in 1995, BOS is a joint-stock city commercial bank formed through the merger of 99 urban credit co-operatives in Shanghai. It is the second largest city commercial bank in China in terms of total assets. As of December 31, 2011, the top three shareholders of BOS were Shanghai United Investment Co., Ltd , HSBC China and China Jianyin.
Cost Nature: The project proposes an IFC investment of up to RMB250 million (US$40 million equivalent) in the form of an unfunded RSF for a portfolio of up to RMB500 million (US$80 million equivalent) comprised of EE and RE loans originated by BOS.

Project Description: The project is the construction and operation of a 130-guest room, 6-storey Courtyard by Marriott hotel.  The project site is located off, Knutsford Boulevard, specifically behind Emancipation Park, on Park Close, next to the National House Trust Building, in New Kingston, Jamaica.  The site area is an approximately 15,000 square meters.
Review Scope: IFC's review comprised a review of social and environmental information provided by the project developer, Caribe Hospitality of Jamaica Ltd.  This included a completed E&S questionnaire completed by the developer, an Environmental and Social Analysis, an ESIA, undertaken by a consultant for the developer, a review of the human resources policies and procedures of Marriott International, the intended operator of the property, permits provided for the project and an account of a public consultation meeting held to discuss the project.It should also be noted that proposed IFC funding for this project would be supplied under the terms of a facility agreement already defined between IFC and the project sponsor, Caribe Hospitality S.A. (the 'Sponsor').  This would be the fourth development by the Sponsor under the terms of this agreement, earlier hotels being a Residence Inn hotel in Escazu, San Jose, Costa Rica, and Courtyard by Marriott properties in Bridgetown, Barbados, and Alajuela, Costa Rica.  IFC has visited all these properties during either their operational or construction phases, and conclusions from these visits inform this review.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This proposed investment is an E&S Category B project according to IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedure, because potential adverse environmental and social risks are limited, reversible and may be readily mitigated.Key environmental and social project issues include, control of dust, noise and workplace safety during construction, labor and working conditions during both construction and operation, building energy efficiency and water consumption efficiency and fire and structural safety aspects of the building's design, construction and operation.Land was acquired through willing buyer/seller process from the previous private owner. No person or economic activity was displaced as a result of this transaction, meaning that Performance Standard 5 is not relevant to this project.PS6, PS7 and PS8: the land to be developed is located in a heavily modified habitat, adjacent to a main road and used for storage and car parking. The area has no known special biodiversity significance, nor are indigenous peoples or cultural heritage encountered.

Role:
(i) With more than a decade experience in supporting EE financing globally, especially in China through CHUEE, IFC is in the leading position to continue innovation to address major market gaps for SMEs to access funding for EE and RE projects and activities;

(ii) Using global and China-specific knowledge and expertise in EE/RE financing, unique to IFC and unavailable in the local market, IFC will leverage public and private sources of capital to increase development impact;

(iii) IFC''s advisory services will be delivered through established platform which has great experience in building banks'' capacity to do EE/RE lending and SME finance;

(iv) IFC is helping partner banks to focus on SMEs, especially those in frontier regions where EE/RE funding is still at an early stage; and

(v) In the absence of IFC''s participation, it will be very difficult to raise funding for first loss and advisory services, both critical for the success of the program.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Bank of Nanjing. Founded in 1996, Bank of Nanjing (formerly called Nanjing City Commercial Bank) is a joint-stock city commercial bank formed through the merger of 40 urban credit cooperatives in Nanjing, the capital city of Jiangsu Province. The bank was listed in Shanghai Stock Exchange in July 2007. Its major shareholders included Zijin Corporation, BNP Paribas, and Nanjing Xingang High Tech as of December 2011.

Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project involves an unfunded RSF aimed to support small to medium energy efficiency and renewable energy loans and has therefore been categorized as FI-2 in accordance with IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. The RSF target loans entail limited advance E&S risk and impacts that are few in number, generally site-specific, largely reversible and can be readily addressed through mitigation measures. For the project BoN will be required to assess and manage the potential E&S risks  of such loans in compliance with the IFC Exclusion List, applicable Chinese E&S laws and regulations, and applicable Performance Standards.

Project Description: The proposed IFC investment consists of an equity investment in EQTL (the Sponsor) common shares with a participation of up to R$200 million (US$99 million equivalent) to support EQTLs acquisition and turnaround of CELPA, the electricity distribution company of the State of Para.  IFCs proposed equity investment will support investments in the expansion of sub-transmission and distribution (ST&D) projects as part of CELPAs rural electrification program.  Some of the key expansion projects to be implemented include:Island of Marajó Project  the Phase I of this project is on-going and is being completed by December 2012. The Marajó Project consists of the installation of 625 km of T&D distribution network (i.e., 138 and 69 kV) with 60-meter wide ROW, across some areas that consist of primary tropical forest of the Amazon Biome. The Phase II of the Island of Marajó Project is expected to start construction during the first half of 2015. This project consists of the installation of 586 km, 60-m wide ROW, mainly across savannah and modified habitat (forest and savannah) but also includes a yet-to-be defined segment in primary tropical forest;  Calha Norte Project - This project is planned for 2015-16 and will consist of the installation of over 600 km of ST&D network that will be constructed mainly along existing roads and modified habitats at or near the Trans-Amazon Highway System. However, this Project may also include construction across approximately 100 km of primary forest; Xingu Region Project  This Project consists of 720 km of ST&D network expansion (69 and 34.5 kV), mainly along the Trans-Amazon Highway System, although potentially with approximately 100 km across primary tropical forest. This project is planned for 2016; andOver the next five to ten years, the government-subsidized rural electrification program Luz para Todos (LPT) will require the installations of tens of thousands of kilometers of additional distribution lines.  The vast majority of these low voltage lines will be installed along existing roads.CELPA has approximately 40 off-grid diesel power stations ranging in size from approximately 0.5 to 7 MWe  for an aggregate total of about 110MWe. These are situated in remote locations, serving isolated networks. About half are owned and operated by CELPA and the other half under contract by a single dedicated service provider.  The aforementioned Island of Marajó interconnection project will result of the shutdown of about 14 of these diesel generation units.
Review Scope: IFC Environmental and Social Due Diligence of this project included a field appraisal mission conducted between October 29 and November 1, 2012.  IFCs due diligence scope included a review of environmental, health, safety and social documentation provided by Centrais Elétricas do Pará S.A. (CELPA or the Company), consisting of various environmental reports used to obtain environmental permits, two simplified Environmental and Social Impact Assessments (ESIAs or Relatório Ambiental Simplificado [RAS]) for the construction of the new transmission and distribution systems in the Island of Marajó; meetings with CELPA representatives responsible for the management of environmental, social, and health and safety aspects of CELPAs projects; a meeting with representatives from the State Secretariat of Environment - Pará (SEMA-PA, the State of Pará environmental regulatory agency responsible for the environmental licensing process); and field visits to the following locations: Curió Substation in the Metropolitan Region of Belém;Location of an innovative distribution switch box in the Metropolitan Region of Belem;Isolated thermal power generating station in the Island of Cotijuba, Archipelago of Marajó; and Community Quilombola CRQ Jacarequara, Municipality of Acará, PA, km 24 of Alça Viária Highway.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The project has been classified as a Category A project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure due to potential risks and impacts associated with the operations and proposed capital investment program of CELPA which includes, among others, the construction of sub-transmission lines in forested regions of the Amazon Biome. Such state is located in its entirety within the Amazon region and most its remaining natural forests are part of the Amazon Biome.

Project Description: IFC is in discussion with Bank of Beijing (BOB or the Bank) to enter into an unfunded risk sharing facility (RSF) to support energy efficiency (EE), renewable energy (RE) and water efficiency (WE) projects with small and medium enterprises (SME) in China (the Project, or CHUEE SME BOB). In this proposed Project, IFC would take credit risk in a loan portfolio to be originated and funded by the Bank. The Project is expected to receive support from the Global Environmental Facility (GEF) and Chinese Central Government.
Environmental Social Info: The main E&S risks and impacts of the project derive from the E&S risks of the RSF target loans, the capacity and systems in place to manage these risks, and BOBs practices with regard to labor and working conditions. At present BOB has developed an Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) for undertaking E&S risk management of its lending activities. However, its implementation of the ESMS for the RSF portfolio will need to be strengthened by incorporating proper E&S review and monitoring in the loan review process and providing additional training to the staff involved in ESMS implementation. BOB will be required to comply with relevant Chinese labor laws and regulations and the requirements of IFC Performance Standard 2 on Labor and Working conditions.
Impact: (i)	Environmental benefit:  Upon full ramp-up for the Project, 233,000 tons of CO2 emission and 600,000 cubic meters of water is estimated to be reduced per year; (ii)	SME access to finance:  Upon full ramp-up for the Project, at least 44 SME borrowers will be financed.  (iii)	Demonstration effect: 1) encourage governments to participate in future public private partnership initiatives of this type, within and beyond China; 2) generate a broader market impact and demonstrate the viability of energy efficiency and water efficiency projects; and 3) catalyze financial institutions to offer sustainable energy/water financing to SMEs;(iv)  Capacity building: (1) promote the improvement of industry-specific loan underwriting process/procedure and strengthen risk management practices; and (2) increase the Bank''s capacity to analyze and finance energy/water efficiency projects;
Role:
(i) With more than a decade experience in supporting EE financing globally, especially in China through CHUEE, IFC is in the leading position to continue innovation to address major market gaps for SMEs to access funding for EE and RE projects and activities;

(ii) Using global and China-specific knowledge and expertise in EE/RE financing, unique to IFC and unavailable in the local market, IFC will leverage public and private sources of capital to increase development impact;

(iii) IFC''s advisory services will be delivered through established platform which has great experience in building banks'' capacity to do EE/RE lending and SME finance;

(iv) IFC is helping Partner Banks to focus on SMEs, especially those in frontier regions where EE/RE/WE funding is still at a relatively early stage;

(v) In the absence of IFC''s participation, it will be very difficult to raise funding for first loss and advisory services, both critical for the success of the Program; and

(vi) facilitate market absorption of water technologies.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Bank of Beijing. Founded in 1996, Bank of Beijing (formerly called Beijing City Commercial Bank) is a joint-stock commercial bank formed through the merger of 90 urban credit cooperatives in Beijing. It is the largest city commercial bank in China in terms of total assets and outlet coverage. The company was listed in Shanghai Stock Exchange in September 2007. As of December 2011, BOBs major shareholders included ING, Beijing State-owned Assets Management Company, Beijing Energy Investment Holding Co. and IFC.
Cost Nature: It is proposed that IFC invests up to RMB440 million (US$70 million equivalent) in the form of an unfunded risk sharing facility for a portfolio of up to RMB880 million (US$140 million equivalent) comprised of energy efficiency, renewable energy and water efficiency loans originated by BOB.
